ex_1_jp: これは、大人のりょうきんです。
ex_1_en: This is the adult price.
ex_2_jp: 大人は三人だけです。
ex_2_en: There are only three adults.
ex_3_jp: 大人たちはいざかやにいった。
ex_3_en: Some of the adults went to an izakaya.
meaning_story: This kanji combines big and person. If you're a child, how do you think of adults? You just think of them like big people. That's why this combination of kanji means adult.
reading_story: "I'm an adult, which means I have adult responsibilities. Oh, Toner (おとな)? I need some of that for my terrible printer..." ... now feel so sad you have such a terrible printer that runs out of toner every day. Ohhhh Toner!
pitch_accent: ウꜜシ *** オトナ *** タイジン *** ダイニン

ex_1_jp: 一人でカラオケにいきました。
ex_1_en: I went to karaoke alone.
ex_2_jp: 一人はアメリカ人です。
ex_2_en: One of them is American.
ex_3_jp: むすめは、きょうはじめて一人でおつかいにいきました。
ex_3_en: My daughter did the errands by herself for the first time today.
meaning_story: When there's one person, what are they? Well, they're either just going to be simply one person or alone.
reading_story: The reading for this vocab doesn't follow any rules you learned previously. It's an exception, which means you have to learn the reading separately too. Spend a few moments trying to remember this word, look away for 10 seconds, and then try to recall its reading. Could you do it? Try again, this time in thirty seconds. Did you do it again? Okay, go ahead and move on. You may know it now, though you'll need to recall it again in the next 5-10 minutes if you want to remember it for good. Alternatively, if you know the reading for the vocab word 一つ (in the same level as this word), you can know that it uses the same reading!

ex_1_jp: おれはアメリカ人か？
ex_1_en: Am I American?
ex_2_jp: アメリカ人が二人います。
ex_2_en: There are two American people.
ex_3_jp: アメリカ人の女とともだちになった。
ex_3_en: I made friends with an American girl.
meaning_story: The アメリカ part is pretty easy so long as you know katakana. It's the word for "America." You know that 人 means "person," so you can figure out that America + Person = American.
reading_story: Often times when two kanji come together to form a combo kanji you use the on'yomi readings. This is similar to that, though instead of another kanji it's a foreign word. So, the reading of 人 is the on'yomi reading じん, which you learned already in the kanji. This pattern works with almost any location as well. Just add a country name + 人 and you've described the people who live there. You'll see more of these before you're finished here.

ex_1_jp: あなたののうは、ほんとうに人工ののうなんですか？
ex_1_en: Is your brain really artificial?
ex_2_jp: この川は、人工の川です。
ex_2_en: This river is man-made.
ex_3_jp: にわに人工しばをしいてみました。
ex_3_en: I put artificial turf in the garden.
meaning_story: A person of industry makes a lot of things by hand, so everything they make is artificial, and also means it's man made.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: このぼうしは大きすぎます。
ex_1_en: This hat is too big.
ex_2_jp: その大きいももを二つください。
ex_2_en: Can I get those two big peaches?
ex_3_jp: わたしのあかちゃんは、こうしとおなじくらい大きい。
ex_3_en: My baby is about as big as a calf.
meaning_story: This is the adjective form of the kanji 大 (big). It has the same meaning, though it is a word for describing. Words that end with い are often adjectives, remember that for future words as well. So, as long as you know the meaning of this kanji, you can transfer that to the meaning of this word. It's the adjective big / large.
reading_story: What do you do when you see something really, really big? You say おお because you can't believe your eyes. Imagine something really large and say おお out loud to help seal the memory in that brain of yours.

ex_1_jp: それは大したことはない。
ex_1_en: It’s not a big deal.
ex_2_jp: まったく大した女だよ。
ex_2_en: She is such a great woman.
ex_3_jp: マクドナルドのしゃちょうになれれば大したものだ。
ex_3_en: Being the president of McDonald’s would be a big deal.
meaning_story: した is the past tense form of する (which means "to do"). So, essentially this word is "did big." What is something that "did big"? It's something that's considerable or great.
reading_story: The reading for the 大 part is actually the on'yomi reading you learned when learning its kanji. So, as long as you remember that (and remember to use that reading), you can read this word as well. 大した = たいした.

ex_1_jp: つくえの下にはなにがありますか。
ex_1_en: What’s under the desk?
ex_2_jp: 下に下りてきてください。
ex_2_en: Please come down.
ex_3_jp: ぼくはTofuguオフィスの下のかいにすんでいる。
ex_3_en: I live on the floor below the Tofugu office.
meaning_story: When a vocab is a single kanji with no okurigana (that's hiragana attached to the kanji) it tends to steal the meaning of the kanji it comes from. So, this one is below or down.
reading_story: When a vocab is a single kanji and is alone it tends to use the kun'yomi reading. You learned the on'yomi reading for this kanji, so now it's time to learn the kun'yomi reading to learn this vocabulary word. What's below you? What's below your foot? Oh no. The worst thing possible: It's した.
pitch_accent: ゲꜜ *** ゲ *** シタꜜ *** シタ *** シモꜜ *** モトꜜ

ex_1_jp: がくせいは、きょううちで、八ページをべんきょうします。
ex_1_en: Students will study page eight at home today.
ex_2_jp: あめを八こカバンに入れました。
ex_2_en: I put eight candies in my purse.
ex_3_jp: 八じ？ほんとうに、八じ？
ex_3_en: Eight o’clock? Are you sure it’s eight o’clock?
meaning_story: When a vocab is a single kanji it usually steals its meaning from its kanji as well. Same goes for this vocab word. It means eight.
reading_story: When a vocab is a single kanji and all alone like this, it's usually going to use the kun'yomi. But, because this is a number (exception) it uses the on'yomi instead, meaning you already know the reading from when you learned the kanji!

ex_1_jp: ふくろには、じゃがいもが八つ入っています。
ex_1_en: There are eight potatoes in a bag.
ex_2_jp: 八つしかありませんよ。
ex_2_en: There are only eight of them.
ex_3_jp: 八つのかおと六つのうでがあるもの、なーんだ。
ex_3_en: What has eight faces and six arms?
meaning_story: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus つ on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for eight plus つ. So, this one is eight things.
reading_story: Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus つ), you really just have to remember the part before the つ (and then remember that the つ is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion). So what eight things do you have? You have eight yachts (やっつ). Go ahead and count them. They're beautiful. Also, be sure not to be confused by this particular reading mnemonic. It includes the つ, even though the つ is outside the reading you need to learn (just makes things easier for you overall). Since you can see the つ outside, it shouldn't be too difficult for you.
pitch_accent: ヤツꜜ *** ヤッツꜜ *** ヤッツ

ex_1_jp: 入り口のところでまっています。
ex_1_en: I will wait for you at the entrance.
ex_2_jp: 入り口が三つあります。
ex_2_en: There are three entrances.
ex_3_jp: 入り口にジョニーデップがいるよ。
ex_3_en: Johnny Depp is at the entrance.
meaning_story: A mouth that you enter is an entrance.
reading_story: Because there's some okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) attached, you can bet that 入り will be a kun'yomi reading. This reading comes from the word 入れる. If you know that word already, this one will be easy. If not, then you'll have to think that the entrance you're going in is eerie (いり). Then, because this word is really two separate words put together to form one word, you can guess that 口 also uses the kun'yomi reading, though the く in くち changes to ぐ due to something called rendaku. Just remember that it's ぐち and not くち here.
pitch_accent: イリク°チ *** イリクチ *** ハイリꜜク°チ

ex_1_jp: フランス人のゆうじんができました。
ex_1_en: I made a French friend.
ex_2_jp: 二人はアメリカ人で、あとの三人はフランス人です。
ex_2_en: Two of them are American and the other three are French.
ex_3_jp: とてもセクシーなフランス人シェフにあった。
ex_3_en: I met a very sexy French chef.
meaning_story: フランス is "France." So what is a "France person?" That would be a French Person.
reading_story: You can treat this word and the 人 kanji on the end like jukugo (combo kanji). Usually, in the case of jukugo, you use the on'yomi reading. So here you'll want to remember to use the on'yomi reading for 人. If you want, you can add 人 to the end of any place name to describe the people that live there!

ex_1_jp: ともだちといっしょに、山にのぼります。
ex_1_en: I climb mountains with my friends.
ex_2_jp: これはせかい一大きい人工の山なんですよ。
ex_2_en: This is the world's biggest man-made mountain.
ex_3_jp: あさ八じに、はだかではげ山にしゅうごうしましょう。
ex_3_en: At 8 am, let’s meet naked on Bald Mountain.
meaning_story: A vocab made of a single kanji all alone with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) usually has the same exact meaning as the kanji it's made from. So by that you know that this vocab's meaning is mountain.
reading_story: When a vocab is a single kanji all alone with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it's usually going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn when you learned the kanji. To remember this word's reading we'll use a mnemonic. What are you doing going up into the mountains? You're hunting for yams (やま). Go ahead, imagine yourself doing just that, climbing up the mountain (it's hard work!) and then digging in the ground with your hands, then pulling up that sweet, delicious yam! Mmm!

ex_1_jp: 口にソースがついていますよ。
ex_1_en: There is some sauce on your mouth.
ex_2_jp: これを口に入れてください。
ex_2_en: Please put this in your mouth.
ex_3_jp: きのうから口がとじられない。
ex_3_en: I haven’t been able to close my mouth since yesterday.
meaning_story: When a vocab is made up of a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it's generally going to have the same meaning as the kanji it came from. From that, you know this word's meaning is mouth.
reading_story: When a vocab is made up of a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it's generally going to use the kun'yomi reading, which you did not learn from learning the kanji. To remember this word, you should use a mnemonic. With your mouth, make a "kuchi kuchi kou" (くち) sound. Go ahead, make it. Focus on your mouth and try to imagine each shape it makes while zooming in on it. You're talking to a baby, which is why you're making all these ridiculous noises. Also, instead of "coo" at the end, you're saying "kou," because that's the reading of the kanji (こう). くちくちこう！くちくちこう！ Sounds like something from Arrested Development, actually.

ex_1_jp: ふじ山に、ごぜん十一じごろつきたいです。
ex_1_en: I want to arrive at Mt. Fuji by around 11 a.m.
ex_2_jp: ふじ山にはいつも大人のフランス人が三人とちいさいアメリカ人が二人とカナダ人が一人います。
ex_2_en: There are always three adult French people, two small Americans, and one Canadian on Mt. Fuji.
ex_3_jp: ふじ山はしろいとりのふんでおおわれていた。
ex_3_en: Mt. Fuji was covered in white bird poop.
meaning_story: Just look at this word. What do you think it means? That's right - it's a name (Fuji) plus the kanji for mountain. Put those together, and you have Mount Fuji. In English the "Mount(ain)" part comes first. In Japanese, it comes at the end, sort of like the name ender さん, ちゃん, and so on. You can add 山 to the end of any mountain's name too, not just Mount Fuji.
reading_story: Normally ふじ would be in kanji, but I wanted you to see this kanji use in action since it's more useful than just being used on Mount Fuji. This is treated like a jukugo word (combo kanji word). In the case of jukugo, usually the on'yomi reading is used, meaning you just have to remember the on'yomi reading of 山. Luckily, you learned this when you were learning the kanji, so you should already know it!

ex_1_jp: まいにち九じかんぐらいべんきょうします。
ex_1_en: I study for about nine hours every day.
ex_2_jp: 九ページをひらいてください。
ex_2_en: Please open the page 9.
ex_3_jp: 九わの九かんちょうをかっていました。
ex_3_en: I used to have nine mynah birds.
meaning_story: When a vocab is made up of a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji), it often has the same meaning as the kanji it's based off of. Same goes for the word 九, as well. It has the same meaning as its kanji counterpart.
reading_story: When a vocab is made up of a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji), it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are the exception, as you might already know. When they're alone with no okurigana they're the on'yomi reading, which you should already know from learning the kanji that makes up this word.

ex_1_jp: きょうのテストには、じしょをつかうもんだいが九つあります。
ex_1_en: There are nine questions that require a dictionary on today’s test.
ex_2_jp: ねこには九つのいのちがあるってほんとう？
ex_2_en: Is it true that a cat has nine lives?
ex_3_jp: ドーナツを九つつくった。
ex_3_en: I made nine donuts.
meaning_story: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus つ on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for nine plus つ. So, this one is nine things.
reading_story: Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus つ), you really just have to remember the part before the つ (and then remember that the つ is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion). What thing do you have nine of? The nine things that you have are nine coconuts (ここの). Imagine yourself juggling nine coconuts in the air. Try counting them while you're doing this, arriving at nine things.

ex_1_jp: 一ど、あいましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s meet up once.
ex_2_jp: 一いはアメリカ人でした。
ex_2_en: First place was an American.
ex_3_jp: ぼくはせかいで一ばんよわい。
ex_3_en: I’m the weakest man in the world.
meaning_story: As is the case with most vocab words that consist of a single kanji, this vocab word has the same meaning as the kanji it parallels, which is one.
reading_story: When a vocab word is all alone and has no okurigana (hiragana attached to kanji) connected to it, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception, however. When a number is all alone, with no kanji or okurigana, it is going to be the on'yomi reading, which you learned with the kanji. Just remember this exception for alone numbers and you'll be able to read future number-related vocab to come.
pitch_accent: イチꜜ *** イꜜツ *** イツꜜ

ex_1_jp: こたえを一つえらびます。
ex_1_en: Choose one answer.
ex_2_jp: お一人さま一つかぎりです。
ex_2_en: It's limited to one per customer.
ex_3_jp: きのう、一つめこぞうにあった。
ex_3_en: I met a one-eyed goblin yesterday.
meaning_story: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus つ on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for one plus つ. So, this one is one thing.
reading_story: Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus つ), you really just have to remember the part before the つ (and then remember that the つ is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion). So, you have one thing. What one thing do you have? You have one of He-Man's Toes, aka a single He-Toe (ひと). So what's the thing you have only one of? You have one He-Toe. Imagine He-Man walking around with one missing toe, trying to find you so he can get it back. At least you'll be able to run faster than him now.

ex_1_jp: やじるしの人はなんといいますか。
ex_1_en: What will the person the arrow is pointing at say?
ex_2_jp: あの人はなに人ですか？
ex_2_en: What is that person's nationality?
ex_3_jp: 人びとは、かれをばかな人だという。
ex_3_en: People say he was a stupid person.
meaning_story: When a vocab is a single kanji all alone, it usually has the same meaning as its kanji parent. That goes for this vocab word as well. Person is person.
reading_story: When a vocab is a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji), it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Since you don't know the kun'yomi reading for this kanji yet, let's use a mnemonic to learn it. What does a person hate more than anything? They hate extreme heat (ひと). You can always put on more clothes to stay warm, but when the heat gets too high, you can only take off so much.
pitch_accent: ニꜜン *** ヒトꜜ *** ヒト

ex_1_jp: ここでは、きっぷがいりますから、きっぷをかってきて下さい。
ex_1_en: You need a ticket here, so please go buy one.
ex_2_jp: りんごを二こ下さい。
ex_2_en: Please give me two apples.
ex_3_jp: フグさん、そっとつねって下さいね。
ex_3_en: Fugu, gently pinch me please.
meaning_story: You know that the kanji 下 means down and that さい sounds like the word "sigh." You need to ask someone for something, so you look down, sigh, and say please give me that thing. You're ashamed that you have to ask. But you still need it. Please, please give it to me! We only use this kanji version of ください when we're asking for something, that's why it's "please give me." If you're just saying "please" you don't need the kanji at all!
reading_story: The reading for this word is an exceptional reading. You just have to be able to recall the くだ part, though (since さい is already there in the form of the hiragana). So, think about why you have to be polite to this misbehaving kid. Turns out, if you don't, he has the power to initiate a Coup d'état against you and your family, who runs the government. Just imagine yourself thinking over and over "Okay... I have to be nice to this kid. If I don't... he'll initiate a Coup d'état... and that would ruin my family..." You're walking on thin ice, here.

ex_1_jp: 人口のはんぶんはだんせいです。
ex_1_en: Half the population is male.
ex_2_jp: このむらの人口はたったの二十三にんです。
ex_2_en: This village's population is only 23.
ex_3_jp: じぶんのまちの人口をしらないにほんじんはおおい。
ex_3_en: Many Japanese people don’t know the population of their own town.
meaning_story: The amount of people with mouths (that you have to feed) is the population that you have to feed.
reading_story: Both kanji in this jukugo (combo kanji) use the on'yomi readings that you've already learned! So just make sure you know those and you'll be able to read this too.

ex_1_jp: おなかがすいて、力がでない。
ex_1_en: I’m hungry and losing strength.
ex_2_jp: あのアメリカ人の女にはふじ山をうごかす力がある。
ex_2_en: That American woman has the power to move Mt. Fuji.
ex_3_jp: おかあさんは、のこりのかぞくがたばになってもかなわない力をもっている。
ex_3_en: My mom is more powerful than the rest of my family put together.
meaning_story: When a vocab word is made up of a single kanji and that's it, it almost always takes the meaning from its parent kanji. So, this vocab word also means power.
reading_story: When a vocab word is a single kanji all alone with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji), it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading with the kanji, so for this vocab word, we'll use a mnemonic. The most powerful man in the world. All his power came from his cheek (ちから). Imagine him blowing up his cheek like a giant balloon, then unleashing his power on you. Thwap thwap thwap thwap.

ex_1_jp: この川には、さかながたくさんおよいでいます。
ex_1_en: There are a lot of fish swimming in this river.
ex_2_jp: にほんいちながい川は、しなの川です。
ex_2_en: Japan's longest river is Shinano River.
ex_3_jp: 川をみるといつもいかりがこみあげてくる。
ex_3_en: Whenever I see a river, I get so pissed off.
meaning_story: When a vocab is made up of a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it will usually take the same meaning as the kanji it comes from. So, from that you know that this word means river.
reading_story: You're in luck - the reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the one you have to learn for this vocab!

ex_1_jp: あしたのあさ、七じにえきであいませんか。
ex_1_en: Why don’t we meet at the station at seven tomorrow morning?
ex_2_jp: みかんが七こあります。
ex_2_en: There are seven mandarin oranges.
ex_3_jp: 七にんのこびととともだちになりたい。
ex_3_en: I want to be friends with the seven dwarves.
meaning_story: When a vocab is alone with no okurigana (that's hiragana attached to a kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji too. That goes for this word as well. So, if you know the kanji's meaning (seven) you'll know the vocab's meaning (seven).
reading_story: Most single-kanji all-alone vocab words like this use the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this rule. That being said, four and seven are exceptions to this exception to the rule (because the on'yomi readings sound too much like the word for "death"). You should learn both readings for this word, though we're going to go with なな for the main one here. You can remember that because you had seven nanas after you.

ex_1_jp: はこのなかにりんごが七つあります。
ex_1_en: There are seven apples in a box.
ex_2_jp: 二人でメロンを七つたべました。
ex_2_en: Just the two of us ate seven melons.
ex_3_jp: 七つかぞえると、わたしは女になる。
ex_3_en: After I count to seven, I will be a woman.
meaning_story: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus つ on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for seven plus つ. So, this one is seven things.
reading_story: Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus つ), you really just have to remember the part before the つ (and then remember that the つ is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion). What thing do you have seven of? The seven things that you have are seven Nanas (なな). These are your grandmas, cloned. Just think, "It's lucky to have seven nanas. They can all cook my favorite foods for me!"

ex_1_jp: このテーブルの大きさは、よこ100センチ、たて120センチです。
ex_1_en: The size of this table is 100cm in width and 120cm in length.
ex_2_jp: テレビの大きさは三十二インチです。
ex_2_en: The size of the TV is 32 inches.
ex_3_jp: ロナルド・マクドナルドはいつも大きさのちがうくつをはいていた。
ex_3_en: Ronald McDonald always wore different-sized shoes.
meaning_story: Words that end with さ are often words that have taken the adjective form (in this case 大きい) of the word and turned into words that describe what the adjective form is doing, if that makes sense. So 大きい (big) goes to 大きさ, and the word that describes what "big" describes is the word size.
reading_story: When a vocab has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it is probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Since you learned the on'yomi reading with the kanji 大, we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember this word. When you saw the size of (pick something surprising), you said "おお *#$@!" Really imagine something surprising. Say the おお part out loud, as well. Think about the size of whatever you're looking at, too, and how big it is.

ex_1_jp: わたしは、ツバメを十わかっています。
ex_1_en: I have ten swallows.
ex_2_jp: あと二かで、十二がつですね。
ex_2_en: It'll be December in two days.
ex_3_jp: 十ねんかん十にんのじゅうにんとくらした。
ex_3_en: For ten years I lived with ten other people.
meaning_story: When a vocab is alone like this with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it tends to steal its meaning from the kanji it came from. That means this vocab word also means ten.
reading_story: When a vocab is alone and consists of a single kanji like this, usually it uses the kun'yomi reading for the kanji. But, numbers are an exception and they use the on'yomi reading (which you learned when you learned the kanji). That means you know that this word's reading is じゅう already.
pitch_accent: ジュꜜー *** トꜜー *** トー

ex_1_jp: このもんだいようしは、ぜんぶで三ページあります。
ex_1_en: There are three pages of these questions total.
ex_2_jp: わたしは三十二さいです。
ex_2_en: I’m 32 years old.
ex_3_jp: 三かいまわってワンとほえろ。
ex_3_en: Turn around three times and bark!
meaning_story: When a vocab is a single kanji and alone like this, it usually steals its meaning from the parent kanji. That goes for this word too, making the meaning of this word three.
reading_story: When a vocab is alone like this with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually uses its kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception, though, and use the on'yomi reading. You learned the on'yomi reading when you learned this kanji, so you already know that the reading for this vocab is さん.

ex_1_jp: わたしには、きょうだいが三人います。
ex_1_en: I have three siblings.
ex_2_jp: その川には二、三人しかいませんでした。
ex_2_en: There were only two or three people in the river.
ex_3_jp: 三人のうちで、だれがいちばんタイプ？
ex_3_en: Out of those three people, which one is your type?
meaning_story: You have the kanji for three and person. Common sense will tell you what this word is. It's three people.
reading_story: This jukugo (combo kanji) word uses the on'yomi readings that you learned when you learned the kanji. That means you should know the reading as long as you know the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 三つのせんたくしがおんせいできこえます。
ex_1_en: You will hear three choices.
ex_2_jp: ここにボールを三つ入れてください。
ex_2_en: Please put three balls in here.
ex_3_jp: 三つもかにかまれた。
ex_3_en: I got three mosquito bites.
meaning_story: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus つ on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for three plus つ. So, this one is three things.
reading_story: Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus つ), you really just have to remember the part before the つ (and then remember that the つ is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion). What thing do you have three of? The three things that you have are actually three versions of yourself. "Who is the real one?" you ask yourself. "It's me!" "Wait, no, it's me!" Just remember that there are three of you, and they're all saying "me me me me me" to try and prove that they're the real you.

ex_1_jp: わたしがやねに上りましょう。
ex_1_en: I can go up to the roof.
ex_2_jp: 十かいまでかいだんを上った。
ex_2_en: I climbed up stairs to the 10th floor.
ex_3_jp: サケが川を上っているのをみた。
ex_3_en: I saw a salmon swimming upstream.
meaning_story: This vocab word is an exception in almost every way. It has a similar meaning to the meaning of the kanji, and you know it's a verb because it ends with an う sound (る, in this case). But, the meaning is to climb. Comparing it to the other 上 verb words, it has the least okurigana (versus 上げる and 上がる). You could remember this and know that the thing you don't want to do the most is "to climb," so that's why it has the least okurigana.
reading_story: The reading for this word is an exception from all the rules of the 上 vocabulary. It consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, so it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to climb the mountain, but a gruff old man grabs your shoulder and says "No boy, you ain't climbing that thing, not today." If you're not a boy, think about how weird it is that he called you a boy. If you are a grown man, think how you wish he called you "dude" or something, not "boy." If you're a boy, well... think about how appropriate it is that he said "no boy."

ex_1_jp: プールに入るまえに、じゅんびうんどうをしてください。
ex_1_en: Please stretch before getting in the pool.
ex_2_jp: ちゃんと入り口から入ってください。
ex_2_en: Please enter from the entrance.
ex_3_jp: へやに入って、いっしょにまゆげをかこうよ！
ex_3_en: Let’s go in the room and draw our eyebrows on!
meaning_story: When a kanji ends with an "う" sound (like る, for this one), it's usually going to be a verb. When the vocab is a kanji + okurigana ending in this "う" sound, it's often going to be the verb form of that kanji. So in this case, the kanji 入 is enter. The vocab 入る is to enter. Just the verb version of the kanji.
reading_story: When a vocab is a single kanji with okurigana, chances are it's going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you don't usually learn in the kanji (you usually learn the on'yomi reading). So, let's learn the kun'yomi reading for this word using its meaning. When you enter the room, what do you do? You say "Hi" (はい) to everyone to the point of absurdity. "Hi there. Oh hi Frank. Oh hi there Susan. Oh hi there lamp."

ex_1_jp: せかいじゅうのかぶかが下がった。
ex_1_en: Stock prices all over the world fell.
ex_2_jp: ねつが三十七どに下がりました。
ex_2_en: My temperature dropped to 37℃.
ex_3_jp: ズボンが下がるようにベルトをゆるめなさい。
ex_3_en: Unfasten your belt so that your pants will hang down.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means below so this means something gets lower, by falling or dropping. For example: Prices get lower or fall. Squirrels come down from trees. See? No direct object here. That's why this verb means to get lower or to fall.
reading_story: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Let's use a mnemonic to remember the reading of the kanji: You know it means to fall so instead of using a saw (さ) to cut down the tree, you decide to let it come to you. It has to come down all by itself. Picture yourself placing a saw at the foot of a tree then sitting back and waiting for it to drop itself at your knees. (This could actually work, don't you judge my methods!)

ex_1_jp: しかくになにを入れますか。
ex_1_en: What will you put in the square?
ex_2_jp: ここにおりがみを十二まい入れてください。
ex_2_en: Please insert twelve pieces of origami paper here.
ex_3_jp: わたしはハンバーガーをひつぎに入れた。
ex_3_en: I put a hamburger into the coffin.
meaning_story: This is similar to the vocab word 入る (to enter), except in this case, instead of entering you're inserting something. So, it's like you're entering something into something else. You can remember that this one is to insert because it's longer than 入る (はいる/to enter). Why? Because it's more difficult to insert something than it is to enter somewhere, which is why you have more help (the extra kana stuck on the end).
reading_story: When a vocab is a single kanji plus some okurigana (hiragana stuck on the end of kanji) it's almost always going to be the kun'yomi reading. This is one of two kun'yomi readings you'll be learning for the kanji 入. As long as you know that this vocab means to insert, you can use that to remember the reading as well. When you insert your hand into the mysterious hole, it feels cold and sticky inside. You scream: "い!" as an eagle flies out.

ex_1_jp: けつあつを下げるほうほうをおしえてください。
ex_1_en: Please tell me how to lower my blood pressure.
ex_2_jp: あのみせは、入り口にふうりんを一つ下げています。
ex_2_en: That shop has one wind chime hanging in its entrance.
ex_3_jp: きおんを下げるために、あまごいダンスをおどってみた。
ex_3_en: I tried to perform a rain dance to lower the temperature.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means below so the verb version of that is when you put something below you. It's to lower something. This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You lower something. Like your blood pressure!
reading_story: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to lower a tree so you need a saw (さ). Lower the tree to the ground gently while you slowly saw it down!

ex_1_jp: このはこをれいぞうこの上に上げてください。
ex_1_en: Please put this box on top of the refrigerator for me.
ex_2_jp: 三センチ上げてください。
ex_2_en: Please raise it three centimeters.
ex_3_jp: りょうてを上に上げて、大きくおならをした。
ex_3_en: I raised my hands and let out a huge fart.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means above so the verb version of that is when you put something above you. It's to raise something. This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You raise something. Like your hands!
reading_story: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to use the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to raise an aardvark (あ) above your head. Why? Because even though aardvarks have long tongues, it can't reach the ants in the trees. But when you raise the aardvark it can get at those yummy ants!

ex_1_jp: どんどんねつが上がっています。
ex_1_en: My fever is rising steadily.
ex_2_jp: 三かいまでエレベーターで上がりましょう。
ex_2_en: Let's go up to the 3rd floor using the elevator.
ex_3_jp: けむりが上がってる。
ex_3_en: Smoke is rising.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means above so this means something rises. For example: A fever rises. The sun rises. See? No direct object here. That's why this verb means to rise or to go up.
reading_story: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you can guess that it uses the kun'yomi reading, which also happens to be a reading you didn't learn when you learned the kanji. Let's use a mnemonic for the kun'yomi reading now, though. You have to remember at least the あ part to read it. You know that this word means to rise. Imagine something just rising on its own, like a floating tree or something. What would you say? Probably a "surprised" sound. Maybe you'd scream "あ!" when you saw this floating tree.

ex_1_jp: 二十一ページの二ばんはクラスでします。
ex_1_en: We will work on question two on page twenty-one in class.
ex_2_jp: わたしのこどもは二さいです。
ex_2_en: My child is 2 years old.
ex_3_jp: わたしのおじは、ねこを二ひきかっています。
ex_3_en: My uncle has two cats.
meaning_story: When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's two!
reading_story: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this. Numbers use the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned by learning the kanji's reading! How nice!

ex_1_jp: DVDを、あねと二人でみています。
ex_1_en: I am watching a DVD with my older sister.
ex_2_jp: あの二人はいつも二人でくみたがる。
ex_2_en: Those two want to be a couple all the time.
ex_3_jp: かのじょは二人ごろしでたいほされた。
ex_3_en: She was arrested for double murder.
meaning_story: When you have two and person and then put them together, what do you get? You get a pair or two people.
reading_story: The reading for this word is quite strange. If you know 二つ's reading, you can use that to remember the 二 part (ふた). But, the り that is the 人 is a total exception, something you won't see too often (though you may have seen it in 一人). If you can use the reading of 一人 (aka if you've learned it already) then definitely use that. If not, do your best to remember the reading on your own. It's a strange one that doesn't connect to much else.

ex_1_jp: 二つのかいわです。
ex_1_en: It’s two dialogues.
ex_2_jp: このカゴにリンゴを二つ入れてください。
ex_2_en: Please put two apples in this basket.
ex_3_jp: かれの二つめのあくぎょうは、かえるのあんさつだ。
ex_3_en: His second evil deed was the frog’s assassination.
meaning_story: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus つ on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for two plus つ. So, this one is two things.
reading_story: Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus つ), you really just have to remember the part before the つ (and then remember that the つ is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion). So what thing do you have two of? The two things that you have consist of one foot and another foot (ふた). Remember from the on'yomi how you had two knees (for the reading に)? Now can move down your leg and look at one foot then another foot.

part_of_speech: ADVERB, NOUN, SUFFIX, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 上のひょうをみてください。
ex_1_en: Please look at the chart above.
ex_2_jp: このフロアの三かい上にトーフグのオフィスがあります。
ex_2_en: The Tofugu office is three floors up.
ex_3_jp: くつ下のかたほうは、かいだんの上にあったわよ。
ex_3_en: One of your socks was at the top of the stairs.
meaning_story: When a vocab word is a single kanji and alone, it tends to steal the meaning from the kanji. Same goes for this one too. It means above or up.
reading_story: When a vocab word is a single kanji and doesn't have okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually will use the kun'yomi. Since you learned the on'yomi reading of the kanji, we'll need to use a mnemonic to learn the reading of this vocabulary word. Above you is a huge weight. You're holding it up and struggling (it's heavy!). You look up and try to crane your neck to see how much it weighs (うえ), but you can't see the numbers on the side of it. How long can you hold it above your head like this?
pitch_accent: ウエ *** カꜜミ *** ジョꜜー

ex_1_jp: この女はだれですか。
ex_1_en: Who is that woman?
ex_2_jp: わたしは女です。
ex_2_en: I'm a woman.
ex_3_jp: おれはこどもをせわする女がほしい。
ex_3_en: I want a woman who will help look after my children.
meaning_story: When a kanji is alone and doesn't have any okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it's usually going to take the same meaning as the kanji it comes from. So in this case, you know that this word means woman.
reading_story: When a word is a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it tends to use a kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading when you learned the kanji itself, so let's use a mnemonic to remember the vocab word. There's a woman in front of you. Who is she? It's just you and her in the store, and you're staring each other down. Oh. It turns out she's the store owner (おんな), which is weird, because you are in a store that makes only manly things. A woman owner of a manly things store? Strange...
pitch_accent: オミナ *** オꜜミナ *** オンナꜜ

ex_1_jp: このスカートは、千円です。
ex_1_en: This skirt is 1000 yen.
ex_2_jp: ぎゅうにゅうのねだんが千円上がった。
ex_2_en: The price of milk rose by 1000 yen.
ex_3_jp: あのやきゅうせんしゅのねんぽうは五千円だ。
ex_3_en: That baseball player makes 5,000 yen per year.
meaning_story: A thousand of these yen things makes this word 1000 yen.
reading_story: Since you know the on'yomi readings of these two kanji, you should know the reading for this vocab word as well!

ex_1_jp: 又してもおまえにやられてしまったぜ...とほほ！
ex_1_en: You’ve deceived me again... boohoo!
ex_2_jp: わたしはアメリカ人です。又、わたしはフランス人でもあります。
ex_2_en: I'm American. And also, I'm French.
ex_3_jp: 又来たぜ！
ex_3_en: Here I am again!
meaning_story: As a vocab made up of a single kanji, you know that the meaning of this vocab word and the meaning of the kanji that makes it are the same: Again!
reading_story: The reading you learned for the kanji is the same as the reading for this word. You won't have to learn it "again."

ex_1_jp: たんじょうびは、四月九日です。
ex_1_en: My birthday is April ninth.
ex_2_jp: 四月はさくらがさくので、王子は日本にいきたがっています。
ex_2_en: Since cherry blossoms are in bloom in April, the prince wants to go to Japan.
ex_3_jp: 四月にりょうしんがりこんしたストレスで、おれのガールフレンドにはすこしひげがはえた。
ex_3_en: My girlfriend suffered from so much stress after her parents divorced in April that she started to grow a little bit of a mustache.
meaning_story: 月 in Japanese means "moon" but it also means "month." Why? Probably because the moon takes about a month to get through its cycles. So, what's the fourth moon of the year? Here's a hint, it's the same as the fourth month of the year: April.
reading_story: The reading for this 四 is different from the one you learned. Instead of よん it's し, the on'yomi reading, which is also fairly common but not as common as よん I'd say (though they're both worth learning, if you can do that right now). You can remember that the word for "April" is read using し for 四 because in April, Charlie Sheen (し) did the most horrible April Fools joke on you. Go ahead and imagine what might be, but make it terrible, like feeding you your prize racing horse or something. Also, this is a specific month, so it uses the がつ reading.

ex_1_jp: うんどうかいで玉入れをしました。
ex_1_en: I played ball-toss during sports day.
ex_2_jp: ここに、白の玉が九つあります。
ex_2_en: There are nine white balls here.
ex_3_jp: けいとの玉のようなどうぶつをみかけませんでしたか？
ex_3_en: Have you ever seen an animal that looks like a ball of wool?
meaning_story: As an alone single kanji vocab, you know that this vocab word has the same meaning as its parent kanji: Ball.
reading_story: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned when learning the kanji: たま.
pitch_accent: ギョꜜク *** ギョク *** タマꜜ

ex_1_jp: この本はどこでかいましたか。
ex_1_en: Where did you buy this book?
ex_2_jp: コウイチがあやしいフランス人からかった本のカバーは本がわのカバーでした。
ex_2_en: The book cover that Koichi bought from a spooky French person was covered with genuine leather.
ex_3_jp: ここで本をよみたければ、きんをわたしてもらおう。
ex_3_en: If you want to read a book here, you have to give me some gold.
meaning_story: This vocab word is exactly the same as its parent kanji, including its meaning as well: book. It doesn't have those other meanings though, when it's just 本 alone, it's just a book.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the single kanji it comes from.
pitch_accent: ホꜜン *** モꜜト *** モトꜜ *** モト

ex_1_jp: それが白人のかんがえかたです。
ex_1_en: That’s how white people think.
ex_2_jp: わたしはケニア出しんのこく人ですが、アメリカの白人かぞくにそだてられました。
ex_2_en: I am black and from Kenya, but I was raised by a white family in America.
ex_3_jp: おおくの白人たちは、日本のなつが大のにが手だ。
ex_3_en: Many caucasians hate summer in Japan.
meaning_story: Not a particularly politically correct word, but it is a word that will help you to learn these two kanji and their readings. It includes the kanji for "white" and "person" ... put those together and you have a white person, aka a caucasian.
reading_story: As a jukugo word, it follows all the rules and uses the on'yomi readings from the kanji (both of which you know from learning the kanji).

ex_1_jp: これは、ピカソがえがいた丸です。
ex_1_en: This is a circle painted by Picasso.
ex_2_jp: このちずにかいてある丸はなんですか。
ex_2_en: What's this circle drawn on the map?
ex_3_jp: わたしのくろラブは、おどろいて、めが丸になった。
ex_3_en: My black lab was shocked and his eyes bulged wide open.
meaning_story: This vocab word and the kanji that makes it have the same meaning: Circle.
reading_story: The reading you learned for this kanji is the kun'yomi one. Since this vocab word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Guess what? That means you already know it!

ex_1_jp: 山田さんがつくったのは、丸いおにぎりです。
ex_1_en: The ones Yamada made are the round onigiri.
ex_2_jp: ちきゅうは丸い。
ex_2_en: Earth is spherical.
ex_3_jp: わたしのかおは丸いとはいいがたい。
ex_3_en: I wouldn’t say that my face is round.
meaning_story: With an い on the end, you can guess that this word is an い-adjective. What is the adjective version of the kanji 丸? "Circle" becomes circular, spherical or round. This, compared to another similar word (円), is more general purpose and can be used with 3D spherical objects as well.
reading_story: This word uses the reading you learned for the kanji 丸, though you'll need to tack the い onto the end too.

ex_1_jp: かれは、じぶんがいつも正しいとおもっている。
ex_1_en: He always thinks he’s right.
ex_2_jp: 王女はいつも正しくて、王子はいつもまちがっている。
ex_2_en: The princess is always correct and the prince is always wrong.
ex_3_jp: ぼくのこころのとびらをあけるには、正しいかぎがひつようだよ、ベイビー。
ex_3_en: If you want to open the door to my heart, you need the right key, baby.
meaning_story: Ending with an い tells you that this word is an い-adjective. So since you know that the kanji 正 means "correct," what is the adjective version of that word? Well, it's also correct.
reading_story: This word uses a reading you didn't learn from the kanji. You have to remember the ただ portion in order to read this word, so think about it this way: "After you get the answer correct a clown jumps out of nowhere yelling "TA DA!!!" Imagine it scaring the crap out of you, too.

ex_1_jp: 犬とねこがいます。
ex_1_en: There is a dog and a cat.
ex_2_jp: その王は犬を六ぴきかっています。
ex_2_en: That king has two dogs.
ex_3_jp: わたしの犬は、白さいがすきだ。
ex_3_en: My dog likes Chinese cabbage.
meaning_story: This vocab made up of a single kanji shares its meaning with said single kanji. That meaning is dog.
reading_story: Since this is a word made up of a single kanji and nothing else, you can assume that this word will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading you learned for this kanji happens to be the kun'yomi reading as well. So if you know the kanji you know the reading.

ex_1_jp: わたしのなつやすみは、八日かんです。
ex_1_en: My summer break is eight days long.
ex_2_jp: すみませんが、水を下さいませんか。もう八日もなにもたべていないんです。
ex_2_en: Could you please give me some water? I haven't eaten anything for eight days.
ex_3_jp: らい月の八日にじの手じゅつをするよていです。
ex_3_en: I’m going to get hemorrhoid surgery on the eighth of next month.
meaning_story: Eighth day or day eight. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading_story: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way: Every eight days you have to buy yogurt to fuel your car (ようか). Your car runs on yogurt, but it needs to be refilled every eight days to keep running. It's really inconvenient because it's just ONE day more than a week. And a week just feels better. Oh well.

ex_1_jp: 夕べ、パーティーにいきました。
ex_1_en: I went to a party last night.
ex_2_jp: デンマークの王子はフランス人二人をおんがくの夕べにしょうたいしました。
ex_2_en: The prince in Denmark invited two French people to a musical evening.
ex_3_jp: 夕べ、ひたいに肉とかいてみた。
ex_3_en: Last night I wrote the kanji for meat on my forehead.
meaning_story: This vocab word has a weird little extra bit on it (the べ). You can sort of ignore that, it doesn't really mean anything in particular. The meaning of this vocab word and the kanji it comes from are the same: evening
reading_story: When hiragana is attached to a kanji, you can usually assume that that kanji is going to be read using the kun'yomi reading, which is exactly what's going on with this word as well. By learning this word's kanji you've also learned the reading for this word.

ex_1_jp: そこは出口ではありません。
ex_1_en: That is not an exit.
ex_2_jp: ふじ山にはひみつの入り口と出口があるらしいですよ。
ex_2_en: I heard that Mt. Fuji has a secret entrance and exit.
ex_3_jp: このきゅうじょうの出口はあちらです。
ex_3_en: This baseball stadium’s exit is over there.
meaning_story: The mouth you exit out of is just a doorway (I hope), but an easier way to describe this word or concept is to call it an exit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 出口 is an exception to this rule, however, and uses its kun'yomi readings. There's no particular reason why this is, but oftentimes a "body part" word (like mouth) changes a word to use kun'yomi readings instead of on'yomi ones. You already know the kun'yomi reading for 口 (くち) from learning the vocab, but to remember the reading for 出 you can think the following: If I exit out this mouth, I'll end up in the ocean (you were swallowed by a whale) and I will surely end up dead (で). Also keep in mind that because of rendaku, くち becomes ぐち.

ex_1_jp: はなこさんの目はいいですか？
ex_1_en: Does Hanako have good eyes?
ex_2_jp: アメリカには目が三つある人々がすんでいる山があって、そこではまいとし二月八日におまつりがある。
ex_2_en: In America, there is a mountain where people with three eyes live and they hold a festival on February 8th every year.
ex_3_jp: うつくしいあおい目のおとこが大すき！
ex_3_en: I love men with beautiful blue eyes!
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it!

ex_1_jp: このじゃがいもを、ゆきだるまの目玉にします。
ex_1_en: I’ll use these potatoes for the snowman’s eyeballs.
ex_2_jp: 王女は目玉をコレクションするしゅみがあります。
ex_2_en: The princess' hobby is to collect eyeballs.
ex_3_jp: ようかいの目玉のようなぶどうだとおもう。
ex_3_en: I think these grapes look like monster eyeballs.
meaning_story: What is an eye ball? Oh wait, that's easy. It's an eyeball!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 目玉, however, is an exception. Perhaps this is because it includes a body part (the eye) in it, which often makes a word switch to kun'yomi readings. Either way, it doesn't matter too much. Both the readings you learned for the kanji in this word are the kun'yomi, meaning you should know how to read this one. Just make sure you watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 二月三日にけっこんしました。
ex_1_en: I got married on February third.
ex_2_jp: 二月は、日本いきのチケットがとてもやすいです。
ex_2_en: In February, air tickets to Japan are very cheap.
ex_3_jp: きょねんの二月に、わたしたちのふりんははじまったの。
ex_3_en: Our affair began in February of last year.
meaning_story: The kanji 月 means both month and moon (because moon cycles take about a month, presumably). So, what is the number two month? It's not January... it's not March... it's February!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. That is true with this word as well. Make sure to take note that 月 is using the がつ reading and not the げつ one. This is true for all "month words" in Japanese.
pitch_accent: ニカ°ツꜜ *** ニカ°ツ *** フタꜜツキ *** フタツキꜜ *** フタツキ

ex_1_jp: 五日もしごとをやすみました。
ex_1_en: I took five days off from work.
ex_2_jp: 六月五日はともだちのたんじょう日です。
ex_2_en: June 5th is my friend's birthday.
ex_3_jp: 五日めに、「これでおしまい。」といった。
ex_3_en: On the fifth day I said, "That's it!"
meaning_story: Day five or the fifth day. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading_story: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way: On the fifth day I have to eat (いつ) five cars. Now imagine yourself eating five cars. How did you manage to get past the first one? I'm impressed.

ex_1_jp: かいてんずしで、五十さらたべた。
ex_1_en: I ate fifty plates at conveyer belt sushi.
ex_2_jp: ある天才いしは、たったの五十えんでつうふうをなおすちりょうほうをはつめいしました。
ex_2_en: One genius doctor invented a cure for gout for only 50 yen.
ex_3_jp: ほぼ五十ねんかんあなたのことがすきでしたが、きのうさめました。
ex_3_en: I loved you for nearly fifty years, but yesterday that ended.
meaning_story: What happens when you have ten five times? You get fifty!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. That's the case for this word too, which means you should already know how to read this word.

ex_1_jp: はやく火をけしてください。
ex_1_en: Please put the fire out soon.
ex_2_jp: 石をつかって火をおこしたことはありますか？
ex_2_en: Have you ever started a fire with stones?
ex_3_jp: 火は、かれのかみの毛をぜんぶやいてしまった。
ex_3_en: The fire burned off all of his hair.
meaning_story: This vocab is made from a single kanji, which means it shares the same meaning as the parent kanji: fire.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: What comes off of fire? Lots and lots of heat (ひ). Feel it coming off the fire, touching and warming your face.

ex_1_jp: トムさんは、コンビニでおにぎりを五こかいました。
ex_1_en: Tom bought five onigiri at the convenience store.
ex_2_jp: わたしのともだちはしょうわ五十五ねん五月いつかうまれです。
ex_2_en: My friend was born on May 5th in the 55th year of Showa.
ex_3_jp: むかしむかし、五ひきの子ぶたをうんだははぶたがいました。
ex_3_en: Once upon a time, there was a mother pig with five baby pigs.
meaning_story: This vocab is made from a single kanji, which means it shares the same meaning as the parent kanji: Five.
reading_story: Since numbers are an exception, this word is read using the on'yomi reading even though it's made from a single kanji all alone. Luckily for you, you learned the reading for this word when you learned the parent kanji.

ex_1_jp: わたしは五つもおもちをたべました。
ex_1_en: I ate five pieces of mochi.
ex_2_jp: 五十人の白人のアメリカ人女子が、五つのおまんじゅうをてにいれようときそいあっています。
ex_2_en: Fifty white female Americans are competing against each other to obtain five manju.
ex_3_jp: 人せいには五つのくるしみがあるが、その一つはへんずつうである。
ex_3_en: There are five hardships in life and one of them is migraines.
meaning_story: From previous number+つ words, you can probably guess that this word means five things.
reading_story: The reading of this word is the kun'yomi reading of the kanji 五, meaning you didn't learn it when you learned the parent kanji reading. To remember this word, think of it this way: You have five things. What do you have to do with them? You need to eat (いつ) them. If you come up with something crazy you have to eat, and focus on the fact that you must eat five of these things, it will help a lot too.

ex_1_jp: Tシャツを四十まいもっています。
ex_1_en: I have forty T-shirts.
ex_2_jp: あの天才アメリカ人は四十才です。
ex_2_en: That genius American is 40 years old.
ex_3_jp: 四十だいにもなると、ぜんしんがかゆい。
ex_3_en: Since reaching my forties, my entire body has been itchy.
meaning_story: What do you get when you have four tens? You get forty.
reading_story: As a jukugo word, you can usually assume that the reading will be on'yomi. That's half true. Since 四's on'yomi reading sounds too much like the word for "death" it will usually use its kun'yomi reading, which you learned when learning the kanji. So, 四 reads as kun'yomi and 十 reads as on'yomi.
pitch_accent: シジュꜜー *** ヨꜜンジュー

ex_1_jp: とうなんアジアを、四十二日かんりょこうしました。
ex_1_en: I took a forty-two day trip around Southeast Asia.
ex_2_jp: フランス人グルメは五月だけでさらうどんを四十二さらたべた。
ex_2_en: The French gourmet had 42 plates of Sara udon in May only.
ex_3_jp: そぼがトイレットペーパーを四十二ロールもかってきた。
ex_3_en: My grandma bought forty-two rolls of toilet paper.
meaning_story: Four tens plus two. That equals forty two. P.S. Please don't panic. "The Answer" is not a correct answer for this. It is just a reference to the greatest book of all time. Sorry for the confusion and so long and thanks for all the fish.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. The only exception to this is 四, which uses the kun'yomi reading, since the on'yomi reading sounds too much like the word for "death." But, since that's the reading you learned with the 四 kanji, it shouldn't be too much of a problem!

ex_1_jp: もんだい四は、えなどがありません。
ex_1_en: There are no pictures for question four.
ex_2_jp: 王のへやには大きい、白い一千万円玉が四こもある。
ex_2_en: There are four big, white, 10 million yen balls in the king's room.
ex_3_jp: おやしらずを四ほんともばっしした。
ex_3_en: I had all four of my wisdom teeth pulled out.
meaning_story: This vocab word has the same meaning as its parent kanji (single alone kanji usually do that!), meaning it means four.
reading_story: Both the reading よん and し are pretty common, but because the on'yomi reading し sounds just like the word for "death" it isn't used as much. Generally when you're just counting (for example, "1, 2, 3, 4...") you will use the reading し. But when you are counting things or people, you'll use よん. There are exceptions to this, but you'll learn them as they come up.

ex_1_jp: らい月の四日に、わたしと一しょにやきゅうをみにいきませんか？
ex_1_en: Why don’t you come watch baseball with me on the fourth of next month?
ex_2_jp: 七月四日はアメリカのどくりつきねん日です。
ex_2_en: July 4th is Independence Day in America.
ex_3_jp: あのくまに出あって四日ご、ぼくのせなかにかびがはえた。
ex_3_en: Four days after I met that bear, my back started growing mold.
meaning_story: Fourth day or day four. No matter how you look at this combination of kanji, the meaning of the word makes a lot of sense!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Counting days, however, are an exception (at least up to ten). You need to use the kun'yomi readings to read this word. You already know the kun'yomi reading for 四, so that's fine (the ん gets turned into a small っ, though). Think of it this way: On the fourth day you buy a yo-yo car, which they call a yo-car. (よっか). Why do you buy a yo-car on the fourth day? Because it's the only day the yo-car shop is open. The fourth of the month! Now walk the dog all the way home.

ex_1_jp: このはこには、みかんが四つあります。
ex_1_en: There are four oranges in this box.
ex_2_jp: 小さい玉ねぎを四つ下さい。
ex_2_en: Please give me four small onions.
ex_3_jp: 今朝、クロワッサンを四つか五つ食べました。
ex_3_en: This morning, I ate four or five croissants.
meaning_story: Any number with a つ attached is a word that means "NUMBER Things." In this case, it's four things.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can assume it uses the kun'yomi reading. Unlike most numbers kanji, you learned this kanji with the kun'yomi reading as よ or よん. This word probably uses the よん reading, though the ん is getting converted to a small っ.
pitch_accent: ヨꜜツ *** ヨッツꜜ *** ヨッツ

ex_1_jp: フォロワーが四千人になりました。
ex_1_en: I hit four thousand followers.
ex_2_jp: これは、ちゅうごく四千ねんのれきしがつくり上げた、せかいに一つしかないとうふです。
ex_2_en: This is the only tofu in the world created by China with great 4000 years of history.
ex_3_jp: 四千ぼんのでんちゅうをいっせいにたおせるくらい、きみのことをあいしているよ。
ex_3_en: I love you so much that I could knock down four thousand telephone poles at once.
meaning_story: You have four and you have thousand. Multiply them together and you have four thousand.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. That's true for the 千 part, but the 四 reading is kun'yomi. You should know how to read this word as long as you've been studying your kanji!

ex_1_jp: かれはしょうぎの天才です。
ex_1_en: He’s a shogi genius.
ex_2_jp: あのフランス人の女は天才だ。
ex_2_en: That French woman is genius.
ex_3_jp: そのゴリラは、まぎれもなく天才だ。
ex_3_en: That gorilla is definitely a genius.
meaning_story: A genius from heaven is still a genius.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

ex_1_jp: ですよ。そっちは女子トイレですよ。
ex_1_en: The girls’ room is over there.
ex_2_jp: わたしは女子ではなく、一人の女せいです。
ex_2_en: I am not a girl but a woman.
ex_3_jp: 女子力をみがくひつようがある。
ex_3_en: It is essential that I improve my strength as a woman.
meaning_story: A woman child is just a girl!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: さとうさんは、うたを上手にうたいます。
ex_1_en: Satou is good at singing.
ex_2_jp: オリーブオイルのつかいかたが上手な王子をしっていますか。
ex_2_en: Do you know any princes who are good at using olive oil?
ex_3_jp: わたしはへんがおをつくるのが上手です。
ex_3_en: I’m good at making funny faces.
meaning_story: Think of someone holding out their hand. This is average. Things rated below the hand are things you're bad at. Things rated above the hand are things you're good at.
reading_story: Both of these kanji use on'yomi reading, though 手 uses an on'yomi reading you didn't learn with the kanji. It's a rare reading, so it wasn't included (and we just have to deal with exceptions like this as we go along). To remember the reading for this word, here's a mnemonic: What are you good at? You're really good at taking your jo (じょう) to the zoo (ず) and hitting animals with it. What a weird thing to be good at. Imagine someone shouting at you from across the panda pen telling you that you're good at it too.
pitch_accent: ウワテ *** カミテ *** カミテꜜ *** ジョーズꜜ

ex_1_jp: 手がカサカサになってしまいました。
ex_1_en: My hands got really dry.
ex_2_jp: おれの女に手を出すな。
ex_2_en: Don't hit on my girlfriend.
ex_3_jp: せんせいの手はどうしてそんなにけぶかいの？
ex_3_en: Teacher, why are your hands so hairy?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Since this is a body part, the kun'yomi reading usually takes priority. That means you learned the kun'yomi reading already when you learned the kanji.

ex_1_jp: ポチは天のほしになりました。
ex_1_en: Pochi became a star in heaven.
ex_2_jp: わたしがコウイチから四千えんをぬすんだことを、天のかみさまはしっかりとみていました。
ex_2_en: God in Heaven definitely saw me steal Koichi's 4000 yen.
ex_3_jp: じゃんけんにかって、わたしは天にものぼるきもちだった。
ex_3_en: I won the rock-paper-scissors competition and I felt like I was in heaven.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it would normally use the kun'yomi reading. The kanji that makes this word only has one important reading, though, and that happens to be the on'yomi. Since you learned the on'yomi reading for this kanji, you've already learned the reading for this word.

ex_1_jp: データの入力をおえました。
ex_1_en: I finished inputting the data.
ex_2_jp: ここに王子のソーシャルセキュリティーナンバーを入力してください。
ex_2_en: Please enter the prince's social security number here.
ex_3_jp: 「ローマじ入力」と「かな入力」、どちらをつかっていますか？
ex_3_en: Do you use "romaji input" or "kana input"?
meaning_story: Enter something with all your strength and you will look down to see that what you're doing is inputting data. You're inputting it right now! Into this site! The answers you enter into WaniKani with all your strength can be said with this word. Wow. Full circle already, and you're only on level 2. Look at you go!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ニューリョク *** ニュꜜーリョク

ex_1_jp: わたしは一月にかんじを千こおぼえました。
ex_1_en: I learned one thousand kanji in January.
ex_2_jp: 一月うまれのアメリカ人と六月うまれのイタリア人では、どちらのほうがおおいとおもいますか。
ex_2_en: Which do you think there are more of: Americans who were born in January or Italians who were born in June?
ex_3_jp: 一月にたべるアイスクリームもわるくない。
ex_3_en: It’s not bad to eat ice cream in January.
meaning_story: Since the kanji 月 mean both moon and month (because a moon cycle is about a month, presumably), what is the number one month? In English we have an actual name for it, and that name is January.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. This is a specific month, so it uses the がつ reading.
pitch_accent: イチカ°ツꜜ *** イチカ°ツ *** ヒトꜜツキ

ex_1_jp: 日本のカレーはおいしいです。
ex_1_en: Japanese curry is delicious.
ex_2_jp: 十月から、日本にすみます。
ex_2_en: I'm gonna live in Japan starting in October.
ex_3_jp: 日本のかたちをしたケーキをやいた。
ex_3_en: I baked a cake shaped like Japan.
meaning_story: Remember the secondary meaning of 本? It's "origin." So, this word technically means "sun origin." Does that sound familiar? Japan's known as "The land of the rising sun." That's why Japan comes from 日本.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well, though take note that the 日 portion is shortened a bit. So instead of being にち it is just に.

ex_1_jp: 六月にとうきょうへいきました。
ex_1_en: I went to Tokyo in June.
ex_2_jp: 五月に刀を二本かって、六月にトーフグのオフィスでつじぎりをします。
ex_2_en: I will buy two katanas in May and test them at the Tofugu office in June.
ex_3_jp: 六月のてんきは、くもりときどきミートボールです。
ex_3_en: The weather for June is cloudy with a chance of meatballs.
meaning_story: Since the kanji 月 means both "moon" and "month," what is the sixth month of the year? January, February, March, April, May, June!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, this is a specific month, so it uses the がつ reading.
pitch_accent: ロクカ°ツꜜ *** ロクカ°ツ

ex_1_jp: あなたは、わたしのほんとうの子ではないの。
ex_1_en: You aren’t my real child.
ex_2_jp: そのロシア人の子は、大人になって、さけよりも上手に川を上れるようになりました。
ex_2_en: When that Russian kid grew up she got better than a salmon at swimming upstream.
ex_3_jp: わたしの子、ビヨンセににているとおもわない？
ex_3_en: Don’t you think my kid looks similar to Beyoncé?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You see a child and walk up to him. Then, you punch him in the face (oh no, how could you!!?). He flies through the air, and he's knocked out. A ref nearby yells that it was a "KO!" (こ). That's a knock out. Make sure you learn this reading pretty well too. Both readings for 子 are going to show up a lot, and this is how you're going to learn the kun'yomi one.

ex_1_jp: このくにの王はわたしだ。
ex_1_en: I am the king of this country.
ex_2_jp: 王の刀をみせてください。
ex_2_en: Please show me the King's sword.
ex_3_jp: 王さまでもカレーをたべるのだ。
ex_3_en: Even kings eat curry.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

ex_1_jp: わたしは、左ききです。
ex_1_en: I’m left-handed.
ex_2_jp: 左の山のなまえはなんですか？
ex_2_en: What's the name of the mountain on the left?
ex_3_jp: あのむすめが左みみのピアスをあけたときのことがわすれられない。
ex_3_en: I will never forget the time that girl got her left ear pierced.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, that's the reading you learned when you learned this kanji as well, so you already know how to read this vocab word.

ex_1_jp: あねの左手には、ほくろがある。
ex_1_en: My older sister has a mole on her left hand.
ex_2_jp: 左手を上げてください。
ex_2_en: Please raise your left hand.
ex_3_jp: 左手に、でんきゅうのタトゥーをほった。
ex_3_en: I got a light bulb tattoo on my left hand.
meaning_story: The kanji for "left" and the kanji for "hand." Put them together and you have a left hand.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This word, however, uses the kun'yomi readings, combined. This is possibly because of 手, which is a body part. When a body part is present in a word, often times it gets changed over to kun'yomi reading for who knows what reason. Either way, both kanji use the reading you learned in this word, so you should already know it.

pronunciation: びーだま, ビーだま
ex_1_jp: ビー玉をつかってゲームをしましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s play a game that uses marbles.
ex_2_jp: アメリカではまいとし一月にビー玉をつかったゲームが上手なフランス人がつどうコンテストがあります。
ex_2_en: In America, there is a contest every January where French people who are good at marbles gather.
ex_3_jp: かれは、けっこんのあかしに一つぶのビー玉をくれた。
ex_3_en: He gave me a single marble as proof of our marriage.
meaning_story: Presumably this ビー is short for the word "bead." Beads used to be glass, which means that if you have a glass bead ball, you probably have yourself a marble.
reading_story: If you know katakana as well as the reading that you learned when you learned the kanji 玉, you should be able to read this. Just watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 五がつ四かにくにへかえりました。
ex_1_en: I went back to my country on May fourth.
ex_2_jp: 五月にはゴールデンウィークがあります。
ex_2_en: Golden week is in May.
ex_3_jp: 五月に川へいきます。
ex_3_en: I’m going to a river in May.
meaning_story: The moon kanji also represents a month, so when you have five of these months, what month of the year is it? That would be May, the greatest month of the year (because it has towel day in it!).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, this is a specific month, so it uses the がつ reading.

ex_1_jp: いえの中は、エアコンがきいていました。
ex_1_en: The air conditioning was working well in the house.
ex_2_jp: おいそがしい中、おへんじを下さりありがとうございました。
ex_2_en: Thank you for giving me a response while you were busy.
ex_3_jp: りょうしんはこどもを中にしてすわっていた。
ex_3_en: The parents were sitting with their child between them.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Something is coming from the middle of the wall. It sounds like a knock (なか), knock, knock noise. You break down the wall, and sure enough there's some creepy dude standing inside. He is the knocker.

ex_1_jp: このきっぷは三千円です。
ex_1_en: This ticket is 3000 yen.
ex_2_jp: 王女があやしいアメリカ人と、王しつのかね一千まん円をもってよにげしてしまった。
ex_2_en: The princess took 10 million yen from the Royal Family and flitted away with a fishy American into the moonlight.
ex_3_jp: 円をアメリカドルにりょうがえしたいんです。
ex_3_en: I want to exchange my yen into American dollars.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This particular word is an exception, however, and uses the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned. Maybe this is because it's usually attached to other things, so it's treated more like a jukugo word. Either way, you already know the reading for it from the kanji, so you should be fine.
pitch_accent: エꜜン *** ツブラ *** ツꜜブラ *** マドイ *** マドꜜイ *** マル

ex_1_jp: こんやは月がきれいですね。
ex_1_en: The moon is beautiful tonight.
ex_2_jp: 六月はふじ山がやまびらきする月です。
ex_2_en: June is the month when Mt. Fuji officially opens.
ex_3_jp: ピンクの月が出たら、出ぱつのあいずだ。
ex_3_en: If the pink moon comes out, that’s our signal to leave.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Look up at that big, bright moon. You have to open it up and take what's inside. To do that, you are required to have two keys (つき), and they have to be turned at the same time. Imagine you and a friend both turning your keys on opposite sides of the moon to open up the center.

ex_1_jp: 九日に、いっしょにサッカーをみにいきませんか。
ex_1_en: Would you like to go watch some soccer with me on the ninth?
ex_2_jp: コウイチは九日もニッカにあっていないので、さびしくてしにそうだ。
ex_2_en: Since Koichi hasn't seen Nikka for nine days, he feels so lonely he could die.
ex_3_jp: マミのたんじょう日は四がつ九日だ。
ex_3_en: Mami’s birthday is April ninth.
meaning_story: Ninth day or day nine. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading_story: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both of the kanji. You learned this reading for 九 when you learned 九つ, so you should be able to read this one too!
pitch_accent: ココノカꜜ *** ココノカ

ex_1_jp: さらいねんの十月で、六十さいになります。
ex_1_en: Two years from now I will turn sixty in October.
ex_2_jp: 十月にはだんだんすずしくなってくるでしょう。
ex_2_en: It should gradually be getting cooler in October.
ex_3_jp: かれがおかしいのは、十月なのにすいえいにさそったわたしのせきにんだ。
ex_3_en: It’s my fault that he’s acting strange; I asked him to go swimming even though it is October.
meaning_story: The kanji for "moon" and "month" are the same, probably because a moon cycle takes approximately a month to occur. So, what is the tenth moon cycle of the year? That would be the awesome month October!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, this is a specific month, so it uses the がつ reading.
pitch_accent: ジューカ°ツꜜ *** ジューカ°ツ

pronunciation: いちにち, ついたち
ex_1_jp: きのうは一日テストのべんきょうをしていました。
ex_1_en: I was studying for the test all day yesterday.
ex_2_jp: 六月一日にアメリカ人とフランス人のふうふ二人がいっしょにエベレストをのぼりきったことは人々のきおくにあたらしい。
ex_2_en: The fact that an American and French couple succeeded to climb Mt. Everest on June 1st is still fresh in people's memory.
ex_3_jp: 本とうに一日でこの本をよんだんですか？
ex_3_en: Did you really read a book in one day?
meaning_story: This word has two different meanings. One day and first day. No matter how you look at this word, those meanings make a lot of sense.
reading_story: The first meaning is one day, and it has the same reading as the kanji you learned, so you should already know this reading. The reading for first day, however, is a big old exception. It doesn’t take the on’yomi or kun’yomi readings, and has its own special (weird) readings. Here’s a mnemonic to help you remember this one: On the first day of your new relationship you can get two touches (ついたち) only. That’s the rule! You can touch their hand and maybe high five. But that’s all you get. Just think when you’re on your first day of dating, two touches! Two touches only!
pitch_accent: イチジツ *** イチニチꜜ *** イチニチ *** ツイタチꜜ *** ヒトꜜヒ

ex_1_jp: そのライブには、一千まん人があつまった。
ex_1_en: Ten million people gathered at the live show.
ex_2_jp: その刀は、一千まんえんです。
ex_2_en: That katana is 10 million yen.
ex_3_jp: 一千フィートのたかさでおならをした。
ex_3_en: I farted at an elevation of 1000 feet.
meaning_story: If you have one thousand, you have one thousand.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The only thing that's a bit weird is the reading of the 一. The ち turns into a small っ, making the reading for this word いっせん.

ex_1_jp: 玉ねぎをきっていたら、なみだが出てきた。
ex_1_en: When I cut the onions, I teared up.
ex_2_jp: この玉ねぎを立たせることができたあなたは天才です。
ex_2_en: You must be a genius if you could make this onion stand up by itself.
ex_3_jp: きみは玉ねぎをいくつわきにはさめるかい？
ex_3_en: How many onions can you hold under your armpits?
meaning_story: ねぎ means "onion" in Japanese. But, there are different kinds of onions, right? This happens to be a "ball onion," which is just one of those round ones, like a Walla Walla Sweet Onion. Do you know?
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can guess it will probably use the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, that's the reading you learned with the only kanji in this word, so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: なぜ人々はくるまをかうのでしょうか？
ex_1_en: Why do people buy cars?
ex_2_jp: おおくのパプアニューギニアの人々は水中でもいきができるらしい。
ex_2_en: I heard that many Papuan people can breathe underwater.
ex_3_jp: このちいきの人々は、みんないい人ばかりです。
ex_3_en: The people in the area are all just good natured people.
meaning_story: Person person, why, that's more than one person. It's people! It's everybody!
reading_story: The reading is the vocab word 人 twice, with the second one getting rendaku'd, turning it into びと.

ex_1_jp: 王子は、じょうばをはじめました。
ex_1_en: The prince started horseback riding.
ex_2_jp: あの王子の左手は大きい。
ex_2_en: The Prince's left hand is big.
ex_3_jp: 王子がかえるにキスをすると、そのかえるは王子をたべてしまった。
ex_3_en: After the prince kissed the frog, the frog ate the prince.
meaning_story: A king kid is the prince. Someday he'll be the 王, if he's lucky, but right now he's just the king's child.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also take note that the reading for 子 (し) is changed to じ.

ex_1_jp: 王子は、王女のうつくしさにうっとりしました。
ex_1_en: The prince was enchanted by the princess’ beauty.
ex_2_jp: 王は王女に木のつくえをかってあげました。
ex_2_en: The king bought a wooden desk for the princess.
ex_3_jp: 王女さまはよろこびをバクてんでひょうげんしているようです。
ex_3_en: The princess expresses her joy by doing backward somersaults.
meaning_story: The "king woman" is the princess. How do you tell this word apart from 女王, which means "queen?" Well, the 女 part comes before the 王 when it's a queen, because the queen always comes before the princess (they're usually pretty selfish in the stories, right?). As for the princess, the 女 comes after the king, because she doesn't have as much power. That's why this one is princess.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: けさ、子犬がうまれました。
ex_1_en: The puppies were born this morning.
ex_2_jp: その子犬は王子にもらった九つの玉をくびから下げて入り口に立っていた。
ex_2_en: The puppy that was standing at the entrance was given the nine balls around its neck by the prince.
ex_3_jp: 子犬ごっこをしましょうよ。
ex_3_en: Let’s pretend we’re puppies!
meaning_story: A child dog is a puppy!
reading_story: Even though this is a jukugo word, it doesn't use the on'yomi readings. Both the kanji 子 and 犬 often favor kun'yomi readings, and this word is no exception. The reading for 犬 is the one you already know, and the reading for 子 as こ is a really common one (perhaps you've already learned that reading?). If not, just think about punching a puppy in the face, and giving it a KO (That's a knock out).

ex_1_jp: それは、女王のいすです。
ex_1_en: That is the queen’s chair.
ex_2_jp: 女王は目が大きくてかわいい王女のことが大きらいです。
ex_2_en: The queen hates the princess because she is cute and has big eyes.
ex_3_jp: エリザベス女王と文つうをはじめた。
ex_3_en: I started exchanging letters with Queen Elizabeth.
meaning_story: The woman who comes before the king is no princess. This is the queen.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あしたはかぞくみんなで田をたがやします。
ex_1_en: Tomorrow we’re tilling the rice field with the whole family.
ex_2_jp: そのフランス人は四十ユーロで田を一つかいました。
ex_2_en: That French person purchased a rice field for 40 euros.
ex_3_jp: わたしのファーストキスは、田んぼのかかしにうばわれた。
ex_3_en: My first kiss was stolen by a scarecrow in a rice paddy.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When you learned the kanji that makes up this word, all you learned was the kun'yomi reading, so you should be good to go.

ex_1_jp: 右のしゃしんは、とうきょうでとったしゃしんです。
ex_1_en: The photo on the right was taken in Tokyo.
ex_2_jp: 右には王の好きなメイドが五十人、ひだりには王子のすうはいする天才かがくしゃが一人いる。
ex_2_en: On the right are fifty of the king's favorite maids and on the left is a genius scientist who worships the prince.
ex_3_jp: うまが右にまがったとき、ロバは右をチラリとみた。
ex_3_en: When the horse turned to the right, the donkey glanced right as well.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, that's the reading you learned when you learned this kanji as well, so you already know how to read this vocab word.

ex_1_jp: 山下さんは、右手にくろいかさをもっています。
ex_1_en: Yamashita has a black umbrella in her right hand.
ex_2_jp: 小さい女の子が、右手にビー玉をにぎりしめて立っていた。
ex_2_en: There was a little girl holding a marble in her right hand.
ex_3_jp: 右あし、右手、右めをつかうほうがすきだ。
ex_3_en: I prefer to use my right foot, right hand, and right eye.
meaning_story: The kanji for "right" and the kanji for "hand." I don't think it gets any clearer than this!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This word, however, uses the kun'yomi readings, combined. This is possibly because of 手, which is a body part. When a body part is present in a word, it usually changes to the kun'yomi reading for who knows what reason. Either way, both kanji use the reading you learned in this word, so you should already know it.

ex_1_jp: 円いおさらをつくえにならべてください。
ex_1_en: Please line up the round plates on the desk.
ex_2_jp: 円いまどがあるのが、王女のへやです。
ex_2_en: The room with the round window is the princess's.
