ex_3_jp: わたしは円い月がこわい。
ex_3_en: I’m afraid of the full moon.
meaning_story: This word is made up of a single kanji with hiragana attached to it. That hiragana ends with い which means it's an adjective. So, what's the adjective form of the kanji that's in this word? 円 means both "yen" and "round" but in this case we're looking at the round one (because something isn't going to be "yenny"). The adjective version of round is round or circular. Just like a yen coin, this "round" is a flat round. As in, if you draw a circle on a piece of paper, you could use this word. Same goes with yen, which is why "yen" and "round" both use the same kanji.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The reading for the 円 portion of this word is the same as a kanji you're learning in this level: 丸. That kanji means something really similar to this kanji. And guess what? They also share a reading. So, if you know that the reading of 丸 is まる then you'll also know that the reading for this word is まる!

ex_1_jp: らい月の二日に、あねとえいがをみにいきます。
ex_1_en: I will go see a movie with my older sister on the second day of next month.
ex_2_jp: 王子が子犬をおってふじ山のじゅかいにきえてから二日がたちました。
ex_2_en: It's been two days since the prince followed the puppy and disappeared in the woods of Mt. Fuji.
ex_3_jp: ひらがななんて、しんけんにべんきょうすれば二日あれば十ぶんさ。
ex_3_en: If you study diligently, two days is enough to learn hiragana.
meaning_story: Second day or day two. No matter how you look at this combination of kanji, the meaning of the word makes a lot of sense!
reading_story: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way: The circus is in town this weekend and you can't wait to get there. You want to show off your new foots car (ふつか) to all the circus clowns. But you have to use your feet to get it there and it ends up taking you two days! Darn this old fashioned foots car!

ex_1_jp: かぜで、七日かんもねこんでいました。
ex_1_en: I was in bed for seven whole days because of a cold.
ex_2_jp: まい月七日に、おはかまいりをします。
ex_2_en: I visit our family grave on the 7th of every month.
ex_3_jp: たった七日でかいしゃをやめた。
ex_3_en: I left the company after only seven days.
meaning_story: Seventh day or day seven. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading_story: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way: You've been stuck inside working for seven days and today you finally have a day off. Your friend asks you if you want to go for a drive but you say, "Nah, no car today" (なのか), because you've been cooped up long enough. Seven days is too long to be inside.

ex_1_jp: 山本さんのでんわばんごうは、六一二の七七三六ですね？
ex_1_en: Is Yamamoto’s phone number 612-7736?
ex_2_jp: 六じにふじ山であいましょう。
ex_2_en: Let's meet at Mt. Fuji at six o'clock.
ex_3_jp: 六かける六は三十六ですよね？
ex_3_en: Six times six is thirty-six, right?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. Numbers, as you know, are the exception to this rule. They usually use the on'yomi reading, and the on'yomi reading is the one you learned along with this kanji, meaning you should be good to go!

ex_1_jp: 十六さいのたんじょうびにふじ山にのぼりました。
ex_1_en: I climbed Mt. Fuji on my sixteenth birthday.
ex_2_jp: もう十六ねんもふじ山の入り口からうごかないアメリカ人がいます。
ex_2_en: There is an American who hasn't moved away from the entrance of Mr. Fuji for 16 years.
ex_3_jp: わたしはえいえんの十六さいです。
ex_3_en: I am forever sixteen.
meaning_story: You have ten and six (not to be confused with six tens!). When you have ten and six, you have a total of sixteen.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well!

ex_1_jp: 二人は、せん月の六日に、どこであいましたか？
ex_1_en: Where did you two meet on the sixth of last month?
ex_2_jp: 六日もがっこうをやすんで、いったいなにをしてたんだい？
ex_2_en: What were you doing when you took six days off of school?
ex_3_jp: 月の六日目に、くまがバーにやってきた。
ex_3_en: A bear came into the bar on the sixth day of the month.
meaning_story: It's the kanji for six and day. Put them together and you have the sixth day (or day six).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This is an exception, though. When you're counting days (at least one through ten), the kun'yomi readings are used. So let's think about that sixth day - what does it entail? The cow (moo / むい) is standing on top of your car (か). Why? Because you only feed the cow once a week, and that is on the seventh day. He's standing there on the sixth day because he's super hungry and knows it's almost time.

ex_1_jp: わたしのへやには、テーブルが一つと、いすが六つあります。
ex_1_en: In my room, there is one table and six chairs.
ex_2_jp: 川から石を六つもってかえりました。
ex_2_en: I brought back six stones from the river.
ex_3_jp: わたしは、六つのカップをかいました。
ex_3_en: I bought six packs of cups.
meaning_story: Any number with a つ attached to it means you are counting that number of things. In this case, it's six things.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can guess that it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you do that: What are the six things that you need to count? This time you are counting six cows (むっつ). The reason it's six, you know, is because you wanted a half a dozen cows. No more, no less.

ex_1_jp: このふくは、わたしには小さいです。
ex_1_en: These clothes are small on me.
ex_2_jp: このクラスには、まだ小さい子もいれば、大人のように大きい子もいる。
ex_2_en: In this class, there are kids who are still small while there are kids who are as tall as adults.
ex_3_jp: ぼくのりそうのマリモは、小さい玉ねぎのようなマリモだ。
ex_3_en: My ideal marimo would look like a small onion.
meaning_story: This kanji has hiragana attached and ends with an い sound. That means it's probably an adjective (and it is!). So, if you take the kanji 小 and its meaning (small), you can figure out the adjective version of it. What is the adjective version of "small?" Actually, it's the same thing: small.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the ちい portion: When you think of the word small, try to think of this cheese (ちい) store. You go inside, and all of their cheeses are so small. They hand you a magnifying glass to see all the cheeses. You look at them and exclaim: "Why are these cheeses so small???"

ex_1_jp: これは、こうしえんの土です。
ex_1_en: This is Koshien’s turf.
ex_2_jp: このビー玉を七つ土にうめたら、天のこえがきこえます。
ex_2_en: If you bury seven of these marbles, you will hear the voice of heaven.
ex_3_jp: マットのしゅみは、土をほりあげることだ。
ex_3_en: Matt’s hobby is digging dirt.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: You look through the soil. You're trying to find something. As you dig and sift, you come across not one but two cheeses (つち). Pull them out of the ground and put them in your mouth. How do the two cheeses taste and compare?

ex_1_jp: 人にむかって石をなげるんじゃない。
ex_1_en: You shouldn’t throw stones at people.
ex_2_jp: 石が一つくつに入った。
ex_2_en: A stone got in my shoe.
ex_3_jp: 石と石がぶつかるおとにいらいらする。
ex_3_en: The sound of stones colliding annoys me.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, that is the reading that you learned, meaning you should know how to read this word as well!

ex_1_jp: そろそろ日がのぼるじかんだ。
ex_1_en: It is time for the sun to rise.
ex_2_jp: きょうは、トーフグがけっこんするたいせつな日です。
ex_2_en: Today is the important day that Tofugu is getting married.
ex_3_jp: 日がおちると、すぐにあたりはまっくらになって、わたしは本をよむことができなくなってしまった。
ex_3_en: Shortly after sunset, it became so dark that I couldn’t read my book anymore.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Take note that this word means both "sun" and "day," though. Why? because the sun takes a day to go around and come back!
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: What do you feel from the sun? You feel the heat (ひ).

ex_1_jp: あのさむらいに、刀をぬすまれたんだ。
ex_1_en: My sword was stolen by that samurai.
ex_2_jp: あのアメリカ人は刀を二ほんもっている。
ex_2_en: That American has two katanas.
ex_3_jp: スラリと刀をぬいたあのおとこはだれだ？
ex_3_en: Who’s the guy who just whipped out a sword?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well!
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. I'm hoping you already know this word - that will make everything much easier. It's かたな (you know what a katana is, right?).
pitch_accent: カタナꜜ *** カタꜜナ *** トꜜー

ex_1_jp: このくすりを、十日かんのんでください。
ex_1_en: Please take this medicine for ten days.
ex_2_jp: 十日でかんせいさせてください。
ex_2_en: Please complete it within ten days.
ex_3_jp: 七月十日はそふのめい日です。
ex_3_en: The tenth of July is the anniversary of my grandfather’s death.
meaning_story: Tenth day or day ten. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading_story: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way: Ten days is just TOO (とお) long from now. Maybe less would have been okay, but ten is too much.

ex_1_jp: 二人は、せんせん月の三日にどこであいましたか？
ex_1_en: Where did those two people meet on the third, two months ago?
ex_2_jp: 三日も水をのんでいません。
ex_2_en: I haven't had water for three days.
ex_3_jp: 三月三日はひなまつりです。
ex_3_en: The third day of March is Girl’s Day.
meaning_story: Third day or day three. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Counting days, however, are an exception (at least up to ten). You need to use the kun'yomi readings to read this word. You already know the kun'yomi reading for 三 from when you learned the word 三つ. Here is a way to remember the reading for 日: On the third day you have to give me (み) a ride in your car (か). I don't have a car of my own, so don't forget me, okay?

ex_1_jp: このりょうりの本は、千円です。
ex_1_en: This cookbook is one thousand yen.
ex_2_jp: そのフランス人は、千に一人の天才です。
ex_2_en: That French person is one-in-a-thousand genius.
ex_3_jp: 白玉を千こたべた。
ex_3_en: I ate a thousand rice flour dumplings.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Normally a single kanji making up a word like this means it will use the kun'yomi readings. Numbers are generally the exception, though, which means this word uses the on'yomi reading. If you learned the kanji, then you should already know this!

ex_1_jp: しせいを正しなさい。
ex_1_en: Sit up straight.
ex_2_jp: 王子はまちがいを正されてプライドがきずついた。
ex_2_en: The princes mistake was corrected and his pride was wounded.
ex_3_jp: あやまりを正すことができれば、ごほうびをあげるわ。
ex_3_en: If you can correct my mistakes, I’ll give you a reward.
meaning_story: This word is made up of a kanji with some hiragana attached, ending in an う sound. That means this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "correct," so what is the verb form of that? It would be to correct.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: After you correct something for someone, you yell out ta da (ただ) very excitedly. Go ahead and imagine yourself doing this a few times to help you to remember.

ex_1_jp: あちらの出口から出てください。
ex_1_en: Please leave using that exit.
ex_2_jp: くしゃみが出そうで出ない。
ex_2_en: It looks like you have to sneeze, but can't.
ex_3_jp: わたしは、パチンコやからいそいで出た。
ex_3_en: I made a hasty exit from that pachinko parlor.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "exit" so what is the verb form of this? It is to exit. Don't get this word confused with 出す, though, which means "to hand over" or "to take something out." You can remember that this word means "to exit" because it ends with る which sounds like the beginning of the word "room." What do you do with a room? you exit it.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to exit the room you're in. Why? Because it has a dead (で) body in it. Seriously. You should exit now.

ex_1_jp: つくえの上に、じしょを出してください。
ex_1_en: Please put the dictionary on the desk.
ex_2_jp: そのアメリカ人は、あしから二ひきのガラガラヘビにかまれたどくをぜんぶ出した。
ex_2_en: That American removed all the venom he got from two rattle snakes out of his leg.
ex_3_jp: どろぼうはぬすんだものをすべて出してくばった。
ex_3_en: The thief handed out all the goods he stole.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "exit" and this is kind of a verb form of this. The word means to remove or to hand over, so it's like you're doing the action of causing something else to exit (rather than exiting yourself). You can remember this because the hiragana す is like the word "sue." Imagine yourself grabbing her and removing her from a box. スーを出す.
reading_story: The part of the word that you have to learn how to read is the だ portion. So, you already removed Sue from the box. Who else is in there that you have to remove? It's your Dad (だ) as well. Go ahead and remove him from the box as well.

ex_1_jp: あそこに立っているのは、ぼくのあにです。
ex_1_en: That person standing over there is my brother.
ex_2_jp: その石の上に立ってください。
ex_2_en: Please stand on the stone.
ex_3_jp: あそこに立っているのが、あなたのみらいの子どもです。
ex_3_en: The person standing over there is your future child.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "stand" so what is the verb version of that? It's to stand.
reading_story: You have to remember the た portion of this word to learn the reading of it. Think of it this way: You have to stand up in order to wave goodbye to someone. When you stand up, you also say ta ta (た)!

ex_1_jp: ロウソクは、なん本立てますか？
ex_1_en: How many candles did you put out?
ex_2_jp: このしゃしん立てを立てるためのスタンドをさがしています。
ex_2_en: I’m looking for an easel for this photo frame.
ex_3_jp: ぼくのつくえにえんぴつを立ててくれませんか？
ex_3_en: Could you please stand some pencils up on my desk?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "stand" so what's the verb version? It's also "to stand." Don't confuse this with 立つ which also means "to stand." It's a different kind of "to stand." With this one, you're standing something up. As in, "I stood up the action figure" or "I will stand up the flag." You're doing the action of standing something up.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the た portion. In order to do that, think of yourself standing up a huge sign. On it it says in big words: " "ta ta!" (た).

ex_1_jp: いえのにわには、さくらの木があります。
ex_1_en: There is a cherry tree in my garden.
ex_2_jp: ともだちのアメリカ人のうちは、木とほねでできています。
ex_2_en: My American friend's house is made of wood and bones.
ex_3_jp: あのりんごの木からおちたのは、はじめてじゃない。
ex_3_en: It wasn’t my first time falling from the apple tree.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You walk up to the tree. You have to get inside, because it takes you someplace secret. So, you take out your key (き) and put it in the slot, opening the door in the tree so you can slip inside.

ex_1_jp: 水中でしか使えない。
ex_1_en: It can only be used underwater.
ex_2_jp: 右をみると、水中のせかいがひろがっていました。
ex_2_en: When I looked to the right, there was an underwater world in front of me.
ex_3_jp: 水中でめをあけることができません。
ex_3_en: I can’t open my eyes underwater.
meaning_story: If you're in the middle of a bunch of water, then you're most likely underwater.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ギターはまだ下手ですが、まいばんれんしゅうしています。
ex_1_en: I’m still bad at the guitar, but I practice every night.
ex_2_jp: アメリカ人のまねが下手な人は、フランス人のまねが上手です。
ex_2_en: The person, who is not good at imitating Americans, is good at imitating French people.
ex_3_jp: わたしははをみがくのが下手です。
ex_3_en: I’m bad at brushing my teeth.
meaning_story: Think of someone holding out their hand at shoulder level. Anything above that equals "skillful." Everything below that equals "unskillful". So, in the case of this word, "below hand" means "unskillful."
reading_story: If you're bad at something and you complain about it, then you're just a hater (へた). Don't be a hater.
pitch_accent: シタテ *** シタデ *** シモテ *** シモテꜜ *** ヘタꜜ

ex_1_jp: 大いにまなびましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s learn a lot!
ex_2_jp: 王は王子と王女に、「大いにこくみんのぜいきんをつかっていいぞ」といった。
ex_2_en: The king said to the prince and the princess, "Go ahead and use a lot of money from the citizen's taxes."
ex_3_jp: きょうは大いにのみたまえ。
ex_3_en: Please drink a lot today.
meaning_story: When you do something with (に) big, you do it very, or with a lot of something.
reading_story: You learned this reading when you learned 大きい. If you can remember that, you should be able to remember this one too!

ex_1_jp: 中々できません。
ex_1_en: I really can’t do it.
ex_2_jp: あの王子も中々やりますね。
ex_2_en: That prince is quite good, huh?
ex_3_jp: マリオカートをきわめることは中々かんたんではない。
ex_3_en: It’s not very easy to make oneself a master of Mario Kart.
meaning_story: The 々 symbol just repeats the kanji that comes before it. You'll see it from time to time, so take note of it, even though it doesn't really have any meaning of its own. So, essentially 中々 is the same as 中中. That being said, you have something that's middle x2. When something is even more middle than middle itself, it is very or considerably something or another.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the kun'yomi reading, since it's like putting two single kanji together rather than a true jukugo word. To learn the kun'yomi reading, take a look at this mnemonic: From the middle of the middle comes a sound. It is a knocking sound. Knock. Knock. Knock. You open up the walls around this thing. Then you open up the second set of walls (middle of the middle). Inside is an old man, who identifies himself as "the knocker." You go inside of him and find another knocker as well. That's why it's a knocker knocker (なかなか).

ex_1_jp: 火山のふんかもありました。
ex_1_en: There was a volcanic eruption too.
ex_2_jp: ふじ山は火山です。いまから四十二じかんごにふんかします。
ex_2_en: Mr. Fuji is a volcano. It will erupt in 42 hours.
ex_3_jp: きっと火山にちがいない。
ex_3_en: I’m sure that’s a volcano.
meaning_story: A fire mountain is probably what you think it is: A volcano.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 山 reading is ざん instead of さん because of rendaku (sequential voicing).

ex_1_jp: 水かおちゃをもらえますか。
ex_1_en: Can I have some water or tea?
ex_2_jp: ふじ山にのぼるときは、水をわすれないようにしましょう。
ex_2_en: Don't forget to bring water when you climb Mt. Fuji.
ex_3_jp: コップ一ぱいの水とあいをください。
ex_3_en: Give me a cup of water and some love, please.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You take a look at some water. It jumps out and takes the form of a woman. "Hello, my name is miss (みず) Mizu," she says.

ex_1_jp: テーブルに、白のおさらをならべてください。
ex_1_en: Can you put the white dishes on the table?
ex_2_jp: 七つの石のうち、三つは白でした。
ex_2_en: Three out of seven stones were white.
ex_3_jp: そのおとこは、ゆきのように白いので、白ゆきおとことなづけられた。
ex_3_en: The man was as white as snow, so he was named "Snow White."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: The word "sheer" means: "A very fine or diaphanous fabric or article." When you think of a sheer (しろ) piece of fabric, I think you generally think of a white piece of fabric.

ex_1_jp: はやく文をよんでください。
ex_1_en: Please read the sentence faster.
ex_2_jp: おどろいたことに、そのアメリカ人の文はイギリス人のわたしの文よりえいごが上手にかけていました。
ex_2_en: To my surprise, that American's English writing was written better than mine, and I'm British.
ex_3_jp: かなしい文をよむと、いつもなみだが二ふん二十びょうだけとまらない。
ex_3_en: Whenever I read a sad story I can’t stop crying for exactly two minutes and twenty seconds.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: You only had to learn one set of readings (on'yomi) for the parent kanji of this word. That means this word uses those readings as well, specifically the ぶん one when alone like this. You can remember this by thinking how whenever you're working on your writing, you get hungry and want to eat a "bun."
pitch_accent: フꜜミ *** フミꜜ *** ブꜜン *** モꜜン

ex_1_jp: わたしは五才です。
ex_1_en: I am five years old.
ex_2_jp: らい月二日に、六十七才になります。
ex_2_en: I'll turn 67 on the 2nd of the next month.
ex_3_jp: ちちの五十五才のたんじょう日に、ホグワーツへしょうたいされた。
ex_3_en: On my dad’s fifty-fifth birthday, I was invited to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.
meaning_story: Although this word consists of one kanji that is all alone, it doesn't share its meaning with the parent kanji. The meanings are similar in a way, though. This word means years old or age. With more years comes more genius, right? That's why this word means "years old" and not "genius," like the parent kanji. Hint: Stick this word onto numbers to say how old someone is!
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it! Don't try to type the 〜 part though.

ex_1_jp: リボンをつけている女の子がはな子ちゃんです。
ex_1_en: The girl wearing the ribbon is Hanako.
ex_2_jp: とてもかわいい女の子ですね。
ex_2_en: She is such a cute girl, isn't she?
ex_3_jp: ぼくのはつこいの女の子は、にんじんがきらいだった。
ex_3_en: The girl who was my first love didn’t like carrots.
meaning_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana stuck in the middle you can guess that it is like putting two separate words that you've learned together into one word. This hiragana is の, a particle that makes something possessive. In this case, the 子 is of the 女. Basically, this suggests that the woman is a child, aka a young lady or a girl.
reading_story: Since there's hiragana in here, you can bet that these kanji will use the kun'yomi readings. You already know the kun'yomi reading for 女. The only thing I have to make sure that you know is 子. When you need to remember the kun'yomi reading of 子, just think about you fighting a child (you're a jerk, apparently!). When you hit him in the face, he flies to the floor, and the ref calls out "KO!" because you just knocked the poor kid out.

ex_1_jp: ひゃくさいまで生きる人は少ない。
ex_1_en: There are few people who live to be 100 years old.
ex_2_jp: りょうりのレパートリーが少ないんです。
ex_2_en: I don't know how to cook many things.
ex_3_jp: びようしさんから、かみのけが少ないとよくいわれます。
ex_3_en: I’m often told by hairdressers that I don’t have much hair.
meaning_story: This word has a single kanji with hiragana attached, ending in a い. This means you know it's an adjective. What is the adjective form of the kanji 少? It's also few.
reading_story: The reading for this one is fairly difficult, as it's the kun'yomi reading (you can tell it's kun'yomi because of all the hiragana attached). You have to remember the すく part to remember the reading of this word. Think of it this way: You have a few of something. This something is suckers (すく). Imagine putting all (three-ish) of them in your mouth at once. How does it taste? Can you taste the flavors from each of the few?

ex_1_jp: ぎゅうにゅうは、少ししかありません。
ex_1_en: There is only little milk.
ex_2_jp: 少ししかのこってないよ。
ex_2_en: There are only a few left.
ex_3_jp: かれのプロポーズは少しあいまいだった。
ex_3_en: His proposal was a little vague.
meaning_story: This word is a single kanji with hiragana attached, though there is no specific clue as to what type of word it is. That means you can usually guess it's a noun, adverb or na-adjective (in this case it's a noun / adverb). The meaning of this word is pretty much the same as the kanji, though, making it fairly easy. The kanji meaning for 少 is few, and the meaning of the vocab form is a little or a few.
reading_story: Did you know that this word created an English word you probably already know? Have you ever heard someone say "just a skosh"? That's 少し! Hopefully you know this English word and therefore know this Japanese word as well.

ex_1_jp: 矢はなん本のこっていますか？
ex_1_en: How many arrows are left?
ex_2_jp: こいのキューピッドが矢をはなとうとしているよ。
ex_2_en: Cupid is about to fire an arrow.
ex_3_jp: ほくべい土人の矢じりがとんできた。
ex_3_en: A Native American arrowhead flew towards me.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

ex_1_jp: バスはなん台いりますか？
ex_1_en: How many buses do we need?
ex_2_jp: し力がよくなるきかいを三台ちゅうもんしました。
ex_2_en: I ordered three machines that makes your eyesight better.
ex_3_jp: あのかねもちしゃちょうはこうきゅうしゃを三台もっています。
ex_3_en: The rich company president has three luxury cars.
meaning_story: This counter is used with some kind of machine or device, usually a fairly large one (so nothing itty bitty). Cars are a good example of this. But it can also be used for things like computers, which were once the size of rooms, but are now nice and small. Thanks technology!
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Be sure to omit the 〜 in your answer as it is only a placeholder for a number.
pitch_accent: ウテナ *** ウꜜテナ *** ダꜜイ

ex_1_jp: 大さか市で生まれました。
ex_1_en: I was born in Osaka City.
ex_2_jp: 市のあたらしいマスコットキャラクターがけっていしました。
ex_2_en: The new mascot of the city has been decided.
ex_3_jp: きょうとの市バスの中で、はいてしまった。
ex_3_en: I puked on a Kyoto city bus.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

ex_1_jp: しゃちょうは牛をかっているらしい。
ex_1_en: Apparently the company president is raising a cow.
ex_2_jp: かの女は、牛がらのドレスをきて、牛どんやに行ってきました。
ex_2_en: She came to a gyudon restaurant in a cow-spot patterned dress.
ex_3_jp: デイブは、牛にゅうのために牛をかっている。
ex_3_en: Dave keeps cows for milk.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: You're leading the cows around the field. To get them to move, you yell out "USH, USH, USH!" (うし) because you have a speech impediment and want to say "MUSH MUSH MUSH." Go ahead and say this out loud, yelling it if you can.

ex_1_jp: 戸口に手ぶくろがおちていました。
ex_1_en: A glove was dropped in the doorway.
ex_2_jp: たまたま、戸口でぬすみぎきしてしまったんです。
ex_2_en: I eavesdropped it at the doorway by accident.
ex_3_jp: 戸口に三枚のトーストがあった。
ex_3_en: There were three pieces of toast in my doorway.
meaning_story: Do you remember the words 出口 (exit) and 入り口 (entrance) from previous levels? The 口 can be a doorway of some kind. This word is literally "door mouth" but I bet you can figure out that this actually means doorway.
reading_story: The reading for this one is mixed. You get the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, even though it's a combo (jukugo) kanji. Since 戸's only reading is the kun'yomi reading you should know it. Also, you should know the kun'yomi reading for 口 as well from level 1. That means as long as you remember that this is a kun'yomi fest over here, you should be able to read this word. Also watch out for the rendaku (also known as sequential voicing). That just means the く becomes the voiced ぐ.
pitch_accent: ココー *** コꜜコー *** トꜜク°チ *** トク°チ

ex_1_jp: かれはまち外れの小さないえにすんでいます。
ex_1_en: He lives in the outskirts of town.
ex_2_jp: 王女は、きせつ外れのドレスをきていた。
ex_2_en: The princess was wearing a dress that doesn't suit the season.
ex_3_jp: 「あたりが出ると、もう一本」とかかれたアイスをかったが、ぜんぶ外れだった。
ex_3_en: I bought some ice cream that had, "If you hit, you get another" written on them, but they were all misses.
meaning_story: The kanji 外 alone means "outside." This word means extremity. How can you remember this? Just think of the れ as a "ray of sunshine." Where you are, in the extremity of space, even the れs of the sun cannot be seen. So, when 外 is combined with れ just think of this.
reading_story: Let's continue the previous story: You're off in the extremity of the space. You are at the edge, and you look further. All you can see is a sticky yellow haze (はず) out in the infinite beyond.

ex_1_jp: 山田さんのまゆげはとても太いです。
ex_1_en: Yamada’s eyebrows are very thick.
ex_2_jp: このおみせのめんはおもったより太かったです。
ex_2_en: This shop's noodles are thicker than I expected.
ex_3_jp: おれの母ちゃんは、ちょう太いんだぜ。
ex_3_en: My mom is so fat.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of the kanji 太? It's the same: Fat.
reading_story: This is the kun'yomi reading of the kanji (because it's a single kanji, all alone with hiragana attached). The part you have to remember is the ふと portion. Let's use a mnemonic. The fat guy looked down and couldn't see his foot (ふと).

ex_1_jp: 父がいるから、さびしくありません。
ex_1_en: I’m not lonely because my father is here.
ex_2_jp: わたしの父は、ドイツ人です。
ex_2_en: My father is German.
ex_3_jp: 父はうしのちちをしぼるのがうまい。
ex_3_en: My father is very good at milking cows.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is the polite and humble form of father. You use this when you're talking about your own father to other people, especially if you aren't very close to them.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

ex_1_jp: お父さんはまい日リンゴをたべます。
ex_1_en: My father eats an apple every day.
ex_2_jp: お父さんにだって分からないことはある。
ex_2_en: Even your father has something he doesn't understand.
ex_3_jp: お父さんのねこはかわいい。
ex_3_en: My dad’s cat is adorable.
meaning_story: This word begins with an honorific (お) making whatever comes after it more elevated. Then there's 父, which you know means father. Lastly, we have the honorific (things you put on people's names in Japanese) さん. This is a nice way to say father. You use it when you're talking to your own dad or talking about him with friends. You can also use this when you're talking about your friends' dads. If you need to talk about someone's father that you don't really know, or you aren't close to, you'll want to use お父様, instead. Don't worry, you'll learn that last kanji in a few lessons. Until then, it's pronounced, おとうさま. Kay?
reading_story: The part you have to learn to read is the 父 portion. This uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn when doing the kanji. Imagine your venerable father standing in front of you. Except, instead of being a human, he is a giant toe (とう). Imagine him talking to you, giving you high fives, whatever. Just make it as ridiculous as possible while you're saying "Yes father. Yes father. Whatever you say, father."

ex_1_jp: たいじゅうけいを五台かいました。
ex_1_en: I bought five scales.
ex_2_jp: あのいえのまえに、パトカーが五台もとまっている。
ex_2_en: There are five police cars parked in front of that house.
ex_3_jp: 五台のバンがげきとつしてめりこんだ。
ex_3_en: The five vans smashed into each other.
meaning_story: As long as you know both of the individual kanji meanings, you should be able to put together this one to get five machines.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 田中さんのむすめさんは外人さんとけっこんしたんだよ。
ex_1_en: Tanaka’s daughter got married to a foreigner.
ex_2_jp: でんしゃでよっぱらった外人にからまれた。
ex_2_en: A drunk foreigner tried to pick a fight with me on the train.
ex_3_jp: 日本人と外人のあしのながさはかなりちがう。
ex_3_en: Leg length is quite different between Japanese people and foreigners.
meaning_story: An "outside person" is a foreigner. This word is fairly common, though it's not super polite, either. It's okay most of the time, but it can be used derogatorily depending on the situation. The more polite version is 外国人 (outside country person) but you won't learn that until you learn the kanji for 国.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, you can remember that for this word it uses じん because foreigners like to wear jeans (じん).

part_of_speech: NOUN, PREFIX, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 生チョコをつくりました。
ex_1_en: I made ganache.
ex_2_jp: 生のやさいはにが手です。
ex_2_en: I don't like raw veggies.
ex_3_jp: 生ビール一ちょう、下さーい。
ex_3_en: Give me a bottle of draft beer!
meaning_story: Normally a single kanji alone like this would mean the same thing as its parent kanji, but in the case of 生 it's a little different (but still related). When you think of something that has life, it's something that's very fresh or raw. Think sashimi or sushi, for example. You want that to be as close as possible to life as you can. That's why you eat it when it's fresh, and that's also when you eat it raw. You'll see this word at the beginning of other words. For example, 生たまご is "raw egg."
reading_story: This uses one of the kun'yomi readings. To remember this one, though, think this: When you get a raw fish in Japan, you never want to name (なま) it, because you'll probably have to eat it (and that would be traumatizing!). Just imagine yourself actually doing that - how terrible would that be?
pitch_accent: ウꜜブ *** キꜜ *** セꜜイ *** ナꜜマ *** ナリꜜ

ex_1_jp: 友人のけっこんしきで、とうきょうにいっていました。
ex_1_en: I went to Tokyo for my friend’s wedding.
ex_2_jp: さらい月、アメリカ人の友人が日本にあそびにきてくれます。
ex_2_en: An American friend will come to Japan to visit me the month after next.
ex_3_jp: あにの友人に、こく白された。
ex_3_en: My brother’s friend told me he has feelings for me.
meaning_story: A person who is a friend is just that, a friend!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あしの毛がボーボーです。
ex_1_en: My leg hair is bushy.
ex_2_jp: うちの犬の毛はよくぬける。
ex_2_en: Our dog's fur falls off a lot.
ex_3_jp: 今一ばん大切なのはあたまの毛だ。
ex_3_en: Right now the most important thing to me is the hair on my head.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Look down! You're wearing something covered in fur. It's a fur kevlar (け) vest! All kevlar is just really tightly woven fur. Didn't you know?

ex_1_jp: 今、公用でパリにきています。
ex_1_en: I’m coming to Paris now on official business.
ex_2_jp: これは公用のアカウントです。
ex_2_en: This is an official account.
ex_3_jp: おれたちがぬすむのは公用のかねだ。
ex_3_en: We’re gonna steal government money.
meaning_story: A public task is going to be government business. You have to think of this public as government to know the meaning of this word easily.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: わたしはこのえいがを三かい半みました。
ex_1_en: I’ve watched this movie three and a half times.
ex_2_jp: JLPTまであと一ヵ月半しかありません。
ex_2_en: There is only a month and a half left until the JLPT.
ex_3_jp: かの女は半じゅくたまごのようにかわいいね。
ex_3_en: She is as cute as a half-cooked egg.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it's supposed to use the kun'yomi reading. But, there is no useful kun'yomi reading for this kanji, so even the single kanji vocab word version uses the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned!

ex_1_jp: この本を半分までよみました。
ex_1_en: I’ve read halfway through this book.
ex_2_jp: このクラスのがくせいの半分は女子です。
ex_2_en: Half of this class's students are girls.
ex_3_jp: ざっくり日本人の半分ぐらいは、にんじゃです。
ex_3_en: Roughly half of all Japanese people are ninjas.
meaning_story: You have half a part. Half a part is still half, right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ハンブꜜン *** ハンブン

ex_1_jp: せつなさで、心がしめつけられた。
ex_1_en: My heart constricted with longing.
ex_2_jp: おもわず心の中でさけんでしまった。
ex_2_en: I couldn't help shouting in my mind.
ex_3_jp: もしアンパンマンがれいこくな心をもっていたらどうしよう。
ex_3_en: I wouldn’t know what to do if Anpanman had a cruel heart.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Imagine a giant heart sitting in a rowing boat. It's also drinking cocoa. Focus on all three of these parts and associate them into one story / memory. Once you've done that, sing the "coccoa row" (こころ) song! I don't know what that song is, but I want you to make one up and actually sing it, out loud. If you do, I bet you won't forget this word's reading too easily.
pitch_accent: ココꜜロ *** ココロꜜ *** シꜜン

ex_1_jp: 今日は、おげんきですか？
ex_1_en: Hello, how are you?
ex_2_jp: 「今日は」はひらがなでかくことの方がおおい。
ex_2_en: "Konnichiwa" is often written in hiragana.
ex_3_jp: 大きなこえで、「今日は」といいましょう。
ex_3_en: Let’s shout, "hello."
meaning_story: This is a strange one. It's こんにちは, which you've probably heard before, but it's spelled using the kanji now and day. So when you say "now day!" you're really saying hello! Warning! Don't mix this up with きょう は! While they may look the same, they don't mean the same thing. We will only ever ask you for こんにちは, so please try to remember that!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be aware that the は at the end is actually the particle は so it's pronounced like わ.

ex_1_jp: これは、メアリーが大切にしている人ぎょうです。
ex_1_en: This is the doll that Mary treats with a great deal of care.
ex_2_jp: そばにいてくれる友人やこい人、かぞくを大切にした方がいいですよ。
ex_2_en: You should cherish your friends, partner, and family who stand by you.
ex_3_jp: 大切なしょるいときくと、いつも中みをみたくなる。
ex_3_en: Whenever I hear that a document is very important, I always want to look at what’s inside.
meaning_story: Think back to the old old olden days. Back when decisions were made with swords. A big cut is going to be important. Just imagine a couple samurai squaring off, then charging, then making one big cut. It's the most important thing they'll do in their lives (if they live!).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: はこの内がわをピンクいろにぬってください。
ex_1_en: Please paint the inside of the box pink.
ex_2_jp: てきは内にあり。
ex_2_en: There is an enemy within.
ex_3_jp: 内にひめたおもいを、日きにつづった。
ex_3_en: The thoughts I hide inside myself were spelled out in my diary.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: There's something inside and you wanna get to what's within. Look inside. Ooh, cheese (うち)! Your favorite. Ooh cheese, how I love you.

ex_1_jp: 戸をたたかないでください。
ex_1_en: Please don’t knock on the door.
ex_2_jp: うちのねこは戸をカリカリするのがすきです。
ex_2_en: My cat likes scratching the door.
ex_3_jp: この戸は立てつけがわるい。
ex_3_en: This door opens and closes hard.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: それは大いにてんきに左右される。
ex_1_en: That really depends on the weather.
ex_2_jp: ビエトのサスペンダー、左右のいろがちがっていておしゃれだね。
ex_2_en: Viet's suspenders have different colors on the right and the left, it's so fashionable!
ex_3_jp: みちをわたるまえに、左右をよくたしかめましょう。
ex_3_en: Make sure you look both ways before crossing the street.
meaning_story: Put left and right together and you end up with left and right! Just make sure you say them in the right order!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned these readings yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you see something moving left and right, you can't help but remember that time someone tried to saw you (さゆう) in half. It was at a magic show and all you can remember was the saw moving left and right, left and right, as the magician tried to saw you in half.

ex_1_jp: わたしがベーコンをたべなくなって久しい。
ex_1_en: It’s been a long time since I stopped eating bacon.
ex_2_jp: へいわボケして久しい日本人には、おそらくりかいできないだろう。
ex_2_en: Japanese people have taken peace for granted for so long that they probably can't understand it anymore.
ex_3_jp: かれが生のきんぎょをたべてしんでから久しい。
ex_3_en: He ate a raw goldfish and has been dead for a long time now.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of long time? Well, it's also long time.
reading_story: You actually learned the kun'yomi reading for this when you learned the kanji, which is what's being used here (single kanji, hiragana attached, kun'yomi no brainer!). So, if you've been studying your kanji, you should know the reading already!

ex_1_jp: 久しぶりですね！
ex_1_en: Long time no see!
ex_2_jp: 久しぶりのビールは、なみだが出るほどおいしかった。
ex_2_en: Beer after being sober for so long was so good it brought me to tears.
ex_3_jp: 久しぶり！とあったことのない人にいわれた。
ex_3_en: I was told "long time no see" by a person that I had never met before.
meaning_story: This is kind of a "set phrase" in Japanese, though we're going to treat it like a vocab word here (because it's so common and useful!). You know that 久 means "long time" - so now let's pay attention to the kana: しぶり. Just imagine that she buried you alive, then a few days later came back to dig you up. The first thing she says is "LONG TIME NO SEE!"
reading_story: The reading for this word is actually the same as the one you learned in the kanji. So as long as you know that, you can read the kanji part of this word (and then the hiragana portion after is a cinch, right?).
pitch_accent: ヒサシブリ *** ヒサシブリꜜ

ex_1_jp: ここからえきまで、あるいて十五分かかります。
ex_1_en: It’s a fifteen minute walk from here to the station.
ex_2_jp: 王子と王女と女王がほとんどぜんぶたべてしまったので、王の分は玉ねぎ半分しかのこっていませんでした。
ex_2_en: Because the prince, the princess, and the queen ate most of it, the only remaining portion left for the king was half an onion.
ex_3_jp: ふぐを七分かんくすぐればどうなるかしっている？
ex_3_en: Do you know what a blowfish would do if you tickled it for seven minutes?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This word is almost always attached to something, which is probably why this single kanji vocab word uses the on'yomi reading instead of the kun'yomi one. If you know the kanji reading, you know this vocab's reading as well.

ex_1_jp: お母さんはどこ？
ex_1_en: Where’s mom?
ex_2_jp: ひこうき代なら、お母さんが出してあげるよ。
ex_2_en: I'm your mother, so I can pay for your flight for you.
ex_3_jp: お母さんのはなげはながい。
ex_3_en: My mom’s nose hair is long.
meaning_story: This word starts with お which makes it more polite. Then, there's the kanji 母 which you know means mother. Last, there's the honorific さん which further adds respect (to the mother). So, this is the nice way to say mother. You use it when you're talking to your own mom or talking about her with friends. You can also use this when you're talking about your friends' moms. If you need to talk about someone's mother that you don't really know, or you aren't close to, you'll want to use お母様, instead. Don't worry, you'll learn that last kanji in a few lessons. Until then, it's pronounced, おかあさま. Kay?
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You have to remember the かあ portion. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: What does your super nice mother do for you (this is why you're so polite to her!)? She drives you all around in her car (かあ) taking you wherever you need to go... soccer, kendo, whatever. What a nice mother you have!

ex_1_jp: 母はタクシーにのりました。
ex_1_en: My mother got in a taxi.
ex_2_jp: いもうとは、どんどん母ににてきました。
ex_2_en: My younger sister is getting to look like our mother more and more.
ex_3_jp: 母はとうふとふぐがすきだ。
ex_3_en: My mother likes tofu and fugu.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is the polite and humble form of mother. You use this when you're talking about your own mother to other people, especially if you aren't very close to them.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but this is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just remember, your mom is a terrible person and won't stop laughing at you: "HA HA HA HA HA!"

ex_1_jp: そぼは市立びょういんに入いんしています。
ex_1_en: My grandmother is hospitalized at the municipal hospital.
ex_2_jp: 市立としょかんまでのみちをおしえてください。
ex_2_en: Please tell me the direction to the municipal library.
ex_3_jp: 大さか市立大がくのまえでさか立ちをした。
ex_3_en: I stood on my head in front of Osaka City University.
meaning_story: The city stand is municipal in nature. Municipal means "of or relating to a city or its governing body", and this vocabulary means just that. Or just city. City is fine too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: えきの北には、びょういんがあります。
ex_1_en: There is a hospital on the north side of the station.
ex_2_jp: 北ちょうせんが又ミサイルをはっしゃした。
ex_2_en: North Korea launched a missile again.
ex_3_jp: 北アメリカのゆうれいはとてもこわい。
ex_3_en: The ghosts in North America are so scary.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're going to the far north where it's very cold (north pole, perhaps?). One of the most important things you bring with you is a survival kit (きた).

ex_1_jp: 今、しんぶんをよんでいます。
ex_1_en: I’m reading the newspaper right now.
ex_2_jp: おれは今までなにをしていたんだ。
ex_2_en: What was I doing until now?
ex_3_jp: 今から、ヘルメットにおはようといいます。
ex_3_en: Now I’m going to say good morning to my helmet.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: What'll you drink now? I'll have a Zima, ima. Say "ZIMA IMA" ten times fast.

ex_1_jp: ぜんぶで十人いました。
ex_1_en: There were 10 people, altogether.
ex_2_jp: トーフグにはなん人のしゃいんがいますか？
ex_2_en: How many workers are in Tofugu?
ex_3_jp: わたしは三人子どもがいます。
ex_3_en: I have three children.
meaning_story: When you see this on a number, for example 7人 or 3人, you're using it to count people. Just remember, both 一人 and 二人 have alternative readings. From 3 and up it's just the number plus にん, like this. ５人 is ごにん, １０人 is じゅうにん, etc. This is the counter for people, which makes this word the number of people.
reading_story: The reading is the にん reading of this kanji. Just think of a number of people, all ninjas, standing there as you count them out.
pitch_accent: ニꜜン *** ヒトꜜ *** ヒト

ex_1_jp: さとうさんの犬は、とても大人しいです。
ex_1_en: Satou’s dog is very obedient.
ex_2_jp: なんなのアイツ。がっこうでは大人しいいんキャのくせに。
ex_2_en: What's with that guy? He is just a quiet nerd at school.
ex_3_jp: 大人しい子どもだったよ。
ex_3_en: He’s an obedient kid.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 大人 means "adult?" Well this is the adjective version of that. The I-adjective (see how it ends in い?). What adjective do adults want to be able to use for their own kids? They want to say they are obedient, quiet kids!
reading_story: You already learned this reading when you learned 大人! You should be able to read this too!

ex_1_jp: そのふくは古いので、もういりません。
ex_1_en: Those clothes are old, so I don’t need them anymore.
ex_2_jp: 古いものにしがみついていては、あたらしいものをうけとることができません。
ex_2_en: If you hold onto old stuff, you can't get anything new.
ex_3_jp: ガレージで、古いパンツをみつけた。
ex_3_en: I found an old pair of underwear in our garage.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of the kanji 古? It's also old.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji with some hiragana attached, it's going to use the kun'yomi reading. You learned the on'yomi when learning the kanji portion, so let's use a mnemonic to help you with the reading of this word: If you're old, you're also full (ふる) of memories. And you're probably full of old secrets. And you're full from old people food.

ex_1_jp: 山下さんはわたしの兄ににていますね。
ex_1_en: You look like my older brother, Mr. Yamashita.
ex_2_jp: 一ヶ月まえに兄がくろラブをつれていえにかえってきました。
ex_2_en: A month ago, my older brother came home with a black labrador.
ex_3_jp: 兄は、とうふにコーヒーをかけてたべるのがすきだ。
ex_3_en: My older brother likes eating tofu covered in coffee.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This implies that it is your older brother, by the way. Not somebody else's.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you learned this reading already, making you awesome at reading this vocab word as well.

ex_1_jp: どれがたかしのお兄さんですか。
ex_1_en: Which one is Takashi’s older brother?
ex_2_jp: 今日のたっきゅうびんのお兄さんのかおがタイプすぎた。
ex_2_en: The mailman's face was totally my type today.
ex_3_jp: お兄さんのはなげがきになってしかたがない。
ex_3_en: I can’t help thinking about my older brother’s nose hair.
meaning_story: This word starts with an お to make it more polite. Then it has the kanji 兄 which you already know. Lastly, it has さん which is an honorific to elevate people and be polite. This is basically the formal way of saying "older brother" (versus plain old 兄).
reading_story: The reading for this one is pretty tricky, and I'd consider it an exception. To remember it, you have to learn the 兄 part, and everything else will fall into place. Here's a mnemonic to help you: Your (kind) older brother pushes you down on the ground. You stand up and look at your knee (にい), which is all bloody. "Why'd you do that to my knee!?" you ask. "You're supposed to be a nice older brother, that's why I call you お兄さん!

ex_1_jp: パチンコで十万円かちました。
ex_1_en: I won one hundred thousand yen at pachinko.
ex_2_jp: このアイフォンは、十万六千九ひゃく円でした。
ex_2_en: This iPhone cost me 106,900 yen.
ex_3_jp: ウォッカをのむと、すう十万でん子ボルトものエネルギーがみなぎってくる。
ex_3_en: Whenever I drink vodka, I get pumped full of hundreds of thousands of electron volts.
meaning_story: Ten ten thousands is equal to one hundred thousand.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このテレビは、一台四万九千円です。
ex_1_en: These televisions are forty-nine thousand yen each.
ex_2_jp: 今はパソコン一台でかせぐじだいですからね。
ex_2_en: We're living in an era where you can make a living with a single computer.
ex_3_jp: タクシーを一台よんでください。
ex_3_en: Could you call me a taxi?
meaning_story: As long as you know the two kanji that make up this word, you should be able to figure out the meaning of this word as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 人生ってすばらしい。
ex_1_en: Life is wonderful.
ex_2_jp: 人生オワタ ＼(＾o＾)／
ex_2_en: My life is over. ＼(＾o＾)／
ex_3_jp: 人生はバナナのようなものさ。どれだけながいのかだれもしらないのさ。
ex_3_en: Life is like a banana, you never know how long it will be.
meaning_story: The kanji for person and life combined makes you think about human life. What is your human life like?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: きのう、元つまにあってきました。
ex_1_en: Yesterday, I ran into my ex-wife.
ex_2_jp: 元のきじはけされてしまいました。
ex_2_en: The original article was deleted.
ex_3_jp: 元もとは、月の出しんなんです。
ex_3_en: I’m originally from the moon.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're trying to trace a person back to their origin so you can learn more about them. You finally get there - it's a castle. The problem is that it's surrounded by a huge moat (もと) and you can't get past it because the drawbridge is up. Feel the frustration of this. Think about your goal and how close you are to getting to it if it wasn't for this lousy moat.

ex_1_jp: 外でまちましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s wait outside.
ex_2_jp: ねこたちは、まどの外にいるとりをジーッとみています。
ex_2_en: The cats are staring at the bird outside of the window.
ex_3_jp: 今日は一日中外であくびをしていた。
ex_3_en: I kept yawning outside all day today.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look outside, it's totally frozen. You throw salt (そと) outside to melt the ice.

ex_1_jp: 今はシアトル市にすんでいます。
ex_1_en: I live in Seattle now.
ex_2_jp: わたしのお母さんは、シアトル市でそだちました。
ex_2_en: My mother grew up in Seattle.
ex_3_jp: あなたのへんがおしゃしんを、シアトル市におくります。
ex_3_en: I will send that funny picture of you to Seattle.
meaning_story: The name of the city (シアトル／しあとる) with a 市 attached to it means it is "the city of ____." You can do this with any city (try it out on your hometown!). Because of this, you should know that this word means Seattle, or more specifically City of Seattle.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 中古ですが、ベンツをかいました。
ex_1_en: It’s used, but I bought a Benz.
ex_2_jp: このあたりは、中古ショップがじゅうじつしています。
ex_2_en: There are a lot of secondhand stores in this area.
ex_3_jp: 中古のかぐのような人とはけっこんしたくない。
ex_3_en: I don’t want to get married to someone who is like a piece of used furniture.
meaning_story: The combination of kanji doesn't make perfect sense, but it's alright. Take something that's middle old and you have something that's used or secondhand. It's not 100% old yet... it's still in the middle, meaning you can give it to someone else to use, like your younger siblings.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: チュꜜーコ *** チューコ *** チューブル

ex_1_jp: やきゅうのしあいは、あめで中止になりました。
ex_1_en: The baseball game was called off due to rain.
ex_2_jp: ざんねんですが、このきかくはいったん中止することになりました。
ex_2_en: Sorry, but it was decided that this project will be canceled for now.
ex_3_jp: たのしみにしていた生ほうそうが中止になった。
ex_3_en: The live show I had been looking forward to was canceled.
meaning_story: When something is in the middle of an action but it's stopped, this means it's put into suspension. Imagine getting frozen while you're running. It's kind of like that.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: なにも用がない。
ex_1_en: I have nothing to do.
ex_2_jp: なにかご用ですか？
ex_2_en: Do you need me for something?
ex_3_jp: 用もないのにでんわしてくんじゃねーよ。
ex_3_en: Don’t call me unless you have a reason.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: パソコンを十台ちゅう文しました。
ex_1_en: We ordered ten computers.
ex_2_jp: ぼうはんカメラを十台せっちしました。
ex_2_en: We installed ten surveillance cameras.
ex_3_jp: たんじょう日にはでんたくが十台ほしい。
ex_3_en: I want ten calculators for my birthday.
meaning_story: If you know the two kanji separately, you should be able to put them together to form the meaning of this kanji.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: わたしのぜんざいさんは一万円です。
ex_1_en: Ten thousand yen is all I have.
ex_2_jp: 一万RTいったら、こく白します。
ex_2_en: If this gets ten thousand retweets, I'll confess my love.
ex_3_jp: ちくしょう！にせの一万円さつをつかまされた。
ex_3_en: Crap! I was cheated into accepting a fake 10,000 yen bill.
meaning_story: When you have one ten thousand you just have ten thousand. In Japanese, though, you specify how many ten thousands you have, though (which is weird in English, but should make sense if you think about it).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本へのひこうきだいは、十万五千円でした。
ex_1_en: The plane ticket to Japan cost 105,000 yen.
ex_2_jp: まいとしコウイチは、バレンタインデーに万たんいのチョコレートをもらいます。
ex_2_en: Every year Koichi receives tens of thousands of chocolates on Valentine's Day.
ex_3_jp: ごしゅうぎのそうばは大たい三万円です。
ex_3_en: The estimate on a congratulatory gift is approximately 30,000 yen.
meaning_story: When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's ten thousand!
reading_story: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this. Numbers use the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned by learning the kanji's reading! How nice!
pitch_accent: バꜜン *** マꜜン *** ヨロズ *** ヨꜜロズ

ex_1_jp: 今月は大じなしけんがあります。
ex_1_en: There is an important exam this month.
ex_2_jp: おそくとも、今月の中じゅんまでにかんせいさせてください。
ex_2_en: Please complete this by the middle of this month, at the latest.
ex_3_jp: 今月は、ちょうのちょう子があまりよくない。
ex_3_en: My stomach hasn’t been feeling well this month.
meaning_story: The now month is actually this month.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日よう日、ヤンさんの子どもが生まれました。
ex_1_en: On Sunday, Yang’s child was born.
ex_2_jp: マイケルせん手の、力づよいフルスイングから生まれるホームランのかずかずをごらんください。
ex_2_en: Please watch this home run produced by the strong swing of the player Michael.
ex_3_jp: 生まれたばかりの子どもに、さけをのませるな。
ex_3_en: Do not make a newborn baby drink alcohol.
meaning_story: Since this is a kanji with hiragana attached that ends with an う sound, you know that this word is a verb. What's the ultimate verb version of the kanji 生? That would have to be phrase to be born. You can distinguish this one from 生む because this word is longer. Why is it longer? Because "to be born" must be a horrifying feeling. Although giving birth must be painful too, just imagine how long and terrifying getting born must be. That's why it feels longer.
reading_story: You have to remember the う part of this word to read it. To remember that, let's use a mnemonic: Just imagine someone being born. All they do is scream: UUUUUuuUuuUUUuuuUUUuu (う) the whole time. Go ahead and imagine yourself being born and doing the same thing. Say UUUuuUUuuu out loud to help you to remember.

ex_1_jp: テープが切れてしまいました。
ex_1_en: The tape was cut.
ex_2_jp: でんわが切れるおとをきくとさみしくなる。
ex_2_en: I feel lonely as soon as the phone line disconnects.
ex_3_jp: この小刀はよく切れる。
ex_3_en: This knife cuts well.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means cut so this means something is cut. Something breaks or snaps. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to be cut.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the き portion: Something is snapping. Turns out that something is your arm. Your arm is a tree (木, き) that grew out of you one day. "What's this ki doing here?" you ask. Then it suddenly breaks in half! "OW OW OW! My ki! It's been cut!!"

translation: to be disconnected, to be out
ex_1_jp: あみ戸が外れてしまいました。
ex_1_en: The sliding door came off.
ex_2_jp: けがをして、スタメンから外れることになっちゃったんだ。
ex_2_en: I got injured, so I'm going to be taken off the starting players.
ex_3_jp: プラグが外れたので、Mr.ロボットはありがとうといえなくなった。
ex_3_en: Since the plug was disconnected, Mr.Robot was no longer able to say, "thank you," anymore.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means outside so this is when something goes too far outside and disconnects. Something comes off. No direct object here, see? That's why this verb means to be disconnected or to be out.
reading_story: You have to remember the はず portion of this word. Think of it this way - you're on your phone and you are disconnected. Why were you disconnected? You look around and see a yellow haze (はず) floating around, melting everyone's phones. Well that's lame. Too bad you can't call anyone to help you get your phone back.

part_of_speech: SUFFIX, TRANSITIVE VERB, AND GODAN VERB
ex_1_jp: つぎに、かみをハサミで切ります。
ex_1_en: Next, you will cut the paper with your scissors.
ex_2_jp: いとを切るはさみをさがしています。
ex_2_en: I'm looking for thread nippers.
ex_3_jp: うっかりかみのけをみじかく切りすぎちゃったけど、そのあといぜんよりもよくナンパされるようになった。
ex_3_en: Even though I accidentally cut my hair shorter than I intended, more people have been flirting with me since.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cut, and the verb form of that is to cut.
reading_story: When you think to cut something, what do you think about cutting? One thing is cutting down a tree, which is also known as 木, or き. You きる a き.

ex_1_jp: 今日のしゅくだいは、二十一ページの二ばんです。
ex_1_en: Today’s homework is question two on page twenty-one.
ex_2_jp: 今日はいつもよりうり上げが少ない。
ex_2_en: Today's sales are less than usual.
ex_3_jp: あら、今日が私のたん生日だったんですか？
ex_3_en: Oh, was today my birthday?
meaning_story: The now day is what day? Oh, it's today.
reading_story: The reading for this word is a complete exception, though the word itself is incredibly common and useful. When you think of "today" think about what you have to do today for work. You have to work in one of those mall kiosks (きょう). Just think about how sad you are that you have to do this today. What a crummy day. It's sunny outside and you're stuck in a mall manning this hermit crab kiosk. Note: This reading mnemonic is pretty far away from the actual reading, as far as reading mnemonics go. Use this to get yourself close, and then use your own brain grapes to get the rest of the way there. This one won't be as easy as most of the others, but do some good old fashioned memorization and you should be okay. I won't ask you to do this much, fortunately. :)

ex_1_jp: さいきん、たべすぎで少し太りました。
ex_1_en: I’ve gotten a little fat from overeating lately.
ex_2_jp: たべても太らない人がうらやましい。
ex_2_en: I envy people who don't get fat even though they eat a lot.
ex_3_jp: 太れば太るほど、わたしはおなかがすく。
ex_3_en: The fatter I get, the hungrier I become.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fat so the verb form of that is to get fat.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You have to learn the ふと portion of this word to be able to read it. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You're getting fat so quickly that you can see your body expanding. You look down - at first you can see your foot (ふと) but then a second later you can't. You can't see your foot because you're getting fat, even when you stick your foot way out. What's going on?

ex_1_jp: かれのはつげんは、ぎもんを生んだ。
ex_1_en: His remark produced problems.
ex_2_jp: ごかいを生むようなとうこうはしないでください。
ex_2_en: Please do not post things that could give rise to misunderstandings.
ex_3_jp: おっとの子ではなかったが、生むしかなかった。
ex_3_en: Even though it wasn’t my husband’s, I had no choice but to give birth to the baby.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "life" so what is the verb form of that? Would it be "to do life"? No, probably not. In this case it is to give birth. You'll have to differentiate this one from the word 生まれる as well. You can remember that this one means "to give birth" because when you compare, the act of giving birth probably feels shorter than the act of being birthed, at least in terms of sheer terror. The pain of giving birth will make it feel quick, when you look back on it... but just imagine how traumatized the baby must be from going through that as well. So, the act of giving birth is shorter, just like the word itself!
reading_story: You have to remember the う part of this word to be able to read it. It's the same as 生まれる, so that could help if you've learned that word already. If not, just imagine yourself giving birth, and all you can do is scream: "UUuUUuuUUuUuu!" (う).

ex_1_jp: しつれんで生きるき力をうしなった。
ex_1_en: I lost the will to live from heartbreak.
ex_2_jp: 今、かれが生きているのかすら分かりません。
ex_2_en: I don't even know if he's alive now.
ex_3_jp: わたしの大好きなアニメキャラが、今生きるかしぬかのせとぎわにいる。
ex_3_en: My favorite anime character is currently in a critical moment between life and death.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "life," making this word mean "to live."
reading_story: You have to remember the い portion of this word to be able to read it. Think of it this way and you should be able to remember it, though: What does it mean to live? Life is pretty icky (いき ... the き comes from the hiragana part), but you have to take that ickiness and roll with it if you want to have a good life... if you want to live!

part_of_speech: INTRANSITIVE VERB, TRANSITIVE VERB, AND GODAN VERB
ex_1_jp: 十引く四は六です。
ex_1_en: Ten minus four equals six.
ex_2_jp: どうせ、女のきを引くためにいってるだけでしょう。
ex_2_en: He probably says that stuff just to get attentions from girls.
ex_3_jp: 引きがねを引いて、フライパンをうった。
ex_3_en: I pulled the trigger and shot the frying pan.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pull and the verb version vocab means to pull. This word has another meaning! When you pull numbers away from other numbers, what you're really doing is subtracting them. That's why this word also means to subtract.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading (ひ) is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it!

ex_1_jp: このにくまんを二人で分けましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s split this meat bun between two people.
ex_2_jp: 生しを分けるけつだんになった。
ex_2_en: It was a decision that spelt the difference between life and death.
ex_3_jp: ピザを半分に分けるなら、大きい方を下さい。
ex_3_en: If you split the pizza, could you give me the bigger half?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う (in this case る) sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means separate (at least, that's one of its several meanings). So, the verb form of that is to separate. You'll have to differentiate this word with 分かる which is very similar but has a totally different meaning. You'll need to learn the reading to do this, but think of it this way: You must "separate" your Wake (わけ) time from your sleeping time.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are to separate a couple of children that really have fun together. When you separate them, they begin to cry and scream: WAAAAAAAAAHHHH (わ). Poor kids.

ex_1_jp: あかしんごうで、くるまは止まりました。
ex_1_en: The car stopped at the red signal.
ex_2_jp: 心ぞうが止まるかとおもった。
ex_2_en: I was so surprised I thought my heart leapt into my mouth.
ex_3_jp: こおりの上で、止まることができなかった。
ex_3_en: I couldn’t stop on the ice.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stop and the verb vocab version of that is to stop. Now, this word refers to when something stops... not when you're doing the action of stopping something. It's stopping on its own (ex "the car stops.") You can remember this because it has a ま in it, and Ma always stops all the bad things that you're doing.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You come to a stop sign. Careening down the road is a giant toe (と) driving a car. He sees the stop sign which causes him to slam on his brakes and to stop. He's also driving around with your ma (ま) if that helps you to remember it any better.

ex_1_jp: おんがくを止めてください。
ex_1_en: Stop the music please.
ex_2_jp: 三びょうかんいきを止めてください。
ex_2_en: Please hold your breath for 3 seconds.
ex_3_jp: かれがはしりさるのを止めるひつようがある。
ex_3_en: We need to stop him from running away.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stop and the verb vocab version of that is to stop something. This particular word is when you're stopping something (i.e. doing the action of stopping it).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to stop something from moving. Maybe a car... or a door... or a person... whatever you want. To stop this thing, you throw out your toe (と), getting it smashed in the process. Imagine it bleeding and swelling up. How much it hurts! You put your toe out to stop this big thing, what a mistake!
pitch_accent: トドメꜜル *** トメル *** ヤメル

ex_1_jp: おいしいかどうか分かりません。
ex_1_en: I don’t know if this tastes good.
ex_2_jp: 分かるような、分からないような。
ex_2_en: I kind of got it, but I am not sure if I understood all of it.
ex_3_jp: 日本ごは分かりますか？
ex_3_en: Do you understand Japanese?
meaning_story: This is a strange meaning for this kanji. This word means to understand and the kanji means many things (understand is one of the lower meanings, which is why I didn't include it in the kanji). This word will often be written in kana alone, but it's written in kanji enough that I thought you should learn it. Think about it this way: You have to separate cars (か) into different groups. Why? Because that's the only way to understand their behaviors and culture. All the Hyundais over here... All the Toyotas over there... Now study them to understand.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you separate all the cars out to understand them, they get really sad. They like being together with their car friends. So, they begin crying and wailing. "WAHHHHHH" (わ) they cry out. "WAHHH."

ex_1_jp: Tofuguににたなまえを用いるものがいます。
ex_1_en: There is a person who uses a name similar to Tofugu.
ex_2_jp: 北ちょうせんは、かくへいきをおどしに用いる。
ex_2_en: North Korea uses nuclear weapon to threaten others.
ex_3_jp: えをかくために用いるふでで、かの女をくすぐった。
ex_3_en: I tickled her with a brush used for painting.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means Task and use. This verb is like a more formal way to say "use," and that is to utilize.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to learn the もち portion of もちいる: What will you utilize to get the job done? You have mochi in your hand, so you'll use that. Now go think of some kind of imaginary task you'll complete with mochi, making it as ridiculous as possible.
pitch_accent: モチイꜜル *** モチール

ex_1_jp: このぶどうは二万円もしました。
ex_1_en: These grapes were 20,000 yen!
ex_2_jp: 二万フォロワーおめでとうございます。
ex_2_en: Congratulations on twenty thousand followers!
ex_3_jp: 二万ドルかけるよ。
ex_3_en: I will bet twenty thousand dollars.
meaning_story: When you have two ten thousands, you have twenty thousand.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どうしてけいたいを二台もっているんですか。
ex_1_en: Why do you have two cell phones?
ex_2_jp: コウイチの母のいえには、ピアノが二台ある。
ex_2_en: There are two pianos at Koichi's mom's house.
ex_3_jp: うちのトイレにはテレビが二台しかない。
ex_3_en: There are only two televisions in our bathroom.
meaning_story: When you combine these two kanji, you should be able to see how it forms the word two machines.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どちらの方がすきですか。
ex_1_en: Which one do you prefer?
ex_2_jp: あちらの方に行ってください 。
ex_2_en: Please go that direction.
ex_3_jp: かの女のわらい方がきらいだ。
ex_3_en: I don’t like the way she laughs.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. That's the one you learned when learning the kanji, so you should be good to go!

ex_1_jp: 友だちのへやは、広くてきれいです。
ex_1_en: My friend’s room is spacious and clean.
ex_2_jp: あのフランス人はおでこが広い。
ex_2_en: That French person has a wide forehead.
ex_3_jp: すげー広いな！
ex_3_en: Wow, this place is huge!
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of wide? It's also wide.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned in the kanji section: ひろ, making this ひろい.

ex_1_jp: ことしの冬は、ゆきがたくさんふりました。
ex_1_en: It snowed a lot this winter.
ex_2_jp: きょねんの冬にかいたえです。
ex_2_en: It's an illustration I drew last winter.
ex_3_jp: 冬をなめるといたい目にあうぞ！
ex_3_en: Don’t make light of winter or you’re sure to have a painful experience.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the kun'yomi reading you learned for the kanji, meaning you should know both!

ex_1_jp: わたしは女の人にいじめられた。
ex_1_en: I was bullied by a woman.
ex_2_jp: そのカフェは女の人だらけでした。
ex_2_en: The cafe was full of women.
ex_3_jp: 女の人としゃべるのがにが手です。
ex_3_en: I’m not good at talking to women.
meaning_story: The の particle makes it so the 人 belongs to the 女. Basically, this literally means "a woman person" or "a person of woman." It's a more polite way to say plain old woman, though, so all you have to remember is that.
reading_story: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). That being said, in level 1 you learned about the vocab readings for these separate words, so use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.

pronunciation: しょうじょ, おとめ
ex_1_jp: その少女は、ゆうめいなアイドルです。
ex_1_en: That young lady is a famous idol.
ex_2_jp: 久しぶりに、天才少女ゴルファーがあらわれました。
ex_2_en: A genius, girl golfer has appeared for the first time in a long time.
ex_3_jp: 犬と少女が、はまべをかけていった。
ex_3_en: The dog and the young lady ran on the beach.
meaning_story: A little woman is a young lady.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 他人のかねにたよるな。
ex_1_en: Don’t rely other people’s money.
ex_2_jp: 他人のあなたには分からないでしょうが、この玉ねぎはわたしのいのちのおん人なんです！
ex_2_en: Being that you are someone other than myself, you may not understand, but this onion is my lifesaver.
ex_3_jp: 他人とは思えないほど親切にしてくれたんだけど、単に自分の叔母さんと私を間違えていただけみたい。
ex_3_en: He was kinder to me than I could have ever expected from a stranger, but it was just because he thought that I was his aunt.
meaning_story: When you have an other person, you really have another person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: そうそう, はやばや
ex_1_jp: 早々におへんじいただきありがとうございます。
ex_1_en: Thank you for your prompt reply.
ex_2_jp: 年まつだからか、人々が早々とすぎさっていく。
ex_2_en: I wonder if this is because it's the end of year, but people are passing by quickly.
ex_3_jp: 新年早々、借金を催促されるなんてひどすぎる。
