ex_3_en: It’s too cruel to demand money right after the start of the new year.
meaning_story: Essentially you have the kanji 早 twice, because 々 is just a repeater kanji. When you have something early twice, it obviously has some kind of urgency to it. You'll need to take an action as soon as you finish whatever it is you're doing there.
reading_story: The reading is just the on'yomi readings (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

ex_1_jp: 大気おせんマップを毎日チェックしています。
ex_1_en: I check the atmospheric pollution map everyday.
ex_2_jp: そらがあおいのは、ちきゅうの大気の分子があおとみどりのひかりをさんらんするからです。
ex_2_en: The sky is blue because blue and green lights are scattered in all directions by the air molecules in Earth's atmosphere.
ex_3_jp: 今日も、ぜんこく的に大気のじょうたいがふあんていです。
ex_3_en: Air conditions are unstable nationwide again today.
meaning_story: If there is a big energy it's going to fill up the atmosphere! Think about big energies you feel in the atmosphere: thunderstorms, tornadoes, the aurora borealis. Just remember, this is the atmosphere in the sky, not the atmosphere in a fancy restaurant.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ぶじに、女の赤ちゃんがうまれました。
ex_1_en: The baby girl was born without complications.
ex_2_jp: このかわいい女の子の赤ちゃんの名まえはエマちゃんです。
ex_2_en: This cute baby girl's name is Emma.
ex_3_jp: あなたの赤ちゃんの頃の写真が見てみたいわ。
ex_3_en: I want to see a picture of you from when you were a baby.
meaning_story: ちゃん is the honorific you put on a child's name. So, who is this mysterious child you're calling red? When a baby is born, what color are they? You got it, they're all red. And, because you want to be nice and cute you add ちゃん to that. That's why あかちゃん is a baby.
reading_story: If you know the reading of the kanji 赤 you should know the reading of this too.

ex_1_jp: このおはしは竹でできています。
ex_1_en: These chopsticks are made of bamboo.
ex_2_jp: 竹は、一メートルぐらいのたかさまで切ってしまうと、ねまでかれてしまいます。
ex_2_en: If you cut a bamboo to about a meter high, it dies and even its roots wither.
ex_3_jp: 竹細工が本当に好きなんだ！うちのテレビも俺が竹から作ったんだよ。まあ、動かないけどね。でも、見た目がいいんだよ。
ex_3_en: I love working with bamboo! I made my television out of bamboo. It doesn’t work, but it sure looks nice.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well!
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is also the reading you associated with the kanji, earlier.

ex_1_jp: 竹の子をゆでているところです。
ex_1_en: I’m boiling bamboo shoots.
ex_2_jp: ふじ山の入り口から北の方にのぼっていくと、と中に竹の子が山のようにとれるところがあります。
ex_2_en: If you go up north from the entrance of Mt. Fuji, there is a place where you can dig up a lot of bamboo shoots on your way.
ex_3_jp: 「あ、お兄さん。わかりました。わかりました。竹の子、好きなだけ持って行ってください。」とパンダが言った。
ex_3_en: "Hey, man. It’s cool, it’s cool. Take all the bamboo shoots you want," said the panda.
meaning_story: What is a child of bamboo? That would be a baby bamboo. Because "baby bamboo" doesn't really make sense, we'll instead call this word bamboo shoots. P.S. Fresh bamboo shoots cooked on a fire are delicious, make sure you try them sometime.
reading_story: If you know the readings of the kanji for 竹 and the vocabulary for 子 you should be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: この字は太字にしてください。
ex_1_en: Make this character bold, please.
ex_2_jp: マンションのエレベーターにのったら、でんこうけいじばんに赤い太字で「じしんです今すぐ外に出てください｣とかひょうじが出てきて、マジびびったよ。
ex_2_en: When I got on the elevator in my apartment, the bold, red message appeared saying "Earthquake! Get out of this elevator right now," on the electric bulletin board so I got really scared.
ex_3_jp: 太字にすることで、その言葉を強調しましょう。
ex_3_en: Let’s put this in bold to add more emphasis.
meaning_story: What do you think a fat letter is? If I were to guess, I'd say a bold letter.
reading_story: The reading for this one is a bit odd. The 太 uses the ふと from ふとい (kun'yomi) and the 字 is just the normal on'yomi reading for "letter." You have to remember this weird mismatched reading pair on your own, I'm afraid. Perhaps if you think about how fat letters don't really fit with the rest of the text, kind of like how the readings of both kanji also don't fit in it will help?

ex_1_jp: 虫はにが手です。
ex_1_en: I don’t like bugs.
ex_2_jp: あの虫、口から白い糸をはいているよ！
ex_2_en: That insect is spinning white thread from its mouth.
ex_3_jp: ううん。その虫は噛まないよ。でも、もし君がそれでもそいつを殺すって言うなら、僕が君のことを噛むよ。
ex_3_en: No, that bug doesn’t bite. However, I will bite you if you still kill it.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, which is also the reading you learned when you learned this kanji!

ex_1_jp: 白い子牛をかっているんです。
ex_1_en: We have a white calf.
ex_2_jp: この子牛は、とても元気です。
ex_2_en: This calf is very energetic.
ex_3_jp: お父さん！サンタ・クロースが昨夜子牛をくれたわ！
ex_3_en: Daddy! Santa Claus gave me a calf last night!
meaning_story: You have a child cow. What do you think a child cow is? Probably a calf or a baby cow.
reading_story: Since you should know the readings of the words 子 and 牛 from the previous level, you should be able to read this word too even though it's using the kun'yomi readings for the kanji.

ex_1_jp: よく平気でいられますね。
ex_1_en: How come you’re always so calm?
ex_2_jp: 王女はペットの子犬をなくしても平気な人です。
ex_2_en: The princess is a type of person who wouldn't get upset even if she lost her pet puppy.
ex_3_jp: 夫が会社を首になったが、意外と平気だ。
ex_3_en: My husband was fired, but I’m surprisingly calm.
meaning_story: You have a flat energy. What kind of energy would be a flat one? Probably a cool or calm one. You'd also tell people about this flat energy by saying you are all right or just okay.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あそこの赤いはたが見えますか。
ex_1_en: Can you see the red flag over there?
ex_2_jp: 他人からどう見えるのかがすごく気になってし方がない。
ex_2_en: I can't help thinking about how others think of me.
ex_3_jp: 太陽が眩しくて、風船がどのくらいの高さまで上がっていったのかほとんど見えなかった。
ex_3_en: The sun was so bright, I could barely see how high the balloon had risen.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means see, and the える (with the え in there) suggests that this is "potential" form. So, instead of just being "to see" this word means can see or just plain old visible.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji (the kun'yomi reading). So as long as you know that you should be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: 日よう日に、車でうみにいきました。
ex_1_en: I went to the ocean in my car on Sunday.
ex_2_jp: だれか車出してくれないかな？
ex_2_en: I wonder if somebody could give us a ride.
ex_3_jp: 私の車は、フロリダまでもたないだろう。
ex_3_en: My car wouldn’t be able to make it all the way to Florida.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You visit your mom who lives inside of a car. It's sad, and you feel bad. The first thing that pops out of your mouth is: "Cool Room, Ma (くるま) because you don't know what else to say about your ma's living situation. Be sure to sort of cut off the last letters of the first two words... something like "coo' roo' ma!" Sad thing is, there is only one room in this car your mom calls home.

ex_1_jp: 中央に立っているのが、田中さんのおねえさんです。
ex_1_en: That’s Tanaka’s older sister standing in the center.
ex_2_jp: 大さかえきの、中央かいさつ口でまっています。
ex_2_en: I’m waiting for you at the central ticket gate of Osaka station.
ex_3_jp: 私の頭の中央部分には小さな凹みがある。
ex_3_en: I have a little dent in the center of my head.
meaning_story: The middle of the central... that is really, really in the center if you ask me (and is very central as well). This is one of those "overdid it on the meaning" words.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: チューオꜜー *** チューオー

ex_1_jp: もっとていねいに字をかいてください。
ex_1_en: Please write the character more carefully.
ex_2_jp: 八の字まゆ毛の男せいとけっこんしました。
ex_2_en: I married a man whose eyebrows are shaped like the character for eight.
ex_3_jp: この字は何という意味ですか？
ex_3_en: What does this character mean?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: You only learned one reading for the kanji that makes up this word, and it's the same as the reading for this word (of course). That means you should already know the reading.
pitch_accent: アꜜザ *** アザナ *** ジꜜ

ex_1_jp: このねこの耳はちゃいろです。
ex_1_en: This cat’s ears are brown.
ex_2_jp: パンの耳はわたしの大こうぶつです。
ex_2_en: I love bread crusts.
ex_3_jp: わたしは、左耳をミミと名付けた。右耳はよく聞こえないので、ママと名付けた。
ex_3_en: I named my left ear Mimi. My right ear doesn’t hear very well, so I named it Mama.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is the reading you learned with the kanji. So you should be able to read this word already.

ex_1_jp: よていより、十五分早くつきました。
ex_1_en: We arrived 15 minutes earlier than scheduled.
ex_2_jp: かの女にこく白するのはまだ早いとおもうんだ。
ex_2_en: I think it's too early to ask her out.
ex_3_jp: 豆腐屋さんの朝はいつも早い。
ex_3_en: A tofu maker always wakes up early in the morning.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of early? It's also early.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the kun'yomi reading, which you did not learn when you learned the kanji. You have to remember the はや portion to be able read this word. In order to do that, here's a mnemonic:

ex_1_jp: お父さんは、元気ですか。
ex_1_en: How is your father?
ex_2_jp: かなちゃんは、元気いっぱいですね。
ex_2_en: Kana is full of energy.
ex_3_jp: 彼は元気そうに見えたが、実はひどい下りだったらしい。
ex_3_en: He seemed fine but apparently he had a bad diarrhea.
meaning_story: What is the origin of your energy? It is your spirit and health (though this vocab word also means energy as well).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今日はあさから気分がいいです。
ex_1_en: I’ve been feeling great since this morning.
ex_2_jp: なんとなくピクニックに出かけたい気分です。
ex_2_en: I feel like going on a picnic now.
ex_3_jp: 君が僕と結婚してくれたら、残りの人生ずっといい気分ですごせると思うよ。
ex_3_en: If you marry me, I think I’ll be in a good mood for the rest of my life.
meaning_story: Part of your energy is your feeling or your mood. Just think of it like you're breaking up your energy into parts. One part is sugar giving you energy. Another part is your happiness. So, when you combine these together you get the total: your mood!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 花火が上がるのはきんよう日だけです。
ex_1_en: The fireworks are only going off on Friday.
ex_2_jp: 昨日、かぞくで花火大かいに出かけました。
ex_2_en: I went to see a fireworks display with my family yesterday.
ex_3_jp: 花火ってめっちゃいい匂いだよね？
ex_3_en: Fireworks have a great smell, don’t they?
meaning_story: The flower fire... what looks like flowers on fire? That would be fireworks. Totally makes sense, right?
reading_story: The readings for the kanji that make this word are the kun'yomi readings, where fire's ひ changes to び. You already learned the kun'yomi reading for 花 when you learned the kanji, so it's only a matter of remembering to use the kun'yomi for 火. If you do, you should be able to read this word.

translation: first of all, to start with
ex_1_jp: 先ず、下ごしらえをします。
ex_1_en: First, we do the prep work.
ex_2_jp: 先ず、その五十ねんかけてあつめた切手コレクションからだんしゃりしましょう。
ex_2_en: Why don't you declutter the stamp collection you've been working on for fifty years first?
ex_3_jp: 先ずは、チキンの羽をむしりとって、それぞれの羽に名前をつけます。
ex_3_en: First you need to pluck the chicken and then name each of the feathers.
meaning_story: The kanji means previous. This is an adverb version of that word. It's a little thing you can begin sentences with. You can't start your sentences with "previous" but you can start it with "First of all" or "to start with." This is usually written without kanji though, so keep that in mind.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. In fact, the reading for this word is very rare, and kind of an exception. We'll use a mnemonic that uses both the kanji part and the hiragana attachment part. First of all and to start with, you have to make it through this maze (まず).

ex_1_jp: 川下さんは、小がく一年生のおとうとがいます。
ex_1_en: Kawashita has a brother who is a first year student in elementary school.
ex_2_jp: ことしの四月、わたしは中がく一年生になり、わたしのいもうとは小学一年生、兄はこうこう一年生、母と父は大学一年生になります。
ex_2_en: This coming April, I'm starting the first year olf middle school, my sister is starting the first year of elementary school, and my mother and father are starting the first year of university.
ex_3_jp: まだ小学一年生が学ぶ漢字ですら知りません。
ex_3_en: I haven’t even learned the kanji that first grade elementary school students know yet.
meaning_story: You'd maybe think this just means one year of life, but it actually means first year student. A second year student is a 二年生, and so on. Just think about how crazy the Japanese are about school. You can see why school is life, and not life itself, making this vocab word "first year student."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: イチネꜜンセイ *** イチネンセイ

ex_1_jp: 三月まつまでに、かん字を五百こおぼえてください。
ex_1_en: Please memorize five hundred kanji by the end of March.
ex_2_jp: 日本には五百円玉というものがあります。
ex_2_en: Japan has 500-yen coins.
ex_3_jp: 「どうやって五百頭もの馬を車に乗せるっていうの？」と女が聞いた。「そうだよね。代わりにバンを持ってきた方が良かったかな。」と男は答えた。
ex_3_en: "How are we going to get five hundred horses into one car?" asked the woman. "You’re right! Do you think I should have bought the van instead?" the man replied.
meaning_story: When you have five hundreds you also have five hundred.
reading_story: This word has a number in it, so it uses the kun'yomi reading for it. But the reading for 百 is the on'yomi reading. This is pretty normal when it comes to counting numbers in Japanese. You know both of these readings already. Hooray!

ex_1_jp: パソコンを、どこか平らなところにおいてください。
ex_1_en: Put your PC somewhere flat, please.
ex_2_jp: その女の子は赤のビー玉を八つ平らなところにおいた。
ex_2_en: That girl put eight red marbles in a flat place.
ex_3_jp: 平らで細長いパスタの名前覚えてない？
ex_3_en: Do you remember the name of the pasta that is thin, long and flat?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same with a little hiragana sticking out. Because the hiragana doesn't really indicate what it is, it's okay to assume that they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a kanji plus some hiragana attached, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Something is very, very flat. Perhaps someone who doesn't eat much, like a model? Which model? Let's imagine it's Tyra (たいら) Banks.

ex_1_jp: ヒマワリは、とてもきれいな花です。
ex_1_en: The sunflower is a very beautiful flower.
ex_2_jp: この花の花ことばは、はな毛ボーボーです。
ex_2_en: In the language of flowers, this one means bushy nose hair.
ex_3_jp: 何か花を使った料理が知りたいんだけど。花のスープとかって聞いたことある？
ex_3_en: I want to learn how to cook with flowers. Have you ever heard of flower soup?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned when you learned the kanji, so you're good to go. Don't forget to stop and smell the roses on the way, though.

ex_1_jp: 足にタトゥーがある。
ex_1_en: I have a tattoo on my leg.
ex_2_jp: わたしは子どものとき、手のことを足、足のことを手だとおもっていました。
ex_2_en: When I was a kid, I thought hands were feet and feet were hands.
ex_3_jp: もし私が足を切り落としても、すぐにまた生えてくるんだよね？
ex_3_en: If I cut off my foot it will grow back soon, right?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. A foot is a foot, you know?
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: If you remember in the radical/kanji mnemonic, you kick someone with your foot. But what happens after you kick them? Turns out they were made of fire, and you just burned your foot off, turning it to ashes (あし). Imagine this happening.

ex_1_jp: このしりょうを四百枚コピーしてください。
ex_1_en: Please make four hundred copies of this document.
ex_2_jp: アメリカのシアトル市で、一やにして四百人がしっそうするというじけんがあった。
ex_2_en: There was an incident where 400 people went missing overnight in the city of Seattle in the US.
ex_3_jp: いったいどうして四百ドルも一本の爪楊枝を買うのに使ったんだい？
ex_3_en: How did you spend four hundred dollars on a toothpick?
meaning_story: When you have four hundreds, you have four hundred.
reading_story: This word has a number in it, so it uses the kun'yomi reading for it. But the reading for 百 is the on'yomi reading. This is pretty normal when it comes to counting numbers in Japanese. You know both of these readings already. Hooray!

ex_1_jp: きのう、ご主人とどこかへいきましたか？
ex_1_en: Did you and your husband go somewhere yesterday?
ex_2_jp: ご主人さま、それは少しかいすぎではないでしょうか。
ex_2_en: I'm afraid you bought too many of them, master.
ex_3_jp: 私の主人は何の信念も無い政治家なんです。
ex_3_en: My husband is a politician who doesn’t have any conviction.
meaning_story: The master person isn't just a master. You have to think back to when they were making these kanji. Who was the master? It was the head of household. This head of household probably told servants what to do and was all bossy and stuff. He was the master person. Also, this often means husband. Because, I guess the head of household back in the day was the husband. Those sexist ancient people!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 休日は、えいがを見ることがおおいです。
ex_1_en: I watched a bunch of movies over the holiday.
ex_2_jp: たのしい休日をすごしてくださいね。
ex_2_en: Have a nice holiday!
ex_3_jp: 休日をツリーハウスで過ごした。
ex_3_en: I spent the holiday in my tree house.
meaning_story: When you have a rest day you have a holiday.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the 日 reading is the alternate reading, じつ.

ex_1_jp: 一しゅうかんで、百ページよみました。
ex_1_en: I read one hundred pages in one week.
ex_2_jp: 王子がレベル百になったら王か女王にてんしょくできますよ。
ex_2_en: When you get to Level 100, Prince, you can change your job from prince to king or queen.
ex_3_jp: 百円で色々なものが買えるんですね。
ex_3_en: I can buy a bunch of different things with a hundred yen.
meaning_story: When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's one hundred!
reading_story: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this. Numbers use the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned by learning the kanji's reading! How nice!

ex_1_jp: 氷をつくっておいてください。
ex_1_en: Please make the ice.
ex_2_jp: タピオカミルクティーを氷ぬきでちゅう文した。
ex_2_en: I ordered a bubble tea without ice.
ex_3_jp: 「どうしてあの女は俺のグラスに氷を入れるのを忘れたんだ？」「彼女は今日自動車にひかれたんです。きっと飲み物を作っている時にまだふらふらしていたんだと思います。」
ex_3_en: "Why did that woman forget to put ice in my glass?" "She was hit by a car earlier today. She must have been a little dizzy still while making your drink."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: わたしは、そのうたを丸ごとあんきしています。
ex_1_en: I’m memorizing the whole song.
ex_2_jp: その牛、半分だけじゃなくて丸ごと一とう下さい。
ex_2_en: Please give me the whole cow, not half.
ex_3_jp: このケーキには林檎が丸ごと入っています。
ex_3_en: This cake is filled entirely with apples.
meaning_story: If you go to (ごと) a circle, you need to go to it in its entirety. That means you have to circle around the whole thing. Otherwise, it isn't even a circle. It's like a line or a squiggle or something.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading, so you should be able to read this too!

ex_1_jp: 不正をはたらいたのはだれですか。
ex_1_en: Who did something dishonest?
ex_2_jp: 中ごくからの不正アクセスにより、トーフグのSNSアカウントがぜんぶのっとられてしまった。
ex_2_en: There was unauthorized access from China and all of Tofugu's social media accounts were hacked.
ex_3_jp: 俺の叔母は、いつも自分が今までにした不正やごまかしについて話をする。
ex_3_en: My aunt always talks about her personal acts of injustice and deception.
meaning_story: When you have something that's not correct, you have no justice. In fact, you have injustice. Just imagine yourself being put in an unjust situation, and think about how not correct it is.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ちょっと車内でまっていてください。
ex_1_en: Please wait in the car for a bit.
ex_2_jp: シアトル市のバスの車内にスタバのコップをもったきょどうふしんな外人がいたとおもったら、ただのドバイのイケメン王子さまだった。
ex_2_en: There was a fidgety-looking man with a Starbuck's cup on a bus in Seattle, but it was actually a handsome prince from Dubai.
ex_3_jp: 誰かが車内にベーコンをいくつか忘れていったようだ。
ex_3_en: It seems like somebody left some bacon in the car.
meaning_story: The car inside is simply that, inside the car.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 先月、田中さんにあいました。
ex_1_en: I met Tanaka last month.
ex_2_jp: 先月、市立びょういんであなたのお兄さんを見ましたよ。
ex_2_en: I saw your older brother in the municipal hospital last month.
ex_3_jp: 彼らは先月コスプレパーティーをしました。
ex_3_en: They had a cosplay party last month.
meaning_story: The previous month is last month.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 去年の四月に日本にきました。
ex_1_en: I came to Japan in April of last year.
ex_2_jp: 去年、はじめて夏コミにさんせんしました。
ex_2_en: Last year, I participated in the Summer Comiket for the first time.
ex_3_jp: 彼はハンバーガーを毎日食べるので、去年よりも太ってしまった。
ex_3_en: He is fatter than he was last year because he eats hamburgers every day.
meaning_story: The past year is just last year.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 文字はきいろにしてください。
ex_1_en: Make this letter yellow, please.
ex_2_jp: マイケルは八じかんかけてコウイチにしょうけい文字で手がみをしたためた。
ex_2_en: Michael took eight hours to write a letter to Koichi in hieroglyphics.
ex_3_jp: あなたからのメール、文字化けしちゃったみたいなんだけど、何て書いてたの？
ex_3_en: It looks like that email from you contained corrupted characters, what did you write?
meaning_story: A writing letter is simpler than it sounds. It's really just a letter, right? You're reading 文字 right now, in fact!
reading_story: The reading for this word is just the jukugo, but the reading for 文 is a little bit modified. Instead of the reading もん, which you learned with the kanji, it's just も. You can remember this because you're shortening this word in a way as well. The "writing letter" is shortened to "letter." So, think of もん being shortened to も.

ex_1_jp: かれは、一代でここまでかいしゃを大きくした。
ex_1_en: He made the company this much larger in just one generation.
ex_2_jp: コウイチは一世一代の大しょうぶに打って出た。
ex_2_en: Koichi went to take a once-in-a-lifetime gamble.
ex_3_jp: 彼は一代で巨額の財産を作ったが、彼の息子がさらにそれを二倍にした。
ex_3_en: He amassed an enormous fortune over the course of his lifetime and his son doubled it.
meaning_story: This word has the kanji for one and period. You only have one period to live in so this is the only lifetime you get. Unless you're reborn, but that will probably be in the next age, not this one. So one lifetime for you!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 主に日本ごをべんきょうしています。
ex_1_en: I’m primarily studying Japanese.
ex_2_jp: ポートランドでは、赤い車と白い車が主にうれています。
ex_2_en: Primarily red and white cars are sold in Portland.
ex_3_jp: 彼は研究者で、主にバナナに興味があります。
ex_3_en: He is a researcher who is mainly interested in bananas.
meaning_story: 主 means master. When you add に to it it's like you're saying "to the master." This might take some mind bending, but where are you going usually? Mainly you're going to the master (because you have to ask him for permission before you do anything, all the time).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who is the master you mainly go to in order to get permission? His name is "Moe" but he makes you call him "Oh Moe The Great!" (おも). Imagine yourself saying "OH MOE THE GREAT!" as you walk into his room.

ex_1_jp: この男はだれですか。
ex_1_en: Who is that man?
ex_2_jp: 今日は男友だちとパチンコを打ちにいくよていです。
ex_2_en: I have a plan to go play pachinko with my guy friend.
ex_3_jp: 知らない男と花火大会で意気投合した。
ex_3_en: I developed quite a rapport with a man I didn't know at a fireworks show.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: There is a man. Think of the manliest man you can. He works in an auto shop. As a child, he was an auto 子 (おとこ), working at the auto shop from an early age. This turned him into a man very quickly. Like other mnemonics that aren't lined up quite perfectly, your goal here is to get close enough to remember the true reading. Step, step, step, jump!

ex_1_jp: かれは、けんどうの名人です。
ex_1_en: He is a kendo master.
ex_2_jp: かの女は、このくにに四人しかいないはいくの名人の一人です。
ex_2_en: She is one of the four haiku masters in this country.
ex_3_jp: 彼はチェスの名人であるだけでなく、トランプの名人でもある。
ex_3_en: Not only is he an expert at chess, he’s also a master at cards.
meaning_story: A person whose name is known (because he's famous?). Why is this person's name known? Why is this person famous? It's because they are a master / expert at something. How else does someone become famous or well-known? That's pretty much it, even if they're just an expert at being an idiot.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: おじぎの仕方をおしえてください。
ex_1_en: Please teach me how to bow.
ex_2_jp: フランス人の友人にフランスしきのあいさつの仕方をおしえてもらいました。
ex_2_en: My French friend taught me how to greet people in the French way.
ex_3_jp: 「運転の仕方」という本は今年のベストセラーとなった。
ex_3_en: "How to Drive" became a best-selling book this year.
meaning_story: The doing way is basically a "way of doing" something. More simply put, this is the method. "What's your way of doing this?" No no no. "What's your METHOD." There we go.
reading_story: You learned these readings for the kanji as well, meaning you should be able to read this word already.

ex_1_jp: このCDは、百万まいうれたそうです。
ex_1_en: I heard that this CD sold a million copies.
ex_2_jp: Wanikaniで百万ドルもうけたので、きんでできたトーフグのおきものをつくるつもりです。
ex_2_en: We are planning to make a Tofugu ornament made of gold with the million dollars we profited from Wanikani.
ex_3_jp: AKB48の裁判を見に、百万人の人々が法廷に出席した。
ex_3_en: A million people attended the AKB48 court case.
meaning_story: One hundred ten thousands is how much? Multiply the two together and you get a million.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 先々月、キューバにりょこうにいきました。
ex_1_en: I took a trip to Cuba the month before last.
ex_2_jp: 先々月、シアトル市で大あめがふったせいで、市のめいぶつの玉ねぎばたけがぜんめつしてしまった。
ex_2_en: Two months ago, due to the heavy rain in the city of Seattle, the city's famous onion field was entirely destroyed.
ex_3_jp: お母さんが先々月の携帯電話代を払ってくれた。
ex_3_en: My mom paid my cellphone bill the month before last.
meaning_story: The previous previous month (remember that 々 just repeats the kanji before it) is the month before last.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: センセꜜンケ°ツ *** センセンケ°ツ

ex_1_jp: 月見のおだん子をつくっています。
ex_1_en: I’m making rice dumplings for moon viewing.
ex_2_jp: 今日のよる、友人たちと、お月見をするよていです。
ex_2_en: I am planning to have a moon viewing party with my friends tonight.
ex_3_jp: そ父は、月見の日に餅でのどを詰まらせて死にました。
ex_3_en: My grandpa passed away from choking on a mochi cake on a moon viewing day.
meaning_story: When you moon see something, you're doing a moon viewing.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. For 見 you already learned the kun'yomi reading when you learned the kanji. For 月 you'll have to think back to the vocab word 月 which uses the つき reading. Combine these two together and you have つきみ.

ex_1_jp: この花の名をおしえてください。
ex_1_en: Please tell me the name of this flower.
ex_2_jp: きょ年のなつ、「きみの名は。」というえいがが日本ではやりました。
ex_2_en: Last summer, the movie "Your Name" became popular in Japan.
ex_3_jp: まだ彼女の名も知らない。
ex_3_en: I still don’t know her name.
meaning_story: This vocabulary word is the same as the 'name' meaning of the kanji. If you can remember that, you'll have no trouble remembering this word as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Just think of the first part of the English word name. What is it? It's na (な), just like this word!

ex_1_jp: なん号車にのるよていですか。
ex_1_en: Which train car are you going to ride in?
ex_2_jp: 天才かがくしゃと天才こうがくしゃの手によって、われわれのみらいを百パーセントよそうてきちゅうできるうらないロボットだい一号がかんせいしました。
ex_2_en: The first fortune-telling robot with 100% accuracy was made by a genius scientist and a genius engineer.
ex_3_jp: 日本では新聞の号外は大抵無料で配られます。
ex_3_en: In Japan, we usually hand out an extra issue of the newspaper for free.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This word is made up of a single kanji all alone, but it uses the on'yomi reading. This is probably because you'll usually see this word attached to other things, like numbers. This shows the edition or number of an item. So, even though it's alone, it's usually used like jukugo, which is why the reading for this one is the same as the reading you learned when you learned the kanji.

ex_1_jp: にがいくすりを一気にのみほしました。
ex_1_en: I drank the bitter medicine down in one gulp.
ex_2_jp: 元気そうな父のかおを見たら、一気に気がぬけました。
ex_2_en: It was such a relief to see my father, who looked well.
ex_3_jp: 僕のひいお婆さんは、ぎょう子を二百こ一気にたべた。
ex_3_en: My great-grandma ate two hundred gyoza in one sitting.
meaning_story: It's weird to think of having one energy. But, what gives you energy? You do it one time every couple of seconds. That would be taking breaths. So, "one energy" is one breath.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the ones you learned with the individual kanji, though いち from 一 is shortened to いっ.

ex_1_jp: かれは、とても一本気なせいかくです。
ex_1_en: He has a really single-minded personality.
ex_2_jp: モテないだん子には、じゅんじょうで一本気なおとこがおおい気がする。
ex_2_en: I feel that many men who are not popular among girls are naive and single-minded.
ex_3_jp: 俺の親友は、とても一本気な男で、90歳になった今でも初恋の女を思い続けている。
ex_3_en: My best friend has a one-track mind; he’s 90 years old and still has feelings for his first love.
meaning_story: You have only one book energy. No other books cross your mind. Only this one book. Why? Because you have such a one track mind.
reading_story: The reading is based off the on'yomi readings for everything, though every reading is slightly altered. いち getting shortened to いっ, ほん changing to ぽん, and き gets changed to ぎ. They're based off the readings you know already, though, so making this shift shouldn't be too hard... that is, unless you have an 一本気, ammiright?
pitch_accent: イッポꜜンキ° *** イッポンキ°

ex_1_jp: 他にしつもんはありませんか。
ex_1_en: Any other questions?
ex_2_jp: クラスの他のがく生はぜんぜん大したことのないように見えた。
ex_2_en: It looked like the students in the other class weren't great.
ex_3_jp: この卵をあいつの家に投げるのは、他の日にしようぜ。
ex_3_en: Let’s throw these eggs at his house some other day.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You need to go for a drive to the public gardens, but you aren't going to get your normal car, you're going to get your other car. Your hoe car (ほか)! It's a car made entirely out of garden hoes. You can drive it and hoe with it at the same time! Your other car can't do that!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: わたしの大すきなバンドが、かつどうを休止しました。
ex_1_en: My absolute favorite band is on hiatus.
ex_2_jp: パソコンのスリープと休止じょうたいのちがいをおしえてください。
ex_2_en: Could you tell me the difference between sleep mode and hibernation mode on the computer, please?
ex_3_jp: しごとのと中で、小まめに小休止をとってエクササイズをするようにしています。
ex_3_en: I'm trying to take little breaks and exercise frequently during work.
meaning_story: A stop that's just a rest (aka not permanent) isn't a straight up stop. You're planning on continuing again. That's why this is a pause.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お皿をあらってから、ベッドにいきました。
ex_1_en: I did the dishes and then went to bed.
ex_2_jp: あとは、この竹の子を皿にもりつければかんせいです。\(*皿* )
ex_2_en: Arrange these bamboo shoots on a plate and it's done! \(*皿* )
ex_3_jp: うちのいいお皿を射撃の標的に使うのはやめてくれ！
ex_3_en: Stop using our good plates for target practice!
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is also the reading you learned when you learned the kanji.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: このビールはとても人気があります。
ex_1_en: This beer is very popular.
ex_2_jp: あのどう人しの人気のひみつをさぐっている。
ex_2_en: I am probing into why that doujinshi is so popular.
ex_3_jp: 私がこの辺りで一番人気の高いベリー採集者であります。」と熊が言った。
ex_3_en: "I am the most popular berry collector around here," said the bear.
meaning_story: If a person has a lot of energy then they're very charismatic and fun! What's another feature of charismatic / fun people? They are most likely popular as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ジンキ *** ニンキ *** ヒトケ

ex_1_jp: それから、ゆうびんきょくへいって、切手をかいます。
ex_1_en: Then I’m going to go to the post office and buy stamps.
ex_2_jp: あの外人さんは切手を一万まいもかっていったよ。
ex_2_en: That foreigner bought 10,000 postage stamps.
ex_3_jp: 彼女を失ってから、切手集めへの興味も失ってしまった。
ex_3_en: Since I lost her, I've lost interest in stamp collecting.
meaning_story: To remember the meaning of this word, just think about how in the olden days, before perforation was invented, people had to cut their postage stamps by hand. It took forever, especially if you had a lot of friends to mail things to. Be thankful that perforation was invented to save you time cutting them.
reading_story: You'd think that the reading for this would consist of the on'yomi readings, but human body parts (hand) do funny things to words. In this case, it's the kun'yomi readings of both the kanji. You should know the kun'yomi reading for 切 and 手 from the previous levels, meaning you should be able to remember the reading for this word fairly easily. Watch out for the small っ, though.

part_of_speech: NOUN, PREFIX, SUFFIX, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 分かるもんだいから先にときましょう。
ex_1_en: You should start with the problems you can solve.
ex_2_jp: この先のみちをまっすぐいって川をこえると、北アメリカに入ります。
ex_2_en: If you go straight up this street and over the river, you will enter North America.
ex_3_jp: 申し訳ないけど、今日は先に元彼とした約束があるので、あなたとは会えません。
ex_3_en: I’m sorry, but I have a prior engagement with my ex-boyfriend today, so I can’t meet up with you.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: When I think about the word "previous" I think of the beginning of a TV show where they say "previously on..." Let's go with that. Previously on Lost (or some other show), everyone gets stuck inside of a sack (さき). Imagine all the characters in the TV show writhing around inside of a sack, trying to get out. You can differentiate this from 先ず (まず) because it doesn't have a hiragana add on. It's plain. It's boring. It's just a sack (and also means the same thing as the kanji it comes from because it's a single kanji with nothing attached, which gets you to previous, which gets you to さき).
pitch_accent: サキ *** サキꜜザキ *** セꜜン

ex_1_jp: 赤いネクタイをください。
ex_1_en: Could I have the red necktie?
ex_2_jp: 今年は赤いマニキュアがはやっています。
ex_2_en: This year the red nail polish is popular.
ex_3_jp: 赤いニット帽を被った女の子がスケートをしている。
ex_3_en: The girl wearing the red knit hat is skating.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of red? Why, it's red!
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: その赤のくつをとってください。
ex_1_en: Please take the red shoes.
ex_2_jp: つぎは、まえがみのいろを赤にしようとおもっています。
ex_2_en: I'm thinking of dying my bangs red next time.
ex_3_jp: オーランド・ブルームという名前を聞くだけで、今でも頬が赤くなる。
ex_3_en: My cheeks still go red when I hear the name Orlando Bloom.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: かとうさんのつぎの休みはいつですか？
ex_1_en: When is Kato’s next day off?
ex_2_jp: ひる休みにカフェでかき氷をたべました。
ex_2_en: During lunch break, I ate shaved ice at a cafe.
ex_3_jp: 明日は休みなので、一日中一人でマリオカートをする予定です。
ex_3_en: Tomorrow is my day off, so I’m planning to play Mario Kart by myself for the entire day.
meaning_story: The kanji rest has a little hiragana attached, but it's nothing that would suggest it's anything but a noun (it is!). It means the same thing as the kanji, rest.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji with some hiragana, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: So, do you want a rest from work or school? You should say "Yes!" (やす).

ex_1_jp: かれは、日けいアメリカ人二世の一人です。
ex_1_en: He’s one of the second generation Japanese-Americans.
ex_2_jp: せいこうしている二世タレントは少ない。
ex_2_en: Not many children of celebrities can be celebrities too.
ex_3_jp: 私は、父が日系イギリス人二世だということを知らなかった。
ex_3_en: I didn’t know that my father is a second generation Japanese-Britain.
meaning_story: The two generation is the second generation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ニꜜセ *** ニセ *** ニꜜセイ

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: いつになったら、本気を出すんですか。
ex_1_en: How soon before you make a serious effort?
ex_2_jp: ついにコウイチが本気を出してきた。
ex_2_en: Koichi is finally getting serious.
ex_3_jp: 私があの男の頭の毛をむしったなんて、本気で思ってないよね？少しは私を信用してよ。
ex_3_en: You didn’t seriously think I pulled that guy’s hair out, did you? Give me some credit.
meaning_story: What is book energy? It is energy you put into reading - it is your studies! In order to have book energy, though, you have to be very serious.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: かき氷は、あついなつによくたべられます。
ex_1_en: I eat shaved ice a lot in hot summers.
ex_2_jp: この赤いシロップがかかったかき氷はトマトあじです。
ex_2_en: This shaved ice with red syrup is tomato flavored.
ex_3_jp: 世界で一番いい気分になる時は、嫌いなやつに冷たいかき氷をぶちまけてやった時だよ。
ex_3_en: The best feeling in the world is when you throw super cold shaved ice with syrup on someone you hate.
meaning_story: This is かき ice, which is shaved ice.
reading_story: The reading for 氷 is the same as the one you learned (こおり) except it gets converted to ごおり because it comes after かき, so it's rendaku'd.

ex_1_jp: かえりに、貝をかってきましょうか。
ex_1_en: Shall I buy clams on my way back?
ex_2_jp: 貝るいやこうかくるいをたべると、からだがかゆくなります。
ex_2_en: My body gets itchy when I eat shellfish.
ex_3_jp: 私は、牡蠣の貝殻の中に置かれていることに気付かずに、婚約指輪を飲み込んでしまった。
ex_3_en: I swallowed my engagement ring because I hadn’t noticed he put it in the oyster shell.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this already.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: おつりが不足しています。
ex_1_en: I don’t have enough change.
ex_2_jp: しきん不足で中央せいふのきかくしたプロジェクトが中止になった。
ex_2_en: Due to the lack of funds, the project that the central government planned was suspended.
ex_3_jp: 経験が不足しているうえにいつも寝不足なので、あなたは首です。
ex_3_en: You are fired because you lack experience and are always sleep deprived.
meaning_story: You have something that's not sufficient. When something isn't sufficient, you have a shortage. Keep in mind that this is a physical shortage, not a shortage of mental ability or something like that. To remember this, just think about how 足 also means "foot." What is a foot? Something physical. That's why this is a physical shortage.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: にわに、みかんの皮がおちていました。
ex_1_en: There were orange peels laying in the garden.
ex_2_jp: らく天で、天ねんの牛の皮でできた小さいラグをかった。
ex_2_en: I bought a natural cowhide rug on Rakuten.
ex_3_jp: 俺のジャケットは、100%竜の皮でできているんだ。
ex_3_en: My jacket is made of 100% dragon skin.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading you learned for the kanji that makes up this vocab is the same as this vocab.

ex_1_jp: 小皿をテーブルにならべてください。
ex_1_en: Please set the small plates on the table.
ex_2_jp: かくじ、小皿にとり分けてたべましょう。
ex_2_en: Why don't we just serve foods into small plates by ourselves and eat at our own pace?
ex_3_jp: このどでかいステーキを、その小皿に載せるのは無理だ。
ex_3_en: It’s impossible to put this huge steak on that tiny dish.
meaning_story: You have a small plate. Wait, is that it? Yep, that's it.
reading_story: さら uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji, except it's ざら this time because of the rendaku. 小 uses an alternate kun'yomi reading. You can remember it by thinking "What are small? Kids (子/こ) are small. Bwahaha."

ex_1_jp: かのじょはとつぜん、気をうしなった。
ex_1_en: She suddenly lost consciousness.
ex_2_jp: 気をつけてかえってきてね。
ex_2_en: Please come back safe.
ex_3_jp: おまえ、気は確かか？
ex_3_en: Are you out of your mind?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji that makes up this word. Lucky you!

ex_1_jp: 女の子は、おこって口を一文字にむすびました。
ex_1_en: The girl got angry and her mouth pursed into a straight line.
ex_2_jp: ペーパータオルでさかなの水気をふきとったら、かわに一文字の切り目を入れてください。
ex_2_en: After wiping moisture off the fish with paper towels, score the skin straight across.
ex_3_jp: 白鳥たちは、うちの風呂場からその湖へ、真一文字になって飛んでいった。
ex_3_en: The swans flew in a straight line from our bathtub to the lake.
meaning_story: When you have one writing letter what do you have? Here's a hint, there's one kanji in this word that consists of one writing letter (aka a straight line).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: イチモꜜンジ *** イチモンジ *** ヒトꜜモジ

ex_1_jp: ボールは、一打でグリーンにのりました。
ex_1_en: The ball landed on the green in one stroke.
ex_2_jp: テニスでは、さいしょの一打を「サービス」とよびます。
ex_2_en: In tennis, a shot to start a point is called "service."
ex_3_jp: 一打逆転の大チャンスだ。
ex_3_en: Just one hit would turn the tables in our favor.
meaning_story: You have one hit. What is (just) one hit? It is a strike or a blow.
reading_story: The reading for this is different from the one you learned with the kanji. The いち part is the same, but the 打 reading is だ. That's because you learned the kun'yomi reading with the kanji because it's more common and useful. Let's use a mnemonic to learn the reading of this 打, though. You get a blow from someone. Who hits you? It's your dad (だ). How unfortunate.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: サワークリームをヨーグルトで代用しました。
ex_1_en: I substituted yogurt for sour cream.
ex_2_jp: きもののこしひもは、ストッキングでも代用かのうです。
ex_2_en: You can use stockings as a substitute for the cord you wear under your kimono.
ex_3_jp: 糊がないので飯粒で代用した。
ex_3_en: We didn’t have glue so we substituted grains of boiled rice for it.
meaning_story: A substitute task is a substitution.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: さくらさんの名字は何といいますか。
ex_1_en: What is Sakura’s last name?
ex_2_jp: コウイチの名字をおしえてくれたら、お礼にてつ人二十八号のフィギュアをあげるよ。
ex_2_en: If you tell me Koichi's surname, I will give you a figure of Tetsujin 28 in return.
ex_3_jp: 私の名字はあなたには絶対教えません。
ex_3_en: I will never tell you my family name.
meaning_story: A name written in letters is the surname. Back in the day your surname was the important name (it's your family name after all, and family was king back in the day). This is the name you'd write out in kanji... aka in letters. So, that's why this combination of kanji means "surname."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the 名 portion is the alternate reading, so adjust your thinking accordingly so you can get to みょう. Just imagine someone saying "more" with a funny accent. They say "myou" instead of "more". Imagine them saying they have myou people in their family than yours. Their surname is spread amongst myou people than yours.

ex_1_jp: 先生がアンナさんに手がみをかきました。
ex_1_en: The teacher wrote a letter to Anna.
ex_2_jp: ダリン先生のつぎの休みはいつですか？
ex_2_en: When is Dr. Darin's next day off?
ex_3_jp: 先生と生徒の恋愛についてどう思いますか？
ex_3_en: What do you think of love between a student and a teacher?
meaning_story: Previous life... So we're talking about someone who has a previous life, or maybe previous life experience? When you have previous life experience, you can teach others about it, making you qualified to be some kind of teacher.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: もうしもうし, もしもし
ex_1_jp: 申し申し、花子ちゃん？
ex_1_en: Hello? Hanako?
ex_2_jp: あの、申し申し？きいていますか？？？
ex_2_en: Hey, hello? Are you listening???
ex_3_jp: 「申し申し。鈴木と申しますが、佐藤さんはいらっしゃいますか？」
ex_3_en: "Hello? This is Suzuki calling. Could I speak to Mr. Satou, please?"
meaning_story: It's kind of like you're saying say say. This is what you say when you answer or greet someone on the telephone. There's a strange story about this. One reason you say 申し申し is because it's hard for foxes to say. So, you're confirming that the other person isn't a fox. The other explanation is that operators would say this, letting the person know on the other line that they're talking by saying "say say" but in a humble way. Either way, this is a telephone hello, so say it next time you talk to someone on the phone who is Japanese... just to make sure they aren't a fox. We usually don't use kanji for this, so don't use it when you're writing. But you'll probably run into it in the wild so it's good to know!
reading_story: This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji. You should know it already.

ex_1_jp: あなたにお礼をいいたかったんです。
ex_1_en: I wanted to thank you.
ex_2_jp: お礼にビールをもらいました。
ex_2_en: I got a beer as thanks.
ex_3_jp: この町が平和を取り戻したことについて、スパイダーマンにお礼を言いたい。
ex_3_en: I’d like to thank Spiderman for taking back the streets and making our city safe again.
meaning_story: The meaning of this word is the same as the kanji, except it has an お before it, which just makes the thing you're saying elevate the other person more. Basically, it's more polite and awesome.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

translation: the other day, a few days ago
ex_1_jp: 先日はどうもありがとうございました。
ex_1_en: Thank you so much for the other day.
ex_2_jp: 先日いった北かいどうのおまつりは二十日かんもつづくものらしい。
ex_2_en: I heard that the festival I went to the other day in Hokkaido is held for twenty days.
ex_3_jp: 彼女は先日からずっと病気で寝ていると嘘をついた。
ex_3_en: She was lying about being sick in bed for a few days.
meaning_story: The previous day isn't necessarily yesterday. It can be any recent day, which is why this word means the other day.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the 日 reading is the alternate reading, じつ.

ex_1_jp: ルイ三世は、フランスのきぞくです。
ex_1_en: Louis III was a French noble.
ex_2_jp: ざい日三世のほとんどはかんこくごがはなせません。
ex_2_en: Most of the third generation Koreans residing in Japan cannot speak Korean.
ex_3_jp: 僕はアニメルパン三世を毎日見ます。
ex_3_en: I watch the anime "Lupin the Third" every day.
meaning_story: The three generation is the third generation. You can use this alone to say you're third generation Japanese or you can specify and say you're third generation something else.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 糸は、ここにまいてください。
ex_1_en: Coil the thread here, please.
ex_2_jp: うんめいの赤い糸をしんじますか？
ex_2_en: Do you believe in the red string of fate?
ex_3_jp: 私は足の傷口を縫うのに針と糸を使った。
ex_3_en: I used a needle and thread to stitch up the gash in my leg.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji it should use the kun'yomi reading (which is the reading you learned with the kanji).

ex_1_jp: バスケのしあいは、引き分けでした。
ex_1_en: The basketball game was a tie.
ex_2_jp: アメリカのベストピックアップトラックをきめるたたかいは、今のところトヨタとフォードの引き分けのじょうたいがつづいている。
ex_2_en: The battle to determine the best pickup truck in America is currently a draw between Toyota and Ford.
ex_3_jp: 私は、じゃんけんが三対三の引き分けに終わったことにとても腹を立てた。
ex_3_en: I was so upset that our rock-paper-scissors game ended in a three way tie.
meaning_story: When you pull something and separate it, you are making everything even. In a game, this would be a tie or a draw.
reading_story: See the hiragana stuck in there? That's hinting that these use the kun'yomi readings. You learned the kun'yomi readings of these two kanji separately in the previous level, so if you know those you should know this word's reading as well.

ex_1_jp: これだけで、足りるのかな。
ex_1_en: I wonder if this much will be enough.
ex_2_jp: モナコの王女はせけんしらずなので、車をかうのに十万円もあれば足りるとおもっている。
ex_2_en: Because the princess in Monaco is ignorant to most things, she thinks that 100,000 yen is enough to buy a car.
ex_3_jp: 今夜、ワインコルクで何か工作をするのに足りるだけのワインを飲むことを誓います。
ex_3_en: I vow to drink enough wine to make something crafty with the corks tonight.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means leg and sufficient. Of course, sufficient is the one we're going to go for, because you can't really "do foot" but you can "be sufficient." What's another word for this? To be enough.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the た portion. Whenever we need to remember the た we use the word "taco." What do you have enough of? What is sufficient? Turns out it's tacos. Your bunker is filled with them and it's going to be enough to last the winter.

ex_1_jp: あなたのお兄さんは、このしゃしんに写っていますか。
ex_1_en: Is your brother in these pictures?
ex_2_jp: 今年とった五百まいの写しんの内、なんと百三まいの写しんに去年しんだ父のすがたが写っていた。
ex_2_en: Among the 500 pictures I took this year, 103 of them had my father who had died last year in them.
ex_3_jp: この写真に写っている男の人は、私のファーストキスです。
ex_3_en: The guy in this picture was my first kiss.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means copy, but what is a copy? It is basically a photograph, which is why this word means to be photographed. You know this one is "to be photographed" because it ends with a る. Someone thinks you're "rude" so they're photographing you.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the うつ part. You're being rude, right? That's why you got photographed. Why are you rude? You're doing beatboxing, constantly saying うつうつうつ over and over again. Say it out loud, too.

ex_1_jp: このぼうし、とっても気に入りました。
ex_1_en: I’m very happy with this hat.
ex_2_jp: 玉ねぎ王子に気に入ってもらうために、アメリカ中の玉ねぎをかいしめて玉ねぎごてんをたてました。
ex_2_en: In order to please Prince Onion, I bought all the onions in America and built an onion palace.
ex_3_jp: 君の新しい子犬が気に入ってもらえるといいんだけど。
ex_3_en: I hope you’re happy with your new puppy.
meaning_story: You enter into the energy. When you're entering (positive) energy into something, you are going to be pleased with it. Just imagine yourself adding some physical, happy energy into something you're pleased with. Smile and feel pleased as well!
reading_story: The 気 portion is pretty straight forward. The 入る portion looks like it's supposed to be はいる but it's not. Do you remember 入れる／いれる? This one is kind of a mix of both of them. It's just いる. Just imagine you're so pleased with something that you just put everything together and end up with a combination of both of them (they both are so pleasing!). So it's not はいる and it's not いれる it's いる.

ex_1_jp: となりのページに、手本の字を写してください。
ex_1_en: Please copy the characters on the next page of your workbooks.
ex_2_jp: ビエトの写す写しんの大ファンです。
ex_2_en: I'm a big fan of the photos Viet takes.
ex_3_jp: お経を書き写すには、千円支払う必要があります。
ex_3_en: You must pay 1,000 yen in order to transcribe a sutra by hand.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means copy so you know this means to copy. You know this word means "to copy" because it ends with す. You're copying the documents you need to sue (す) someone who screwed you over.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the うつ part. To remember that, think of yourself as a beatboxer. You're saying うつうつうつ over and over again. Thing is, the other beatboxer is going to copy everything you do. That's why you're suing him.

ex_1_jp: 本ものかにせものか見分けられない。
ex_1_en: I can’t tell whether it’s real or fake.
ex_2_jp: こい人がサイコパスかどうか見分ける方ほうはありますか？
ex_2_en: Is there a way to find out if my significant other is a psychopath?
ex_3_jp: 首輪をつけておくべきだったよね。だって、どっちの犬がどっちの犬か見分けるのが難しくなっちゃったよ。
ex_3_en: We should have put collars on our dogs, because now it's difficult to tell which one is mine and which one is yours.
meaning_story: You see something, then you separate (分ける) it. This is the same thing as to distinguish.
reading_story: You should know the reading of 見 already. The second part, 分ける is a word you should have learned in the previous level. Combine that knowledge together and you get the reading for this word.
pitch_accent: ミワケル *** ミワケꜜル

ex_1_jp: 母は、デパートへかいものに出かけました。
ex_1_en: Mom went out shopping at the department store.
ex_2_jp: おっとが子どもをつれて出かけたので、今日はドラクエ三まいです。
ex_2_en: Since my husband went out with kids, I can play Dragon Quest as much as I want.
ex_3_jp: 日曜日は家族で海に出かけるの。
ex_3_en: I’m going out to the beach with my family on Sunday.
meaning_story: You exit but you do it with かける added to it. Just think of that かける as you exiting and being "cocky" about it. You do this when you want to go out or to leave. You go out in a cocky way! This word can only be used for a person going out. You can't say a train 出かける'd.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 出る, so if you can remember that, you should be able to remember this one too!

ex_1_jp: カブレラがホームランを打ちました。
ex_1_en: Cabrera hit a home run.
ex_2_jp: ぼくの先生は、キーボードを打つのが世かいで一ばんはやい。
ex_2_en: My teacher is the world's fastest keyboard typer.
ex_3_jp: ママは狂って、人参で僕のおしりを何度もひどく打った。
ex_3_en: My mom went crazy and pounded my butt with a carrot.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hit so the vocab is to hit or to pound.
reading_story: You learned the kun'yomi reading when you learned this word's kanji, meaning you should already be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: もしよければ、代わりましょうか。
ex_1_en: If you don’t mind, can I take your place?
ex_2_jp: 王子は、けん玉に代わるあたらしいあそびを見つけた。
ex_2_en: The prince found a new way to amuse himself, replacing kendama.
ex_3_jp: 私はスティーブ・ジョブズに代わる天才を探しています。
ex_3_en: I am looking for another genius to replace Steve Jobs.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means substitute, so we can get to the meaning of this word through that: To replace / to substitute for.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the か portion. You have to replace your car (か). It is getting old, and seems like it will explode at any moment, literally. It's actually about to わる (wear) out!

ex_1_jp: わたしはいえで休んでいます。
ex_1_en: I’m resting at home.
ex_2_jp: やるときにきちんとやることをやって、休むときはしっかり休んだ方がいいよ。
ex_2_en: You should rest up well when you can, and then work hard when you have to.
ex_3_jp: 一日で休むことができるのは、トイレに座っている時だけだ。
ex_3_en: The only time that I rest each day is when I’m sitting on the toilet.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rest, so what's the verb version of that? It's to rest.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to rest, right? Answer the question! You should say yes (やす).

ex_1_jp: トーフグのコウイチと申します。
ex_1_en: I am Koichi of Tofugu.
ex_2_jp: トーフグが日本のわかものにモノ申す！
ex_2_en: Tofugu gives frank advice to young Japanese people!
ex_3_jp: 申すまでもなく、私の上司は性転換手術をなされました。今の彼女は大変嬉しいそうだ。
ex_3_en: It goes without saying that my boss underwent a sex change operation. Now she’s very happy.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means Say / Say Humbly. This is just the verb form, to say humbly. Please note that this is a very polite and humble way to say "to say" so it's used in especially polite situations. Because of this, it's probably going to be the ます form, which is 申します. You can also call this "to say" as well, just remember that it's humble and polite!
reading_story: The reading for this kanji is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji. High Fives.

ex_1_jp: このもんだいでは、えを見ながらしつもんをきいてください。
ex_1_en: In this problem, please listen to the questions while looking at the pictures.
ex_2_jp: その女がのっていた車のうんてん手は、よくみるとわたしの主人でした。
ex_2_en: When I looked closer, the driver of the car the woman was in was my husband.
ex_3_jp: ちょっと僕の手を見て、それが縮んでいるかどうか教えてくれませんか？
ex_3_en: Can you please look at my hand and tell me if it is shrinking?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means see so the vocab here means to see.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji (kun'yomi) so you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: みせの人は、なんのえを女の人に見せましたか？
ex_1_en: What picture did the shop worker show the woman?
ex_2_jp: 今年のなつは、すはだをチラリと見せるトップスが人気のようです。
ex_2_en: It seems tops that show a bit of skin are popular this summer.
ex_3_jp: もし俺がこのポーカーゲームでかったら、お前らに俺のリザードンのカードを見せてやるよ。
ex_3_en: If I win this poker game, I’ll show you guys my Charizard card.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. Also present is the せ which means you're causing someone to do something. You could say you're causing someone to see something, but that's sounds weird. A better translation would be to call this word to show.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the one that you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read it.

ex_1_jp: この町には、コンビニがおおいです。
ex_1_en: There are a lot of convenience stores in this town.
ex_2_jp: よる、一人でこの町をあるくのはきけんだ。
ex_2_en: It's dangerous to walk alone in this town at night.
ex_3_jp: 私の町は、最高のエアギターを作ることで有名です。
ex_3_en: My town is famous for making the best invisible guitars.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You walk into this town. You hate it (because it's vocab, and who doesn't hate vocab?). So what do you do? You pull out a match (まち) and burn this town to the ground. Whoa, you some kind of psycho?

ex_1_jp: 二十日にテストがあります。
ex_1_en: There is a test on the twentieth.
ex_2_jp: あと二十日で２０１９年です。
ex_2_en: It will be 2019 in twenty days.
ex_3_jp: 毎月二十日は給料日です。
ex_3_en: Payday is the twentieth day of every month.
meaning_story: Two times ten days is twenty days.
reading_story: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. The readings for 二十 are exceptions, and 日 takes the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help with that: If you make one hat for twenty days you'll have enough hats (はつ) to fill up your car (か) completely! That's a lot of days and a lot of hats.

ex_1_jp: オーブンを、二百どによねつしてください。
ex_1_en: Please preheat the oven to two hundred degrees.
ex_2_jp: フェイスブックで二百もいいねをもらいました。
ex_2_en: I got two hundred likes on Facebook.
ex_3_jp: 僕は、レジの人に二百ドルをあげて、これで制汗剤を買うように言いました。
ex_3_en: I gave the cashier two hundred dollars and told her to buy some deodorant.
meaning_story: When you have two hundreds, you have two hundred.
reading_story: This word has a number in it, so it uses the kun'yomi reading for it. But the reading for 百 is the on'yomi reading. This is pretty normal when it comes to counting numbers in Japanese. You know both of these readings already. Hooray!

ex_1_jp: ことしは花見にいかなかった。
ex_1_en: I didn’t go sakura viewing this year.
ex_2_jp: 北りくち方の花見の名しょをごしょうかいします。
ex_2_en: I'm gonna introduce you to the best cherry blossom viewing spots in Hokuriku region.
ex_3_jp: 死ぬ前にもう一度花見をしながら宴会がしたいなあ。
ex_3_en: Before I die, I want to have a drinking party under the cherry blossoms one more time.
meaning_story: When you have flowers that you see you are viewing flowers. But not just any flowers. What flowers do Japanese people love viewing? That's right, this word refers to viewing cherry blossoms.
reading_story: The reading for this vocab is all kun'yomi, but you learned the kun'yomi readings of both these when you learned their kanji. So no worries there. You can spend the extra time viewing the cherry blossoms.

ex_1_jp: ちかくに村があります。
ex_1_en: There is a village nearby.
ex_2_jp: あなたのお母さんはこの村で生まれたのよ。
ex_2_en: Your mother was born in this village.
ex_3_jp: ええ、私はあなたの村で一度本当に馬糞を踏んでしまったんです。
ex_3_en: Yes, I have definitely stepped in the horse poop in your village.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned already with the kanji. Huzzah!

ex_1_jp: 村人は、年よりばかりです。
ex_1_en: The villagers are all old people.
ex_2_jp: なんかファンタジーゲームの村人っぽいセリフだよね。
ex_2_en: That line is kinda like something a villager would say in a fantasy game, isn't it?
ex_3_jp: 悲観主義者は「もうコップ半分しかない」と言うが、その村人は「おかわり！」と言って私を驚かせた。
ex_3_en: Pessimists say, "the glass is half empty," but the villager surprised me by shouting "Refill!"
meaning_story: You have a village person. That isn't someone dancing while wearing construction worker clothes, that's a villager.
reading_story: This word uses double kun'yomi for its reading, probably because it's like two separate words (village and person) put together into one big word. You should know these two kun'yomi readings (it's the main reading for 村 that you learned and you should know 人 by now), though you will need to look out for the rendaku'd びと reading.
pitch_accent: ムラビト *** ムラꜜビト

ex_1_jp: このひょうの見方が分かりません。
ex_1_en: I don't know how to look at this chart.
ex_2_jp: いろんな見方やとらえ方があります。
ex_2_en: There are various ways of seeing and understanding.
ex_3_jp: 私の見方では、被害者の女性は新車の臭いがしていたに違いない。
ex_3_en: From my perspective, the female victim must have smelled like a new car.
meaning_story: The way you see is the way of seeing something. This is like when someone has a dumb opinion and you're like "oh, okay, so that's one way of seeing it..."
reading_story: This word uses the readings of the kanji you've already learned, even though they're kun'yomi.

ex_1_jp: 今日は天気がわるいです。
ex_1_en: The weather is bad today.
ex_2_jp: 天気よほうをかくにんしましょう。
ex_2_en: Let's check the weather forecast.
ex_3_jp: 天気と気候の違いは何ですか？
ex_3_en: What’s the difference between weather and climate?
meaning_story: What is the heaven energy? If you think about it, that's all the stuff that falls on us from the sky. Lightning, rain, snow, hail... What is all of that? It's the weather.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 平日は仕ごとをしています。
ex_1_en: I have work on weekdays.
ex_2_jp: ざんねんだけど、平日だからたぶんいけないなぁ。
ex_2_en: Sadly, I probably won't be able to go because it's on a weekday.
ex_3_jp: 私は料理人で、平日は仕事で忙しいので、家庭ではふだん料理をしません。
ex_3_en: I am a chef but because I’m busy working on weekdays I usually don’t cook at home.
meaning_story: The flat days are boring. They're the same. One day after another. That's definitely not your exciting weekends... that's your boring, flat weekdays.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 日 in this one uses its じつ reading.

ex_1_jp: かれは、わたしにこっそり耳打ちしました。
ex_1_en: He secretly whispered in my ear.
ex_2_jp: ミーティングのときに、コウイチがニッカになにか耳打ちしてるのをみてしまった。
ex_2_en: I happened to witness Koichi whispering something in Nikka's ear during the meeting.
ex_3_jp: 私が彼に、何かセクシーな言葉を耳打ちしてというと、彼は「テープやCDは好きかい？」と囁いてくれた。
ex_3_en: I told him to whisper something sexy in my ear and he said, "Do you like tapes and CDs?"
meaning_story: A hit to someone's ear... you'd think that would be like yelling into their ear, but it's not. Think of it like you're hitting your mouth to their ear so that it's nice and close so you can whisper in ear.
reading_story: This word uses the readings you learned with both of the kanji in it.
pitch_accent: ミミウチ *** ミミウチꜜ *** ミミウꜜチ

ex_1_jp: 外では、白いゆきがふっていました。
ex_1_en: There was white snow falling outside.
ex_2_jp: うちの牛は白いのよりもくろいのの方が元気がいい。
ex_2_en: Our black cows are more energetic than the white ones.
ex_3_jp: フワフワで白いウサギが野原でピョンピョン跳ねていました。
ex_3_en: A fluffy, white rabbit was hopping in the field.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of white? White, of course!
reading_story: This has the same reading as the vocab 白 you learned, so you already know the reading. Go you!

ex_1_jp: 年内には、かんせいするはずです。
ex_1_en: It should be complete within the year.
ex_2_jp: 年内にフォロワー10万人目ざします。
ex_2_en: I'm aiming to reach 100,000 followers by the end of this year.
ex_3_jp: この暗殺は、年内に遂行されなくてはならない。
ex_3_en: The assassination must be carried out before the year is over.
meaning_story: The inside of a year is what happens within a year.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このアプリは、まだ世に出ていません。
ex_1_en: This app still isn’t world famous.
ex_2_jp: まったく世も末だね。
ex_2_en: The world really is coming to an end.
ex_3_jp: 暗殺者は別にして、スズメ蜂ほど怖いものはこの世の中にない。
ex_3_en: Other than assassins, nothing in this world is scarier than wasps.
meaning_story: This is one of those exceptions where even though this vocab is a single kanji with nothing attached, it does not have the same meaning as the kanji you learned, though it's close. The meaning is world or society, but what is the world made up of? What is society made up of? That would be generations of people. So, when you think generations of people, think of them all coming together to make up society.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: Since you have generations of people making up this world, think of the rapper generation. What do they say all the time (obviously I don't know anything about rap)? They say "Yo yo yo!" (よ).

ex_1_jp: どうぞよいお年をおむかえください。
ex_1_en: I hope you have a happy New Year!
ex_2_jp: 今年もぶじに年をとりました。
ex_2_en: Once again, I was able to age this year without issue.
ex_3_jp: あくる年、エリカは白い牛に乗った王子様に出会いました。
ex_3_en: The next year, Erika met a prince riding a white cow.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: This year I refuse to watch tosh.0's (とし) show. It is terrible.

pronunciation: にせんじゅういちねん
ex_1_jp: ２０１１年に、日本にいきました。
ex_1_en: I went to Japan in 2011.
ex_2_jp: 主人は、２０１１年から火せいではたらいています。
ex_2_en: My husband has been working on Mars since 2011.
ex_3_jp: 父は、２０１１年にようやくドラッグの使用を認めました。
ex_3_en: My father finally admitted to drug use in 2011.
meaning_story: It's the 2011 year. I think the meaning is pretty obvious. This just means year 2011 or simply 2011.
reading_story: The reading is a little trickier. You start with two thousand (二千／にせん), then you need to add eleven to it (十一／じゅういち). Then, you simply add the reading for 年 which you already know. You can assume it's the on'yomi reading because it's attached to something else, like a jukugo. From there, you get the entire reading.

ex_1_jp: この町のそらは、年中どんよりしています。
ex_1_en: The sky in this town is dull all year.
ex_2_jp: トーフグのしゃいんは、二十四じかん年中むきゅうではたらいている。
ex_2_en: Tofugu employees work twenty four seven, year round.
ex_3_jp: この国では一年中雨が降るんだが、妻もまた年中その文句を言うんだ。
ex_3_en: It rains year round in this country and my wife complains about it year round as well.
meaning_story: The year middle sounds like it should be something like "the middle of the year," but it's not. Think of something that happens in the middle of the year and then all other parts of the year. It's just referring to everything within this year, which is how we get year round.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 中 does have a strange reading, though, which is じゅう. This is basically just ちゅう changing to ぢゅう, but since nobody uses ぢ it just switches to じ and you end up with じゅう. That's called rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 少年は、やきゅうが大すきでした。
ex_1_en: The boy loved baseball.
ex_2_jp: けいさつかんは、一ぱんてきに、少年はんざいのかがいしゃを、けいさつの少年かにれんこうします。
ex_2_en: Police officers generally bring young offenders in to the police department's juvenile division.
ex_3_jp: 私は腕白な少年ではなく、気が弱くて無口な少年でした。
ex_3_en: I wasn't a naughty boy, but a dimwitted and hesitant one.
meaning_story: Someone of few years is someone who's young. But, back in the day the Japanese and Chinese tended to favor the boys, so this one means young boy. Sorry girls! Use your irritation at this kanji to remember it better.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 大学を一年かん休学していたんです。
ex_1_en: I’m taking a one year leave of absence from university.
ex_2_jp: ビエトは大学のとき、学こうを一年かん休学してじ分さがしのたびに出た。
ex_2_en: When Viet was a college student, he took a year of leave from school and went on a journey of self discovery.
ex_3_jp: 「どうしてケリーが三週間も休学しているか知ってる？」「知ってるよ。ケリーは結膜炎がひどいらしいよ。」
ex_3_en: "Do you know why Kelly has been absent from school for the past three weeks?" "Yes, apparently she has a really serious case of pink eye."
meaning_story: When you rest from school you are absent from school. This is only for very long absences though, not a day or a week, but months or years. Think about it like taking an extended leave of absence from school.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: アルコールの作用をおしえてください。
ex_1_en: Teach me about the effects of alcohol.
ex_2_jp: 今日、学こうで、作用・はん作用のほうそくを学んだ。
ex_2_en: I learned Newton's third law of motion at school today.
ex_3_jp: このケーキの味がする薬には、副作用はありませんか？
ex_3_en: Does this cake-flavored medicine have any side effects?
meaning_story: When you make a task you're looking for a certain action and/or effect. What task can you make right now to get the effect of learning more kanji?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Remember when you learned the kanji for 作 and we said you'll see some that take just さ instead of the whole さく? This is one of those!

ex_1_jp: かの女が花をつむ仕草が大すきです。
ex_1_en: I love to see her picking flowers.
ex_2_jp: 男せいがすきな女せいの仕草はなんですか。
ex_2_en: What kinds of female gestures do men usually like?
ex_3_jp: 煙草を吸う大人の仕草にドキッとした。
ex_3_en: I was appalled by the smoking adults’ behavior.
meaning_story: Things you end up doing in the grass and not inside probably take a lot of big actions and gestures. You have to do them outside on the grass because if you did them anywhere else you might break something.
reading_story: The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this. Just watch out because rendaku makes くさ become ぐさ.

ex_1_jp: ちょっとは空気をよんでください。
ex_1_en: Please just take the hint.
ex_2_jp: 冬のあさの空気はつめたい。
ex_2_en: The morning winter air is cold.
ex_3_jp: 海賊の宇宙船に乗っている猿は、三時間後に大気圏に突入する予定だ。猿は、肺に好きなだけ空気を吸い込むことが待ちきれない。
ex_3_en: The monkey in the pirate’s space ship will be reentering the atmosphere in 3 hours. He can’t wait to draw as much air into his lungs as possible.
meaning_story: The sky energy... once known of as a mystical thing that kept us from flying into space. Now we know this is the air. It can also mean atmosphere, though, because that's what a bunch of air between the earth and space is called. ここの空気はいいね！
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このはいゆうは、万人に人気がある。
ex_1_en: That actor is popular with everyone.
ex_2_jp: セキセイインコのにおいは万人にうけるにおいらしい。
ex_2_en: I heard that everybody likes the smell of parakeets.
ex_3_jp: これは万人に共通の感想だろう。
ex_3_en: This seems to be the common impression among everybody.
meaning_story: If we're talking about ten thousand persons, then we might as well be talking about all people and everybody, because that's a lot of people, you know?
reading_story: The reading for 万 is a bit weird. It's ばん instead of まん. So, when you think of this word and think of all people, think about how they're all cheering "banzai!" at the same time, together. BANZAI BANZAI ALL PEOPLE RULE.
pitch_accent: バンジン *** バンジꜜン *** バンニン *** バンニꜜン

ex_1_jp: だんだん売り上げがへってきた。
ex_1_en: Sales gradually decreased.
ex_2_jp: アメリカ人人気はいゆうが主えんしたハリウッドえいがのDVDは、日本だけで売り上げが八百万まいになった。
ex_2_en: The DVD of the Hollywood movie in which a popular American actor played the main character has sold eight million copies in Japan alone.
ex_3_jp: あの性差別の広告のせいで、売り上げが激減した。
ex_3_en: Sales have decreased rapidly because of that sexist advertisement.
meaning_story: The selling that you've raised (上げ) is the amount sold or number of sales. Think of a graph going upward, where it's rising as you sell more things.
reading_story: The reading for 売 is the one you learned with the kanji. The reading for 上げ is the same as the reading for 上げる, a word you learned previously. If you know those two separate things you should be able to combine them into one awesome vocab thing.

ex_1_jp: カッパは、日本古来のようかいです。
ex_1_en: The kappa is an ancient Japanese yokai.
ex_2_jp: 古来、この池は、「ワニカニの池」という名まえでしられていました。
ex_2_en: In ancient times, this pond was known as "WaniKani Pond."
ex_3_jp: トイレは、古来から現代へと受け継がれてきた素晴らしい発明品だ。
ex_3_en: The toilet is a wonderful invention that has been handed down since ancient times to the present-day.
