meaning_story: If you come to the party wearing something really, really old, everyone will know you're from ancient times (as if your wrinkles didn't give it away already, right?).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このえいがは、ヒッチコックの大作だ。
ex_1_en: This movie is a Hitchcock epic.
ex_2_jp: 今世き一ばんの大作ともいわれているえいがのタイトルは「フグの一生」です。
ex_2_en: The title of the most epic film this century is said to be, "A Life of Fugu."
ex_3_jp: ベートーベンが作曲した曲は、どれも大作だった。
ex_3_en: Every score that Beethoven wrote was a masterpiece.
meaning_story: The big make! What is your big make? Bigger than anything else. It is your epic (as in an epic that you write). Also could be an epic, epic saga, and masterpiece.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: つぎの角を、左にまがってください。
ex_1_en: Please turn left at the next corner.
ex_2_jp: あの先生は、とうふの角にあたまをぶつけて気ぜつしたらしい。
ex_2_en: I heard that that the teacher got knocked out from hitting her head on the corner of a block of tofu.
ex_3_jp: 正三角形では，三つの角の大きさがみんな同じです。
ex_3_en: All three internal angles of an equilateral triangle are equal.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. But this word has two different meanings and each one has its own reading. You should make sure you don't mix them up. The first one is the reading you learned with the kanji. かく means angle. The second reading (かど), is something you haven't learned, and it means corner. Just picture a deck of cards (かど). Now take one card at a time and fold them to make a corner. Now tape those cards into all the corners of your house. Why? Because it's artsy!
pitch_accent: カꜜク *** カク *** カクꜜ *** カꜜド *** ツノꜜ

ex_1_jp: たからくじで当たりが出るかくりつはとてもひくいです。
ex_1_en: The odds of winning the lottery are very low.
ex_2_jp: あんなしょっぼい当たりのゴロでヒットになるわけがない。
ex_2_en: Such a weak-hit grounder can't be a hit.
ex_3_jp: 僕が開いた父さんの５０歳の誕生日パーティーは大当たりで、父さんはそこで新しい彼女まで見つけてしまった。
ex_3_en: The party I threw for my father’s 50th birthday was a success and he even found a new girlfriend there.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji right. What happens when you get "a right?" You get a success.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the あ portion of this word to read it. What is the correct answer that will give you a success? It is the first answer, A (あ).

ex_1_jp: 今すぐ、会いに行きましょう。
ex_1_en: Let's go meet them right away.
ex_2_jp: テキストフグのシーズン１なら、むりょうで今すぐよめますよ。
ex_2_en: You can read season 1 of TextFugu right now for free.
ex_3_jp: いいから黙って今すぐ来い!
ex_3_en: Be quiet and come over at once!
meaning_story: You'll have to learn this word in two parts. You already know the meaning of 今 because of the kanji, which means "now." The すぐ part, however, is a new word, meaning "soon." The two words even start with the same "soo" sound. If you put these two together, you get "now soon." Put in better English, that's at once or right now.
reading_story: Since you already know the vocab word 今 (read いま), you should be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: いえのちかくのえきででんしゃをおりて、スーパーに牛肉をかいに行きました。
ex_1_en: I got off the train at a station near my home and went to the grocery store to buy beef.
ex_2_jp: 去年、えいこくさん牛肉のゆ入がさいかいされました。
ex_2_en: Last year, the import of UK beef was resumed.
ex_3_jp: 牛肉はありえないくらい生焼けだ。この牛肉のせいで今夜はキッチンの悪夢を見ることになりそうだ。
ex_3_en: The beef is so undercooked. I may have a kitchen nightmare tonight because of this.
meaning_story: What do you call cow meat? You call it beef (what's for dinner?).
reading_story: Both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: わたしは日本人ですが、生まれはサンフランシスコです。
ex_1_en: I’m Japanese, but I was born in San Francisco.
ex_2_jp: つまは、アメリカ生まれの日本人なんです。
ex_2_en: My wife is American-born Japanese.
ex_3_jp: 生まれは大阪ですが、育ちは奈良です。
ex_3_en: My birthplace is Osaka, but I was raised in Nara.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 生まれる means "to be born?" Well once you're born that place where it happened becomes your birthplace!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 生まれる. Just drop the る off the end and you have your reading!

ex_1_jp: 青いとりがいます。
ex_1_en: There is a blue bird.
ex_2_jp: そのリンゴ、まだ青いんじゃないの。
ex_2_en: That apple hasn't ripened enough yet, has it?
ex_3_jp: うわっ、この青いペンキ、あの赤いペンキと全く同じ臭いがする。
ex_3_en: Wow, this blue paint smells exactly like the red paint.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of blue? It's still blue!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the あお portion to read this word. Think of blue things on your body. Those are bruises. Touch them. What would you say? OW! (あお).

ex_1_jp: おふろに入ると、はじめに体をあらいます。
ex_1_en: When I take a bath, I wash my body first.
ex_2_jp: ジャマルって何でそんなに体がやわらかいの？
ex_2_en: Jamal, why is your body so flexible?
ex_3_jp: なぜだか、体中がかゆいんだ。
ex_3_en: My entire body is so itchy for some reason.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You have your body. It's nice - looking good! What would really mess up your body? It would be a car raider (からだ). I'm talking about a dude who is a raider of some kind driving a car. If he runs into your body, you're done for, so watch out for the car raider. Of course, this mnemonic is only meant to get you close to the reading. Hopefully it is close enough to get you to the actual reading, からだ.
pitch_accent: カラダ *** タꜜイ *** テꜜイ

ex_1_jp: まえにいる男の子は、おか田さんの子どもです。
ex_1_en: The boy in front of them is Okada’s child.
ex_2_jp: おめでとうございます、お母さん。かわいい男の子ですよ。
ex_2_en: Congratulation, mom. It's a cute baby boy!
ex_3_jp: あの男の子は元気が良すぎる。今さっきも叔母さんの頭に卵を二十個投げつけて、うまく逃げ切ったんだ。
ex_3_en: That boy has so much energy. He just threw twenty eggs at his aunt’s head and managed to run away.
meaning_story: A child of a man is no man, it is a boy.
reading_story: If you know the kun'yomi readings of both of these kanji you should be okay. You have two separate single-kanji words put together by a の. That's why it's the kun'yomi reading - they're separate.

ex_1_jp: キャベツに毛虫がついていました。
ex_1_en: There was a caterpillar on the cabbage.
ex_2_jp: 毛虫かと思ったら妹のつけまだった。
ex_2_en: I thought it was a caterpillar, but it was actually my sister's fake eyelashes.
ex_3_jp: 私は巨大な毛虫と巨大なムカデが戦っているところをビデオに収めた。
ex_3_en: I videotaped a giant caterpillar fighting a giant centipede.
meaning_story: When you think of a fur insect what do you think of? My mind immediately goes to a caterpillar. Imagine the furriest caterpillar you can and touch it. How does it feel? Furry?
reading_story: The readings for this word are strange. Both use the kun'yomi readings - 虫 uses the reading you learned with the kanji, so that's easy. The 毛 part is like the vocab word 毛 you learned in the previous lesson.

ex_1_jp: わたしのいえはえきから近いです。
ex_1_en: My house is close to the station.
ex_2_jp: 今日は、ほぼすっぴんに近いです。
ex_2_en: I'm wearing close to no makeup today.
ex_3_jp: アメリカのビールって、カヌーの上ででんぐり返しをするみたいなものだよね。超水に近いんだもん。
ex_3_en: Drinking American beer is like doing somersaults in a canoe. It’s too close to water.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of near? It's close or nearby.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ちか portion to be able to read this word. Imagine someone close to you... Too close. They are so close to you that they're touching their cheek (ちか) to your cheek. Feel the cheek on yours, it's getting awkward.

ex_1_jp: 何色がすきですか。
ex_1_en: What color do you like?
ex_2_jp: ピーマンはうれるとみどり色から赤色になります。
ex_2_en: Bell peppers turn from green to red when they ripen.
ex_3_jp: 僕は色盲なので、赤色はオレンジ色に、青色は黒色のように見えます。
ex_3_en: I’m color blind, so my reds appear orange and my blues appear black.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji and uses the kun'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned with the kanji, though, so enjoy.

ex_1_jp: 会社へは、何で行っていますか。
ex_1_en: How do you go to your company?
ex_2_jp: トーフグは日本ごの学しゅうきょうざいをつくったり、日本についてのじょうほうをはいしんしたりする会社です。
ex_2_en: Tofugu is a company that deals with things like developing Japanese language learning materials and delivering Japanese-related information.
ex_3_jp: 私が働く会社の社長は、ハムスターのような容貌をしている。
ex_3_en: The president of the company I work for looks like a hamster.
meaning_story: The place where your company meets is your company. Sony is a company. Nintendo is a company. Etc.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この作文を、中川先生にわたしてください。
ex_1_en: Please hand this essay in to professor Nakagawa.
ex_2_jp: 作文のテストで百てんをもらいました。
ex_2_en: I got 100 percent on the essay exam.
ex_3_jp: 僕の作文は、まだ間違いだらけです。
ex_3_en: My essays are still full of mistakes.
meaning_story: When you make writing, what are you doing? Simply put, you're writing. If you want to be fancier about it, you could say this is composition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 工作はとくいではありません。
ex_1_en: Construction is not my strong point.
ex_2_jp: アリバイ工作にしっぱいした。
ex_2_en: I failed to set up a reasonable alibi.
ex_3_jp: 私は小学生の頃、夏休みの自由工作の宿題で、アイスクリームを作る機械を作った。
ex_3_en: When I was in elementary school, I made a machine that makes ice cream for my school crafting project over summer break.
meaning_story: What is the "industry of make"? Well, it's an industry where you make things, obviously. That can only be construction!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日よう日は、サッカーの大会に出じょうします。
ex_1_en: I am participating in the soccer tournament on Sunday.
ex_2_jp: 花火大会では、アイスクリームがよく売れます。
ex_2_en: At fireworks events, ice cream sells well.
ex_3_jp: 私がマラソン大会で優勝したのは、オナラを止めることができず、他のランナーがその臭いを嗅ぐたびにペースを落としていったからだ。
ex_3_en: I won the marathon because I couldn’t stop farting and all the other runners slowed down whenever they smelled them.
meaning_story: When you have a big meet there's a lot of people together. Why would you have a bunch of people gather together? Probably for a convention or some kind of competition or tournament.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 下の図を見てください。
ex_1_en: Please look at the diagram below.
ex_2_jp: クリックすると、かく大図がひょうじされます。
ex_2_en: If you click it, an enlarged view will appear.
ex_3_jp: あなたのお兄さんは、自分と彼女の関係を簡単な図に表しました。
ex_3_en: Your brother drew a simple diagram of the relationship between him and his girlfriend.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: While words that are made up of a single kanji usually take the kun'yomi reading, this one takes the on'yomi reading. Luckily, this is the same reading you learned with the kanji, so it shouldn't be too hard to remember.

ex_1_jp: 今日は、日本の外交についてはなしあいをしました。
ex_1_en: We discussed Japanese diplomacy today.
ex_2_jp: 外交かんが不足している。
ex_2_en: We have a shortage of diplomats.
ex_3_jp: 日本は外交があまり上手ではない。
ex_3_en: Japan isn’t very good at diplomacy.
meaning_story: You want to mix opinions from outside your country into the way you handle things. That's called diplomacy. If you mix your country with the ones outside of your own, you'll all profit!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: わたしは、下町でそだちました。
ex_1_en: I grew up downtown.
ex_2_jp: とうきょうの下町にあるむかしながらのさかばに行ってみたいです。
ex_2_en: I'd like to go to a good old fashioned saloon in the backstreet areas of the old cities of Tokyo.
ex_3_jp: 下町とは、日本の古いスタイルのダウンタウンのことで、現代のものとは異なっている。
ex_3_en: A shitamachi is an old Japanese style of downtown; it isn’t the same as the downtown we think of today.
meaning_story: You have the below town. Does this sort of sound familiar? We have another word for it in English, but it's essentially the same thing: downtown.
reading_story: The reading for this word is all kun'yomi despite being jukugo. Just think of sketchy things going on in the downtown, just like how there's sketchy kun'yomi readings for this word. You should know both the kun'yomi readings from the previous level, though, so if you do you know the reading for this word as well.

ex_1_jp: わたしのせんもんは、工学です。
ex_1_en: My specialization is engineering.
ex_2_jp: ハーバード大学の工学のクラスは目玉がとび出るほどむずかしかった。
ex_2_en: The engineering class at Harvard University was excessively difficult.
ex_3_jp: 僕はこの仕事にぴったりだと思うんだけど、応募するには工学の学位がいるんだ。
ex_3_en: I’d be perfect for this job, but I need an engineering degree in order to apply.
meaning_story: Someone with the study of industry is someone who creates things. That would be the study of engineering.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: わたしは日本ご学こうで、毎日べんきょうしています。
ex_1_en: I study every day at a Japanese language school.
ex_2_jp: 名古やから、大さかにあるアメリカ村に毎日かよっています。
ex_2_en: I'm commuting from Nagoya to Americamura in Osaka every day.
ex_3_jp: 毎日17から21個のチーズバーガーを食べます。
ex_3_en: I eat anywhere between 17-21 cheeseburgers every day.
meaning_story: Every day is daily (or just every day).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: まいげつ, まいつき
ex_1_jp: うちの学こうでは、毎月テストがあります。
ex_1_en: There is a test at my school every month.
ex_2_jp: ゆうふくないえではありませんでしたが、わたしが大学生のとき、りょうしんは毎月生かつひをしおくりしてくれました。
ex_2_en: Although my family wasn't rich, my parents sent a living allowance to me when I was in university.
ex_3_jp: 毎月どのくらい家賃を払っていますか？
ex_3_en: How much do you pay for rent each month?
meaning_story: Every moon is every month (as you know from all the month-related vocab). This can also mean monthly.
reading_story: For the first reading, the reading is the on'yomi readings put together. For the other reading (which is just as good), you use the kun'yomi reading of 月. It's good to learn that both exist. Since you know 月 as つき from the vocab already, this shouldn't be too hard, hopefully!
pitch_accent: マイケ°ツ *** マイツキ

ex_1_jp: このマラソン大会には、毎回出じょうしています。
ex_1_en: I enter this marathon every time.
ex_2_jp: コウイチは毎回ミーティングのと中でクネクネうごく。
ex_2_en: Koichi wiggles during each meeting.
ex_3_jp: 笑おうとすると、毎回歯茎から血が出始める。
ex_3_en: Every time I try to smile, my gums start bleeding.
meaning_story: Every times is really just every time. Do you get your kanji readings correct 毎回?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: まいとし, まいねん
ex_1_jp: 山田さんは、毎年どこにりょ行に行きますか？
ex_1_en: Where does Yamada go for her trip every year?
ex_2_jp: あのか手は毎年引たいを口にしているので、きっと今回もただのつりでしょう。
ex_2_en: That singer hints at retiring every year, so he must be saying it again this time just to get people to react.
ex_3_jp: 私は、ジョンソンさん一家のために、10年間毎年新しい扉を建てている。どうしてジョンソンさんたちはトロールに扉を使わせないようにしないのだろうか。
ex_3_en: I’ve built a new door for the Johnson family every year for the past decade. Why don’t they just stop letting the troll use it?
meaning_story: You have every and year to combine into every year (yearly works as well).
reading_story: The reading for 毎 is what you'd expect. The reading for 年 is the kun'yomi reading, though. So, use your knowledge of the vocab 年 to help yourself to remember the reading for this word. You'll need to remember that the reading for this word is strange to get it into that brain of yours. That being said, the reading まいねん works as well. I don't like this one as much as まいとし but it's equally acceptable.
pitch_accent: マイトシ *** マイネン

ex_1_jp: 小とりは、羽をパタパタうごかしました。
ex_1_en: The small bird flapped its wings.
ex_2_jp: 手羽先のからあげはたべたことがあるけど、ちょうちょうの羽のからあげはたべたことがありません。
ex_2_en: I have eaten deep-fried chicken wings before, but I've never eaten deep-fried butterfly wings.
ex_3_jp: 「この羽、どの鳥の羽か分かるかな？」と彼は自分の鼻毛を持ちながら聞いてきた。
ex_3_en: "Do you know what kind of bird this feather is from?" he asked me, holding out some of his own nose hair.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji with nothing attached it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: 毎あさ、林をさんぽしています。
ex_1_en: Every morning I walk in the forest.
ex_2_jp: 林先生が早足で林をあるいているのを見ちゃった。
ex_2_en: I happened to catch Mrs. Hayashi speed walking in woods.
ex_3_jp: 家に帰るまで待てずに、林の中に濡れた靴下を残した。
ex_3_en: I couldn’t wait until I got to the house, so I left my wet socks in the woods.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji it uses the kun'yomi reading. You've already learned this reading with the kanji, though, so you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: です・ます形ではなしをするとていねいにきこえます。
ex_1_en: When you talk using desu and masu forms you sound polite.
ex_2_jp: ひてい形から会わに入る人はコミュしょうのかのうせいがたかい。
ex_2_en: A person who starts conversations with negative form sentences is likely to have some difficulties in communicating with others.
ex_3_jp: どうして今、過去形で言ったの？
ex_3_en: Why did you just say that in past tense?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It doesn't just mean form though, it means tense too. Like verb tense.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
pitch_accent: カタꜜ *** カタチ *** ナリꜜ

ex_1_jp: かれは、わたしの三十年来の友人です。
ex_1_en: He’s been my friend for thirty years.
ex_2_jp: わたしの年来のきぼうがついにかないました。
ex_2_en: My long-cherished wish has finally come true.
ex_3_jp: 数年来彼女をデートに誘っているんだが、いつも「髪の毛を洗うのに忙しいから」と断られる。
ex_3_en: I’ve been trying to ask her out for a few years now, but she always says she will be busy washing her hair.
meaning_story: When you have years coming and going, you know it is for some years. Don't confuse this one with 来年 which means "next year." The kanji 来 comes after the kanji for year, so instead of "coming year" it's "years that come (and go)." At least, you can think of it that way to differentiate. You can also add numbers to this word. For example ５年来 means something to the tune of "for five years." But this is a pretty formal word. Just keep that in mind.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ネꜜンライ *** ネンライ

ex_1_jp: 大体あっています。
ex_1_en: That’s about right.
ex_2_jp: 大体同じぐらいのせです。
ex_2_en: We are about the same height.
ex_3_jp: 私は大体6時に起きます。
ex_3_en: I generally get up at 6 o’clock.
meaning_story: If all you can see is a big body of a person, then you'll only have a general idea of what they look like. You know their outline is quite big, but you don't know anything else.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 金のネックレスをプレゼントしました。
ex_1_en: I gave her a gold necklace.
ex_2_jp: お金があったら、金正ウンとおそろいの、金のロレックスをかいたいとおもっています。
ex_2_en: If I had money, I would like to buy the gold Rolex that Kim Jong-un has.
ex_3_jp: この毛糸は24時間後に金に変わるんだけど、クリスマスプレゼントとして少しあんたにあげるよ。感謝しろよな。
ex_3_en: This yarn will turn into gold in 24 hours and I’ll give you some as a Christmas present, so you should appreciate me more.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji you would normally think it uses the kun'yomi reading. Not this word, though. It still uses the on'yomi reading, which you learned with the kanji. Don't confuse this one with お金, though. That one uses kun'yomi which you know because it has a hiragana attached.

ex_1_jp: そろそろ草をからなくてはなりません。
ex_1_en: You have to cut the grass soon.
ex_2_jp: お金がないから草をたべて生きています。
ex_2_en: I don't have money, so I live by eating grass.
ex_3_jp: どうして隣の人の草はあんなに青いんだろう。どうして彼の家はあんなに大きいんだろう。
ex_3_en: Why does my neighbor have such green grass? And why is his house so big?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 本社はとうきょうにあります。
ex_1_en: The headquarters are in Tokyo.
ex_2_jp: 月よう日に、トーフグの本社におじゃましてきました。
ex_2_en: On Monday, I visited Tofugu HQ.
ex_3_jp: 今日は本社がやけに静かだな。俺が働いていない音まで聞こえるぜ。
ex_3_en: It’s so quiet in the head office today, I can hear myself not working.
meaning_story: The origin company is where everything in your company comes from. This is your main base. This is your headquarters.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ちょっと里心がついちゃったんです。
ex_1_en: I’m a bit homesick.
ex_2_jp: なつかしいメロディーに、里心がわいた。
ex_2_en: The nostalgic melody made me homesick.
ex_3_jp: この仔犬は里心がついて泣いているのかもしれないけど、そんなのかまうもんか。
ex_3_en: This puppy may be crying because he is homesick, but who cares?
meaning_story: You have your home village and your heart. Your heart always resides in your home village, so when you leave you feel homesick. Young people don't really use this word anymore. It's more for the oldies. If you're an oldie, go right ahead. If you're a youngie, then talk to more oldies!
reading_story: The readings are double kun'yomi. The kun'yomi reading is what you learned with 里 already, though you'll have to pull out the 心 vocab reading to remember it all. Not only that, the 心 gets rendaku'd here making it ごころ. Make sure you watch out for that.

ex_1_jp: いつ里にかえってくるんだい。
ex_1_en: When will you come back to the village?
ex_2_jp: そんな言ばづかいをしていると、お里がしれますよ。
ex_2_en: If you use language like that, you'll give away where you're from.
ex_3_jp: ふる里に帰るんだけど、顔見知りに会わないことを願っているよ。
ex_3_en: I’m traveling to my hometown and I’m hoping I don’t run into anyone I know.
meaning_story: This is the village you came from. This is where your parents live. This is your home village (same meaning as the kanji you learned).
reading_story: The reading is the same as with the kanji you learned. It's like the village vocab word goes home to its kanji every once in a while. They share the same reading origin because of this.

ex_1_jp: 何日仕ごとを休んでいたんですか。
ex_1_en: How many days will you take off of work?
ex_2_jp: 何日がごつごうよろしいですか？
ex_2_en: What day would be good for you?
ex_3_jp: あなたはその島から何日間出られなかったんですか？
ex_3_en: How many days were you stuck on that island?
meaning_story: What day equals the fairly obvious translation "what day." But, it also means how many days.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: そのパーティーには、何人の人がさんかしましたか。
ex_1_en: How many people participated in the party?
ex_2_jp: 今までこの池で何人の人々がさつ人ぎょにころされましたか。
ex_2_en: How many people have been killed by the killer fish in this pond?
ex_3_jp: 夕食にはいったい何人の人がやって来るんですか？
ex_3_en: How many people will be joining us for dinner?
meaning_story: When you ask what people you're not actually asking "what people?" You're asking how many people. One thing you'll notice with Japanese and kanji is that 何, when added to other things, often means "how many _____" rather than "what ____." Just something you have to know and experience a bit to catch on to, but you will, I believe in you.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 何 and the on'yomi reading for 人. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that 人 uses its にん reading here.
pitch_accent: ナニビト *** ナꜜンニン *** ナンピト

ex_1_jp: 日本へ来るのは、今回で何回目ですか。
ex_1_en: Including this time, how many times have you come to Japan?
ex_2_jp: このビデオ、おもしろすぎて何回も見てしまうわ。
ex_2_en: This video is so funny that I have to watch it a bunch of times.
ex_3_jp: 事をはっきりさせるまでに、いったい何回この会話を繰り返さないといけねえんだよ？だから俺はリューク・スカイウォーカーじゃねえんだよ。映画でその役を演じただけだっつーの。俺の名前はマークだ。シカゴに住んでる。
ex_3_en: How many times do we have to have this conversation until it finally sinks in? I am not Luke Skywalker. I played him in a movie. My name is Mark. I live in Chicago.
meaning_story: What times? This doesn't make any sense. One thing you'll notice with Japanese and kanji is that 何, when added to other things, often means "how many _____" rather than "what ____." Just something you have to know and experience a bit to catch on to, but you will, I believe in you. So, for this one it's how many times.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 外来の言ばは、カタカナでかきます。
ex_1_en: Imported words are written with katakana.
ex_2_jp: 毎日外来に来ていたかんじゃさんが、来なくなったので心ぱいしています。
ex_2_en: I'm worried because the patient who would come to the outpatient clinic every day stopped coming.
ex_3_jp: 日本のものと全然違うので、私はとても外来品に興味がある。
ex_3_en: I’m really interested in foreign things because they’re so different from what’s in Japan.
meaning_story: From foreign lands it has come. How would you describe that item? Simply by calling it imported or foreign. This word is also used in hospitals for outpatient clinic. That's pretty good to know if you plan on going to the hospital to get checkups in Japan.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: むすこもようやく自立しはじめました。
ex_1_en: My son is finally starting to be self reliant.
ex_2_jp: 自立しんけいしっちょうしょうがなおったら、自立しようとおもっています。
ex_2_en: I'm thinking of being on my own, if I recover from autonomic dysfunction.
ex_3_jp: もしあなたが強くで自立した日本人女性で、男なんて必要ないというなら、これをシェアしてください。
ex_3_en: Share this if you are a strong, independent Japanese woman who doesn’t need a man.
meaning_story: You are able to stand using your self. Nobody is helping you. Nobody is holding you down. This is your independence!.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ちが、体内でどんなはたらきをしているのかしっていますか。
ex_1_en: Do you know what function blood has within the body?
ex_2_jp: カボチャに多くふくまれるβカロテンは体内でビタミンAにかわります。
ex_2_en: The kabocha squash is high in beta-carotene and it's converted into vitamin A in the body.
ex_3_jp: 人間の体か吸血鬼の体かにかかわらず、血液は体内を循環する。
ex_3_en: Blood circulates through the body regardless of whether it’s the body of a human or the body of a vampire.
meaning_story: Something that's inside your body... hmm, could be a lot of things, but we can generalize and just say it's internal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: まったく皮肉なものですね。
ex_1_en: That’s really ironic, isn’t it?
ex_2_jp: あの肉やさんは、大した皮肉やだよ。
ex_2_en: That butcher is a such a sarcastic person.
ex_3_jp: 「Ironic」という曲の中に、うまい皮肉はひとつも見当たらなかった。
ex_3_en: Not one thing in the song "Ironic" is a proper example of irony.
meaning_story: The skin on the meat is kind of like the outer shell. It's not very nice, and people who eat only meat skin tend to use sarcasm and irony. That being said, Japanese people don't really understand sarcasm. So, maybe that's why "meat skin" means "sarcasm." Is this ironic? Now I'm not even sure.
reading_story: The reading for 皮 is one you haven't learned. Who is sarcastic? He (ひ) is. You should be able to read 肉 already.

ex_1_jp: この会社には、四月に入社しました。
ex_1_en: I joined this company in April.
ex_2_jp: トーフグの入社しけんはグーグルの入社しけんよりもむずかしい。
ex_2_en: Tofugu's employment exam is more difficult than Google's.
ex_3_jp: 大学を卒業したらすぐに、大きな金融機関に入社するか、アメリカ合衆国の大統領になれたらいいなと思っている。
ex_3_en: As soon as I graduate from college, I hope to either join a big financial firm or be the president of the United States.
meaning_story: When you enter a company you're actually joining a company. Welcome, new recruit. Prepare to be hazed!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: そんな大声を出さないでください。
ex_1_en: Please don’t use such a loud voice.
ex_2_jp: おもわず大声を出してわらってしまった。
ex_2_en: I couldn't help laughing out loud.
ex_3_jp: クリスティーナは大声の持ち主で、残念なことにそれを使うのを全くはばからない。
ex_3_en: Christina has a loud voice, and unfortunately, she’s not afraid to use it.
meaning_story: A large voice is probably pretty large. Maybe even annoying, too. That's why this is a large voice or a loud voice.
reading_story: The reading for 声 is ごえ (rendaku'd version of the reading you know: こえ). The reading for 大 is the kun'yomi reading, like with the word 大きい (おおきい). Just imagine a loud voice saying "おお！."
pitch_accent: オーコ°ꜜエ *** タイセイ

ex_1_jp: 太ようの光がまぶしいので、カーテンをしめてください。
ex_1_en: The light from the sun is blinding, so please close the curtains.
ex_2_jp: 月の光にてらされて、かなえちゃんの歯がまるでパールのように見えるよ。
ex_2_en: In the moonlight, your teeth look just like pearls, Kanae.
ex_3_jp: 北朝鮮で行方不明になったあなたの子供には、まだ微かに希望の光が残っている。
ex_3_en: There is still a slight glimmer of hope left for your child who was lost in North Korea.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You have a ton of sunlight where you live. This creates heat. With this sunlight heat you're able to make your favorite food in the world: hickory (ひかり) smoked bacon. Mmm, taste that delicious bacon.

ex_1_jp: ちきゅうから月までは、一おく分の四光年です。
ex_1_en: It is four one hundred millionths of a light year from the earth to the moon.
ex_2_jp: ポートランドの中しんから北の方に四光年すすんだら、どこにつきますか。
ex_2_en: If we go north from the center of Portland for three light years, where will we be?
ex_3_jp: 光年とは、光の速度で1年間進み続け到達出来る距離だ。貴様が俺と対決しようなんて、一万光年早いわ。
ex_3_en: A light year is the distance that light can travel over the course of one year. You are 10,000 light years too early to be facing me.
meaning_story: What happens when light travels a year? You have a light year.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: コーネン *** コꜜーネン

ex_1_jp: 文学をよむいみとは何だろうか。
ex_1_en: What’s the significance of reading literature?
ex_2_jp: わたしは大学で、イギリス文学をせんこうしていました。
ex_2_en: I was majoring in English literature in university.
ex_3_jp: 村上春樹の作品は、純文学のふりをした大衆文学だと思います。
ex_3_en: I think Haruki Murakami's work is pop literature pretending to be pure literature.
meaning_story: If you study writing it's called literature. You'll get to study lots of things other people wrote before you!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ああ！この男の人が、すず木さんですか。
ex_1_en: Ah! Is that guy Suzuki?
ex_2_jp: あそこに立っている外人の男の人のとなりにいる女の人があのゆう名なまつい一代さんです。
ex_2_en: The lady next to the foreign guy standing over there is THE famous Kazuyo Matsui.
ex_3_jp: 背の高い男の人はTシャツを着ていて、背の低い男の人はセーターを着ています。
ex_3_en: The tall guy is wearing a T-shirt and the short guy is wearing a sweater.
meaning_story: The の particle makes it so the 人 belongs to the 男. Basically, this literally means "a man person" or "a person of man." It's a more polite way to say plain old man, though, so all you have to remember is that.
reading_story: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). That being said, in level 4 you learn about the vocab readings for these separate words, so use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.

ex_1_jp: このりょうりは多すぎます。
ex_1_en: There is too much food.
ex_2_jp: 「自分は正しい」とおもいこんでいる人は多い。
ex_2_en: There are many people who firmly believe that they are right.
ex_3_jp: 電車にはとても多くの乗客が乗っていたので、眠ることはできなかったが、大声で歌うことはできた。
ex_3_en: I wasn’t able to sleep because there were far too many people on the train, so I just sang loudly instead.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of many? It is also many (or you could say much). Speaking of which, there are so many kanji to learn, ammiright?
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think of something that is many. Doesn't matter what it is as long as you imagine a ridiculous number of them. Many of them. So many that they start avalanching into you and crushing you. The last thing you yell is "おお!!!" as you get smushed.

ex_1_jp: かさは、多分外にあります。
ex_1_en: Maybe the umbrella is outside.
ex_2_jp: 多分、レイヤーさんなのかもしれないよ。
ex_2_en: Perhaps, she is a cosplayer.
ex_3_jp: 明日の夜は多分雪になるから、雪だるまを作ろう。
ex_3_en: It’s probably going to snow tomorrow, so let’s make a snowman.
meaning_story: You have many parts. Look at them all. You have to choose one of the parts. You can't decide which one you want. This one? Maybe. How about this one? Hmm, maybe that one too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 水よう日は、肉がやすいです。
ex_1_en: On Wednesday, meat is cheap.
ex_2_jp: 牛肉とぶた肉ととり肉の中ではどれが一ばんすきですか。
ex_2_en: Among beef, pork, and chicken, which meat do you like the best?
ex_3_jp: お肉は、二枚の食パンに挟まれる、もっとも重要な具材です。
ex_3_en: Meat is the most important component between two slices of bread.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Luckily for you, this word uses the on'yomi reading that you learned even though it's a single kanji all on its own. So, you should know it already!

ex_1_jp: きんようびの夜に、女子会をします。
ex_1_en: I’m having a girls-only party on Friday night.
ex_2_jp: そのメンバーの会はとてもおも白そうですね。
ex_2_en: The assembly with those members sounds very interesting.
ex_3_jp: この会、また開こうよ！
ex_3_en: Let’s open this meeting again!
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji meet. So it means meeting.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: この写しんは、お金よりも大切です。
ex_1_en: This photo is more important than money.
ex_2_jp: お金をなめているとバチが当たるよ！
ex_2_en: If you're careless with money, it's going to bite you in the butt.
ex_3_jp: この機械は、お金を取りあげるけどなんの見返りもくれないから、気をつけた方がいいよ。
ex_3_en: You should be aware that this machine takes your money and gives you nothing in return.
meaning_story: The お is an honorific that makes this word a bit more fancy. When you're talking about money you gotta be fancy, after all. So, you're basically saying "gold" in a nicer way. What was gold back in the day? It was money.
reading_story: The reading for 金 is different from the one you learned with the kanji. Makes sense since this is a single kanji with hiragana attached. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You've saved up a ton of money. With it you're going to buy something awesome. Then, suddenly someone hits you in the knees with a bat. Now you have to spend all your money buying a cane (かね). Sucks for you :(

ex_1_jp: そのよるは、月光がとてもきれいでした。
ex_1_en: The moonlight was very beautiful that night.
ex_2_jp: 一りんの白い花に、月光がさえざえとふりそそいでいた。
ex_2_en: The bright moonlight was beaming down onto a white flower.
ex_3_jp: 月光に照らされた彼女は、とても美しかった。
ex_3_en: She looked so beautiful in the moonlight.
meaning_story: The moon light (not sunlight!) can be bright sometimes. This is night when you're stumbling home from a nomikai after work. What is this light from the moon called? It's moon light. This word can also mean a moonbeam as well.
reading_story: The reading is the on'yomi readings put together, though 月 is modified and shortened a bit. げつ goes to げっ. Make note of the different sized つ otherwise you'll be confused why you keep getting this one wrong over and over again!

ex_1_jp: 来月たん生日会をするので、かなえさんも来てください。
ex_1_en: I am having a birthday party next month, so please come too, Kanae.
ex_2_jp: 花火大会の日は来月の何日でしたっけ？
ex_2_en: What day next month is the day of the fireworks display?
ex_3_jp: 今日海に落とした眼鏡を探すために、来月スキューバダイビングを始めることにしたよ。
ex_3_en: Next month I’ll start scuba diving to find the glasses I lost at sea today.
meaning_story: The next month is the next month! It isn't this month or the month before, it's the next one!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 来年はアメリカにかえるつもりです。
ex_1_en: I’m thinking of going back to America next year.
ex_2_jp: 今年も来年もさ来年もわたしはニートをつづけるつもりです。
ex_2_en: I plan to continue being a NEET this year, next year, and the year after that.
ex_3_jp: 来年の今頃に来てくれよ。ハウストレーラー用のキャンプ場で、一番でかいトレーラーが俺のだよ。
ex_3_en: Come at this time next year. I’ll have the biggest trailer in the trailer park.
meaning_story: The next year is next year! It isn't last year or this year, it's the next one!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ひこうきは、北西にむかっています。
ex_1_en: The airplane is heading northwest.
ex_2_jp: ポートランドから車で一じかん半ほど北西の方にいくと、シーサイドというまちにつきます。
ex_2_en: If you drive about an hour and a half northwest from Portland, you will arrive at a city called Seaside.
ex_3_jp: ここから北西の方角のどこかに、パンストを落とした。
ex_3_en: I lost my pantyhose somewhere northwest of here.
meaning_story: This word is so simple. North + West = Northwest.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ちゃんと自分でしゅくだいをしました。
ex_1_en: I finished the homework perfectly all by myself.
ex_2_jp: 自分に自しんがないとえらべない色だよね。
ex_2_en: That's the color you can only choose if you are confident with yourself, isn't it?
ex_3_jp: もちろん私は自分と話しますよ。だって、時には専門家の意見が必要ですもの。
ex_3_en: Of course I talk to myself. Sometimes I need expert advice.
meaning_story: You have your self part. Part of your self is you. This is oneself. This is myself. Wait, who is this part of me? You're not sure... wait, no, it's myself. Is it? Be a little psychotic for a moment as you try to remember this vocab word.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もう一回、言ってください。
ex_1_en: Please say it once more.
ex_2_jp: 平日は一日に一回シャワーをあびますが、休日はぜんぜんあびません。
ex_2_en: I take a shower once a day during week, but not at all over the weekend.
ex_3_jp: もう一回欲しいのかい、ハニー？
ex_3_en: Do you want it one more time, honey?
meaning_story: One times is one time. How many times? Just one.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that 一 is shortened (as it often is) to いっ.

ex_1_jp: タクシーのひょうじが「空車」となっているときは、おきゃくさんはだれものっていません。
ex_1_en: When a taxi is displaying "Open Taxi," there are no customers aboard.
ex_2_jp: この辺りのコインパーキングがいつも空車なのがふしぎでしょうがない。
ex_2_en: I'm really curious why the parking lots around here are always empty.
ex_3_jp: 空車のタクシーが全然通らない。
ex_3_en: No empty taxis have passed us.
meaning_story: When a car has sky in it (and not, say, a bunch of people) it is free to give you a ride. If you see this sign lit up on a taxi feel free to hail it down, it will be able to take you somewhere. It is an open taxi.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: カラク°ꜜルマ *** クーシャ

ex_1_jp: このサイトは本来かめのせいそくちとしてつかわれていた。
ex_1_en: This site was originally used as a turtle habitat.
ex_2_jp: その言ばの本来のいみをしっていますか。
ex_2_en: Do you know the original meaning of that word?
ex_3_jp: 本来漢字は悪いものではない。
ex_3_en: Kanji in and of itself isn’t a bad thing.
meaning_story: You want to talk about the origin of something but it's already moved onto its next form, so you have to find a way to express that you're talking about what it was in the beginning. That's why this word means originally. It's a way of talking about what it was, without people mistaking it for what came after.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: わたしは体力があまりありません。
ex_1_en: I have practically no physical strength.
ex_2_jp: コウイチには、うで立てふせを八十回する体力はありません。
ex_2_en: Koichi doesn't have physical power to do 80 push-ups.
ex_3_jp: その熱が彼の体力を弱めたが、まだ自分で水を飲む体力は残っていた。
ex_3_en: The fever weakened his body, but he was still strong enough to drink water by himself.
meaning_story: You have your body power. This is just another way to say physical strength. HULK SMASH!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この池は大きすぎる。
ex_1_en: This pond is too big.
ex_2_jp: 池に竹の矢をおとしたら、中からかみさまがあらわれて、「おまえがおとしたのはこの竹の矢か、それともこの金の矢か。」ときかれたので、正じきに「竹の矢ですが、その金の矢もほしいです。」といった。
ex_2_en: When I dropped a bamboo arrow in the pond, God came out of it and asked me, "Did you drop this bamboo arrow or this gold arrow?" So I answered honestly, "I dropped the bamboo arrow, but I want the gold arrow, too."
ex_3_jp: うちのご近所さんは、鳥を撃ち落としては、うちの池に投げ入れる。
ex_3_en: My neighbor keeps tossing the dead birds that he shoots into my pond.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji it uses the kun'yomi reading - this is also the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: たしか、かれは公社ではたらいています。
ex_1_en: If I remember correctly, he works at a public corporation.
ex_2_jp: このりょきゃくてつどうは、みなみアフリカりょきゃくてつどう公社がうんえいしています。
ex_2_en: This passenger rail services were operated by the Passenger Rail Agency of South Africa.
ex_3_jp: 4月1日に国営公社である日本郵政公社が業務を開始したが、エイプリルフールのジョークではなかった。
ex_3_en: On April 1st, a public company called Japan Post opened for business and it wasn’t an April Fools’ joke.
meaning_story: This is a public company, which can also be called a public corporation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 雨はまだふっていません。
ex_1_en: It hasn’t rained yet.
ex_2_jp: 一年中雨がふるくにの王子として生まれたことをくいています。
ex_2_en: Unfortunately, I was born prince of a country that has rain all year long.
ex_3_jp: 私は雨の臭いが好きで、あなたはそんな臭いがする。だからあなたのことが大好きなの。
ex_3_en: I like the smell of rain and you smell like it. That’s why I love you.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji it uses the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, you learned this reading with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: それは本当ですか？
ex_1_en: Is that true?
ex_2_jp: さいきんの大学生はスマホでレポートをかくってきいたけど、本当かなあ。
ex_2_en: I heard that these days university students write essays on their smart phones, but I wonder if that's true.
ex_3_jp: 本当に下手なのです。
ex_3_en: I’m really awful at it.
meaning_story: What is real is right. It is the reality. It is also the truth. Don't believe anything that is not real and right.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 近年、日本しゅがまたブームになっています。
ex_1_en: There has been another boom in Japanese alcohol in recent years.
ex_2_jp: 近年のディズニーランドは、あまりこんざつしていないというのはかんぜんなるデマです。
ex_2_en: It's a total lie that Disneyland hasn't been that packed in recent years.
ex_3_jp: 豆腐を食べている河豚の存在が、近年徐々に明らかとなってきた。
ex_3_en: The existence of a tofu-eating fugu has slowly been coming to light in recent years.
meaning_story: The close years are years that aren't too long ago. They are the recent years.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 米をかうのをわすれてしまいました。
ex_1_en: I forgot to buy rice.
ex_2_jp: １おく円のおもさはやく１０キロときいたので、１０キロのお米のふくろをだきしめながら、１おく円をもっているところをそうぞうしてみた。
ex_2_en: I heard that the weight of 100 million yen is about 10kg, so I tried to imagine what it would be like to hold 100 million yen while holding a bag of 10kg rice.
ex_3_jp: 私の一番好きな朝ごはんは、生米と味噌汁です。
ex_3_en: My favorite breakfast consists of uncooked rice and miso soup.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that this word refers to the grains of rice more than something that's a meal. If you're eating rice at a meal you'd call it ごはん. This is like when you're talking about the rice in the fields or rice grains or something like that.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: "Everyone, we have rice! Come (こめ) and get it!"

ex_1_jp: この文と大体同じいみの文があります。
ex_1_en: There is a sentence that means basically the same thing as this sentence.
ex_2_jp: 今回のしけんは、ぜん回とほぼ同じ内ようでした。
ex_2_en: This exam was almost the same questions as last time.
ex_3_jp: あの店と同じ味のラーメンがどうしても作りたいんだ。
ex_3_en: I want to make ramen that tastes the same as that shop’s no matter what.
meaning_story: This word is the kanji same with hiragana attached. Since the hiragana doesn't suggest it's a verb or adjective, you can assume it's a noun. What's the noun version of "same"? It's also same.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you think of the word "same" think same owner (おな). You're looking at a restaurant that has a sign that says "new owners!" But when you walk in you see it's the same terrible owner you remember from before. What a liar.

ex_1_jp: それらは、同日にはつばいされました。
ex_1_en: Those were launched on the same day.
ex_2_jp: すきなバンドのライブがちがうはこで同日にかぶっていて、どれにいこうかちょうぜつまよっています。
ex_2_en: The bands I like have concerts in different music clubs on the same day and I'm really not sure which one I should go to.
ex_3_jp: 父の死と同日に、アポロ11号が月面着陸に成功した。
ex_3_en: On the same day of my father’s death, Apollo 11 succeeded in landing on the moon’s surface.
meaning_story: You have the same day, which comes out to same day.
reading_story: The readings follow the regular jukugo rules (on'yomi reading) but take note that 日 is read as じつ, the alternate on'yomi reading. You've been seeing this reading a lot lately, so hopefully you know it by now and it's easy!
pitch_accent: ドꜜージツ *** ドージツ

ex_1_jp: これは、入学のおいわいのプレゼントです。
ex_1_en: Here is a congratulatory present for getting into school.
ex_2_jp: 父が入学金をはらうのをわすれてしまったんです。
ex_2_en: My father forgot to pay the enrollment fee.
ex_3_jp: トムはオックスフォード大学に入学できたと思っていたんだけど、どうもその合格証明書はトムの両親がエイプリルフールのジョークとして作ったものだったようだぜ。
ex_3_en: Tom thought he got into Oxford, but apparently the acceptance letter was an April Fool’s joke his parents made.
meaning_story: You enter into a study (place). When does this happen? It happens when you get accepted into a school, aka school admission.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: かれは、兄と同じ学年です。
ex_1_en: He is in the same year as my older brother.
ex_2_jp: トーフグには、小学こうてい学年のファンもいれば、１００才をこえるファンもいる。
ex_2_en: Tofugu not only has fans in early elementary school, but also elderly fans over 100 years old.
ex_3_jp: あの給食の後、三年生の学年の三分の一が吐いた。
ex_3_en: One third of the third grade threw up after school lunch.
meaning_story: Your study year is kind of like the years you've studied. Where do you study? School. What is a year of study in a school? It's your school grade.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あの売り手にだまされました。
ex_1_en: I was cheated by that vendor.
ex_2_jp: 空ぜんの売り手市場ですね。
ex_2_en: This's the hottest seller's market ever.
ex_3_jp: その家の売り手は、「近所の人が本当にひどいやつなので、家を手放すことにしたんだ」と、私に話してくれました。
ex_3_en: The guy selling that house told me he’s selling it because his neighbor is a real jerk.
meaning_story: The hand that sells the items is connected to a person who is known as the seller or the vendor.
reading_story: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji, though they are both kun'yomi. One hint that this is a kun'yomi reading word is the hiragana in the center. It's like two separate words combined together, and when a word is a single kanji / a single kanji with hiragana attached it is usually kun'yomi. This is like two of those, combined.

ex_1_jp: わたしには、兄弟が二人います。
ex_1_en: I have two siblings.
ex_2_jp: マリオとルイージって兄弟だったの！？
ex_2_en: Were Mario and Luigi brothers!?
ex_3_jp: あの兄弟は好きだけど、あいつらのもっているぬいぐるみは好きじゃない。
ex_3_en: I like those brothers, but I hate their stuffed animals.
meaning_story: You have an older brother and a younger brother. Wow! Both are here. Of course, in old China sisters don't even get included into this calculation, so when you think of your older and younger brothers, just think of it as your siblings (sorry girls!).
reading_story: The readings for these are on'yomi which is fine for you and 弟 but not so good with 兄 (with which you learned the kun'yomi). To remember the reading of 兄, think about how 今日 (きょう/today) you're going to spend time with your siblings because you're a good brother / sister.
pitch_accent: キョꜜーダイ *** ケイテイ

ex_1_jp: 空にきれいなにじがかかっている。
ex_1_en: There is a beautiful rainbow in the sky.
ex_2_jp: 女心とあきの空といいますが、男心だってかわりやすいんですよ。
ex_2_en: They say that women's minds and the autumn skies change quickly, but men's minds change quickly too.
ex_3_jp: 今夜映画E.T.の有名なシーンがちゃんと見れるくらい、空が晴れ渡っているといいんだが。
ex_3_en: I hope the sky tonight is clear enough for us to see the famous scene from the movie E.T.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: In the sky, you are the ruler. You are known as "The soarer!" (そら). Imagine your theme song and make sure it includes "soarer of the sky" or something awesome like that.
pitch_accent: ウロ *** カラꜜ *** クꜜー *** クー *** ソꜜラ

ex_1_jp: あの水色のバッグがほしいんですが。
ex_1_en: I want that light blue bag.
ex_2_jp: トーフグのTシャツは、さわやかな水色です。
ex_2_en: Tofugu T-shirt is breezy sky blue.
ex_3_jp: どうして今日の空は水色なんだろう？
ex_3_en: Why is the sky light blue today?
meaning_story: You'd think that water color would have something to do with watercolors, but it doesn't. No, it has to do with the color of water, which, ironically, is sky blue in English. Light blue works as well.
reading_story: The reading for this word consists of the kun'yomi reading of 水 and the kun'yomi reading of 色. For 水 you'll know this reading via your vocab studies. For 色 it just so happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: そのざっしは、売り切れです。
ex_1_en: That magazine is sold out.
ex_2_jp: トーフグのこうえん会のチケットが売り切れとしってなきそうになった。
ex_2_en: I almost cried when I learned that tickets for the Tofugu lecture were sold out.
ex_3_jp: ジョーンズさん、本当に申し訳ないのですが、動物クッキーは売り切れてしまいました。
ex_3_en: I’m terribly sorry Mr. Jones, but we are all sold out of animal crackers.
meaning_story: When the selling is cut, that means something is sold out. You'll see this word a lot in stores (or, hopefully you won't...) in Japan. Look out for it if you're able!
reading_story: The readings for the kanji in this word are the kun'yomi readings. 売 is the same reading you learned with the kanji 売. 切's kun'yomi reading is a reading you should have learned through vocab practice in earlier levels.

ex_1_jp: このゲームは、近日はつばいよていです。
ex_1_en: This game is scheduled to be released soon.
ex_2_jp: 田中さんがたのしみにしていたえいがが、ついに近日こうかいします。
ex_2_en: The movie Mr. Tanaka was looking forward to will finally be released in a few days.
ex_3_jp: 近日中にお会いして、ネットで見たことを一緒に語り合いましょう。
ex_3_en: Let’s hang out in person soon and talk about things we saw online.
meaning_story: The near day is a day coming very soon. It's a day coming in a few days.
reading_story: The readings are both on'yomi readings that you've learned. Just take note that 日 is the alternate reading じつ.
pitch_accent: キꜜンジツ *** キンジツ

ex_1_jp: 二かいから、大きな音がしました。
ex_1_en: There was a loud noise upstairs.
ex_2_jp: となりのいえから、すごく上手なリコーダーの音が聞こえてきます。
ex_2_en: I can hear the sounds of a very good recorder coming from next door.
ex_3_jp: 金魚が泣いている音を聞いたことはある？
ex_3_en: Have you ever heard the sound that a goldfish makes when it cries?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Did you hear that sound? It's barely audible (おと. Go ahead and say the word "audible" with the pronunciation of おと to help you to remember this.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: じゃがいもを、四角に切ってください。
ex_1_en: Cut the potatoes into squares, please.
ex_2_jp: ツイッターのアイコンの形を今の丸から四角にもどしてほしい。
ex_2_en: I want the twitter icon to go back from the current round shape to the square one.
ex_3_jp: どうしてほとんどの窓は真四角か長四角なんだろう。イタリア型の窓とかも作ったらいいのに。
ex_3_en: Why are most windows either squares or rectangles? They should start making windows shaped like Italy.
meaning_story: What shape has four angles? The most common one is a square.
reading_story: The reading for 四 is the on'yomi reading (which you didn't learn with the kanji), which is し. Remember this by thinking about a square shape, then look at that square shape, which is a square shaped Charlie Sheen. The square-Sheen looks up and asks you if it's a square. The reading for 角 is what you'd expect, the on'yomi reading.

ex_1_jp: 学生は今日、うちでどこをべんきょうしますか。
ex_1_en: Which parts will students study at home today?
ex_2_jp: 学生わり引ってありますか？
ex_2_en: Do you have student discount?
ex_3_jp: 「我々はみな人生の学生だ。」と言いながら、父はおならをした。
ex_3_en: "We are all students of life," my dad said while farting.
meaning_story: Who has a study life? Only one person that I know of, and that's a student.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日光をあびすぎるのは体によくない。
ex_1_en: Bathing too long in the sunlight isn’t good for your body.
ex_2_jp: できるだけちょくしゃ日光にさらされないよう気をつけています。
ex_2_en: I'm being as careful as possible to not get exposed to direct sunlight.
ex_3_jp: 何故か日光を見るといつもくしゃみが出ます。
ex_3_en: Seeing sunlight always makes me sneeze for some reason.
meaning_story: You have sun light. What kind of light would this be? Obviously sunlight.
reading_story: The reading for this one uses the on'yomi readings, though にち gets shortened to にっ, so take note of that. Otherwise, you should be able to read this one!

ex_1_jp: 金玉がヒリヒリするんです。
ex_1_en: My testicles sting.
ex_2_jp: おれの金玉はぜったい他の男のばいはたらいてるとおもうぜ。
ex_2_en: I'm sure that my testicles are working twice as hard as the other mens'.
ex_3_jp: もし婆ちゃんに金玉があれば、俺は爺ちゃんって呼ぶよ。
ex_3_en: If grandma had testicles, I would call her grandpa.
meaning_story: You have some gold balls. What balls are more important than any other balls, at least for a dude? That would be his testicles. This word came about because tanuki scrotum skin would be used to pound down gold into sheets. Tanuki scrotums are apparently very good at this because they are very strong and very flexible. Strange, yeah? That's why Gold balls = testicles.
reading_story: This word uses the on'yomi for 金 and the kun'yomi for 玉. If you know the readings of your kanji, you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今回は、やめておきます。
ex_1_en: I decided to pass this time.
ex_2_jp: 今回のマラソン大会では一いでした。
ex_2_en: I was the first place winner at this marathon.
ex_3_jp: 前回お前が運転した時は、岸にぶつかりそうになったじゃん。だから今回は俺が釣り船を運転するよ。
ex_3_en: I’ll drive the fishing boat this time because last time you drove it, we almost ran into the shore.
meaning_story: The now times is this time.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: いつも自分の考えを上手くせつめいできません。
ex_1_en: I can never explain my own thoughts well.
ex_2_jp: あなたの考えはあますぎます。
ex_2_en: Your thoughts are too optimistic.
ex_3_jp: あなたの考えを百円で買わせてもらえませんか？
ex_3_en: Can I buy your thoughts for 100 yen?
meaning_story: This is a noun version of think. What is "a think"? It's a thought.
reading_story: This vocab uses the same reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 何千回も、れんしゅうしました。
ex_1_en: I’ve practiced thousands of times.
ex_2_jp: とつぜん、何千ものベーコンがそらからふってきた。
ex_2_en: Suddently, thousands of bacon strips dropped from sky.
ex_3_jp: 巨人攻撃の被害者は、何千人にものぼった。
ex_3_en: Victims of the titan attack numbered in the thousands.
meaning_story: What thousand? Could be five thousand, two thousand, or ten thousand, since you're asking. Let's generalize. How do you say all of those amounts at the same time? You say "thousands."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just take note that 千 is read as ぜん and not せん because of rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 日本に一回行ったことがあります。
ex_1_en: I’ve been to Japan once.
ex_2_jp: アメリカから日本までおよいでわたるけいかくを立てたが、もう八回ほどと中で中止になっている。
ex_2_en: I've made plans to swim from America to Japan, but they've been put on hold eight different times now.
ex_3_jp: 何回砂を食べたか自分でも数えきれないよ。
ex_3_en: I can’t count the number of times I’ve eaten sand.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the on'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji. This is probably because this word gets attached to numbers usually, which makes it behave more like jukugo. So, you can have １回, ２回, ３回, or even １００回 if you're into that sort of thing.

translation: to be on target, to guess correctly
ex_1_jp: 人に石が当たったらどうするんだ。
ex_1_en: If a person was hit with a stone, what would you do?
ex_2_jp: まんいんでん車で、手がとなりの女のしりに当たってしまい、ちかんにまちがえられたらどうしようと不あんでいっぱいになった。
ex_2_en: In a packed train, my hand accidentally touched the butt of the woman next to me and I was so worried I'd mistaken for a molester.
ex_3_jp: 自分の予想が当たって、嬉しいです。
ex_3_en: I'm glad my guess was right.
meaning_story: You know this is a verb because it ends with an う sound. The kanji for this word is right or success, so what's the verb form of that? Turns out it's a ton of things. Like, a crazy amount of things. I tried narrowing it down for you, but it will still be a lot. This word tends to be about getting an answer right. As in, to guess correctly or to be on target. It means many other things too, but I think these are the two meanings you'll see the most, so focus on those.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the あ portion. You need to guess the correct answer. What do you choose? You guess A (あ) and hope it's right. Turns out you were right on the money. Well done! Imagine yourself winning a fabulous prize.

ex_1_jp: よていどおり、日よう日にうんどう会を行います。
ex_1_en: We will perform in the athletic meet on Sunday as planned.
ex_2_jp: 来しゅうの月よう日は、学生が、えきでうちわのむりょうはいふを行うよていです。
ex_2_en: The students are scheduled to hand out free uchiwa fans at the station next Monday.
ex_3_jp: 東京病院に豚の心臓を運ぶ仕事を任されましたが、もし私がその仕事を行わなければ、誰かが料理を完成させることができなくなってしまいます。
ex_3_en: I’ve been entrusted with the job of delivering a pig heart to Tokyo hospital and if I don’t carry out my task someone won’t be able to finish the meal they’re cooking.
meaning_story: The meaning of this word is pretty strange, having very little to do with the kanji meaning you learned. This word means to carry out a task. Maybe you can think of it like someone is saying "You (う) go do that task!" to get yourself to carry out a task. Whatever you do, just know this is a weird exception word, so you may have to do some extra work to remember it.
reading_story: The reading is also a strange exception. You have to remember the おこな portion. Think of it this way: You have to carry out a task but you have to wait for the go-ahead to start. Then, your boss tells you "Okay now! (おこな) and you can begin. The reading mnemonic isn't totally close to the actual reading, though, so be sure to make note in your mind that this mnemonic is only supposed to get you part of the way there. You'll have to get yourself the rest of the way for this one.

ex_1_jp: アメリカから来ました。
ex_1_en: I came from America.
ex_2_jp: 来る、きっと来る。
ex_2_en: She will come. I'm sure she will come.
ex_3_jp: 二度と戻って来るんじゃねーぞ！
ex_3_en: Never come back!
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means come so you know this word means to come.
reading_story: The reading for this word is pretty strange. It changes depending on the type of verb form you use (it's a pesky exception verb). To remember the reading of this word, here's a mnemonic: "I want you to come to the cool (く) side, Luke," says Darth Vader. "What?" replies Luke. Just replace this line into the famous line from Star Wars. Say it out loud. Do the Vader voice. It'll help you to remember.

ex_1_jp: ごぜん中は、かいものに行ったり、そうじをしたりします。
ex_1_en: In the morning I do things like shop and clean.
ex_2_jp: ようじができて、行けなくなってしまいました。
ex_2_en: Something came up, so I'm not be able to make it.
ex_3_jp: タコベルが無いので火星には行きたくない。
ex_3_en: I wouldn’t want to go to Mars because they don’t have Taco Bell there.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means go so the verb form of this is to go.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the い portion. To remember い we use the word "eagle." You want to go somewhere (anywhere!) but you can't. An eagle (い) blocks your path. You try to go forward and it opens its wings and bites at you. You try to go back and it jumps at you. There's nowhere for you to go with this eagle standing there.

ex_1_jp: あごひげがよく生えます。
ex_1_en: My beard grows quickly.
ex_2_jp: 「くさ生える」とは、おも白いとおもったときにつかう日本のネットスラングで、「w」をくさに見立てたことからつかわれはじめました。
ex_2_en: "Weeds grow," is Japanese Internet slang used when you think something's funny. It started because "w" (lol) looks like weeds.
ex_3_jp: こんなところにキノコが生えるのかね。
ex_3_en: Do mushrooms grow in places like this?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. Remember how 生きる means "to live?" Well this is what happens right after it starts to live. It begins to grow!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When something starts to grow it also learns to laugh. Imagine a little plant growing out of the ground laughing. "Ha (は) ha ha ha!" it says, as it sprouts out of the ground.

ex_1_jp: わたしは、どく学で日本ごを学んでいます。
ex_1_en: I’m learning Japanese through self-study.
ex_2_jp: 日本ごをべんきょうするのはやめて、トーフグといっしょにへんがおとへんなポーズを学びませんか？
ex_2_en: Why don't you learn how to make weird faces and poses with Tofugu, instead of studying Japanese?
ex_3_jp: 学ぶことは大切だけど、おそらくもっと大切なのはどのように学ぶかということじゃないだろうか。
ex_3_en: Learning is important, but perhaps what’s more important is how you learn.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means study or learning. When you do these things, what ends up happening? You learn. That's why this word means to learn. There is another word that means "to learn" that is going to be more common, which is 習う. You'll learn this one later on. 学ぶ sounds a little more serious compared to 習う, so keep that in mind when you use it.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the まな part to learn this word's reading. Think about a class you're taking. It's a manners class, and you're there to learn manners (まな). Imagine this study of manners and imagine yourself practicing it.

ex_1_jp: 今日は、ばんごはんにやきそばを作ります。
ex_1_en: Today, I will make yakisoba for supper.
ex_2_jp: フェイスブックのアカウントをふくすう作る方ほうをおしえてください。
ex_2_en: Can you teach me how to create multiple Facebook accounts, please?
ex_3_jp: テスラ・コイルをどうやって作るのかを知っていたら良かったんだけどな。
ex_3_en: I wish I knew how to make a Tesla coil.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means make. The verb form of that is to make.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the つく portion. In order to do that let's think about something that you're going to make. Imagine something really awesome. You complete it and look at your masterpiece. It's amazing. You realize right then and there that it's too cool (つく) for the general public to see. You proceed to smash it. It's way too cool.

ex_1_jp: 日よう日に会う。
ex_1_en: We’re meeting on Sunday.
ex_2_jp: ポートランドくうこうでばったりコウイチに会いました。
ex_2_en: I ran into Koichi at the Portland airport.
ex_3_jp: 明日の午後、大好きな俳優に会えるんです！
ex_3_en: I get to meet my favorite actor tomorrow afternoon.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means meet so the verb form of that is to meet or to encounter.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the あ part but let's include the う as well for this one. Who do you want to meet more than anyone? Think about it. Then, imagine meeting them. The first thing they do is grab your arm and pinch it. You yell out "OW!" (あう) and they laugh and run away.

ex_1_jp: トランプをよく交ぜてください。
ex_1_en: Mix the cards up well, please.
ex_2_jp: どうしてたくさんの男たちの中に女を一人交ぜたんだ？
ex_2_en: Why did you mix one woman into group with a bunch of men?
ex_3_jp: 豆腐と河豚を交ぜるのは危険です。
ex_3_en: It’s dangerous to mix tofu and puffer fish.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mix so the verb version is to mix. There are similar words to this one, including 交じる which means "to be mixed" and 交わる which means "to intersect." This one is when you're doing the mixing. Like 交じる, the connotation is that the things being mixed are distinguishable from each other, like two types of fish, or books being mixed together. They don't become homogenous like paint or something would.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ま portion. Who would mix things for you (like cakes and other goodies) growing up? That would be your Ma (ま).

ex_1_jp: 今日は、おきゃくさんと１８ホールを回りました。
ex_1_en: I went around 18 holes with a customer today.
ex_2_jp: 百円玉はまだつくえの上で回っています。
ex_2_en: That 100 yen coin is still spinning on the desk.
ex_3_jp: 惑星が太陽の周りを回るように、その子猫たちが親猫の周りを回っている。
ex_3_en: Those kittens revolve around their mother like the planets revolve around the sun.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means times. There's no good verb for the word "times" but you can probably imagine something doing something over and over and over again. What word would represent this? It would be to revolve.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have a bag of walnuts that you're bringing to a friend's house but you trip and drop them all on the ground. You shout, "Mah Walnuts! (まわ)" as they start to revolve around you on the ground. Picture your walnuts going around you, getting all dirty.

ex_1_jp: えいがにおくれそうだったので、走りました。
ex_1_en: I ran because I was almost late for the movie.
ex_2_jp: コウイチはカメよりもはやく走れる。
ex_2_en: Koichi can run faster than a turtle.
ex_3_jp: 人生走り続けるより、侍に首をはねられる方がずっとましだという結論に達しました。
ex_3_en: I’ve come to the conclusion that having my head cut off by a samurai would be much worse than running for my life.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means run so now you know the verb version of that is to run.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the はし portion. Think of yourself running. It's nice. As you run, though, you notice the ground changing into something weird and mushy. Everything is turning into hash (はし) browns. You start to get sucked in, and soon you can't run anymore. Smell the hash browns and taste them too. What a terrible run this was.

ex_1_jp: ゆっくり言ってください。
ex_1_en: Please say it slowly.
ex_2_jp: いつもありがとうってえいごで何て言うの？
ex_2_en: How can I say, "Thank you always," in English?
ex_3_jp: ジェイクに、足を踏んでごめんって言うつもりなの？
ex_3_en: Are you going to say sorry to Jake for stepping on his foot?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means say, so the verb version of that is to say.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To remember the reading "い" we use the word "eagle." You're trying to say something, but every time you try to say anything an eagle swoops down and pecks at your face then flies away. Just imagine yourself saying tiny bits of words, then an eagle crashing down on your face. Then, you wait in silence. Nothing happens. You try to say something again, and the eagle swoops down on you again.

ex_1_jp: ここに、日本ごのじしょは売っていますか。
ex_1_en: Are Japanese dictionaries sold here?
ex_2_jp: この村では、人々は大麦を売って生けいを立てています。
ex_2_en: In this village, people make a living by selling barley.
ex_3_jp: 請求書の支払いをするために車を売る必要があるが、そうすれば今度は仕事にいけなくなってしまう。
ex_3_en: I need to sell my car to pay the bills, but if I do that I won’t be able to get to work.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sell, so the verb version of that is to sell.
reading_story: The reading you learned with this kanji is the same reading that's used here, so you should be able to read it.

ex_1_jp: 少し考えさせてください。
ex_1_en: Please let me think about it a little.
ex_2_jp: 考えるな！かんじろ！
ex_2_en: Don't think. Just feel!
ex_3_jp: 私の娘は、もしタイタニック号が沈まなければ、みんなその代わりにディズニーランドに行くことができて、もっといい映画になったのにと考える。
ex_3_en: My daughter thinks that the movie Titanic would have been better if the ship never sank and everyone went to Disney World instead.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means think, so the verb version is to think about or to consider. Note that this isn't the "to think" that is like "I think that he is a power ranger." No, this is more like the actual thinking action. That's why this word is "to think about" or "to consider" rather than plain old "to think" which is 思う.
reading_story: This word uses the same reading you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read it.
pitch_accent: カンカ°エꜜル *** カンカ°ꜜエル

ex_1_jp: しん大さか行きのしんかんせんのきっぷをください。
ex_1_en: One shinkansen ticket for Shin-Osaka, please.
ex_2_jp: 行きもかえりもあるくつもりです。
ex_2_en: I'm thinking of walking both ways.
ex_3_jp: この電車は、Tofuguオフィス行きです。
ex_3_en: This train is bound for Tofugu Office Station.
meaning_story: This is a weird word. Call it exceptional. You'll see this at train stations, especially. You know the kanji means go. So, something is going somewhere. Now just use the き to help you to remember that this word means train direction (aka it tells you which direction a train is going), because this word is the key (き) to you knowing what direction you're going in so you don't get lost. You could also remember this word as "bound for" aka "Bound for Tokyo Station."
reading_story: The reading is also an exception. It can be いき, but instead we're focusing on the ゆき reading. You have to remember the ゆ portion, so think of it this way: Just think about the train direction that you (ゆ) need to go in. It's all about you. Not your friends or anyone else. You. You are the most important person at this train station.

ex_1_jp: あなたの車の走行マイルをおしえてください。
ex_1_en: Can you tell me the mileage of your car?
ex_2_jp: バスの走行中にせきを立つのはきけんです。
ex_2_en: Leaving your seat while the bus is moving is dangerous.
ex_3_jp: その電車は、ストライキが終わり次第、ホグワーツ魔法魔術学校への走行を再開する。
ex_3_en: The train will start running to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry again as soon as the strike is over.
meaning_story: When you run go you're going somewhere and fast. If you go somewhere fast, one could say you are traveling.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 三角のクラッカーをかってきてください。
ex_1_en: Please go buy triangle crackers.
ex_2_jp: 今、三角かんけいになっちゃってるんだよね。
ex_2_en: I am stuck in a love triangle now.
ex_3_jp: カナダ人はピカソにかなり刺激を受けたに違いない。四角い箱に、丸いピザ、三角のピザスライスがあちこちにある。
ex_3_en: Canadians must have been inspired by Picasso quite a bit. Square boxes, round pizzas, and triangle pizza slices are everywhere.
meaning_story: When you have something with three angles, what shape is that? It's a triangle.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: わたしの大学には、中ごく人がたくさんいます。
ex_1_en: There are a lot of Chinese people in my university.
ex_2_jp: アメリカの大学と日本の大学の主なちがいはなんですか。
ex_2_en: What are the main differences between American universities and Japanese universities?
ex_3_jp: 大学で解剖学を勉強したが、教科書は一度も開かなかった。
ex_3_en: I studied anatomy in college, but I never opened a textbook.
meaning_story: What's the big study? If I had to choose, I'd probably say this is college or university.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今まで何をしていたんですか。
ex_1_en: What have you been doing until now?
ex_2_jp: コウイチが今まで付きあったかの女は百万人に上るが、ようやく一人の女の人におちつきつつある。
ex_2_en: Koichi had a million girlfriends up until now, but he is finally about to settle down with one woman.
ex_3_jp: お前が今までの中では一番の彼女だよ。
ex_3_en: You are the best girlfriend I’ve had so far.
meaning_story: You know that 今 means now. What you probably don't know is that まで means "until." So, this word means until now.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the kun'yomi reading which you learned previously when you learned the vocab word 今. You can tell this is a kun'yomi reading because it has hiragana attached. So if you know that, you should be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: あそこの谷で、くまを見ました。
ex_1_en: I saw a bear in that valley.
ex_2_jp: はこねには大わく谷というむかし「じごく谷」といわれた谷があって、かんこうの名しょになっています。
ex_2_en: In Hakone, there is a valley called Owakudani, which used to be called "Death Valley" a long time ago, and it is a famous tourist spot nowadays.
ex_3_jp: 死の谷で自殺した男は、ダース・ベイダーのコスプレをしていた。
ex_3_en: The guy who committed suicide in Death Valley was dressed as Darth Vader.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji, too, so don't feel like you're stuck in a valley of despair or anything. Rejoice!
