part_of_speech: ADVERB, NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 色々な小せつをよみました。
ex_1_en: I’ve read various types of novels.
ex_2_jp: 色々考えたけっか、日よう日にたこやきパーティーをすることにしました。
ex_2_en: After thinking about various things, I've decided to hold a takoyaki party on Sunday.
ex_3_jp: 私のベッドの下に住んでいるトロールには色々な種類がいます。
ex_3_en: There are various species of trolls that live under my bed.
meaning_story: This is the kanji color repeated twice (the 々 character just repeats the kanji before it). When you have colors and colors and colors, you have a lot of variety. That's why this word means various.
reading_story: The reading for this kanji is just the kun'yomi reading twice. Since you've learned the kun'yomi reading already, you should be able to read this word as well. Nothing tricky about it.

ex_1_jp: はし本さんの声は、とてもひくいです。
ex_1_en: Hashimoto’s voice is very low.
ex_2_jp: 友人の声とその子どもの声がそっくりだ。
ex_2_en: My friend's voice and her kid's voice are very alike.
ex_3_jp: あんたの声、ひどいな！
ex_3_en: Your voice sounds awful!
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji making it easy to remember!

ex_1_jp: 考え方は、人それぞれです。
ex_1_en: People have their own way of thinking.
ex_2_jp: そもそも、父と母は考え方がまったくちがうんです。
ex_2_en: My mom and dad's thought processes are totally different to begin with.
ex_3_jp: 自分のことを悪い人間だと思うのは、もし自分が実際に悪女だったとしても、良くない考え方です。
ex_3_en: Even if you really are an awful woman, thinking badly about yourself still isn’t a healthy way to think.
meaning_story: The think way is really the way someone thinks. That's why this word means way of thinking.
reading_story: The reading for 考え is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Then, just add the vocab word / kanji 方 to the end (another reading you know) and you have yourself the reading for this word.

ex_1_jp: びょういんの西のたてものがわたしのアパートです。
ex_1_en: The building on the west side of the hospital is my apartment.
ex_2_jp: ダリンは、西にむかっています。
ex_2_en: Darin is heading west.
ex_3_jp: その頃、西ポートランドでは、鰐蟹がその道を渡っていた。
ex_3_en: Meanwhile in West Portland, the Crabigator was crossing the road.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You go off to the west. It's the Wild West, even. There aren't many people out here, making it easy to find a niche (にし) for your snake oil business.

ex_1_jp: 何と言いますか。
ex_1_en: What would you say?
ex_2_jp: あなた、何さまのつもりですか。
ex_2_en: Who do you think you are?
ex_3_jp: 僕達がタイのホテルで飲んだ飲み物の名前は何？
ex_3_en: What was the name of that drink we had at the hotel in Thailand?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. What? Yeah, that's what.

ex_1_jp: 学こうは何月にはじまりますか。
ex_1_en: What month do you start school?
ex_2_jp: それって何年何月何日何びょう、ちきゅうが何回回ったとき？
ex_2_en: When did it happen? What year, what month, what day, what time, what second was it? How many times did Earth spin when it happened?
ex_3_jp: 田中さんは何月生まれですか？
ex_3_en: What month were you born in, Ms. Tanaka?
meaning_story: You have what month - as in: what month is it? It's １０月, you fool. Get a job, hippy.
reading_story: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. 何 is technically the kun'yomi, but it feels pretty on'yomi-ish if you ask me. The 月 uses the on'yomi, though.

ex_1_jp: 何年生まれですか。
ex_1_en: What year were you born?
ex_2_jp: おたくのお子さんは、何年に大学に入りましたか。
ex_2_en: What year did your kid enter college?
ex_3_jp: アメリカの南北戦争は、何年間続いたんですか？
ex_3_en: How many years did the American Civil War last?
meaning_story: You have the kanji what and year, as in: "what year is it?" This also means how many years too, depending on the context. As in: "How many years did you play soccer?"
reading_story: The readings are both the readings you learned with the separate kanji, meaning you should know them. How many years have you been studying kanji now? You should be able to read this one.

ex_1_jp: わたしは、麦アレルギーがあります。
ex_1_en: I have a wheat allergy.
ex_2_jp: 大麦と小麦のちがいは何ですか。
ex_2_en: What's the difference between barley and wheat?
ex_3_jp: 「スクワット、スクワット、スクワット、麦とスクワット♪」屈伸をしながら彼は歌った。
ex_3_en: "Squats, squats, squats, squats, oats and squats," he sang while squatting.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji that uses the kun'yomi reading which is the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: このゆびわは、一生、大切にします。
ex_1_en: I’ve taken care of this ring my whole life.
ex_2_jp: わたしの父は、しぬまで一生どくしんでした。
ex_2_en: He remained single all his life.
ex_3_jp: 一生かけて償います。
ex_3_en: I'll make up for it with my life.
meaning_story: One life is all you get. It's your whole life.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 生 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who has been in charge of you your whole life? The shogun (しょう). He owns everyone and that's how it will stay for your entire life.

ex_1_jp: つぎの日よう日に、社内のバスケットボール大会があります。
ex_1_en: Next Sunday there will be an in house basketball tournament.
ex_2_jp: 花さんは、社内けっこんをしてたいしょくしました。
ex_2_en: Hana left the company after she married a man who worked in the same company.
ex_3_jp: 最近、社内で変なことが流行っている。従業員が、会社の冷蔵庫の中の食べ物に名前をつけるのだ。今日は、俺は、「鈴木」と名付けられたオニギリを食べた。
ex_3_en: Recently, there is a strange new trend in our company. Workers put names on food in the company fridge. Today, I had a rice ball named "Suzuki."
meaning_story: When you're doing something inside the company you're doing it within the company or in-house. For example, we do our kanji in-house. It gives it that artisan flavor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: みどり色の毛糸はありますか。
ex_1_en: Do you have green wool?
ex_2_jp: 今日はとてもさむいので、友人があんでくれた毛糸のセーターをきています。
ex_2_en: It is very cold today, so I am wearing the wool sweater that my friend knitted for me.
ex_3_jp: 「毛糸の玉をほどいてください。お願いします。お願いします。」と、その幽霊は何度も私に頼んできた。
ex_3_en: "Unwind a ball of yarn please. Please. Please!" the ghost asked me over and over again.
meaning_story: When you have fur string (aka string made of fur) what do you think of? Hopefully wool yarn.
reading_story: The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. With 毛 you should have learned this reading via the vocab word in the previous level. With 糸 it's actually the main reading for the kanji, so you should already know it.

ex_1_jp: わたしの弟は、テレビを見ない。
ex_1_en: My little brother doesn’t watch TV.
ex_2_jp: その青いかみの青年はぼくの弟です。
ex_2_en: That young man with blue hair is my younger brother.
ex_3_jp: 弟がビリヤードのボールを頭に投げつけてきたので、昨夜僕は病院に行くはめになった。
ex_3_en: I ended up going to the hospital last night because my younger brother threw a pool ball at my head.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look at your younger brother. He's a scheming one. He's smiling up at you. Why? Because he's lit a firecracker on your foot. It explodes, sending your toe flying. You yell "OH. Toe? TOE!" (おとうと) as you realize what's going on.

ex_1_jp: とてもさわやかな青年でした。
ex_1_en: He was a very invigorating young man.
ex_2_jp: その青年は、ぼう走ぞくの一いんです。
ex_2_en: That young man is a member of a motorcycle gang.
ex_3_jp: どうして日本の青年は、下心があっていやらしい笑みを浮かべていることを隠そうとするのか？
ex_3_en: Why do youths in Japan try to hide their nasty smiles when they’re up to something?
meaning_story: Someone who is blue in their years. This makes sense when you know that Asian babies are often born with blue butts, which you can associate with being young. So, Blue = Young (not only in this word, but in others as well). Someone who is blue in their years is a youth.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 後でいっしょにお茶でもしませんか。
ex_1_en: Why don’t we have some tea together later?
ex_2_jp: 後で、「言わんこっちゃない」って言わせないでよ。
ex_2_en: Don't make me say, "I told you so," later.
ex_3_jp: その映画を見終わった後で、もう一度それを見るために違う映画館へ向かった。
ex_3_en: After the movie, we headed across town to watch it again in another theater.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: After. Everything happens after. It's a cause and effect chain. One thing happens, and then another thing happens after. This is life. This is the universe. Everything is after. It's an automatic (あと) cycle that just keeps going and going and going. You can differentiate this one from 後ろ because it has a で on the end. "Day" (で) follows night which follows "day" again, automatically.

ex_1_jp: 全て上手く行きました。
ex_1_en: It all went smoothly.
ex_2_jp: 申しわけございませんが、げんざい全てのおせきがうまっているじょうきょうでして...。
ex_2_en: I am sorry, but all the seats are fully occupied at the moment, so...
ex_3_jp: 僕が先だよ。ウィキペディアが僕の宿題を全て真似したんだ。
ex_3_en: I was the first to do it. Wikipedia copied my entire homework assignment afterwards.
meaning_story: This has a little hiragana attached to it but nothing that suggests it's a verb or a noun. That means you can assume this word has the same meaning as its parent kanji.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the すべ part, which is an admittedly difficult sound to remember. You have to think of the concept of all or entire. When you think of that concept, think of someone's entire fortune. All their money. You want to get all of Beth's money, so you sue beth (すべ) for all she has.

pronunciation: ぜんにほん, ぜんにっぽん
ex_1_jp: これは、全日本バレーボール大会のしあいの写しんです。
ex_1_en: This is a picture of a Japanese National Volleyball tournament match.
ex_2_jp: コウイチは、けん道の全日本せん手けんのしあいを見るために、日本に行っています。
ex_2_en: Koichi is in Japan to watch the All Japan Kendo Championships.
ex_3_jp: 全日本が生クリームに包まれている。
ex_3_en: All of Japan is covered in whipped cream.
meaning_story: You know 日本 means "Japan." So, now you have the kanji for all added to it, making this word All Japan (as in "All Japan Railways" or something like that).
reading_story: You know the reading of 日本. Now just add the on'yomi reading of 全 and you should be able to read this word.
pitch_accent: ゼンニッポꜜン *** ゼꜜン・ニッポꜜン

ex_1_jp: このデパートは、午前十じにひらきます。
ex_1_en: This department store opens at 10:00 am.
ex_2_jp: わたしのむす子は、まだ午前中にあさねをするひつようがあります。
ex_2_en: My son still needs to take a nap in the morning.
ex_3_jp: 今日は午前9時にテレパシーで投稿する予定にしているので、もし君がその時何か面白いことを考えたら、それは私の仕業だから。
ex_3_en: I’ll be posting telepathically at 9AM today, so if you think of something funny, that was me.
meaning_story: You have something that's before (or in front of) noon. What is before noon? That is AM.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 米国の大とうりょうの名まえを知っていますか。
ex_1_en: Do you know the name of the president of the United States?
ex_2_jp: 米国には元々何もきたいなんてしてなかったよ。
ex_2_en: I never expected anything from America anyways.
ex_3_jp: 多くの人は、単にマクドナルドのスーパーサイズコンボのために米国に移住する。
ex_3_en: Many people immigrate to America solely for the super-size combos at McDonald’s.
meaning_story: America is the country of rice. I guess this is from all those rolling plains and such we have. Another way to say America in Japanese is アメリカ, but this is another more formal (and older) way. "Rice Country" aka America.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 足首をひねってしまいました。
ex_1_en: I twisted my ankle.
ex_2_jp: 右の足首がすごくいたいんです！
ex_2_en: My right ankle hurts a lot.
ex_3_jp: 宙に舞う羽から逃げる途中で、足首を捻挫した。
ex_3_en: I sprained my ankle while running away from a feather floating in the air.
meaning_story: What is the neck of your leg? Think about it. It's your ankle.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know the kun'yomi reading of 足 from previous vocab and you know the kun'yomi reading of 首 from learning that kanji. So, you should be able to read this kanji so long as you remember that it's all kun'yomi.
pitch_accent: アシꜜクビ *** アシクꜜビ

ex_1_jp: 今年の年次けいかくを立てましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s decide on this year’s annual project.
ex_2_jp: マリ子は年次有きゅう休か、何日もらえるの？
ex_2_en: How much annual paid leave do you get, Mariko?
ex_3_jp: 生徒たちの日本語がどれだけ上達したかに関する年次報告書を作成する。
ex_3_en: We write an annual report on how much our Japanese language students are improving.
meaning_story: The year that is next is coming up. What will you do in the year that is next that you did this year too? What do you do that is annual?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あなたの後ろのドアをしめてください。
ex_1_en: Please close the door behind you.
ex_2_jp: チャイルドシートは、かならず後ろのざせきにせっちしてください。
ex_2_en: You must install the child carseat on the rear seat of the car.
ex_3_jp: 振り返って後ろを見た後、さらにもう一度振り返ったら、僕のことが見えるよ。
ex_3_en: If you turn around to look behind you and then do it again, you’ll see me.
meaning_story: The hiragana attached to this word doesn't suggest it's a verb or an adjective, so we can assume it's a noun. While 後で (you may or may not have seen this word yet) means "after," this one means all the other meanings you learned with the kanji: behind, back, and rear. Think of the ろ as a hint. It's like saying you're on the "road" (ろ) and you're driving so fast you're leaving everything "behind."
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Continue to think you're driving on this road. You hit something, then look behind you, seeing you hit a cow. Know the word for cow in Japanese? You should. It's うし, which is also the reading for this word.

ex_1_jp: なかなか出血が止まりません。
ex_1_en: The bleeding won’t stop.
ex_2_jp: Tofuguはぜっさん出血大サービス中です。
ex_2_en: Tofugu is providing you with a huge discount!
ex_3_jp: 指を抜いていれば、鼻からの出血は止まると思います。
ex_3_en: I think my nose would stop bleeding if I kept my finger out of it.
meaning_story: When the thing that is exiting is blood, you are probably bleeding.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the しゅつ from 出 gets shortened to しゅっ. That's a small つ there, not a big one.

ex_1_jp: シャツに血がついていますよ。
ex_1_en: There is blood on your shirt.
ex_2_jp: うんちをするときにおしりから血が出るのはなぜなんだ！
ex_2_en: Why does my bum bleed when I poop?
ex_3_jp: 血が滴るぐらいのステーキが好きです。
ex_3_en: I like steak when it still has lots of blood in it.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You cut yourself and there's blood everywhere. You need to stop the bleeding with something, but the only thing nearby is a block of cheese. You grab the cheese and stuff it into your gash, but the blood comes out the holes (it is Swiss cheese, blargh!). Imagine this in great detail to be able to remember it well.

ex_1_jp: 姉も妹も、両方とも大さかにすんでいます。
ex_1_en: My older and younger sisters both live in Osaka.
ex_2_jp: じかんはあるんだから、両方やってみたら？
ex_2_en: You've got time, so why don't you try it both ways?
ex_3_jp: ダメだよ！両方とも僕のだよ。
ex_3_en: Nope. They’re both mine.
meaning_story: Here you have both directions / ways. Every time you have to choose between something it's like having to choose between two ways. That's why this word is simply both. Close to the kanji is the meaning both sides, as well. Learn either for 両方, they're pretty similar.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know the on'yomi reading for 両 but the on'yomi reading for 方 is something you didn't learn with the kanji. Think of it like you're choosing between two directions, looking down two paths. On one path you see Harry Houdini. You look down the other and... wait, that's also Harry Houdini. Somehow Houdini (ほう) is on both paths. That's a pretty cool magic trick!
pitch_accent: リョーホꜜー *** リョーホー

ex_1_jp: 両日とも、会ぎが入っています。
ex_1_en: I’ll be in a meeting both days.
ex_2_jp: とうふまつりは、両日ともせい天にめぐまれた。
ex_2_en: The tofu festival had good weather for both days.
ex_3_jp: iPadの使い方についての講義に両日とも参加したが、まだ使い方が分からない。
ex_3_en: I attended the iPad lecture session on both days, but I still have no clue how to use it.
meaning_story: Kanji doesn't go together much better than this. Both plus day equals both days. This is a bit of a formal word though, you'll hear important people say it more than your friends.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 日 uses the reading じつ for this one instead of にち.

ex_1_jp: 両手を上げて、バンザイをしました。
ex_1_en: They raised both hands and shouted banzai.
ex_2_jp: ビエトは両手に花ですね。
ex_2_en: Viet is between two beautiful women.
ex_3_jp: バランスの良い食事とは、両手にチョコレートクッキーを持つことです。
ex_3_en: A balanced diet is a chocolate cookie in both hands.
meaning_story: Don't use one hand when you can use both hands. This is simply both plus hand put together.
reading_story: This word uses the readings you learned with both kanji. No problemo for a kanji master such as yourself.

ex_1_jp: このへやは明るい。
ex_1_en: This room is bright.
ex_2_jp: トーフグの社いんは、みんな明るい。
ex_2_en: Tofugu workers are all happy people.
ex_3_jp: 未来はまだまだ明るいよ、おじいちゃん。
ex_3_en: Your future is still bright, Grandpa.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of bright? It's also bright.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the あか portion. What is あか in Japanese? It is "red." So, think of something that's really bright. Now, imagine it being totally red (aka あか). In Japan, the color red is associated with the sun, and the sun is pretty bright. If you can remember this you can also remember the reading of this word.

ex_1_jp: ★に入るばんごうを、茶色にぬります。
ex_1_en: Please color the number that best matches the ★ with brown.
ex_2_jp: 明るい茶色にカラーリングしてください。
ex_2_en: I'd like to dye my hair light brown, please.
ex_3_jp: 私の白いTシャツ全ての脇のところに、茶色のシミがある。
ex_3_en: All of my white t-shirts have brown armpit stains on them.
meaning_story: What is the color of tea? You'd think it would be green, assuming it's Japanese... but this word came from China. What color is Chinese tea? It tends to be more brown. Think Oolong tea, for example.
reading_story: The readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this already.

ex_1_jp: かれがおこるのは、仕方がないよ。
ex_1_en: If he’s angry, it can’t be helped.
ex_2_jp: 泣いてばかりいても仕方がないよ。
ex_2_en: There's no use in just crying.
ex_3_jp: お前は本当に仕方がないやつだ！
ex_3_en: You’re really hopeless!
meaning_story: The kanji part of this word is like saying "the doing way" ... aka the way you do something. So, when you don't have a way to do something, there's nothing you can do. Thus is born the popular Japanese phrase: 仕方がない, which means can't be helped. This is a very good word to know if you're in Japan.
reading_story: The readings for the kanji portion are in line with the readings you learned with the individual kanji, so as long as you know those you should be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: さいしょの字は、大文字でかいてください。
ex_1_en: Please capitalize the first letter.
ex_2_jp: タイトルを大文字でかき直してください。
ex_2_en: Please rewrite the title in uppercase letters.
ex_3_jp: 何故だかわからないけど、小文字より大文字の方が好きです。
ex_3_en: For some reason I like uppercase more than lowercase.
meaning_story: You have big writing letters. What do you think these are? THAT WOULD HAVE TO BE CAPITAL LETTERS, RIGHT? Whoops, sorry, caps lock was on for a moment, there.
reading_story: The readings for the kanji in this word are a bit strange. The 大 portion is actually read using the kun'yomi, the same reading as you learned with 大きい (おおきい). Everything else is just on'yomi. So, you'll need to remember the one exception with 大. If you do, you should be okay.
pitch_accent: オーモジ *** ダイモンジ *** ダイモꜜンジ

ex_1_jp: そして、でん車は安い方がいいです。
ex_1_en: Also, the cheap train is better.
ex_2_jp: タイのぶっかはアメリカよりも安いです。
ex_2_en: Prices in Thailand are cheaper than America.
ex_3_jp: アパートの屋根に投げて粉々になるのを見てみたかったので、昨日すごく安いラジオを買った。
ex_3_en: I bought a very cheap radio yesterday just so I could throw it off the roof of my apartment and watch it shatter.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cheap? It's also cheap. Time to go to a 100円 shop and get some 安い goods, ammiright?
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "Would you like this item for cheap?" "Uh, yes (やす) please!"

ex_1_jp: 来月は、出ちょうで中国に行きます。
ex_1_en: Next month I’m traveling to China on business.
ex_2_jp: 冬休みに、中国でりゅう星ぐんを見ました。
ex_2_en: During winter break, I watched the meteor shower in China.
ex_3_jp: どうして日本人は中国を支那と呼ぶことをやめて中国と呼び始めたんだろう。
ex_3_en: Why did Japanese people stop calling China "Shina" and start calling it "Chuugoku?"
meaning_story: The middle country... who could that be? Let's think about it. Who invented kanji and therefore probably thinks they're the middle of the world? Who also is just a huge country that ruled much of Asia? That would be none other than China.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just make sure you watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 社長は会ぎ中です。
ex_1_en: The company president is in a meeting.
ex_2_jp: あの人気サービスのねだんを下げるなんて、トーフグの社長はどうかしてるよ。
ex_2_en: The president of Tofugu is insane to lower the price of that popular service.
ex_3_jp: 全社員は社長のことを嫌っているが、私は単に彼は少し意地悪なだけだと思っている。
ex_3_en: All my coworkers hate my boss, but I just think just he’s a little mean.
meaning_story: The company leader is the company president, manager, or director. Be sure to greet your 社長 with a hearty good morning when he stumbles in!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今日は、どうしの活用をべんきょうします。
ex_1_en: Today we will learn verb conjugation.
ex_2_jp: ちょこっとあいたじかんを活用して、ワニカニで日本ごをべんきょうします。
ex_2_en: I make use of small pockets of time and study Japanese on Wanikani.
ex_3_jp: このデータをうまく活用して、何かできないかな。
ex_3_en: I don’t know if I can put this data to good use.
meaning_story: What do you use to show that a word is lively? Conjugation! Lively things are happening, so you have to conjugate your words to match. It also has another meaning. When you want to actually use something lively you are making practical use of it. I mean, you're using it, after all. So as long as you aren't pretending to use it, it's probably practical.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お国はどちらですか。
ex_1_en: Which country are you from?
ex_2_jp: この国は安全だと思っていたのに、がっかりです。
ex_2_en: I thought this country was safe, but now I'm disappointed.
ex_3_jp: 私の国には、猫が焼くアップルパイのお店がある。
ex_3_en: In my country, there is a shop that sells apple pies made by a cat.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Tell me about your country. Now imagine your country covered in raccoons (くに), taking up every inch of the ground. In your country you have to walk on top of them there are so many. That's why your country is known as "(rac)coon country."

ex_1_jp: 日本の文化にきょうみがあります。
ex_1_en: I’m interested in Japanese culture.
ex_2_jp: この国の文化にはなれましたか？
ex_2_en: Have you adapted to the culture of this country yet?
ex_3_jp: コスプレは日本の文化の一つですか？
ex_3_en: Is cosplaying part of Japanese culture?
meaning_story: Writing has changed our entire culture. In fact, when someone reads a good piece of writing it changes them, and changes their culture too. What writing has changed you so much it has changed your culture and the way you act?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: だれが死体を見つけましたか。
ex_1_en: Who found the dead body?
ex_2_jp: だれが死体いきのようぎでたいほされたって？
ex_2_en: Who did you say was arrested for abandoning a corpse?
ex_3_jp: 私が初めて死体を見たのは、六歳の時です。
ex_3_en: The first time I saw a dead body was when I was six years old.
meaning_story: The kanji for death and body put together make for a dead body. Hopefully you don't have to use or see this vocab too much.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その死は早すぎました。
ex_1_en: Their death was too soon.
ex_2_jp: 人は死をのがれることはできない…コウイチい外は。
ex_2_en: People cannot escape death, except for Koichi.
ex_3_jp: 愛犬の死に打ちひしがれています。
ex_3_en: I’m stricken with grief over the death of my pet dog.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 方言のじしょを作っています。
ex_1_en: I’m making a dialect dictionary.
ex_2_jp: ああっもうっ！かれしの方言がうつっちゃってるずら。
ex_2_en: Damn! My boyfriend's dialect has rubbed off on me.
ex_3_jp: 私の国の東側出身の人達は変わった方言で喋るので、彼らが何を言っているのか全く分かりません。
ex_3_en: People from the eastern part of my country use such an odd dialect that they are impossible to understand.
meaning_story: The way you say things could be translated as your accent... but this is much bigger. This is an entire "way" of speaking. This is a dialect. You can even think of the 方 as being "direction" where you go in different directions in a country and discover different dialects, if that way of thinking helps.
reading_story: The reading for this word is double on'yomi, except you didn't learn the on'yomi reading for 方 with the kanji (uh oh!). The on'yomi reading for 方 is ほう, so think of this word this way: You're talking to different people with different dialects, and come across a particularly interesting one. It's a far north people, and they all look like santa. They end every sentence with "ho ho ho!" (ほう) giving them a strange dialect indeed. Another way to remember this one is to think of Hulk Hogan (ほうげん) having a strange speaking dialect. Whatever is easiest for you, I'd say.

ex_1_jp: わたしは、方向が分からなくなりました。
ex_1_en: I lost my bearings.
ex_2_jp: めっちゃ方向音ちなんですよ。
ex_2_en: I'm super terrible with directions!
ex_3_jp: こっちの方向であってるの？チャッキー・チーズは反対方向だと思ってたんだけど。
ex_3_en: Are we going in the right direction? I thought Chuck E. Cheese was the other way.
meaning_story: The direction yonder over there is still just the direction of something, though a complicated way to say it, I think. This direction is the "what direction did he go in?" sort of direction.
reading_story: This word uses double on'yomi, but when you learned the reading for 方 you learned the kun'yomi reading because it pops up more. The reading for 向 should be fine, but to remember the 方 part here's a hint: What direction are you going to go in? You have a couple of choices. One is a dark corridor with the faint sound of "ho ho ho" (ほう) coming from it. You choose this one, and go in the direction of the "ho ho ho." By the next level I'm going to assume you know both the on'yomi and the kun'yomi readings of 方 so make sure you learn this as a separate sort of thing as well!

ex_1_jp: きのうはどうして早く学こうに行きましたか。
ex_1_en: Why did you come to school early yesterday?
ex_2_jp: ゆっくり休んで早くよくなってください。
ex_2_en: Please get plenty of rest and feel better!
ex_3_jp: 早く食べなさい。
ex_3_en: Eat quickly.
meaning_story: This is the adverb version of the kanji early It's a little thing you can begin sentences with to say you're doing something early or quickly.
reading_story: Since you already know the reading of the vocab word 早い, you should be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: 一まいのはっぱが、ひらりと地におちた。
ex_1_en: One leaf fell lightly to the ground.
ex_2_jp: コウイチはむかしはおおものだったけど、イノシシとのたたかいにまけてから、ひょうばんが地におちたよね。
ex_2_en: Koichi used to be a big shot, but his reputation hit rock bottom after he lost a battle against a wild boar.
ex_3_jp: しかし、コウイチ氏は意外と地に足をしっかりつけ続けています。
ex_3_en: And yet, Koichi himself remains charmingly down-to-earth.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Although this is a single kanji all alone, it uses the on'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck.

ex_1_jp: えきの東がわにあるきっ茶店で会いましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s meet in the cafe that's on the east side of the station.
ex_2_jp: どっちの方角が東？
ex_2_en: Which direction is east?
ex_3_jp: 空港の東側に住んでいます。
ex_3_en: I live on the east side of the airport.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: There are the ten rice fields in a man's area (see the radicals of the kanji of this word). He decides to go to the East side rice field. On his way there, He gashes (ひがし) his foot on some sharp fins sticking out of the ground, tearing it up really bad. Then he takes another step and he gashes his foot again.
pitch_accent: アꜜズマ *** ヒカ°シ *** ヒカ°シꜜ

ex_1_jp: 東方の空が明るくなりだした。
ex_1_en: The eastern sky grew bright.
ex_2_jp: あの外国人は、大さかえきの東方やく五キロのところに住んでいる。
ex_2_en: That foreigner lives about five kilometers east of Osaka Station.
ex_3_jp: 日本はイギリスの東方にある。
ex_3_en: Japan is to the east of Great Britain.
meaning_story: The East direction is Eastward.
reading_story: This word uses both on'yomi readings, though you learned the kun'yomi reading with 方. To remember the 方 reading, think of the word this way: You're going Eastward. It's where Santa Claus has gone, and you have a score to settle. To find him, you're following his laugh, which you can hear in the distance towards the east. "Ho ho ho... ho ho ho..." (ほう). You keep following. 東 is the on'yomi reading which you have learned, so that should be okay.
pitch_accent: トーホー *** ヒカ°シカ°タ

ex_1_jp: この町は、とても活気があります。
ex_1_en: This city is very lively.
ex_2_jp: ニッカはいつも活気にあふれている。
ex_2_en: Nikka is always full of energy.
ex_3_jp: 市場は活気にあふれていた。
ex_3_en: The market was overflowing with energy.
meaning_story: If you have lively energy you have more than enough energy for everyone to start noticing. They come up to you and compliment you on your amazing liveliness.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful because かつ is being shortened here to かっ. It's a pretty common change for on'yomi ending in つ, so keep your eyes open for more that do this!

ex_1_jp: いえの近くに、有名なすしやがあります。
ex_1_en: There is a famous sushi restaurant near my house.
ex_2_jp: このきじはトーフグを一やくちょう有名にした。
ex_2_en: This article suddenly made Tofugu super popular.
ex_3_jp: 俺は有名だけど、お前はどうよ？
ex_3_en: I’m famous, are you?
meaning_story: When you have a name (that is known to people) or you have famousness, you are probably someone who is famous.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: クリスマスソングの名曲といえば、何だと思いますか。
ex_1_en: Speaking of famous Christmas songs, what do you think?
ex_2_jp: この曲は名曲だと言われているけど、わたしには他の曲と大してかわりない。
ex_2_en: This is known for being an excellent piece of music, but to me it's just like all the others.
ex_3_jp: ベートーベンの「スモークサーモン」は名曲だ。
ex_3_en: Beethoven’s "Smoked Salmon" is a masterpiece.
meaning_story: Famous music that you know the name of is famous music.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: はやくち, はやぐち
ex_1_jp: わたしの兄は、とても早口です。
ex_1_en: My older brother is a really fast talker.
ex_2_jp: お前のことが一ばん大すきだよって、何でそんなに早口で言ったの？
ex_2_en: Why did you say that you love me the most so quickly?
ex_3_jp: こんなに早口の赤ん坊なんて見たことないよ。
ex_3_en: I’ve never seen such a fast talking baby before.
meaning_story: When you have a fast mouth, you're probably a fast talker, right motormouth?
reading_story: Remember how body parts often change even jukugo words to kun'yomi readings? That's what happened here too. Both readings are kun'yomi, making this one はやくち. Alternatively, you can read this as はやぐち as well.

ex_1_jp: わたしたちはまだ外国に行ったことがありません。
ex_1_en: We haven’t gone to other countries yet.
ex_2_jp: 外国へでんわをするのはこれがはじめてです。
ex_2_en: This is my first time making an overseas call.
ex_3_jp: もし外国にいるなら、有名人になっても構わない。
ex_3_en: I wouldn’t mind being a celebrity if I was in a foreign country.
meaning_story: An outside country is one outside of your own country. That is a foreign country.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ガイコク *** トツクニ *** トꜜツクニ *** トツꜜクニ

ex_1_jp: 今日、外国人の友だちと、かいものに行きました。
ex_1_en: Today, I went shopping with my foreign friends.
ex_2_jp: その外国人の目は血走っていた。
ex_2_en: That foreigner's eyes were bloodshot.
ex_3_jp: いいえ、私は人種差別主義者ではありません。世界中の全ての外国人に会って、それぞれ個人的に嫌いになっただけです。
ex_3_en: No, I’m not racist. I’ve met every kind of foreign person on the planet and I just hate each of them equally.
meaning_story: You know 外人 the word that means "foreigner," but that word is a bit informal and can come off as rude. The nicer, more politically correct version of the word is the one above. An outside country person. To differentiate this from "foreigner" we're going to use the more polite English version of this word as well (just like in Japanese): Foreign Person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 前は花やで、花やのとなりはさかなやです。
ex_1_en: In front is a flower shop and next door to it is a fish shop.
ex_2_jp: 毎あさ、会社に行く前に、スクワットを五百回します。
ex_2_en: Every morning I do 500 squats before leaving for work.
ex_3_jp: 赤信号の前にいる時、「もうすぐ青に変わるぞ！」と思うとかなり興奮する。
ex_3_en: When I’m in front of a red light, I get very excited at the thought of it turning green soon.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: What's in front of you? Think about it. Make it something ridiculous. Now look at a tag that's on it. Who does this thing belong to? Oh, wait, it's my (まえ) thing there in front of me. Say that out loud for better memory.

ex_1_jp: えきまで、全力で走りました。
ex_1_en: I ran with all my might to the station.
ex_2_jp: その中国人の女は、王子が自分とけっこんしてくれるよう全力でせっとくしたが、しっぱいにおわった。
ex_2_en: That Chinese woman tried her best to persuade the prince to marry her, but she failed.
ex_3_jp: そのゾンビは、死から蘇ろうと全力を尽くしていた。
ex_3_en: That zombie is using up all its strength trying to come back from the dead.
meaning_story: When you put all your power into something, you're putting your full effort into it. Hopefully that's what you put into your kanji learning as well!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 川田さんは、とても正直な人です。
ex_1_en: Kawata is a very honest person.
ex_2_jp: かれの正直なところがすきなんです。
ex_2_en: I like his honesty.
ex_3_jp: 僕は水中で息をしている火星からきた王子だし、他の人の模範となる必要があるので、いつも正直でいようと心がけています。
ex_3_en: I try to be honest all the time because I’m an underwater-breathing Martian prince and I need to set an example for people.
meaning_story: You have correct and fix. When you're always fixing things to make them correct (for example, someone's lies!) you are a very honest person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ショージꜜキ *** ショージキꜜ

ex_1_jp: この後、本州に行くつもりです。
ex_1_en: After this I plan on going to Honshu.
ex_2_jp: 本州とは、いったいぜんたい日本のどこにあるんですか？
ex_2_en: Where the heck in Japan is Honshu?
ex_3_jp: 本州がどこか分からなければ、パソコンでしらべたらどうですか？
ex_3_en: If you don't know where Honshu is, why don't you look it up on your computer?
meaning_story: You have your origin state. For Japan (since this is a Japanese word), that would be the main island, the big one in the middle: Honshu. You'll have to know some minor Japanese geography for this. Go look at a map of Japan and study it over real quick to see where I'm talking about if you don't know already.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あの国王は、とてもよくばりです。
ex_1_en: That king is very greedy.
ex_2_jp: わたしは、国王のことをじょじょにりかいしてきました。
ex_2_en: I'm starting to understand the king.
ex_3_jp: 18歳という若さで国王になった。
ex_3_en: I became the king as a youth of 18.
meaning_story: A country king is still a king, just of a bigger area.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ポチはきっと天国にいるんだよ。
ex_1_en: Poochie is definitely in heaven.
ex_2_jp: 天国がこんなとこだったなんて、本当にがっかりです。
ex_2_en: I am so disappointed to learn the Kingdom of Heaven is that kind of place.
ex_3_jp: タバコを天国で吸いましょう。
ex_3_en: Let’s smoke cigarettes in Heaven.
meaning_story: This is heaven country. Where is that? Probably just in heaven (or if you want to be fancy, the kingdom of heaven).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 国 is changed to the reading ごく, though because of rendaku. Even heaven changes a little bit.

ex_1_jp: 九州のりょうりはおいしいです。
ex_1_en: Kyushu cuisine is delicious.
ex_2_jp: 九州までは、フェリーでかた道一じかんです。
ex_2_en: It takes an hour to get to Kyushu by ferry.
ex_3_jp: 九州には、綺麗な女性が多い。
ex_3_en: There are many beautiful women in Kyushu.
meaning_story: The nine states. This refers to a section of Japan from a long time ago that was presumably made up of nine states. Now it's just one big island, though, and that island is Kyuushuu. Go take a look at a map and find this giant island, it's a cool part of Japan!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ここは、あなたの土地ではありません。
ex_1_en: This isn’t your land.
ex_2_jp: コウイチはマインクラフトに広大な土地をもっている。
ex_2_en: Koichi owns a a vast tract of land in Minecraft.
ex_3_jp: もし自分の土地があれば、ようやくそこに自分のベッドルームを手に入れることができるぜ！
ex_3_en: If I had some land of my own, I’d finally get my own bedroom.
meaning_story: The soil of the earth is the portion of the earth that is made up of land.
reading_story: The reading is the on'yomi reading, but 土 gets modified to と for some reason. Just remember that the land you're standing on is made of toes... millions of them. Yuck.

ex_1_jp: アメリカと日本の生活のちがいをおしえてください。
ex_1_en: Please tell me the difference between American and Japanese life?
ex_2_jp: あなたとの生活をもう一どやり直したいんです。
ex_2_en: I want to get back together and live with you again.
ex_3_jp: 毎日の生活でアニメを見ながらマシュマロを食べることができたら、とても幸せです。
ex_3_en: I would be very happy if I could watch cartoons and eat marshmallows every day of my life.
meaning_story: When you have life and are lively that right there is true life. What is your 生活 like? Do you live?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このえいがは長かったです。
ex_1_en: This movie was long.
ex_2_jp: あそこのドアの近くに立ってるかみの長い女性が、たん当しゃの方です。
ex_2_en: That lady with long hair standing by the door is the one in charge.
ex_3_jp: 長い距離のランニングを避けるため、自分の足の骨を折ってしまおうと思っている。
ex_3_en: I'm thinking about breaking my own legs to avoid going long distance running.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of long? It's also long.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have something that's really long. It's this crazy hair growing out of the tip of your nose. You don't really care either way if it stays or goes, but you're too lazy to cut it off. Your parents, though, keep trying to nag (なが) you to trim it. Imagine this process happening and be irritated about it. What naggers.

ex_1_jp: どうやって小文字と大文字を切りかえますか。
ex_1_en: How do you switch from lowercase to uppercase?
ex_2_jp: パスワードには、かならず大文字、小文字、すう字を一つい上つかってください。
ex_2_en: Passwords must contain at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter and a number.
ex_3_jp: 君のEメールアドレスって、全部小文字なの？本当に？ちょっとおかしいんじゃないの？
ex_3_en: Is your email address in all lowercase letters? Is it really? Are you crazy?
meaning_story: You know that 文字 means "letters". So, what are "small letters"? That would be lowercase letters.
reading_story: The reading for 小 is an exceptional reading. You know it means "small," so think about what else is small: a child. How do you say "child" in Japanese? こ. You also know how to say the 文字 portion from the previous level, so combine those together and you have こもじ.

ex_1_jp: スマートフォンで地図を出しました。
ex_1_en: I got out the map on my smartphone.
ex_2_jp: 地図をかた手に東京を歩きました。
ex_2_en: I walked around Tokyo with a map.
ex_3_jp: 先生、もし世界地図を忘れたのなら、私の額にタトゥーの世界地図がありますよ。
ex_3_en: Teacher, if you forget your world map I have one tattoo'd on my forehead.
meaning_story: The diagram of the earth. What could that be other than a map?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 一とうの牛が草地をのんびり歩いていました。
ex_1_en: There was a cow walking leisurely in the meadow.
ex_2_jp: アイルランドには、ぼく草地や草地が多い。
ex_2_en: There are a lot of pastures and grasslands in Ireland.
ex_3_jp: この金は、あそこの草地に隠そう。
ex_3_en: Let’s hide this money in the meadow over there.
meaning_story: Grass covering the earth is a meadow. Or, if you're less creative, it's grassland.
reading_story: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: 水星には大気がありません。
ex_1_en: Mercury does not have an atmosphere.
ex_2_jp: こんなはずじゃなかったんですが、もう十年も水星でホームレスをしています。
ex_2_en: This isn't what I asked for, but I've been homeless for 10 years on Mercury.
ex_3_jp: 水星は、日の出直前、または日没直後しか見ることができない。
ex_3_en: I can only see Mercury just before sunrise and right after sunset.
meaning_story: The water star is the planet Mercury. That's where we hid all of our secret moon water. Mercury looks enough like our moon, so we put it there so no one could find it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 星 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you point your telescope at Mercury you'll see Hard Gay shouting Sei, (せい) sei, sei! all over the planet. I hear he's going on a universe tour sei-ing on every planet.

ex_1_jp: けさ、テレビで中東のニュースを見ました。
ex_1_en: I watched the news on the Middle East on tv this morning.
ex_2_jp: きんきゅうじたいで中東に行かなくてはいけなかったんだから、けっこんしきに来れなかったのは仕方がないよ。
ex_2_en: You can't help it that you couldn't make it to the wedding because you had to go to the Middle East for an emergency.
ex_3_jp: 中東で一番楽しまれているゲームは何ですか？
ex_3_en: What is the most played game in the Middle East?
meaning_story: The middle of the east is more simply known as the middle east.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: やさいをたくさん食べると、死亡リスクがへるそうです。
ex_1_en: I heard that when you eat a lot of vegetables you can lower your risk of mortality.
ex_2_jp: 山田さんの弟さんの死亡のげんいんはなんですか？
ex_2_en: What is the cause of Mr. Yamada's younger brother's death?
ex_3_jp: チーズバーガーの発明により、全先進国の死亡率が三倍に跳ね上がった。
ex_3_en: Since the invention of the cheeseburger, mortality rates in all first-world nations have tripled.
meaning_story: Death and deceased. That's a lot of death. This is mortality.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 全国でインフルエンザがはやっています。
ex_1_en: The flu is spreading nationwide.
ex_2_jp: リンゴのしゅうかくりょうが全国で一ばん多いけんはどこですか？
ex_2_en: Which prefecture is the largest producer of apples nationwide?
ex_3_jp: 彼は全国規模のサイバーいじめのスキャンダルに関与していた。
ex_3_en: He was involved in a nationwide cyber bullying scandal.
meaning_story: When something involves all the country you know it's nationwide or national.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: パソコンのしすぎで、首がいたいです。
ex_1_en: I’ve been using my computer too much so my neck hurts.
ex_2_jp: 首をねちがえました。
ex_2_en: I cricked my neck in my sleep.
ex_3_jp: 腺ペストって、首から胸が生えてくる病気のことですか？
ex_3_en: Is the bubonic plague the illness that made people grow boobs on their necks?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: You learned the reading for this word via the kanji, so you should be able to read this word just fine.
pitch_accent: クビ *** コーベꜜ *** コーベ *** コꜜーベ

ex_1_jp: 海王星は、太ようから八ばん目のわく星です。
ex_1_en: Neptune is the eighth planet from the sun.
ex_2_jp: 海王星に行くことをずっとゆめ見てきたんです。
ex_2_en: I've always dreamed of going to Neptune.
ex_3_jp: 海王星は1846年9月23日に発見されました。
ex_3_en: Neptune was discovered on September 23rd, 1846.
meaning_story: The star named after the king of the ocean is Neptune! If you know anything about Roman mythology this should be easy to remember!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 星 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you point your telescope at Neptune you'll see Hard Gay shouting Sei, (せい) sei, sei! all over the planet. I hear he's going on a universe tour sei-ing on every planet.
pitch_accent: カイオꜜーセイ *** カイオーセイ

ex_1_jp: 次のでん車にのりましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s catch the next train.
ex_2_jp: 次のよていは、決まり次だいお知らせします。
ex_2_en: I'll let you know once we decide on the next plan.
ex_3_jp: このバスツアーの次の目的地は、マイケル・ジャクソンの家です。
ex_3_en: The next destination on this bus tour is Michael Jackson’s house.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Someone yells out "NEXT!" because the first thing didn't work on you. That was a single guillotine. Now they are going to try two guillotines (つぎ) and see how that works on your thick neck. NEXXXXT!

ex_1_jp: 次回の作ひんも、たのしみにしています。
ex_1_en: I’m looking forward to the next production.
ex_2_jp: 次回なんてないんだよ。人生は一どきりなんだから。
ex_2_en: There is no next time. We only live once.
ex_3_jp: 兄貴、心配するなよ。次回は絶対あいつらを仕留めてやろうぜ。
ex_3_en: Don’t worry, bro. We’ll get them next time, yo.
meaning_story: The next time you look at this kanji, you should know that it means next time.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: きのうの夜、パーティーに行きました。
ex_1_en: I went to a party last night.
ex_2_jp: きのうの夜は、こうふんしてほとんどねむれませんでした。
ex_2_en: Last night, I was so excited that I barely slept.
ex_3_jp: 夜には、モンスターたちが床から這い上がり、私のベッドの下でお茶会を開くんだよ。
ex_3_en: Night is the time when monsters crawl up through the floor to have tea parties under my bed.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: It is the night, but it is your (よる) night.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: このひ行きは、東京に直行します。
ex_1_en: This airplane is nonstop to Tokyo.
ex_2_jp: 今日は、日本との会ぎの後、トーフグとのアポに直行します。
ex_2_en: Today after the meeting with Japan, I'll go directly to the appointment with Tofugu.
ex_3_jp: ごめんなさい、今は話せません。トイレへ直行しているところなのです。
ex_3_en: I’m sorry, I can't talk right now. I’m on a nonstop trip to the bathroom.
meaning_story: If you think about direct going (aka transportation) how would you make it better? You'd make it so everything was nonstop and direct. Just imagine how much nicer it would be if every airplane you took was direct and you never had to stop. So nice!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word and uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. The ちょく of 直 is shortened with a small っ, though, so make sure to take note of that.

ex_1_jp: 東北で、ボランティアをしていました。
ex_1_en: I was volunteering in Tohoku.
ex_2_jp: 東北で一人ぐらしをしています。
ex_2_en: I'm living by myself in Tohoku now.
ex_3_jp: マグニチュード8.9の地震が、日本の東北地方の海岸を襲った。
ex_3_en: A magnitude 8.9 earthquake slammed into Japan’s northeastern coast.
meaning_story: The East North is also known as the Northeast. But, it's not just the Northeast, it's a region as well. You may have heard of the Tohoku Region before? It was the one hit by the 2011 Tohoku Earthquake.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お金が十円足りないんです。
ex_1_en: I’m ten yen short.
ex_2_jp: もしスペースが足りなければ、べつの用しについきして、それをてんぷしてください。
ex_2_en: If there is insufficient space, attach a separate sheet with additional information.
ex_3_jp: ビル・ゲイツは私の息子なのだが、それを証明するための証拠がまだ足りない。
ex_3_en: Bill Gates is my son, but there isn’t enough evidence to prove it yet.
meaning_story: You know the word 足りる from Level 4. What is this one? it's the opposite (negative form on a verb is ない). So, what is the opposite of 足りる (To be sufficient)? The opposite is to not be sufficient or not enough.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 足りる (たりる) which you should have seen in Level 4.

ex_1_jp: 海の公えんで、先生が学生にはなしています。
ex_1_en: The teacher is talking to her students in Marine Park.
ex_2_jp: 海でおよいだあと、目がじゅう血しました。
ex_2_en: I got red eyes after swimming in the sea.
ex_3_jp: 映画「水の世界」は、実は、海の底に住んでいる超頭のいい魚によって書かれた作品だ。
ex_3_en: The movie Water World was actually written by a race of super-intelligent fish that live at the bottom of the ocean.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You visit the sea. Strangely, it asks you who is visiting. You're so full of yourself (even in front of the sea/ocean) that you reply: "um, me?" (うみ). Imagine yourself feeling this full of yourself.

ex_1_jp: 年上の人と、デートするのははじめてです。
ex_1_en: This is my first date with an older person.
ex_2_jp: 人生はよそく不かのうだ。お前が年上のび人とけっこんするかのうせいだってゼロパーセントではない。
ex_2_en: Life is unpredictable. It's not a zero percent chance that you will get married with a beautiful older woman.
ex_3_jp: お父さんが、お母さんのお母さんはピラミッドよりも年上だと言うんだよ。
ex_3_en: My dad says that my mom’s mom is older than the pyramids.
meaning_story: When you're years above someone else, you are older than that person.
reading_story: The reading for this one is an exception, because it uses kun'yomi readings even though it is a jukugo kanji. You already know the separate kun'yomi readings from the vocabulary of the last level, but you will have to remember to actually use this knowledge when this word comes up.

ex_1_jp: みどりちゃんのお姉さんはめがねをかけています。
ex_1_en: Midori’s older sister is wearing glasses.
ex_2_jp: あなたのこと、てっきりビエトくんのお姉さんだと思ってたんですが、ちがったんですね。
ex_2_en: I totally thought you were Viet's older sister, but you aren't, eh?
ex_3_jp: 私のお姉さんは、バイクを買うことが彼氏を見つけることに繋がると考えています。
ex_3_en: My older sister thinks that buying a motorcycle will help her get a boyfriend.
meaning_story: The お makes the word more polite. You're elevating the "older sister" title because you're a good younger sibling. Otherwise, the meaning of this word is the same as the kanji - just the feeling is different.
reading_story: The reading is different too. It has some hiragana attached to it, which is a clue that this uses a kun'yomi reading. Let's use a mnemonic to learn that reading. Imagine your older sister (even if you don't have one). She is, for some reason, a horse. Imagine petting her, giving her carrots, and doing other horse-related things with her. What do horses say? they say nehhhh (ねえ).

ex_1_jp: 姉のいえに行くところです。
ex_1_en: I’m just about to go to my older sister’s house.
ex_2_jp: わたしは、姉の五ばいのりょうの本をもっています。
ex_2_en: I have five times as many books as my older sister does.
ex_3_jp: 姉はスチュワーデスをしています。
ex_3_en: My big sister works as a stewardess.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is your older sister, by the way. Not somebody else's.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading so here's coming to help you remember: Picture your older sister (even if you don't have one), her birthday is coming up and there's only one thing she wants from you. A necklace (あね). She's wanted a necklace for years and you're finally going to give her one. She'll be so happy.

ex_1_jp: ようやく、ゆめに向かって一歩ふみ出しました。
ex_1_en: I’ve finally taken one step forward toward my dream.
ex_2_jp: 千里の道も一歩からって言うでしょ？
ex_2_en: They say, a journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step, right?
ex_3_jp: 最初の一歩を踏み出すのに勇気がいる。
ex_3_en: It takes courage to take the first step forward.
meaning_story: If 歩 is "walk" and you take one walk, then really you are just taking one step. When there's a number before 歩, it refers to the number of steps you're taking. The most common is this one, and you'll see it on urinals when they kindly ask you to please take one step forward because peeing isn't a game and somebody has to clean up after you.
reading_story: The reading is pretty standard in its trickiness. The いち shortens to an いっ and the ほ rendakus to ぽ. One step at a time, right?

ex_1_jp: しょう来は、海外ではたらきたいです。
ex_1_en: I want to work overseas in the future.
ex_2_jp: ほけんぎょうかいに八年つとめた後、アメリカへ海外りゅう学しました。
ex_2_en: After having worked in the insurance industry for eight years, I went to America to study abroad.
ex_3_jp: 私はどこか海外で住みたいと思っているが、旅行は嫌いだ。
ex_3_en: I want to live somewhere overseas, but I hate traveling.
meaning_story: The outside of the sea is someplace overseas. It can also be foreign or abroad if those words are easier to remember for you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 平安じだいはいつですか。
ex_1_en: When was the Heian period?
ex_2_jp: 平安をみだす人がいないワニカニフォーラムは、わたしの心に平安をあたえてくれる。
ex_2_en: The Wanikani forums don't have any trolls, so it gives me peace of mind.
ex_3_jp: ブリティッシュコロンビアの古の森を歩く時、心に平安を感じる。
ex_3_en: Walking through the old growth forests in British Columbia was so peaceful.
meaning_story: Something is flat and relaxed. That is you. What words does that describe? To me, that would be peace and tranquility. Just imagine something that is flat and relaxed, like a field of grass with happy people in it. It's so peaceful! It's so tranquil!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 女の人は、あしたの午後、何をしますか。
ex_1_en: What are the women going to do tomorrow afternoon?
ex_2_jp: 直近の午後で空いているじかんは何じですか？
ex_2_en: What's the closest time in the afternoon that's available for an appointment?
ex_3_jp: 午後三時に、足の巻き爪を取り除くためのお医者さんの予約がある。
ex_3_en: I have an appointment with my doctor at 3PM to remove an ingrown toenail.
meaning_story: What is noon after? That is PM or the afternoon.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ねつが、三十八点九どあります。
ex_1_en: I have a fever of 38.9 degrees.
ex_2_jp: このクローゼットにある二点五ばいのりょうのふくが他のへやにもちらばっています。
ex_2_en: Compared to what's in this closet, I have as 2.5 times as many clothes scattered around in the other rooms.
ex_3_jp: あの映画が駄作だったという点ではあなたに同意しますが、時間の無駄だったと気づいたのは映画が終わってからでした。
ex_3_en: I agree with your point that the movie was really bad, but I didn’t realize it was such a waste of time until it was over.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the reading for the kanji that makes it.

ex_1_jp: ただいま、車両の点けんをしています。
ex_1_en: Hi there, I’m examining the railroad cars.
ex_2_jp: 日本では、車両は左がわを走ります。
ex_2_en: In Japan, vehicles drive on the left side of the road.
ex_3_jp: この車両は女性専用車両です。
ex_3_en: This railroad car is a women-only carriage.
meaning_story: A car with more cars on both sides is a car that hooks into other cars... specifically other railroad cars. They have hooks on both sides, they hook into other cars, and they fit all the requirements of this vocab word's kanji.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: これで安心です。
ex_1_en: That’s a relief.
ex_2_jp: あの子は次の行どうがよそくできないから、安心できないのよね。
ex_2_en: I never know what that kid will do next, so I can't get peace of mind.
ex_3_jp: お父さんの癌が無くなったことを聞いて、とても安心した。
ex_3_en: I feel so relieved now that I know my dad no longer has cancer.
meaning_story: When your heart is relaxed, how do you feel? What if this is after something startling happens? You would feel relief or peace of mind.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: きょう室に入ってください。
ex_1_en: Come into the classroom, please.
ex_2_jp: このゲーム、むずかしすぎるよ。このめんで、１５６９号室まで行くには、どうがんばってもじかんが足りないんだ。
ex_2_en: This game is too difficult. I never have enough time to get to room number 1569 in this stage no matter how hard I try.
ex_3_jp: 保健室で眠っていました。
ex_3_en: I was sleeping in the school infirmary.
meaning_story: You'll see this attached to other words... like "waiting" or "guest." When you see this, you'll know it is a ___ room, making this word mean room (same as the kanji).
reading_story: The reading is the on'yomi reading. Don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.

ex_1_jp: ここまで来れば、安全です。
ex_1_en: If I come here, I’m safe.
ex_2_jp: ゆっくりでかまいませんので、安全うんてんでおねがいします。
ex_2_en: I don't mind if we're a little slow, so just please drive safely.
ex_3_jp: 安全第一が私のモットーです。
ex_3_en: My motto is safety first.
meaning_story: When you are all relaxed you are finally in safety.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どれが土星か、分かりますか。
ex_1_en: Do you know which one is Saturn?
ex_2_jp: 土星にはどうやって行けばいいですか？
ex_2_en: How can I get to Saturn?
ex_3_jp: 私は土星出身の宇宙人です。
ex_3_en: I’m an alien from Saturn.
meaning_story: The ground star is Saturn. That's why it's called "sat"urn. Because the first people to find it sat on the ground there. It's a star made completely of sit-on-able ground.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 星 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you point your telescope at Saturn you'll see Hard Gay shouting Sei, (せい) sei, sei! all over the planet. I hear he's going on a universe tour sei-ing on every planet.

ex_1_jp: かの女のせんもんは、科学です。
ex_1_en: Her major is science.
ex_2_jp: 日本は科学ぎじゅつというめんにおいてとてもすぐれています。
ex_2_en: Japan is very advanced in the fields of science and technology.
ex_3_jp: 我々に蚊除け剤を作らせてくれる科学は、本当に偉大だ。
ex_3_en: Science is really amazing because it allowed us to make mosquito repellent.
meaning_story: The study of science is plainly known as science.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どうぶつえんで、羊にえさをやりました。
ex_1_en: I got to feed the sheep at the zoo.
ex_2_jp: いつ何がおこるか分からないんだから、羊がかいたいなら、かいたいと思ったときにかった方がいいよ。
ex_2_en: Anything can happen at any moment, so if you want a sheep, get it.
ex_3_jp: 毛を刈られた時、羊も恥ずかしい思いをしていると思う？
ex_3_en: Do you think sheep feel embarrassed when they have their wool sheared off?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Imagine a sheep fighting with Jesus. The first thing it does is hits Jesus (ひつじ) in the stomach with its fists, then hits Jesus again with its horns. Try to imagine this playing out, with an announcer calling the shots as well.

ex_1_jp: 四国にはまだ行ったことがありません。
ex_1_en: I still haven’t been to Shikoku.
ex_2_jp: 四国での生活にはなれましたか？
ex_2_en: Have you gotten used to life in Shikoku yet?
ex_3_jp: 最高の饂飩の作り方を求めて、四国を旅していた。
ex_3_en: I was traveling through Shikoku to learn how to make the best udon noodles.
meaning_story: The four country is another section of Japan. It's quite nice, too. Look on a map and try to find it. So, the meaning of this word is also the reading, which you should be able to figure out because it's all on'yomi: Shikoku.
reading_story: The reading for 四 isn't the one you learned, but by now you should have seen the し reading pop up. You at least know the reason why it's not し, right? し sounds too much like death, so if it helps, you can think of this area of Japan as the "Death Country," aka the しこく.

ex_1_jp: えきからその店までの地図をかいてください。
ex_1_en: Please draw a map from the station to the store.
ex_2_jp: この店は年内はすでにずっとよやくでいっぱいだ。
ex_2_en: The restaurant is already fully booked for the rest of the year.
ex_3_jp: この店のこと絶対気に入るぜ。世界一うまいミートローフがあるんだよ。
ex_3_en: You’re going to love this shop. They have the best meatloaf in the world.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think of your favorite shop. Okay, now imagine yourself going to it. When you arrive, the entire shop is totally missing (みせ). Feel the shock and awe of this. It's as if it picked up and left overnight. No building, no anything. Just missing.

ex_1_jp: 二人の姉妹はとてもよくにています。
ex_1_en: Those two sisters look so alike.
ex_2_jp: 何か、二人って姉妹みたいだよね。
ex_2_en: Hey, you two kinda look like sisters.
ex_3_jp: 単なる女友達には無い絆が、姉妹の間にはある。
ex_3_en: There is a bond between sisters that isn’t shared between girls who are just friends.
meaning_story: Your older sister and your younger sister. These are your sisters.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: キョꜜーダイ *** シꜜマイ

ex_1_jp: この世の中には、色んな人がいます。
ex_1_en: There are many types of people in the world.
ex_2_jp: 世の中には、しんじつを知らない方がいいことだってあるんだよ。
ex_2_en: In this society, not knowing the truth is sometimes better.
ex_3_jp: 我々は、警察よりも先にピザが家に到着するような素晴らしい世の中に住んでいる。
ex_3_en: We live in a great society where pizza gets to your house before the police.
meaning_story: The middle of society is still just the society. You can also call it the world.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. Why? Because this word is really two separate words connected together into one bigger word. You know the kun'yomi readings for vocab practice in previous levels.

ex_1_jp: としょかんの南に、交ばんがあります。
ex_1_en: There is a police station on the south side of the library.
ex_2_jp: どうして東日本りょかくてつ道と西日本りょかくてつ道はあるのに、北日本りょかくてつ道と南日本りょかくてつ道はないんだ？
ex_2_en: Why isn't there a North Japan Railway Company and a South Japan Railway Company, even though there's an East Japan Railway Company and a West Japan Railway Company?
ex_3_jp: 南球場でブラッド・ピットを見た。
ex_3_en: I saw Brad Pitt at the south baseball stadium.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think about the south. What's down there? Mean Amy (みなみ) lives down there. Think of the last mean thing she did to you and imagine it while yelling out "MEAN AMYYYYY" at the sky.

ex_1_jp: 車は、南東に向かってすすみました。
ex_1_en: The car continued heading southeast.
ex_2_jp: てっきり今日は日が南東にしずむもんだとおもっていたよ。
ex_2_en: I totally thought the sun would set in the southeast today.
ex_3_jp: 南東の方角に、流れ星を見た。
ex_3_en: I saw a shooting star in the southeast.
meaning_story: The South East is the Southeast.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 夜には、星がとてもきれいでした。
ex_1_en: That night the stars were really pretty.
ex_2_jp: 今夜はたくさんながれ星が見れるといいんですが。
ex_2_en: I hope we can see a lot of shooting stars tonight.
ex_3_jp: お父さん、どうして今日は星型の眼鏡をかけているの？
ex_3_en: Dad, why are you wearing star-shaped glasses today?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: You learned this reading with the kanji! You're a star!

ex_1_jp: ニューヨーク州の出しんです。
ex_1_en: I’m from New York state.
ex_2_jp: アメリカがっしゅう国には、五十の州があります。
ex_2_en: There are fifty states in the United States.
ex_3_jp: オレゴン州ポートランド市には、Tofuguの本社がある。
ex_3_en: The headquarters of Tofugu is located in Portland, Oregon.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the on'yomi reading that you learned with the kanji, probably because it normally gets added on to other things, like the names of the state. Examples: カリフォルニア州, ニューヨーク州, etc.

ex_1_jp: 代わりの先生をさがしています。
ex_1_en: We’re looking for a substitute teacher.
ex_2_jp: この世のどこにも、かれの代わりはいないんです。
ex_2_en: There is no replacement for him anywhere in the world.
ex_3_jp: 日本語を教わる代わりに、英語を教えることができますよ。
ex_3_en: I can teach you English and in exchange you can teach me Japanese.
meaning_story: You've seen that 代わる means "to substitute for" or "to replace." This is the noun version of that (no う sound on the end). So, what is the noun version of those verb words? It would be substitute or replacement.
reading_story: You should be able to figure out the reading from learning 代わる in the previous level.

ex_1_jp: 目次のページがやぶれています。
ex_1_en: The table of contents page was torn out.
ex_2_jp: 先ずはじめに、目次をごせつ明いたします。
ex_2_en: First, I would like to explain the table of contents.
ex_3_jp: この本全部読まないとだめ？目次だけ読むってことは無理かな？
ex_3_en: Do I have to read this whole book? Can’t I just read the table of contents?
meaning_story: Your eye is on what's next. How is this possible to see what's coming up? That's because you're looking at a table of contents.
reading_story: The readings are the on'yomi readings, but you learned the kun'yomi reading for 目 before. So, you have to remember that this word uses もく instead of め. To do that, imagine yourself looking at a table of contents. Instead of being a normal table of contents there, it's just line after line of text trying to mock (もく) you. Come up with what those lines are and think about how you're being mocked.

ex_1_jp: わたしはお茶をのみませんでした。
ex_1_en: I didn’t drink tea.
ex_2_jp: 死ぬ前に、ベーコンのお茶づけが食べたい。
ex_2_en: I want to eat bacon rice covered in tea before I die.
ex_3_jp: 何故かおならがしたくなるので、もうお茶を飲むことはできない。
ex_3_en: I can’t drink tea anymore because it makes me fart.
meaning_story: The お just makes the word more polite. Since tea is so important in Japan, it gets the お. Otherwise, you should be able to figure out the meaning as it's the same as the kanji.
reading_story: The reading is the on'yomi reading, just like you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 山下さんのかぞくは、今年の冬休みはどこに行きますか？
ex_1_en: Where is your family going to go on winter vacation this year, Yamashita?
ex_2_jp: おきなわのせい人しきは今年も大あれだった。
ex_2_en: The coming-of-age ceremony in Okinawa went wild again this year.
ex_3_jp: ようやく今年の年を2013年と書くことを覚えたところで、年が2014年に変わった。
ex_3_en: As soon as I got used to writing 2013 as the date for this year, 2014 arrived.
meaning_story: The now year is which year? It is this year.
reading_story: With the first reading (the more common one), the こん of 今 is actually just こ. This gets shortened sometimes, so look out for it. Also, the 年 is the kun'yomi reading for some reason. It's a total mystery why this is. Perhaps the ancient aliens know, but I do not. You're going to have to remember this exception with that brain of yours and rely on the SRS to bestow this knowledge upon you. The second reading, which is less common but still common enough, makes more sense. It is こんねん and just follows the jukugo patterns.

ex_1_jp: まんがを三百さつもっています。
ex_1_en: I have three hundred manga.
ex_2_jp: ひるねをしていた時に、だれかがインターホンを三百回もならした。
ex_2_en: When I was taking a nap, somebody rang the doorbell 300 times.
ex_3_jp: 一年は三百六十五日です。
ex_3_en: One year is three hundred and sixty-five days.
meaning_story: You have three hundreds. What does that come out to? Three hundred.
reading_story: The reading is a little bit weird, so be careful. You should already know the on'yomi readings, but the ひゃく rendakus to びゃく. This pattern will repeat itself with 三 + many counter kanjis that can rendaku, so pay attention for it as you read Japanese.

ex_1_jp: 三足す二は五です。
ex_1_en: Three plus two is five.
ex_2_jp: このスープ、もう少し水を足した方がいいんじゃないかな。
ex_2_en: Maybe it would be better to add more water to this soup.
ex_3_jp: ここにもう少し文章を書き足すことはできますか？
ex_3_en: Can you add a little more to this sentence here?
meaning_story: Remember 足りる? That is "to have enough." How do you have enough? You keep adding things to the pile until you reach that point where you have enough. That's why this verb is to add, because you keep adding until you 足りる. Maybe you add so much that someone tries to sue (す) you for that nasty pile of squirrels you keep outside.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 足りる, so if you know that you can add things up to this.

ex_1_jp: やっとJLPTN1にごうかくすることが出来ました。
ex_1_en: I was finally able to pass JLPT N1.
ex_2_jp: ここまではできましたが、最後の問題が難しくて出来ませんでした。
ex_2_en: I could do up to here, but the last question was really difficult and I couldn’t do it.
ex_3_jp: 私は内面を美しくするために化粧品を食べました。あなたにもそれが出来ますか？
ex_3_en: I ate my make-up to be pretty on the inside. Can you do that, too?
meaning_story: When you exit and come, apparently it means to be able to do. I think of it like you're leaving a location (出) to do a task and then you come (来る) back after you did it. Perhaps you were waiting in a room training like someone from Dragonball. When you leave the room, you are ready to fight the enemy and win. You train in that room to be able to do whatever you need to do, and only leave and come back alive because you were able to do it.
reading_story: The readings are a bit strange. Both kun'yomi, where 出 is で and 来る is きる. This is different from the reading you learned with 来る (くる), though, so be careful. If you can remember that and remember the kun'yomi readings from the previous vocab, you should be able to learn this one's reading as well.

ex_1_jp: こしょうした車が直るのはいつですか。
ex_1_en: When can I get my broken car fixed?
ex_2_jp: それでアヤの気げんが直るなら、おれはぜんぜんかまわないよ。
ex_2_en: If it makes you feel better, then I don't mind at all, Aya.
ex_3_jp: 農夫の壊れたトラクターは直った。
ex_3_en: The farmer’s broken tractor was fixed.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fix so the verb version is similar to that, to be fixed. This word is for when something is fixed, but you're not the one fixing it.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to learn the なお part. Think of it this way. Something needs to be fixed. It's urgent! You have to fix it now! (なお). This will also work with the similar word, 直す, which you'll learn soon if you haven't already.

ex_1_jp: 死ぬかと思いました。
ex_1_en: I thought I would die.
ex_2_jp: わたしのそ母は、がんで死にました。
ex_2_en: My grandmother died from cancer.
ex_3_jp: 私は絶対に死なないと約束するよ。
ex_3_en: I promise you that I will never die.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means death, so the verb version is to die.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 毎あさ、なっとうを食べます。
ex_1_en: I eat natto every morning.
ex_2_jp: いつも、けんこうにいいものを食べるじかんがないんです。
ex_2_en: I never have enough time to eat healthy foods.
ex_3_jp: 私は、寝ながら食べるのが好きだ。夢遊病のような感じで、それは夢遊食事病と呼ばれる。
ex_3_en: I like to eat while I’m sleeping. It’s just like sleepwalking, but it’s called sleep-eating.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means eat so the verb version is to eat.
reading_story: You have to remember the た portion if you want to be able to read this word, which uses the kun'yomi reading. Think about yourself eating some tacos (た). Imagine yourself eating it, that raw beef taste in your mouth (either like it or hate it).

ex_1_jp: こっちを向いてください。
ex_1_en: Turn this way, please.
ex_2_jp: このへやは、南を向いているので日当たりがいい。
ex_2_en: This room is facing South, so it gets very sunny.
ex_3_jp: 今度は、お父さんの方を向いて、どうして赤ちゃんの格好をしているのか聞いてみましょう。
ex_3_en: Now, let’s turn toward your dad and ask him why he’s wearing a baby costume.
meaning_story: You know that the kanji means yonder, which is like "over there." This is the verb version of "yonder." That being said, "to yonder" isn't really a thing, so you have to think of what happens when you "look yonder." This word means to face or to turn toward. You're looking yonder, but you have to turn towards said yonder to look that way.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You turn to face a new direction and look out into the distance. There is a single cow out there. It turns to face you too, and says moo (む).

ex_1_jp: パソコンがこわれたんですが、直せますか。
ex_1_en: My PC broke. Can you fix it?
ex_2_jp: 考え直した方がいいですよ。
ex_2_en: You'd better think it through again.
ex_3_jp: もし壊れていなければ、それを直そうとする必要はないよ。
ex_3_en: You don’t need to fix something if it’s not broken.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fix so this vocab word means to fix. This is when you're fixing something, as in doing the actual physical action of fixing.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to learn the なお part. Think of it this way. You need to fix something! It's urgent! You have to fix it now! (なお). This will also work with the similar word, 直る, which you'll learn soon if you haven't already.

ex_1_jp: 先月、会社を首になりました。
ex_1_en: I was fired from the company last month.
ex_2_jp: しゅう金したお金をつかいこんだら、首になるに決まってるじゃん！
ex_2_en: Of course you would get fired, if you used up the collected money.
ex_3_jp: マーチングバンドを職場に引き連れてきたことが理由で、私は昨日首になりました。
ex_3_en: I got fired yesterday for bringing a marching band into work with me.
meaning_story: The になる part means "to become," so literally this means "to become neck." If you think about it, when something becomes neck, it has to do with you getting your head cut off (at the neck). But, in today's modern society we don't do that too often. Instead, this means you lose your job, aka to get fired.
reading_story: This word contains the reading you learned with the kanji. Everything else is hiragana.

ex_1_jp: マヨネーズなら、まだ少し有ります。
ex_1_en: We still have a little mayonnaise.
ex_2_jp: 一じかんに一本しかでん車は有りません。
ex_2_en: There is only one train per hour.
ex_3_jp: 彼の家には金も有るが、屋根の上に銀も有る。
ex_3_en: There is gold in his house as well as silver on his roof.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.
