The kanji itself means have and so the verb version means to have. An alternative meaning is to exist though this refers only to non-living inanimate things, not moving and living things. So really, this is similar to "to have" as well. These kanji aren't used too often, so when you're writing just use the kana. But you'll see the kanji used sometimes so it's important to be able to recognize them!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To have something is very nice. But now, the only thing you possess are screams. Imagine this. You are in a totally empty room with no possessions. You open a little box and look inside. It contains screams that yell: "AAAAHHHH" (あ).

ex_1_jp: 何も知らない。
ex_1_en: I don’t know anything.
ex_2_jp: ルーターのさいきどうの仕方を知っていますか？
ex_2_en: Do you know how to reboot the router?
ex_3_jp: あなたも知っているように、コウイチはロボットです。
ex_3_en: As you know, Koichi is a robot.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means know so the verb version means to know.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The first thing you know is that Charlie Sheen (し) is crazy. The second thing you know? Well, that Charlie Sheen is crazy. You're stuck in a loop. All you know is that Charlie Sheen is crazy. Worry a lot about this, because this is the only thing you can pull out of your brain.

ex_1_jp: 東京えきから中川えきまででんしゃで行って、中川えきからみかん山までバスで行きます。
ex_1_en: We will take a train from Tokyo station to Nakagawa station, and then we will take a bus from Nakagawa station to Mikan mountain.
ex_2_jp: 今から東京に行かなくてはいけないので、そろそろお会けいおねがいします。
ex_2_en: I have to go to Tokyo now, so may I have the bill, please?
ex_3_jp: 東京についてすぐに、マクドナルドに行った。
ex_3_en: As soon as I arrived in Tokyo, I went to McDonald’s.
meaning_story: The East Capital in Japan is Tokyo. If you look on a map and compare it to 京都 (Kyoto, the other capital in history), you'll see it's East of Kyoto, making it the East Capital, Tokyo.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今夜、いっしょにのみに行きませんか。
ex_1_en: Would you like to go out for drinks with me tonight?
ex_2_jp: 明日しけんがあるから、今夜はてつ夜でがんばります。
ex_2_en: The exam is coming up tomorrow, so I am gonna burn the midnight oil tonight.
ex_3_jp: 今夜は晩ご飯に手羽先が食べたい気分だ。
ex_3_en: I feel like eating chicken wings for dinner tonight.
meaning_story: The now night is the current night, aka tonight.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: まつ本さんが、亡くなったそうです。
ex_1_en: I heard that Matsumoto passed away.
ex_2_jp: わたしの妹は、五才のときに、はいえんで亡くなりました。
ex_2_en: My younger sister died of pneumonia when she was five.
ex_3_jp: もし母さんが亡くなったら、僕の料理を作ってくれる人がいなくなってしまう。
ex_3_en: If my mom passes away, the person who makes food for me will be gone.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This word is actually two words put together, though. 亡く means "be deceased." なる means "to become." So put that all together and you have to pass away or to become deceased. It's basically a polite way to say something died (死ぬ).
reading_story: To learn to read this kanji you have to remember the な part of 亡く, though our mnemonic will use the whole thing. If you're about to become deceased, you are probably knocking (なく) on death's door.

ex_1_jp: かんとくは、ピッチャーを代えるだろう。
ex_1_en: The coach is replacing the pitcher, I think.
ex_2_jp: ふだんは、ヨーグルトをサワークリームに代えてつかっています。
ex_2_en: I usually substitute yogurt for sour cream.
ex_3_jp: この指輪をお金に代えることはできません。
ex_3_en: I can’t exchange this ring for money.
meaning_story: You know the kanji is substitute, and you know this is a verb. There are other similar ones, but this one means to replace. In order to remember that this particular word means "to replace" focus in on the え. You have an egg in your hands that you notice isn't any good (it's black and moldy). So, you replace it with another egg (or substitute it with another egg, or exchange it with another egg, etc).
reading_story: The reading for this one is the same as 代わる which you learned in a previous level. As long as you know that one you should be able to learn this one's reading as well.

ex_1_jp: かれも来ると思いますよ。
ex_1_en: I think he’s coming too.
ex_2_jp: ハリケーンのきせつはメキシコに行くのをさけた方がいいと思いますか。
ex_2_en: Do you think I should avoid going to Mexico during hurricane season?
ex_3_jp: 思うだけならまだ違法じゃないよ。
ex_3_en: The simple act of thinking is not illegal, yet.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means think so the verb version is to think.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the おも part to read this word. To do this, though, you'll have to think about that guy... hmm... what was his name? He's on The Simpsons... he's the bartender? I think? Oh! Moe (おも) is his name! Thank you. Now I remember. If you don't know Moe from the Simpsons use a different Moe, perhaps the one from the Three Stooges? You should be able to come up with one.

ex_1_jp: 学こうまで歩くつもりです。
ex_1_en: I’m planning to walk to school.
ex_2_jp: あなたと手をつないで歩くなんて、何年ぶりかしら。
ex_2_en: It's the first time we've walked holding hands in a long time.
ex_3_jp: 私はとても太いので、私が道を歩いる時にペニーを踏んだら、女王様の鼻から鼻くそが飛び出ます。
ex_3_en: I’m so fat that when I walk down the street and step on a penny, I squeeze a booger out of the Queen’s nose.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means walk so the verb version means to walk.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the ある portion. Imagine yourself going to walk outside. But, as you walk, you walk like a pirate. You have a peg leg, a parrot, and a hook. Lastly, you say "arrrrr" (ある). Go ahead, say it out loud while walking around your room like a pirate. It will help.

ex_1_jp: その曲の名まえ、何だったっけ。
ex_1_en: What was the name of that song?
ex_2_jp: 何かおすすめの曲はありますか？
ex_2_en: Are there any songs you would recommend?
ex_3_jp: 彼がピアノで一曲弾いてくれたんですが、何故かそのピアノはギターの様な音がしたんです。
ex_3_en: He played a tune for us on the piano, but for some reason, the piano sounded like a guitar.
meaning_story: This almost shares the meaning with the kanji. It's essentially the same thing, though when it's alone it refers to a specific piece of music (aka a tune).
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji as well, so you should be able to read it.

ex_1_jp: 地中は、冬にはあたたかく、なつはつめたいです。
ex_1_en: Underground it’s warm in the winter and cold in the summer.
ex_2_jp: 多くのみずうみは、地中の水ろでつながっています。
ex_2_en: Many of the lakes are connected by subterranean channels.
ex_3_jp: 地中の温度を測るにはどうすればいいですか。
ex_3_en: What do I need to do to gauge the temperature underground?
meaning_story: If you're in the middle of the ground, then you're most likely underground. Are you a moleperson? That's pretty cool.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: チチュー *** チチュꜜー

ex_1_jp: このたてものの地下に、トイレがあります。
ex_1_en: There is a restroom in the basement of this building.
ex_2_jp: デパ地下でたくさんし食をしました。
ex_2_en: I ate a lot of food samples at the food section of the department store basement.
ex_3_jp: ヨハネの黙示録がもうすぐ実現されるから、私は地下室を建設しているのだよ。
ex_3_en: The Apocalypse is coming soon so I’m building an underground cellar.
meaning_story: Below the ground is underground.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ごうかくしているか不安です。
ex_1_en: I’m anxious about passing.
ex_2_jp: 出さんを目前に不安な気もちでいっぱいです。
ex_2_en: I'm so nervous about the impending childbirth.
ex_3_jp: あの殺人事件を目撃してからというもの、不安を取り除くことができない。
ex_3_en: Since I witnessed the murder, I haven't been able to rid myself of these feelings of anxiety.
meaning_story: When you're not relaxed how do you feel? Uneasiness is what you'd feel.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このはなしの作しゃは不明です。
ex_1_en: The author of this story is unknown.
ex_2_jp: この牛にゅうのしょうみきげんは不明です。
ex_2_en: This milk doesn't have an expiration date on it.
ex_3_jp: え？寝る時、玉ねぎを枕にしたの？あんたの言ってること、意味不明なんだけど。
ex_3_en: Huh? When you were sleeping you used an onion for a pillow? I don’t really get what you’re saying.
meaning_story: Something that is not bright is cloudy and fuzzy. What do you think when you look into the fuzzy clouds? It is the unknown, the unclear, the uncertain.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あそこに見えているのは、金星です。
ex_1_en: What you see over there is Venus.
ex_2_jp: 金星の学こうには、うんどう会はありますか？
ex_2_en: Do they have Sports Day in the school on Venus?
ex_3_jp: 人類はいつか金星に移住することになるだろう。
ex_3_en: Someday humans will migrate to Venus.
meaning_story: The gold star is Venus. It's the only planet in our solar system that's the same color as gold.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 星 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you point your telescope at Venus you'll see Hard Gay shouting Sei, (せい) sei, sei! all over the planet. I hear he's going on a universe tour sei-ing on every planet.
pitch_accent: キンセイ *** キꜜンボシ

ex_1_jp: 冬休みに、かぞくで山の中のホテルにとまりました。
ex_1_en: During winter break my family stayed in a hotel in the mountains.
ex_2_jp: 冬休みは子どもたちがいえで兄弟げんかばっかりしていて大へんでした。
ex_2_en: Winter holiday was pretty tough because my sons fight so often at home.
ex_3_jp: 冬休みは、毎日一日中ジョギングをしていました。
ex_3_en: During winter vacation, I jogged everyday, all day long.
meaning_story: The winter rest! Wait, nobody calls it that. This is a winter holiday or winter break.
reading_story: The readings for these are both the kun'yomi readings. Hopefully you learned them when you were doing vocab in the previous levels so that all you have to do now is combine the two separate words into one bigger word. Please don't take a winter break until you figure this word out.

ex_1_jp: クリスマスプレゼントに、羊毛のブランケットをもらいました。
ex_1_en: I got a wool blanket as a Christmas present.
ex_2_jp: この羊毛フェルトの人形に出会えて本当によかった。
ex_2_en: I'm so happy to have come across this wool felt doll.
ex_3_jp: 羊毛の手袋は、枕の詰め物に適している。
ex_3_en: Woolen mittens are great for stuffing pillows.
meaning_story: A sheep's fur is wool.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ころんで手首をひねった。
ex_1_en: I fell and twisted my wrist.
ex_2_jp: あぶらが手首にはねてヤケドしてしまった。
ex_2_en: Hot oil splashed on my wrist and I got burned.
ex_3_jp: 双子の妹には、手首にホクロがあるんだ。
ex_3_en: My twin sister has a mole on her wrist.
meaning_story: Your hand's neck is your wrist!
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!

ex_1_jp: もり田さんには、年下のかの女がいます。
ex_1_en: Morita has a younger girlfriend.
ex_2_jp: コウイチはアーノルドシュワルツネッガーより三十八才年下だ。
ex_2_en: Koichi is 38 years younger than Arnold Schwarzenegger.
ex_3_jp: あの子は年下なのにとても大人びている。
ex_3_en: Even though that kid is younger, he’s really mature.
meaning_story: When you have someone who has years below your own, this person is younger than you.
reading_story: The reading for this one is kind of strange. It is the kun'yomi reading for both of the kanji. You know the kun'yomi readings from earlier, back when you learned the vocab 年 and 下.

ex_1_jp: 田中さんの妹はどの人ですか。
ex_1_en: Who is Tanaka’s younger sister?
ex_2_jp: 妹にうら切られた気分です。
ex_2_en: I feel betrayed by my little sister.
ex_3_jp: 私の妹は、バービー人形にウィッグを作ってあげたいからと、自分の髪の毛を切った。
ex_3_en: My younger sister just cut off all of her hair so she could make wigs for her Barbie dolls.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your younger sister is really into emotes (いもうと). Look up this word if you're not a teenage girl. Just imagine her sending you these on your phone over and over. You tell your younger sister: "HEY, STOP SENDING ME EMOTES."

ex_1_jp: 先回りして、まちぶせしよう！
ex_1_en: Let’s go ahead and ambush them!
ex_2_jp: リクはとてもせっかちで、いつも人の話をかっ手によそうして先回りして話すから、すごくイライラするんだよね。
ex_2_en: Riku is very impatient, and always tries to guess what I'm going to say before I've said it, and it's been really annoying me.
ex_3_jp: 彼は先回りをして富士山の頂上に着いており、私のことをのろまと笑った。
ex_3_en: He beat me to the top of Mt. Fuji and then laughed at me for being slow.
meaning_story: If you know of something that happens previous to something rotating (回り), you will then be in anticipation of its actions and rotations based on previous knowledge.
reading_story: This consists of a couple kun'yomi readings put together. You can tell it's kun'yomi because of the hiragana sticking out at the end. In the previous level you learned both the words 先 and 回る (verb version of 回り). If you know those, you should be able to put them together to learn the reading of this word as well.
pitch_accent: サキマꜜワリ *** サキマワリ

ex_1_jp: わたしは、日本の考古学にきょうみがあります。
ex_1_en: I’m interested in Japanese archeology.
ex_2_jp: 今月末でこの考古学のしごとをやめるんです。
ex_2_en: I'm going to quit this archeology job at the end of the month.
ex_3_jp: この大学では、考古学を学べます。
ex_3_en: You can study archeology at this university.
meaning_story: If you often think about studying old things, it's called archeology. All archeology involves thinking about old things, at least a little bit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 考 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who is the best at archeology? Why こういち, of course. He can spend hours and hours thinking and studying old things buried in the sand.

ex_1_jp: その辺に、ホテルはありますか。
ex_1_en: Is there a hotel around there?
ex_2_jp: あの辺はごう雪地たいです。
ex_2_en: They have very heavy snowfall in that region.
ex_3_jp: 正三角形の辺の長さから、高さと面積が計算できます。
ex_3_en: I can calculate the height and area from the length of an equilateral triangle.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 辺りはしーんとしずまりかえっていた。
ex_1_en: The area fell silent.
ex_2_jp: そうだ、ちょっと言いわすれていたんだけど、この辺りにえきはないからね。
ex_2_en: Oh, I forgot to tell you that there is no station in this neighborhood.
ex_3_jp: 彼のトイレはこの辺りに違いない。
ex_3_en: His bathroom must be somewhere around here.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji for area. This makes it have the same meaning as the kanji: area or vicinity.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you think about an area that you're in, it's the place you're at (あた).
pitch_accent: アꜜタリ *** ホトリ *** ホトリꜜ

ex_1_jp: この辺は、人が少ないのでしずかです。
ex_1_en: There aren’t many people around here, so it’s quiet.
ex_2_jp: この辺に、スタバはありますか？
ex_2_en: Is there Starbucks around here?
ex_3_jp: この辺では、言葉に気をつけた方がいいぜ。町のこちら側に住んでいるやつらは、口笛を吹いただけでも顔に唾をぶっかけてきやがるからな。
ex_3_en: You have to be careful about what you say around here. People on this side of town will spit in your face just for whistling.
meaning_story: この means "this" so この辺 just means this area.
reading_story: The reading for the kanji portion is just what you've already learned with the kanji 辺 so this shouldn't be a difficult one to read for you.

ex_1_jp: あこがれの作家さんから、サインをもらいました。
ex_1_en: I got an autograph from an aspiring author.
ex_2_jp: この作家、ずいぶん思い切ったね。
ex_2_en: This novelist pushed things pretty far, eh?
ex_3_jp: あのベストセラー作家の趣味はサッカーだ。
ex_3_en: That best-selling author’s hobby is playing soccer.
meaning_story: This is a strange one. You make a house. You'd think this would mean something like "building a house" or "construction" or something. Instead, it means author. Think of it this way: An author builds a house and home for all the characters in his/her books. The book is like the home he's making for them. Who's the one making this house? It's the author.
reading_story: The readings are on'yomi readings, though さく from 作 gets shortened to さっ. Just be sure to remember that and you should be able to read this word just fine.

ex_1_jp: あのピエロが、風船で犬を作ってくれたんだ。
ex_1_en: That clown made a dog out of a balloon for me.
ex_2_jp: ひ行きによったば合は、この風船をエチケットぶくろの代わりにごしようください。
ex_2_en: Please use this balloon as a motion sickness bag when you feel air sick.
ex_3_jp: 風船を使って実際に空飛ぶ家を作った人たちがいます。
ex_3_en: Some people actually made a house float using balloons.
meaning_story: A wind boat. This is a strange one for sure. You may assume this is like one of those giant balloons you can go ride around in, and you'd be partly right. Really, this word covers the general word balloon, though it especially has to do with the toy-style balloons (or smaller balloons). It's a little round wind ship!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: ちかぢか, きんきん, ちかじか
ex_1_jp: それについては、近々はっぴょうがあると思いますよ。
ex_1_en: I think there will be an announcement about it soon.
ex_2_jp: 近々雪がふるはずなので、たくさんつもったらかまくらを作ります。
ex_2_en: We're supposed to get snow soon, so if we get a lot, I will make a snow igloo.
ex_3_jp: もしタバコを吸い続けるなら、あなたは近々癌を発症するでしょう。
ex_3_en: You’ll get cancer before long if you keep smoking.
meaning_story: When something is close close (the 々 character repeats the kanji that was before it) it will happen before long.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi reading twice; that's the one you learn with the vocab word 近い from the previous level. The second 近 gets converted to ぢか, though, so take note of that.

ex_1_jp: この公えんには、きれいな鳥がたくさんいます。
ex_1_en: There are a lot of beautiful birds in this park.
ex_2_jp: けさカーテンをあけたら、何もかもが鳥のふんにおおわれていました。
ex_2_en: When I opened my curtain this morning, everything was covered with bird poop.
ex_3_jp: 自分が鳥だったらいいのになと思うよ。だって、そうすればもう鳥みたいに歩いているとからかわれないだろうからね。
ex_3_en: I wish I was a bird because then I wouldn’t get made fun of for walking like one.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: When you think about birds, what is the most common bird you can think of? What bird do you hate the most or like eating the most? Either one will work. Now, imagine yourself going up to that bird. You did something terrible. You tore (とり) off its wing and started eating it (pretend it's cooked first, if that makes you less nauseous).

ex_1_jp: その上の、黒いぼう子をとってください。
ex_1_en: Can you get me the black hat up there?
ex_2_jp: あの黒ひげの男ははら黒いことで有名です。
ex_2_en: That man with the black goatee is notorious for being black-hearted.
ex_3_jp: 私の一番好きなテレビ番組は、「黒い画面」です。この番組は、停電になった時だけ放送されます。
ex_3_en: My favorite channel on TV is called "Black Screen." It only airs when the power goes off.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of black? It's also black. Special Note: The noun version of black also exists in Japanese. It is just 黒 with the same pronunciation, but minus the い which makes it adjective-tastic.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think of black things. One very common black thing is the common crow (くろ). Associate those two together.

ex_1_jp: なぜ未だに黒人をさべつする人がいるのか、りかいできません。
ex_1_en: I can’t understand how there are still people who discriminate against black people.
ex_2_jp: おれは黒人であいつは白人だけど、それがどうしたの？
ex_2_en: I'm black, he's white. What's wrong with that?
ex_3_jp: ピーナッツバターは、ジョージ・ワシントン・カーヴァーという名の黒人によって発明された。
ex_3_en: Peanut butter was invented by a black person named George Washington Carver.
meaning_story: A black person is simply a black person, kind of like how a 白人 is a "white person," but a different color.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 青空のせいで海は青いの？
ex_1_en: Is the ocean blue because of the blue sky?
ex_2_jp: 未来の子どもたちに、今と同じくらいうつくしい青空をのこしてあげましょうよ。
ex_2_en: Let our future generations have the same beautiful sky as we do.
ex_3_jp: 今日は一日中晴れて、青空が広がっていました。
ex_3_en: Today, it was sunny all day and the blue sky was above us.
meaning_story: This is simply a blue sky (aka a blue sky!).
reading_story: You'd think that this word would use on'yomi readings to read it, but it doesn't (shake that angry fist at the kanji gods!). Instead, it's double kun'yomi, probably because this word is really like two separate words put together, "blue" and "sky." In the previous level you unlocked these two separate words, learning their readings. That means you should be able to read this as well. One quick note is the rendaku-fication of 空 as well. It becomes ぞら.

ex_1_jp: 次の船は、何時に出ぱつしますか。
ex_1_en: What time will the next ship leave?
ex_2_jp: 船にのると必ず船よいしちゃうんだよね。
ex_2_en: I always feel sea sick when I'm on a boat.
ex_3_jp: 俺様が船のすべてを取り仕切る船長だ。
ex_3_en: I’m the captain and I run this entire ship by myself.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're riding in a boat. It's great. Imagine it being the best time you've had in your life. You tell everyone: "This is fun, eh?" (ふね). You're on a Canadian ship, which is why you add the "eh" in there. Say this out loud wherever you are right now while imagining the sea smell, the wind, and the excitement of boats.

ex_1_jp: 学生は、教室ではじめに何をしますか。
ex_1_en: What will the students do in the classroom first?
ex_2_jp: かれは教室でタバコをくわえたところを、先生に目げきされました。
ex_2_en: The teacher witnessed him putting a cigarette in his mouth in the classroom.
ex_3_jp: 先生がいなくなったのはたったの五分間だけだったが、大学生たちは完璧に教室を滅茶苦茶にしてしまった。
ex_3_en: The teacher had only been gone for five minutes, but the university students had completely trashed the classroom.
meaning_story: The teaching room is just a classroom.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このどうしの活用形を教えてください。
ex_1_en: Please teach me the conjugated form of this verb.
ex_2_jp: 昨日から、じょどうしの活用形をべんきょうし直してます。
ex_2_en: Yesterday, I started re-learning the conjugated form of auxiliary verbs.
ex_3_jp: この辞書アプリでは、活用形から動詞の逆引き検索も可能です。
ex_3_en: In this dictionary app it’s possible to lookup verbs using their conjugated forms.
meaning_story: You know that 活用 means "conjugation" and that 〜形 means "form, so that means this is the conjugated form!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あなたの日記も、この本と一しょにここにおいておきます。
ex_1_en: I’m going to leave your diary with this book here.
ex_2_jp: 北米には、こうかん日記みたいな文化はないんだよ。
ex_2_en: We don't have a culture of diary exchange in North America.
ex_3_jp: 昨日の夜、フグの日記を読んだんだけどさ、実はとても悲しい日記だったんだよね。
ex_3_en: I read Fugu’s journal last night and, to be honest, it was really sad.
meaning_story: When you write down your day (and do it every day) that's your diary.
reading_story: This jukugo word uses the on'yomi readings, except the 日 (にち) is shortened with a small っ, making the reading にっき.

ex_1_jp: ぼくのかの女は、同じ町の二丁目にすんでいるミイコちゃんです。
ex_1_en: My girlfriend Miiko lives in 2-chome too.
ex_2_jp: その台風で、一丁目と二丁目がしん水してしまいました。
ex_2_en: The typhoon flooded both 1-chome and 2-chome.
ex_3_jp: この桃、三丁目の田中さんから頂いたの。
ex_3_en: I got this peach from Tanaka of 3-chome.
meaning_story: A street you can see with your eye isn't soooo big you can't see it (like a town would be), but it's still pretty big because it has a street. This section of the town is the district of a town, or a city block (though specifically one of an irregular size).
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, so use those and you'll be A-Okay.

ex_1_jp: たん生日プレゼントに、人形をもって行きます。
ex_1_en: I’m going to bring a doll for her birthday present.
ex_2_jp: その人形、ちゃんと元のところにもどしておいてね。
ex_2_en: Put the doll back the way you found it.
ex_3_jp: 17歳まで、私の親友は靴下で作った腕人形だった。
ex_3_en: Until the age of 17, my best friend was a sock puppet.
meaning_story: Something that is person shaped that isn't a person? That has to be some kind of doll or puppet.
reading_story: The reading for 人 is pretty normal, though the reading for 形 is different from the one you learned. To remember this, think of a doll... made totally of gyoza (ぎょう) dumplings. This doll is crazy (like most dolls) and it's eating itself and trying to get you to eat some of it too. Hey... why you no eat me? Mmmm. Gyoza doll.
pitch_accent: ニンキ°ョー *** ヒトカ°タ

ex_1_jp: 小学生だからって、あまく見てるとけがするぜ！
ex_1_en: I may just be an elementary school student, but if you underestimate me, you'll regret it!
ex_2_jp: きょうしつのドアをあけると、一人の小学生が石ころみたいにぐっすりねむっていました。
ex_2_en: When I opened the classroom door, there was a grade schooler sleeping like a rock.
ex_3_jp: 小学生の頃、いつもコインを投げて自分の行動を決めていました。
ex_3_en: When I was an elementary school student, I always made my decisions by flipping a coin.
meaning_story: You know 学生 is student, so what is a small student? Think young. That would be a Elementary School Student.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 月末までに五キロやせます。
ex_1_en: I’m going to lose five kilos by the end of this month.
ex_2_jp: ここ、ブラックきぎょうすぎるから、月末ににげ出すわ。
ex_2_en: This company exploits its employees too much, so I'm bailing out at the end of the month!
ex_3_jp: 私の上司は、コアラで給料を払います。毎月末、わたしには二匹のコアラが支払われます。
ex_3_en: My boss pays me in koala bears. I get two at the end of every month.
meaning_story: You know how 月 can also mean month? If you add 末 on there you have the "month end" aka the end of the month.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ゲツマツ *** ツキズエ *** ツキズꜜエ

ex_1_jp: 魚はすきですが、生魚はにが手です。
ex_1_en: I like fish, but I don’t like it raw.
ex_2_jp: バランスのいいちょう食をとるために、いつもグラノーラと魚を食べます。
ex_2_en: I always eat granola and fish for a well-balanced breakfast.
ex_3_jp: もう絶対にメキシコの軽トラの積み荷から魚を買うもんか。
ex_3_en: I’ll never buy fish from the back of a pickup truck in Mexico again.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Imagine a fish. Now imagine the fish playing soccer, while wearing a nun's outfit. This is a soccer nun (さかな).

ex_1_jp: 必死にがんばっても、どうにもならないこともある。
ex_1_en: Even if I try desperately, it might still be futile.
ex_2_jp: わたしのそ父は、必死のかくごでせんじょうに向かったそうです。
ex_2_en: I heard that my grandfather went to the war front prepared to die.
ex_3_jp: 「隊長、私はどうしても火星に戻る必要があるんです。アイフォンを忘れてしまったのです。」彼は必死に頼んだ。
ex_3_en: "Captain, I really need to return to Mars. I left my iPhone there," he said desperately.
meaning_story: Your future consists of certain death. How would you feel in this situation? Probably very frantic and desperate. Another translation for this word is simply certain death, though I'd rather you learn one of the first two before this one if you can.
reading_story: The readings are the on'yomi readings, though 必 (ひつ) gets shortened to ひっ. In your desperate situation just imagine that you're trying to get out of it, and to do so you move the つ only to find a smaller っ blocking your way. It is certain death.

ex_1_jp: 一人ぐらしをはじめて、自由なじかんができました。
ex_1_en: I started living by myself and I have some free time to spare.
ex_2_jp: 自由になるための道のりはまだまだとおいですが、ぜったいにあきらめません。
ex_2_en: To obtain freedom, we still have a long way to go, but we will never give up.
ex_3_jp: 日本のサラリーマンが自由に使えるお金は、毎月平均たった三万五千円だ。
ex_3_en: The money Japanese salarymen can use freely every month is, on average, usually only 35,000 yen.
meaning_story: When you have self reason, you are able to think for yourself. When you can think for yourself, you have freedom. Very philosophical this vocab is.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 自分の氏名ぐらいは、日本ごでかけるようになりたいよね。
ex_1_en: You at least want to be able to write your full name in Japanese, right?
ex_2_jp: ごさん考までに、わたしの氏名は、高 一子です。
ex_2_en: For your information, my name is Ichiko Ko.
ex_3_jp: そちらの誓約書に氏名をご記入頂ければ、大砲で貴方の頭の上の林檎を撃ちぬいて差し上げます。
ex_3_en: If you would please write your first and last name on the waiver, we will proceed with shooting an apple off of your head with a cannon.
meaning_story: Both of these kanji have to do with names. You have both family name and name. Both of those names together makes for a First And Last Name... a full name if you will.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: タイムスリップできるなら、未来に行きたいな。
ex_1_en: If I could time travel, I’d want to go to the future.
ex_2_jp: 週末は、未来とか去を行ったり来たりしていました。
ex_2_en: On the weekend, I was traveling back and forth through time.
ex_3_jp: コウイチにはうちゅうひ行しとしての大きな未来があるんだから、たのむからじゃましないでやってくれよ。
ex_3_en: Koichi has a bright future as an astronaut, so please don't interrupt him.
meaning_story: What has not yet come? The future.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 一人で地理のべん強をするのもすきですが、友だちとべん強する方がたのしいです。
ex_1_en: I like studying geography by myself too, but it’s more fun to study with my friend.
ex_2_jp: アメリカ人の友人は地理が全くのにが手で、さい近まで日本が中国の首とだとおもっていたらしい。
ex_2_en: My American friend is not good at geography at all, so I heard that she used to think Japan was the capital of China until very recently.
ex_3_jp: 俺たちが道に迷ったってどういうことだよ？お前、地理の先公じゃねえのかよ？
ex_3_en: What do you mean we’re lost? Aren’t you a geography teacher?
meaning_story: The reason the earth is the way it is is because of the geography of it. Though it may seem kind of strange that geography is bringing reason to the earth, if you think of geography as a study, then you can think about how you try to get reason through that, as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: これは、五年前の夏まつりの金魚すくいですくった金魚です。
ex_1_en: I scooped this goldfish at a goldfish scooping booth during a summer festival five years ago.
ex_2_jp: 金魚もかぜをひくんですか？
ex_2_en: Can goldfish get colds, too?
ex_3_jp: 金魚は、三秒間しか記憶がないので、自分たちがお城に住んでいることに気がづく度に驚いています。
ex_3_en: Goldfish only have three second memories so they’re always surprised when they realize that they live in a castle.
meaning_story: A gold fish is really just gold in color, but it's still called a goldfish.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: これから、みなさんを二組に分けます。
ex_1_en: After this, we’ll be splitting into two teams.
ex_2_jp: オレたちの組はこの辺じゃ有名なんだぜ。
ex_2_en: Our group is famous around here.
ex_3_jp: 三年二組のコウイチくん、またこく白されたらしいよ。
ex_3_en: I heard Koichi in grade 3 class 2 was asked out again.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're part of a special group. It is the cumin group, and they deal with all things cumin (the spice / seed). Smell the cumin. Touch it. Taste it. You live and breathe the stuff, because you are the president of this cumin group. P.S. This can also be spelled 組み (same overall reading: くみ).

ex_1_jp: このテーブルは、林さんの手作りです。
ex_1_en: This table was handmade by Hayashi.
ex_2_jp: 毎日手作りのバランスのいい食じをとるようにしています。
ex_2_en: I try to have a homemade, well-balanced diet every day.
ex_3_jp: 手作りのプレゼントは、どれだけ暇な時間があるかってことがバレてしまうので、結構怖い。
ex_3_en: Handmade presents are pretty scary because they reveal that you have too much free time.
meaning_story: When something is made with hand, it is handmade.
reading_story: The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. Just think of this word as two separate words put together (手 and 作る). The る in 作る gets changed to り because it's a noun, and the つ in つくり gets changed to づ because of the way the words are combined with each other. You should know most of the reading that is in this word, though it will probably take a little bit of thinking to sort out the little changes in those readings.

ex_1_jp: 大空を見ていたら、いやな気もちがふきとんだ。
ex_1_en: The unpleasant feeling vanished when I looked up at the sky.
ex_2_jp: アイリちゃんは大空にうかぶお星さまになったんだよ。
ex_2_en: Airi became a star in the firmament.
ex_3_jp: 鷲が大空を悠々と飛んでいた。
ex_3_en: The eagle flew leisurely in the heavens.
meaning_story: The big thing in the sky is the heavens. The heavens where birds and planes soar, not the one you go to after you die if you've been really good.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that そら becomes ぞら because of rendaku here.

ex_1_jp: 高校まで、車で行けば十分ですよ。
ex_1_en: It only takes 10 minutes to get to the high school if you drive.
ex_2_jp: 高校ではいつも、おひるにどんなものを食べていますか？
ex_2_en: What kind of food do you guys usually have for lunch in high school?
ex_3_jp: 高校に行って初めて話をし始めたんです。そして、今は、話を止めることができません。
ex_3_en: I didn’t start talking until I went to high school. Now I can’t shut up.
meaning_story: The tall school is for when your kids get about as tall as they're going to get. That's high school, when most people stop growing taller.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: みなさん、家にあそびに来てください。
ex_1_en: Everyone, please stop by my house.
ex_2_jp: いいかげん、家をかた付けた方がいいよ。
ex_2_en: You really need to clean your house.
ex_3_jp: 家とは、みんなの心と食べ物がある場所です。
ex_3_en: Home is where the heart is. And the food.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You visit your friend's home. However, this home isn't any normal home. They live at the video game company EA (いえ). Imagine yourself going to your friend's home from school every day. You go to EA, settle in, and play some video games. What a great home that would be to visit. There's another reading as well, though, and it's うち. This reading is used for your own home. For someone else's home you'd use いえ, though.

ex_1_jp: おいしいマカロニチーズの作り方を教えてください。
ex_1_en: Please teach me how to make delicious macaroni and cheese.
ex_2_jp: 麦茶の作り方には、おゆでわかしながらに出す方ほう、ふっとうさせたおゆでジワジワおゆ出しする方ほう、つめたい水でジワジワ水出しする方ほうの三しゅるいありますが、それぞれメリットデメリットがあります。
ex_2_en: There are three ways to make barley tea; steeping it in boiling water, steeping it slowly in boiled water, and steeping it slowly in cold water, and each comes with pros and cons.
ex_3_jp: 手裏剣の作り方を知りたいですか？
ex_3_en: Do you want to know how to make a ninja star?
meaning_story: This is the way to make something. This is how to make something. You'll see this for directions on building something.
reading_story: You should know the kun'yomi readings for both of these from lower level vocab. Use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.
pitch_accent: ツクリカタꜜ *** ツクリカꜜタ

ex_1_jp: 船体にらくがきをしたのはだれだ！？
ex_1_en: Who graffitied the hull?
ex_2_jp: クラーケンがしょく手で船体をつきやぶったんだ。
ex_2_en: The kraken smashed its tentacles through the ship's hull.
ex_3_jp: 船体は思った以上に大きかった。
ex_3_en: The hull was bigger than I thought.
meaning_story: A boat's body is called the hull.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: セꜜンタイ *** センタイ

ex_1_jp: 大きくいきをついてください。
ex_1_en: Please exhale deeply.
ex_2_jp: このトウフ＆フグのピザチェーンは、大きくきぼをかく大している。
ex_2_en: This Tofu & Fugu pizza chain is expanding its franchise in a big way.
ex_3_jp: 円の価値が大きく上昇した。
ex_3_en: The value of yen has risen greatly.
meaning_story: This is the adverb version of the kanji big It's a little thing you can put in front of things to say that they are "in a big way" or "on a grand scale."
reading_story: Since you already know the reading of the vocab word 大きい, you should be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: 一万円札を小ぜににくずしてもらえませんか？
ex_1_en: Could you give me change for a 10,000 yen bill?
ex_2_jp: この二千円札、千円札二枚と両がえしてくれない？
ex_2_en: Can you break this 2,000 yen bill to two 1,000 yen bills, please?
ex_3_jp: トーフグのオフィスのあちこちに、百ドル札が隠されているらしいぜ。
ex_3_en: Apparently, there are many hundred-dollar bills hidden all over the Tofugu office.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji (and is a suffix), it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You can't find your label anywhere. It was on your lapel, you swear, but now it's nowhere to be found. You forget about it for a while, then you eat your dinner (you're at a fancy dinner party). As you finish up your meal you see something. Your label fell into your food (ふだ)!

ex_1_jp: 先週は学校はお休みでした。
ex_1_en: School was out last week.
ex_2_jp: 大きくなったねー。先週はまだあんなに小さかったのに。
ex_2_en: You sure have grown a lot! You were still tiny last week though.
ex_3_jp: 先週出席した経済相互援助会議で、喋る犬にインタビューされたんだが、あいつは本当に嫌なやつだった。
ex_3_en: I was interviewed by a talking dog about the Comecon convention I attended last week. He was so insulting.
meaning_story: The previous week was last week.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 五千円以下の本だなをさがしています。
ex_1_en: I’m looking for a bookshelf that’s 5,000 yen or less.
ex_2_jp: コウイチのすきなネコのしゅるいは以下の通りです。
ex_2_en: The list of cat breeds that Koichi likes is as follows:
ex_3_jp: 以下同文です。
ex_3_en: Those below are the same.
meaning_story: When you're doing something by means of below, you're using less than you need. You're definitely not exceeding the amount you need, at least.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 外国に手紙を出しました。
ex_1_en: I sent a letter to a foreign country.
ex_2_jp: その金正日からの手紙、ネットオークションに出しちゃえば？きっとだれかしらかうと思うよ。
ex_2_en: Why don't you put up the letter from Kim Jong Il for online auction? I think somebody would buy it.
ex_3_jp: 私はコカコーラ宛に、心のこもった手紙を書いて、どうして彼らの製品にたくさん砂糖が入っているのかについて尋ねたいと思います。
ex_3_en: I’m going to write a very heated letter to Coca-Cola and ask why there is so much sugar in their products.
meaning_story: A hand paper being a letter seems kind of strange, but think of it this way: Paper that you can fit in your hand? That's good for a letter. Also, you could write a letter on your hand if you want, though it would hurt a lot to chop off your hand and send it (imagine doing this).
reading_story: The reading is double kun'yomi (body parts tend to make kanji in words change to a kun'yomi reading). Both kanji in this word had you learn that reading right from the start, though, so you should be able to read this word. Just watch out for the rendaku making it がみ, not かみ.

ex_1_jp: 二人とも、どうして小声ではなしているの？
ex_1_en: Why are they both whispering?
ex_2_jp: 「ビエトに学ランをきてもらいたいんだ。に合うと思うんだよね。」と、わたしのもうそうの中でコウイチがビエトに小声で言った。
ex_2_en: "I want you to try on a school uniform. I think you'll look good in it." Koichi whispered to Viet in my fantasy.
ex_3_jp: 男は、小声で話し始めた。
ex_3_en: The man started speaking in a low voice.
meaning_story: A small voice is so small that you can hardly hear it. It's a low voice or a whisper.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because, like in 大声, the こえ becomes ごえ thanks to our old friend rendaku.

ex_1_jp: ねこの心理を思うがままにあやつれるようになりたい。
ex_1_en: I want to be able to manipulate cat's minds as much as I want.
ex_2_jp: 春人以外の男どもには、女せいのせんさいな心理は分からないんだよ。
ex_2_en: Men, with the exception of Haruto, don't understand the delicate psychology of women.
ex_3_jp: サーモンと彼女に翻弄される人々の心理を、君の小説で描いてみてもらえないかな？人気が出ると思うんだけど。
ex_3_en: Can you depict the mental state of Salmon and those she deceives in your novel? I think people would love it.
meaning_story: The reasoning that your heart makes decides what you do. Probably when kanji was being made people thought that the heart directed our actions, not our brains. So, if you think about it that way, the reasoning of your heart is your mental state. Nowadays that's known as psychology.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 中学生にもなって、まだお母さんといっしょにおふろに入ってるんですか？
ex_1_en: You are a middle schooler now, but you're still taking baths with your mom?
ex_2_jp: かち目のないたたかいはしない方がいいということは、中学生でも知っているよ。
ex_2_en: Even a junior high student knows that you should choose your battles wisely.
ex_3_jp: 中学生の頃、自分自身に、「書かなくても覚えられるから大丈夫」という大法螺をふいてしまいました。
ex_3_en: When I was a middle school student, the biggest lie I said to myself was, "I can remember that without writing it down."
meaning_story: You've seen 学生 (means student). Now let's look at a student who's in the middle. Perhaps we can call this a middle school student or a junior high school student, depending on where you're from.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: チューカ°ꜜクセイ *** チューカ°クꜜセイ

ex_1_jp: やはり、アベ氏のはつげんはいつも全くブレませんね。
ex_1_en: As we all know, Mr. Abe’s statements never change.
ex_2_jp: コウイチ氏とビエト氏はとても気が合う。
ex_2_en: Mr. Koichi and Mr. Viet have good chemistry.
ex_3_jp: おお、ホワイト氏、ちょっと座れば？
ex_3_en: Yo, Mr. White, why don’t you just sit down?
meaning_story: The kanji means family name because it goes after a family name in very formal situations. So, it's really closely tied to that. Because only men got the respect back in the day, we're calling this vocab word mister. You can call me Mr. Koichi if you'd like, too.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji.

ex_1_jp: このえいがは、十八才以上しか見れません。
ex_1_en: Only people 18 or older can watch this movie.
ex_2_jp: 手つづきは以上です。
ex_2_en: That's all for the paperwork.
ex_3_jp: １００歳以上の人は、必ずブラジャーを着用し無くてはならない。
ex_3_en: People who are 100 years old or older must wear bras.
meaning_story: When you're doing something by means of above, you're using more than you need. This is a weird word though, it also means that's all. Just think that if you're using "more than" you need, you'll probably say "that's all" at some point because it's too much.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今は、学校の近くに、姉とすんでいます。
ex_1_en: I’m currently living with my sister near the school.
ex_2_jp: あのアイドル、近くで見るとあんまりかわいくないね。
ex_2_en: Seen close up, that teen idol is not pretty at all, huh?
ex_3_jp: 近くの焼き鳥屋で、一杯ひっかけていかないか。
ex_3_en: Don’t you want to have a drink at the yakitori shop nearby?
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji near. So it also means near, or in the neighborhood of something.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 近い, so you should be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: 来週の日よう日にレストランに行きます。
ex_1_en: I’m going to a restaurant next Sunday.
ex_2_jp: 来週はどれぐらい雪がふるかな？
ex_2_en: I wonder how much snow we'll get next week.
ex_3_jp: 飲み会は来週に延期になりました。
ex_3_en: The drinking party was postponed until next week.
meaning_story: The next week is the next week. It isn't last week or this week, it's the next one!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 未だ二百才まで生きた人げんはいない。
ex_1_en: There’s still never been a person who’s lived to two hundred years old.
ex_2_jp: 未だ、時さボケがあるんですよね。
ex_2_en: I’m still jet-lagged.
ex_3_jp: 仕事が決まったのかどうかは未だ分からないんだ。向こうは未だ、十二人も面接しなきゃいけないみたい。
ex_3_en: I’m not sure if I got the job yet. It seems like they still have to interview twelve other applicants.
meaning_story: This is the adverb version of 未, meaning it means the same thing: not yet.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone's telling you "not yet... not yet.... not yet..." you have some food on your nose, but you're not allowed to eat it until your ma says it's okay. "Not yet... Not yet..." Why would your mom treat you like a dog like this? Oh well... maybe she'll let you eat the food soon, at least.
pitch_accent: イマダ *** イꜜマダ *** マꜜダ

pronunciation: かいぎょ, うみざかな
ex_1_jp: さけは海魚ですか？それとも川魚ですか？
ex_1_en: Is salmon a saltwater fish? Or is it a freshwater fish?
ex_2_jp: 海中には、色とりどりの海魚がおよいでいました。
ex_2_en: In the sea, there were a lot of colorful ocean fish swimming around.
ex_3_jp: 水族館には沢山の種類の海魚がいますが、スタッフは僕達に一匹も食べてはいけませんと言いました。
ex_3_en: There is a wide variety of saltwater fish at the aquarium, but the staff said we’re not allowed to eat any of them.
meaning_story: An ocean fish is simply an ocean fish. They also happen to be the most delicious kind of fish.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 三時になったらおやつ休けいにしましょう。
ex_1_en: When it’s three o’clock let’s have our afternoon snack break.
ex_2_jp: コウイチの家の台どころで二時半にまちあわせね。
ex_2_en: Let's meet up at Koichi's kitchen at 2:30, ok?
ex_3_jp: いつも何時にワニカニのレビューをしますか？
ex_3_en: What time do you usually do your Wanikani reviews?
meaning_story: If there's a number before it's referring to the hour. For example, if you see １時 it is "1:00." If you see ２３時 it's 23:00 or 11pm.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 毎日一時かんぐらいおふろに入ります。
ex_1_en: I take a bath for about an hour every day.
ex_2_jp: 一時までにおもちゃをかたづけなさい。
ex_2_en: Put your toys away by one o'clock.
ex_3_jp: もし私のところで働くなら、あなたのシフトは午後一時から遅くとも三時までになりますが、よろしいですか？
ex_3_en: If you worked for me, your shift would start at one o’clock in the afternoon and end at three o’clock at latest. Sounds good?
meaning_story: When it's one o'clock it's time to eat lunch, or take a nap, or something. It's also one o'clock.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: イチꜜジ *** イットキ *** イットキꜜ

ex_1_jp: ビール以外ならなんでもいいです。
ex_1_en: I’m okay with anything other than beer.
ex_2_jp: マンガ以外は何もよみません。
ex_2_en: I read nothing but manga.
ex_3_jp: 式の間中新郎が花嫁の胸元を上から眺めていたこと以外は、とても素敵な結婚式でした。
ex_3_en: Other than the groom looking down the front of the bride’s dress during the ceremony, it was a nice wedding.
meaning_story: By means of outside sources. You are using something other than what you are provided with. That's why you had to pull from the outside.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 紙とえんぴつとけしゴムをつくえに出してください。
ex_1_en: Please put some paper, a pencil, and an eraser on your desk.
ex_2_jp: あたらしい紙をかうのがたのしみでしかたがない。
ex_2_en: I'm so looking forward to buying a new piece of paper.
ex_3_jp: 昨日、紙の切れ端に詩を書いている狼を見かけた。
ex_3_en: Yesterday, I saw a wolf writing a poem on a piece of paper.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but lucky for you that's the reading you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this vocab too.

ex_1_jp: 今の時代は、インターネットで何でもかうことができます。
ex_1_en: In this era, you can buy anything on the Internet.
ex_2_jp: 明里は、わたしの大学時代の友人です。
ex_2_en: Akari is my friend from college.
ex_3_jp: 紫式部は、平安時代中期の女性作家かつ歌人です。
ex_3_en: Murasaki Shikibu was a female writer and poet from the mid–Heian period.
meaning_story: You have a period of time and it's called a period or era! Simple!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 以前、パーティーで一どお会いしましたよね。
ex_1_en: I met you once before at a party, right?
ex_2_jp: 以前はよく船よいしていたんですが、今はさっぱりなくなりました。
ex_2_en: I used to get seasick all the time, but not anymore.
ex_3_jp: 私の親友は、以前は天文学者に知られていなかった惑星の出身です。
ex_3_en: My best friend is from a planet that was previously unknown to astronomers.
meaning_story: By means of before... This is simply before or previously.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: えいぎょうをするなら、心理学を学んだ方がいいよ。
ex_1_en: You should study psychology if you work in sales.
ex_2_jp: 心理学のせつ明によると「あい手にひどいことが言えるということは、その人にいぞんしてるということ」らしいです。
ex_2_en: According to the psychology explanation, it looks like when you are able to say something mean to a person, you're actually being dependent on them.
ex_3_jp: 私は大学で犯罪心理学を専攻していました。
ex_3_en: My major was criminal psychology in college.
meaning_story: The reason your heart does what it does is all psychological. The study of that is psychology.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本の人たちは、本当にやさしいです。
ex_1_en: Japanese people are really kind.
ex_2_jp: このせいひん、本当に高くなっちゃったねー。
ex_2_en: This product has gotten truly expensive.
ex_3_jp: 本当にこの道であっていますか？
ex_3_en: Is this really the way?
meaning_story: 本当 is reality or truth (level 5 vocab). If you go towards truth and reality, you are saying that it is really and truly true. 本当に! It is!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It shares the reading with the level 5 本当 as well, but just has a particle on the end to show you're going towards reality. Really!

ex_1_jp: とくに理由はありません。
ex_1_en: I don’t have any specific reason.
ex_2_jp: 未だけいひのせいさんをしてないのには、何か理由があるんですか？
ex_2_en: Do you have any reason for not having settled your business expenses yet?
ex_3_jp: 論理的な理由から、彼は行方不明になったゴム手袋の事件の犯人が風船屋であることを導いた。
ex_3_en: Using logic and reason, he solved the case of the rubber gloves and the culprit was the balloon maker.
meaning_story: The reason reason is so reason-ish! That's why this word means reason as well, how could it not? Do you have a reason why it shouldn't be? I thought not.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: おきゃくさまのおへやは、302号室になります。
ex_1_en: Your room is 302.
ex_2_jp: このマンションの444号室はゆうれいが出ることで有名です。
ex_2_en: The room 444 of this apartment is known for being haunted.
ex_3_jp: 102号室の坂本と申します。
ex_3_en: I’m Sakamoto from room 102.
meaning_story: This is a counter that can be used after numbers to let you know what number room it is. It's a room number counter that you use in apartments and hotels to know exactly which room you're looking for.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 失礼ですが、日本ごははなせますか。
ex_1_en: Excuse me, but can you speak Japanese?
ex_2_jp: じっさいの会話で「あなた」という言ばを使うと、失礼にきこえることが多いです。
ex_2_en: If you use "anata" in an actual conversation, it often sounds impolite.
ex_3_jp: もし私があなたに太いと言えば、失礼だと思いますか？
ex_3_en: Would you think I’m rude if I told you that you’re fat?
meaning_story: When you do something that's your fault and then you say "thanks" after you do it, that's super-duper rude, wouldn't you say? Imagine doing something like this and then thinking to yourself after... wow, I was really rude.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 先生が教室に入ってきたと同時に、しぎょうのチャイムがなりました。
ex_1_en: At the same time teacher came in the classroom, the bell rang.
ex_2_jp: でん子レンジとトースターを同時につかったから、ブレーカーがおちちゃったんだ。
ex_2_en: I was using the microwave and the toaster at the same time, and the circuit breaker tripped.
ex_3_jp: 「今日はよくできましたね。それではまた来週同じ時間に。」と、コスプレのプロとアニメオタクが同時に言った。
ex_3_en: "Good lesson today. I’ll see you this time next week," the professional cosplayer and the anime nerd said at the same time.
meaning_story: The same time? Okay, let's say what we think this word means at the same time. Whoops, I just said it, sorry.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: わたしは歩いて学校に行っています。
ex_1_en: I go to school on foot.
ex_2_jp: 学校にてい出するので、ちえんしょう明しょを下さい。
ex_2_en: I have to submit an absentee notice to my school, so can I have one, please?
ex_3_jp: 今日はどうして学校で授業中にホットドッグをバーベキューするの？
ex_3_en: Why are we barbecuing hot dogs at school during class today?
meaning_story: A study school is obviously a place where people study and learn. In English, that's simply a school.
reading_story: This jukugo word consists of on'yomi readings, except 学 (がく) is shortened with a small っ to make it がっこう.

ex_1_jp: つまとそうだんして、形より内ようをおもんじたけっか、この形にきめました。
ex_1_en: I spoke with my wife and we decided to go with this shape, because we value substance over form.
ex_2_jp: これでなんとか形がつきました。
ex_2_en: With this, I could somehow manage to keep up appearances.
ex_3_jp: ねえ、私の、お尻の形をしたお腹、撫でたい？
ex_3_en: Hey, do you want to rub my butt-shaped belly?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You really want to eat food that's in neat shapes, so you decide to use a cutter (かた) on your cheese (ち) to make it a new shape. Square cheese is so boring. After you cut it up you have mouse shaped cheese! It just tastes better like that.
pitch_accent: カタꜜ *** カタチ *** ナリꜜ

ex_1_jp: だれだって、何かしらの欠点をもってるものさ。
ex_1_en: Everyone has some sort of weakness.
ex_2_jp: そうだ、ちょっと思い出したんだけど、かの女って欠点がないんだよ。
ex_2_en: Oh, I just remembered, she doesn't have any faults.
ex_3_jp: 私は欠点がありすぎるので、絶対にプロのサッカー選手にはなれません。たとえば、私には足がありません。
ex_3_en: I’ll never become a professional soccer player because I have too many shortcomings, for example, I don’t have any legs.
meaning_story: You have a lack of points. These are things about yourself you wish were better. These are your shortcomings.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out because けつ is being shortened to けっ here!

ex_1_jp: 日本でも、雪がふりますか？
ex_1_en: Does it snow in Japan too?
ex_2_jp: そっちも雪、つもった？
ex_2_en: Did you also get snow over there?
ex_3_jp: 私が初めて雪を見たのは、四十六歳の時でした。
ex_3_en: The first time I ever saw snow was when I was 46 years old.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for this vocab word. Enjoy the snow!

ex_1_jp: 今家を出ても、社会のじゅぎょうに間にあわないと思います。
ex_1_en: Even if I leave home right now, I think I’ll probably be late for social studies.
ex_2_jp: 国さい社会の一員として、めしテロにはだんじてくっしません。
ex_2_en: As a member of the international society, I will not yield to food porn.
ex_3_jp: 社会問題として、若者がお葬式で自分撮りをすることについて考える必要がある。
ex_3_en: As a society, we need to be concerned about youths taking ’selfies’ at funerals.
meaning_story: Not to be confused with 会社, which is a company, this is society. When a company meets together, it's like a bunch of people, who are in groups, who come together to live in one world. That is a society.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: このボンドは、かなり強力なので気をつけてください。
ex_1_en: This glue is pretty strong, so please be careful.
ex_2_jp: 強力なミニウォーターポンプの作り方をおしえてもらいました。
ex_2_en: I was taught how to make a powerful, mini water pump.
ex_3_jp: 彼女を見つめると、まるで十人力ぐらい強力になったように感じる。
ex_3_en: When I look at her, I feel as though I have the strength of ten men.
meaning_story: You have strong power. This is your strength.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: キョーリョク *** ゴーリキ *** ゴーリキꜜ

ex_1_jp: この中で一ばん強いのはだれですか。
ex_1_en: Who is the strongest among these people?
ex_2_jp: クチバシと羽の色からさっするに、こいつはおそらくめちゃくちゃ強いカラスだね。
ex_2_en: By the shape of the beak and color of the feathers, this would probably be a very strong crow.
ex_3_jp: 海流はとても強く、その猫を川まで運んだ。
ex_3_en: The ocean's currents were too strong for the cat and it was carried away.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of strong? It's also strong.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: So you wanna be strong huh? Well, all you have to do is eat these two yogurts (つよ). One is filled with horse steroids, the other is full of bull steroids. They will make you so strong.
pitch_accent: キツイ *** コワꜜイ *** ツヨꜜイ

ex_1_jp: 今年の夏は、さく年よりもあついです。
ex_1_en: This summer is hotter than last year.
ex_2_jp: 近いうちに夏ワンピをかいに行きたいんだよね。
ex_2_en: I want to go buy some summer dresses sometime soon.
ex_3_jp: 夏にして楽しいことは三つだけだ。映画、ビデオゲーム、それから木彫の鴨を作ること。
ex_3_en: Summer is only good for three things. Movies, video games, and duck carving.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for the vocab.

ex_1_jp: 夏休みは、一ヶ月あります。
ex_1_en: Summer vacation is one month long.
ex_2_jp: 夏休みにおきなわでダイビングをした時、しんじられないくらいたく山のしゅるいの魚を見ることができました！
ex_2_en: I can't believe all the different kinds of fish we saw when diving in Okinawa during summer break.
ex_3_jp: 小さいころ、夏休みに両親がディズニーランドに連れて行ってくれました。でも、帰り際、両親は何と私のことを忘れて帰ってしまったのです。あの時だけは、迷子になったことを嬉しく思いましたね。
ex_3_en: When I was a kid, my parents took me to Disney Land for summer vacation, but they forgot me there when they left. It was the only time I was happy to be lost.
meaning_story: You know that 夏 means summer and 休 means rest. What is a "summer rest" though? It's a summer break or summer vacation.
reading_story: The readings are kun'yomi readings because this word is essentially two separate words put together into one word. You should know the reading for 夏 from the kanji and the reading for 休み from the vocab.

ex_1_jp: かれは必ずもどってくるので、大じょうぶです。
ex_1_en: He’ll definitely come back, so I’m okay.
ex_2_jp: 必ずねる前にコンタクトを外した方がいいよ。でないとし力がさらにおちるよ。
ex_2_en: You should always take out your contacts before going to bed. Otherwise your eyesight will get worse.
ex_3_jp: 何があっても必ずさい後までワニカニをやりとげます。
ex_3_en: I will certainly complete Wanikani no matter what.
meaning_story: This word looks like a verb but it's not (sorry!). It's an adverb. The kanji itself means certain and the vocab version means all sorts of variations on that: surely, certainly, and without exception to name a few.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Ra, the Egyptian god asks you: "Can you do it? Are you certain you can build the pyramids?" "Yes I can ra (かなら). Yes I can," you reply.

ex_1_jp: 自どりをするためだけに白鳥をみずうみから引きずり出すなんてひどすぎるよ。
ex_1_en: Pulling a swan out of the lake just to take a selfie with it is too cruel.
ex_2_jp: 白ワインは魚りょうりに合うっていうけど、白鳥りょうりに合うワインは何か知っていますか？
ex_2_en: They say that white wine goes well with fish, but do you know what kind of wine would go well with swan?
ex_3_jp: 白鳥はとても美しいが、汚らしい言葉遣いをする。
ex_3_en: Swans are so pretty, but they use foul language.
meaning_story: There are many white birds out there, for sure, but one really stands out if you ask me. That bird is the swan. It's big, it's white, and it's majestic.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この店は、高いですがおいしいです。
ex_1_en: This restaurant is expensive, but delicious.
ex_2_jp: わたしには高すぎてとどかないので、とてもせが高いジェームズ・ステュアートを天国からよんできました。
ex_2_en: That is too high for me to reach, so I've brought James Stewart, who is very tall, down from Heaven.
ex_3_jp: どうして、「ビッグアンドトール」のスーツはあんなに値段が高いんだ？
ex_3_en: Why are suits from the "Big and Tall" store so expensive?
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of tall or expensive? It's the same: tall or expensive. Weird that this word means both of these things, yeah? Just imagine money piled up to be really tall. That money is tall because it needs to buy something expensive.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: There's a tall dude trying to sell you something really expensive. He's really going off on how great this item is and how you should buy it. This guy is a real salesman. A real talker (たか).

ex_1_jp: こんなあそびがはやるとは、世も末だな。
ex_1_en: If this kind of game is popular, then it’s the end of the world.
ex_2_jp: おたくのむす子さんは末が本当にたのしみですね。
ex_2_en: You must be looking forward to seeing what your son accomplishes in the future.
ex_3_jp: 激しい口論の末、末息子が私の金をこの道の突き当りのどこかに埋めました。
ex_3_en: After a heated discussion, my youngest son buried my gold somewhere at the end of this road.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Throw a "the" in there if you'd like, as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You've reached the end of the universe. Nothing is there. You step out, and you're surprised because you get greeted by Sue. Imagine meeting this Sue, and talking to them for a while. You should come up with a Sue that you know or a famous Sue that you know. Just pick something you can remember.

ex_1_jp: 一体どうなっているんだ。
ex_1_en: What the heck is going on?
ex_2_jp: 「あいとにくしみはひょうり一体」って、一体全体どういういみなんだ！？
ex_2_en: What the heck does, "There's a thin line between love and hate," mean?
ex_3_jp: 一体俺が何をしたって言うんだよ？
ex_3_en: What the heck did you say I did?
meaning_story: Okay, so this one is really weird, sorry. Each of us only get one body in our lifetimes, right? Well what the heck! What if I want more than one body. Let's all be mad about this together.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because いち is shortened to いっ here!

ex_1_jp: 本当に国民はわれわれにさんせいしてくれるのでしょうか。
ex_1_en: Will the people really give us their approval?
ex_2_jp: どうすれば日本国民になれますか。
ex_2_en: How do you become a citizen of Japan?
ex_3_jp: 昨夜、PS4の新ゲームを買うために並んでいた国民たちは、凍って死にました。
ex_3_en: The people waiting in line for the new PS4 game last night froze to death.
meaning_story: The country peoples are the people of your country. They are the people.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: クニタミ *** コクミン

ex_1_jp: 今週は仕ごとがたくさんあります。
ex_1_en: There is a lot of work to do this week.
ex_2_jp: 今週の火よう日の午前十一じに、しぶ谷のハチ公前でまち合わせをしましょう。
ex_2_en: Let's meet up in front of the Hachiko statue at 11 a.m. this Tuesday.
ex_3_jp: 新しいゲームを４つ買ったので、今週はかなり忙しくなる。
ex_3_en: This week is going to be really busy because I just bought four new video games.
meaning_story: The now week is this week.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 千円札のおつりが不足しています。
ex_1_en: I don’t have change for a thousand yen bill.
ex_2_jp: これは、水そうから紙のひしゃくで千円札をすくうゲームです。
ex_2_en: This is a game in which you scoop thousand yen bills with a paper scoop from a water tank.
ex_3_jp: 「千ドル札を燃やしてるの？」「いや、ただの千円札だよ。」
ex_3_en: "Are you burning a thousand dollar bill?" "No, it’s just a thousand yen bill."
meaning_story: You know what 千円 is (1000 yen). So if you add a bill to that you get a thousand yen bill. That's just the little rectangular piece of money that is worth 1000 yen.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: れいぼうをつける時は、白いボタンをおしてください。
ex_1_en: When you want to turn on the air conditioning, please press the white button.
ex_2_jp: 時がかい決してくれるのをまつしかないよ。
ex_2_en: We can do nothing but wait for time to solve this.
ex_3_jp: 幸せな時、いつも時が止まればいいのに、と思う。
ex_3_en: Whenever I’m happy, I always think it would be nice if I could stop time.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: What time is it? It's time to key (とき) your enemy's car. Imagine yourself looking at your watch, waiting until the correct time to perform a synchronized keying of someone's car. Who do you hate the most? Whose car would you like to key?

ex_1_jp: グリルドチーズにはケチャップを付けるはですか？
ex_1_en: Are you one of those people who puts ketchup in their grilled cheese?
ex_2_jp: どうしてワンちゃんに、ニッカって名前を付けたんですか？
ex_2_en: Why did you name your doggy Nikka?
ex_3_jp: どうして頭に蛭を付けているんですか？
ex_3_en: Why are you attaching leeches to your head?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means attach so the verb version is to attach.
reading_story: The reading is actually the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this one just fine.

ex_1_jp: さいふが見当たりません。
ex_1_en: I can't find my wallet.
ex_2_jp: さがしたけど、どこにも見当たらなかったんです。
ex_2_en: I looked for it, but couldn't find it anywhere.
ex_3_jp: 俺の老眼鏡が見当たらないんだ。
ex_3_en: I can’t find my reading glasses.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. It's made up of the kanji for see and right, so what happens when you see the right thing? You manage to come upon what you're looking for or to be found, if you're the one who's lost and you see the right people that are looking for you. Note: This verb is almost always used in the negative form. It is very, very rare for it to be positive. So when you're using it, make sure no one found the thing you're talking about!
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ミアタル *** ミアタꜜル

ex_1_jp: このゲーム、ぜったい売れるだろ。
ex_1_en: This game will definitely sell well.
ex_2_jp: その千円札、五百円でネットオークションにかけたら、よゆうで売れるっしょ。
ex_2_en: I'd say, if you put up the thousand yen bill for online auction, it would easily sell for five hundred yen.
ex_3_jp: 売れる小説の書き方を教えてあげよう。
ex_3_en: I will teach you how to write novels that sell.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sell, so the verb version is to sell or to be sold.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: 自てん車でこけて、前ばが欠けてしまった。
ex_1_en: I fell off my bike and chipped my front teeth.
ex_2_jp: たとえばの話なんだけど、もしコウイチのお気に入りのきゅうすが口が欠けたせいでわたしたちがかいこされてしまっても、しつぎょうほけんをしんせいすることってできるのかな。
ex_2_en: Hypothetically speaking, if we got fired because the spout of Koichi's favorite teapot got chipped, are we still entitled to apply for Employment Insurance?
ex_3_jp: 私には、セーラームーンを見るのを止めるための強い意志が欠けている。
ex_3_en: I lack the willpower to stop watching Sailor Moon.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lack so the vocab verb version means to lack.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You lack something... it's a car (か). You can't stop thinking about this because you have to walk 40 miles to get to your destination. If only you didn't lack a car this would be easier. Imagine the sweat... the pain... the thirst... all because you lack a car.

ex_1_jp: もうおれには失うものが何もないんだ。
ex_1_en: I already have nothing to lose.
ex_2_jp: トーフグがギャンブルで全ざいさんを失ったというじょうほうは、しんぴょうせいに欠けている。
ex_2_en: The information that Tofugu gambled away its entire assets is not reliable.
ex_3_jp: 人生最悪の日は、私がAKB48のフィギュアを失った日です。
ex_3_en: The worst day of my life was when I lost my AKB48 Barbie doll.
meaning_story: The kanji portion means fault, so you would think the verb version is "to fault." It's a little different, though. Think of it this way, if you "fault" something, you're messing up. What's a great way to mess up? By losing something. That's why this word means to lose. Pretend like you are supposed to hold on to someone's wedding ring. You make the biggest fault of all. You lose it. Ouch.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: How did you lose this wedding ring? An 牛 Nun (うし + な) ate it. The only way to get it back is to cut open this cow nun and get it back.

ex_1_jp: このみちは、ほそくて通りにくいです。
ex_1_en: This road is narrow and difficult to pass through.
ex_2_jp: 日本ごがペラペラになるなんてありえないと思うかもしれませんが、それはあたらしい言ごを学ぶだれもが通る道です。
ex_2_en: It seems impossible to become fluent in Japanese, but　everybody who learns a new language travels along the same road.
ex_3_jp: お茶会のためのメープルシロップを買うために、カナダを通ってイギリスに行った。
ex_3_en: I stopped by Canada on the way to England to get some maple syrup for the tea party.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pass through so the verb vocab version means to pass through.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

ex_1_jp: 星がきらきら光っている。
ex_1_en: The stars are shining.
ex_2_jp: 右のくつに、光るとりょうが付いてるよ。
ex_2_en: You've got some glittery paint on your right shoe.
ex_3_jp: あそこで確かに何かが光るのを見たんだ。
ex_3_en: I’m sure I saw something shining over there.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sunlight, so the verb is to shine or to glitter. Just imagine what happens when sunlight hits things!
reading_story: Remember how you learned the reading for 光? Well this is almost the same thing. Just change the り to る and you'll know this reading!

ex_1_jp: こたえ方を教えてください。
ex_1_en: Please teach me how to answer.
ex_2_jp: ワニカニで日本ごを教える人の中には、「鬼コーチ」はいないよね？
ex_2_en: There aren't any "demon coaches" among people who teach Japanese on Wanikani, are there?
ex_3_jp: 皆さん、お早うございます。今日は、皆さんに、茄子を食べることの危険性について教えたいと思います。
ex_3_en: Good morning, class. Today I’m going to teach you about the dangers of eating eggplant.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means teach so the verb vocab version means to teach.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about your favorite teacher. Now think about him/her teaching you the following: "Today I'm going to teach you about the ocean (おし)." It is big. Really big. Inside it are krakens, space aliens, and lost cities. Here is where you continue the lesson in your head, making it the most ridiculous lesson about the ocean you've ever heard. Focus in on the ocean part, since that's the reading, always coming back to it.

ex_1_jp: 今すぐ町民をひなんさせるべきです！
ex_1_en: The townspeople should find shelter right now!
ex_2_jp: この町民たちは、みんなちゃんと後かた付けができる。
ex_2_en: These townspeople are all able to clean up after themselves.
ex_3_jp: この町の人達はみんな、この町の町民であることを誇りに思っています。
ex_3_en: I feel like all the people in this town boast about being townspeople here.I feel like all the people in this town boast about being townspeople here.
meaning_story: Town peoples are the townspeople!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ここでは、交通じこがよくおきるんです。
ex_1_en: Traffic accidents happen a lot here.
ex_2_jp: トーフグのオフィスが入ったビルの前の通りはは交通がはげしい。
ex_2_en: There's heavy traffic on the street in front of the building the Tofugu office is in.
ex_3_jp: もし俺の車にヘリコプターのプロペラがあれば、空を飛んで交通渋滞を回避することができるのになぁ。
ex_3_en: I wish my car had helicopter blades so I could fly over this traffic jam.
meaning_story: When things get all mixed up while trying to pass through each other it becomes a mess. This can be people, cars, bikes, what have you. Anything that has to move around and pass through each other. When this happens things slow down and you get traffic.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: さんかくけい, さんかっけい
ex_1_jp: どうすれば、三角形のオニギリをにぎれるんですか？
ex_1_en: How do you make onigiri into a triangle?
ex_2_jp: 夏の夜空には、天の川をはさんでことざとわしざと白鳥ざの一とう星をむすんだ大三角形が広がります。
ex_2_en: A big triangle, consisting of three magnitude stars from Lyra, Aquila, and Cygnus, stretches out in the summer night sky.
ex_3_jp: そこには、三角形の公園があります。
ex_3_en: There is a triangle park there.
meaning_story: You already learned that 三角 means "triangle." Well this means triangle too, but it's the mathematical term. You should use it in math class.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: サンカꜜクケイ *** サンカクꜜケイ *** サンカꜜッケイ

ex_1_jp: そのえいがのかいえん時かんは二時半です。
ex_1_en: The film begins at two-thirty.
ex_2_jp: 二時半に大じなやくそくがあるのにねぼうしちゃって、ちょっと今かなりテンパってます。
ex_2_en: I have a important appointment at 2:30, but I overslept and now I'm freaking out.
ex_3_jp: 「私は明日午後二時半に、私のお母さんのお父さんの娘の姪っ子に会います。」「なんで、単にお姉ちゃんとランチに行くって言わないの？ありえないんだけど！」
ex_3_en: "I’m meeting my mom’s father’s daughter’s niece tomorrow at two-thirty in the afternoon." "Why didn’t you just say you’re meeting your older sister for lunch tomorrow? Jeez!"
meaning_story: When it's two o'clock and a half what time do you think it is? That would be two thirty.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今回の台風は弱いので、あまり心ぱいしなくてもよさそうです。
ex_1_en: This typhoon is weak, so it seems that we don’t have to worry too much.
ex_2_jp: ひじょうに強い台風トウフ号が、月よう日、西日本に上りくしました。
ex_2_en: Strong typhoon Tofu made landfall in western Japan on Monday.
ex_3_jp: 大型の台風が日本列島に近づいています。
ex_3_en: A large typhoon is approaching the Japanese islands.
meaning_story: A machine that pumps wind can malfunction and make too much, causing a typhoon. It's a really powerful machine to be able to move that much wind.
