reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Instead of だい for 台 though, this uses the reading たい. Remember it like this: When a typhoon is coming you have to tie (たい) down all of your stuff. Or, you know, if you already know the word typhoon, that's fine too.

ex_1_jp: 男の大学生と女の大学生がはなしています。
ex_1_en: A male university student and a female university student are talking.
ex_2_jp: あの大学生の女せいは、ダイエット中です。
ex_2_en: That college girl is on a diet.
ex_3_jp: マカロニチーズしか食べていないっていうのに、いったいどうして大学生は一日中勉強して夜中中お酒を飲む元気があるっていうんだ？
ex_3_en: How do university students have the energy to study all day and drink all night when all they eat is macaroni and cheese?
meaning_story: You know that 学生 means "student" and you know that 大学 means university/college. Combine the two and you have a university student / college student.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ダイカ°ꜜクセイ *** ダイカ°クꜜセイ

ex_1_jp: 今年、もっとも不人気だったアニメは何だと思いますか。
ex_1_en: What do you think is the most unpopular anime this year?
ex_2_jp: コウイチたいマイケルのすもうのし合は、Youtubeで見るとはく力に欠けるので不人気です。
ex_2_en: The Koichi vs Michael sumo match is unpopular because it lacks the intensity when you watch it on YouTube.
ex_3_jp: 「お前の母ちゃんに言ってやる」が口癖だったため、彼はクラスメートに不人気だった。
ex_3_en: He was unpopular among his classmates because his favorite phrase was, "I’m gonna tell your mom."
meaning_story: You already know 人気 which means "popular." And you also know that 不 means "not." So what do you get when you combine the two? Something that's not popular or unpopular.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: そうは言っても、言い方ってもんがあるだろ！
ex_1_en: That make sense, but you should think about the way you say things!
ex_2_jp: そうだ、話はかわるんだけど、コウイチのネコって言ばの言い方、めっちゃかわいくない？
ex_2_en: Oh, sorry for changing the subject, but don't you think the way Koichi says the word cat is so cute?
ex_3_jp: あなたの物の言い方はとても馬鹿です。
ex_3_en: Your way of saying that is so stupid.
meaning_story: The way of saying something is your way of saying. This could be your accent or simply the way you talk.
reading_story: You've seen 言う. Let's steal that word's reading. And, you already know 方 and its reading. Combine those together and you have the reading for this word.

ex_1_jp: わたしは、あさに弱いです。
ex_1_en: I am not a morning person.
ex_2_jp: ユイは体は弱いけど、人のいたみがわかる人げんです。
ex_2_en: Yui is physically weak, but she is a person who understands others' pain.
ex_3_jp: インフルエンザにかかると、スーパーマンでさえもとても弱くなります。
ex_3_en: Even superman gets really weak when he gets the flu.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of weak? It's also weak.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You just got beaten up because you're weak. Then the bully asks you: "Yo! Why (よわ) you so weak?"

ex_1_jp: ついにアイツの弱点を見つけたぜ！
ex_1_en: I finally discovered his weak point!
ex_2_jp: あの体そうせん手の弱点は、せいかくがじゅうなんせいに欠けているところだ。
ex_2_en: That gymnast's weakness is that her personality lacks flexibility.
ex_3_jp: 私の従業員としての弱点は、恐らく弱点が一つも無いことです。
ex_3_en: My weak point as an employee is probably that I have no weaknesses.
meaning_story: The weak point is your weakpoint.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ジャクテꜜン *** ジャクテン

ex_1_jp: 週末は、おきなわにりょ行に行っていました。
ex_1_en: I was in Okinawa over the weekend.
ex_2_jp: せん週末、雪が十センチつもりました。
ex_2_en: We got 10 centimeters of snow last weekend.
ex_3_jp: 宝くじに当たったんだけど、週末ローマにピザでも食べに行かない？
ex_3_en: We just won the lottery, so do you want to go to Rome this weekend for pizza?
meaning_story: The end of the week is the weekend... that is, unless you work on the weekend, but we can't cater to everyone here.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 何時のひ行きにのるんですか？
ex_1_en: What time will your plane leave?
ex_2_jp: 目まいをかんじはじめたのは何時ですか？
ex_2_en: What time did you start to feel dizzy?
ex_3_jp: 今夜何時にボーリングに行くの？
ex_3_en: What time are you going bowling tonight?
meaning_story: This is a good word to know to ask for the time. What is the time? This is how you ask what time it is.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: イꜜツ *** ナꜜンジ *** ナンドキ

ex_1_jp: 外では、つめたい風がふいていました。
ex_1_en: Cold winds were blowing outside.
ex_2_jp: 風が強くなってきましたね。
ex_2_en: The wind is picking up, isn't it?
ex_3_jp: 風が彼女のカツラを吹き飛ばした時に、私は自分が坊主の女性にとても魅力を感じることに気が付きました。
ex_3_en: When the wind blew the wig off of her head, I realized that I’m really attracted to bald women.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Do you know the word "kamikaze" from WWII history? Well, it means "divine wind." The "kaze" part is the wind part, and this word uses the same reading, making it かぜ as well.

ex_1_jp: すみませんが、年末は、ちょっとバタバタしてじかんがとれなさそうです。
ex_1_en: I’m sorry, but I’ll be super busy around the end of the year and I probably can’t make time for it.
ex_2_jp: マイケルは、年末にトーフグのだい二えいぎょうぶにいどうになりました。
ex_2_en: Michael was transferred to Sales Division II of Tofugu at the end of the year.
ex_3_jp: 年末までには、氷中毒から立ち直れるといいんだけど。
ex_3_en: I hope to have gotten over my addiction to ice cubes before the end of the year.
meaning_story: The year end is the year end aka the end of the year.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 黄色かみどり色のペンはありますか？
ex_1_en: Are there yellow or green pens?
ex_2_jp: アメリカのカラスは、美しい黄色の羽をもっていることで有名です。
ex_2_en: An American crow is well known for the beauty of its yellow wings.
ex_3_jp: もし尿のいろが透明から黄色に変わってしまったら、もっと水を飲んだ方が良いという合図です。
ex_3_en: If your urine changes from clear to yellow, you should drink more water.
meaning_story: The yellow color is just the color yellow.
reading_story: The readings are the same as the readings you learned with the kanji meaning you should be able to read this word right off the bat.

ex_1_jp: 木のはが地上におちた。
ex_1_en: The leaves fell to the ground.
ex_2_jp: コウイチは地上1kmの所に、ひみつき地をもっている。
ex_2_en: Koichi has a Secret Base 1km above ground.
ex_3_jp: 東京タワーは、地上から見上げると物凄い迫力がありますね。
ex_3_en: When you look at Tokyo Tower from the ground it feels tremendously powerful.
meaning_story: Remember 地下, which is "below ground." Well, this is ground and above combined together, so I bet you can guess that this means above ground. But usually things above ground don't float (unless you're in space), so it's really on the ground.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: こちらにあなたの家の住所をかいてください。
ex_1_en: Please write down your home address here.
ex_2_jp: クリスマスカードをおくりたいので住所をおしえてくれませんか？
ex_2_en: Can you please give me your address so I can send you a Christmas card?
ex_3_jp: 私が月に購入した土地には、住所はありますか？自分宛に酸素を送りたいので、よろしくお願い致します。
ex_3_en: Does the land I purchased on the Moon have an address? I want to mail myself some oxygen tanks.
meaning_story: Your dwelling place is the place you live. How do you identify one's dwelling place? By using the address.
reading_story: This word is made up of the on'yomi readings that you've already learned with the kanji. Have at it!

ex_1_jp: わたしの母は、来年のはるから、かいごしせつに入所することになりました。
ex_1_en: My mother will be admitted to a nursing home next spring.
ex_2_jp: こちらに入所年月日を記入してください。
ex_2_en: Please write down your admission date here.
ex_3_jp: 俺の兄貴は今入所中だ。
ex_3_en: My yakuza boss is in jail now.
meaning_story: You enter a place. So, you have been given (or forced) admission into this place. You have been given entrance. For example, "admission" into a prison is something you could gain by not doing your WaniKani reviews in certain Crabigator ruled countries.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あなたの助言、ぜんぜん役に立たなかったんだけど。
ex_1_en: But your advice wasn’t helpful at all.
ex_2_jp: かの女の助言にしたがって、コウイチはついにタバコをやめたんだよ。
ex_2_en: In keeping with his girlfriend's advice, Koichi finally quit smoking.
ex_3_jp: そのチョコレートをくれたら、助言をあげるわ。
ex_3_en: I will give you advice, if you give me that chocolate.
meaning_story: When you say things that help you are giving advice, though not everyone will think it's good.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ジョケ°ン *** ジョコ°ン

ex_1_jp: これは、全米がなみだした、大ヒットチョ～大作えいがです。
ex_1_en: This is a mega-hit blockbuster that brought all of America to tears.
ex_2_jp: まつ山ひできは、2017年の全米オープンで二いに入った。
ex_2_en: Hideki Matsuyama finished second at the 2017 U.S. Open.
ex_3_jp: 全米ヒットチャートで今一位の曲は何ですか？
ex_3_en: What's the No. 1 song on the U.S. hit chart now?
meaning_story: Do you remember how 米国 can mean "America?" That 米 means America sometimes. So, when you see all rice (I mean, America), you can think of this word as meaning All America (sort of like how 全日本 means "All Japan.").
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 思い出って、むねにそっとしまっておくものなんじゃないの？
ex_1_en: Aren’t memories things you lock safely away in your chest?
ex_2_jp: 子どものころ、日がくれるまで友だちとあそんでいたことは、今となってはとてもなつかしいいい思い出です。今はもうかん全ボッチですからね。
ex_2_en: I used to play with my friends until it got dark. It's a really great, nostalgic memory now especially because I don't have any friends anymore.
ex_3_jp: 私のお父さんが毎週日曜日の朝にチョコレートでコーティングされたベーコンを作ってくれたのは、とてもいい思い出です。
ex_3_en: My dad making chocolate covered bacon for us every Sunday morning is such a good memory of mine.
meaning_story: Do you remember the word 思う? It means "to think." So, when you're exiting you're thinking, it's coming out of your head. You're recalling a memory and/or memories.
reading_story: The readings are both kun'yomi, but based off of previous experience with the two separate words that make up this word, you should be able to read it. Just remember that it's kun'yomi. One hint is the hiragana sticking out of the 思.

ex_1_jp: 気がついたら、五時間ぐらいねむっていました。
ex_1_en: When I came to, I had been sleeping for almost five hours.
ex_2_jp: たのむから三分間だけだまっててくれないか？
ex_2_en: For heaven's sake, can't you just be quiet for three minutes?
ex_3_jp: 試験の中に、一定時間息を止めるというものがありました。一番難しかったのは、三時間息を止めるというものだったけれど、私はなんとかやり切りました。
ex_3_en: The test involved having to hold my breath for fixed intervals of time. The most difficult one was for 3 hours, but I did it.
meaning_story: When you stick this onto the end of another word that talks about an interval of time in some way, you're indicating the amount of time that has gone past. For example, 二年間 is "two years." 一時間 is "one hour." Any amount of time + 〜間 will make it an "amount of time" instead of just a specific time.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. This should save you at least 二分間.
pitch_accent: アꜜイ *** アイダ *** カꜜン *** マ

ex_1_jp: ここじゃなくて、どこか他所の店に行こうよ。
ex_1_en: Not here, let’s go to another store somewhere else.
ex_2_jp: 他所は他所、家は家！
ex_2_en: Don't compare us to other families.
ex_3_jp: 私は暴力夫から逃れるために、他所に移り住んだ。
ex_3_en: I moved somewhere else to escape from my abusive husband.
meaning_story: When you're talking about some other place you're talking about another place.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 答えは、１、２、３、４から、一番いいものを一つえらんでください。
ex_1_en: Please choose the best answer among 1, 2, 3, and 4.
ex_2_jp: 山口さんの答えは、いつも通りでした。
ex_2_en: Mr. Yamaguchi's response was the same as usual.
ex_3_jp: テストの最初の質問、何て答えた？「名前をここに書きなさい」ってやつだよ。自分の名前を書き込んだ？それとも「名前」ってそこに書いた？
ex_3_en: How did you answer the first question on the test? The one that said, "Write Name Here." Did you put down your own name or did you just write "name?"
meaning_story: You can guess this is a noun version of the kanji because the hiragana sticking out of it isn't an う-related sound or an い-related sound. So, what is the noun version of answer? It's also answer.
reading_story: The reading is kun'yomi, but this is also the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this and then give your 答え correctly.

ex_1_jp: そのせつは、ご助力をたまわりかんしゃ申し上げます。
ex_1_en: Thank you for your assistance at this time.
ex_2_jp: Youtubeのどうがさい生カウントをのばすため、コウイチは助力をもとめてタランティーノに電話をかけた。
ex_2_en: Koichi made a phone call to Quentin Tarantino seeking help to increase his Youtube view counts.
ex_3_jp: スパイダーマンの助力を求める必要はない。
ex_3_en: You don’t need to request Spiderman’s assistance.
meaning_story: When you have the power to help someone, you are giving them assistance and support.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ジョリョク *** ジョꜜリョク

ex_1_jp: ワトソンはかせは、シャーロック・ホームズの助手ではなく、あくまで友人です。
ex_1_en: Dr. Watson isn’t just Sherlock Holmes’ assistant, he’s his friend till the end.
ex_2_jp: わたしの助手は、年末に肉ばなれになりました。
ex_2_en: My aide got a torn muscle at the end of the year.
ex_3_jp: もし私が今首になった助手の助手だとしたら、それってつまり私も首になっちゃったってこと？
ex_3_en: If I’m the assistant to an assistant who was just fired, does that mean that I’m fired too?
meaning_story: Someone who gives you a helping hand is an assistant.
reading_story: The readings are both on'yomi, which is fine for you and 助 but not for 手, which you've associated with the kun'yomi reading, て. Just think of your assistant doing everything for you, even putting your shoe (しゅ) on for you (but not both, just one shoe, which makes it weird). If you remember it that way you should be able to remember that this reading is しゅ and not て.

ex_1_jp: この小せつの作者の名前がどうしても思い出せません。
ex_1_en: I just can’t remember this novel’s author’s name.
ex_2_jp: ついにテキストフグの作者に会えました。
ex_2_en: We could finally meet with the writers of Textfugu.
ex_3_jp: 俺の兄貴がギリシャ神話の作者だったんだが、今は失業している。
ex_3_en: My brother was an author of Greek mythology, but now he’s unemployed.
meaning_story: Someone who makes is someone who creates things. Back in the day, a creator like this may have been known as many things, but the big one that stands out is an author.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: サꜜクシャ *** サクシャ

ex_1_jp: このおもちゃの電車は、電池でうごきます。
ex_1_en: This toy train moves with batteries.
ex_2_jp: ママ、見てー！電池が取れちゃった。
ex_2_en: Mom, look! The battery came off.
ex_3_jp: 自作のロボット犬の電池を買いに、ちょっくら町へ行ってくるよ。
ex_3_en: I’m heading to town to buy a battery for the robot dog I created.
meaning_story: A pond for electricity? May seem weird at first, but if you think of something that's gathering all the electricity into one pond... that thing is like a battery (and is a battery).
reading_story: This word uses on'yomi readings as it's a jukugo word. You know the 電 portion but for 池 you learned it as いけ. To remember that 池 is read as ち, you can think about this great battery you make, completely out of cheese and cheetos (ち). Power this battery up and hook it to something. That thing turns cheese colored. Your cheese battery has worked! Now hook it up to yourself. How does it feel? Cheesy?

ex_1_jp: リストラとりこんで、身も心もズタズタです。
ex_1_en: My body and my mind are torn apart from getting fired and divorced.
ex_2_jp: この魚の身はたん白でおいしいね。
ex_2_en: This fish meat tastes light and delicate, doesn't it?
ex_3_jp: 現金は常に身につけておく方がいい。
ex_3_en: You should always carry cash on you.
meaning_story: The kanji is somebody, but the word is body. I guess somebody is somebody's body, so they are similar at least.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Who is that somebody? Who is that body? Why, of course it is me (み).

ex_1_jp: かれは、心身ともに、つかれきっていたんだと思います。
ex_1_en: I think his body and mind were both worn out.
ex_2_jp: 取りえは、心身ともにけん全であることだけです。
ex_2_en: My only strength is being of sound mind and body.
ex_3_jp: ヨガは、心身共にとても健康にしてくれる。
ex_3_en: Yoga is excellent for the health of your body and mind.
meaning_story: Technically this kanji is heart and somebody, but think about it this way. Where does everything come from inside somebody? The heart! It keeps things going by pumping blood, providing the foundation for both a good mind and body.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: シꜜンシン *** シンシン

ex_1_jp: それは、両者にひがあると思うよ。
ex_1_en: I think they’re both at fault for that.
ex_2_jp: コウイチせん手とマイケルせん手、今のところ両者のじつ力はほぼご角のようです。
ex_2_en: Player Koichi and Player Michael both seem to be pretty equally matched so far.
ex_3_jp: 車両事故に関与している両者は、共に衝突時に携帯電話で話をしていた。
ex_3_en: Both of the people involved in the car accident were talking on their cell phones at the time of the crash.
meaning_story: When you have both someones, you have both people. You'll notice over time that 者 is often used to indicate a person or type of person, so keep that in mind for future words as well!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今年の夏、私は山田君と、ディズニーランドの中にあるホテルにとまりました。
ex_1_en: This summer, I stayed in a hotel in Disney Land with Yamada.
ex_2_jp: ビエト君って、せんたくきを一日に七十七回も回すらしいよ！
ex_2_en: I heard that Viet runs the laundry machine seventy-seven times a day.
ex_3_jp: 日本の男の子の名前の後ろには「君」という言葉が付けられるそうだが、ラという名前の男の子があまりいないというのは残念ですね。
ex_3_en: "Kun" is used as a suffix for boys’ names in Japan. It’s too bad there aren’t a lot of kids with the name "Ra."
meaning_story: Add this to the end of someone's name, it's like saying ______buddy. It's generally used as a name ender (like さん) for boys and young men. Don't use this on people who are higher ranked than you (socially or literally). As in, you wouldn't use it on your boss. Use it on your younger male subordinates as well as boys who aren't adults yet.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji (on'yomi), probably because it usually is attached to other words (aka names, like こういち君) making it act more like jukugo words do.

ex_1_jp: わたしのおっとは、大さか支店の支店長をつとめています。
ex_1_en: My husband is the branch manager of the Osaka branch.
ex_2_jp: この支店には、一人で行どうすることがすきな人もはたらいている。
ex_2_en: In this branch shop, there are workers who like to do things alone as well.
ex_3_jp: 支店長の髭は少し長すぎる。
ex_3_en: Our branch manager’s mustache is a bit too long.
meaning_story: The support shop is the branch office. Presumably this is because the regular "shop" is the "shop" and anything that supports it is the local (branch) office. If it helps, this word has the same meaning as 支局 which you will also be learning in this level.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 千ば支局にてんきんすることになりました。
ex_1_en: I was transferred to the Chiba branch office.
ex_2_jp: FBI東京支局の支局員のたこやきパーティーによんでもらった。
ex_2_en: I got invited to the takoyaki party for the agents of FBI field office in Tokyo.
ex_3_jp: テレビ大阪京都支局の前でくしゃみが出た。
ex_3_en: I sneezed in front of the Kyoto branch of Television Osaka, Inc.
meaning_story: The support bureau is the group that supports a business. It is the branch office. If it helps, this word has the same meaning as 支店 which you will also be learning in this level.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: シキョク *** シキョꜜク *** シꜜキョク

ex_1_jp: 朝ごはんにパンとたまごをたべた。
ex_1_en: I ate bread and eggs for breakfast.
ex_2_jp: 朝ごはんにはベーコンに決まってるだろ？こんな当たり前のことも分からないのか。
ex_2_en: Of course breakfast has to have bacon! Why can’t you understand something so obvious?
ex_3_jp: 滅茶苦茶お腹が空いていて、朝ごはんに腐った卵を６つも食べてしまったこと、今までにある？
ex_3_en: Have you ever been so hungry that you ate six rotten eggs for breakfast?
meaning_story: ごはん is a food or meal (maybe you'll learn the kanji for it later, but it's not usually used, so you're learning it this way now). What is your morning meal? That is breakfast (not to be confused with second breakfast, you hobbit).
reading_story: The reading for あさ is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read everything here.

ex_1_jp: ゆうびん局とびょういんもあります。
ex_1_en: There is a post office and a hospital, too.
ex_2_jp: あのテレビ局、のっとっちゃおうぜ！
ex_2_en: Let's take over that TV station!
ex_3_jp: 彼は、マクドナルドのドライブスルーで待たされすぎたからといって、アメリカ連邦捜査局に電話をかけようとした。
ex_3_en: He tried calling the Federal Bureau of Investigation because he had to wait too long in the drive-thru at McDonalds.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The kanji and the vocab are exactly the same, even the reading. This one uses the on'yomi probably because it's often attached to other words (specifying a bureau, for example), so that's why it follows jukugo conventions despite being all alone.

ex_1_jp: タオルや石けん、おかし、おそばなどをもっていく場合が多いです。
ex_1_en: In many circumstances, we take things like towels, soap, snacks, or noodles.
ex_2_jp: 出来るかぎり早くEメールにへんしんできるよう努めておりますが、すぐにへんしんできない場合もありますのでごりゅういください。
ex_2_en: We try our best to respond your emails as soon as possible, but please note that we may not be able to respond immediately.
ex_3_jp: その場合には警察を呼んだ方がいいと思う。
ex_3_en: In this case, I think it would be good to call the police.
meaning_story: What suits a location? Or, another way to think about it, what happens when everything fits for that location? You have yourself a case or circumstance that happens because of the location and its suitability.
reading_story: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji. The exception here is that 合 is あい instead of just あ. It's strange, but this strangeness with kanji happens in certain circumstances. Just think "in this case, あ becomes あい because I (あい) said so.

ex_1_jp: 雲一つない青空でした。
ex_1_en: It was a blue sky without even a single cloud.
ex_2_jp: この間おごってくれたおかえしに、あそこの雲をあげるよ。
ex_2_en: I'll give you that cloud over there as thanks for when you treated me to a meal.
ex_3_jp: 飛行機は雲の後ろに消え、もう二度とその姿を現すことはなかった。
ex_3_en: The plane disappeared behind a cloud and was never seen again.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi reading because it's a single kanji on its own. Luckily, that's the reading you learned with the kanji already, so you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: あんたはそうやって楽することばっかり考えて！
ex_1_en: You only think about taking the easy way out!
ex_2_jp: このいすめっちゃ楽だわー。
ex_2_en: This chair is very comfortable!
ex_3_jp: 私は愛犬トトと一緒にいる時が一番楽です。
ex_3_en: I am most at ease when I am with my dog, Toto.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji you learned, too, making this one an ease to learn!
pitch_accent: ガꜜク *** ガク *** ラꜜク *** ラクꜜ

ex_1_jp: これじゃあ、全く話にならないよ。
ex_1_en: If you're going to be like this, then I can't take it seriously.
ex_2_jp: コウイチは、全く見かえりをもとめずに人助けをします。
ex_2_en: Koichi never asks for anything in return when he helps people.
ex_3_jp: コンドームも全く安全だって訳はない。俺の友達はゴムを着けてたけど、軽トラにはねられたしな。
ex_3_en: Condoms aren’t completely safe. My friend was wearing one and got hit by a pickup truck.
meaning_story: This is the adverb version of the kanji all. So, it's like you add an 'ly' to it. But, that doesn't work too well (allly? c'mon). So, instead think of this word as completely, entirely or one of the other definitions listed above.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The person who completely doesn't understand this vocab word is matt (まった). Be sure to take note of the small っ, too.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あととりあらそいで、兄と弟は対立してしまったんです。
ex_1_en: The older and younger brothers are in opposition over the succession dispute.
ex_2_jp: 対立するんじゃなく、一しょにきょう力してがんばろうよ！
ex_2_en: Why don't we cooperate and work hard together instead of competing?
ex_3_jp: もう一回俺のことを対立を避けるような人間だと言ってみろ！お前の顔面をぶん殴ってやる。
ex_3_en: I’ll punch you in the face if you say I’m a non-confrontational person one more time.
meaning_story: When you stand up versus someone, you're looking to get into a confrontation. Just imagine yourself doing this to someone bigger than you. You stand up to versus them and then realize this confrontation is a bad idea.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 男の人と女の人が、大学のろう下で会話をしています。
ex_1_en: A man and a woman are having a conversation in the hallway of the university.
ex_2_jp: ペースのはやい日本ごの会話は、まだりかい出来ません。
ex_2_en: I can't understand fast-paced Japanese dialogue yet.
ex_3_jp: どうして私達の会話はいつも野球についてなのでしょうか？
ex_3_en: Why are our conversations always about baseball?
meaning_story: When you meet your talk with someone else, you're having a conversation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: それでは、決をとりたいと思います。
ex_1_en: Well then I think that’s the decision I want to make.
ex_2_jp: なかなか決が出ないみたいだね。
ex_2_en: It seems that it's taking a while to make a decision, right?
ex_3_jp: ジョン、ホットドッグアイスなんてものを作り始める決を下したのはお前だろう？だから首になったんだよ。
ex_3_en: John, you made the decision to start making hotdog ice cream and that’s why you got fired.
meaning_story: Noun version of decide? It's a decision.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji!

ex_1_jp: あなたのおかげで、せい形手じゅつをする決心がつきました。
ex_1_en: Thanks to you, I’ve decided to get plastic surgery.
ex_2_jp: インスタセレブになるというトーフグの決心はトウフと同じぐらいかたい。
ex_2_en: Tofugu's resolution to being an Instagram celebrity is as firm as Tofu.
ex_3_jp: ついに、あなたに、どこから私の誕生日プレゼントの酒を買ってきてもらうか決心したよ。それは…日本だ。楽しんできてね！
ex_3_en: I’ve finally made up my mind about where you’ll be buying me drinks for my birthday... In Japan. Enjoy!
meaning_story: When you decide with your heart you have true determination, unlike when you decide with your mind.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just make sure you take note of the shortened つ. So, けつ goes to けっ.
pitch_accent: ケꜜッシン *** ケッシꜜン

ex_1_jp: 今日は医者に行かなくちゃいけない。
ex_1_en: I have to go see a doctor today.
ex_2_jp: ある夜、とあるあやしいレストランに、もくもくとサメを食べる三人の医者がいました。
ex_2_en: One night, in a shady restaurant, there were three doctors stuffing themselves with shark.
ex_3_jp: 僕は医者になりたいけど、人に触ることが嫌いなんだ。それってやっぱり問題かな？
ex_3_en: I want to be a doctor, but I hate touching people. Do you think that will be a problem?
meaning_story: Someone who works in medicine is a doctor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: おれのゆう者としての役目は、もうおわったんだ。
ex_1_en: My duty as a hero is already over.
ex_2_jp: サラさん、来客のめんどうを見るのはあなたの役目でしょう？
ex_2_en: Sarah, it is your business to take care of visitors, right?
ex_3_jp: 役目を果たせなかったことを残念に思っています。
ex_3_en: Unfortunately, I wasn't able to fulfill my duty.
meaning_story: If you have an eye for service, then you always think helping people is your duty! If you see it, then you offer your service. It's the right thing to do!
reading_story: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 役 and the kun'yomi reading for 目. You've learned them both so you should be able to read this word too!

ex_1_jp: えきの東口で大道げいをしている人がいたよ。
ex_1_en: There’s someone doing a street performance at the station’s east exit.
ex_2_jp: 東口でとった写しん、たぶん手ブレしたみたいで、ちょっとブレちゃってる。
ex_2_en: The photo taken at the east gate is a bit blurry, probably from the camera shaking.
ex_3_jp: 緊急の際には、このビルの東口から避難してください。そこでは、コーヒーとドーナツが支給される予定です。
ex_3_en: In the case of an emergency, please evacuate the building through the east exit. There will be coffee and donuts waiting for you there.
meaning_story: Remember how 入り口 means entrance and 出口 means exit? This is just the 口 part with a direction on it. That means it can be both entrance or exit. So when you have East up there this word can mean both East exit and East entrance. This is a great word to know if you need to know which side of a train station you need to leave on to go somewhere or meet someone!
reading_story: This word uses kun'yomi readings, possibly because of 口, which is a body part (body parts do that quite a bit in words and kanji). You should hopefully have seen both the kun'yomi readings from previous levels meaning you can read this word as well. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes くち to ぐち.

ex_1_jp: 電気をつけてください。
ex_1_en: Please turn on the light.
ex_2_jp: 電気をつけっぱなしにしないでって言ったじゃん！かせぎが少ないんだから、ちゃんと電気代せつやくにきょう力してよ。
ex_2_en: I told you not to leave lights on. You don't earn very much, so you'd better cooperate to save on the electricity bill!
ex_3_jp: 子供の頃は暗闇を恐れていたが、今は電気料金の請求書を受け取る度に、光が怖いと思うよ。
ex_3_en: When I was little I was afraid of the dark. Now, when I get my electric bill I’m afraid of the light.
meaning_story: Electricity energy is just a fancy way to say electricity.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 2016年4月から日本でスタートした、電力自由化についてくわしく教えてください。
ex_1_en: Can you tell me everything you know about the Electricity Liberalization that started in Japan in April of 2016.
ex_2_jp: あの電力会社には電気代をはらいたくないよ。
ex_2_en: I don't want to pay the bill to that electric company.
ex_3_jp: 電力が約三時間で復旧したので、私は面接の前に電動バリカンで頭を刈って整えることができました。
ex_3_en: Power was restored in roughly three hours and I was able to fix my hair with my electric hair clippers before the interview.
meaning_story: The electricity power of something is its electric power.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: デꜜンリョク *** デンリョク

ex_1_jp: 電子のおもさはいくらですか？
ex_1_en: How much does an electron weigh?
ex_2_jp: その電子ピアノを直すのに、どれくらい時間がかかると思いますか？
ex_2_en: How long do you think it will take to fix the electric piano?
ex_3_jp: ティラノサウルスは、1万電子ボルトの衝撃を受けた。
ex_3_en: The Tyrannosaurus Rex was shocked with 10,000 electron volts.
meaning_story: An electricity child. What is a really small part of electricity? What makes up electricity? That would be the electron. This word can also refer to things that are electronic as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: みなさんは絵文字はつかいますか？
ex_1_en: Do you all use emoji?
ex_2_jp: しいて言えば、この絵文字がすきです。
ex_2_en: If I had to choose, I like this emoji.
ex_3_jp: 一番よく使う絵文字を教えてください。
ex_3_en: Can you tell me which emoji you use the most?
meaning_story: When you use a drawing to replace your letters to type, you're using emoji! Those are the faces you send when you text or email.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「ルンバ」をはつ明したロボット工学者はだれですか？
ex_1_en: Who’s the robotics engineer that invented the Roomba?
ex_2_jp: あの工学者のことはきらいですが、そうするべきだと思ったから、助けてあげました。
ex_2_en: I helped that engineer, even though I don't like him, because I thought it was the right thing to do.
ex_3_jp: 工学者になるためには、長期間勉強をする必要があります。
ex_3_en: To become an engineer, you have to put in long hours of studying.
meaning_story: Do you remember 工学 from a couple levels ago? This is someone who is in 工学. If 工学 is "engineering" then 工学者 is an engineer.
reading_story: The readings are just the on'yomi readings of the kanji. All things you should know now.

ex_1_jp: 会場に入場するには、チケットが必ようです。
ex_1_en: You need a ticket to enter the venue.
ex_2_jp: さいしゅう入場時かんは午後五時です。
ex_2_en: Last admission is at 5 pm.
ex_3_jp: ちくしょう！「確実な死への部屋」への入場門が塞がれている。
ex_3_en: Damn it! The entrance to the "Room of Certain Death" is blocked.
meaning_story: The location from which you enter is where you make your entrance. It has to do with thing like "entrance fees" and "entrance was not permitted," etc.
reading_story: Unfortunately, you didn't learn the reading for 場 in this word. Just think of how when you go to the entrance, you are met by your friend Joe, who is standing there all cool. Welcome to the entrance, he says. (It will help if you imagine a Joe you know of in real life / from pop culture).

ex_1_jp: 毎朝、シャワーをあびます。
ex_1_en: I take a shower every morning
ex_2_jp: 毎朝、本当に楽しかったです。ありがとうございました。
ex_2_en: I had a really great time with you every morning. Thank you so much.
ex_3_jp: 毎朝ラジオ体操をします。
ex_3_en: I do radio exercises every morning.
meaning_story: Every morning is every morning!
reading_story: The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.
pitch_accent: マꜜイアサ *** マイアサ

pronunciation: こうじょう, こうば
ex_1_jp: トヨタの工場に行きたいんですけど、何で行くのがべんりですか。
ex_1_en: I’d like to go to the Toyota factory - which way would be the most convenient?
ex_2_jp: 毎ばん、ベーコン工場のせじょうをするのは、わたしの主人の役目です。
ex_2_en: It's my husband's job to lock up the bacon factory every night.
ex_3_jp: 私が働きたいと思う唯一の工場は、クッキー工場です。
ex_3_en: The only factory I would want to work in is a factory that makes cookies.
meaning_story: An industry location is a place that builds industry. Think of the industrial revolution. What did they have a lot of? The answer is: factory.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Unfortunately, you didn't learn the on'yomi reading for 場, so let's do that now! The factory you're building is one that builds people named Joe (じょう). It's a well kept secret that no person named "Joe" is a real person.
pitch_accent: コージョꜜー *** コーバꜜ

ex_1_jp: ポートランドのかん光名所を教えてください。
ex_1_en: Can you tell me about some Portland tourist spots?
ex_2_jp: 名所めぐりの日にちが近くなってきたら、またれんらくするね。
ex_2_en: I'll get in touch with you when we get closer to the day we're visiting famous places.
ex_3_jp: 私は、スターバックスやデニーズ、それからニューヨーク郵便局など数々の名所を見るために、ニューヨークへ行きます。
ex_3_en: I’m going to New York to see all the famous places like Starbucks, Denny’s, and the New York City post office.
meaning_story: A famous place is a famous place. When traveling around Japan, you should ask about the 名所 if you can.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ナドꜜコロ *** メイショꜜ *** メイショ

ex_1_jp: せん後、日本の対外せいさくはどのようにかわっていったのでしょうか。
ex_1_en: How did Japan’s foreign policy change postwar?
ex_2_jp: 日本の対外せいさくについてのポッドキャストをレコーディングしています。
ex_2_en: We are recording a podcast about Japan's foreign policy.
ex_3_jp: アメリカの対外債務が5000億ドルを突破した時に、俺の個人負債が500万ドルを突破したのは、単なる偶然なのか？
ex_3_en: Is it just a coincidence that my personal debt shot past $5 million when America’s foreign debt shot past $500 billion?
meaning_story: Something is versus the outside. Back in the day, everything was a battle with the outside. You had the Mongols... the rebels... and the foreigners. So, when you say something is "versus the outside" you're just saying it's something compared to where you are right now. It's something that's foreign or from overseas.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このゲームは、とても楽しくて、おも白いです。
ex_1_en: This game is really fun and interesting.
ex_2_jp: テレビを見ながら食べる方が、しゃべりながら食べるより楽しいよ。
ex_2_en: It's more fun to watch TV than chatting while eating.
ex_3_jp: 飛行機から飛び降りるって、物凄く楽しいよ！
ex_3_en: Jumping out of an airplane is so much fun!
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of pleasure? Well, you could say it's "pleasurable," but I'm afraid that's not what we're going for here. In this case, this word is a little more innocent. It just means fun.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: How much fun did you have? You just had a ton o' (たの) fun!

ex_1_jp: ぼくは、北海道で雪合せんをしたことがあります。
ex_1_en: I’ve gone yukigassen snowball fighting in Hokkaido.
ex_2_jp: 北海道についたどー！本もののすしを食べるどー！
ex_2_en: I've arrived in Hokkaido! Time to eat some real sushi!
ex_3_jp: 北海道のお土産といえば、何が有名でしょうか。
ex_3_en: Speaking of Hokkaido souvenirs, what’s famous?
meaning_story: The north sea road is the road you take to get to the northern sea. That is an area of Japan, actually. That area is known as Hokkaido. It's a very nice place, be sure to visit it if you can for some of the freshest seafood around.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ほく does get shortened though, so be careful!

ex_1_jp: あの馬に、ニンジンやリンゴをあげてもいいですか？
ex_1_en: Is it okay to give those horses carrots and apples?
ex_2_jp: わたしの馬は、また一つこんなんをのりこえました。
ex_2_en: My horse has overcome yet another difficulty.
ex_3_jp: お年寄りたちが次から次へと馬から落ちたの、めちゃくちゃ面白いと思うんだけど〜！
ex_3_en: I find it unreasonably funny when old people fall off of horses one after another.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Imagine someone riding a horse. Who is that person? It's Uma (うま) Thurman, the famous actress.

ex_1_jp: 自どう車の馬力を上げるには、どうすればいいですか。
ex_1_en: What’s the best way to increase a car’s horsepower?
ex_2_jp: アサヒのじいちゃんって、本当に馬力があるよね。
ex_2_en: Asahi, your grandpa is such an energetic person, isn't he?
ex_3_jp: 約四年間いじくり回したおかげで、今俺の芝刈り機は450馬力もあるんだぜ。
ex_3_en: I tinkered with my lawnmower for about four years and now it has 450 horsepower.
meaning_story: This word was probably made pretty recently. A horse's power? That is horsepower.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the reading for 力 is the りき version of the reading. You can remember this by thinking about how it's Ricky who drives the high horsepower cars. Vroom vroom Ricky!

ex_1_jp: さっきカフェで、人間のようにコーヒーをのんでるしば犬を見かけたよ。
ex_1_en: A while ago I saw a shiba inu drinking coffee like a human at a cafe.
ex_2_jp: わたしのすきなしは、あい田みつをの、「つまづいたって　いいじゃないか　にんげんだもの」というしです。人間というかん字がひらがなでかかれているところがすきです。
ex_2_en: My favorite poem is Mitsuo Aida's, "It’s ok to stumble, isn’t it, we are humans after all." I like this because the kanji for humans is written in hiragana.
ex_3_jp: 人間はいつも人生の目的について悩んでいる。でも、私はその答えを見つけた気がします。Tofuguで勉強することです！
ex_3_en: Humans have always wondered about the purpose of life. I believe I have found the answer: studying on Tofugu.
meaning_story: The person interval. Just think of different intervals each with a different type of species. The raccoon interval... the dog interval... the person interval... they are the humans.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. For 人 that's okay. For 間 it's something weird, something you didn't learn with the kanji. To remember this, think of the humans, living on this earth. They are only a small part of this earth's existence, though. This human generation (げん) is hopefully going to be a long one, but we'll see how that goes.

ex_1_jp: この大役をしっかりはたせるよう、一生けんめいがんばります！
ex_1_en: I will try with all my might to successfully accomplish this important task.
ex_2_jp: ずい分とまた大役を買って出たものだね。
ex_2_en: You volunteered for such a great duty, eh?
ex_3_jp: ロード・オブ・ザ・リングでフロドは大役を任されたが、靴も履かずに見事にやってのけた。
ex_3_en: Frodo, of the Lord of the Rings, was given the most important task and he did it all without putting on shoes.
meaning_story: A big duty is a great duty. It can also be an important task. Think about a some kind of big duty you have. Then, think about what an important task it is too. Feel proud of your important task.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: たいてい、ねている間は、だんぼうを切ります。
ex_1_en: Usually, I turn off the heater while I’m sleeping.
ex_2_jp: その間に、いそいでひるごはんをかきこみました。
ex_2_en: Meanwhile, I shoved my lunch in my mouth.
ex_3_jp: 筏を作っている間に、俺達みんな餓死にしちまうよ！泳いで川を渡った方が無難なんじゃないか？
ex_3_en: In the time it takes to build a raft we’ll die of starvation! Wouldn’t it be safer to just swim across the river?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Don't confuse this with 〜間 which is similar in meaning but different in reading. The 〜間 means it's attached to something. This is a standalone word.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: In terms of intervals of time, time goes stagnant when you arrive in Idaho (あいだ). No time intervals move when you're there. Imagine this actually happening. You're looking into the state of Idaho and seeing everyone move at a snails pace because time moves differently there. If you don't know where Idaho is, you can alternatively think about a mnemonic you'd make. You say: "In terms of a new mnemonic, I'd uhh... (あいだ) uh... I can't think of anything better, that's a hard one!"
pitch_accent: アꜜイ *** アイダ *** カꜜン *** マ

ex_1_jp: 研究にねっ中しすぎて、気がついたら12時をすぎていました。
ex_1_en: I was so absorbed in my research that when I noticed it was already past 12 o'clock.
ex_2_jp: わたしは、トーフグの研究者で、バイオ医やくひんのせいぞう研究にたずさわっています。
ex_2_en: I'm a Tofugu researcher taking part in the study of biopharmaceutical production.
ex_3_jp: 現在、我々の巨人に関する研究に参加を希望する申込者を受付けている。
ex_3_en: We are currently accepting applicants to participate in our research study of Titans.
meaning_story: When you sharpen research you're just doing a study or investigation. Oh, and to make things simple, you're also doing research as well!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お前は本当にしんそうを究明するつもりがあるのか？
ex_1_en: Are you really going to investigate the truth?
ex_2_jp: コウイチのおかしな言どうのしんのどうきはまだ究明されていない。
ex_2_en: The true motive behind Koichi's strange words and deeds have not yet been brought to light.
ex_3_jp: 私が大学で取っている授業の一つで、現在「鳥が先か卵が先か」について究明しているんです。
ex_3_en: One of the classes I’m taking in college is currently investigating whether the chicken or the egg came first.
meaning_story: When you brighten your research it's like you're shedding light on it. To do that, you have to perform an investigation. This word is particularly used in academic and scientific situations.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 前回のじゅぎょうでは、カエルのかいぼうをしました。
ex_1_en: Last class we dissected a frog.
ex_2_jp: それでは、前回のつづきからはじめたいと思います。
ex_2_en: Okay so... we will continue from where we ended last time.
ex_3_jp: 前回のレッスンの復習は家でちゃんとやってきましたか？
ex_3_en: Did you guys review the last lesson at home properly?
meaning_story: The before time was last time.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ゼꜜンカイ *** ゼンカイ

ex_1_jp: そういえば、この前、しょうてんがいでさくら子ちゃんとバッタリ会ったよ。
ex_1_en: That reminds me, last time I was at the shopping district I ran into Sakurako.
ex_2_jp: この前、日本ごの曲のCDを買ったんだよね。
ex_2_en: I recently bought a Japanese music CD.
ex_3_jp: この前、思わずノートをとるぐらい完璧な日没を見たのはいつだったかな？
ex_3_en: When was the last time I saw a sunset so perfect that I had to take note of it?
meaning_story: この means "this." And, you know what the word 前 means (front/before). So "this before" has to do with something that happened previously. That's why this word means last time, recently, and lately.
reading_story: The reading for 前 is the kun'yomi, like the reading for the vocabulary word 前. So long as you know that word, you'll be able to read this one too. The reason it's not on'yomi is because it's like two words put together. The word この and the word 前.

ex_1_jp: おかしいなー、ちゃんと長さをはかったつもりなんだけどなー。
ex_1_en: Weird, I was sure I measured the length properly.
ex_2_jp: こちらのヘビは3センチたんいの長さで切り売りはん売しています。
ex_2_en: This snake is sold in three centimeter long pieces.
ex_3_jp: 僕がよろめいてしまった主な原因は橋の長さです。僕にはちょっと長すぎました。
ex_3_en: The length of the bridge was one of the main reasons why I faltered. It was just too long for me.
meaning_story: You know the word 長い from a couple levels ago. This is like the word 大きい versus 大きさ, where 大きさ is "size" and 大きい is "big." So, 長い is "long" and 長さ is length.
reading_story: If you know the reading of the word 長い from level 6 you'll know the reading for this word too. Only difference is the さ at the end, which is hiragana so it should be easy to read.

ex_1_jp: マリメッコの生地でクッションを作りました。
ex_1_en: I made a cushion out of Marimekko fabric.
ex_2_jp: このカーテンは、パラシュート生地でできています。
ex_2_en: This curtain is made of parachute material.
ex_3_jp: 冷凍のパイ生地を買ってきてください。
ex_3_en: Please go buy a frozen piecrust.
meaning_story: Life that comes out of the earth is made up of different kinds of materials. Sometimes it's cloth, sometimes it's dough, but everything has to be made out of something.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 生 and the on'yomi reading for 地. You haven't learned either of these readings yet, sorry! Here's some mnemonics to help you: If you want the best material to make clothes or pies out of, the key (き)is asking Jesus (じ)! He knows everything, including where to find the materials for whatever weird thing you're making. Just remember: Who's the key? Jesus!

ex_1_jp: 川下さんは、石田中学校で数学の先生をしています。
ex_1_en: Ms. Kawashita is a mathematics teacher at Ishida junior high school.
ex_2_jp: 数学のしけん、明日だっていうのに、海人はホントききかんがねーよな。
ex_2_en: The math exam is tomorrow, but Kaito doesn't seem to have any sense of urgency.
ex_3_jp: 数学さんよ、どうか大人になって自分の問題は自分で解決してくれよな。
ex_3_en: Dear Math, please grow up and solve your own problems by yourself.
meaning_story: The study of numbers is mathematics (or math).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: さい近は、医学の本を月に三さつぐらいよんでいます。
ex_1_en: Lately, I’ve been reading about three medical science books a month.
ex_2_jp: わたしの兄は、医学ぶを目ざしています。
ex_2_en: My older brother is trying to get into a medical school.
ex_3_jp: 医学はいつも最新の薬を発見し続けている。昨日は、医者が皿洗いをするようになる薬を私にくれたよ。
ex_3_en: Medical science is always discovering new medications. Just yesterday, my doctor gave me a pill that makes it so I can wash dishes.
meaning_story: The study of medicine is medical science. It can also be called medicine, but make sure to think of it as the "medicine" where it has to do with "medical science."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: わたしは、医大を目ざしてべん強しています。
ex_1_en: I’m studying to get into medical school.
ex_2_jp: 医者のたまごをかれ氏にするため、医大生のふりをして、医大にせん入してみました。
ex_2_en: I pretended to be a med student and snuck into med school to find a future doctor boyfriend.
ex_3_jp: 私は、ポケモンコレクションを売って、医大の学費を払った。
ex_3_en: I paid my tuition for med school by selling my Pokémon collection.
meaning_story: You've seen 大学 to mean "college." So take the 大 and put it with medicine to create "medicine college," or medical university.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: さい近、地中海りょうりにハマっているんですよね。
ex_1_en: Lately, I’ve been obsessed with Mediterranean cooking.
ex_2_jp: ただ今、地中海からきたく中でーす。
ex_2_en: I'm on my way home from the Mediterranean Sea.
ex_3_jp: 夏休みに、家族で地中海をクルーズしてきました。
ex_3_en: I went on a cruise with my family on the Mediterranean Sea over summer vacation.
meaning_story: Earth's middle sea is the Mediterranean Sea. It may not look like it's in the middle of the earth, but a long time ago that's what people thought. It's the sea between Southern Europe and Northern Africa.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 先生が、じゅう道のルールややり方を教えます。
ex_1_en: The teacher is going to teach the rules and the methods of Judo.
ex_2_jp: 北海道で、けん道をきわめるつもりです。
ex_2_en: I'm gonna master the way of sword in Hokkaido.
ex_3_jp: 武士道と騎士道の違いについて説明してください。
ex_3_en: Could you please explain the difference between bushido and chivalry?
meaning_story: This is a word that's attached to the end of various other words. Think of a "road" as a way or method of something. For example, the どう in Judo is the soft "way." There are many words that end with 道, and you'll see them later on. For now, know that this means method of or way.
reading_story: This word is added to the end of many different words, meaning it's treated like most jukugo (and uses an on'yomi reading). You know the on'yomi reading, so you should be able to read this word. Be sure to drop the 〜 when writing in the reading in the test, though. It's only there to show that it's added onto things and not part of the correct answer.

ex_1_jp: 天のうのいる日本は君主国ですか、それとも民主国ですか？
ex_1_en: Japan has an emperor, so is it a monarchy or a democracy?
ex_2_jp: やっとこの君主国にもどって来たぜ！
ex_2_en: Ah, I'm finally back in this monarchy!
ex_3_jp: イギリス君主国は、別のラップ音楽のビデオを作る締め切りをまた大幅に過ぎている。
ex_3_en: The British Monarchy is long overdue for making another rap music video.
meaning_story: When you're buddy-buddy with the master of a country, you are rewarded splendidly. Why? Because this is a monarchy where being buddies with the master is a very advantageous thing!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 朝のあいさつをしてください。
ex_1_en: Please say the morning greeting.
ex_2_jp: 朝は毎日、トロトロの半じゅく目玉やきを食べます。
ex_2_en: Every morning I eat over easy and sunny-side-up eggs.
ex_3_jp: 明日の朝は早起きをしなくてはいけません。だって、XBOXをプレイしまくるという長い一日が待っているから。
ex_3_en: I have to wake up early tomorrow morning because I have a long day of XBOX playing to do.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Hopefully this means you won't have to wake up too early in the morning to study kanji, now.

ex_1_jp: 明日の朝、一しょに山にのぼって朝日を見ませんか？
ex_1_en: Would you like to climb a mountain with me tomorrow morning to see the morning sun?
ex_2_jp: どうしてあの朝日の絵をかべから外してしまったんですか？
ex_2_en: Why did you take the picture of the rising sun off of the wall?
ex_3_jp: 日本は「日野出国」として知られているが、それは「日出ずる国」に見事に描写されている。
ex_3_en: Japan is known as "the Land of the Rising Sun," which is excellently depicted on its "Rising Sun" flag.
meaning_story: The morning sun is not only the morning sun, but it's the rising sun as well (because that's when the sun rises, right?).
reading_story: The readings are both kun'yomi readings, though you've either learned or come across both of these readings. Perhaps you can think of it this way: The morning sun is when you wake up... you're lazy. So, you use the kun'yomi readings because they're the traditional Japanese readings, not the Chinese ones. Maybe in the evening you'll switch to on'yomi, but for the morning, it's kun'yomi all the way until you've had your coffee.

ex_1_jp: べん強してから音楽をききます。
ex_1_en: I’ll listen to music after I study.
ex_2_jp: 音楽をききながら仕ごとをすることはよくないと思いますか？
ex_2_en: Do you think it isn't good to work while listening to music?
ex_3_jp: 違ったタイプの音楽が創りだされることはもう無いのかなって思ったりするんだよね。あなたは、人類は既に全ジャンルの音楽を全て創りだしちゃったと思う？
ex_3_en: I wonder if another type of music will be created. Do you think mankind already made every possible genre?
meaning_story: What is the sound of pleasure? What sound puts you at ease? For most people that is some nice music. Just be sure you don't put on any Bieber... that would be like 不音楽 or something... I kid, I kid.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 楽 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you play your music too loud, people will come and gawk (がく) at you. But if you try to turn it off and say, "OH WHAT I DON'T LIKE MUSIC ANYWAY!" they'll gawk at you even more. Learn proper music etiquette and people won't gawk at you so much, okay?
pitch_accent: オꜜンカ°ク *** オンカ°ク

ex_1_jp: あの人の名前は何ですか。
ex_1_en: What is that person’s name?
ex_2_jp: 名前はきいたことがあるけど、あまりよく知らないかな。
ex_2_en: I've heard the name, but I don't know much about it.
ex_3_jp: 私は名前を「ああ」に、名字を「そうそう」に変えたい。
ex_3_en: I want to change my first name to "Ah" and my last name to "Soso."
meaning_story: Your name that's in the front. That is not your last name, that is your regular name or your first name.
reading_story: This word uses both kun'yomi readings (oh darn!). That being said, you've seen the kun'yomi readings for both the kanji that make up this word. The word 名 (な) and the word 前 (まえ) both are kun'yomi, so use those words and Voltron them into a single word, なまえ.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: こんな当たり前のこと、どうして分からないの？
ex_1_en: This is normal stuff, why can’t you get that?
ex_2_jp: でも、これが当たり前のことだとは思わないでくださいね。
ex_2_en: Don't take it for granted though.
ex_3_jp: 今日のような当たり前の日をすごせることに、かんしゃしなきゃいけませんよね。
ex_3_en: Shouldn't we be thankful we're able to have an ordinary day like today.
meaning_story: You've seen how 当たり means success. If you've experienced success before, everything after that seems to be pretty obvious.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あのう、お知らせしたいことがあるんですが、今、いいですか？
ex_1_en: Excuse me, I have something that I’d like to tell you - do you have some time now?
ex_2_jp: 学校からのお知らせはもうよみましたか？
ex_2_en: Did you read the notice from the school already?
ex_3_jp: 残念なお知らせがあります。昨夜誰かがこの家に侵入し、冷凍庫に入っていたアイスクリームを全部盗んでしまいました。
ex_3_en: I have some bad news. Someone broke into our home last night and stole all the ice cream we had stored in our freezer.
meaning_story: This is a strange word, so you'll have to bear with me. You know that 知 means know. But in the case of this word, what do you know? Look at the second half. らせ sounds a bit like "race." So, you know about a "race." How do you know about this race? You got a notice or notification about it.
reading_story: Remember 知る? This is the same reading (し). So, if you know that, you'll be able to read this one as well.

ex_1_jp: あなたのじゅけん番号は何番ですか？
ex_1_en: What is your exam number?
ex_2_jp: 三十分で、この番号をおぼえてください。
ex_2_en: You have 30 minutes to memorize a series of numbers.
ex_3_jp: 今、めちゃくちゃ落ち込んでるんだよ。だって、彼女に偽の電話番号を渡されたんだよ。
ex_3_en: I’m really disappointed right now because she gave me a fake phone number.
meaning_story: A number in a series plus a number. You know what happens when two kanji with basically the same meaning get combined into one by now, right? It just turns out to be the same meaning, basically. This word means number.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: おかしいわ、どうしても数が合わないのよ。
ex_1_en: Oh weird, the numbers don't match for some reason.
ex_2_jp: 1985年におきたニューヨーク大地しんの死しゃの数は何人でしたか？
ex_2_en: What was the death toll of the 1985 New York earthquake?
ex_3_jp: この映画には、数々の日本映画のお兄ちゃん役で知られているコウイチが、数を数えるのが得意な数学教師の役で出演しています。
ex_3_en: In this movie, the role of the math teacher who is good at counting is played by Koichi, who is known for playing the role of numerous older brother figures in countless Japanese films.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Imagine yourself counting by playing a kazoo (かず). Each number you count, you toot your kazoo. How fun!

ex_1_jp: イチゴあじのあめが、この中で一番すきです。
ex_1_en: I like the strawberry flavored candy best out of all of these.
ex_2_jp: わたしが人生で一番さいしょによんだ教かしょは、テキストフグです。
ex_2_en: The first textbook I read in my life was Textfugu.
ex_3_jp: シドニー・クロスビーは、世界で一番うまいホッケー選手だ。
ex_3_en: Sydney Crosby is the number one hockey player in the world.
meaning_story: When you're the number one in a number in a series, you're number one ba-bay!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: イチꜜバン *** イチバン *** ヒトꜜツカ°イ

ex_1_jp: き末しけんで、学年で二番になりました。
ex_1_en: I got second place in final exams for my year.
ex_2_jp: これは二番目に古いゴジラえいがです。
ex_2_en: This is the second oldest Godzilla movie.
ex_3_jp: カルロス・スリムは、世界大富豪番付けで二番に順位を下げた。
ex_3_en: Carlos Slim fell to the number two spot on the list of the world’s richest people.
meaning_story: When you're number two in a number in a series you're number two. Not quite as good as being 一番, but take what you can get, you know?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 数字がのびるからといって、下ひんなきじをけいさいするのはよした方がいい。
ex_1_en: Regardless of the increase in numbers, you shouldn’t publish vulgar news stories.
ex_2_jp: この子は、一万五千六百七十二けたの数字をあん記している天才じです。
ex_2_en: This child is a genius who memorized a 15,672-digit number.
ex_3_jp: 数字の十一は、私がバレーボールをする時にいつも身に付ける背番号です。
ex_3_en: Eleven is the number I always wear when I play volleyball.
meaning_story: A number letter isn't a letter like the ones you're reading now, it's more like a numeral, like 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, etc.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: しんじられないような出来ごとが次々とおこったんです。
ex_1_en: Seemingly unbelievable events were occurring one after the other.
ex_2_jp: コウイチかんとくは、さく夜、Youtubeで次々とヒット作を生み出すゆめを見ました。
ex_2_en: Last night, Director Koichi had a dream that he made one Youtube hit after another.
ex_3_jp: ヨーロッパの街は、次々と疫病に侵されていった。
ex_3_en: One by one, the cities of Europe fell to the plague.
meaning_story: When something is happening next, next (next next next), it's happening in succession, or one by one. Just imagine a line of people going through to get stamps on their heads. The person at the stamp counter is saying "Next! Next!" and then shouting "C'mon people, one by one, alright?"
reading_story: The reading is the same as the word 次 (so it's つぎ), but this time you do it twice. No strange rendaku or anything like that either, which makes everyone happier.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: その考えには反対です。
ex_1_en: I’m opposed to the idea.
ex_2_jp: 不自由の男神は、アッパーわんをはさんで、自由の女神の反対がわに立っています。
ex_2_en: The Statue of Restriction is standing on the opposite side of the Statue of Liberty in middle of the Upper Bay.
ex_3_jp: チェンジビルに引っ越してからというもの、あいつは昔のあいつとは正反対の人間になっちまったんだ。
ex_3_en: He’s the complete opposite of what he used to be like ever since he moved to Changeville.
meaning_story: The anti versus... You'd think this would be a double negative, but it's like a lot of other words where you have two similar words combined... it just means the same thing as those two words. In this case, the anti-versus of something would be the opposite. Alternatively, it can be the opposition. You choose.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 向こうのパンやで、パンを買いましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s buy bread at the bakery over there.
ex_2_jp: 一花は、向こうの世界からやって来たのかもしれない。
ex_2_en: Ichika might have come from the other side of the world.
ex_3_jp: もし君が道路の向こう側に立つのであれば、私の秘密を君に打ち明けるよ。
ex_3_en: I’ll tell you my secret if you go stand on the opposite side of the road.
meaning_story: You know that 向 means yonder. So, think of a "yonder こういち." All you know is that he's over there on the other side / opposite side of where you are. Basically, he's just pretty far away, wherever he is.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Standing with こういち is a cow. It is saying moo (む). Weird, now こういち is saying it too. Also, if you know the reading of 向く you should be able to read this one as well.

ex_1_jp: この絵は、クリックでかく大します。
ex_1_en: The picture gets bigger when you click it.
ex_2_jp: この絵をかべにかけ直してくれませんか？
ex_2_en: Could you put this picture back on the wall?
ex_3_jp: 昨夜美術館からピカソの絵が五枚も盗まれたが、誰も気にしていないようだ。
ex_3_en: Five Picasso paintings were stolen out of the museum last night, but nobody seems to care.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: しょうさいは未決です。
ex_1_en: The details are undecided.
ex_2_jp: 未決しょるいは、コウイチのデスクの上の赤いトレイに入れてください。
ex_2_en: Please put the pending documents in the red tray on Koichi's desk.
ex_3_jp: 彼女の裁判はもう十三年近くも未決となっています。そんなに待たなくてはいけないなんて、とても不公平です。
ex_3_en: Her court case has been pending for nearly 13 years. It’s so unfair to have to wait that long.
meaning_story: Something that is not yet decided... it is pending... it is unsettled.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 分からない所があれば、手を上げてください。
ex_1_en: If there’s a spot you don’t understand, please raise your hand.
ex_2_jp: まだおとし所をさがしていると中です。
ex_2_en: We are still searching for common ground.
ex_3_jp: 七十二回も同じ所を歩いているので、私達は道に迷ったんだと思います。
ex_3_en: I think we’re lost because we’ve walked by the same place 72 times now.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Here's the place! Either you have to talk or row (ところ). If you talk, maybe you can talk your way out of this problem you're in. If you row, you may be able to escape. Either way, this is the place for it.

ex_1_jp: いつもは教室にあつまりますが、明日は場所がちがうので、まちがえないでくださいね。
ex_1_en: Usually we gather in the classroom, but the location is different tomorrow, so make sure you don’t go to the wrong place.
ex_2_jp: 自分がたたかうべき場所をきちんと知っておくべきだ。
ex_2_en: You should know your own battlefield.
ex_3_jp: この場所は私が初めてローズに会った場所です。でも、あの日どうして靴を脱いだのかは思い出せません。
ex_3_en: This is the place where I first met Rose. But, I forget why I took my shoes off that day.
meaning_story: A location place is a either a place or a location, just like the kanji it's made from.
reading_story: So long as you know the readings from the kanji, you'll know the reading of this word too. What a good place you are in!

ex_1_jp: ワニカニに百点まん点で点数をつけるなら、何点になると思いますか？
ex_1_en: If you were to give WaniKani a score out of 100, how many points would you give it?
ex_2_jp: この点数は、こないだくれたプレゼントのおかえしだよ。
ex_2_en: These points are in return for the present you gave me.
ex_3_jp: 「どうしてそのテストでこんなに低い点数をとったの？」「欠席のせい。つまり、僕の隣の席の子が休んでたんだよ。」
ex_3_en: "Why did you get such a low grade on that test?" "Because of absences. I mean, the kid who sits next to me was absent."
meaning_story: The number of points is how many points there are (aka the score).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 交番で、大しかんまでの道をききました。
ex_1_en: I asked for directions to the embassy at the police box.
ex_2_jp: 新しく入って来たヒマリちゃんは、この交番のアイドルです。
ex_2_en: Himari, the new girl in this police box, is Miss Popular.
ex_3_jp: すみません、お巡りさん。一番近い交番はどこですか？ある男が私のことをデブと言ったので、警察を呼ぶ必要があるんです。
ex_3_en: Excuse me, officer. Where is the nearest police box? I need to call the police because some man just called me fat.
meaning_story: I have no idea how this one works, admittedly. You mix a number in a series and you get a police box. A police box? Who would want to work in one of those? Think of it this way: all the police have to draw numbers from a hat (they're all mixed up in there). Those who pull out the wrong numbers are on police box duty. That's why mixed numbers in a series = police box. Do you see it?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この番組はおも白くありませんでしたが、わたしのすきなはいゆうが出ていました。
ex_1_en: This TV program wasn’t interesting, but my favorite actor was in it.
ex_2_jp: きのうの番組で、あの二人はついに両しゃがなっとくするだきょうあんにたどりついたよ。
ex_2_en: In the yesterday's program, those two finally managed to work out a compromise.
ex_3_jp: 最近はバラエティ番組しか見ません。
ex_3_en: I haven’t watched anything but variety programs lately.
meaning_story: Use a number in a series to group the things you watch and listen to. That makes them your programs. Your TV and radio programs, specifically. If you watch TV you'll hear it a lot!
reading_story: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 番 and the kun'yomi reading for 組. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too!
pitch_accent: バンク°ミ *** バンク°ミꜜ

ex_1_jp: せいじ家や役人には下手にさからわない方がいい。
ex_1_en: You shouldn’t carelessly disobey politicians or public officials.
ex_2_jp: コウイチはトーフグの社長であるだけでなく、文ぶ科学しょうの役人でもある。
ex_2_en: Koichi is not only the president of Tofugu but also an official in the Ministry of Education.
ex_3_jp: 私の街の役人の一人が、カメラの前で嘘をついたということで、調べを受けている。
ex_3_en: One of my city’s public officials is under investigation for lying on camera.
meaning_story: A person with duty is someone who works for the government... a government official or public official.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: こんなしん夜に大声でけんかをしたら、近りんの住人にめいわくだろう。
ex_1_en: If you argue loudly so late at night, you’ll bother your neighbors.
ex_2_jp: 話し合いの末、森の住人とみずうみの住人は、一しょに百本のけんを買うことにした。
ex_2_en: After talking it over, forest-dwellers and lake-dwellers agreed to buy 100 swords together.
ex_3_jp: 私は地球の住人です。パーティーにようこそ。
ex_3_en: I am a resident of planet Earth. Welcome to the party.
meaning_story: A person of a dwelling is someone who lives at that dwelling. They are a resident.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 男の人が、交番で道をたずねています。
ex_1_en: A man is stopping by a police box for directions.
ex_2_jp: ほら、千里の道も一歩からって言うでしょ？
ex_2_en: They say a journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step, right?
ex_3_jp: この道を車で20分ぐらい行けば、未確認動物ビッグフットが目撃された場所に辿り着くよ。
ex_3_en: Drive down this road for about twenty minutes and you’ll come to the place where an unidentified creature was spotted.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Don't confuse this with the word 〜道, though. This one doesn't have a 〜 at the beginning, meaning it's not attached to other words. This word is just plain old road. It has its own meaning!
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're walking down the road. On the road, you bump into your friend, Mitch (みち). Imagine saying hello, then continuing down the road. What's weird is you're both walking down a paved road with cars on it. Seems dangerous, but you and Mitch, you know what you're doing. If you don't know anyone named Mitch, think of a famous Mitch or a Mitch you've made up.

ex_1_jp: コウイチが、クママン役でドラマに出えんすることになりました。
ex_1_en: Koichi played the role of Kumaman in the drama.
ex_2_jp: コウイチは役作りのために、一年間ホームレスになってみました。
ex_2_en: In order to prepare for the part, Koichi became a homeless for a year.
ex_3_jp: マイケル、めちゃくちゃ役になりきってるじゃん。
ex_3_en: Michael is throwing himself into the role very well, eh?
meaning_story: If you have a certain duty then it's your job to play that role. You have to play the part. Like in a play!
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji you learned, meaning you should be able to read this one as well.

ex_1_jp: かれのお父さんは、立ぱな学者です。
ex_1_en: His father is a splendid scholar.
ex_2_jp: あの学者はけいれきさしょうをしています。
ex_2_en: That scholar is a resume faker.
ex_3_jp: 私は世界でも有名なハロー・キティ学者です。
ex_3_en: I am a world renowned scholar of Hello Kitty.
meaning_story: Someone who does study for a living. That is a scholar.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あんまり自分を安売りすると、後で辛くなりますよ。
ex_1_en: If you sell yourself too short, it’ll be tough later.
ex_2_jp: このジャケット、めっちゃ好きだけど、ちょっとよゆうがないんですよね。近々安売りするよていとかってないですかね？
ex_2_en: I really love this jacket, but can't afford it. Are there any upcoming sales?
ex_3_jp: そうだよ。君に売った時にはそのテレビは壊れていたさ。でも、だからこそ安売りしたんじゃないか。
ex_3_en: Yes, the tv was broken when I sold it to you, but that’s why it was on sale.
meaning_story: When you sell something cheap, you're selling it at a discount. Alternatively you can remember this word as sell cheaply or bargain sale. These are good deals!
reading_story: The hiragana on the end hints that the reading is the kun'yomi readings. Use your memory of 安い and 売る to help you to remember how to read this.

ex_1_jp: 数年がすぎさった。
ex_1_en: Several years passed.
ex_2_jp: 数年前まで、日本に住んでいました。
ex_2_en: I lived in Japan until a few years ago.
ex_3_jp: この絵が完成するには、あと数年かかります。
ex_3_en: It will take several years for that painting to be complete.
meaning_story: When a number of years have passed you say that several years have passed! You don't want to say how many years, so just say several years.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうして自てん車が歩道を走ってはいけないんですか？
ex_1_en: Why can’t bicycles travel on sidewalks?
ex_2_jp: まもなくうごく歩道がおわりますので、足元にごちゅういください。
ex_2_en: You are approaching the end of the moving walkway. Please watch your step.
ex_3_jp: 自転車は、忙しい車道じゃなく、歩道を走るべきだ。
ex_3_en: Bicycles should be ridden on sidewalks, not on busy city streets.
meaning_story: The road you walk on is the sidewalk... at least I hope that's where you walk.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: わたしが合図をしたら、大声で「エイドリアーン！」とさけんでください。
ex_1_en: When I give the signal, yell, "Adrian!" loudly.
ex_2_jp: わたしに、売りか買いかの合図の出し方をおしえてくれませんか？
ex_2_en: Can you teach me how to give the buy or sell signal, please?
ex_3_jp: 彼女は彼に、秘密の合図を送った。
ex_3_en: She sent a secret signal to him.
meaning_story: A diagram everyone joins together to see is a sign!
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 合 and the on'yomi reading for 図. Luckily, you've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this!

ex_1_jp: 間もなくかいえんです！
ex_1_en: The curtain rises soon.
ex_2_jp: 大学いん研究生のしょう学金についてのへんじが、間もなく来るはずです。
ex_2_en: I'll probably get a reply regarding the postgraduate research scholarship before long.
ex_3_jp: もう間もなく夕飯が出来上がる頃ですが、クッキーを食べる手が止まりません。
ex_3_en: Supper will be ready really soon but I still can’t stop eating these cookies.
meaning_story: The もなく part is like saying "also don't have." So, when you "also don't have an interval of time," things will happen soon or before long.
reading_story: The reading for this one is weird, though. It's a second kun'yomi reading (there is also あいだ), read as ま. So what is happening soon? Your Ma is going to be here before long. You better hurry and prepare, because your room looks terrible... "間もなく," your mom is about to show up!"

ex_1_jp: このニュースの出所はどこですか？
ex_1_en: Where’s the source of this news?
ex_2_jp: 出所したら、ちゃんとかしをかえしてくれよな。
ex_2_en: When you get out of the prison, please return the favor, okay?
ex_3_jp: この名言は、シェイクスピアが出所だと思っていました。
ex_3_en: I thought this quote was originally from Shakespeare.
meaning_story: The place from which something exits is the source or origin of that thing. Just think of a baby being born. That exit place is their origin. Note: Some Japanese people may look at this word and think about someone being released from prison, but that's really only in spoken Japanese. For our purposes (reading comprehension), remember this as source!
reading_story: The reading follows on'yomi protocols, but you just have to be careful of the shortened しゅつ which becomes しゅっ.
pitch_accent: シュッショ *** シュꜜッショ *** デドコꜜ

ex_1_jp: 学生時代に、バックパッカーとして南米をりょ行しました。
ex_1_en: In my school days, I took a backpacking trip through South America.
ex_2_jp: このホテルの水道水は、南米で今までのんだ水の中で一番おいしい。
ex_2_en: This hotel's tap water is the best water I’ve ever had in South America.
ex_3_jp: ごめんなさい。南米はアメリカの一部だと思っていました。
ex_3_en: I’m sorry. I thought South America was a part of the United States of America.
meaning_story: Remember how 米国 can also mean America? That goes for North and South America, actually, not just the United States. So, south America is South America.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: そこに行くなら、南口から出るのが一番近いです。
ex_1_en: If you’re going there, leaving from the south exit is the fastest.
ex_2_jp: このモールの南口で今UFOが見られるよ！
ex_2_en: You can see a UFO at the southern entrance of this mall right now!
ex_3_jp: 新宿南口でナンパされた。
ex_3_en: I was hit on at the south exit of Shinjuku station.
meaning_story: The South mouth isn't actually a mouth you find in the south pole or anything, it's an entrance or exit. This is kind of like how 入り口 means entrance (the 口 represents a doorway). You'll see this word a lot in places like train stations or airports. It means both South exit and South entrance.
reading_story: The reading for these kanji are both kun'yomi. Probably because it's two words put together (South + Exit) rather than a single word. Also, body parts tend to change words into kun'yomi readings as well. So, you've seen vocab words that give you the kun'yomi reading of both 南 and 口, right? Now you just need to combine the two vocab readings into one to be able to read this word. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes くち to ぐち.

ex_1_jp: あの人と同じ空間にいるだけで心がいやされるんです。
ex_1_en: Just being in the same space as that person can heal your heart.
ex_2_jp: 日本人の中には、ベビーカーは空間をたくさんとるので、まんいん電車ではきん止にするべきだとかんがえる人もいます。
ex_2_en: Some Japanese people think that strollers should be banned in crowded trains because they take up a lot of space.
ex_3_jp: 宇宙空間には空気がないけど、それでもやっぱり月に住みたい。
ex_3_en: Even though there is no air in space, I still want to live on the moon.
meaning_story: The sky interval is an area of the sky. In places that are just empty sky, there is only space. Of course, not technically... there's something there, but back in the day when kanji was being made, nobody knew that. This word can mean both space in regards to outer space as well as the space around you in your room.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: とくいな科目とにが手な科目を教えてください。
ex_1_en: Tell me about your strong subjects and weak subjects.
ex_2_jp: 多分、その科目、さいじゅこうしないといけないと思う。
ex_2_en: I probably have to retake that course.
ex_3_jp: 好きな科目は何ですか？
ex_3_en: What subjects do you like?
meaning_story: If you've got an eye for science you're going to end up taking lots of subjects in school. After all, science is tied to almost all learning. All those courses are exactly what you have your sciencey eyes on!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あのさむらいは自決した。
ex_1_en: That samurai committed suicide.
ex_2_jp: コウイチ社長は、トーフグは自決けんを強く心からしじするということを、何どもくりかえした。
ex_2_en: President Koichi reiterated Tofugu's strong and wholehearted support for our right to self-determination.
ex_3_jp: 彼は、獄中で絶望し、自決してしまったんです。
ex_3_en: He was depressed during his imprisonment and committed suicide.
meaning_story: When you decide with your self, that is your own decision. That comes from you. That comes from your self determination. But the word is mainly used in Japan as an euphemism for suicide. It's kind of important that you know that.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 電話で家ぞくと話しています。
ex_1_en: I’m talking on the phone with my family.
ex_2_jp: 夜おそくに電話してごめんね。
ex_2_en: Sorry to call you so late at night.
ex_3_jp: アレクサンダー・グラハム・ベルが自分の電話の着信音を何にしていたのかが気になります。
ex_3_en: I wonder what ringtone Alexander Graham Bell had on his telephone.
meaning_story: An electricity talk. What is this witchcraft? The only way to talk via electricity is with a telephone.
