reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 明日は、学校で身体そくていがあります。
ex_1_en: There will be body measurements tomorrow at school.
ex_2_jp: この図しょかんには、身体しょうがいしゃがつかえるトイレはありますか？
ex_2_en: Is there a handicap accessible restroom in this library?
ex_3_jp: 空こうで、まやくをかくしもっていないか、身体けんさをされました。
ex_3_en: At the airport, they searched me for hidden drugs.
meaning_story: Somebody's body. This refers to the very general word the body. As in, "the human body" or something like that. This can also refer to health as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: カラオケに行く人数は全ぶで何人ですか。
ex_1_en: What’s the total number of people going to karaoke?
ex_2_jp: トーフグのあたらしいライターのぼしゅう人数は何人ですか？
ex_2_en: What are the recruitment numbers for the new Tofugu writers?
ex_3_jp: 沢山の人数の人が、この国の人は同じズボンを履くべきだという私の提案に反対しました。
ex_3_en: There are a great number of people who disagree with my proposal that everyone in this country must wear the same pants.
meaning_story: The person count is the number of people. Don't confuse this with the "population" or something like that, though. This is more like "how many people are at this event?" What's the 人数, you know?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to take note of the rendaku for the second half, where すう goes to ずう.
pitch_accent: ニꜜンズー *** ニꜜンズ *** ヒトカズ

ex_1_jp: 先生はいつ時間がありますか。
ex_1_en: When do you have time, professor?
ex_2_jp: 今日の午後でしんさつしてもらえる時間ってありますか？
ex_2_en: Are there any available spots for a checkup this afternoon?
ex_3_jp: スーパーマンは、アクアマンに、最も真剣な質問をした。「もう一度、ウォータースライダー に乗る時間、ある？」
ex_3_en: Superman then asked Aquaman the most serious question, "Do we have enough time to go on the waterslides again?"
meaning_story: The time interval of time is just the time. As is often the case, if two similar meaning kanji are combined into one word, they tend to produce a word with a similar meaning. Excuse me, friend, what's the 時間?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このもんだいに、じしょをつかって答えてください。
ex_1_en: Please answer this question using a dictionary.
ex_2_jp: どうしてしつもんに答えられないの？
ex_2_en: Why can't you respond to my questions?
ex_3_jp: 面接官に今までに嘘をついたことがあるかどうか聞かれた時に、何て答えればいいのか分からなかったよ。
ex_3_en: I didn’t know how to answer when the interviewer asked me if I have ever lied before.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means answer so the verb version means to answer.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi reading as you'd expect with all the hiragana, but luckily that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.
pitch_accent: コタエꜜル *** コタꜜエル

ex_1_jp: 三つ目のしんごうを、右に曲がってください。
ex_1_en: Please turn right at the third light.
ex_2_jp: そのカレー色のネクタイ、ちょっと曲がってるよ。
ex_2_en: Your curry colored necktie is a bit crooked.
ex_3_jp: 野球のボールが当たってから、僕の小指はちょっとだけ左に曲がっています。
ex_3_en: Since getting hit with a baseball my pinky finger bends slightly to the left.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means both music and bend. In the case of this word, we're looking at "bend." So, the verb form of bend is to be bent. This is when something bends on its own, not when you're doing the bending. It's just bending.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Something, let's say a road, starts out straight. But, with some magic, a witch causes it to curve.

ex_1_jp: おいしいカレーが出来上がりました。
ex_1_en: The delicious curry was finished.
ex_2_jp: 日本りょ行のけいかくは、ギリギリになってようやく出来上がりました。
ex_2_en: Our Japan travel plans were finished at the last minute.
ex_3_jp: 豆腐と河豚のハンバーガーが出来上がりました。
ex_3_en: The tofu and fugu hamburgers are done!
meaning_story: You've seen the word 出来る (to be able to do), which is the first part. Then the second part, 上がる means to rise. So, think like you're lifting up (rising) something you were able to do. You're lifting it up to show it off because it's finished. That's why this verb means to be finished.
reading_story: The reading is a combination of the readings from 出来る and 上がる. So long as you were paying attention in lessons past, you should be able to read this word as well just by combining those other words.
pitch_accent: デキアカ°ル *** デキアカ°ꜜル

ex_1_jp: 空と海が交じるところが、世かいのはてなのさ。
ex_1_en: The place where the sky and the sea meet is the edge of the world.
ex_2_jp: きたいと不安が交じった気もちです。
ex_2_en: My anxiety is mixed with excitement.
ex_3_jp: わたしのさいふをすった後、そのスリはす早く人ごみに交じってきえました。
ex_3_en: After snatching my wallet, the pickpocket quickly blended in with the crowd and disappeared.
meaning_story: You know that 交ぜる means to mix and that the kanji means mix as well. So, this probably has something to do with mixing things. This word means to be mixed. This is when something is mixed but it's not mixed by you. It's just being mixed. Think of it this way - the じ in 交じる is Jesus, who just uses Jesus magic to mix something. So, you're not mixing it. It's just when something is to be mixed.
reading_story: The reading is the same as with 交ぜる. So long as you know the ま portion of that word's reading, you'll be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: 次は、右足のひざを90ど曲げてください。
ex_1_en: Next, please bend your right knee at a 90 degree angle.
ex_2_jp: このYoutubeビデオでは、コウイチがスプーンを百本ひたすら曲げつづけます。
ex_2_en: In this Youtube video, Koichi is just keeps bending 100 spoons.
ex_3_jp: スーパーマンはなんでも曲げられます。すでに曲がっているものでさえも。
ex_3_en: Superman can bend anything, even something that is already bent.
meaning_story: This is a verb because it ends with an う sound. What does the kanji mean? It's music and bend. In the case of this word, we're going with the "bend" version. The verb of that is to bend. This is when you're doing the bending. You can remember this because げ is the gentleman you're bending. He looked good before you bent him in half.
reading_story: How did you bend this gentleman? You bent him using magic (ま). Just imagine yourself bending a gentleman with magic. Go ahead, do it in your mind.

ex_1_jp: 日本ごのべん強の役に立つサイトを見つけました。
ex_1_en: I found a website that is helpful for studying Japanese.
ex_2_jp: ハンガリーには、にげるははじだが役に立つ、ということわざがあります。
ex_2_en: In Hungary there is a proverb meaning, "Running away is a shame, but it's useful."
ex_3_jp: ゾンビがいっぱいの町を歩くなら、銃よりも剣の方が役に立つだろうか？
ex_3_en: Would a sword be more useful than a gun for walking through a city full of zombies?
meaning_story: When you stand up to do your duty you're standing up and finally being useful. That's why this verb means to be useful.
reading_story: The reading for 役 is the one you learned with the kanji. The 立つ reading is that of the 立つ vocabulary, which you should be familiar with by now.

ex_1_jp: トイレットペーパーと肉とやさいとしょうゆを同じ日に買いたいです。
ex_1_en: I want to buy toilet paper, meat, vegetables, and soy sauce on the same day.
ex_2_jp: どうしてそのスマホを買うことにしたんですか？
ex_2_en: Why did you end up buying the smartphone?
ex_3_jp: コウイチのボブルヘッド人形を買うために、長い行列ができていた。
ex_3_en: There was a long line of people waiting to buy the Koichi bobblehead.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means buy so the verb form is to buy.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. If you remember your kanji readings, you'll be just fine.

ex_1_jp: たまごの白身の黄身に対するわり合は、２対１です。
ex_1_en: The egg ratio of white and yolk is 2:1.
ex_2_jp: お前って、両しんに対する思いやりに欠けてるよね。
ex_2_en: Your lacking in consideration for your parents, don't you think?
ex_3_jp: あいつらの関係が修復不可能だってことは明らかだね。だって、スタートレックに対する意見が全く違っているんだから。
ex_3_en: It’s clear now that their relationship will never work because their opinions on Star Trek are the complete opposite.
meaning_story: When you do (する) versus you're putting two things together to compare to each other. Imagine putting two dogs in a ring (show dogs, not fighting dogs, c'mon). Then someone announces the start, and the judges look at them, trying to compare one to the other to decide which is better. Alternatively, you can use this to say to face each other as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read this word no problem.

ex_1_jp: ねられないとき、羊を数えるのはなぜですか。
ex_1_en: When you can’t sleep, why do you count sheep?
ex_2_jp: いのちがおしけりゃ、十数えるうちにきえろ。
ex_2_en: If you value your own life, get lost in ten seconds.
ex_3_jp: スミス先生、生徒が二人足りません。数えましたが38人しかいないんです。
ex_3_en: There are two students missing, Mr. Smith. I only counted thirty-eight children.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means count, so obviously the verb version is to count.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You begin to count vocabulary words. You're out of control and you can't stop. One after another. Scientists have to come in, but they can't figure out the cause (かぞ) of your counting. They drag you away to a padded cell where they keep testing you trying to figure out the cause of your craziness.

ex_1_jp: 大学をそつぎょうしたら何をするか、もう決めましたか。
ex_1_en: Have you decided what you’ll do after graduating from university?
ex_2_jp: おなかが空きすぎてて何食べるか決められないから、よかったらユイちゃんが決めちゃって。
ex_2_en: I'm too hungry to decide what we eat, so it's your choice where we go, Yui.
ex_3_jp: 残りの人生をどう過ごすか、みんなは一体どうやって決めるんだい？選びきれないほど仕事があるじゃないか。
ex_3_en: How do people decide what they’re going to do for the rest of their lives? There are so many jobs to choose from.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decide so the verb version is to decide.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to decide. You have two keys (き) in front of you. You have to decide on one of them and use it to unlock the door to get away from the monster. Why do monster attacks always come down to keys and doors?

ex_1_jp: カメラマンが近づくとカメはにげてしまった。
ex_1_en: When the cameraman approached it, the turtle ran away.
ex_2_jp: おれの女に近づくな！
ex_2_en: Don't go anywhere near my girlfriend!
ex_3_jp: 私達に今近づいてきているゾンビ、めちゃくちゃ私のタイプなんだけど。
ex_3_en: Strange as it is, the zombie approaching us right now is actually my type.
meaning_story: Because this word ends with an う sound, you can tell it's probably a verb. The kanji portion means near. The verb version of that is to draw near, to get close or to approach. Essentially, the general idea is that you're getting closer to something. You're becoming more nearby. You're approaching.
reading_story: There's hiragana attached to this kanji, which means it's probably the kun'yomi reading (and it is). You've seen the kun'yomi reading via the word 近い. So, as long as you know that word, you should be able to read this one as well.

ex_1_jp: この貝がら、耳に当てるとなみの音がするの。
ex_1_en: Put this shell to your ear and you’ll hear the sound of the waves.
ex_2_jp: ひる休みに、だれがうそをついているのかを当てるゲームをしました。
ex_2_en: We played a game trying to guess who was lying during lunch break.
ex_3_jp: ボールをバットに上手く当てたと言いたかったんだけど、間違えてお尻に当てたと言ってしまった。
ex_3_en: I wanted to say, "I hit the ball really well with my bat," but I accidentally said butt.
meaning_story: You know that the kanji 当 means right or success. So since this is a verb, you're doing right and success (which doesn't make much sense). Instead, you're guessing something and getting it right. So, this word means to guess or to guess something. Hopefully you don't have to guess too hard when it comes to the meaning of this word as well.
reading_story: The reading can be remembered via the word 当たる which you learned a few levels ago. Use that knowledge to remember that this word is read as あてる. The important part is the あ.

ex_1_jp: ワニカニとトーフグがおぼれていたらどちらを助ける？
ex_1_en: If WaniKani and Tofugu were drowning, which one would you save?
ex_2_jp: このかわいそうなすて犬ちゃんを助けてあげることができる人はいませんか？
ex_2_en: Is there anybody who can rescue this poor abandoned puppy?
ex_3_jp: チリチーズブリトーを食べるのを助けて欲しい人はいますか？私はそれがとても得意ですよ？
ex_3_en: Does anybody need any help eating their chili and cheese burrito? I’m really good at it.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means help so the verb version is to help. Don't confuse this with 助かる which means "to be helped." You know that 助ける is "to help" because you're doing the helping. You know that you're doing the helping because you care (ける).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to help someone. Someone is hanging off a cliff and out of reach. They ask you, the person standing above them, to toss (たす) them a rope, but you refuse. "TOSS IT!" they yell. "I WILL NOT TOSS IT," you respond. You're a jerk.

ex_1_jp: オレンジとあい色が交わる、夕ぐれの空が大すきなの。
ex_1_en: I love the evening sky when orange meets indigo blue.
ex_2_jp: このオフィスでは、時々、日本とアメリカの文化が交わります。
ex_2_en: In this office, Japanese and American culture sometimes intersect.
ex_3_jp: 婆ちゃんの乳はとても長いので、たまに相互に交わることすらできる。
ex_3_en: My grandma’s boobs are so long that they sometimes cross over each other.
meaning_story: You know that the kanji means mix and the word 交ぜる means "to mix," so it probably has something to do with that. This word means to intersect, which is kind of like mixing. When two things intersect with each other, they're getting mixed up, so that's where this word gets its meaning. To remember that this one means "to intersect," remember the わ as walk. You're walking around, and then you intersect with some people on the street.
reading_story: The reading is almost the same as 交ぜる which you should be familiar with by now. It has the ま but it also has an extra じ in there. That じ is there because you intersect with a group of mages (まじ) that catch you on fire as you walk past.

ex_1_jp: わたしは、父と母と一しょに住んでいます。
ex_1_en: I live with my father and mother.
ex_2_jp: 青木ヶ原のじゅ海は、住むにはおそろしすぎる場所です。
ex_2_en: Aokigahara's Jukai is a terrifying place to live.
ex_3_jp: ホビットの穴に住んでみたいのですが、どうやって掘ればいいのか分かりません。
ex_3_en: I want to live in a hobbit hole, but I don’t know how to dig.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dwelling, so the verb version means to dwell. It can also mean to live or to reside. Basically, someone is living somewhere. Where do you live?
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have a place to live... but not for long. You are being sued (す) out of your house and home so you will have nowhere to dwell.

pronunciation: あした, あす, みょうにち
ex_1_jp: 明日、びょういんへ行きましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s go to the hospital tomorrow.
ex_2_jp: 明日は明日の風がふく。
ex_2_en: Tomorrow is another day.
ex_3_jp: 一ヶ月イタリアに行くことを知らせるために、明日学校に電話しなくてはいけません。
ex_3_en: I need to call the school tomorrow to inform them that I’m going to Italy for a month.
meaning_story: A bright day isn't today (because today was terrible), it's tomorrow, because you can always look to tomorrow to be a better, brighter day.
reading_story: The reading makes no sense at all. You have to learn it straight up, and can't rely on the kanji it's made from. Why is tomorrow going to be such a bright and awesome day? Because you're making ash tacos for dinner, and that's your favorite. Imagine imagining tomorrow, full of ash tacos and deliciousness. Maybe you could use some of those Dorito taco shells? A note about the other two readings あす and みょうにち: あす is used in the news and in weather reports, and みょうにち is really only used in business, so you should really only be using あした for now. But it's good to know that the other two readings exist!
pitch_accent: アシタꜜ *** アシタ *** アスꜜ *** アス *** ミョꜜーニチ

ex_1_jp: もう一ど、けいかくを見直しましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s look at the plans one more time.
ex_2_jp: この間のはいひん回しゅうの日、主人が思ったよりたよりになって、ちょっと見直しちゃった。
ex_2_en: On the last junk removal day, my husband was much more dependable than I expected and it made me look at him differently.
ex_3_jp: 大学の授業の選択を見直す方がいいと思うよ。だって、愚鳩を捕まえるのが、いいキャリアになるとは思えないもん。
ex_3_en: I think you should reevaluate your choices in university classes. I don’t think catching dodo birds is a good career path.
meaning_story: You know the word 直す from a couple levels ago. It means "to fix." So, when you fix what you see, what are you doing? You're reevaluating something. That's why this word means to reevaluate.
reading_story: The readings are all kun'yomi readings, like the vocab you've seen already. This is like two vocab words put together, which is why it's using the kun'yomi reading. The hiragana on the end is a hint!
pitch_accent: ミナオス *** ミナオꜜス

ex_1_jp: わたしは、家を出る時、いつも家の前でひかれた子犬のことを思い出します。
ex_1_en: When I leave home, I always remember my puppy that got run over in front of the house.
ex_2_jp: 四けたのあんしょう番号が思い出せなくて、めっちゃあせったよ。
ex_2_en: I was so panicked because I couldn't recall my 4 digit PIN code.
ex_3_jp: 人に思い出してもらう一番の方法は、その人たちからお金を借りることだ。
ex_3_en: The best way to make somebody remember you is to borrow money from them.
meaning_story: You know that 思う means to think (so 思い is a thought). You also know that 出す means to remove. So, when you remove a thought, you are remembering something. This is a verb, so the verb form of remembering something is to remember.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the kun'yomi readings. You should know the words 思う and 出す and their readings, so you should be able to read this word if you know those words.
pitch_accent: オモイダꜜス *** オモイダス *** オモꜜイダス

ex_1_jp: ニッカはいつもオフィス内を走り回っています。
ex_1_en: Nikka is always running around the office.
ex_2_jp: うちの子なら、あの交通じこからもうすっかり立ち直って、元気に走り回っていますよ。
ex_2_en: My kid completely recovered from the traffic accident and now he's just running, full of energy.
ex_3_jp: コウイチが蜂の巣を撃った後、蜂から逃げるために約十分間走り回った。
ex_3_en: After Koichi shot the bee hive, we ran around for nearly ten minutes trying to escape from all the bees.
meaning_story: You've seen the words 走る (to run) and 回る (to revolve). So, when you're running and revolving while you're doing it, you're running in circles. So, the verb form of that is to run around.
reading_story: The readings are those like the words 走る and 回る. Make sure you know those words from before and apply that knowledge to read this word as well.
pitch_accent: ハシリマワꜜル *** ハシリマワル *** ハシꜜリマワル

ex_1_jp: 女の人と男の人が写しんを見ながら話しています。
ex_1_en: A woman and a man are talking while looking at a picture.
ex_2_jp: 早く日本ごがうまく話せるようになりたいです。
ex_2_en: I want to become fluent in Japanese soon.
ex_3_jp: あなたが話すのを聞いていると、なぜかいつも、紐無しで橋からバンジー・ジャンプをしているような気になります。
ex_3_en: Every time I hear you speak, I feel like jumping off of a bridge without a bungee cord for some reason.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means talk so the verb version of this is to talk or to speak.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Every time you try to speak, 花s (はな) just sprout out of your mouth preventing you. Imagine your mouth full of flowers. Taste them, spit them out, and try to speak again. Same problem.

ex_1_jp: 肉りょうりには赤ワインが合います。
ex_1_en: Red wine pairs well with meat dishes.
ex_2_jp: 合うかどうか、しちゃくしてかくにんした方がいいよ。
ex_2_en: You should try it on to see if it suits you.
ex_3_jp: アメリカのインド料理は、アメリカ人の口に合うよう、実際のインドでの調理方法とはかなり違った方法で作られている。
ex_3_en: Indian cuisine in America is altered quite a bit from how it’s prepared in India to suit American tastes.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means suit so the verb version is to suit. This word also means to come together as well. Presumably when something suits something else, it comes together with it flawlessly. That's why this word also has this other meaning (and it will be important for future vocab as well).
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: やっぱり、おれのしゅう入だけで、一家を支えるのはきびしいよ。
ex_1_en: After all, it’s difficult to support a family on just my income.
ex_2_jp: アメリカのけいざいは、トーフグによって支えられている。
ex_2_en: The United States economy is supported by Tofugu.
ex_3_jp: 壁に寄りかかって体を支えるのがとても楽しかった。
ex_3_en: It was very fun for me to support myself up against the wall.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means support so the verb version is to support.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to support someone. In order to support them, you grab two saws. One saw and another saw. A saw saw (ささ combination good enough to do all the supporting you need - and maybe cut some supports too).
pitch_accent: ササエル *** ササエꜜル *** ツカエꜜル *** ツカꜜエル

ex_1_jp: このあたらしいボールは、とても投げやすいです。
ex_1_en: This new ball is very easy to throw.
ex_2_jp: どうしてあの人たちは、かんそうした大ずを投げているんですか？
ex_2_en: Why are those people throwing dried soy beans?
ex_3_jp: ピッチャーがボールを投げたんですけど、ちょうどバッターの前を飛んでいた鳩に当たったんですよね。
ex_3_en: The pitcher threw the ball and it struck a pigeon flying in front of the batter.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means throw so the verb version means to throw.
reading_story: The reading is kun'yomi because of the hiragana sticking out, but that's the reading you also learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this one A-okay.

ex_1_jp: かの女は、化しょうをすれば、び人に化けることで有名です。
ex_1_en: She’s famous for transforming into a beautiful woman with makeup.
ex_2_jp: あのようかいは、人間に化けることができる。
ex_2_en: That yokai can transform to a person.
ex_3_jp: 私の家はリフォームの後で全く違う家に化けてしまったので、息子は学校が終わった後にどの家に帰るのか分からなくなってしまいました。
ex_3_en: My house was so completely transformed after the renovation that my son didn't know which home to go to after school.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means change so you'd think the verb version is "to change" but it's a little different. This word means to transform, which is a lot like "to change" but this is more like when a person transforms into something else, like a dinosaur.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You try to transform. You want to turn into something awesome, like a dinosaur, but then *poof* you turn into a sheep. "Baaaa," you say. "Baaa."

ex_1_jp: きのうは一日中、人さしゆびでピザを回すれんしゅうをしていました。
ex_1_en: I practiced spinning pizza on my index finger all day yesterday.
ex_2_jp: ドアノブを回す音で、赤ちゃんの目がさめてしまいました。
ex_2_en: The door knob turning noise made the baby wake up.
ex_3_jp: 私がこの一ドル硬貨を十分速く回したら、もしかすると百ドル札になるかもしれない。
ex_3_en: If I spin a one dollar coin fast enough, maybe it will turn into a one hundred dollar bill.
meaning_story: You've probably seen the word 回る, which means "to revolve." This word is similar, except for you're doing the turning/rotating action on something else. You can simply say to turn or to rotate when answering this question, but be sure to think of yourself actually turning/rotating something. Remember this by using the す on the end. You've taken your friend Sue and put her on a stick. You're rotating her over a fire on a spit because you're a sick cannibal.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the word 回る (まわ). So long as you know that level 5 word, you'll be able to read this one as well. Use both of these words together to remember their readings.

ex_1_jp: 電気を点けてくれ。
ex_1_en: Turn on the light.
ex_2_jp: ラジオの点け方が分かりません。
ex_2_en: I don't know how to turn on the radio.
ex_3_jp: テレビを点けてもらえますか。
ex_3_en: Can you turn on the tv?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means point so the verb version is something you need to point your finger to do. Picture pointing your finger and pushing a lightswitch to turn on the light. You won't be able to switch on a lamp if you can't point your finger.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You aren't able to turn on the light with just one finger though, you need to use two (つ). Either you have really weak fingers, or that's a really strong lightswitch. Either way, you need two fingers to switch on the light.

ex_1_jp: おれはとつぜんカメラを向けられるのが大っきらいなんだよ！
ex_1_en: I have a huge phobia of cameras suddenly pointing toward me.
ex_2_jp: スマホじゃなくて子どもに、目を向けてあげてください。
ex_2_en: Please turn your attention from your phone to your kid.
ex_3_jp: その男はゆっくりと俺に銃口を向けた。
ex_3_en: The man slowly pointed the muzzle of the gun at me.
meaning_story: You know that 向く means "to face" or "to turn toward" - so, this is a different version of that. This is when someone turns or points something, but you aren't turning. That's why it means to turn (something) towards and to point. In order to remember that this particular word means "to turn (something) towards," focus on the け. You have a bottle of ketchup in your hands and you're turning it toward your worst enemy to spray them. Picture yourself pointing the ketchup toward them.
reading_story: The reading for this one is the same as 向く which you learned in a previous level. As long as you know that one you should be able to learn this one's reading as well.

ex_1_jp: 役場でしょう明しょをもらってきてください。
ex_1_en: Please get the certificate from the town hall.
ex_2_jp: 役場のかべ紙は、かべからはがれてきています。
ex_2_en: The town hall's wallpaper is peeling off the wall.
ex_3_jp: 役場に行って転出届を出してきたよ。
ex_3_en: I went to the town hall and submitted my change of address information.
meaning_story: A service location is a place that people go when they're in need of a service. The best place for this is the town hall. Everyone goes to this one location to voice their complaints and in return their needs are serviced by the officials in the town hall.
reading_story: The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: 下のひょうは、「電車の時間」と「バスの時間」です。
ex_1_en: As for the chart below, it shows "train times" and "bus times."
ex_2_jp: この電車にのって、トトロえきでおりて、ネコバスにのりかえてください。
ex_2_en: Get on this train, get off at Totoro Station and transfer to the Catbus.
ex_3_jp: ホグワーツ特急は電車じゃなくて汽車です。
ex_3_en: The Hogwarts Express isn’t an electric train, it’s a steam train.
meaning_story: You would think that an electricity car was an electric car, but this word was made before the days of the Prius. This refers to a train, which I guess was electric at some point.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: デンシャ *** デꜜンシャ

ex_1_jp: この水道の水は、のんでも平気ですよ。
ex_1_en: This tap water is safe to drink.
ex_2_jp: 水道代がはらえなかったので、水道が止められてしまいました。
ex_2_en: I couldn't pay the water bill, so my water was shut off.
ex_3_jp: 水道が凍結してしまいました。
ex_3_en: The water line froze.
meaning_story: A water road carries your water supply. In the old days, these were called aqueducts.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: わたし、全身毛むくじゃらのワイルドな男せいがすきなんです。
ex_1_en: I love men whose entire bodies are covered in wild, thick hair.
ex_2_jp: コウイチは全身にタトゥーを入れようと思っているみたいなんだけど、どう思う？
ex_2_en: Apparently Koichi is looking to get a full body tattoo. What do you guys think?
ex_3_jp: 昨日七ヶ月ぶりにランニングしたから、今日は全身筋肉痛だよ。
ex_3_en: I went running for the first time in seven months yesterday and now my whole body hurts.
meaning_story: The all of somebody is someone's whole body.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 土よう日に、森でピクニックをしました。
ex_1_en: On Saturday, we had a picnic in the woods.
ex_2_jp: お母さんは木を見て森を見ずなんだよ！
ex_2_en: You can't see the wood for the trees, mom!
ex_3_jp: 赤ずきんちゃんが森の中を歩いていると、死んだ狼に出くわしました。赤ずきんちゃんはその場を立ち去り、訪れたお婆さんの家で素晴らしい時間を過ごしました。
ex_3_en: Little Red Riding Hood was walking through the forest when she came upon a dead wolf. Then she went on her way and had a lovely visit with her grandmother.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this one too.

ex_1_jp: 一生お前といっしょに生きていきたいんだ。
ex_1_en: I want to live my whole life with you.
ex_2_jp: 女のことお前ってよぶ男本当にきらいだわ。
ex_2_en: I really hate men who call women "you."
ex_3_jp: お前の作る餃子は本当に美味しいな。
ex_3_en: The gyoza you make is really tasty.
meaning_story: The お is added to elevate someone in front of you. But it's done in a sarcastic way, so this word means you. That's right, plain old "you." This "you" is usually used casually, between men.
reading_story: The reading for 前 is the kun'yomi, like the reading for the vocabulary word 前. So long as you know that word, you'll be able to read this one too.

ex_1_jp: 君とぼくは、いつもいっしょだよ。
ex_1_en: You and I will always be together.
ex_2_jp: 君はけっこうせがひくいから、シャワーヘッドをフックから外せるか心ぱいです。
ex_2_en: You're pretty short, so I'm worried if you'll be able to reach the shower head and take it off the hook.
ex_3_jp: 君は、エレベーターで一緒に閉じ込められたくない人ナンバーワンだ。
ex_3_en: You are the worst person to be stuck with in an elevator.
meaning_story: Okay, so the kanji itself means buddy and so does the word, but it also means you as well. This is one of the several ways to say "you" in Japanese, and this one is kind of an "affectionate" you. Maybe you'd say it with someone you're close to. Maybe you'd say it with a girlfriend or boyfriend. You wouldn't want to use it with your boss or teacher, though. Make sure to keep that in mind. It's kind of like saying "hey buddy" or "hey you," after all.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Who's your buddy? It's Kimmy (きみ)! If you know a Kimmy, imagine her. If you don't, find a famous Kimmy or make up a Kimmy to imagine. You ask... is it you?? Wait, you're my buddy?

ex_1_jp: 全部ですか。
ex_1_en: All of it?
ex_2_jp: わたしのベーコンクッキーを一はこ全部食べちゃったのはだれ！？
ex_2_en: Who ate the whole box of my bacon cookies?
ex_3_jp: この靴下、全部穴があいていますよ。
ex_3_en: These socks are all holes.
meaning_story: If you take all parts and put them together, you have all things. The entire collection. It is whole.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ニッカちゃん、マジ天使だわー。
ex_1_en: Nikka really is an angel.
ex_2_jp: あの天使と、少しきょりをおきたいと思っています。
ex_2_en: I think I need to distance myself from the angel for a while.
ex_3_jp: 天使のように可愛い女の子に会った。
ex_3_en: I met a girl who was as cute as an angel.
meaning_story: One who uses heaven to their advantage is someone from heaven, like an angel.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: べつの角度から、もう一度見てみましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s try looking again from a different angle.
ex_2_jp: ピサのしゃとうはたしかにへんな角度で立っている。
ex_2_en: The Leaning Tower of Pisa sure stands at an odd angle.
ex_3_jp: もしマイリー・サイラスが一番好きな歌を歌っているのをこの角度から見ることができたら、俺の夢を叶えてくれたってことで神様の存在を信じると思う。
ex_3_en: If I can see Miley Cyrus singing my favorite song from this angle, I will believe in God because it would mean that He made my dream come true.
meaning_story: The degree of the angle shows what the angle is. 90 degrees? 160 degrees? They're all still angles when you come down to it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今夜、コウイチから、重大な発表があります。
ex_1_en: This evening there will be an important announcement from Koichi.
ex_2_jp: ピカチュウは、今朝、ポケモンから引たいすることを発表した。
ex_2_en: Pikachu announced his retirement from Pokemon this morning.
ex_3_jp: 明日、みんなの前でSNSの研究成果について発表をしなければならないので、緊張しています。
ex_3_en: I'm nervous because I have to give a presentation about my social media research outcome in front of everyone tomorrow.
meaning_story: I'm going to express my departure. That is my only announcement.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ひょう changes to ぴょう and the はつ gets shortened, though, so just about everything about this word is weird.

ex_1_jp: ねえ、日よう日、予定を入れてもいい？
ex_1_en: Hey, can I make plans on Sunday?
ex_2_jp: その小わく星は地きゅうに向かっていて、北大西ようのどこかにしょうとつする予定だ。
ex_2_en: The asteroid is on a direct path to Earth and it will hit somewhere in the North Atlantic Ocean.
ex_3_jp: 私がせっかく予定を立てても、誰もその通りに動いてくれないことが嫌です。
ex_3_en: I hate when I plan out my day, but nobody follows the script.
meaning_story: Something has been determined beforehand. What is this thing? This action? It is a plan.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: わたしは、アメリカの教いくについて、記事をかきました。
ex_1_en: I wrote an article about American education.
ex_2_jp: クリスティンの記事、今月号のナショナル・ジオグラフィックで見たよ！
ex_2_en: Kristen, I've just found your article in this month's national geographic magazine!
ex_3_jp: この記事はデタラメだ。
ex_3_en: This news story is nonsense.
meaning_story: When you write down a lot of stuff focusing on one thing it's called an article. If it's on something that just happened it will probably be a news story.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: でも、それはたんなる仮定の話でしょう。
ex_1_en: But that’s just an assumption, right?
ex_2_jp: たとえば、一ドル百円と仮定すると、一本一ドルのコカコーラは百円になりますよね？
ex_2_en: For example, if we say one dollar is one hundred yen, then one can of $1 coca cola is one hundred yen, right?
ex_3_jp: 彼女のベッドに積まれた札束のせいで、今とんでもない仮定が俺の頭の中を飛び交っている。
ex_3_en: Since seeing that pile of money on her bed, crazy assumptions have been flying around in my head.
meaning_story: A temporary determination is something you're not totally sure about. You've decided to think of something in a certain way, but only for now. If more information comes to light, you may change. That's why this word means assumption or hypothesis.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この通りをまっすぐに行って、三つ目のしん号を左に曲がってください。
ex_1_en: Please go straight on this street and turn left at the third light.
ex_2_jp: この通りでは、一日中車が行き交っています。
ex_2_en: This road is busy all day long.
ex_3_jp: チーズベーコンバーガー通りには、ガソリンスタンドってあったっけ？
ex_3_en: Were there any gas stations on Bacon Cheeseburger Avenue?
meaning_story: You know the word 通る hopefully by now. That is the verb version of this word, which means "to pass through." So, if this is the noun version, what is it that you use to pass through something? To drive or walk along? That would be an avenue (or street, road, etc). This is a pretty common word in Japan, and good for not getting lost.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the word 通る, so as long as you know that, you should be able to read this one as well. Mind the strange long お sound!

ex_1_jp: 美しいスカーフ、ありがとうございます。大切にします。
ex_1_en: Thank you for the beautiful scarf. I’ll cherish it.
ex_2_jp: クリステン王女の赤いかみ、ほんと、美しすぎてなみだが出る。
ex_2_en: Princess Kristen's red hair is so beautiful it makes me cry.
ex_3_jp: なんてこった、君の目は宝石のように美しいよ、クリスティーン。
ex_3_en: Oh my, your eyes are as beautiful as jewelry, Christine.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of beauty? It's beautiful.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you. It's a long reading for a mnemonic, but try your best. You look at someone who is beautiful. What an easy life they've lived. No hard work and all they do is pamper themselves to stay beautiful. Feel disgusted. You walk up to this person and say: "U too cushy! (うつくしい). Sorry for adding the whole word in there for the reading mnemonic, but I thought it worked out better that way. Just know that the word isn't うつくしいしい or something weird like that. The hiragana on the end is part of the mnemonic as well.

ex_1_jp: あなたのおくさんは、美人だし、とても上ひんですね。
ex_1_en: Your wife is beautiful and so refined.
ex_2_jp: 物は言いようなんだから、馬か正直にならすに、美人ですねって言っておけばよかったんだよ。
ex_2_en: It's a matter of how you put it, so you should have just told her that she is beautiful instead of being foolishly honest.
ex_3_jp: 彼は誰の忠告も絶対に受けないなんて言っていたが、美人の忠告なら話は別だろう。
ex_3_en: He says he never needs advice from anyone, but as soon as a beautiful woman offers him some, he’s all ears.
meaning_story: A person who is beautiful is a beautiful woman. Wait, why isn't this a beautiful person? Because of course only women can be beautiful - men tend to be handsome, or just generally not as good looking. So, while both "beautiful woman" and "beautiful person" are technically correct, you're generally only going to hear it as beautiful woman, so remember that meaning.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あぶらを使ったちょうりをするさいは、火事にならないよう、気をつけてください。
ex_1_en: When you cook using oil be careful you don’t start a fire.
ex_2_jp: このマグカップ、あついから、気を付けてね。
ex_2_en: This mug is hot. Be careful.
ex_3_jp: これから雪を食べる時はもっと気を付けてよ。色盲だから、色が黄色でも分かんないんだから。
ex_3_en: You need to be more careful when you eat snow from now on. You're color blind, so you can’t tell even if it is yellow.
meaning_story: This word contains the words 気 (energy) and 付ける (to attach). So, when you attach energy to something you're focusing in on it, right? This word is a sort of "order" as well, since it's te-form there at the end. It's a set phrase people say to other people who are doing dangerous things. It's kind of like saying "Attach energy to what you're doing! Stay focused!" A simpler way to translate this would be to say this word means be careful or take care, though. Learn this word so that you can always show that you're caring for your friends!
reading_story: The readings come from the two words 気 and 付ける. So long as you know those from the previous levels, you should be able to read this one as well.

ex_1_jp: このベーコン、なんか苦い。
ex_1_en: This bacon is a little bitter.
ex_2_jp: このくすりはすっごく苦いから、気をつけてね。
ex_2_en: This medicine is very bitter, so brace yourself!
ex_3_jp: カラメルは、焦がさないように気を付けてください。でないと、苦い味になってしまいます。
ex_3_en: Be careful not to let the caramel burn or it will taste bitter.
meaning_story: The kanji for 苦 means suffer. This word, however, is quite different. It means bitter tasting. Just think of ways you can suffer, though. Then, think of putting the most bitter thing in the world in your mouth. You feel sick, your mouth gets all weird, and you try to spit it out but the bitterness remains. Bitter tasting things are super gross.
reading_story: Like the word meaning, the reading is an exception as well. You can remember it by thinking: The taste is so bitter that you fall to your knees really, really hard. Luckily, you were wearing your knee guards (にが). Feel the relief that you were wearing them. Ack, no relief now. It's still bitter in your mouth.

ex_1_jp: 白黒ハッキリさせようぜ。
ex_1_en: Let’s make it clearly black and white.
ex_2_jp: この白黒の写しん、すてきですね。
ex_2_en: This black and white photo is very lovely.
ex_3_jp: カナエちゃんがいつもオシャレな服装をしているってことは認めるけどさ、今日の白黒のドレスはちょっとなんかパンダみたいじゃない？
ex_3_en: I agree that Kanae always wears very chic clothes, but today that black and white dress just makes her look like a panda, doesn’t it?
meaning_story: Something is both white and black. It is black and white (you can also say white and black if you prefer).
reading_story: The readings are kun'yomi, but you should have seen both 白 and 黒い separately as vocabulary by now. It's the same readings here, so you can apply that knowledge and read this word!
pitch_accent: シꜜロクロ *** シロクロ

ex_1_jp: アンナさんの体重は、何キロですか？
ex_1_en: What is Anna’s body weight in kilograms?
ex_2_jp: 次の身体そく定で体重をはかるのが待ちきれない。
ex_2_en: I can’t wait to weigh myself at my next body measuring.
ex_3_jp: どうして私があなたの体重を知っているのか聞かないで。ジェシカが口を滑らせたことは絶対に誰にも言わないって、あの子と約束したんだから。
ex_3_en: Don’t ask me how I know your weight. I promised Jessica that I wouldn’t tell you that she told me.
meaning_story: How heavy is your body? Figure that out and you'll have your body weight.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: よくその本屋に行きます。
ex_1_en: I go to that bookstore often.
ex_2_jp: この本屋には、ツアーガイドブックがたく山おいてあります。
ex_2_en: This book shop has a lot of tourist guidebooks.
ex_3_jp: 本屋のレジでアルバイトをしています。
ex_3_en: I work part time at the bookstore cash register.
meaning_story: A book shop is a shop that sells books. A bookstore.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あそこの肉屋で、合いびき肉を100g買ってきてちょうだい。
ex_1_en: Could you buy 100 grams of ground beef and pork from the butcher shop over there?
ex_2_jp: あそこのお肉屋さん、新しいあじのビーガンとうふバーガーをかいはつしてるらしいよ。
ex_2_en: I heard that butcher shop is creating a new flavor of vegan tofu burgers.
ex_3_jp: 私の小さな町には「お肉屋さん」とい名前のレストランがあったんだけど、本当の「お肉屋さん」がどんなものかを知った時にはとてもショックでした。それで、今、私はベジタリアンなんです。
ex_3_en: My small town had a restaurant called The Butcher Shop, so I was really surprised to learn what a real butcher shop is. I’m a vegetarian now.
meaning_story: A meat shop is a place that sells meat. Who sells meat? A butcher shop.
reading_story: For 肉 you use the にく reading (which you learned with the kanji). For 屋 you use the kun'yomi, which you learned with the kanji. Basically, if you learned the kanji readings, you can read this word!

ex_1_jp: 服を引き出しの中に入れてください。
ex_1_en: Please put your clothes in the drawer.
ex_2_jp: かわいい！おそろいの服をきてるんですね。
ex_2_en: How cute! They are wearing matching clothing.
ex_3_jp: 今日はチョー暑くて、あなたはあまりにも多くの服を着ているよ。
ex_3_en: It’s so hot today. You’re wearing too many clothes.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji and uses the on'yomi even though it's a single word. Very strange, but convenient for you so long as you remember this exception reading word.

ex_1_jp: そのまんがなら、部室に全かんそろってるよ。
ex_1_en: As for that manga, we have the whole series in the clubroom.
ex_2_jp: 何ぜか部室に魚を口にくわえたネコがいるんです。
ex_2_en: For some reason, there is a cat with a fish in its mouth in the clubroom.
ex_3_jp: 部室に忘れ物をしちゃった。
ex_3_en: I forgot something in the clubroom.
meaning_story: A club room is a clubroom!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 母の具合があまりよくないんです。
ex_1_en: My mother’s condition isn’t very good.
ex_2_jp: なんかめっちゃ具合わるそうだけど、大じょうぶ?
ex_2_en: You don't look great at all. Are you okay?
ex_3_jp: ちょっと昨日から具合が良くなくて。
ex_3_en: I was a little under the weather yesterday.
meaning_story: You have to find the right tool to suit your condition. If you have a health condition, the tool is a pill, or exercise, or real life friends. But it always depends on the condition you're in.
reading_story: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 具 and the kun'yomi reading for 合. You've learned them both so you should be able to read this word too!

ex_1_jp: きのうてつ夜で仕事だったんですが、朝から工事の音がうるさくてぜんぜんねむれてないんです。
ex_1_en: I worked all night last night, but I haven’t been able to sleep at all because of the loud construction that started this morning.
ex_2_jp: 町中で一日中工事しているので、通行止めだらけでいやになるよ。
ex_2_en: Because there's construction going on all day, all over town, there are roads closed everywhere and I'm sick and tired of it.
ex_3_jp: この工事は今日終わったんですよね？
ex_3_en: This construction finished today, right?
meaning_story: Industry actions are things industries do. The actions of industry create a lot of construction, whether it be the construction of items or the construction of roads, factories, and more.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 相談の時間は、午後六時から午後九時です。
ex_1_en: The consultation time is from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m.
ex_2_jp: こ人的に相談したいことがあるんですが、ちょっとお時間よろしいですか？
ex_2_en: If you don't mind, I'd like to discuss something with you in private. Do you have a minute?
ex_3_jp: 私は医者に痔の相談をした。
ex_3_en: I consulted my doctor about my hemorrhoids.
meaning_story: A mutual discussion. Both sides are talking to each other and the feelings are mutual. Imagine you're discussing a problem. You want to get help with it, so you get some consultation from your friend. This discussion was very helpful.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチとスティーヴ・ブシェミのゆめの対談が実げんしました！
ex_1_en: The dream of Koichi and Steve Buscemi talking came true!
ex_2_jp: ざんねんながら、そろそろこの対談をおわらせる時間になってしまいました。
ex_2_en: Unfortunately, it's time to bring this conversation to a close.
ex_3_jp: 有名な作家と対談してみたい。
ex_3_en: I want to talk with a famous writer.
meaning_story: A versus discuss is when you sit and look at another person. You are discussing something versus them, so you talk back and forth to each other. In this way, you are having a conversation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: クママンまんがの、アニメ化が決定しました！
ex_1_en: They’ve decided to turn the Kumaman manga into an anime!
ex_2_jp: これはさいしゅう決定になりますので、その後の変更はできませんが、よろしいでしょうか？
ex_2_en: This will be your final decision and it can't be changed later. Is that okay?
ex_3_jp: 君の妹の結婚式と俺の母さんの葬式、どちらに出席するかの決定は君に任せるよ。
ex_3_en: I’ll leave the decision of whether we’re going to attend your little sister’s wedding or my mother’s funeral to you.
meaning_story: It's been decided and determined. The decision has been made.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to take note of the shortened けつ in 決. It goes to けっ.

ex_1_jp: 弟は、かぜで38度のねつがあります。
ex_1_en: My brother has a cold and a fever of 38 degrees celsius.
ex_2_jp: エアコンのおん度はいつも何度ぐらいにしていますか？
ex_2_en: What temperature do you usually set the AC to?
ex_3_jp: ２４度ぐらいがちょうどいいと思うんだけど。
ex_3_en: I think about 24 degrees is just right for me.
meaning_story: The kanji degree can mean both degree in terms of angles and degree in terms of temperature. This word is how you talk about these things. Just attach it to a number and you have yourself the number of degrees that something is.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned. When writing out the answer to this reading, omit the 〜 as it's only there to let you know that some other word should come before it.
pitch_accent: タビꜜ *** タビタビ *** ド

ex_1_jp: 大しきゅう、へんしゅう部の部長をよんでくれないか。
ex_1_en: Could you call the head of the editorial department ASAP?
ex_2_jp: 中学の時は、けん道部でした。
ex_2_en: I belonged to a kendo club back in junior high school.
ex_3_jp: 経理部の部長をしています。
ex_3_en: I’m the head of the accounting department.
meaning_story: You'll see this attached to other words... like "sales" or "tennis." When you see this, you'll know it is a ___ department, or a ___ club, making this word mean department or club, similar to the kanji meaning.
reading_story: The reading is the on'yomi reading. Don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.

ex_1_jp: 出発まで五分です。
ex_1_en: There are five minutes until departure.
ex_2_jp: 二週間後に、東京に出発する予定です。
ex_2_en: I'm going to leave for Tokyo in two weeks.
ex_3_jp: ほとんど喋ったことのない同僚の出発の門出を祝う飲み会にお誘い頂き、どうも有難う御座います。
ex_3_en: Thank you so much for inviting me to a drinking party to celebrate the departure of a co-worker that I rarely spoke to.
meaning_story: You exit and then make a departure. This is just a departure.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The しゅつ gets shortened and はつ changes to ぱつ. No wonder you want to make a departure, you want to get away from crazy readings like this.

ex_1_jp: 何不自由ない生活をしてるくせに、ぜいたくだよ！
ex_1_en: You’ve been living in such comfort. You shouldn’t ask for too much.
ex_2_jp: このせきは、お年よりや体の不自由な方のためのゆう先ざせきですよ。
ex_2_en: This is priority seating for the elderly and disabled, okay?
ex_3_jp: 私の兄は、足が不自由です。
ex_3_en: My older brother’s legs are disabled.
meaning_story: Remember how 自由 means freedom? Well when you add not it causes you discomfort and really inconveniences you. That not is in the way of your freedom.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: フꜜジユー *** フジꜜユー

ex_1_jp: 自たくのベランダで、イモムシを発見しました。
ex_1_en: I found hornworms on my balcony.
ex_2_jp: がんは、早き発見することがひじょうに重ようです。
ex_2_en: It’s very important to have early detection for cancer.
ex_3_jp: Facebookでお金を稼ぐ方法を発見したぜ。しかも超簡単なの。まず、アカウント設定に行くだろ、それからアカウントを停止して、仕事に行くんだ！
ex_3_en: I discovered how to make money from Facebook. It’s easy. Just go to your account settings, deactivate your account, and go to work.
meaning_story: You make departure from your home off into the great beyond. You will go to see the unseen, and hopefully make a great discovery.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know the はつ part, which gets shortened to はっ. The 見 is unlike what you learned with 見, though. In order to remember that this is けん, imagine you're going out to make a discovery of some strange new lands. With strange new lands, there comes strange new people. You find an island inhabited entirely by Ken (けん) dolls. They are not friendly.

ex_1_jp: 分からないかん字の下に、二重せんを引いてください。
ex_1_en: Please draw double lines under kanji you don’t know.
ex_2_jp: 日本は二重国せきをみとめていません。
ex_2_en: Japan doesn't allow dual citizenship.
ex_3_jp: 「それでは、世間話はそれぐらいにして、本題に入ろう。今日の議題は何だったかな？」「今日はあなたの二重あごについて話しをすることになっています。」「そうだったな。それでは始めようか。」
ex_3_en: "Well, let’s stop the small talk and cut to the chase. What was the topic of today’s meeting?" "We were going to talk about your double chin, sir." "Right, right. Let’s get started."
meaning_story: When you have two heavy things, you have double and dual the heavy (compared to one, at least). This word is a prefix attached to other words to show that it is "double." 二重 kanji time!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ニジュー *** フタꜜエ *** フタエꜜ

ex_1_jp: 毎度おさわがせして、申しわけありません。
ex_1_en: I’m sorry for all the times I’ve troubled you.
ex_2_jp: 毎度のことだが、空は今日もちゅう文を決めるのがおそい。
ex_2_en: Sora can't make up his mind about which one to order, as usual.
ex_3_jp: 毎度有難う御座います。
ex_3_en: Thank you for your continued patronage.
meaning_story: When something happens at every occurrence and at every degree, it's something that happens frequently. It happens each time.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 今回のテストは、楽勝だったね。
ex_1_en: This test was a piece of cake.
ex_2_jp: 「JLPT5はどうだった？」「ワニカニのおかげで、楽勝だったよ。」
ex_2_en: ”How was the JLPT5?" "Thanks to Wanikani, it was easy peasy."
ex_3_jp: 戦争では、より高度な技術を持っている側が通常楽勝する。
ex_3_en: The side who has better technology in a war will usually have an easy victory.
meaning_story: A win that was an ease. That is an easy victory or an easy win. Don't hope for a lot of these, though. Hope for tough wins instead, they actually make you better.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 小学校で、小さな子どもたちに、色々な絵本をよんであげています。
ex_1_en: I'm reading various picture books to little children in elementary schools.
ex_2_jp: あの小学校には、コウイチ気取りの六年生の男の子がいます。
ex_2_en: In that elementary school, there is a sixth grade boy who is a Koichi wannabe.
ex_3_jp: 小学生の頃から、君のことずっと気になっていたんだ。
ex_3_en: I’ve had feelings for you since I was in elementary school.
meaning_story: You've seen 学校 from a couple levels ago. Now we're adding a small to it. What is a "small school"? That's a school for small people, making it an elementary school.
reading_story: The reading is the regular on'yomi reading of 小 plus the vocab word 学校 that you've seen previously. Combine these two things for the reading of 小学校.

ex_1_jp: 用事をおねがいしてもいいですか。
ex_1_en: Would you mind if I asked you to do some errands?
ex_2_jp: ごめんなさい！ちょっと用事が出来てしまって、今日のレッスンをキャンセルしないといけなくなってしまいました。
ex_2_en: Sorry! I have to take care of something and I have to cancel my lesson today.
ex_3_jp: 大事な用事があるので、明日は出勤することができません。
ex_3_en: I have an important matter to attend to so I will not be able to work tomorrow.
meaning_story: A task action is something you have to do (because 事 is all about actions). What's another way to say "an action that is a task," though? I would say errand or even business.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 重要なしょるいなので、なくさないようちゅういしてください。
ex_1_en: They’re important documents, so please be careful not to lose them.
ex_2_jp: この国にとって、国民一人当たり一羽の白鳥をかうことはとても重要なことなんです。
ex_2_en: For this country, it is a very important that each citizen raises one swan.
ex_3_jp: 私にとって人生で一番重要なものはビールですって？そんなこと言ってないわよ。言いもしないことを言ったなんて言わないでよ。
ex_3_en: The most important thing in my life is beer? I didn’t say that! Don’t put words in my mouth.
meaning_story: When something has a heavy need, you know that that thing is essential. It is important.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 丁度おふろから出たところです。
ex_1_en: I just got out of the bath.
ex_2_jp: 丁度いいゆかげんです。
ex_2_en: The bath temperature is just right.
ex_3_jp: まあ、偶然！今丁度あなたに電話をしようと思っていたところよ！
ex_3_en: What a coincidence! I was just about to call you!
meaning_story: Okay, we're going to cheat a little bit to remember the meaning of this word. Let's say you take the temperature of the street. It is exactly one hundred degrees. That's exactly what it is. Just 100 degrees, not one degree more or less. You put your eggs on the street and watch them cook.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あなたの気持ちはよく分かります。
ex_1_en: I know exactly how you feel.
ex_2_jp: 気持ちがわるくてはきそうです。
ex_2_en: I feel sick, like I'm going to throw up.
ex_3_jp: これ、つまらないものですが。ささやかな感謝の気持ちです。どうぞ、開けてみてください。
ex_3_en: Here’s a little something for you. This is just a small token of my appreciation. Go ahead, open it.
meaning_story: The energy you hold in your body is your feelings. It can take the form of all kinds of things. Good feelings, bad feelings, that "strange feeling." Now, don't confuse this with the future vocab word 気持ちいい which means "good feeling." This one just means "feeling" because it doesn't have an adjective attached to it, telling you more about this feeling that you're having.
reading_story: The readings are the same as the ones you learned with the kanji, though 気 is on'yomi and 持ち is kun'yomi. One of those weird exception readings, but it worked out for you anyways as long as you're studying the kanji well enough.

ex_1_jp: 火事があった場所は、アパートの五かいです。
ex_1_en: The fire place is on the fifth floor of the apartment.
ex_2_jp: 何か臭うんだけど。もしかして、火事じゃない？
ex_2_en: I smell something strange! Maybe a fire?
ex_3_jp: 昨日、家が火事になる夢を見たんです。
ex_3_en: Yesterday I had a dream that my house caught on fire.
meaning_story: Fire is a thing that makes more fire. Basically fire is fire.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 魚屋で金目だいを買ってきたの。
ex_1_en: We went to buy splendid red bream at the fish store.
ex_2_jp: この魚屋のゆかはすべりやすいから気を付けてね。
ex_2_en: This fish shop floor is very slippery, so be careful.
ex_3_jp: あの魚屋さんは百円おまけをしてくれた。
ex_3_en: The fish shop gave me a 100 yen discount.
meaning_story: A fish shop is a fish shop, a place from which you buy fish. Especially in Japan, very important.
reading_story: The kun'yomi reading is used for the 魚 (so it's さかな) and the kun'yomi reading is used for 屋 (や). You'll have to use the reading of 魚 from the vocabulary from a couple levels ago to remember the reading of this one.

ex_1_jp: 安田さんは、食べ物をおねがいします。
ex_1_en: Please bring some food, Ms. Yasuda.
ex_2_jp: かなしい時や、おちこんでいる時は、いつも食べ物がのどを通らなくなってしまうんです。
ex_2_en: I've always had issues with eating whenever I get sad or depressed.
ex_3_jp: 食べ物を粗末にするとバチが当たりますよ。
ex_3_en: When you waste food, heaven will punish you.
meaning_story: An eat thing (aka "a thing you eat") is food. Eat those things. Eat that food. Because it's a "thing" you know it's a noun. Interesting how this kanji can turn a verb like this into a noun, right? Look out for it because this pattern will show up with other verbs as well!
reading_story: The reading comes from 食べる (the hint is in the べ) and the reading you learned with 物.
pitch_accent: タベモꜜノ *** タベꜜモノ

ex_1_jp: この夏、Tofuguから、「ベーコンとおこのみやきのチーズタルト」が発売されることが決定しました！
ex_1_en: We’ve decided to sell bacon and cheese tart okonomiyaki from Tofugu this summer.
ex_2_jp: コウイチのつめのあかをせんじたポートランド名物トーフグ茶がトーフグのウェブサイトででぜっさん発売中です！
ex_2_en: Portland's famous Tofugu tea, with the dirt of Koichi's nails, is now on sale on the Tofugu website!
ex_3_jp: Tofuguのデート用抱きまくらが発売されるのが待ち遠しい。
ex_3_en: I can’t wait until the Tofugu dating pillows are on sale.
meaning_story: You want things to depart from your store so you have to sell them. You put all these things up for sale. They are selling these items.
reading_story: The reading is a bit strange. 発 (はつ) is good, but the 売 kanji uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. It's not too hard, though. What do people do when they purchase your goods that are up for sale? They buy (ばい) them.

ex_1_jp: 表はピンク色にぬってください。
ex_1_en: Please paint the front pink.
ex_2_jp: コウイチの表のかおはトーフグ社長であるが、うらのかおは世界でも有数のジャグリングせん手である。
ex_2_en: Koichi's public face is the president of Tofugu, but his private face is the most well-known juggler in the world.
ex_3_jp: 十円玉の表はどちらですか？
ex_3_en: Which side of a ten yen coin is the face?
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji express. If you want to understand what something is trying to express you usually look at its front or its exterior. This word is usually used for the exterior face of buildings.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're standing in front of a building, staring at its front. You spend some time gazing at it before you realize what it is. "Oh, motel (おもて)", you say aloud. A little time looking at the exterior and you're able to figure it out.

ex_1_jp: 今週末は、新きょの家具を買いに行く予定です。
ex_1_en: I plan to go buy furniture for my new house this weekend.
ex_2_jp: 王女の家具は本当にすばらしいですね！さすがです！
ex_2_en: You have such wonderful furniture, Princess! Very impressive.
ex_3_jp: 家具はあなたの家にお運びしましたが、もう少し腰を軽くして扉と窓を早く取り付ける方がいいのではないかと思います。
ex_3_en: We moved the furniture to your new house but you should act quickly to get the doors and windows installed.
meaning_story: Your house tools aren't the tools you use to build a house. They're more like the things that are a part of your house that you use like tools. Those things would be your furniture. So, remember, your house tools are just furniture.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お客さんが入ってくると、このベルがなります。
ex_1_en: When customers come in, this bell rings.
ex_2_jp: 東京えきで、お客さんと会いました。
ex_2_en: I met up with my guest at Tokyo Station.
ex_3_jp: お客さんを獲得するにはどうすればいいと思いますか？
ex_3_en: What do you think I should do to get customers?
meaning_story: The さん on the end is the name honorific さん. It's there to show some respect. It's like saying "Mr. Guest!" or something like that. But that sounds dumb in English. We'll just call this word guest, visitor, or customer. You'll hear this word a lot when you're at a store or you're a customer somewhere in Japan. You are the お客さん, in that situation. Alternatively, you'll also hear お客さま which is a more polite version of this word (because it ends in さま and not さん).
reading_story: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just add the hiragana on the end and you'll be good to go.

ex_1_jp: 大すきなアイドルと、ろ天ぶろ付の客室にとまることがゆめなんです。
ex_1_en: My dream is to stay in a guest room attached to an open air bath with the idol I love.
ex_2_jp: このホテルでは全ての客室にコンシェルジュサービスが付いてきます。
ex_2_en: In this hotel, all the guest rooms have concierge service.
ex_3_jp: ちょうど客室のリフォームが終わったところなんですの。是非うちにいらして、ご意見を聞かせてくださいな。
ex_3_en: I just finished renovating the guest room. Come over and tell me what you think.
meaning_story: A guest's room is the guest room (the room you put guests in, duh!).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: ハートがた, はーとがた
ex_1_jp: ネイル用に、ハート形のストーンをさがしています。
ex_1_en: I’m looking for a heart shaped stone to use on my fake nails.
ex_2_jp: クリスティンは、くぎをくわえながら、ハート形のハンマーをふり回していた。
ex_2_en: Kristen was swinging a heart shaped hammer around while holding nails in her mouth.
ex_3_jp: フラミンゴがキスをする時、二羽の頭と首がハート形を描く。
ex_3_en: When flamingos kiss, their heads and necks form a heart shape.
meaning_story: ハート is of course "heart" and you know that 形 means shape. You've probably already figured this one out. It's heart shaped. You can add this kanji to all sorts of other things too to say "____ shaped." Give it a try!
reading_story: The reading for the kanji portion uses the kun'yomi reading. This is kind of like the reading you already learned for 形 just without the ち part. And rendaku happens too, so it become がた. If you can remember that, you should be able to remember this reading too!

ex_1_jp: そのにもつは重そうですね。
ex_1_en: That luggage looks heavy.
ex_2_jp: この車、重すぎてうでがもげそう。
ex_2_en: This car is so heavy that my arm is about to fall off.
ex_3_jp: 「足を踏んでしまってごめんなさい。」「ちょっと重かったけど、どうってことないよ。」
ex_3_en: "I’m sorry I stepped on your foot." "No problem. It was a little heavy, but no harm done."
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of heavy? It's also heavy.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're lifting something that's really heavy. Oof! You lift it above your head. You're so awesome. You scream: "OH! MORE!" (おも) they put more. You yell it again: "OH, MORE!" and again: "OH, MORE!" Go ahead and act this out wherever you are, pretending like you're holding a couch or two or three over your head, saying "OH MORE!"

ex_1_jp: あいつのテンションの高さはやばいよな。
ex_1_en: His excitement levels are dangerously high, right?
ex_2_jp: トーフグのサボテンは、1.5メートルの高さにまでせい長しました。
ex_2_en: Tofugu's cactus has grown to a height of 1.5 meters.
ex_3_jp: 「この建物の高さについてどう思いますか？少し高すぎますかねえ？」「申し訳ありませんが、分かりません。私には難しすぎます。」
ex_3_en: "What do you think about the height of this building? Is it too high?" "Sorry, but I don’t know. It’s over my head."
meaning_story: You've seen the word 高い from a couple levels ago. This word is related to that. It's like 大きい versus 大きさ, where one describes the other. In this case, the 高さ is the height of something (while 高い is tall). This word isn't "price" though. For that you'd ask いくらですか？ (how much is it?).
reading_story: Use the reading of 高い (たかい) to help you to learn and remember the reading for this one. They are the same with just the hiragana at the end different.

ex_1_jp: 今日は、高校生たちが、このパン工場の見学に来ます。
ex_1_en: Today, high school students are coming to this bread factory on a field trip.
ex_2_jp: わたしは高校生の時、毎日のように海に行っては魚をとって食べていました。
ex_2_en: When I was a high school student, I would go to the sea every day to catch fish and eat them.
ex_3_jp: あいつはただの高校生デビューだよ。
ex_3_en: He's just trying to look cool because he’s in high school now.
meaning_story: You know 高校 means "high school." So, a "life" that does high school is a high school student. This is like how 中学生 are middle school students and 小学生 are elementary school students!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Use the reading of 高校 from before to learn the reading of this word as well, if it helps.

ex_1_jp: 家事、ほんとにめんどくさいけど、がんばる。
ex_1_en: Housework is really annoying, but I’ll do my best.
ex_2_jp: 主人はいつもわたしにばかり家事をおし付けてくるから本当にこまります。
ex_2_en: My husband has me do chores all the time and I'm not happy about it at all.
ex_3_jp: 家事全般が苦手なんですよね。
ex_3_en: I’m bad at all of the housework.
meaning_story: The only action you should be doing in my house is the housework and my chores. This isn't a hotel. Get moving! Clean my dishes!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 人生には本当に大切なしゅん間が何度かおとずれる。
ex_1_en: We all have really important moments, a few times in our lives.
ex_2_jp: トーフグは、おなかが空いたサメに食べられそうになったことが何度もある。
ex_2_en: Tofugu has almost been eaten by the hungry shark many times.
ex_3_jp: 何度同じことを言えば分かるんだ？
ex_3_en: How many times do I have to say the same thing before you understand?
meaning_story: If someone asks you what occurrence or what degrees they're really trying to ask you how many times something happened. Sometimes they're asking what temperature it is too.
reading_story: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: 大事なのは、きちんとあいさつをすることです。
ex_1_en: The important thing is to greet them properly.
ex_2_jp: 日本ごのべんきょうのために、毎日ワニカニにログインしてレビューをするのはとても大事なことです。
ex_2_en: Logging onto Wanikani and doing your reviews every day is very important for your Japanese learning.
ex_3_jp: リラックスする時間をとることは、とても大事だよ。
ex_3_en: Taking time to relax is important.
meaning_story: A big action means something big is going down. This is no ordinary action. It is an action that is important.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: オーコ°ト *** オーコ°ꜜト *** ダꜜイジ *** ダイジꜜ *** ダイジ

ex_1_jp: このもんだいでは、始めにしつもんをきいてください。
ex_1_en: For this problem, please begin by listening to the question.
ex_2_jp: 始めにカナエがたん生日ケーキにしょうゆをこぼしてしまったこと以外は、コウイチのサプライズバースデーパーティーは大せいこうでした。
ex_2_en: Koichi's surprise birthday party went really well except that Kanae spilled soy sauce on his birthday cake in the beginning.
ex_3_jp: 聖書の一番始めには何が書かれているの？
ex_3_en: What are the first words at the beginning of the Bible?
meaning_story: You know the kanji part means begin. The に on the end refers to a direction. So, think of this like "the direction of the beginning" which would be where things all started. That's why this word/phrase means "in the beginning."
reading_story: The reading is kun'yomi (look at all that hiragana!) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji, so have no fear, you got it!

ex_1_jp: 和風のあじ付けがすきなんですよ。
ex_1_en: I do like Japanese flavors.
ex_2_jp: かえりにスーパーで、和風ごまドレッシングを買ってきてください。
ex_2_en: Can you get Japanese sesame dressing from a grocery store on the way back?
ex_3_jp: これが和風ホットドッグです。
ex_3_en: This is the Japanese style hotdog.
meaning_story: The Japanese style style. The Japanese often like to think they're very unique and have a very special kind of style (and often times they do). So, you'll hear this word used when someone wants to describe this unique sense of style. Wafuuuu! Note that this word uses alternative kanji meanings in both of the kanji. They're in the kanji explanation, but they're not the primaries, so it may take a little extra effort to learn this word depending on what you studied!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 和服もに合ってるね。
ex_1_en: You look good in Japanese style clothes too.
ex_2_jp: 何ちゃく和服をもっていますか？
ex_2_en: How many Japanese style clothes do you have?
ex_3_jp: 和服でマラソンをする日本人を見たことがありますか？
ex_3_en: Have you seen Japanese people running marathons in Japanese style clothes?
meaning_story: Japanese style clothes (Japanese Style Clothes). We're talking kimonos and yukata and things like that. Basically, this differentiates Japanese clothing from Western clothing. What kind of clothes will you wear to the festival tonight? Oh, probably some 和服.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 朝ごはんは、和食がいいですね。
ex_1_en: Well I like having Japanese style food for breakfast.
ex_2_jp: アメリカ人の中にもさい近、よう食よりも和食がすきな人がふえている。
ex_2_en: There's been an increase in Americans who prefer Japanese cuisine to Western cuisine.
ex_3_jp: 和食イコール寿司ってわけじゃない。
ex_3_en: Japanese style food doesn’t always mean sushi.
meaning_story: Japanese style eat ... well, let's change "eat" to "food" and you have Japanese style food. This is a good way to differentiate between an American style restaurant and a Japanese style restaurant. What kind of food you feeling like tonight? Oh, how about some 和食?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 和室でねるのは、これがはじめてです。
ex_1_en: This is my first time sleeping in a Japanese-style room.
ex_2_jp: この和室、ドッグフードとコウイチの足のにおいがまざったようなにおいがしない？
ex_2_en: Don't you think this Japanese-style room smells like a mix of dog food and your feet, Koichi?
ex_3_jp: 私のお兄ちゃんは、和室で大きな蜘蛛を飼っています。
ex_3_en: My older brother has a huge pet spider in his Japanese-style room.
meaning_story: A Japanese style room tends to be pretty small. This mainly refers to the kind of room that's covered in tatami mats, though. If you're looking for places to stay in Japan, a 和室 will be something like that. You'll pull the futon out of the closet and sleep on the floor. So comfy, these Japanese style rooms!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: まずは、仮名をかくれんしゅうから始めましょう。
ex_1_en: First, let’s begin by practicing writing kana.
ex_2_jp: ワニカニでかん字をべん強するのに、まずは仮名を全部知っている必要がある。
ex_2_en: In order to study kanji on WaniKani, you must first know all of the kana.
ex_3_jp: この書類の漢字全部に、振り仮名を振ってもらえませんか？
ex_3_en: Could you add kana to all the kanji in this document, please?
meaning_story: The temporary names. These are the kana (that's hiragana and katakana). Why are the "temporary names" kana, though? Perhaps they were never meant to be a main way to write the names of the kanji... They are just a temporary way to write the name of kanji you don't know how to write the "correct" way (aka kanji)? That's just a guess, but it should help you to remember that this word means "kana," at least.
reading_story: The reading for 仮 is the one you learned with the kanji. The 名 portion is not, however, and uses its kun'yomi reading (な), which you saw with the kanji 名 (な). How to remember all this, though? Think of it this way: The people who made kanji really don't want you to know kana. It's bad for business. They want anyone who uses the word "kana" to suffer, so they decided to make one part on'yomi and another part kun'yomi. Don't let them get you!

ex_1_jp: かわらでなぞの生物を発見した。
ex_1_en: A mysterious creature was discovered at a dry river bed.
ex_2_jp: 地きゅう上でもっとも大きい生物はシロナガスクジラではなく、シロナガスフグです。
ex_2_en: The largest living thing on the planet isn't blue whale but blue blowfish.
ex_3_jp: こないだの生物の授業のノート、見せてくれないかな。
ex_3_en: Can I see your notes from the other day in Bio?
meaning_story: A thing that has life is a living thing!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 物 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you can't tell the difference between living things and non-living things just check which one can wear boots (ぶつ). Can a cat wear boots? Yes! It's a living thing. Can a rock wear boots? Nope. Definitely not alive. Easy!
pitch_accent: セꜜイブツ *** ナマꜜモノ

ex_1_jp: ポートランドの名物は何ですか。
ex_1_en: What is Portland’s specialty?
ex_2_jp: トーフグの名物社長から、東京名物の東京ばななをおみやげにもらいました。
ex_2_en: I got Tokyo's famous "Tokyo Banana" from the Tofugu's famous-for-being-unique president.
ex_3_jp: たこ焼きは絶対に大阪名物の一つです。
ex_3_en: Takoyaki is definitely one of the most famous foods in Osaka.
meaning_story: The famous thing of an area is their famous product, but it sound better in English if you say it's the local specialty. When you're traveling around Japan, be sure to be on the lookout for the 名物! It's always fun.
reading_story: The reading is both on'yomi ... only problem is you learned the kun'yomi reading of 物. To help you to remember 物 think of the famous product of the area being boots (ぶつ). You buy the famous boots, wear them, and feel awesome. The 名 portion is just the on'yomi reading you learned with the kanji, so don't worry too much about that part.

ex_1_jp: もう少し要点をせいりしてからいけんをのべてください。
ex_1_en: Please state your opinion after rearranging your main point a bit more.
ex_2_jp: ユウサクが要点をはあくしているとは思えないんだけど。
ex_2_en: I don't think Yusaku got the gist.
ex_3_jp: いいから！早く要点を言ってよ！
ex_3_en: Come on! Get to the point!
meaning_story: The needed point is the main point. It's the gist of what you're trying to say.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 勝負は引き分けにおわった。
ex_1_en: The match ended in a tie.
ex_2_jp: これは、一発勝負のコンテストです。
ex_2_en: This is a contest decided by a single round.
ex_3_jp: この一年は、勝負の年だと思っています。
ex_3_en: I think this is the year things happen for me.
meaning_story: Win, lose... both will happen in tonight's match! What a showdown it will be!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that ふ becomes ぶ because of rendaku here.

ex_1_jp: 今、食事中なので、後でまたかけます。
ex_1_en: I’m in the middle of eating a meal, so I’ll call you back later.
ex_2_jp: どうぞごゆっくりお食事をお楽しみください。
ex_2_en: Please relax and enjoy your meal!
ex_3_jp: もし残りの人生毎日同じ食事しか食べられないとしたら、何を選びますか？
ex_3_en: If you could only have one meal every day for the rest of your life, what would you choose?
meaning_story: The action of eating is when you have your meal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: それより、中学校の前でとった写しんがいいよ。
ex_1_en: All that aside, you should choose the photo taken in front of the junior high school.
ex_2_jp: ちょっとまってて。その中学校のば所を今しらべてあげる。
ex_2_en: Give me a sec, I'll look up the location of the middle school for you.
ex_3_jp: ええっと、私は中学校の教師ですよね。そこで、時間を無駄にしないためにも、とりあえず私は絶対に間違ったことを言わない、ということにしておいてください。
ex_3_en: I’m a middle school teacher, right? To save time, let’s just always assume that I am never wrong, okay?
meaning_story: You know that 学校 means school. So, people who are in the middle school are in... wait for it... middle school. And, of course, if you're one of those people that call it junior high school you can do that too.
reading_story: The reading is a combination of 学校 and 中. Really, it's all on'yomi too, so you should be able to read this one. Take note of the がく turning to がっ, though.

ex_1_jp: 名古屋にはおいしいものがたくさんあります。
ex_1_en: Nagoya has a lot of delicious food.
ex_2_jp: 今日も名古屋で仕事があった。
ex_2_en: I had work in Nagoya today again.
ex_3_jp: 名古屋にいる友人を訪れた際、矢場とんというとても美味しいトンカツをご馳走してもらいました。
ex_3_en: When I visited my friend in Nagoya, I was treated to a delicious pork cutlet called yabaton.
meaning_story: The place that's famous for old roofs. I don't know why, but it's the city of Nagoya. Just associate the two things together and it'll be hard to forget (so long as you've heard of Nagoya before - if not, read up about it!).
