reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji (except for 名 and 屋, which are kun'yomi here). If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. For な just think to 名前 (なまえ) which uses the な reading. The "name" (名前) of this city is what? It's Nagoya. Watch out for rendaku changing こ to ご too.

ex_1_jp: バスをおりてから、少し歩く必要があります。
ex_1_en: I have to walk a little while after getting off the bus.
ex_2_jp: JETのめんせつに合かくするために必要なことって何ですか。
ex_2_en: What is necessary to pass the JET interview?
ex_3_jp: 日本に行ったら必要になるものって何だろう？
ex_3_en: What would I need if I went to Japan?
meaning_story: It's certain that you need it. This thing is necessary. It is needed.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この付近に、コンビニはありますか？
ex_1_en: Does this neighborhood have a convenience store?
ex_2_jp: 付近には、外国人見物客もたくさんいました。
ex_2_en: There are many foreign viewers nearby as well.
ex_3_jp: この付近に公衆便所はありますか。
ex_3_en: Is there a public restroom in this neighborhood?
meaning_story: If you attach things near you, they end up being in the same neighborhood as you. They're attached nearby so they can't go much further.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 付 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your neighborhood is full of fools (ふ). Fools everywhere. You're probably one too, since you live nearby.

ex_1_jp: 新しいえんぴつですね。
ex_1_en: This pencil is new, isn’t it?
ex_2_jp: じゃあ、あの新しいスタバでね！
ex_2_en: I'll see you at the new Starbucks!
ex_3_jp: あの男、バンジージャンプするのに私の新しいスカーフを使うなんて、信じられない！
ex_3_en: I can’t believe he used my new scarf to bungee jump!
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of new? It's new.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your family buys you a new Atari! You're so excited! But wait... what's this? This is no Atari. This is an Atara... a knockoff video game system :(

ex_1_jp: 新年、明けましておめでとうございます。
ex_1_en: Happy New Year!
ex_2_jp: 新年のほうふはもう決めましたか？
ex_2_en: Have you decided your New Year's resolution yet?
ex_3_jp: 新年の挨拶に、親戚の家を回りました。
ex_3_en: We went around to our relatives houses exchanging New Year’s greetings.
meaning_story: A new year is a new year. Hope you had / have / are having a good one, depending on when you read this.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 食べすぎて苦しい。
ex_1_en: I ate too much and it’s painful.
ex_2_jp: トーフグにあいをこく白できなくて苦しいよ！
ex_2_en: I'm agonizing over the fact that I'm not able to confess my love to Tofugu.
ex_3_jp: 絶望のどん底に落ちて、苦しい思いをしている、そこのあなた！もしや、銀行があなたの家を差し押さえちゃったとか？もし、そうなら、我々はあなたのためにとっておきのものをご用意しております…その名も「インスタント・アルツハイマー」！我々のこの新薬を使えば、あなたは辛い思い出を忘ることができますよ！
ex_3_en: Are you suffering from a broken heart? Has the bank recently foreclosed on your house? If so, we have just the thing for you... "Instant Alzheimer’s." Our new medication will allow you to put your woes behind you.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of suffering? It's a description of that word, making it painful.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're suffering real bad. Why? You have something heavy on top of you, crushing (くる) you.

ex_1_jp: まずは、相手の話をちゃんときいてあげようよ。
ex_1_en: First, you will listen closely to what your partner has to say.
ex_2_jp: うらないによると、わたしのけっこん相手はどこかの国の王子さまだそうです。本当かな？
ex_2_en: According to my fortune, my future partner is a prince in some country. I wonder if it's true.
ex_3_jp: 馬鹿な話し相手は欲しくない。
ex_3_en: I don’t want a stupid talking companion.
meaning_story: Your mutual hand is someone else's hands (or just someone else, if you remembered that 手 can also refer to a person as well). Whose hands are these? These are your partner's hands. That's why everything is mutual.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. For 手, that's no problem for you. For 相, that's more of an issue since you learned the on'yomi reading for it. Thinks of it this way: Your partner wouldn't be your partner without you. Your partner is: I (あい) and you. Remember that as you gaze into your partner's eyes. "I and you."

ex_1_jp: いつになったら、世界は平和になるんだろうか。
ex_1_en: So when do you think the world will find peace?
ex_2_jp: 安全で平和な地いきに住みたいです。
ex_2_en: I want to live in a safe and harmonious community.
ex_3_jp: どうして日本ではみんなあの平和のシンボルを写真にかざすの？
ex_3_en: Why does everyone in Japan use the peace sign in pictures?
meaning_story: The flat peace. This is a peace that will last, because there's no waves... no ripples... just flat. This is plain old peace.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この部分は、何色にしますか？
ex_1_en: What color do you want for this part?
ex_2_jp: のうの前の部分の名前って何だっけ？
ex_2_en: What was the front part of the brain again?
ex_3_jp: この映画、共感出来る部分だらけでめちゃくちゃ泣けた。
ex_3_en: The movie was full of parts I sympathized with and I cried all over myself.
meaning_story: Part of a part? That's a portion, a section of that part, and even a part in itself!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

ex_1_jp: 何県の出身ですか。
ex_1_en: What prefecture are you from?
ex_2_jp: なら県の小学校では、せい服をきないといけない学校が多いです。
ex_2_en: There are many elementary schools in Nara that require students to wear uniforms.
ex_3_jp: 今まで日本の何県に行ったことがあるの？
ex_3_en: Which prefectures in Japan have you been to?
meaning_story: Attach this word onto the end of a prefecture place name and you have the prefecture portion of _____ prefecture. These are a lot like states or provinces.
reading_story: The reading for this is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because it's always attached to things (so it's like jukugo). Don't write the 〜 when you're writing in the answer, just the けん portion, and you'll get this one correct.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: このたんごの発音を教えてください。
ex_1_en: Please teach me the pronunciation of this word.
ex_2_jp: タイラーさんは日本ごの発音がとても上手ですね。
ex_2_en: Taylor, your Japanese pronunciation is so good.
ex_3_jp: わあ！スペイン語の小さな家って言葉の発音、日本語の「お腹すいた」にめちゃくちゃ似てる！
ex_3_en: Wow, the pronunciation of the Spanish word "una casita" sounds similar to "I’m hungry" in Japanese.
meaning_story: The sound that departs from your mouth is you talking. Imagine yourself saying things and words departing your mouth. They are bent in different ways and have different colors, highlighting your pronunciation of certain words and phrases.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このかん字の部首は何ですか？
ex_1_en: What is this kanji’s radical?
ex_2_jp: 部首をわらうものは部首になく。
ex_2_en: Someone who laughs over radicals will eventually cry over radicals.
ex_3_jp: 私は全部の部首を覚えています。
ex_3_en: I remember all of the radicals.
meaning_story: Picture the part of your body that makes up your neck. Are you picturing it? That's a building block that makes up your body. A really important one. If you didn't have that neck, you wouldn't look like a person at all. Sound familiar? It should! Because that part of your neck is a radical! Just like part of your neck is a building block of your body, the radical is a building block of kanji. Get it? I sure hope so!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 首 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A radical is just a part of the whole kanji just like a shoe (しゅ) is only a part of what you're going to wear today! I hope. Please wear more than just a single shoe! *cough* ...I mean, anyway. Just picture shoes when you think of radicals.

ex_1_jp: まだ返事をおくっていません。
ex_1_en: I haven’t responded yet.
ex_2_jp: 出せきのお返事、ありがとうございます。
ex_2_en: Thanks for your RSVP.
ex_3_jp: 私は、お金が欲しいというメールを百通以上ビル・ゲーツに送りましたが、まだ返事をもらっていません。
ex_3_en: I sent Bill Gates over one hundred messages about giving me money, but he still hasn’t replied.
meaning_story: The action of returning. That is a reply.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 市はひなん所をかいせつして、住民にひなんをよびかけています。
ex_1_en: The city established a shelter and appealed to the citizens to take refuge.
ex_2_jp: 住民たちは、みんなすぐに打ちとけました。
ex_2_en: The residents got along with each other right away.
ex_3_jp: あのアパートの住民には無料のエアコンが与えられるが、何故か冬の間だけなのである。
ex_3_en: The residents of that apartment are given free air-conditioning, but only in winter for some reason.
meaning_story: The peoples who make their dwelling here are the residents.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: かれ、お金持ちなんだけど…
ex_1_en: He’s rich though…
ex_2_jp: ちょうお金持ちとけっこんしたい。
ex_2_en: I want to marry someone who is filthy rich.
ex_3_jp: 若い頃、お金を稼ぐために、近所のお金持ちの人たちの使い走りをしていました。
ex_3_en: I used to run small errands for a wealthy neighbor of mine to make money when I was young.
meaning_story: When you hold gold you are rich person.
reading_story: Do you remember the word お金? This is the 金 in this word. The reading for 持ち is the も you learned with the kanji. So, combine the かね of お金 and the 持ち and you have the reading of this word. Alternatively, you can say this word as お金持ち as well.
pitch_accent: カネモꜜチ *** カネモチꜜ

ex_1_jp: 妹は部屋のそうじをしました。
ex_1_en: My younger sister cleaned the room.
ex_2_jp: わたしの学校には、音楽室の中に夜だけにあらわれる部屋があるそうです。
ex_2_en: I heard that there is a room that only appears at night in the music room of my school.
ex_3_jp: 部屋を片付けようとすると、いつも途中で見つけた別のものに気を取られてしまって、片付けることができません。
ex_3_en: I can’t clean my room because whenever I try I just get distracted by all the stuff I find.
meaning_story: If you have a part of a roof, that part is your room. Just imagine a roof divided into sections in a house, with the sections going all the way down to the ground. Each section is its own room, right?
reading_story: The reading is kind of an exception. The 屋 is normal (や) but the 部 is weird. It is へ. Just imagine that you rent out a room and the only one they have is just the hay (へ) room in the barn, so you sleep there for the night. Imagine the smell of hay and how scratchy it is to sleep in this room.

ex_1_jp: おも白そうだから、見物してみましょう。
ex_1_en: It seems fun, so let’s have a look.
ex_2_jp: オフィスのまどから、クリスマスパレードを見物しました。
ex_2_en: We watched the Christmas parade from the office windows.
ex_3_jp: 母ちゃんなら、東京見物に出かけたぜ。
ex_3_en: Mom would have gone sightseeing in Tokyo.
meaning_story: If you try to see a bunch of things at once, you are probably sightseeing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn these readings yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you go sightseeing you happen to see Ken (けん) from Street Fighter hiking in boots (ぶつ). That's strange, Ken usually doesn't wear boots. You'll end up spending all your time watching him instead.

ex_1_jp: 近くにくすり屋と肉屋もあります。
ex_1_en: There is a pharmacy and a butcher shop nearby too.
ex_2_jp: 王女にてんしょくする前は花屋ではたらいていました。
ex_2_en: Before I changed my job to being a princess, I was working at a flower shop.
ex_3_jp: 焼肉屋さんを経営している人と結婚するのが夢です。
ex_3_en: It’s my dream to marry someone who owns yakiniku restaurants.
meaning_story: You'll see this attached to other words... like "meat" or "fish." When you see this, you'll know it is a ___ store, making this word mean store (same as the kanji).
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi reading. Don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.

ex_1_jp: じん社で必勝をきがんしてきました。
ex_1_en: I prayed for certain victory at a shrine.
ex_2_jp: 空手のし合で、「必勝」とかかれたハチマキをしている人を見ました。
ex_2_en: I saw a person wearing a headband that said "Sure Victory" at the karate match.
ex_3_jp: もし虎と七面鳥が戦争することになったら、それはもう虎の必勝になるだろうね。それから、ついでに、養鶏所で働く人も喜ぶだろうね。
ex_3_en: If tigers were to go to war against turkeys, it would mean certain victory for the tigers. Chicken farmers would be happy, as well.
meaning_story: A certain win sounds like a great thing. When these two kanji are put together, a certain victory is inevitable.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the つ in ひつ is turned into a small っ, though.

ex_1_jp: マイケルは魚よりも泳ぎが上手です。
ex_1_en: Michael's swimming is better than the fish's!
ex_2_jp: カエルの泳ぎにあこがれて必死に平泳ぎをれんしゅうしていたら、手と足がほそ長くなりました。
ex_2_en: I admired frogs' swimming so I frantically practiced the breaststroke until my arms and legs got longer.
ex_3_jp: 泳ぎはあまり得意ではありません。
ex_3_en: I’m not very good at swimming.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji swim, so it means swimming.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: あなたは、父さんの教えをしっかりまもって生きるのよ。
ex_1_en: You keep my father’s teachings alive and well.
ex_2_jp: それはすばらしい教えですね。
ex_2_en: It's such a great lesson, isn't it?
ex_3_jp: 君の教えに従うと、ろくなことがない。
ex_3_en: When I follow your teachings nothing goes well.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji teach. So it means teaching.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 教える, so you should be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: ポートランドでは、トーフグ茶屋の、ふぐもちが人気です。
ex_1_en: The Tofugu tea shop in Portland has popular fugu mochi.
ex_2_jp: きょうとにりょ行したとき、コウイチは毎ばん茶屋あそびを楽しみました。
ex_2_en: When Koichi traveled to Kyoto, he enjoyed teahouse entertainment every night.
ex_3_jp: 日本人は現代的なカフェを「カフェ」、昭和の香りのするコーヒーラウンジを「喫茶店」、伝統的なお茶屋さんを「茶屋」と呼びます。
ex_3_en: Japanese people call modern cafes "Cafe," slightly old fashioned coffee lounges "Kissaten," and traditional tea shops "Chaya."
meaning_story: A tea shop is a tea shop. Mmm, delicious, delicious tea.
reading_story: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 仮にコウイチが『トーフグはめすだ』と言っても、多くのユーザーはそのいけんに反対するんじゃないだろうか。
ex_1_en: Even if Koichi said, "Tofugu’s female," I believe many users would have opposing opinions.
ex_2_jp: 仮にトーフグにさいあくのじたいがおきたとしたら、ライフタイムメンバーの人たちはどうなるんですか？
ex_2_en: If the worst were to happen to Tofugu, what would happen to lifetime members?
ex_3_jp: え？あの娘の胸は風船で作られているって？仮にそうだとしても、だから何なんだよ！
ex_3_en: What? Her boobs are made of balloons? Suppose that were true, who cares?
meaning_story: The kanji itself means temporary. When you add the に on there you're going towards temporary, which is temporarily.
reading_story: The reading is kun'yomi, so here's a mnemonic to remember it: Would you mind carrying (かり) this temporarily?

ex_1_jp: さい近のCGは、パッと見たかんじ本物にしか見えないのがマジですごいと思う。
ex_1_en: Current CG is so realistic that it feels real at a first glance, and I think that’s really cool.
ex_2_jp: トーフグが本物そっくりのにせ札を作っているという黒いうわさをききました。
ex_2_en: I heard a dark rumor that Tofugu is making fake bills that look exactly like the real thing.
ex_3_jp: 小さいころ、父さんはいつも僕に「本物の男は誠実でいつづける」って言ってたけど、結局浮気をして、両親は離婚することになったんだ。
ex_3_en: When I was a kid, my dad always told me that real men stay faithful, but he ended up cheating on my mom and now they’re going to get a divorce.
meaning_story: The real thing is the real thing, aka the real deal. If you learned 本 as book you can also think of this word as the "book thing." What is this book thing? Is it the real version of the book? Is it the real deal? If so, I'll pay you a million.
reading_story: The readings are on'yomi plus kun'yomi (kun'yomi is 物). This word uses the reading you learned for both of these kanji, though, which means you should be able to read it.

ex_1_jp: しかし、この世界にはどちらもありません。
ex_1_en: However, neither of them exist in this world.
ex_2_jp: ふじ山は世界いさんにとうろくされています。
ex_2_en: Mt. Fuji is registered as a World Heritage Site.
ex_3_jp: あいつは自分の世界に閉じこもっていて、そこから出てこようとしないんだ。
ex_3_en: He lives in his own world and doesn’t want to leave it.
meaning_story: The generations (and society!) that make up the world create our world. The World. This word is used more like "the biggest dog in the world" or "the fattest cat in the world." For example, you'll hear words like 世界一番 (number one in the world) thrown around a lot.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: スモモさんが、ピンク色のいしょうをきる事が多いのはなぜですか？
ex_1_en: Why do you think Ms. Sumomo wears so many pink clothes?
ex_2_jp: 後はいが言っている事がいつもよく分からなくてこまっています。
ex_2_en: I often have trouble understanding what my junior colleague is saying.
ex_3_jp: すまないが、ちょっと今はする事がたくさんあって、忙しいんだ。
ex_3_en: I’m sorry but I’ve been busy recently because I have a lot of things to do.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Additionally on top of thing there are the meanings matter and action as well. Like the kanji, this word has to do with action things... things that you do, for example, rather than physical things.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: It's hard to start a mnemonic with the word "thing" or "action," so let's continue off the kanji mnemonic where you're brushing your teeth with a cross shaped thing. After you're done, it's time to go out. You put on your coat (こと) and walk out the door.

ex_1_jp: マサルさんが持っている物は何ですか。
ex_1_en: What is that thing Masaru has?
ex_2_jp: うちのワンちゃんを物あつかいしないでください！
ex_2_en: Don't treat my dog like a thing!
ex_3_jp: 私の好きな物を三つ挙げるなら、チキンと揚げ物とご飯です。
ex_3_en: My three favorite things are chicken, fried foods, and rice.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is the reading you learned with the kanji. Huzzah!

ex_1_jp: じゃあ、やっぱり今度にしよう。
ex_1_en: Okay, then let’s do it next time.
ex_2_jp: 今度は本当に本気の本気で日本ごをべんきょうします！
ex_2_en: I'm really, really serious about studying Japanese this time.
ex_3_jp: 今度俺がお前を泣かせる時は、嬉し泣きだ。
ex_3_en: The next time I make you cry it will be because you are happy.
meaning_story: In the now occurrence you'll learn your kanji, no? This word means this time (same like "now occurrence"). Despite being "this time" it has the feeling of next time, though. It's like saying "okay, this time we'll get it" where "this time" really means "next time," making it a little bit different from 今回.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今このパソコンを買うと、オマケがつくので、おとくですよ。
ex_1_en: If you buy this computer now, you’ll get something thrown in, so it’s a deal.
ex_2_jp: マイケルは毎日のようにサラダのドレッシングをTシャツにこぼしているので、かれのTシャツにはドレッシングのしみがたく山付いています。
ex_2_en: Michael spills salad dressing on his t-shirt almost every day, so his t-shirts have a lot of stains.
ex_3_jp: あなたの耳たぶに付いてるそれ、何？
ex_3_en: What’s that thing attached to your earlobe?
meaning_story: You know the that the word 付ける means "to attach" and you know that the kanji 付 means attach. So, this word probably has something to do with attaching. This is the intransitive version, though, where something is attached (and you're not doing the attaching). You can use the く as a hint. You see something attached on the wall. You say "Coo'"
reading_story: The reading can be derived from 付ける, a word you should have seen a few levels ago. If you know that word's reading you should be able to figure out this word's reading as well (and vice versa).

ex_1_jp: そのえいがは何時から始まりますか。
ex_1_en: What time does the movie start?
ex_2_jp: アメリカと中国のしれつなけいざいせんそうが始まりました。
ex_2_en: A fierce economic war between America and China has begun.
ex_3_jp: 銃声が、大食いパイコンテストの始まりの合図となります。
ex_3_en: The sound of the rifle means the pie eating contest has started.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means to begin, though this is specifically when something just begins (and you're not doing the action of beginning something). For example, a "race begins." Just imagine that it's something your ma ま would have done for you. You know you're not doing it because it's something your ma took care of for you.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so that's good. You can start on the next item, now.

ex_1_jp: 何から始めるのがいいのか、分かりません。
ex_1_en: I don’t know what to start from.
ex_2_jp: むすめさん、四年生になったら、何かならい事を始めるの？
ex_2_en: Will your daughter start any extracurriculars when she reaches fourth grade?
ex_3_jp: 生地をフライパンに流し始める前に、材料を全て混ぜる必要があります。
ex_3_en: You need to mix all the ingredients together before you can start transferring the batter to the pans.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means begin and the vocabulary version means to begin. This version of "to begin" is when you do the action of beginning, not when something just begins. Think of it this way: who started something? Me め! Okay, so those aren't pronounced the same. But they're spelled the same, so give it a shot. Maybe imagine your name is May. Who started it? Me, May!
reading_story: The reading is kun'yomi, but this is the reading you learned with the kanji. So, throw that はじ in there and begin to read away.

ex_1_jp: でも、ろこつに不かいかんを表すのはよくないよ。
ex_1_en: But it’s not okay to express your discomfort so bluntly.
ex_2_jp: 国民はみんな、高がくのぜい金に不まんを表していますよ。
ex_2_en: All citizens are expressing some dissatisfaction with the high tax.
ex_3_jp: このアップルシナモンウィスキーがどれだけ美味しいかを言葉で表すことはできない。
ex_3_en: I can’t begin to express how good this apple cinnamon whiskey is.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means express so the verb vocab version is to express.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're trying not to say it directly, and trying to figure out how to express that you are a wuss (あらわす). Sorry, had to be expressed.
pitch_accent: アラワꜜス *** ヒョꜜース

ex_1_jp: むしさされって、見付けるととたんにかゆくなるよな。
ex_1_en: The moment you find a bug bite it makes you itchy, don't you think?
ex_2_jp: このぼう子は、コウイチのかつらを見付けるための手がかりになるかもしれません。
ex_2_en: This hat might help us find Koichi's wig.
ex_3_jp: 私は今朝、虹の端にあると言われている金の壺を見付けるために四時間以上も費やしました。
ex_3_en: I spent over four hours this morning trying to find the pot of gold that they say is at the end of the rainbow.
meaning_story: You know that 付ける means "to attach" and that 見 means "see." So, when you attach your seeing to something, it's like you're looking around trying to find something. When you find what you're looking for, imagine your eyeballs flying out and attaching to that item, then yelling "I FOUND IT!"
reading_story: The readings come from 見る and 付ける. If you use those readings, you'll be able to read this word too.

ex_1_jp: 子どもを助手せきに乗せるのはきけんです。
ex_1_en: It’s dangerous to let children ride in the passenger's seat.
ex_2_jp: 机に足を乗せるのは行ぎがわるいですよ。
ex_2_en: Putting your feet on a table is bad manners.
ex_3_jp: 男は、女性の自転車が完璧に壊れているのを見て、「町まで車に乗せてあげるよ」と言った。
ex_3_en: The man saw that the woman’s bicycle was completely destroyed so he offered to give her a ride back to town.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ride so this word has to do with riding. There's another word that's similar (乗る which means to ride). This particular one means to give a ride. Use the せ as a hint. The せ is a "sail" (せ) that you use on your boat to give someone a ride. How nice of you.
reading_story: The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be okay with this. Allow me to give you a ride to the next item to study.

ex_1_jp: あらきさんは、けしゴムを持っていますか？
ex_1_en: Do you have an eraser, Araki?
ex_2_jp: コウイチは、実はなんしきやきゅうしんぱん員のしかくを持っています...というのは実はうそです。
ex_2_en: Actually, Koichi has a license to be a soft baseball referee. ...actually, that's a lie.
ex_3_jp: 一等に当選したことを知った時、宝くじを持つ手の震えが止まらなかった。
ex_3_en: When I realized I won the grand prize, the hand I was holding the lottery ticket with couldn’t help but shake.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hold so the verb version is to hold. This word is for when you're carrying or holding something, simply.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi reading (check out that sexy hiragana), but that's the reading you learned with the kanji, so rejoice!

ex_1_jp: お肉には、しっかり火を通してください。
ex_1_en: Please heat the meat thoroughly.
ex_2_jp: きちんとすじを通すべきだよ。
ex_2_en: You guys should go through the proper channels.
ex_3_jp: 針に糸を通すのは難しい。
ex_3_en: Threading a needle is difficult.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that 通る means to pass, but this is a little different. You aren't the one passing, Sue (す) is. So you have to let Sue pass. That's why this means to let pass.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 通る. Switch the る for a す and you'll be all set!

ex_1_jp: すきなチームが負けたので、くやしいです。
ex_1_en: My favorite team lost, so I’m frustrated and heartbroken.
ex_2_jp: 食パンマンは、アンパンマンに、チェスでこてんぱんに負けました。
ex_2_en: Breadman was badly defeated in a chess game by Anpanman.
ex_3_jp: 「今夜は、どこで食事したい？」「あなたが決めてよ。私はじゃんけんに負けたんだから。」
ex_3_en: "Where do you want to eat tonight?" "It’s your call. I lost the rock-paper-scissors."
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lose so the verb vocab version means to lose.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You lose your tournament/soccer game/whatever (you decide something applicable to you). You're sad about this. Who's there to comfort you? Your Ma (ま). She's a nice lady.

ex_1_jp: 先ぱいを待たせるのはよくないよ。
ex_1_en: It’s not okay to keep your senpai waiting.
ex_2_jp: 一体何時まで待たせるつもりですか？
ex_2_en: How much longer will I have to wait?
ex_3_jp: お待たせしてすみません。いや〜バスにえらく長いこと待たされましてね。
ex_3_en: Sorry for making you wait so long. I had to wait for the bus for such a long time.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wait so this word has something to do with waiting. Use the たせ as a hint. Someone "tossed" a ball off into a ditch, and then they had to find it. They made you wait for them to get the ball too, even though it's a cheap piece of crap. Feel upset about this.
reading_story: The reading is kun'yomi, but you learned the kun'yomi reading with this kanji, meaning you can read it!

ex_1_jp: イメージトレーニングとじゅんびうんどうは欠かすな！
ex_1_en: Don’t forget to warm up with some visual training.
ex_2_jp: どの社いんもみんな、トーフグにとって欠かすことのできない社いんです。
ex_2_en: All workers are indispensable for Tofugu.
ex_3_jp: 私の生活に、携帯電話を欠かすことはできない。
ex_3_en: I cannot live without my cell phone.
meaning_story: Remember how 欠ける means "to lack?" Well this is a stronger version because you cuss (かす) at the end. So it means to miss. You're cussing because you aren't just lacking something, you completely missed it: I missed it?! Well $*&%!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: 玉ねぎとトマトと大こんが要ります。
ex_1_en: You need onions, tomatoes, and daikon.
ex_2_jp: ふくろは要りますか？
ex_2_en: Do you need any bags?
ex_3_jp: 要るものと要らないものをリストに書き出しなさい。
ex_3_en: Write out a list of things you do and don’t need.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means need and the verb vocab version is to need.
reading_story: Since the reading isn't like the one you learned, think about what you are going to need... like, what you're really going to need, more than anything. Then, think of an eagle, because you really need an eagle. You'll need to come up with the reason why you need an eagle though, so hopefully it's a good one.

ex_1_jp: これが、ロブさんがかりたいと言っていた道具です。
ex_1_en: This is the tool that you told me you wanted to borrow, Rob.
ex_2_jp: ドラえもんの道具の中で一番使ってみたい道具は何ですか。やっぱりどこでもドアですか？
ex_2_en: Out of all of Doraemon's tools, which one would you want to use the most? Obviously the Anywhere Door, right?
ex_3_jp: 昨日買った道具入れの中に、なんとベイブ・ルースのルーキーカードが一枚入っていたんだ！
ex_3_en: I bought a tool pouch yesterday that had a Babe Ruth rookie card hidden inside it.
meaning_story: The tools you use on the road of life are important to have. What is your most important tool?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: しけんを受ける人は、13:00までに大学の受付に来てください。
ex_1_en: If you’re taking the exam, please come to reception at the university by 13:00.
ex_2_jp: トーフグの言ばをまともに受ける必要はないよ。
ex_2_en: You don't have to take Tofugu's word as is.
ex_3_jp: 僕の手は他の人のよりも15倍も大きいけど、それでも野球ボールをうまく受けることができないんだ。
ex_3_en: Even though my hands are fifteen times larger than anyone else’s, I still can’t catch a baseball very well.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means receive and so the verb vocab version means to receive.
reading_story: The reading is kun'yomi, but that's the reading you "received" from the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 今日、としょかんに本を返しに行かなくちゃいけないんです。
ex_1_en: Today I have to go to the library to take back a book.
ex_2_jp: 返す言ばが見当たらないよ。
ex_2_en: I have nothing to say back to you.
ex_3_jp: 「昨日あげたクッキー返してくれない？」「えっ、吐きだせってこと？」
ex_3_en: "Could you return the cookies I gave you yesterday?" "Huh? You mean, I should throw them up?"
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return so the verb version means to return. This is more like "to return a thing" rather than returning home, which would be 帰る, a word you haven't seen yet (but will soon, I'm sure!).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to return the Car egg (かえ) you found on the side of the road. It will birth a little car, but it needs its mother. So, you try to figure out how to return it. Go ahead and think through that process in your mind. Also think about how weird a car egg would be.

ex_1_jp: バスに乗って、海へ行きました。
ex_1_en: I took a bus to go to the sea.
ex_2_jp: 東京・しな川方めん行きではなくて、上野・池ぶくろ方めん行きに乗ってください。
ex_2_en: Make sure you take the train headed to Ueno and Ikebukuro and not Tokyo and Shinagawa.
ex_3_jp: ジェットコースターに乗るのは大好きなんだけど、どの席もいつもゲロ臭いんだよね。
ex_3_en: I love to ride on roller coasters but they always smell like vomit.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ride so the verb vocab version means to ride.
reading_story: The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji. Enjoy the ride!

ex_1_jp: スミスさんに手紙を送りました。
ex_1_en: I sent a letter to Mr. Smith.
ex_2_jp: 後で写しんLINEで送るね。
ex_2_en: I'll send you the photos later on LINE.
ex_3_jp: 遅くなったね。今日はここまでにしよう。家まで送るよ。
ex_3_en: It’s getting late. Let’s call it a day. I’ll walk you home.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means send so the vocab verb version is to send.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to send an entire oak (おく) tree in the mail, but it's too big. Imagine yourself dragging one to the post office. They tell you that you can't send that here... Go to the oak sending facilities.

ex_1_jp: ここで泳いではいけません。
ex_1_en: Do not swim here.
ex_2_jp: あんた、目が泳いでるよ。
ex_2_en: Hey, your eyes are shifty.
ex_3_jp: 私はベッドの上にある見えないプールで泳いで運動しているんです。
ex_3_en: I exercise by swimming in an invisible pool on my bed.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means swim so the verb vocab version is to swim.
reading_story: The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana sticking out?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 友だちのじしょを使いたいです。
ex_1_en: I want to use my friend’s dictionary.
ex_2_jp: いたいのはとても苦手なので、ますいを使ってください。
ex_2_en: I'm not good with pain, so please use anesthetics.
ex_3_jp: そんなに屁っ放り腰にならないで！知ってる日本語をできるだけ使うようにしなよ。
ex_3_en: Don’t be afraid of that. You should use the Japanese you know as much as possible.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means use so the verb version is to use.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Mr. Tsukalos (つか), the famous Ancient Alien theorist, is always trying to use "aliens" to explain everything. Go read more about him to help you with this mnemonic.

part_of_speech: INTRANSITIVE VERB, TRANSITIVE VERB, AND GODAN VERB
ex_1_jp: きっ茶店で、五時間待っていましたが、かれは来ませんでした。
ex_1_en: I was waiting for five hours at the cafe, but he didn’t come.
ex_2_jp: スタバで待ってますね。
ex_2_en: I'll be waiting for you at Starbucks.
ex_3_jp: ちょっと待って！財布を家に忘れたかも。
ex_3_en: Wait! I might have forgotten my wallet at home.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wait so the verb version is to wait.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi reading (check out that hiragana sticking out!) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji. Throw that into this word and you'll be able to read it.

ex_1_jp: サッカーのし合では、1対0で勝つことができました。
ex_1_en: At the soccer game, we managed to win 1-0.
ex_2_jp: 四つの時に、し合には勝ったが勝ぶに負けた。
ex_2_en: When I was four, I won the match but I felt like I lost anyway.
ex_3_jp: 明日のドッグ・レースにペットのウサギの参加を申し込むつもりなんだけど、確実に勝てると思うんだよね。
ex_3_en: I’m entering my pet rabbit in tomorrow’s dog race and I guarantee it's going to win.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means win so the verb version is to win.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What did you just win? You won a new car (か)!

ex_1_jp: コウイチのフラダンスの実力は本物です。
ex_1_en: Koichi's hula dancing abilities are genuine.
ex_2_jp: ビエトが本気の実力を出した所を見た人はまだだれもいません。
ex_2_en: There is no one who has witnessed Viet's true power yet.
ex_3_jp: 運も実力のうちってよく言うだろ。
ex_3_en: They usually say, "luck is what you make of it."
meaning_story: The truth behind someone's strength is their true strength. It is also their true ability.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 事実かもしれないけど、なっとくはできないな。
ex_1_en: That may be true, but I'm still not convinced.
ex_2_jp: あのせいじ家の言っていることは、事実に反します。
ex_2_en: What that politician has been saying contradicts the facts.
ex_3_jp: 口髭を生やした男が気味悪く見えるのは、科学的な事実です。
ex_3_en: It is a scientific fact that a man with a mustache looks creepy.
meaning_story: The action of truth is just truth itself, though it's also facts and reality as well. Really, it's the idea of "truth" in a way.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 実は、わたし、こうみえてもオリンピックに出たことがあるんです。
ex_1_en: Well actually, even though I don’t look like it, I used to be an Olympian.
ex_2_jp: 実のところ、おれたちはお前の実のおやじゃないんだよ。
ex_2_en: To tell you the truth, we are not your real parents.
ex_3_jp: すまない、お前。実は、俺達の貯金を全部、プロ野球カードと風船ガムにはたいちまったんだ。
ex_3_en: I’m sorry, Honey. The truth is I spent all of our savings on baseball cards and bubblegum.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the on'yomi reading, same like you learned with the kanji. That is the truth, I promise.

ex_1_jp: 乗り物の中でタバコをすわないでください。
ex_1_en: Please don’t smoke in vehicles.
ex_2_jp: 乗り物よいしちゃった。
ex_2_en: I got motion sickness.
ex_3_jp: 「あの乗り物、どうだった？」「ああ、怖かったさ！小便チビっちゃうくらい怖かったぜ。」
ex_3_en: "How was the ride?" "Oh, it was terrifying! I spent the whole time trying not to pee my pants."
meaning_story: You know that 乗り has something to do with riding and that 物 is a thing. So what is a "riding thing?" Nowadays, at least, that would be a vehicle.
reading_story: The readings are kun'yomi, but those are the readings you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read this one.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あんなに弱虫でなき虫だったむす子も、もう一人前の大人です。
ex_1_en: My son, who was such a weakling and a crybaby, is already an adult.
ex_2_jp: 多くのアメリカ人はなっとうごときが食べられない弱虫です。
ex_2_en: Many Americans are cowards who can't even eat a bit of natto.
ex_3_jp: 弱虫毛虫は、挟んで捨てろ！
ex_3_en: Cowards should be treated like hairy caterpillars - picked up and thrown out!
meaning_story: A weak insect. This is what people call weaklings in Japan. This is a good word to know if you're a bully, or something.
reading_story: The reading for this one is a weird one. It uses the kun'yomi readings for both, meaning you'll have to pull your knowledge of the word 弱い from earlier and apply it here. 虫 should be okay, though, as this is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just remember, only weak bugs use kun'yomi, and that weak bug is you in this instance.

ex_1_jp: なんか、弱々しいうたごえだったから、ちょっと心ぱいになっちゃった。
ex_1_en: I was starting to worry about you because you had such a weak singing voice.
ex_2_jp: むかしは強く見えた父が年とともにだんだん弱々しく見えてきました。
ex_2_en: My father, who used to look strong, gradually began looking weaker year after year.
ex_3_jp: その弱々しい患者は河豚の毒で苦しんでいた。
ex_3_en: That weak looking patient is suffering from puffer fish toxins.
meaning_story: Something that is double weak is probably pretty weak. You also know that this is an adjective because it ends with い. You know that 弱い is weak, so it probably isn't that. Instead, this one is weak looking or frail. If you know the grammar らしい you can kind of use that as a hint. The しい on the end reminds me of らしい which is like "seems to be." So, "seems to be weak" = "weak looking."
reading_story: The reading is double kun'yomi, as you can probably guess due to all the hiragana involved. So, you double up on よわ and then add the しい to read this vocabulary word.

ex_1_jp: 勝者だけが次のステージにすすめます。
ex_1_en: Only the winner will advance to the next stage.
ex_2_jp: せんそうに勝者はいないのですから、どうかそんなむいみなたたかいは止めてください。
ex_2_en: There are no winners in wars, so please stop such a meaningless fight.
ex_3_jp: ビエトは、72時間耐久スクラブルゲームの勝者となった。
ex_3_en: Viet emerged the victor in the 72 hour Scrabble game.
meaning_story: Someone who wins is the winner / victor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 2014年に、トーフグ学院をそつぎょうしました。
ex_1_en: I graduated from Tofugu Academy in 2014.
ex_2_jp: かん西学院大学の多くの学生はざい学中にりゅう学をけいけんします。
ex_2_en: Many students from Kwansei Gakuin University get to study abroad while at college.
ex_3_jp: やあ！こいつはワニカニ。あだ名はクラビゲーターだよ。トーフグ工業学院で働いてるんだ。
ex_3_en: Hey! This guy is WaniKani, a.k.a. the Crabigator. He works for Tofugu Institute for Industrial Education.
meaning_story: A study institution is an academy. That's where all the fancy people study, anyways.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 知り合いにたのんで、トーフグのコウイチからサインをもらいました。
ex_1_en: I asked an acquaintance if they could get me Koichi’s autograph from Tofugu.
ex_2_jp: 今知り合いにれんあい相だんしてるから、カラオケには行けないかも。ごめんね！
ex_2_en: I’m consulting my acquaintance about my relationship with my boyfriend right now, so I probably won’t be able to join the karaoke party. Sorry!
ex_3_jp: ここだけの話なんだけど、上司が知り合いの人妻と浮気しているのよね。
ex_3_en: Don’t tell a soul but my boss is having an affair with a married woman who is an acquaintance of mine.
meaning_story: You've probably seen the word 知る and 合う by now. This is something that "suits" your "know." Think of this word as someone who you know enough to suit your memory of them (you know them, but you don't really know them. This person is an acquaintance.
reading_story: The readings are that of 知る and 合う. So long as you know those words, you should be able to read this one too.

ex_1_jp: わたしは足し算ができない。
ex_1_en: I can’t do addition.
ex_2_jp: その足し算コンテストに、かん客としてさんかすることはできますか？
ex_2_en: Can I participate in the addition contest as a spectator?
ex_3_jp: 今日、学校で足し算の勉強をしました。
ex_3_en: Today we studied addition in school.
meaning_story: Remember how 足す means "to add?" Add calculate to that and you'll have addition! It's the type of calculation you're doing when you add.
reading_story: This is the kun'yomi reading for 足 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

ex_1_jp: げんざい、六つのプロジェクトが進行中です。
ex_1_en: Six projects are currently progressing.
ex_2_jp: おいしゃさんに、進行がんがあると言われました。
ex_2_en: The doctor told me that I have advanced cancer.
ex_3_jp: フグエキスから作られた新しい薬がその病気の進行を抑えた。
ex_3_en: The new drug made from Fugu extract has suppressed the progression of the disease.
meaning_story: When something advances and goes, it is moving forward. If you do this you will advance. You will progress.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: わたしたちは、さく年、む人とうで農業を始めました。
ex_1_en: We started farming the deserted island last year.
ex_2_jp: 最近日本では、農業にきょうみのあるわか者がふえています。
ex_2_en: In Japan, there have been more young people who are interested in agriculture recently.
ex_3_jp: 僕は今はセックスにあまり興味が無いんだよ。しばらくはただ農業に集中したいんだよね。
ex_3_en: I’m not interested in sex right now. I just really want to focus on agriculture.
meaning_story: What's another way to call the farming business? If you encapsulated it into one word (assuming we're talking about plant farming, here), you could call it agriculture.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: うちのお店は、ウェスタン通りから、少し路地に入ったところにあります。
ex_1_en: Our store is in a small alley off of Western Street.
ex_2_jp: その路地は、夜は少しきけんだから気を付けてね。
ex_2_en: That path is a bit sketchy at night, so be careful.
ex_3_jp: 警察官は、路地まで苺泥棒を追いかけた。
ex_3_en: The policeman chased the mugger who stole the strawberries down the alley.
meaning_story: If you think about it, an earth road isn't going to be the main road. It will be the road less traveled. You could call it a path (you know, like a dirt path!). Alternatively, another less traveled street that would probably be made out of dirt back in the day (before everything was paved) would be an alley. Imagine yourself walking down a dirt alley at night with no shoes. Scary!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've learned these readings already, so you should be able to read this word too! And remember, that it's the じ reading that you learned with 生地 here.

ex_1_jp: 明日の算数のじゅぎょう、定ぎと分度きわすれずにね！
ex_1_en: Don’t forget a ruler and a protractor for math class tomorrow.
ex_2_jp: 立ち入ったことをお聞きしますが、よみ・かき・算数、どれが一番とくいですか？
ex_2_en: I need to ask you a personal question. Between reading, writing and arithmetic, which one are you the best at?
ex_3_jp: 「連絡するのに時間がかかっちゃってごめんなさい。最近、仕事で忙しかったものだから。」「君の仕事って何だっけ？」「小学校の算数の先生よ。」
ex_3_en: "I’m sorry it took me so long to get back to you. I’ve been tied up with work." "What was your job again?" "I’m a math teacher at an elementary school."
meaning_story: What is it called when you calculate numbers? That is the study of math and arithmetic.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 早速使わせていただきました。
ex_1_en: I used it immediately.
ex_2_jp: 早速のごへんしん、ありがとうございます。
ex_2_en: Thank you for your immediate response.
ex_3_jp: 私はその茄子を早速彼に送ります。
ex_3_en: I will send the eggplants to him at once.
meaning_story: Doing something both fast and early probably requires you to do it at once or immediately. Whatever it is, be sure to do it without delay.
reading_story: The reading for this one is strange. The reading for 速 (そく) is what you'd expect (on'yomi), but 早 gets a reading you haven't seen before, meaning you should treat this as an exception. Just think about how you're learning this word at once and without delay so there's no time for any sass (さっ), just kanji learning.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: かれが元気がないのはめずらしいので心配です。
ex_1_en: I’m worried because it’s unusual for him to be so down.
ex_2_jp: この船の進行方向が西なのか東なのか心配になった。
ex_2_en: I got worried about whether the ship was heading east or west.
ex_3_jp: 心配しないで。すべて上手くいくよ。私の言うことを信じて。
ex_3_en: Don’t worry, everything is going to be fine. You can believe what I say.
meaning_story: When you distribute your heart around you, it's like your heart is everywhere at once, but not in your body. You feel frantic, you don't know what to do because your heart is out there. This represents the feeling you have when you have a worry or concern. 心配しないでね！
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the ぱい in 配 got rendaku'd from はい, as well.

ex_1_jp: わたしは自転車で会社に行っています。
ex_1_en: I go to work by bike.
ex_2_jp: 自転車を買ってあげるよ。お返しは要らないからね！
ex_2_en: I'll buy you a new bicycle, no strings attached.
ex_3_jp: 「ごめん。てっきり君が僕の自転車を壊したのかと思ってたよ。」 「何それ！ひどい。私がそんなことするはずないでしょ。」
ex_3_en: "I’m sorry. I thought for sure you were the one who broke my bike." "What? That’s awful. You know me better than that."
meaning_story: A self revolving car. You'd think this would be a regular car, but bicycles were probably introduced before cars were, meaning the self revolving car is the bicycle, not the car. Just imagine yourself on a bike, and you don't even have to move the pedals. They revolve themselves, but now you're going too fast and it's scary.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ジテꜜンシャ *** ジテンシャ

ex_1_jp: かれは千葉けん人です。
ex_1_en: He’s from Chiba.
ex_2_jp: わたしの母は、千葉県さんの落花生が大すきです。
ex_2_en: My mom loves peanuts made in Chiba.
ex_3_jp: ここから千葉までだと、片道1時間30分から2時間はぐらいかかりますね。
ex_3_en: It usually takes an hour and a half to two hours for a one way trip from here to Chiba.
meaning_story: There is only one place in Japan that has a thousand leaves and that's Chiba. Picture all of those leaves swirling around you on your vacation to Chiba. Beautiful.
reading_story: This is a place name and it uses the kun'yomi. You haven't learned kun'yomi for 千 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: While you're admiring all of the leaves in Chiba, you realize you're craving something. What goes well with watching leaves? Why, cheese (ち) of course. Delicious Chiba cheese.

ex_1_jp: ま、親友には反対されたんですけどね。
ex_1_en: Well, I was objected to by a close friend.
ex_2_jp: コウイチとビエトは親友で、友だち以上、こい人未まんのかんけいです。
ex_2_en: Koichi and Viet are good friends. They are more than friends, but not lovers.
ex_3_jp: 「ねぇ、知ってる？サラがベスと付き合ってるのよ。」「え、知らなかった。サラのこと親友だと思ってたけど、私そのこと何も聞いてないわ。」
ex_3_en: "Hey, you know what? Sara is going out with Beth." "What? I didn’t know that. I thought she was my best friend but she never told me about that."
meaning_story: A friend who is like one of your parents is someone who will look out for you. They are like family, in fact! That's why this word means best friend or close friend. Just imagine someone who watches over you like a parent would. This is the way to describe them.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: みんなから集金して、花たばと色紙を買いました。
ex_1_en: We collected money from everyone and bought a bunch of flowers and a message board.
ex_2_jp: 集金のことはもう心配するなよ。なるようになるさ。
ex_2_en: Don't worry about collecting money anymore. What will be, will be.
ex_3_jp: やらなければならない仕事が山のようにあるよ。とりあえず、お客さんから集金することから始めようかな。
ex_3_en: I’ve got tons of work I have to catch up on. Anyway, maybe I should start collecting money from my clients.
meaning_story: When you collect gold you are collecting money (or doing money collection). Of course, back in the day gold was like money, which is why this word works the way it does. Hopefully you don't have to deal with too much 集金 in your daily life. We'll try to keep WaniKani nice and reasonably priced for you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 会ぎに集中しすぎて終電をのがしてしまいました。
ex_1_en: We were too concentrated on the meeting and we missed the last train.
ex_2_jp: 集中集中！気合いを入れろ！
ex_2_en: Concentrate! Focus! Give it your all!
ex_3_jp: もう！まとわりつくのは止めてよ！集中できないでしょ。
ex_3_en: Hey! Stop breathing down my neck. I can’t concentrate.
meaning_story: When you collect to the middle of yourself, you are collecting towards your brain. All energy is going towards there, massing up in the middle, giving you extreme concentration abilities. Just imagine a light in the middle of your brain, so concentrated that you're able to concentrate, shooting a little laser out of your forehead onto the thing you're concentrating on.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この調子でがんばるぞ！
ex_1_en: I’ll keep doing my best!
ex_2_jp: 最近、トーフグの調子はどう？
ex_2_en: How's Tofugu doing lately?
ex_3_jp: あの男はみんなに調子のいいことばかり言うから嫌いよ。
ex_3_en: I hate that guy because he only says things that flatter the listener.
meaning_story: Imagine yourself investigating a child. You heard this child was having a rough time, so you need to come check on the condition of his home and life. You find the condition to be terrible, and you tell the parents you have to take the child away because of these conditions (imagine them being ridiculously bad... perhaps they raise raccoons in their kitchen?).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このドレスは、曲線を美しく出してくれます。
ex_1_en: This dress gives me beautiful curves.
ex_2_jp: ブーメランパンツから出てるコウイチのおしりの曲線…いいね！
ex_2_en: The curve of Koichi's butt protruding from the speedo is very... nice!
ex_3_jp: あなたが怒った時の、ほおの柔らかく歪んだ曲線が好きよ。
ex_3_en: I really love the soft, slanted curve of your cheek when you get mad.
meaning_story: A bend in a line is merely a curve.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 開発チームがみなさんのごしつもんにお答えします。
ex_1_en: The development team will answer everyone’s questions.
ex_2_jp: トーフグの開発ひ話を教えてください。
ex_2_en: Please tell us about the story behind Tofugu's development.
ex_3_jp: コウイチは新しい日本語学習サイトを開発するために徹夜をした。
ex_3_en: Koichi pulled an all-nighter to develop a new Japanese learning site.
meaning_story: You are now open for departure. You get on your boat and leave this place. You are going to another place to start its development where you will create a new world.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: メニエール病をわずらっているので、よくめまいが起きるんです。
ex_1_en: I suffer from Ménière’s disease, so I often get dizzy when I get up.
ex_2_jp: ぼくがワニカニレベル1から全ぜん進めないのはきっと外国語できない病にかかったからにちがいない。
ex_2_en: The reason I haven't been able to get further than Level 1 on WaniKani must be because I have "can't-learn-foreign-language" syndrome.
ex_3_jp: 彼の言ったことを大袈裟に考えないで。難病で苦しんでるなんて明らかに嘘なんだから。
ex_3_en: Don’t make a big deal out of what he said. It’s definitely a lie that he’s suffering from an incurable disease.
meaning_story: As you can probably imagine, when you add the kanji sick to another word, you're saying what kind of sickness it is; you are mentioning what disease it is.
reading_story: Since this is attached to other words, it's treated like jukugo and gets on'yomi treatment. This is the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 東きゅう電鉄によりますと、東きゅう東よこ線は人身じこのえいきょうで、げんざい運転を見合わせています。
ex_1_en: According to the Tokyu Corporation, the Tokyu Toyoko line has currently suspended operations due to an accident involving personal injury.
ex_2_jp: 電鉄会社ではたらくのがゆめです。
ex_2_en: My dream is to work for an electric railroad company.
ex_3_jp: 「はい、どうぞ。あなたが好きな阪急電鉄の写真よ。」「うわぁ！やったぁ！俺の大好きな阪急電鉄じゃん！」
ex_3_en: "Here you are, dear. Some of those Hankyu Railway pictures you like." "Oh wow, I absolutely love the Hankyu Railway!"
meaning_story: The electricity iron sounds scary, but if you think to back in the day and to where iron was used a lot, you probably think of the railway systems... big hunky pieces of iron on the ground to make the railway. So, you can advance this by adding electricity instead of coal, creating an electric railway.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの記事は超ドきゅうにおも白くて役に立つことを強調しておきたい。
ex_1_en: I'd like to emphasize that Tofugu articles are super high quality, interesting, and helpful.
ex_2_jp: 大事な用語は、けい光ペンで強調するとおぼえやすいよ。
ex_2_en: Highlighting important words with a highlighter helps you memorize them.
ex_3_jp: この仕事では身支度をきちんとしていることと礼儀正しいことが重要になることを改めて強調させて頂きます。
ex_3_en: I’d just like to stress again that dressing neatly and being polite are very important for this job.
meaning_story: If you use a strong tone on certain words, then you are putting emphasis on whatever it is you're talking about it. It's the stress you put on things that are important because your tone gets stronger on those words or syllables.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 大さか公えん1日目終了しました！
ex_1_en: The first day of the Osaka performance has ended!
ex_2_jp: 主人公が死んでゲームが終了してしまいました。
ex_2_en: The main character died and the game was over.
ex_3_jp: 「もし私がまたデブになったらどうする？」 「まぁ、俺達の関係が終了しないのは確実だね。」
ex_3_en: "What if I got fat again? " "Well, our relationship wouldn’t end, that’s for sure."
meaning_story: It's the end. It's the finish. This word means end. Or finish! How convenient.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日に日に進化してるのが実かんできて、うれしいです。
ex_1_en: I’m glad I’m able to recognize how much I progress every day.
ex_2_jp: みなさんのおかげで、トーフグは大きな進化をとげることができました。
ex_2_en: Thanks to you all, Tofugu made such tremendous progress.
ex_3_jp: おい、お前って本当に阿呆だな。ダーウィンの進化論はディズニー映画のタイトルなんかじゃねえよ。
ex_3_en: Jeez, you’re really dumb. Darwin’s theory of evolution is not the title of a Disney movie.
meaning_story: Think of things that advance and change. Does this sound familiar? Does this sound like evolution?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このころのたえ子ちゃんは、まだ顔付きが子どもっぽいね。
ex_1_en: Taeko still looked like a kid back then.
ex_2_jp: あのミニチュアハスキーは、とてもりりしい顔付きをしているね。
ex_2_en: That miniature Husky has such a gallant facial expression.
ex_3_jp: うわぁ、すっかり大きくなったね！顔付きはお父さんそっくりそのままだ。
ex_3_en: Boy, have you ever grown up, young man. You are the spitting image of your father.
meaning_story: The thing that is attached to your face isn't a big booger or anything like that. It's something that's always there. It's your expression.
reading_story: The readings are both kun'yomi, but they're the readings you've already learned when you learned the kanji.

ex_1_jp: きのう目がいたくなって、目医者に行ったら、ものもらいだった。
ex_1_en: My eye started hurting yesterday, I went to the eye doctor, and it was a sty.
ex_2_jp: 週末も開いている目医者をさがしています。
ex_2_en: I'm looking for an eye doctor who is open on weekends.
ex_3_jp: 「よお、目医者さん。もう何もかもばれているんだよ。だから、目について何も知らないふりをする必要はないぜ。」
ex_3_en: Listen, Mr. Eye Doctor. The cat's out of the bag, so there's no need to pretend you don’t know anything about eyes.
meaning_story: Do you remember 医者 (doctor)? What happens when you add eye on there? You have yourself an eye doctor.
reading_story: The reading is just the vocab word 医者 (いしゃ) plus the reading 目 (め), the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: きのう会ったりょ行会社の人の顔をもうわすれました。
ex_1_en: I already forgot the face of the travel agent I met yesterday.
ex_2_jp: コウイチって、顔がこいよね？
ex_2_en: Koichi has very defined facial features, don't you think?
ex_3_jp: 「おい、お前。何か文句でもあんのか？ジロジロ見てんじゃねぇぞコラ。」「えっと、あなたの顔、かなり青く見えるんですが、大丈夫ですか？」
ex_3_en: "Hey, buddy. Are you picking a fight with me? Why are you staring at me like that?" "Well, your face looks really pale. Are you okay?"
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is kun'yomi, since it's a kanji all alone with nothing attached. Luckily, that's also the reading you've already learned, so associate that with this vocab word.

ex_1_jp: 日よう日、小麦のしゅうかくを体けんしに、農場へ行ってきました。
ex_1_en: I went to a farm on Saturday to experience the wheat harvest.
ex_2_jp: 農場で、引きつづきはたらかないかと聞かれました。
ex_2_en: I was asked if I'd like to keep working at the farm.
ex_3_jp: オーガニック農場を始めるつもりです。
ex_3_en: I’m planning to start an organic farm.
meaning_story: The place you do your farming is a farm!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ノージョー *** ノージョꜜー

ex_1_jp: 新かん線はふつうの電車より速いです。
ex_1_en: The shinkansen is faster than a normal train.
ex_2_jp: ポートランドから東京まで、だれが一番速く泳げるかきょうそうしました。
ex_2_en: We had a competition to see who could swim from Portland to Tokyo the fastest.
ex_3_jp: うちの家族は、ご飯を食べるのがとても速いです。
ex_3_en: In my family, we eat dinner really fast.
meaning_story: Just like the meaning of the kanji (fast) this adjective also means fast.
reading_story: Remember how 早い means "early"? If you are early to something, it probably means you moved fast to get there. These two words share a reading (and have similar meanings, in a way, as well!).

ex_1_jp: このごうかな朝食を食べ終わって、一番目のかんそうは、やっぱりベーコンはおいしい、です。
ex_1_en: The first thing that comes to mind after finishing this wonderful breakfast is that bacon is delicious, as we all know.
ex_2_jp: 一番目のらんには、すきな人の名前をかいてください。
ex_2_en: Please write down the name of the person you like in the first column.
ex_3_jp: 「僕は毎朝一番目に、5キロのランニングをするんだぜ。」「大したことないよ！僕は10キロ走るよ。」
ex_3_en: "The first thing I do every morning is run five kilometers." "Big deal! I run ten!"
meaning_story: You've seen 一番 (number one), so what in the world is this eye on the end? This eye (目) signifies the order. So, add this to "number one" and you have the first thing / the first.
reading_story: The reading for this word is just the vocab word 一番 plus the word 目. If you know both of those readings you'll be able to read this one as well.
pitch_accent: イチバンメꜜ *** イチバンメ

ex_1_jp: げんざいの中国語では、たくさんの日本語が外来語として使われています。
ex_1_en: Many Japanese words are used as loanwords in modern day Chinese.
ex_2_jp: リュックサックは、外来語ですか？それとも和せいえい語ですか？
ex_2_en: Is rucksack a foreign word, or Engrish?
ex_3_jp: ねえ、煙草って外来語なのに漢字があるって知ってた？
ex_3_en: Hey, did you know that there's kanji for the word tobacco even though it’s a loanword?
meaning_story: You know the word 外来 to mean "imported." So, combine that with the kanji for language and you have an imported word, aka a borrowed word. There are a lot of these in Japanese, which makes this word important. Almost everything in katakana is a 外来語, in fact.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: ふらんすご, フランスご
ex_1_jp: わたしのむすめは、フランス語もえい語も話せます。
ex_1_en: My daughter can speak both French and English.
ex_2_jp: アフリカの多くの国では公用語にえい語とフランス語が使用されています。
ex_2_en: In many African countries, both English and French are used as their official languages.
ex_3_jp: フランス語の学習は僕には難しすぎるよ。もうたく山だ！勘弁してくれよ！
ex_3_en: Learning French is too difficult! I can’t take it anymore. Give me a break!
meaning_story: I bet you can guess that フランス means "France." So what happens when you add language to it? You get the "France Language" aka the French Language.
reading_story: The reading is just the on'yomi reading for 語 which is the reading you learned with the kanji. This is probably because it gets added onto a lot of other words so it's treated like a jukugo. For example: 日本語 = "Japanese Language." 中国語 = "Chinese Language." スペイン語 = "Spanish Language."

ex_1_jp: 青葉が目にしみるきせつとなりました。
ex_1_en: It's that time of year again when the leaves make my eyes burn.
ex_2_jp: 家のにわの青葉に虫がいっぱい付いてる！
ex_2_en: There are a lot of bugs on the young leaves in our garden!
ex_3_jp: お前の頭、ちょっと変なにおいがするぞ。 乾燥した青葉か何かみたいな。
ex_3_en: Your head smells a little weird. It’s like dried up leaves or something.
meaning_story: So there's this weird thing with Japanese people. Many things that most people would consider "green" are actually "blue" in their eyes. So, things like plants and street lights are "blue" even though you may think of them as green. Remember that for this word, where we talk about a blue leaf. In your head, though, think "green leaf." Now think of all things that have green leaves. This is greenery.
reading_story: The readings for the kanji in this word are the kun'yomi readings. Since you've already seen the word 青, hopefully you can just combine it with 葉 (you learned the reading for this part with the kanji). Be sure to pay attention to the rendaku, though. は goes to ば in this word, making it あおば.

ex_1_jp: 大学院をそつぎょうしたんだけど、仕事が見つからないんだ。
ex_1_en: I graduated from grad school, but I can’t find a job.
ex_2_jp: この大学院の自どうはん売きは、つめたい飲み物しか売っていません。
ex_2_en: You can only buy cold drinks from the vending machines at this grad school.
ex_3_jp: 私は大学院進学を考えております。
ex_3_en: I’m thinking about going to graduate school.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 大学 means "college?" Well the institution you go to after college is graduate school!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 頭をあらってあげましょう。
ex_1_en: I’ll wash your head.
ex_2_jp: ひるねをすると、いつも頭がすっきりします。
ex_2_en: Taking a nap usually refreshes my mind.
ex_3_jp: 頭が痛いので、喋らないでください。
ex_3_en: I have a headache so please stop talking.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji earlier. No problem!
pitch_accent: アタマꜜ *** アタꜜマ *** カシラꜜ *** カブリꜜ *** カꜜブリ *** カブリ *** コーベꜜ *** コーベ *** コꜜーベ *** ズ *** ツムリꜜ

ex_1_jp: 病院までタクシーで、千円ぐらいです。
ex_1_en: It takes about a thousand yen to get to the hospital by taxi.
ex_2_jp: この病院の院長は、九九もできない。
ex_2_en: The head of this hospital can't even do his multiplication tables.
ex_3_jp: この病院で医者をすることには本当に嫌気が差すね。患者は馬鹿ばっかりなんだ。
ex_3_en: I hate being a doctor in this hospital. The patients are all idiots.
meaning_story: A sick institution is a place where sick people go. That is a hospital.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 病じょうがあっ化し、入院する事になりました。
ex_1_en: His condition deteriorated and they decided he's to be hospitalized.
ex_2_jp: 入院中は、たいくつであくびが止まらなかったよ。
ex_2_en: While I was hospitalized, I was so bored that I couldn't stop yawning.
ex_3_jp: 今度、乳癌で入院することになったんです。
ex_3_en: I'm going to be hospitalized due to breast cancer soon.
meaning_story: If you end up in a situation where you have to enter an institution it's called hospitalization. Hopefully you aren't there for very long.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日本では工業が発たつしています。
ex_1_en: Japan has an advanced industry.
ex_2_jp: 工業デザイナーの中山さんは、ワニカニをストレス発さんに使っています。
ex_2_en: The industrial designer, Mr. Nakayama, uses Wanikani for stress relief.
ex_3_jp: 「工業技術プロジェクトの進み具合はどう？」「今のところは順調だよ。」
ex_3_en: "How is your industrial technology project going? " "So far, so good."
meaning_story: The business of industry is... well... industry.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: まだ親しい友人にしか話してないの。
ex_1_en: I've only told this to close friends.
ex_2_jp: 「親しき仲にも礼ぎあり」って言うでしょ？いくら親しいからってトイレはのぞかないで！
ex_2_en: They say, "A hedge between keeps friendship green," right? We're good friends, but don't peek at me when I'm on the toilet.
ex_3_jp: ちょっと、コウイチ。落ち着いてよ。 親しい友人たちに誰か80セント貸してあげれる人がいないか聞いてみてあげるから。
ex_3_en: Oh Koichi. Calm down. I’ll ask my close friends if anyone can lend you the 80 cents.
meaning_story: Your parents are very close to you, most likely. They are your closest relatives. They are the ones who are intimate and friendly with your affairs. They want to know everything!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Those who are most intimate with you hang out with you even when you're doing gross things, like sitting on the sh*tter (した). Gross, your family is.
pitch_accent: シタシꜜイ *** チカシꜜイ

ex_1_jp: いいですか。英語じゃなくて日本語ですよ。
ex_1_en: Okay? Not English, Japanese.
ex_2_jp: 今ワニカニを買うと、もれなく日本語でかかれたトーフグのサインが付いてきますよ。
ex_2_en: If you subscribe to Wanikani right now, it will come with Tofugu's autograph in Japanese.
ex_3_jp: 間違うことを恐れるなよ。日本語で喋ってみろって。やってみろよ。君ならできると思うよ。
ex_3_en: Don’t be afraid of making mistakes. Speak in Japanese. Give it a shot. I think you can do it.
meaning_story: You know 日本 is "Japan." So, when you add language onto the end of that you have Japanese language.
reading_story: The reading is just the vocab word 日本 (にほん) plus the reading that you learned for 語. Combine them together to get the reading for this word.
pitch_accent: ニッポンコ° *** ニホンコ°

pronunciation: にほんしゅ, にっぽんしゅ
ex_1_jp: 日本酒はあまりすきではないんです。
ex_1_en: I don’t really like Japanese alcohol.
ex_2_jp: その日本酒のボトルから、値札を外してもらってもいいですか？
ex_2_en: Could you remove the price tag from the Japanese sake bottle for me?
ex_3_jp: 「何飲んでるの？」「日本酒だよ。一口飲んでみる？」「それじゃ、お言葉に甘えて一口もらってみようかな。」
ex_3_en: "What are you drinking?" "Japanese rice wine. Would you like a sip?" "Well, I suppose I’ll give it a try."
meaning_story: You know that 日本 is "Japan" so when you add alcohol onto the end of that you have Japanese Style Alcohol (what's the big Japanese style alcohol that everyone knows? That's sake).
reading_story: The reading is just the vocab 日本's reading plus the reading you learned for 酒, put together.

ex_1_jp: わたしは漢字をかくのが下手です。
ex_1_en: I’m bad at writing kanji.
ex_2_jp: わたしの名前の漢字には、ウィスコンシン州でくらせますように、といういみが込められています。
ex_2_en: The kanji for my name includes the meaning, "you may live in Wisconsin."
ex_3_jp: 「これ、君への誕生日プレゼントだよ。」「わあ！漢字のテキストじゃない！どうもありがとう。あなたのおかげで本当に幸せな気分になったわ。」
ex_3_en: "Here is a gift for your birthday." "Wow! A Kanji textbook! Thank you so much. You really made my day."
meaning_story: The Chinese letters... you're finally learning the word for them, the thing you've been studying this whole time for so long! This is kanji, your new best friend (they came from China, which is why they're Chinese letters).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: いつも親切にしていただいて、ありがとうございます。
ex_1_en: Thank you for always being kind.
ex_2_jp: トーフグのような親切な会社と出会ったのははじめてです。
ex_2_en: I've never seen a company as kind as Tofugu.
ex_3_jp: わぁ。すごい！なんてクリーミーなの。 信じられない。今まで食べた中で一番のチーズケーキだわ。 あなたってとても親切だから、きっと最後の一切れは私にくれちゃうわよね？でしょ？有難う、有難う！
ex_3_en: Wow. Oh my, it’s so creamy. Oh my gosh, this is the best cheesecake I have ever had. You are awfully kind to give me the last piece. Don’t you think? Thank you. Thank you.
meaning_story: When your parents cut you you'd think they are being mean... but they're not. They are bleeding all the bad blood out of you. They are truly being kind. Just think of how crazy it would be for your parents to cut you... then think about some kind of twist to make it so they are being kind instead.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 母は、台所でりょうりをしています。
ex_1_en: My mother is cooking in the kitchen.
ex_2_jp: マイケルの家の台所にはなっとうの空きばこが三百万八千九百十七こおいてあるんだって。
ex_2_en: I heard that in Michael's kitchen, there are 3,008,917 empty natto boxes.
ex_3_jp: 台所から焦げ臭い臭いがするよ。
ex_3_en: I smell something burning in the kitchen.
meaning_story: What place in your house has most of the machines in it? Your kitchen! Just think about it. Refrigerator, freezer, dishwasher, stove, microwave, WOW! That's so many. The kitchen definitely has the most machines.
reading_story: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 台 and the kun'yomi reading for 所. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too!

ex_1_jp: わたしは子どもの時、研究室ではたらくのがゆめでした。
ex_1_en: When I was a child, my dream was to work at a laboratory.
ex_2_jp: くどいようですが、山田さんのかつらについて話すのは、この研究室ではタブーですからね。
ex_2_en: Excuse me for repeating myself, but talking about Mr.Yamada's wig is a big no no in this study room, okay?
ex_3_jp: 蛙の解剖を始めるので、皆さんには研究室に移動して頂きたいと思います。
ex_3_en: I’d like everyone to move into the laboratory now so that we can start dissecting the frogs.
meaning_story: Remember how 研究 means “research?” Well the room where you do research is a laboratory!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今人気のプログラミング言語は何ですか？
ex_1_en: What are the popular programming languages right now?
ex_2_jp: 言語オタクたちが朝まで言語について語りつくすオフ会にさんかしてきました。
ex_2_en: I joined an offline gathering where language geeks got together and talk about language all night long.
ex_3_jp: 新しいコンピュータ言語の勉強を始めました。
ex_3_en: I started to study a new computer language.
meaning_story: When you say words in a language, you are speaking a language. Not sure what that language is, but since you're saying it it must be real.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 大すきなドラマの最終回を見のがして泣いた。
ex_1_en: I missed the last part of my favorite drama and cried.
ex_2_jp: 今乗ってきた電車が最終だったから、もうかえれないよ。
ex_2_en: The train we just took was the last one of the day, so we can't go back anymore.
ex_3_jp: これが我が社の最終提案です。後はあなたの決断次第です。
ex_3_en: This is our final offer. Now the ball is in your court.
meaning_story: The most end thing is the last thing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お前に金をやるのは、これが最後だ。
ex_1_en: This is the last time I give you money.
ex_2_jp: うちのつま、いつも最後に一言多いんですよね。
ex_2_en: My wife always ends up with one word too many.
ex_3_jp: とにかく、最後まで聞いてよ。そうすれば分かるから。
ex_3_en: At any rate, just listen until the end. Then you’ll understand.
meaning_story: The thing that is the most after everything else is at the very end. It is the last.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 電車でばくすいしてしまって、終点でうん転手さんに起こされたことはよくありますね。
ex_1_en: I often fall asleep on the train and have to be woken up by the driver at the last stop.
ex_2_jp: このシカゴ発のアムトラックの終点の駅は何て言う名前ですか。
ex_2_en: What's the name of the last stop on the Amtrak leaving from Chicago?
ex_3_jp: お願いがあるの。私がたとえ何と言っても、何をしようとも、終点に着くまで私が電車から降りないようにして。分かった？
ex_3_en: You have to do me a favor. No matter what I say, no matter what I do, please do not let me get out of the train until it gets to the last stop. Okay?
meaning_story: The end point is where everything ends... but for this example, think of a map with a route on it. The last spot on the route is the "last point." It is the last stop.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: きのうは風が強かったので、木から葉が全部落ちてしまいました。
ex_1_en: Yesterday, the wind was so strong that all the leaves fell off of the trees.
ex_2_jp: あきになって、木の葉の色が色んな色にかわってきた。
ex_2_en: In fall, the leaves on the trees had changed to different colors.
ex_3_jp: 大根の葉でふりかけを作りました。
ex_3_en: I made furikake with daikon leaves.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: このはこは、あのはこよりも軽い。
ex_1_en: This box is lighter than that one.
ex_2_jp: この毛ぬき、びっくりするぐらい軽いんだけど。
ex_2_en: This pair of tweezers is surprisingly light.
ex_3_jp: 毎日軽い朝ごはんを食べる。
ex_3_en: Every day I eat a light breakfast.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of lightweight? It's also lightweight.
reading_story: The reading you learned with the kanji is the reading you'll be using here. Because of that, this word is kind of a lightweight.

ex_1_jp: 分数をかく時にまん中に引く線の名前は、かつ線です。
ex_1_en: The line in the middle of a fraction is called the "vinculum."
ex_2_jp: しぶ谷で山手線に乗ってください。
ex_2_en: Please get on the Yamanote Line at Shibuya.
ex_3_jp: 本当にこの線が完璧だって思ったの？しかも、全然真っ直ぐじゃないじゃない！
ex_3_en: You really thought this line was perfect? It’s not even close to straight!
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This also works for "train lines" as well. You'll see this attached onto the ends of names describing them.
reading_story: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same for this vocab word. Enjoy it!

ex_1_jp: あなたに会うのが楽しみです。
ex_1_en: I’m looking forward to seeing you.
ex_2_jp: 夏休みの楽しみと言えば、海にキャンプに色々あると思いますよ。
ex_2_en: I think there are lots of different fun activities during summer break, like going to beach and camping and stuff.
ex_3_jp: 私達、みんな亀を燃やすのを楽しみにしているんだよね？
ex_3_en: We are all looking forward to burning turtles, aren’t we?
meaning_story: You've seen the word 楽しい, which means "fun." This is obviously very similar looking, though this one means looking forward to. Why? Because it has a み on the end, saying "who is going to have fun? It's me! That's why I'm looking forward to it!"
reading_story: The reading is just like 楽しい, so make sure you know that and you'll be able to read this one as well.
pitch_accent: タノシꜜミ *** タノシミꜜ *** タノシミ

ex_1_jp: 最近みょうに運がいいんだよな。
ex_1_en: I’ve been really lucky lately for some reason.
ex_2_jp: こんな美人のよめさんもらって、お前って本当に運がいいな。
ex_2_en: You are so lucky to have such a beautiful wife.
ex_3_jp: 日本語の授業でAが取れたんだけど、ただ単に運がよかっただけだと思うの。
ex_3_en: I got an A in Japanese, but I think I was just lucky.
meaning_story: The いい portion means "good." So, when what you carry is good you are lucky. Just think of it in terms of luck being a physical item you carry in your hands. Now imagine yourself carrying it. Now think to yourself "what I'm carrying is good, it's lucky!"
reading_story: The reading for the kanji in this vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: これは子ども向けの作ひんではないですよね。
ex_1_en: This work isn’t intended for children.
ex_2_jp: このカレーは、日本人向けのあじですね。
ex_2_en: This curry was made for Japanese tastes.
ex_3_jp: コウイチが履いてるパンツは、子供向けなんじゃないのか？ツンツルテンだよ。
ex_3_en: Aren’t the underpants Koichi is wearing for children? He’s outgrown his clothes.
meaning_story: You've hopefully seen 向く and 向ける by now. They mean "to face" and "to turn toward." This has a similar idea.
