When you add 向け to something imagine you're turning it, aiming it at someone. It's aimed at them, meaning it's made for them. Turn a book toward someone, now it's aimed at them, it's made for them. See the connection?
reading_story: The reading is the same as the word 向く so work off of that word to be able to read this one.

ex_1_jp: 近所の人はしずかですか？
ex_1_en: Are the neighbors quiet?
ex_2_jp: トーフグのオフィスの近所には、おしゃれなお店が多く集まっています。
ex_2_en: Many chic shops are gathering in the neighborhood of the Tofugu office.
ex_3_jp: 近所にコインランドリーがあるわよ。
ex_3_en: There is a laundromat in the neighborhood.
meaning_story: The place you live near is your neighborhood!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own as long as you remember the rendaku on しょ making it じょ.

ex_1_jp: 父は、毎朝新聞を読みます。
ex_1_en: My father reads the newspaper every morning.
ex_2_jp: 今朝の地元の新聞の一めんでトーフグとどーも君がコラボしていたよ。
ex_2_en: Tofugu and Domo-kun were collaborating on the front page of the local newspaper this morning.
ex_3_jp: この新聞すっげー専門用語だらけじゃん。スコットがこの新聞を何回も読まなきゃいけないのは当然だな。
ex_3_en: This newspaper is so highbrow. No wonder Scott had to read it so many times.
meaning_story: The new hear is what it sounds like. It's new things that you're hearing about in your ear... at least that's what it was back a long time ago. Now those new things that get to your ear get to you via other mediums. In this case, a newspaper.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: うちも、開業当時はしゃっ金だらけだったんだよ。
ex_1_en: We also had a ton of debt when we opened our business.
ex_2_jp: この目医者は、今年で開業して三十五年になります。
ex_2_en: As of this year, this eye doctor has been in practice for 35 years.
ex_3_jp: コウイチの開業準備を手伝うために、昨日は学校をサボったんだ。
ex_3_en: I blew off school yesterday to help Koichi prepare for the opening of his business.
meaning_story: This is one of those words that has kanji that basically tell you the meaning. You open a business... aka opening a business.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: どうがが公開されるのはいつですか？
ex_1_en: When will the video be released to the public?
ex_2_jp: Etoeto発売を記ねんして、コウイチの半生をドキュメンタリーにしたえいがが公開になりました。
ex_2_en: A documentary movie of half of Koichi's life has been open to the public to commemorate Etoeto's release.
ex_3_jp: 「この写真を公開したのは、写真より実物の花子がの方がずっと可愛いんだってことをみんなに教えたかったからだよ。」「あんたって本当口からでまかせばっかりよね！」
ex_3_en: "I only published that picture to show people that you look much better in person, Hanako." "That is such a lie!"
meaning_story: When something is public open it is open to the public. You can go look at things that are 公開.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: わたしの親は、先週病院の近くに引っこしました。
ex_1_en: My parents moved near the hospital last week.
ex_2_jp: うちの親、かほごすぎると思うんだよね。
ex_2_en: I think my parents are overprotective.
ex_3_jp: これって、すごく不公平だわ！ ミドリは私が欲しいものを全部手に入れて、その上私のパパとママが親じゃないだなんて！
ex_3_en: This is so unfair! Midori gets everything that I want. And, on top of that, she doesn’t have my mom and dad for parents.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Just imagine your parents saying oh yah (おや) over and over at you. What did you do at school today? I beat up this kid. "Oh yah?"

ex_1_jp: 大雪で、高速道路が通行止めになっているそうですよ。
ex_1_en: It looks like the highway is closed because of the heavy snow.
ex_2_jp: ミネソタ州は夏に道路工事ばかりしています。
ex_2_en: So many roads are under construction in Minnesota during the summer.
ex_3_jp: この町は本当につまらない。基本的に道路と家しかないし。あぁ〜もう！どこか楽しいところはないのかな？
ex_3_en: This town is really dull. There are basically only paved roads and houses. Ugh! Where can I get some action?
meaning_story: A road road is obviously the best kind of road. It's double road, after all. So, what is this ultimate road? It is a paved road.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: え戸時代の農民でも、全てがまずしかったわけではないはずだ。
ex_1_en: That doesn't mean all peasants in the Edo period were poor.
ex_2_jp: この村の農民たちは、クロールの泳ぎ方を知りたがっている。
ex_2_en: Farmers in this village want to know how to swim the forward crawl.
ex_3_jp: おぉ！あの農民の腹筋すげぇな。
ex_3_en: Wow! That farmer has some amazing abs.
meaning_story: The peoples who work in the farm are the farmers... the peasants.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「リキュール」には、「利休酒」という当て字が使われます。
ex_1_en: "利休酒" are the phonetic kanji used for "liqueur."
ex_2_jp: 近ごろは、当て字を使ったキラキラネームを持つ子どもがたくさんいます。
ex_2_en: Lately, there've been a lot of kids with bizarre names using phonetic kanji.
ex_3_jp: 時々、漢字は、亜米利加 (アメリカ)のようにそれぞれの意味を無視して、読み方だけで選ばれます。これらの漢字を当て字と言います。
ex_3_en: Sometimes kanji are selected solely for their sounds and the meaning is ignored as in 亜米利加 (アメリカ). These are called phonetic kanji.
meaning_story: 当て means something like to guess correctly. 字 means letter. So, this is a letter you guessed correctly. This refers to phonetic kanji, which are kanji that are used in words simply for their sounds, not for their meanings. They are there to be phonetic, and that is all. That is why this word refers to phonetic kanji.
reading_story: The readings are the on'yomi reading for 字 and the kun'yomi reading for 当て. You've seen 当てる in the past, though, so you should be able to read this portion as well. Combine the two together and you have yourself a nice reading.

ex_1_jp: 大雨で、線路わきの土しゃがくずれ、線路が土しゃでうまってしまっているもよう。
ex_1_en: It seems that the earth beside the train track collapsed from the heavy rain and covered the tracks.
ex_2_jp: だれかが線路に立ち入ったため、電車が止まってしまった。
ex_2_en: The train has stopped since somebody trespassed on the train tracks.
ex_3_jp: 「あぁ、ごめん。今はあんまりそういう気分じゃないんだ。」「あなた、どうしたの？」「実は、さっきそこの線路で男が飛び込み自殺をするのを目撃したんだ。」
ex_3_en: "Well, sorry. I’m not really in that kind of mood right now." "Honey, what’s going on? " "Well, I just saw a guy commit suicide on the railroad track over there."
meaning_story: A line that runs on a road is a railroad track. First you have to get into your mind that the "line" in question is a railway line. Then, what railway line runs on a road and what kind of road is it? It's a railroad track.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 楽ふの読み方を知らない。
ex_1_en: I can’t read sheet music.
ex_2_jp: 三だんらく目の七行目のこのたん語は、なんて読むんですか？
ex_2_en: How do you read this word in the 7th line of the 3rd paragraph?
ex_3_jp: あなたの名前の漢字の読み方を教えてください。
ex_3_en: How do you pronounce the kanji in your name?
meaning_story: You know that this has something to do with reading and you know that 方 means way or method. So, when you think of a "way of reading" you can think of a couple other better words, such as reading (aka the reading of a word) or pronunciation. Anytime you need to know how something sounds, this is what you'll ask for.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings, but they're the readings you've learned with the kanji. 方 is like many other words you've come across as well, such as 見方 or 作り方.
pitch_accent: ヨミカタꜜ *** ヨミカꜜタ

ex_1_jp: 女の人は、最近、どのぐらい本を読んでいますか。
ex_1_en: How many books has she read recently?
ex_2_jp: 最近のトレンドファッションにはもう付いていけません。
ex_2_en: I can't follow the latest fashion trends anymore.
ex_3_jp: 「ござる」という言葉は最近はあまり使われなくなったようだ。
ex_3_en: The term "Gozaru" doesn’t seem to be used as much lately.
meaning_story: The most nearby is something that happened close to now. It happened recently.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: けんきゅうしょ, けんきゅうじょ
ex_1_jp: とあるアメリカの研究所が、日本語がペラペラになるくすりを開発したそうだ。
ex_1_en: I heard that a certain American lab has made a pill that will make you fluent in Japanese.
ex_2_jp: 今日は、みそしる研究所で、ぼうさいくんれんがあります。
ex_2_en: There is an emergency drill in the Miso Soup Research Facility today.
ex_3_jp: 私はバーガーキング研究所で働いています。私の仕事は、フライドポテトを食べ、その後自分の体重を測ることです。
ex_3_en: I work for the Burger King Research Institute. My job consists of eating french fries and then having my body weighed.
meaning_story: You've seen that 研究 is research from previous vocab. So, a "place" that is a research place could be many things, though mainly a research institute or research laboratory.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know the reading of 研究 already. Also note that 所 is normal for one reading, but also gets the rendaku treatment, meaning しょ becomes じょ, for the secondary reading.
pitch_accent: ケンキュージョ *** ケンキュージョꜜ

ex_1_jp: ペットのハムスターがものすごいいきおいで回し車を回転させています。
ex_1_en: My pet hamster is vigorously rotating his hamster wheel.
ex_2_jp: あそこの回転ずし、もう行った？なんか、そこのすししょく人は皿がきらいらしく、すしが回転してあつくなってるコンベアベルトの上に直でおかれているらしいよ。
ex_2_en: Have you been to the conveyer belt sushi restaurant over there? Apparently their sushi chefs hate plates there, so the sushi is directly on the rotating, hot conveyor belt.
ex_3_jp: 月は地球の周り回転していて、地球は太陽の周りを回転している。
ex_3_en: The moon revolves around the earth and the earth revolves around the sun.
meaning_story: You revolve X number of times. Really, the times isn't so important, but the revolving is. That's why this word is revolve or rotate.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. P.S. Ever heard of "回転ずし?" That's the kind of sushi that's on conveyer belts, rotating around and around, bringing you delicious plates of things.

ex_1_jp: わたしはパーティーでお酒を飲んだ。
ex_1_en: I drank alcohol at the party.
ex_2_jp: 今、そのお酒はシーズンではないので、申しわけありませんがご用いできません。
ex_2_en: That sake is out of season now, so I'm afraid it's not available.
ex_3_jp: 「割り勘にしよう。」「いや。今日は俺の奢りだよ。しかも、俺はお酒をたくさん飲んだけど、お前は一滴も飲まなかったじゃないか。」
ex_3_en: "Let’s split the bill." "No, it’s on me this time. I drank a lot of alcohol, but you didn’t drink anything"
meaning_story: This is just the noun version of the kanji 酒 - it has an お there to be nice. This word can mean both alcohol (same like the parent kanji) or sake (the main kind of Japanese alcohol, at least back in the kanji days).
reading_story: The reading is kun'yomi, which isn't what you learned with the kanji. But, it should be pretty easy. You know what Japanese alcohol is called already, right? It's さけ, simple as that. So long as you've heard of sake you should be A-Okay with this reading.

ex_1_jp: わたしはスーパーで買い物をしています。
ex_1_en: I’m shopping at the grocery store.
ex_2_jp: 買い物はいつもネットショッピングですませています。
ex_2_en: As for shopping, I usually just do it online.
ex_3_jp: 今日はクリスマスの買い物に行くの！すごくワクワクするわ！
ex_3_en: We’re going Christmas shopping today! I’m so excited!
meaning_story: You've hopefully seen 買う by now and know it means "to buy." So, 買い is going to be similar to that. Add that to thing and you have a "buying things" sort of word. What does "buying things" describe? It describes shopping.
reading_story: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. Also, you can use the reading for 買う to help you with 買い as well. 物 is just もの, like you learned.

ex_1_jp: 上手な絵をも写する事は、上たつの近道です。
ex_1_en: Tracing a good picture is a shortcut for improvement.
ex_2_jp: ワニカニで漢字をおぼえることは、本当に日本語習とくの近道になると思いますか？
ex_2_en: Do you really think memorizing kanji on WaniKani is actually a shortcut to Japanese acquisition?
ex_3_jp: 「ありえねぇ！お前って本当脳みそ無いのな。なんで一方通行を逆走してるんだよ。」「近道になると思ったんだよ。」
ex_3_en: "Oh my God! You are such an airhead! Why are we going down a one-way street?" "I thought it would be a shortcut!"
meaning_story: Taking the nearby road will get you to your destination more quickly (because it's more close by!). This is a shortcut, aka the short way.
reading_story: The reading is a bit weird in this one. Its kun'yomi reading for both kanji, even though it looks just like it should be all on'yomi reading. It's like you're taking a shortcut with your kanji readings and doing the native Japanese readings (kun'yomi) instead of the more intellectual Chinese ones (on'yomi). Luckily, you've hopefully seen both of these kanji as vocab already. You have ちか for 近 (short for 近い) and you have 道 (みち), just like the word "street" you learned before. Combine these together and you have the reading for this word. Perhaps it's like this because you're combining a couple concepts together into one word, at least when it comes to "short + way."

ex_1_jp: 母の病気は、まだよくなりません。
ex_1_en: My mother’s illness still hasn’t improved.
ex_2_jp: おしりからおならが止まらない病気にかかってしまい、外に出られなくなってしまいました。
ex_2_en: I got a disease that makes me fart all the time, so I've haven't been able to go outside.
ex_3_jp: 「先生、僕のママの病気、直せるの？」「やってみるけど、当てにしないでね。」
ex_3_en: "Can you fix my mom’s illness, doctor?" "I’ll give it a try, but don’t count on it."
meaning_story: When your energy is that of sickness, you are probably sick.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: うつったらいやだから、病人には近よりたくない。
ex_1_en: If you don’t want to catch something, you shouldn’t go near sick people.
ex_2_jp: うらないしに、前世は病人だったと言われました。
ex_2_en: The fortuneteller told me that my previous life was as a sick person.
ex_3_jp: 「調子はどうだい？」「絶好調だよ。」「それは良かった。病人からその言葉を聞けるとは思ってもみなかったがな。」
ex_3_en: "How’s it going?" "Couldn’t be better." "Good. I’m surprised to hear that from a sick person though."
meaning_story: A person who is sick is a sick person. They are also a patient, at least we can hope they are, for their sake.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that this uses the にん reading for 人. This is because every sick person enjoys laying in bed playing nintendo.

ex_1_jp: きっ茶店の横に、食どうがあります。
ex_1_en: There is a diner next to the cafe.
ex_2_jp: もし強とうがトーフグのオフィスにやって来たら、コウイチのデスクまで走ってその横にしゃがみこむんだ。そこが最も安全な場所だからね。
ex_2_en: If a robber breaks into the Tofugu office, just run to Koichi's desk and crouch down next to it because it's the safest spot.
ex_3_jp: 午後の仮眠の間に横向きに寝る。
ex_3_en: During my afternoon nap I sleep on my side.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Please note that this word refers to "the side of something." Not "the right side," for example. That would be 右側.
reading_story: The reading for this vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, lucky you!

ex_1_jp: 歌手になったのは、母のえいきょうが大きいです。
ex_1_en: My mother had a large influence in my becoming a singer.
ex_2_jp: あの歌手、かなり日やけしたね。
ex_2_en: That singer got quite a tan, didn't she?
ex_3_jp: 子どもの頃は、歌手だったのよ。なんちゃってね。今でも歌手なんですけど。
ex_3_en: I used to be a singer when I was kid. Well, who am I kidding, I’m still a singer now.
meaning_story: Remember how 手 can sometimes refer to a person? In this case, we have a song person (or perhaps a "person who handles songs"). What is a song person also known as? A singer.
reading_story: The readings are on'yomi readings. Hopefully you've seen enough vocab that use 手 in its on'yomi form (しゅ) to know it by now, just via context. If so, this word's reading shouldn't be a problem. Just think of the singer putting a shoe (しゅ) in their mouth, being unable to do what they do best. Also, the shoe is full of cashews (かしゅ)?

ex_1_jp: でも、日本の歌はあまり知りません。
ex_1_en: But I don’t know Japanese songs very well.
ex_2_jp: これはたんなる歌じゃなく、ひみつのあん号でもあるんじゃないかという気がしています。
ex_2_en: It feels like this isn't just a song, but a secret code too.
ex_3_jp: 「ジェイソン！あんた、アマンダのために歌を作ったの？」「えーと、これはそういうのじゃないんだ。」「もう！とぼけないでよ。」
ex_3_en: "Jason! You made a song for Amanda?" "Ah, this isn’t what it looks like." "Come on! Don’t give me that."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think about a song... but not just any song... think about the utter (うた) song, and make it up right now and sing it out loud. What does the utter song sound like? Why do you love utterances so much that you made a song about them?

pronunciation: すぺいんご, スペインご
ex_1_jp: 明日はスペイン語の小テストだぜ！
ex_1_en: There’s a Spanish quiz tomorrow!
ex_2_jp: そのスペイン語のテキストは今売り切れているので、ご用いできません。
ex_2_en: That Spanish textbook is currently sold out, so it's not available.
ex_3_jp: ニンニクはスペイン語で「ajo」っていうんだけど、「アホ」って発音されるんだよ。「アホ」は日本語で「stupid」って意味だよ。
ex_3_en: Garlic in Spanish is "ajo," which is pronounced "aho." "Aho" means "stupid" in Japanese.
meaning_story: You can probably figure out that スペイン is "Spain" just by reading it. Add the kanji language on there and you have the Spanish language (or just Spanish), if you'd like.
reading_story: The reading for the kanji portion is just the reading you learned with the kanji. Since it's attached to something, it's like a jukugo word.

ex_1_jp: インターネットの速度がおそすぎてイライラしています。
ex_1_en: The internet speeds are too slow and it’s pissing me off.
ex_2_jp: もう少し速度をおとして走行してください。
ex_2_en: Please drive a little bit slower.
ex_3_jp: ドアを開けたら、冬の突風が物凄い速度で吹きこんできた。
ex_3_en: When I opened the door, a wintry gust rushed in with great speed and force.
meaning_story: The degree of fastness is a measurement of speed, plain and simple.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 夏には、テラスせきで立ち飲みもできます。
ex_1_en: In summer you can stand and drink on the terrace.
ex_2_jp: 東京の新ばしえき近辺には立ち飲み屋がたく山あります。
ex_2_en: There are a lot of stand-and-drink bars near Shinbashi Station in Tokyo.
ex_3_jp: 昨日、あの立ち飲み屋の後、誰かとやった？
ex_3_en: Did you get any action last night after leaving the standing bar?
meaning_story: The meaning is the same as the kanji. When you stand and drink, you're probably at a stand and drink place.
reading_story: The readings are from the words 立つ and 飲む put together.

ex_1_jp: このゲームは、明日はいしん開始です。
ex_1_en: This game will be released tomorrow.
ex_2_jp: Etoetoの先行予やく受付を開始しました。
ex_2_en: We've started accepting preorders for EtoEto.
ex_3_jp: 現在、Tofuguは枕業界で巻き返しを図っており、新しいモデルの枕の販売を開始した。
ex_3_en: Tofugu is currently still working to catch up in the pillow market, so they started selling new models.
meaning_story: The open of the start is the start or beginning.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You learned 開's reading, but you learned the kun'yomi vocab reading for 始. To remember this, just think that Charlie Sheen (し) is starting your race. "1, 2, 3, スタート!" WINNINGEST.

ex_1_jp: それから話を聞いて、もんだい用紙の１から４の中から、一番いいものを一つえらんでください。
ex_1_en: And then you will listen to the story and choose the best answer between 1-4 on the answer sheet.
ex_2_jp: 話がちがうよ！
ex_2_en: I didn't sign up for this!
ex_3_jp: 「それから、私、他にも言いたいことがあるのよ、ブリタニー！」「ジェレミー、いい加減黙ってくれないか！君の話はもう聞き飽きたよ。」
ex_3_en: "Now, I’d also like to say something else, Brittany!" "Jeremy! Give it a rest! I’m tired of listening to you."
meaning_story: The kanji version of 話 means talk. This word also means talk, but it means a few other things as well. This can refer to a speech or story as well. Basically anything that involves a session talking. So, before you go, I hope you stay awhile and listen to my 話.
reading_story: Who tells a great story? Hana, she (はなし) tells a great story! If you know someone named Hana or Hanna you can use that person to help you to remember this one better too. You can also use 話す's reading to help you to remember this one, as well.

ex_1_jp: うちの社長は、鉄人すぎます。
ex_1_en: My company president is way too much of a macho man.
ex_2_jp: わたしが一番すきな番組はりょうりの鉄人です。
ex_2_en: The TV program I like most is Iron Chef.
ex_3_jp: 私はスーパーで赤ちゃんに「いないいないばぁ」をしている鉄人を見た。
ex_3_en: I saw a tough guy playing peak-a-boo with a baby in a grocery store.
meaning_story: A man made of iron is a strong man... aka a huge badass. Have you seen "Iron Chef?" The Japanese translation is 料理の鉄人, which means "Chef Iron Man" aka "Chef Badass," at least in my book.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 主語をハッキリさせてくれないかな。
ex_1_en: Can you make the subject clear?
ex_2_jp: この主語を明かくにする新サービスは、本当に役に立つ。
ex_2_en: This new service that clarifies the subject is very useful.
ex_3_jp: 日本語は、主語ー目的語ー動詞の言語ですが、英語は主語ー動詞ー目的語の言語です。
ex_3_en: Japanese is a subject-object-verb language whereas English is a subject-verb-object language.
meaning_story: The master language isn't some sort of Aryan race thing. No, the master portion of a language is the most important part of a language (any language!). What is necessary for any language, more so than anything else? Knowing what you're talking about, and that's the subject.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もちろん、わたしは引き算ができます！
ex_1_en: Of course I can do subtraction!
ex_2_jp: この引き算のじゅぎょうは長すぎて、あくびが止まりません。
ex_2_en: Subtraction class is so long that I can't stop yawning.
ex_3_jp: 引き算を習うのは、小学校何年生ですか？
ex_3_en: What year of grade school will we learn subtraction?
meaning_story: Remember how 引く means "to subtract?" Add calculate to that and you'll have subtraction! It's the type of calculation you're doing when you subtract.
reading_story: This is the kun'yomi reading for 引 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

ex_1_jp: 地下鉄に乗って行きます。
ex_1_en: I’ll go on the subway.
ex_2_jp: 東京の地下鉄はかなりふくざつです。
ex_2_en: Tokyo's subway is extremely complex.
ex_3_jp: ああ、よかった！地下鉄に乗り遅れちゃうかと思ったよ。
ex_3_en: What a relief! I thought I missed the subway train.
meaning_story: The iron below ground isn't a deposit of iron. It's man made. And what is made of iron? Trains and subways. In this case, because it's underground, it's definitely a subway, though.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 物語の主人公にでもなったつもりでいるんだろう。
ex_1_en: I think she's acting like she's the main character of a story.
ex_2_jp: 竹とり物語は日本の有名な物語です。
ex_2_en: The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter is a famous Japanese legend.
ex_3_jp: 今物語を書いているんです。悲しい子犬フェチの男の話です。
ex_3_en: I’m writing a story right now. It’s about a sad guy who is obsessed with puppies.
meaning_story: A language about things. This is a confusing one. Just think of it more like someone talking about things, anything, really. Someone who just talks about things is someone who tells stories. So, this word means tale or story or legend (not the Tom Cruise one, though).
reading_story: The reading for this is messed up. You have 物 as もの, which is fine, but 語 decides to go all crazy on you. Maybe you've heard the word ものがたり before (it's in some film names / book names). If not, think of a story being told about a great gatling (がたり) gun that wandered the land, mowing everything down in its path. It's a terrible legend, but what if it were true???

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 仕事終わりのビールは最高だな。
ex_1_en: Beer when work ends is the best.
ex_2_jp: 東京わんの夜けいを見ながら最高の一時を楽しんでいます。
ex_2_en: I'm enjoying the best moment, looking at the night view of Tokyo Bay.
ex_3_jp: 「うわ！あんたの作ったの、今までで最高のチョコレートケーキだわ。でも、一体どうしちゃったの？お菓子作りなんてしたことなかったじゃない。」「別に。何か新しいことをしてみたかっただけだよ。」
ex_3_en: "Wow, you made the best chocolate cake. But, what’s gotten into you? You’ve never baked before." "Nothing, I just wanted to do something new."
meaning_story: The most tall isn't literally the most tall. When you think of something high above the rest, you think of something that is the best.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: げしとは、一年で最も夜がみじかくなる日のことだ。
ex_1_en: The summer solstice is the shortest night of the year.
ex_2_jp: ふじ山は日本で最も高い山です。
ex_2_en: Mt. Fuji is the tallest mountain in Japan.
ex_3_jp: 彼、今日の夜何食べたか知ってる？焼き肉食べ放題に行ったんだよ。最も臭いおならに備えておいた方が身のためだよ。用心に越したことはないんだから。
ex_3_en: Do you know what he ate tonight? He went to an all you can eat yakiniku restaurant. We’d better prepare for the smelliest farts imaginable. Better safe than sorry.
meaning_story: This is the adverb version of the kanji, so it has the same meaning, basically. You can say this is the most or just most. You can also use it as extremely.
reading_story: The reading for this is a reading you didn't learn with the kanji (the kun'yomi reading). To learn it, let's look at a mnemonic. Think of the most ridiculous motto (もっと) you've ever heard. Now imagine a motto that's even more ridiculous. Here are some actual totally real mottos that are the most ridiculous: "What Can Brown Do for You?" "It's Not for Women" "If It Doesn't Get All Over the Place, It Doesn't Belong in Your Face" and of course, "Why Not Enjoy the Go?"
pitch_accent: モットꜜモ *** モꜜットモ

ex_1_jp: 今朝、くすりを飲むのをわすれました。
ex_1_en: I forgot to take my medicine this morning.
ex_2_jp: 今朝から両足がいたくて思うように歩けません。
ex_2_en: My legs have been hurting since I woke up this morning, so I can't move as much as I'd like.
ex_3_jp: 今朝ここで玉突き事故があったんだ。
ex_3_en: This morning there was a multi-vehicle accident here.
meaning_story: Now morning is just another way of saying this morning. It's the closest morning to right now!
reading_story: This reading is an exception. Let's use this mnemonic to remember it: This morning you want a quesadilla (けさ) for breakfast. You can't wait until tomorrow morning, you NEED it this morning! Imagine eating a delicious quesadilla first thing this morning. Mmm!

ex_1_jp: 仕事は進んでいますか？
ex_1_en: Are you making any progress in your work?
ex_2_jp: トーフグは、いつも一歩先を進んでいるよね。
ex_2_en: Tofugu always goes one step ahead, doesn't it?
ex_3_jp: お嬢さんは他の学生よりずっと進んでいる。
ex_3_en: Your daughter is advancing faster than the other students.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means advance so the verb vocab version means to advance.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In order to advance, you must sue Sue for her misdeeds against you. Imagine her standing in your way, literally. She keeps saying, "You'll have to sue me if you want to get past me!" So you do. You sue Sue.

ex_1_jp: 仕事が決まってからは、きょうみがなくなりました。
ex_1_en: Since I got the job, I’ve lost interest.
ex_2_jp: コウイチは毎朝かみがたが決まらないせいで会社にちこくする。
ex_2_en: Every morning Koichi is late for work because he hasn't decided on a hairstyle yet.
ex_3_jp: 「それは本当にいい考えだね。そうしよう。」「よし、じゃあ、それで話は決まりだ。」
ex_3_en: "That’s a really good idea. Let’s do that." "Okay, then it’s been decided."
meaning_story: You've seen the word 決める before, hopefully. This is similar, except for instead of doing the action of deciding, something has just been decided (by something or someone else). You are not the decision maker, here. That's why this word is to be decided.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 決める, so make sure you know that word so you can apply that knowledge over here.

ex_1_jp: まだ助かる見こみはあるんですか。
ex_1_en: Is there still a chance it will be saved?
ex_2_jp: コウイチ先生にもらったれんあいのアドバイスのおかげで、助かりました。
ex_2_en: I was rescued by the relationship advice that my teacher Koichi gave me.
ex_3_jp: 「で、私達付き合ってるのよね？どうなの？はっきりさせてよ。」「えーと…」＜その時、インターホンが鳴った。:ピンポーン＞「ふぅ、間一髪で助かった。」
ex_3_en: "So, are we going out or what? Make it clear!" "Um…" (The front doorbell rings: ring-ring.) "Phew, saved by the bell."
meaning_story: You know that 助ける means "to help" - so, this is a different version of that. This is when someone is helping someone else, or something is helping you, but you're not doing the action of helping someone. Use the か to help you remember: The "car" helps you to drive around. That's why this word means to be helped. It also can be used to talk about how you were rescued, which is like being helped, right? If you want to memorize it that way, that's fine too.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 助ける, so hopefully you know that word and can apply that knowledge over here.

ex_1_jp: 今すぐタクシーに乗れば、まだ間に合うかもしれません。
ex_1_en: If we get in a taxi right now, we might still make it on time.
ex_2_jp: ごめん！じゅうたいにはまっちゃって、待ち合わせに間に合いそうにない。
ex_2_en: Sorry! I'm stuck in traffic, so I'm most likely not going to make it to the appointment on time.
ex_3_jp: 「間に合うと思う？」「もうすぐ7時なんだから、後は自分で考えればわかるだろ。」
ex_3_en: "Do you think we can make it in time?" "Well, it’s almost seven o’clock. Do the math."
meaning_story: There is an interval (of time) that will "come together" (合う) to start something. You need to be there before then. That's why this word means to be in time for.
reading_story: You learned this reading for 間 when you learned 間もなく. And the reading for 合う is just that of the word 合う. If you remember them both, you'll remember this word!

ex_1_jp: あっぱくめんせつって、終わった後、ほんと病むよな。
ex_1_en: Stress interviews make you feel really sick afterwards, don't you agree?
ex_2_jp: しょく場の同りょうは、仕事のストレスが原いんで病んでしまいました。
ex_2_en: My coworker got sick from work-related stress.
ex_3_jp: まさかアイツが心を病むなんてな。
ex_3_en: I never thought that he would get mentally ill.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sick, so the verb version is to be sick. It can also be used as to come down with when you have the flu or some other illness.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: There is only one time you allow yourself to be sick, and that's when the Yankees (や) are playing. You can't miss any games so you just happen to fall ill whenever they're playing so you can stay home and watch. That's pretty convenient, isn't it?

ex_1_jp: たぬきやきつねは、人間を化かすのがとくいだ。
ex_1_en: Tanuki and foxes are good at bewitching humans.
ex_2_jp: わたしの友人はいつも化しょうで男の人を化かしています。
ex_2_en: My friend enchants men with makeup all the time.
ex_3_jp: 「遅くなってすみません。いやあ、きつねに化かされちまってねえ。」「心配しないでください。それはどうしようもないことですからね。」
ex_3_en: "I’m sorry I’m late. I was bewitched by a fox." "No worries. Things like that can’t be helped."
meaning_story: You've seen the word 化ける (to transform) before. Now we have a similar word. This word means to bewitch because when you cuss (かす) you are saying a magic word and bewitching the person in front of you. Imagine yourself yelling out cuss words, and every time a new enchantment falls upon your victim.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 化ける, so make sure you know that word and you'll be able to learn this word's reading as well.

ex_1_jp: 所とくぜいがくを算定するためのけいさんしきを知っていますか。
ex_1_en: Do you know the equation to calculate your income tax?
ex_2_jp: ワニカニのユーザーのぞうげんを算定するAIをやといました。
ex_2_en: We hired an AI that can calculate WaniKani user increases and decreases.
ex_3_jp: このプログラムは、該当ユーザーに選択されたバナー広告の掲示数に応じて、広告費用を算定するんだ。
ex_3_en: This program calculates the advertising cost corresponding to the number of times a banner advertisement is selected by the user.
meaning_story: When you calculate and determine (the calculation), you are determining the calculation. That's why this word is to calculate.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: INTRANSITIVE VERB, TRANSITIVE VERB, AND GODAN VERB
ex_1_jp: あ、それから、つくえを運ぶのをわすれないでください。
ex_1_en: Oh, and don’t forget to move the desk.
ex_2_jp: 私の父親としての役目は、食べ物をテーブルに運んで、娘と一緒にお茶会をすることだ。
ex_2_en: My duty as a father is to put food on the table and have tea parties with my daughter.
ex_3_jp: この教科書を運ぶための鞄がほしい。
ex_3_en: I want a bag to carry these textbooks.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carry so the verb version is to carry.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine you have to carry a hawk (はこ). Imagine carrying it in your hands, it trying to claw and peck itself free, but you don't let go. It is your job to carry this hawk with you everywhere.

ex_1_jp: 子犬がワンワン鳴いています。
ex_1_en: The puppy is barking.
ex_2_jp: あそこでコケコッコーとおんどりが鳴くまねをしているのが、うちの社長です。
ex_2_en: The guy mimicking a rooster's cock-a-doodle-doo over there is our president.
ex_3_jp: 今夜、あの新しい洒落た日本食レストランに行こうよ。知ってた？あそこには、ホーホケキョと美しい声で鳴く鶯も何羽かいるんだぜ。
ex_3_en: Let’s go to the new, chic Japanese restaurant tonight. Did you know that it has a few cute Japanese bush warblers singing with their beautiful voices?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means chirp so the verb vocab version would be to chirp. Alternatively, this word can also be used for the sounds other animals make as well, though the primary definition has to do with birds chirping (it has bird right in the kanji, after all).
reading_story: The reading is the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. So, spend more time chirping and less time memorizing, okay?

ex_1_jp: 青いシャツをきている人を集めてください。
ex_1_en: Please assemble the people wearing blue shirts.
ex_2_jp: ユーザーからのフィードバックを集めています。
ex_2_en: We've been gathering feedback from users.
ex_3_jp: 私は外国の食べ物の写真を集めている。
ex_3_en: I am collecting pictures of foreign food.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means collect so the vocab verb version means to collect.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you only have one thing, there's only one thing. Nothing is collected. But when you have two... "ah two!" (あつ). Now you're starting to collect things.

ex_1_jp: バレンタインデーには、友だちに、手作りのおかしを配るんです。
ex_1_en: For Valentine’s Day we’ll distribute handmade sweets.
ex_2_jp: しんぶんを配るバイトって月にいくらくらいかせげるのかな。
ex_2_en: I wonder how much I could earn from the newspaper delivering job.
ex_3_jp: このパーティーマジでつまんない。道でティシュでも配ってる方がマシだよ。
ex_3_en: This party blows. Even passing out pocket tissues on the street would be better.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means distribute so the verb vocab version is to distribute.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to distribute some fliers to everyone. On the fliers it talks about a striptease show where kublai (くば) Khan does something naughty. Imagine this show, and imagine your shame of being the person handing out these fliers. How far the Khan has fallen.

ex_1_jp: のどがかわいたので、何か飲みましょう。
ex_1_en: I’m thirsty, so let’s drink something.
ex_2_jp: この水道水は飲めますか？
ex_2_en: Can you drink this tap-water?
ex_3_jp: 「何をお飲みになりますか？ ジン、ウォッカ、ビール、ワイン、日本酒、それとも焼酎？ 　何でもおっしゃってください。お酒なら何でも揃っていますから。」
ex_3_en: What would you like to drink? Gin, vodka, beer, wine, sake, or shochu? You name it, we’ve got it, but only if it’s alcohol.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drink so the vocab verb version is to drink.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go have a drink in the great Allicrab's name!

ex_1_jp: 休日には、とくにあてもなく運転するのがすきなんだ。
ex_1_en: I really like driving around aimlessly when I’m on holiday.
ex_2_jp: 運転する時は、ぜっ対に後ろはふり返りません。サメと同じで、前しか見ないんです。
ex_2_en: I never look back when I drive. I'm like a shark—only looking forward.
ex_3_jp: このフグモデルの車は最高だね！とても気に入ったよ。毎日運転するのが待ち遠しいよ。
ex_3_en: This Fugu model car is amazing! I love it! I can’t wait to start driving it every day.
meaning_story: A thing that carries rotations (think wheels!) is most kinds of vehicles. So, it's kind of like saying you're "doing vehicles" here... but that doesn't make sense. What do you do to vehicles though? You drive them. That's why this word means to drive.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 学校が終わったら、買い物に行きます。
ex_1_en: When I finish school, I'll go shopping.
ex_2_jp: ギャンブルにまけて人生終わってしまった。
ex_2_en: My life was over when I lost it all gambling.
ex_3_jp: おい、こら！引っ込んでろ！原子爆弾の解体が終わるまでは、私に近づくなと言っただろ。
ex_3_en: Hey, man! Back off! I told you to stay away from me until the atomic bomb has finished being dismantled.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means end and so the verb version of this is to end (or to finish).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It is time to end this. You are the debt collector and so you go to the ower (おわ) to collect what is due. Hey, it's time to end this fool! You are the ower!

ex_1_jp: まどから、海の美しいけ色を楽しむことができます。
ex_1_en: You can enjoy the beautiful ocean view from the window.
ex_2_jp: このプロジェクト、みんなすごく楽しみながらやってます。
ex_2_en: We are having a lot of fun with this project.
ex_3_jp: うさぎちゃん、いい加減目を覚ましなって。タキシード仮面のことなんか忘れて、うさぎちゃんはうさぎちゃんの人生を楽しんだらいいんだよ！
ex_3_en: Snap out of it, Usagi. Forget Tuxedo Mask and enjoy your life!
meaning_story: You've hopefully seen the word 楽しい, which means "fun." Now you're going to figure out the verb version (ends in an う sound, right?) of it. That would be to enjoy. Speaking of which, I hope you're enjoying WaniKani so far!
reading_story: The reading is the same as the word 楽しい, so be sure to know that word and you'll be able to apply it over here.

ex_1_jp: あなたのけしゴム、つくえの下に落ちていますよ。
ex_1_en: Your eraser fell under the desk.
ex_2_jp: しけんに落ちた日に、ひろうから、はがぬけ落ちました。
ex_2_en: On the day I failed the exam, I dropped my teeth from exhaustion.
ex_3_jp: 「何してるの？私も入れて？」「本当？俺たち、ステアフォールっていう、棒人間がひたすら階段から落ちるゲームをしてるんだけど。」「おもしろそうじゃん。」
ex_3_en: "What are you guys playing? Let me in!" "Really? We’re playing a game called Stair Fall where a stickman just keeps falling down the stairs." "Sounds fun!"
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fall so the vocab verb version means to fall.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you start to fall down, what do you yell? "OHHHH (お)!"

ex_1_jp: テキストを聞きます。
ex_1_en: We are going to listen to the text.
ex_2_jp: この日本語は分からないから先生に聞きましょう。
ex_2_en: Let's ask the teacher since we don't understand this Japanese.
ex_3_jp: ねえ、聞いて、エイミー。これはあなたのせいじゃないわ。だって、ケンカしたからって、他の人と寝ていい正当な理由にはならないでしょ。
ex_3_en: Listen to me, Amy. This is not your fault. He is not justified in sleeping with someone else just because you two had a fight.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hear so the vocab verb version is to hear.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to hear something very important, but you can't. In order to hear, you have to take a key (き) and unlock the doors covering your ears. Go ahead and imagine yourself doing that, focusing on the key.

ex_1_jp: 今日の午後は、としょかんでせんそうについて調べました。
ex_1_en: This afternoon, I looked up things about the war at the library.
ex_2_jp: けいさつがコウイチの車の中を調べると、中から酒によったフグが出てきました。
ex_2_en: When the police investigated inside Koichi's car, a drunken blowfish came out.
ex_3_jp: カピバラが食べられるのかどうか、ちょっと調べてくれない？
ex_3_en: Can you research capybaras and see if they are edible?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means investigate so the vocab verb version means to investigate.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are hired to investigate someone's wife. It is said that she loves (しら) another man... but you need to investigate her to find out if that's true, for her husband of course.

ex_1_jp: 日本に来てから、いろんな言葉を習いました。
ex_1_en: I’ve learned many different words since I came to Japan.
ex_2_jp: うちのむす子は、しょ道を習っています。
ex_2_en: My son is learning calligraphy.
ex_3_jp: 今日は、世界一のフグクッキーの作り方を習いに行くのよ。それ、子供たち大好きよね。
ex_3_en: I’m going to learn how to make the world’s best fugu cookies today. Kids will love that, right?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means learn so the vocab verb version means to learn.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to learn about Nara, the city of deer... lots and lots of deer. If you don't know about it, how about learning about it?

ex_1_jp: わたしたち、ちょっと出会うのが早すぎたみたいね。
ex_1_en: It looks like we happened to run into each other a little too early.
ex_2_jp: きのうの夜、クラブで、れんあいかんじょうぬきでただ楽しみたいっていう男に出会ってさ、ハマっちゃいけないのは分かってるけど、めちゃくちゃタイプだったんだよね。
ex_2_en: Last night, I met a guy who's looking for no strings attached fun at a club and I know I shouldn't be into him, but he was really my type.
ex_3_jp: 「ニコールって、今、付き合っている人いるの？」「ええ。エリックと1年間付き合っているわ。」「そうなんだ！彼とは、どこで出会ったの？」
ex_3_en: "Are you seeing anyone now, Nicole?" "Yes, I’ve been seeing Eric for a year." "Wow, where did you guys meet?"
meaning_story: You exit your house and you meet someone. You didn’t mean to meet them, but it happened anyway. That’s why this word means to meet by chance.
reading_story: The reading is that of the word 出る and the word 会う, both of which you've hopefully seen. The 出 portion may be confusing, but you can usually assume that if one part of the word is kun'yomi / vocab reading, the other part is too, which is why 出 uses the vocab reading. Oh by the way, this word can be written like this too: 出合う. It’s not as common, but you may come across it every now and then, so it’s good to know!

ex_1_jp: かの女は口調がキツイのでちょっと苦手です。
ex_1_en: I don’t really like her because of her harsh tone.
ex_2_jp: コウイチは、とてもきびしい口調で、「うんも実力のうちだ」と言った。
ex_2_en: Koichi said, in a very stern voice, that luck is just part of his talents.
ex_3_jp: 厳しい口調で責め立てられた。
ex_3_en: She scolded me violently in a severe tone.
meaning_story: When your mouth makes tones we call it your tone or tone of voice. They're different kinds of sounds you make with your mouth that make you sound happy, sad, mean, etc.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 口 yet. Remember when you learned the vocabulary word 口? Just take the ち off and you get its other on'yomi reading く. That's easy, right?

ex_1_jp: 日本語のじしょを開けてください。
ex_1_en: Please open your Japanese dictionary.
ex_2_jp: わたしのかれ氏は、車に乗る時は、いつもドアを開けてくれるよ。
ex_2_en: My boyfriend always opens the car door for me when I get in.
ex_3_jp: 「ねぇ、このワインボトルを開けてもらえないかな？」「いいよ。朝飯前だよ。」
ex_3_en: "Can you open this bottle of wine for me?" "Of course. Piece of cake."
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means open so the verb vocab version is to open.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go to open the door. When you do, a huge scream comes out: "AAAHHH!" (あ). Imagine giant あ characters flying out of the door you opened as well.

ex_1_jp: 次の文を読んで、しつもんに答えてください。
ex_1_en: Please read the following text and answer the questions.
ex_2_jp: ビエトとコウイチのひみつの交かん日記を内しょで読んでしまいました。
ex_2_en: I secretly read the hush-hush diary that is exchanged between Viet and Koichi.
ex_3_jp: あんたの彼氏が書いた「旅の注意書き」読んだ？二、三本傘を持参するべきって書いてあるけど。
ex_3_en: Did you read the note your boyfriend left you about your trip? It says that you should bring two or three umbrellas with you.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means read so the verb vocab version is to read.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go read something else, now.

ex_1_jp: あんたのけいたいなら、その辺に転がってたわよ。
ex_1_en: Your cell phone was left somewhere around here.
ex_2_jp: ダリンは、トーフグオフィスの前にフグの死体が転がっているのを発見しました。
ex_2_en: Darin discovered the dead body of a blowfish, lying in front of the Tofugu office.
ex_3_jp: 転がる石？イギリスのロックバンド、ザ・ローリング・ストーンズのことですか？
ex_3_en: A rolling stone? Do you mean the English rock band The Rolling Stones?
meaning_story: You know that the kanji here means revolve. The verb version of this is similar. It means to roll or to tumble. When something is doing these things it is revolving, right?
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine something rolling down a hill. Inside is a very important uranium core (ころ) that you need to keep spinning. That's why they have it rolling down hill after hill, because they don't have anything else to keep it spinning like that, preventing it from exploding. This core is very important!

ex_1_jp: 次のセミナーでは、何について語る予定ですか？
ex_1_en: What do you plan to talk about at the next seminar?
ex_2_jp: 田中さん、時間がないので、ぼうけんだんを語るのはこの辺で止めてください。
ex_2_en: Mr. Tanaka, time is up, so please wrap up your adventure tale.
ex_3_jp: この事件を人に語ることはできない。
ex_3_en: I can’t talk about this case with people.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means language, so when you do language you're going to talk.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Sometimes when you're trying to talk, there will be that one person who always cuts you off to tell everyone what they want to say. We call them language cutters (かた). They cut you off and make everyone pay attention to what they're saying. Don't be a language cutter.

ex_1_jp: むすめから、頭に花びんを投げ付けられて、七はりをぬう大けがを負いました。
ex_1_en: My daughter threw a vase at my head and gave me a serious injury that needed seven stitches.
ex_2_jp: せつ分の日にコウイチにまめを投げ付けてじゃ気をはらいました。
ex_2_en: On the Setsubun, we threw dried beans at Koichi and chased the evil sprits away.
ex_3_jp: 「サーモン、僕は君に夢中なんだ。」「フグ、私はあんたに怒り心頭よ。どうして私に向かってニンニクなんて投げ付けるのよ！」「ご…ごめん。鮭はニンニクの臭いが好きって聞いたことがあったんだ。」
ex_3_en: "Salmon, I’m mad about you." "Fugu, I’m actually mad at you! Why did you throw garlic at me? "S..sorry I’ve heard that salmon like the smell of garlic."
meaning_story: You know that you're throwing something that is attaching to something else. How else can you say that? The best way would be to say to throw against or to throw at.
reading_story: The readings just come from two vocab words you've hopefully seen already: 投げる and 付ける. So long as you know the readings for those words, the reading for this word should be no problem for you.

ex_1_jp: 父は、毎朝六時に起きます。
ex_1_en: My father gets up at six o’clock every morning.
ex_2_jp: いつも朝起きるのめっちゃ早いですね。まだ四時ですよ。
ex_2_en: You're always up so early! It's still 4 o'clock, you know.
ex_3_jp: 三段腹を無くすために、毎朝起きたらすぐに100回腹筋をします。
ex_3_en: I do 100 sit-ups every morning right after waking up to get rid of my three pack.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wake up so the verb vocab version is to wake up.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so tomorrow when you wake up you hopefully won't have to relearn this vocab's reading.

ex_1_jp: そのメール、私にも転送してくれない？
ex_1_en: Could you forward that email to me?
ex_2_jp: 海外に住んでいる日本人は、よく日本のウェブサイトから物を買って、海外の住所に転送しています。
ex_2_en: Japanese people who reside overseas often buy things from Japanese websites and have them forwarded to the foreign addresses.
ex_3_jp: 郵便物をこちら住所の方へ転送して頂きたいんですが。
ex_3_en: Could you please forward my mail to this address?
meaning_story: So, you're sending something that revolves. It's a little transfer / transmission, going through the wires. Little messages that revolve around as they zip through the lines to get to their destination. Try to imagine this happening in slow motion, getting to the other end.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 思わず本音を口にしてしまいました。
ex_1_en: I spoke of my real intentions unintentionally.
ex_2_jp: コウイチがすんげー大きな音のオナラをしたから、みんな思わず耳をふさいだんだけど、はなをふさいだ方がよかったね。
ex_2_en: Koichi farted sooooo loudly that everybody reflexively covered their ears, but we should have covered our noses instead.
ex_3_jp: 美味しそうな写真を見て、思わず涎が出た。
ex_3_en: I saw the delicious looking picture and involuntarily started drooling.
meaning_story: This is the adverb version of the kanji think. You can't help but think, you do it unintentionally. So put this in front of things to say that you did them involuntarily.
reading_story: The reading for this is the kun'yomi reading which you learned already, so you should be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: なかなか作業がはかどらないんです。
ex_1_en: I’m not making any progress in my work.
ex_2_jp: きのうは、一日中作業ハンドブックを作る作業をしていました。
ex_2_en: Yesterday, I was working on making an operations handbook all day long.
ex_3_jp: あなたのせいで、製造作業が全て停止してしまったってこと、分かっていますか？
ex_3_en: Do you understand that all manufacturing operations were shut down because of you?
meaning_story: If you want to make a business successful you need to be prepared to do a lot of work.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 英語が母国語でない人で、ネイティブレベルや上級の英語を話す人もいれば、そうでない人もいます。
ex_1_en: Some non-native speakers speak English at a native or advanced level, while others do not.
meaning_story: When you are at an above rank, you are at an advanced level. This is referring to things like proficiency in Japanese, or things like that.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: お前はいったいどっちの味方なんだ？
ex_1_en: Who the heck are your allies?
meaning_story: The flavor of this direction is one I'd like to follow and go in, along with you. You have a good flavor and you're going in a good direction. Will you be my ally? I'll be your supporter.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あの不良少女の成績が大幅に下がって、ギャングに参加しました。
ex_1_en: That delinquent girl’s grades dropped drastically and then she joined a gang.
meaning_story: Something that's not good is bad. Alternatively, it can be substandard.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 良 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine being in a very substandard row (りょう) boat. It's terrible in every way. There's holes. The oars are made of snakes. It's just bad. Why did you get in this bad rowboat?

ex_1_jp: フランス語を初歩から学び始めました。
ex_1_en: I’m starting to study the basics of French.
meaning_story: The first thing you walk through when you learn something new will always be the basics. You never start by running, you always have to start slow and work your way through the ABCs before you start to run.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼はマクドナルドに行く途中、血みどろの戦いに遭遇したが、その後そのままビッグマックを食べに行った。
ex_1_en: On the way to McDonald’s he got in a bloody fight but that didn’t stop him from getting his Big Mac.
meaning_story: Don't let this word confuse you. It may end in い, but it's not an adjective, it's a noun. There are no rules in war, after all. This word describes what happens in war. Those things are battles, fights, and conflicts.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In a fierce battle, there's always a lot of collateral damage. One of the things that gets destroyed is your car. But you can't do anything about it, it's battle time! So you wave goodbye to your car saying, "Ta ta car (たたか)!" as you punch some jerk in the face.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは頼れるやつだ。たとえ戦場にいたとしても、俺達を決して見捨てやしないよ。
ex_1_en: Koichi is a dependable guy. He would never let us down even if we were on a battlefield.
meaning_story: A war location is the battlefield. That's where the wars are fought, anyways.
reading_story: The reading for 戦 is the one you know. The reading for 場 is the other reading, which you've hopefully seen via other vocabulary, but didn't learn with the kanji. Just think of how you fight on the battlefield with a jo-stick, which is why this reading is じょう.

ex_1_jp: 予め予習しておいた甲斐がありました。
ex_1_en: Preparing the lesson in advance was worthwhile.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What did you do beforehand? You had a raw casual (あらかじ) encounter with a raw Cage, Nic Cage. You probably should have planned something better ahead of time.

ex_1_jp: 私の日本語はまだ初級レベルですが、一生懸命勉強しています。
ex_1_en: My Japanese is still at an elementary level, but I’m working hard at it.
meaning_story: The first rank of something is the beginner level. Compare this to 中級 and 上級 (vocab from this level) to get a fuller understanding.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: デザイナーになりたいなら、生物学も学んだ方がいい。
ex_1_en: If you want to become a designer, you should also study biology.
meaning_story: Remember how 生物 means "living things?" Well when you study living things you're studying biology.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今、家の前のバス乗り場で通り過ぎる車を見ながらダラダラしているよ。
ex_1_en: At the moment I’m chilling at the bus stop in front of my house looking at cars passing by.
meaning_story: You've seen the word 乗る by now, hopefully, and know it means "to ride." So this word has to do with a "riding location." Where do you go to get a ride somewhere? Most likely, it's a bus stop or taxi stand.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. Also use 乗る to help you to remember the reading for 乗り.

ex_1_jp: 私は彼が間違った道を進んでるんじゃないかと心配しているのよ。注意したんだけど、聞く耳持たずって感じで。
ex_1_en: I’m worried that he’s going down the wrong path. I cautioned him, but he doesn’t listen to me.
meaning_story: When you pour your ideas into something, you're thinking a lot about it. You're paying close attention and using caution. You'll see this on a lot of signs marking dangerous things in Japan, so be sure to pay attention to them!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは昔はAKB48をよくディスっていたのに、今はすっかり大ファンになっちまった。まるで別人のようだよ。
ex_1_en: Koichi used to often diss AKB48, but now he is a crazed AKB48 fan. It’s as though he is a different person.
meaning_story: A separate person is someone who is different from who they were before. I saw you a year ago and you were someone else. Now you're a different person, in a good way! You're a changed man.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「コウイチが熟女好きっていう噂を聞いたんだけど。」「マジかよ！もしそれが本当なら、俺とコウイチに共通点ができるってことになるぜ。」
ex_1_en: "I heard a rumor that Koichi likes older women." "Seriously? If that was true it would mean that he and I have something in common."
meaning_story: We pass through this point together. This point is our common point. It is where our ideas, philosophies, and bodies pass through each other.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 学校での厳しい一日を終えて、仲間たちとリラックスをした。
ex_1_en: Me and my group of friends relaxed after a hard day at school.
meaning_story: Your relationship intervals... this doesn't make much sense at first, but if you think about it, at certain intervals from within your friends, you'll run into someone who's your companion... not just any old friend. Something better. Something part of your group.
reading_story: The reading for 仲 is the one you learned. The reading for 間 (ま) is one you didn't learn with the kanji. Think through all your companions in your life. Imagine one of them is your Ma (ま). She's on your pirate crew, and a pretty awesome pirate.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あいつら、もうちょっと落ち着いた方がいいよ。いっつもお互いで競争して、しかも両方共負けず嫌いとくるんだから。
ex_1_en: These guys really need to chill out. They are always competing with each other and they both hate losing.
meaning_story: When you compete to the point of conflict, you know that this person / entity is your competition. Gotta beat out that competition. For example, in order to beat out the competition, WaniKani has a mascot that can eat every other small furry animal that the competition has for their mascot. Case closed.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 生活は日に日に便利になっていく。
ex_1_en: Life is getting more convenient day after day.
meaning_story: When you profit from your convenience, that means you have something very convenient or handy. Remember, you can profit in other ways besides money. This convenience could be giving you a profit in happiness or extra time as well. All these things are very handy to have.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 彼は共同貯金をこっそり使い果たしてしまった。
ex_1_en: He secretly used up our joint savings.
meaning_story: People working together on the same thing is cooperation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: それとこれとは話が別だろう。
ex_1_en: This and that are two different stories.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「教育があって常識がないよりも、教育がなくて常識がある方がはるかによい。」って誰の言葉だっけ？
ex_1_en: "Do you remember who said ’it is a thousand times better to have common sense without education than education without common sense’? "
meaning_story: Teach and nurture. That's what your education is supposed to do.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「お夕飯は何が食べたい？」「何でもいいよ。特にこだわりはないよ。」
ex_1_en: "What would you like for supper?" "Anything is fine. I’m not especially picky."
meaning_story: Something is towards (に) special. That thing is especially special, wouldn't you say?
reading_story: The reading is the same reading you learned for this kanji.

ex_1_jp: iPhoneをダメにしちゃった。用を足した後のトイレに落としちゃったよ。まぁ、これがアイツの運命だったのかもしれないけどさ。でも、おれは猛烈に悲しいぜ。
ex_1_en: Rest in peace iPhone. I just dropped it in a toilet filled with more than just water. Maybe this was just fate but I am so sad right now.
meaning_story: Everyone has to carry their fate. So what is the thing you're carrying? It's your fate.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あの子は、心持のよい素直な子です。
ex_1_en: They’re a pleasant, obedient kid.
meaning_story: Your heart holds a lot of feelings. They can be overwhelming and sometimes it feels like there are none in there at all, but that doesn't mean they aren't there in your heart.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that it's not も, it's もち, like 気持ち and 金持ち. Sometimes you'll see this written 心持ち too. Keep your eyes open and maybe you'll see them both used.

ex_1_jp: 突然中指が痛くなったんだけど。
ex_1_en: I just had a sudden pain in my middle finger.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Those kun'yomi body parts, mang.

ex_1_jp: 指先がかじかんでいます。
ex_1_en: My fingertips are getting numb.
meaning_story: You know that previous part of your finger? The part I just chopped off? Well that was your fingertip! I only had time to get the tip. It used to be on your finger and now it's right here, in my hand. Sorry, I guess.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!
pitch_accent: ユビサキ *** ユビサキꜜ

ex_1_jp: お母さん！僕、あのテストで滅茶苦茶良い点をとったんだよ！なんとランキングでは一位だったんだ！
ex_1_en: Mom! I really aced that test! I ranked at the top of my class!
meaning_story: Rank one is the first place.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: これは日本の昔話ですか？
ex_1_en: Isn’t that a Japanese legend?
meaning_story: Long ago people used to talk about all sorts of things. Most of them weren't true. Long ago people liked to lie a lot. Now we call those things they talked about folklore and legends.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them both already, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for the rendaku of はなし to ばなし.

ex_1_jp: 仲良くなれば、彼女が中々面白い酒飲みだということが分かるよ。
ex_1_en: Once you get to know her you’ll understand why we say she’s an amusing drunk.
meaning_story: When the relationship is good, that means you're friendly with that person. You're also on good terms.
reading_story: The readings are kun'yomi, but those are the readings you learned with the kanji, so hopefully we can stay on good terms, right?

ex_1_jp: 彼女はとても友好的で経験豊富な日本語教師ってだけじゃなく、実はヤクザの隠れメンバーでもあるんだよ。
ex_1_en: She is not only a very friendly and experienced Japanese teacher, but also a secret member of the Yakuza.
meaning_story: If you have a friend you like, well, that's true friendship!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: くやしいから、なんか仕返ししたいな。
ex_1_en: It was mortifying, so I wanna get even.
ex_2_jp: キャットウーマン！あんたって本当に最低の女だね！いつか仕返ししてやるわ！
ex_2_en: Catwoman! You are so evil! I’ll get you back soon!
meaning_story: When you return the doings of another person, you're doing it to get even (whether it's a nice thing or a mean thing).
reading_story: The readings are a bit weird, here. 仕 gets its on'yomi reading... you should be okay with that. 返し gets the kun'yomi reading, though, which is the reading you saw with the word 返す in level 9. You can tell this part uses the kun'yomi vocab reading because it has that hiragana attached to it. Just remember to distinguish between the two parts of the word to remember the readings.

ex_1_jp: 神様は水の上を歩けるかもしれないけど、俺は陸の上を泳ぐことができるんだぜ。
ex_1_en: God can walk on water and I can swim on land.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Do you know the word "Kamikaze"? Also, do you remember the word 風 from a previous level? Kamikaze means "divine winds" or "godly winds." If you know the word "Kamikaze" you can apply it to this single word, that means "god" or "gods." Use your prior knowledge to remember this reading.

ex_1_jp: 良い考えだけど、実はお金を十分に持っていない。
ex_1_en: That’s a good idea, but that fact is that we don’t have enough money.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of good? It's also good.
reading_story: The reading you learned with the kanji can be applied here. That's good, yeah?

ex_1_jp: マッサージは気持ちいい。
ex_1_en: This massage feels good.
meaning_story: When you have a feeling (気持ち) that is いい (that means "good" by the way), you have a good feeling.
reading_story: The reading comes from the vocab word 気持ち, so if you know that (or the vocab words 気 and 持ち you should be A-okay on this one. Maybe even feeling good about it?

ex_1_jp: 「今何しているの？」「うんこしてるんだよ。放っておいて。」「はぁ？いくら仲良しだからって、そんなことまで教えてくれなくても良いわよ。親しき仲にも礼儀ありって言うでしょ！」
ex_1_en: "What are you doing?" "I’m taking a crap. Leave me alone." "What? We may be good friends but you don’t need to tell me that. Good fences make good neighbors."
meaning_story: You have a good relationship with someone. This is someone who is your good friend or intimate friend.
reading_story: The readings are kun'yomi as you probably guessed from the hiragana sticking out, but that doesn't matter because you learned the kun'yomi readings with these kanji.

ex_1_jp: 努力しても、結果が出なくては意味が無い。
ex_1_en: Even if you make a great effort, it doesn’t mean you get results.
meaning_story: You toil and use your strength. Ugh! How difficult. You really put in a great effort.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: うちのお風呂って、シャワーの位置が固定されちゃってるから、浴槽を洗って流すときにかなり苦労するんだよね。
ex_1_en: Since the shower head’s position is fixed in my bath tub, it’s such a pain to rinse the tub out when I wash it.
meaning_story: Suffering and labor. Sounds like the kind of thing these soft hands wouldn't want to deal with. These are hardships and troubles. Hopefully you don't have too much of this with kanji anymore!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 俺とおまえは昔は切っても切れない仲だっただろ。でもさ、 ほら、今は昔とは違うというか何というか、えっと…正直いって、お前のこと苦手なんだよ。
ex_1_en: You and I used to be inseparable, but you know, now it’s like… things are different. Honestly, I feel uncomfortable with you.
meaning_story: A "suffering hand" is a little misleading. Think more in terms of the words 苦い (bitter) and 手 (person... remember how that happens sometimes?). Now think of this word like you're bitter about having to work with someone. Why? Because they are extremely hard to deal with.
reading_story: The reading is that of 苦い (にがい) plus regular old 手 (て). Remember, this is your bitter person, the person who's "hard to deal with." So, it uses the strange にがい reading.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: この高級レストランはビップ専用となっているので、入店するには招待状か紹介状が必要になります。
ex_1_en: This high end restaurant is for VIP only. In order to enter, you need an invitation or a letter of referral.
meaning_story: A tall grade item is really just a high grade or high class item.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 平仮名は読めるけど書けません。
ex_1_en: I can read hiragana but I can’t write it.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 仮名 means "kana?" Well this is flat kana. Flat kana is just hiragana.
reading_story: You should know the reading for this word because it's the same as the English meaning.

ex_1_jp: 一緒に仕事ができるように、俺の犬に金槌の使い方を訓練してみようと思うんだ。
ex_1_en: I’m going to train my dog how to use a hammer and bring him to work with me.
meaning_story: You've seen the word 使う hopefully by now. If you have, you know it means "to use." So, the way to use something is the way of using (aka how to use). This will be a word you see when you're looking at directions for how to use something.
reading_story: The readings come from the vocab words 使う and 方. So long as you're okay with those you can apply that knowledge over here.

ex_1_jp: この部屋は冷蔵庫、洗濯機付きです。
ex_1_en: This room is furnished with a refrigerator and a washing machine.
meaning_story: You know that the kanji 付 means attach and words like 付く mean "to be attached." This has the same idea. When you see this attached to another word, for example, you might know that something is attached to something else, or perhaps included with it. For example, if you stay at a hotel room, maybe it is a breakfast付き, i.e. "including breakfast."
reading_story: The reading comes from the reading of the kanji as well as from words like 付く and 付ける.

ex_1_jp: 俺の隠れ家へようこそ。ビールは冷蔵庫に入ってるぜ。ちょっと不便かもしれねぇが、煙草は外で吸ってくれよな。
ex_1_en: Welcome to my man cave. Beers are in the refrigerator. It may be a bit inconvenient for you, but you’ve got to go outside to smoke.
meaning_story: Something that is not convenience is inconvenient.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 英語力が中級や初級の人たちと会話をする能力は、実は、訓練して身につくスキルなんです。
ex_1_en: The ability to communicate with people who speak English at an intermediate or beginner level is actually a skill that can be developed over time with practice.
meaning_story: Something at the middle rank or grade is at an intermediate level.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「時間内に、この仕事を終えられると思うか？」「さあ、それはどうかな。」
ex_1_en: "Do you think we can finish this work in time?" "Well, I wouldn’t bet on it."
meaning_story: Your "doing actions" are the things you do. What do you say when someone asks "what you do"? You tell them what your job is.
reading_story: This word uses the on'yomi reading for 仕 and the kun'yomi reading for 事. Please note that 事 uses the reading こと, which you didn't learn with the kanji, but you have come across it once or twice by now, and because of the way rendaku works, it's changed to the voiced ごと.

ex_1_jp: このぐらいの気温が丁度いいですね。
ex_1_en: This temperature is just right.
meaning_story: If 丁度 is "exactly", then "exactly good" is going to be just the right amount, aka just right.
reading_story: If you know the reading for 丁度 you'll know the reading for this too. Your knowledge should be just right, as they say inside my head.

ex_1_jp: ちょっとコピー機使わせてもらってもいい？新しい労働者を雇うために、チラシを作ってるんだけど。
ex_1_en: Can I use the photocopier? I’m making up flyers to try to get new laborers.
meaning_story: Someone who does labor for work is a laborer.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 主位的請求と予備的請求は共に棄却された。
ex_1_en: Both the primary and secondary claims were rejected.
meaning_story: The master rank is the person who is the master in whatever is being ranked. That person is the leading person or the person in first place.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: セーラームーンの命は危ない！
ex_1_en: Sailor Moon’s life is in danger!
meaning_story: The kanji for this means fate... but what is your fate, really? Your fate is to live out your life the way you're being fated to live out your life. Then, when your life runs out, your fate runs out.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: The Book of Enoch (いのち) has passed down your fate and told you how to use your life. You must read the book of Enoch and find out what you're supposed to do.
pitch_accent: イꜜノチ *** ミコト *** メꜜイ

ex_1_jp: そのままの君が好きなんだ。だから、他のやつのために自分を変えようなんてしないでくれよ。
ex_1_en: I like you just the way you are so please don’t try to change yourself for anyone.
meaning_story: You know that 好 means like. This is a weird word, though. It's kind of half an adjective, half a noun. Anyways, the vocab word and the kanji kind of mean the same thing. You have like, fondness, and love.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who do you like more than anyone? Your friend Sue. If you know someone named Sue, pretend you like her. If you don't, think of a famous person you know named Sue and use her, pretending you're good friends that like each other a lot.

ex_1_jp: 彼は文字通り、「天才」です。
ex_1_en: He’s literally a genius.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned the words 文字 and 通り? Well an "avenue" made of "letters" is literally to the letter. Wink.
reading_story: This is a combination of the words 文字 and 通り, which you learned already, so you should be able to read this one. Just make sure you remember that とおり becomes どおり because of rendaku.

ex_1_jp: またシュートミスっちまったぜ。突き指してる小指のせいで今日はまじでダメだわ。
ex_1_en: That’s another air ball. I’m doing badly today because of this jammed pinky finger.
meaning_story: The small finger is your little finger or pinky finger. Makes sense.
reading_story: The reading for 小 is the こ reading. Hopefully by now you're familiar with it, at least. It shows up in a few things, like 小皿 and 小文字. Use your knowledge of those words to remember that this word uses weird kun'yomi readings.

ex_1_jp: 「あなた、今夜の予定は？」「昔の飲み仲間とちょっと出かけてくる予定だよ。」
ex_1_en: "What are your plans for tonight, Darling?" "I’m going out with my old drinking buddies."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is a good way to start stories, by the way: 昔々に… (Long, long ago).
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. むかし sounds like a kun'yomi reading, doesn't it? It's so long.

ex_1_jp: この負け犬のオタクめ！キモいんだよ！
ex_1_en: You are a loser, a nerd, and really creepy!
meaning_story: You've hopefully come across 負ける by now, which means "to lose." So, you can figure out this word means "losing dog." Well, calling someone a dog isn't so nice, so you're probably just calling them a loser. As Ace Ventura would say: "Lehuzeherrrr. LOSER."
reading_story: The readings are kun'yomi, but you should be familiar with 負ける and of course 犬 well enough to learn the reading here.

ex_1_jp: 「ねぇ、ゆきちゃん。あんた、あまり元気じゃなさそうね。」「うん。そうなの。低血圧症って診断されたわ。」「何それ？」「つまり、私の血圧がめちゃくちゃ低いってこと。」「どれくらい低いの？」「えっと、今朝は上が80で下が40ぐらいだったかな。」
ex_1_en: "Hey, Yuki. You don’t look so good." "Yeah, I know. I was diagnosed hypotension." "What’s that?" "It just means that my blood pressure is really, really low." "How low is that?" "Well, this morning was about 80/40."
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of low? It's low.
reading_story: You look down and very low to the ground is a man, looking up at you. Your friend is there too, but you don't know this little man. Your friend says "He coo', he coo," referring to the low to the ground man.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 俺には何が必要か知ってるかい？趣味の部屋と新しい車だよ。労働の対価をきちんと受け取る必要があるだろ？
ex_1_en: You know what I need? A man cave and a new car. I need to properly reward myself for my labors.
meaning_story: The labor work is when you're doing work with your body, right? That's manual labor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「あなたって、もっと賢いと思っていたわ。」「おい、それってどういう意味だよ!?」
ex_1_en: "I thought you were smarter than that." "Hey, what’s that supposed to mean?"
