meaning_story: The flavor of an idea, what is that? Imagine yourself licking an idea to figure out what it tastes like. What do you think you'll be tasting? Probably the meaning of said idea.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: そちらのバス待合所でお待ち下さい。
ex_1_en: Please wait in the bus shelter over there.
meaning_story: The place you wait to join other people is a meeting place.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings, but it's like the hiragana that normally sticks out is stuffed in. 待ち → 待, 合い → 合 and is pronounced the same too. I know it's confusing, but once you get it down you'll never forget!

ex_1_jp: 中指を立てるんじゃない！
ex_1_en: Don’t stick out your middle finger!
meaning_story: The middle finger is the middle finger, of course!
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この小説は、読み返す度に新たな発見がある。
ex_1_en: Every time I reread this novel I make a new discovery.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji new, so it means new too.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your parents put a newly wrapped present under the Christmas tree. You don't want to wait to see what new thing they got you so you rip it open to find they got you a raw (あら) steak. Getting a new steak is cool and all, but a raw steak is pretty gross. It's dripping blood all over the place.

ex_1_jp: 「おお、フグ。最近どうよ？」「別に変わりないね。ワニ君、君はどうだい？」
ex_1_en: "Hey, Fugu! What are you up to lately?" "Nothing in particular. How about you, Wani?"
meaning_story: If someone asks if you want a separate knee (に), you'll say not particularly. I mean, you've never thought about it, but do you really need more knees? Not really...
reading_story: The reading is just the reading you learned with the kanji. Well done!

ex_1_jp: 少年ジャンプ６月号、ただいま絶賛発売中。
ex_1_en: The June issue of Shonen Jump is now on sale with critical acclaim.
meaning_story: You have 発売, which refers to an item for sale, and then you have 中 which is middle. So, an item that is in the middle of being for sale is an item that is now being sold. It's now on sale! You'll see this for items which have recently been released or when a shopkeeper wants to let you know that they're selling something now, finally, or whatever.
reading_story: The reading comes from 発売 and 中 (kanji reading) put together.

ex_1_jp: うわ！あの老人めちゃくちゃイケメンでマッチョなんだけど。
ex_1_en: Wow! That old man is such a hunky beefcake.
meaning_story: An elderly person is an old person (or an elderly person). Don't call a person a 古い人, though. 古い is used for things, not people. Be nice, they're your elders.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: これは俺の個人的な意見なんだけど、たまに、日本は本当に変わった国だなぁと思うんだよね。
ex_1_en: This is my personal opinion but I sometimes think that Japan is a really weird country.
meaning_story: The idea you see in your head is your opinion. As the dude once said... "That's just, like, your 意見, man."
reading_story: The reading is all on'yomi, meaning 意 is just fine. 見's on'yomi (けん) is a reading you didn't learn with the kanji because it's so much less useful, but you do have to know it here. You've seen it with 発見 a couple levels ago, so that should help. In this case, just think about how your opinion is that Ken needs a new girlfriend. Barbie doesn't treat him right and he's always coming to the bar with new bruises... That Ken. Tell him your opinion.

ex_1_jp: 「ほら！何をチンタラ待っているの? 走って！」「俺に命令するんじゃねぇよ！」
ex_1_en: "C’mon! What are you waiting for? Run!" "Don’t order me around!"
meaning_story: Your fate orders are the orders you get from above. You are ordered and commanded to carry out said orders.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: それは無理な注文だが、やるっきゃない。
ex_1_en: That’s an unreasonable request but we don’t have a choice.
meaning_story: You pour writing onto a form. You're filling out this form to order something new for yourself. It's a formal request to get this new thing (imagine it being something you're excited about ordering right now, and imagine yourself ordering it by pouring writing onto an order form).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 現在、ほとんどの河豚は繁殖期である春に収穫され、太平洋に浮かぶ籠の中で養殖されます。
ex_1_en: Most pufferfish nowadays are harvested in the spring during the spawning season, then farmed in floating cages in the Pacific Ocean.
meaning_story: The fat flat ocean is the Pacific Ocean. I guess it's fatter than the Atlantic? Whatever it is, it's the ocean that China/Japan would have known the most about when they were coming up with words and kanji, which is why this is the Pacific, not the Atlantic.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 鍋の用意は全てこちらで致します。
ex_1_en: We will do all the nabe preparations.
meaning_story: When you have an idea for a task you are in preparation for actually doing it. Because it's still just an idea you're still getting ready.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 母は台所で夕飯の支度をしています。
ex_1_en: Mom is preparing dinner in the kitchen.
meaning_story: This one's a little weird. When you want to support someone in degrees you need lots of preparation. It takes time and planning to support someone over a period of time like that.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 度 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember them together: Before every performance Charlie Sheen sits on a tack in preparation. He can't make that angry face without it. The people who help him with the arrangements call it the Sheen (し) tack (たく) and they all agree it's super weird.

ex_1_jp: ねぇ、レイとアミ。これは私が口出しするようなことじゃないだろうけど、あんた達、公共の場で一緒にいるところを見られちゃいけないんじゃなかったの？だって、セレブでしょ？
ex_1_en: Hey, Rei and Ami. Y’know, this is probably none of my business, but weren’t you guys supposed to not be seen in public together? You guys are celebrities, right?
meaning_story: When the public comes together you have yourself a nice community made up of the public.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: マラソン大会で一位になったので、両親がマウンテンバイクを買ってくれた。
ex_1_en: I came in first at the marathon rally, so my parents bought me a mountain bike.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the on'yomi reading, which you learned. This is probably because you'll see this word attached to other words, showing the rank of that thing.

ex_1_jp: ごめん、よく聞こえないよ。ここは電波が悪いみたい。
ex_1_en: Sorry, you sound kind of choppy. It seems like I’ve got bad reception here.
meaning_story: The electricity wave is a wave of electricity going through the air. There are many words one can use to describe this, but the easiest one is reception (aka the reception on your phone, for example). Other more technical meanings are radio wave and electromagnetic waves. Which one you like is up to you, but reception is going to be the most common meaning on the street. Luckily people in Japan don't have AT&T otherwise you'd hear this word a lot more...
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The は from 波 rendakus to ぱ, so be careful. Maybe it's your pa who has bad reception every time you try to call him?

ex_1_jp: え？知らない。受付で聞いてない？
ex_1_en: Huh? I don’t know. Why don’t you ask at the reception desk?
meaning_story: Imagine someone accepting something and then attaching something. This person is a receptionist, because they are accepting the call, writing down the information, and then attaching said information to a sticky note for you to read. You say, "No, I'm not available."
reading_story: For this reading you have to think back to the verb words that get used with this kanji, namely 受ける and 付ける. Then just drop off the るs and put them together. 受 becomes うけ and 付 becomes つけ and you're left with うけつけ. This is what's called a compound word. And now you know it. Nice!

ex_1_jp: 過去のことは水に流して、仲直りしようよ。
ex_1_en: Let’s let bygones be bygones and just make peace with this.
meaning_story: When you fix a relationship you are going through reconciliation.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. For 仲 you're fine. That's what you learned with the kanji. For 直り think back to the vocab word 直る. That's what's going on here.

ex_1_jp: キンニクマ：「うわ！お前らちょっと仲良すぎじゃね？」 ワニカニとトフグ：「なんで？ただのマブダチだよ。」
ex_1_en: Kinnikuma: "Wow! You guys have a close relationship, don’t you?" Wanikani and Tofugu: "How so? It’s just a bromance."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi reading since it's a single kanji, all alone, but this is the reading you learned with the kanji, so you should be okay and have a great relationship with this word going forward.

ex_1_jp: 屋上でバーベキューをします。
ex_1_en: I’m doing a rooftop barbecue.
meaning_story: Above the roof is the rooftop. What else would be up there?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 屋 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: One place in the world has more rooftops than any where else, and that's Oklahoma (おく). They get so many tornados that they need extra rooftops for when the first few blow off.

ex_1_jp: 「今日、私達と一緒に海岸に行かない？」「またの機会にするよ。」
ex_1_en: "Do you want to go to the seashore with us today?" "I’ll take a rain check this time."
meaning_story: The ocean/sea coast is the seashore. Then again, it could also be the coast as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あなたの発音をたったの十秒でネイティブレベルにしてみせますよ。
ex_1_en: Your pronunciation can reach native-level in just ten seconds.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as you learned with the kanji. It's presumably because it's usually attached to other things, like numbers, making it act more like a jukugo word would. Anyways, you should only need a second to learn this reading, since you already should know it.

ex_1_jp: 私は家を二軒所有している。三ヶ月ほど前に購入した場所と、谷底にもう一件別の家がある。
ex_1_en: I own two houses. I bought this place about three months ago and I own another place down in the valley.
meaning_story: The の is there to indicate that it is the difference of something. For example this is like saying "the separate ______" or "the different _____" or "another ______". 別 by itself just means separate, different, or another.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned. Move on to a 別の漢字, mmk?

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「私達、本当に別々の道を進まなきゃいけないの？」「ああ。でもまたすぐ会えるさ。」
ex_1_en: "Now, do we really have to go our separate ways?" "Yup, but I believe we’ll see each other again soon."
meaning_story: When you separate separate you're putting things off into their own areas. You're marking them off separately and individually.
reading_story: The reading is just the べつ reading you know, twice.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「あのヨットは素敵ですね。あなたのですか？」 「兄貴と共有なんですよ。」
ex_1_en: "That is a very nice yacht. Is that yours?" "I share ownership with my brother."
meaning_story: The things you together have are the things that are shared.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どうして神道には絶対的な神がいないのですか。
ex_1_en: Why doesn’t Shinto have an absolute God?
meaning_story: The way/road of the god(s) is, as you can probably guess, a big Japanese religion. There's two, and I'll give you a hint, this one isn't Buddhism (that would probably have the kanji for Buddha in it, no?). So what's the other big one? It's Shinto. If you're having trouble remembering this because you've never heard of it before, skip to the reading. The reading will help.
reading_story: The reading is a bit wonky. 神 should be no problem. 道 on the other hand is almost the one you learned (どう) but now it's とう for some reason. Perhaps the gods took away the dakuten to make it とう, who knows. All I know is that it's best not to question said gods. If you already know of Shinto in English, though, this reading should be really easy. If you don't, perhaps you can use this reading to help you to remember Shinto the religion.

ex_1_jp: よぉ、中々イケてる自分撮りじゃん。でも、お前なんで学校じゃなくて神社になんていたんだよ？
ex_1_en: Yo! Very cool selfie, but why were you in a shinto shrine instead of being at school?
meaning_story: A God company... think of this as "what 'company' does the god's work?" Well, the answer to that is a shrine, probably. In this case a Shinto Shrine because of the しん in the 神.
reading_story: But wait! 神 is read じん in this word for some reason. Darn them gods, always messing around, adding dakuten. Maybe this will help, though: Imagine yourself at a Shinto Shrine. You are praying to the Gods, asking for food. Out from the sky rains Ginger (じんじゃ). You are pelted with it and not sure if you should be happy or upset.

ex_1_jp: 相図をしたら、スクワットを始めて下さい。
ex_1_en: Start squatting on my signal.
meaning_story: A mutual diagram is one that's for everyone to see. It's a sign.
reading_story: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: 私は時々トフグホテルの最上階のレストランでトフグの記事を読むことが好きです。
ex_1_en: Sometimes I like to read Tofugu articles in the top-floor restaurant of the Tofugu hotel.
meaning_story: You know the single word 時, right? It means time. This is that twice. So you have one time, and you have another time. They are separate. Things don't happen in every of these times you have. They happen sometimes.
reading_story: The reading is the vocab word 時 twice, with the second one getting rendaku'd.
pitch_accent: トキꜜドキ *** トキドキ

part_of_speech: ADVERB, NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: コウイチはその特別古い車を運転してるから、有名人みたいに見えるね。
ex_1_en: Now that Koichi is driving that special, old car he looks like a celebrity.
meaning_story: Something that is special and separate from the rest is, well, special.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 見事な松の木ですね。
ex_1_en: It’s a splendid pine tree, isn’t it?
meaning_story: Every single thing you see is splendid. You saw it after all, so of course it's magnificent. Your eyes are so great that they make everything reflect you. And you're beautiful.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼が待ちぼうけを食らったと思わないように、明日の会議が中止になったことを伝えてあげてくれるかな？
ex_1_en: Could you please tell him tomorrow’s date has been cancelled so he won’t feel like he’s been stood up?
meaning_story: With 待ち you know you're waiting, but what's a ぼうけ? Turns out it's the long version of ボケ which means idiot. Basically, in this case you're a waiting idiot. Why? because you were stood up.
reading_story: The reading for 待ち comes right from the kanji (and also you've seen 待つ by now). So, you probably are able to read this word already!

ex_1_jp: 「ビジネスで成功したければ、型にはまらない考え方をしなさい」と言われて、カレー味の歯磨き粉を思いついたんだ。
ex_1_en: I created a curry flavored toothpaste when I was told, "if you want to be successful in business, you need to think outside the box."
meaning_story: When you become achievement, you have probably gained plenty of success.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 九時午後、明日の作戦を話したい。
ex_1_en: At 9PM I want to talk about our strategy for tomorrow.
meaning_story: When you make war, you're building it up like you'd build a building. You have to make strategy, you have to plan, you have to come up with awesome tactics.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「俺の戦車のタイヤ、どう？」「もう少し空気を入れるか、戦車用の履帯に換えた方がいいと思いますよ。」
ex_1_en: "How are the tires on my tank?" "I think you should either pump them up a lot more, or switch to tank treads."
meaning_story: A war car is probably a little more dangerous than the Honda you drive. No, a war car is a tank.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このフグの刺し身の味、最高だよ！まさにこれだって感じだね！
ex_1_en: The taste of this blowfish sashimi is amazing! Just what I wanted!
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You may have the ability to taste things now, but just wait until you get up there in age (あじ). You'll find that the tastes and flavors you once liked will become bland, and you'll need a lot of Sriracha to make things taste better.

ex_1_jp: お前本当に下手くそだな！初心者でもこんなに下手くそじゃねぇだろ。俺が最初にこのゲームをプレイした時は、お前よりずっと上手かったわ。
ex_1_en: You’re awful at this! Even a newbie couldn’t be that bad! When I played this game for the first time I was way better than you.
meaning_story: The most first thing is the first thing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: えっ、君が日本語学習クラブに参加するのは今回が初回なんだ？よし、みんな。彼は初心者だから手加減してあげようぜ。
ex_1_en: Oh, is this your first time attending our Japanese language club? Okay everyone, he’s a newbie, so let’s go easy on him.
meaning_story: The first of something you'll do several or many times is the first time.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: ADVERB, NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: えぇっ！あの試験で最低点を採ったの？参ったなぁ。
ex_1_en: Wow, I can’t believe you got the lowest score on the test. What a bummer!
meaning_story: The most low is the lowest. It's also what you call something when you think it's the worst or just plain terrible. Try yelling this out when you're disgusted about someone or something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: これは、西洋の妖怪です。
ex_1_en: That’s a Western ghost.
meaning_story: The Western styled West is still known as the West. The one everyone refers to over in Asia when they talk about Western countries in Europe and North America. This is the place you'll hear people say you're from if you live in Canada or something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 親指にタコができました。
ex_1_en: I’ve got a callus on my thumb.
meaning_story: Your parent finger is your thumb! It's bigger than your other fingers, so that means it's in charge too!
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too!

ex_1_jp: 向こうに指定された喫煙エリアがあるから、私じゃなくてそこに行って喫煙者がどれだけ臭いかについて文句を言った方がいいんじゃない。
ex_1_en: There is a designated smoking area over there, so you should go there and complain how stinky smokers are instead of just telling me.
meaning_story: When you determine and use your finger to point at someone or something, you're going to appoint them. Just imagine yourself determining who's the best for the job then pointing with your finger. That is who you will appoint. The する on the end makes it a verb, so 指定 would be "appointment" or "designation" or something along those lines. Cool how する works.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. For 指 you learned the kun'yomi. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You're going around appointing different people to different positions. Soon you realize that you're only picking females: "She (し) gets to go... She gets to go... She gets to go..." People are starting to think you're kind of sexist. All she she she and no he he he.

ex_1_jp: うわーー！！コウイチがとうとうアメリカ大統領になったよ。「為せば成るなさねばならぬ何事も、成らぬは人の為さぬなりけり」だね！
ex_1_en: Oh my God! Koichi finally became the President of the United States! Where there is a will, there is a way!
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means become so the vocab verb version would be to become.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are starting to become something else. You're transforming, but you're not sure what it is. First, you get fins... uh oh, something in the water. Then, you gain a tail and rubbery skin... hmm, something sea mammal-like. Oh, and then a huge horn flies out of your nose. You are going to become a narwhal (な).

ex_1_jp: コウイチは中々融通の利く男だ。
ex_1_en: Koichi is a pretty flexible man.
meaning_story: You know the kanji means profit. When you make it into a verb, though, it means to be effective. If you think about it, profiting things are effective, which is why this word is to be effective.
reading_story: What is so effective? Your special key (き) that can unlock anyone and anything's potential. Imagine putting it into a key slot in someone's back. Someone who's a good for nothing can't-do-anything is now an effective member of society! Go around using your key on other non-effective things and make them effective.

ex_1_jp: 私は明治神宮がとっても好きなの。森が、自然の森として育つように計算して造られているので、とても美しいし、自然的な空間なの。
ex_1_en: I really like the Meiji Shrine because its forest was carefully designed to mimic a natural forest and because of that it’s beautiful and has a very natural atmosphere.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means raise so the verb vocab version means to be raised. P.S. This word is for when you are being raised, not when you are doing the raising of someone. That's 育てる. You'll learn it later.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you were raised, you were raised completely on soda (そだ). That's all you drank. No water, no juice... just tons and tons of soda. Imagine this.

ex_1_jp: かしたお金がちゃんと返ってくると思ったら大まちがいよ。
ex_1_en: Thinking my money would be returned properly was a huge mistake.
ex_2_jp: 我に返ると、彼はトフグオフィスのソファーに横たわっていた。
ex_2_en: When he came to, he was lying on the sofa in the Tofugu office.
meaning_story: You hopefully know the word 返す, which means "to return" (as in, you're doing the direct action of returning something). This word, on the other hand, is the version where something just returns (and you're not doing the action of returning). Use the る to help you to remember this. る the Kangaroo is returned to you. You don't do any of the returning, it just happens or someone else does it. That's why this word means to be returned.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 返す, so as long as you know that you'll be able to apply it here to learn the reading of this word as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチ社長は今晩テレビで重大な決定を放送することになっている。
ex_1_en: President Koichi’s important announcement will be broadcast on television tonight.
meaning_story: You are going to release and send something out. Imagine this message going out through the sky to everyone around you. You are going to broadcast it to the world! The する is on there to make this noun a verb. Without the する it would be the noun "broadcast."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どんなに大変でも、私は自分の夢を追い続けるつもりなの。もし私の夫になりたいなら、そのことを理解してもらいたいの。
ex_1_en: I’ll follow my dream no matter how hard it is and I want you to understand that if you are going to be my husband.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means follow so the verb version is to follow (it's also to chase, because when you follow something you are chasing it too).
reading_story: You've learned this reading already, so you should know how to read this word!

ex_1_jp: 私の妹は、四月からトフグ学園に通うことになります。
ex_1_en: My younger sister will attend Tofugu Academy starting in April.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means pass through but we already know the word 通る which means to pass through. This word means a different kind of passing through, like how you pass through the halls of your school everyday. But we don't say to pass through school, we say to attend school, or to commute to school.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use one of the kun'yomi readings. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You live in the middle of three different school districts so you need to decide which of the three schools you want to attend. You decide you don't mind that you have to commute to the farthest of the three because their mascot is Wile E. Coyote (かよ). He's your favorite Looney Toon because he always has the energy to go back and forth after that road runner. (Don't get him confused with the other coyotes (かい), he's one of a kind!)

ex_1_jp: コウイチとビエトは、年に一度トフグオフィスで開かれる剣道の大会で、優れた腕前を披露しようと競い合いました。
ex_1_en: Koichi and Viet competed with each other to demonstrate their prowess at the annual Kendo competition held in the Tofugu office.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means compete so the verb vocab version means to compete.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to compete for kisses (きそ) from that boy/girl you like. Imagine yourself doing this, competing with a rival.

ex_1_jp: 現在、トフグチームはXXXという秘密のプロジェクトに集中し、全力で取りかかっています。
ex_1_en: Currently, Team Tofugu is concentrating on a secret project called XXX.
meaning_story: You collect and focus in on the middle. Really zoom in on it. When you do this, you're concentrating on this spot, thus making the meaning of this word to concentrate.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: クソワロタwwwこのテレビ番組クソほど面白いじゃねーかよ。俺の一番好きな番組に決定したわ。
ex_1_en: ROFL! This TV show is hilarious, man. I’ve decided that this is now my new favorite show.
meaning_story: A 決定 is a "decision." So, when you add する to it you're making it a verb, meaning this word means to decide.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 決定 with する added. Make sure you know 決定 and you'll know this word as well.

ex_1_jp: あるゲームにアクセスするために、ポートを開放する方法が知りたいんだ。
ex_1_en: I want to know how to open ports to give access to a game.
meaning_story: When you open then release, say, a door, you're flinging it open (because, well, you released it!). So, this word, with the する to make it an action, means to fling open.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: よっしゃ！完璧なシュートが決まったぜ！俺、ここの便所のバスケットゴール付きのゴミ箱めっちゃ好きだわ。
ex_1_en: Oh yeah! Nothing but net! I really love that this restroom’s trashcan has a basketball net on it.
meaning_story: *Ahem.* This is the place of convenience. What place above all others do you want to be convenient? Just in case, you know... that would be the toilet.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: おい、スティーヴ！お前はもうずいぶん長く日本に住んでいるんだから、そろそろ日本の習慣とかに合わせたほうがいいんじゃないのか？好き嫌いは止めて、魚も食べるようにしろよ！
ex_1_en: Hey, Steve. You’ve been living in Japan for a pretty long time now so don’t you think it’s time for you to adjust to Japanese customs? Stop being so picky and start eating fish.
meaning_story: You know that the alternative kanji meaning for 合 is join, which is what we're using here. The verb form of join is to join together, but we'll also call this to unify together.
reading_story: The reading comes from 合う, so if you know that reading you'll know this reading as well.

ex_1_jp: だれかが道端にソファを捨ててたんだけど、まだ使えそうだったから、拾ってきたよ。
ex_1_en: Someone had thrown a couch away on the side of the road, but it still looked useful, so I picked it up.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pick up so the verb vocab version is to pick up.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Nicely done!

ex_1_jp: ああ、あなたは色盲なんですか。ということは、どっちが赤色でどっちが緑色かを指すことはできませんね。
ex_1_en: Oh, you’re color blind, eh? So that means you can’t point at which one is red and which one is green, then.
meaning_story: The kanji means finger. So, if you "to finger" something, what are you doing? You're pointing. That's why this word means to point.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are pointing at something in fear. It is a saw (さ). Thing is, you're pointing at this saw with a missing finger. It just cut off your finger and you're freaking out, trying to point with a bloody non-finger.

ex_1_jp: 「もう少しワインを注いでいただけますか？」「もちろん。“そこまで”って言ってくださいね。」「あ、そこまで！それくらいで結構です。有難うございます。」
ex_1_en: "Can you pour some more wine for me, please?" "Sure. Just say when." "Yes! There! That’s perfect. Thank you."
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pour so the verb vocab version is to pour.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are going to pour some sauce (そそ).
pitch_accent: ソソク° *** ソソꜜク° *** ツク°

ex_1_jp: あなたって本当に落ち着いているし楽しいし、あなたと遊ぶのは最高だわ。しかも、私たち言い争ったこともまだ一度も無いわよね。それってすごくない？
ex_1_en: You are so chill. It’s great hanging out with you. You know what? We’ve never had an argument yet, either. That’s crazy, isn’t it?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conflict so the vocabulary means to quarrel or to compete (because when you're quarreling you're really competing with the other person for victory).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're starting to quarrel with your rival. You're punching each other in the faces, causing a huge scene, and making people call the cops on you. Because of your quarrel, you have both now been arrested (あらそ) and are now spending time in prison. This isn't the perfect reading, but it hopefully can get you to the correct reading with a few tries. Try to make the connection.
pitch_accent: アラカ°ꜜウ *** アラソꜜウ

ex_1_jp: あんたが私にアイスクリームをくれるなんて、本当に信じられないよ。あんたがそんなに優しいなんて今まで気付かなかったわ！
ex_1_en: I can’t believe you gave me your ice cream. I didn’t realize that you were so kind until now.
meaning_story: When you attach your energy (imagine someone suddenly looking up at something, attaching their energy to it), they have noticed or realized something. That's why this word means to realize or to notice. Don't confuse this with 気を付けて which is similar in that it has all the same kanji. It's just used a little different. Try to remember the difference before moving on.
reading_story: The readings come from the 気 kanji (which you know) and the word 付く which you should know by now. Combine these together and you have the ability to read this word. Take note that the 付く part is rendaku'd, though, so it is a tiny bit different.

ex_1_jp: フグを海に放すといつも、泳いで逃げちゃって、私が呼んでも知らんぷりするの。どうすれば逃げないように教えることができるのかしら。
ex_1_en: Every time I let Fugu loose in the sea, he swims off and when I call him he doesn’t listen. What should I do to teach him to not run away?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means release so the verb vocab version is to release.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine you are going to release something. It is a 花 (はな). You release it from your hand and it falls, hitting the ground in slow motion. You have the power to release and you are doing the releasing (versus 放れる where something is just released). You can remember this because even though you did the releasing of the flower, you're going to sue the pavement company for breaking your flower. It's all a big scam you're running.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは、彼らを見送った後、どっと涙の雨を流した。
ex_1_en: Koichi burst into tears after seeing them off.
meaning_story: You know the words 見る and 送る by now, hopefully. Here you're "seeing" the "sending." You're seeing someone off, so this verb is to see off.
reading_story: The readings come from the vocab words 見る and 送る. Make sure you know those and you'll know this word's reading as well.
pitch_accent: ミオクル *** ミオクꜜル

ex_1_jp: オレは家にいるおまえの新妻のことを考えて言ってるだけだよ。分かるか？彼女がお前の死で一生苦しむことになっても、本当にいいのか？だから、自殺なんてするなって。
ex_1_en: I’m just thinking about your new wife at home. Okay? Do you really want to make her suffer from your death for the rest of her life? So, don’t commit suicide.
meaning_story: You learned the word 苦しい (hopefully) in level 9. That word means suffering. So, if you make that into a verb version, you have to suffer.
reading_story: The reading comes from 苦しい, so as long as you're on top of that word, this word should be readable for you as well.

ex_1_jp: お父様とお母様にも、よろしくお伝えくださいね。
ex_1_en: Please tell your mother and father I send my regards.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transmit so the verb vocab version is to transmit.
reading_story: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. Time to transmit you to the next lesson.
pitch_accent: ツタエル *** ツタエꜜル

ex_1_jp: 「金曜日、Tofuguの記事を読みに来ませんか？」「行きたいんですが、金曜日の夜は遅くまで働かないといけないんです。」「それは残念ですね。それでは、また今度。」
ex_1_en: "Would you like to come read Tofugu articles on Friday?" "I’d like to but I have to work late Friday night." "That’s too bad. Maybe some other time."
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means work so the verb vocab version means to work.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you are as mad as a hatter you'll need to work very hard to regain your sanity. You know The Hatter from Alice in Wonderland? Imagine how hard he would have to work to be considered "normal".

ex_1_jp: フグは物凄く走るの速いよ。海ではあまり良いスイマーじゃなかったってことと、大学に入るまで陸上での競技に出たことがなかったてのは、本当に意外だよ。
ex_1_en: Fugu is a really fast runner. The surprising thing is, he was never a good swimmer in the sea and never raced on land until he was in college.
meaning_story: Something outside your normal idea of how things work will come as unexpected to you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 早い者勝ちなんだだから、急ごうよ！あのフグのキーホルダーすごく欲しいんだよね！この機会を逃したくないんだ。
ex_1_en: It’s first come, first served. Let’s get a move on! I really want the Fugu keychain. I don’t want to miss out on this chance.
meaning_story: You've hopefully seen 勝つ by now, which means "to win." This is a nouny version of that. So, what's the noun version of "to win?" It's a win or a victory.
reading_story: The reading comes from 勝つ. So as long as you have some understanding of that reading, you should be able to read this one as well.

ex_1_jp: 戦争が始まる前に、腹筋を六つに割りたい。
ex_1_en: I want to get a six pack before the war begins.
meaning_story: You have war and conflict. Of course, conflict comes with war, so this word just means war.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 波にゆらゆら揺られるのが気持ちいい。
ex_1_en: The rocking of the waves to and fro feels good.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You jump on a wave and ride around the world on it. It doesn't drop you off anywhere, until you reach a certain location: Vietnam (なみ). You jump off the wave and look at Vietnam. Imagine the most Vietnamese things you can think of to help you to make this wave-Vietnam association.

ex_1_jp: 早く洋服を着ないと、学校に遅れるわよ。
ex_1_en: You should get dressed really quickly or you’ll be late for school.
meaning_story: Western style clothes is just Western Clothing (or Western style clothes). We're talking things that aren't kimonos, etc.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ええっ！あそこのレストランで洋食ランチセットを食べたの？ははは。どおりでまだお腹がいっぱいなはずだわ。
ex_1_en: Oh, did you eat the western-style lunch-set at that restaurant? Hahaha. No wonder you still feel full.
meaning_story: The Western eats are Western food. Mmmm, 'dem hamburgers.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私の家は家具を完璧に洋風に揃えているので、畳はありません。
ex_1_en: My house is entirely furnished in the Western style, so there are no tatami mats.
meaning_story: Remember how 風 can mean "style" as in 和風? Well, this is now Western style style, more simply put as Western style.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の部屋は六畳の洋室で、壁の色は私の好きな水色です。
ex_1_en: My room is a ten meters squared, western style room with light blue painted walls, which is my favorite color.
meaning_story: A Western style room is a Western style room. We're talking something that's not a tatami mat filled room. Good to know this word if you're staying in hotels or ryokans and prefer not to sleep on a futon, etc.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は、週末はコスプレイヤーとして活動しています。
ex_1_en: She’ll be an active cosplayer this weekend.
meaning_story: The lively moves you make are actions. They're the activities you do every day to stay fit and healthy!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 空港で借りた車の中に、パスポートを忘れた気がする。
ex_1_en: I think I left my passport in the car that I’d rented at the airport.
meaning_story: Put aside your steampunk blimp fantasies for a moment. A sky harbor is an airport, nothing more.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼は大酒飲みだが、赤ワインが苦手だ。
ex_1_en: He’s a heavy drinker but he doesn’t like red wine.
meaning_story: You've seen 飲む, so you know this has to do with drinking alcohol. Someone who's known as someone who drinks alcohol is an alcoholic.
reading_story: The readings are the vocab words お酒 and 飲む combined together into one. You can guess it's a kun'yomi reading because of the み on the end of 飲, which should make you think back to vocab words that use these kanji and the kun'yomi readings. If you can do that, you can read this word (and many others, probably!).
pitch_accent: サケノꜜミ *** サケノミꜜ

ex_1_jp: ああ、母さん、そうだよ…。俺が話をしている全員が俺の彼女だよ。
ex_1_en: Yes, mom. Yes... Everyone I talk to is my girlfriend.
meaning_story: All members means all members. This is also a fancy way to say everybody.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチはTofugu動物園で、100人の重要人物のためのパーティーを開催した。私は何故招待されなかったのか分からない。私も彼にとっての重要人物の一人だと思っていたのだが…。
ex_1_en: Koichi hosted a party at the Tofugu Zoo for 100 VIPs. I don’t know why I wasn’t invited. I thought I was a VIP to him, too.
meaning_story: A moving thing... think about the "things" that move. Technically it could be a lot of things (aka basically anything), but in this case we are talking about moving living things. We won't include humans, because humans are too good to be called things. This refers to animals instead.
reading_story: The reading is all on'yomi. Unfortunately, you learned the kun'yomi reading for 物, so let's use a mnemonic to help you to remember the ぶつ portion: You are looking at all these animals moving around, but for some reason you can only focus on their butts (ぶつ) because you're some kind of animal ... *ahem* ... lover. Stop staring at those horse butts, the farmer will get upset.

ex_1_jp: 自動販売機の下から子犬の鳴き声が聞こえるんです。
ex_1_en: I hear a puppy barking under the vending machine.
meaning_story: The chirp voice is a sound an animal makes. Sure, it works for birds (which chirp), but it also works with most other animals as well. So, we call this an animal cry.
reading_story: The readings are those that you learned with the kanji. 声 gets changed to ごえ, though, so take note of that in your head. Perhaps you can imagine an animal that does a "GOEEEEE" cry.
pitch_accent: ナキコ°ꜜエ *** ナキコ°エ

ex_1_jp: 私は、村上春樹の気障で気取った文章があまり好きではありません。
ex_1_en: I don’t like Haruki Murakami’s cheesy and pompous writing style very much.
meaning_story: The writing chapter on its own is more like an article or something like that. Even if it's a sentence long.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「サーモン！フグは五回も浮気したんだよ。そんな男のこと、信じちゃダメだってば。」「分かってるんだけど、でも、彼、私がいないと生きていけないって言うの。」「じゃあ、もう、勝手にすれば！」
ex_1_en: "Salmon! Fugu cheated on you five times. Never trust such a guy." "I know… but he says he can’t live without me." "Well, suit yourself then!"
meaning_story: The hand (or person, as you know 手 often refers to a person) that wins gets to do as one pleases.
reading_story: The reading for this is weird. It's all kun'yomi, which luckily you've seen before, but still strange. I guess when you do as one pleases you can read kanji however you want, in this case the kun'yomi readings. Do note that there's a small っ in there before, presumably to connect the two readings of the two kanji together.

ex_1_jp: 牛乳は悪くなっていたけど、俺は気にしなかった。
ex_1_en: The milk went bad, but I didn’t care.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of bad? It's also bad.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Do you know how in the Mario universe all the bad versions are called "WARU"? For example: "WARUIJI" and "WARIO." That's because they are bad. They come from this kanji. So, if you ever need to remember this reading, just think back to Wario and Waruigi.

ex_1_jp: お前、本当に善人と悪人を区別することが可能だと思っているのか？
ex_1_en: Do you really think it’s possible to differentiate between good people and bad people?
meaning_story: A bad person is a bad person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning_story: Field Sphere! The greatest sport to grace this earth since a very similar (aka the same) sport, baseball. Think about it, you play on a field and you use a little sphere. Awesome!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「何か冷たい飲み物はいかがですか？」「それでは、牛乳パックを二本頂けますか？」
ex_1_en: "Would you like something cold to drink?" "Well then, could I have two cartons of milk?"
meaning_story: A thing you drink is a beverage.
reading_story: These are both the kun'yomi readings. You've learned them already, so you already know how to read this word!

ex_1_jp: 私の父は血族じゃないが、まだ本当の父を考える。
ex_1_en: My dad isn’t a blood relative but I still think of him as my real dad.
meaning_story: Your tribe's blood (lots of inbreeding) are the blood of your relatives. These are blood relatives.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ケツꜜゾク *** ケツゾク

ex_1_jp: 親分にバレたら大目玉を食らうぞ。
ex_1_en: The boss will chew us out if we let it slip.
meaning_story: Who is part parent to you? Your boss! They make it so you can take care of yourself by paying you, don't they? They'll break the legs of someone who crosses you. But they won't help you get back to sleep after you have nightmares. So they're only part like a parent.
reading_story: This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for 親 and the on'yomi reading for 分. You've learned both of these so you should be able to read this already!
pitch_accent: オꜜヤブン *** オヤꜜブン

ex_1_jp: 水中で息はしないでください。
ex_1_en: Please do not breathe underwater.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You smell someone's icky (いき) breath. It's gross. Your skin crawls and your eyes roll back in your head from the icky, icky smell. You might die.

ex_1_jp: 学校卒業後に商売を始めたんですが、すぐに商売をすることは簡単ではないことを学びました。
ex_1_en: After leaving school I went into business for myself, but I soon learned that running a business is no easy task.
meaning_story: A place that sells merchandise is a business.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn the on'yomi for 売 with the kanji, but you've seen it before so you should have no problem with this kanji. Just remember that you "buy" stuff when you do business and commerce and you'll be fine.

ex_1_jp: 私の一番の心配事は、町に降り落ちる火山灰です。
ex_1_en: My biggest worry is volcanic ash falling over the city.
meaning_story: The actions and things you have to 心配 about are your cares and worries.
reading_story: The reading is the reading of 心配 (which you've hopefully gotten down okay by now) and 事 using the (こと) reading. It is rendaku'd, as well, so beware of the ごと (just another 心配事, ammiright?).
pitch_accent: シンパイコ°ト *** シンパイコ°トꜜ

ex_1_jp: 虫歯がいっぱいあるんだけど、歯科保険が無いので、治療代を捻出することができないんだ。
ex_1_en: I have so many cavities but I don’t have any dental insurance and I can’t afford to get them treated.
meaning_story: A tooth bug... Luckily, it's not some bug living in your tooth, though you can see why someone might think this is what happens. A tooth with a "bug" in it is a tooth with a cavity.
reading_story: The readings are both kun'yomi, but those are the readings you learned with these kanji. Notice that は turns to ば, though. Presumably this is because you might yell out "BAH!" when you find out you have a cavity.

ex_1_jp: まじで？君もその本読んでるの？俺、昨日ちょうど第二章読み終わったところなんだけど。もしそれより先に進んでるなら、何も言わないでね。
ex_1_en: No way! Are you reading that book too? I’ve just finished chapter two. Don’t tell me anything if you’re farther than me.
meaning_story: The ordinal prefix number two chapter has a much simpler way of describing it, which is chapter two.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: うちの家族は貧乏だが陽気だ。
ex_1_en: My family is poor but cheerful.
meaning_story: If you have a spirit of sunshine you're a really cheerful person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 宮沢賢治の童話「祭の晩」は、私が子供の頃大好きなお話でした。
ex_1_en: Miyazawa Kenji’s fairy tale "Night of the Festival" was my favorite story when I was a child.
meaning_story: Don't think of this as a juvenile talk. Think of 話 the vocab word, which means "story." If you do that, you get a "juvenile story." What's a juvenile story? It's a children's story.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本語の音読みと訓読みの違いは何ですか？
ex_1_en: What’s the difference between the Chinese reading and the Japanese reading in the Japanese language?
meaning_story: The sound reading. What could this be...? Wait a sec, think to Japanese and kanji. What's the reading that uses sounds from another place, specifically China? That's the Chinese reading, aka the on'yomi. Sounds familiar?
reading_story: The reading for 音 is the 音読み. 読み uses the kun'yomi, though, strangely. Way to mess up the one word that should be all on'yomi, Japan. Way. To. Go.

ex_1_jp: 何かおもしろい都市伝説を知っていますか？
ex_1_en: Do you know any interesting urban legends?
meaning_story: A metropolis city is a city. When you're referring to just a plain ol' city, sans name, you can use this word.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: こんな田舎じゃなく、私は都会で働きたいのよ。
ex_1_en: I want to work in the city, not the country.
meaning_story: When metropolises meet they become a city. Usually a nice big one.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 僕がハワイに行くのは、寒さから逃れるためだけではなく家族に会うためでもあります。
ex_1_en: I’m going to Hawaii not only to escape the cold, but also to see my family.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cold? It's cold.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji (Samurai (さむ)). Remember?

ex_1_jp: あの会社員は麻薬所持で逮捕された。
ex_1_en: That employee got busted for drug possession.
meaning_story: A "company" (会社) member is someone who works at a company. This is a company employee. There are many of these in Japan. Most of them are drunk.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あいつの話には落ちが無いんだよな。
ex_1_en: His speech doesn’t have much of a conclusion.
meaning_story: When you're talking or writing a paper, the part that falls at the end is the conclusion.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: おお、これいいんじゃねえ？めちゃくちゃいい大根だよ。お前も、一本欲しいか？
ex_1_en: Hey, check it out! These are really nice Japanese radishes. Do you want one of these?
meaning_story: This will be easier if you've seen or heard of daikon before. It's a really big root in the ground that's pretty delicious. It's known as daikon in the grocery stores for the most part, though occasionally you'll see it as Japanese radish instead.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 大 uses the だい reading because if you try to put the whole thing in your mouth at once you'll probably end up choking and dieing.

ex_1_jp: 魚たちが、親や兄弟、高校時代の友人たちとの深い繋がりを保っていることが多いって、本当ですか？
ex_1_en: Is it true that fish tend to maintain a deep connection to their parents, siblings, and high school friends?
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of deep? It's also deep.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. Because the reading sounds just like a dirty word, and there may be innocent children about, I'll let you come up with your own mnemonic for this one. Maybe someone pushes you into a deep hole that will surely kill you so you yell something out as you fall down it?

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: サーモンと俺は、光が到達できる海の最深部に位置するロマンチックな秘密の洞穴で、結婚式をあげた。
ex_1_en: Salmon and I had our wedding ceremony in a romantic hidden cave located at the deepest part of the ocean that light can still reach.
meaning_story: The most deep is the deepest.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼はただ不良に憧れてるだけだと思うよ。絶対に本物の不良にはならないね。だって、歯医者さんに行くのですら怖がってるんだよ！
ex_1_en: I think he’s just a wannabe delinquent. I doubt he’ll be a real one because he’s still afraid of going to the dentist.
meaning_story: You know that a 医者 is a doctor. So what is a tooth doctor? A dentist. Seriously, don't forget to floss. 歯医者 hate when you forget to floss.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 昼に食べたラーメンをまだ消化しきっていない。
ex_1_en: I haven’t finished digesting the ramen I ate for lunch.
meaning_story: What is something that will first extinguish something and then change it? One thing I can think of is your body. It takes in food, extinguishes it in your stomach, then changes it into things your body can use (and then excrete). That's why this "extinguish-change" process is your digestion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: うわ！君のお兄さんって、君の二倍の体重があるんだね！
ex_1_en: Wow! Your brother weighs twice as much as you, huh?
meaning_story: Something that is two times is double (or it is just simply two times. Of course, this all works with things like 三倍, 百倍, and 四十二倍 as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 運転手は大丈夫だったみたいだけど、車は事故でめちゃくちゃになっていたよ。
ex_1_en: The driver seemed okay but his car was totaled in the accident.
meaning_story: You know that 運転 has to do with driving, right? And you know that 手 often has to do with a person doing something in words like these. So, a person who does driving is what? A driver.
reading_story: The reading is all on'yomi, because it's jukugo. You should know the on'yomi reading of 手 by now just by seeing similar word patterns to this one.

ex_1_jp: この会社の社員は、全員奇抜だ。
ex_1_en: The employees in this company are all weird and wonderful.
meaning_story: The company members are the employees and the staff.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: インドには多様な民族がいますが、みんながみんなカレーを食べるのでしょうか。
ex_1_en: India has a lot of ethnic diversity but I wonder if all of them still eat curry.
meaning_story: A peoples tribe (or tribe of peoples) is a group that all stick together. They are one single ethnic group. What's your 民族?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その悪女は息をのむほど美しかった。僕は彼女に夢中だった。
ex_1_en: The evil woman took my breath away. I was crazy about her.
meaning_story: A bad woman is an evil woman. Surprisingly, "mother in law" is not one of the meanings for this word.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は読書よりも運動の方が好きなので、本も、新聞も、雑誌も読みません。
ex_1_en: I read neither books, nor newspapers, nor magazines because I like exercising more than reading.
meaning_story: When you carry your movements (or carry something along with your movements, like weights, for example) you are doing exercise. Speaking of which, perhaps you've been studying kanji a little too much lately. Time to get up and do some squats.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ウォール・ストリートは常にトップレベルの人材を求めていますが、コウイチならきっとそこでも期待に応えられると思います。
ex_1_en: Wall Street always needs top-level talent and I’m pretty sure that Koichi will be able to live up to expectations.
meaning_story: For a period of time you have to wait. During this waiting period, you are expecting or anticipating something to happen. Waiting, expecting, waiting, expecting...
reading_story: The reading is on'yomi, so you should be okay with 期. For 待, though, a mnemonic: Why are you waiting and what are you expecting? You're waiting for help, because someone has tied you up. If you don't get help, you'll get hit by the train that's coming, so expect away!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「聞いてよ。最初は、お姉ちゃんの彼氏だから、クリスと仲良くしようとしてただけだったの。でも、次々にいろんなことが重なって、知らない間に、お…落ち葉を一緒に熊手で集めてたの。」「ロ…ローラったら、なんてことなの。」「ケーラ、待って。一度だけよ。それに、私は何とも思わなかったわ。」
ex_1_en: "Look, when it started I was just trying to be nice to Chris because he was my sister’s boyfriend. Then, one thing led to another and before I knew it, we were... raking fallen leaves together." "L-Laura. Why would you do that?" "Kayla, wait. We only did it once. It didn’t mean anything to me."
meaning_story: The leaf that falls are fallen leaves.
reading_story: The reading for this one is a bit strange. You'll have to pull from your knowledge of 落ちる and use that for the first half. Then, 葉 is rendaku'd to ば. Because, when a leaf falls, Scrooge says "BAH! Humbug!" (probably because he's losing money).

ex_1_jp: 今度、俺の日本への家族旅行のことを君に話したいな。
ex_1_en: I wanna tell you about my family vacation in Japan some time.
meaning_story: Your house tribe is your family. They live in the same house as you and they're part of your "tribe." This is closer than family, though (depending on how you look at family). This is your immediate family because these are the people you live with and give birth to, etc.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本女性と比べると、外国の女性は家庭の時間と仕事の時間を分けることには、かなり厳格です。
ex_1_en: Compared to Japanese women, foreign women tend to be pretty strict about separating family time and working time.
meaning_story: This is a strange one. Your house garden is your family. Why? Think of your house as a garden. It grows things, like children. It also grows adults, too. It grows a family.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 家族はみんな父親のこと嫌ってるから、父はいつも一人裏通りで夕飯を食べてるわ。
ex_1_en: My father eats his dinner by himself in the alley because everyone in my family hates him.
meaning_story: Your father parent is your father.
reading_story: The reading here is pretty weird. It's all kun'yomi. My guess is this translates literally to "father parent" (two different words, therefore uses the other readings). You should know the readings of these two separate words, though. It is 父 (ちち) and 親 (おや).

ex_1_jp: 日本の多くのお祭は、仏教や神道と結びついています。
ex_1_en: Many Japanese festivals have connections to Buddhism or Shintoism.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Sounds like someone deserves to go to the kanji festival this year, right? Right? P.S. You'll also see this word read as 祭り with the り on the end. Both are correct. Both are confusing. Just know when you see them they're the same thing.

ex_1_jp: 「荷物はどこに置いたらいいかな？」「一階でも、二階でも、下でも、どこでも。あなたの好きなところに置いてくれていいよ。」「わかったわ。有難う。」
ex_1_en: "Where should I put my stuff?" "Here, the first floor, the second floor, anywhere. You can put them any place you’d like." "Okay. Thank you."
meaning_story: The one floor is the first floor (or floor one). Pretty simple. Unless you're British, that is. For you this is the ground floor!
reading_story: The reading is on'yomi because it's a jukugo kanji. Be careful of the 一 though. It gets shortened and has a little っ in there.

ex_1_jp: あきら入社するまで、ヒロは五年続けて、社内で売り上げ第一位だった。
ex_1_en: Hiro had been the top sales person in the company for five consecutive years until Akira joined the company.
meaning_story: The ordinal number prefix one rank. Basically, this means "first rank" or first place.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今や、コウイチは一流社会の仲間入りだ。たくさんのセレブに会ったり、シャンパンパーティにもすぐ行き始めるだろう。
ex_1_en: Now that Koichi is a part of the upperclass. He will meet a bunch of celebrities and start going to champagne parties soon.
meaning_story: This is a weird one. You have one stream. This is first rate stream material we have here, though. If you think about it, if you only have one stream (instead of a ton of streams), you can put all your effort and energy into it. When you do that, you're making sure it is a first rate stream in terms of quality and anything else.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このアパートの十三階に住んでいます。
ex_1_en: I live on the thirteenth floor of this apartment.
meaning_story: You know that the kanji refers to a floor (as in the "fifth floor"). This word represents the version that comes after a number, shown with a 〜. Essentially, this has the same meaning as the kanji you learned, making it nice and easy.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Don't type in the 〜 or you'll get it wrong!
pitch_accent: カꜜイ *** キザꜜハシ *** キザハシ

ex_1_jp: 引っ越しって、色々事務手続きがあって結構面倒くさい上に、対応の悪い担当者とかもいたりするよね。でも、今回の引っ越しで最悪だったのは、引っ越しの日にエレベーターが故障中だったことだよ。俺の部屋、四十二階なのに。
ex_1_en: It’s pretty annoying that there’s a lot of bureaucratic red tape involved in moving, and to make things worse, sometimes the person in charge has an attitude problem. However, the worst part of my moving this time was the elevator was out of service when I moved in and my room was on the 42nd floor.
meaning_story: You know that 四十二 means "forty two." So, as long as you know floor you'll know this means forty-second floor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 美しい庭があるが、近所の人の鶏は花を食べておく。
ex_1_en: I have a beautiful garden but my neighbor’s chickens keep eating my flowers.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add the meaning yard to your memory bank as well, if you'd like.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look at your garden. It doesn't meet your expectations so you decide it's time to get a newer (にわ) garden. Tear it all down, folks! Getting a newer garden, here!

ex_1_jp: 正月の集まりに弟が彼女を連れてきやがった。
ex_1_en: My younger brother brought his girlfriend to our New Years get together.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji gather, so it means gathering.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
pitch_accent: アツマリꜜ *** アツマリ *** アツマꜜリ

ex_1_jp: 大学院生ってどんなことをするんですか？
ex_1_en: What kinds of things do graduate students do?
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 大学院 means "graduate school" and 大学生 means "college student?" Well smush them together and you have a graduate student!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 不思議な船が港に漂着した。
ex_1_en: There was a mysterious ship drifting in the harbor.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This is a single kanji with no okurigana, so it's using the kun'yomi reading. You don't know this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go down to the harbor and speak the secret password me natto (みなと) to buy some fresh natto. Imagine the salty air hitting your face as you whisper, "me natto." Now eat that yummy natto by the water! Mmmm!

ex_1_jp: きつい言い方に聞こえることは分かってるんだけど、つまらない言い訳はしたくないの。
ex_1_en: I understand it sounds harsh, but I’m up to my neck with lame excuses.
meaning_story: You've seen 聞く by now hopefully. This is similar, but instead of meaning "to hear" it means hearable (or to be audible). Just think about that こえ hanging off there as the voice you can hear.
reading_story: The reading comes from 聞く, so if you know the reading of that word, you can apply it here.

ex_1_jp: 広島と長崎に投下された原爆は、一瞬で十万人以上の人々の命を奪った。
ex_1_en: The atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki instantly killed more than 100,000 people.
meaning_story: The wide island... this isn't helpful on its own, but this wide island is Hiroshima (heard of it?). When you do the reading it will make more sense.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of both of these which is what you learned with the individual kanji. Just make sure you know those readings and you'll be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: 私の父も母も温泉が好きじゃありません。
ex_1_en: My dad and mom both don’t like hot springs.
meaning_story: A warm spring (like the water kind of spring) is a hot spring. These are really nice. You should go to them in Japan.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お湯を沸かしてくれないか？
ex_1_en: Could you boil some water?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: クソ暑いし蒸し蒸しするしたまんねぇな！この暑さでは寝られないよ。プールに行こうぜ！
ex_1_en: It’s too hot and humid! I can’t sleep in this heat. Let’s go to the pool!
meaning_story: This is the adjective form of hot... but we're going to call it hot weather. Why? Because there's a difference between something that's hot and the weather or atmosphere being hot. This is that kind of hot, as in..."Damn, man, it's hot out here!"
reading_story: This uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji, so you're good to go here!

ex_1_jp: あいにく今、その質問に答えられる者がいないのですが、もしインターネットをお持ちなら利息のレートはそちらでもご確認頂けますよ。
ex_1_en: I’m afraid there is no one here who can answer your question right now, but you can also check your interest rate online, if you have the Internet.
meaning_story: You receive profit at every breath. What kind of profit is this? It's interest. As time goes by and as you take more breaths you gain more bank interest.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この島で一週間生活をしてもらいます。
ex_1_en: I’m going to have you live on that island for a week.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 上司へのメールに顔文字を使うんじゃない！
ex_1_en: Don’t use kaomoji when you’re emailing a superior!
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 文字 can mean "characters?" Well make a face out of those characters and you've made a kaomoji! ʅ(◔౪◔ ) ʃ
reading_story: This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for 顔 added to the jukugo word 文字 that you already learned. You've learned these readings before, so reading this word should be nice and easy!

ex_1_jp: 母親に、既婚女性か未婚女性かで着物の種類が異なると教えてもらいました。
ex_1_en: My mom told me that married women and unmarried women wear different kimonos.
meaning_story: The things you wear are your clothes. Oh, and Japanese clothes count too. We're talking kimonos.
reading_story: The reading is a bit strange using kun'yomi readings. Lucky for you it's the readings you learned with the kanji already, so go put on that kimono of yours and relax at the 温泉 for a bit.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは本日は既に京都へ発ってしまいました。明日の朝一番に折り返しお電話をさせましょうか？
ex_1_en: Koichi has already left for Kyoto today. Shall I have him call you back first thing tomorrow morning?
meaning_story: The capital metropolis back in the day was kyoto. Now of course the capital is Tokyo, but kanji doesn't know this. That's why Kyoto is the capital metropolis!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「もし終電に乗り遅れたら、いつでも電話してくれていいよ。」「有難う。覚えておくよ。」
ex_1_en: "If you ever miss the last train, you can always call me." "Thanks, I’ll keep that in mind."
meaning_story: We've seen a few times where 電 refers to a train. They're big deals, after all, and use a ton of electricity. So, the end train for this word would refer to the last train.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: これで運を使い果たしちゃったかも。
ex_1_en: I might have run out of luck.
meaning_story: This takes the luck meaning from the kanji. Think of it this way: If you're "carrying" you're going to create your own luck. Now nobody will mess with you, kanji gangstah. You carry guns and have a ton of luck because of it.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji! How... shall I say... luck-filled?

ex_1_jp: 日本文学の本流と言って、最初に思い浮かぶのは誰ですか？
ex_1_en: When you say mainstream Japanese literature, who is the first author that comes to mind?
meaning_story: The origin stream, that's where everything comes from. That is the mainstream.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 会員カードはお持ちですか？
ex_1_en: Do you have a membership card?
meaning_story: If you meet enough members you will become a member yourself!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼、私に自分は商人だって言ってたんだけど、でも実は貧乏なホームレスで、仕事はなんと空き缶収集だったの。
ex_1_en: He told me that he was a shopkeeper, but I found out that he was actually a poor homeless man who supports himself by collecting trash from garbage cans.
meaning_story: A merchandise person is a merchant. You want to buy something or you just looking?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: アキュꜜード *** アキꜜンド *** ショꜜーニン

ex_1_jp: 環境難民となった熊たちは、深夜、新しい国で食べ物を探すために、国境を越えた。
ex_1_en: The environmental refugee bears crossed the border late in the night to find something to eat in a new country.
meaning_story: The deep night is the middle of the night. It doesn't get any deeper than that before you start coming out of the night to start the next day.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「ごめんなさい。明日のランチ、キャンセルしなくちゃいけなくなったの。母親がちょっと体調崩しちゃって。」 「大したことないわ。また今度、会いましょう。それより、お母様、早く良くなるといいわね。」
ex_1_en: "I’m sorry but I have to cancel lunch tomorrow. My mother got sick." "It’s no big deal. Let’s meet another time. I hope your mom gets well soon."
meaning_story: The mother parent is the mother.
reading_story: The reading for this is strange. It's the kun'yomi vocab reading, probably because the literal translation is "mother parent" and therefore consists of a couple words combined together into one concept. So, make sure you know the separate word readings of 母 and 親. If you do, you should be able to read this too.

ex_1_jp: 「登山に行くってのはどう？」「さあ、どうしようかなあ。」
ex_1_en: "How about we go mountain climbing?" "Well, I don’t know about that."
meaning_story: Climb a mountain. That is mountain climbing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note this uses the alternative と reading, not to be confused with とう (actually, very confusing, sorry!). Just imagine you cut your toe off with an ice pick while mountain climbing. You know it's a short と because your toe is now short. And さん becomes ざん thanks to our old friend rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 根気よく日本語の勉強を続けていれば、いつかはペラペラになれるさ。
ex_1_en: Keep studying Japanese patiently and you’ll be fluent someday.
meaning_story: The root of your energy. You have to dig deep into your energy, all the way to the origin and source of it, to have enough patience to deal with this dumb kid who's eating away at your not-root energy. It's all you have, and you need to use it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 期間限定で販売しています。
ex_1_en: They are on sale for a limited time.
meaning_story: A period of time interval is still a period or interval of time.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 残念ながら園芸の才能は無いんだけど、植物を育てるのは好きなので、彼女が一週間近くも植物に水をやるのを怠ったっていうのはちょっと信じられません。
ex_1_en: Unfortunately, I don’t have a green thumb but I like to grow plants and I can’t believe she neglected to water her plants for almost a week.
meaning_story: Plant things are plants or vegetation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You'll need to remember the 物 reading as ぶつ, though. Why? Because you like looking at plant butts. You get off on it. You're weird like that. Imagine this.

ex_1_jp: 君はお昼までに屋根の雪を取り除いて下さい。
ex_1_en: Please clear the snow off the roof by noon.
meaning_story: The root of your roof is still your roof. If it helps, imagine roots growing out of your roof. They protect you from the rain.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi readings. The kun'yomi for 根 is ね. For a mnemonic, we'll use the sound a horse makes, neigh (ね). Why is the horse neigh-ing? It's stuck on the roof.

ex_1_jp: 彼は素敵な人だと思うかもしれないが、根がひどい男なのだ。
ex_1_en: You might think he’s a great person but he’s really a horrible man at heart.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: The root you have is a ne-root, used to perform necromancy (it's why it's called a ne-root). Grind it up and use it on some dead bodies to bring them back to life (in your imagination, of course).

ex_1_jp: クリスティンはベーコンを食べませんが、この問題の根本はどこにあると思いますか？
ex_1_en: Kristen doesn’t eat bacon, where do you think the root of this problem lies?
meaning_story: The root origin is the root of something. Possibly even more root than root, but we'll stick with root.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Careful, 本 is ぽん, which is a weird rendaku.
pitch_accent: コンポン *** コンポꜜン

ex_1_jp: あなたが悲しい気持ちの時は、お父さんも私も幸せじゃないですよ。
ex_1_en: When you feel sad, neither your dad nor myself are happy.
