meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of sad? It's sad, sadly.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. No reason to be sad about that!

ex_1_jp: 祖父は海軍の船員でした。
ex_1_en: My grandfather was a sailor in the Navy.
meaning_story: A member of a boat is called a sailor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 学期末試験は三月なので、まだまだ勉強する時間はたっぷりあります。
ex_1_en: Final exams are held in March so there is still plenty of time to prepare.
meaning_story: The study period of time isn't the pitiful amount of time you spend studying. It's something much bigger: the school term. Ugh, how much longer is this study period of time???
reading_story: The reading is on'yomi because it's a jukugo word but がく gets shortened to がっ, so be careful. Maybe you just wish the school term would get shorter which is why you shortened がく like that?

ex_1_jp: 毎日午後に二階にある同じ教室に行って、英語を二時間教えます。
ex_1_en: Every afternoon I go to the same classroom on the second floor and teach two hours of English.
meaning_story: The two floor is the second floor. Going up!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ええっと、レジの順番待ちの列に並んでいる時に、ある店員さんが「万引きです！捕まえて！」と叫ぶのが聞こえたので、彼を捕まえたんです。
ex_1_en: Well, while standing in the checkout line I heard one of the salespeople yell, "Shoplifter! Grab him!" so I grabbed him.
meaning_story: The shop member is someone who is a "member" (aka employed by) the shop. This is the shop staff.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: わぁ！あんたの尻尾が私より短いなんて、知らなかったわ。
ex_1_en: Wah! I didn’t know your tail was shorter than mine.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of short? It's short.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Please accept my apology in advance for this one, but if you're very short you may be a midget. And if you're a midget you probably drive a midget car (みじか).

ex_1_jp: 私は父に、短期的なコスト削減のためにリーダーシップ研修を縮小している企業は、一文惜しみの百知らずだと教えられました。
ex_1_en: My father told me that companies that cut back on leadership training to save money in the short term are penny wise and pound foolish.
meaning_story: The short period of time is the short term. You know not to think short term anyways, right? You're learning kanji, after all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の父は、母に短刀で刺されて死にました。
ex_1_en: My mother stabbed my father with a dagger and he died.
meaning_story: The short sword is the short sword. What's another word for a short sword? It's a dagger.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 全くひどい息子をもったもんだよ。あいつは昨夜私のケーキの残りをこっそり盗み食いしやがったんだ。
ex_1_en: I have the most beastly son. He sneakily ate up the rest of my cake last night.
meaning_story: The breath child (that lets you release your breath when it's born) is a son. Nowadays it's cool to have a girl, but back in the day you wanted a son to carry on your underwater basket weaving legacy. That's why this is a son.
reading_story: The reading of this is messed up. 子 is こ, that should be okay. 息 is むす for some reason though. Why? Because you gave birth to a son, but he was a moose (むす). You better hold that breath again, because this is not what you wanted.

ex_1_jp: ねぇ、新しい野球の球を買ったんだけど、一緒にキャッチボールしない？
ex_1_en: Hey, I got a new baseball. Do you want to play catch with me?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Another meaning I'm going to add is sports ball because this is the word used for balls in various sports (soccer, baseball, etc).
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're holding onto a sports ball in your hand, let's say it's a baseball for this mnemonic's sake. You throw it at your friend who's going to catch it. As it flies through the air, though, it transforms into a tomahawk (たま). Imagine your shock and fear as you see this happening, flying towards your friend! It's going to stick in his forehead. He can't catch this with his glove! Also notice that it has the same reading as the vocab word 玉. So, if you know that one, you may know this one too! They're kind of similar. This can be read きゅう too, if you're talking about more of a globe sphere than the ball sphere you throw.

ex_1_jp: わぁ！すごく綺麗。何か特別なダイエットでもしたの？それとも、若返りの泉でも見つけたとか？
ex_1_en: Wow! You look beautiful! Did you go on a special diet? Or did you find the Fountain of Youth?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're looking at a natural spring in the ground. Water is bubbling up, but then something changes. It looks a bit clogged... something is poking out. Then, all of a sudden, Mario flies out of the springs, falls in front of you and yells: "izumeeeee (いずみ), Mario!"

ex_1_jp: 美味しい寿司飯を作るには、しゃもじを使って、湯気が立つ炊きたての熱いごはんに酢を混ぜる必要があります。信じられないかもしれませんが、実際に米一粒一粒を潰さずに酢を混ぜるには技術が必要です。
ex_1_en: To make good sushi rice, you need to mix vinegar into steaming hot, freshly cooked rice, using a paddle. Believe it or not, it actually takes skill to mix the vinegar into the rice without crushing the individual grains.
meaning_story: Hot water's energy isn't the hot water itself, it's what comes out of it (when it's boiling, for example). This is the steam and vapor.
reading_story: The ゆ part of the reading makes sense. The げ part for 気 is a bit of an exception. Just think of yourself standing in the steams and vapors. You're getting all hot and sweaty, but the feeling makes you incredibly happy and gay (げ). Then someone asks, as they look at you in the steam: "Hey, you gay?" (ゆげ). You answer however you want to answer.

ex_1_jp: 英語の勉強、頑張って下さいね。私も日本語をずっと勉強しているので苦労はよくわかります。
ex_1_en: Keep up your English language studies. I’m always working on my Japanese too, so I know how hard it is.
meaning_story: Your exertion is strong. You'd think this means you're working hard or something, but it means studies (like studies you have for a test or something). So for this, just imagine yourself exerting yourself really strongly on your homework. These are your studies / what you study.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本万国博覧会のシンボルは、岡本太郎が作った「太陽の塔」で、それは今も日本の大阪の吹田にある万博公園にそびえ立っています。
ex_1_en: The symbol of Expo ’70 was the Tower of the Sun, created by Taro Okamoto, and it’s still standing in the Expo Commemoration Park in Suita, Osaka, Japan.
meaning_story: The fat sunshine thing up in the sky... what is it called? Oh, that's right. It's the sun.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 水着はありますか？とびきりセクシーなのを探しているんですが。
ex_1_en: Do you have swimsuits? I’m looking for a super sexy one.
meaning_story: The water wear that you wear is a swim suit.
reading_story: The reading for this one is all kun'yomi vocab reading, but you should know these by now. 水 is みず. 着 uses the reading you learned with the kanji but this words employs that pesky rendaku, so remember that き becomes ぎ here.

ex_1_jp: 最も有名な「猫島」といえば、日本の宮城県にある田代島という島です。
ex_1_en: The most famous "cat island" is the island Tashirojima in Miyagi prefecture, Japan.
meaning_story: It's an island where they use cats as a substitute for rice! Lovely Tashirojima. Don't worry, they don't eat them! ...or, wait, do they?
reading_story: This is a place name and it uses the kun'yomi. You haven't learned this particular kun'yomi for 代 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: When you go to Tashirojima, make sure you visit the old woman. You know what woman I'm talking about, the one who starred on Murder she wrote (しろ). She writes a lot about cats now, I guess.

ex_1_jp: 茶の湯の世界には、「一つ一つの出会いを大切に」という意味の「一期一会」という言葉があります。この言葉は、映画「フォレスト・ガンプ」の副タイトルとしても使われました。
ex_1_en: In the world of tea ceremonies there is a saying, "Ichi-go ichi-e," which means "to treasure every encounter." This saying was also used as the subtitle for Japan’s release of Forrest Gump.
meaning_story: The hot water of tea. That is part of the ceremony that goes into the tea ceremony.
reading_story: The readings are both the readings you learned with the kanji. Now you can spend a little more time drinking tea at a tea ceremony and a little less time trying to remember kanji readings.

ex_1_jp: 気温が急に下がった。
ex_1_en: The temperature fell suddenly.
meaning_story: The energy of the warmth will cause the temperature to go up and down. Energy goes up? Higher temperature because of more movement and activity. Energy goes down? Well, temperature gets colder and slower.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 醸造中に天気や温度がほんの少し変化しただけで、酒の味に影響することがあるため、酒を作ることは非常に難しいと言われています。
ex_1_en: It’s said to be very difficult to make sake because the slightest change in the weather or temperature during brewing can affect it’s taste.
meaning_story: The warm degrees is how many degrees warm it is in here. Of course, there can be very few warm degrees as well, making it very cold. What is all this? It's the temperature.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 地球という名前を考えたのは誰だ？
ex_1_en: Who came up with the name Earth?
meaning_story: The earth sphere! It's where we live and the planet we call home. It's the earth!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: これで終わりだ。
ex_1_en: This is the end.
meaning_story: By now you should know that 終わる means "to end" or "to finish." So what is this noun-version of that word? It would be the end or the finish.
reading_story: The reading comes from 終わる. So long as you know that word, you can learn this word's reading as well!

ex_1_jp: あの有名なフグ一家の第一印象はどうでしたか？
ex_1_en: What was your first impression of the famous blowfish family?
meaning_story: The ordinal number prefix one refers to the first thing. This is the number one place you can get. In fact, it's simply the best.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「昨夜、自動車を盗まれちゃったんだよ。」「げっ、最悪じゃん。」
ex_1_en: "My car was stolen last night." "Oh, no! That’s the worst!"
meaning_story: The most bad is the worst. At least all there is is up now, right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本の有人島の多さは、インドネシア、フィリピンに次いで、世界で三番目だってこと、知ってた？
ex_1_en: Did you know that Japan has the third highest number of inhabited islands in the world, after Indonesia and the Philippines?
meaning_story: Remember 一番目? This is just like that, but with three, making it the third thing or simply the third.
reading_story: Use your knowledge of the reading for 一番目 to remember the reading for this word as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼は単にある時期にさしかかっているだけだよ。ほら、外国で暮らす人はたいてい、カルチャーショックの時期を経験するっていうじゃない？
ex_1_en: It’s just a phase he’s going through. Don’t they say people living in a foreign country usually experience a period of culture shock?
meaning_story: The time period of time is a period of time of time. If anything, just notice how many times the word "time" is used and you'll remember this word means time. The meaning is a specific type of time, though. This is talking about a season or period of time, not the concept of time itself. That would be 時間 or something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 回転寿司の普及に伴い、日本におけるサーモンの消費量は輸入開始から三倍となった。
ex_1_en: Since the introduction and subsequent spread of conveyer belt sushi shops, salmon consumption in Japan has tripled.
meaning_story: Throw this onto a number and you have yourself the number of times something has increased. For example, 3倍 means something increased "three fold."
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Omit the 〜 when writing out the answer, though. That just represents that there should be something before the kanji in this word when being used.

ex_1_jp: 列車は時間通りに着かない。
ex_1_en: The train didn’t arrive on time.
meaning_story: This word is tough, because there's another word in this level (着る) that means "to wear" that is so similar. This word, however, means to arrive. You should have seen that meaning with the kanji 着 as well, so I hope that helps. To differentiate between this and 着る, though, zoom in on the く. You want to be cool (く) so you arrive to the party late.
reading_story: The reading is one of the readings you learned with the kanji (sadly there were two, and this was the secondary one). So to help you, keep thinking about the party you showed up late to. How late were you? Two (つ) hours and two minutes late, to be exact.

ex_1_jp: 一生の内、少なくとも一度は富士山に登ることが夢なんです。
ex_1_en: A dream of mine is to climb Mt. Fuji at least once in my lifetime.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means climb so the verb vocab version would be to climb (or to ascend), if that's the kind of thing you're into.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. This has the same reading as 上る which you learned all that time ago in Level 1. If you can remember that, you can remember this one!

ex_1_jp: 見て！あそこにヤンキーたちがたくさん集まってるよ。
ex_1_en: Look at that bunch of miscreants gathering over there!
meaning_story: I bet you remember 集める which means "to collect." This is similar to that, except you're not doing the action of collecting, it's just happening. Instead of "to collect" it's to come together. You can remember this because a herd of Marus (the cat) will come together into one place if they sense a box there.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 集める so if you know that word you'll know how to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: 「今日、『男を落とす方法』っていう本を買ったんだけど、帰り道にどこかで落としちゃったみたいなんだよね。」「ええ〜。それは運が悪かったわね。でも、そんなに肩を落とさないで。そのうち良いことあるわよ。」
ex_1_en: "Today I bought a book called "How to Make a Man Fall In Love With You," but I lost it somewhere on the way back home." "Aww. That’s too bad, but don’t be too disappointed. Your day will come."
meaning_story: You've seen how 落ちる means "to fall down." Now you're doing the action of "falling something down," aka you're dropping it. You can remember this because you kind of toss (とす) something and it drops to the ground, making this word mean to drop something.
reading_story: The reading comes from 落ちる. So long as you know that word you can apply that reading over here, too.

ex_1_jp: 教室を出た後は電気を消すのを忘れないで下さい。
ex_1_en: After you leave the classroom, please don’t forget to turn off the light.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means extinguish so the verb vocab version is to extinguish. You can also use this word to refer to turning something off (like lights). Technically you're extinguishing the lights or power, right?
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The kettle is getting too hot so it catches on fire. You have to extinguish the flames before your house burns down too, just because of this stupid little kettle.

ex_1_jp: コウイチはもう少しで地面に転ぶところだったが、スーパーマンのコスプレをしたビエトに助けられた。
ex_1_en: Koichi had almost fallen to the ground, but Viet, who was wearing a Superman costume, saved him.
meaning_story: Do you remember the word 転がる? This is kind of similar, except now you're falling over (and tumbling rolling around, I don't know). So, this version of the word is to fall over. You can remember this because when you hit the ground you yell out "BOOOOObs!" (because you fell on your boobs, and it hurts).
reading_story: The reading comes from 転がる. Hopefully you know that one well enough to associate it with this one, meaning you can read them both.

ex_1_jp: トフグの風習に、河豚の形に切りとった紙を、コウイチの誕生日に川に流すというものがあります。
ex_1_en: A Tofugu custom involves cutting paper into the shape of Fugu and setting them afloat down a stream on Koichi’s birthday.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stream, but what in the world could "to stream" be (remember, there weren't streams of StarCraft II games back in the day when this word was made up)? Well, let's think water. If you're streaming water, it's going to flow. Alternatively, to flush works too.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you do with someone who is a nagger (one who nags)? You have to flush them down the toilet. Imagine someone nagging you to do your chores so you flush them down the toilet, somehow.

ex_1_jp: スカイツリーがそびえ立つ東京都墨田区では、今年は昨年よりも早く木の葉が落ち始めた。
ex_1_en: The leaves started falling earlier this year than last year in Tokyo Metropolis’ Sumida Ward, where the Tokyo Sky Tree stands.
meaning_story: The Tokyo Metropolis is, of course, the Tokyo Metropolis. Technically this is one of Japan's prefectures, but it's called a "Metropolis" instead. It's the capital and the largest city in all of Japan!
reading_story: The reading is just 東京 and 都 (と). Really it's all just the reading you learned with the kanji, too, so you can think of it that way as well.

ex_1_jp: くそ〜。パソコンが動かなくなっちゃったぜ。どうしてこうなったんだろう？
ex_1_en: Shoot! My computer doesn’t work. What brought this on?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means move so the verb vocab version is to move.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone is telling you to move. They are saying "you go (うご) over there. Move! Move!" If it helps, have them pronounce "You go" more like "Ugo."

ex_1_jp: 「ねぇ、僕にキスしたい？」「ありえない。100万年経ってもあんたとキスなんて絶対にしたくないから。天地がひっくり返っても、起こりっこないよ。」
ex_1_en: "Hey, do you want to kiss me?" "Absolutely no way would I ever want to kiss you in a million years. That would never happen even if heaven and earth were turned upside down."
meaning_story: You know that 起きる means "to wake up." This word, however, means to occur. Think of it this way. When an action "wakes up" in a way it is occurring as well. That's why this word means to occur. Just imagine a core (こる) of uranium just occurring out of nowhere to help you to remember this word.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji and the same as 起きる too, meaning you should be able to put together the reading on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「すみません。トフグ博物館は明日は開いてますか？」「開いてますよ。でも、混雑が予想されるので、早めにお越しになられることをお勧めします。」「分かりました。有難うございます。」
ex_1_en: "Excuse me. Is the Tofugu Museum open for business tomorrow?" "Yes, but it might be quite busy, so I suggest you get there early." "Okay, thank you."
meaning_story: You should know 開ける by now. This word is similar to that, except it has to do with when things are just open. It's the same thing, though. The meaning is also to open.
reading_story: The reading can come from 開ける. So if you know the reading of that word (I hope you do!) then you can apply that knowledge here.

ex_1_jp: 電動歯ブラシを買うことを考えているんだが、どれも値段が高いんだよね。
ex_1_en: I’m thinking about buying one of those electric toothbrushes, but they’re so expensive.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading that you learned with the kanji is the same as this one. HA! Take that, kanji.

ex_1_jp: この種をどこに植えるつもりだい。
ex_1_en: Where do you plan on planting that seed?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means plant, so the verb version is to plant.
reading_story: You haven't learned this reading for 植 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decided to plant an uni (う) tree in your backyard. That's right, you can plant uni and they'll grow like fruit off a really spiky tree. Just picture it. And then you'll get to eat all the uni you want!

ex_1_jp: 雷が鳴るが、雨が降らなかった。
ex_1_en: Thunder rumbled but it didn’t rain.
meaning_story: This is a lot like 鳴く, which means "to chirp" (or some other animal noise). This has to do with noises too, but not so much animal and more like bells (including telephones). This word means to ring. If it helps, think of the る as a hint, kind of like the first sound of the word "ring" (る). So, る = "ring" and it's a verb, so to ring.
reading_story: The reading can come from 鳴く. So long as you know the reading for that word you can know the reading for this word as well.

ex_1_jp: 「外は雨が降ってるね。外出せずに家で歌でも歌いたいな。」「じゃあ、こうしよう。今夜は出かけるのをやめよう。で、私が夕食を作るから、あなたは私のために歌ってよ。」
ex_1_en: "It’s raining outside. I just want to stay in and sing." "I’ll tell you what. Let’s stay in tonight and I’ll make dinner for you if you’ll sing songs for me."
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means song so the verb vocab version of this is to sing, because you don't "to song," you "to sing."
reading_story: Awesomely, this uses the same reading as the reading for the vocab words 歌. Just throw the う onto the end and you have yourself the reading. So, sing your heart out and learn this word easily. "IIIIiiIIIiiiII WILLL ALLllwaYYYs Loovvve YoOooOOooooOOOO ♬!"

ex_1_jp: 私は一昨日の彼氏の誕生日会に、黒の膝丈のドレスを着ていったわよ。
ex_1_en: I wore a knee-length black dress at my boyfriend’s birthday party the day before yesterday.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wear so this word means to wear or to put on. You'll need to differentiate it from 着く which means (to arrive), though. Just think of how the る is the rude guy trying to get you to wear things you don't like wearing.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, though it is one of two. To remember that this particular one is き just imagine that you have to wear a dress made completely of keys. Feel the metal on your skin and the weight on your shoulders. It's not a comfortable thing to put on.

ex_1_jp: 外では雪がしんしんと降っており、地面が凍りだしているので、彼氏の家に行くときに丘を車で登りきれるのかどうか心配しています。
ex_1_en: The snow is falling heavily outside and the roads are getting pretty icy, so I’m worried about being able to drive up the hill to my boyfriend’s house.
meaning_story: You know that 心配 is "a worry." What about the verb version of that? It would be to worry.
reading_story: The reading comes straight from 心配 so try to make sure you know that word so you can read this word! It's also all jukugo on'yomi reading, too, so you should be able to figure it out regardless.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
pronunciation: りゅうこう, はやり
ex_1_jp: ねぇ、フグ。魚達向けに、流行のヘアスタイルを掲載した雑誌を出版したらどうかなって思ってるんだけど、あなたはどう思う？
ex_1_en: Hey, Fugu. I’m thinking of publishing a magazine cataloging trendy hairstyles for fish, but what do you think?
meaning_story: Where the stream is going is where everyone's going. That's what tends to be the trend of things. Imagine a trend going on in your society right now. Imagine it going down a stream with everyone following it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ハヤリꜜ *** リューコー

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あなたが私の旅行について話したいのは分かるんだけど、それよりも先に、私がいない間、どうしてたの？
ex_1_en: I know you want to talk about my trip but first things first, how have you been while I was away?
meaning_story: When you go on a trip you're taking a trip. This is travel. You should try to do this occasionally! Perhaps a nice 旅行 to Japan?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私はもうすっかり旅支度ができているよ。
ex_1_en: I’m already prepared for our trip.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You are going on your trip but you need to bring your little tabby (たび) cat with you to keep you company. This cat keeps you calm and lets you leave your house, but the airlines won't let you take it on this trip. What to do?

ex_1_jp: どの下着が欲しい？植物柄？それともアニマル柄？好きなものを選んでいいよ。
ex_1_en: Which underwear do you want? The plant or animal patterned ones? Pick whichever one you like.
meaning_story: The things you wear below your other clothes. That is your underwear. You do wear underwear, right?
reading_story: The reading is all kun'yomi. For 下 you should know this reading by now (the reading you use with the vocab word 下). For 着 it's just the reading you learned, though you'll have to take into account the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 「デザートに温かいアイスクリームはいかがですか？」 「いいえ、もう結構です。」
ex_1_en: "Would you like some warm ice cream for dessert?" "No, we’re all set."
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of warm? It's warm.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Touch something that's warm... too warm! You pull your hand back and go "AH ta ta! (あたた). People make this noise when they touch something that's hot, I hear. It's almost like saying "hot hot hot" while dropping the "h" sound.
pitch_accent: アタタカꜜイ *** アッタカꜜイ

ex_1_jp: ダイビングをしている際に、彼は水深十メートルのところで虹色の海藻を見つけた。
ex_1_en: While diving at a depth of ten meters, he found rainbow color seaweed.
meaning_story: The water deepness is the water depth. You should check this before diving into the water so you don't hit your face.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: うわぁ！君の話し方、まるで母国語が日本語の人みたいだね。
ex_1_en: Wow! The way you talk sounds just like a native Japanese person.
meaning_story: The way of speaking is your way of speaking (or it could be your speaking style). This is how someone talks. Some people have an interesting speaking style, after all.
reading_story: The readings come from 話す and 方. By now you should have seen these words separately and should be able to read this word too.
pitch_accent: ハナシカꜜタ *** ハナシカタ *** ハナシカタꜜ

ex_1_jp: 私は言葉に詰まった。
ex_1_en: I was at a loss for words.
meaning_story: A leaf of the things you say is like a leaf from a tree of speaking. That leaf is a part of the whole language, it is a single word, though it can add up to be a language or manner of speech.
reading_story: The reading for 言 is one you haven't learned. It's kind of an exception, in fact, though you might see it from time to time. You'll want to imagine yourself playing a koto (こと). Each strum of the instrument sends forth several words from its strings, flying at the person you're talking to. You speak your words via music, specifically the koto (so think about using other instruments as well to communicate... they just don't work).

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ケイティは、真面目で熱心な働きと細かい気配りで、同僚たちを感心させた。
ex_1_en: Katie earned the admiration of her co-workers with her hard work and attention to detail.
meaning_story: Your feelings are in your heart. When your feelings are in your heart they are pure feelings. You can be happy for people and feel admiration for their successes. This is a great feeling to have in your heart.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 入館料、もう10％値引きしていただけませんかねぇ？
ex_1_en: Could you give us an additional ten percent discount on the admission fee?
meaning_story: The fee for entering a public building is the admission fee. Gotta pay it if you want to get inside.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 俺の養子の態度が悪いから、叱った。
ex_1_en: I scolded my adopted son because he has such a bad attitude.
meaning_story: A foster child you bring into your family is your adopted child. This can also be your son-in-law too. If you bring in a son via your daughter, that's kind of like adopting a son too, right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 別れた彼氏の写真を整理しました。
ex_1_en: I adjusted the picture of my ex-boyfriend.
meaning_story: An arrangement using reason is something you've thought about. It's still just arrangement, though, no matter how well arranged it is and how much reason you put behind it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もしテキストフグの永久購読権を購読されるのであれば、日本語の学習がし放題ですよ。
ex_1_en: If you purchase a lifetime subscription to Text Fugu you can study Japanese as much as you want.
meaning_story: Just release the topic... let it go free! Let it do whatever it wants. Sometimes the topic will be food... if that's the case, just release yourself and do whatever you want with the food (eat it all!). If it's drinks, drink it all! This word has to do with doing whatever you want and as much as you want. You'll see this attached to "all you can ____" words, so look out for them in the next couple levels.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ねぇ、ビエト！どうやってこんなに面白い暗殺計画を思いついたの？
ex_1_en: Hey, Viet! How did you come up with such a unique assassination plan?
meaning_story: A dark kill is an assassination. It's done by someone who is in a ninja outfit and dark, hiding in the shadows for his moment to strike.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 銀行を強盗した人は牢屋行きなのに、銀行が人々からお金を奪ったら、ボーナスがもらえるんだよ。それってすごく不公平じゃない？
ex_1_en: When people rob banks they go to prison. When banks rob people they get bonuses. It’s so unfair, isn’t it?
meaning_story: Time to go get your silver from the bank.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguよ安らかに眠ってくれ。今月初めに、僕の一番好きな日本語学習サイトが倒産しちゃったんだ。
ex_1_en: R.I.P. Tofugu. At the beginning of this month my favorite Japanese learning site went bankrupt.
meaning_story: This is a time based word (because of the に). What is the first point of time when you are beginning something? That is the beginning.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. What are you beginning? You are beginning Haj (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja).

ex_1_jp: その1603年に建てられた橋の名前は日本橋というんですが、日本橋はその名の通り、まさに日本の中心でした。
ex_1_en: The name of the bridge built in 1603 is Nihonbashi and it was truly the central point of Japan, as its name suggests.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji! No need to burn any 橋s with this word and its kanji.

ex_1_jp: 私達は変顔コンテストの賞金をいつもらえるんですか？
ex_1_en: When do we get the prize money from the funny face competition?
meaning_story: A prize of gold is so old fashioned. We use cash now, which is why this word means cash prize.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 警察はすべての事情を利用しなければならない。
ex_1_en: The police must take all circumstances into account.
meaning_story: The feeling of the actions going on around you are the circumstances. For example: you feel like things are going pretty poorly right now, which is why the circumstances are looking pretty dire for you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: まず最初にごはんを器に入れて、次にハンバーグをのせて、それからグレービーソースをかけて、最後に卵をのせたら…ジャーン！ロコモコの出来上がり！
ex_1_en: First you put some rice in a bowl, then you put a hamburger patty on the rice, followed by some gravy, and then an egg on top. Then, ta-da! Now, your Loco-moco is done!
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also, you can call this a bowl, too, if you want.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You have this container. It's upside down with a stick holding it up and a string on the stick. You're going to catch some U2s (like, the band). You put some food under it and wait. Then, out of the bushes comes Bono. He sniffs around for a bit and then goes under the container. You pull! U2 walked (うつわ) right into the trap! Haha!

ex_1_jp: 最近、暗いニュースばっかりだけど、こんな暗い世の中でも滅茶苦茶良いことだってあるんだよ。えっと、それで…うーん。何を言いかけたのか忘れちゃったんだけど、とにかく、僕と結婚してくれませんか？
ex_1_en: Everything in the news has been depressing lately, but there is a great big silver lining to this dark cloud, you know. And... well... I kind of lost my train of thought, but, anyway, will you marry me?
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dark? It's dark.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're thrown into something dark and small. A lid is closed on top of you, and you are confused. What have you been thrown in? You find out you've been thrown in a cooler (くら). Feel afraid like you would be if you were thrown in such a dark cooler like this. Is it cold?

ex_1_jp: 彼女はいつも明るくて良い子なんだけど、あまり器用じゃないので、首にしようか迷ってるんです。
ex_1_en: She is always a cheerful and agreeable girl but she’s not very skilled with her hands, so I’m wondering if I should fire her.
meaning_story: Your task is to open this pickle container. Why you? Because you are so dextrous and skillful when it comes to opening pickles.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: フグ市長は好きですが、私たちの地域に何をしてくれたかって聞かれると、まだ疑問です。
ex_1_en: I like Mayor Fugu but if I was asked what he could do for our community, I still have my doubts.
meaning_story: A doubt problem is caused by having too much doubt. Just think about it. Don't doubt yourself, it's why you're getting those vocab words wrong! :P
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の妻は酒好きなので、アル中にならないか心配だ。
ex_1_en: My wife is a drinker and I’m worried about her becoming an alcoholic.
meaning_story: When you like alcohol a lot, you're probably a heavy drinker.
reading_story: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading here as you can probably guess from the hiragana sticking out on the end. You should know the readings of these as separate words already (酒 and 好き) which means all you need to pay attention to is the rendaku of すき to ずき.
pitch_accent: サケズキ *** サケズキꜜ

ex_1_jp: お袋が飲み会には行っちゃダメだって言うんだよね。お前んとこの親がアルコールとかに対して厳しくないの、羨ましいよ。
ex_1_en: My mom says that I can’t go to the drinking party. Your parents are really chill about stuff like alcohol. I’m jealous.
meaning_story: You know that 飲む is drink, so this has to do with drinking. Also, 会 means meet, so when you meet to drink you're getting together with others to drink. It's a drinking party!
reading_story: The readings come from the 飲む vocabulary word and the regular kanji reading for 会. Hopefully you know both of those by now so you can apply them to the reading of this word, too!
pitch_accent: ノミカイ *** ノミꜜカイ

ex_1_jp: トフグの新入社員はみんな、仕事にやる気を見せることに熱心で、寝てもいい時間でさえも、仕事をしていた。
ex_1_en: Tofugu’s new employees were all keen to show their enthusiasm and worked even when they could have been sleeping.
meaning_story: When your heart is feverish and hot about something, it is obviously something you have a lot of enthusiasm about. Think about the things you've enthusiasm for. Then, imagine your heart beating and getting all hot from thinking about it. Why else would people get so upset when talking about religion and politics. It's their feverish heart! Their enthusiasm!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Be careful of the ねっ portion (normally is ねつ).
pitch_accent: ネꜜッシン *** ネッシꜜン

ex_1_jp: 「分かりましたか？」 「申し訳ないのですが、チンプンカンプンで全然わかりません。今言ったことをもう少しゆっくり言っていただけませんか？」
ex_1_en: "Did you get that?" "I’m sorry. I’m completely lost. Could you say that again more slowly?"
meaning_story: It's all nature out there. It's entirely nature and not at all city. This word is weird. It means two opposite things. Thanks Japanese! Just look out for a negative word after the 全然. If it is negative it's "not at all" if it's not negative it might be "entirely."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: みなさん, みんなさん
ex_1_jp: 皆さん、こんにちは。今週中には、トフグセミナーの日程を確定させたいと思っています。数日中にビエトと話しをして、その後で皆さんに日程をお伝えさせて頂きます。
ex_1_en: Hello everyone. I am hoping we can nail down some of the dates for the Tofugu seminars this week. I’ll talk to Viet in the next few days and then I will announce everyone’s schedule.
meaning_story: Everyone + さん (normal name ender). This is the normal way to say everyone
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

pronunciation: みなさま, みんなさま
ex_1_jp: 「皆様、ご着席いただけますか？」「お言葉ですが、それは良い考えではないと思います。何故だか分かりませんが、我々の椅子に接着剤が付いているのです。」
ex_1_en: "Could everyone take their seats, please?" "With all due respect, I don’t think it’s a good idea. There is super glue on our chairs for some reason."
meaning_story: Everyone (formal name title). This is just a polite way to say everyone (and you want to be polite to everyone, because everyone > you).
reading_story: The reading for both kanji here are the same as the ones you learned with their kanji. Everyone can breathe easier now.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 予想外の出来事が生じているため、今日は氷の舟で溶岩のプールを渡ることはできません。
ex_1_en: Due to unforeseen circumstances, the ice boat will not be traveling across the lava pool today.
meaning_story: You have an idea of the concept beforehand, aka you know what's going to happen, or at least you have an idea. This is an expectation of what's going to happen next. But don't let your anticipation get the better of you!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 子供達の表情は、みんなとても活き活きとしていた。
ex_1_en: The children’s faces all looked very lively.
meaning_story: When you express a feeling it shows on your face. This is called a facial expression.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「申し訳ありませんが、この料金が精一杯です。」「うーん。まぁ、妥当な値段のようですね。分かりました。これで手を打ちましょう。」
ex_1_en: "I’m afraid this price is the best price we can offer." "Well, that sounds fair. Okay, let’s finalize the deal."
meaning_story: The fee gold (or money, if you will) that you have to pay are your fees and bills.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: リョꜜーキン *** リョーキン

ex_1_jp: コウイチさん、社長になるって、どんな感じですか？
ex_1_en: What’s it like to be a company president, Mr. Koichi?
meaning_story: This is a noun version of the kanji feeling. What is that? It's a feeling as well.
reading_story: The reading for both on'yomi and kun'yomi of this kanji are the same, actually. So long as you learned the reading that was with the kanji, you can't go wrong. Feel good?

ex_1_jp: 感情に流されすぎてはいけないよ。自分の感情に負けることには何の価値もないよ。
ex_1_en: Do not give in too much to your feelings. There’s no point in letting your emotions get the better of you, right?
meaning_story: Feeling + feeling = feeling! It can also mean emotion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今日は少し熱があるので外出できない。
ex_1_en: I have a bit of a fever today so I can’t go out.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so don't get all feverish over this one.

ex_1_jp: トフグのコウイチ様御一行九名様ですね。お席のご用意ができましたのでどうぞ。
ex_1_en: Mr. Koichi from Tofugu, party of nine. Your table is ready.
meaning_story: Add this onto the end of someone's name. It's probably too polite, to be honest, unless you're talking to one of your customers or something. It's good to know, but you're probably not going to use it, despite seeing and hearing it fairly often.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
pitch_accent: サマꜜ *** ザマꜜ *** ヨꜜー

ex_1_jp: 「もしかして、日本はこれが初めて？」「はい。そうなんです。」「そうなんだ。日本はどう？」「かなり気に入ってるわ。」
ex_1_en: "Is it possible this is your first time in Japan?" "Yes, it is." So how do you like it?” "I really like it!"
meaning_story: You know that 初 means "first" This word means for the first time. Think of めて as "meet." Then think "when we met for the first time ____ happened."
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. What are you beginning? You are beginning Haj (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja).

ex_1_jp: なんで私に、駅前で撮ったこんな変な自撮り写メを送ってきたの？
ex_1_en: Why did you just send that weird looking selfie taken in front of the station to me?
meaning_story: The station front is the front of station. This word is great for telling people where you want to meet, by the way.
reading_story: This is like two separate words put together into one, so you can imagine it's the kun'yomi readings. You learned the right reading for 駅 in the kanji, and you should know the vocab word 前 by now. Combine the two together and you have yourself front of station.
pitch_accent: エキマꜜエ *** エキマエ

ex_1_jp: 福島問題に関するメールは、全て私をCCに入れてもらえますか？
ex_1_en: Please CC me on all emails concerning the problems of Fukushima.
meaning_story: The luck island wasn't actually too lucky. This is Fukushima where the nuclear meltdown happened after the 2011 earthquake. So, when you think of "luck island" this is where you should think.
reading_story: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. If one thing is lucky, it's probably that.

ex_1_jp: トフグの目標について、もう少し具体的に話しをして頂けませんか？
ex_1_en: Could you be a little more specific about Tofugu’s goals, please?
meaning_story: The signpost you have your eye on is your goal and target. Just imagine looking at this signpost in the distance. You know you have to get to it from where you are. That is the goal of your hike and journey.
reading_story: You've had the on'yomi reading of 目 with 目次 way back in level 6. For this vocab, you're trying to get to your goal, that signpost in the distance. As you're trekking towards it there are people standing to the side mocking you, telling you you'll never make it to your goal. Imagine this happening.

ex_1_jp: 神様のいたずらだったのだろう。
ex_1_en: It’s probably just the mischief of god.
meaning_story: God (formal name ender) is God! Or the gods, if you're talking to more than one. You have to be polite to them, so you add that ender on there.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too!

ex_1_jp: 女神のように美しい女声に出会った。
ex_1_en: I came across a beautiful woman’s voice that sounded like a goddess’.
meaning_story: A woman who is also a god is a goddess.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 女 yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: This goddess has the most beautiful 目 (め) you've ever seen. You can't stop staring into them. This must be how people know they've met a god.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: A:「このネクタイ、どうかな？」 B:「そうねぇ。こっちの緑色のをしてみてよ。」 A:「わかったよ。これでどう？」 B:「うん。そっちの方がいいわね。」
ex_1_en: A: How do you like this tie? B: Here. Try this green one. A: Okay. How’s this? B: Yeah. That’s more like it.
meaning_story: The green color is the color green.
reading_story: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji, combined!
pitch_accent: ミドリイロ *** リョクショク

ex_1_jp: A:「僕はこの赤いのが気に入ったよ。」 B:「私は緑の方がいいわ。」 A:「ああ、そうかい。じゃあ、好きなようにしろよ。」
ex_1_en: A: I like the red one. B: I prefer green. A: Oh. OK then, have it your way.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 私はその神社で心願成就の御札を買いました。
ex_1_en: I bought a charm at the shrine to help fulfill my heart’s desires.
meaning_story: The thing your heart requests is what your heart wants. This is your heartfelt desire.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: シンカ°ン *** シꜜンカ°ン

ex_1_jp: 「でも、ママ！僕…」「つべこべ言わないの。さあ、自分の部屋へ行って、宿題をしなさい。」
ex_1_en: "But, Mom! I..." "No buts. Now go to your room and do your homework."
meaning_story: The lodge you're staying in has a topic around it. Think of it as a theme. This theme is doing your homework. So yeah, you just went to a nice lodge for vacation only to have to do homework everywhere.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「どうぞ、お熱いうちにお召し上がりくださいね。」「有難うございます。でも、ええっと、ちょっと熱すぎるので、まだ食べられません。」
ex_1_en: "Please eat it while it’s hot." "Thank you, but... well, it’s so hot that we can’t eat it yet."
meaning_story: This is for when a thing is hot, making this word hot thing. When the weather is hot that's 暑い. This is when you touch something and you burn yourself.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: This has the same reading as 暑い, so if you've learned that you'll know how to read this word as well. If you haven't run into that word, you've probably run into the kanji 暑 at least. That uses the reading あつ. Two similar concepts, but there are two kanji to differentiate, which gets confusing.

ex_1_jp: 私達はTofuguの毎日のブログ記事を通して、日本人の生き方や人情を描き出すことを目指しています。
ex_1_en: Our goal with the daily Tofugu articles is to depict human nature, emotions, and the everyday lives of Japanese individuals.
meaning_story: The person (people) feelings are human feelings. That is what humanity is all about.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 出張の領収書は全部とっておいてください。経費は二億円までなら後で精算されますので。
ex_1_en: Please keep all the receipts from your business trip. You will be reimbursed for your business expenses later, as long as they’re under two hundred million yen.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, presumably because it's normally attached onto other numbers to signify how many hundred millions of ____ there are.

ex_1_jp: 地震を想定した避難訓練を行います。
ex_1_en: We will now conduct the disaster drill assuming there is an earthquake.
meaning_story: You're trying to determine the concept behind something but you have to test your hypothesis first. You have your assumptions, but you're not entirely sure you're right yet because all you have is the concept to go off of.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 残念。この画像はちょっとボケてるので使えないよ。
ex_1_en: What a shame. This picture is a little out of focus so you can’t use it.
meaning_story: A drawing of an image is an image. Back in the day images were usually drawn. This is also portrait or picture, too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私達のサイトについて、感想をお聞かせください。どんなご意見でも結構です。
ex_1_en: Please look at our site and tell us your impressions. Any comments would be appreciated.
meaning_story: When you take your feelings and conceptualize them, you come up with your impressions and thoughts on the subject. That's why this word is thoughts or impressions.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「なんでこの旅館、こんなにゴキブリが出るの？」「最近雨ばっかり降ってるからじゃない？」
ex_1_en: "Why are there so many cockroaches in this Japanese inn?" "I think it’s because of all the rain we’ve been getting."
meaning_story: A public building for taking trips is a place you stay when you are taking a trip. Back in the day that would just be an inn or something. Now, this specifies that the inn is a Japanese inn or Japanese hotel. A lot of people even just call it by its Japanese name: ryokan.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 五年前、神風が吹き、コウイチはビエトの軍隊を海岸から後退させた。
ex_1_en: Five years ago, Koichi drove Viet’s troops back from his shores where they were swallowed up by a divine wind.
meaning_story: Wind of the Gods. These are divine winds. More popularly, this is a word known as Kamikaze, which became known because of the kamikaze pilots during WWII. This was used before WWII, though, when the entire Mongol fleet was destroyed by a storm, preventing an invasion of Japan. How lucky.
reading_story: The readings are kun'yomi readings for both, probably because this is two words put together into one. You know the reading of 風 from previous levels, hopefully. Now all you need to do is apply your knowledge of the word 神 to be able to read the rest.

ex_1_jp: あの王様は、とんでもなくケチなんだ。
ex_1_en: That king is ridiculously stingy.
meaning_story: The king (formal name ender) is the king, and you're talking to him politely. He's the king after all! If you don't he might behead you!
reading_story: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 王 and the kun'yomi reading for 様. You've learned them both so you should be able to read this word too!

ex_1_jp: 「どういったご用件でしょうか？」「あなたが左利きかどうかだけ知りたいんですが。」「あいにくそれはご案内できないことになっております。」
ex_1_en: "May I ask the purpose of your call?" "I just want to know if you are left handed." "I’m afraid I’m not at liberty to disclose that information."
meaning_story: If you profit from the left, you're probably doing everything on the left. That's your good side. You're probably left handed.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings, so combine the readings of the words 左 and 利く together to get the reading of this one. It makes sense since this word is like two words put together.
pitch_accent: ヒダリキキ *** ヒダリꜜキキ

ex_1_jp: 宿がまだ決まってないんだよ。
ex_1_en: We still haven’t decided on a hotel yet.
meaning_story: A lodge is a form of lodging. It is also considered to be an inn or hotel.
reading_story: Yah do (やど) what you must to get lodgings for the night. Whether that's an inn or hotel or whatever. Yah do what you gotta do.

ex_1_jp: あの百貨店の本館で働いている店員は、別館で働いている人たちに比べて、なんか働かされてるって感じだった。愛想がやけに悪いっていうかさ。
ex_1_en: Lots of the people working in the main building of the department store act like someone is forcing them to work, compared to those working at the annex. They have awfully bad attitudes.
meaning_story: One of the meanings of 本 is main (which is what we're using here). The main public building is the main building.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼はクラスのお調子者で、いつもボケているが、暗記力はすごい。
ex_1_en: He is the class clown and is always playing the fool, but he is very good at memorization.
meaning_story: In the dark if you try to write down something it won't work very well. You can't see. So, how can you "write something down" in the dark? You write it down in your mind. This is memorization! Recognize this word? The SRS application "Anki" comes from this word, I'm guessing!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 昔はみんな水銀体温計をお尻に差し込んでいたんだよね。めっちゃうける。
ex_1_en: It’s so funny that people used to insert mercury thermometers into their bottoms.
meaning_story: This is a fun one. Water silver is mercury, which makes a lot of sense. Mercury is liquidy like water, but it is all silver like silver. So silver water isn't some new mineral water you can get for $4 at the store, it's mercury! Or quicksilver, if you prefer.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「今朝、鏡が盗まれたよ。数週間前に歯ブラシと櫛を盗まれたばかりなのに！」「まぁ、人生そんなもんだよ。」
ex_1_en: "My mirror was stolen this morning. I just had my toothbrush and comb stolen a few weeks ago!" "Well, that’s life."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 「僕は映画スターになって、自家用ジェット機を買うよ。それから、君は僕のお嫁さんになるんだ。」 「おじいちゃん、何寝ぼけたこと言ってんの。」
ex_1_en: "I’m going to be a movie star, buy a private jet, and you will be my wife." "Yeah, dream on, grandpa."
meaning_story: It's a drawing that uses reflections to project the image. And, the image is moving! How amazing! What is this? It is a movie.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 一人の殺人者として言わせてもらうけど、俺はあまり彼女を評価していないよ。殺人方法がつまらないからね。
ex_1_en: From a murderers perspective, I am not very pleased with her because her methods of killing are so boring.
meaning_story: When a person is killed, you have yourself a murder.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「あなたのCDを持ってくるのを忘れてしまったわ。」「別にいいよ、またの機会で。でも、その代わりにBGMとして何か楽器を弾いてくれない。」
ex_1_en: "I forgot to bring your CD." "That’s okay. I can get it another time, but instead can you play an instrument for the back ground music."
meaning_story: Remember how 楽 was used in 音楽 and meant "music"? Well this is that 楽 again. A music container is something that can produce music. It is a musical instrument.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Be careful of how がく turns into がっ, though.

ex_1_jp: 「あんな素敵な奥さんがいるなんて、お前は本当に運がいいよな。当然のことだなんて思うなよ。」
ex_1_en: You are very lucky to have such a lovely wife. Don’t take her for granted.
meaning_story: Something that's naturally right is something that's very obvious and natural. You know that, right? 当然!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私達はアメリカ政府から、フグを自然に返すように言われました。
ex_1_en: The US government told us to release Fugu into the wild.
meaning_story: Self nature is nature itself. That is nature, like all those green things and 青葉 outside. Many apologies if someone hundreds of years from now is reading this. It used to be pretty green outside before the robots. If you call this "natural" then you are using the な adjective 自然な, but I thought it pertinent to add that in here too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Wait! Except 自 is し and not じ! That is because when you add the little dakuten you are adding to the し. When it has no dakuten, it is in the form that nature intended.

ex_1_jp: 宝くじで一億ドル当たったけど、私は既に兆万長者なので全部慈善活動に寄付したよ。
ex_1_en: I won a hundred million dollars in the lottery, but I donated it all to charity because I’m a trillionaire.
meaning_story: One hundred million is one hundred million. That's a lot of zeros.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「さっき一億円が入ったスーツケースを無くしちゃったんだけど。」「えぇっ！見つかるといいね。」
ex_1_en: "I just lost a suitcase that had one hundred million yen in it.” "What! I hope you find it."
meaning_story: One hundred million yen! So rich! You have one hundred million yen!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguオフィスの棚に整然と並べられていたワインボトルを、マミが全部空けてしまった。
ex_1_en: The neatly arranged wine bottles on the shelves of the Tofugu office were all emptied out by Mami.
meaning_story: When you arrange things in the way that nature intended, you're doing things in a quite orderly fashion. This is the natural state of things, nice and arranged and natural. Orderly!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは、日本とアメリカの伝統を融合させることに、生涯情熱を捧げることを決意しました。
ex_1_en: Koichi decided to make his passion in life achieving a fusion between Japanese and American tradition.
meaning_story: If you're feeling the fever, you're getting so into something that your body is heating up. You have a ton of passion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「体育の日に、一緒にバレーボールしない？」「ああ、確か祝日だったよね。十月十日とかだっけ？」「そうそう。祝日。でも、もう十月十日じゃないよ。ハッピー・マンデー制度ができてから、十月の第二月曜日になったんだよ。」
ex_1_en: "Do you want to play volleyball with us on Physical Education Day?" "Oh, it’s a national holiday, right? Isn’t it October 10th or something?" "Yes, it’s a holiday, but is not October 10th anymore. Now it’s the second Monday of October because of the Happy Monday system."
meaning_story: Remember how 教育 means "education?" Well, the 育 here is referring to the education word, but this time it's a body education. What do you call the body education at school? Physical education or PE.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は君のお情けなど少しもいらないよ！ちょっと手を貸して下さい。
ex_1_en: I don’t need your pity! Just lend me a hand, please.
meaning_story: You have your feelings... these are the feelings humans have. When you ask someone to have feelings (Have feelings, KAY?? (け at the end)), you are asking them to pity or have mercy on you. Please! Have those human feelings that people have, like sympathy or pity. Don't kill me, man!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who are you begging to have pity on you? It's NASA. They have you hanging outside of the space station and they're going to push you towards earth where you'll burn up in the atmosphere. You don't want that, so you beg mission control for some pity. What will they do? You decide.

ex_1_jp: 通路側の席をお願いします。窓から外の景色を眺めるのが嫌いなんです。
ex_1_en: Could I have an aisle seat, please? I hate looking out from the window.
meaning_story: This is a tricky word that doesn't really have a good translation. The best ways I've seen it done in terms of getting a meaning across are please and please help me. When you say this word you're kind of saying "please help me out and I'm relying on you and you're kind of awesome too." Anyways, please is a pretty good way to do it. So, when you see this word you'll notice it has the request kanji in it. You can guess you're requesting something. What is that thing? It's help (please help me) and you're asking very nicely too (please).
reading_story: You ask for help by saying please help me, and that person does try to help you... but the amount they do for you is so negligible that it hardly does anything to help you at all. Please try to help me again, this time better?

ex_1_jp: 今日の宿題は、日本語で詩を書くことです。
ex_1_en: Today’s homework is to write a poem in Japanese.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji as well! You are so happy that you could write a poem all about this... The vocab reading Is the same as the kanji Crabigator love How was that?

ex_1_jp: 君は詩人で、暗喩を使うことが好きなのかもしれないけど、もっと分かりやすく話さないと相手はわからないよ。
ex_1_en: Even though you’re a poet and you like using metaphors, you have to speak more clearly or people won’t understand.
meaning_story: A person who does poems is a poet.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 詩歌とは日本の詩のことですが、一般的には漢詩や和歌、俳句のことを指します。
ex_1_en: Shiika means Japanese poetry and that generally includes kanshi, waka, or haiku.
meaning_story: A poem song is poetry. It's not quite a song but I think you can make the connection.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 僕が世界ランキング一位を維持し続けているのは、日本語を毎日七時間練習しているからだと思います。
ex_1_en: I believe the reason I continue being ranked one in the world is that I devote seven hours a day to practicing Japanese.
meaning_story: You practice something to learn it. That's still called practice! The important part about this is that you're learning while you practice too. It's right in the word. So, when you practice kanji and Japanese vocab, make sure you're learning as well as practicing. If you're not learning, you're not really practicing, are you?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは素晴らしい剣道の選手です。
ex_1_en: Koichi is magnificent kendo pro.
meaning_story: This is a strange one, but in one way it makes sense. Just make sure you're thinking of 手 as the word for "person," kind of like 運転手 or something along those lines. If you do that, you can say "the person that you choose." One situation in which you'd choose a person to do something is in sports. That's why this is a pro athlete or sports player.
reading_story: The reading for 選 is what you'd expect. 手 is the on'yomi reading as it is every once in a while, especially when it has to do with representing a person, so you'll have to remember that. I think you've seen 手 using this reading enough to be able to remember it, though.

ex_1_jp: 「お願いがあるんだけど。」「いいけど、何？」「週末、私の犬の世話をしてもらえないかな？」「問題ないよ。任せといて。」
ex_1_en: "Can you do me a favor?" "Sure, what is it?" "Can you look after my dog for the weekend?" "No problem. You can count on me."
meaning_story: The problem topic is the problem or question you have to answer. If you think about it, topics as problems tends to be a school-related thing. So, when you have to answer a problem in school, that's 問題.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: アメリカへ行って初めて、日本はなんと小さい国かと実感した。
ex_1_en: Only after I went to America did I realize how small Japan really is.
meaning_story: Your truth feeling is the feeling you are feeling truthfully. It's your real feeling, your actual feeling. It's okay, you can tell me how you're feeling.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading for 実 gets changed to じっ so be careful!

ex_1_jp: お前って、天然ボケで、一緒にいていつも楽しいなって思うんだ。俺、お前のこと大好きだよ。
ex_1_en: You’re kind of goofy and that makes you fun to hang out with. I really like you.
meaning_story: You've hopefully seen 好き by now, which is "to like." So, what happens when you have a 大 (big) like? You really like something.
reading_story: The reading comes from 好き which you've hopefully seen. Then, 大 is the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: あの新しい日本映画見た？映画自体はいまいちだったんだけど、映像が物凄く美しかったよ。
ex_1_en: Did you see that new Japanese movie? The movie itself wasn’t very good, but the shots they captured were beautiful.
meaning_story: An image is reflecting on the mirror. You're looking at the mirror, confused. Don't worry, it is only a reflection, an image. It's not real.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ファミリー・ガイは、急に馬鹿げた回想シーンを使うことでよく知られている。
ex_1_en: Family Guy is famous for its random and stupid flashbacks.
meaning_story: You think about the concept of a certain number of times, each time thinking of each time you've thought about this concept before. Each time you look back, that is retrospection on that concept. You look back more and more times until there are no more times to look back on.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女のこと、すごく好きだったんだけど、右利きだって分かってから冷めちゃったんだよね。どうしてかは分からないけど。
ex_1_en: I really liked her but I was turned off when I found out that she was right handed. I don’t know why.
meaning_story: The right side of your body is the side you profit most from. So, you use it a lot more. That's because you're right handed.
reading_story: Both kanji use the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, think to the words 右 and 利く to learn how to read this one. It probably reads like this because it's two separate words come together (right + handed) rather than one word.

ex_1_jp: うわっ！コウイチ、なんで金の輪っかのイヤリングなんて付けてるの？
ex_1_en: Ew! Why are you wearing gold hoop earrings, Koichi?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You put on the ring you found, hoping it will be the one ring to rule them all (invisibility!). Instead, it turns out it's a special Walken ring, made out of Christopher Walken's bones. It talks up to you, telling you how he kept this ring in his (*ahem*) butt during the war so he could get it to you. First of all, why is this ring talking? Second, why is it talking like Walken. Third, eww, gross, it was in his anus.

ex_1_jp: 学問を疎かにしてはいけない。
ex_1_en: You must not neglect your studies.
meaning_story: How can you solve your study problem? With a little extra scholarship and studying.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 課長が少しうざいんだよね。他の社員に良い印象を与えようといつも頑張っちゃってさ。
ex_1_en: My section manager is kind of annoying. He is always trying to impress the other workers.
meaning_story: Remember how 社長 is the company president? This uses the same 長 meaning (where it means something like "boss"). Since 課 means section, this is the section manager.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 新宿には危険な香りのする赤線地区があるので、気を付けた方がいいですよ。
ex_1_en: Shinjuku has a sketchy red light district so you had better be careful.
meaning_story: The new lodge area is Shinjuku, a popular district in Tokyo. Perhaps there are many places to stay in Shinjuku. Either way, you should visit, it's fun! It will help if you've heard of Shinjuku before, too. Do some research about Shinjuku if you've never heard of it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be careful of the しゅく changing to じゅく. Once again, will help if you've heard of Shinjuku.

ex_1_jp: 私のダンスの相手は、あの銀色のコスチュームを着たフグって男よ。
ex_1_en: My dance partner is that guy in the silver costume. His name is Fugu.
meaning_story: The silver color is just silver (the color).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 赤信号で、銀色の軽トラが私の横に止まった。
ex_1_en: At the red light a silver pick-up truck pulled up alongside me.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji.

ex_1_jp: ようやく直接お話することができてよかったです。まさか駅でバッタリお会いするなんて思ってもいませんでしたよ。
ex_1_en: It was nice finally talking to you in person. I never thought I would run into you at a station.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Usually this refers to a train station in particular, but can be any kind of station.
reading_story: The kanji here uses えき as both its on'yomi and kun'yomi, so no worries here. You can go to this station or that station, and both stations will use the same reading as the kanji it comes from.

ex_1_jp: うわっ！あの駅長、今電車に唾はかなかったか？お前、見たか？
ex_1_en: Oh my God! Did the station master just spit on the train? Did you see that?
meaning_story: This word uses 長 in the same was as 社長, where it means something like "boss" or "manager." So, this 長 is the boss of the station, right? What do you call someone like that? You call them the stationmaster (that is, unless you want to be thrown to the trains).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本の自殺名所のリストを、メールで送ってもらえますか？あと、ファイルを送る際に圧縮して頂けると助かります。
ex_1_en: Could you e-mail me that list of famous suicide spots in Japan? I’d appreciate if you could compress the file before you send it to me too.
ex_2_jp: 彼は元気そうに見えたが、昨夜自殺した。
ex_2_en: He seemed fine but he committed suicide last night.
meaning_story: A self kill is when you kill yourself. That's suicide.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お集まりの皆さん、本日は度重なる力士の不祥事に関する会議にご出席いただき有難うございます。
ex_1_en: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for attending today’s conference regarding the repeated misconduct of our sumo wrestlers.
meaning_story: A power samurai isn't a samurai at all. A Samurai's all about precision, after all. So, imagine someone that's a huge mass of muscle (and fat). This Japanese warrior is all about power... ramming into people as hard as they can to knock them over. This person is a sumo wrestler.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「私、フグのこと嫌い。」「同感だわ。」
ex_1_en: "I hate Fugu." "I feel the same way."
meaning_story: When you have the same feeling as someone else, you have sympathy for them, because you know how they feel. How kind of you!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「どうして、食器が一式多いの？」「お前がフグを招待したからだろ。」「あぁ、そっか。 ごめんなさい。 フグは来ないのよ。 数日前に元カノが街に遊びにやってきて、よりを戻したから、サンクスギビングは彼女と一緒に過ごすんだって。」
ex_1_en: "How come we have one extra place setting?" "Because you invited Fugu." "Oh, right. Sorry, but Fugu’s not coming anymore. His ex-girlfriend came to town the other day and they got back together, so he’s spending Thanksgiving with her."
meaning_story: Your eating containers can be a lot of things. For a more general meaning, this can be your tableware. But, more specifically it can also mean your eating utensils or your utensils. Basically, it's stuff you use to eat your food.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to note the shortened しょく.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私達のお客様全員に感謝したいと思います。私達は、皆さん無しには、ここには居られません。
ex_1_en: I would like to express my gratitude to all our clients. Without you, we would not be here.
meaning_story: You have feelings of apologizing. Strangely, this word means thanks and gratitude, though. Perhaps someone did something so nice for you that you want to apologize for how many nice things they're doing for you. You are this grateful to them!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 五感に関する日本語の単語と動詞の他に、第六感に関する語彙も学習してください。
ex_1_en: Please study Japanese words and verbs related to the five senses, as well as some Japanese vocabulary related to the sixth sense.
meaning_story: The five feelings that you have are what? Sight, sound, taste, touch, and smell (don't count the sixth one where you see dead people). These are the five senses that you probably have.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチはTofuguの創始者であり、近代日本を代表する啓蒙思想家である。
ex_1_en: Koichi is the founder of Tofugu and one of the great modern Japanese thinkers.
meaning_story: The concept you think about is your thoughts. It is your ideas.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今日、ちょっと自転車貸してもらえないかな？今、車輪を取り替えてもらっているので、自分のが無いんだよね。
ex_1_en: Could I borrow your bicycle today? I don’t have mine right now because I’m having a wheel replaced.
meaning_story: The car rings are what part of your car? What's round and ringy? Those are your tires. So, a car ring is a tire.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 君が満足する結果が得られないのは申し訳ないけど、自分でやってもいないことに謝るつもりはないよ。
ex_1_en: I’m sorry that you won’t get a satisfying result, but I refuse to apologize for something I didn’t do.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means apologize so the verb vocab version is to apologize.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you say you're sorry to apologize, you'd probably start with: "I am (あやま) sorry!"

ex_1_jp: なんてこった！今までの人類の歴史上で最高の日本語学習教材を作っちまったぜ！みんなマジで感動するだろうな！
ex_1_en: Oh my God! I just made the best Japanese learning material in the history of mankind! Everyone will be really excited!
meaning_story: You know this is a verb from the する. Your feelings have been moved. So, when your feelings have been moved, you are emotionally moved. This word is to be emotionally moved or simply to be moving. Just be sure to know this has to do with emotions.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
