ex_1_jp: コウイチは湖の水面に映る美しい山に感動し、ホロリと涙を流した。
ex_1_en: A tear rolled down Koichi’s cheek when he saw the beautiful mountains reflected on the surface of the lake.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means reflect. The verb vocab version means to be reflected. You're not doing the reflecting directly. You can remember this by thinking how rude (る) it is that someone's reflecting your image using a mirror for everyone outside the dressing room to see.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your reflection is getting reflected onto the mirror. You don't like it, it doesn't look like you. Impostor reflection! You take a hammer and you 打つ (うつ) it as hard as you can, glass flying everywhere. Then some dubstep starts playing from the broken mirror: うつうつうつうつ. You're obviously on meth or something.

ex_1_jp: ようやく子どもから手が放れたと思ったんだが、五十三歳の妻がまた妊娠してしまってね。
ex_1_en: I thought that I was finally free of having to care for my children but then my 53-year-old wife got pregnant again.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means release and the verb vocab version means to be released. You can differentiate this one from 放す (to release) by thinking that it's pretty rare (れる) for you to be released by your arch nemesis like this. He just let you go, strangely. How rare.
reading_story: The reading comes from 放す. As long as you know that word you can apply that reading over here as well.

ex_1_jp: 忍者Tofugu組が夜に城へ忍び寄ったということが、コウイチ将軍に伝わった。
ex_1_en: A message about how the Tofugu ninjas crept towards the castle during the night was transmitted to Shogun Koichi.
meaning_story: This is similar to 伝える, which was a couple levels ago. This time something is being transmitted (and you aren't doing the actual transmitting, directly). You can remember this because of the わる. In the wall there are tons of cables. All of them are transmitting electricity and information without your help. That's why this one is to be transmitted rather than to transmit.
reading_story: The reading comes from 伝える. So long as you know that you can "transmit" the reading to this word as well, you should be fine.

ex_1_jp: ビエトとコウイチは、オフィスで野菜を育てるのが大好きです。
ex_1_en: Viet and Koichi love growing vegetables in their office.
meaning_story: This is similar to 育つ, except now you're doing the raising of someone. This word means to bring up or to raise. You can remember this because of the てる. Your version of bringing a child up involves tearing (てる) all their clothes to make them look poor so they can get the cheaper lunch at school. You're rich because of all the tax breaks you get from all the children you're raising, but you could always use more money to fuel your Starcraft addiction (we've all been there).
reading_story: The reading comes from 育つ. So long as you know that one, you know how to read this one as well.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの塗り絵は人気すぎて、生産が需要に追い付かなかった。
ex_1_en: Tofugu’s coloring book was so popular that production couldn’t keep up with demand.
meaning_story: You follow then attach yourself to the thing you're following. You have now caught up! This verb is to catch up.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, but you can also just notice that this word includes 追う and 付く combined.

ex_1_jp: 良いフグのコスチュームをお選びになりましたね。
ex_1_en: You chose a great Fugu costume.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means choose is to choose.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have the opportunity to choose. You choose, and a bright sign lights up reading "error" (えら).

ex_1_jp: 最近兄に冷たくされていると感じます。
ex_1_en: I feel like my older brother has been giving me the cold shoulder recently.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means feeling so the verb vocab version is to feel.
reading_story: Guess what? Even though this would use the vocab kun'yomi reading, usually, the readings for both on'yomi and kun'yomi on this kanji are the same, meaning you can read this word no matter what. Feeling better now?

ex_1_jp: 剣道は通常、一対一で戦う武道だが、コウイチは五年前、二人の男を同時に相手にしなくてはいけなかった。
ex_1_en: Kendo is normally a one-on-one martial art, but 5 years ago Koichi had to fight against two guys at the same time.
meaning_story: This is the verb version of the vocab word 戦い, which I'm hoping you learned earlier. The verb version of course means to fight or to battle.
reading_story: The reading comes from 戦い a word you've hopefully seen by now. Associate these words together in your mind and you'll be able to read them so long as you know the other one.

ex_1_jp: シャチの群れを追いかけてるフグを見たよ。
ex_1_en: I saw Fugu following a pod of killer whales.
meaning_story: You know that 追う is "to chase." So, you're chasing something or someone, or something similar. Just think of the かける as you being all "cocky" about it. You're not just chasing this person, you're following them too. So, this word is to follow and to stalk. Scary!
reading_story: The reading comes from 追う as well as the kanji reading you learned too.

ex_1_jp: たまにはあなたのご主人にも感謝しろよ。あいつだって、立派に家族を養ってきたじゃないか。
ex_1_en: You should thank your husband sometimes. He has done a good job supporting your family, hasn’t he?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means foster so the verb vocab version is to foster.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're offering to raise some girl as your own. After the paperwork is over, you can finally say: "Yah, she now (やしな) is my kid!"
pitch_accent: ヤシナꜜウ *** ヤシナウ

ex_1_jp: ごめんなさい。お手伝いしてあげたいんだけど、私にはどうにもできないんです。
ex_1_en: I’m sorry. I’d like to help but my hands are tied.
meaning_story: When you transmit your hand to something or someone, you're putting out your hand to help them or to assist them.
reading_story: Both of these are the kun'yomi readings that you learned with the kanji! The things is, the た goes to だ for who knows what reason. Perhaps you can ask for someone to help you to understand this dumb reading change.

ex_1_jp: もし指を喉に突っ込む以外でゲロを吐く方法を学びたいなら、裸のコウイチを想像するといいよ。
ex_1_en: If you want to learn how to vomit without sticking your finger down your throat, just imagine Koichi naked.
meaning_story: To do a concept of an image (in your mind) would require you to imagine it, because it's just a concept and not real.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私、シンデレラは実際、継母のこと殺したくて仕方がなかったと思うんだよね。
ex_1_en: I think Cinderella was actually really keen on killing her step mother.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means kill so the verb vocab version is to kill.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You kill someone! Oh no, what are you going to do? Where will you put the body? You decide to stuff it into the core (ころ) of a nuclear silo. It will melt and disappear in there, right? At least, that's what you think. Imagine opening up the core of the nuclear silo and feel the burn of the radiation. You throw the body in and close the core, then run away. Unfortunately, this nuclear core will kill you too, eventually. Then, it will kill everyone in the area, because the body you threw in will overheat the core, causing a giant explosion.

ex_1_jp: ガシャーンと大きな音がして、私は思わず後ろを見返った。
ex_1_en: There was a huge crash and I involuntarily looked behind me.
meaning_story: Your seeing is returning on something. This is when you look back at something you've already looked at before. This word means to look back at.
reading_story: The readings are just 見 and the vocab word 返る, combined together. So long as you know both of those you should be able to combine them into the reading for this word.
pitch_accent: ミカエル *** ミカꜜエル

ex_1_jp: 外食でも、お持ち帰りで注文しても、僕はどちらでも構わないよ。
ex_1_en: We could eat out or order take-out. I don’t mind one way or the other.
meaning_story: You hopefully have seen the word 注文 (order, request). This is just the verb version: to order / to request.
reading_story: If you know the reading of 注文 you should be able to read this one too. Also, it's just all jukugo on'yomi readings, so you should be able to read it anyways.

ex_1_jp: ここまでは理解していただけたかと思うのですが。それでは、次の話題に移りましょうか。トマトの原産地が南米であるということ以外に、フグの一番好きな野菜だってことを知っていましたか？
ex_1_en: I hope you’ve understood so far. All right, now let’s move on to the next topic. Did you know tomatoes are not only native to South America but they’re also Fugu’s favorite vegetable?
meaning_story: The topic that we are talking about is the topic that we are talking about. It's the subject of our conversation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女と別れる時に、涙が止まらなかった。
ex_1_en: When I parted from her, the tears didn’t stop.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means separate, so you can guess the meaning is to separate or to be divided.
reading_story: Remember the word 分ける? That word means "to separate" too. The reading is similar, though not the same, but we can at least use it as a jumping off point. We go from わける to わかれる. It's like we've "separated" the け and the る and combined them in the middle. け, making a かれ, which gets you to わかれる.

ex_1_jp: 動画を共有する方法を教えてください。
ex_1_en: Please teach me how to share videos.
meaning_story: This is the same as 共有 but the verb version.
reading_story: The reading comes from 共有 as well as the readings you learned via the kanji.

ex_1_jp: この駅員、こう見えてすっごくお金持ちなのよ。
ex_1_en: You couldn’t tell from looking, but this station attendant is a really rich guy.
meaning_story: A train station member is someone who works at the train station. They are a train station employee. Feel free to ask them if you need help knowing which direction to train in.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: エキꜜイン *** エキイン

ex_1_jp: トフグの社員は、どこの出身かによって、肌の色も体型も大きさも様々で、みんなそれぞれユニークな個性をもっています。
ex_1_en: Tofugu workers vary in size, shape, and color, depending on where they come from. They all have unique characteristics.
meaning_story: This is a weird word, sorry ahead of time. You have the formal name title plus another formal name title (thanks to the 々). When you have several different kinds of formal name titles you have all kinds of fancy people that you're talking to. Each one of them is different. There are many various people!
reading_story: The reading is just the reading you learned with the kanji. The second one is ざま however, which plays right into the "various" meaning of the word. There's even various ways to read さま in this word!
pitch_accent: サマꜜザマ *** サマザꜜマ

ex_1_jp: 数日前、病院の待合室で経済についての本を読んだんだけど、結構良かったよ。
ex_1_en: I read an economics book the other day in the hospital waiting room and it was pretty interesting.
meaning_story: A room where you join other people to wait. This is a waiting room.
reading_story: Remember how you learned 待合 already? Well throw the on'yomi for 室 on the end of that and you have your reading!

ex_1_jp: 私は英語のネイティブスピーカーだが、日本語でテレパシーをする能力がある。
ex_1_en: I’m a native English speaker, but my telepathic abilities are in Japanese.
meaning_story: Your ability power is what you can do. This is your ability. It is also your capability.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: Tofugu的秘密計画って一体何ですか？もう少し具体的におっしゃって頂けませんか？
ex_1_en: What do you mean by a Tofugu-style secret plan? Do you think you could be more specific?
meaning_story: This is a strange word, I'm afraid. You'll have to bear with it. This, when added onto a word, is like adding an "-al" to a word (or a -like to a word). For example, add it onto 日本 (Japan) and you have "Japanese-like," which comes out to "Very Japanese." It's a weird sort of modifying word that really depends on each situation it's in, though -al and -like often do a decent job. For now, just know this word means these things. We'll start applying it to various words in the future, slowly but surely.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, probably because this is usually added onto other words, making it behave like a jukugo.

ex_1_jp: 今度の日曜日に、私達はマクドナルドでTofuguの五周年記念を祝います。
ex_1_en: Next Sunday we’ll celebrate Tofugu’s fifth anniversary at McDonald’s.
meaning_story: When you wrap around the entire circumference of the year you've come back around to the start of it. This is the anniversary.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: アヤは、芸術と音楽への愛をもっと多くの人に伝えるべきだ。
ex_1_en: Aya should share her love of art and music to more people.
meaning_story: The acting arts are the greatest arts of all. Back in the day they were the only arts, which is why the art of acting is just art itself. In fact, it's THE arts.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ゲイジュツ *** ゲꜜイジュツ

ex_1_jp: えーっと、なんだか会議は煙たい雰囲気で終わったよね。まさか最後に社長が屁をこくなんてね。まぁ、おもしろかったけどさ。
ex_1_en: Well, the meeting ended with an awkward atmosphere, didn’t it? I can’t believe our president farted at the end. It was funny, though.
meaning_story: The surrounding energy in the atmosphere is what makes up the atmosphere. I love it when it takes three kanji to represent what one of the three kanji already represents.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「土曜日と日曜日、どちらの方が都合がいい？」「どちらでもいいよ。」
ex_1_en: "Which day is convenient for you, Saturday or Sunday?" "It makes no difference to me."
meaning_story: This one makes no sense (sorry!). When you join together with someone at a metropolis, you do it at your convenience. You're important, after all, so you just do what you want and make the other person wait in this giant metropolis while you move along leisurely. Imagine this, and keep thinking "at your convenience" as you walk about. This word is usually used in a nicer way, though. As in, "do it at your convenience!"
reading_story: The reading for this kanji makes very little sense. You didn't learn the readings for either of these kanji like this, so let's just learn it using a mnemonic. You're going to go (つごう) to the metropolis to join up with your friend, at your convenience. You're going to go as slow and leisurely as you want.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの方針で、許可無くコウイチのベーコンを食べた社員は、自動的に退職処分となる。
ex_1_en: It’s Tofugu policy that workers caught eating Koichi’s bacon without permission are automatically fired.
meaning_story: Something that can move by its self is something that's automatic.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 僕の両親は、今後の寝る時間に悪例を残すことになるからって、絶対に夜更かしさせてくれないんだ。
ex_1_en: My parents never let me stay up late because they believe that it would set a bad precedent for future bedtimes.
meaning_story: A bad example is a bad example and is something you don't want.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 昨夜、Tofuguのオフィスに放火する夢を見たんだけど、焼け跡の灰には、大量の魚の骨があったよ。
ex_1_en: Last night, I dreamt that I was burning the Tofugu office. In the ashes of the ruins, I saw a mountain of fish bones.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Take a look at your own bones. They have been upgraded with special technology, allowing you to hone (ほね) in on targets, then shoot your bones at them. Go ahead and imagine yourself using this crazy new bone technology. Wolverine is jealous.
pitch_accent: コツꜜ *** コツ *** ホネꜜ

ex_1_jp: しばらくみんなで一緒に会ってないよね〜。最近どうしてるの？私は足の小指を骨折した以外は特に変わりないよ〜。（笑）
ex_1_en: It’s been a while since we all got together. How have you been? Things are pretty much the same with me except I broke my pinky toe. Lol.
meaning_story: When your bone gets folded like paper, or something, you can bet you have a broken bone or fracture.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out because こつ is shortened to こっ here.

ex_1_jp: どうしてもコピー用紙がいるんだけど、この花束とそのコピー用紙一束を交換してもらえないかな？
ex_1_en: I have to get some copy paper. Could you exchange a bundle of copy paper for this bouquet of flowers?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You are counting your bundles. There are a lot of them, so you have to create tabs (たば) in your notebook to properly categorize everything. Imagine yourself doing this (physically creating the tabs in your notebook, even though your notebook didn't come with tabs).

ex_1_jp: コウイチは人格者です。毎週日曜日に孤児院に出向いて、ベーコンを寄付しているのです。
ex_1_en: Koichi is a person of integrity. Every Sunday he goes to the orphanage and donates bacon.
meaning_story: Your person status is where you yourself are as a person. This is more than skin deep, though, this is your status after all. This is your character and personality. What's the status of your character? Good? Bad? Getting there?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 周りの目が気になるんです。
ex_1_en: Everyone around me is worried.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji circumference, so it means circumference too.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You really want to measure the circumference of something but there doesn't seem to be anything round around. That's when you remember, "Mah Walnuts! (まわ)." The walnuts in your pocket have an easy edge to measure.

ex_1_jp: 彼は根っからの芸人かもしれない。
ex_1_en: He might be a natural born performer.
meaning_story: A person who does humorous acting is a comedian. You might think that this would be actor most of the time, but actually - it's usually comedian.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ああ、もう！お前のせいで完全に気が散っちゃったじゃないか！話したいことって何なんだよ。オフィスで飼う犬だっけか？
ex_1_en: Oh jeez! Now you’ve completely distracted me. What was it that you wanted to talk about... office doge, was it?
meaning_story: When something is all perfect it is complete. Not only that, but it's perfect (because it's ALL perfect, not just partially so).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 我々の新しい日本語学習アプリは、あと一ヶ月程で完成します。
ex_1_en: Our new Japanese learning app will be completed in a month or so.
meaning_story: When something has become perfect it has reached completion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 携帯の充電が完了してから折り返してもいいかな？
ex_1_en: I’ll call you back when my cellphone battery is fully charged, okay?
meaning_story: A perfect finish is when everything is at total completion. Nothing is left over and all is done.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この仕事に、妥協は許されないよ。
ex_1_en: At this job, compromise is not allowed.
meaning_story: When you have gentle cooperation nobody has their way. You're very gently coming towards the middle, coming to a compromise. (Whether you like it or not.)
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 簡単な料理しかできません。
ex_1_en: I can only cook simple cuisine.
meaning_story: There is a reason for this fee that you have to pay to get in here. We are doing cooking and cuisine for you to eat while you're watching the show. If we weren't doing cooking, we probably wouldn't charge you this fee!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 我々に協力するか、少なくとも協力するふりをしてくれませんか？
ex_1_en: Could you please cooperate or at least pretend to cooperate with us?
meaning_story: Cooperation power is your level of cooperation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 東北の天気は短い周期で変わる。
ex_1_en: Tohoku’s weather changes in short cycles.
meaning_story: If you follow the circumference of a period of time, you end up back at the beginning and it makes a full cycle. Events in history always repeat, right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この要求はいくらなんでも無茶だ。
ex_1_en: These demands are way too absurd.
meaning_story: You need this request to happen, so you don't just request it, you demand it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このプールの深さを教えて下さい。
ex_1_en: Could you tell me the depth of this pool?
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji deep, so it means depth.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 深い so you should be able to read this one too!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 結婚願望はあるんだけど、なかなか理想通りの相手が見つからなくてさ。
ex_1_en: I want to get married but can’t find anyone that’s up to my standards.
meaning_story: The hope you request is your desire. Just imagine yourself hoping and requesting some higher power for something you really want. What is this? It's your desire or wish.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ガンボー *** ガンモー

ex_1_jp: マジ、自分に超失望中だよ〜。ノースリーブのシャツが着たいんだけど、ポッチャリ二の腕が気になってさ。しかも、腰まわりもたるんできたし。彼氏は私のポッチャリした指が好きだとか言うんだけど、そんなの全然嬉しくないってのさ。
ex_1_en: I’m really disappointed. I want to wear sleeveless shirts, but my chubby arms bother me a lot. My waist is getting flabby, too. My boyfriend tells me that he likes my pudgy fingers, but it doesn’t make me happy at all, you know?
meaning_story: There is fault in your hope. It breaks, and everything falls apart. You feel massive disappointment and despair.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: けしごむ, けしゴム
ex_1_jp: 「謝るチャンスをあげようと思ってたんだけど、コウイチ。」「何のために？ 俺たちのオフィスから、オレを放り出させたことにか？」「それは、君が僕の消しゴムを盗んだからそうなったんだろう？謝ってよ！」
ex_1_en: "I was gonna give you a chance to apologize to me, Koichi." "For what, Viet? For letting you throw me out of our office?" "It happened because you stole my eraser! I need an apology!"
meaning_story: You've seen the word 消す, I hope. This comes from that. You're extinguishing something with ゴム. ゴム is a word for either gummy or rubbery things. So, this is a gummy thing that extinguishes something. This is an eraser that extinguishes pencil markings.
reading_story: The reading comes from 消す, so make sure you know that word so you can read this one!

ex_1_jp: ところで、そもそも、何の経験もなくて、どうやってその職を得たの？あ、悪気は無いよ。
ex_1_en: By the way, how did you get the job in the first place without any experience? No offense.
meaning_story: Someone with bad energy is someone who has evil intent. Hopefully you don't have too much 悪気.
reading_story: The reading itself has a lot of 悪気 with all the exceptions it has. The 悪 part is read like 悪い. Then, 気 is rendaku'd. What an evil reading. Just think "what's the most evil reading I can come up with?" when you see this word. Then you should hopefully be able to read it.

ex_1_jp: 何故だか分からないんだけど、僕の先生は例文を作る時にいつも僕の名前を使うんだよね。
ex_1_en: For some reason my teacher always uses my name when she makes example sentences.
meaning_story: Example writing is a piece of writing that is an example for maybe a word or a kanji or something like that. This is an example sentence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチはいつも朝遅くまで寝ていますが、金曜日はスーツを着なくてはいけないので例外です。
ex_1_en: Koichi usually sleeps in, but Friday is an exception because he has to wear a suit.
meaning_story: Something that's outside the example doesn't follow the rules. It's not what it's supposed to be (the example), it is the exception.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は女の子なんかじゃないよ。私はれっきとした女性だよ。
ex_1_en: I am not a girl. I’m a lady.
meaning_story: Someone who's of the woman gender is probably going to be female.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ジョセイ *** ニョショー

ex_1_jp: アヤは、人間の剥製という美しい美術作品が並べられたアジトを「Tofuguの恐ろしい美術館」と名付けた。そして、コウイチとビエトもその剥製の一つにされようとしていた。
ex_1_en: Aya named her hideout "Tofugu Terrible Art Gallery" because it was filled with her beautiful art work - stuffed corpses. Koichi and Viet were to join her collection.
meaning_story: The beauty art is not just any art. It's the best art. It's fine art.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: なぁ、さくらちゃん、例えば、週に一度や二度ぐらい、うちに来ないか？
ex_1_en: Hey, Sakura, why don’t you come over to my house, like, once or twice a week or something?
meaning_story: This has almost the same meaning as the kanji it comes from. Instead of just simply being "example," though, it's for example. So, you could start a sentence with this and be all like "例えば, I am using 例えば in a sentence."
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Using all kinds of "for examples" like this, you were taught (たと) many things throughout your life. For example, you were taught about...

ex_1_jp: 私は日本語の基本中の基本も知らない超初心者です。
ex_1_en: I’m a super beginner who doesn’t even know the most basic of basics of Japanese.
meaning_story: The origin of your foundation is where you have to work from when learning something new. For example, the 基本 portions of WaniKani are the earlier levels, especially the radicals. They are the foundation you need to learn your kanji and vocab later on.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチ、昨日は私達が芸者遊びをしている間、フグと私の子どもを見ててくれてありがとう。再度お礼を言いたくて。
ex_1_en: Koichi, I just wanted to say thank you again for taking care of Fugu and my kid yesterday while we were drinking with geisha.
meaning_story: You'd think that someone who does acting is an actor or something... but think about the reading for this kanji. What is it? Do you recognize the word? It's geisha.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 性というところに男性か女性か記入してください。
ex_1_en: Please fill out whether you are a man or a woman under gender.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
pitch_accent: サꜜカ° *** ショꜜー *** セꜜイ

ex_1_jp: その患者さんの経過は過去六ヶ月間良好で、普段通りの生活を送ることができています。
ex_1_en: The patient has been doing great for the last six months and has been able to live a normal life.
meaning_story: A good like is something you like really good, if that makes any sense. This thing is a good and favorable thing.
reading_story: The reading is all on'yomi, though you learned kun'yomi with 良. You've seen the りょう reading before by now, though, so hopefully you'll just know it already and be able to use it. That would be good, anyways.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 先生は、日本語が話せると、卒業生の就職の可能性が高くなると思いますか？
ex_1_en: Teacher, do you think that being able to speak Japanese enhances a graduate’s chances of finding a job?
meaning_story: The business of you graduating is your graduation. If you think about it, it's kind of a big business, getting you graduated from expensive schools. The graduation business focuses on graduations, and getting you there (hint: this business is a school, probably).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: アヤがキンニクマの洗濯板のような腹筋と岩のように固い胸筋を触っているのを見ちゃったんだよね。
ex_1_en: I saw Aya touching Kinnikuma’s washboard stomach and rock-hard pecs.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of hard? It's hard.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to cut something that's extremely hard so you pull out your diamond cutters (かた). Go ahead and imagine yourself cutting this ridiculously hard thing. Good thing you have diamond cutters, though.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: やったー！ついに念願の彼氏ができたよー！やっぱ一生懸命願えば叶うもんだね！超幸せー！
ex_1_en: Yay! After all this waiting, I finally got a boyfriend. I guess if you wish hard enough, you really can get what you want. I’m so happy!
meaning_story: What your thoughts request inside your head, nonstop like a crazy person, are your heart's desires.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ネンカ°ン *** ネンカ°ꜜン

ex_1_jp: トフグのブログで拝見した求人の件でお電話しました。プログラマー職に応募したいのですが、ビエトさんはまだ生きていらっしゃいますか？今朝方刺客を送り込んでおいたのですが。
ex_1_en: I’m calling regarding the position advertised in the Tofugu blog. I’d like to apply for the programmer position, but is Mr. Viet still alive? I sent an assassin after him this morning.
meaning_story: When you're requesting people you're seeking workers. "Help wanted!" is what this word is basically saying.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「お座席のご希望はございますか？」「はい。窓側の席を取っていただけますか？」「かしこまりました。」
ex_1_en: "Do you have a seating preference?" "Yes, can I have a window seat please?" "Certainly."
meaning_story: Both your hopes and wishes are held within this vocab word. So, what is the meaning of this word? It is both hope and wish. Either will work.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 人性論における人間の本性について、私は結局人の性質は善悪を共に備えていると思います。
ex_1_en: With regard to the discussion about original human nature in Confucianism, I believe that human nature is equipped with both good and evil sides after all.
meaning_story: A person's nature is just human nature! Everyone has their own human instincts.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 昨日の夜、バーデビューしちゃった。私もちょっとずつ大人の階段登ってるって感じ？
ex_1_en: I went to a bar for the first time last night. I feel like I’m becoming an adult little by little.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: If you're lucky, you already know this (very) common word's reading. It's the word for "I," probably one of the first things you'd learn in Japanese. The reading for this is わたし. If you don't know that already, just think: "What, a し?" referring to the reading of the kanji, which is し.

ex_1_jp: 今、消化不良で苦しんでるの。胸焼けもするし、膨満感もあるし、すごく気持ち悪い。しばらく放っておいてくれない。
ex_1_en: I am suffering from indigestion. I have heartburn, bloating, and I feel sick to my stomach. Please leave me alone.
meaning_story: You've hopefully seen 消化 by now and know that it means "digestion." If you know that, then you can see that the "digestion" is not good. When your digestion is not good, what do you have? Indigestion. Excuse me, I have to run to the restroom...
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 消化 and 不良 will help as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の好きな食べ物は饂飩ですが、麺の材料は、小麦粉と塩と水だけなんですよ。
ex_1_en: My favorite food is udon noodles and the ingredients are just wheat flour, salt, and water.
meaning_story: You have a fee for lumber, so imagine yourself paying this fee for this lumber. You need this lumber for ingredients for your stew that you're making. Now imagine yourself putting this lumber in your stew and tasting it. How is it? Now look at the ingredients for this stew on your cookbook, only to realize it doesn't actually ask for any lumber.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私のビジネスの秘書としてサーモンを迎え入れた後で、彼女が職場で突然感情を爆発させる性格であることが判明したのです。例えば、自分のデスクの電話を引き抜いて、粉々にブチ壊しちゃったりとか、まあ、ほんの一例を挙げればそんな感じです。
ex_1_en: After I hired Salmon as the secretary for my business, I found out that she was the type of person who has sudden emotional outbursts in the office. For example, she ripped the telephone from her desk and smashed it to pieces, just to name one small incident.
meaning_story: One example is just an instance of what you're describing. Just one example.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 熊は、動物の本能で危険を察知した。
ex_1_en: The bear sensed danger with its animal instincts.
meaning_story: The abilities you originally start out with are instincts. Animals have lots of them because they aren't very good at learning. They have to start out knowing them from the start.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ホꜜンノー *** ホンノꜜー *** ホンノー

ex_1_jp: 意図的に情報を操作している奴がいる。
ex_1_en: There’s a guy manipulating the news on purpose.
meaning_story: You wouldn't put your idea in a diagram ~like format if it wasn't intentional. Doing that takes a lot of work. So you can only make diagram like things on purpose!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 図 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You intentionally stub your toe (と) all the time! If you hurt your toe on purpose you can get out of class and work! Its a really simple injury, but you can't do other stuff while it's hurt, so you always do it on purpose to get out of things.

ex_1_jp: 材木が来たらすぐに犬小屋作りに取り掛からないとな。
ex_1_en: We should get started building the doghouse as soon as the lumber gets here.
meaning_story: Lumber trees are what you use to make lumber and timber.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチと付き合うチャンスを得るために、 まず本当のことを言わなきゃなんだけど、でも、どういう風に昔は男性だったってこと打ち明けたらいいんだろう。
ex_1_en: If I’m ever gonna have a chance with Koichi, I gotta come clean, but how can I tell him I used to be a man?
meaning_story: A man's gender is known as "male."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どうして妹に意地悪ばっかりするの！
ex_1_en: Why are you so mean to my little sister?!
meaning_story: A person whose ideas are grounded in evil is a malicious, mean jerk!
reading_story: This reading is a combination of the on'yomi readings for 意 and 地, and the kun'yomi reading for 悪. You've learned them all already, so this should be cake!
pitch_accent: イジワꜜル *** イジꜜワル

ex_1_jp: とても近代的な建物ですね。
ex_1_en: It’s a really modern building, isn’t it?
meaning_story: Something that looks like it was made near the period you're currently in is really modern! But if it looks like it's from a period not near the one you're in... throw it away! It isn't modern enough to touch your hands!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お互い色々あったんだけど、山登りをしながらじっくり話し合ってさ。なんと復縁することになったよ。
ex_1_en: Both of us have been through a lot, but we had a long talk while climbing a mountain and decided to get back together.
meaning_story: You've hopefully seen how 登る means "to climb." So, if you're climbing a mountain what is that? It's mountain climbing.
reading_story: The reading comes from combining 山 and 登る together to form one word, 山登り. If you know the readings of those two words you know the reading of this word too.

ex_1_jp: あの人、何だか動きが不自然ですね。
ex_1_en: That person’s movements are a little unnatural.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji move. So it means movement.
reading_story: This is the same reading you learned from the word 動く. If you know that word, you know how to read this word!

ex_1_jp: トフグチームは世界一周旅行に出かけるので、オフィスは約一年間不在となります。
ex_1_en: The Tofugu team is going to make an around the world trip, so the office will be closed for about a year.
meaning_story: One circumference is one time around. How many times will you go around the moon? Just 一周?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the いち becomes いっ as it often does when being used in a counter (一階, 一回, etc).

ex_1_jp: 残業後にイタメシ屋でお一人様しちゃったよ〜。なかなか寂しかったぜぃ。笑
ex_1_en: After working overtime I went to an Italian restaurant alone. I felt pretty lonely. lol
meaning_story: The remainder of time that you work at the ol' business is extra time that you're working (above the normal work hours). This is overtime!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 富士山の火口の周囲は約三キロメートルで、深さは二百三十七メートルだと聞きました。
ex_1_en: I was told that Mt. Fuji’s crater is about three kilometers around and two hundred and thirty-seven meters deep.
meaning_story: The circumference that surrounds us is the perimeter of the area. Do not cross it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の旦那さんの性格はのんびり屋で、忘れっぽくて、優柔不断です。彼のことは大好きだけど、たまにイラッとくるんだよね。
ex_1_en: My husband is really easy going, but forgetful and indecisive. I love him but sometimes it drives me nuts.
meaning_story: For some reason the status of your gender is what dictates your personality. Think of it this way: What kind of personality does someone of the female gender usually have? What about the personality of a male gender? Their personality status always seems to fit into gender roles, which is why the status of the gender dictates the personality. Make sense?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチ、仕事で相当ストレスがたまっているみたいで、私生活が荒れてきてるんだよね。ちょっと相談相手になってあげてくれないかな。誰か聞いてくれる人が必要だと思うんだよね。
ex_1_en: Koichi has a lot of stress from work and his personal life is getting messed up. Could you advise him? I believe he needs someone to listen to him.
meaning_story: You've seen 生活 before, right? So what about the "life" of I? Who's life is that? Why, that's my own personal life.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その松買うのに、二十分間も待ったんだよ。
ex_1_en: I bought that pine tree and yet I had to wait twenty minutes to get it.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so no need to think too hard.

ex_1_jp: 今度の昇給が得られれば、ようやく両親に松葉ガニを買ってやることができる。
ex_1_en: Getting this raise will finally enable me to buy a Matsuba crab for my parents.
meaning_story: The leaves of a pine are not really leaves, they're more like needles, thus making this word pine needle.
reading_story: If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 葉 gets rendaku'd to ば though, so watch out for that.

ex_1_jp: ここ数年の間に、「ミーム」はインターネットでの流行語となりました。
ex_1_en: In the past few years, "meme" has become a popular word on the internet.
meaning_story: The stream go language. This is language that goes down the stream with everything else. Imagine this language being carried away quite quickly so everyone standing on the edge of the stream can grab some of this language. This thing streaming down it is a popular phrase. Yolo!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は、流行歌ではないけど良い曲を見つけるのが好きです。
ex_1_en: I like finding good music, but not necessarily popular songs.
meaning_story: You know that 流行 refers to a "trend." So, a "trend" song is a popular song.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: コウイチがカフェでこっそり会っていた男の人は、私立探偵だったということが判明しました。
ex_1_en: I found out that the guy Koichi secretly met at the cafe was a private detective.
meaning_story: The place where I stand is my own private area. Think of the "circle of personal space." This is where you stand plus an arm's length. This area is very private to you. Who knows what you do in your own private area.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: シꜜリツ *** ワタクシꜜリツ

ex_1_jp: 私は、とある日本の大手私鉄会社で働いております。
ex_1_en: I work for one of the major private railway companies in Japan.
meaning_story: A private iron (remember how 鉄 often has to do with railroad tracks and the like? Same goes here) is a private railway. There are a good number of these in Japan.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日程の件で色々と振り回しちゃって本当にごめんね。四日なら都合がつきそうです。次は今回みたいなドタキャンは絶対しないって約束します!
ex_1_en: I’m really sorry to cause so much scheduling trouble. I can free up the fourth. I promise I will never cancel at the last minute like this again.
meaning_story: A promise bundle is still a promise no matter how many you have wrapped up there. One promise is just another promise which is just another promise.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今までで、約百万人の人がTofuguのフェイスブックページに「いいね」をした。
ex_1_en: Approximately a million people have liked Tofugu’s Facebook page so far.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. See? I promised this one would be easy and it was.

ex_1_jp: 私たちの目的は、一緒に楽しみながら皆さんに日本語を勉強してもらうことです。
ex_1_en: Our goal is to make you all have fun while studying Japanese together.
meaning_story: When your eye is on the target you know your purpose. You also have your eye on the goal (that's the target, after all!).
reading_story: The reading is a reading for 目 that's abnormal. You've seen this reading with 目標 and 目次, though, so hopefully it won't be too hard at this point. Just imagine telling someone your 目的, only to have them laugh in your face and begin mocking もく you for it. Now you're not so sure if your goal is going to work.

ex_1_jp: ダメだと分かっていたが、理性を保てなかったんだ。
ex_1_en: I understood it was hopeless, but I couldn’t hold on to reason.
meaning_story: The nature of reason is still reason.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今夜はデートがあるので、晩御飯は残り物を温めて食べてね。ママより。
ex_1_en: I’m going on a date tonight. You can heat up some leftovers to eat for dinner. Love, Mom.
meaning_story: This has the same meaning as the kanji. The little り thrown on there is just a little remainder sticking off the end of the kanji. No need to pay attention to that.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're waiting inside. The remainder of your forces are out there, fighting. You don't know who will survive... or if they even will. You have a secret knock (のこ), though, that you use to find out if it's one of the remaining forces outside or the enemy, broken through. You hear a knock. What is it? Is it your men or theirs? Imagine it out, focusing on the knock conversation that happens between you and the remainder.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: パーマとカットの予約をしたいんですけど。
ex_1_en: Could I make an appointment for a haircut and a perm?
meaning_story: A beforehand promise is a promise you've made beforehand. This is a reservation or appointment. Makes sense, right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 新しく回転ずしのお店がオープンした。
ex_1_en: A new conveyer belt sushi shop opened.
meaning_story: You know that 回転 is "rotation" and you probably know what すし is (gets rendaku'd in this word to ずし). So, what is "rotation sushi?" It's rotating sushi, also known as conveyer belt sushi. Look it up if you don't know what it is.
reading_story: The reading comes from 回転, so be sure to know that to know this one. Also, it's just the readings of the kanji you learned too, so shouldn't be too hard.

ex_1_jp: 悲しみで食欲が全くわかなかった。
ex_1_en: My sadness made me completely lose my appetite.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji sad, so it means sadness.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
pitch_accent: カナシミ *** カナシミꜜ *** カナシꜜミ

ex_1_jp: うちの学校の文化祭にも遊びに来て下さいね。
ex_1_en: Please come visit my school’s culture festival!
meaning_story: Remember how 文化 means "culture?" Well add festival to it and you end up with a culture festival! These happen all the time at Japanese schools, so sometimes they're called school festivals too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 祭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you go to a school festival, make sure you visit the cyclops (さい) booth! You know how they have cafes and mini restaurants and stuff? Yeah, child's play. Find the class that's dressed up like cyclopses and you'll have way more fun.

ex_1_jp: 性病を移してくれてどうも有難う。とても嬉しいです。
ex_1_en: Thank you very much for giving me an STD. It means a lot to me.
meaning_story: A gender sickness is one you catch from *ahem* doing things with those of another or the same gender. You only catch these sicknesses this way, meaning they're sexually transmitted diseases (save yourself some typing and just answer with STD).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「何でミカサがエレンのことを好きなのか私には分からないわ。だって、エレンって傲慢だし、思いやりがないし、それに格好良くもないのに。」「恋は盲目っていうじゃない。」
ex_1_en: "I don’t understand why Mikasa likes Eren. He’s arrogant, he’s inconsiderate, and he isn’t even good-looking." "Love is blind."
meaning_story: You like the status of what's in front of you. It has an excellent shape and form to it. Imagine something that would be pleasing to you in terms of its shape.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to note the かく reading, which gets changed to かっ.

ex_1_jp: 芸能界のゴシップなんて全然興味ねーよ。どうでもいいっつーの。
ex_1_en: I’m not interested in the gossip of the world of show business. I couldn’t care less.
meaning_story: The world of acting ability is the world of showbusiness. Save your self some letters, honey, and call it showbiz.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コーラが骨格の発育に悪影響を与えるという噂は本当ですか？
ex_1_en: Is the rumor that Coca-cola is detrimental to skeletal development true?
meaning_story: The status of your bones (aka how they're all arranged and put together) equals your skeleton. That bone status is lookin' good on you!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that こつ changes to こっ.

ex_1_jp: 逃走するために、俺はCIA諜報員としての年月で習得した技能を駆使した。
ex_1_en: To escape, I used the skills that I had acquired in my years as a CIA agent.
meaning_story: Your skill and ability are kind of similar things. That's why this word means either or. Your skill ability is your skill and ability.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチの特技はお菓子作りです。お菓子作りが好きな理由は、みんなの嬉しそうな顔を見るのが好きだからだそうです。
ex_1_en: Koichi’s specialty is making desserts. He said he likes making them because he likes seeing everyone’s happy faces.
meaning_story: Your special skill is your specialty. So, what is your 特技?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: いつの間にか、言葉つきが女っぽくなっていた。
ex_1_en: Before he knew it, he’d started speaking like a woman.
meaning_story: Remember how 言葉 means "language?" Well when you add つき to the end of it you end up talking the whole time the moon (つき) is out and paying more attention to your own speech and wording.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 運動会の日、晴れるといいですね。
ex_1_en: I hope it’s sunny on the day of the sports festival.
meaning_story: Remember how 運動 means "exercise?" When you meet with a bunch of other people to exercise it's call Sports Day! This is a day at schools in Japan where everybody does physical stuff together! It's fun and also very tiring!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: フグは根っからの頑固者で、自分のやり方にこだわります。
ex_1_en: Fugu is stubborn to the core and is set in his ways.
meaning_story: A hard stubborn person is very stubborn no matter how you look at them. Try to break through that hard stubbornness and all you'll find is more stubborn.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 君はゴミをゴミ箱に投げ入れる才能があるね。
ex_1_en: You have a talent for throwing garbage into trash bins.
meaning_story: She who has genius ability has quite the talent.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 柔道では力より技のほうが大切であります。
ex_1_en: In judo, technique is more important than strength.
meaning_story: What is a skill? It's something you can do, and do quite well. It is a technique that you can make happen with ease.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You do your technique on a bad guy, coming at you. You flip him over and knock him out. He was (わざ) a threat, but now he's not. You look closer at the bad guy. Turns out it's Woz, the Apple Co-founder. He was just trying to hand you an iPhone12, not grab your wrist. Whoops!

ex_1_jp: 日本の四季と、それぞれの季節にどんなことをしたりどんなものを食べるのかについて、教えてもらえませんか？
ex_1_en: Can you tell me about Japan’s four seasons and what people do and eat during those times?
meaning_story: The four seasons are the four seasons. For some reason many Japanese people think that Japan's the only place with four distinct seasons. Obviously they haven't been to half the places on their latitude around the world.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 四 is read using the on'yomi reading, which you've seen a few times over the course of WaniKani. Think of し meaning "death" (like 死), and how with the four seasons there comes death every Fall and Winter.

ex_1_jp: そう悲しむなって。お前の日本語は今はそれで十分だよ。ただ、勉強することを投げ出さずに、少しずつ上手くなればいいさ。
ex_1_en: Don’t be sad. Your Japanese is good enough for now. Just don’t stop learning and you’ll improve little by little.
meaning_story: You've hopefully seen 悲しい (sad) by now, a level 12 item. It probably won't surprise you that 悲しむ (ends with an う sound, so probably is a verb) means to be sad.
reading_story: If you know the reading of 悲しい you'll be able to read this. Also, the kanji 悲 uses this reading as well.

ex_1_jp: 「ちくしょう、上司のやつ！もう、頭にきた！こんな仕事、辞めてやる。」「おいおいおい、そう焦るなって。ちょっと落ち着けよ。 」
ex_1_en: "Damn him! I’m sick of my boss. I’m going to quit my job." "Whoa, whoa, whoa. Don’t be in such a hurry. Calm Down."
meaning_story: Hey. Drop yourself down and arrive back to me. You're going nuts over there. Lower down. Come back. Arrive. You need to do these things to calm down.
reading_story: The readings come from 落ちる and 着く. Hopefully you know these words so you can read this word as well! If you don't, just 落ち着く and everything will be okay.

ex_1_jp: 私は毎日神社に参ります。
ex_1_en: I visit a Shinto shrine every day.
meaning_story: The kanji itself means participate, so you'd think this word would mean "to participate" but it doesn't (sorry!). It's a little more complex. Think of it as "to participate" but where you have to come or to go in order to do it. This is the humble way to say those things, so you're going to these places with your tail between your legs, just happy you can participate more than anything.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You get to come to participate! "It's my (まい) lucky day!" you exclaim.

ex_1_jp: 今、フグの刺し身を百切れ食べたよ。消化するのにちょっと時間がかかりそう。(ゲップ)
ex_1_en: I just ate 100 pieces of fugu sashimi. It’s gonna take a while to digest. (Burp)
meaning_story: You know how 消化 is "digestion"? Well, The verb form of that is this word, which is to digest.
reading_story: If you know 消化 you should be able to read this. Also, it uses the readings you learned with the kanji anyways, so no problemo there.

ex_1_jp: 彼は、彼女が視界から完全に消えるまで、さようならと手を振り続けた。
ex_1_en: He waved goodbye until she completely disappeared from view.
meaning_story: You've seen that 消す is "to extinguish." So, this is another verb version of that. This time, you're not doing the extinguishing, it's just happening. Something is going to disappear on its own. How can you differentiate this from 消す? Well, える allows you to notice how the object disappeared into thin air (える). You know you didn't do it, so it disappeared on its own, making it to disappear.
reading_story: The reading is different from 消す, unfortunately, so you can't use that. Just think about how after the object in front of you disappears you use a key (き) to open an invisible door. That's where everything's disappearing to! You see all your disappeared stuff on the other side of this invisible door which you opened with a magical key.

ex_1_jp: バレンタインのチョコレートを期待する。
ex_1_en: I expect Valentine’s chocolate.
meaning_story: Hopefully you know the word 期待 by now (expectation). This is the verb version, which makes it to expect.
reading_story: The reading comes from the the word 期待, so make sure you know that to know this one as well.

ex_1_jp: ちょっと、そんな風に腕を曲げるのやめてくれない？めちゃくちゃ気持ち悪いんだけど。
ex_1_en: Stop bending your arms like that. It’s seriously weirding me out.
meaning_story: The feeling is bad. So, you can imagine how you feel isn't good, it's to feel terrible.
reading_story: The readings come from the words 気持ち and 悪い. Hopefully you've seen both and can combine them together to know the reading automatically. No bad feelings with this word, right?

ex_1_jp: その紙を折った時に、指を切ってしまったんだ。
ex_1_en: When I was folding the paper I got a paper cut.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fold so the vocab verb version is to fold.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You fold your arm in half. "OH!" (お) you cry.

ex_1_jp: あのバイク事故のせいで、もう脚を動かすことができなくなっちゃったんだ。
ex_1_en: I can’t move my legs anymore because of the motorcycle accident.
meaning_story: You've seen 動く hopefully, and know it means to move. This is similar to that, but now you're moving something else. You know this because as you go to move something the thing you're moving starts to cuss (かす) you out because it's angry.
reading_story: The reading for this can come from 動く. If you know that word, you know how to read this word!

ex_1_jp: 「このテレビ番組のために私が蜘蛛を食べなくちゃいけないって、本当？」「残念ながらそのようです。」
ex_1_en: "Is it true that I have to eat spiders on this TV program?" "Unfortunately, it is."
meaning_story: The remainder of your thoughts are very small. You've thought of everything you possibly can to solve this problem. In the end, the remainder of your thoughts is left with one phrase: "too bad." There's nothing else to think but the remainder.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 表向きは入学試験に合格するために学習塾に通ってたんだけど、私は実は友達と一緒にいたかっただけなんです。
ex_1_en: I attended a cram school ostensibly to pass entrance exams, but actually I just wanted to hang out with my friends there.
meaning_story: The status joins together. Think of this like a bunch of status messages on Facebook, all coming together at the same time. A big government test has just finished. Everyone's status' are joining on Facebook together to say they passed, showing to pass a test.
reading_story: The reading for 合 is the on'yomi that you didn't learn with the kanji. You have seen this before, but perhaps a mnemonic will help. When you pass a test, what will you do? You'll go (ごう) party. No more studying. Go party!

ex_1_jp: 本契約期間中、Tofugu株式会社は日本政府に対し、日本語の教科書の年間最低発注数を定めて発注し、買い取ることを約する。
ex_1_en: During the term of this agreement, Tofugu Corporation shall guarantee the Japanese government a minimum annual purchase of their Japanese textbook.
meaning_story: To do a promise is to promise. Don't break your 約 now. You 約した!
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. See? I promised you it would be easy, and it was. You're welcome.

ex_1_jp: このお守りを肌身離さず身に着けると約束してくれないか？
ex_1_en: Could you promise me that you will wear this good luck charm all the time, please?
meaning_story: Another verb for this kanji! Crazy! I know, I'm sorry. The previous ones were: 着る (to wear), 着く (to arrive), and now 着ける (to put on / to wear). At least it's similar to 着る, right? In this case, this word is like 付ける, which means "to attach." Think about how you're attaching your clothes to your body (and putting them on). That's why this is to put on or to wear. Same sound, different kanji, similar ideas.
reading_story: The reading is the same like 着く's reading, but it might be easier to think it shares a reading with 付ける, which has a similar meaning. Put on clothes, attach on clothes, etc!

ex_1_jp: 新しいテキストフグは、今までで最高の日本語学習教材として、歴史に残るでしょう。
ex_1_en: The new Text Fugu will go down in history as the best Japanese learning material ever.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means remainder, so the verb vocab version is "to remainder." Let's make that sound better: to remain behind.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to remain behind. Everyone else leaves, and you think you're alone. Then, someone knocks (のこ) on the door. Your heart jumps in your throat. They knock again.

ex_1_jp: この椅子はこんな風に回転するんだ。
ex_1_en: The chairs rotate like this.
meaning_story: You know that 回転 means "rotation" or "revolution." So, what happens when you make it into a verb? It becomes to rotate and to revolve.
reading_story: The reading comes from 回転 of level 10. Alternatively, you can just use the readings of the kanji as well. EZPZ.

ex_1_jp: 流れる水の音が好きなので、涙が君の頬を流れるままにしておいてくれよ。ほら、とても美しいよ。
ex_1_en: I like the sound of flowing water, so just let your tears stream down your cheeks. See? It’s so beautiful.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stream? It's to stream (though it's also to flow, a very similar word). You can differentiate this from 流す because with 流す you flush something down the toilet, which causes it to overflow so you sue (す) the toilet maker. With 流れる you find a rare (れる) jewel trying to flow down the river. You grab it, and see it's a rare diamond!
reading_story: The reading is the same as 流す. So long as you know that you should be able to read this one as well!

ex_1_jp: ちょっと忙し過ぎて、アインシュタインの相対性理論について勉強する時間がないだけなんです。
ex_1_en: I’m too busy and I just don’t have enough time to study Einstein’s theory of relativity.
meaning_story: You've seen 勉強 (study) by now, right? Well, this is the verb version of that. This is to study.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 勉強. It's also the readings you learned with these kanji.

ex_1_jp: 日本は海に囲まれているんだから、塩はいつでも手に入ったんじゃないんですか？
ex_1_en: Since Japan is surrounded by ocean, has salt always been available there?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surround so the verb vocab version is to surround.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have been surrounded. They circle around you, calling you a chicken. "Cacko! (かこ) Cacko! Cacko!" Wait, this isn't the sound a chicken makes, right? You laugh at them, thinking their way of making a chicken noise is weird. Go ahead and join in with them and say "Cacko" with them as well.

ex_1_jp: マジ、終わってる。一緒に旅行をした後、彼が一週間も電話を折り返してこないの。きっと、私寝っ屁をこきまくってたんだわ。
ex_1_en: Seriously, It’s already been a week since our trip together and he hasn’t called me back. I must have farted too many times while I was sleeping.
meaning_story: You've hopefully seen 旅行 by this point. This is the verb version of that. Instead of "trip" it's to travel or to take a trip. These are fun to do. You should do them!
reading_story: The reading is the same as 旅行, but it also happens to use the reading you learned with the kanji anyways, so you should be able to read it.

ex_1_jp: ビエットが100%正しいよ。今すぐコウイチ起こすべきだよ。
ex_1_en: You are absolutely correct, Viet! We should definitely wake Koichi up right now!
meaning_story: You've seen 起きる which is "to wake up." This is similar, except you are doing the waking up, which makes the meaning of this word to wake someone up. How do you differentiate between this and 起きる? Because of the す on the end. You wake someone up violently, wrenching their neck. They turn around and sue (す) you, making you wish you never woke them up.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 起きる, so as long as you know that word you should be able to read this one. Of course, you can also imagine them yelling "OH!" when you shake them awake too, if that helps.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの顧客は、ますます環境に優しい日本語学習製品を求めるようになってきている。
ex_1_en: Increasingly, Tofugu clients are demanding environmentally friendly Japanese learning products.
meaning_story: What's the verb form of request? It's to request. It also is for when you want something (to want), because when you request something you probably want it.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What is it that you want? You want a moat (もと) around your home. Your neighbor's cats keep pooping on your lawn, but if you had a moat they wouldn't be able to get to your lawn in the first place, since cats hate water (and alligators). You request a moat!

ex_1_jp: 水に入れて温めると、昆布のうまみ成分がしみ出てきます。
ex_1_en: Kombu seaweed releases its sweet flavor when it’s soaked in water and heated up.
meaning_story: Have you seen 温かい (warm) yet? Probably. If you have, you can guess that this verb version. It is to warm up or to warm.
reading_story: The reading is the same like 温かい. As long as you know that word, you should be able to associate that reading with this word.
pitch_accent: アタタメꜜル *** アッタメꜜル *** ヌクメꜜル

ex_1_jp: 髪切ったんだけど、逆に童顔に磨きがかかっちゃってさあ。年相応のお洒落な三十五歳の女性になることを望んでたのに。。。とほほ。
ex_1_en: I got a haircut but it just made me look even more childish. I was hoping to look like a stylish 35-year-old. Boo!
meaning_story: If you have a hope and you turn it into a verb, you'd think it would be "to hope." But what is really behind a hope? It's a desire or wish, right? That's why this word means to wish or to desire.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your one wish that you have is to have a bigger nose (のぞ). Feel your nose, it's too small. You wish it was two or three inches longer. Of course, if it helps to imagine you want a smaller nose or a nose at all, that's fine too. Just make sure you wish you have something nose-related.

ex_1_jp: ねぇ、見て見て。あの旅行者の服装、全然年相応じゃないと思わない？
ex_1_en: Hey, look, look. Don’t you think that tourist is wearing clothes completely unsuitable for her age.
meaning_story: You've seen that 旅行 is "trip." So who is someone who goes on trips? That is a tourist or traveler.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know the reading of 旅行 already.

ex_1_jp: こんにちは。僕はコウイチといいます。オレゴン州ポートランド市のポートランド剣道協会で、イベントマネージャーをしています。
ex_1_en: Hello. My name is Koichi and I am the events manager for the Portland Kendo Association here in Portland, Oregon.
meaning_story: When you meet for cooperation, you're coming together to help each other. One form of this is when people form unions. They're all cooperating and coming together to help each other and themselves.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: わるくち, わるぐち, あっこう
ex_1_jp: 友達がみんなで私の悪口を言っているのを聞いちゃったんだよね。
ex_1_en: I heard that all of my friends were bad-mouthing me.
meaning_story: Your bad mouth is saying bad things (as usual!). Everything that comes out of this bad mouth of yours is verbal abuse. One day someone's going to pop you in that bad mouth of yours.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings for these two kanji, probably because this word is just two words put together into one (bad + mouth). Use your knowledge of the vocab words 悪い and 口 to learn the reading of this word. Okay, I lied. You can also do わるぐち if you want. Sorry to say such bad things before.
pitch_accent: アッコꜜー *** アッコー *** ワルꜜクチ *** ワルꜜク°チ

ex_1_jp: フグは、サーモンの中に「日本的な優しさ」を見出した。
ex_1_en: Fugu found a typical Japanese gentleness in Salmon.
meaning_story: Things that are targeted as Japanese are more than just Japanese, they are very Japanese. This word may be hard to understand at first, but there are many things the Japanese consider to be Japanese-only. These theories range from reasonable to ridiculous, but either way, you'll see them described as 日本的.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know how to read 日本 as well.

ex_1_jp: サーモンの望み通り、フグは彼女にプロポーズをした。
ex_1_en: Just as Salmon had hoped, Fugu proposed to her.
meaning_story: A hope is really a wish that you have inside of you (though it can still be a hope too).
reading_story: What's your one big wish? It's to have a different nose (のぞ). Alternatively, you could think "nose on me" for のぞみ.

ex_1_jp: うーん。折角イメチェンするいい機会だし、後ろ髪を三十センチくらい切ってもらおうかな。
ex_1_en: Well, it’s a good opportunity to make a long-awaited change to my look, so I might as well get it shortened in the back by about 30 centimeters.
meaning_story: When you fold things at all sorts of angles you have quite a mess. It's not easy going through life with all these folds and angles. That's why this word means with trouble because you certainly aren't traversing along a nice and flat piece of space-time, are you? Nah, it's all angled and folded :(
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Watch out for the せつ changing to せっ, though. Another thing you have to go through with trouble, I'm afraid.

ex_1_jp: 二日なら時間を作れるよ。いつもの木材置き場で話さない？
ex_1_en: I can make time on the second. Why don’t we meet up at the lumberyard and talk?
meaning_story: Wood that is lumber is lumber wood.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: モクꜜザイ *** モクザイ

ex_1_jp: 紀元前五十年から紀元後二十年の間に作られたとされるこの地域の土器に、同じようなフグの模様が見られるんです。
ex_1_en: Similar Fugu patterns can be seen on local earthenware made between 50 B.C. and 20 A.D.
meaning_story: The origin is after the narrative. What narrative was this? It's THE narrative, to many. This is the narrative of Jesus. This was so important that they decided to start a new era after it, making this era after death* or AD. *Yes, I know it's not actually "After Death" but it's so commonly misconceived as such that I put it in there as the definition. You understand the meaning still, right? Anno Domini is also available as a definition too, so don't fret!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「じゃあ、あなたは昨夜飲み放題に行っていた訳ですね。他には何かしましたか？」「いや、まあそんなところだよ。」
ex_1_en: "So, you went to an all you can drink place last night. Anything else?" "No, that’s about it."
meaning_story: Drinking as much as you want is nice and all, but don't get sick. When you see this word, you know you're at an all you can drink place. Tip: Usually there's a time limit, so drink up!
reading_story: The reading comes from the word 放題 (ほうだい) and 飲む (のむ). So long as you know those vocab words, you'll be able to read this one as well.

ex_1_jp: よし、今がチャンスだ。さあ、焼き肉食べ放題へ行こう。
ex_1_en: Ok, the coast is clear. Let’s go get all you can eat yakiniku.
meaning_story: When you eat as much as you want, you are getting an all you can eat deal.
reading_story: The reading consists of the readings of 食べる and 放題. If you know those you should be able to read this too.

ex_1_jp: あなたの上司はちょっと変人ですが、すぐに馴染めると思いますよ。
ex_1_en: Your boss is a little eccentric but I think you’re going to fit right in.
meaning_story: A strange person is an eccentric. They are also an oddball.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ヘンジン *** ヘンジꜜン

ex_1_jp: 多くの人が京都や奈良に残る日本の伝統建築に魅了されますが、私もその一人です。
ex_1_en: Many people are fascinated by the traditional architecture found in places like Kyoto and Nara and I’m one of them.
meaning_story: When it comes to building and constructing, the thing that puts them all together into one is architecture. If you don't have any architecture, who knows what the building will look like.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「ちょっとお願いがあるんだけど……。」「もちろん。言ってみて。」
ex_1_en: "Can you do me a favor...?" "Of course. Name it."
meaning_story: The noun form of request (don't be tricked by the い on the end, it's not an adjective). So, request goes to a request.
reading_story: The reading is the same like お願いします. Hopefully you're able to read that by now so you're able to read this too.

ex_1_jp: とりあえず軍の拠点に戻ってみましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s go back to the army base for now.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
pitch_accent: イクサꜜ *** イクサ *** グꜜン

ex_1_jp: はぁ？まだ秋に一回ご飯食べに行っただけなの？あんた頭イッちゃってるんじゃないの？どう考えても彼氏って呼ぶのはおかしいでしょ。それは付き合ってるとは言えないと思うよ。
ex_1_en: What? You’ve only gone out for dinner with him once so far this fall? Have you lost your mind? Don’t you think it’s strange to think about calling him your boyfriend? I don’t think you can say you’re dating him.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, あき.

ex_1_jp: シャークがあなたのこと、名ばかりの上司だと言ってましたよ。
ex_1_en: Shark said you are the boss in name only.
meaning_story: The director who is above you is your boss or superior.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは、夢の中で大きな岩が頭上に落ちてくるところで、目が覚めた。
ex_1_en: Koichi woke up as a huge rock fell toward him in a dream.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so you can read this one!

ex_1_jp: 英国と米国は敵対関係にある。
ex_1_en: The UK has an antagonistic relationship with the United States.
meaning_story: The England country is where England is. This word can refer to Britain, the United Kingdom and England! Note that イギリス is more common for "England" - but, since this is a kanji learning website you should learn this word.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「知らぬが仏」や「仏の顔も三度まで」など、仏に関する諺はいくつかありますね。
ex_1_en: There are some proverbs related to Buddha such as "what you don’t know can’t hurt you" and "the crushed worm will turn."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
