reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You go up to Buddha. You want to rub his head for good luck, because that's what you hear is good to do. Right before you touch him, he backs off and says, "Whoa! I'm hot, okay?" (ほとけ). You touch him and it burns your hand clean off. Imagine saying "hot, okay?" in a strange accent to help you to remember.

ex_1_jp: 仏教に伴って、お香は六世紀に日本に伝来しました。
ex_1_en: Along with Buddhism, incense was brought to Japan in the 6th century.
meaning_story: The buddha teachings are what you have to learn when you're studying Buddhism.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 仏 gets changed to ぶっ for this one.
pitch_accent: ブꜜッキョー *** ブッキョꜜー

ex_1_jp: お母さん！こんなに沢山の計算をしたら、数学の天才になるかわりに、逆に頭がおかしくなっちゃうよ。
ex_1_en: Mom! If I do all of these calculations, instead of becoming a math genius, I’ll just lose my mind.
meaning_story: When you measure and then calculate something, you are making a calculation. For example, you measure the length of a frog, then you calculate how many frogs you'd need to reach the moon. What is that? A calculation, of course.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 助けてくれ！俺の飼い猫がスクラブルの ’M’のコマを飲み込んじゃったんだ！
ex_1_en: You’ve got to help me! My cat swallowed an "M" Scrabble tile!
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Meow!
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Neko neko neko! Kawaiiiii.

ex_1_jp: あいにく、その日のスケジュールは少しきついですね。今世紀最大の日本語学習祭り関連の会議がいくつか入っているんですよ。
ex_1_en: I’m afraid my schedule is a little tight that day. I have several meetings related to a Japanese learning festival, which will be the largest one this century.
meaning_story: The account of a generation... this covers a whole generation, and considering how long Japanese people live, this account totals a whole century.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: いったい式場はどこなんだ？
ex_1_en: Where the heck is the ceremony being held?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. In fact, this kanji's on'yomi AND kun'yomi are しき, so you can never go wrong.

ex_1_jp: うわ！すごいね。既に変化が現れているのが分かるよ。
ex_1_en: Wow! This is amazing! I can see the change already.
meaning_story: Change and change equals even more change.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ヘꜜンカ *** ヘꜜンケ° *** ヘンケ°

ex_1_jp: 晴れてよかったですね。
ex_1_en: It’s a good thing it’s clear out.
meaning_story: If you say something is going to clear up, you're usually talking about the weather. That makes it clear weather!
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 私の主人は堅苦しくて不器用ですが、正直者です。
ex_1_en: My husband is strict and clumsy, but he’s an honest person.
meaning_story: You know how 器用 means "dextrous" and "skillful"? Well, this is when you're not those things. When you're not dextrous, you're clumsy and when you're not skillful you're unskillful.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just keep in mind that the reading of 不 changes from ふ to ぶ. If you're clumsy you'll get a lot of boo-boos (ぶ), get it?

ex_1_jp: ビエトは、誰よりもコウイチのことをよく知っているので、誰よりもうまくコウイチの顔を描ける自信があると言っていた。
ex_1_en: Viet said that he was sure he could draw Koichi’s face better than anyone else because he knew him better than anyone else.
meaning_story: When you believe in your self you have plenty of confidence (or self confidence). This is a good thing to have!
reading_story: How much 自信 do you have that you know how to read this word already? I bet you have some, at least! This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「フグ、私のお父さんは素晴らしい人だったのよ。いつも私に、流れに逆らって泳ぐには力と勇気が必要だ。浮かぶだけなら死んだ魚でもできるって言ってたわ。」「サーモン、それって、サミュエル・スマイルズの名言じゃなかったっけ。」
ex_1_en: "Fugu, my dad was a great person. He always told me that it requires strength and courage to swim against the stream, while any dead fish can float with it." "Salmon, isn’t it a quote by Samuel Smiles?"
meaning_story: That feeling of courage is courage.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ここ最近、横浜の外国人居留区では、暴力行為がかつてないほど横行している。
ex_1_en: Recently, the foreign quarter of Yokohama has suffered from an unprecedented level of violence.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

ex_1_jp: コウイチは、近日中に地区検察局に自白内容を収めたビデオテープを送ることを計画しているようですよ。
ex_1_en: It seems that Koichi is planning to give a videotaped confession to the district attorney’s office soon.
meaning_story: The earth district isn't our solar system or something like that. We're talking about a specific portion of earth, and naming it as a district. So, what is this patch of earth? It's a district, area, or zone.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 新しい日本語学習教材を部分的に公開することは、我々の会社が何か事実を隠蔽しようとしているとの不信を招くかもしれないじゃないですか？
ex_1_en: Don’t you think that only partial release of the new Japanese learning material may feed suspicion that our company is covering up some facts?
meaning_story: When you can't (not) believe in someone, it's because you distrust them. Why? Due to their unfaithfulness.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私は、テロ行為と合法的な戦争を区分する必要は無いと思います。
ex_1_en: I don’t think it’s necessary to distinguish terrorism from legitimate warfare.
meaning_story: Think about a part of the district. Separate them out in your mind (these parts). Each part is a division of the district. You can also take each division and create a classification of them. Go ahead and classify each one.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: まさか。また英会話のテストに落ちちゃったよ。ショックすぎる。
ex_1_en: Oh no, I can’t believe I failed another English conversation test. I’m so shocked.
meaning_story: English meeting and talking with each other. This is English Conversation. This is used a lot when talking about "speaking in English" for studying English and whatnot.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「僕たちは皆、英語と数学の授業が嫌いだ。」「ちょっと、一緒にしないでよ。私は両方共好きだし。」
ex_1_en: "All of us hate our English and Math classes." "Hey, speak for yourself. I like both of them."
meaning_story: The English language is the language you're reading right here and now. This is the English language. It is English.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: おっと、コウイチが泣きそうだ！ちょっとあの英和辞典を探して来て、コウイチに渡してあげてくれない？
ex_1_en: Uh-oh, Koichi’s about to cry! Can you go to find the English-Japanese dictionary and give it to him?
meaning_story: This is seen on things like dictionaries. When you have an English and Japanese (style) dictionary, for example. You'll see it the other way around too, but this particular one is English Japanese.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ねぇ、忙しいところ悪いんだけどさ、この英文の翻訳にちょっと手こずっちゃってるんだよね。手伝ってもらえないかな？
ex_1_en: Hey, sorry to bother you, but I am kind of stuck on these English sentence translations. Could you help me?
meaning_story: England writing is English Writing (or if you want to be fancy, English Composition).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 毎晩５時に夕食を食べて、１０時に寝る。
ex_1_en: Every night I eat dinner at 5 o’clock and go to bed at 10 o’clock.
meaning_story: Every night is simply every night. What do you do every night?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: マꜜイバン *** マイバン

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 彼の家族はとても信心深くてスピリチュアルなので、お酒を飲まずにスピリッツだけ飲みます。
ex_1_en: His family is very religious and spiritual, so they only drink spirits without alcohol.
meaning_story: What you believe in your heart, and not in your head, is your faith. This is something that doesn't follow logic, it's all heart belief, it's all faith.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that しん changes to じん.
pitch_accent: シンジꜜン *** シꜜンジン

ex_1_jp: フグが私に食中毒の危険性をレクチャーしてくれたんだけどさぁ、説明がすっごく分かりにくかったんだよね。
ex_1_en: Fugu gave me a lecture about the risks of food poisoning, but his explanation was very hard to understand.
meaning_story: Poison inside the food is food poisoning. No fun when you get this :(
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「彼女、大仏さんと付き合っているのよ。」「とても信じられないわね。だって、彼女の父親と言ってもいいくらい年上でしょ？」
ex_1_en: "She’s dating Mr. Giant Buddha Statue." "You could have fooled me. He is old enough to be her father."
meaning_story: A large Buddha doesn't make sense if you don't know the context. There are giant statues of Buddha, and these are called Daibutsu, making this word translate to Giant Buddha Statue.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ダイブツ *** ダイブツꜜ

ex_1_jp: 今晩は、コウイチおじさん。今日は私とフグの赤ちゃんの面倒をみてくれて有難うございます。あ、ところで、電子レンジは使わなかったよね？ 母乳だから、電子レンジ使ったらいけないんだよ。
ex_1_en: Good evening, Uncle Koichi. Thank you for taking care of our baby today. Hey, you didn’t microwave that, did you? Because it’s breast milk, and you’re not supposed to do that.
meaning_story: This is a strange one. It's like こんにちは, which is written as 今日は, oddly. Same for good evening, which also has the now kanji in it. Switched with "day" is night. So, when you say "now night!" you're really saying good evening.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be aware that the は at the end is actually the particle は so it's pronounced like わ.

ex_1_jp: 私の上司、見た目はできる男なのに、いつも間違った文法を使うのが残念すぎるよ。
ex_1_en: My boss looks like a smart person so it’s too bad that he always makes grammar mistakes.
meaning_story: The method of writing is how you write. You can have vocabulary words, but you have to be able to put them together using some kind of method. This method happens to be grammar.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ほう changes to ぽう.

ex_1_jp: 話を変える訳じゃないんだけど、そのスカートはちょっと丈が長過ぎるんじゃないかしら？
ex_1_en: Not to change the subject, but isn’t that skirt just a little too long for you?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. An additional meaning for this word is only or just. Usually this version is written in kana alone, but I'll include it here as a possible answer / reading for this vocab just in case.
reading_story: The reading is different from what you learned with the kanji. Remember the word 竹? It has the same reading as this. Just think of everyone measuring the heights of things with bamboo (たけ) poles with markers on them. Okay, this one is 5 bamboo poles high!

ex_1_jp: ほら、また始まった。あんたって本当にいつも自分の夫の不満ばかり言っているよね。
ex_1_en: There you go again, always complaining about your husband.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think about your husband even if you don't have one. What's his name? It's Otto (おっと), and he's always leaving you at home because he's working at the auto (おっと) shop.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 不法な捜査で得た証拠は法廷では使えませんよ。
ex_1_en: We can’t use evidence obtained through an illegal search at the court.
meaning_story: A not law is something that's against the law. It's illegal or unlawful.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 満州事変について説明をしてもらえますか？
ex_1_en: Can you explain what Manchurian Incident is?
meaning_story: An action that takes place that could change the locale or even the world has got to be a big incident. You'll sometimes see this on the ends of "incident" names, like the "Manshuu Jihen" (満州事変), aka the "Manshuu Incident." You know that it isn't an unusual or strange incident (like 変事) because the "strange" kanji (変) doesn't come first with this word. Instead, it comes after and means "change" in this case.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 誰かの伝があるといいんだけど。
ex_1_en: But I think some kind of intermediary would be good.
meaning_story: When you get someone to transmit information, they're a type of intermediary, a go-between, if you will.
reading_story: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it takes the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: When the go-between gets back and is about to tell you everything the other group said, it takes him two takes (つて) to get it all right. The other group had a lot to say and he had trouble getting it all on the first take, but he totally nailed it on the second.

ex_1_jp: 私達、ちょうどこの子猫を見つけて、飼い主をさがしているんです。
ex_1_en: We just found this kitten and we’re looking for the owner.
meaning_story: A child cat is an adorable kitten. D'awww!
reading_story: The reading is the vocab word 子 (こ) and the reading for cat (ねこ).

ex_1_jp: 昨年は旅行でグアムに行きました。
ex_1_en: I went on a trip to Guam last year.
meaning_story: Yesterday's year was actually last year. Today is must be New Years then!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ベーコンショップの前には長い列ができていた。
ex_1_en: There was a long line in front of the bacon shop.
meaning_story: When things are put in a row they end up forming a line. This can be a line of people or a line of random stuff.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: あと５分で昼休みだ。
ex_1_en: Lunch break is in five minutes.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 休み means "break?" When you take a break at noon it's your lunch break! Or, if you aren't hungry, it's a noon break instead.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this too!

ex_1_jp: しまった！ご飯こぼしちゃった。
ex_1_en: Damn it! I just spilled my rice.
meaning_story: The ご just makes this word more polite and fancy. When it comes to food, it's nice to be those things. This has the same meaning as the kanji (meal) making it meal, but it also refers to cooked rice as well. So, "Come eat your ご飯" can be both "come eat your rice" and "come eat your meal." Really, since most Japanese meals come with rice, though, you can see how the overlap happens.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now how about you "hand" me another bowl of rice?

ex_1_jp: あそこの飯は本当に臭かったぜ。二度と塀の中には戻りたくねえな。
ex_1_en: Those were some really stinky smelling meals! I never want to go back to prison.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It also refers to cooked rice, because you gotta eat cooked rice with every meal, so it's basically synonymous with "meal" itself.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're eating a meal... MMmm, delicious! What are you eating? Well, it's a Mesh (めし) net. Taste the mesh net. It tastes terrible. This is a bad meal. Feel it in your mouth. It's weird and meshy.

ex_1_jp: シャーロック・ホームズって、古びた犯罪調査方法を使っているよね？
ex_1_en: Sherlock Holmes has an old method of investigating crimes, doesn’t he?
meaning_story: The way method or the method way is the method or way. This is a good word for talking about how to do something. What's the 方法? Well, first you...
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本の政治家には、本当に情けない奴が多い。
ex_1_en: There really are a lot of deplorable Japanese politicians.
meaning_story: You've seen how the word 情け means pity, so adding ない to that turns it into an adjective meaning pitiable and miserable.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: 「今夜、映画館に行かない？」「そうできればいいんだけど、このレポートを仕上げなくちゃいけないんだ。」
ex_1_en: "Would you like to go to the movie theater tonight?" "I wish I could but I have to finish this paper."
meaning_story: You've hopefully seen 映画 in level 13. A public building for movies (映画) is a movie theater.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: おい、昨日駅でお前が彼女といるのを見かけたぜ。お前の彼女、人殺しとも付き合えないぐらい不細工だな。
ex_1_en: Hey, I saw you with your girlfriend at the station yesterday. She’s so plain, she probably couldn’t even get a date with a murderer.
meaning_story: When you kill a person that's murder.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, if you know 人's reading as a vocab word and 殺す's reading, you should be able to read this word. Just note that ころし goes to ごろし due to rendaku.
pitch_accent: ヒトコ°ロシ *** ヒトコ°ロシꜜ

ex_1_jp: 今の今まで、俺の友達の人生は信じられない苦難の連続でした。彼の人生は殺人者の子どもとして始まりました。
ex_1_en: Up until now, my friend’s life has been an epic struggle. He began his life as the baby of a murderer.
meaning_story: You've hopefully seen 殺人 (murder) from level 13. So, someone who does murder is what? A murderer.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 電話に出れなくてごめん。信じられないかもしれないけど、実は今海軍の船の上なんだよね。降りたら電話するね。
ex_1_en: I’m sorry I couldn’t catch your call. Believe it or not, I’m actually on a navy boat right now. I’ll call you when I get off.
meaning_story: The sea army are the branch of the military that has boats and does ocean/sea things. What's that? The navy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 悲しいことに夫に捨てられちゃいました。新築の一軒家を買ったばっかりなのに。話しを聞いてほしいんだけど。
ex_1_en: I’m sad. My husband left me even though we just bought a newly built house. I need someone to talk to.
meaning_story: Something that's newly constructed is something that's newly built.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「よお！今晩、飲みに行かないか？」「ごめん。今、禁酒中なんだよ。」
ex_1_en: "Hey, why don’t we go for a drink tonight?" "Sorry, I’m staying sober now."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading here is the same as the kanji reading!

ex_1_jp: 今から一時間昼休憩を取るので、電話は取り次がないようにしてください。
ex_1_en: I’m going to take a one hour lunch break, so please hold my calls.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji it comes from, so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: もし俺たちがエッフェル塔を盗むというなら、かなりしっかりした計画を練る必要がある。
ex_1_en: If we’re going to steal the Eiffel Tower, we need to have a really good plan.
meaning_story: When you do a drawing of a measurement you want to do on the chalkboard, you're drawing up a plan for doing something. All things require some kind of measurement, so drawing that measurement up is your plan.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 画 is the secondary reading though (かく), so take note of that.

ex_1_jp: フグはとても美味しく、食べる人の心を豊かにしてくれますが、一方で猛毒も持っています。
ex_1_en: While puffer fish is very delicious and provides a deeply satisfying culinary experience, it also carries a deadly poison.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji's reading.

pronunciation: どくがす, どくガス
ex_1_jp: 「この野郎！また屁をこきやがったな！毒ガスのように臭いじゃねえか。」「すみません。もう二度とおならはしません。」「いいや、きっとまたこくさ。もう堪忍袋の緒が切れた。お前は首だ。」「そんな〜。」
ex_1_en: "You bastard! You’ve farted again. It’s as stinky as poison gas!" "I’m sorry. I will never do it again." "No, I’m sure you will. That’s the last straw. You’re fired." "Oh no~!"
meaning_story: Poison Gas is a nasty thing. It is poison gas.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji it comes from. The ガス is of course "gas."

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: フグは麻薬中毒から逃れようとしてリハビリセンターに行ったが、結局また麻薬中毒になってしまった。
ex_1_en: Fugu tried to rid himself of drug addiction and went to rehab, but eventually ended up relapsing.
meaning_story: When poison is put inside of something, that is a poisoning.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ビエトだけがコウイチのオナラが有毒ガスのような臭いがすることを知っている。
ex_1_en: Only Viet knows that Koichi’s farts smells like toxic fumes.
meaning_story: When something has poison it is poisonous and toxic.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お疲れ〜。返信したつもりだったんだけど、どうやら力尽きて、送信ボタンを押す前に寝てたみたい。ごめんね、許して〜。
ex_1_en: How’s it going? I thought I sent a reply to you, but it seems that I was too tired and fell asleep before pressing the ’send’ button. Sorry. Forgive me.
meaning_story: You gotta believe it will return. What are you believing in returning? The reply. You made a request for something (come up with something you want really bad but have to ask for). Now you wait for the reply.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「ボーナスが出たら、ダイヤモンドの指輪を買ってやるよ。」「あなたはいつも口先ばかりでしょ。」
ex_1_en: "When I get a bonus, I’ll buy you a diamond ring." "You always say that, but they’re just words."
meaning_story: A finger ring is the kind of ring you'd put on your finger. That's just simply a "ring" though, so you'll have to know what "ring" this is via context.
reading_story: The readings come from the individual vocab readings, 指 and 輪. In English we don't distinguish some other ring from a "finger ring" but in Japanese, you can think of this as two separate words coming together to form one word, which is why it uses the kun'yomi vocab readings like this. So, if you know the individual words, you should be able to figure out this word is read as ゆびわ.

ex_1_jp: わぁ！そのワンピマジで可愛い！カラフルな輪ゴムの絵がたくさんプリントしてあるんだね！そんなワンピ初めてみたよ。
ex_1_en: Oh my God, I just totally love your dress! So many colorful rubber band pictures printed on it, eh? I’ve never seen such a dress before.
meaning_story: A ring of gum (ゴム) (which is what Japanese people call rubber quite often) is a ring of rubber. What is a ring of rubber that people use often? It's a rubber band.
reading_story: The reading for 輪 is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which is わ, making this word わゴム.

ex_1_jp: 日本語を習得するのは大変ですが、頑張ってね。
ex_1_en: Learning Japanese is difficult, but do your best!
meaning_story: A big change is a really serious thing. And people don't like change, either, making it a terrible event. Also, in more recent history this has come to mean very as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 酔っ払うと、眠りが浅くなっちゃって、早朝覚醒しちゃうんだよね。
ex_1_en: Whenever I get drunk, I only have a light sleep and wake up early in the morning.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of shallow? It's shallow.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, making this あさい

ex_1_jp: 剣道では、単に相手を倒すことだけではなく、自らの心を鍛えることも重要です。
ex_1_en: In Kendo, it’s important not simply to defeat your opponent but also to train your own mind.
meaning_story: If you're moving towards (に) simple, you're saying simply or merely. This is one of those words that come at the beginning of a sentence. "Simply... "
reading_story: If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: スター選手であったフグを失ってから、Tofugu野球チームの調子は下り坂となってしまった。
ex_1_en: The Tofugu baseball team has been on a downward slope since it lost its star player, Fugu.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as this one.

ex_1_jp: 昨日、上司に俺はリストラで首になるって言われちゃってさ。だから、今、軍人になることを真剣に考えてるんだ。
ex_1_en: My boss told me yesterday that I am going to be laid off, so now I’m seriously thinking about becoming a soldier.
meaning_story: An army person is someone in the army. What are those people called? They're soldiers.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 眼鏡屋さんで、とても頑丈な眼鏡を作ってもらいました。
ex_1_en: I had a really sturdy pair of glasses made by my optician.
meaning_story: A stubborn height is a shorter, stockier height. It makes a person especially solid, firm, and stout.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「お前のチーム、春の大会ではどうだったの？」「へへ。大勝したっての！」
ex_1_en: "How did your team do in the spring tournament?" "Hehe. Epic win."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Ah, the beauty of spring! Err... はる, I mean.

ex_1_jp: そろそろ風邪治った？春休みに風邪引くなんて最悪だよね。もしまだ辛いなら、夜更かししちゃだめだよ。早く良くなってね。
ex_1_en: Are you over your cold yet? It sucks having a cold during spring break, eh? If it’s still bad, don’t stay up late. Get well soon.
meaning_story: You've seen 夏休み and 冬休み. If that isn't enough, you can see that this is a spring rest of some kind. That would be a spring break or spring vacation.
reading_story: The reading for 春 is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. The 休み part is the same as the vocab word 休み, which hopefully you can read! If you know those readings, you can read this too.

ex_1_jp: 変だなぁ。僕のメールボックスには、君が送ったと言っているメールがどこにも見当たらないよ。
ex_1_en: That’s strange. I can’t find the email you say you sent me anywhere in my mailbox.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is more the "strange" meaning though, not the "change" one. As in, you 変な猫！.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. How strange! Or not.

ex_1_jp: 私は変事の前の不気味な静けさにいつもワクワクする。
ex_1_en: I always get nervous when that ominous silence happens before an accident.
meaning_story: A strange action that takes place is something that shouldn't have happened (but it did). This is a strange incident. The difference between this and 事変 is that while 事変 can also be used to describe a strange incident, it also can be used to talk about another type of incident as well. For example, the "Manshuu Jihen" is the "Manshuu Incident." This word, 変事 is more just a strange or unusual incident.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼が丈夫な男だってことは分かってるけど、暴飲暴食の習慣がちょっと心配なんだよね。
ex_1_en: I know he’s a tough guy, but I’m a little worried about his excessive eating and drinking habits.
meaning_story: With the height of my husband, he's very firm. Try to push him over. Impossible. He's so tall and sturdy due to his height.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
pitch_accent: ジョꜜーフ *** ジョーブ *** マスラオ *** マスラꜜオ

ex_1_jp: たぶんもうすぐ反映されると思う。私のエバーノート今同期中だし。
ex_1_en: It will probably show up soon. My Evernote is syncing right now.
meaning_story: Something is making one thing the same as another inside a period of time. You'll see this word on computer-ish things a lot. This is syncing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 最近、Tofuguのオフィス内に、料理の美味しいパブがたくさん開店してるんだよね。
ex_1_en: Recently, a lot of pubs with delicious food have been opening in the Tofugu office.
meaning_story: Something with a beauty taste is something that is really tasty / good tasting / delicious. Mmmm, yum!
reading_story: The reading for this makes no sense at all. You'll have to learn it straight up, that is, unless you know the word おいしい already, which many people do as it's used in every other sentence in every Japanese variety show. If you don't know this word already, just think of yourself eating something delicious. It's so delicious it makes you mad, I have no idea why. You yell at the chef: "OI (おい). OI! WHY IS THIS SO DELICIOUS????"
pitch_accent: オイシイ *** オイシꜜイ

ex_1_jp: 日本の地元のお寺で誕生日会を開いたんだけど、すぐに追い出されちゃった。お寺ってロック・コンサートをやる場所じゃないってこと、知っておけばよかったんだけど。
ex_1_en: I held a birthday party at one of the local temples in Japan. We got kicked out pretty quickly. I should have known that a temple wasn’t a good place to have a rock concert.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji too! You must have been praying to the kanji Gods at the local お寺.

ex_1_jp: 昨今の流行りにあやかって、コウイチはオフィスで柴犬を飼うことに決めました。
ex_1_en: According to the current trend, Koichi decided to have a Shiba-inu doge in our office.
meaning_story: Previous from now are the times around now. They're these days.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that さく changes to さっ as many K-column sounds do in situations like this.

ex_1_jp: ホルモンバランスを整える方法をご紹介致します。
ex_1_en: We’ll introduce you to hormone balance adjustment methods.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means arrange, so the verb version is to arrange.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go to arrange a bunch of food on a table for the people of OZ. You turn around to grab the last one and hear all of plates start crashing to the ground. You turn around and yell, "Toto no (ととの)!" Your dog Toto jumped on the table and is knocking everything over. Now you'll have to prepare everything all over again. Dammit Toto.
pitch_accent: トトノエꜜル *** トトノꜜエル

ex_1_jp: ちょっと話を整理させてね。つまり、男の人が浮気をするのはいいけど、女の人がするのはだめってこと？それがあなたの言いたいこと？
ex_1_en: So let me get this straight, it’s okay for men to cheat, but not for women. Is that what you’re trying to say?
meaning_story: When you arrange something with reason you're arranging it. That's why this is to arrange.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチさん、申し訳ありませんが、好むと好まざるとに関わらず、あなたの秘密は暴露されてしまうかもしれません。
ex_1_en: I’m sorry, Mr. Koichi. Whether you like it or not, your secrets might be revealed.
meaning_story: You know that 好き is "like." Although 好き is kind of like a verb already, this is definitely a verb. It can be to be fond of or to like.
reading_story: The reading is a strange one, different from anything you've learned, kanji on'yomi or vocab kun'yomi. The reading is この, so think of this. What is it that you're particularly fond of? Getting a cone (この) with your ice cream (which you're also fond of, who isn't?). Think of all the different cones you can get: waffle cones, sugar cones, oreo cones, yum!

ex_1_jp: 自分がもはやサンタ・クロースを信じていないということに、最近イライラしている...と思うんだよね。
ex_1_en: I’m recently bothered, I suppose, by the idea that I no longer believe in Santa Claus.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means believe so the verb vocab version is to believe.
reading_story: The reading for 信 is しん no matter what! See, if you believe, good things will happen. You should be able to read this.
pitch_accent: シンジꜜル *** シンジル

ex_1_jp: 我が社は、外国の子どもたちに学校を建ててあげるために貯金をしています。
ex_1_en: Our company is saving money to build a school for children in another country.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means build so the verb vocab version is to build.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about what happens when you build something. What are you doing? You're standing it up. How do you say "to stand" in Japanese? たてる. That's the reading of this word as well. If you think about it they're similar!

ex_1_jp: 眉毛の形を変えると、まるで別人のようだ。
ex_1_en: When you change the shape of your eyebrows, you look like a different person.
meaning_story: The kanji is change, but this verb is to change. If you change one thing for another thing, you are going to change it, after all. This word refers to changing one thing for a similar thing.
reading_story: I don't like this car. I would like to change it for another car (か).

ex_1_jp: ようやくフグと結婚することになったので、是非式に来てほしいなと思っています。詳細を同封した招待状を後ほどお送りしますね。パーティーは野外の予定なので、当日晴れるといいんだけどな。
ex_1_en: I’m finally getting married to Fugu and I want you to be at our wedding. I’ll send you an invitation with all the details later. The reception will be outside, so I hope it’s sunny that day.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means clear up, so the verb vocab version is to clear up. It also means to become sunny as well.
reading_story: The reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here. One of those words where the kun'yomi's going to be more useful.

ex_1_jp: 減給になっちゃって泣いてます。もっと給料のいい会社に移りたいよ。
ex_1_en: I’m crying because my salary was cut. I want to transfer to a higher paying job.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cry so the verb vocab version is to cry.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. If you remember the kanji reading you'll have no problem with this word.

ex_1_jp: この鳥はいつか籠から放つつもりだ。
ex_1_en: This bird is always trying to break out of its cage.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned the verbs 放す and 放れる but this one is a little different. This is a specific kind of releasing. It means to fire an arrow, or to hit a baseball. It even works when you're releasing a fart. Yes, it means to break wind too. What a great word!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: 答案は提出する前に見返したほうがいい。
ex_1_en: You should look back over your test before you submit it.
meaning_story: When you want to see something one more time before you have to return it, you need to look back at it. It might be your last chance to look at it, you know?
reading_story: The readings are from the words 見 and 返す put together.
pitch_accent: ミカエス *** ミカꜜエス

ex_1_jp: 文を丸ごと暗記する方が、単語だけを暗記するより効率がいい。
ex_1_en: Memorizing sentences is more efficient than memorizing words by themselves.
meaning_story: Hopefully you've seen 暗記 before now. It means "memorization." So, turn that into a verb and you have to memorize.
reading_story: The reading comes from 暗記. It also is the reading you learned with the kanji too.

ex_1_jp: 「俺達、惨敗しちまったな。」「ああ、惨敗しちまった。もっとたくさん練習しないとな。」
ex_1_en: "Dude, we were absolutely crushed." "Yeah, it was a complete failure. I guess we need more practice."
meaning_story: You've hopefully seen 練習, which means "practice." So, if you make it into a verb, you have to practice.
reading_story: The reading comes from the kanji as well as from the vocab word 練習. You should be able to read this!

ex_1_jp: ビエトだけが、コウイチが鏡に全身を映すのが好きだということを知っている。
ex_1_en: Only Viet knows that Koichi really likes seeing himself reflected full-length in the mirror.
meaning_story: You know that 映る is "to be reflected." Now you're doing the reflecting, which is really projecting (light). That's why this word is to project.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 映る. So long as you know the reading of 映る you should be able to read this one too.

ex_1_jp: 「お腹が空いたし足が痛いよ」と、ホビット庄に帰るちょっと前にビルボーは言った。
ex_1_en: "I’m hungry and my legs are sore," Bilbo said, just before turning to return home to the Shire.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return home so the verb vocab version is to return home.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You can return home happily, knowing how to read this word!

ex_1_jp: 何度も足し算をしたんですが、その度に合計が違ったんですよね。私、馬鹿なんでしょうか？
ex_1_en: I added the numbers over and over again and got a different total each time. Am I stupid?
meaning_story: When you join all your measurements together you have yourself a total.
reading_story: You know the ごう reading of 合 from other vocabulary, hopefully! If so, you should be able to read this word.

ex_1_jp: いいか、よく聞けよ。六つ目の信号で左折した後、八つ目の角まで歩いて右折したら、そこで会った人に向かってお尻を振るんだ。それが秘密のサインだからな。そしたら、奴はお前を俺たちのアジトまで連れて行ってくれるさ。
ex_1_en: Listen carefully. Turn left at the sixth traffic light, walk another eight blocks, turn right and shake your butt toward someone you will meet there. That’s the secret sign, okay? Then, he will take you to our hideout.
meaning_story: If you believe in the numbers, there will be no traffic because the traffic light will be functioning properly. Traffic lights are based all off of traffic data and numbers. You just have to believe and hope it all works out in terms of these traffic lights.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は、掃除や料理、マッサージや寝る前の歌なんかで、妻から信用点をつけられていると思っていたが、なんと逆に離婚されてしまったよ。
ex_1_en: I thought I would score some credit with my wife if I cleaned the house, made dinner, gave her a massage, and sung her to sleep, but instead she divorced me.
meaning_story: Your task is to believe. In order to do that, you have to have plenty of trust in what you believe in... not to mention confidence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチが謎の変死を遂げたというニュースは、全国民を震撼させた。
ex_1_en: The news that Koichi met a mysterious and unnatural death shocked the nation.
meaning_story: A strange death is one that doesn't seem right. It's an unnatural death, and probably an accidental death (ie wasn't caused by natural causes).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ねぇ、あなたの時計に唾が着いてない？
ex_1_en: Hey, Isn’t that spit on your watch?
meaning_story: A thing that gives you time measurements is a watch or clock. Most people have these in their phones instead of their wrists now.
reading_story: The reading for this is pretty weird. 計 is all nice and normal, but 時 is と for some reason. It probably is coming from the vocab word 時 (とき), is my guess. But even if it is, it's shortened, making it a step more complicated. Maybe it's just better to imagine that your watch is a walky talky (とけい) and run with that?

ex_1_jp: 日本語の単語ゲーム作ったんだけど、やってみない？
ex_1_en: I created a Japanese word game. Do you want to try?
meaning_story: The simple bits of language are the individual words. If you think about it, this is true. First of all, there are a ton of them. Second, they're tiny. They're just little bits of language and the "word" for these little bits is word.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 昨日は、大学の課題で、沢山の叙事詩を読まなくてはいけませんでした。
ex_1_en: We had to read many epic poems yesterday for a university assignment.
meaning_story: The yesterday day is yesterday. What a blast from the past!
reading_story: Oof. The reading for this word makes no sense. You'll have to forget everything you've learned about the readings of the kanji and just go straight up mnemonic for the word on its own. Okay. Think about what you did yesterday, all day. You played keno (きのう), gambling away your grandmother's money. Yesterday was the worst day ever because you lost everything playing Keno. Today is different, not like yesterday, right?
pitch_accent: キノꜜー *** キノー *** サクꜜジツ

ex_1_jp: 私の夫は出張で留守がちです。彼が留守にしてる間、とても寂しいので、一日少なくとも五回は彼に電話をします。
ex_1_en: My husband is always away from home because of his business trips. I get very lonely so I call him at least 5 times a day.
meaning_story: You have gotten a mission. You must go out and detain a dangerous criminal to protect your country. While you go do that, you will be away from home and have an absence from society.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その料理人は、冷凍庫のドアから栓抜きを剥ぎ取った。
ex_1_en: The chef grabbed the bottle opener hanging from the freezer door.
meaning_story: You've seen 料理 and probably know it means "cooking." So, what is a person who does cooking? That is a cook or chef.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: リョーリニン *** リョーリꜜニン

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 日本語に馴染みのない私にとっても、テキストフグは絶好の入門書だと思う？買った方がいいかな？
ex_1_en: Do you think that Textfugu is the best introduction to Japanese even for someone like me who’s unfamiliar with it? Should I purchase it?
meaning_story: If you are able to enter the gate then you have gained admission and entrance to the facility.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私たちはナイル川を遡るっている冒険旅行をしたんだけど、彼氏が西ナイル熱にかかっちゃってさあ。未だに病院で入院してるんだよね。
ex_1_en: We went on an adventure trip up the Nile River, but my boyfriend caught West Nile virus and he is still in the hospital.
meaning_story: You dare to do something risky. It's adventure time! Imagine yourself daring yourself to do risky things. Is this an adventure? If not, make it so!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は技術的に優れたボクサーと結婚した。
ex_1_en: I married a technically brilliant boxer.
meaning_story: You've seen 技 as a vocab word meaning "technique." This is sort of using that meaning. So, a technique of art is still art, but it's also your craft, your technique.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチさんから開業祝いの品が届いたので、机の上に置いておいたよ。ちなみにメッセージカードには、「あまりにも早く独立開業を成し遂げたあなたのパワーに圧倒されています」って書いあるよ。
ex_1_en: A congratulatory gift for the new business’s opening arrived from Mr. Koichi and I put it on your desk. On the card he wrote that you overwhelmed him with your power and how fast you were able to open your business.
meaning_story: This is the same as the kanji, at least in regards to the article or goods meaning, which means you can use this word to mean article or goods.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 再来月のマラソン大会、芸術家達と一緒に参加するってのはどう？
ex_1_en: How about running a marathon with a bunch of artists the month after next?
meaning_story: You know that 芸術 is art so you'd think that 芸術家 would be something like "art house." Well, it's not. Think of it this way: Who is the person who works for "House Art"? It's the artist.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もし誰かがあなたの家に侵入したら、この機械が自動的に警備会社に通報します。
ex_1_en: If someone breaks into your house this machine will automatically send a message to the security company.
meaning_story: An automatical (自動 + 的) thing of course isn't "automatical." A better way to say it is to cut off the -al and call it automatic.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the reading of 自動 as well.

ex_1_jp: 自動車の運転免許を失くしてしまいました。
ex_1_en: I lost my driver’s license.
meaning_story: You know that 自動 is automatic. So what is an automatic car? That is an automobile.
reading_story: The reading comes from 自動 and the kanji 車's readings, combined.
pitch_accent: ジドꜜーシャ *** ジドーシャ

ex_1_jp: 久々にいい作品に出会ったわ。進撃の巨人は、私の好きなアニメの歴代三位に入るんじゃないかってくらい良かったよ。マジでお薦めするわ。
ex_1_en: It’s been a while since I came across a work I like. Attack on Titan is so good that it might be one of my top three anime. I really recommend it.
meaning_story: A product you make is a fine work. It is a work you made. It is of your production.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 明日あなたにお弁当作ってあげようと思うんだけど、何か苦手なものとかあるの？
ex_1_en: I think I’ll make a bento box for you tomorrow, is there anything you’d prefer not to have?
meaning_story: You know how 弁 means dialect and 当 means success? Well, this isn't going to help you much, because this means bento or box lunch. Chances are, though, you know the word "bento" from English. So, if you read this word (which you should be able to) you can figure out it's べんとう. If you do that, you can realize this word means bento too!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: トフグのオフィスに届いた箱の中には、辞書と死んだフグが詰まっていた。
ex_1_en: The box that arrived at the Tofugu office was crammed with dictionaries and dead puffer fish.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 「新しいパソコンを買ったんだって？」「うーん。新品ではないんだけどね。ビエトのお下がりだよ。」
ex_1_en: "I heard you bought a new computer." "Well, it’s not brand new. It’s a hand-me-down from Viet."
meaning_story: A new product is something that's brand new or a new item. I like looking around the store for the brand new stuff because it's interesting!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Notice though that ひん changes to ぴん. This is because you're buying some brand new pins?

ex_1_jp: 仏典がどのようにしてサンスクリット語から漢語に訳されたのかご存じですか？
ex_1_en: Do you know how the Buddhist scriptures were translated from Sanskrit to Chinese?
meaning_story: The Buddha rules are the rules Buddha made for Buddhists. These can be found in the Buddhist Scriptures and Buddhist Writings.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that ぶつ gets shortened to ぶっ.

ex_1_jp: この書道字典は古本屋で買ったんです。
ex_1_en: I bought this calligraphy dictionary at a second hand bookstore.
meaning_story: The rules for letters can be found in a character dictionary. In Japanese, one "letter" or "character" can have a lot of information (we're talking kanji here). That means you need dictionaries for these individual letters as well! That's what this is.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あの日本の古典的なスタイルの画家は、私が知っている人の中で、一番好みがうるさいです。どうしてそんなに色々気にするのか理解不能です。
ex_1_en: That classical style Japanese painter is the pickiest person I know. I can’t understand why she cares so much.
meaning_story: When something is "old rules-like," it is not very modern. It is in the past. It is classical.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ビエトが全治六カ月の重傷を負った時、コウイチは特殊治癒能力を使ってビエトの傷を治した。
ex_1_en: When Viet suffered severe cuts that would have normally taken 6 months to heal completely, Koichi healed them with his special healing powers.
meaning_story: All cured! That means you've made a complete recovery! You're healed!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 当社トフグ、ならびに当社製品に関心をお寄せいただき、有難うございます。
ex_1_en: Thank you for your interest in our company, Tofugu, and in our products.
meaning_story: The things related to your heart are the things that concern and interest you the most.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「彼は前に結婚していて、子供も3人もいるのよ。」「知ってるわよ。でも、それとこれとは関係ないでしょ。」
ex_1_en: "He’s been married before and has three kids." "I know, but that has nothing to do with it."
meaning_story: A connection related to another connection obviously has some kind of connection, at least between all those meanings.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチはビエトに、年をとるにつれて保守的になる人が多いけど、俺はそうはなりたくない、と言った。
ex_1_en: Koichi told Viet that people tend to become more conservative as they get older, but he doesn’t want to be like that.
meaning_story: Who are all like "I want to preserve and protect what I have, get out of my business, government!"? That's why people who want to preserve and protect are conservative.
reading_story: The reading doesn't match up for this word's 守. The reading is しゅ, but you can remember that because the conservatives want to protect and preserve their hoes (ほ) and their shoes (しゅ) from the government. For some reason those get taxed a lot.

ex_1_jp: あなたの下品なメールは会社に戻ってからじっくり読ませてもらいます。
ex_1_en: I’ll carefully read your crude email for you when I get back to the office.
meaning_story: Things that are below normal products are the cheap knockoffs and bad quality items. These items are incredibly crude in their manufacturing and design. So much vulgarity!
reading_story: You haven't seen this reading for 下 yet (sorry there's so many for this kanji!). Those items are so crude that you can't even tell what they're supposed to be. Honestly they all just look like statues of lumpy geckos (げ). That says it's a lamp but it looks more like a gecko looking at the sky. That chair? Definitely a bunch of geckos having a pool party. Are you sure you didn't get this stuff from a weird gecko artist?

ex_1_jp: 危ない会社のこんなに危ない計画に巻き込まれることに、誰も反対しなかったなんて信じられないよ！
ex_1_en: I can’t believe no one opposed getting involved in the risky plan of such a risky company.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dangerous? It's dangerous.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone is in danger! It's poor old abe (あぶ) Lincoln. You try to save him, yelling out 危ないよ！！！！, but he get shot in the back of the head anyways.
pitch_accent: アブナイ *** アブナꜜイ

ex_1_jp: 肝心なのは、この日本語の課題を金曜日までに終わらせなければならないということだ。
ex_1_en: The bottom line is that we have to finish this Japanese assignment by Friday.
meaning_story: The weekday day is the day of the week, as in "Monday" or "Tuesday." You'll be learning those on level 18, but first you should learn 曜日 to get you prepared.
reading_story: This word uses the on'yomi reading for 曜 and the kun'yomi reading for 日. You've learned both of these already, but be careful because ひ of 日 changes to び here.

ex_1_jp: 関西弁で喋る女性はとても可愛いと思います。
ex_1_en: I think women who speak with a Kansai accent are really cute.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. The 〜 is there to show this attaches onto things, like 東京弁, meaning "Tokyo Dialect."
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Because it's normally attached to other words it uses the on'yomi reading like a jukugo word normally would.

ex_1_jp: 「愛」という字を辞書で引いて、意味の上に彼氏の名前を書いておいたの。そしたら、彼に見つかっちゃって、それで振られちゃったのさ。
ex_1_en: I looked up the word love in my dictionary and wrote my boyfriend’s name over top of the definition, but he dumped me when he saw it.
meaning_story: Take all the words you use in writing, put them together and you have a dictionary!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 辞典の使い方が分かりません。
ex_1_en: I don’t know how to use a dictionary.
meaning_story: You need to know the word rules of the language you're learning, don't you? Then you need a good dictionary that can explain its lexicon!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 本としてはちょっと大きすぎたので、私は百科事典を枕として使っていました。
ex_1_en: I used my encyclopedia as a pillow because it was too big to be a book.
meaning_story: Something filled with the rules of various actions is something that contains a ton of knowledge. It contains all things and actions, right? What kind of "thing" is filled with all this information (that existed during the creation of words and kanji?)? One thing would be an encyclopedia.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 君のことをぶったのは、愛の証だよ。だって、もし愛していなかったら、君の浮気なんて気にしないんだから。
ex_1_en: Slapping your face was proof of my love. If I didn’t love you, I wouldn’t have cared about you cheating on me.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Someone left some evidence behind at the crime scene. You pick it up, it's a kashi (あかし) bar. It has genetic evidence on it, because the criminal was eating it at the crime scene.

ex_1_jp: FBIは、生存者を求めて、夜通しTofuguオフィスの中を捜索した。
ex_1_en: The FBI searched all night for the survivor in the Tofugu office.
meaning_story: Suppose that life is in existence on this planet... What would that say about life and survival in such an unforgiving place?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あーーーしまったーーーー。急行列車が行ってしまった。ってことは私の遅刻も確定だ。コウイチから受ける処罰がすんごく怖いんですけど。
ex_1_en: Oh, noooooo, the express train just left. That means I’ll be late. I’m really scared of being punished by Koichi.
meaning_story: Things that hurry and go faster than the other things are express. This is often used with trains or subways, so look out for it if you're looking to get somewhere in a hurry. Also be careful in case it doesn't stop at your stop, because 急行 trains don't stop at every station (which is what makes them express!).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼の外面に騙されない方がいいですよ。私がインストラクターのことが嫌いだったのは、上司にはいい顔をして陰で後輩のことを小突き回していたからです。
ex_1_en: You shouldn’t be fooled by his outward appearance. I hated my instructor because he showed his superiors a nice face while he bullied subordinates, including me, behind their backs.
meaning_story: The outside face to something is the exterior of that thing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ガイメン *** ガイメꜜン *** ソトズラ *** トꜜノモ

ex_1_jp: 私はアスファルトに顔面を強打した。
ex_1_en: I hit my face on the asphalt.
meaning_story: The face of a face is a face, but more specifically the face of a person. Probably because the most face-like thing you can ever have is a human's face... at least in our eyes (by "our" I mean the human race's eyes, because I am totally with you guys on that one).
reading_story: The reading for 顔 isn't the one you learned with the kanji. But, we're going to learn that reading right now. The worst thing that can happen to a face is if a face disappears. If it becomes totally gone (がん). A man that is walking up to you with no face, is a man with a gone face. Those men are men who are a part of the gone men (がんめん). Faces, totally gone!
pitch_accent: ガンメン *** ガンメꜜン

ex_1_jp: あんなに簡単な試験が不合格だったなんて本当に恥ずかしいよ。穴があったら入りたいぐらいだ。
ex_1_en: I’m so embarrassed I failed such an easy test. I wish I could sink through the floor.
meaning_story: You know that 合格する is "to pass a test," so what's the opposite of that? Fail a test or failure.
reading_story: If you know the reading for 合格, all you have to do is add 不 to it! You've learned all these readings, yay!
pitch_accent: フゴꜜーカク *** フコ°ꜜーカク

ex_1_jp: 東京は、ポートランドからどれくらい遠いの？歩くにはちょっと遠すぎますか？
ex_1_en: How far is Tokyo from Portland? Is it too far for me to walk?
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of far? It's also far (or it's far away).
reading_story: The reading you learned with the kanji can be used here. Be careful, it's that tricky とお thing!

ex_1_jp: 遠くの方で銃声が響いた。
ex_1_en: A gunshot went off in a far off direction.
meaning_story: This is the noun/no-adjective version of the kanji far, so it means far away or distant.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: 「なんてこった！今夜の君はとてもきれいだね。まるで、お姫様みたいだよ。」「パパ、お世辞を言っても何も出ないわよ。」
ex_1_en: "Oh wow! You look so beautiful tonight. Like a princess!" "Flattery will get you nowhere, daddy.”
meaning_story: When you quit your current generation to join an older one you need all the flattery you can get because you're starting to feel old. People probably still won't like you though, ya old fart.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ズボンには折り目を付けてもらえますか？
ex_1_en: Could you put a crease in my trousers?
meaning_story: A fold you can see with your eye is a fold or crease in something.
reading_story: The readings are both kun'yomi vocab readings. You should have seen 折る by now which should help you to read 折り. Then there's 目, which I'm guessing you won't have a problem with.

ex_1_jp: 手紙や小包を送る時には、いつも前面にTofuguのステッカーを貼ります。
ex_1_en: Whenever we send a letter or a package, we put the Tofugu sticker on the front of it.
meaning_story: The front face of something is the front or the front side of it (kind of like how 外面 is the exterior because it's the outside face).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ゼンメン *** ゼンメꜜン

ex_1_jp: どのくらい頻繁に超基本的な間違いをしてびっくりしますか？
ex_1_en: How often are you surprised by making basic mistakes?
meaning_story: The things that are basic (基本) like (的) are your basics and fundamentals. These are like the radicals you learn with your kanji. They're the fundamentals!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing how to read the word 基本 will be helpful too.

pronunciation: ごみばこ, ゴミばこy
ex_1_jp: ゴミ箱のゴミを捨てる時のあなたってとってもセクシーだと思うのよね。だから、ちょっと私のためにゴミ箱のゴミを捨ててくれないかな？
ex_1_en: I think you are so sexy when you empty the garbage can, so could you empty the garbage for me please?
meaning_story: ゴミ means "garbage." Add a box to it and you have a garbage box aka a garbage can or garbage bin.
reading_story: The reading is just the on'yomi reading, the one you learned with the kanji. Be sure to pay attention to the rendaku though. はこ changes to ばこ.

ex_1_jp: 私は植物園の近くに住んでいます。
ex_1_en: I live near the botanical garden.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Lucky you, the word garden is read the same way as the kanji is read. Kind of a Garden of Eden for kanji and vocab, no?

ex_1_jp: 門には鍵がかかっているんだ。
ex_1_en: The gate is locked.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 幸運になるおまじないよ。
ex_1_en: I’ll get good luck with this good luck charm.
meaning_story: When you carry happiness with you, you look at the good side of everything and end up having really good luck. Someone who carries happiness will be really lucky in life.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私達の記事が政府から出版を禁止されているなんて信じられません。Tofuguには政府を批判する権利があります。
ex_1_en: We can’t believe that the government has prohibited our articles from being published. Tofugu has the right to criticize the government.
meaning_story: Politics and government. They are needed to keep the government rolling.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 卒業式の後の旅行超楽しみだよ〜！ゆっくり露天風呂に入って、山の幸をいっぱい食べ尽くそうね。ところで、念のため確認だけど、宿の予約してくれたんだよね？
ex_1_en: I’m so excited for the trip after our graduation ceremony! Let’s get in the hot spring to relax and eat a lot of local delicious food. By the way, just making sure but you made a reservation at the cottage, right?
meaning_story: You know that 卒業 is graduation so what about when you add ceremony to it? That makes it a graduation ceremony.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know how to read 卒業 already as a word, too.

ex_1_jp: 食料品売場はどこにありますか。
ex_1_en: Could you tell me where the grocery section is?
meaning_story: Products you're paying a fee to eat later are your groceries. Buy them now, eat them later, yum!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ショクリョーヒン *** ショクリョꜜーヒン

ex_1_jp: コウイチはフグを優しく撫でてから、地面に降ろしてあげました。
ex_1_en: Koichi gently stroked Fugu and placed him on the ground.
meaning_story: The ground/earth face is the surface that makes up the ground or the Earth's surface.
reading_story: The reading for 面 is what you'd expect. 地 on the other hand is じ, which is a bit different (though close sounding) to what you learned previously. Thank the Chinese and their ever changing language for this one. Think of Jesus laying on the ground, telling you how comfortable the ground is. You say "Jesus, you have to get off the ground, you have a dinner to go to," but he doesn't want to leave.

ex_1_jp: 恐らく灰色熊が近寄ってくるかと思いますが、とても安全なのでご安心ください。ご保証致します。
ex_1_en: The grizzly bears will probably approach you, but don’t worry. It’s very, very safe. We guarantee it.
meaning_story: Evidence that something will be preserved is a form of guarantee, at least as long as the evidence is strong enough. Also, 保 also means guarantee, so use that to help you to remember this word.
reading_story: Evidence that something will be preserved is a form of guarantee, at least as long as the evidence is strong enough. Also, 保 also means guarantee, so use that to help you to remember this word.

ex_1_jp: うわぁ、阪神タイガースのファンたち、恵比寿橋からあの汚い川にダイブしたんだって？すげぇな、あいつらの頭大丈夫かよ！
ex_1_en: Oh my God! Hanshin Tigers fans dived off the Ebisu bridge down into the dirty river? Wow, they are nuts!
meaning_story: The slopes of the gods! What could this be? Well, it's mainly just a company, known as Hanshin. They're everywhere, though, and even have a baseball team (the Hanshin Tigers), so it's good to know.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は幸運の星のもとに生まれたため、幸福すぎて毎日涙が止まらないんだよ。
ex_1_en: She was born under a lucky star and she has so much happiness in her life that she can’t help but cry every day.
meaning_story: With a little luck and happiness you can achieve happiness, though that goes without saying.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「私はお金で幸せは買えると思います。何故なら、私は花火を見ていると幸せな気持ちになるからです。もし私が大金持ちだったら、毎日花火を楽しんでずっと幸せな気持ちでいられることができます。」彼女は幸せそうな口調でそう言った。
ex_1_en: "I think money can buy happiness because watching fireworks makes me happy. If I had a lot of money, I could enjoy fireworks every day and feel happy all the time." she said happily.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji 幸. Kanji means happiness and the vocab word means happiness.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're seeking true happiness. You're following the great guru, Charlie Shee-awasay (しあわせ, which you remember because it sounds like "She Ow! Say..." which is the chant you all do to try to become happy.

ex_1_jp: 記念日を忘れるなんて、最低よ！
ex_1_en: Forgetting something like Memorial Day is the worst!
meaning_story: Some days are so special that you have to write down all your thoughts when they're done. These are special days like holidays and your anniversary.
reading_story: The reading is a combination of on'yomi for the first two and kun'yomi for the last one. That being said, all of the readings for all of the kanji are the readings you've learned already, so you should be able to read this word too. Just watch out because ひ is rendaku'd into び.

ex_1_jp: 誰かがうちのオフィスに毎月仏像を一体ずつ送ってくるんです。心当たりのある方は、どうか名乗り出て下さい。
ex_1_en: Someone sends a Buddhist statue to our office every month. If you are that person, please come forward and identify yourself.
meaning_story: You have Buddha's image. What is that? It's an image of Buddha.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 勝ち試合が雨で中止になり、Tofuguソフトボールチームのシーズンが不完全に終わった。
ex_1_en: The Tofugu softball team had an incomplete end to their season when the game they were winning was suspended due to rain.
meaning_story: You know that 完全 means "complete" or "perfect." So, a not "complete" or "perfect" is something that is incomplete or imperfect.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It also will help if you can read 完全.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは一度不治の病に倒れ、「俺たちは必ず、また会えるよ」とビエトに言い残し亡くなったのですが、言葉通り次の日にはオフィスに出勤し、以前と全く同じように業務をこなしました。
ex_1_en: When Koichi fell incurably ill and died, his last words to Viet were, "We will meet again." True to his words, he came back to the office the next day and did everything the same as he had before.
meaning_story: When you can not cure something, this is a problem of incurability.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: フチꜜ *** フꜜチ *** フꜜジ

ex_1_jp: しまった。また家に健康保険証を忘れてきちゃった。
ex_1_en: Oh no, I left my health insurance card at home again.
meaning_story: When you are able to guarantee against risk, it's probably because you bought some good insurance! What do you use? The gecko 保険?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あはははは！超ウケるんだけど。今まで聞いた中で、一番面白い話だわ。
ex_1_en: Ahahaha! You crack me up, Fugu! That’s the most amusing thing I’ve ever heard.
meaning_story: The face of this object is so white! Why is it so white compared to everything else? This is so interesting...
reading_story: The reading is unlike what you've learned before, at least with the 面 part (白い is just like the vocab word 白い). When you look at the white face of the object you say to your friend Moe: "Oh mo!" (おも) because you want him to come over and look at this. Try to imagine someone you know named Moe, or at least a celebrity or something named Moe.

ex_1_jp: 冗談はヤメてよ！何でフレンチレストランなんて行きたいの？私達の柄じゃないっしょ。飲めればどこでもいいじゃん？違う？
ex_1_en: Stop joking. Why do you want to go to a French restaurant? We shouldn’t break our pattern. If we’re just going drinking, anywhere is okay, right?
meaning_story: When you discuss something superfluous you aren't being serious, you're telling a joke.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: こいつは完全に関西は初心者だから、俺らが案内してやらないとな。
ex_1_en: This guy is a total noob in Kansai, so we’ll have to show him around.
meaning_story: The Kansai region of Japan is the Southern Central part of Japan. It actually connects the East side of Japan (at least back in the day) to the West side, making it the "connection to the west." For our purposes, though, we should call it "Kansai."
reading_story: Urgh, what a confusing reading! The 西 is さい instead of せい. Readings like this just make you want to sigh (さい), no?

ex_1_jp: 「年末年始のお休みいつからいつまでなの？一緒に図書館に行こうよ。」「十二月三十日から五日間だけど、図書館も閉まってるはずだよ。」
ex_1_en: "When is your New Years Holiday vacation? I want to go to the library with you." "I have five days off starting December 30th, but I’m afraid the library will be closed too."
meaning_story: A public building where written things are all diagramed out in a way that lets you find said written things? That sounds like a library to me!
reading_story: The 書館 part should be readable by you, but it's the 図 that's troublesome with an alternate reading from the one you learned. Imagine yourself at the library. You check out every single book you can about the human toe (と). You have a giant stack of books on it, then you drop it... ironically on your toe. You decide to show Khan (your buddy) your smashed toe.

ex_1_jp: 日本では、女性の生命保険販売員は「生保レディ」と呼ばれますが、彼女たちの中には大きなコミッションや昇進のために枕営業をする人がいるとよく言われます。
ex_1_en: Life insurance saleswomen are called ’seiho ladies’ in Japan and it’s often said that some of them sleep their ways to big commissions or promotions.
meaning_story: A Life guarantee is something you get on someone else. If their life ends, it's guaranteed with money. That's a life insurance policy, for yah!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 特急券を先に買っておいたので、今出れば三時五十分の特急に間に合うよ。
ex_1_en: I already got an express ticket for you, so if you leave now you can still catch the 3:50 express train.
meaning_story: Something that's special and in a hurry must be special indeed. This refers to limited express trains in Japan. They go fast, they stop at fewer stops (because they're special!) and they hurry. Look out for these if you want to get somewhere in a jiffy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the とく goes to とっ.

ex_1_jp: 「誰かさんが車から荷物を降ろさないといけないんだけど…。」 「わかったから、それ以上言わなくていいよ。」
ex_1_en: "Someone ought to unpack the luggage from the car…" "Alright. Say no more."
meaning_story: A luggage thing is your luggage. It's also your baggage and load too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You'll need to remember the 物 reading as もつ, though. Why? Because all your luggage just got thrown into various moats along the countryside. It's going to take you forever to collect your luggage from these moats and by then it'll be all soggy. Dangit...

ex_1_jp: わぁ、びっくりした！なんで仮面なんて被ってるの？
ex_1_en: Ah, you startled me! Why are you wearing that mask?
meaning_story: A temporary face is something you put over your face to cover it. It's a mask.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 明治時代の生活を描いたドラマを見ているんですが、当時は一万円が大金だったということに驚きました。
ex_1_en: I was watching a drama series about life in the Meiji Era and was surprised that ten thousand yen was a large amount of money those days.
meaning_story: It’s the era of Bright Rule! If this doesn't make sense, don't worry about it. Focus more on the reading, which is めいじ. Sound familiar? This is the famous Meiji Era or Meiji Emperor. If you don't know about it consider reading up, it's interesting history!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私はこの新商品は大成功を収めると信じているんだが、君にはこの商品の店内キャンペーンでの販売促進に取り組んでもらいたいと思っているんだ。頼りにしているよ。
ex_1_en: I believe this new product will be a big success and I’d like you to work on promoting this product through in-store campaigns. I’m really counting on you.
meaning_story: Articles of merchandise are still merchandise.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「どうやって美術館のツアーガイドになれるの？芸術の専門家か何かじゃなくちゃいけないんじゃないの？」「いいや、そうでもないよ。 美術館が情報を全部くれるから、まぁ、台詞を覚えるようなもんだよ。」
ex_1_en: "How can you be a tour guide in the museum? Don’t you have to be an art expert or something?" "No, not really. They give you all the information, it’s like memorizing a script."
meaning_story: You know 美術 is fine art. So what is a public building that contains said fine art? It's a museum.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ビジュツꜜカン *** ビジュꜜツカン

ex_1_jp: 私のことをこの数年間支えてくれたみなさん、本当に有難うございます。お陰様で、ついに折り紙で河豚が折れるようになりました。
ex_1_en: I want to thank everyone who has shown me support over the years. Thankfully, I’ve finally mastered how to make an origami Fugu.
meaning_story: You know that 折る is "to fold," so what about "to fold paper"? Ever heard of something that involves lots of folding of paper that is Japanese? Most likely you have. This is origami, aka the art of paper folding.
