reading_story: The reading comes from 折る and the vocab word 紙. As long as you know those you should be able to read this. Also, you probably already know this reading because it's an English word, too.
pitch_accent: オリꜜカ°ミ *** オリカ°ミ

ex_1_jp: あいにくですが、来週の水曜日はちょっと都合がつかないんです。代わりに来週の木曜日に大阪に行くってのはどうでしょうか？
ex_1_en: I’m afraid I won’t be able to make it next Wednesday. What about going to Osaka next Thursday instead?
meaning_story: The big heights. What a nice area to be, it's where everyone wants to live! This magical place is Osaka. Heard of it before? It's a city, and kind of the rival to Tokyo.
reading_story: The reading is pretty weird, but then again so are people from Osaka (just kidding, Osakazens!). The 大 reads like おお from おおきい. Then, 阪 uses the kun'yomi reading as well, which you didn't learn. That being said, doesn't this kanji look like 坂, which also means slope? Well, it shares a kun'yomi reading as well, so if you've seen 坂 you can apply that reading over to here, making おおさか. Then again, if you know this word means Osaka you probably can figure out how to write it too. Don't forget the double おお though!

pronunciation: わたしじしん, わたくしじしん
ex_1_jp: あなたがもし私自身よりも私のことを知っていると思っているんだとしたら、 それはとんだ大間違いよ。
ex_1_en: You’re way off base if you think you know me better than I know myself.
meaning_story: "When it comes to somebody like myself... aka I..." When you say this you're really saying "personally" or "as for me."
reading_story: The readings are a bit weird here. The 私 is わたし and the rest is on'yomi kanji readings. So, it's a mix of both, I'm afraid. "When it comes to me, I like mixing up on'yomi and kun'yomi because I hate myself."

ex_1_jp: ご依頼のフグのヌード写真集を同封いたします。
ex_1_en: Enclosed are the nude photos of Fugu you requested.
meaning_story: A copy of reality is a lot like magic. How do you make a copy of reality, though? You take a photo.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: やばい、超絶に可愛い真っ黒なワンピース見付けちゃったんだけど。
ex_1_en: OMG, I just came across the cutest pure black dress.
meaning_story: The reality is that it's black. Like, so black that it's beyond fake black, it's reality black. This is so black it's pitch black.
reading_story: The reading for the 真 is the vocab kun'yomi reading. Think of what is pitch black. It's your poor Ma (ま). She is so dark that she sucks in light, like a black hole... wait, she is a black hole, it explains why your Ma is pitch black.

ex_1_jp: ワシントンDCで起きている政治騒動なんてお構いなしに、トフグは共和党と民主党の両地域で雇用を生み出している。
ex_1_en: Being mindful of the political turmoil occurring in Washington D.C., Tofugu has created employment for both the Republican Party and the Democratic Party.
meaning_story: If you want to cure the government, you have to get into politics. Gotta join 'em to fix them... but can you survive that long without being corrupted yourself?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このベーコンは、着色保存料を一切使用しておりません。じゃ、本当にベーコンではありません。
ex_1_en: This bacon contains no food colorings and preservatives at all. Well, then it really isn’t bacon.
meaning_story: We can preserve that, I suppose. You suppose? Okay, fine, we can preserve it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あの出火した私立大学は、私が通っている学校だよ。
ex_1_en: The private college that’s on fire is the college I’m currently attending.
meaning_story: You've seen 私立, which is "private," and you've seen 大学, which is "college" or "university." So, combine them together and you have a private college / private university.
reading_story: If you know the readings of the words 私立 and 大学 you'll be able to read this. It's also all jukugo on'yomi readings too, so you can read it that way.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: テキストフグ、ワニカニ、エトエトの各コースが修了するごとに、修了証明書のようなものが受け取れた方がいいですか？
ex_1_en: Do you want to receive some sort of certificate proving you finished the textfugu, wanikani, and etoeto courses?
meaning_story: Is the evidence bright enough to convince me? Is this really proof enough?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この辺りは治安も悪くないからね。
ex_1_en: This area doesn’t have bad public peace either.
meaning_story: If everything in the world is healed to the point where you can relax it's called good public order. The public safety and public peace are great because there's nothing to worry about anymore, now that it's all been healed!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「フグと一緒にいった公園、どうだった？」「正直今までに行った公園の中で一番楽しかったよ。」
ex_1_en: "So, how was the park you and Fugu went to?" "That was actually the most enjoyable park we’ve ever been to."
meaning_story: A public park is a park that is public. It's a public park.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguは、火星での安定的で繁栄的な情勢を保持することに、微力ながら貢献したいと思います。
ex_1_en: Tofugu will contribute our humble efforts to maintain a stable and prosperous environment on Mars.
meaning_story: When you hold on and preserve something you are doing the act of retention or maintenance on it. This is preservation.
reading_story: The ほ part is fine to read, but the じ is an exceptional reading. Think about what you want to maintain/preserve. How about preserving Jesus in your home. You found his body, and you want to keep it preserved for generations to come (if you touch it, you get miracles!).

ex_1_jp: 我が社は現在債務不履行の危険性に瀕しているが、リスクを覚悟のうえで、信頼に基づいて行動し続けるしかないと思うんだ。
ex_1_en: Our company is at risk of defaulting on its loan, but I believe that we have to keep taking risks and acting based on our faith.
meaning_story: Something that is dangerous and risky is probably pretty risky dangerous, and unsafe.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 最後の場面で泣いてしまいました。
ex_1_en: I cried during the last scene.
meaning_story: Everything on a location's surface is really just a part of the scene before you. This is the kind of scene that would be set in a novel. It's the setting.
reading_story: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: 変なんだよ。ビエトはいつも通り画面に釘付けになって何時間も座ったままでいるんだけど、その画面が今朝から真っ黒なんだよね。
ex_1_en: It’s weird. Viet is sitting glued to a screen for hours as usual, though his screen has been completely black since this morning.
meaning_story: The surface of a drawing is a screen. Just imagine your computer screen. On its surface is a drawing, right? It just happens to move around all the time, but it's still a screen!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この笑顔の素敵な男は俺の連れで、コウイチっていうの。
ex_1_en: This smiling, lovely guy with me is Koichi.
meaning_story: A laughing face is a smiling face (or just a smile!). 笑顔s all around!
reading_story: The reading for this word won't make you smile, though. You were smiling, but then you heard about the reading of this kanji. It made you yell out "EH??" (え).

ex_1_jp: 私の専門は天文学です。新しい星を発見したいです。
ex_1_en: My major is astronomy. I want to discover new stars.
meaning_story: Your specialty gate is the thing you open to let out your specialty. Imagine the thing you're best at (your specialty). Now imagine opening a gate in your chest that lets it out, allowing you to be good at it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 約束を来週の日曜日に変更していただけませんか？土曜日に、留学の書類を取りに日本総領事館に行かなければならなくなってしまって。
ex_1_en: Could you reschedule my appointment for next Sunday? On Saturday I have to go to the Japanese Consulate General to get some study abroad documents.
meaning_story: You detain your study and take it away to a foreign place. That foreign place is having you study abroad.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 留 is the りゅう version. You can remember this because Ryu (りゅう) from street fighter is doing a study abroad program to learn more karate.

ex_1_jp: 彼とはよく喧嘩になっちゃって、それが本当に嫌だったんだけど、今では喧嘩もできなくなっちゃってすっごく悲しいよ。まさか心臓発作で急死しちゃうなんて思ってもみなかったからさ。
ex_1_en: I often argued with my boyfriend and I hated it, but I even miss the arguments now. I never expected that he would drop dead from a heart attack.
meaning_story: When someone experiences a hurry death it's a very sudden death.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: えっ、クリステン！急にそんなことを言われても、困るよ...。
ex_1_en: Oh, Kristen! Even if you tell me that sort of thing immediately, I’m at a loss...
meaning_story: If you go towards something and hurry while you do it, you are doing it suddenly.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Suddenly you can read a new word!

ex_1_jp: トフグのワンコは、ベランダで日光浴をするのが大好きです。
ex_1_en: The Tofugu dog loves to sunbathe on the balcony.
meaning_story: You know that 日光 is sunlight so when you add bathe you get "sunlight bathe" ... but that sounds dumb, so let's call this word sunbathe instead!
reading_story: The reading is just the word 日光 and よく, which isn't the reading you learned. You can remember this reading because when you go out sunbathing, you put an egg yolk on top of your face because you think it will help you get tan. Instead, you just have an egg yolk shape after it fries it on your face.

ex_1_jp: あなたに、面と向かってお話したいことがあります。ご予定は、いつが空いていますか？
ex_1_en: I have something to talk to you about face-to-face. When are you available?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
pitch_accent: オモテꜜ *** ツラꜜ *** メꜜン *** メン

ex_1_jp: フグが先生の林檎に河豚毒を塗ったと疑われた時、クラスメート全員が彼は無実だと証言した。
ex_1_en: When Fugu was suspected of placing some puffer fish poison on the teacher’s apple, all his classmates testified that he was innocent.
meaning_story: Evidence that you say is testimony. Hopefully you won't have to give too much of this in your lifetime.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ショーケ°ン *** ショーケ°ꜜン

ex_1_jp: 教科書を持ってくるのを忘れました。
ex_1_en: I forgot to bring my textbook.
meaning_story: A teach science writing is a writing that is used for the science of teaching. It's a science because it's regulated and straightforward. Only way to do that is to have a textbook that everybody uses. That's why this is a textbook.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: フグは私に親友の天然鯛を紹介してくれました。鯛君は、深海に住んでいるので日光をあまり浴びないんだと言っていました。
ex_1_en: Fugu introduced me his best friend, Wild Red Sea Bream. He told me Sea Bream lives at great depths and is bathed in hardly any sunlight.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bathe so the verb vocab version is to bathe.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, so go bathe all that worry away and move on to the next lesson!

ex_1_jp: ビエトは、Tofuguのオフィスで働いている時に、アジトでの発砲に関する電話を受けた。
ex_1_en: While working at the Tofugu office, Viet received a call concerning a shooting at his hideout.
meaning_story: You know that 関 means connection. So, when you add する to it you make it a verb. Now it means to be connected to.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: もし毒抜きをせずに河豚を食べたら、命に係わりますよ。
ex_1_en: If you ate blowfish without taking the poison out, it would be a matter of life and death.
meaning_story: You know that the kanji means connection. This is a verb, so one meaning is to be connected with. There are many other ways to say this too. This word is a bit full featured. You can say to be involved with or even To Be Affected. Basically things that have to do with being connected with something else.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who have you gotten involved with this time? The "Kaw Kaw (かか) Crow Gang" this time? They are bad news, always eating from garbage and stuff... You don't want to be connected with them.

ex_1_jp: そんなことを言われると、心が折れるよ。
ex_1_en: My heart breaks when you say that.
meaning_story: You already learned how 折る means "to fold." Well this is what happens after that. You folded it too far and now it's starting to break.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 折る, so you should know this one too!

ex_1_jp: 「ねぇ、サーモン。あんたとフグが一緒に住み始めた時、やっぱり二人とも妥協しなきゃいけなかった？」「うーん。私はしなかったけど、フグはね！」
ex_1_en: "Hey Salmon, did you and Fugu have to make compromises when you first moved in together?" "Well, not me, but Fugu did."
meaning_story: You know that 妥協 means compromise. So, what happens when you make it a verb? It becomes to compromise.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the vocab word 妥協, so if you know that you should be good (also, just the reading of the kanji works too).

ex_1_jp: ビエトだけが、コウイチが怪我や病気を治すことができる不思議な力を持っていることを知っている。
ex_1_en: Only Viet knows that Koichi has strange powers that can heal injuries and sicknesses.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cure, so the verb vocab version is to cure. Don't get this confused with 治る which means "to be healed." This particular verb is when you do the curing. How do you know that? Because when you try to heal them, you mess up, and then they try to sue (す) you.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I need you to heal him, and I need you to heal him right now (なお). NOW NOW NOW! This also shares the reading for 直す, a very similar word you learned previously, which means "to fix." I'm guessing that the Japanese word なおす was only one word ("to fix" and "to cure" are pretty similar, right?). Then, there were two Chinese words for it (as you can see with the kanji), so the one Japanese word got split into two very similar words.
pitch_accent: シロシメꜜス *** ナオꜜス

ex_1_jp: 彼にお金を要求されたから、ふざけるなって言ってやったんだけど、それからボコボコにされて、財布から無理やりお金を盗られちゃったよ。
ex_1_en: When he demanded money from me I told him to kiss my ass. Then I was beaten up and he forcibly stole the money from my wallet.
meaning_story: You hopefully know that 要求 is a demand. When you make that a verb it becomes to demand.
reading_story: The reading is just the vocab word 要求. It's also the regular on'yomi jukugo reading.

ex_1_jp: 私の兄は障害を乗り越え、大学を卒業しました。私は兄をとても誇りに思います。大学卒業は彼の決意と努力の賜物です。
ex_1_en: My brother overcame his disability and graduated from college. I’m very proud of him. His graduation is the result of his determination and effort.
meaning_story: You know that 卒業 is "graduation." Make it a verb, and you have to graduate.
reading_story: The reading is just the same as the vocab word 卒業.

part_of_speech: INTRANSITIVE VERB, TRANSITIVE VERB, AND GODAN VERB
ex_1_jp: 「もう！急いでよ！遅れちゃうわ。」「今起きたから、すぐ行くわ。」
ex_1_en: "Hey, hurry up! We’ll be late." "I just woke up, I’m coming."
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hurry so the verb vocab version is to hurry.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone who is trying to hurry is someone who is not at ease (いそ).

ex_1_jp: 年末でお忙しいとは存じますが、この記事を読んで頂ければ嬉しく存じます。
ex_1_en: This article will be posted during the busy end of the year season, but I would appreciate it if you could read it.
meaning_story: This is like a fancy and humble way of saying to know. Sure, the kanji means suppose, but think of it this way... When you say "I suppose" it's like a humble way of saying "I know." You're not being as direct about it this way, and in Japanese, that makes you more humble and polite. So, that's why 存じる means to know.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. If you remember the kanji reading, you'll have no problem remembering this vocabulary reading as well!

ex_1_jp: 「ねえ、無料で東京弁のレッスンを受けたいんだけど。」「コウイチに聞けよ。アイツは何でもするぞ。」
ex_1_en: "I need to get some free Tokyo dialect lessons." "Ask Koichi. He’ll do anything."
meaning_story: You know that 東京 is Tokyo, and you know that 弁 is dialect, so you have yourself Tokyo dialect.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know how to read 東京 already, which you should.

ex_1_jp: 「昨夜、フグとデートをしたの。」「どうだった？」「楽しかった。めちゃくちゃ笑ったわ。」
ex_1_en: "I had a date with Fugu last night." "How did it go?" "It was fun. I laughed a lot."
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means laugh so the verb vocab version is to laugh.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You can laugh freely, now!

ex_1_jp: 昨夜Tofuguオフィスに泥棒が入り、Tofuguステッカーを何枚か盗んで行ったのですが、馬鹿な泥棒たちは、指紋を残すという初歩的な過ちも犯しました。
ex_1_en: Thieves broke into the Tofugu office and stole some of their stickers last night, but they were so stupid that they made the elementary mistake of leaving behind their fingerprints.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means remainder, but you can't really "to remainder." What is something that's similar that would make sense? How about to leave behind. This is when you're actually doing the leaving behind too. For example, you eat some food and you leave behind your rice because you're a bad child. You can remember this because of す. Every time you leave some food behind your mom would sue you, because she was a terrible mom. Imagine this.
reading_story: The reading for this word can come from level 14 item 残る. Associate the two in your mind and you'll be able to read both.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは、日本に軍隊を派遣する決意を固めた。
ex_1_en: Koichi decided to fortify his position and send his troops to Japan.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hard so the verb vocab version? To make hard. You need to differentiate this from 固まる, though, which means "to harden" (the hardening happens on its own). This word means "to make hard," because you're doing the hardening. You can remember this because you want to make something hard. And to do that, you send special "mail" (める) to this thing you want to make hard, and this mail does that for you.
reading_story: Since the reading for 固 (かた) is different than the one you learned with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. A caterpillar (かた) forms a cocoon. The caterpillar's cocoon is hard and the caterpillar made it that way. Keep this in mind and you too will blossom into a beautiful butterfly.

ex_1_jp: あのお医者さんに、「体調を保つためには、日々の運動が大切だよ」なんて言われたけど、そのお医者さん自体がすっごく太ってるんだよね。
ex_1_en: The doctor told me that it’s important to exercise regularly to maintain your physical health, but he is so fat.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means preserve so the verb vocab version is to preserve.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have something you want to preserve. What you want to preserve is the great classic cartoon, "Tom (たも) & Jerry." Kids don't watch the good stuff anymore, so if you preserve it you'll be able to share it with your kids too. Alternatively, you can think about how you want to preserve the version of Tom Cruise that existed before Scientology so that he never becomes the future Tom Cruise.

ex_1_jp: いいか、わが愛犬よ、よく聞け。家族を守るのは、お前の責任だ。
ex_1_en: Listen to me, my dog. It’s up to you to protect your family.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means protect so the verb vocab version is to protect and also to defend.
reading_story: You need to protect against breast cancer, so you get yourself a mamogram (まも).

ex_1_jp: フグが会社を辞めるので、お餞別に浮き輪を買おうと思っています。一緒に買いたい人は連絡ください。
ex_1_en: Since Fugu quit, I’m thinking about getting him a swim ring as a farewell gift. If anyone wants to join my idea, let me know.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means quit so the verb vocab version is to quit.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "Hey, you going to quit?" "Yah (や) man, I'm going to quit."

ex_1_jp: 日本語を勉強することがあなたの人生で唯一の喜びだと聞いて、私達はとても嬉しく思っています。喜んでアドバイスするので、質問があればいつでも聞いてくださいね。
ex_1_en: They were so pleased to hear that studying Japanese is your only joy in life. We’d be happy to offer you some tips, so feel free to ask us any questions at anytime.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rejoice so the verb vocab version is to rejoice. Possible better translations are to become happy.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. It's a bit mouthy, but because you know the reading you should rejoice a bit.

ex_1_jp: 雨が降っているので、待ち合わせを地下に変更することを希望しますが、どう思われますか？
ex_1_en: It’s raining, so I hope we can change our appointment to be held underground, what do you think?
meaning_story: You know that 希望 is a "wish" or a "hope." So, when you "do a wish" or "do a hope." When you do that, that means to request or to wish.
reading_story: The reading comes from 希望. It's also the on'yomi jukugo reading as well, if that helps any.

ex_1_jp: 私がこの行動の責任はすべて取ります。本当にごめんなさい。
ex_1_en: I take full responsibility for my actions. I am truly sorry.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means take, so the verb vocab version is to take.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so take control and move on to the next lesson.

ex_1_jp: よっしゃ！今コウイチのフェイスブックアカウントをハッキングしてやったぜ！これから、コウイチのポストとして、何でも好きなことを書くことができる。へへへ。
ex_1_en: Yay! I just hacked into Koichi’s Facebook account. Now I can make Koichi’s posts whatever I want to write about. Hehehe.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means write so the verb version means to write.
reading_story: The reading you learned with the kanji is the on'yomi one, but this word is read with the kun'yomi, か. So just be sure to remember the kun'yomi reading to read this word in the car (か) ... or to write it, or whatever.

part_of_speech: ADVERB, NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 真実から目を背けないで。結局マザコンだってこと、認めなさいよ。あんたのお母さんはあんたのことを愛しているし、あんたもお母さんのことを愛しているんでしょ。
ex_1_en: You’ve got to face the facts! Admit that you’re a momma’s boy after all. Your mother loves you, and you love her too.
meaning_story: The reality of the truth is nothing more than the truth and the reality. Doesn't get any more real than this.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 不幸は仲間を好むと言って、私はあなたを付き合う理由を説明しているよ。
ex_1_en: They say misery loves company, which explains why I’m dating you.
meaning_story: When you do not have happiness, you have unhappiness and misfortune.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今夜店を出発する前に残品を数えておきましょう。
ex_1_en: Before we leave the store tonight, let’s go ahead and count the remaining stock.
meaning_story: The remainder products are the things that haven't been sold. It's the unsold merchandise. It's the remaining stock.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that ひん changes to ぴん.
pitch_accent: ザンピン *** ザꜜンピン

ex_1_jp: 急な依頼ですみません。
ex_1_en: Sorry for the sudden request.
meaning_story: You only need to hurry to something if it's urgent and it happened all of a sudden. You didn't even have time to prepare.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 証人として、遠回しに言わずに率直に君の質問に答えさせてもらうよ。ああ、あのフグが確かに君のプリンを食べていたね。
ex_1_en: As a witness, I won’t beat around the bush, I’ll answer your question frankly. Yeah, that Fugu was certainly eating your pudding.
meaning_story: An evidence person is a witness, because witnesses are people who provide evidence (you know, with their mouths or something).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ヤクザだって動物園に来ることもあるさ。
ex_1_en: Even yakuza can come to the zoo.
meaning_story: Remember how 動物 means animal? Well when you add park it becomes a zoo. It's a park for animals. Except the animals can't leave. Ever.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 大変申し訳ないのですが、急な出張が入ってしまったので、今夜の同窓会は欠席させて頂きます。
ex_1_en: I’m terribly sorry, but an urgent business trip has come up, so I’ll be absent from the reunion party tonight.
meaning_story: When a seat is lacking the person it's supposed to have in it, there is an absence. Where is Johnny? Another absence? Ugh. Johnny. C'mon.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the けつ is shortened to けっ as つs often are when in a situation like this.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの製品に興味がありそうな人を知っていたら、是非私達に知らせてくださいね。
ex_1_en: Please notify us if you know someone who may be interested in Tofugu products.
meaning_story: Absolutely an injustice! We must absolutely punish the perpetrator, by all means.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: カレーソースでいっぱいのプールで泳ごうなんて、彼も無茶なことをした物だ。
ex_1_en: It was absurd of him to try to swim in a pool filled with curry sauce.
meaning_story: The tea supply is down to nothing??? That's absurd! For Americans, I imagine this word would be "無コーヒー" instead. Get it?? If you're a caffeine addict this word will make total sense.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: バレンタインの友チョコを買いに行ったんだけど、結局自分用チョコしか買わなかったわ。
ex_1_en: I went to buy some valentine chocolates for my friends, but in the end I only got some for myself.
meaning_story: If you tie the bureau up with your delays this may not get done this year after all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note the けつ gets changed to けっ as つs in this situation often do.

ex_1_jp: フグが日本の愛知県に引っ越した後、サーモンが切ない思いをしていることを、誰一人知らなかった。
ex_1_en: After Fugu moved to Japan’s Aichi Prefecture, no one knew of Salmon’s hopeless longing for him.
meaning_story: The Love Know Prefecture! I want to live here, because people must know love! Of course, we don't call it that in English. You'll have to know the reading of the kanji to know the reading of this prefecture, which is Aichi Prefecture (jump to the reading to figure this out).
reading_story: The reading here is all the on'yomi jukugo madness you can handle. If you learned the kanji, you should be able to read this. If you can read it, you can translate it to "English" even though only half of it is English.

ex_1_jp: フグは、無名のまま死にたくないと思っている。
ex_1_en: Fugu feels that he doesn’t want to die in anonymity.
meaning_story: Someone with "nothing" for their name is trying to remain anonymous.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の家は有名な建築家によって設計されたんですよ。
ex_1_en: My house was designed by a famous architect.
meaning_story: You know that 建築 is architecture. So, someone of house architecture is someone who does architecture. They are an architect.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know how to read 建築 already.

ex_1_jp: 核兵器の所在地の移動に関するEメールが、とあるTofuguユーザーから送られてきた。
ex_1_en: We received an email from a Tofugu user about the movement of the location of the nuclear weapons.
meaning_story: The containers that soldiers use aren't just bowls and stuff, they're the things that hold their arms and weapons. Think spear and sword containers, full of weapons!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 相変わらず面白いことをしてるね。
ex_1_en: It’s interesting, as usual.
meaning_story: A mutual change you make with other people will go so smoothly that it will seem like everything is working as usual. It will be like everything is the same as it was before because the change was mutual.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 老朽化した原子力発電所は、多くの国々にとって悩みの種です。
ex_1_en: Aging nuclear power plants are a problem for many countries.
meaning_story: The original child of everything is the atom. It is the child from which everything else is created, for it was the original child. Atoms are the building blocks of all things!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 別の便に乗せていただけますか？どうしても、主要国首脳会議に出席しなくてはならないんです。
ex_1_en: Could you put me on another flight? I really have to attend the annual G8 leaders summit.
meaning_story: The people who exit their seats at the end of the show are the number of people who showed up, not counting empty seats. This is the true attendance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note the しゅつ gets changed to しゅっ, as many つs do in this situation.

ex_1_jp: As soon as Fugu shows any attention to other girls, Salmon loses consciousness.
meaning_story: The discerning you do with your ideas shows your awareness. It shows you're consciously thinking, because you not only know that you have ideas, but you think about them and discern them.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: こんなに不味い味噌汁を飲んだことはありません。
ex_1_en: I’ve never eaten such disgusting miso soup.
meaning_story: You've seen 美味しい by this point. This is the opposite of that. Instead of 美 you have 不 (not), so something that does not have flavor is something that doesn't taste good. i.e. something bad tasting. This can also refer to someone who's unskillful at something as well.
reading_story: The reading doesn't follow any of the rules you've run into. It's まずい. Think about how you're going through this really long maze (まず) and how you're promised a really tasty wonderful treat at the end for getting through it (you're a lab rat or something). When you get to the end, there's your treat! What joy! You eat it and... oh man... it is so bad tasting you can't even believe it. Be sure to imagine the terrible taste and the terrible disappointment after going through that difficult maze only to get this... this... terribly unappetizing cheese.

ex_1_en: もしタイムマシーンがあったなら、紀元前三千年紀に行ってみたいな。
ex_2_jp: If there was a time machine, I would want to go to 3000 B.C.
meaning_story: Remember how 紀元後 is "After death" or "AD"? Well, this is the opposite because it has a before (前) in it. It's BC or Before Christ.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know how to read 紀元後 already, because then you'll just have to remember the 前.

ex_1_jp: 両側に女の子をはべらせたビエトの写真がパパラッチに売りつけられた。
ex_1_en: A picture of Viet, with girls on both sides of him, was sold to the paparazzi.
meaning_story: Both sides is both sides. Which side? Both sides.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 靴の底にガムがついてるよ。
ex_1_en: There’s gum stuck to the bottom of your shoe.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This vocab uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. Well played!

ex_1_jp: 新しい部署、優しい人がいっぱいで、心底ホッとしたよ。
ex_1_en: There are a lot of nice people in my new department and I feel a tremendous relief.
meaning_story: The heart bottom is the bottom of one's heart. Do you want to learn kanji? Do you want to learn it from 心底? Okay, fine, you can move onto the reading then.
reading_story: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this too!
pitch_accent: シꜜンソコ *** シンソコ *** シꜜンテイ *** シンテイ

ex_1_jp: 「ねぇ、さっきコウイチにサプライズ朝ごはんパーティーの事を教えたでしょ？」「えっ！サプライズだったなんて知らなかった！」
ex_1_en: "Did you just tell Koichi about his surprise breakfast party?" "Oh! I didn’t know it was a surprise."
meaning_story: You know how 晩ご飯 is "dinner"? Well, that word is so 12 hours ago. This is morning and in the morning your meal is breakfast.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. It's also like the vocab: 朝 is like the vocab version, あさ and ご飯 is like the word you learned, ごはん.

pronunciation: いぎりすじん, イギリスじん
ex_1_jp: 知らないイギリス人から友達申請が来たよ。
ex_1_en: A friend request came from some English person I don’t know.
meaning_story: You've probably seen 英国 for "England" already. This is just another version I wanted to make sure you knew about. Not kanji, sure, but it's a little more common than 英国 so I wanted to make sure you got it here. To stay with the spirit of "learning kanji" though, we've added 人 to the end. I bet you can guess the meaning of this already. English + Person = English Person or British Person.
reading_story: The first part's reading is just in katakana. The second part is the じん from 人.

ex_1_jp: 「あなたとその建物を一緒に見に行きたいと思うのですが、いつがご都合よろしいですか？」「ええっと、あなたのご都合に合わせますよ。」
ex_1_en: "I’d like to go see the building with you so when would be convenient for you?" "Well, I’ll adjust my schedule accordingly."
meaning_story: A thing you build is a building. There aren't too many other things you build, at least not to this extent.
reading_story: The reading is a bit weird. It's kun'yomi readings across the board, meaning your knowledge of 建てる hopefully can come into play here. A building is something you build, so how do you say "to build"? It's 建てる (たてる). Since it's a thing you build, it's a たてもの. This reading is a bit confusing, but hopefully after a while you'll get it if you get it wrong too many times! Maybe if you think about the building you're in and call it a 建物 a few times it'll sink in better?
pitch_accent: タテꜜモノ *** タテモꜜノ

ex_1_jp: お昼ごはん、食堂で食べない？もしよければ、私二限目のクラスが無いから、席取っておけるよ。
ex_1_en: Do you want to eat lunch in the cafeteria? If so, I don’t have any class in second period, so I could find some seats for us.
meaning_story: An eating hall is a big room in which you eat. What big rooms do you eat in? How about a cafeteria or dining hall?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 心配ないよ。ビエトがすでに不具合の原因を突き止めて、現在修復作業中だよ。
ex_1_en: Don’t worry. Viet has already uncovered the cause of the bugs and is fixing it right now.
meaning_story: The original cause is how you got into this mess. Forget all the things it caused, the first cause is the origin and source of what's going on right now. You can pinpoint one thing that caused all of this!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 常識は脇に置いて、少しだけ既存の考えに囚われずに考えてみませんか？
ex_1_en: How about putting aside your common sense and thinking outside the box for a moment?
meaning_story: Normal discerning is the discerning you do on a daily basis, without thinking. It is all the things that you do that are common sense.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この漫画はまだ完結していません。
ex_1_en: This manga hasn’t been completed yet.
meaning_story: The perfect way to tie up a research paper is with a conclusion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 禁煙して三ヶ月になるけど、まだ時々煙草を吸いたいという衝動に駆られるね。興味深いことに、煙草が吸いたくなる時、自分ではそれをあまり自覚してないんだ。自分の人差し指を噛みしめているのに気づいて、ようやく自覚するんだよ。
ex_1_en: I’ve stopped smoking for three months now, but I still get the urge to smoke a cigarette every once in a while. Interestingly, when I really want to smoke, I’m not really aware of it. I only just realize it when I find myself chewing on my index finger.
meaning_story: You can memorize with your self and your self is memorizing things. It's remembering them for later use, which means you have reached a state of consciousness that animals cannot achieve. They just think about things, they don't memorize like you yourself does.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチだけがビエトが泣き虫だということを知っている。
ex_1_en: Only Koichi knows Viet is a crybaby.
meaning_story: You've seen that 泣く is to cry, so you can probably guess that 泣き is just "cry." You've also seen how 虫 is rarely a nice thing to call someone. So what's a mean thing you can call someone who cries? How about a crybaby?
reading_story: The readings come from 泣く and 虫. So long as you're okay with those two words you should be able to read this one too.
pitch_accent: ナキムꜜシ *** ナキムシꜜ

ex_1_jp: 赤ん坊の泣き声を聞くのは耐え難いことだというのは分かるのですが、だからって赤ちゃんを電車に乗せない方がいいってことにはならないと思うのですが？
ex_1_en: I understand that hearing a crying baby can be unbearable, but that doesn’t mean that people shouldn’t bring their babies on the train, right?
meaning_story: A cry voice is a sound of crying or a sob. Don't cry! Kanji will get easier someday!
reading_story: The reading comes from the vocab words 泣く and 声. So long as you know those two words okay, you should be able to read this word too!
pitch_accent: ナキコ°ꜜエ *** ナキコ°エ

pronunciation: おととい, いっさくじつ
ex_1_jp: 一昨日、夫の不倫現場を見てしまったんです。
ex_1_en: The day before last I caught my husband cheating on me.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 昨日 means "yesterday?" Well one day previous to that day is the day before last.
reading_story: This reading is an exception. Let's use this mnemonic to remember it: The day before last you bought an "O" toe toy (おととい). It's a kid's toy in the shape of the letter O that you put on your toe. You know it was the day before last because you wore it all yesterday, and now today your toe is sore. If only you could go back to the day before yesterday to tell yourself not to buy that O toe toy! Or at least not to wear it for the whole next day!
pitch_accent: イッサクꜜジツ *** オトトꜜイ *** オトトイ

ex_1_jp: 晩ご飯の後の散らかった台所を見て、コウイチは気が狂いそうだった。
ex_1_en: Koichi went mad when he saw how messy the kitchen was after supper.
meaning_story: The night meal is the meal you eat at night. That is dinner.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は外交官で、どうしても今日日本に飛ばなければいけないんだ。空席を待ちさせてもらえますか？
ex_1_en: I’m a diplomat and I really need to fly to Japan today, so could you put me on the waiting list?
meaning_story: Someone from the outside who comes in to mix with the government is a diplomat. Really, that's what diplomats do, right? They come from the outside (country). They mix with the government, and they do what they're there to do!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチから腹ペコの社員への差し入れのベーコンは、まさに干天の慈雨だった。
ex_1_en: The supply of bacon Koichi got for the starving workers was like a welcome rain after a drought.
meaning_story: Remember how 天気 is weather (and how 天 often refers to sky things?). Well, when those sky things are dry, you have dry weather.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: カンテン *** カンテꜜン

ex_1_jp: 飛行場の東側なので、ダンダス通りを真っ直ぐ東側に三十分ぐらい行くと着きますよ。
ex_1_en: It’s on the east side of the airport, so just go east on Dundas for about thirty minutes.
meaning_story: The East side is the East side.
reading_story: Remember how 東口 read as ひがしぐち? This word is like that too, with 東 being read as ひがし. 側 is read like you learned it with the kanji.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: いつでも家に非常食を備えて置くことは良いことです。
ex_1_en: It’s always good to keep some emergency rations at home.
meaning_story: A normal injustice! It's a terrible thing that happened, and despite it being normal it's still an emergency.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 毎日泣いてばかりいるのは虚しい。
ex_1_en: It’s futile to do nothing but cry everyday.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of void? It's empty or vacant. Just think of what happens has to happen to make a void in the first place.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If everything in life seems empty and futile, even cows will be affected. Listen to them say, "Moo, nah (むな), never mind. What's the point?" Nothing makes life seem empty like a cow saying "Moo, nah."
pitch_accent: ムナシꜜイ *** ムナシイ

ex_1_jp: 新しい言語を学ぶ際、まず始めに日常で一般的に使われる実用的な言葉から覚える方が効率的だ。
ex_1_en: When you learn a new language, it’s more efficient to begin with everyday, practical words at first.
meaning_story: Normal days are what you have in your regular everyday life. This is your normal life.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 聖書には、業について何て書いてあるんだっけ？悪因悪果とかだっけか？
ex_1_en: What does the Bible say about karma? Was it like ’evil begets evil’ or something?
meaning_story: Things that cause evil are the fruits of evil. This is a nice little saying. In English, you might say it as evil breeds evil. Remember that.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The last 悪果 gets the 悪 shortened a little bit.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ごめん。さっぱり分からないよ。もう一度説明してもらえないかな？
ex_1_en: I’m sorry, I don’t understand at all. Can you explain that one more time?
meaning_story: When you make your theory bright (and clear and easy to understand) you must have come up with an explanation for it. Before it was dark and murky in everyone's mind. But, when you give your explanation, it gets bright and easy to understand! Yay!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 正直言って、君が作ったこの映画は失敗作だね。でも、一度失敗したからといって、くよくよしてちゃ駄目だよ。誰かも、「成功とは、失敗から失敗へと熱意を失うことなく進んでいける能力である」って言ってただろ？
ex_1_en: To be honest, this movie you made is a flop. However, you can’t let it get you down just because you failed once. Someone said that success is the ability to go from one failure to another with no loss of enthusiasm, right?
meaning_story: A fault and a failure, all in one. This must have been one big failure and mistake you've made.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 失 gets shortened, though. Don't make that 失敗.

ex_1_jp: 私の兄は、自分が河豚の王だという馬鹿げた幻想を持ち続けている。
ex_1_en: My older brother maintains the ridiculous fantasy that he is the king of the blowfish.
meaning_story: An illusion that changes your concept of the world is a big fantasy (it's also an illusion). This makes sense, though, right? An illusion is an illusion, sure. But, when it changes your concept of the world, it becomes a total fantasy!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: クリスマス、一人ぼっちで過ごしたくないんだけど、もう予定立てちゃった？もしまだなら、ポール・マッカートニーのチケットが二枚あるんだけど、無料で一枚プレゼントするよ。
ex_1_en: I don’t want to be alone for Christmas, have you made plans already? If not, I have two Paul McCartney concert tickets and I could give you one for free.
meaning_story: When the fee is nothing it is free and without charge!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ムリョー *** ムꜜリョー

ex_1_jp: 「果物屋さんが閉まるまでに、仕事終わりそう？」「大丈夫。もし終わらなかったら明日に回すよ。」
ex_1_en: "Do you think you’ll finish your work before the fruit shop closes?" "Don’t worry. If I can’t finish, I’ll just leave it for tomorrow."
meaning_story: A fruit thing is just fruit.
reading_story: The reading for this is an exception, at least for the 果 portion. To remember this part, imagine yourself asking for some fruit. Could I (くだ) have some fruit, please?

ex_1_jp: コウイチの栄光の瞬間は、二十二歳でブロガーのチャンピオンになった時にやって来た。
ex_1_en: At 22, Koichi’s moment of glory came when he became a blogger champion.
meaning_story: Not only do you have prosperity, but you have a ton of light shining behind you. Imagine yourself standing on a cliff, all prosperous and stuff. The light makes you look crazy awesome. This is pure glory! This is Sparta!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 金曜日に親友が一万ドルの公的資金を濫用したとして官金私消罪で逮捕されたのだが、私には彼女がそんなことをしたとは思えない。
ex_1_en: My best friend was arrested on Friday for the embezzlement of over $10,000 of government funds, but I doubt she actually did it.
meaning_story: Government gold (aka money) is what makes up government funds.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: フグは幻覚作用のあるキノコを食べたせいで、幻覚に襲われていたに違いない。
ex_1_en: Fugu must have been hallucinating from the hallucinogenic mushrooms he ate.
meaning_story: You have memorized an illusion. You see it there, as if it's real, as if it's in your memory and brain. But it's not real. It's a hallucination.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 失恋しちゃって、超切ないよ。ストレス解消に買い物に行きたい。今週末バーゲンに行ってお昼も一緒に食べようよ。
ex_1_en: I’m heart broken and it really hurts. I want to go shopping to get rid of my stress. Why don’t we go to the sale this weekend and have lunch together?
meaning_story: The fault of romance isn't the romance itself, it's when everything falls apart. It's when you experience heartbreak. Have you ever felt the fault of romance? If so, remember back to that time, and think about how terrible of a fault it is.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの本社で勤務する機会を頂いたことを、とても光栄に思います。皆さんのお役に立てるよう精一杯頑張りますので、どうぞよろしくお願いいたします。
ex_1_en: I’m deeply honored to have this opportunity to work at the Tofugu headquarters. I’ll do my best to be of use to you all.
meaning_story: When someone shines light on your prosperity, they have noticed your great deeds. They want to bestow upon you an honor for all the great things you've done by shining a light on them. Don't confuse this with 栄光, though. With that one, you have prosperity and then the light shines through you, making you look glorious. With this, light is shining on your glory, and you receive honor from it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 爆笑！お前鼻歌下手すぎだっつーの。
ex_1_en: LMAO! You are just too awful at humming.
meaning_story: Try singing a nose song. How does it sound? Like humming perhaps?
reading_story: The readings are both kun'yomi vocab readings, probably because a 鼻 is a body part, and body parts do that to jukugo words. You know 鼻's reading from the kanji (はな) and you know 歌's reading from the vocabulary word 歌 (うた). Combine them together and you have a very nice humming tune and reading, はなうた.

ex_1_jp: 面白いとは思うのですが、もしそれを題材に記事を書きたいのであれば、その仮説を裏付ける資料を見つけてくださいね。
ex_1_en: I think that’s interesting, but if you want to write an article about that topic you need to find data to prove your hypothesis.
meaning_story: A temporary theory isn't one that's set in stone yet. In fact, it's not really a theory at all, it's more of a hypothesis.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 無知をさらけ出したからって恥ずかしがることなんか無いよ。あいつらこそ、自分たちの無知を隠していることを恥じるべきさ。
ex_1_en: You shouldn’t be ashamed of yourself after admitting your ignorance. They should be ashamed of themselves for hiding their own ignorance.
meaning_story: When you know nothing (Jon Snow), you know nothing. This is ignorance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 恍惚状態の中でサーモンの幻を何度も見た後に、フグはようやく彼女が12年前に死んだことを思い出し、自分が幻を見ていたことに気づいた。
ex_1_en: After a series of ecstasy filled visions of Salmon, Fugu finally remembered she had been dead for 12 years, and he realized he was seeing an illusion.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add phantom to the meanings as well, because phantoms are kind of like illusions.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look up to see a crazy illusion. You can't believe it's real. Master Roshi, from Dragonball, is standing in front of you (you thought he was a cartoon!). Then, he splits into a million versions of himself, creating a mob of Roshis (まぼろし). This mob goes on to train many people to fight.

ex_1_jp: もし解説と共に図説があれば、より分かりやすくなるかと思うんですが、如何でしょうか？
ex_1_en: I think it would be easier to understand if there is an illustration with an explanation, but what do you think?
meaning_story: A diagram theory is an illustration that is used as an explanatory diagram. Just imagine a chalk board with all sorts of drawings of things, showing how they work, at least in theory.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 自分の肘を舐めるのは無理です。
ex_1_en: It’s impossible to lick your own elbow.
meaning_story: If you can do nothing within reason, then what you're trying to do is unreasonable and probably downright impossible. If you still try, you're probably just overdoing it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

ex_1_jp: 僕達の赤ちゃんは、母親であるサーモンの感情や不安をすごく敏感に察知するんです。
ex_1_en: Our baby is very sensitive to the emotions and anxieties of his mom, Salmon.
meaning_story: Okay, so you guess but you also kind of know. You can make an inference as to what the answer is... You're not 100% sure, but you think you know, even though you're guessing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 察 gets shortened to さっ.

ex_1_jp: ゾンビを中に入れないために、内側から鍵を掛けて金属製のシャッターを下ろす必要があります。
ex_1_en: We need to lock the door and lower the metal shutters from the inside to shut the zombies out.
meaning_story: The inside side is the inside. A little redundant but makes a lot of sense.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. With 側 you've already learned it. With 内 you'll have to remember the kun'yomi reading of うち. Combine them together and you have うちがわ. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember that pesky うち portion. What is it that's drawn you inside? "Oo, cheese!" (うち) Cheese has drawn you inside. You're so excited that you exclaim, "Oo, cheese!"

ex_1_jp: コウイチは、どんなことにも干渉してくるタイプの上司ではありませんが、何故かビエトが何をしているのかについては口出しするのが好きなようです。
ex_1_en: Koichi is definitely not the type of boss to interfere, but he likes meddling in what Viet is doing for some reason.
meaning_story: When you're fording a stream, and you suddenly feel dry feelings around you, that doesn't make any sense for something wet. This dryness is an interference. It's an intervention trying to stop you from fording.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は長い間内因性精神疾患に悩まされています。
ex_1_en: For a long time the actual reason I’ve been suffering was a mental disorder.
meaning_story: The inside cause is an internal cause. Internal causes are usually the nastiest causes, if you ask me.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本語の知識を身に付けたいですか？恐がらなくてもいいですよ。簡単です。あなたの知識を別の言語で表現する方法を学べばいいだけなんですから。
ex_1_en: Do you want to acquire a good knowledge of Japanese? Don’t be afraid. It’s easy. You just need to learn how to express information in another language.
meaning_story: You're discerning about what you know. You choose what to keep and what not to keep in your brain. This is the sum of your knowledge.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 寝る時は、左側を下にして横になる方が好きです。
ex_1_en: When sleeping, I prefer to lie down on my left side.
meaning_story: The left side is the left side. Simple as that.
reading_story: The reading for this is vocab kun'yomi readings. Just take the vocab 左 and add it to 側 to have yourself ひだりがわ.

ex_1_jp: お前めちゃくちゃモテるな！マジで伝説的だよ。
ex_1_en: Girls love you, man. You are legendary, seriously!
meaning_story: Let me transmit to you a theory... a theory that perhaps a great legend is true.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You just have to remember that 伝 is read as でん in this case. Just imagine yourself sitting in your den (でん) as you get cozy and listen to this theory about a great legend.

ex_1_jp: スポーツを見るとき、全力を尽くした負け犬と自分を重ね合わせてみなよ。それって楽しい？達成感はある？何か意味はあるの？意味無いよね？敗者から勝者に生まれ変わらなきゃ。
ex_1_en: Whenever you watch sports, you identify yourself with the underdog that tried their best. Is that fun? Do you feel like you achieve something? What’s the point? No point, right? You have to change yourself from a loser to a winner.
meaning_story: The failure someone (person) is the loser or the defeated.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私はお金は愛より大切だと思います。よく「愛があれば山でも動かせる」なんて言いますが、実際はお金が無いとそんなことできないでしょ。
ex_1_en: I think that money is more important than love. It’s often said "love can move mountains," but in reality you can’t do that without money.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji. Now that is true kanji love.

ex_1_jp: フグのことが頭から離れないの。これって恋の始まりなのかな？
ex_1_en: I can’t get Fugu out of my head! Is there love in the air?
meaning_story: When you have romance you also have love and lust. Meow! Be careful though. This word doesn't share its meaning with its kanji. But, that's how romance is. It gets all crazy and turns to love and lust really fast.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your lusty love isn't towards a person, it's towards this giant Koi (こい) fish you met the other day. Imagine feeling lustful for a fish. Ew. Okay. Stop. You probably remember this word's reading now.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 恋愛での別れ際は、切なくて甘酸っぱい。
ex_1_en: Parting from someone you love is always painfully bittersweet.
meaning_story: When you have romance and love all in the same package. Well, that is love! Ah, love! This is the word used when talking about love, though. You don't use this to say "I love you."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 愛情たっぷりのビーフシチューです。
ex_1_en: It’s beef stew that’s full of love.
meaning_story: Those love feelings you're having mean you're in love!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お前は愛人にすらなれなかったんだよ。
ex_1_en: You couldn’t even be his lover!
meaning_story: The person you make love to is your lover. Woooh! Don't worry I won't tell. Have fun and be safe, kids.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: しまったぁ、またトーストを焦がしちゃったよ。最後の一枚だったのに。何か別のものを昼ご飯に探さなくちゃ。
ex_1_en: Oh no, I just burned the toast again. It was the last slice. Now I have to find something else for lunch.
meaning_story: The noon meal is the meal you eat at noon. What meal is that? It's delicious, delicious lunch.
reading_story: The readings come from the words 昼 and ご飯. If you know how to read those words you can read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: 癌や自閉症など、多くの病気の主因は未だに分かっていません。
ex_1_en: The main cause of many diseases, such as cancer or autism, are still unknown.
meaning_story: The master cause is the main cause and primary cause. Why? Because this cause is the master of all the other causes, so it leads them and is the main cause!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 咳がひどいんですが、妊娠中に薬用せき止めドロップを服用しても大丈夫でしょうか？
ex_1_en: I have a horrible cough, but is it okay for me to take medicated cough drops while I’m pregnant?
meaning_story: Something that's used for medicine is medicinal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は薬の中で座薬が一番好きです。
ex_1_en: My favorite kind of medicine is the suppository kind.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. If you're looking for medicine in Japan, look for this sign.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You need some medicine, stat! But, nobody wants to give you any medicine. You keep asking your pharmacist, Yuri, if he'll give you some medicine. He says no. You get pissed off, and you cuss yuri (くすり) out. He gives you the medicine after you cuss him out.

ex_1_jp: 今までに何か薬物によってアレルギー反応が引き起こされたことはありますか？
ex_1_en: Have you ever had any medicine induced allergic reactions?
meaning_story: Medicine things are medicines and drugs. Try not to take too many of these, now!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ヤクꜜブツ *** ヤクブツ

ex_1_jp: トフグ軍の改革のため、コウイチは兵員の数を削減をしなくてはならなかった。
ex_1_en: As a result of the Tofugu army reform, Koichi had to reduce the amount of military personnel they had.
meaning_story: A soldier member (or a member of the soldiers) is a person that is of the military personnel. It also shows the amount of military strength an army has. The more soldier members, the more military strength and military personnel it has!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その演劇で水兵を演じた素晴らしい俳優は、観客を大いに沸かせた。
ex_1_en: The brilliant actor who played a navy soldier in the play really wow’d the audience.
meaning_story: A water soldier is a soldier that is out to sea. That is a navy soldier.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 新婚旅行の際、フグはサーモンが値段の交渉が得意だということを知ってとても感心した。
ex_1_en: On their honeymoon, Fugu was very impressed to find out Salmon is very good at negotiating on prices.
meaning_story: When you ford into the thick of things and mix everything up, you're getting involved in a negotiation. That's what negotiations are though, right? You gotta get right in there, fording through the muck. Then, you gotta mix things up and compromise between both parties.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguのウェブサイトは、24時間年中無休で開いております。
ex_1_en: Tofugu’s website is open 24 hours a day, every day of the year.
meaning_story: If rest is nothing then there are no holidays. If there are no holidays, then that means a place is always open.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 鼻の病気のせいでストレスが溜まっているからって、私たちに八つ当たりしないでよ！
ex_1_en: Just because your nose sickness is making you stressed, doesn’t mean that you have to take it out on us.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji. Smells nice, right?

ex_1_jp: すみません。ちょっと一言、言わせてもらいたいんだけど、あなた、鼻血が出てますよ。
ex_1_en: Excuse me. I just need a quick word with you, your nose is bleeding.
meaning_story: A nose with blood is a nose with a nosebleed. It is a bloody nose.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You already know 鼻's reading from the kanji and vocab, and you should know the vocab reading of 血 as well. Put them together and you have はなち, though you want to change the ち to ぢ. Alternatively, it's possible (though less common, but it doesn't matter if you're turning it to kanji via an IME anyways) to write it as はなじ. I guess that blood added a little tenten (it represents the blood coming out of that nose!). Spurt spurt spurt.

ex_1_jp: この小説マジで大好きだわ。これはホンモノだよ。
ex_1_en: I seriously love this novel. This is legit.
meaning_story: A small theory is some idea you have that you put on paper. Perhaps it's an idea about life, that you write in the form of a novel?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本人は、人生の節目節目に、願い事だけでなく感謝の気持ちを伝えるために、神社を訪れます。
ex_1_en: Japanese people visit shrines on important occasions not only to make wishes but also to offer thanks.
meaning_story: You know that an お願い is a request, and that 事 is a "thing" or "action." So, this is a "request action," in a sense. A better way to say that is one's wish or a prayer, because that's what you're doing when you do the action of requesting something.
reading_story: The readings come from the words お願い and 事. If you know how to read those you should be able to read this word too.
pitch_accent: ネカ°イコ°ト *** ネカ°イコ°トꜜ

ex_1_jp: まだ空席はたくさんありますか？できれば前の方の席がいいのですが。
ex_1_en: Are there still many open seats left? If possible, I’d prefer to sit in the front.
meaning_story: A sky seat is a seat full of sky (aka nothing!). This is an empty seat or open seat.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 自分の親が常に正しいわけではないことを知るのに、時間がかかる子どももいます。
ex_1_en: It takes some kids a while to realize their parents aren’t always right.
meaning_story: Something that goes towards normal is something that happens ordinarily.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn. In order to learn it, think of this: Ordinarily, I tune (つね) my violin, but today I just said "screw it" and didn't tune it. So, now I sound like crap. Imagine this compared to how I ordinarily sound.

ex_1_jp: この漫画は、テレビアニメとドラマの原作です。
ex_1_en: This manga was made into a TV anime and drama series.
meaning_story: The original thing you make is the original work. It's always better to have the original, rather than a copy, I think.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: サーモンのフライを作ろうとしたんだけど、外側だけ焦げちゃって内側は血生臭いオレンジ色のままになっちゃった。油がちょっと熱すぎたのかも。
ex_1_en: I tried to deep fry some salmon, but the outside got burnt and the inside stayed bloody and orange. I guess the oil might have been too hot.
meaning_story: The outside side is the outside.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from the kanji. Since you learned the kun'yomi reading for 外 with the vocabulary, you should be just fine here.

ex_1_jp: あの国が、誤った教育を通じて子どもたちに愛国心を植え付けようとしているのは好ましくないと思います。
ex_1_en: I don’t like that the country is trying to instill patriotism in children through misguided education.
meaning_story: When you have love for your country deep within your heart, that is patriotism.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: アイコクꜜシン *** アイコꜜクシン

ex_1_jp: 警察署での出会いから一時間後、その警察官と泥棒はすっかり意気投合した。
ex_1_en: One hour after meeting at the police station, the police officer and the robber had completely hit it off.
meaning_story: They warn you and they guess when you've done something wrong (with evidence, of course!). They are the police.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 警察はそのストーカーに対して無力で何をすることもできず、結局彼女は殺されてしまった。
ex_1_en: The police were powerless to do anything about the stalker and in the end she was killed.
meaning_story: When your power is nothing you are powerless.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. You also can know that 力 uses its りょく reading because when you tried to pick up a tiny rock (りょく) you couldn't, because you were powerless.

ex_1_jp: 古い薬方の中には、危険であるということで現代医療からは除かれているものもある。
ex_1_en: Some of the old prescriptions were considered to be dangerous and have been removed from use in modern medicine.
meaning_story: When medicine is sent to your direction it's going to you. That's your prescription.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: よく「本音と建前」は日本独特の文化だと言われますが、実際は世界中に存在します。
ex_1_en: It’s often said that "the contrast between one’s personal feelings and public behavior" is a characteristic unique to Japanese culture, but that exists all over the world.
meaning_story: What you build up in front of other people is your public image. This is your public behavior, how you act around others you don't really know. This concept is surprisingly important in Japan, so you'll hear it often enough despite being such a strange concept in other places. You'll have to think of this like you're building buildings of personality in front of you. These show off who you are on the outside, but it protects what's on the inside.
reading_story: The reading is pretty strange. It's a lot like 建物 in that it's read as たて, which is like the word 建てる even though the て isn't showing here. So, you'll have to remember it's read like 建てる but the て gets pushed into the kanji.

ex_1_jp: その結果には全然満足していませんよ。彼女の役に立とうという計画は、いつも裏目裏目に出るんです。今回もまた然りでした。
ex_1_en: I’m not pleased with the results at all. My plans to help her always backfire for some reason and this time was no exception.
meaning_story: You tie up all the fruit because you're going to use them to make giant fruit letters. These giant fruit letters will show the result of the big monkey election.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the 結 gets shortened to けっ.

ex_1_jp: 心霊写真を撮っちゃったの。ほら。この写真の右側に、その場にはいなかった幼い女の子が写ってるのよ。分かる？
ex_1_en: We took a picture of a ghost. Look. There is a little girl who wasn’t there on the right in the picture. Can you see her?
meaning_story: The right side is the right side.
reading_story: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading. You should know the reading of the vocab word 右 by now. Also, the 側 reading happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji as well as with the word 側.

ex_1_jp: 「サーモンはゴールデンウィーク期間中何してたの？」「結婚指輪を川で無くしちゃって、ずっと探してたの。三日もかかったけど、ようやく川底に沈んでいる指輪を見つけたわ。」
ex_1_en: "What did you do during Golden Week, Salmon?" "I lost my wedding ring in a river, so I was looking for it. It took me three days, but I finally found it submerged in the riverbed."
meaning_story: The river bottom is the river bottom, also known as the riverbed.
reading_story: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. Just don't forget the rendaku for 底!

ex_1_jp: 本当に赤ん坊は私達の言葉が分からないと言い切れるんですか？もし私の双子ちゃんが、「お医者さんが今ママに、僕達がママの子宮から無事に出られるかどうかは、五分五分だって言ったみたいだね。」なんて話をしてたらどうするんですか？ああ、私の赤ちゃん、きっと先生の言葉に震え上がってるに違いないわ。
ex_1_en: Are you sure that the baby doesn’t understand our language? What if my twins are talking right now like, "The doctor told our mom that it’ll be a toss-up whether we could emerge safe and sound from her uterus." Aww... they must have been scared by your words, doctor.
meaning_story: The actions around here are nothing. Absolutely nothing is going on. If nothing is going on, that means it is safe and sound for you.
reading_story: One thing that's not safe and sound is the reading of the 無 in this word. Instead of む it's ぶ. Why? Because you thought it was safe and sound, but you were fooled. There are ghosts everywhere, all jumping out and screaming Boo! (ぶ) at you. Feel the surprise. You thought it was safe and sound!

ex_1_jp: けしからん！一体どうやってそんなに馬鹿なことが出来るんだ？砂糖と塩を入れ替えるなんて、いくら今日がエイプリルフールだからといっても、ちっともおもしろくないぞ。お前が馬鹿者だ！
ex_1_en: Oh my God! I can’t believe you could be so stupid! Replacing salt and sugar is not funny at all, even though it’s April Fool’s today. You are the fool!
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, no extra salt needed.

ex_1_jp: 塩水につけて天日干ししたフグってきっと美味しくなると思うんだけどなあ。
ex_1_en: I think puffer fish dipped in salt water and dried in the sun would be pretty tasty.
meaning_story: Water with salt in it is salt water. Best not to drink 塩水.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You know 塩's from the kanji and you know 水's from the vocab word 水. Combine them together and you have しおみず.

ex_1_jp: 「ねぇねぇ！コウイチに塩味のジェロを作ってあげたら、テキストフグのアカウントが無料でもらえるって聞いたんだけど。」「信じないほうがいいよ。それって嘘だと思うよ。」
ex_1_en: "Hey! I heard that if I make salty jello for Koichi, I’ll get a free TextFugu account." "It’s better if you don’t believe that. I think it’s a lie!"
meaning_story: The taste of salt is a salty taste (it's also when something tastes salty).
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, take the readings of 塩 (you learned the reading with the kanji) and 味 and you have yourself しおあじ.

ex_1_jp: 「すみませんが、席を詰めて私を座らせてもらえませんか？」「申し訳ないんですが、この席は空いてないんです。」
ex_1_en: "Excuse me. Could you move over and let me sit down, please?" "I’m sorry, this seat is taken."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the on you learned with the kanji. Have a seat and relax.

ex_1_jp: 時節柄、お風邪など召しませぬよう、くれぐれも御自愛くださいませ。
ex_1_en: I sincerely hope you’ll take good care of yourself and not to catch a cold or such things in these times.
meaning_story: If you love your self that is self love. Some would call too much self love selfishness as well.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, you self lover you.

ex_1_jp: もし本当に煙草を止めたいなら、肺を病む人特有の感覚を知ってみることだね。
ex_1_en: If you really want to quit smoking, you should see what it feels like to be someone with diseased lungs.
meaning_story: You know how we use feelings to memorize things here on WaniKani? I ask you to feel angry or sad or happy while imagining out the mnemonic stories. I also ask you to use your senses, because feelings are memorized best when you use the senses.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 性欲が無いのか性愛恐怖症なのか自分では判断できません。
ex_1_en: I’m not sure if I’m asexual or have erotophobia.
meaning_story: Gender love is that kind of love that has to do with gender parts. That's sexual love.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ソファの右側に植木を置こうかなと思ってるの。
ex_1_en: I think you should put the potted plant on the right side of the sofa.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
pitch_accent: カワꜜ *** ガワ *** ソꜜバ

ex_1_jp: 細則を読まずに契約書に署名しない方が良かったことは分かってたんですが、一見したところ大家さんがいい人そうだったので、つい。
ex_1_en: I knew I shouldn’t have signed the contract before reading the fine print, but the landlord seemed like such a nice person.
meaning_story: When you write your name for a government office, they require you to write out your signature. Printing won't do for official government office business.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 毎晩無言電話がかかってくるんです。
ex_1_en: Every night I get a silent prank phone call.
meaning_story: When you have nothing to say you sit in silence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 言 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Nothing cuts through silence like a gong (ごん). Once it's done gonging you really notice how silent the world around you is.

ex_1_jp: フグが僕のことを自分勝手だって責めるんだ。目くそ鼻くそを笑うだよね。
ex_1_en: Fugu accused me of being selfish. Talk about the pot calling the kettle black. **The last phrase literally means "an eye crust laughs at a booger" - a similar idiom.
