meaning_story: Maybe you didn't know this, but if you're like everyone else learning a new language, you learn the cuss words first. くそ is sh*t / garbage, though it's not really a "bad" word in Japanese like it is in English. So, what is your nose sh*t? It's your snot and boogers. Ewwww, stop eating them!
reading_story: The reading is just like what you learned with the kanji. はなくそ.

ex_1_jp: ここで、アメリカ兵たちがよく屯しています。
ex_1_en: American soldiers frequently gather here.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: その兵士はコウイチの車に火を付けた。
ex_1_en: The soldier set Koichi’s car on fire.
meaning_story: A soldier samurai is still just another soldier.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチが、薬学者の募集を検討しているって、本当ですか？
ex_1_en: Is that true that Koichi is thinking of hiring a pharmacologist?
meaning_story: People who study about medicine are studying the study of pharmacy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ヤクカ°ク *** ヤクꜜカ°ク

ex_1_jp: 私のダイエット計画は、基本的に友達全員にカップケーキを作ることです。つまり、みんなを太らせれば太らせるほど、私が細く見えるってわけ。
ex_1_en: My dietary plan is basically to make all of my friends cupcakes. The fatter they get, the skinnier I look.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of thin? It's also thin, though it can be slender as well.
reading_story: You learned two readings for this kanji, and this word uses one of them, namely the ほそ one. You can remember this because a hose (ほそ) is thin and slender, so this is ほそ.

ex_1_jp: フグはサーモンの鼻先が赤くなってるのを見て、とても可愛いと感じた。
ex_1_en: When Fugu saw that tip of Salmon’s nose is so red, he found it very cute.
meaning_story: You know the previous part of your nose? The part of your nose I just chopped off? Well, you were lucky, as that was only the tip of the nose. Time to cut off the rest, next!
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. With 鼻 you learned that with the kanji. With 先 you learned that with the vocab. So, you should have all the pieces to be able to read this. Remember, body parts tend to change words into kun'yomi readings for some reason, no exception here.

ex_1_jp: 化粧でこんなに変わるものかね。
ex_1_en: I can’t believe how much makeup can change a face.
meaning_story: You've seen how 変える means "to change" something. This word means that something changed by itself, it means to be changed or to be altered.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: オリンピックの予選第一回戦で敗れた日本代表のアイスホッケーチームに、怒ってカレーを投げつけた男の話し聞いた？
ex_1_en: Did you hear that a guy got upset with Japan’s national hockey team when they were defeated in the first round of a preliminary game for the Olympics and threw some curry at them?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means failure, but "to failure" doesn't make sense. What happens when you experience failure, though? Well you get defeated, and you're also unsuccessful. So, this verb is to be defeated and to be unsuccessful.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have been defeated. You lay there on the ground, and the fans around the stadium are disgusted with your performance. Some hipster walks up to you and says: "Yah, Boo" (やぶ) referring to how poorly you did. "No boo!" you reply back. "Yah boo" they say again.

ex_1_jp: 少年は、喜び勇んで旅に出発した。
ex_1_en: The boy left for his trip in high spirits.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means courage so the verb version is what happens when you have lots of it. Someone with courage is probably the kind of person to be lively and to be encouraged.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who is the one person who always seems to be encouraged and excited? Isabel (いさ)! She's so positive and always cheers everyone, including herself, up.

ex_1_jp: サーモンと僕は、浜辺の北端に建つ家を買おうと相談してるんですが、ちょっと私達には値段が高いんですよね。
ex_1_en: Salmon and I are discussing buying a pre-built home at the north end of the beach, but it’s a little expensive for us.
meaning_story: You know that 建てる is "to build." This is similar to that, but it's the version where you're not doing the building. Something is just getting built. That's why this word is to be erected and to be built. You can recognize that because of the つ, which tells you that two (つ) guys are building the building while you watch. So you're not doing it, they are, and it's just happening.
reading_story: The reading is shared with 建てる, so if you know 建てる then you should be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: 洗濯物を外に干したかったんだけど、物干し竿が壊れちゃって。
ex_1_en: I wanted to put our laundry outside to dry, but our clothesline just broke.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dry so the verb vocab version is to dry.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Why do you need to dry something off? Because someone used a hose (ほす) and got everything all wet. Ugh, you shouldn't leave that hose out anymore...

ex_1_jp: いつ果てるともなく続く会議に、社員は全員ウンザリしていた。
ex_1_en: The meeting continued without any sign of ending and the employees were getting fed up.
meaning_story: If you tear (てる) up a fruit it's life is going to end. Fruit can't go on when they've been beaten up so much.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The fruit's life is about to end and you laugh, "Hahahaha (は)!" And then you start tearing at it more! What's wrong with you? Weirdo...

ex_1_jp: 中国には、覚せい剤の生産で栄えていた村がありました。
ex_1_en: There was a village in China flourishing on their production of stimulants.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means flourish or prosperity, so the verb vocab versions of these would be to flourish or to prosper.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you flourish at? You're an amazing soccer (さか) player who flourishes and prospers no matter where you go to play this wonderful (but not as good as baseball) sport.
pitch_accent: サカエꜜル *** サカꜜエル *** ハエꜜル

ex_1_jp: いくつかの記事を読んで、私はTofuguチームには何か暗黙の構想があることを察しました。
ex_1_en: From reading a few articles, I sense that the Tofugu team has some kind of implicit plan.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means guess so the verb vocab version is to guess. Alternatively, you can learn this as to sense or to presume.
reading_story: The reading for this is actually the same as what you learned with the kanji, but the さつ is shortened to さっ. If you had to guess be sure to guess with the shorter つ.
pitch_accent: サッスル *** サッスꜜル

ex_1_jp: 愛する人を傷つけてしまった。
ex_1_en: I hurt the person I love.
meaning_story: You know that 愛 means love. So, when you add する to it you make it a verb. Now it means to love.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 給料日が来たら、一粒一万円もする高級梅干を買ってあげるよ。
ex_1_en: As soon as payday comes, I’ll buy the high grade, pickled Japanese plums that costs 10,000 yen a piece.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. It's also the same as the meaning of the kanji / vocab, though you can think of this as Japanese plum as well if you want.

ex_1_jp: よっしゃ〜花金だ〜。今夜の自家製梅酒が待ち遠しい。
ex_1_en: Thank God it’s Friday! I’m looking forward to drinking homemade plum wine tonight.
meaning_story: Alcohol that comes from ume is ume wine. It can also be called plum wine or plum liquor. If you're of age give it a taste, it's quite nice!
reading_story: The reading is just the readings of the kanji that you learned. How about a toast to easy to read words!

ex_1_jp: すごい。今日は本当にいいお天気だね！今日なら何百人もの米兵を倒せそうな気がする。
ex_1_en: Wow, what beautiful weather! I feel like I could kill hundreds of American soldiers today.
meaning_story: Remember how 米国 is "America." Well, more of that again. With 米 representing "America" you can combine that with 兵 (soldier) to have yourself a US soldier / American soldier.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguソフトボールチームに入る際の第一規則は、虚栄心をベンチに置いておくことです。
ex_1_en: The first rule of Tofugu’s softball team is that you have to leave your vanity on the bench.
meaning_story: When prosperity goes into your heart and just enters a void it will rarely mean anything to you. A person who has this trait is going to have extreme vanity because he/she just needs to suck more and more prosperity into their bottomless pit of a heart. It's like a black hole. They need more and more and more so then they have to become vain.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の両親はいつも、全力を尽くしさえすれば、勝敗は問題ではないと言っていたけれど、私はそれが好きじゃありませんでした。もちろん、私は勝敗をとても気にします。だって、ベストを尽くした後に負けるなんて、意味が無いじゃないですか。
ex_1_en: My parents always told me that it doesn’t matter if I win or lose, as long as I try my best, but I didn’t like it. Of course, I care very much about winning and losing. If I lose after doing my best, then there’s no point.
meaning_story: You have win and you have failure. When you are talking about both in one word, you have victory or defeat.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私の息子は生まれつき虚弱体質で、運動はできません。
ex_1_en: My son was born with a weak constitution so he can’t exercise.
meaning_story: You have yourself a void of weakness. This means you are weak and feeble.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今年の二月三日に巻き寿司を食べるなら、西側を向いて食べなくてはいけませんよ。
ex_1_en: If you eat maki-sushi on Feb 3rd of this year, you have to face the west bank.
meaning_story: The West side of something is known as the West side. Sorry, I have no story to go along with your West side.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You should know both of them, with 西 being にし and 側 being がわ (what you learned with the kanji).

ex_1_jp: この話は、一旦無しにしてもらえますか。
ex_1_en: Could you cancel this deal for now?
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji nothing, so when you have nothing, you are without.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you are without you don't have anything to eat either, so you end up gnashing (なし) your teeth together instead.

ex_1_jp: 殺人予告を告げる手紙が、Tofuguオフィスに届けられた。
ex_1_en: A letter giving advance notice of a murder has arrived at the Tofugu office.
meaning_story: If you announce something beforehand you will have advance notice. Advance notice is always nice to give.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ビエトはコウイチに、アヤがTofuguの広告にものすごく変わった絵を描いたことも告げた。
ex_1_en: Viet also told Koichi that Aya created the strangest picture ever for Tofugu’s advertisement.
meaning_story: When you announce something to a wide audience, you're just throwing your message out there for everyone to hear. This is just a big wide advertisement.
reading_story: Sorry, you learned the kun'yomi reading with 広. So, think of it this way when you need to remember this word's meaning: You're advertising something. It's a big advertisement to advertise how terrible a person こういち is. Come up with some terrible things he's done so that you can imagine this crazy Koichi advertisement you made and ran on national TV.

ex_1_jp: 映画を見て泣くなんて、お前らしくないじゃないか。いつもどの映画のどんな深刻なシーンにも大笑いしてるのに。
ex_1_en: It’s not like you to cry at movies. You always laugh really hard when there are any serious scenes in movies.
meaning_story: You know that 笑う is "to laugh." This is the noun version, because the う in 笑う turns to い (so don't confuse this as an adjective). What is the noun version of "to laugh"? It's a laugh.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 笑う, so just make sure you know that so you can know this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「一生懸命何しているの？」「弓道だよ。」
ex_1_en: "What are you working on?" "Japanese Archery."
meaning_story: The path of the bow. This is archery.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: サーモンさんと我が社で取り交わした契約によると、残念なことに彼女が競合他社のCMに出演することについて我々は何の取決めも行っておりませんでした。
ex_1_en: According to the contract between our company and Ms. Salmon, it is unfortunate, but we did not make an agreement regarding her appearance in our competitor’s commercials.
meaning_story: You've taken a decision from someone. By doing this, you've created a kind of arrangement with them. Imagine yourself pulling this decision out of the person. They don't want to necessarily give it to you, but they're letting you pull it out of them, kind of. When you've pulled it out, you've come to an arrangement, though they've pulled some of your decision out too.
reading_story: The readings for this word are strange. It's all verb vocab readings, but instead of 取 being just と, it's read とり like with 取る, but all inside the one kanji. The 決め is like 決める, though, so hopefully that doesn't give you any trouble. That being said, you'll also see it get spelled like 取り決め, but it makes more sense to learn it the hard way so the easy way is just common sense.

ex_1_jp: 私はバスの運転手をしておりますが、息子から、「バスが黒煙をまき散らしていることを知りながら、それでもバスの運転手を続けたいなら、排気管からの黒煙を少し吸ってみるといい」と言われました。
ex_1_en: I was looking forward to being a bus driver but my son told me that if I know that buses spread black smoke, and I still want to be a bus driver, then I should try inhaling some of that black smoke that comes out of my exhaust pipe.
meaning_story: Black smoke is black smoke. It's also something you should avoid if you can.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: クロケꜜムリ *** コクエン

ex_1_jp: 日本語には、別の言語から借用された言葉がたくさんあります。
ex_1_en: In Japanese, there are a lot of words that have been borrowed from other languages.
meaning_story: The task of borrowing something is when you're borrowing something. It's also when you get a loan.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ああ、ローソンは確かに二十四時間営業だけど、でもさぁ、あの、多分弓と矢は置いてないと思うよ？
ex_1_en: Yeah, Lawson is open 24/7, but, you know, I don’t think they carry bows and arrows.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You have your bow and you use it to shoot things, sure, but you've also covered it in candy so you can eat it when you're waiting out in the woods waiting for a buck to come by. You lick your candy bow and say: "yummy!" (ゆみ). Imagine the taste of your bow. What taste would make you say yummy?

ex_1_jp: この国で、人々が脳を食べることを知っているか？珍味だよ。
ex_1_en: Did you know that people eat brains in this country? It’s a delicacy.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Don't have to use your brain for that.

ex_1_jp: 昨年イギリスで、脳死と判定された人のうち2~3人の人が息を吹き返し、さらに昏睡状態の間の会話を一部覚えていたという。
ex_1_en: I heard a few people who were considered brain dead came back to life in the UK last year and they remembered parts of conversations from when they were unconscious.
meaning_story: If your brain is dead you have brain death.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「ドタマかち割って脳みそストローでチューチュー吸うたろか！」とお化けは怒って言った。
ex_1_en: "Do you want me to crack your skull open and suck your brains out with a straw?" the ghost said angrily.
meaning_story: Do you know みそ Soup and how miso goes in it? This is that miso. It's soft and strange feeling. Now, your brain miso, that's your brains or your gray matter. Essentially, if someone cuts your head open with a katana, this is perhaps what would come out.
reading_story: Reading is just what you learned with the kanji. Just use your 脳 a bit and it should be easy.

ex_1_jp: 多くの日本のネット住民は、日本のテレビ番組に韓国コンテンツが急増していることを洗脳行為のようなものだとなぞらえる。
ex_1_en: Many Japanese netizens liken the surge of Korean content on Japanese TV to an act of brainwashing.
meaning_story: Give your brain a nice wash. No! Wait! It's not as nice as it sounds. This is brainwashing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その魔女は仏僧の心をも燃え上がらせた。
ex_1_en: The witch set even the Buddhist priest’s heart on fire.
meaning_story: A Buddha priest is a Buddhist Priest.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 便秘の時には、心の平静を失いやすくなる。
ex_1_en: I easily lose my calm when I’m constipated.
meaning_story: A place that is peace and quiet is a very calm and serene place. Ahh, so nice!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ２ヶ月間旅行したければ、留守番を雇う必要があります。
ex_1_en: If you want to travel for two months, you need to hire a house-sitter.
meaning_story: You know how 留守 means "absence" or "away from home"? Well, now that you're absent from your home, it's someone else's turn to come to your home and take care of it. This person is the caretaker, someone who's looking after one's house.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 留守 will be important as well.

ex_1_jp: 誰がマネー・ロンダリングするのに洗車ビジネスなんて買うっていうのさ？
ex_1_en: Who would buy a car wash business for money laundering?
meaning_story: A wash that washes cars is a car wash.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Don't confuse this with the same-sounding 戦車 though... unless you're washing your 戦車 in a 洗車...

ex_1_jp: 身分証明書をご提示頂けますか？
ex_1_en: Could I check your ID?
meaning_story: You hopefully know that 証明 means "proof." So, when the proof is written down, what kind of proof is it? It's a certificate of some kind. I'm going to need to see some 証明書 if you want to get in here, sir.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 証明's reading will also be helpful.
pitch_accent: ショーメイショ *** ショーメイショꜜ

ex_1_jp: たくさんのお守りを同時に付けない方がいいですよ。逆に不幸をもたらすかもしれないですからね。
ex_1_en: You shouldn’t wear multiple lucky charms at the same time. It could bring you bad luck instead.
meaning_story: You know how 守る is "to protect," right? this is like that, but it's the noun version. It's not really "a protection," though it kind of is. What things can you wear to protect you from things like bad luck, demons, and ancient aliens? That would be a charm or an amulet. You'll see these kinds of things sold at temples and such.
reading_story: The reading is like that of 守る, so if you know the reading of that word you should be able to read this one as well.
pitch_accent: オマモリ *** オモリ *** オモꜜリ

ex_1_jp: Tofuguのテーマソングの歌詞は胸にぐっときます。
ex_1_en: The lyrics of the Tofugu theme song caused a swell of emotion in my chest.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. At least I won't have to bring up the image of you mooning people with your breasts or whatnot. Oh dang, I just went and did it.

ex_1_jp: テロリストは人質の扱い方の違いで大きく2つに分類されます。「フレンドリーな奴」と「フレンドリーじゃない奴」です。
ex_1_en: Terrorists generally fall under two categories according to how they treat hostages: the friendly kind and the unfriendly kind.
meaning_story: You take a type of something and break it off into a part. This part is the classification of that item.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 夢の中で、私はお笑い芸人で、テレビでお客さんの前でオナラをしなくちゃいけなかったんだけど、うまくできなかったの。それで、その番組の司会を務めてた先輩芸人にすごく怒られたのよね。
ex_1_en: In my dream, I was a comedian and I had to fart on purpose in front of the TV audience, but I couldn’t do it. Then I was scolded by the experienced comedians who hosted the show.
meaning_story: You know that 笑う is "to laugh." This is a noun version of that, though it's not "a laugh," (that's 笑い). The お is going to be your hint. You use that one for things you want to elevate. One thing you often elevate is a person. A person who makes you laugh or does laughs is a comedian.
reading_story: The reading is the same 笑う or 笑い. It's also the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 日本語で、文句という言葉が、英語の僧侶という単語と発音が似ているということは面白いですね。
ex_1_en: It’s funny that the Japanese word for complaint is pronounced like the English word monk.
meaning_story: A paragraph in writing is what you send someone when you want to submit a complaint. You want to make sure these are in writing, though, otherwise you don't have proof of your complaint. Also, don't make it longer than a paragraph, because that's too long and nobody cares about how you think the shop staff mistreated your dog Fluffy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 会計事務所でのアシスタントの仕事を得た後に、彼女は実は数学があまり得意ではないことを告白した。
ex_1_en: After getting an assistant position in a finance office, she confessed that she is actually bad at math.
meaning_story: You can often associate "good" or "pure" things with the color white. So when you announce something that's white (and pure) it's a confession. You're getting out the evil and making yourself white and pure with your announcement.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 無理は承知なんですが、どうにかご主人を取材させてもらうことはできないでしょうか？もし何とかして頂ければ、本当に本当に感謝します。
ex_1_en: I know it’s difficult, but isn’t there anyway that I could collect some data on your husband? If you could help me set up the interview, I would really really appreciate it.
meaning_story: You take lumber and you pile it up. This is all because you are covering an event on the dangerous chemicals and bugs that are inside the lumber that goes into your house! You're collecting data so that you can have a good, solid story to cover.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. The on'yomi for 取 is しゅ, so let's use a mnemonic to help us remember. You are covering an event for the news. It's about all the really dumb shoes being sold these days, like toe shoes, or shoes with lights, etc. Just think about how you're upset you have to go cover this event on shoes when your peers are out there covering real news stories.

ex_1_jp: フグ: サ…サーモンって、わぁっ、な、なんて可愛い名前なんだ。 サーモン: そう思う？ 私はずっと自分の名前があんまり好きじゃないんだよね。
ex_1_en: Fugu: S-Salmon... Wow what a, what a cute name. Salmon: You think so? I’ve always kinda hated it.
meaning_story: It's possible to love this thing. It's so gosh darn cute! Any really cute thing is possible to love.
reading_story: The reading for this word is screwed up, though if we're lucky, you already know the word for cute. It seems to have injected itself into American and English culture a decent amount, anyways. If you are one of the lucky ones, you'll know that this word is read as かわいい. If you're not, think of the cute thing being a cow. Then you say, "that cowはいい" (かわい), or "that cow is good" because it's so cute.

ex_1_jp: 失敬、失敬、通らせて。借金取りに追われているんだ。
ex_1_en: Excuse me, excuse me. I’m trying to get through here. I’m running away from a debt collector.
meaning_story: The money (and gold) you borrow is your debt. Be sure to pay it back before the yakuza come for you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The しゃく gets shortened to しゃっ though, so beware. Just think of that like the little bit that you lost to the yakuza, because they weren't happy you didn't pay back your debt. *cut*

ex_1_jp: 食べたの辞書形は食べるです。
ex_1_en: The dictionary form of tabeta is taberu.
meaning_story: This is a combination of the word 辞書 "dictionary" and the suffix 〜形 or "form." Put them together and you get dictionary form!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 預貯金などの可分債権は、原則として遺産分割の対象にはなりません。
ex_1_en: As a general rule, divisible claims, like savings accounts, do not become the target of divisions of inherited property.
meaning_story: When it's possible to separate something, it's divisible. Just imagine separating things into parts. It's possible. So, if that's possible, it's divisible. Now think of something that's nothing (i.e. "no candy bars"). That is not possible to separate into parts. That is not divisible.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「いつTofuguの機密書類が欲しい？」「早ければ早いに越したことはないな。」
ex_1_en: "When do you want Tofugu’s secret documents?" "The sooner, the better."
meaning_story: If you put writing into a category, you'd have to write it down after you've chosen what category it is in. Where would you write that down? Into a document, probably.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この「外では上品だけど、ベッドでは情熱的な女性がいい」って歌詞、まさに俺の理想だよ。
ex_1_en: This lyric is my ideal: I want a lady in the street, but a freak in the bed.
meaning_story: Remember how 下品 is "crude" and "vulgar" - this is obviously the opposite. This is elegant.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: オタクだけではなく他の人にとっても、ネット上で大文字を使うことは大声を出すことに等しいですよ。
ex_1_en: Even for people who aren’t geeks, using uppercase letters on the internet is equivalent to shouting.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of equal? It's equal (and also similar or equivalent). That "similar" one is a bit weird, because "similar" is not equal, though I'd lean more towards equal.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What should be equal above all things? I think each person (ひと) should be equal!

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あなたとは対等に話をすることができません。
ex_1_en: I can’t talk to you like an equal.
meaning_story: It doesn't matter what you say versus equal rights. If you really want things to be equal, you have to support equality.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 等号の右側の数式が正か不かについて、注意する必要があります。
ex_1_en: You have to pay attention to whether the formula to the right of the equal sign is true or false.
meaning_story: How do you represent an equal number? With an equal sign.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今日は取り分け寒いという訳ではない。
ex_1_en: It’s not especially cold today.
meaning_story: When you take something and separate it into parts, you want to be especially careful not to give anyone an unequal share. This is especially important because we're dealing with money, and people will flip out and shoot you under the table if you aren't especially accurate.
reading_story: The readings come from the words 取る and 分ける. So long as you know those words you should be able to read this one as well.

ex_1_jp: 「ところで、試験はどうだった？」「パパ、その話はやめてよ。」
ex_1_en: "By the way, how was the exam?" "Stop talking about that, dad."
meaning_story: If you attempt a test, you're taking an examination. There are a lot of these in Japan, so make sure you know this word if you want to fit in with all the whining and whinging that students do, especially come the final year of high school.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あの留学生、いつも私と彼氏の写真に変顔とか変なポーズで写り込んでくるんだけど。ちょっとうざいんだよね。
ex_1_en: That exchange student is always photobombing pictures of my boyfriend and me. It’s kind of annoying.
meaning_story: Remember 留学, which means "study abroad"? Do you also remember 学生, which is "student"? This word is like those two words mashed together (they share a 学), making it a "study abroad student." What's a better way to say that? How about exchange student!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: リューカ°ꜜクセイ *** リューカ°クꜜセイ

ex_1_jp: これは、コウイチ自身が日本へ留学した時の体験を元にした作品です。
ex_1_en: This is a story based on Koichi’s own experiences from when he studied abroad in Japan.
meaning_story: Your body goes through tests and each time it does, it gains a little more experience. What has your body experienced? What tests has your body been through?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私達の新製品「フグ風味の豆腐」の実験台になりたい人はいますか？
ex_1_en: Who wants to be the person we experiment on for our new Fugu Flavored Tofu project?
meaning_story: A test that tries to find truth is an experiment. This is because you don't know the truth, so the only way to find it is to try things out and test them. Thus, experiment!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 実 is shortened to じっ, so be careful with that. It usually is, though.

ex_1_jp: このベーコンのキーホルダーは、私がベーコンのコスプレ大会で一等賞を取った時にもらったんです。
ex_1_en: I won this bacon keychain when I took first prize in the bacon costume competition.
meaning_story: When you're equal to one you are the very top. You are first class and first rank. In fact, you are the best.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. いち gets shortened to いっ though, so watch out for that if you want to remain the best, yeah?
pitch_accent: イットー *** イットꜜー

ex_1_jp: いいですね。五枚のステッカーをオマケに付けておきますね。
ex_1_en: Sounds like a plan. I’ll give you five extra stickers as a bonus too.
meaning_story: You know that 枚 is a flat objects counter. So, now we're counting! You have five flat objects.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguのステッカーを何枚か買いたいのですが、一枚いくらになりますか？
ex_1_en: I’d like to buy some Tofugu stickers, but how much would one be?
meaning_story: This is a counter that can be used with various "flat" things, which is why it is referring to a flat object. Other things it can refer to include clothing items, sheets, paper, stamps, dishes, and more. Notice how they're all kind of flat shaped?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 宇宙服を脱ぎっぱなしにするんじゃない！禁止事項の一つだろうが！
ex_1_en: Don’t take off your spacesuit! It’s one of the things that’s prohibited.
meaning_story: Stop! That's prohibition (prohibited)! When something is prohibited and you're forced to stop, that thing is obviously forbidden. If you see this you should probably not do the thing it's telling you not to do.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 天気予報によると、カナダは今年はずっと雪が降る見通しです。
ex_1_en: According to the weather forecast, this year Canada is expecting snow all year round.
meaning_story: A news report that covers things beforehand (before they happen) is a forecast. For example, a weather forecast is a 天気予報.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「フグのコスチュームですが、いつ頃仕上がりますかねえ？」「金曜日の午後までにはできていると思います。」
ex_1_en: "When will my Fugu costume be ready?" "It’ll be ready by Friday afternoon."
meaning_story: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The gold day of the week is the greatest day. It's the day that makes you feel like gold because it's the end of the weekdays and the beginning of the weekend! This day is Friday.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

ex_1_jp: 「側にいてくれてありがとう。」「何言ってるのよ！友達じゃないの！」
ex_1_en: "Thank you for taking my side." "What are you talking about? We’re friends, aren’t we?"
meaning_story: A friend that you attain is your friend. This is the most common way to say "friend," so learn it if you want to make any!
reading_story: The readings for both of these are readings you haven't learned yet, though maybe you already know this word since it's fairly common. Think of it this way. You have your friend Tom (とも) Cruise. You like him, and he likes you. You're close enough friends that you can touch (だち) each other too. Like, on the shoulder or on the hand or whatever, without it being awkward. So, you like to Tom touch (ともだち) when you can, because he has nice skin.

ex_1_jp: 「あの野球の試合は本当にひどかったね。」「本当にそうだね。」
ex_1_en: "That baseball game was really terrible." "Tell me about it."
meaning_story: An attempt to join together isn't just any get together. Imagine two people boxing. They attempt to knock each other out when they join together. That's why this word is game or match. Did you watch the 試合 today? No! Don't tell me what happened, I recorded it on the VHS.
reading_story: This word uses the on'yomi し for 試 and the kun'yomi あい for 合. You learned these when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this one already!

ex_1_jp: もし賢い愛人を見つけたいのなら、東京の銀座に行くのがいいかもね。
ex_1_en: If you want to find a clever mistress, maybe you should go to Ginza, Tokyo.
meaning_story: The silver seat isn't some crazy kingdom where the king sits upon a silver seat. It is a famous place in Tokyo. Perhaps if you read the reading it will become more apparent what the meaning is (since they're the same). This silver seat place is Ginza.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: スプレーでの落書きアートは既に少し時代遅れです。新しい芸術家達は、壁の汚れをゴシゴシ擦って洗い落としながらアートを創りだします。
ex_1_en: Spray-painting graffiti is already a bit old-fashioned. The newer artists create art works by scrubbing the dirt off the wall.
meaning_story: When writing just happens to "fall" on the wall (whoops, wasn't me who did that, how strannnnge) it's writing that's not supposed to be where it is. This kind of writing is graffiti.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 書, however, is kun'yomi in this case and also has rendaku. So just remember that it's read as が for this vocab and you'll be fine.

ex_1_jp: 税関と手荷物受取所を通るのに、絶対に30分以上かかると思うよ。
ex_1_en: I think it would definitely take more than thirty minutes to go through customs and baggage claim.
meaning_story: Remember 荷物 and how it means "baggage" or "luggage." Add a hand to it and you have hand baggage or hand luggage.
reading_story: If you know 荷物 and you know 手, then you should be able to Voltron the two together into one mega reading.

ex_1_jp: 幸い命に別状はありませんでした。
ex_1_en: Fortunately, it was not life-threatening.
meaning_story: Happiness is happiness!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: If your life is filled with nothing but happiness, every time someone says something to you, all you can do is say, "Sigh, what (さいわ)?" You sigh and say what. Because you're too happy to really listen. You're just sighing all day and not paying attention.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あなたの国の高等教育について教えて下さい。
ex_1_en: country
meaning_story: When you are higher than equal, you are above the very top, you are above everyone. You are high class.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ステッカーは何枚欲しいんですか？大量買されるなら割引できますよ。
ex_1_en: How many stickers do you want? For a large amount, we could give you a discount.
meaning_story: You have flat objects but what amount of flat objects? This word is asking that question: "how many flat objects are there?" If this doesn't make sense, think back to words like 何回 or 何千 or 何年 which ask "how many ____" just like this one.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 美味しいベーコンは、サクサク仕事を進めるのに不可欠です。
ex_1_en: Tasty bacon is essential for promoting efficient work.
meaning_story: It's not possible to lack. It is indispensable and essential, so don't lack it!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私は連立不等式が得意です。
ex_1_en: I’m pretty good at simultaneous inequalities.
meaning_story: When something is not equal it suffers from inequality.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: えーっと、Etoetoプロジェクトの件で情報を交換したいんですが、後ほどお伺いしてもよろしいですか。
ex_1_en: Well, I’d like to stop by later to exchange information on the Etoeto project, if it’s okay with you.
meaning_story: The feeling of news is that it should give you information and data, not fluff.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 喜びを表す、面白い顔文字を探しています。
ex_1_en: I’m looking for an interesting kaomoji to express my joy.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji rejoice, so it means joy and delight. You rejoice because there are lots of reasons for your glee.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 喜ぶ so you should be able to read this one too!
pitch_accent: ヨロコビ *** ヨロコビꜜ *** ヨロコꜜビ

ex_1_jp: 彼、私に向かって、「お前のこと嫌いやねん」とか「帰れや」とか言ったのよ。ひどいでしょ？でもさ、実は関西弁で言われたもんだから、ちょっと格好いいなんて思っちゃったんだよね。何か、すごいセクシーだったの。
ex_1_en: He said things to me like, “I hate you” and like “go home” and it sounds awful, doesn’t it? But I actually thought it was pretty cool because he said it using the Kansai dialect. It was really hot.
meaning_story: Do you remember 関西, which is the Kansai region of Japan? Well, they have their own dialect, and it is Kansai Dialect.
reading_story: The reading is the vocab 関西's reading and the kanji reading of 弁, combined.

ex_1_jp: ビエトは、どんな不測の事態にも対応できるように、あらゆる種類のプログラムをダウンロードします。
ex_1_en: Viet downloads all kinds of programs to prepare against any unexpected situations.
meaning_story: The kind and type is the kind or type. Basically, if you know the meaning of either of these kanji you'll know the meaning of this word as well, since they all share nicely.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: いつも訓読みと音読みを間違えてしまう。
ex_1_en: I mix up kun’yomi and on’yomi all the time.
meaning_story: The instruction reading may not make a lot of sense, but you've heard this word before. Jump to the reading and you'll know what the meaning of this word is.
reading_story: The reading is the word 読み (like 読む) and the reading you learned for 訓 combined, making くんよみ. Sounds familiar? It's that kun'yomi reading you've heard so much about.

ex_1_jp: 前職から学んだ最大の教訓を教えてください。
ex_1_en: Tell me about the biggest lesson you learned from your previous company.
meaning_story: At least way back in the day, things that teach instructions to people are things that teach a lesson or moral. Back in the day, lots of learning was done through storytelling, and storytelling taught lessons and morals, thus, this word.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 子供の頃に歌ってもらった子守歌なんです。
ex_1_en: This lullaby was sung for me when I was little.
meaning_story: A song you sing to protect your child while they sleep is called a lullaby.
reading_story: The readings for this word are all kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 守 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you finish singing a lullaby to your child they always ask for more (もり). It doesn't matter how many you sing, they always want at least one more before they will fall asleep.

ex_1_jp: アヤは、ベーコンは人類が後世に残すべき最も重要な遺産の一つだと主張した。
ex_1_en: Aya insisted that bacon is one of the most important things for humankind to hand down to future generations.
meaning_story: If you categorize people into types, you have different races of people. Or, you can categorize people as one type of "people" in this universe. If you did this, you'd call us mankind.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お父さんは、ピザ配達の分野で、世界レベルの達人であると評判になっています。
ex_1_en: My dad is famous for being a world-level master in the realm of pizza delivery.
meaning_story: A person who has "attained" is someone who knows much. He/She is a master or expert, obviously.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 月曜日、熱々のロマンスとか、ゾッとするホラーみたいな感じの楽しい映画をあなたと一緒に観たいなって思うんだけど、どうかな？
ex_1_en: On Monday, I would like to watch some fun movies with you, like a steamy romance or blood-curdling horror film. How does that sound?
meaning_story: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The "moon" day of the week is monday. Why? Because "Moon" is pretty much just "Mon," right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

ex_1_jp: 報道によると、本日早朝に起きた玉突き事故で、20匹の魚が地域の病院へ運ばれたそうだよ。
ex_1_en: According to the news report, twenty fish were transported to a local hospital after a pileup that occurred early this morning.
meaning_story: The way of news is to do lots of news reports.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 母親に禁煙するように言ったんですが、逆に母親から、禁煙したらおそらく気が狂って、父親と離婚することになると言われました。
ex_1_en: I told my mom to quit smoking and she told me that if she did, she would probably go crazy and my parents would get divorced.
meaning_story: If smoke is prohibited you probably shouldn't smoke. Aka no smoking, okay?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ステッカーの枚数については、何枚くらい注文できるかはまだはっきり分かりませんが、少なくとも百枚にはなると思います。
ex_1_en: I’m not exactly sure how many stickers I’m going to order yet, but I think it will be at least one hundred.
meaning_story: You have flat objects. You have a number of them. These flat objects are flat things, right? Flat things like sheets of paper, perhaps (or other sheets of things). So, this word is number of sheets.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「心配しないで。君が大阪弁を喋るってことは誰にも言わないよ。秘密は守るよ。」「おおきに！」
ex_1_en: "Don’t worry. I won’t tell anyone that you speak with the Osaka dialect. Your secret is safe with me." "Thanks."
meaning_story: Remember 大阪 (Osaka)? This is the dialect they speak, making this word Osaka dialect.
reading_story: If you know how to read 大阪 you can just add 弁 to it and be able to read the whole thing, though maybe not in Osaka dialect. Okay, fine, it's probably the same thing in Osaka dialect.

ex_1_jp: 平仮名の綺麗な書き方を勉強することには、心底飽き飽きしてるんだよね！
ex_1_en: I am bored out of my mind with studying how to write Hiragana neatly.
meaning_story: This is the way of writing (kind of like how 見方 is the way of seeing). A better way to say this though would be to call it penmanship, though. How's your 書き方? Mine is terrible.
reading_story: If you know how to read 書く and 方 separately, you should be able to read this one too.
pitch_accent: カキカꜜタ *** カキカタꜜ

ex_1_jp: もしコウイチと一緒に写真を撮りたいなら、ビエトの許可が必要です。
ex_1_en: If you want to take a picture with Koichi, you need permission from Viet.
meaning_story: I've permit that it is possible. So, go ahead, do it. I give you permission.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あなた達はまだ未成年でしょう。
ex_1_en: Aren’t you still minors?
meaning_story: You'll see this attached to other words to make them plural. That's why it's called a pluralizing suffix.
reading_story: This is almost the same reading you learned with the kanji. Remember たつ? Well this is read たち. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: If you want to pluralize something, touch (たち) it to something else. One egg touches another egg, well now they're eggs. Plural eggs! One friend? No. Touch them! Touch them right on the face. Now there are two friends. Plural friends! Thanks to the good ol' pluralizing suffix touch! Oh, and don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.

ex_1_jp: 私は年間一億ドルを稼ぐことは実現可能だと思います。
ex_1_en: I’d say earning a hundred million dollars a year is possible.
meaning_story: The ability is there, so it is possible... wait, there's enough ability to make this possible? Let's do it!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチが実はとある秘密の国の王子様で、のっぴきならない理由のためポートランドオレゴンで身分を隠してTofuguの社長として生きているという奇妙な葉書を受け取った。
ex_1_en: I received a weird postcard saying that Koichi is actually the prince of a secret country, but he is living incognito as the Tofugu president in Portland, Oregon for some unavoidable reason.
meaning_story: A writing that you put on a leaf is like something else. Instead of a leaf, think about writing you put on a leafish sized item. A postcard perhaps?
reading_story: The reading is kind of weird, sorry. The reading for 葉 is the は you know and love. Then, 書 is かき despite not having a き on the end like you'd expect. So, it's weird. It's shortened like a postcard is a shortened letter, I suppose? Technically it is the 書き reading, but keep in mind that 書き gets rendaku'd.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの益々の発展と繁栄を祈念して、乾杯！
ex_1_en: Let’s pray for more and more growth and prosperity for Tofugu, cheers!
meaning_story: Your thoughts are prayers. These pray thoughts are prayers.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「サーモンの手術が上手くいきますように！」と、フグは神様に祈願した。
ex_1_en: "May Salmon’s surgery go well," Fugu prayed to God.
meaning_story: You pray and request. This is your prayer.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: こないだ言ってた私大の学園祭の件なんだけど、今回は私の事数にいれないで。ごめん。でも悪く思わないでね。時間ができたら連絡するから。
ex_1_en: As for the school festival of the private college you told me about the other day, could you count me out this time? I’m sorry, but don’t get mad at me. I’ll contact you when I have free time.
meaning_story: You know how 私 can mean private and how 大 is the first half of 大学? Well, combine those together and you have the shortened version of private college or private university.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本には、電子公告規則という法律がありますが、あなたの国はどうですか？
ex_1_en: There is a law in Japan called the Electronic Public Notice Rules, do you have something like that in your country?
meaning_story: A public announcement is a public notice.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチとビエトが乗り込むと、そのタクシーは静かに動き出した。
ex_1_en: Koichi and Viet got in and the taxi quietly started to move.
meaning_story: This is the な adjective form of quiet, which is kind of just like the noun, anyways. What is the adjective version of quiet? It's also quiet.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to be quiet. She's (しず) being nice and quiet, unlike you!

ex_1_jp: 僕のお父さんは人種差別主義者のくせに、僕には人種で人を判断してはいけないって言うんだ。
ex_1_en: My father is a racist and yet he tells me that it’s wrong to judge people by their race.
meaning_story: A kind or type of person is when you categorize a person into different types. How do we do that? Well, you categorize by race of people (or more simply by race).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: サーモンがあんな風に洗練された日本語を話すなんて知らなかった。
ex_1_en: I didn’t know that Salmon spoke refined Japanese like that.
meaning_story: You take your practice and you wash it. Slowly chunks fall off and it becomes more and more simple. You are washing away the gunk on the outside to attain refinement and polish yourself, via practice.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼は全親類と縁を切った孤独な男だ。
ex_1_en: He’s a really isolated guy who cut off all contact with his relatives.
meaning_story: These people are kind of like a type of parents. Not quite parents, but kind of, in a pinch anyways. These are your relatives.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: しゃくや, しゃっか
ex_1_jp: 家を買う代わりに借家を借りる提案をサーモンに切り出そうとしてるんだけど、彼女、その話題には触れないようにしてるみたいなんだよね。
ex_1_en: I’m trying to talk to Salmon about renting a house instead of buying one, but she kind of keeps skirting the issue.
meaning_story: When you borrow a house you are renting a house. Also, this is a house for rent.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't seen this reading for 家 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're renting a house, someone has to give you the keys and let you in and stuff. You're only renting, after all. So when they let you in they'll say, "Here's a shack for yah! (しゃくや) Enjoy!" By the way, in the secondary reading, the しゃく goes to しゃっ. You'll see しゃくや more often, though.

ex_1_jp: 彼が逃げ出さないように、めちゃくちゃ面白い妊娠の報告方法を考えているの。
ex_1_en: I’m thinking about the funniest way to inform my boyfriend that I’m pregnant so that he won’t run away from me.
meaning_story: A news report that is to announce the news is a just a report. Just imagine someone announcing the news outside. They are giving you a report on the information going on with the news.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私のせいにしないで。あなたの焼き鳥なんか食べてないわよ！
ex_1_en: Don’t blame me! I didn’t eat your skewered roast chicken.
meaning_story: A baked bird isn't just any bird, it's roast chicken. You may also know it by its romanized Japanese name: yakitori.
reading_story: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings. With 焼き, you can use the reading you learned with the kanji. With 鳥 just remember back to the vocab word, とり. Combine and eat.

ex_1_jp: 私が特にイライラするのは、焼き肉をクチャクチャ音を立てて食べる人です。
ex_1_en: I find it really irritating when people chew grilled meat too loudly.
meaning_story: Mmmmm, yum! Take some meat and cook it. Then you have roast meat or cooked meat. If you go to Japan look out for 焼肉 places (same meaning/reading). They are good, if you're into meat at least.
reading_story: 焼き uses the reading you learned with the kanji. 肉 does too. Combine them together onto one skewer and enjoy.

ex_1_jp: アヤって、いつも最初に鉛筆で下書きしてるのかな。それとも、下書き無しで絵を描いてるのかな。
ex_1_en: I wonder if Aya usually makes a rough copy with a pencil first or if she just draws freehand.
meaning_story: Something below your writing isn't what you want to necessarily publish to the world. It's below your writing, after all. This is merely a rough draft.
reading_story: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading, as you can maybe guess from the hiragana sticking out. If you know the readings of the words 下 and 書く separately, you should be able to combine them into one reading.

ex_1_jp: いつでも大丈夫だよ。こっちは君の都合に合わせるから、お好きな時にどうぞ。
ex_1_en: Anytime is okay. I’ll go with whatever time is convenient for you, so it’s whenever you’d like.
meaning_story: The big height of your husband makes everything safe and all right. Nothing you need to worry about when you have your super giant husband around to protect you. This is a really useful word, and it is used all the time. If someone asks: "Are you alright?" you could say in response "大丈夫" to mean you're doing all right.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
pitch_accent: ダイジョꜜーフ *** ダイジョꜜーブ

ex_1_jp: スーパーで試食販売をしている人は、日本の食品業界では「マネキンさん」と呼ばれる。
ex_1_en: The person who offers food samples in grocery stores is called ’Ms. Mannequin’ in the Japanese food industry.
meaning_story: Go ahead and try an eat. How was that little try? That little sample? That little taste?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: クソ上司に土曜日も働かなきゃいけないと言われた上に、風邪をひいてしまい、さらには彼女にも振られたよ。俺の人生はクソだ。
ex_1_en: My stupid boss just told me that I have to work Saturday. Plus, I just caught a cold. On top of that, my girlfriend dumped me. My life sucks.
meaning_story: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The earth day of the week is a day you find yourself close to the earth. Either you found you drank too much on Friday, so on this day's morning you're laying right on the ground of earth. Or, maybe you just want to sleep in after staying up late on Friday. Either way, this day you lay close to the earth is saturday.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

ex_1_jp: 車内で、サーモンが座席から身を乗り出してフグにキスをした瞬間、信号が青に変わった。
ex_1_en: The moment Salmon leaned across the seat to kiss Fugu in the car, the traffic light turned green.
meaning_story: A sit seat is probably going to be a seat.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 法要の間長時間正座をしていたので、足がすごく痺れています。
ex_1_en: I knelt for so long during the Buddhist memorial service that my legs were completely numb.
meaning_story: The correct way to sit is this way: traditional Japanese sitting (this is when you sit on your legs on your feet, kneeling). You can also call it seiza. Learning the reading will help with the meaning.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ビエトは、コウイチのパソコンの向こうから立ち上っている煙を見て驚きました。何故なら、オフィスは禁煙だったからです。
ex_1_en: Viet was surprised to see smoke rising from the other side of Koichi’s computer because smoking is banned in the office.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're standing around a smoke machine. It's billowing up smoke. Strangely, your buddy Bill Murray is here too. For some reason, he loves the smoke, and he puts his head in it, breathing it in deeply until he goes into a coughing fit. You decide it's time to stop him. "Kay, Murray (けむり), it's time to stop that," you say.

ex_1_jp: やばーい！ちょっと面白すぎっしょ〜！何で鼻で喫煙できるなんて思っちゃったわけ？爆笑してるんですけど。。。
ex_1_en: Oh my gosh! That was just way too funny! Why did you think you could smoke with your nose? I am laughing so hard right now.
meaning_story: If you consume smoke you are smoking.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 汽船での世界一周旅行の費用なんて、どうやって捻出するんだよ？
ex_1_en: How can we finance our trip around the world by steamboat?
meaning_story: A steam ship is a steam ship or steam boat. So fancy back in their day!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「すみません。汽車は何分おきに来ますか？」「大体20分おきくらいです。」
ex_1_en: "Excuse me, how often do the steam trains come？" "About every twenty minutes."
meaning_story: A steam car is a car that runs on steam. No regular car runs on steam, but what thing that has things called "cars" does run on steam? How about a steam train? You can also think about 電車s, which are electric cars (but means "train"). This is similar to that, but now it's run with steam, making it a steam train.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 弓道では、矢を放つ前に、弓を引ききった状態で一瞬静止する必要がありますが、西洋のアーチェリーも同じですか？
ex_1_en: In Japanese archery you need to stand still for a moment with the bowstring fully drawn back before releasing the arrow, but is that the same as Western archery?
meaning_story: Everything is quiet and stopped. The world is still and everything is at rest.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ハワイでは強い日焼け止めが必需品で、人達を日焼けから守るのにシートで覆ったりもします。
ex_1_en: In Hawaii, a strong sunscreen is essential and covers are also used to protect people from getting sunburned.
meaning_story: When the sun cooks something, and that something is you, it is giving you sunburn.
reading_story: The readings here are the vocab kun'yomi readings. You have ひ for 日 and や for 焼け (which you learned with the vocab). Combine it with some sunscreen and hopefully you'll prevent the sunburn.

ex_1_jp: 毎週日曜日は、彼女のサーモンとテニスをするとかアイスを食べるというようなことをする。
ex_1_en: On Sundays, I do things like play tennis and eat ice cream with my girlfriend Salmon.
meaning_story: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The Sun day of the week is Sunday. Doesn't get much easier than that for you. Lucky!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

ex_1_jp: 昨日、海岸から見た夕焼けはとても眩しくて天国のようだったわ。そのせいで左目を失明しちゃったけどね。
ex_1_en: Last night the sunset on the beach was so radiant that it was like heaven, but because of that I went blind in my left eye.
meaning_story: When the evening is burning with sun, it is the sun going down, getting all close to the horizon and earth. This is the sunset.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. Combine 夕 and 焼け (you learned the reading via the kanji) and you'll have ゆうやけ.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguソフトボールチームに入る際の第二規則は、お腹がすきすぎちゃうので、昼食前には「ベーコン」という言葉は禁句だということを肝に銘じることです。
ex_1_en: The second rule of Tofugu’s softball team is that you have to keep in mind that "bacon" is a taboo word before lunch time because it makes us too hungry.
meaning_story: A paragraph that is under prohibition is under prohibition because it contains a taboo word or taboo phrase. Do not say this word, please!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は受験票を持って行くのを忘れてしまいましたが、母が届けてくれました。
ex_1_en: I forgot to take the exam admission slip, but my mom dropped it off for me.
meaning_story: When you accept a test you are going in to take an exam. Good luck! A++++!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. When we learned the reading for 受 before, we learned the kun'yomi. Let's use a mnemonic to remember the on'yomi reading for this vocab. When you take an exam you need complete silence, but the person behind you has a small juice (じゅ) box that she keeps sipping. It's so loud. You can't concentrate on the test in front of you because it's all you can hear.

ex_1_jp: 「去年、ブラジルの喫茶店で偶然コウイチに会ったよ。」 「本当？ そう言えば、長いことあいつの顔見てないなぁ。」
ex_1_en: "Last year I ran into Koichi in a cafe in Brazil." "Oh, really? Now that you mention it, I haven’t seen him for years."
meaning_story: A tea shop where you consume (tea) is a tea house. Welcome! Sit down. Relax. Have some tea.
reading_story: The readings are what you'd expect except for きつ getting shortened to きっ and 茶, which has this strange さ reading. To remember that it's さ instead of ちゃ, think of this tea house you're going in. You think it's nice and pleasant, and it is for a while... until someone starts working a saw (さ) outside, ruining the atmosphere. BEWWEEEEHHHEEEHHHHHE gatatatatatat BWEEEHEEE.
pitch_accent: キッサテン *** キッサꜜテン

ex_1_jp: 初めまして。今日からこの僧院で働く予定になっているコウイチです。よろしくお願いいたします。
ex_1_en: Nice to meet you. I’m Koichi. I’m scheduled to start working in this monastery today. I’m looking forward to working with you all.
meaning_story: An institution for monks is going to be a temple or monastery. What a nice place to live, I'm sure!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 木曜日に、雪だるまを作るとかかまくらを作るみたいな、何か楽しいことをしたくない？
ex_1_en: Do you want to do something fun like making a snowman or building an igloo on Thursday?
meaning_story: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The tree day of the week is Thursday. Tree day comes after water day (which is Wednesday, for Water-Wednesday!). Trees need water to grow, which is why the tree comes right after the water.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

ex_1_jp: ビエトはコウイチに、マミはみんなの想像の斜め上を行く変人だと告げた。
ex_1_en: Viet told Koichi that Mami is much weirder than everyone imagined.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means announce so the verb vocab version is to announce.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'd like to announce... we're not having one baby, we're having two (つ) babies!

ex_1_jp: 目標人数に達するまで、あと少しだ。
ex_1_en: Only a little bit more until we reach the target number of people.
meaning_story: You know that 達 means attain. So, when you add する to it you make it a verb. Now it means to attain.
reading_story: This reading for this is a bit of an exception. You know the reading for 達 is たつ, but here it's shortened, to just たっ. So make sure you remember.

ex_1_jp: 肘を舐めれるかどうか分からないけど、試しにやってみるよ。
ex_1_en: I don’t know if I can lick my elbow, but I’ll give it a try.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means attempt or try. The verb vocab version is to attempt or to try out. Why don't you try out the meaning of this verb, while you're at it?
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Okay. Here's the deal. We have this wild animal. I want you to attempt to tame (ため) it. Now, imagine trying to tame this wild animal. Yeehaw!

ex_1_jp: あなたの旦那さんも、ケーキを焼くの？
ex_1_en: Does your hubby bake cake too?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bake or cook. So, the verb vocab version is to bake or to cook.
reading_story: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 「ごめんね。君から借りていた恋愛小説をなくしちゃったんだ。」「気にしないでいいよ。それはもう必要ないから。彼女ができたんだ。」
ex_1_en: "I’m sorry I lost the romance novel I borrowed from you." "Don’t worry about it. I won’t need it anymore. I have a girlfriend now."
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means borrow so the verb vocab version is to borrow.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Dude, can I borrow your car (か)? Please?

ex_1_jp: ビジネス街にオフィスを設けるとなると賃料はかなり高くつきますが、我々のイメージにとって重要な事でもありますし、一年ぐらいで元は取れるのではないかと思うんです。
ex_1_en: Rent for an office in the business district will be considerably expensive, but it’s important for our image and I think it will pay for itself in about a year.
meaning_story: This is like 取る, which is "to take." Now though, instead of you doing the taking, it's just "taking itself" so to speak. That doesn't make sense, though. When something its taken by itself, it is something that just comes off. So, you can call this to come off. You can remember that this is "to come off" instead of "to take" because it is rare (れる) that something comes off on its own without your help.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 取る so if you know that you'll know this!

ex_1_jp: 使わないのにどうしていちいち新聞から割引券を切り取るのさ？
ex_1_en: Why do you bother clipping coupons from newspapers if you never use them?
meaning_story: If you cut and take something, you are going to cut it right off. So, this verb is to cut off.
reading_story: The readings come from 切る and 取る. So, know those words separately and you can combine them into this word.
pitch_accent: キリトꜜル *** キリトル

ex_1_jp: 僕のお父さんはピザの配達人です。誰よりも速くピザを配達することができます。
ex_1_en: My daddy is a pizza delivery driver. He can deliver pizzas faster than anybody else.
meaning_story: You distribute the goods, they attain the goods. You are going to deliver to everyone.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もう忘れなって。過ぎてしまったことは今さらどうにもならないんだから。
ex_1_en: Forget about it. It’s water under the bridge.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means forget so the verb vocab version is to forget.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Wait, what was (わす) the reading? I forget... What was it?

ex_1_jp: そろそろプリンが固まる頃かしら。
ex_1_en: I wonder when the pudding will finally harden.
meaning_story: You've seen how 固める means "to make hard." This word means that something hardened by itself, it means to harden or to solidify.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: 自国の地位を保持することをまず優先した方がいい。
ex_1_en: You should prioritize maintaining your own country’s status first.
meaning_story: This is the verb version of 保持, from two levels ago.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 保持, so if you know that word's reading you know this one too.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの社員は、月曜日は青色、茶色、鼠色などの地味な色の服を着る事しか許されません。
ex_1_en: On Mondays, Tofugu workers are only allowed to wear clothes in subdued colors, such as blue, light brown, and grey.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means permit so the verb vocab version is to permit. It also means to forgive, in that "I'll permit it this time... but only this time." Look out for 許さない in TV shows, too. It means "I won't permit this!" or "I won't forgive you!"
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going to allow it. You're (ゆる) allowed to do it this one time, okay?

ex_1_jp: オーブンからフグを取り出しておいてくれない？あと五分で着くから。
ex_1_en: Can you take the blowfish out of the oven for me? I’ll be there in five minutes.
meaning_story: To take something and then remove it, is when you reach in and grab something and choose it and pull it out. This is to pick out or to take out.
reading_story: The readings come from the individual words 取る and 出す. Put them together and you should be able to read this word too.
pitch_accent: トリダꜜス *** トリダス

ex_1_jp: 日本の国技である相撲が、かつては米の豊作を祈る儀式だったことを知ってる日本人がたくさんいるとは思えないな。
ex_1_en: I don’t think many Japanese people know Japan’s national sport ’sumo’ used to be a ritual to pray for a bountiful rice harvest.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pray so the verb vocab version is to pray.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You gotta pray if you want Santa to bring you Christmas presents!" "I know (いの), I know," you reply as you begin to pray to Santa. You should say this out loud to remember it better.

ex_1_jp: この部屋では、私語を禁じる。
ex_1_en: In this room, whispering is prohibited.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means prohibition so the verb version means to prohibit.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
pitch_accent: キンジル *** キンジꜜル

ex_1_jp: Tofuguは、初音ミクの独占取材を報じた。
ex_1_en: Tofugu reported on an exclusive interview with Hatsune Miku.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means news report so you could try to say "to news report" but that doesn't make sense. What does make sense is "to report on," however.
reading_story: The reading doesn't seem like it's the kanji's on'yomi reading, but it is. What an oddity! Do you think it's worth doing a news report on it? Koichi, reporting in on this strange reading that is readable by you right now. Signing off.
pitch_accent: ホージル *** ホージꜜル

ex_1_jp: 「これを書き直す時間があると思う？」「私はそうは思わないね。」
ex_1_en: "Do you think we have enough time to rewrite this?" "I don’t think so."
meaning_story: If you take your writing and fix it, you are taking your writing and rewriting it. This word means to rewrite, because the fixing is really heavy, so regular revisions won't do.
reading_story: The readings come from 書く and 直す. Know those and you'll know how to read this word too!
pitch_accent: カキナオꜜス *** カキナオス

ex_1_jp: ずっと座っていると、お尻が汗ばんできます。
ex_1_en: When I’m sitting for a long time my butt gets sweaty.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sit so the verb vocab version is to sit.
reading_story: The reading is unlike the kanji reading, so let's use a separate mnemonic to remember this. Just imagine yourself going to sit down. You sit down, and the ground collapses below you and you fall. When you land, you find yourself in a nasty, stinking sewer (すわ). It is so gross. Taste the sewage in your mouth. Smell it. Feel gross. You shouldn't have sat down on that spot, it was looking awfully dangerous, now that you think about it.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguは、常に新しい事を試みる人を探しています。
ex_1_en: Tofugu is looking for someone who always tries to do something new.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means try so the verb vocab version is to try or to attempt.
reading_story: You know how when you try to do something you put your whole heart into it? Well, think of that in Japanese. You put your whole 心 (こころ) into it.

ex_1_jp: ああ、私達は無洗米を使ってるので、洗う必要は無いですよ。
ex_1_en: Oh, we are using pre-washed rice, so you don’t need to wash it.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wash so the verb vocab version is to wash.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to wash a rock (あら) you found. It looks shiny, but you can't tell until you wash it.

ex_1_jp: 日本語の学習予定を書き入れるTofugu手帳をコウイチに作ってもらいたいな。
ex_1_en: I want Koichi to make a Tofugu notebook so that we can write our Japanese study schedules in it.
meaning_story: To insert what you write into something is to write in or to fill in.
reading_story: The readings come from 書く and 入れる. Combine those two words to get the reading of this word.
pitch_accent: カキイレꜜル *** カキイレル

ex_1_jp: 日本語の訓練所を破壊する秘密組織があると聞きました。
ex_1_en: I heard that there is a secret organization that destroys Japanese language training camps.
meaning_story: You've got your instruction and you have your practice. Time to start your training.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
