ex_1_jp: あっ、おにぎりを持ってくるのを忘れた？お昼は駅弁を買わなければならない。
ex_1_en: Oh, you forgot to bring the onigiri? We’ll have to buy a station bento for lunch.
meaning_story: Remember how 弁当 is "bento"? Well, the 弁 in this word comes from that, so pretend it means "bento." Then, when you have a train station to go along with the bento, you have a train station bento. As you might think, a train station bento is just a bento that's sold at a train station. Easy!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は、人々が新しい言語を学んでいる時の、ニューロンの信号伝達について研究しています。
ex_1_en: I’m researching the neural signal transmission that occur while people are learning a new language.
meaning_story: When you transmit something and you attain it on the other end, you've done a transmission.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. You will probably have to pull from your knowledge of 伝説 to remember the on'yomi reading of 伝, though.

ex_1_jp: 火曜日は野球でコテンパにやられたよ。
ex_1_en: I got owned in baseball on Tuesday.
meaning_story: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The fire day of the week is the day after the worst day of the week (monday). You set fire to everything because you're so pissed off about yesterday, which makes today Tuesday.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 警告を無視するつもりなのか？
ex_1_en: Do you intend to ignore this warning?
meaning_story: When you announce something to warn somebody, you're warning them. Sometimes you're just trying to give them some helpful advice.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 水曜日の夜、彼はかなり酔っていて、トラックに轢かれてしまったんだ。
ex_1_en: He got drunk out of his mind Wednesday night and was run over by a truck.
meaning_story: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The water day of the week is where the water flows from. Think of your entire week as a big hill, with Wednesday (hump day) being in the middle. This hump is a hill. What originates from hills? Water! That's why Water day is Wednesday.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

ex_1_jp: 多くの日本企業では、新入社員は忘年会で一発芸を披露しなくてはならない。
ex_1_en: In many Japanese companies, new workers are required to do a short performance at an end of the year party.
meaning_story: Time to get together and forget the year... what a terrible year, good thing a new one is coming. This get together is a year end party.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の友達はお坊さんで、自分のお寺で座禅の会を開いています。彼は、座禅によって、リラックスできるだけでなく、欲望や執着心が無くなる悟りの境地に至ることもできると教えてくれました。
ex_1_en: My friend is a monk and he does Zen meditation sessions in his temple. He told me that we could not only relax but also attain enlightenment and be free of desire and attachment from Zen meditation.
meaning_story: When you sit and do zen you are probably doing zen meditation. Hummmmm.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もし禅僧になりたければ、とんでもなくきつい修行を終える必要があります。
ex_1_en: If you want to be a Zen priest, you have to go through ridiculously tough training.
meaning_story: A Zen priest is a zen priest.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 天龍寺という、十四世紀に京都市西部に建てられた禅寺が好きです。
ex_1_en: The Tenryuuji is a Zen temple built in the 14th century in the west Kyoto that I like.
meaning_story: A zen temple is just what it sounds like, a zen temple. Sounds nice.
reading_story: The reading is the two words 禅 and 寺 put together. The てら gets changed to でら, though. In terms of when it's pronounced ぜんじ, if you put this word onto the end of the name of a 禅寺 the pronunciation changes to ぜんじ. It makes sense - it's more like a jukugo word that way (not that the original isn't, but you can see the separation of words coming together which gives the hint that it's a kun'yomi combo reading). Anyways, you may need a zen temple to keep your mind pure enough to remember this, but it's a good thing to keep in mind if you can.

ex_1_jp: 「お母さん、私ね、今日もテストで満点とったの。」「それがどうしたのよ？あんた本気で学歴が全てだと思ってるわけ？」
ex_1_en: "Hey, mom! I got a perfect score on my test again." "So what? Do you really believe a person’s academic record is everything?"
meaning_story: A continuation of studying is the time that passes that we study. This is academic history, so pay close attention!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その面接試験で、自分を表現するのに最も適した形容詞を選んで、その理由を説明しなくちゃいけなかったんだ。
ex_1_en: At the job interview, I had to choose the most suitable adjective to describe myself, and explain why.
meaning_story: A part of speech that creates the shape and form of a word is something that is descriptive (its shape and form are in there, after all!). This shape and form part of speech is an adjective. You are so beautiful!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この名簿では、学生の名前は名字で五十音順に記載されています。
ex_1_en: In this list, the students’ names are placed in Aiueo order by surname.
meaning_story: This is a little confusing for someone who didn't grow up with the Japanese language. You have fifty sounds. Then, they're in a certain order. So, these fifty sounds are the Japanese syllabary. That's hiragana / katakana, probably from back in the day when there were more sounds than there are now. So, the "fifty sounds in order" makes up aiueo order, where the "aiueo" is あいうえお representing the five columns.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 君との人生は本当に驚きの連続だよ。まさか365日連続で遅刻するなんて思ってもみなかったよ。
ex_1_en: Life with you is truly full of surprises. I can’t believe you were late for work for 365 consecutive days!
meaning_story: If you take along and continue something, you are creating a series. Come along now. Okay, continue! Come along now. Okay, continue! This is how Lord of the Rings was made, probably. Come along now.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この決断は果たして正しかったのだろうか。
ex_1_en: I wonder if this is really the right decision.
meaning_story: So this doesn't really make much sense in terms of the kanji and word, but it is what it is. This word means as was expected or just as I thought. Maybe because things have "fruited the way I thought they would!"? Take what you will from that, but be sure to remember the phrase that is associated with this word.
reading_story: To remember the reading, just imagine yourself snorting out a sharp "HA!" (は) right before saying the phrase: "HA! Just as I thought."

ex_1_jp: コウイチは猫舌なので、スープをふうふうしないと食べられない。本当でしょうか嘘でしょうか？
ex_1_en: Koichi doesn’t like hot food, so he can’t eat soup without blowing on it. Is this true or false?
meaning_story: A cat's tongue is for some reason associated with an aversion to hot foods. I guess I haven't seen a cat drinking up boiling milk, but whatever. Just imagine a cat licking up something super hot and freaking out. Cats don't like hot things, which is why this is an aversion to hot foods.
reading_story: The reading is the two vocab words separately put together, just as you'd expect from a body-part related kanji. So, 猫 plus 舌 = ねこじた. Just remember that 舌 is read here as じた, and not した.
pitch_accent: ネコジタ *** ネコꜜジタ

ex_1_jp: 私の祖父は、オウム真理教の敬虔な信徒でした。
ex_1_en: My grandfather was a devout follower of the Aum Shinrikyou religious cult.
meaning_story: A junior believer is a believer or follower. They certainly aren't the leader or anything because of their junior status, but at least they're there, and at least they're believing. Oh, and excuse me, may I take a moment of your time? I'd like to tell you about the glory that is the Crabigator....
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ルックスがいい人は絶対に得だと思います。
ex_1_en: I believe that having good looks is absolutely an advantage.
meaning_story: When you are able to acquire whatever you want, you start to see the benefits of everything around you and begin to profit from them. Aren't you so amazing?
reading_story: The reading for this is the same as with the kanji you learned. とく!

ex_1_jp: 毎日毛布を百枚も洗うなんて想像もつかないよ。
ex_1_en: I can’t imagine myself washing one hundred blankets every day.
meaning_story: A fur cloth isn't something you'd just throw away. You'd probably turn this warm fur cloth into a nice blanket.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: すみません、ちょっとお声が遠いようなのですが。日本語の教科書が何冊いるとおっしゃりましたか？
ex_1_en: Excuse me, I’m having trouble hearing you. Did you say how many Japanese textbooks you want?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as well. It's probably treated like on'yomi jukugo because it's attached to things (like numbers!).

ex_1_jp: どうして日本人は、ほとんどの人が仏徒なのに、クリスマスをお祝いするの？
ex_1_en: If Japanese people are mostly Buddhists, why do they celebrate Christmas in Japan?
meaning_story: A Buddha junior or follower is someone junior to Buddha (who isn't, really?). They follow what the Buddha says and does. They are a Buddhist.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the ぶつ is shortened to ぶっ just as many つs are.

ex_1_jp: 今日は忙しかったね。なんてったって、今日だけで1000語も新しい日本語を学んだんだから。
ex_1_en: Today was hectic. Just today, we learned 1000 new Japanese words.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of busy? It's also busy.
reading_story: We made you learn the kun'yomi reading for this kanji when you were learning the kanji. Lucky you. Now you won't be so busy with this word and perhaps you'll finally be able to learn some other words!
pitch_accent: イソカ°シꜜイ *** コゼワシꜜイ *** セワシꜜイ

ex_1_jp: 多忙な生活を送る。
ex_1_en: I lead a busy life.
meaning_story: If you've had many busy days, then you're even more busy than you thought! It's probably from all that pressure at work.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 忙 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: You've been so busy from the pressure at work that you decide to blow off some steam and go bowling (ぼう). You may be busy, but you always have time for bowling.

ex_1_jp: 記事の年代順リストとかってやっぱり作った方がいいのかな？
ex_1_en: Should we make a list of our articles in chronological order?
meaning_story: You put years in order of the period they come in and you're really putting them in chronological order.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 布おむつの方が紙おむつよりも健康にいいと聞いたことがあります。
ex_1_en: I’ve heard that cloth diapers are better for your health than disposable ones.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You take your cloth and put it on top of your head. It's there because right at noon (ぬの) the sun is in the middle of the sky and burns your scalp. So, you cover it with a cloth. Imagine yourself setting an alarm for noon to help you to focus on the noon part.

pronunciation: れんちゅう, れんぢゅう, れんじゅう
ex_1_jp: あの連中はいつもくだらない話ばかりしている。
ex_1_en: Those guys always have nothing but stupid conversations.
meaning_story: People you want to take along to the middle of somewhere are probably people you know pretty well. They're your colleagues, they keep you company. These guys, am I right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.
pitch_accent: レンジュー *** レンチュー

ex_1_jp: 申し訳ないけど、そんな中途半端なやり方じゃ新入社員が混乱しちゃう気がします。
ex_1_en: I’m afraid that your half-baked policy may cause confusion among the new employees.
meaning_story: There's a riot and everything's getting all mixed up! Within that, there is of course a ton of confusion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 一部のTofuguファンは、内容と正確さについて非常に厳しいことでよく知られています。
ex_1_en: Some of the Tofugu fans are well known for being relentless about details and accuracy.
meaning_story: Inside that form... there is something inside there. What are the contents?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 誰がコウイチの鼻の写真を撮ったの？その光と影の対比がすごく好きなんだけど。
ex_1_en: Who took the picture of Koichi’s nose? I really love the contrast between the light and the shadows.
meaning_story: You're comparing something to another thing, each versus one another. When you do that, you look at both sides. You contrast each and then you come up with a comparison.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: フグが暗殺された後、サーモンに残されたのは借財だけだということが明らかになった。
ex_1_en: After Fugu’s assassination, it became clear that the only thing he left behind for Salmon was debt.
meaning_story: The wealth you borrow is your debt.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Make sure you remember ざい over さい, though. Why? Because you got all this debt trying to buy your way into Zion.

ex_1_jp: モデル達の写真を顔が大きい順に並べました。
ex_1_en: We lined up the pictures of the models faces, largest first.
meaning_story: When the order is from big (to small), you are talking about decreasing order. That's largest first.
reading_story: The reading is the word 大きい plus 順's reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 木を見て森を見ず、だぜ。細かいことにばかり気をとられずに、もっと大きいスケールで物を考えてくれよ。
ex_1_en: You can’t see the wood for the trees. Don’t just focus on the details, look at the bigger picture.
meaning_story: Remember 細い and how it means "thin." Well, this is another adjective that comes from the kanji 細 with a similar but different meaning (sorry!). If you think about something that's very thin, though, there isn't much surface area. In order to use this very thin thing (say, to put your favorite model railroad on) you have to zoom way in and get incredibly detailed with it. It's super small and fine, so get your magnifying lens out! You can remember that this one is "detailed" or "fine" because the かい makes you think of coyotes. You put a ton of work into this detailed and fine model railroad on a very thin piece of land. Then, a coyote comes in and trashes it all, because you made the mistake of making it out of meat.
reading_story: The reading for this is the other reading I had you learn with the kanji: こま. You can remember this, because after the coyote wrecks your pretty train things he bites you on the head, sending you into an indefinite coma (こま).

ex_1_jp: 日本語学習は容易ではないよ。必死で頑張らないといけないよ。
ex_1_en: Learning Japanese isn’t easy. You have to work really hard.
meaning_story: The form in front of you is easy. Whatever it is, you'll be able to do it with ease.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 試験の時、易しい問題から先に解いてしまう方が好きなんです。
ex_1_en: During an exam, I like solving the easy questions first.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of easy? It's also easy.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Everything is so easy for you to do. Why? Because you don't do anything yourself. You ask others. You say things like "Hey, can you get me some water?" They say "yassah!" (やさ) very enthusiastically.

ex_1_jp: 小説をたった八冊出版したからって、自分の事を小説家だなんて呼びませんよ。五十冊出版すれば、もしかするとそう呼ぶかもしれないけどね。
ex_1_en: I won’t call myself a fiction writer after only publishing eight books. If I publish fifty books, then I’ll call myself that.
meaning_story: When you have eight books you have eight books. This is an example of how to count books, so if you have eight of them this is what you'd say.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はち part gets shortened as it often does when put into situations like this, making it はっ. The 冊 is all normal, and to the "book(s)." Har!

ex_1_jp: コートの下にアヤが描いた絵を隠すと、泥棒は非常口からこっそりと抜け出した。
ex_1_en: After putting Aya’s drawing under his coat, the thief slipped out through the emergency exit.
meaning_story: You know how 非常 means emergency and how 口 can be some kind of doorway (like in 入り口, for example)? Well, if that's the case, then you have an emergency doorway. Usually you run away from emergencies, though, making this an emergency exit.
reading_story: The reading is the words 非常 and 口 combined together. The thing that makes this weird is that it's a mix of the kun and on'yomi readings. I guess things get all jostled up when you have yourself an emergency.

ex_1_jp: 祭りは連日大賑わいだ。
ex_1_en: This festival has had a great turnout day after day.
meaning_story: What happens when you take along a day? It becomes every day.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの笛を持っている男の人がコウイチさんだよ。
ex_1_en: That guy holding the whistle is Mr. Koichi.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Pretend you're trying to whistle, but you can't. All that comes out is air. You make a "Fuuuuuuueh" sound over and over, because you can't get the whole whistling thing down. Go ahead and pretend to do that (or do it for real).

ex_1_jp: 私の趣味は、教師と生徒の禁断の愛をテーマにした本を読むことです。
ex_1_en: My hobby is reading books about the forbidden love between students and their teachers.
meaning_story: One who is junior in life is a follower or pupil. It's kind of like how a 先生 is someone who came previous to you in life is a teacher. Cool how that works, right? Okay 生徒, get back to work!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ○×クイズ: ビエトは等身大の初音ミク人形を買うお金を儲けるために、二枚舌を使ってコウイチを騙しました。○か×か？
ex_1_en: Yes or No Quiz: In order to get the money for a life-sized Hatsune Miku doll, Viet used his forked tongue to cheat Koichi. Yes or No?
meaning_story: You have two flat objects that make up your tongue. What kind of tongue is made up of two of anything? That's a tongue that's split, that's a forked tongue.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that 舌 is read here as じた, and not した.

ex_1_jp: 布団の勧誘って、何であんなにしつこいのかなぁ。何度来られても買わないものは買わないっつうの。ほんと、鬱陶しい！
ex_1_en: I’m getting sick of these futon salespeople. Can’t they understand that if I don’t buy something after several visits, that I’m never going to buy it? So annoying.
meaning_story: This one's a little weird. You have a group of cloth. Think about this. If you group together a bunch of cloth into one big cloth, you have something nice and soft. What can you use this nice and soft cloth things for? Well, you can sleep on it. This is the Japanese word futon, which you may have heard in English before (though the Japanese futon is quite different from the American one). You can also translate this to bedding or sleeping mat too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 団 is the secondary reading that went with the kanji, though, so watch out for that. If you can figure out the meaning of this word, chances are you already know how to spell it, so carry that over to Japanese.

ex_1_jp: 彼は赤ちゃんなので、まだ善悪の区別がつきません。
ex_1_en: He is just a baby so he still doesn’t know the difference between right and wrong.
meaning_story: You have morally good and bad. This is the battle between good and evil.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: コウイチもビエトも、サルサはあまり得意ではない。
ex_1_en: Neither Koichi nor Viet is any good with salsa.
meaning_story: When you're able to acquire ideas at a fast rate, you must be familiar with whatever it is you're doing. If you acquire ideas in this way, there's a good chance you're good at or skilled at this action.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本語の文法で、修得するのが最も難しいもののうちの一つが助詞です。
ex_1_en: In Japanese grammar, one of the most difficult things to master is particles.
meaning_story: A part of speech that's just meant to help your grammar out are the little things. They tie grammar and words together, and that's about it. These are grammar particles or just plain old particles.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは終盤で集団を抜け出し、ホノルルマラソンで優勝した。
ex_1_en: Koichi broke out ahead of the pack at the end of the race and won the Honolulu Marathon.
meaning_story: A group that has collected together is a bunch of people. It is a group or crowd.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの歴史について簡単に説明させてください。
ex_1_en: Let me give you a brief explanation of Tofugu’s history.
meaning_story: The continuation of history is history itself. This is the main word for "history" and you'll see it a lot if you're in school or something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私達のサイトに関して、何か改善すべき点などがございましたら、どうぞご連絡くださいませ。
ex_1_en: If you have any suggestions for the improvement of our site, please contact us.
meaning_story: When you renew something and it ends up morally good it's definitely an improvement.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 空欄を埋めて、数字を小さい順に並び替えなさい。
ex_1_en: Fill in the grid, and rearrange the numbers to put them in ascending order.
meaning_story: When something goes from small and goes in order it's in increasing order, or smallest first.
reading_story: The reading is the word 小さい plus the reading for 順.

ex_1_jp: 私が大の苦手としていることの一つに、他動詞と自動詞があります。
ex_1_en: Some of the things I really dread are transitive and intransitive verbs.
meaning_story: An automatic part of speech is an intransitive verb. Intransitive verbs are actions that just happen, aka you're not the one doing the action or thing. These are words like 付く or 消える, where you aren't doing the action. That's why they're automatic!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 十月二十三日金曜日、Tofugu野球チームは、Tofuguオフィスで入団テストを実施します。
ex_1_en: The Tofugu baseball team will hold tryouts at the Tofugu office on Friday, October 23rd.
meaning_story: If you enter a group you are going to join or enlist.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「よくも私に対して昆布を投げつけてくれたわね。」「ごめん。そんな大ごとだとは思わなかったんだよ。」
ex_1_en: "How dare you throw konbu seaweed at me!" "I’m sorry. I didn’t think it would be that big of a deal."
meaning_story: This one is pretty weird. The cloth of our descendants is konbu. This is a type of seaweed that is very common in Japan. It is used in foods and in broths. It is everywhere, and delicious. If you're not familiar with it already this may be a hard word to learn, but I believe in you. Maybe if you read up on konbu for a bit it will help you to remember your descendants' cloth.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 布 part gets changed to ぶ, probably because if a food doesn't have konbu you say boo (ぶ).

ex_1_jp: 「先月、恋人と別れたんだ。」「大丈夫だよ。お前には他にもっといい子がいるよ。」
ex_1_en: "My lover and I broke up last month." "It’s okay, you’ll find someone better."
meaning_story: A person of romance is someone you do romancey things with. That person is your lover.
reading_story: The reading is a bit strange. it's the two separate words 恋 and 人 put together, making the reading こいびと. Oooh lala. Two words coming together like two people coming together. Rawrs.

ex_1_jp: セール初日、モールは人でごった返しになり、まるで大乱戦のようだった。
ex_1_en: On the first day of the sale, the mall became super crowded, as if it was a battle royal.
meaning_story: A riot of war is where things go nuts. This is a melee! A free for all!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 日本人の新生児の三十人に一人は混血だそうですね。
ex_1_en: One in thirty newborn Japanese babies is of mixed parentage.
meaning_story: If you have mixed blood, some people might say you're of mixed race. Own it!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: このゲームでは固有名詞は使えませんよ。
ex_1_en: You can’t use proper nouns in this game.
meaning_story: A name part of speech is when you are naming something. What part of speech has names in it? That would be the noun.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチはゴジラと戦うために、原子力で稼働するTofuguロボットを作った。
ex_1_en: Koichi made a nuclear powered Tofugu robot to fight against Godzilla.
meaning_story: The power of the atom (原子) is nuclear power.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本語の数詞が勉強できるゲームがあればいいのに。
ex_1_en: I wish there was a game that could help me study Japanese numerals.
meaning_story: A number part of speech is a numeral or number word.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ワニカニに新しい単語が続々と登場する日が待ち遠しい。
ex_1_en: I can’t wait for the day when new words pop up one after another on Wanikani.
meaning_story: When you continue and then you continue again (that's the repeater kanji), you get things happening one after another. Continue continue continue!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ゾクゾク *** ゾꜜクゾク

ex_1_jp: あなたのために旅の間に読める本を一冊買っておいたの。タイトルは『地図』よ。
ex_1_en: I bought you a book to read during your trip. The title is "Map."
meaning_story: When you have one books you really just have one book.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 一 portion gets shortened to いっ as it often is.
pitch_accent: イッサツꜜ *** イッサツ

ex_1_jp: コウイチは順番にEmailに返信をします。
ex_1_en: Koichi replies to his emails in order.
meaning_story: When you go in order of turns that's the order. It also represents one's turn in said order as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「何か今日の俺、マジでイケてる。ひょっとしたらアイツらの乱交パーティにも誘われちゃうかも。」「ははは〜。そうだといいね。」
ex_1_en: "I look so good today that it’s possible I may be asked to join an orgy party." "Haha. You wish!"
meaning_story: A big mix of folks forming a kind of riot. You'd think this would be something more violent, but it's really just an orgy. Lots of mixing, I guess, and not very much organization on the orgy-organizer's part, at least according to this kanji sequence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: フグ、サーモンはあなたが復縁したいって知らないのよ。 もし知ったら、彼女も違うように感じるかもしれないわ。もしかしたら、他の魚と月を見に宇宙へなんて行かないかもしれないわよ。
ex_1_en: Fugu, Salmon doesn’t know that you wanna get back together. If she did, she might feel differently. She might not even go to space to see the moon with a different fish.
meaning_story: The mid air of outer space is the space that's in outer space which is outer space, space, and the universe!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 久々の飲み会参加でエンジョイしちゃってまーす。今日は超リア充って感じだよ〜。
ex_1_en: It’s been a while since I participated in a drinking party and I’m really enjoying it. I’m feeling super-charged!
meaning_story: When you participate, adding yourself to the activity, that is participation. Well done, you earn a gold star for participating!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この文章を品詞に分解しなさい。
ex_1_en: Please break down this sentence by parts of speech.
meaning_story: A product of part of speech is more part of speech. Evil begets evil, so to speak.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: フグは、自分が非常に優秀な魚だということが、物凄く目立つ履歴書を作成した。
ex_1_en: Fugu prepared a resume that makes him really stand out as an extraordinary fish.
meaning_story: The continuation of being in someone's boots and getting it written down, that's the writing of "walking in someone's shoes" so to speak. It gives you an idea of that person. It is a personal history, though it can also be a resume.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: リレキショ *** リレキショꜜ

ex_1_jp: 日本に住むために、まず最初に自分の親を説得しなくてはいけません。
ex_1_en: In order to live in Japan, the first thing I have to do is persuade my parents to let me do it.
meaning_story: You acquire theory after theory. In doing this, you have a lot of theories in your head. You use all these theories as tools for persuasion. These theories will allow you to convince anyone of anything.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 説 gets shortened to せっ.

ex_1_jp: すみません、 前を通らせてもらってもよろしいでしょうか。あの梅干しが入った小瓶を買いたいので。
ex_1_en: Excuse me. May I get through? I’d like to buy that jar of pickled plums.
meaning_story: This is a food pretty specific to Japan, making it a slightly weird one to learn. You have a Japanese Plum. Then you have dry. So when the Japanese plum is dried, it's not a dried plum (that would be too easy), it is a pickled plum or pickled ume. If you know the name of this food, you can call it by that too: umeboshi.
reading_story: The reading for this one, like the meaning, is kind of strange. It's the kun'yomi readings, so apologies in advance for that. You have うめ plus ぼし, which comes from 干す though the し is stuffed inside the 干 for some reason. It's also rendaku'd. Basically, everything is all screwed up, so you know, deal with it. This food is awesome, and common, so you have to learn it. I guess the pickling process has mangled the reading of this word. At least it tastes good.

ex_1_jp: 遅かれ早かれ、Tofuguは財閥として日本のビジネス界に君臨するでしょう。
ex_1_en: Tofugu will come to reign the business world in Japan as a zaibatsu sooner or later.
meaning_story: A wealth clan is a group of people who do whatever they can to get their money. These are the plutocrats of the world, but you can also call them financial clique or even the Zaibatsu (sometimes brought up in English language history / economic books regarding Japan).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ねえ、お父さん。お母さんさぁ、近所の井戸端会議で仕入れたいい加減な情報に踊らされるの、いい加減に止めるべきだと思わない？
ex_1_en: Hey, Dad. Don’t you think it’s time for mom to stop being manipulated by pointless gossip from idly chatting with the neighbors.
meaning_story: You add and you subtract. This brings you back to zero. There was absolutely no point in doing those actions. Completely pointless. The extra いい is there to mean "good," as in "good, you've figured out how pointless that was, now stop."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「昨夜、フグと別れたの。」「サーモン、何があったの？」「フグが、私が警官だってことを知って、それで、もう私とは会わないって言われたの。」「そんなに簡単に？」「ええ。あっけないものね。」
ex_1_en: "I broke up with Fugu last night." "What happened, Salmon?" "Well, He found out that I’m a police officer and said he wouldn’t see me any more." "Just like that?" "Yeah. Just like that."
meaning_story: You know how 警察 is "police"? Well, this is kind of like that. This time you have someone from the government trying to warn you about the bad things you do. This person, like 警察 is a police officer.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本の警察署に英語が喋れる人が常駐してたらいいのにな。
ex_1_en: I wish there was always someone who could speak English in police stations in Japan.

ex_1_jp: 外国語能力は、いつでも時間変化率に比例するという訳ではない。
ex_1_en: Foreign language ability doesn’t always improve in proportion to the rate of change.
meaning_story: This is a tough one. When you compare examples (in this case of numbers) you are figuring out the proportion / ratio. A ratio, for example, has one number on top of another. They are examples being compared. Same with proportions. Without two things to compare, proportion doesn't make sense. That's why when you compare examples, you are dealing with proportions or ratios.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE

reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 心配しないで。季節の変わり目に風邪をひくのは、私の習慣のようなものなの。

reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「端午の節句」と呼ばれる日本の男の子の日に欠かせないのが、鯉をかたどった「鯉のぼり」と呼ばれる吹き流しです。

reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that せつ gets shortened to せっ just like many つs do in this situation.

ex_1_jp: 月曜日に席順を変更したいと思います。
ex_1_en: We are going to change the seating order on Monday.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 1985年、雑誌Tofuguの別冊本に、生まれたばかりのコウイチの写真が掲載されました。
ex_1_en: In 1985, newborn Koichi’s photograph was published in an extra issue of the Tofugu Magazine.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The べつ gets shortened to べっ, though, probably because it's a つ and that's what つs do for a living in jukugo words.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguのテーマ曲の歌詞は、とても独創的でユニークでなきゃね。
ex_1_en: The lyrics of the Tofugu theme song should be very creative and unique.
meaning_story: A song's part of speech is the part of the song where you're talking (aka singing). These are the word parts of the song. These are the song lyrics. Anyone ready for some カラオケ?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 問題は宙に浮いたままだ。
ex_1_en: The problem is up in the air.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 昨日の夢で、幸運にもタイタニック号が汽笛を鳴らすところを見たよ。
ex_1_en: In my dream last night, I was fortunate enough to witness the blowing of the Titanic’s steam whistles.
meaning_story: A steam flute is a flute that goes off using steam. The only time I can think of this happening is via a steam whistle. Choo choooo!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 物理の問題で、ベクトル減法はあまり見ませんが、たまに出てくることがあります。
ex_1_en: In physics problems, we don’t come across vector subtraction very often, but it does pop up some times.
meaning_story: What's a method to decrease something? Well, you take something away. You do subtraction.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the ほう changes to ぽう. This is because you're trying to subtract Polar (ぽう) bears from the area around you as they're very dangerous and you use a cologne made from meat.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは、許可無くコウイチのベーコンを食べたという容疑でマミを起訴する準備を進めている。
ex_1_en: Koichi is preparing to prosecute Mami because he suspects her of eating his bacon without permission.
meaning_story: You have the appearance of doubt about you. Is that suspicion you're feeling?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「今日は日本の小説を三冊読むぞ！」「はは。出来るもんならやってみな。」
ex_1_en: "I’m gonna read three Japanese novels today!" "Haha. You wish."
meaning_story: Three books equals three books.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本で英語を教えるという経験から、たくさんのことが得られました。
ex_1_en: I got a lot out of my experience teaching English in Japan.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means acquire so the verb vocab version is to acquire.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to acquire an elephant (え) for your elephant collection. If you don't acquire an elephant, you'll look like an idiot in front of your elephant collecting friends.

ex_1_jp: ビエトは酔って暴れたが、コウイチがなんとか落ち着かせた。
ex_1_en: Viet got drunk and disorderly, but Koichi managed to calm him down.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means violence. "To violence" doesn't sound great, so instead this word is to act violently or to rage.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're about to rage all over the place. You're going nuts. You're going to act violently. Then, a calm wizard steps in front of you and mutters "abara kadabara," (あば) causing you to calm down immediately.

ex_1_jp: オバマ大統領が作った料理に、塩をひとつまみ加えた。
ex_1_en: I added a pinch of salt to the dish President Obama made.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means add so the verb vocab version would be to add.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You hold a Christmas party every year. This year, instead of just Christmas you have to add other winter holidays to the mix so people don't get upset. First up? Kwanzaa (くわ).
pitch_accent: クワエル *** クワエꜜル

ex_1_jp: いつも右の靴の踵が左よりも速く擦り減るんだ。
ex_1_en: My right shoe always gets worn down at the heels faster than my left one.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decrease so the verb vocab version is to be decreased.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your status is to be decreased amongst the eyes of the Gods. They decide your punishment is to be decreased into hell (へる) where you will live the rest of your days.

ex_1_jp: 「どうして遅くまでお店を開けておけないの？」「すみませんが、私に言われても困ります。私はただここで働いているだけなので。」
ex_1_en: "Why don’t you stay open later?" "Sorry, it’s not really my call. I just work here."
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means distressed and troubled. The verb version of those are to be distressed and to be troubled.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so no need to feel too distressed about it.

ex_1_jp: サーモンと離婚した後、フグは生活が乱れた。
ex_1_en: After the divorce with Salmon, Fugu’s life was in disarray.
meaning_story: The kanji means riot, but this verb version word doesn't really mean "to riot." It's more like to be in disorder. But if you think about it, when things are rioting and crazy, they definitely are in disorder, so you can think of it that way. You can differentiate this from the future word 乱す because with れる you know it is rare for it to be like this. You aren't doing it, but it just happens on occasion (rarely) so you take advantage of it.
reading_story: When everything is in disorder it's finally your chance! You run to the bar, break the windows, and grab all the mead (みだ) you can carry.

ex_1_jp: そう改まるなよ。コウイチ大統領は、とても気さくなんだから。
ex_1_en: Don’t be so formal! President Koichi is very friendly.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means renew so the verb vocab version is to be renewed. You're not doing the renewing directly, it's just happening (as renewing often does).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To be renewed you decide to go to a spa. You get in a bathtub and they pour in a lotta (あらた) leeches and eels to help you to be renewed. Feel the fear. There are a lot of them! Alternatively, you can imagine them pouring in allota Maru cats, because that's way fuzzier.

ex_1_jp: 主人と私は、私達の双子をできるだけ比べないようにはしていますが、やっぱり難しいですね。
ex_1_en: My husband and I have tried not to compare our twins with each other, but it’s difficult.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means compare so the verb vocab version is to compare.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Look at this cooler (くら). No look at this cooler. No, wait, we need to compare the two coolers. Think about all the features each one has and really compare, like you have a list or something.

ex_1_jp: ごめん、行かなきゃ。予定を調べて、後で折り返し連絡するよ。
ex_1_en: Sorry, I’ve gotta go. Let me check my schedule and I’ll get back to you.
meaning_story: You take along a message and entangle it into the telephone. From there it buzzes off to the person in order for you to contact them.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 金玉を捻ってしまい、痛みが五時間以上も続いています。
ex_1_en: I twisted my testicles and the pain has lasted for over five hours.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means continue so the verb vocab version is to continue. Please continue.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Two dudes (つづ) get to continue on. I'm afraid you two ladies are going to have to stay here. This is a dude's only night club.

ex_1_jp: 最悪！ネチャネチャの風船ガムが髪に絡まっちゃった！どうやって取ればいいんだろう。
ex_1_en: Oh no! Sticky bubblegum got tangled in my hair! How can I get it out?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means entangle so the verb vocab version is to get entangled. This is when something gets entangled on its own (you're not directly doing the entangling). You can remember this because of the む, which is you saying move (む) out of the way, I have to take care of this entanglement mess that just happened on its own.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The entanglement mess you're fixing is a couple of kids that got their hair tangled up. They were doing some sparring in their からて class and one thing led to the other and suddenly both their hair was entangled together.

ex_1_jp: みんなの会話に混ざることができなくて、とても悲しかったし寂しかったよ。
ex_1_en: I felt really sad and lonely because I couldn’t contribute to the conversation at all.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mix so the verb vocab version is to get mixed or to be mixed. This is when something is just getting mixed and you're not directly doing the action of mixing anything. You can remember this because the Tzar (ざる) of Russia is very impressed that things mix on their own and you're not doing the mixing. The connotation for this word is you can't distinguish the things you're mixing, like combining paints, which become one mixed color that isn't two separate colors anymore.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're not doing the mixing, in order for things to get mixed you call your ma (ま) up and ask her to mix it. What a terrible lazy child you are.

ex_1_jp: 漢字を覚えるのは難しい。
ex_1_en: It’s hard to memorize kanji.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means memorize so the verb version is to memorize. That shouldn't be too hard to remember, right?
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use one of the kun'yomi readings. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The best way to memorize and to remember something is to make up a song and play it on your oboe (おぼ). Something about playing it makes it so you can memorize anything. You're so talented.

ex_1_jp: ねぇ、気をつけた方がいいよ。あの男がさっきあんたの飲み物に何か混ぜてたのを見たよ。
ex_1_en: Hey, you should watch out, I saw that guy mix something into your drink.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mix so the verb vocab version is to mix. This is when you're doing the mixing. You can remember this because "there (ぜる) is much mixing to be done so it's best if you just do it because nobody else will." The connotation for this word is you can't distinguish the things you're mixing, like combining paints, which become one mixed color that isn't two separate colors anymore.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're doing mixing like your ma (ま) taught you, which is why when you do the mixing things get done around here a lot faster. You can also use the level 5 vocab 交ぜる to help you remember as it has the same meaning and reading!

ex_1_jp: いえ、結構です。昨夜、舌を焼いたので、コーヒーを飲みたくない。
ex_1_en: No, thank you. I burned my tongue last night, so I don’t want to drink any coffee.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Uses the same reading that you learned with the kanji. Go ahead and use your tongue and say the reading out loud... "した."

ex_1_jp: 道路上のウンチを踏まないようにするために、人々がハイヒールを履き始めたって知ってた？
ex_1_en: Did you know that people started wearing high heels in order to avoid stepping on poop in the streets?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means boots, but "to boots" doesn't make sense. What actions do you do with boots, though, usually? You put them on. That's why this word is to put on shoes (or boots, I guess). It's also to put on pants, probably because it's all kind of the same motion, no?
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to put on shoes. That will teach Mrs. Cho and her nail-streets! "HA (は) HA HA!" you laugh out loud like a maniac.

ex_1_jp: フグを動物保護施設に連れていくしかありませんね。
ex_1_en: We have no choice but to take Fugu to the animal shelter.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means take along so the verb vocab version is to take along.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What are you going to take along? Whoa. That much? Why in the world do you have two (つ) of everything?

ex_1_jp: 昨日の会議で、シャークの奴大失敗しちゃったんだよ。もしかすると今のポジションから降ろされちゃうかも。
ex_1_en: In the meeting yesterday, Shark really made a huge mistake. I think he might lose his position.
meaning_story: You know how 失敗 is a mistake? Well, a large mistake is going to be a total failure or a huge mistake. So terrible!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 失敗 on its own as well.

ex_1_jp: 我々は素晴らしい。何故なら、無意識にクリエイティブとなることができるからだ。
ex_1_en: We’re awesome because we can be involuntarily creative.
meaning_story: Know how 意識 is "consciousness"? What about when this consciousness doesn't exist (aka it is nothing)? That's when it becomes unconsciousness.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know how to read 意識, though.

ex_1_jp: もし自分を表現するために動詞を一つだけ選ばなくてはいけないとしたら、どの動詞を選びますか？
ex_1_en: If you had to choose one verb to describe yourself, which verb would you choose?
meaning_story: A part of speech that represents moving is a part of speech that describes actions. That is a verb.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチ大統領の支持率は非常に高い。
ex_1_en: President Koichi’s approval ratings are extremely high.
meaning_story: When something is moving towards emergency (非常), it is something that is very, extremely bad. Like, exceedingly so. It's nuts.
reading_story: The reading comes straight from the word 非常, which you hopefully know okay by now!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「父さん、友達が僕のこと、乱暴だって言うんだ。」「それがどうした。そんな奴の言うことなんかどうでもいいよ。そんな馬鹿たれ、こてんぱにしてやれ！」
ex_1_en: "Dad, my friend says I’m violent." "So what? Who cares what he thinks? Just beat the stupid guy up!"
meaning_story: Riot and violence. That sounds terrible! That sounds like a place full of violence, because rioting is violent and violence is violent too!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 親は本当に、暴力的な映画やビデオゲームが子供の目に触れる事を制限すべきなのでしょうか？
ex_1_en: Do you really think that parents should limit their children’s exposure to violent movies and video games?
meaning_story: The power of violence is more violence, and it is a force to be reckoned with.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私のお母さんが、若布と豆腐のお味噌汁を作ったんだけど、食べる？
ex_1_en: My mom made a miso soup with wakame seaweed and tofu. Do you want some?
meaning_story: A young cloth for some reason is the seaweed wakame. If you've never heard of wakame before, go look it up. It's delicious and really good for you. Seaweed is kind of like cloth in the sea, right? Well, this young cloth is nice and soft and thin, like wakame. I imagine young people are soft and thin too, which is why the young cloth gets to be wakame.
reading_story: The reading doesn't make any sense, except for how 若い has わか in it. If you can figure out the meaning, though, you can use that to remember the reading (since they're the same).

ex_1_jp: 「ちょっと待って。財布を落としましたよ！」「ありがとう。でも、もし私がわざと落としたって言ったら、どうしますか？」
ex_1_en: "Hold up! You dropped your wallet!" "Thank you, but what would you do if I said I dropped it on purpose?"
meaning_story: Your wealth cloth is your wallet. Really, a wallet is just a piece of cloth you keep in your pocket that has your wealth in it, right? This can also be your purse or handbag as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私達は現在、日本語で書かれた説明書を英語に翻訳してくださる方を探しています。
ex_1_en: We are currently looking for someone who can translate some instructions written in Japanese into English.
meaning_story: An explanation (説明) in writing is a written explanation. I guess sometimes you don't want to do your explanations in person, huh?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: セツメイショ *** セツメイショꜜ

ex_1_jp: あの若い女性は、あなたには到底手の届かない高嶺の花だってことに気づいてるわよね。
ex_1_en: You do realize that young woman is way out of your league, right?
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of young? It's young.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Oh how nice it is to be young and to be able to remember that.

ex_1_jp: この若者はすごいよ。大物になる前にサインをもらっておいた方がいいよ。
ex_1_en: This young man is terrific. You should get his autograph before he becomes a big-shot.
meaning_story: A young someone is a young person.
reading_story: The reading for this one is a pain. 若 is the same as what you learned with the kanji (わか), but 者 is もの, which isn't what you learned. Think of this: A young person does what they want. They don't follow tradition or do anything the way you'd want them to, just like the reading of this word. Also, their actions make you really want to moan (もの) because ugh, young people. Get off my lawn.

ex_1_jp: 私の祖母は九十代ですが、六十代の人よりも若く見えます。若さの秘訣は、若々しい気持ちでいることと、よく噛むことだそうです。
ex_1_en: My Grandmother is in her nineties and she looks younger than some people in their sixties. She says that feeling young and chewing foods a lot are two big secrets to her youth.
meaning_story: A young young thing has youthfulness on their side. Oh to be youthful again!
reading_story: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. Same goes for the repeater kanji.

ex_1_jp: 彼はとても素晴らしい犯罪者で、自分一人でも、いとも簡単にとても危ない状態から抜け出すことが出来ました。そして、共犯者は一生必要ないとも豪語していました。
ex_1_en: He was a really wonderful criminal who could easily get out of the most dangerous situations by himself. He boasted that he would never need an accomplice.
meaning_story: Someone who does crime together with you is your accomplice in crime. It's best to "take care of these" before the coppers get to him/her.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 君って、ああ言えばこう言うし、しかも言うことがどれもいちいち正確なのが結構頭にくるんだけど。
ex_1_en: Actually, I’m pretty annoyed at how you have a comeback for everything and how what you say is so accurate.
meaning_story: It is correct and you're certain of it. When you've done this much checking and you're this sure, your measurements must be very accurate and precise.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その地震の後に、余震が相次ぎました。
ex_1_en: The earthquake was followed by aftershocks.
meaning_story: A surplus (that's an extra!) earthquake is a quake that comes after the main (non-surplus) quake. That's an aftershock.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は飛行機が苦手なので、一生日本に行けることはないでしょう。
ex_1_en: I dislike airplanes, so I would never be able to go to Japan.
meaning_story: The fly and go machine is some machine you get into that flies and goes places. It's an airplane.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguのオフィスに何度も何度も電話をしていますが、いつも留守番電話です。
ex_1_en: I called the Tofugu office over and over again, but I always get the answering machine.
meaning_story: You hopefully know that this has something to do with housesitting (留守番). So, a telephone (電話) that does housesitting for you is what? It's your answering machine.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どうしてあなたの妹は人類学の授業を受けたかったのかな。
ex_1_en: I wonder why your sister wanted to take an anthropology course.
meaning_story: The study of mankind (人類) is known as anthropology.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチとビエトは、夕飯に何を食べるかについて数時間に渡って議論に議論を重ねたが、結論には至らなかった。
ex_1_en: Koichi and Viet debated on what to eat for dinner for hours without reaching a decision.
meaning_story: There is much deliberation and theory exchanging when you are trying to present an argument. Of course, it's a very nice one. Lots of thinking and stuff, you know? That's why there's deliberation and theories instead of just screaming. That kind of "argument."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 昨年はこの街だけで100余りの企業が倒産した。
ex_1_en: Last year there were more than a hundred bankruptcies in this city alone.
meaning_story: Say you give birth to a baby. Then, after that everything falls apart and your life is overthrown. You lose it all because of this baby (babies are expensive). When you have your baby and everything is overthrown, you yourself are thrown into bankruptcy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 血圧の薬を飲んでも血圧が高いままであることを医者に言うと、血圧を抑えるにはストレスを減らすことが重要だよと教えられました。
ex_1_en: When I told my doctor that even though I take blood pressure meds, I still have high blood pressure, he told me the importance of reducing stress to control my blood pressure.
meaning_story: Check the pressure of your blood. It's your blood pressure.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あのマンションは、幽霊屋敷であるという評判のせいで借り手がつかない。
ex_1_en: That apartment still doesn’t have any tenants because it’s rumored to be haunted.
meaning_story: The hand who borrows is the borrower.
reading_story: You'll want to know the words 借りる and 手 to be able to read this one. Combine them to know the reading.

ex_1_jp: 昔はうさぎ狩りに弓矢を使っていました。
ex_1_en: We used to use bows and arrows for hunting rabbits.
meaning_story: A bow and an arrow. Put them together and you have a bow and arrow.
reading_story: The reading is the vocab readings, 弓 and 矢, put together. This is probably because this word is like two separate words put together, thus the "and" in the middle of the English translation.

ex_1_jp: ほとんどの日本人が誕生日にお尻を叩くなんて聞いた事がないと思うよ。
ex_1_en: I bet most Japanese people have never heard of a birthday spanking.
meaning_story: The お is just there to be nice to your butt. This word simply means butt.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 確かにTofuguは、伝統的な日本語学習業界にダブルパンチを食らわせました。
ex_1_en: Tofugu has certainly delivered a one-two punch to the traditional Japanese language learning industry.
meaning_story: This is an adverb, but it has the same meaning (basically) as the kanji. It means certain but it can also mean probable or surely.
reading_story: The reading for this one is certainly weird. To remember the reading for this word, just think how you're certain that if you stash the treasure, nobody will find it here.

ex_1_jp: 私がこの会議の議長を務めさせていただきます。
ex_1_en: I am acting as chairman of this meeting.
meaning_story: The person in charge of long discussions is the chairman, or the speaker. They also say who gets to talk and for how long.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今は会議室で寝泊まりしています。
ex_1_en: I’m staying in the conference room now.
meaning_story: A room where you meet for discussions is known as a conference room.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「穴子の握り、もう一貫頼む？」「うん！あたり前田のクラッカーだよ。」
ex_1_en: "Do you want another piece of conger eel nigiri-sushi?" "Sure. Why not?"
meaning_story: A hole child isn't some kind of creepy hole child (not sure how else to describe it). It's a conger eel, a type of tasty eel eaten in Japan. It might be easier to learn the reading first, though, and use that, because the second meaning option is anago, the Japanese word for it (also used in English).
reading_story: The reading is the two kun'yomi vocab readings combined. So, 穴 and 子 to make あなご.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「サーモン。あのさ、多分知らなかっただろうけど、高校生の頃、き、きみに夢中だったんだ。」「知ってたわよ。フグ。」
ex_1_en: "Salmon, you know, you probably didn’t know this, but back in high school, I was, um, crazy about you." "I knew, Fugu."
meaning_story: Even in the middle of your dream you're thinking about your body pillows. You're crazy about them, wrapped in absorption.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ああいう子供がそのまま大きくなるから、若者の犯罪が増えるんだよ。そう思わない？
ex_1_en: The reason crime among youth is increasing is because kids like that get bigger but don’t change. Don’t you think?
meaning_story: You have crime and you have guilt. Sounds like you did the crime.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は抜け目のない犯人にやられてしまったんだよ。私は全てを失って、犯人は指紋一つさえ残さなかったんだ。
ex_1_en: I’ve been struck by a smooth criminal. I lost everything and he didn’t even leave one fingerprint.
meaning_story: A crime person is a criminal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 2008年の世界的な金融危機では、Tofuguも経営難に陥ったのですか？
ex_1_en: Did Tofugu run into trouble during the global financial crisis of 2008?
meaning_story: A dangerous machine is walking through your town, destroying everything. This is a huge crisis!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 君に非難の目つきで見られることは予想していたけど、それでもやっぱり悲しかったんだ。
ex_1_en: I totally expected a critical look from you, but even without it, I felt sad.
meaning_story: A difficult injustice to take from someone is a criticism. Ugh, what a pain to be criticized! So difficult, and besides, it's an injustice, because I'm perfect!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私達は、洪水の被害があった地域に、今日の利益を募金としてお送りします。
ex_1_en: We are going to send in what we made from fund-raising to the area with flood damage.
meaning_story: When you incur damage you are doing damage and harm.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もう議会で決定したことなんだ。
ex_1_en: The Diet has already come to a decision.
meaning_story: The place you meet for deliberation in Japan is called the Diet. It's their version of congress.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「これはどうすればいいの？」「ロケット科学みたいに難しいものじゃあないよ。貸して。やってみせてあげるよ。」
ex_1_en: "How do I do this?" "It’s not as hard as rocket science. Give me that. Let me show you."
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of difficult? It's also difficult.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It's awfully difficult to load a cow into your Moo-zooka (むずか). Click. Boom!
pitch_accent: ムズカシイ *** ムズカシꜜイ

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あいつの顔を見るだけで、嫌悪を催す。
ex_1_en: The only thing to see on his face was hatred.
meaning_story: You dislike someone so badly that it turns to disgust and hate.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 悪 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you feel disgust for someone all you can manage to say when you see them is, "Oh... (お), it's you." Feel the anger when you see their face, "Oh, you again. Bleh."

ex_1_jp: 食事代を支払う代わりに皿洗いをすることができるラーメン屋さんが日本にあるって本当ですか？
ex_1_en: Is it true that there is a ramen restaurant in Japan where you can wash dishes to pay your bill?
meaning_story: You know the word 皿 (plate) and the word 洗う (to wash), right? You can probably guess dish washing is happening here, but this is a noun, so it's the idea of dishwashing or even a dishwasher.
reading_story: The readings are the individual vocab words (you can tell because there's a bit of hiragana stuck on there). It's the reading for 皿 and 洗う combined.

ex_1_jp: 「これ以上は安くできないよ。嫌ならやめて帰ってくれ。」 「分かったよ。買うことにするよ」
ex_1_en: "That’s my final offer. If you don’t like it stop coming back." "Alright, alright. I’ll take it."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading for this word is pretty weird. It's different than the 嫌い word you will see in this level too. It is いや, so when you think of something you dislike, just think "iyah, I dislike it." Also, think about that eww feeling it gives you when you think of the thing you dislike most.

ex_1_jp: それは大胆だね！君が本当に立入禁止って書いてる場所に入ってションベンしたなんて信じられないよ！
ex_1_en: That is wild! I can’t believe you went into a place marked "Do Not Enter" and then pissed there!
meaning_story: Standing and entering are both prohibited (禁止). If you see this sign, it's essentially saying do not enter or no entry.
reading_story: The reading for this one is weird. 立 is たち and 入 is いり. It's like you're taking the words 立つ and 入れる and stuffing their hiragana parts back into the kanji (and changing it to いり in the case of 入れる). So, that's something you'll want to try to remember. 禁止 is normal, though, so at least you have that.

ex_1_jp: 私の夢は漫画家になることです。叶うといいな。
ex_1_en: My dream is to become a manga artist. I hope it will come true.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're having this crazy dream. The dream allows you to do anything you want. Every time you ask "hey, can I do this?" The answer is always "you may" (ゆめ). Think of some things you'd want to do if you could do anything. Ask permission and get this answer in your imagination.

ex_1_jp: 「昨夜の地震について話したいんだけど。」「ぜひ聞きたいから話してよ。」
ex_1_en: "I want to talk to you about the earthquake last night." "I’ll totally listen to what you have to say."
meaning_story: An earth earthquake is just another way to say earthquake.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Notice that 地 is read as じ instead of ち. You've seen this happen a few times before, so just try to remember that this is the case here.

ex_1_jp: 日本に行く時に、2011年の東北大震災の大津波に耐えた一本の松の木を見に行きたいです。
ex_1_en: When I go to Japan, I want to see the single pine tree that withstood the giant tsunami caused by the Great Tōhoku Earthquake in 2011.
meaning_story: An earthquake disaster is just that, an earthquake disaster. These are no good.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 災 is the さい reading because *sigh* earthquakes suck man.

ex_1_jp: マグニチュードと震度って、何が違うの？
ex_1_en: What’s the difference between magnitude and earthquake scale?
meaning_story: The earthquake degrees is how you measure an earthquake. The 震度 is the earthquake intensity.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どうしていくつかの航空会社は、飛行中の電子機器の使用についての規制を緩和し始めたんでしょうか？
ex_1_en: Why did some airlines start relaxing their rules about the use of electronics during flights?
meaning_story: You have an electronic (電子) container machine. This is just a machine that contains electricity and electric parts. It is, basically, just electronic equipment. Though, you can say electronics if that's easier for you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 行列の最後尾はこちらです。
ex_1_en: The end of the line is this way.
meaning_story: You already know that 最後 means "end" so the tail end is the end of a line.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ええっ！入学試験に落ちちゃったの？
ex_1_en: What! She’s failed the entrance exam?
meaning_story: For school admission (入学) you're taking an examination (試験). What exams do you have to take to get into a school? How about entrance exams? The Japanese ones are pretty hard. Another word for them is "hell tests."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It'll also help if you know the two separate words that make up this longer word.
pitch_accent: ニューカ°クシꜜケン *** ニューカ°クシケꜜン

ex_1_jp: うまくいけば、大学の卒業論文今日中に書き終わるかなって感じ。
ex_1_en: Hopefully, I’ll finish writing my college graduation thesis today.
meaning_story: A writing of your theory is usually an essay. Remember how school teachers always wanted you to present theories in writing? These always were essays. Ugh. Essays.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「コウイチさんが存在するとは思えない…」とフグは言った。
ex_1_en: "I can’t believe Koichi exists..." Fugu said.
meaning_story: I exist, I suppose... this is the kind of existence I have. I'm not really sure either way, and I don't care. Existence is futile, I suppose.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「そうだ、結婚カウンセリングは試してみたの？」 「もちろん、とっくに経験済みだわよ。でも、うまくいかなかったわ。」
ex_1_en: "Oh! Have you tried marriage counseling yet?" "Of course. We experienced that a long time ago, but it went badly."
meaning_story: Through various tests over the passage of time, you have gained much experience. Time and testing is all it takes.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼は深夜二時に換気扇を回さずにフライパンでステーキを焼いて、火災警報装置を鳴らした。
ex_1_en: He cooked a steak in a frying pan without running the ventilation fan at 2AM and the fire alarm went off.
meaning_story: A fire disaster is a fire disaster. Maybe you'll get to meet a sexy firefighter if things go well...
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: Tofuguはどのくらいの頻度で防火訓練を実施しますか？
ex_1_en: How often does Tofugu have a fire drill?
meaning_story: Trying to prevent fire? Better get into fire prevention.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は、水害の起きやすい島で育ちました。
ex_1_en: I grew up on a flood-prone island.
meaning_story: Water damage is so bad they call it water damage. Doesn't get any clearer than this.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今日何か忘れ物をしたような気がするんだけど、それが何だったかをどうしても思い出せないんだよな。
ex_1_en: I feel like I forgot something today, but I can’t remember what it is at all.
meaning_story: Remember how 忘れる is "to forget"? Well, a thing you've forgotten is a forgotten item.
