reading_story: Since you didn't learn this reading for 忘 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. If you study this vocabulary out the wazoo わす, it'll never become a forgotten item!

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あの男は、他人の心を自在に操れる。
ex_1_en: That man can manipulate minds at will.
meaning_story: When you can exist all by yourself, then you can do things freely as you please.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 飲酒運転で有罪になるのはご免なので、運転はできません。
ex_1_en: I can’t drive because then I’d be guilty of drunk driving.
meaning_story: Someone who have (has) guilt is someone who is guilty.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: TofuguTシャツに洗濯機は使えません。手洗いをしなくてはいけません。
ex_1_en: You can’t use a washing machine for Tofugu T-shirts. You have to wash them by hand.
meaning_story: You remember how 洗う is "to wash"? Well, when you wash your hands you're doing hand washing.
reading_story: The readings are the vocab readings 手 and 洗う put together.

ex_1_jp: 私の祖母は歩くのが困難なので、今日は買い物に行くのを手伝ってあげないといけません。
ex_1_en: My grandmother has difficulty walking, so I have to help her go shopping today.
meaning_story: You're distressed and it's difficult. This is quite the hardship you're feeling.
reading_story: The reading for 困 isn't the one you learned. Just another hardship you have to deal with when it comes to vocab readings. To remember this one, just think of another hardship you have, one where Conan the Barbarian comes to your family farm on a daily basis, creating hardship by destroying things then running off.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 心配しなくていいよ。Tofuguに毒は無いから。彼は無害だよ。
ex_1_en: Don’t worry. Tofugu doesn’t have any poison. He’s harmless.
meaning_story: Psh, that guy's damage is nothing. He's what I'd call "mostly harmless."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 朝からカツ丼なんて、胸焼けしないの？
ex_1_en: Don’t you get heartburn from eating katsu-don in the morning?
meaning_story: When your chest is cooking and burning, you have what's known as heartburn.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings (hint is that there's hiragana sticking out there). So, just make sure you know the word 胸 and 焼く. If you do, you can combine that knowledge into this word, and hopefully not get any heartburn in the process.
pitch_accent: ムネヤケ *** ムネヤケꜜ *** ムナヤケ *** ムナヤケꜜ

ex_1_jp: 彼が深くて素晴らしい穴を掘るのは、持って生まれたものです。
ex_1_en: He has the natural ability to dig deep, magnificent holes.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for this word. No holes in your knowledge!

ex_1_jp: あのことがあって以来、もう二度とああいう思いをしたくないし、周りにも迷惑をかけたくないので、フグ釣りの穴場に行くことは止めました。
ex_1_en: Ever since then I’ve never wanted to have that kind of experience again, or to cause trouble for others, so I’ve stopped going to the little-known place where you can fish for fugu.
meaning_story: A hole place is what's known as a hole in the wall. This is a place that looks small, hidden and dingy, but probably has awesome food.
reading_story: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: フグ夫妻はともにとても口が達者で、近所の人達に大量の海藻を売りつけた。
ex_1_en: Mr. and Mrs. Fugu were such smooth operators that they sold tons of seaweed to their neighbors.
meaning_story: You have a husband and a wife. Combine them together and they're husband and wife.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ご存知のように、豆腐と河豚は不可分です。
ex_1_en: As we all know, Tofu and Fugu are inseparable.
meaning_story: If something is not divisible (可分), then it is indivisible.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know how to read the word 可分.

ex_1_jp: 彼女の不満は理解できたんだけど、ただ論理的に私達の問題を考えてほしかったんだよね。そしたら今度は、私がいつも誰のせいかってことを決めたがるとか言ってきて。全然そんな事ないのに。
ex_1_en: I understood her frustration, but I just wanted her to think about the issues between us logically. Then she told me that I’m always trying to find out who’s fault things are, which was not true at all.
meaning_story: Using theory and reason, you are one who uses much logic. Imagine this type of person, I bet you know at least one.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは会社用にバッティングセンターの機械を買ったの？
ex_1_en: Did Koichi buy the batting cage machine for the office?
meaning_story: A machine contraption is just a machine
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今はまだ、機を窺っているんだ。
ex_1_en: We’re still examining the machine.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: この会議の目的は、我々の現状と新しい計画についての話し合いをすることです。
ex_1_en: The purpose of this meeting is to discuss our current situation and go over new plans.
meaning_story: A place where people meet and do deliberation. Sounds boring, but also sounds like some kind of meeting or conference.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 議員バッヂを失くしてしまった。
ex_1_en: I lost my Diet member badge.
meaning_story: A discussion member talks about all the really important things that need to be discussed for the sake of the country. They are a member of the Diet. The Diet is Japan's version of congress. Diet members discuss really important matters.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうしてあいつはあんなに災難に見舞われてばかりいるのかな？本当に偶然なのか、それともあいつ自体に何か問題があるんだろうか。
ex_1_en: I wonder why misfortune is always following that guy? Is it just by chance or is there something wrong with him?
meaning_story: A disaster that is difficult is particularly difficult, making it more of a misfortune. Obviously a disaster that wasn't difficult wouldn't really be that bad, so a difficult one gets the "misfortune" or calamity label.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「彼女は朝、機嫌が悪いわね。」「ええ、全くその通りね。」
ex_1_en: "She’s in a bad mood in the morning." "Yeah, don’t I know it!"
meaning_story: Machines dislike everything. Their mood is very sour. What about your mood?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. けん gets changed to げん, though, so don't let that ruin your mood.

ex_1_jp: それぞれの部屋には、災害の場合に備えて懐中電灯とペットボトルのお水が何本か用意してあります。
ex_1_en: Each room has been prepared with flashlights and water bottles in case of a natural disaster.
meaning_story: A disaster that does damage. Usually these are natural disasters, though they could also just be regular disasters as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 太った猫になって歩けないという悪夢を見た。
ex_1_en: I had a nightmare that I became a fat cat that couldn’t walk.
meaning_story: A bad dream is also known as a nightmare. Ah! Noooooo!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「君の鼻の穴…。」「何？聞こえないわ。」「ええっと、やっぱり何でもないよ。大したことじゃないから。」「教えてくれなきゃだめよ。何を言おうとしてたの？」
ex_1_en: "Your nostril..." "What? I can’t hear you." "Well, never mind. It’s nothing." "Now you have to tell me. What were you saying?"
meaning_story: What's your nose's hole? How about your nostril?
reading_story: The reading is the readings for 鼻 and 穴. Smell that fresh air through your nose hole.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私はいつか映画のように公務執行妨害で逮捕されてみたい。
ex_1_en: Someday I want to be arrested for interfering with police officers, like in the movies.
meaning_story: Something that obstructs and also does damage is an obstruction. No obstruction is ever good and if left too long it really will cause damage and interference as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ビエトはシュークリームがとっても好きなので、毎日少なくとも一個は食べます。
ex_1_en: Viet likes cream puffs so much that he eats at least one every single day.
meaning_story: The counter 個, which means individual on its own, refers to "an individual thing." This is usually a small thing, so it's used to count small things. This word here talks about one individual. A better way to translate that would be to call it one small thing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The いち gets shortened, but I bet you knew that already.

ex_1_jp: 漢字の音訓ってすごく紛らわしいので嫌いです。
ex_1_en: The Japanese and Chinese readings for kanji are so confusing, so I hate them.
meaning_story: You've seen (hopefully) 音読み and 訓読み. This is a combination of the two. This is on'yomi and kun'yomi, aka the Chinese and Japanese readings.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 在外投票をする前に、申し込み用紙を日本大使館か日本領事館に提出する必要があります。
ex_1_en: Before casting an overseas ballot, you have to submit an application to the Japanese embassy or the Japanese consulate.
meaning_story: When you exist outside (outside of what? Japan, of course), you are overseas or abroad.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お父さんがピザの配達人であることを笑う人達もいますが、僕はお父さんのことをとても誇りに思っています。
ex_1_en: There are some people who make fun of my dad for being a pizza delivery man, but I’m very proud of him.
meaning_story: The kanji 達 pluralizes things sometimes. So, when you have a plural amount of a person you have more than one person, you have people. Take note! When using this word, you want to attach it to the type of "people" you are talking about. For example, あの人達 (those people over there). Other examples: 男の人達, その人達, 向こうの人達, etc. You don't use this by itself, instead you use it with something describing what kind of people you're talking about.
reading_story: The readings are both kun'yomi readings of the kanji. The readings come from the word 人 and the だち of 友達, though now it's たち because it hasn't been rendaku'd. You like to touch (たち) people, you perv.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの自己資本比率は100％だと思います。
ex_1_en: I guess Tofugu has a capital-to-asset ratio of 100%.
meaning_story: You compare the percent and by doing that figure out the percentage and ratio of something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 個人主義と自分勝手の違いがよく分かりません。
ex_1_en: I don’t really see the difference between being an individualist and simply being selfish.
meaning_story: In terms of an individual person... well, that's personal, and depends on the individual. Whatever it is, an individual person has personal tastes, so make sure to think of that.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: シャークは他人の災いを願っているようだね。
ex_1_en: It seems like that Shark wishes misfortune upon other people.
meaning_story: This is the noun form of disaster, though it is more like a personal disaster or personal misfortune. Just think of the arrows taking you to your own personal disaster, rather than one that everyone experiences. How nice that the disaster comes up with an iteration just for you!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When a personal disaster strikes, you start moaning and groaning. Say it along with me: "Wahhhhh! Zaahhhh! Waahhhh!" (わざわ). Be careful of the い on the end, it can be tricky and make you think it's an adjective when it's a noun.

ex_1_jp: 私の息子は、公害による呼吸器疾患に苦しんでいます。
ex_1_en: My son is suffering from a pollution-triggered respiratory illness.
meaning_story: Public damage is something that affects everyone, the whole public. What is in the air and gets into everything no matter where you are? How about pollution?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 全ての男性が一夫多妻制を支持する訳じゃない。
ex_1_en: It’s not like all men support polygamy.
meaning_story: One husband, many wives. Sounds a bit sketchy. This is polygamy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the 一 gets changed to いっ and the 夫 gets changed to ぷ from ふう for some reason. You can imagine that this is because when you are the type that has many wives, you're probably the type who makes them clean up your poo for you as well.
pitch_accent: イꜜップタサイ *** イꜜップ・タサイ

ex_1_jp: 思いついた考えは、どれも実現の可能性は無さそうでしたが、私達はそう簡単には諦めませんでした。
ex_1_en: None of the ideas we came up with sounded feasible, but we didn’t give up easily.
meaning_story: Your possible (可能) gender is one of two things. This means there's a possibility you'll either be a boy or a girl. Or maybe something else! Who knows?!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to be able to read 可能 as well.

ex_1_jp: ワニカニがベータ版から脱するよう、我々はコウイチに圧力をかけ続けなくてはいけない。
ex_1_en: We must keep the pressure on Koichi to get Wanikani out of beta.
meaning_story: The pressure power is the pressure. This can also be stress as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 日本人も10年ごとに破傷風の予防接種を受けるのですか？
ex_1_en: Do Japanese people get a tetanus vaccination every 10 years, too?
meaning_story: To prevent beforehand is still prevention.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本の通貨は、世界一優れた偽造防止技術が使われていることで知られていますが、ビエトはそれを打ち負かそうとしています。
ex_1_en: Japanese currency is known for incorporating the world’s most advanced counterfeit prevention technology, but Viet is planning to defeat it.
meaning_story: To prevent and stop someone from doing something is prevention. It's good to have prevention instead of letting something bad happen.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 忘年会に個室を予約しました。
ex_1_en: I reserved a private room for our year-end party.
meaning_story: An individual room just for you is your own private room. How nice!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ビエトはコウイチに、Tofuguが成功する確率は二百パーセントだと言いきった。
ex_1_en: Viet told Koichi that the probability of Tofugu succeeding was 200%.
meaning_story: You're certain there is this percent chance it will happen? You know that this is the probability?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 公爵夫人は静々と部屋に入って、公爵にキスをした。
ex_1_en: The duchess quietly entered the room and kissed the duke.
meaning_story: Quiet quiet! Do it quietly, please.
reading_story: You know how 静か is しずか? Well, this is the same reading as that. Say it in a whisper with me: "しずしず." Shhh!

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの読者のうち、日本語学習者はどのくらいいますか？
ex_1_en: Among Tofugu readers, how many are Japanese students?
meaning_story: The reading someone is someone who is reading. They are the reader (of a book, blog, article, etc).
reading_story: The reading for 読 is the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. This reading is どく, and you can remember it by thinking about how you are the reader, and as the reader you choose where to read. For you, the best place to read is a peaceful dock (どく). Sit on the dock and relax. Be the reader.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの顔は、実在の人物をモデルに作られたという噂があります。
ex_1_en: There’s a rumor that Tofugu’s face was modeled after a real person.
meaning_story: The truth is that you exist in reality. Well, that makes sense, I suppose.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 残余リスクの計算式を忘れてしまった。
ex_1_en: I forgot the formula to calculate residual risk.
meaning_story: The remaining surplus is the remainder or residual left over.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ビザと在留資格は別物です。
ex_1_en: A visa and status of residence are two different things.
meaning_story: The place you're detained is where you exist. As long as you're in this place, this will be your residence. Note: mainly means "residence" in the broader sense and is parts of words like "residence card" or "foreign residents."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 高等学校で教頭をしております。
ex_1_en: I’m the vice principal of a senior high school.
meaning_story: Remember when you learned that 高等 means "high class" and 学校 means "school?" Well put them together and you have senior high school! It's the most high class school you've got (unless you go to university, but that's considered to be separate). Fun fact: 高校 is the abbreviation of this word. Neat, right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 指圧をしすぎると体に良くないこともあると言う人もいます。
ex_1_en: Some people say that getting too many shiatsu massages isn’t good for you.
meaning_story: Finger pressure is nice to have. When someone puts finger pressure on you, what kind of massage is that? It's shiatsu. Perhaps if you take a look at the reading you'll be able to know this word's meaning better?
reading_story: The reading is the on'yomi reading. You've seen the on'yomi reading of 指 enough to know it is し by now, I think. So, as long as you know that you'll know how to read this word as well. Then, when you can read this word you'll notice that this means "shiatsu" as well!

ex_1_jp: コウイチは罪なき一般市民を殺害した人は雇わないと思うよ。
ex_1_en: I don’t think Koichi would hire anyone who has committed the crime of murdering innocent civilians.
meaning_story: If you have guilt then you have committed a sin or crime. Come here and confess to Father Koichi.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: When you come to confess your sin to me, you start claiming it wasn't you. You say it was some other version of you! What? How could this be? Well, you say "there are two mes (つみ) out there!" One is doing the bad stuff, and the other is you, and you haven't done any sins!

ex_1_jp: 煙いなあ！一体いつになったら煙草やめるんだよ？本当に臭いんだけど。
ex_1_en: It’s so smoky! When the heck are you going to quit smoking? This really smells awful.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of smoke? It's smoky.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: All this smokiness is from a terrible chemical (けむ) spill that happened nearby. It was acid, so it burned everything up real good, causing the air to get pretty smokey.

ex_1_jp: ニンニク臭くてごめんね。すごい臭いよね。さっきラーメン食べたんだ。
ex_1_en: Excuse my garlic breath. It smells terrible, eh? I just ate ramen.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of stinking? It's also stinking (or stinky).
reading_story: The reading you learned with the kanji can be used here, too.

ex_1_jp: 新しいパソコンとAKB48のフィギュアを買いたいが、今は余裕が無い。
ex_1_en: I’d love to buy a new computer and AKB48 figures, but I can’t afford to right now.
meaning_story: You have an abundant surplus! How nice it must be to have a surplus with so much leeway.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ビエトがコウイチにかかった殺人の嫌疑を晴らした。
ex_1_en: Viet dispelled suspicions of Koichi being a murderer.
meaning_story: I dislike him and I have doubts about him. I therefore have much suspicion against him as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どうして犬の尾を短くする習慣が産まれたのでしょうか。
ex_1_en: Why do you think the custom of shortening dog’s tails started?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You look down and you've sprouted a tail! You're so shocked that all you can say is "Oh. (お) Oh okay..." This your life now. A life with a tail.

ex_1_jp: 理論的に説明するのは苦手です。
ex_1_en: I’m bad at giving theoretical explanations.
meaning_story: You have reason behind your theory, making it a real theory (unlike those that don't have reason, I guess?).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは、厚い苔の上で休んでいる病気のミミズを見つけた。
ex_1_en: Koichi found a sick earthworm resting on some thick moss.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of thick? Also thick.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. No thick books needed to understand this reading, yeah?

ex_1_jp: チーズバーガー三個と照り焼きバーガー三個とナゲットをいくつか食べたので、今とても気持ちが悪い。
ex_1_en: After eating three cheeseburgers, three teriyaki burgers, and several nuggets, I feel really awful.
meaning_story: Three individuals is three small things. The kanji 個 can be used to count small objects, just like this! Try other numbers as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このパンはこんがりとよく焼ける。
ex_1_en: This bread toasts well.
meaning_story: You know how 焼く is to cook? Well, 焼ける is to be cooked. This is when you're not doing the actual cooking, and the cooking is just happening. Can also refer to when something burns, making it to burn as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 焼く, so just use that knowledge and apply it here to be able to read this too.

ex_1_jp: 私達の果樹園にはあり余るほどの林檎があります。
ex_1_en: There is an abundance of apples in our orchard.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surplus so the verb version would be to be in surplus or to remain left over. Too much!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "I have a surplus of kittens from that last batch we made, Reddit. AMA (ask me anything, あま)."

ex_1_jp: ビエトはミスを犯すことなどない。ビエトに不可能は無い。
ex_1_en: Viet is incapable of making mistakes. For Viet, nothing is impossible.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means crime so the verb vocab version would be to commit a crime (because you don't just "to crime," right?).
reading_story: You go to commit a crime. How did it go, you think? Well, I thought it went okay (おか). Imagine yourself committing a crime and it going just okay. Not great, not bad... meh. Okay.

ex_1_jp: 意見を言っただけなのに、上司に「文句するな」と怒鳴られました。
ex_1_en: I was just saying my opinion, but my boss yelled, "don’t complain," at me.
meaning_story: You know how 文句 is a complaint, right? Well, add する to make it a verb and you have to complain. This is a really casual way to complain though, usually used in manga or on social media. Keep your eye out for it!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このダウンジャケットは、寒さをとってもよく防いでくれますよ。
ex_1_en: This down jacket will really protect you from the cold.
meaning_story: You're doing a prevention. When you prevent something, what are you really doing? You're trying to defend against something from happening. That's why this verb is a little weird and means to defend or to protect against. It can also be to prevent, too, but just make sure you're thinking of it more like you're defending something with your prevention.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to defend yourself? You should probably put out that fuse (ふせ) attached to that giant bomb first then.

ex_1_jp: 色々と振り回してごめんなさい。嫌なやつと思ってるかもしれないけど、嫌いにならないで。
ex_1_en: I’m sorry to cause so many problems. You may think I’m unpleasant, but please don’t hate me.
meaning_story: You dislike something. This is one of those weird words in Japanese where it's an adjective in Japanese but in English it's a verb but in Japanese it's treated like a verb and omegad I just confused you didn't I? Anyways, you'll learn to dislike this word because even though it looks like an adjective we're going to treat it like it's a verb by making it "to dislike" with a "to" and everything.
reading_story: Of all the things out there to dislike the thing I dislike the most is the killer (きら) of people. People should never kill people.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの最新のEブックは、飛ぶように売れています。
ex_1_en: Tofugu’s latest e-book is flying off the shelves.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fly so the verb vocab version is to fly.
reading_story: When you try to fly, the main thing holding you back is your toe (と). It's like forty pounds and holds you down.

ex_1_jp: コウイチ先生：よし、もう一度いきむ準備はいいかい？君は双子の赤ちゃんを産むんだよ！ サーモン：もう一人生んだじゃない。放っておいてよ。 フグ：大丈夫、大丈夫。頑張れ、サーモン！君ならできるよ！
ex_1_en: Dr. Koichi: Okay. You ready to push again? You are going to have twins! Salmon: I already gave birth to one baby. Leave me alone. Fugu: Okay, okay, come on, you can do it. You can do it!
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give birth so the verb vocab version is to give birth. PUSH. PUSSHHH! You know another 産む as well (生む). This 産む is more sciency, but both are good to know.
reading_story: You know another "to give birth" word (生む). Guess what!? They share readings!

ex_1_jp: 日曜日、僕は父と一緒に木を何本か切り倒した後、それを叩き切って薪にしました。
ex_1_en: My dad and I cut down some trees and chopped them up for logs this Sunday.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means overthrow or collapse. This is when you are doing those things to something else. If you do, you're going to knock over whatever it is you're trying to knock over.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You use the power of the Tao (たお) to do all of your knocking down. Imagine yourself contemplating Tao philosophy, then using those pleasant thoughts to knock everything over around you. BLAM!

ex_1_jp: どうして人々は宇宙人が地球にやってくる事を妨げようとするのか理解できません。
ex_1_en: I don’t understand why people try preventing aliens from reaching the earth.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means obstruct, so what is the verb vocab version? It's to obstruct.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your woman friend (see radical) is trying to obstruct you. "Sama(n)tha!" (さまた) you yell. "Let me pass!"

ex_1_jp: 「あいつら、幸せな結婚生活を送れると思う？」「時間が経てばわかるよ。」
ex_1_en: "Do you think they will have a happy marriage?" "Time will tell."
meaning_story: You know how 経 means passage of time, right? Well, this is the verb form of that. What does time do when it passages? It passes. So, this verb means to pass or to expire.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you say to time as it begins to pass you by? "Ta ta (た), Time!"

ex_1_jp: 大阪で雨の日に、中年のおばさんがビニール袋を被りながら自転車に乗っているのを見たことがあります。
ex_1_en: On a rainy day in Osaka, I saw a middle aged woman wearing a plastic bag on her head while riding a bicycle.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means incur so you'd think this would mean "to incur," but it doesn't. This is to put a hat on. Yep, it's the verb that's made for putting on hats. So, think of it this way. You "incur" a hat when you go to put on a hat. Pretty weird but you'll get it if you put on your thinking cap.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The hat that you put on is none other than a hat made from a bear cub (かぶ). The mother bear comes for you and takes it back the hard way.

ex_1_jp: 私の言ったことを覚えておいて。あのフグ少年はきっと面倒を引き起こすわよ。
ex_1_en: Mark my words. That Fugu boy is going to cause trouble.
meaning_story: When you're looking straight into the face of a collapse it means trouble and difficulty coming soon.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The とう goes to どう, though. Agh, what a 面倒.

ex_1_jp: 他人の事情に首を突っ込むのは、まったく余計なお世話だってことは分かっていたんですが、つい好奇心に負けてしまいました。
ex_1_en: I knew it wasn’t really my business to be sticking my nose in other people’s affairs, but curiosity got the better of me.
meaning_story: I've measured the surplus and it's all unneeded and more than enough. Maybe we should get rid of all this surplus?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: この防水ブーツ、防水されているとはとても言えないな。この辺りを歩いてるだけで、足がビショビショになっちゃったよ。
ex_1_en: These waterproof boots are far from being waterproof. My feet got soaking wet from just walking around here.
meaning_story: Something that prevents water is waterproof and watertight. Time to take a bath with my 防水 cell phone...
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 僕の両親はド金持ちって訳じゃないけど、比較的裕福な方ではあります。
ex_1_en: My parents are not super rich but they are relatively wealthy.
meaning_story: You have such abundant luck! When you have abundant luck, most people probably would think you also have a lot of wealth, because lots of wealth equals lots of luck, right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ユꜜーフク *** ユーフク

ex_1_jp: 天気予報は見事に外れた。
ex_1_en: The weather forecast was crazy off.
meaning_story: This is a combination of the words 天気, meaning "weather," and 予報 meaning "forecast." Put them together and you get the weather forecast!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 元妻が、「私みたいな女にはもう巡り合わないわよ」とか言うんだけどさ…っていうか、それが俺の計画なんですけど、みたいな？
ex_1_en: My ex-wife says, "You’ll never find someone like me." Well, exactly! That’s the plan!
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is used to refer to your own wife, though, for the most part.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your wife does everything for you. She feeds you, she bathes you, she cleans up after you and even wipes your butt when you poop. Really, she is doing too much (つま), and you should stop being a baby.

ex_1_jp: 新しい支店に転勤になって、やる気満々だよ〜。イイ男探しを日課に頑張ってます。妻子持ちだろうが関係ないかんね。笑
ex_1_en: Now that I’ve been transferred to the new branch store, I’m feeling really motivated. Working hard to find a good man has become one of my daily routines. I don’t care whether he has a wife and kids, you know? lol
meaning_story: You have your wife and you have your child. These are your wife and kids.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私達はコウイチをすごく頼りにしていますが、どうしていつもそんなに陽気にしてるのか不思議にも思っています。
ex_1_en: We all depend on Koichi, but we also wonder why he seems so oddly cheerful all the time.
meaning_story: This is not what you thought would happen during your deliberation. You thought it would be very normal. Instead, it's the opposite. It's full of wonder and mystery.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今現在、実際にTofuguは何名の顧客を抱えているのですか？
ex_1_en: How many clients does Tofugu actually have at the moment?
meaning_story: On this occasion it is the truth. It actually, really is the truth.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The つ is shortened to っ.

ex_1_jp: コウイチの写真は、火星で干ばつと大恐慌の犠牲となった宇宙人たちを正直に、かつ同情を込めてとらえている。
ex_1_en: Koichi’s photographs honestly and sympathetically portrays aliens who were victims of drought and the Great Depression on Mars.
meaning_story: You know how 宇宙 is space? Well, a person from space is an alien.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help to know how to read the word 宇宙 on its own, too.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 電気分解の分解効率を向上させることはできる、お父さん？
ex_1_en: Can you improve the decomposition efficiency of electrolysis, dad?
meaning_story: Take all the separate parts. Now untie them, unraveling the connections between the two parts. In this way we can do our analysis and breakdown.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 分かっていると思うけど、油断大敵だよ。「猿も木から落ちる」って言うだろう？
ex_1_en: As you all know, overconfidence is man’s greatest enemy. People say "even monkeys fall from trees," right?
meaning_story: Your big enemy is your worst enemy. Your arch enemy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: フェミニストの中には、生理中に血を垂れ流しにすることが女性の権利だと主張する人まで出てきました。
ex_1_en: Some feminists started claiming that free-bleeding during their period is a women’s right.
meaning_story: You have rights to profit! This is a right you have!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 我々は、お客様に総体的に満足して頂けるよう努力しています。
ex_1_en: We are concentrating on the overall satisfaction of our customers.
meaning_story: With the whole body. Do it as a whole instead of as a part, or something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ビエトさん、あなたが暴走族をしていた頃のエピソードについて、早急にお返事いただけると幸いです。
ex_1_en: Mr. Viet, I would be grateful if you could reply as soon as possible about your time spent in a biker gang.
meaning_story: A tribe that runs wild (暴走) is what the Japanese call a biker gang. Just imagine them riding around on their bikes, running wild. They're also close, like a family. How nice!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その本についての批判的な書評があまりにも多いので、買う気が失せたよ。
ex_1_en: There were so many critical reviews of a book I was thinking of reading that I lost my desire to buy it.
meaning_story: A writing that has been evaluated has gotten a book review.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: こんな得体の知れないもの、食べられないよ。
ex_1_en: I can’t eat something so strange.
meaning_story: With time your body will acquire a certain type of character. It shows your true nature as a person.
reading_story: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: 北米でギョウ虫検査があまり一般的ではないなんて、驚きです。
ex_1_en: I was surprised that pinworm tests aren’t commonly administered in North America.
meaning_story: We're going to need to examine and inspect you for our annual checkup, mmk? Now drop your pants and cough, please.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: レースを布地にたたきつける。
ex_1_en: I stitched lace into cloth.
meaning_story: Cloth from the earth is still cloth, just a little dirty.
reading_story: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: 愛してるよ、ソファー。お前だけは俺のことを理解してくれる。
ex_1_en: I love you, sofa. Only you understand me.
meaning_story: I've untied all the reason and made it even simpler, making it easier to understand. This increases my comprehension and understanding by quite a bit!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 母は、フグと私がこのアール・デコ様式の建物に引っ越すよう強制しました。
ex_1_en: My mother forced Fugu and I to move into this historic art-deco property.
meaning_story: They have strong control over us. That's why they can make us do all this compulsory stuff. We have to do it. They're too strong!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: フグ、金曜の夜の飲み会に行ってもいいけど、一つだけ条件があるわ。お酒は飲まないでね。
ex_1_en: Fugu, you can go to the drinking party on Friday night, but on one condition - you can’t drink alcohol.
meaning_story: A clause in the matter complicates things. It adds conditions, terms and requirements to an otherwise simple matter.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ジョーケꜜン *** ジョーケン

ex_1_jp: 確認画面が出たらIDとパスワードを入力してログインをしてください。
ex_1_en: When the confirmation screen shows up, please enter your ID and password to login.
meaning_story: Just be sure to make certain that you recognize him. We need confirmation and verification, so make certain again, please.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の両親は、二人とも教師で、めちゃくちゃ古風な保守主義者です。
ex_1_en: My parents are both teachers and extremely old-fashioned conservatives.
meaning_story: Those who want to protect and conserve, and those who are the master of righteousness. They are the conservatives (or, at least, that's how they describe themselves). This also is similar to 保守的, which also means conservative.
reading_story: This word uses the reading of 保守的 for the first half and then the regular kanji readings for the second half. Combine those things and you'll be a master of righteousness and / or kanji.

ex_1_jp: 私はかつて古代ローマが建設された丘の近くに住んでいた。
ex_1_en: I used to live near the hills on which the ancient city of Rome was built.
meaning_story: Build and establish. To do this, you'll need to do lots of construction.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチには内緒にしておいて、正解だったね。
ex_1_en: We were right about keeping it a secret from Koichi.
meaning_story: It is correct you have solved the answer, getting the correct answer. You'll see this on Japanese game shows a lot. 正解！！！
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 暴力団と関東連合の違いは何ですか？
ex_1_en: What’s the difference between the Yakuza and Kanto RENGO?
meaning_story: A group that has power using violence? Sounds like some kind of crime syndicate to me.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 批判の的となっても仕方がないと思っている。
ex_1_en: Sometimes you can’t help but be the subject of criticism.
meaning_story: A criticism is when you judge. It is still just a criticism.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 映画の中で十歳の女の子が評論をしているのが可愛いのよね。
ex_1_en: It’s so cute to see a ten year old girl make a critique in a movie.
meaning_story: Evaluate my theory. Then, when you evaluate, please give me critique and criticism to help me get better?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ビエトはあまりにも怒っていたので、コウイチを殴って「いい加減にしろ！」と叫ばずにはいられなかった。
ex_1_en: Viet was so angry that he couldn’t restrain himself from punching Koichi and screaming, "Cut it out!"
meaning_story: You know how いい加減 is unfounded or pointless? Because if you add and then decrease you haven't really done anything? Well, this is like saying "do the pointless!" Okay, that doesn't make any sense. This is a phrase that means something similar to cut it out or cut the BS!
reading_story: The reading is the same as いい加減, which you (hopefully) learned earlier.

ex_1_jp: スパムメールの定義は何ですか？
ex_1_en: What’s the definition of spam mail?
meaning_story: Please determine what righteousness means. I want the definition for it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 任務完了前に撤退することは許されないとコウイチに言われました。
ex_1_en: Koichi told me that I’m not allowed to leave before the job is done.
meaning_story: You have a duty. You have a task. You have both a duty and a task to do.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチが大統領に就任してからというもの、アメリカの経済は急ピッチで回復している。
ex_1_en: Since Koichi was inaugurated as President, the US economy has continued to recover at a rapid pace.
meaning_story: When a passage of time comes to an end, you look back on it and see how well you did. Did we make more money? Did we make less? That's all economics, baby (that's money, baby!).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The さい changes to ざい, though, so watch out for that.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: コウイチは、選挙演説中にブルースを歌って声がつぶれた。
ex_1_en: Koichi lost his voice from singing the blues during his election speech.
meaning_story: You have to choose someone and raise them up to office. This is an election.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「フグ、あなたはどっちの味方なの？私の敵なの？」「僕は君の味方だよ、サーモン。」
ex_1_en: "Which side are you on, Fugu? Are you my enemy?" "I’m on your side, Salmon."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. No enemies here!

ex_1_jp: 私のパスポートに上陸許可の判子を押してくれた入国審査官は、コウイチにそっくりでした。
ex_1_en: The immigration inspector, who stamped my passport with the landing permission seal, looked just like Koichi.
meaning_story: I will judge and inspect you. This is an examination, so we'll see if you pass.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あの先生の解説はとても分かり易いね。
ex_1_en: The teacher’s explanation is really easy to understand.
meaning_story: When you untie a theory for someone, you're taking it apart and making it more understandable to them. You are doing an explanation of something for them.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この地域は昔はスラム街でしたが、政府の戦略としての居住地域の高級化が功を奏し、住環境ががらっと変わったんですよ。今は評判もすこぶるいいです。
ex_1_en: This area used to be a slum, but the governmental strategy of gentrification has changed the neighborhood and now it has a really good reputation.
meaning_story: When people evaluate and judge you at every turn, it means you have much fame and reputation. Wouldn't this be terrible if people evaluated and judged you 24/7? Having that kind of fame would be difficult.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はん changes to ばん, too, so be careful of that.

ex_1_jp: 日本語で、屋内の履き物は「上履き」、屋外の履き物は「外履き」と呼ばれます。
ex_1_en: In Japanese, indoor footwear is called "uwabaki" and outdoor footwear is called "sotobaki."
meaning_story: You know how 履く is to put on shoes or put on boots, right? Well, what are those things called? How about footwear or shoes?
reading_story: The reading is that of 履く and 物 put together. Just know those separately and you should be able to figure this one out as well.

ex_1_jp: ベンチャー・キャピタル、いわゆる冒険資本が不足するには、訳があります。
ex_1_en: There’s a reason for the venture capital shortage.
meaning_story: The main resources are the funds and capital we're getting. Everything else can be gotten using said funds, which is why they're the main resources we have!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 資金が底をつき始めたときに、パリでホテル代を払ってくれるというあの素晴らしいお方にお会いしたのです。
ex_1_en: When we started running out of funds, we met a wonderful person in Paris who offered to pay for our hotel bills.
meaning_story: The resources of gold that we have are our current funds. If the resources include a lot of gold, then we have a lot of funds. If they don't, then we don't have a lot of funds.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の猫は立派な髯を生やしているので、「ヒゲ」と名付けました。
ex_1_en: My cat grew very handsome whiskers, so I named him Hige.
meaning_story: The sect that stands the highest are those who are high class, splendid, and fine. 立派だ!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The りつ shortens to りっ though, so keep an eye on that you splendid frood you. Oh and は changes to ぱ too. Because rendaku and all that.

ex_1_jp: 服装規定が人権侵害にあたることがあるという人もいますが、それについてどう思いますか？
ex_1_en: Some people say that dress codes can violate human rights, what do you think about that?
meaning_story: People Rights are human rights.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この「盗まれたコウイチの下着」事件について、できるだけ早く報告してください。
ex_1_en: Get back to me as soon as possible about the incident regarding Koichi’s stolen underwear.
meaning_story: An action matter is really just something that happens. It's an incident or case.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お正月に餅を食べ過ぎて、体重が五十キロも増加した。
ex_1_en: I ate way too much mochi on New Years and my weight increased 50 kilos.
meaning_story: An increase will add to what you had before. This is an increase, addition, or growth.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは国際会議でTofuguの開発成果について発表する予定です。
ex_1_en: Koichi is going to announce the development of Tofugu at an international conference.
meaning_story: You have an occasion to check out another country. Wow, so international!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: リスクの高い投資商品にまで手を出したくはないんです。
ex_1_en: I don’t want to get involved in high risk investments.
meaning_story: Go ahead and throw your resources at the project. It could use the investment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well, but since you didn't learn the on'yomi for "throw" before, here's a little mnemonic to help you out. You're building Tokyo (とう) Tower. You need to throw resources at it to make Tokyo Tower grow!

ex_1_jp: フグは肉を食べないよ。菜食主義者だからさ。
ex_1_en: Fugu doesn’t eat meat. He’s a vegetarian.
meaning_story: The master of righteousness is into every ism there is. Buddhism, Shintoism, socialism, communism, you name it. That's why he's the master of righteousness. No matter what, he's righteous about whatever you are because he's something else!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の母はいつも人を見た目で判断してはいけないと言っていたのに、父が禿げたことだけを理由に父と離婚しました。
ex_1_en: My mom always told me not to judge people by their appearance, but she divorced my father just because he went bald.
meaning_story: I judge to cut off your head. That is my judgement!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ハꜜンダン *** ハンダꜜン

ex_1_jp: 私は審判でもあり、スポーツ解説者でもあります。
ex_1_en: I’m not only a referee, but also a sports analyst.
meaning_story: This word has judge and judge in it, so it has something to do with judgment. It's usually used in sports, so it's the referee or umpire, depending on your sport of choice.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: シンパン *** シꜜンパン

ex_1_jp: Tofuguチームは正義の味方です。
ex_1_en: Team Tofugu takes the side of justice.
meaning_story: The correct righteousness is always your righteousness. It is your form of justice.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 先輩が就職活動の心得を教えてくれました。
ex_1_en: My senpai passed on his knowledge about job hunting.
meaning_story: What does your heart want to acquire above all other things? Knowledge! That's why you're here isn't it? Dig deep and see that all your heart wants is more information and understanding of Japanese to be happy.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ココロꜜエ *** ココロエꜜ

ex_1_jp: 彼の他の人を助けたいっていう熱意が、素敵だなって思うのよね。
ex_1_en: I find him attractive because of his enthusiasm for helping others.
meaning_story: The element of enemy isn't something you should think of as bad. You have to have the "enemy element" if you are to have lovely, dreamy, and beautiful things too. This is a good word when you're talking about some dude you think is hawt. Doesn't work as well with girls.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もしよろしければ、いくつか資料をお送りさせて頂けませんでしょうか？
ex_1_en: If you don’t mind, would I be able to send you some data?
meaning_story: The material you use to make resources is still material.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 風紀委員は、保健体育の授業で教師が夢精について生徒たちに教える必要は無いと判断した。
ex_1_en: The school’s disciplinary committee decided that teachers don’t need to teach students about wet dreams in the physical education class anymore.
meaning_story: A committee member is a member of a committee (or a committee member).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ビエト財務省国際局次長は現在ダイエット中であり、砂糖の代わりにサッカリンを用いているため、彼の食事には砂糖を使用しないでください。
ex_1_en: Mr. Viet, Senior Deputy Director General, International Bureau, Ministry of Finance, is on a diet right now and substitutes sugar with saccharin, so don’t use sugar in his meal.
meaning_story: Let us conserve our tasks. We will give it to the Ministry Of Tasks!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今日の授業は形容動詞でした。
ex_1_en: Today’s class was on na-adjectives.
meaning_story: A 形容詞 is an adjective. So what about an adjective with a 動詞 (verb) in there? How does that make sense? I'm not entirely sure either, but an adjective with movement in it is a na adjective. These are the adjectives that can end with な (便利な, for example). In fact, they're more like nouns than they are verbs, so what gives? Whatever it is, just decide you don't want to deal with this craziness. Just say nah, I don't care about this anymore.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 形容詞 and 動詞 as well, since they're both parts of this word.

ex_1_jp: 家事をするのは、夫と子どもに対する妻の義務だと言う人が多くいますが、果たしてそれは本当でしょうか？
ex_1_en: Many people say that doing housework is a wife’s obligation to her husband and children, but is that really true?
meaning_story: My righteousness task is my obligation to these people. I will go out and purge the world of evil, be righteous, and make things happen. It's my duty!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 当社トフグの事務所を簡単にご案内させてください。
ex_1_en: Let me quickly show you around the Tofugu office.
meaning_story: The place where actions and tasks happen is the office. None of that happens at home. The office is more of an action / task place.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 岡山県には、土地特有の建築物はありますか？
ex_1_en: Is there any vernacular architecture in Okayama prefecture?
meaning_story: Okayama (岡山) Prefecture is a prefecture in Japan. Learning the reading will help you to remember the meaning of this word since half of it is in Japanese.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the first two kanji. Luckily you learned them when you learned the kanji. Then, stick 県 on there and you should be good to go!

ex_1_jp: この書類には、コウイチによって公的な判子が押されています。
ex_1_en: This document was officially sealed by Koichi.
meaning_story: The child of a judge is the thing he puts on his judgements. What does he put on his judgments? His seal, you know, to make it all official and stuff.
reading_story: 判 is the reading you learned. 子 is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which I bet you know pretty well by now as well. You just have to remember to use it here.

ex_1_jp: あいつほど楽天主義なやつはいない。
ex_1_en: There isn’t a more optimistic guy than him.
meaning_story: You know that 主義 is "-ism." If you add that to being comfortable like you're in heaven then you have lots of optimism. You're sure you'll be okay in any situation!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 名前と住所は法律で答えなくてはいけないと決まっているものですか？それとも任意ですか？
ex_1_en: Do I legally have to tell you my name and address, or is it optional?
meaning_story: My idea of duty is that you don't really have to do it. It's optional, you know?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: オリンピックの総合メダル獲得数では、アメリカが一位だった。
ex_1_en: America got first place in overall total medals in the Olympics.
meaning_story: When you take the whole and join it together, you get a good overall picture of things.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 合 reading is the on'yomi reading which you didn't learn with the kanji, but you've seen it so much by now that hopefully it's just as easy to recall if not easier, now.

ex_1_jp: 映画好きのパーティーの最年長参加者は、なんと百歳だった。
ex_1_en: Surprisingly, the oldest participant of the moviegoer party was 100 years old.
meaning_story: You know that 参加 is participation, so someone who does participation is a participant.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 初めまして。私は経営企画部部長のコウイチと申します。
ex_1_en: Nice to meet you. I am Koichi, the head of project management.
meaning_story: Take your plan and make a drawing out of it. This is your plan.
reading_story: The かく reading was not the one you learned with the kanji. It is an exception that was introduced with the word 計画 not long back. Just keep that in mind and you'll be fine.

ex_1_jp: 警察官が容疑者を発見した際、男は丘の上で美しい風景画を描いていました。
ex_1_en: When the police officer found the suspect, he was painting a beautiful landscape on a hilltop.
meaning_story: The police (警察) government is full of police officers. This is a nice way to say "police officer." Don't confuse it with 警察署, though.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ケイサツꜜカン *** ケイサꜜツカン

ex_1_jp: Tofugu.comは総理大臣賞を受賞した。
ex_1_en: Tofugu.com won the Prime Minister’s Prize.
meaning_story: He's the whole reason this country is still running. If it wasn't for the prime minister here we'd all be doomed I say. DOOMED!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 誰だって面倒な手続きは避けたい。
ex_1_en: Everybody wants to avoid troublesome formalities.
meaning_story: Someone takes your hand and shows you how to continue. "This is the procedure," they say. Move your hand like this. Verrrryyy goood. Good procedure. Good!
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of 手 and 続く put together into one. Darn these body parts making everything kun'yomi.

ex_1_jp: しりとりに固有名詞は使えません。
ex_1_en: You can’t use proper nouns in the game Shiritori.
meaning_story: A noun (名詞) that has hardness is a noun that can't be budged. It's a big noun, so big that you have to capitalize these kinds of nouns in English. It is a proper noun.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 名詞 as well.

ex_1_jp: もし沖縄を旅行するなら、牧志公設市場に行った方がいいよ。
ex_1_en: If you travel to Okinawa, you should go to Makishi Public Market.
meaning_story: It's public establishment. It is public.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 一流の資格を持っていたって、食いっぱぐれることはあるさ。
ex_1_en: You can have the best qualifications and still lose the ability to make a living.
meaning_story: The credible resources that determine your professional status are your qualifications. You need some good ones if you want to get into a good school or land a sweet job.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: このレストランでは、素材そのものの味を楽しんでもらうために味付けは控えめにしています。
ex_1_en: In this restaurant, seasoning is kept to a minimum for you to enjoy the natural taste of the ingredients.
meaning_story: The element of lumber is to be a raw material for building big things. It's the basic of what you need to build a building in the old days.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 素 is the そ reading, so be careful. You can remember by thinking how you have to sew the building together using these raw materials.

ex_1_jp: 反省しているので、そんなにきつく当たらないでください。
ex_1_en: I’ve been reflecting on it, so please don’t be so hard on me.
meaning_story: Now you're anti conserve. You're the opposite now, in fact. You've done some heavy reconsideration and reflection to realize you ought to conserve less.
reading_story: The reading for 反 is all good. The reading for 省 is an exception, however. Who made you go through a reconsideration process about your ways? None other than the venerable Hard Gay. "Sei (せい), sei, sei!!"

ex_1_jp: 日本のサラリーマンは責任を取る事を嫌がる傾向にある。
ex_1_en: Japanese salarymen tend to hate taking responsibility.
meaning_story: You can blame duty all you want, but you still have a responsibility as well, no matter what your duty dictates.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私としては、断然フランボワイヤン様式の方が良かったんですが、そこはまぁ自制しています。
ex_1_en: I definitely prefer flamboyant styles, but I practice self restraint.
meaning_story: Self control is self control and self restraint. Have some!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 義理の父に義理チョコを買いました。
ex_1_en: I bought an obligatory box of chocolates for my father in law.
meaning_story: You have righteousness and then a reason behind it, at least in your own mind. This is your sense of duty. And it really is a "sense" in a way, too. You just feel it. It's not an actual thing that is tangible. It is your own personal reason for this righteousness.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ドレスが派手すぎるので、ブライズ・メイドには絶対なりたくありません。
ex_1_en: I never want to be a bridesmaid because the dresses are too flashy.
meaning_story: This is a weird one. Just think about the sect of hands. They are always doing jazz hands and things like that, trying to be all showy and flashy. Ugh, what a dumb sect, you think.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, though て goes to で.

ex_1_jp: 小さい頃、友人達と毎日水際で遊んでいました。
ex_1_en: When I was little, I would play by the water’s edge every day with my friends.
meaning_story: Even though the kanji mainly means occasion, for some reason this word means side or edge. I suppose on occasion kanji takes you to the edge of what ought to make sense when it comes to kanji.
reading_story: You're on the very edge of the world. You heard that at the edge of the world are the key words (きわ) written there in big fiery letters, telling you the meaning of life. Supposedly these are the words of God himself. They say: "We apologize for the inconvenience." WHAT? THESE ARE THE KEY WORDS???

ex_1_jp: トフグの株式を上場させる前に、解決しなければならない難題がまだ山積みになっている。
ex_1_en: Before taking Tofugu public, many difficult problems that have been piling up have to be solved.
meaning_story: To solve the problem we decided to come up with a solution.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 十六台の宇宙船のほとんど全てが、保持され改装されました。
ex_1_en: Nearly all of the sixteen space ships were retained and refurbished.
meaning_story: You know how 宇宙 is outer space and how 船 is ship, right? Well, put those together and you have an outer space ship (better known as a space ship).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 宇宙 beforehand as well.

ex_1_jp: 振り付け師になるのが夢だという子どもが、急増しています。
ex_1_en: The number of children who dream of being a choreographer has increased suddenly.
meaning_story: An increase that hurries is an increase that's quick. How about a sudden increase?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その容疑者は、どういう訳か十代の若者たちに大志と楽観主義のメッセージを伝えた。
ex_1_en: The suspect somehow conveyed a message of ambition and optimism to teenagers.
meaning_story: I have a suspicion (容疑) about someone. That someone is my main suspect.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to be able to read 容疑 first, though.

ex_1_jp: これは、新制度についての初心者向け案内書です。
ex_1_en: This guidebook for the new system is intended for beginners.
meaning_story: You control every degree of this system. Think about a system. It's designed to create more control for you, degree by degree by degree. That's why they call it "The system," after all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の両親があなたを養子縁組したのは、ただ税金の控除を受けたかったのが理由です。
ex_1_en: My parents only adopted you because they needed the tax deduction.
meaning_story: The tax gold is what you have to pay when you have to pay a tax.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お酒が無税だったらいいのにな。
ex_1_en: I wish alcohol was tax-free.
meaning_story: When the tax is nothing things are tax free.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: さっき届いた請求書の固定資産税が、50%も増税されてたんだけど、間違いだよね。そうであってほしい。
ex_1_en: I just received a 50% increase on my property tax, but it’s a mistake. At least, I hope it is.
meaning_story: When you increase tax you're doing a tax increase.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もしここにコウイチがいたら、こんな数学の問題五秒で解けちゃうよ。コウイチにとってはちょちょいのちょいだね。
ex_1_en: If Koichi was here, he would be able to solve this math problem in five seconds. It’s a piece of cake for him.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means untie so the verb vocab version is to become untied. You know that this is the version where something just unties on its own (you're not doing the untying) because you don't have a care (ける) in the world. You just watch things getting untied and don't do it yourself.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In fact, while you're sitting there with no cares, waiting for things to become untied, you stare down at your toe (と). Really imagine doing that while things around you are getting untied.

ex_1_jp: 君はおそらく混乱すると思うけど、弟は今、死への恐怖を克服しようと必死で努力しているところなの。だから、そっとしておいてあげてくれないかな？
ex_1_en: You’re probably confused, but my brother is striving to overcome his fear of death right now, so please leave him alone.
meaning_story: If 混乱 is confusion then making it into a verb would cause it to be to be confused.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 混乱 so no reason for you to be confused, right?

ex_1_jp: 電車は毎日混みますが、あなたのせいではありません。自分を責める必要はありませんよ。
ex_1_en: The train is crowded every morning, but it’s not your fault. There’s no need to blame yourself.
meaning_story: This one is a little strange. You have 混じる (to get mixed up in), 混ぜる (to mix), 混ざる (to get mixed), and now this: 混む, to be crowded. It makes sense that when everyone's all mixed up it's going to be crowded, but how to differentiate between this and the other 混 words? Just think of how Cows (muuuuu) get all bunched up and crowded, which is why this word is to be crowded.
reading_story: Hey, come (こむ) out of that crowd of cows. It's going to be crowded in there.

ex_1_jp: 「自分でちゃんと確かめるべきだったよ。」「そんなに自分を責めないで。あなたのせいじゃないわよ。」
ex_1_en: "I should have checked it out myself." "Don’t blame yourself. It wasn’t your fault."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blame so this is to blame.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You say (せ) I did it. I say you did it. Everyone is going to blame everyone, apparently!

ex_1_jp: 謝ったんだけど、「これは謝って済む問題じゃない」なんて言われちゃって、それで頭にきて彼の顔をひっぱたいちゃったのよね。
ex_1_en: I apologized, but he told me that apologizing wouldn’t end the problem, and because of that, I slapped him in the face.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means come to an end so the verb vocab version is to come to an end.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your romp finally has to come to an end when someone decides to sue (す) you for all your romping.

ex_1_jp: 一日中寝続けられるので、週末は最高だ。
ex_1_en: Weekends are awesome because I can continue to sleep all day long.
meaning_story: This is like 続く except for now you're the one doing the continuing. Unfortunately, there's no good way to differentiate the two "continues" using just the meaning, but you can think of it this way: With ける, you really care about continuing this thing so you are continuing it (doing the action of continuing). With く you're just like "that's coo' if it continues, but I don't really care...
reading_story: The reading is the same as 続く, so be sure to know that so you can know this.

ex_1_jp: その疫病は、河豚の数をそれまでの水準の半分に減らした。
ex_1_en: The plague reduced the number of blowfish to half its previous level.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decrease so the verb vocab version is to decrease. You can differentiate this from 減る because with this one, you are the one that is going to be doing the decreasing. The rush (らす) of decreasing something fills your veins.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 減る, so if you know that reading you should know this one.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは、新しい従業員規則を設けることを検討しているようです。
ex_1_en: Koichi often considers establishing new rules for his employees.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means establish so the verb vocab version is to establish.
reading_story: What are you going to establish? How about a new bar in Springfield called Mooe's (もう). You had to add that extra "o" in there because "Moe's" was already taken. Do'h!

ex_1_jp: あなたの新しいビジネス用のメールアカウントを、グーグルに設定しました。
ex_1_en: I set up a new business mail account in google for you.
meaning_story: When you establish and determine something, you are making an establishment. When you make that into a verb, you have the word to establish.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Careful because the 設 gets shortened to せっ.

ex_1_jp: 悪魔からのメッセージは偽りだが、我々を混乱させるために嘘と真実が入り混じっている。
ex_1_en: The message from the demon is a lie, but he will mix lies with the truth to confuse us.
meaning_story: This one is a little strange. You have 混む (To Be Crowded), 混ぜる (to mix), 混ざる (to get mixed), and now this: 混じる, To Get Mixed Up In. It makes sense because it has to do with mixing, but how to differentiate from the rest? Well, for this one just imagine Jesus (じ) getting mixed up in a pot of soup. He's getting mixed up in this giant pot of soup because someone thinks that if they eat him, they'll gain his powers.
reading_story: The reading is the same as (almost) all the other 混 verbs. All about mamamamama!

ex_1_jp: ここ5年間、ビエトの一日当たりの飲酒量が増えてきています。
ex_1_en: Over the past five years, Viet’s daily amount of alcohol has been increasing.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means increase, so the vocabulary verb version means to increase. This is when something is just increasing on its own, and you're not doing the increasing. You know this because you like to err (える) on the side of caution and not touch anything when it's increasing, therefore you're not doing any of the increasing yourself (it's just happening).
reading_story: It would be foolish (ふ) of you to touch anything while things are increasing anyways. You don't want to mess up a good thing, do you? Don't be a fool.

ex_1_jp: 警察が私の車を検問している時、どきどきしました。
ex_1_en: While the police were inspecting my car, my heart was racing.
meaning_story: You examine the problem. In order to do this, you need to inspect it or to examine it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このロボットが多くの人手を省くはずだったが、状況は変化しないままである。
ex_1_en: This robot was supposed to eliminate many human worker’s hands, but the situation remains unchanged.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conserve... but why stop there when you could try to omit everything and to eliminate everything? Just take exactly what you need, conserve it, and omit everything else.
reading_story: You have (はぶ) what you have, and omit what you don't need. Perfect life.

ex_1_jp: 今週の日曜日、摩天楼の見学ツアーに参加します。
ex_1_en: I’m participating in the skyscraper observation tour this Sunday.
meaning_story: You know how 参加 is participation? Well, make that a verb with する and you have yourself to participate.
