reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know the reading of 参加.

ex_1_jp: ロックミュージシャンになるには、親父を説得する必要がある。
ex_1_en: I need to persuade my dad to become a rock musician.
meaning_story: You know that 説得 is persuasion, so what is the verb version of that? to persuade.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also immensely help to know the reading of the word 説得.

ex_1_jp: 「何それ？」「わっ！何でもないよ。」「何か企てているでしょう？」
ex_1_en: "What is it?" "Ah, nothing!" "You’re planning something, aren’t you?!"
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means plan so the verb vocab version is to plan.
reading_story: What are you trying to plan? No. Wait. How could you? You're trying to plan a coup? Whadda (くわだ) you thinking???

ex_1_jp: 注意欠陥過活動性障害の子どもは、生活のリズムを乱されることに耐えられないことが多いです。
ex_1_en: Kids with ADHD typically can’t stand having the rhythm of their lives thrown out of order.
meaning_story: You know how 乱れる is "to be in disorder"? Well, now you're the one causing this. So, by doing this you are going to put in disorder things. Just imagine all the people who will try to sue (す) you for your actions.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 乱れる, so make sure you know that so you can know this as well.

ex_1_jp: 認めるのは悔しいけど、今回はフグはいい仕事をしていると思うよ。
ex_1_en: I hate to admit it, but I think Fugu is doing a great job this time.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means recognize so the verb vocab version is to recognize.
reading_story: The reason I was able to recognize you is because your face was covered in meat (みと). Your face was always covered in meat all those years ago too!
pitch_accent: シタタメꜜル *** ミトメル

ex_1_jp: コウイチ大統領はビエトを次期国務長官に任命したが、ビエトはそれを断った。
ex_1_en: President Koichi appointed Viet as the next Secretary of State, but he refused.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cut off. What happens when you do the action of cutting someone off? You're going to refuse them of whatever it is they want.
reading_story: By trying to refuse this person, you're going to start a 事 war (a war of actions). They will do one war-like action, then you will do a war-like action until it escalates into a 事 war (ことわる).

ex_1_jp: 自分がヒゲ大賞の候補に挙がっているなんて、信じられないよ。
ex_1_en: I can’t believe that I’m nominated for the Mustache Award.
meaning_story: When you raise something you are causing it to rise.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The reading for this is the same as the other "to rise" word, 上がる. Nice how that works, right? So, just associate the two and you have yourself a reading.

ex_1_jp: この裏ワザを使うと、朝、すっきり目覚めることができます。
ex_1_en: I use this lifehack in the morning so I can wake up properly.
meaning_story: If your eyes are awake then you're going to wake up. Your eyes are usually the first thing to awaken when you're waking up, you know? This word can also mean to awaken but it's like when you to come to your senses, not literally waking up.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 覚 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you start to wake up in the middle of the night, it's because of the wake up wizard (ざ). He sneaks into your house when you're sleeping and pokes you with his wand. Wizards like when you wake up. They're weird.

ex_1_jp: 田村さんは田中さんの個人秘書を一年間務めたんだけど、あまりうまくいかなかったんだよね。
ex_1_en: Tamura worked as Tanaka’s private secretary for one year, but it didn’t really work out.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means task so what's the verb vocab version? Well, when you do a task, you are going to work for or to serve at the person you're doing that task for, so let's go with that.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: to work for and to serve at me, you will have to complete a task. A task where you bring me two toes (つと)! You want a toe? I can get you a toe, believe me. There are ways, Dude.

ex_1_jp: その動詞が他動詞か自動詞かを学ぶには、まる暗記するしかないのかな。
ex_1_en: Is memorization the only way to learn if the verb is transitive or intransitive?
meaning_story: Remember how 自動詞 was "intransitive verb"? Intransitive verbs are when something just happens. You aren't doing the action to them. This word, however, is the other kind. A transitive verb is when you are directly doing something to something else. That's why it has other in there, because it's a verb (動詞) you do to another thing, directly.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチの今年の抱負は、ベルサイユ条約の全文を暗記することです。
ex_1_en: Koichi’s New Year’s resolution is memorizing the entire text of the Treaty of Versailles.
meaning_story: There are many clauses about the promises you make in this contract considering it's supposed to be a treaty.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: アヤに、制服を着た女の子の絵を、立体派の画風を取り込みながら描いてもらいたいんだよね。
ex_1_en: I want Aya to draw girls in school uniforms and integrate cubism style into it.
meaning_story: If you control people, you make them wear the same clothes. That's a uniform.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: しりとりで、コウイチは無敵だ。
ex_1_en: Koichi is invincible at Shiritori.
meaning_story: You have nothing when it comes to enemies. Why? It's not because you're super kind and everyone likes you. No, it's that you've defeated anyone who's tried. You are unrivaled and invincible.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 口笛が下手くそなので、私が口笛を吹いても犬が来てくれません。
ex_1_en: My dog doesn’t come to my whistle because I’m bad at whistling.
meaning_story: A mouth flute... Normal flutes you blow air through to make a sound. How do you blow air through your mouth to make a sound? By whistling.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi readings put together. Thank 口 for being a body part, which tends to cause this to happen. So, you have 口 (くち) and 笛 (ふえ) put together, though to ふえ changes to ぶえ, maybe because you can't whistle properly? Buuuweeee. Buwwweee.
pitch_accent: クチブエ *** クチブꜜエ

ex_1_jp: 西洋と違い、日本では歴史上、大きな女権拡張運動は起きていない。
ex_1_en: Unlike the West, Japan does not have a history of strong women’s rights movements.
meaning_story: A woman's rights consist of women's rights.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「そんな風に自分を安売りしないで。君は素晴らしい女性だよ。」
ex_1_en: "Don’t sell yourself short like that. You’re a magnificent woman."
meaning_story: An element of clear up (like the sky clearing up!) is so wonderful and splendid. Sort of a weird word, but very useful. Just think of that wonderful feeling you get when the sun breaks and things clear up and it's awesome.
reading_story: The reading is a bit weird, too. Luckily, both readings that you learned with the kanjis are the readings you'll be using here. 晴れる is はれる. That's the reading you use here, though は goes to ば.

ex_1_jp: 私は昨日、日本語の時を表す副詞を学びました。
ex_1_en: I learned Japanese adverbs that show time yesterday.
meaning_story: This is like your side part of speech, as in, you add it to the side of a verb because it's an adverb.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 罰金については、追ってご連絡を差し上げます。
ex_1_en: We’ll contact you shortly about the fine.
meaning_story: Penalty gold is the money you pay when you get a penalty. It's for a fine.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ばつ gets changed to ばっ though, so don't get it wrong (or you'll get a 罰金!).

ex_1_jp: あの熱心に声を出す応援者はいったい誰なんだ？
ex_1_en: Who the heck is that enthusiastic and vocal supporter?
meaning_story: You must respond with aid in order to give aid to someone who needs it. Also, if you respond with aid to someone who needs it, you are going to root for them as well. This meaning will be helpful for a level 24 vocab word.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 少子化なのにどうして待機児童が増えるんですか？
ex_1_en: If birth rates are declining, why are waitlists for schools increasing?
meaning_story: You want a machine to wait so you put it on alert. If the machine is your computer you put it on standby. You just want it to stay there and do nothing until you're ready, that's all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 本日のプレゼンでは、主に3つの策を取り上げます。
ex_1_en: In my presentation today, I will cover three main plans.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Lucky for you, even though this word is a single kanji, it uses the same reading you learned, meaning you know how to read it already. Time to plan and scheme for your next vocab/kanji.

ex_1_jp: 私のホームドクターは、いつも急いでいて、自分の症状について調べてきた患者の話を聞かずにけんもほろろに追い出すので、評価が低い。
ex_1_en: My family doctor has a low rating because he is always in a rush, is unwilling to listen to patients who have researched a medical problem they have, and often dismisses their worries.
meaning_story: Let's evaluate the value. What is this also known as? An appraisal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: はんのう, はんおう
ex_1_jp: 反応しないアプリケーションを強制終了する方法を教えてくれませんか？
ex_1_en: Could you tell me how to force quit an unresponsive application, please?
meaning_story: Whoops, this one comes out weird. You have anti respond though the meaning of this word is a response. Maybe you're "anti respond" but you have no choice, you have to give a response despite that fact?
reading_story: The 反 reading is all good an merry, but the 応 reading gets a bit wonky, turning into のう. This is probably because it's just way easier to say than はんおう and sounds basically the same too. So, はんおう goes to はんのう and everyone's happy. Do you have a response? The reading はんおう is also going to be included since it's technically correct though a less common spelling.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: このオナラ計画が成功するには君の援助がぜひ必要です。
ex_1_en: Your assistance is vital to the success of this fart plan.
meaning_story: If you aid and help someone you are giving them assistance. How kind!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あいつ、誰と話をしているかによって、態度を180度変えるからね。信じられないよ。
ex_1_en: I can’t trust him because his attitude takes a 180 degree turn depending on who he’s talking to.
meaning_story: Your appearance has many degrees. You turn it up a dial, and you show off one attitude. Then you turn it down a degree and you have another attitude. So many attitudes to show off.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: サーモンとコンサートに行ったんだけど、なんと他の観客は全員お相撲さんだったんだ。
ex_1_en: I went to a concert with Salmon and surprisingly, everyone else in the audience was a Sumo wrestler.
meaning_story: The guests who are viewing are the audience and spectators. That's all that viewers who are guests at a location do, right? Makes total sense.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あーどうしたら赤ん坊を泣き止ませることができるんだろう。ミルクもあげてみたし、オムツもかえてみたでしょ。それに、げっぷもさせてみた。あ、これはどうかな？赤ちゃんを体に引き寄せて抱っこして、左右に素早く揺らしてみるって書いてあるわ。
ex_1_en: Well, how can we get this baby to stop crying? We already tried feeding him, changing him, and burping him. Oh, here is something! It says to try holding the baby close to your body and then rocking it quickly from side to side.
meaning_story: Here's a weird one for you. You have a red monk. What is this? It's a baby. Think about it. Babies, when they come out, are all red. Also, they have a shaved head, just like a monk would. So, a "red monk" is really just a baby. I wonder who's getting the shorter end of the stick here, the monk or the baby? Probably the monk.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of 赤 (you learned this with the kanji) and the reading you learned for 坊 as well.
pitch_accent: アカンボー *** アカンボ

ex_1_jp: 花江は今、不機嫌なのよ。
ex_1_en: Hanae is in a bad mood right now.
meaning_story: Remember how 機嫌 means mood? Well when you add not it becomes a bad mood. It's so bad it's like you have no mood at all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: ばつげーむ, ばつゲーム
ex_1_jp: この罰ゲームについて、がっかりもしてるんだけど、ワクワクしてもいるんだよね。
ex_1_en: I’m kind of disappointed about this penalty game, but I’m also a little excited.
meaning_story: A penalty game (ゲーム) is a fun kind of game you see on Japanese television a lot. When you mess up, you are punished. Usually it hurts. You can call this a batsu game or a penalty game. Don't call it anything else, though, or you know what happens...
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の誕生日は四月八日で、お釈迦様の誕生日と同じ日です。
ex_1_en: My birthday is April 8th, which is the same birthday as Buddha’s.
meaning_story: Give birth to life! That is a birth.
reading_story: The 誕 reading is what you'd expect. The 生 reading is an exception though. Just imagine the birth of your friend Joe (じょう). Pick a Joe you know well, or if you don't know a Joe use a famous Joe, like good ol' Joe Biden.

ex_1_jp: 社長は大失態を犯し、それを隠蔽しようとしたが、さらにその隠蔽工作が裏目に出てしまった。
ex_1_en: The president made a huge blunder and he tried to cover it up, but it backfired.
meaning_story: The appearance of fault is a huge blunder on our family. At least do not have the appearance of fault.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The しつ gets shortened to しっ, though, so make that blunder.

ex_1_jp: 日本政府は、その区域の正確な大気中の放射能濃度を公表しているのですか？
ex_1_en: Will the Japanese government announce the exact zone in the atmosphere where the radioactivity is concentrated?
meaning_story: What shows the district and region and where they exist? That would be the boundary. It is what surrounds every district and region, showing where it exists.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 息子よ。現実的になれ。いい加減俺の後を継いで坊主になったらどうなんだ？
ex_1_en: Hey, son. You have to be realistic. Isn’t it about time you followed in my footsteps and became a Buddhist priest?
meaning_story: A monk who is at master status is probably a priest by now... though not just any priest, this refers to a Buddhist priest.
reading_story: The 坊 reads like you'd expect. Unfortunately 主 is an exception and read ず. Just think of a zoo that holds Buddhist priests in captivity. How sad, these Buddhist priests.

ex_1_jp: 私は社費で日本語を勉強させてもらっています。
ex_1_en: I’m studying Japanese at my company’s expense.
meaning_story: A company expense is a company expense. These are nice, by the way, if you can get them.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 妹は、精神状態が不安定であるということを私に打ち明けた。
ex_1_en: My little sister told me about her unstable state of mind.
meaning_story: The condition that something is in and the appearance of it is the condition / state of that object.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 豆乳や納豆の消費が増加しています。
ex_1_en: Soymilk and natto consumption have been increasing.
meaning_story: You extinguish an item and therefore have to expense it. This is how consumption works. Expense, extinguish, consumption.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ショーヒ *** ショꜜーヒ

ex_1_jp: 本日参りました理由は、当社の最新防犯グッズをご紹介するためです。
ex_1_en: The reason I’m here today is to introduce our latest crime prevention products.
meaning_story: To prevent crime is a good thing. To do this you use crime prevention techniques.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 大勢の人の前で話す事に慣れていないので、今からもう手が震えています。
ex_1_en: I’m not used to speaking in front of crowds, so my hands are already shaking.
meaning_story: You have a large force at your disposal. This large force is a group of people (just think to when this word was probably made up... a long time a go, and the biggest force you could have was a huge group of people). This group of people force is also known as a crowd.
reading_story: The reading for 大 is the おお reading (like 大きい). Nothing you can do about that but remember it. Then, 勢 is rendaku'd to become ぜい. Also something you'll just have to remember. Say this word a few times in your head, then you'll be able to come up with an idea of what sounds right and what sounds wrong so that you can figure it out next time this word comes up.
pitch_accent: オーゼꜜイ *** オーゼイ *** タイセイ *** タイゼꜜイ *** タイゼイ

ex_1_jp: 電車が脱線しましたが、怪我人はありませんでした。
ex_1_en: The train was derailed, but nobody was injured.
meaning_story: When you undress from the line it's like you're peeling something off the line, going off in another direction, and then causing a digression in whatever the line was about. It's like when you're talking and you digress. Think of your speech as a line. Then, undress a part of it and let it fall away. That is your digression.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 誰でも、前進するためには未知の領域に足を踏み入れなくてはいけない。
ex_1_en: Everyone has to take a step into unknown territory to progress.
meaning_story: This is my territory. This is my region. This is my domain! Also works with "domain names" like on the interwebs.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: まず始めに、各チームの代表者を決めて下さい。
ex_1_en: First, choose a representative for each team.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji, though it's kind of like an add-on for other words in a sense, which makes it behave like jukugo, I think. Don't confuse this with 各々 though. That one does use the kun'yomi reading, which is strange when you consider this one doesn't. Every kanji has its own "perks" I suppose.

ex_1_jp: どうやら各々独自のポテトチップスの食べ方をもっているようだ。
ex_1_en: It seems that each person has their own way of eating potato chips.
meaning_story: You have each each which is each (or every, or "respectively"). Kind of goes along the lines of "each and every" in English.
reading_story: The reading is weird. So sorry. Just imagine you look at each item. Everyone is messed up in some way. Possibly they are robots all accidentally programmed to need to kill humans. You say "oh no oh no" in quick succession because this is a bad situation.

ex_1_jp: 父の仕事の都合で、私の家族は各地を転々としなくてはいけませんでした。
ex_1_en: My family had to move from place to place because of my dad’s job.
meaning_story: Each ground is its own ground. It is each area.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 遠足には、各自お弁当とお菓子、水筒を持参してください。
ex_1_en: You need to bring your own bento box, snacks, and water bottle for the school trip.
meaning_story: Each self refers to each person or individual.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本では引っ越し費用の平均って大体どれくらいなの？
ex_1_en: Roughly how much is the average cost of moving in Japan?
meaning_story: The use of expenses are the expenses and costs we have to pay, I'm afraid.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチはTofuguに犯罪経験者を雇うと思いますか？
ex_1_en: Do you think Koichi would hire an experienced criminal at Tofugu?
meaning_story: Someone who has experience (経験) is an experienced person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このアパートメントの外観が好きです。
ex_1_en: I like the outward appearance of this apartment.
meaning_story: The outside view of you is your external appearance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼が私に微笑みかけている姿が頭に焼きついて離れない。
ex_1_en: I can’t get the image of him smiling at me out of my mind.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: What's that figure / shape in the distance? Is that who I think it is? Is that Sugar Tom (すがた)??? You'll have to make up some lore about this "Sugar Tom" but whatever you do be excited about him. He's a dude who gives you tons of sugar, I'm guessing, and you always see him coming from a long ways away because of his Sugar Tom hat, or something like that.

ex_1_jp: 私達の犬は、誰と競争している訳でもないのに、いつもすごい勢いでミルクボーンに向かって行きます。
ex_1_en: Our dog always bolts towards the milk-bone even though he isn’t racing anyone.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, which means you think it ought to be an adjective, but it's not, it's a noun :( What's the noun form of force? It's also force.
reading_story: This is a rough one. There is much force behind you, so when you come at me I scream: "EEK! OI! (いきおい), Get away from me!"

ex_1_jp: 日本郵政をどうして官営から民営に変える必要があったのか、未だに分かりません。
ex_1_en: I still don’t understand why Japan Post needed to change from government management to private management.
meaning_story: Managed by the government? Then it is run by government management or it is a government operation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 甥っ子が高校の入学試験に合格した時に、祝賀状を送りました。
ex_1_en: I sent a congratulations card to my nephew when he passed his high school entrance exam.
meaning_story: Congratulations on your condition. I'll send you a greeting card to make it official.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「二人なんですが、席は空いていますか？」「お席にご案内するまで少しお待ちください。」
ex_1_en: "Do you have a table for two?" "It will be just a moment before I will guide you to your seats."
meaning_story: The plan inside this piece of paper is the guide you'll be using. It's a plan. It's inside. Use it as your guide!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: フグは高血圧で、塩分の少ない食事を取る必要があるとお医者さんから言われたのに、まだ毎日ハンバーガーを食べているの。
ex_1_en: Fugu has high blood pressure and was told that he must stick to a low-salt diet by a doctor, but he still eats hamburgers every day.
meaning_story: Remember blood pressure (血圧)? Well, now the blood pressure is tall... so you have "tall blood pressure." Well that's dumb. Let's call it high blood pressure instead.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: コーケツꜜアツ *** コーケꜜツアツ

ex_1_jp: コウイチの秘密の日記が、オークションで歴代最高値で落札された。
ex_1_en: Koichi’s secret diary fetched a record high price at the auction.
meaning_story: A tall value. If you paid for something that had a tall value, it would have a high price.
reading_story: The reading for this one is pretty weird. It's the たか from 高い. The 値 is also the kun'yomi reading, but that's the one you learned with the kanji. Main thing is you remember that the 高 reading is たか.

ex_1_jp: 彼はちょっと頭が悪いよね。どうしてあれが嫌味だってことに気づかないのかしら。
ex_1_en: He’s kind of an idiot, really. Why didn’t he realize that it was sarcastic?
meaning_story: You have a flavor of dislike. If someone gives you "flavor" and you dislike it, what might that "flavor" be? How about hurtful words.
reading_story: The reading for 味 is the on'yomi you learned with the kanji, but the reading for 嫌 is the kun'yomi, いや. Just imagine someone saying words so hurtful that you have to scream, "Iyaaaaa!" いや.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 彼女は芸術においては素晴らしい美の観念を持っているのに、どうしてあんなに不細工な男性と付き合っているのかが理解できない。
ex_1_en: She has a keen sense of beauty for art, so I don’t understand how she’s dating such an ugly guy.
meaning_story: You have a thought on a particular view. This is your idea or notion on it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あのポーカーのトーナメントで、悪い予感はしてたんだけど、捨てるのは不可能な手札を持っていたんだよ。
ex_1_en: In the poker tournament, I had a bad feeling, but it wasn’t possible for me to fold my hand.
meaning_story: You already know how 可能 means possible. So when you add not it becomes impossible.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know how to read 可能 first as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本で最も重要な産業は何ですか？
ex_1_en: What is the most important industry in Japan?
meaning_story: What will give birth to business? Well, some kind of industry, probably. Though heavy industry is pretty good too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その武装勢力は、急速に勢力を増大している。
ex_1_en: The armed insurgents are rapidly increasing their influence.
meaning_story: Your force and power combine together to create an influence (or a force).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 指示を無視するのはよくありませんが、指示待ち族にはなってもらいたくはありません。私の言っている意味が分かりますか？
ex_1_en: Ignoring orders is not good, but I don’t want you to be someone who can’t work without instructions. Do you know what I mean?
meaning_story: Use your finger to indicate some things. These are your instructions. Okay, do this (point), do that (point), and then finally do this (point).
reading_story: The readings are the on'yomi readings. You learned the on'yomi reading of 示, so that's good. The on'yomi reading for 指 has come up a few times as well, so I think you know it. Perhaps you can think of it this way, though. You give instructions. What were they? To take out both Charlie Sheen and Jesus. What? Impossible.

ex_1_jp: あの医者の対応は素晴らしかった。
ex_1_en: Interacting with that doctor was wonderful.
meaning_story: You respond versus someone else to have an interaction with them. If one of you stops responding, so does the correspondence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「今日も残業するつもりなの？」「えっと…ですね、今日は寝不足なのでどちらかというと早くあがりたいと思っています。」
ex_1_en: "So are you going to work overtime again today?" "Well actually, I was kind of hoping to get off work early today because I’ve been missing out on a lot of sleep."
meaning_story: Remember how 不足 is a physical shortage? Well, now you have a physical shortage of sleep. That's a lack of sleep.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ふ in 不 goes to ぶ, so hopefully you've been getting enough sleep.
pitch_accent: ネブꜜソク *** ネブソク

ex_1_jp: 幸運なことに、私の両親は地価が高騰する前にその土地を買い、最高値で売り抜けました。
ex_1_en: Luckily, my parents had bought the land before the price of land went sky-high and sold it at the highest price.
meaning_story: The ground's value is the land value.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私はこの長靴を驚くほどの安値で買いましたが、防水加工がされてませんでした。
ex_1_en: I bought these rain boots at an unbelievably low price, but they aren’t waterproof.
meaning_story: A cheap valued item comes at a low price. What a good deal!
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings of the two kanji. For 値 that's the reading you learned with the kanji. For 安 you have to think back to 安い.

ex_1_jp: くそ、彼女が付き合ってた坊さんたちには太刀打ちできないよ。あいつら俺とはかなりレベルが違うんだ。
ex_1_en: Man, I can’t compete with the monks she goes out with. They’re on a whole other level.
meaning_story: さん is what you put on people's names. It's like "Mr." sort of. So a "Mr. monk" is a monk.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. ぼうさん！

ex_1_jp: コウイチはただ今昼寝中です。おかけになって少々お待ちください。
ex_1_en: Koichi is napping at the moment. Please be seated and wait for a moment.
meaning_story: A noon sleep is sleep you do during the day, also known as a nap.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 誤字脱字を見つけたら、遠慮せずに教えてくださいね。
ex_1_en: Don’t be afraid to let me know if you find misspelled or missing words, please.
meaning_story: An undressed letter is one that's missing. It's an omitted character or omitted word.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は、彼に態と気のないふりをした。
ex_1_en: She pretended to be indifferent toward him on purpose.
meaning_story: So this doesn't quite make sense in terms of the meaning of the kanji... but you'll be okay. This means on purpose. Perhaps when you do something that has the appearance of doing what you wanted to do you're doing it on purpose.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You did that to me on purpose? Whazapp with that?"

ex_1_jp: 「土曜日に夕食にいらっしゃいませんか？河豚のパイ生地包み焼きを作る予定なんですよ。」「喜んで行きたいのですが、会議がありますので。またの機会にお願いします。」
ex_1_en: "Would you like to come to dinner on Saturday? I’m going to make Fugu-wellington." “I’d like to, but I have a meeting. I’ll take a rain check."
meaning_story: When the machines meet, you finally have the opportunity to take them all out at once. DIE MACHINES!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: キカꜜイ *** キカイ *** シオꜜ

ex_1_jp: あいにくですが、トフグのオフィスには今、ご対応できる者がおりません。社員がみんな寝坊してしまったのです。
ex_1_en: I’m afraid no one in the Tofugu office is available at the moment. Every worker overslept today.
meaning_story: You sleep like a monk, as in you never stop sleeping (because you sleep while you meditate). When you sleep like a monk like this you constantly oversleep, probably because you're up late doing sutras or something. I have no idea why monks wake up late, but figure something out to make this stick in your brain cage.
reading_story: These are the readings you learned with the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 主人は宮仕えでとても忙しくしており、私は四週間も顔も見ていません。
ex_1_en: My husband is so busy with the imperial court service that I haven’t seen him for four weeks.
meaning_story: This shinto shrine you're staying at? Turns out you go inside and it is magically turned into this amazing palace. Wow! I'm totally becoming a Shinto monk.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

ex_1_jp: 玉ねぎが目にしみたことは過去に一度もありません。
ex_1_en: My eyes have never watered from onions before.
meaning_story: If you surpass the past then you're going backwards in time (at least if you're coming from the "present.") If this is the case, then you are definitely in the past.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: クラスの生徒全員がカンニングで罰を受けたなんて、信じられない。
ex_1_en: I can’t believe that all the students in the class received punishment for cheating.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji... and you thought I was about to punish you because it was a single kanji vocab word. Now get over here. Time for a dirty spanking for thinking such a thing.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 実は、ちょっと恥ずかしい話なんだけど、俺の親父めちゃくちゃ変態で、児童ポルノの一斉捜査で捕まっちゃったんだよね。
ex_1_en: Actually, it’s sort of an embarrassing story, but my father is so perverted that he was caught in a massive child porn ring.
meaning_story: Your appearance is strange. You're abnormal. Oh, and you're a pervert because you look so abnormal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お集まりの皆さん、本日は我々の諸政策についてのプレゼンテーションの機会をいただき、有難うございます。

meaning_story: A plan made by the government is usually known as a policy. "The government passed a policy prohibiting the use of guns on zombies, dooming us all."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 位置について、用意、ドン！
