reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 恐らく姿勢が悪いことが首の痛みの原因でしょう。
ex_1_en: Your poor posture is probably causing your neck pain.
meaning_story: Put a force on your figure to make it into a certain shape. This is your posture.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: トフグライターへの応募者の提出物について教えて頂けますか？また、必要なスキルは何ですか？
ex_1_en: Could you tell me what a Tofugu writer applicant needs to submit and what skills are required?
meaning_story: Go ahead and present then exit. This will be your presentation of the materials.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ほら、彼はここの大統領としての仕事がとても好きだったんです。 それに、現実を見つめてください。彼がしてた仕事と同じくらい良い仕事をする人を見つけられないでしょう。 そうじゃないですか？
ex_1_en: Look, he loved his job as president here. And let’s face it, you’re not gonna find anyone who did it as well as he did it. Isn’t that true?
meaning_story: When you big unite in a territory you need a great leader. Someone like a president, perhaps?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well

ex_1_jp: この価格はちょっと高すぎやしないかい。
ex_1_en: The cost is a little too high.
meaning_story: When you value status you really care about how much the price of things are. The more things cost, the more you value them.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日本では、物価が上がり始めたようだ。
ex_1_en: In Japan, it seems that prices have begun to go up.
meaning_story: Things with value have prices. This is just the general prices of things.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ぶつ changes to ぶっ, though, so hopefully that doesn't change the price you're willing to pay for this vocab? Right? Please give me your money.

ex_1_jp: 私の両親は、私営の葱園を所有しています。
ex_1_en: My parents own a private green onion garden.
meaning_story: Anything that's privately managed is private and privately run.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「提案はどうだった？」「うーん。まあまあって感じかな。」
ex_1_en: "So what did you think of the proposal?" "Well, I think it was just okay."
meaning_story: Please present your plan in the form of a proposition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もし収入がものすごく低いのであれば、安い公営のアパートに住めるかもしれませんよ。
ex_1_en: If your income is really low, you may be able to live in a cheap public apartment.
meaning_story: Something that is publicly managed is something that is public aka government run. Compare this to 私営 which is private / privately run.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 毎年いつ頃日本の地価公示価格が公表されるのか教えて頂けませんか？
ex_1_en: Could you tell me when Japanese land prices are announced each year?
meaning_story: Please indicate this in a public way. How about a public announcement?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 先週購入したTofugu製品の受領書を送って頂けませんか？
ex_1_en: Could you send me the receipt for the Tofugu products I bought from you last week?
meaning_story: Please accept this territory. Oh, you want some writing to make the deal official? Okay, here's a receipt.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: スーパーマンはその地域へ食料と新鮮な水を急送した。
ex_1_en: Superman rushed food and fresh water to that region.
meaning_story: The region that is this ground is the region / area. Just think of each area of ground. Each area is each region.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 大阪市は、舞州にすごくユニークな市営のゴミ焼却炉を建設しました。
ex_1_en: Osaka City built a very unique, city run incineration plant in Maeshima.
meaning_story: Something that is managed by the city is run by the city / city run.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: フグは県営図書館でサーモンといちゃついていて、図書館司書さんに怒られた。
ex_1_en: Fugu was scolded for making out with Salmon in the prefectural library by a librarian.
meaning_story: Prefecture managed things are run by the prefecture.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ああ、あの風俗店は今日は営業してるよ。どの娘に会いに来たんだい？
ex_1_en: Yes! That pink house is open for business today. Which girl are you going to see?
meaning_story: Managing a business? Then you are running a business.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 副業で、私の彼氏はネットワークビジネスをしている。
ex_1_en: As a side business, my boyfriend works for a company using multi-level marketing techniques.
meaning_story: A side business is a side business.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 観光案内のパンフレットありますか？
ex_1_en: Can I have a sightseeing brochure?
meaning_story: Let's go view some sunlight! Oh wait, we can't do that here. We will have to go sightseeing to go see this amazing sunlight thing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: まだお土産を選んでいません。
ex_1_en: I haven’t picked out a souvenir yet.
meaning_story: Are you visiting a neat place? Grab some dirt and bring it back with you. Then pretend to give birth to it in front of your friends. That dirt is now a special souvenir! It's the best present you could ever give someone!
reading_story: These readings are exceptions, sorry! Here's a mnemonic to help you: When someone asks you who gave you a souvenir, just say "Miya gave (みやげ) it to me." Who's Miya? No idea. But neither do they. You never have to remember who gave you anything ever again! Miya gave you everything you own. She's probably a great person.

ex_1_jp: 彼女の文章はとても主観的だが、だからこそとてもユニークでもある。
ex_1_en: Her writing is very subjective but that’s what makes it so very unique.
meaning_story: Okay, so that's just the view of the master, and we all know his view displays subjectivity towards himself.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 昨晩、私の本にぴったりのすごくいい副題を思いついたの。
ex_1_en: I came up with a killer subheading for my book last night.
meaning_story: The side topic is the subtitle or subheading.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 心あるオナラ臭い支援を有難うございます。
ex_1_en: Thank you for your hearty and farty support.
meaning_story: To support and aid is to support.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あの可愛い柴犬が、尻尾を振りながらコウイチに近づき、飛びついた。
ex_1_en: That cute Shiba came towards Koichi wagging its tail and jumped on him.
meaning_story: Your butt tail is just your tail, though I wonder why they had to specify that it was your butt tail. Where else do you have a tail, I wonder?
reading_story: The reading for this word is a bit of an exception. You kind of already know the reading for 尻 from the kun'yomi しり you learned already. Here it gets shortened to しっ. The reading for 尾 is totally different from what you learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The animal with the best tail in the world is the polar (ぽ) bear. They're stubby and white and cute. Only polar bears have tails like that!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私は小さい頃、両親から親切な人になるよう教わりましたが、二人は脱税容疑で逮捕されました。
ex_1_en: My parent’s taught me how to be a kind person when I was little, but they were arrested on charges of tax evasion.
meaning_story: To undress your taxes is to throw them away. Just throw it out, who needs 'em? I'm not going to pay these taxes, therefore I am committing tax evasion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 一応念のため、全データのバックアップをこのハードディスクに取っておきました。
ex_1_en: For now I made a backup of all the data on this hard drive, just in case.
meaning_story: Okay, only one response for that, and that is that tentatively we have an agreement... for now. Just think of the one response you have, and that one response is to just get everyone off your back, so you agree with them... for now.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ブログでは、国家間の領土問題にはあまり触れたくありません。
ex_1_en: We don’t want to touch on the territorial disputes between nations on our blog.
meaning_story: The soil that makes up your territory is your territory. Ain't nobody goin' set foot on my soil nuh'uh.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どうして素直に有り難うと言うことができないんだろうね。
ex_1_en: Why won’t you just obediently say thank you?
meaning_story: Some people have a difficult time saying thank you. But not you now that you know how! Did you know this is an abbreviation of 有難うございます? You can also spell it like this: 有難う.
reading_story: You've heard people say ありがとう before right?!

ex_1_jp: 子どもたちは両親が不祥事を隠したことを非難した。
ex_1_en: The kids criticized their parents for hiding the scandal.
meaning_story: Know how 非難 is a criticism? Make it a verb and you have the word to criticize.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, it will be really helpful to know the word 非難 to start.

ex_1_jp: 重い刑罰を言い渡された犯罪者が、刑務所から脱走した。
ex_1_en: The criminal, who had received a heavy sentence, broke out of prison.
meaning_story: You undress and run out of that room. You had to take off your clothes in order to escape, but now you can run and start to flee. Just imagine some sort of contraption that holds you in place via your clothes, and you need to escape from it by taking said clothes off. Now imagine running away from that place naked. Escape!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The だつ changes to だっ, though, so be careful of that.

ex_1_jp: 私は死後の世界は存在すると思います。
ex_1_en: I think that life after death exists.
meaning_story: Know how 存在 is existence? Well, make it a verb and then you have to exist.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: そのマラソン選手は、ゴールの直前で疲れきって倒れてしまいました。
ex_1_en: The marathon runner collapsed from exhaustion right before the finish line.
meaning_story: You've seen how 倒す is "to knock over." But this is when something gets knocked over by itself. You know that you're not doing anything here, because when you're not touching all these fine glass items, it's very rare (れる) that anything gets knocked over (because you're not touching anything, you clumsy dumsy). It's also when you or someone else collapses. You didn't push yourself over, you just kind of fell by yourself.
reading_story: The reading is the same like 倒す. If you knew 倒す you will know the reading of this one too.

ex_1_jp: コウイチはあなたのことが大嫌いなので、彼に代わってビエトがお会いします。
ex_1_en: Mr. Viet will meet with you instead of Mr. Koichi because Mr. Koichi really hates you.
meaning_story: Remember how 嫌い is to dislike? When that dislike is big, you really dislike it. That means you are going to hate (or really hate) it.
reading_story: The reading is the reading for 大, and the reading for 嫌い is like the one you learned with 嫌い in level 20.

ex_1_jp: お手洗いは、真っすぐ行って左です。
ex_1_en: The restroom is straight and to the left.
meaning_story: You know that 手洗い is "handwashing" (and also a not as polite way to mention a bathroom). When you add お you're suddenly making it polite. Why? Because you're talking about something a little more crass than handwashing. You're talking about the toilet or restroom or bathroom. Ewww. Poops goes there.
reading_story: The reading comes from 手洗い, so if you know that you'll know this too!

ex_1_jp: 約束なんてしないで。言葉ではなく行いで示してよ。
ex_1_en: Don’t promise me anything. Actions speak louder than words.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means indicate so the verb vocab version is to indicate or to show. This isn't used for "showing" a physical thing, this is more like when "a study shows that ...."
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Studies seem to indicate that She-man (しめ) is way more powerful than her boyfriend He-man. I mean, to show you I can just point to her. Look how much bigger her sword and biceps are. Why didn't She-man get her own show?

ex_1_jp: フグは、センターオーバーの三塁打をかっ飛ばした。
ex_1_en: Fugu sent a triple flying over center field.
meaning_story: Remember how 飛ぶ is to fly? This is when you make some thing fly. So, this word is to let fly or to send flying. You can remember this because you use your massive strength to let fly a bus (ばす). You're that buff.
reading_story: The reading is just like 飛ぶ, so if you know that reading you can figure out this one.

ex_1_jp: よし、そろそろ寝るね〜。おやすみ〜。また明日〜。
ex_1_en: Alright, I’m gonna go to bed. Sleep well. See you in the morning.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lie down so the verb vocab version is to lie down.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. So, you can go ahead and lie down for a moment before moving on to the next item.

ex_1_jp: ちゃんとドアに鍵をかけたかどうか確かめた方がいいですよ。
ex_1_en: You should make sure the door is properly locked.
meaning_story: Like with 確か, which means certain, this is the verb version of that. So when you "do certain" you are going to make sure of something or you're going to verify something.
reading_story: This one is kun'yomi followed by okurigana. If you remember the reading you learned with 確かに, you should know this one!

ex_1_jp: この新しいサイトは他社の日本語学習サイトを圧倒するだろう。
ex_1_en: This new site will overwhelm other Japanese language sites.
meaning_story: The pressure used easily collapses whatever it's pushing against. That's why this verb means to overwhelm.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the あつ goes to あっ, as you'd probably expect.

ex_1_jp: コウイチはTofuguの秘密を漏らした従業員を罰した。
ex_1_en: Koichi punished the employees who leaked Tofugu’s secrets.
meaning_story: When you do a penalty to someone you are trying to punish or to penalize them.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Just remember that the つ becomes a small っ so I don't have to punish you.
pitch_accent: バッスル *** バッスꜜル

ex_1_jp: フグと私は今距離を置いてるの。
ex_1_en: Fugu and I are putting some distance between us right now.
meaning_story: When you put something you don't just put it, you have to put down this item or even (to) set down the item. Basically, you have to put something down with this verb. It's a little different from the kanji meaning you learned but not that different.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just imagine you're putting down Oreos (お). One after another. Each oreo that you try to put down say in your head "Hello Mr. Oreo, I'm going to put you down.. ooh yes, you like that don't you?" REPEAT.

ex_1_jp: 外国人が日本に在留する時に必要になるものは何ですか？
ex_1_en: What do foreigners need when they stay in Japan?
meaning_story: If 在留 is residence, then the verb version of that would be to reside.
reading_story: The reading comes from 在留 so you should be able to read this one already!

ex_1_jp: 先方は、我々の二割りの値下げ要求に応じるでしょうか？
ex_1_en: Do you think they will respond to our request for a 20 percent discount?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means respond so the verb vocab version is to respond.
reading_story: The reading is actually the same as the one you learned with the kanji! Not too shabby.
pitch_accent: オージル *** オージꜜル

ex_1_jp: 私の両親はマッサージ業を営んでいるので、私はそこで「マッサージ受け放題」なんです。
ex_1_en: My parents run a massage therapy business, so I can get ’all-you-can-take-massages’ at home.
meaning_story: The kanji means manage, but when you manage something, what are you usually managing? How about a business? So this word means to run a business even though the kanji is manage.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to run a business. Your business is to make people eat who don't want to eat. "HEY, YOU EAT NOW!" (いとな).

ex_1_jp: アル中の父の手は、いつも震えていた。
ex_1_en: My alcoholic father’s hands always shake.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means earthquake so the verb means to shiver and to shake, like you would if there was an earthquake happening right now.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You start to shake in an earthquake because you're really full (ふる) from eating lunch. Now your full belly is shaking and quaking with the ground! Ahh It's awful! You never want to be full again!

ex_1_jp: これを最後に、きっぱりとタバコを吸うのを止めるつもりなんだ。
ex_1_en: I’m going to quit smoking once and for all.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means suck so the verb vocab version is to suck, but it's usually used to talk about what you do to cigarettes, so a better translation I think is to smoke.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You smoke too much, and that gives you cancer. You decide to sue (す) the cigarette makers.

ex_1_jp: 彼は私には優し過ぎます。
ex_1_en: He is too classy for me.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surpass so the verb vocab version is to surpass.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In order to surpass your rivals you will have to sue (す) them. You're bad at this sort of thing, so you have to cheat.

ex_1_jp: 「分かったよ。気温が何度だろうが、服を脱いでやるよ。」「いいぞ。その意気だ。」
ex_1_en: "Alright, I’ll take my clothes off no matter what the temperature is." "Good! That’s the spirit."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means undress and the verb is to undress.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you go to undress your goal is to become nude (ぬ).

ex_1_jp: どっちの映画を観るか迷っています。
ex_1_en: I can’t decide which movie to watch.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means view so what is the verb vocab version? It's to view. This is mainly used for spectators who are viewing something.
reading_story: The reading here is actually the same as 見る. This is easy to remember because the meanings are so similar too, not to mention it has a 見 right inside the kanji itself!

ex_1_jp: あの日本の伝統衣装の名前って何だっけ？単語をすっかり忘れちゃったよ。
ex_1_en: What was the name of that traditional Japanese costume we saw yesterday? I completely forget the word.
meaning_story: When you transmit something that unites the people, you are probably pulling on tradition. Tradition is what unites us all and transmits who we are to everyone else. What is your 伝統?
reading_story: The reading is でん for 伝, which you've seen a few times by now. For 統 it's just the reading you've learned.

ex_1_jp: 毎日鎌で草を刈るのは本当に面倒くさい。
ex_1_en: Cutting the grass with a sickle every day is such a bother.
meaning_story: Something is a trouble (面倒) and it is smelly (臭い). So what is something that's smelly and a trouble? Well, something that's troublesome or a bother, I suppose. Basically you can ignore the smelly part. For some reason someone threw that back in, but smelly things are a bother, I suppose.
reading_story: The reading is the words 面倒 plus 臭い added together. Just make sure you know those words and you'll know this one too!

ex_1_jp: 日本語学習は私にはかなりハードルが高いんじゃないかと思っていたんですが、案外そうでもなかったです。
ex_1_en: I thought learning Japanese would be very difficult for me, but unexpectedly, it actually wasn’t that bad.
meaning_story: Something that happens outside the plan is something that happens unexpectedly.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: アꜜンカ°イ *** アンカ°イ

ex_1_jp: 全ての国が一つの政府に統合される日がいつかやってくると思いますか。
ex_1_en: Do you think the day will one day come when all countries are united under one government?
meaning_story: Unite and join together. It is unification time. Integration!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Put'm together.

ex_1_jp: あなたと話していると、いつも嫌悪感を抱くのです。
ex_1_en: I’m always filled with disgust when I talk with you.
meaning_story: Bad feelings that you dislike are unpleasant feelings. These unpleasant feelings include things like hatred, disgust, revulsion, and fear. All of those are considered to be a part of the term unpleasant feelings.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these readings already so you should be able to read this one too!

ex_1_jp: その価には同意できないな。タダ同然じゃないか。
ex_1_en: I can’t agree with this price. It’s just not right.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Okay, this is a great value. Wait, what is? A tie (あたい). Get a tie, and it will make you more professional which will help you to get a better job. Great value, right there, just for a tie.

ex_1_jp: コンピュータの無い人生なんて生きてる価値がない。
ex_1_en: A life without computers isn’t worth living.
meaning_story: A value and a value. Obviously this is something that has much value.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You unfortunately learned the kun'yomi reading for 値, though, so you should use this mnemonic to help you: What is worth the most value to you? Something that has value 2x? That would be cheese (ち), the greatest thing in the world. Imagine eating the most valuable cheese you can think of. So gooooood!

ex_1_jp: 羽毛布団はやっぱり値が張るね。
ex_1_en: A down quilt is expensive, as I expected.
meaning_story: The value is the value, though it's also the price.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, huzzah!

ex_1_jp: その犯罪は本当に残忍だったので、被害者家族だけではなく全ての人が裁判官が極刑を言い渡すことを願っている。
ex_1_en: The crime was so brutal that not only the victim’s family, but everyone else, is hoping that the judge will sentence him with the ultimate punishment.
meaning_story: The someones (people) who incur damage are the victims. WILL SOMEBODY THINK OF THE VICTIMS HERE???
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 被害 as well.

ex_1_jp: メニューにある、この藤セットって何ですか？
ex_1_en: What’s this Wisteria Combo on the menu?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned! Now you just have to make sure you know what a Wisteria is... This word is often found in names, like a lot, so look out for it in that way.

ex_1_jp: 植物が水分を取り入れる時って、どれくらいのスピードで吸収するんですか？
ex_1_en: When plants get water, how long does it take for them to absorb it?
meaning_story: You suck something in and obtain it. Shhheewwwwww! When you suck something in and obtain it into your body, you have done absorption because it's been sucked inside of you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あの女優の演技力は素晴らしい。
ex_1_en: That actress’ acting ability is magnificent.
meaning_story: Your performance skill allows you to be great at acting and doing awesome performances.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私の恋人は、この芝居で馬の役を演じている俳優よ。
ex_1_en: My boyfriend is the actor performing the part of the horse.
meaning_story: A superior haiku requires someone really famous and well known to read it... it's just on that level. Who is super well known and who deserves to read this superior haiku? A great actor, perhaps?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ホームレスの男性が、「主演男優賞を狙いたい」と真面目に語った。
ex_1_en: A homeless guy said seriously, "I’d like to try to win the award for best actor."
meaning_story: A man who is superior to you is someone who's super famous and awesome like Brad Pitt. What is Brad Pitt besides a superior man? He is also an actor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 現にさっきそう言ったじゃありませんか。
ex_1_en: Didn’t you actually say that a while ago?
meaning_story: The present time is the time you're actually in. You aren't really in any other time, because that's not how time works!
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 今月は沢山の金を手に入れた。
ex_1_en: I got a lot of money this month.
meaning_story: Swamps and mountains happen a lot in Japan. That's why we use this to mean many! Because there are many of them!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. This word is usually written in kana though, so keep that in mind when you're writing it to use kana and not these kanji!
pitch_accent: タクサꜜン *** タクサン

ex_1_jp: グッドマン弁護士はウォルトに会いたくなかったので仮病を使った。
ex_1_en: The lawyer, Goodman, faked an illness because he didn’t want to see Walt.
meaning_story: A samurai who uses speech to defend people. This samurai does their battle in the court of law. This "samurai" is an attorney or a lawyer.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 走りすぎる新幹線の鈍い轟を除いては物音一つ聞こえなかった。
ex_1_en: I could hear nothing, save for the rolling thunder of a Shinkansen passing by.
meaning_story: This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading first. Technically this is the "New Tree Trunk Line" but you wouldn't realize this is the Japanese bullet train aka Shinkansen from that, would you? Maybe going to the reading will help you after all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Read this to be able to remember the meaning, too, which is Shinkansen.

pronunciation: ばすてい, バスてい
ex_1_jp: このバス、あのバス停で止まるのか？おい、このバス、あのバス停で止まるのかって聞いてんだよ！バスの運転手さんよお！お前、耳が聞こえねえのか！
ex_1_en: Is this bus going to stop at the bus stop? Hey, is this bus going to stop at the bus stop!? Yo, bus driver! Are you deaf?
meaning_story: This is where the bus (バス) halts. It's the bus stop.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今日志賀直哉の小説『城の崎にて』を読み始めました。
ex_1_en: I started reading Naoya Shiga’s novel, "At Cape Kinosaki" today.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: この法律の施行の責任を誰が負っていたのか覚えていますか？
ex_1_en: Do you remember who is responsible for the enforcement of this law?
meaning_story: When you go to carry out something, you are carrying it out. That's why this is carry out (that is しこう). Alternatively, when you go carry out something, you are making sure something is getting done. You are doing enforcement on that thing that you're carrying out on.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Another alternative reading is せこう, which is more often used when talking about something law related.

ex_1_jp: もし宝くじが当たったら、裏庭に自分のお城を建てるね。
ex_1_en: If I won the lottery, I would build my own castle in the back yard.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: ジャイアンツは去年はボロ負けだったが、今年はリーグ優勝を果たした。
ex_1_en: Although the Giants got their butts kicked big time last year, they won the championship this year.
meaning_story: The superior person wins. They will win the championship and be able to claim victory over all others.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: いい加減、委員会での重要な問題に対して意見をころころ変えるのをやめてくれないか。みんなにいい迷惑だよ。
ex_1_en: You should stop flip-flopping on important issues in the committee, it’s irresponsible. Everyone finds it annoying.
meaning_story: There are member(s) of a committee (委員) all getting together to meet. This is the committee itself.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course it will help to know 委員 as well, since it's 2/3rds of the word.

ex_1_jp: 彼は弱々しいうなずいて了解の意を示して、立ち去った。
ex_1_en: He expressed his understanding with a weak nod and walked away.
meaning_story: When you've finished solving something, you've come to a point of comprehension and understanding. Also, used in (often radio) communication to signify you know what's up. It's like saying "roger!"
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの犯罪現場で実際に何が起きたのかがすぐに明るみに出ることを期待しよう。
ex_1_en: Let’s hope that what actually happened at the scene of the crime will come to light soon.
meaning_story: Your present location is your current location.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
pitch_accent: ゲンジョー *** ゲンバ

ex_1_jp: おい！下手な芝居はやめて正体を現せ！この、鬼め！
ex_1_en: Hey! Stop this weak act and show us your true form, you demon!
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Demons are mean. This particular demon bites you on the knee, creating an "O" shape on your knee. He tells you he has cursed you with the "O" knee (おに).

ex_1_jp: こんな簡単な割り算の問題を間違えちゃったよ。
ex_1_en: I made a mistake on such a simple division problem.
meaning_story: Divide and calculate? Why, that's just division!
reading_story: This is the kun'yomi reading for 割 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

ex_1_jp: ほんの短い時間だけでしたが、あの医師は二度テレビに出たことがあります。
ex_1_en: That doctor appeared on TV twice, though just for short amounts of time.
meaning_story: A medicine expert is someone who knows a lot about medicine. Those people are (I hope) generally doctors.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 近年でも、多くの日本の住宅で畳が使われています。
ex_1_en: Even in modern times, many Japanese homes continue to use tatami mats.
meaning_story: Your dwelling house is your dwelling (or residence).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は経済的に苦しい立場にあるため、週五日フルタイムの仕事をしているうえに、週六日パートタイムでも働いています。
ex_1_en: I work full time five days a week and part time six days a week because I’m in a tough financial situation.
meaning_story: 経済 is economics. So, something that has to do with economics is the economic or financial situation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 経済 as well.

ex_1_jp: 経済学のけの字も知らないので、学校に行くことにしたんです。
ex_1_en: I don’t know the first thing about economics, so I decided to go to school.
meaning_story: You know how 経済 is economics, right? Well, add study to that and you have the study of economics, aka economics.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 経済 as well.

ex_1_jp: 私がインターネットで出会った男性は、三十代で有職ですが、子持ちです。
ex_1_en: I met a guy online who is in his thirties and has a job, but he also has a kid.
meaning_story: When you have employment you are probably employed.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ユꜜーソク *** ユーソク

ex_1_jp: 昨夜の夢で、私たちの赤ちゃんに「乳歯が抜けそうだった時、言葉では表現できないほど痒かった」って言われたの。
ex_1_en: Last night in my dream, our baby told me that it’s time for her baby teeth to come out and she can’t express in words how itchy they are.
meaning_story: When you express something that's of the present time, you are saying something that only people of the current time understand. These are expressions or figure of speech. You say these things during the present time, not the future, not the past, the present time. Otherwise nobody would understand.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ヒョーケ°ꜜン *** ヒョーケ°ン

ex_1_jp: 二十歳の誕生日だからって贅沢な事は何もしたくないわ。良い本が読めればそれでいいの。
ex_1_en: I don’t want to do anything extravagant for my twentieth birthday. All I want to do is read a good book.
meaning_story: A luxury swamp. Really? You got yourself a luxury swamp? That's not even a thing, not to mention probably really expensive. You are being too extravagant.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ゼイタꜜク *** ゼイタクꜜ

ex_1_jp: つけ睫毛を付けるなんて反則だよ。ほとんど別人みたいじゃないか。
ex_1_en: Wearing false eyelashes isn’t fair. Don’t you think you almost look like a different person.
meaning_story: An anti rule is when you break the rules. It's when you do a foul.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: フグはちょっとヤンチャだけど、ああ見えてすごく優しいよ。
ex_1_en: Fugu is a bit on the wild side, but very kind despite his appearance.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of gentle? It's gentle (but also kind or warm hearted).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do people who are gentle and kind say when someone asks of them a favor? Always "yessir" (やさ). Always, always "yessir"!

ex_1_jp: 彼女は不注意ですが、とても頭のいい指導者です。
ex_1_en: She is a bit careless, but she’s a very good guide.
meaning_story: Take your finger and lead with it. Just point at things. Tell people where they need to go, what they need to do, all with your finger leading them. This is guidance you are providing.
reading_story: The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've probably seen the on'yomi reading of 指 enough to remember it by now, but if not just think of Charlie Sheen giving you guidance. He is a terrible person to give guidance to people, but that's what makes it good.

ex_1_jp: 彼が今日詠んだ俳句、すごくロマンチックだったわよね。
ex_1_en: The haiku he composed today was so romantic, wasn’t it?
meaning_story: A haiku paragraph is just a haiku. Haikus are little haiku paragraphs. You will learn kanji The Crabigator watches He feeds on reviews
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今日、宅配便でラクダが届いた。
ex_1_en: The camel was delivered by the express home delivery company today.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go home now.

ex_1_jp: その海外での仕事に就けば、おそらく収入が半分になるだろう。
ex_1_en: If I take the job overseas, my income will probably be half what it is now.
meaning_story: Please enter what you've obtained in here. We'll divvy it all up later. But we have to enter it all here so we know our income.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 児童養護施設の仕事がきついので辞めたいんですが、一方で今まで築き上げてきた関係も壊したくはないんです。
ex_1_en: I’d like to quit my job at the children’s nursing home because it’s too hard, but, at the same time, I don’t want to go burning any bridges.
meaning_story: Go ahead and carry out the task and establish the institution. To carry out and establish something is to institute it too. What do you institute? An institution.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 失業なんて気にするなよ。俺なんてかれこれもう約二年間も求職活動中だぜ。
ex_1_en: Don’t worry about being unemployed. I’ve been job hunting for almost two years now.
meaning_story: Ugh, time to request employment again. Time to go job hunting.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 川崎病という子どもの病気があると聞きましたが、それはどんな病気ですか？
ex_1_en: I heard that there is a disease affecting children called Kawasaki Disease, but what kind of disease is it?
meaning_story: This is one of those words that's easier to know if you jump to the reading first. Why? Because it's the name of a city / a name. It's Kawasaki.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, making it Kawasaki.

ex_1_jp: もし一ヶ月の間に全法律用語を覚えることができたら、百万ドルお支払いしてもいいですよ。
ex_1_en: If you can memorize every legal term within one month, I will pay you a million dollars.
meaning_story: Though there's no law about two kanji with the same meaning producing the same meaning, a law law is probably a law.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: フグは日本で鰐革のサンダルを買った。
ex_1_en: Fugu bought crocodile skin sandals in Japan.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Leather is the skin of a cow, right? How do you say "skin" in Japanese? Remember 皮 aka かわ? It has the same reading as that, and they're both skin, so hopefully that makes it easier to remember.

ex_1_jp: 何度か洗濯したら、皮革の色があせ始めたんだけど、もしかしたら洗っちゃいけなかったのかな。
ex_1_en: After washing it several times, my leather jacket’s color has started to fade. Now I’m wondering if I was even supposed to wash it.
meaning_story: Skin leather is really just leather because leather is also skin. It's also hides.
reading_story: The reading you learned for 皮 isn't the reading here. To remember that it is ひ, think about how this leather provides you with valuable heat (ひ) on your skin, because it's basically another skin on your skin, so of course it provides more heat.

ex_1_jp: この各駅停車はちょうどトンネルを通り過ぎたところです。
ex_1_en: The local train just has passed through a tunnel.
meaning_story: A car that halts at each station. These trains aren't the big and fast ones, they're the local trains, and you'll need to ride them to get to smaller stations.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「おはよう。はい、牛乳よ。」「ああ、ありがとう。やっぱりこれだよね。一日の始まりに、美味しい牛乳に勝るものはないね。」
ex_1_en: "Good morning. Here’s your milk." "Oh, thanks. That hits the spot. There’s nothing like a great glass of milk to start the day."
meaning_story: Cow milk is cow's milk, though most people just call cow's milk milk.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あなたへのお土産に長崎カステラを買いましたよ。
ex_1_en: I bought some Nagasaki sponge cake for you as a souvenir.
meaning_story: This word will be easier if you jump to the reading, since it's the name of a place, Nagasaki.
reading_story: The 長 is the kun'yomi reading, which comes from 長い. The 崎 part is the same reading that you learned with the kanji (though also kun'yomi). Combine those together and you have ながさき. Sound familiar? It should. This is the city of Nagasaki, one of the cities in which the A-bombs fell.

ex_1_jp: 年賀状以外の挨拶状は出さない。
ex_1_en: I don’t send any greeting cards save for New Year’s cards.
meaning_story: A year congratulations condition is when you tell the world about your condition for the new year. What's a better way to tell them than by using a New Year's Card?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ネンカ°ꜜジョー *** ネンカ°ジョー

ex_1_jp: あんたの乳首から血が噴き出しているのを見て、思わずパニクッちゃったよ！
ex_1_en: When I saw all the blood spurting out of your nipples, I couldn’t help but panic!
meaning_story: What is a milk neck? Think about where milk comes from. Now, think of what looks like a little neck on the thing that milk comes from. What is that thing? It's a nipple.
reading_story: The reading for this one is an exception, at least for the 乳 part. It's read as ち, and 首 is read as くび. You can remember the reading of nipple by thinking of a very special "nipple" you have on your face. A bee has burrowed into your cheek, and it squirts out milk from its butt, which sticks out of your cheek. You can't get it out, so you've decided to call this little cheek bee nipple your cheek bee (ちくび). Buzz buzz *milk*
pitch_accent: チクꜜビ *** チꜜクビ *** チチꜜクビ

ex_1_jp: その看護師は患者に作り笑いをした。
ex_1_en: The nurse faked a laugh to her patient.
meaning_story: An expert who watches over and defends people at all hours is the nurse. That's what nurses do, 24/7. They have to check up on people, defend their health, and watch over them, making sure they're okay. What a tough job.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女の職業はモデルなの？写真写りがとてもいいんね。
ex_1_en: Is her occupation being a model? She comes out really well in photos.
meaning_story: Your employment business is your occupation. What is your employment business?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: フグ、現実を見つめて。今のところ、サーモンはまだあなたのこと好きじゃないわよね！でも私がそれを良くできるわ！まずは彼女を自宅に招待するといいわよ。
ex_1_en: Let’s face it, Fugu. Salmon hasn’t fallen in love with you, yet. But I can turn that around! You should invite her to your home this weekend.
meaning_story: Your self home is your own home. It's one's home.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 演芸のチケットはどこで買えますか？
ex_1_en: Where can I buy tickets to the performance?
meaning_story: A performance art is a performance. It is entertainment! Lights, action! Welcome to Broadway!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ライオンキングの上演時間を教えて下さい。
ex_1_en: Can you tell me the time of the Lion King performance?
meaning_story: When you perform above the stage it's a performance. This word is usually used for musical and theatrical performances.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は教師ではありませんが、学校職員です。
ex_1_en: I’m not a teacher, but I am part of the school staff.
meaning_story: The members of employment in your business are your personnel or staff. You employed them, so they're your personnel!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もし兎が高速で走っている電車の車内で真っすぐ上に飛び跳ねても、慣性の法則によって同じ場所に着地することになります。
ex_1_en: If a rabbit jumps through the cabin of a high speed train and out the other side, according to the law of inertia, it will land in the same place.
meaning_story: It's both a law and a rule. This usually refers to something that is a physical law, but also can simply be a law, too. Anyways, lots of rules. Lots of laws. It's both, so the stronger one (law) takes precedence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もしこの職場に残りたいのなら、物事をたいそうに考える癖を無くしてください。
ex_1_en: If you want to stay in this workplace, you’ve got to quit your habit of making everything out to be big deal.
meaning_story: Your employment location is your place of work or place of employment. It's also your workplace.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. So, are you playing WaniKani at your 職場 right now? Wouldn't that be funny.
pitch_accent: ショクバ *** ショクバꜜ

ex_1_jp: どうしてまだ停電してるって分かってるのに、電気のスイッチを何度も付けたり消したりしちゃうんだろう。
ex_1_en: Why do I keep flipping light switches on and off if I know that there is still a power outage.
meaning_story: When you halt electricity you experience a power outage. Makes sense. When the electricity stops you don't have any more power.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: おはよう。朝ご飯の準備ができてるわよ。
ex_1_en: Good morning, your breakfast is ready!
meaning_story: I will provide you with the standard things you need. You can use these for your preparations. It's what everyone gets and it's what you will get too. If it helps, imagine getting some actual things, and use them to prepare for something else. Imagine everyone else getting these standard things to prepare with too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 現在一日に何件のEmailを受信しますか？
ex_1_en: How many emails are you getting a day now?
meaning_story: In the present time we exist. What time is it? It's present and now. It is the current time!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女のことについては、総理府で働いているという以外には何も知らなかった。
ex_1_en: I knew nothing about her except that she worked in the prime minister’s office.
meaning_story: The prime minister's (総理) government is where he does all his governmenting. It's where the Prime Minister's office is located as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 総理 beforehand as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 我が社は新しいベーコンフレーバーの開発を優先するべきだ。
ex_1_en: We should put priority on developing a new flavor of bacon.
meaning_story: It was superior previously, so we need to go back there. That, amongst all the other things, is our highest priority.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本では、蕎麦粉の割合が100%の蕎麦を十割り蕎麦と呼びます。
ex_1_en: In Japan, noodles that contain one hundred percent buckwheat flour are called Juwari-soba.
meaning_story: Divide then join something back together. When you join it back together, it won't be whole again, but you can see the two parts you divided apart. You can also compare them and see which is bigger and by how much. You can easily find the ratio this way, too.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this one already!

ex_1_jp: 「頼むから、現実を見てくれよ！これはケーキじゃなくてうんちなんだ！」
ex_1_en: "For God’s sake, face reality! This isn’t cake, it’s poop!"
meaning_story: The present is the truth. It is what's going on right now. It is reality.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: これを返品したいのですが。これが領収書です。
ex_1_en: I’d like to return this. Here’s the receipt.
meaning_story: I obtain some territory, so I want a written record of it. How will I get a written record of my obtained territory? How about with a receipt? Emailing one will do just fine.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: リョーシューショ *** リョーシューショꜜ

ex_1_jp: 上司にはっきりと「あなたの代わりはいくらでもいる」と言われたので、その会社を辞職しました。
ex_1_en: My boss told me flat-out that I was disposable, so I left the company.
meaning_story: If you quit your place of employment, you are quitting, aka putting in your resignation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 革命の後、情勢は好転した。
ex_1_en: The situation changed for the better after the revolution.
meaning_story: Leather's fate is in the hands of a revolution. It's the leather revolution! Off with these normal clothes and on with leather ones!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今朝、たくさんの兎が庭で律動的に飛び跳ねているのを見ました。
ex_1_en: This morning, I saw a lot of rabbits jumping rhythmically in my garden.
meaning_story: The law of movement is governed by rhythm. Imagine moving around to a boss beat. As you move, you start to feel the rhythm in your step. Go ahead and walk around your room and feel this rhythm. Note that リズム is probably going to be more common of a word to use for rhythm, but this is a kanji learning site after all. One thing you will see more often is 律動的 which means "rhythmic."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: インターネットは今後の選挙において益々重要な役割を担っていくでしょう。
ex_1_en: The internet will play a more important role in future elections.
meaning_story: Let's divide the duty up amongst various people. Each person will have their own role in completing this duty.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. See how we divide up the duty of learning kanji into radicals and kanji and vocab? Makes it nice, right? Each piece is its own 役割.
pitch_accent: ヤクワリ *** ヤクワꜜリ *** ヤクワリꜜ

ex_1_jp: 「それが規則だ。分かったか？」「分かりました。」
ex_1_en: "Those are the rules. Understand?" "I understand."
meaning_story: A standard rule is just one of the rules or regulations. Nothing weird about these rules.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 規律に従って酒は一滴たりとも飲んでいないと断言します。
ex_1_en: I swear I followed the rules and didn’t drink, not even a drop.
meaning_story: The standard laws are the rules and laws you have to know about life. With these standard laws comes order and discipline from the people as well. If you don't have these it will be chaos!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼は責任感が強いのかもしれないけど、私には少し失礼で自分勝手な気がしました。
ex_1_en: He may have a strong sense of responsibility, but to me he seemed a little rude and selfish.
meaning_story: 責任 is responsibility. If you add 感 you get a "feeling of responsibility." That's not really a thing people say. What people do say, however, is sense of responsibility. Do you have one?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: こんな長い台詞、よく覚えられるわね。
ex_1_en: You remember these long speeches well.
meaning_story: A part of speech machine spits out speeches. It's all the machine is programmed to do.
reading_story: The reading for this is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you: The only font the machine can print speeches in is serif font (せりふ).

ex_1_jp: 私達は、製品の品質において、業界基準を大きく上回っています。
ex_1_en: The quality of our product is far above industry standards.
meaning_story: The foundation of your standard is where you place your standard. No more, no less. This foundation is where the standard is all based off of.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の兄は一度心肺停止にまで至ったんですが、外科医が心臓マッサージを施した後に、心臓が再び脈動しだしたんです。
ex_1_en: My brother once went into cardiopulmonary arrest, but his heart started beating again after the surgeon performed a cardiac massage.
meaning_story: Halt and stop. When something does this, it's in a stoppage.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 優秀なシステム管理者は、ハッキングによるいかなる攻撃の可能性にも備えます。
ex_1_en: Superior system administrators prepare for any possibility of hacking.
meaning_story: Something that's superior will excel. It is superior in every way.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: フロリダのとある沢のほとりで、巨大なワニを見ました。
ex_1_en: I saw a gigantic alligator near a swamp in Florida.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: The beginning of the word "swamp" is actually pretty similar to this word's reading. さわ = "swa"? I'd say it's close enough to make a mnemonic out of in your head.

ex_1_jp: あの教師は歴史認識をころころ変えるからあまり好きじゃない。
ex_1_en: I don’t like that teacher because he is always flip-flopping on historical facts.
meaning_story: A teaching expert/teacher is a teacher.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「この河豚、ちょっと高すぎますよ。まけてもらえませんか？」「一割引きにしてあげましょう。」
ex_1_en: "This blowfish is too expensive. Can you give me a discount?" "We’ll give you a 10% discount."
meaning_story: One division is ten percent. You'll just have to imagine this in terms of tens going by. Must be some old Japanese percentage system that carried over or something. Just remember that one wari is ten percent, two waris are twenty percent, and so on.
reading_story: The readings are the same as what you learned with the kanji. You know much more than ten percent of this word's reading already.

ex_1_jp: 私の猫はおそらく夕飯時頃に現れるでしょう。
ex_1_en: My cat will probably appear around mealtime.
meaning_story: The kanji means present time, but when something "does present time" it is making itself known in the present time. It is showing itself. When it does present time, it causes it to appear or to emerge (as in right now, during the present time).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It looks like something is going to appear in front of you. You are so scared and surprised you can't even speak properly: "Are what??" (あらわ) you ask, trying to figure out what's appearing in front of you.

ex_1_jp: 彼はあなたの命の恩人なんだから、誕生日会に呼んだ方がいいわよ。
ex_1_en: He saved your life so you should invite him to your birthday party.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means call so the verb vocab version is to call or to call out. As in "HEY, YOU!"
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji, so you should be good here. Just imagine yourself calling out to someone: "YO (よ)! You!"

ex_1_jp: 我が社がついに赤字を脱したことを確認した時、私は胸を撫で下ろしました。
ex_1_en: I was so relieved when I confirmed that our company finally got out of the red.
meaning_story: 確認 is confirmation. When that's a verb, you have to confirm or to verify.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help immensely if you know the word 確認 already as well.

ex_1_jp: あそこで虫をついばんでいる鳥は、国際間で保護することが取り決められた鳥です。
ex_1_en: The bird pecking at worms over there is actually an endangered bird species and is to be protected worldwide.
meaning_story: To Preserve and defend something is to conserve and to protect. I won't let you destroy this land I'm trying to protect!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の彼は、散々私を批判した後で飴をくれた。
ex_1_en: My boyfriend gave me a hard candy after harshly criticizing me.
meaning_story: 批判 is criticism so the verb version of that would be to criticize.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will be much easier to read this if you know 批判, as well.

ex_1_jp: 酔っぱらった時に何をしでかしたかを考慮すると、あなたは絶対にお酒を断つべきですよ。
ex_1_en: Take into account that you don’t know what you could do while you’re drunk, so you should really cut yourself off from drinking alcohol.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cut off so the verb vocab version is to cut off. Don't confuse this with 断る which means "to refuse." You know this is to cut off because of the つ, which hints that you have had two (つ) too many chocolates, and it's time to cut you off.
reading_story: URGH! The reading isn't even the same as 断る, how frustrating. To Cut Off is read as たつ. Instead of eating too many chocolates and getting cut off, maybe you're eating too many tater tots (たつ). Don't eat so many of those, it's unhealthy. You have to cut off tater tots from your diet so you don't get fat.

ex_1_jp: 7割る2が3で余りが1になることを解くのに一時間かかった。
ex_1_en: It took me an hour to figure out that 7 divided by 2 equals 3 with a remainder of 1.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means divide so the verb vocab version is to divide.
reading_story: The reading you learned with the kanji is the one you'll use here. It's the わ one, though, making it わる.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの会長を決めるのに、毎年選挙をするべきだと思います。
ex_1_en: I think we should have an election every year to decide the Tofugu Chairman.
meaning_story: Election is 選挙 so when you make that word into a verb, you have to elect.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, the reading just comes from 選挙 so if you know that you know this as well.

ex_1_jp: このクーポン券を使えば、血液を検査するのに10ドルの節約になります。
ex_1_en: If you use this coupon, you can save ten dollars when you get your blood checked.
meaning_story: You know that 検査 is inspection, so the verb version of that would be to inspect.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 検査 already as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は鼻くそをほじくることだけには秀でています。実際、鼻血を出すはめになったこともありません。
ex_1_en: The only thing I excel at is picking my nose. In fact, I have never made my nose bleed.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means excel so the verb vocab version is to excel.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "He-e (ひい) is going to excel," you stutter. "He-e is!"

ex_1_jp: 私は本当に何もやっていません。今朝そこで、父のためにちょっと用事を済ませていただけなんです。
ex_1_en: I swear I didn’t do anything. I was just running some errands there for my dad this morning.
meaning_story: Remember 済む and how it means "to come to an end." This is like that, but slightly different. This is to finish or to settle, because this is when you're doing the coming to an end action. You can remember this because you're coming in to finish the score uno mas (ます)times. This is the last time.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with 済む, so if you know that you'll be able to finish this vocab.

ex_1_jp: 平日に家族と過ごす時間を増やすために、宿題は全部週末にやることにしてるんだ。
ex_1_en: I save all my homework for the weekend so I can spend more time with my family on weekdays.
meaning_story: Remember how 増える is "to increase" (as in, something just increases, you aren't doing the increasing yourself). This one is that one, where you're doing the increasing. So, this word means to increase something. You know you're doing the increasing because you said "yes" (やす) to increasing something, and did it yourself.
reading_story: The reading is the same like 増える. If you know that vocab word you probably can read this one as well.

ex_1_jp: その男が殺人犯であることがわかったが、時効を迎えているので法的には誰も彼を裁く事ができない。
ex_1_en: It came out that the man is a murderer, but the statute of limitations already ran out, so no one is legally able to place judgement on him.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means judge so the verb version is to judge.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you go to judge people, there are different types. The one you truly hate the most, however, is the sobber (さば). "The Sobber" is the worst kind. They just sob and sob and sob and it's really hard to move on to your next judging.

ex_1_jp: 聞いたことから判断すると、真打ちは最後にあるようだね。
ex_1_en: Judging from what I’ve heard, the best seems to have been saved for last.
meaning_story: 判断 is judgement. Make that into a verb and you have to judge.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 判断 before learning this, but if you don't I won't judge you (the Crabigator will).

ex_1_jp: このお方をどなたと心得るか。
ex_1_en: Does anyone know who this woman is?
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 得る means "to acquire?" Well when you acquire something, it stays in your heart and you start to know it really well. So just remember that when you acquire something in your heart you'll know!
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あなたは父のことを誤解していると思います。彼は決して誰かを凶悪犯罪へと導くような人ではありません。
ex_1_en: I think you misunderstand my father. He’s not the type of person who would lead someone into committing a heinous crime.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lead so the verb vocab version is to lead.
reading_story: The reading for this one is a bit difficult, but there's a hint in the kanji. See the 道 in there on the top? What's the reading for the vocab version of that kanji? It's みち. That's the first part. Now, who are you leading? Lets say you're leading a bee back to its nest, via the road. It's a 道 Bee (みちび)!

ex_1_jp: こんな大役を演ずることができて、とても光栄です。
ex_1_en: I am very honored to be able to play such an important role.
meaning_story: If 演 is performance then the verb version of this would be to perform.
reading_story: The reading looks weird, but it's actually just the reading you learned with the kanji.
pitch_accent: エンズル *** エンズꜜル

ex_1_jp: 気持ちを引き締めて敵の攻撃に備えろ！
ex_1_en: Brace yourself and prepare for your opponent’s attack!
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means provide so the verb vocab version is to provide.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to provide your friends with their own sauna (そな) because they don't want to use your shower. This requires you to go out and buy a sauna for your house (very expensive) just so you can provide your needy friends with what they want (a sauna). Feel angry you have to provide this.
pitch_accent: ソナエꜜル *** ソナꜜエル

ex_1_jp: 私は結婚式を市役所で挙げましたが、そのことを恥ずかしいとは思っていません。
ex_1_en: I held my wedding ceremony in city hall, but I’m not ashamed of that.
meaning_story: Remember 挙がる, which means "to rise"? Well, this word means to raise or to elevate, and this time you're the one doing the raising.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 挙がる, so if you know that reading you should know this one as well.

part_of_speech: INTRANSITIVE VERB, TRANSITIVE VERB, AND GODAN VERB
ex_1_jp: バレーボールのネットを張ったのは誰ですか？
ex_1_en: Who put up the volleyball net?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stretch so the verb version is to stretch.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine yourself trying to stretch (or better yet stand up and do it). Every time you stretch you start to laugh uncontrollably. HA (は) HA HA HA HA HA. Go ahead and laugh like that out loud while you stretch, it will help you to remember this reading.

ex_1_jp: お前が彼のことを愛しているのは理解するけど、あいつがお前にキスをするのは許せないよ。
ex_1_en: I understand you love him, but I can’t forgive him for kissing you.
meaning_story: 理解 is understanding, so the verb version would be...? How about to understand or to comprehend? Well, do you?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, if you know 理解 already this one is easy to comprehend.

ex_1_jp: プレゼントのリボンを解くのが好きなんです。
ex_1_en: I like untying the bows on presents.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means untie so the verb vocab version is to untie. You know this verb is when you are doing the actual untying because you think it's super coo' (く) to untie things, which is why you do it nonstop.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 解ける, so if you know that you can read this one too.

ex_1_jp: 木の幹に絡まっているツタを取り除いた方がいいよ。
ex_1_en: You should remove the ivy winding around the tree trunk.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When you cut the tree down to produce a tree trunk, out jumps Mickey Mouse. "WHY YOU CUT DOWN MY TREE BRO?" he yells. I'm Mickey Mouse and I don't stand for this.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: この貯金箱には小遣いからためた80ドルが入っているんだけど、裁判を起こすには到底足りないと思うんだよね。
ex_1_en: This piggy bank contains the eighty dollars I’ve saved from my allowance, but I guess it is not close to enough to file a lawsuit.
meaning_story: You're going to get judged times two. Judge and judge again. Once by the judge and another time by the jury. This is a whole trial here.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はん goes to ばん though, so be careful.

ex_1_jp: 彼は完璧な夫ですが、一つだけ問題があるんです。十年間ずっと無職なんです。
ex_1_en: He would be the perfect husband, save for one thing - he has been unemployed for ten years.
meaning_story: When the status of your employment is "nothing" then you're probably experiencing unemployment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 学校では日本語でしか話してはいけないという不文律のようなものがあります。

ex_1_jp: この川がちょうど両州の境となっているんですよ。
ex_1_en: This river forms the boundary between the two states.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You walk up to the boundary. You're there to pick something up to take it across. This thing you're smuggling across the boundary is a sockeye (さかい) salmon. You take it across the boundary and sell it for a big profit.

pronunciation: かねんごみ, かねんゴミ
ex_1_jp: あなたが私から貰うクリスマスプレゼントは、可燃ごみだけだよ。

meaning_story: Possible to burn ゴミ (garbage). This is burnable garbage.

ex_1_jp: 笑いは人間だけの特質なのかな？それとも動物も笑うのかな？
ex_1_en: Is laughter a characteristic that only humans have, or can animals laugh as well?
meaning_story: Your special quality is your characteristics or your traits.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お前の子供、イケメンすぎて、お前の子供だとは思えねーよ。
ex_1_en: Your child is way too good looking, I can hardly believe he’s your kid.
meaning_story: A child servant is a child. Children are basically like little servants anyways, what else are they good for?
reading_story: The readings for this one are the kun'yomi readings of each kanji. 子 is just こ, like the individual vocab word. 供 is ども, however. Remember this by thinking how much children love domo-kun. Also, 子ども is kind of more "politically correct" with the kana hanging off there. 子供 is still used in a lot of situations, usually stiff ones. The second kanji means servant, and some people don't like that. It's still used quite a bit though, but the second version pops up a decent amount, so it's good to be familiar with that as well.

ex_1_jp: もし「親展」と書かれている封書を勝手に開けたら、信書開封罪とみなされて一年以下の懲役又は二十万円以下の罰金に課せられるかもしれませんよ。
ex_1_en: If you opened a sealed envelope marked "Confidential" without permission, it could be considered as an unlawful opening of a letter and you could be punished with imprisonment with work detail for under one year, or a fine of up to 200,000 yen.

ex_1_jp: 私の兄は、東京都警視庁公安部に勤めています。
ex_1_en: My brother works for the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department Public Security Bureau.
meaning_story: They warn, they look at crime, and they're an agency of the government. They are the metropolitan police department.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どうして日本人は血液型をそんなに気にするんですか？
ex_1_en: Why do Japanese people care about blood types so much?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: What model cutter (かた) is this? I can only use a certain type for my work.

ex_1_jp: 月額たったの5ドルでできる新しい日本語学習体験を促進するための広告キャンペーンを打ち始めます。
ex_1_en: We are starting an advertising campaign to encourage a new Japanese learning experience that costs only five dollars a month.
meaning_story: A month's amount is the monthly amount.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 結婚相手と価値観が近いことって結構大切だと思うんだよねー。
ex_1_en: I think it’s quite important to share similar values with your spouse.
meaning_story: These views have merit (価値). What views have the best merit? Moral values.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: カチꜜカン *** カチカꜜン

ex_1_jp: かわいそうなことに、彼の視力はレーシック手術の後に一層悪化してしまった。
ex_1_en: I feel sorry that his eye sight got even worse after the lasik surgery.
meaning_story: One layer... that's it? We need much more!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. いち goes to いっ.

ex_1_jp: コウイチ、おもちゃを片付けなさい！さもないと、暗くて狭いクローゼットに閉じ込めるわよ。
ex_1_en: Koichi, put your toys away! If you don’t I’ll put you in the dark, narrow closet.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of narrow? It's narrow.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji, so you're good to go here. It may be a narrow way of thinking about this kanji, but it will help you out the most.

ex_1_jp: 国境警備隊の隊員がアメリカに不法入国した外国人を国境のそばの茂みで見つけることはよくあることです。
ex_1_en: It’s common for a US Border Patrol Guard to find an illegal alien in the bushes right by the national border fence.
meaning_story: A country boundary is that country's national border. Be careful about crossing it if you're carrying bananas. The border police seem to hate when you tell them you're carrying a banana in your pants when they ask you if you're bringing any fruits back. No idea why.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The こく gets shortened to a nice little こっ.
pitch_accent: クニザꜜカイ *** コッキョー

ex_1_jp: 警視庁と警察庁の違いは何ですか？
ex_1_en: What’s the difference between the Metropolitan Police Department and the National Police Agency?
meaning_story: Unlike the 警視庁, who look at things, this is just the police officer (警察) agency. Just the general police agency of the whole country, making them part of the National Police Agency.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ケイサツꜜチョー *** ケイサꜜツチョー

ex_1_jp: 私は近視と乱視の両方があります。
ex_1_en: I have both nearsightedness and an astigmatism.
