meaning_story: When you can look at things that are near well but you can't see things far away, you have nearsightedness. Good to get those eyes checked out occasionally.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: ふねんごみ, ふねんゴミ
ex_1_jp: 不燃ゴミは火曜日に出してください。
ex_1_en: Please take out the nonburnable garbage on Tuesday.
meaning_story: These are not burnable garbages (ごみ). Pay attention to this on signs when you throw things away. You want to put the right things into nonburnable garbage.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本で臓器提供者になる同意書にサインをするには、どうすればいいですか？
ex_1_en: How can I register to become an organ donor in Japan?
meaning_story: When you present something to your servant you're doing them a favor. You're kindly giving them an offer. Or, because they're a poor student, maybe you're offering program sponsoring to them. You know, because you're so nice.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 営業中に電話しないでって言ったじゃない。
ex_1_en: I asked you not to call me when the shop is open.
meaning_story: 営業 means running a business. You're in the middle of running a business, which means you're open for business (otherwise you wouldn't be in the middle of running it, you'd be at the beginning or something).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 営業 first.

ex_1_jp: この場合は過去形は使わないんですか？
ex_1_en: Don’t you use the past tense in this case?
meaning_story: The past shape is how things were in the past. To describe those things (like you would with an adjective, aka 形容詞), you'd use past tense.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本にUFO現象を調査しているUFO団体はありますか？
ex_1_en: Are there any UFO groups investigating the UFO phenomenons in Japan?
meaning_story: A present time phenomenon is a phenomenon whether it's in the present or in the future or in the past.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 妹は二歳の時に甘い咳止めシロップを一気飲みしてしまい、鼻から管を通して胃を洗浄するはめになった。
ex_1_en: My sister chugged a bottle of the sweet kind of cough syrup when she was two and she had to get a tube shoved through her nose and into her stomach to pump it out.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: "That's coo' だ," you like to say in response to pipes. You've never seen pipes before, which makes them pretty cool to you. You've been using an outhouse your whole life, so pipes are pretty neat.

ex_1_jp: 洗面台の下にタオル置き場があるから、シャワーの後勝手に取って使ってね。
ex_1_en: We have a place for the towels under the sink, so help yourself after your shower.
meaning_story: 置く is to put down something. So a location where you put something down is a place to put something.
reading_story: The reading is the readings of 置く and 場 put together.

ex_1_jp: 『古事記』所載の日本最古の和歌について何か知っていますか？
ex_1_en: Do you know anything about the Japanese first waka published in the Kojiki?
meaning_story: The item is in a place in its existence where it is published. If something is in this place, it is printed and published.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 我が社の新製品に関する会議を火曜日の午後に延期することは可能かな？
ex_1_en: Would it be possible to postpone the launch of our new product until Tuesday afternoon?
meaning_story: Manufactured goods are manufactured goods. What does that end up being? A product.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私たちはまず初めに、粘土で彫刻の原型を作るんです。
ex_1_en: We usually sculpt a model out of clay at first.
meaning_story: The original model of something isn't usually very good. It's rough. It's a prototype.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 外国語指導助手の質は人によって全然違うので、心配です。
ex_1_en: The quality of assistant foreign language teachers varies from person to person and I’m worried about that.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 仕事の量を考えると、この給料じゃ割りに合わない。
ex_1_en: Given the amount of work, we’re being badly paid.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 彼はある観客からの予想外の質問にたじろいだ。
ex_1_en: He flinched at the unexpected question from an audience member.
meaning_story: A quality problem is worth a question. A low quality problem however... don't ask the question. There are stupid questions, after all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 小論文を提出したが、日付を記載するのを忘れてしまった。
ex_1_en: I turned in my essay but I forgot to record the date on it.
meaning_story: Please write down and publish this so we have a record of it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 残額は五百円あるので、次の旅行に繰り越すこともできるし、半日市内バス観光をすることもできます。
ex_1_en: The balance is 500 yen, so we could carry it over to the next trip or we could also go on a half-day bus tour of the city.
meaning_story: The remainder amount is the remaining amount.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ああ、君が応援団長だね？噂はかねがね伺っておるよ。
ex_1_en: Hey, you are the leader of the cheerleaders, right? I’ve heard a lot about you.
meaning_story: A group that roots for you is your rooting section or cheerleaders. Go go go you!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 応援 is a word you've seen before, so if you know that this word will be easier.

ex_1_jp: 我が社の販売員の多くは、八月に休暇を取ります。
ex_1_en: Many of the salespeople at our company are taking time off work in August.
meaning_story: Sell, sell, sell. This is the attitude you need if you want to work in sales or do sales. You have to work on your selling.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which means you need to know the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You know them both, hurray!

ex_1_jp: コウイチは武士のようにストイックに走り続け、フルマラソンを完走した。
ex_1_en: Koichi kept running as stoically as a samurai and finished the full marathon.
meaning_story: A military samurai is a samurai. This is how most people say "samurai" in Japanese.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ブꜜシ *** モノノフ *** モノノꜜフ

ex_1_jp: 視覚障害のある社員を差別したとの理由から、上司が解雇された。
ex_1_en: My superior was fired for discrimination against a visually disabled worker.
meaning_story: You look at things and memorize them via your sight, using your sense of sight.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 肩がこっているんだけど、ちょっと揉んでくれない？
ex_1_en: My shoulders are stiff, so could you rub them a bit?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 彼は世間の規準からはちょっと外れた、ユニークな人です。
ex_1_en: He is a unique person who is slightly out of the ordinary.
meaning_story: The standard of standards is the main standard we work off of.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは株でガッポリ儲けたので、車のタイヤをどでかいホイール・タイヤに変えて、シートも革張りにしてカッチョ良くしちゃおうと決めた。
ex_1_en: Koichi made tons of money on the stock market and decided to swag out his car with big wheels and leather seats.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 株式市場が底なしの下落に陥ったようだというニュースは、彼に大きな精神的ダメージを与えた。
ex_1_en: The news that the stock market seemed to go into a bottomless decline was a great blow to him.
meaning_story: A stocks ritual is the dance a stock company has to do for their shareholders to keep them happy. Must be tough being a stock company.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: これはとても主観的な見方かもしれないけど、僕にとっては君は働き過ぎだと思うんだよね。近々休みを取った方がいいよ。
ex_1_en: This may be a very subjective view, but to me, you work too much and should take time off sometime soon.
meaning_story: 主観 is subjectivity. So when something moves towards subjectivity it is becoming subjective.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know 主観.

ex_1_jp: 勤続三十年の従業員は、勤続手当として二週間連続有給休暇の対象となる。
ex_1_en: Employees who work for this company for thirty years are subject to two straight weeks off with full pay as a reward for their many years of service to the company.
meaning_story: The versus phenomenon is what you're going up against. It's your target because you're heading towards this phenomenon you're versusing against.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: まだ時差ボケに苦しんでいるんです。
ex_1_en: I’m still suffering from jet lag.
meaning_story: The time distinction is how you tell apart time zones. It is the time difference.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 俺はポテトチップス一袋を買うのに、他人からの援助を必要とするほど貧しい。
ex_1_en: I’m so poor that I need help from others just to buy a bag of potato chips.
meaning_story: You know that 援助 is assistance or aid. So the verb vocab version is to assist or to aid.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 援助. It is also just the readings you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguからの手紙がちょうど今届きました。
ex_1_en: The letter from Tofugu was just delivered.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deliver so the verb vocab version here is to be delivered or to arrive. You know this one is "to be delivered" (aka it's just getting delivered, you aren't doing the delivery) because when this item arrives at your house you say "coo'" (く), it arrived.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji: とど!

ex_1_jp: ベテラン社員とは違って、新入社員の基本給はあまり高くない。
ex_1_en: The base pay of new employees isn’t very high, it’s different for veteran employees.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means different so the verb vocab version is to be different... and of course, to be different is also to be wrong in Japan. Don't be different!
reading_story: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. It's not different at all.

ex_1_jp: 新入社員の代表として受けた私のインタビュー記事が、社内報の春季号に載りました。
ex_1_en: My interview as the representative of the entry-level employees was published in the spring edition of the company newsletter.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means publish so the verb vocab version is to be published. You know this is "to be published" (you're not doing the publishing) because it is rude (る) to not read something your friend has published.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Did you get your work published? Did someone publish your writing for you? NO (の). This is usually the answer to this question, that or "No, I'm self-published."

ex_1_jp: 何かを完全に灰になるまで燃やすことが大好きだ。
ex_1_en: I really like burning things until they’re reduced to ashes.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means burn and the verb vocab version is to burn something (or to burn).
reading_story: This is when you're burning something. To remember this meaning, you have to remember the も part. So, just think of your friend Moe (も), and how you're going to burn him... uh... just a little bit.

ex_1_jp: 日本に行ったら、お祭りで神輿を担いでみたい。
ex_1_en: If I go to Japan, I’d like to carry a portable shrine in a parade.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carry so the verb vocab version is to carry. This has to do with carrying something literal, unlike 担う which is not necessarily literal. You can remember that it's literal from the reading mnemonic, which has you carrying literal cats.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You love to carry things, especially cats (かつ).

ex_1_jp: 日曜日におじいちゃんの還暦を祝うために、中華を食べに行きます。
ex_1_en: We are going to a Chinese restaurant to celebrate grandpa’s 60th birthday on Sunday.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means celebrate, so the verb vocab version is to celebrate. When you burn this word, you should 祝う!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you celebrate something, you have to yell out your celebrations. Yell out いわう three times! It's kind of like a combination of the word いい (good) and "wow." いいwow! いいwow! Just make sure the いい gets shortened, because it's getting combined.

ex_1_jp: 年寄りの風邪は肺炎に発展しやすいんだよ。
ex_1_en: When old people catch a cold, it can easily develop into pneumonia.
meaning_story: Let's depart from this place and expand it out. To do that we'll have to develop it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はつ gets shortened to はっ, though.

ex_1_jp: 休暇届を申請したが、上司に無視された。
ex_1_en: I requested a day off for personal reasons, but my boss ignored it.
meaning_story: I will look at nothing. I am going to ignore you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 明日お墓に供える花を、帰りに買ってきてくれない？
ex_1_en: Can you buy some flowers to place on the graves tomorrow on your way home?
meaning_story: You don't servant something... but what do servants do? You are their god, so they have to make an offering to you every day.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The offering you demand from your servants? A sonata (そな), written in your honor.
pitch_accent: ソナエꜜル *** ソナꜜエル

ex_1_jp: 体重計で自分の体重を量るのが恐い。
ex_1_en: I’m scared of weighing myself on the scale.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means quantity, but you don't "to quantity." To figure out the quantity, however, you have to measure / to weigh whatever it is you want to get the quantity of.
reading_story: You need to measure the quantity of something, but don't have a scale or anything. Luckily, you are quite the hacker (はか) and hack together a scale using only rubber bands and beans.

ex_1_jp: 上司に全く正反対の意見を述べるのは気が引けます。
ex_1_en: I don’t feel like explaining to my boss that I have a completely different opinion than he has.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mention so the verb vocab version is to mention.
reading_story: I have to mention this thing... "NO," (の) you quickly respond. I don't want you mentioning that here and now.

ex_1_jp: 短時間の仕事で良い給料をもらい過ぎだよ。
ex_1_en: You get paid way too well for working such short hours.
meaning_story: 過ぎる is to surpass. When you surpass what is needed, what are you left with? Just this word: too much.
reading_story: The reading comes from 過ぎる. Know that and you know too much. Dial it down to get 過ぎ.

ex_1_jp: 「しまった！寝坊した！」と思ったんですが、有り難いことに日曜日でした。
ex_1_en: I thought, "Oh no! I overslept," but thankfully, it was Sunday.
meaning_story: 寝坊 is oversleep. Make that into a verb and you have to oversleep.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It also just takes the reading from 寝坊.

ex_1_jp: 人を指差すのは失礼だよ。
ex_1_en: It’s rude to point at people.
meaning_story: When you want to use your finger to explain the distinction between more than one thing you need to point at it. Otherwise the person you're talking to won't be able to tell which one you're talking about.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 本日は、新しい投資信託をご提案させて頂きたいと思います。
ex_1_en: I’d like to propose a new mutual fund to you today.
meaning_story: You remember 提案, which means proposition? Make that into a verb and you have to propose.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どちらの力士を応援しているんだい？
ex_1_en: Which sumo wrestler are you rooting for?
meaning_story: 応援 is aid and root for, but for this verb the "root for" one is going to be more on the money. You can call this To root for, to cheer on or to cheer for.
reading_story: The reading comes from 応援. It's also just the on'yomi readings you learned.

ex_1_jp: 道ばたで営業する占い師が、どれくらいのお金を稼ぐのか知ってる？
ex_1_en: Do you know how much money a fortune teller doing business on the street makes?
meaning_story: 営業 is running a business. The verb version of that is to run a business.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, it shares the reading with 営業.

ex_1_jp: 窓の外を見ると、もう雨が上がって薄日が差していた。
ex_1_en: When I looked outside the window, the rain had already stopped and a soft light was shining through.
meaning_story: The kanji is distinction. To distinct something would be nice, but this is used more like to shine at or to shine on, like when a light shines on someone on a stage, distinguishing them from everyone else.
reading_story: The reading of the kanji is actually the same as the reading for this word, making things easy (both on'yomi and kun'yomi are さ).

ex_1_jp: 何が起ころうが君を支援しようとしたけど、できなかったんだ。
ex_1_en: I tried to stand by you no matter what happened, but I failed.
meaning_story: To support and aid is to support.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お菓子代は、全額自己負担でお願いします。
ex_1_en: Please pay the total amount for the candy yourself.
meaning_story: All of the amount is your total.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 上司が私のお尻を触った翌日、私は会社を一日休んだ。
ex_1_en: I took a full day off from work the day after my boss touched my butt.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means touch so the verb vocab version is to touch.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're an idiot. You try to touch a saw (さわ).

ex_1_jp: このストールの感触、シルクみたい。
ex_1_en: This scarf feels like silk.
meaning_story: Your feeling of touch is your touch sense (or simply just touch).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その観光客は、アメリカで医者の診断書をもらうために50ドルを支払わなければならなかった。
ex_1_en: The tourist had to pay $50 to get a doctor’s note in the U.S.
meaning_story: Sightseeing (観光) guests are tourists and sightseers.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 観光 as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の兄は、カフェで初めての美術展示会を開催した。
ex_1_en: My brother organized his first art exhibition in a cafe.
meaning_story: I want to expand my business. I want to show my goods. I want to do this in a place where everyone meets up to do these things. You can do this in a trade show.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 褌は、伝統的な日本の男性用下着です。
ex_1_en: Fundoshi is traditional Japanese underwear for guys.
meaning_story: Transmits the feeling of wanting to unite behind something. What do people unite behind, if they're all part of a similar people? Tradition. Add 的 on there and you have traditional.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 輸送コストを教えて下さい。
ex_1_en: Please tell me the transportation cost.
meaning_story: You want to transport something by sending it? Well that's transportation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうして彼のことを典型的な日本人だっていうの？
ex_1_en: Why do you call him a typical Japanese person?
meaning_story: The rule model is the model that follows all the rules. It's the normal model. It is typical.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 中小企業が海外展開をする利点とは何でしょうか。
ex_1_en: What are the advantages of small businesses expanding overseas?
meaning_story: To expand and open. Just imagine something happening like this. This is when something is unfolding or in development.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 10月23日の自動販売機に関する会議は、コウイチの誕生日会のため、10月24日に変更されました。
ex_1_en: The October twenty-third meeting about the vending machines has been rescheduled for October twenty-fourth due to Koichi’s birthday party.
meaning_story: Automatic (自動) sell sell machine. The machine sells things by itself, basically. This is a vending machine. There is a shorter version of this, but good to learn the long one first :)
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Remember those, and you'll be fine here.

ex_1_jp: やってみるべきだと思うけど。大統領は無理でも、副大統領ぐらいなら狙えるんじゃない？
ex_1_en: I think we should give it a try. You may not become the president, but maybe you’ll become the vice president.
meaning_story: You know about 大統領 (president), right? Well, this is the vice version of the president, aka the vice president.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know the word 大統領 first, though.

ex_1_jp: 腰に激痛が走ってるんだ。もう一歩も歩けないよ。
ex_1_en: My waist is in intense pain. I can’t take another step.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 全ての警察官に武器を使う資格があるわけではないというのは本当ですか？
ex_1_en: Is it true that not all police officers are qualified to use their weapons?
meaning_story: A container used by the military is probably going to be used as a weapon. After all, that's what the military does... weapons.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 気象予報士と気象学者の違いが説明できますか。
ex_1_en: Can you explain the difference between forecasters and meteorologists?
meaning_story: The energy phenomenon. That's when energy is doing stuff in the sky and nobody understands it. That's the weather for you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 俺の木製バットは、あいつの内角速球によって折れてしまったんだ。
ex_1_en: My wooden bat was broken by an inside fastball thrown by that guy.
meaning_story: Tree manufactured items are wooden / made from wood.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 俺の無くなった腕時計についてちょっと話がしたいんだけど、いいか？あまり時間は取らせないよ。
ex_1_en: Can we talk about my missing wristwatch for a second? I won’t take up too much of your time.
meaning_story: Remember how 時計 is watch? An arm is now there too, making this a wristwatch.
reading_story: The readings are the words 腕 (same reading as what you learned with the kanji) as well as the reading for 時計. Just don't forget that rendaku!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 毎月きちんとお金を払って頂けるなら、告訴はしません。
ex_1_en: I won’t take legal action as long as you pay me every month.
meaning_story: I've announced I'm going to sue you. The accusation and charge I have against you for suing you? Uh... You suck.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「ホグワーツ魔法魔術学校にはもう行きたくない。女優になりたいの。」「もう、馬鹿なこと言わないで。ハーマイオニーったら。」
ex_1_en: "I don’t want to go to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry anymore. I want to be an actress." "Oh, don’t be ridiculous, Hermione."
meaning_story: Remember how 男優 was "actor"? Well, I bet you can extrapolate what this one means because it now has woman in it. This is an actress.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ジムで水泳をすることが、最も効果的なダイエット方法だと聞きました。
ex_1_en: I heard swimming at the gym is the most effective way to lose weight.
meaning_story: The fruit of something that's effective is an effect.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ラッシュ時の電車内で痴漢行為を働いたとして、危うく誤認逮捕されるところだった。
ex_1_en: I was almost arrested by mistake for molestation on the rush hour train.
meaning_story: When you apprehend and catch someone, that leads to an arrest / capture.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 所属部署に病欠のための診断書を提出しておいた方がいいよ。
ex_1_en: You should turn in doctor’s notes for sick days to your own department.
meaning_story: A place where something belongs is where it is attached. It's where it's attached to. It belong(s) to that place.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは票の大半を得て相手候補者に圧勝し、アメリカ合衆国の大統領となった。
ex_1_en: Koichi defeated the other candidate with a majority of the votes and became the President of the United States of America.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It can also be a vote, because that's what ballots tend to do.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 給料日は毎月5日と20日で、会社の業績次第で賞与金が年末に支払われます。
ex_1_en: Our paydays are the fifth and the twentieth of every month and a bonus may be paid at the end of the year depending on how well the company has done.
meaning_story: It's a prize where you are given gold. In business, this is called a bonus. You didn't expect it (not your salary) and it is given to you (and is gold, if you're lucky).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本の景況感が大きく上向くのは、まだまだ先のことだろう。
ex_1_en: It is only in the far away future that Japan’s situation will soar.
meaning_story: Take a look at this scene and the condition it’s in. This is the climate of the situation, but more specifically the business climate. This word is really only used to talk about the state of business and economic stuff.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 学歴的には、候補者として十分通用するはずが、彼は性格に難があるからね。
ex_1_en: Academically speaking, the candidate would be very useful, but he has such a bad personality.
meaning_story: The candidate is someone who's a supplement to the entire political system. Despite being a supplement, (s)he's still a candidate nonetheless, unless she can win!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 気候は荒れ模様だが、新しい仕事ではいいスタートが切れた。
ex_1_en: I got off to a good start with my new job, considering the threatening climate.
meaning_story: The energy of the climate is the climate. High energy? Climate. Low energy. Climate.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は息を飲むような富士の全景を期待していたが、実際はかなりお粗末なものだった。
ex_1_en: I was expecting a breathtaking panorama of Mt. Fuji, but the reality of it was pretty pathetic.
meaning_story: When you can see all the scene you have a complete view.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: しっかりしろよ。状況はお前が思っているほど悪くないみたいだぜ。
ex_1_en: Get a grip! The situation isn’t as bad as you think.
meaning_story: The condition condition is the condition. It's also the circumstances if you can remember that. It's like saying "What's the condition!??" which is similar to saying "What's the circumstances?"
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 本日は捜査に関する重要書類を作成する予定です。
ex_1_en: I’m going to draw up some important documents for a criminal investigation today.
meaning_story: When you search and inspect things, you are probably part of a criminal investigation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「たばこ、止めたんじゃなかったの？」「まあ、ほら、『古い習慣はなかなかなくならない』って言うだろ。」
ex_1_en: "I thought you quit smoking." "Well, they say old habits die hard."
meaning_story: I've learned to be accustomed to this. It has become my custom and habit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「あんた、もう少しであの男を絞殺しかけたのよ！」「ごめん。やりすぎたよ。」
ex_1_en: "You almost strangled that guy to death!" "I’m sorry. I went too far."
meaning_story: A strangle kill is when you are strangled to death. Try to avoid this.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ちょうどホームページへ割引クーポンの追加をしようと思ってたところだよ。
ex_1_en: I’ll set about adding a discount coupon to the website.
meaning_story: Divide that price and pull it apart. You only have to pay for one part! What a discount.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. き from ひき kind of just gets stuffed into the 引き and hidden away like that strange collection of fingernails you have hidden in your closet drawer inside of a 35mm film container. Also remember that the reading gets changed to びき here because of that pesky rendaku.

ex_1_jp: この記事への反響はとても大きかった。
ex_1_en: The influence of this article was huge.
meaning_story: An anti echo is still an echo! It's just going back and forth with a normal echo. Together they get a weird reverberation going.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あなたの今日のプレゼンテーションは、前回に比べて効力が少し弱いような気がしました。
ex_1_en: Your presentation today seemed like it was a bit weaker in its effectiveness compared to the last one.
meaning_story: Your effective power is your effectiveness.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 効率が第一だということを、しっかり心に刻んで置いてください。
ex_1_en: Keep in mind that efficiency is our top priority.
meaning_story: Your effective percent shows how effective you are. If you're at an effective percent of 80%, that's your efficiency.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 年輩の上司が、牛の乳搾り体験の費用を払ってくれた。
ex_1_en: My elderly boss pays for the cost to experience milking cows.
meaning_story: Someone who is a comrade with years has been around a lot of said years. They are an elderly person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はい goes to a ぱい, because elderly persons love pie, right?

ex_1_jp: 「今日は他には何か、ございませんか？」「いいえ。それだけで結構です。」
ex_1_en: "Would you like anything else today?" "No, that’s alright."
meaning_story: Bind and set up everything so it is fairly fine and alright. This word is used like this: "That's fine, no more" 結構です "It's fairly big" 結構大きい "It's alright" 結構です etc.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The けつ shortens to けっ.

ex_1_jp: 上巻の終わりは、すごく続きが気になる感じで終わった。
ex_1_en: The ending of the first volume was a real cliff-hanger.
meaning_story: The above scroll is the top scroll, the one you read first. It's the first volume. Many Japanese books come in parts, so look for this if you want to get the first one.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このカメラでは、どうすれば前景の被写体にピントを合わせることができるんですか？
ex_1_en: How can I focus on something in the foreground with this camera?
meaning_story: The front scene is the foreground.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 前の職場では、止めろと言われるまでいつも残業していたので、毎日五時に退社するのはとても新鮮です。
ex_1_en: I always worked overtime at my last job until I was told to stop, so it’s very new to me to leave work at five o’clock every day.
meaning_story: New and fresh is fresh (has to be new if you want it to be fresh, after all).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 俺の魚屋で働いている限り、従業員は福利厚生として鮮魚をもらう権利を、放棄することはできないぜ。
ex_1_en: Employees cannot waive their right to receiving fresh fish as a benefit as long as they work for my fish shop.
meaning_story: Fresh fish is fresh fish (and the best fish, nom nom nom).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 明日の夜は満月なんだって。曇らないといいね。
ex_1_en: Tomorrow night will be a full moon. I hope it’s not cloudy.
meaning_story: The full moon is a full moon.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 誰にとっても、含意を汲み取るのは難しいことだ。
ex_1_en: It’s difficult for everyone to understand the implied meaning.
meaning_story: Include your ideas here, but think about the implications they will result in too, especially considering you're just including them now. They have implications!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今は絶好調のように思えるが、需要は無限には増加しないだろう？
ex_1_en: The situation looks bright at the moment, but the demand won’t increase perpetually, right?
meaning_story: The limit is nothing. What? No limit? That means it will never stop! It is infinite!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 残業は健康に悪影響を及ぼす可能性があるということを考えた方がいいですよ。
ex_1_en: You should consider that working extra hours may have a negative influence on your health.
meaning_story: In the shadows you still echo. Your echo leaves the shadows and hits people, creating an influence on them. You're like the shadow person pulling the strings, making things do what you want... influencing them.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 不規則な生活で体調を崩してしまった。
ex_1_en: A disorderly life will destroy your physical condition.
meaning_story: You know that 規則 means "rule" or "regulation." So a not "rule" or "regulation" is an irregularity.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: フキꜜソク *** フキソꜜク

ex_1_jp: お前は俺のお気に入りの後輩だから、どんなことがあってもちゃんと面倒みてやるよ。
ex_1_en: I’ll take care of you, no matter what happens because you’re my favorite underclassmen.
meaning_story: The comrade who's behind you is your junior.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 後 is the long こう reading, though. Just think of your junior being こういち.

ex_1_jp: 上巻を買ったつもりが下巻を買ってしまっていた。
ex_1_en: I thought I bought the first volume, but it was actually the last volume.
meaning_story: The scroll that's below is the last scroll you read, making it the last volume.
reading_story: The 下 uses the alternative reading of げ but 巻 is all good and normal.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: その訴訟に関する書類は、弁護士によって全てきちんとファイルされている。
ex_1_en: The documents related to the lawsuit have all been neatly filed away by the lawyer.
meaning_story: If you sue and bring about a lawsuit, you are bringing about a lawsuit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: かわじゃん, かわジャン
ex_1_jp: お洒落大好き人間にアドバイスされたってだけで、あんな高い革ジャンは買うわけないじゃん。
ex_1_en: I’m not buying such an expensive leather jacket just because a fashionista told me to.
meaning_story: 革 is leather and ジャン is short for ジャンパー (Jumper, like a jacket). So, put those together and you have a leather jacket.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the vocab word 革, because this word is like two separate words put together (so it's treated as single words too, giving it that reading).

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: お母さん、あの限定販売のTofugu人形が欲しいんだけど、百万ドルくれない？
ex_1_en: Mom, I really want the limited edition Tofugu dolls, so can’t you give me one million dollars?
meaning_story: Your limit is determined. It is where it is. It is your limit after all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その野球選手は、自分の限界を感じて引退した。
ex_1_en: The baseball player retired when he felt that he had reached his limit.
meaning_story: The limit of the world is the limit. It's the boundary too. You can't go beyond the world's limit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このクレジットカードの限度額がいくらだったか忘れちゃったんだよね。
ex_1_en: I forget what my limit is on this credit card.
meaning_story: The limit degree is how far you can go. It's your limit. Turn things up one more degree and it's too much. Keep it right where it is and it's perfect. It's your limit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 肥料工場での社員間のいざこざについて、どう対処していいか全くわかりませんでした。
ex_1_en: I had no idea how to handle the conflict among the workers at the fertilizer factory.
meaning_story: Your fee for being obese is lots of manure coming out of your butt. If you eat a lot you'll poop a lot of manure.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 厳しい景況にもかかわらず、あの金属メッキ工場は成長を続けている。
ex_1_en: The metal-plating factory is thriving despite the challenging business climate.
meaning_story: Gold belongs to this family... "What is metal?"
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 明日、塾で掛け算のテストがあるんです。
ex_1_en: There’s a multiplication test in cram school tomorrow.
meaning_story: If you try to calculate something, but instead you feel like urge to hang your teacher, you know you're doing multiplication. It's hard, guys. Like really hard. The hardest kind of math of them all. But you can do it! No one needs to get hanged. And don't hang your head in defeat either. Multiply those numbers like a boss! Hang the numbers instead!!
reading_story: This is the kun'yomi reading for 掛 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

ex_1_jp: 私は長崎県の出身で、家族の墓も全部そこにあります。
ex_1_en: I am from Nagasaki prefecture and my family graves are all located there, too.
meaning_story: Long Cape Prefecture. This will make more sense when you look at the reading. Hint: It's Nagasaki Prefecture.
reading_story: The readings are 長 from 長い, normal 崎 and normal 県.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あの肥満上司が、私たちに対する全権限を持っていて、先週は二名を解雇しやがったんだよ。
ex_1_en: That obese boss has authoritative power over us and he terminated two workers last week.
meaning_story: Obese and full. Probably not a good idea to eat until you're full if you're obese. That will lead to obesity.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 一巻では、全ての引用に脚注がつけられ出典が記されています。
ex_1_en: In the first volume, all sources are cited in the footnotes.
meaning_story: One scroll is one scroll back in the day, but now it refers to books and means one volume.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. いち goes to いっ.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: この映画は二部構成になっている。
ex_1_en: This movie is composed of two parts.
meaning_story: Set up and become something. When you set up and care for something like this you're doing organization of this thing. The configuration is so nice.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の妻は、小さな花の模様が好きです。
ex_1_en: My wife likes patterns with small flowers.
meaning_story: An imitation manner is something that does something in the manner of something else. Imitation over and over and over. Make it into a pattern.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 様 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. You see a pattern in your yogurt (よう). The yogurt is an imitation of life. So deep, man. So deep.

ex_1_jp: 満点をとったら、先生に花丸をもらえるの。
ex_1_en: When I get a perfect score, my teacher draws a flower on the paper.
meaning_story: Full points are when you get a perfect score.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 祖父は、最初は従業員一人の小売模型店からこのビジネスを始めました。
ex_1_en: My grandfather started his business out as a small one person plastic model retail shop.
meaning_story: An imitation model is obviously not the real thing. It's (usually) a plastic model or just a model figure or something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 毎日満員電車にぎゅうぎゅう詰めになって乗り込む人がたくさんいる以上、日本の生活がとても豊かだと言う事はできないね。
ex_1_en: As long as so many people have to squeeze onto the crowded train every day, I can’t say Japanese life is very satisfying.
meaning_story: This is the same as the kanji 豊, making it plentiful (though can also be abundant).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Don't worry, these resources are plentiful. You take (ゆた) what you want.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は豊満な胸をもっており、いつも美しい谷間を覗かせている。
ex_1_en: She has full breasts and always has lovely cleavage.
meaning_story: Plentiful and full, you are. That's the nice way of saying it. Actually, you're a bit plump. Wait, you want me to be nice again? Sorry, you're full figured.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 不況時に金の価格は上昇しやすい。
ex_1_en: The price of gold tends to rise during recessions.
meaning_story: A "not condition" is where nothing is going well. How are things going? Not well. The condition is bad. We're in a recession.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 規則正しい生活を送って下さい。
ex_1_en: Please live a regular life.
meaning_story: This is a combination of the words 規則 and 正しい, that you learned already. If you follow the correct rules everything will stay regular and well regulated.
reading_story: This is a combination of the words 規則 and 正しい, which you learned already, so you should be able to read this word too.

ex_1_jp: お前は本当に隠居したいのか？
ex_1_en: Do you really want to retire?
meaning_story: You hide away but you're alive. You've lived your life, so now it's time to hide and live the rest of it out until you're not alive. You've reached the age of retirement.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は情熱的なフランス人革命者と恋に落ちた。
ex_1_en: She fell in love with a passionate French revolutionary.
meaning_story: Someone who wants a revolution (革命) is someone who wants to change the government or whoever's in charge. What? Not in my house! This person will be known as a revolutionary.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course it will help to know 革命 already as well.

ex_1_jp: この音楽はとても律動的ですね。
ex_1_en: This music is very rhythmic.
meaning_story: Rhythm is 律動, but by adding a 的 in there we get the adjective version of that word, making it rhythmical or rhythmic.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 律動. The 的 part you should also be able to read by now.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ビジネスが順調なので、ようやく満足しています。
ex_1_en: My business is doing well so I finally feel satisfied.
meaning_story: I am full and sufficient. I am satisfied.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that the reading for 足 in this one is ぞく because of that pesky rendaku.

ex_1_jp: あなたにとってはただの規模の小さな会社かもしれませんが、私は両親の会社に誇りをもっています。
ex_1_en: It may be just a small scale firm to you, but I’m proud of my parents’ company.
meaning_story: The standard of imitation is to imitate to the scale and scope of the original.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は京都の景観がとても好きです。
ex_1_en: I really like Kyoto’s scenery.
meaning_story: Quite the scene, this view is. What you're looking at is called scenery. And, in fact, it's a spectacular view!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ちょっといつもと違った景色を見るために、今日は回り道をしてみない？
ex_1_en: Do you want to make a detour to see some different scenery than usual today?
meaning_story: The scene's color is the scenery, scene, and landscape. Looking good, scenery!
reading_story: The reading for this one is a bit weird and pretty exceptional. The けい is shortened to け and 色 uses the on'yomi reading しき. If you have a good idea for a mnemonic for this one send it in, but until then do your best to just remember this word's reading the best you can!
pitch_accent: ケイショク *** ケꜜイショク *** ケꜜシキ

ex_1_jp: 日本では、通常手紙は時候の挨拶から書き始められる。
ex_1_en: People usually begin letters with a seasonal greeting in Japan.
meaning_story: The time's climate is the current season. Each season has a different climate and exists in a different time of year.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 二巻では、引用の出典に関する別表が作成されました。
ex_1_en: They made an appendix for all sources cited in the second volume.
meaning_story: The number two scroll is the second volume. With Japanese books, they often come in pieces with groups of three being common. This represents the second volume.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 俺の先輩、悪い人では無いんだけどさ、ただちょっと俺とは反りが合わないんだよね。
ex_1_en: My superior isn’t a bad guy, but he and I just haven’t been able to hit it off.
meaning_story: My comrade who came before me is my senior, my senpai (せんぱい).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「私、もう何週間もフグを見てないわ。」「ほら、見て。ちょうど今フグが来たわよ。」「あら、噂をすれば影がさす、ね。こんにちは。私たち、今ちょうどあなたのことを話していたのよ。」
ex_1_en: "I haven’t seen Fugu for weeks." "Oh, look. Here comes Fugu right now." "Well, speak of the devil. Hi, there. We were just talking about you."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Just imagine the shadow of a cage (かげ). Lots of long bars. Looks good.

ex_1_jp: 毎朝、新宿駅に着くまで、満員電車の中に立っていなくてはいけないのが苦痛です。
ex_1_en: I hate that I have to stand in a packed train until I arrive at Shinjuku station every morning.
meaning_story: Full of members, so sorry, no more room. This place is all sold out.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: このような絵のように美しい光景は今までみたことがありません。
ex_1_en: I’ve never seen such a beautiful sight before.
meaning_story: A scene that's as awesome and bright as sunlight is quite the spectacle.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ビザの期限が切れるので、来月日本を出なくてはいけません。
ex_1_en: I have to leave Japan next month because my visa will expire.
meaning_story: The period of time limit is nothing more than a period or term of time. There's a limit there, and that limit is defined by the term.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 繁忙期に旅行をすれば費用が嵩むのは分かっているけど、そうはいっても天候もその時期が一番いいからね。
ex_1_en: I know there will be extra costs if we travel during peak season, but the weather will be the best around that time.
meaning_story: Heaven's climate is the weather.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 時限爆弾がきちんと引き出しの中にしまわれていることを確認した。
ex_1_en: I made sure that the time bomb was neatly placed in the drawer.
meaning_story: A time limit is a time limit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ジケ°ン *** ジケ°ンスꜜト *** ジケ°ンストꜜ

ex_1_jp: 全社員が新システムに関する知識を吸収する良い機会です。
ex_1_en: This is a great opportunity for all of the workers to absorb knowledge about the new system.
meaning_story: If 吸収 is "absorption" the verb version is to absorb.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: うちの猫は大抵二階の寝室に居るんです。
ex_1_en: Our cat is usually in our bedroom upstairs.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means alive so the verb vocab version is to be alive.
reading_story: Do you know the word いる? This is it. This is when you're referring to the existence of something alive and moving. If you've been studying Japanese up to this point (level 25) you probably already know that word. You can associate these two things together into one and remember the reading at the same time!

ex_1_jp: おばちゃんと呼ばれる年になってしまったことがちょっと悲しかった。
ex_1_en: I was a little sad to reach an age where I can be called a middle-aged woman.
meaning_story: If 呼ぶ is "to call" then this is something similar. This is when you are called by someone (and you're not doing the calling). This word is to be called.
reading_story: The reading is shared with 呼ぶ, so remember that and you'll be able to read this too.

ex_1_jp: 最初スピード違反で止められたんだけど、その後飲酒運転で捕まっちゃったんだよ。
ex_1_en: At first I was just stopped for speeding, but I ended up being caught for drunk driving.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means catch so the intransitive verb vocab version is to be caught. This is a literal, physical catch. So, for example, you can catch a criminal using this verb but not catch the drift of an idea, which would be 捕らえる, coming up in level 27.
reading_story: The reading is つか, so to remember that with to be caught, think about how you're a police officer trying to catch some criminals. Unfortunately, they have split up into two cars (つか) meaning you won't catch both of them, since you only have one car.

ex_1_jp: 裾上げをお願いできますか？自分ではあまり縫い物に慣れてなくて。
ex_1_en: Could you bring the hem up for me? I’m not really used to sewing.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accustomed so the verb vocab version is to become accustomed.
reading_story: What have you become accustomed to? All the Narwhals (な) you hang out with. They take some getting used to.

ex_1_jp: 大便がしたくてたまらなかった彼は、ドアを拳で割れるほど強く叩いた。
ex_1_en: He needed to poop so badly that he almost broke the door from pounding on it with his fists.
meaning_story: Remember how 割る is "to divide"? Now you're learning the similar intransitive version. Instead of you doing the dividing, something just gets divided. This is to be divided.
reading_story: The reading is shared with 割る.

ex_1_jp: 肺癌の治療に最も良く効く薬を探しています。
ex_1_en: I’m looking for the most effective medicine for treating lung cancer.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means effective. The verb vocab version is to be effective (since "to effective" doesn't make sense).
reading_story: What is particularly effective? It's your key (き). It's effective at opening your house door.

ex_1_jp: 四年生の時は誰のグループに属していたの？
ex_1_en: Whose group were you in when you were in grade four?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means belong so the verb vocab version is to belong to.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. This kanji is going to belong to you.

ex_1_jp: もしご迷惑でなければ、席を替わってもらえませんか？彼女と一緒なんですが、席が別々になってしまったんです。
ex_1_en: Would you mind switching seats with me? I’m with her and our seats are separate.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means replace. This word means to be replaced. You can differentiate it from 替える, which has you doing the action of replacing, by thinking that with わる Wario is doing the replacing for you, not you, making this to be replaced.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 「こちらの品は百万円ほどお高くなります。」「それでも構わないよ。それを頂くよ。」
ex_1_en: "This one will cost about a million yen more." "I still don’t mind. I’ll take it."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means care so the verb vocab version is to care about.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Do you care a lot about grammar? I don't care, unless it has to do with commas (かま). Then I do flip out.

ex_1_jp: 橋を渡り終わったところで、右に曲がって下さい。
ex_1_en: After crossing the bridge, please turn right.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transit, but when you think about "to transit" this doesn't make too much sense. When you "transit" something, though, you're going across it. That's why this word is to cross or to cross over.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 争いを収めるにはどうすればいいのだろう。
ex_1_en: What I should do to finish the fight?
meaning_story: When you obtain something, it's only right that you decide to dedicate it to someone else. Or to make an offering to the gods for letting you obtain something nice. It's only right to give after you get, you know?
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know who didn't like to make an offering like he should have? Osama (おさ) Bin Laden. And you know what happened to him? Yeah. Don't be like him.

ex_1_jp: 大きな契約を勝ち取るには、顧客の心に響く素晴らしい提案書が必要だ。
ex_1_en: To win a major contract, we’ll need a great business proposition that resonates in our customers’ hearts.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means echo so the verb is to echo.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing...

ex_1_jp: ワサビ抜きにしてもらえますか？
ex_1_en: Can you leave out the wasabi?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means extract so the verb vocab version is to extract.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Just go ahead and extract it out of your memory so you can use it here.

ex_1_jp: まず初めに、お忙しい中足をお運び頂き誠に有り難うございます。また、このような素晴らしいプレゼンテーションの機会を与えて頂いたことにも、感謝申し上げます。
ex_1_en: Let me start off by thanking you all for coming and giving me such a great opportunity to show my presentation.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give so the verb vocab version is to give or to grant.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go to give a bone to your dog. Atta (あた) boy, sparky! Atta boy.

ex_1_jp: 彼が私にペンを渡してくれた時、胸がどきどきした。
ex_1_en: When he handed me the pen my heart was pounding.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transit, but the vocab isn't quite the same. You are transiting one object over to another person (the word is to hand over), though, so it kind of makes sense. You see the す? You're suing somebody, so you hand over the papers telling them you're suing them. Don't confuse this with 渡る which is "to cross over." す is sue.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 彼の死後、くれた絵をどこに掛けたらいいかしら。
ex_1_en: Since his death, I don’t know where I should hang the picture he gave me.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hang so the verb vocab version is to hang. This is when you hang something, like a picture. You can remember this because you don't really care (ける) about where you hang it, as long as you're the one to do it.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 秘密の花園への入口は隠されている。
ex_1_en: The entrance to the Secret Garden is hidden.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hide so the verb vocab version is to hide.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Hide your cock (かく)! You have a ton of roosters but you don't want people to know about them, so you gotta hide your cocks. What did you think I was talking about?

ex_1_jp: アルカリを含む温泉にはどのような効能があるのですか？
ex_1_en: What kinds of benefits does a hot spring containing alkali have?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means include so the verb vocab version is to include.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: They don't want to include you in their game? Well "F*&k You (ふく)!" you yell at them, because they wouldn't include you.

part_of_speech: INTRANSITIVE VERB, TRANSITIVE VERB, AND GODAN VERB
ex_1_jp: 砂糖でさらに甘みが増しますよ。
ex_1_en: Sugar will make it much sweeter, you know.
meaning_story: It's another verb with the kanji 増! This one means to increase too! But! These are unconscious increases, whereas 増やす are usually for conscious increases.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: What increases with time? Your love for your mama (ま)! Your love for her will grow and grow the older you get! I love you, mama!

ex_1_jp: やっぱり、日本語の勉強はTofuguに限るよ。
ex_1_en: Of course, your studying of the Japanese language is limited to Tofugu.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means limit so the verb vocab version is to limit.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to limit your use of face cream. I know you have a super kaggy (かぎ) face but if you don't limit your use bad things will happen.

ex_1_jp: 見渡す限り、向日葵畑が続いていた。
ex_1_en: The sunflower field went on as far as the eye could see.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji mean see and transit, but the vocab isn't quite the same. You are going to transit your eyes over an area to take in what you see. So you're really going to look out over everything. This word is usually used when you're looking at landscapes or a really large area.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ミワタス *** ミワタꜜス

ex_1_jp: 「そのまま頑張って。あなたなら大丈夫よ。」
ex_1_en: Hang in there, you can do this.
meaning_story: 張る is to stretch. You're stubborn and want to stretch out what you're doing right now. Although you're stubborn, you keep doing it. You persevere. That's why this word is to persevere.
reading_story: The reading for this word is the reading for 頑 and 張る put together but the 張る part gets rendaku'd so keep that in mind.

ex_1_jp: 準備する前に先に朝ご飯食べちゃいなさい。
ex_1_en: Finish your breakfast before getting ready.
meaning_story: You've seen that 準備 is preparations. This is the verb version, so you get yourself to prepare.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 準備.

ex_1_jp: お父さんに電球を替えるようにもう頼んだよ。
ex_1_en: I already asked dad to change the bulb.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means replace so the verb vocab version is to replace. You know that you're doing the replacing because of the air (える). You're replacing the air as quickly as you can because if you don't you wouldn't be able to breathe in this small room.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 二時間かけて髪を巻いたが、それでもあまりうまく巻けなかった。
ex_1_en: I spend two hours curling my hair, but it still doesn’t curl well.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scroll. But, you don't "to scroll." What do you do to scrolls, though? You roll them up, making this word "to roll" or "to roll up."
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you are rolling up is your ma (ま). She's going wild again, so you throw her into a blanket and roll her up to hold her down.

ex_1_jp: 祖母を捜しているんです。アルツハイマーがあって、昨日から家に帰ってないんです。
ex_1_en: I’m looking for my grandmother. She has alzheimer’s and hasn’t come home since yesterday.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means search so the verb vocab version is to search.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're searching all around for a "sagger" (さが) on your body. This is a flap of skin that is sagging on your body really far, and you probably should get it removed.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は最後には本性を現すと思ってたよ。
ex_1_en: I knew that she would show her true colors in the end.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means present time, but you can't "to present time." If you try to do present time, the best you can do is try to show it. Kind of a weird connection, but if you think through it a couple times it might get better.
reading_story: Remember 表す and how it means "to express?" This has the same exact pronunciation. If you want to show something you have "to express" it as well, otherwise people won't understand what they're being shown. You have to あらわす it in more than one way.

ex_1_jp: 意地悪な上司との関係をどうやって保つか、毎日知恵を絞っています。
ex_1_en: I rack my brain every day about how to manage my relationship with my mean boss.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means strangle so the verb vocab version is to strangle.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Oh my god. How could you. That lady. She bowed (しぼ) down and you just grabbed her neck to strangle her? What were you thinking? THAT WAS A BOW, NOT AN INVITE TO STRANGLE HER WTH.

ex_1_jp: 多くの女子社員がセクハラを訴えたため、私の直属の上司は二、三週間前に解雇されました。
ex_1_en: A couple weeks ago, my direct supervisor was let go because many female workers complained about his sexual harassment to the branch office manager.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sue so the verb vocab version is to sue.
reading_story: YOU TAKE (うった) MY THINGS, I AM GOING TO SUE YOU!
pitch_accent: ウッタエꜜル *** ウッタꜜエル

ex_1_jp: 欠員を補うために、ボーリングゲームに参加しました。
ex_1_en: To compensate for the empty spot, I joined the bowling game.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means supplement so the verb vocab version is to supplement.
reading_story: Oh, gee, now (おぎな) you're going to supplement it? That would have been helpful earlier. Might help to say "oh gee now" with a ぎ sound instead of "ji" sound out loud, too. This is a tricky reading, won't be learned too easily, so think about it a bit now.

ex_1_jp: この会社では、毎年CEOを選ぶために全社員が投票することになっている。
ex_1_en: In this company, every year all the workers have to vote to choose the CEO.
meaning_story: Throw a ballot in the ballot box to vote.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. You may have to think back to some other words using 投 to remember the on'yomi reading, 投資 for example.

ex_1_jp: 家庭教師のアルバイトをしています。
ex_1_en: I work part time as a tutor.
meaning_story: This is a combination of the words 家庭 and 教師. A "teacher" who only teaches when you're with your "family" is known as a tutor. They don't teach you at school, they're a private teacher that comes to your home to help you learn.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 新しい人事部長は、強制的なサービス残業に関する問題を鮮やかに解決してのけた。
ex_1_en: The new personnel manager brilliantly solved the problem regarding mandatory overtime without pay.
meaning_story: Alright, so it's not quite the same, but something that is fresh is also vivid and splendid. I know those are a couple things I'd associate with freshness. Try to make the connection here before moving on.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: This vivid and splendid fresh fish is MINE! You grab the other (あざ) one that's not as vivid and splendid. This one is mine.

ex_1_jp: ひき逃げ事故のせいで、買ったばかりの牛肉が挽き肉になった。
ex_1_en: Due to the hit-and-run accident, the beef he bought became ground beef.
meaning_story: The actions he took as well as the particular circumstance is what caused this accident. It all aligned too perfectly.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 針医の技術の進歩には驚くばかりです。
ex_1_en: It’s amazing to think that acupuncturist techniques have come this far.
meaning_story: Needle medicine is when you stick needles into people to cure them. This is done via an acupuncturist.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: もしできるなら、再び肘を舐めてみるべきだ。
ex_1_en: If you can, you should lick your elbow again.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of 再, so it shares the meaning again and also has the meaning once again.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Once again, you put a footer in your note because you can't remember the reading to this word because the mnemonic is so bad (sorry!).

ex_1_jp: 彼は独り住居だ。
ex_1_en: He lives alone.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is different from the one you learned (this is kun'yomi). There's an easy way to remember it, though. 一人 and 独り share the same readings and mean almost the same thing. Just try to remember that this ひとり is used to emphasize solitude and independence.

ex_1_jp: 新しい市場に参入したことは間違いじゃなかった。
ex_1_en: Expanding into new markets was not a mistake.
meaning_story: We waited an interval of time, and at each interval it was different. They're all supposed to be the same. Is there some kind of mistake?
reading_story: Take the reading of 間 (ま from 間に合う) and 違う and you'll have the reading for this word too.

ex_1_jp: その外交官は人造人間十八号に刺された。
ex_1_en: The diplomat was stabbed by Android No.18.
meaning_story: A person created item is artificial, not "real."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あの男の人、獣のような目をしていて、恐いわ。
ex_1_en: That guy has eyes like a beast, he’s scary.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: A beast... what do you think of when you think of a beast? How about a thing (物, もの) full of fur (毛, け), aka a けもの (fur thing)? A beast is a fur thing, and in Japanese that's けもの. Punnnns.

ex_1_jp: 引越しを考えてるんだけど、どこも鳥獣類禁止ばっかりなの。
ex_1_en: I’m thinking of moving, but just about everywhere prohibits birds and animals.
meaning_story: Things that are of the beast type or animal type are within the beasts and animals category.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 堅い木の椅子と柔らかい快適な椅子じゃあ大違いだよ。
ex_1_en: There is a big difference between a hard wooden chair and a soft cushy chair.
meaning_story: 違い is difference, so a big one of those is a big difference.
reading_story: The reading is 違う plus 大 of 大きい (おお) put together. You can remember this because when you see the difference (the BIG difference), you say "oohhhhh" (お), because you were surprised you didn't see it before.

ex_1_jp: ジムの会員権や食事だけではなく酒まで無料の特典として提供されるので、私はこの酒造での仕事が好きです。
ex_1_en: I like working for this brewing company because they offer all these perks like free gym membership, free food, and even free sake.
meaning_story: The act of alcohol creation is done via brewing and distilling.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼が受話器に戻ってきて会社の住所を尋ねたので、名刺に記載されていることをお伝えしました。
ex_1_en: He came back on the line and asked for our company address, so I told him that it’s on my business card.
meaning_story: Take your name and stab someone with it... using your business card. Your business card has your name on it. Also, you "stab" it at people who are willing to take it and read it. Not a real stab, but a metaphorical.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 冬には運河の上でスケートができますよ。
ex_1_en: You can skate on the canal during the winter.
meaning_story: It can carry a river. It's a canal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The か goes to が, probably while floating down said canal.

ex_1_jp: 小さい頃、お菓子の家に住むことが夢でした。
ex_1_en: When I was a little, my dream was to live in a house made of candy.
meaning_story: A cake for a child is the candy and sweets that children like to eat. Mmm, candy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
