ex_1_jp: 優柔不断と事なかれ主義が彼の特徴だ。
ex_1_en: His personality is characterized by indecision and immobilism.
meaning_story: A special indication on something or yourself is a special characteristic. It's a distinctive feature that exists.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: それ故、兄は両親から勘当されてしまったのです。
ex_1_en: For that reason, my older brother was disinherited by our parents.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When thinking about the circumstances of your current situation (which is studying kanji and vocab). Who's fault is it? It's WaniKani's fault! But, your brain has been beaten to a mush from all the studying, so when you say "it's your fault" it comes out as "it's yue fault!" Go ahead and say it out loud that way.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 偽物のダイヤと本物のダイヤを直接比較してみれば、どっちがどっちだかすぐに分かるよ。
ex_1_en: If you directly compare a false diamond with a real one, you’ll know which one is which right away.
meaning_story: A compare and contrast will give you a comparison of something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 引っ越しお祝いを渡さなくちゃいけないわね。
ex_1_en: You have to bring a moving gift.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji celebrate, so when you put a お before it to raise it up, it means congratulations! When someone has something to celebrate you should congratulate them.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

pronunciation: かぶしきがいしゃ, かぶしきかいしゃ
ex_1_jp: Tofugu株式会社に電話を入れて、ファックスの送信がきちんと完了しているかどうか確認してくれる？
ex_1_en: Can you call Tofugu Corporation to make sure the fax went through alright?
meaning_story: This company (会社) has done the ritual required to create stocks for their company. When a company has stocks, they become a corporation.
reading_story: The readings for everything here are the readings you learned with the individual kanji, though not all are on'yomi. This word is usually rendaku'd too, but sometimes you'll see the non-rendaku version when it comes to English language legal stuff, so keep that in mind.

ex_1_jp: この吹雪の中、パンツ一丁で踊るなんて、気違いにも程がある。
ex_1_en: Dancing around in a snow storm in nothing but your underpants is just too crazy.
meaning_story: Your energy is ... well ... different. That's the nice way to put it. You're crazy, actually. Note that this is kind of a mean word to say, kind of like a swear word, but only kind of.
reading_story: The reading is 気 plus 違い.

ex_1_jp: 私の妹は、創造力がとても豊かだ。
ex_1_en: My little sister is very creative.
meaning_story: Create! Create! If you do this, you are doing creation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私は給与削減と年金減額に関する討論に加わった。
ex_1_en: I participated in the discussion about salary cuts and the reduction of pensions.
meaning_story: I'm going to chastise you about this theory. When I do this, this is a debate. Doesn't it feel like you're being chastised when people are debating with you sometimes, especially with your own theories? I think so.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 俺は世界一の独裁者になるんだ。
ex_1_en: I’ll become the best dictator in the world.
meaning_story: When one person is in a position to judge everyone alone by themselves, they're definitely a part of a dictatorship. One person should never be alone to judge everyone because that's how dictators are made and they're not so great.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 君と彼が僕のベーコンを食べたって話は、彼から直接聞いたんだよ。
ex_1_en: I heard that you two ate my bacon directly from him.
meaning_story: I'm going to direct and adjoin the routes together. No more multiple stops. This is direct.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 障害があることがバレて、内定が取り消された。
ex_1_en: When it leaked out that I have a disability, the job offer I had was cancelled.
meaning_story: There is damage that hinders you from doing things normally. This is a disability.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私のCDはしばらく売上不振に苦しんでいたが、ラジオで紹介されてから今月は売上げが上昇しています。
ex_1_en: My CD was suffering from a slump in sales for a little while, but since being introduced on the radio, sales are rising again.
meaning_story: There are not any shakes or waves or anything fun like that. It is just pure dullness.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ここの従業員たちは、大阪支店の従業員たちより楽観的なようだ。
ex_1_en: Employees here seem to be more optimistic than their Osaka-branch counterparts.
meaning_story: You must obey your business. When you're in this situation, you've found employment through them, which is why you must obey them (if you weren't employed, you wouldn't have to listen to them).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: テレビ番組が放映された後、何百にも及ぶ激励の電話が、数時間に渡って掛かってきた。
ex_1_en: After the TV show, hundreds of calls offering encouragement came pouring in for hours.
meaning_story: Some fierce encouraging is what you need. Some encouragement!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 電車に乗り遅れて、会社の創立記念のイベントに遅れそうだ。
ex_1_en: I’ve missed my train and I’m running late for my company’s anniversary event.
meaning_story: Create it and stand it up. This is your establishment, your founding.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 時々、夜になると激しい不安を感じるの。
ex_1_en: Sometimes at night I feel an intense anxiety.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of fierce and violent? Fierce and violent!
reading_story: What is fierce and violent? That old hag (はげ). Imagine her coming at you attacking you violently!

ex_1_jp: オペレーターは、電話をかけてくださったお客様にとって、会社の 第一印象になるということを教えられました。
ex_1_en: We were all taught that an operator is the first impression that a caller has of our company.
meaning_story: The first (第一) phenomenon is what's sealed into your head. This is your first impression of something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 星占いによると、フグと私ってあまり相性が良くないみたいなんだよね。
ex_1_en: According to the stars, Fugu and I aren’t supposed to have so much chemistry between us.
meaning_story: Although this has a い on the end it's tricky and not an adjective. The kanji is fortune, and the vocab word is fortune telling.
reading_story: I'm going to do some fortune telling on you... hmmm... I see... ohhhh... Looks like you'll be living on uranus (うらな) in your near future, that will be $50. What a dumb fortune telling for $50, you definitely won't be living there, unless he meant your butt, then maybe.
pitch_accent: ウラナイ *** ウラナꜜイ

ex_1_jp: 万年筆を落とされましたよ。
ex_1_en: You dropped your fountain pen.
meaning_story: The only kind of writing brush you can use for ten thousand years is a fountain pen! All other pens run out of ink and then you're out of luck. But fountain pens can be refilled, making them work for pretty much exactly ten thousand years.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「豆腐と河豚のサンドイッチをお願いします。」 「同じく。」
ex_1_en: "I’ll have a blowfish and tofu sandwich." "I’ll have the same."
meaning_story: The river pig is what's known as fugu or blowfish. That's the mascot for our best friend, the Tofugu!
reading_story: The reading makes no sense, really. Neither kanji readings work. But, if you remember that a river pig is a fugu, you can know the reading is ふぐ as well! YOU ARE A BLOWFISH, JESSE!

ex_1_jp: アメリカで有名な学校の怪談はありますか。
ex_1_en: Are there any famous school ghost stories in America?
meaning_story: If you discuss the suspicious you're talking about something that may or may not be real. One of those things you could be discussing is a ghost story... you know that one with the hook?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: スーパーマンは、怪獣に数分遅れて現れた。
ex_1_en: Superman turned up a few minutes later than the giant monster.
meaning_story: Look at that suspicious beast... it's Godzilla, walking around looking suspicious. What is Godzilla? He is a giant monster.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 地球温暖化のために、毎年溶けている氷河が増えている。
ex_1_en: The number of melting glaciers has been increasing every year due to global warming.
meaning_story: An ice river is some ice that moves (very slowly) like a river. That is a glacier. In fact, many inlets and sounds were created with glaciers, because glaciers moved through them like rivers... not very quickly, though.
reading_story: The reading for 氷 is the one you didn't learn. Think of the glacier coming slowly to your door. It rings your doorbell and says heyo (ひょう).

ex_1_jp: 日本にはどんな社会保障がありますか。
ex_1_en: What kind of social security is there in Japan?
meaning_story: Preserve your current state and avoid any hindering of you. That is our guarantee and security.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: おたんじょうびおめでとう
ex_1_jp: 遅れたとしても、「お誕生日おめでとう」って言う方が言わないよりもいいよ。
ex_1_en: Better late than never with saying happy birthday.
meaning_story: 誕生日 is birthday. おめでとう is like "congratulations." So, congratulations for your birthday is like happy birthday!
reading_story: The reading is the same as 誕生日, so if you know that you know this!

ex_1_jp: 我関せずって感じのアイツの態度、超嫌なんだけど。
ex_1_en: I hate him acting as if he doesn’t care.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: It is I! Due to my ego, I love the Wii and no other gaming device. I love playing all the Wii-ware (われ) that's available, and everything else sucks.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 兄の会社が輸入家具マーケットにビジネスに広げるのですが、私はそのプロジェクトマネージャーに抜擢されました。
ex_1_en: My brother’s company is going to expand its business in the import furniture market and he chose me as the manager for the project.
meaning_story: The transport of things that enter your country are imports.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE

ex_1_en: If you say not many people who left the company and went independent succeeded, show me the data, their plans, and how they failed.
meaning_story: Alone I stand. I have independence!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 電気コードに躓いた時に、人差し指を切っちゃったんだよね。
ex_1_en: I cut my index finger when I tripped over the electrical cords.

reading_story: The readings are all the kun'yomi readings of everything. The word 人, the word 差す, and the word 指. Take your time with this one, it's kind of weird.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_en: I plead guilty to intentionally eating Koichi’s secret bacon.
meaning_story: The circumstance was caused by the idea I had. Because I had this idea before the circumstance, it shows I had intention of doing it. I did it on purpose.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 面接の合否に関して、印刷物の郵送は行っておりません。
ex_1_en: We don’t send out any hardcopy materials for the interview results.
meaning_story: Our faces have adjoined in this one room to talk. You did the telephone interview where you didn't show the face of your face. Now you're showing it, so we can begin the real interview.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 障子から差し込む光で、朝目を覚ますのが好きです。
ex_1_en: I like being woken up by the sunlight filtering gently through shoji screen.
meaning_story: It can hinder a child, but that's about it. This is a Japanese Sliding Door. They're often made of rice paper after all, so, you know, an adult can go through it but a child would be hindered by it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 子 is change from し to じ, though, so be careful.

ex_1_jp: まるで河童が存在していることを信じているかのようにリアクションしてもらえますか？
ex_1_en: Can you react as if you believe Kappa really exist?
meaning_story: A river juvenile... not what you think. It's a kappa, a mythological Japanese creature. That being said, it lives in / around rivers and is about the size of a juvenile, so maybe this makes sense.
reading_story: The reading for 河 makes sense. The reading for 童 however is weird. Since the meaning is "kappa" though you can use that to remember the reading as well. If you don't know what a kappa is do some research on the internets and figure out about them. It's interesting, and it will help you to remember this word.

ex_1_jp: 大学を卒業した時、造園会社から内定をもらっていました。

reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

reading_story: Lots of lead, all in bullet form. That's what it was like in nam, 'arry" (なまり).

The reading of 便 (びん) in this vocabulary is an exceptional reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. You get a lot of junk mail so you throw it in the waste bin (びん). The waste bin is where junk mail goes.

ex_1_jp: 腕時計の秒針が折れちゃってるの。
ex_1_en: My wrist watch’s seconds hand has been broken.

Since you didn't learn the on'yomi reading for 針 (しん) with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. The seconds hand starts spinning around really fast, flies off the clock, and hits you in the shin (しん). The impact from the seconds hand really hurts. Your shin is in a lot of pain.

ex_1_en: That professor prefers filing cabinets to digital files.
meaning_story: If you teach and instruct then you are doing teaching. Who does teaching? A professor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: キョージュ *** キョꜜージュ

ex_1_jp: 我が社の純利益は前年比で70％も上昇したが、それを達成するために私が重要な役割を担ったんだ。
ex_1_en: My company’s profits soared 70% over last year and I played an important part in achieving that.
meaning_story: 担ぐ is more like when you're carrying something physical. 担う is when you carry a responsibility, which is why this word means to assume responsibility. You can remember this because YOU (う) are responsible for this. You assume this responsibility.
reading_story: What is your responsibility? To raise this girl named Nina (にな).

ex_1_jp: 化学の実験をしている最中に、前髪に火が燃え付いた。
ex_1_en: My bangs caught fire during a chemistry experiment.
meaning_story: When something attaches a burn to something that something is about to catch fire.
reading_story: This is the readings of 燃える and 付く put together.

ex_1_jp: 今夜お前のところに俺のパソコンと外付けハードディスクを届けるよ。
ex_1_en: I’ll deliver my computer and external hard drive to you tonight.
meaning_story: 届く is "to be delivered." This word is when you're doing the actual delivering, making it to deliver. You can remember this because you care (ける) about the package so much that you deliver it yourself, thus doing the action of delivering it!
reading_story: The reading is the same as 届く and you can use that to deliver the memory to your brain.

ex_1_jp: 誰かに差別されたことはありますか。
ex_1_en: Have you ever been discriminated against by someone?
meaning_story: 差別 is discrimination. This is the verb version, to discriminate.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 落ち込んでいる人を励ますのは難しい。
ex_1_en: It’s hard to cheer up someone who’s depressed.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means encourage and the verb vocab version is to encourage someone (or to encourage).
reading_story: Think about encouraging a hag (はげ). She needs encouragement because she's a hag, and nobody likes her much because of that.

ex_1_jp: 分厚いノートパソコンから薄型タブレットへの買い替えを検討している。
ex_1_en: We’re looking into replacing our bulky laptop with a slim tablet.
meaning_story: You examine it but you also chastise it, because you want to make sure this examining is correct. This is to examine or to study or to look into. All require chastising things to be sure for sure.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼らはライオン、トラ、くまなどたくさんの動物を輸出する。
ex_1_en: They export a lot of animals like lions, tigers, and bears.
meaning_story: Remember how 輸出 is an export? This is the verb, so this is to export.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know the word 輸出.

ex_1_jp: 誰かが肩に触れるのを感じて振り返ったが、そこには誰もいなかった。
ex_1_en: I felt somebody touch my shoulder and I looked back, but nobody was there.
meaning_story: 触る means "to touch." This means "to feel." It's kind of similar but somewhat different and also uses a different reading, making this word very hard in some ways. Just think how it's rare (れる) for you to feel anything at all, but this time you are, so that's nice, I guess.
reading_story: The reading is totally different from 触る so don't let that fool you. In this case, you feel some fur (ふれ).

ex_1_jp: 城は燃える木のにおいで充満しているようでした。
ex_1_en: The castle seemed to be full of the smell of burning wood.
meaning_story: You've seen how 燃やす is to burn something. Now something is just getting burned but you're not doing the actual action yourself. You know this because of the える part which refers to the letter "L" which is getting burned. You like L okay because it stands for "love," but others don't like it so they burn it.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the word 燃やす.

ex_1_jp: パソコンの動作を速くするのに役立つアプリケーションを無料で差し上げます。
ex_1_en: I’ll give you this application that helps make your computer run faster for free.
meaning_story: This is a really polite way to say "to give," probably because you're lowering yourself down and raising the item above your head so far that you have to point at it because if you were touching it you'd be defiling it anyways so, you know, point at it and raise it way up, you little worm on the ground.
reading_story: The reading is 差す and 上げる put together, both hopefully words you know okay by now.
pitch_accent: サシアケ°ル *** サシアケ°ꜜル

ex_1_jp: 彼女の金切り声が時々癪に障るんだよね。
ex_1_en: Sometimes her shrill voice can be really irritating.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You saw a (さわ) hinderance that will surely try to hinder you from getting what you need to get done, done.

ex_1_jp: 私の最近の趣味は、手作りのビールを造ることなんですよ。
ex_1_en: My recent hobby is brewing homemade beer.
meaning_story: When you create something you make something. If you create something good, you'll want to make more. You'll want to mass produce it so everyone can get what you created.
reading_story: The reading is like 作る, which means "to make." They have very similar meanings, but different kanji. Use 作る to help you to remember the reading of this word.

ex_1_jp: もう少しここの幅を狭めることはできますか？
ex_1_en: Can you narrow the width a little more here?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means narrow, so the verb version is to narrow.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to narrow the gap between yourself and your opponent so you pull out your saber (せば) and joust your way in! As long as you have your saber out, they can't stop you from narrowing the distance!

ex_1_jp: もし彼の命令に従わなければ、どうなると思う？
ex_1_en: What do you think what would happen if I didn’t obey his orders?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means obey so the verb vocab version is to obey.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: l am going to obey you, but just know I think your order is a bit of shit, が (したが) I'll do it and obey you.
pitch_accent: シタカ°ウ *** シタカ°ꜜウ

ex_1_jp: Tofuguがベーコン市場を買い占めるつもりだと聞きましたよ。
ex_1_en: I heard Tofugu is thinking of cornering the bacon market.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means occupy so the verb vocab version is to occupy.
reading_story: The kanji also means fortune, though this word means to occupy. The fortune teller tries to occupy the street area where he tries to give people fortunes. This fortune teller is Charlie Sheen (し).

ex_1_jp: 自分の写真をインターネットに載せるのには、ちょっと抵抗があります。
ex_1_en: I’m a little uncomfortable publishing my own picture on the Internet.
meaning_story: You remember how 載る is "to be published"? This one is to publish, as in you do it yourself. You know this because you self (せる) publish, which makes it so you're able to publish something (no publishers would accept that rubbish about the vampires, sorry).
reading_story: The reading is shared with 載る, so as long as you remember that you can remember this.

ex_1_jp: 大きなビジネスを始める前に、元手を貯える必要がある。
ex_1_en: We need to save up some funds before we can start a big business.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means savings, so the verb vocab version would become to save or to put something aside. Basically, you're saving up, which is good to do, I'm told.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to save, so you take one (たくわ) and put it aside, then take another and use it. This way you will have saved at least half.

ex_1_jp: 「彼に振られたなんて信じられない。」「あんた、浮気してたんでしょ。自業自得だよ。」
ex_1_en: "I can’t believe he broke up with me." "You cheated on him. You had it coming."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shake so the verb vocab version is to shake.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The building starts to shake. The most unfortunate thing here is that you're totally full (ふる), and you throw up because of the shaking (and you're full, gross!).

ex_1_jp: 電気料金の支払いが三ヶ月遅れて電気を止められちゃって、あのクソ暑い日をエアコン無しで過ごさなきゃならなかったんだ。
ex_1_en: Our electricity stopped because we fell three months behind on our utility bill, so we had to spend the hot day without an air‐conditioner.
meaning_story: 過ぎる is to surpass... 過ごす is to spend time on... for some reason. I suppose if you surpass something or someone, you must spend time to do it.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 過ぎる. Time to surpass this kanji? Or, maybe it's time to spend time on it instead.

ex_1_jp: 「それじゃあ、いくらお金があれば幸せになれるっていうの？」 「う～ん。痛いところを突かれたな。」
ex_1_en: "Well then, how much money do you need to be happy?" "Ah. You can really poke at my sore spots."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stab so the verb vocab version must also be to stab.
reading_story: If you're going to get stabbed, don't get stabbed two (つ) times. You can remember that this is the "two time stab" stab because it has a hole that's big. The hole is big because you got stabbed twice.

ex_1_jp: 母親をナイフで刺したにもかかわらず、私はその夜熟睡した。
ex_1_en: Although I had stabbed my mom with a knife, I slept soundly that night.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stab so the verb vocab version is to stab.
reading_story: If you're going to get stabbed, don't get stabbed by a saw (さ). That is the worst. You can remember that this is the "saw" stab because it has ribs. Imagine your ribs getting stabbed by a saw, then pulling it out. Zeeeuuuurrup!

ex_1_jp: 相手は、埋め立て計画に反対する請願書を再度持ってくるかもしれませんよ。
ex_1_en: They may bring forward a petition against our landfill project again.
meaning_story: Again with that occurrence? That occurrence has now happened twice.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that there's a い hiding in there!

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: この香辛料は独特の香りがする。
ex_1_en: These spices have a unique aroma.
meaning_story: It is alone and special. Nothing is like it. It is very unique.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 従来、一年目の新入社員はこの会社では有給休暇は一日ももらえません。
ex_1_en: So far, first year employees are given zero paid holidays in this company.
meaning_story: You've come and you've obeyed the whole way up to now. I guess it's time for you to know my secret. Really, I am a ...
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 父親が誕生日に自販機をプレゼントしてくれた。
ex_1_en: My father gave me a vending machine as a birthday present.
meaning_story: Remember the super long vending machine that is 自動販売機? This is a shorter easier to remember and say version. Basically every other kanji is removed, making it 自販機.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know 自動販売機 already.

ex_1_jp: あの獣医さんに行く一番のメリットは、もちろん先生が優しくて賢いってこともあるけど、それだけじゃなくて治療費を分割で支払えるのよ。
ex_1_en: Going to that veterinarian has the best benefits. Of course he’s kind and intelligent, but not only that, you can split up your bill into separate payments.
meaning_story: One who does beast medicine is a veterinarian, taking care of all them animals.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 車の中で、エンジンの振動を感じるのが好きなんです。
ex_1_en: I like feeling the vibration of an engine in a car.
meaning_story: The movement that has to do with shakes is vibration and oscillation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: スピード違反で捕まった。
ex_1_en: I was caught speeding.
meaning_story: If you're anti- something in a way that's different from the norm then you'll be in violation of the law! The laws that the "not" different people made. Either way, those people will give you a hard time for your anti-stance against the thing they like, and say it's a transgression.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 違 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you find yourself in violation of the law just pull out your pet eagle (い). Eagles are so majestic, they'll forget all about your transgression and let you go. If you're going to go be anti-something make sure you bring that eagle. People seem to care more about animals than other people like that.

ex_1_jp: やっと気象庁に電話が繋がったと思ったら、切られたんだよ。ありえなくね？
ex_1_en: I thought I finally got my call through to the weather agency, but they hung up on me. Unbelievable.
meaning_story: The energy phenomenon agency sounds like something that could be really cool but it's really just the weather agency / meteorological agency. Nothing shady going on here.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: コーヒーメーカー とか、キッチン向けの小型電気器具を売ってるいい感じのお店を見つけたんだけど、再来週一緒にいってみない？
ex_1_en: I found a really nice shop selling small kitchen appliances, like coffee makers, so do you want to go there with me week after next?
meaning_story: You know how 来週 is next week? Well, if you do next week again, you have the week after next.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 何故復讐しようと思ったんですか。
ex_1_en: How do you think you’ll get your revenge?
meaning_story: When you want to know what the circumstances are around you, you have to ask why. Why do things happen around you? Asking why is very important if you want to understand the world.
reading_story: The reading for this is an exception. The reading for 何 is just the first な from なに. You can remember the second part this way: No one knows quite how or why that big zeppelin (ぜ) crashed in the 1930s. People are still asking today and no one has any answers. We have to keep asking until we get some.

ex_1_jp: あのカップル、まさに「美女と野獣」って感じだね。
ex_1_en: That couple is exactly like the Beauty and the Beast.
meaning_story: A field beast/animal is one that lives outside and not under human care. It is a wild beast / wild animal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もし値ごろ感が重視されるのなら、我々の針金が圧勝することになるだろう。
ex_1_en: If affordability is a necessity, our wires will win hands down.
meaning_story: A needle made of gold is a wire. Perhaps wires were made from gold mostly back in the day? And they were thin like needles? That's my guess.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi reading of both. It's what you learned with 針's kanji, but 金 is more like お金, rendaku'd.

ex_1_jp: 筆マークのアイコンの上にカーソルを合わせて、マウスの左のボタンをカチカチッと２回クリックしてください。
ex_1_en: Put the cursor over the brush icon and click the left mouse button twice.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: For as long as you can remember, your family and another family has had a bloody feud (ふで) over this one writing brush. Just think of all the people killed over this brush. This feud has to end.

ex_1_jp: 再来年まで継続する二年契約を提案するべきではないでしょうか。
ex_1_en: We should propose a two year contract that lasts until the year after next.
meaning_story: You have next year (来年), but then you do a year again. That's the year after next.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 毎月の給与は、指定の銀行口座にお振り込み致します。
ex_1_en: We transfer your monthly allowance to your appointed bank account.
meaning_story: The salary I give you is your allowance. It is the wages you earn.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 健忘症に苦しんでいる親戚がいます。
ex_1_en: I have a relative who is suffering from amnesia.
meaning_story: A healthy bit of forgetting symptoms means you might have amnesia.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ケンボꜜーショー *** ケンボーショー

ex_1_jp: 私の両親は、この夏に南極に行ってみることを決心しました。
ex_1_en: My parents have decided to go to Antarctica this summer.
meaning_story: The extreme south is the extreme of south. It's about as south as you can go. That place is known as Antarctica.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 日本では、通常歯医者に一回の訪問で治療を済ませてもらうことはできません。
ex_1_en: In Japan, you usually can’t go to the dentist and get everything done in just one visit.
meaning_story: A visit problem is when someone makes a visit, because you're the type of person who doesn't like visitors, since they're usually so inconsiderate and you have to feed them. That's why a visit is a visit problem.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 悩み事の相談に乗るのは構わないんだけど、金欠なんだよね。外食したいなら、あんたの奢りだよ。
ex_1_en: I don’t mind hearing your advice about my troubles, but I’m running out of money. If you want to eat out with me, it’s your treat.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of worry, making it a worry or a worry.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. Nicely done, no need to have a worry about it.

ex_1_jp: 悪影響が自分の子どもにまで及んでいたことに気が付き、彼女は泣き出した。
ex_1_en: She cried as she realized that her bad influence filtered down to her children.
meaning_story: 影響 is influence, so an evil influence is a bad influence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あのクソ野郎がセールス・マネージャーに昇進するなんて本当に気に食わねぇ。
ex_1_en: That bastard got promoted to sales manager. I’m sick to my stomach.
meaning_story: Ugh, that field guy. He's the worst. Always in the fields, making us look bad, quite the bastard. Really though, he's just this guy, but for some reason I sometimes don't like him.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お前ちょっと腹が出てきたんじゃねぇか？
ex_1_en: You are getting a little fat around the belly, aren’t you?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: If anyone ever tries to touch your belly make sure you yell "Sekuhara (はら)! Sekuhara!” Sekuhara is short for sexual harassment in Japan. And if you don't want someone to touch your belly, but they're trying to, then that's sekuhara!

ex_1_jp: 病院のベッドに横になりながら、彼は明日妻にいい長靴を買ってやろうと思った。
ex_1_en: While laying in his hospital bed that night, he decided he would get a nice pair of rain boots for his wife next day.
meaning_story: Long shoes aren't long in that the feet part are long (that wouldn't make sense). Instead, the top part is long, making them into boots.
reading_story: The reading is a bit weird. Double kun'yomi, so think along the lines of 長い and 靴 getting added together. 靴 is the reading you learned with the kanji, however. It also gets rendaku'd.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 果てしなく続く空の下で、生徒たちは果てしなく長くて退屈な校長の話を聞かなくてはならなかった。
ex_1_en: Beneath the endless sky, students had to listen to the principal’s endless and boring speech.
meaning_story: I retreat! I yield! I can't take it anymore, it's so boring. Just imagine yourself giving up on whatever you're doing because you're so darn bored. You can't stand it. You have to retreat. You are ready to yield. Booooooring.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 母は、私の着替えを持ってくるのを忘れた事を謝りました。
ex_1_en: My mother apologized for forgetting to bring me a change of clothes.
meaning_story: You know how 替える is to replace? Well, you're replacing what you wear. That's a change of clothes.
reading_story: The reading is 着る and 替える put together. The か goes to が.

ex_1_jp: 警察は消えたベーコンの謎について何か手掛かりを見つけましたか？
ex_1_en: Have the police found any clues regarding the mystery of the vanishing bacon?
meaning_story: It was a hand which hangs the things we're looking for: a clue! Clues really are usually put down by people quite often. Or, perhaps, think of a hand hanging on something as your clue.
reading_story: The reading is 手 plus 掛かる put together.

ex_1_jp: 管理職に昇進する前に辞職する腰抜け社員が多すぎる。
ex_1_en: There are too many coward employees who resign before being promoted to management.
meaning_story: If you extract your waist you're pulling your body from the situation and trying to escape. What a coward. Or, picture a little kid trying hiding behind their mom. Try to extract them from behind their mom's waist. They're holding on! They don't want to come out. What a coward of a child! There are lots of different kinds of cowards.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: コシヌケ *** コシヌケꜜ

ex_1_jp: あなたの血中アルコール濃度については追って連絡致します。
ex_1_en: I’ll get back to you on your blood-alcohol concentration.
meaning_story: The degree of human thickness in the area will show the amount of people. Higher degrees of human thickness = more people. Lower degrees of human thickness = less people. That is the population density of the area, or a the concentration of people.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 妻の神経性ヒステリー症について、医者に相談しなくてはいけません。
ex_1_en: I should consult a doctor about my wife’s neurotic hysteria.
meaning_story: See this on the end of a word, and you know that it is a ______symptom. When you have a _____symptom, you have some kind of disease or sickness (otherwise why would you have a a symptom of some kind?).
reading_story: Since this is attached to things, it's treated like a jukugo word, so the on'yomi reading is used here.

ex_1_jp: すぐ帰りますので、お構いなく。
ex_1_en: I’ll be home soon so don’t worry.
meaning_story: Remember how 構う is "to care about"? This is when you tell someone to not care about something, aka don't worry about it.
reading_story: The reading comes from 構う, so if you know that you know this!

ex_1_jp: まあ、結果を気にせずに、頑張れよ！
ex_1_en: Well, don’t worry about the results, just try your best!
meaning_story: Remember 頑張る? This is just another form of that, this time you're telling someone to 頑張る, making this word mean something along the lines of good luck or do your best! Speaking of which, 頑張れ, you!
reading_story: The reading comes from 頑張る.

ex_1_jp: 私は大粒の涙がコウイチの目の端からこぼれ落ちるのを見てしまった。
ex_1_en: I saw a big tear drop falling from the corner of Koichi’s eyes.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This refers to a literal edge, not a figurative one.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you're on edge, just eat some hash (はし) browns to feel better! And if you're going to the edge of the world, hash browns will probably help you make it there too. Hash browns are so useful!
pitch_accent: タꜜン *** ハꜜ *** ハシ *** ハジ *** ハタ *** ハꜜナ

ex_1_jp: 成果主義の給与制度は、良い社員を引き込む最も効果的で公平な方法である。
ex_1_en: Performance based salaries are the most effective and fairest ways to attract good workers.
meaning_story: It's effective and you gain fruit from doing it. What you are doing is obviously effective.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 就業規則についての話し合いをするために、 私たちは月一のペースで会っている。
ex_1_en: We meet on a monthly basis to discuss employment regulations.
meaning_story: Settle in to the business. You've been here a while and you have employment now.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 君は奇跡を起こすことができるかもしれない。でも、僕は君には極端なことは避けてもらいたいんだよ。
ex_1_en: You may be able to perform miracles, but I want you to avoid doing extreme things.
meaning_story: At the extreme edge, which is just the extreme.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「いくつか就職の面接をしたんだけど、まだどこからも内定が出ないんだ。」「お互い大変だな。」
ex_1_en: "I’ve had several job interviews, but I haven’t received any job offers yet.” “Join the club.”
meaning_story: Settle in for employment, well, that is, if you can even find a job at all, you lazy bum. Finding Employment is what you need to do to settle in for employment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の日本語が段々うまくなっていると言ってもらえて、すごく嬉しいです。
ex_1_en: I’m glad to hear that my Japanese is gradually getting better.
meaning_story: Step by step. If you take step by step, you're moving up gradually, taking steps.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ダꜜンダン *** ダンダン

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 俺は中途半端な生き方をしてきたかもしれないけど、マフィアに入りたいって思ったことは一度もないよ。
ex_1_en: My life may be incomplete, but I would never dream of joining the mafia.
meaning_story: Take the middle route, half on the edge. You don't do anything the full way. Just to the middle. Just to the half. Not to the edge. This was really half finished and half assed of you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ぱ at the end is the only tricky part here since that isn't a common reading (or the one you learned before) for the kanji. Just watch out for that, and you'll be fine.

ex_1_jp: 頭痛が頻発することを母親に相談しました。
ex_1_en: I discussed my frequent headaches with my mother.
meaning_story: Head pain is when you have a headache.
reading_story: The reading for 痛 should be okay. The reading for 頭 isn't one you've learned before, however. Just think, every time you go to the zoo (ず) you get a terrible headache. Must be the animal feces floating around in the air.

ex_1_jp: 会社側が負担する健康保険は、諸手当の中に含まれているのでしょうか。
ex_1_en: Is company-paid health insurance included in the fringe benefits?
meaning_story: Your healthy health is your health. So healthful!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: いつもどのくらい前から休暇の予定を立てますか？
ex_1_en: How far in advance do you usually make vacation plans?
meaning_story: The rest you do in your spare time is your time off. It is your holiday.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼に間抜けな田舎者のお上りさんだと思われたくないの。
ex_1_en: I don’t want him to think of me as a stupid country bumpkin.
meaning_story: 抜く is to extract. If you extract yourself for an interval of time from the world, you won't learn anything and become an idiot.
reading_story: The readings come from the ま reading of 間 and from 抜く.

ex_1_jp: 彼と仕事をするのがストレスで、不眠症になってしまいました。
ex_1_en: Working with him is so stressful that I got insomnia.
meaning_story: The not sleep symptom shows you have a disorder that involves not sleeping. That is insomnia.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: フミンショー *** フミꜜンショー

ex_1_jp: 扉が開き、居酒屋の中に老婆が一人ぼっちで入ってきた。
ex_1_en: The door opened and an old woman walked into to the Izakaya restaurant by herself.
meaning_story: An alive alcohol shop is a place that does a lot of alcohol. In Japan, these places are often izakaya, or, if you don't know Izakaya already from English, you can consider it to be a Japanese Style Bar.
reading_story: The readings here are a bit weird. If you know what an izakaya is already from English, you can use that to remember the reading quite easily.
pitch_accent: イザカヤ *** イザカꜜヤ

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「聞いて聞いて、昇進したんだ！」「本当？すごいね！おめでとう！」
ex_1_en: "Guess what? I got a promotion at work!" "Really? That’s awesome! Congrats!"
meaning_story: Ascend and advance! Congratulations, you ascend and advance by getting a new job promotion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 細川は、原発再稼働に反対する大規模デモの実現に協力してくれたことについて、児島に礼を述べた。
ex_1_en: Hosokawa thanked Kojima for helping him stage a large-scale rally against resuming nuclear power plant operations.
meaning_story: Remember how 規模 is scale? Well, this is a big scale, which is on a large scale.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 一緒に学校を早退しない？
ex_1_en: Why don’t you leave school early with me?
meaning_story: An early retreat means that you leave early.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本では三台のみの限定販売になるそうなんだが、寝台車付き特急の実物大型模型を買おうか迷っているんだよ。
ex_1_en: I’m thinking of getting a life‐size model of bullet train with sleepers but they’re limited edition and only three will be sold in Japan.
meaning_story: The selling (販売) of something has a limit (限定). This kind of item is one of limited edition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 父は居間でテレビを観ています。
ex_1_en: Dad is watching TV in the living room.
meaning_story: A room that comes alive in intervals is your living room. You don't spend all your time in there, so it can only be alive sometimes. This word is usually used for western style living rooms by the way, so don't mistake it for a traditional Japanese one.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 迷子の子どもの両親を探してあげようとしていただけなのに、誘拐未遂で起訴されてしまいました。
ex_1_en: I was just trying to find the parents of a lost child, but I was accused of attempted kidnapping.
meaning_story: A child that's astray is a lost child. Help them home, don't invite them into your windowless van, please.
reading_story: The reading for 迷 is an exceptional reading. The ご comes from こ. Think of the まい as the child asking: "Where is my (まい) mommy???"

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 誰一人としてその迷路の出口を見つけることができませんでした。
ex_1_en: Nobody found their way out of the maze.
meaning_story: A road where you're astray is a road that goes all around in different ways, tricking you and making you lost. This is a maze.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 後で、今日習った日本語での両替の仕方について復習したいと思います。
ex_1_en: I’ll review today’s lesson about how to exchange money in Japanese later.
meaning_story: I can replace both of your moneys for other moneys at this money exchange. I can also make change for you too, if you'd like. You'll probably see this word the most in Arcades where you can go to the 両替 machine and get coins to feed your UFO catcher addiction.
reading_story: The reading here is a bit weird. Instead of just being か (it changes to が for the rendaku), it is がえ. Just think that if you want change exchanged, I'm your guy (がえ).

ex_1_jp: いいえ、結構です。夕食はいりません。申し訳ありませんが、ストレスで食欲がないんです。
ex_1_en: No, that’s okay. I don’t want dinner. Sorry, but I’m so stressed that I have no appetite.
meaning_story: 結構 is something like "fine" or "alright." This is just a little more polite. You can use this to say no thank you to someone trying to offer you something.
reading_story: The reading comes from 結構.

ex_1_jp: 「今すぐに来られますか？」「ええ。今向かっている途中です。」「え？ということは、場所をご存知なんですね？」「いいえ、分かりません。」
ex_1_en: "Can you come over right now?" "Sure, I’m actually on my way now." "Huh? Do you know where you’re going?" "Nope, I don’t."
meaning_story: If you're in the middle of the planned route you're on the way / en route.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私がこの組織で昇格の決定を担っている桜庭と申します。
ex_1_en: I’m Sakuraba, the man responsible for making the promotion decisions for this organization.
meaning_story: A group that's weaved together so tightly with hierarchy and everything else is a little more complicated than a group. It's an organization.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この部屋じゃ煙が目に入って痛いので、会社は屋外に喫煙場所を指定するべきだと思うね。
ex_1_en: Our company should designate an outdoor smoking area because the smoke gets in my eyes in this room and it hurts.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of pain? It's painful. It's also when you say ow and ouch.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: An eater (いた) is someone who eats. But, the eater hurt his mouth. So now it's painful to eat.

ex_1_jp: 間違いで極楽に行った男についての小説が、映画化されました。
ex_1_en: The novel about a man who went to paradise by mistake was made into a movie.
meaning_story: This place has extreme comfort. It is paradise.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ゴクラク *** ゴクラクꜜ

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 減給されるし、上司も嫌な奴だし、会社を辞めて転職先を探すことを本気で考えてるんだよね。
ex_1_en: I got a pay cut and my boss is mean so I’m seriously thinking of quitting and looking for a different job.
meaning_story: A decrease in salary is a pay cut.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 業界の景気回復に伴い、昇給を願い出たんだが、うまくいかなかったよ。
ex_1_en: When the industry made an economic comeback I applied for a raise, but it didn’t work out.
meaning_story: When you ascend in salary you get a pay raise at work.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 全ての人々が、世界の迫害と差別の歴史を学ぶべきだと思います。
ex_1_en: I think all people should learn the history of persecution and discrimination in the world.
meaning_story: Your urge is to damage things. You are always trying to commit persecution onto others.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 圧迫に耐えないので、宇宙飛行士になる夢を諦めた。
ex_1_en: I gave up my dream to become an astronaut because I couldn’t stand the pressure.
meaning_story: The pressure is urging outward. It's the pressure, so much pressure!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The あつ turns into a small っ, and はく goes to ぱく.

ex_1_jp: テレビとタイアップした書籍を手がけているのは本当だが、まだ値段は決まっていない。
ex_1_en: It’s true that we are working on our TV tie-in book, but the price hasn’t been decided yet.
meaning_story: The value is in various steps. Each step is a different amount, and each amount is a price or cost.
reading_story: The reading is 値 plus 段 (learned with the kanji). Combine them together to get the reading here.

ex_1_jp: この宿には、貸し切りの温泉があります。
ex_1_en: This inn has a reserved hot spring.
meaning_story: When the lending has been cut, it means that item has already been reserved.
reading_story: It's the reading of 貸す and 切る put together. Know those two readings and you know this one as well. Sometimes you'll see this word as 貸切り or 貸切 as well.

ex_1_jp: そろそろYoutube界を引退しようと考えてるんだ。
ex_1_en: I intend to retire from the Youtube world soon.
meaning_story: There comes a time when you need to pull yourself out of the workforce and retreat into retirement. At some point in everyones lives you just can't do it anymore and you have to pull yourself out to settle down and retire.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 引 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You can only retire from your life and go up to heaven if you are found innocent (いん) of all the bad things you did on earth. Just like your job won't let you retire with good benefits if you weren't found innocent of eating your bosses cookies everyday. So if you want to have a good retirement, you better be innocent.

ex_1_jp: 「君も巻きずしを食べてみるべきだよ。きっと気に入ると思うよ。」「わかったわ。あなたがそう言うのなら。」
ex_1_en: "You should try the sushi roll. I’m sure you’ll like it." "Okay, if you say so."
meaning_story: 巻く is "to roll." ずし is すし. This is rolled sushi.
reading_story: The reading comes from 巻く.
pitch_accent: マキズシ *** マキꜜズシ

ex_1_jp: その年老いた武士は、切腹をすることに固執した。
ex_1_en: The old samurai insisted on committing ritual suicide.
meaning_story: When you cut your abdomen you are committing seppuku aka ritual suicide. It will help if you already know the word "seppuku" from English, as it is the reading.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. But it's got shortening and rendaku going on, so you have to remember those if you want to get it right. Or just know the word seppuku already since it's pretty popular. That works too.

ex_1_jp: 「ああ、足が棒だよ。痛くて死にそう。」「言わんこっちゃない。だから、もっと歩きやすい靴を履けって最初に言ったじゃないか。」
ex_1_en: "Ah, my feet are killing me." "Told you so! That’s why I told you to wear more comfortable shoes."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Huzzah!

ex_1_jp: 靴屋での仕事に内定が出たが、丁重にお断りさせてもらったよ。
ex_1_en: I was offered a job at the shoe store, but I politely declined.
meaning_story: A shoes shop is one that sells shoes. It's a shoe store or shoe shop.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 彼は、給与の良い管理職へ昇格したいがために、睡眠時間を削って一生懸命働いている。
ex_1_en: He wants to be promoted to management for better pay so he works hard by cutting down on his sleep.
meaning_story: Feeling drowsy and like I want to sleep. I just want to sleep so bad.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 渋滞に巻き込まれた時、目も開けていられないくらい眠い状態でもありました。
ex_1_en: When I was caught in the traffic jam I was also so sleepy that I could barely keep my eyes open.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of sleep? It's sleepy.
reading_story: You're so sleepy you can't even remember your own name (ねむ).

ex_1_jp: 私達はみんな、啓介に小規模農場なんて始めない方がいいと警告したんです。
ex_1_en: We all warned Keisuke against starting a small scale farm.
meaning_story: 規模 is "scale." This is a small one, making this small scale.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ピンクの靴下を取ろうと一番上の棚に手を伸ばしたが、背丈が足りずに届かなかった。
ex_1_en: I tried to reach the top shelf to get a pair of pink socks, but I wasn’t tall enough.
meaning_story: What's below your shoes? Your socks.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this word too!
pitch_accent: クツꜜシタ *** クツシタꜜ

ex_1_jp: 私達は空気洗浄機とか家電を販売してるんですが、お客さんがあまりこないので、お店では正直暇してます。
ex_1_en: We sell home electronic appliances like air purifiers, but not many customers come in and honestly, I have a lot of free time at the store.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: In your spare time you like to drink hima (ひま), an off brand version of Zima.
pitch_accent: イトマ *** イトマꜜ *** ヒマ

ex_1_jp: 「私の春巻き食べたでしょ？」「ごめん。その通りだよ。」
ex_1_en: "Did you eat my spring rolls?" "Sorry, I did."
meaning_story: 巻く is "to roll up." If you roll up spring, you get a roll that's spring flavored. These are known as spring rolls.
reading_story: The readings come from 春 and 巻く.

ex_1_jp: 彼氏は、私が妊娠からかなり経った段階まで妊娠の事実を伝えなかったことについて私を責めました。
ex_1_en: My boyfriend accused me of not telling him I was pregnant until I was in the advanced stages of pregnancy.
meaning_story: The current step of the floor is at the second stage. Now it's at the third stage. Now it's in the final phase! Nice!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 充は、私が階段の掃除を手伝った事に礼を述べた。
ex_1_en: Mitsuru thanked me for helping him clean the stairs.
meaning_story: The floor that makes up the steps are the stairs. Don't get this confused with the similar word 段階, which is the stairs making up the floors to a certain stage.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ムエタイではあなたの打撃の構えが最も重要な事である。
ex_1_en: In Muay Thai, your battle stance is the most important thing.
meaning_story: You are doing a set up of something. It's a nice little noun sort of situation, where the word doesn't make too much sense. So, you set yourself up. To do this, you set up a stance to fight your opponent.
reading_story: The reading is like 構う, so as long as you know that you know this too.

ex_1_jp: ストレスで、胃がキリキリします。
ex_1_en: My stomach aches from stress.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 禁煙してから、激しい胃痛も治まっている。
ex_1_en: Since I quit smoking my intense stomach aches have also stopped.
meaning_story: When your stomach hurts you have yourself a little stomachache. Try keeping your stomach warmer next time.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 年寄りは迷信を信じやすい。
ex_1_en: Old people tend to be superstitious.
meaning_story: Led astray in what you believe by all these superstitions. These superstitions will lead you astray, don't believe them!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 最優先事項は供給を安定させることだ。
ex_1_en: Our maximum priority is to stabilize the supplies.
meaning_story: I'm a servant to my salary. It is the supply that keeps me going, and also allows me to buy my supply.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の症状について、一度同僚に相談しました。
ex_1_en: I consulted with my colleague once about my symptoms.
meaning_story: Your symptom condition is your symptoms that you have.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ショージョꜜー *** ショージョー

ex_1_jp: フグは、サーモンの唇を奪いたいという誘惑に抗うことはできなかった。
ex_1_en: Fugu could not resist the temptation to kiss Salmon.
meaning_story: You're being invited, but you're also being misguided. This is temptation that's talking. A misguided invitation is never a good thing, like temptation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 第一段階として、まずは基本の復習をしなくちゃいけないかもしれない。
ex_1_en: I may need to review the basics for the first step.
meaning_story: 第一 is the first thing. 段 is a step. So, this is the first step.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 理屈ばっかりこねて、本当に嫌味な人ね。
ex_1_en: The only reason you argue is because you’re really a disagreeable person.
meaning_story: Reason yields to theory and more reason.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は彼の髪は濃い紫色にしようかなって思ってるんだよね。
ex_1_en: I’m thinking of dyeing his hair a deep purple.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of thick? It's also thick.
reading_story: What is thick and dense? A 子 is thick and dense. You poke the child and you see how thick he is.

ex_1_jp: そのお箸の先端は焦げています。
ex_1_en: The tip of the chopsticks are burnt.
meaning_story: Previous to the edge is what's right before the edge is over. That's the tip of the edge. It's also a word used to describe the latest (technology, etc), because it's on the bleeding edge, so to speak. The tip!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もし今この場を去らなければ、公務執行妨害で逮捕するぞ。
ex_1_en: If you don’t leave now, I’ll arrest you for violating laws against interfering with a public servant in the act of duty.
meaning_story: Remember how 逮捕 is an "arrest" or "capture"? This is the verb version, and it is to arrest or to capture.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also be helpful to know the word 逮捕 already as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は天にも昇る気持ちで、大学からの合格通知を何度も読み直した。
ex_1_en: I felt like I was ascending to heaven as I read my college acceptance letter over and over.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ascend so the verb vocab version must be to ascend.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but it's pretty easy. How do you read all the other "to climb" words? 登る is one example. 上る is another. They're all のぼる, and so is this. Unlike the other climbing words, though, this suggests there's no effort involved. That's why you're "ascending" and not climbing, because climbing is a bit of work.

ex_1_jp: 死者の霊魂を招く歌を作ってみた。
ex_1_en: I wrote a song to summon the spirits of the dead.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means beckon so the verb vocab version is to beckon. It can also mean to invite or to summon as well.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You move to beckon your friend over. You can't see him well, so that's why you invite him to come closer. He is hiding something, and it turns out to be his long, luxurious horse mane (まね). Why does he have a mane!? Horse steroids?

ex_1_jp: すぐに退院することができるといいんだけど。
ex_1_en: I hope I will be released from the hospital soon.
meaning_story: Time to retreat from the institution. Basically, you are leaving an institution, particularly institutions like hospitals, asylums, etc. When you are leaving one of these places, it means you are to be discharged.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 最初の放射線療法から十日目に、髪の毛が抜け始めました。
ex_1_en: My hair started falling out ten days after I began radiation therapy.
meaning_story: Remember how 抜く means "to extract" or "to pluck"? This one is to be extracted. You're not doing the extracting. Why? Because you really don't care (ける).
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Also, it is the same as 抜く.

ex_1_jp: 「やばい。多分あれ元彼だ。速く隠れなきゃ。」「まじで？フグってこと？」「違うよ。サメだよ。」「 サメ？サメって誰のこと？てか、あんた元カレ多すぎだっつーの！」
ex_1_en: "Oh no. I think I just saw my ex. Quick, hide!" "What? You mean Fugu?" "No. Shark." "Shark? Who’s Shark? You have way too many exes!"
meaning_story: 隠す is "to hide." 隠れる is to be hidden. You know that this is the version where something is hidden (and you're not doing the hiding) because it is rare (れる) that you ever find something that has been hidden (not by you).
reading_story: The reading is the same as 隠す. So as long as you know that you know this as well.

ex_1_jp: ルーヴル美術館に行った時、モナリザが曲がって掛かっていた。
ex_1_en: When I went to the Louvre, the Mona Lisa was hanging crooked.
meaning_story: 掛ける is "to hang something." This is the version where something hangs by itself. At some point someone decided for it to be hung and now it's hanging there. You know this because there is a car (かる) hanging there on the wall. How silly, you certainly didn't hang it, that would be impossible. It's just hanging by itself.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 掛ける, so as long as you know that you know this too.

ex_1_jp: 惑う鹿がぐるぐる回っていたので、首を銃で撃ち抜いた。
ex_1_en: The perplexed deer was spinning in circles, so we shot it in the neck.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means misguided so the verb vocab version is to be misguided.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you are going to be misguided you're going to be mad (まど) about it, most likely. Nobody likes to be misguided, so imagine how mad you feel when you are.

ex_1_jp: 日本語を極めるのは、生易しい事ではない。
ex_1_en: It is no easy task to master the Japanese language.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means extreme. The verb vocab version isn't "to extreme" because that wouldn't make sense. Instead, you carry it to extremes, making this word to carry to extremes.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you go to carry to extremes, you're going too far, so there has to be a key word (きわ) that you say to make the other person stop. "CACAO! CACAO!"

ex_1_jp: どうしてあの国が突然平和友好条約を締結したのか不思議に思うよ。
ex_1_en: It’s strange, I wonder why those countries entered into a peace treaty so suddenly.
meaning_story: Go ahead and tighten then tie the loose ends. It will bring about the conclusion and allow us to conclude things.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: そろそろ我々のOA機器を最新のものに取り替える方がいいんじゃないでしょうか。
ex_1_en: We should gradually replace all of the office automation equipment for the latest versions.
meaning_story: Take and replace something. That is to exchange something with something else.
reading_story: The readings are 取る and 替える put together into one. If you know those words you'll be able to read and understand this one as well.

ex_1_jp: 「フグ、どうしてサーモンがお前のことを怒っているのか分からないんだろ？」「うん。さっぱり分からないよ。」「そうだと思ったよ。」
ex_1_en: "Fugu, you don’t understand why Salmon is mad at you, do you?" "No, I have no idea." "That’s what I thought."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means angry, the verb vocab version is to get angry.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're starting to get angry about something. It's mostly this okra (おこ). It tastes terrible.

ex_1_jp: 無糖珈琲を買おうかどうか迷っています。
ex_1_en: I’m not sure if I should buy unsweetened coffee.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means astray and the verb vocab version is to go astray (because you don't just "to astray" now do you?).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you are going to go astray, one way to do it would be to eat wayyyy to much mayo (まよ). I can't think of a worse way to go astray, personally.

ex_1_jp: 私の猫は鼠を捕えることが得意なんです。
ex_1_en: Catching mice is my cat’s specialty.
meaning_story: Remember 捕まる from level 25? This has a similar idea, but it's a little different (sorry!). 捕まる has to do with catching or grabbing something physical. This means that too, but it can also mean to catch an idea or concept. That's why this word means to grasp an idea or to grasp a concept. Hopefully if you review this enough you'll be able to grasp the concept as well, but you can differentiate the two by thinking how an error (える) is why you can't grasp the data in your head. It just doesn't make any sense. Oh, wait, it's because there's an error.
reading_story: The reading is also not the same as 捕まる. Sorry again! It does have a similar reading to 取る though, which also has to do with grabbing things (like grabbing onto an idea, for example). You can use 取る as a jumping off point for remembering the reading of this word. It won't be perfect, but it will get you part of the way there while you solidify the actual reading in your head through reviews.

ex_1_jp: プレゼントを手渡す勇気はありません。
ex_1_en: I don’t have the courage to hand him the present.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 渡す means "to hand over?" Well you can use your actual hand to hand over something too!
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どのお友達を誕生日会に招待するか決めましたか。
ex_1_en: Have you decided which friends to invite over for your birthday party?
meaning_story: You beckon someone to come to you, but then you wait. This is because they aren't really near you, so your beckon is more like an invitation. That's why this word means to invite or to summon.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「ついに彼女をデートに誘ったんだけど、なんとOKの返事をもらえたんだよ。だから、今夜、食事をしに出かけるんだ。」「そうなんだ！楽しんできてね！くれぐれも悪いことはしないようにね。」
ex_1_en: "I finally asked her out on a date and she said yes, so we’re going out for dinner tonight." "Well, have fun! Don’t do anything I wouldn’t do."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means invite. The verb vocab version is to invite.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You saw so (さそ) much in this person that you decided to invite them to dinner.

ex_1_jp: 「君の車を貸してくれない？」「絶対にだめだよ。まだ免許持ってないじゃないか。」
ex_1_en: "Can you lend me your car?" "Absolutely not. You don’t have a license yet."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lend so the verb vocab version is to lend.
reading_story: Allow me to lend you some advice. The reading you learned from the kanji can be used here.

ex_1_jp: 隠居してから、祖父は毎朝自宅で瞑想をしています。
ex_1_en: Since he retired my grandfather had been meditating in his house every morning.
meaning_story: 隠居 is retirement. Make that a verb and you have to retire.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 隠居 as well.

ex_1_jp: うちの母親は父親の嘘を見抜くのがうまい。
ex_1_en: My mother is great at seeing through my father’s lies.
meaning_story: Whenever you see something you extract it into your eyes as well. By extracting so much with your eyes, you're able to see through things and ideas.
reading_story: This is the reading for 見る and 抜く put together.

ex_1_jp: 彼は背広から銃をそっと抜き出した。
ex_1_en: He secretly started to pull a gun out of his business suit.
meaning_story: You know 抜く from before, it's to extract. Then you have 出す which is to remove. So, if you extract and remove something, you are moving to extract something. By extracting it you are also going to select it as well.
reading_story: The readings are from 抜く and 出す, combined together. Know those two and you'll be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: どうして日当で給与を支払う会社に就きたいの？
ex_1_en: Why do you want to take a position at a company that pays you per diem?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means settle in. The verb vocab version is to settle in.
reading_story: Try to settle in to this life. Wow, you are too (つ) settled in now, don't get too comfortable.

ex_1_jp: 「キンニクマってよく怒鳴るよね。」「そうだね。でも、心配しないで。彼は口は悪いけど根は悪い人ではないから。」
ex_1_en: "Kinnikuma yells a lot." "Yeah, but don’t worry. His bark is worse than his bite."
meaning_story: An angry chirp is a type of shout. The verb version is to shout at.
reading_story: This is a combination of the reading for 怒 and the reading for 鳴る. If you know those things you can read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: 屈むと腰が痛いんです。
ex_1_en: I get a pain in my lower back when I bend down.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means yield, and when you do that to someone else you tend to lean over or to bow to show them respect.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who do you need to stoop and to bow before? Takeshi Kaga (かが), that's Chairman Kaga to you! Before you can start cooking for him in Iron Chef, you must bow! Otherwise you'll be disqualified for being rude.

ex_1_jp: ガスの元栓、ちゃんと締めた？
ex_1_en: Did you tightly turn off the gas?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tighten so the verb vocab version means to tighten.
reading_story: You go to tighten and to tie your captive up. This man is Charlie Sheen (し).

ex_1_jp: 彼に金を返すよう迫ったが、逃げられてしまった。
ex_1_en: I pressed him to pay back the money, but he ran away.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means urge so the verb vocab version is to urge.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Are you trying to urge me to do that? Are you trying to coerce me to do that? Which one is it? It's all semantics (せま)!

ex_1_jp: 家を訪ねる前に、電話してみた方がいいよ。
ex_1_en: You should call her before visiting.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means visit so the verb vocab version is to visit.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.
