You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to visit your friend Taz (たず) the Tasmanian Devil. He's your best bro, so imagine visiting him and having a good time and saying you're going to visit him again.

ex_1_jp: 私の母親は、最近手織り機でカーペットを織ることにはまっているんです。
ex_1_en: My mother is very much into handwoven carpets lately.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means weave so the verb vocab version is to weave.
reading_story: When you have to weave the only thing you can weave is an O (お) shape. That's it. Just O's.

ex_1_jp: ソフトボールチームのヘッドコーチのポジションを退くには、まだ早過ぎますよ。
ex_1_en: It’s still too early for you to step down from your position as head softball coach.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means retreat. The verb vocab version is to withdraw from and to retreat.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You try to withdraw the enema from your patients' 尻s (しりぞ). They have lots of poop that needs to be cleared, and there are a lot of them, which is why there are so many 尻s.
pitch_accent: シリゾꜜク *** ドク *** ノク *** ヒク

ex_1_jp: 「どうしたの？何を悩んでいるの？」「昨日、彼女に振られたんだ。」
ex_1_en: "Hey! What’s troubling you?" "My girlfriend dumped me last night."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means worry so the verb vocab version is to worry.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, so no need to worry about it.

ex_1_jp: 日本語が下手なので、あなたに迷惑をかけてしまうかもしれません。
ex_1_en: I am bad at Japanese, so I might be an inconvenience to you.
meaning_story: You've been lead astray and you've been misguided. What a trouble and annoyance all this is.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あの榊氏までもが、私が宇宙の究極の原理を解明したことに祝いの言葉を述べてくれました。
ex_1_en: Even Mr. Sakaki congratulated me on finding out the ultimate fundamental truth of the universe.
meaning_story: You are trying to research the extremes. If you do that, you'll be able to figure out the ultimate weapon. Just researching the safe middle-ground stuff won't get you ultimate. Extreme research, however, will.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ヤクザからお金を借りなければいけないという切迫した危機に直面している。
ex_1_en: I’m facing an imminent crisis so I need to borrow money from the yakuza.
meaning_story: We're cut right down to the end, reaching that urge position where urgency and pressure are so strong.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The せつ of 切 gets shortened to a small っ. The はく becomes ぱく.

ex_1_jp: 「君の上司が、君の給料を上げるつもりだって聞いたよ。」「まさか！そんなことあり得ないよ。」
ex_1_en: "I heard your boss is going to give you a raise." "Really? That’ll be the day."
meaning_story: Your salary fee are the moneys you get for your salary. These are your wages and pay.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 学校のある夜は、外出できないって言ってるでしょ。だめだと言ったら絶対にだめだからね！
ex_1_en: You can’t go out on a school night. If I say it’s no good, it’s absolutely no good!
meaning_story: Extinction will happen as you go versus extinction. It will happen absolutely. It will happen without fail. There's nothing you can do to stop extinction.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 進撃の巨人にはまっています。
ex_1_en: I’m hooked on Attack on Titan.
meaning_story: You advance and attack! This is a charge on someone or something, though it can also be an advance on them. Yep, this is the 進撃 from 進撃の巨人 the popular anime / manga. Don't say you never learned anything useful here.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the ones you learned with the kanji. Advance! Charge! Move on to the next item!

ex_1_jp: 前売り券は他の割引とは併用できませんって書いてあるよ。
ex_1_en: It says that tickets sold in advance can’t be used with other discounts.
meaning_story: A ticket you sell beforehand are advance tickets. This is a ticket sold in advance. Buy your tickets early, or how else will you get in on a Conan audience?
reading_story: The readings are 前 売る and 券 combined into one awkward word.

ex_1_jp: 「何してるの？」「俺達、進撃の巨人を見てるんだよ。って、あぁ、しまった。最後の字幕見逃しちゃった。ちょっと巻き戻してくれない？」「了解。ストップって言ってね。」「ストップ！」
ex_1_en: "What are you guys doing?" "We are watching Attack on Titan. Oops. I totally missed the last subtitle. Can you rewind it a bit?" "OK. Just tell me when to stop." "Stop!"
meaning_story: A giant person is a giant.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: キョꜜジン *** キョジン

ex_1_jp: この鰐蟹軍隊の成功のためには、あなたが必要なんです。どうか入隊してください。
ex_1_en: I need you. You are crucial to the success of this crabigater army. Please join us.
meaning_story: The army squad is an army. It's also just the army. It refers more to "an" army rather than "the" army. Just a group of people who do army things.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あの矢印の道路標識は何という意味ですか。
ex_1_en: What does the arrow road sign mean?
meaning_story: An arrow seal is an arrow you stick down on a sign or piece of paper or document or whatever. We can just call it an arrow, though.
reading_story: The reading is 矢 and 印 put together into one. The 印 is like the actual vocab word 印, so think back on that.

ex_1_jp: 彼が私の金庫を盗んでいた時、私はその物音が聞こえないふりをしていました。
ex_1_en: I pretended not to hear him when he stole from my safe.
meaning_story: Gold storage is where you put your gold. You want it to be safe, so you put it in a safe.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今日の星占いで、頭にたんこぶができないように気をつけた方がいいと出ていたの。
ex_1_en: Today’s horoscope says I should be careful of getting a bump on my head.
meaning_story: 占い is "fortune telling." Star fortune telling is when you use the stars for fortune telling. That's known as astrology or horoscope.
reading_story: one

ex_1_jp: 今まで見た中で一番セクシーなミサイル攻撃だったよ。
ex_1_en: It was the sexiest missile attack I’ve ever seen.
meaning_story: With aggression you attack the enemy. This is an attack.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: エンジンの調子がおかしくなったので、浜に着くほんの手前で車を止めなきゃいけなくなっちゃったんだよ。
ex_1_en: Our car’s engine was making strange sounds so we had to stop right before we were going to arrive the beach.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. A better way to say beach is 海.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 一緒に浜辺を散歩しないか。
ex_1_en: Shall we take a walk on the beach together?
meaning_story: A beach area is just a beach!
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 辺 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Beach starts with be. Be is べ! (I mean, it's pronounced differently, but they're spelled the same!) When you think of the beach, think of べ!

ex_1_jp: 何故なら、彼は魔法使いだったのです。
ex_1_en: Because, he was a wizard!
meaning_story: When someone asks you 何故, or "why," you did something, you respond with, "何故なら blah blah blah." That makes it mean because. Why did you do that? Because I was mad! Why did you dance? Because I was happy!
reading_story: This reading is an exception but you learned them already because they're the same as the word 何故, which you learned a few levels ago. It just as some kana attached to it!

ex_1_jp: 非常に有益な情報を提供して頂き、誠に有り難うございます。
ex_1_en: Thank you very much for your very useful information.
meaning_story: To have benefit is to be beneficial.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女をデートに誘ったが、それは大間違いだった。
ex_1_en: I asked her to go out with me, but it was a big mistake.
meaning_story: A 間違い is a mistake. A big mistake is a big mistake.
reading_story: The reading is 大 and 間違い put together into one not so mistaken word.

ex_1_jp: 電車の回数券は金券ショップでも買えますよ。
ex_1_en: You can also buy a book of train tickets from a ticket outlet.
meaning_story: Many times is how many times you can use this number of tickets. That means there are many tickets, making this a book of tickets.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お母さん、心配しなくていいよ。あのお菓子屋さんなら僕、一人でも行けるよ。
ex_1_en: Don’t worry mom. I can go to the candy store by myself.
meaning_story: お菓子 is "candy," right? Add store onto that and you have a candy store.
reading_story: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. It will help to know the word お菓子 as well.

ex_1_jp: 「昨日、幼年時代の友人に偶然会ったの。彼には何年も会っていなかったんだけど。」「そう言えば、サーモンって、幼年時代の友人のフグと結婚したのよね。」
ex_1_en: "I ran into a childhood friend yesterday. I hadn’t seen him in years." "Speaking of which, Salmon married her childhood friend, Fugu."
meaning_story: You have 時代 as a "period" of time you're talking about. What period? The infancy years. Those years are not just when you're a baby, but when you were growing up, too. That was your childhood.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私が幼い頃は、何事もうまくいっていたんだ。
ex_1_en: When I was really young everything went smoothly.
meaning_story: The kanji means infancy. The adjective version refers more to your entire child-times, including baby times. But, if you're described as being like a child from child times, what are you called? Childish.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you were childish and immature you were sent off to do prayers to ask for forgiveness. One of the things you had to do was sing "hosanna (おさな) in the highest."
pitch_accent: イトケナꜜイ *** オサナꜜイ

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: どうして幼稚な喋り方をする日本人女性が多いのですか？
ex_1_en: Why do so many Japanese girls speak like children?
meaning_story: He who is both childish and immature is probably childish and immature.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あの幼児のテディベアの毛はベルベットのように滑らかだった。
ex_1_en: The fur of that little kid’s teddy bear was as smooth as velvet.
meaning_story: Childish children are children.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 児童の九割が欠席しました。
ex_1_en: Ninety percent of the children were absent.
meaning_story: The child who is a juvenile is just a child. A group of them is children.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 冷たいコーヒーのことを、日本語では「アイスコーヒー」と呼びます。
ex_1_en: We call cold coffee "ice coffee" in Japanese.
meaning_story: Something that is cool is cold. This refers to something that is cold to the touch, not the weather or something like that (which is 寒い).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's mnemonic to help you: Something that is really cold to the touch is cold enough to make ice cream with.

ex_1_jp: 彼は新しいプログラミング言語を比較的速く修得します。
ex_1_en: He learns new programming codes relatively quickly.
meaning_story: 比較 is a comparison. Add 的 to it and you have comparatively.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know the word 比較.

ex_1_jp: 憲法改正案の見直しで依然として忙しい。
ex_1_en: I’m still busy reviewing the constitutional amendment.
meaning_story: The constitution laws are what makes up the constitution.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 憲政の危機って何ですか。
ex_1_en: What is a constitutional crisis?
meaning_story: A constitution government is a constitutional government.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ケンセイ *** ケꜜンセイ

ex_1_jp: 冷静にネット上の荒らしに対処する方法を学ぶ必要があります。
ex_1_en: You need to learn how to be cool-headed when handling internet trolls.
meaning_story: You're cool and quiet. That's you, daddio. Nice and cool headed.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: いつ誰に対して織田軍が反攻を開始したのか覚えてる？
ex_1_en: Do you remember when and who Oda’s army starting the counterattack against?
meaning_story: Anti aggression is when you receive some aggression, then respond to it with anti aggression, aka your counterattack.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: これで、あなたには創造的な仕事にもっと集中してもらえます。
ex_1_en: Now you can focus more on creative work.
meaning_story: If 創造 is creation, then you add 的 to it, which means you have a creational thing, which is quite creative wouldn't you say?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あなたのような創造力のある人と仕事ができることを、とても楽しみにしています。
ex_1_en: I’m so excited to work with a creative person like you.
meaning_story: If 創造 is creation and you add power to it, you have creative power.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well!

ex_1_jp: 彼は、上司が顧客のクレーム処理をしないことについてぶつぶつ文句を言っている。
ex_1_en: He complains that his boss doesn’t deal with clients’ complaints.
meaning_story: I can deal with it, no matter what the reason. I can take care of this problem and deal with it on my own.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼は実際は35歳だが、3歳児と同程度の知能水準しかない。
ex_1_en: He is actually 35 years old, but has no more intelligence than a three year old kid.
meaning_story: The extent degrees show to what degree or extent you're willing to take something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女の微かな香水の香りに、妙に興奮してしまった。
ex_1_en: I got strangely excited by the faint smell of her perfume.
meaning_story: The kanji is delicate, and the vocab has this meaning too. It's that kind of "subtle" delicate, not so much that something will break (like it is with the kanji). Something that is a bit faint and indistinct is going to be delicate in this sense, perhaps, too.
reading_story: If you're going to cuss (かす) up a storm that's not really being delicate.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 相手チームに15点差で負けているので、かなり絶望的な状況です。
ex_1_en: The other team is fifteen goals ahead of us, so we are in a pretty hopeless situation.
meaning_story: When hope has died out, you have no more hope, only despair.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 幸運なことに、私の家族はあの日本の大地震や大津波による直接的な被害は受けませんでした。
ex_1_en: Fortunately, our family wasn’t directly damaged by the huge earthquake or the tsunami in Japan.
meaning_story: 直接 is direct. Add 的 to the mix and you have directly.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know 直接 already.

ex_1_jp: 私の息子は、ある生徒に苛めを行い、退学処分を受けました。
ex_1_en: My son was expelled from school for bullying a student.
meaning_story: Please deal with part of this trash. It is too much to handle all at once when it comes to the disposal of it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 国外移住者になるのは容易なことではない。
ex_1_en: It’s not easy to be an international immigrant.
meaning_story: Someone who has to shift their dwelling is someone who moves their home (and in this case) to another country. They are an emigrant / immigrant. Welcome to this country, friend!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本人男性がアメリカ軍に入隊することはできますか。
ex_1_en: Can a Japanese man enlist in the U.S. army?
meaning_story: Enter into a squad... an army squad. When you do this, you enlist in the army.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: まだ夜明けまでは一時間程あったが、驚く程青い目をした男は既に起床し、珈琲を作り始めていた。
ex_1_en: It was still an hour before dawn, but a guy with startling blue eyes already had gotten up and was making coffee.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: You'll remember this kanji to the extent that you study it. If you study it like Hodor (ほど) would study it, you won't learn it at all. You would only be able to say "hodor, hodor," over and over again, which isn't helpful at all.

ex_1_jp: 「わっ！君にビールをこぼしちゃったよね！本当にごめんなさい。」「大丈夫よ！このスカート、妹のなんだけど、妹はそもそも不潔だから多分気にしないと思うわ。」
ex_1_en: "Ah! I just spilled beer on you, I’m really sorry." "It’s okay! This skirt is actually my sister’s and she’s pretty filthy anyway, so she probably wouldn’t care."
meaning_story: Not pure things are filthy and dirty. Ewughh.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は道路の凍結についてよく文句を言っています。
ex_1_en: She often complains about frozen roads.
meaning_story: When things are frozen they get tied up in ice, causing a freeze.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 良い冷凍庫が見つかるといいですね。
ex_1_en: I hope you find a good freezer.
meaning_story: A cool frozen storage is one which is really cold on the inside, so cold it can freeze things. This is called a freezer, not to be confused with 冷蔵庫, which is refrigerator, and doesn't have the kanji for "freeze" in it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 警察が昨夜私の見込み客が雪山で凍死しているのを発見したので、私に事情聴取をしたいそうです。
ex_1_en: The police discovered that a potential client of mine was frozen to death on a snowy mountain last night and they want to talk to me.
meaning_story: A frozen death isn't a bad way to go, I hear. Still, you don't want to freeze to death if you can help it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 漢字に振り仮名を振る仕事を見つけました。
ex_1_en: I found a job where I write furigana above kanji.
meaning_story: 振る is "to shake." 仮名 is kana. This word refers to furigana, which is the little kana that's put next to kanji for the people who don't use WaniKani and can't read anything. As to why it's called "shake kana"? I have no clue. Just imagine putting little kana next to kanji and watching them shake around, though, and you should be good to go.
reading_story: The readings are 振る and 仮名 put together into one. If you know those words, you won't need no furigana to help you with this word.
pitch_accent: フリカ°ナ *** フリカ°ꜜナ

ex_1_jp: 博打を打つことは日本では違法です。
ex_1_en: Gambling is illegal in Japan.
meaning_story: A gambling hit can be multiple things. One type of gambling in Japan that was popular in the day involved betting these awesome wooden block things. You'd gamble by hitting them down on the ground, making a nice thunk sound. Another way to think about it is like blackjack. You want a card? You hit! Either way, it's gambling.
reading_story: The reading is weird on this one, but gambling is weird, I guess. はく goes to ばく, maybe because you're playing some gambling backgammon. The ち can be cheating, where you cheat at this gambling backgammon. So, you're backgammon cheating (ばくち), you big cheater.

ex_1_jp: 両親の車を車庫に入れる時に、柱にぶつけてしまいました。
ex_1_en: When I was backing my parents’ car into the garage I ran it into a pole.
meaning_story: Car storage is where you store your car. It's your garage.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 大衆の感じ方次第です。
ex_1_en: It depends on how people feel.
meaning_story: A big populous place sounds like a place with a lot of people but it's more like a big part of the populace. It's most of the populace, sure, making it the general public.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ダイシュ *** ダꜜイシュ *** タイシュー

ex_1_jp: 日本人の人たちと、身振り手振りで何とかコミュニケーションをとることができた。
ex_1_en: I managed to communicate to Japanese people with gestures.
meaning_story: Somebody shakes something at you. It was a finger, it seems. What a weird little gesture.
reading_story: The reading is 身 and 振る put together, where the 振り gets rendaku'd to ぶり.

ex_1_jp: 家政婦を雇おうかと思っているんです。
ex_1_en: I think we should hire a housekeeper.
meaning_story: The person who governs your house like a wife is your housekeeper.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ある衆議院議員が公費でボートを借りたことが明らかになりました。
ex_1_en: It was revealed that a member of the House of Representatives chartered a boat at government expense.
meaning_story: It's the institution that does deliberation on behalf of the populace. They represent the people. They are the house of representatives.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あの主婦の肌はものすごくスベスベしている。
ex_1_en: That housewife has really smooth skin.
meaning_story: The master wife is the one that takes care of all your stuff for you. She is the housewife, a very common profession for married ladies in Japan, though things have been changing little by little. Still, being a housewife means you control the money, which is pretty neat if you ask me.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼はとっても忙しい巨大企業の社長さんなんだから、アポの約束は絶対に早目に取っておいた方がいいよ。
ex_1_en: I strongly suggest that you schedule the appointment with him well in advance because he is the president of an enormous company and he is very, very busy.
meaning_story: A giant big thing is something that is huge and gigantic.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ねぇ、あなた。これから先、私たち夫婦の間で色々なことがうまくいくといいわね。
ex_1_en: Oh, Honey. Now that we’re a husband and wife, I hope things go smoother between us.
meaning_story: A husband and wife combo are a husband and wife.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私は、自分が違法移民であるという秘密を彼女に告白した。
ex_1_en: I confessed my secret that I’m an illegal immigrant to her.
meaning_story: Shift the peoples of that country into this country. Immigration nation!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: もし自分の彼氏が後ろ向きで入る並列駐車が上手くできなかったら、がっかりしちゃうと思う。
ex_1_en: If my boyfriend was bad at reverse parallel parking I’d be disappointed in him.
meaning_story: Line up everything in a row. When you do that, they're all in a row.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 成程、これなら誰にも見つからずに手紙を出すことができる。
ex_1_en: I see! I can send this letter without anyone finding out.
meaning_story: If you become aware of something to an extent you'll end up saying I see or That's right! But you won't see if you didn't become aware enough. So it's that extent of understanding you're trying to reach before you can chime in with an "Ahh, indeed."
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. The reading for 成 is from 成る and it keeps the る part. It's just hidden in the kanji. If you can remember that, you'll know this reading!

ex_1_jp: あの婦人、俺の手には負えなくなってきたよ。どうしたらいいかな？
ex_1_en: That lady is getting out of hand. What should I do?
meaning_story: A wife person is a lady, because I guess ladies are wife people? I'm guessing this is pretty sexist somewhere, somehow, but words were made a long time ago so hopefully you can give all those dead people a break.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どうやって私の小さな郵便箱にこの本が入ったんだろう。
ex_1_en: How could this book fit in my small mailbox?
meaning_story: 郵便 is the mail. A box that's used with said mail is a mailbox.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私はファイン・アートを専攻しています。
ex_1_en: I’m majoring in fine art.
meaning_story: Your specialty, which you focus on with aggression, is your major in college (your college major). Study hard, young grasshopper.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 従兄弟同士は結婚できるんだぜ。
ex_1_en: Cousins can get married?!
meaning_story: Remember how 兄弟 means "siblings?" Well when they're siblings you have to obey they're not your brother or sister, they're your cousin. Because obeying is involved, this means they're specifically your male cousin. When your male cousin tells you to do something you have to obey them.
reading_story: The entire reading for this is an exception. Sorry about that. Here's a mnemonic to help you: What are the two defining traits your male cousin has? He's good and a child. いいと子, or いとこ for short. Just remember your good, kid cousin. Your いとこ cousin.

ex_1_jp: アルバイトをしながら、修士号を取るために勉強しています。
ex_1_en: I’m studying to get my master’s degree while working part time.
meaning_story: The discipline of a samurai. You need this in order to complete your master's degree. It's hard to get one of those things, and even though samurais didn't really get master's degrees all too much, they had the discipline for it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 微生物学の専門家は何時に来る予定ですか。
ex_1_en: What time is the the microbiology specialist scheduled for?

reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE

ex_1_en: That depends on whether or not you will move to this country.
meaning_story: Shift your dwellings! Everyone shift! Somewhere else, please. Time for a migration.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_en: You get worn out when you migrate long-distance by bus.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「サーモン、昨日の博物館デート、どうだった？」「ひどかったわ！」「どうして？何があったの？」「フグったら、ずっと他の女の子をじろじろ見てたのよ！すごくむかついたわ。」
ex_1_en: "How was your museum date yesterday, Salmon?" "Horrible!" "Why? What happened?" "Fugu was checking out other girls the whole time! I got pissed off."
meaning_story: An exhibition for things is put in a public building for anyone to see. This place is a museum.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本人の英会話力不足によって、将来国益が損なわれる可能性がある。
ex_1_en: Japanese people’s poor English could damage national interests in the future.
meaning_story: The country will benefit from these actions. It will create national benefit or national interests.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: うーん…なんとも微妙な感じですね。
ex_1_en: Well... I have mixed feelings.
meaning_story: This word is pretty weird. It has two distinct sort of meanings. One is the "not so good" meaning, and the other is the "delicate" meaning. Lately the "not so good" meaning has taken priority, I think, so let's focus on that for now. Something is both delicate and strange. This delicate strange thing really is just not so good. It's not terrible, but it's not great either. It's just not so good. Why? Because if you touch it too hard, it will break. Also, it's not that normal either, so it's not helpful to you. Imagine a thing that could be like this, then think: Is this good? not really. It's not so good.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 妙だな。今日はまだお袋から電話がかかってこないよ。
ex_1_en: It’s strange that my mother hasn’t called me yet today.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though "odd" is getting the number one definition for this word, and strange comes in later.
reading_story: The reading is actually the same as the kanji you learned. On'yomi all the way, despite being all alone. Strange!

pronunciation: ぎゃくこうか, ぎゃっこうか
ex_1_jp: 彼女に焼き餅を妬かせようとして他の女にキスをしたら、全く逆効果になってしまった。
ex_1_en: I kissed that other girl to make my girlfriend jealous, but it really backfired.
meaning_story: A 効果 is an effect. So, the reverse of said effect is the opposite effect that you were shooting for. Whoops.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 効果 as well.
pitch_accent: ギャクコꜜーカ *** ギャッコꜜーカ

ex_1_jp: 運動神経は並だったが、頭はすこぶる良かった。
ex_1_en: He had ordinary reflexes, but a great mind.
meaning_story: The things that line up are the ordinary and average things. The extraordinary things skip the line, because they don't have to wait. Sad for all the ordinaries.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: All the people who went off to fight in Nam (なみ) were just ordinary, average folk.

ex_1_jp: 逆説的に聞こえるかもしれないが、長い結婚生活を送ってきた年配の人達は、ちょっと違ったことに取り組むことは夫婦関係の刺激になると認めている。
ex_1_en: It may sound paradoxical, but many long-married old people admit that some differences can spice up a relationship.
meaning_story: It is reverse to the theory! What is going on? Things aren't right. There must be some kind of paradox going on, where all theories are reversed! D:
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 複数の言語を並行して勉強することは、ひとつだけを学習するよりも効率的だと聞いたことがあります。
ex_1_en: I heard that studying multiple languages at the same time is more efficient than only studying one.
meaning_story: Line up and go together. If lines did that, they'd be parallel.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ホテルの金庫に貴重品と旅券を預けたいのですが。
ex_1_en: I’d like to deposit my valuables and my passport into the hotel safe.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: まだ新しい郵便番号を覚えていません。
ex_1_en: I haven’t memorized my new postal code yet.
meaning_story: You know that a 郵便 is the mail and that a 番号 is a number. So a "mail number," what is that? Usually refers to your post number or postal code. It is also often referred to with a symbol, which is 〒, so look out for that.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 郵便局のサービスに対して苦情を言いました。
ex_1_en: I made a complaint about the post office’s service.
meaning_story: With 郵便 being mail and 局 being bureau, we have the "mail bureau." They're more often known as the post office.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 郵便 as well.

ex_1_jp: 3Dプリンタは発明されたものの、我々の高精度の研削盤に技術が追いつくにはまだ時間がかかるだろう。
ex_1_en: Even though the 3D printer was invented, it would take a while for its technology to catch up with our high precision grinding machines.
meaning_story: The degree of your spirit is what helps you to hone your precision and accuracy, for some reason. Just imagine yourself throwing a ball. You miss the target. Hmm, okay... time to power up like on Dragonball. Up that spirit energy. Turn the degrees up on it. Boom. Awesome. Now throw again. Hit! You hit it! What great precision you have gained by honing your spirit!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 普通の主婦が無差別に脅迫状を送りつける気違いに成り下がった過程を説明してもらえますか。
ex_1_en: Can you explain the process of how an average housewife ended up being a psychopath who sent out a bunch of threatening letters to random people?
meaning_story: Surpass the extent... okay, what does that even mean? You figure out the extent of your abilities, and then you surpass them to get better. You have to do this over and over again in order to keep getting better. It's a process that must be accomplished if you ever hope to get better than you are now.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この新しいタイプの下着が、莫大な年間利益を上げることを予想しています。
ex_1_en: We are expecting that this new type of underwear will yield a large annual profit.
meaning_story: The profit is really a benefit. Let's make more profit then.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は公益法人で働いています。
ex_1_en: I’m working for a nonprofit foundation.
meaning_story: Something for public benefit is for public benefit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は清い心を持っており、人々をとても思いやります。
ex_1_en: She has a pure heart and is very considerate of others.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of pure? It's pure.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "In order to stay pure and clean, you shouldn't ever do anything dirty or bad. That is the key, yo (きよ)."

ex_1_jp: 実際には清潔だけど、見た目は汚らしくてちょっと影がある男の人がタイプです。
ex_1_en: My type is a guy who is actually clean but looks dirty and sketchy.
meaning_story: Pure and pure. Sounds like this word means pure.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 俺にもお前みたいな潔い心があればいいんだがな。
ex_1_en: Wish I had a pure heart like yours.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of pure? It's also pure.
reading_story: Oh man, the reading for this is... like... crazy. First part can be something like it's soggy (いさぎ)... then the second part is like the word 良い (good). So, you can think of a pure hearted person eating soggy cereal. He/she is so pure hearted that it doesn't matter to them how soggy it is. In fact, they seem to enjoy it! They keep saying "it's soggy, good!" over and over again while eating the terribly soggy food.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は、バイク事故で投げ飛ばされる飛距離の世界記録を樹立した。
ex_1_en: She set the world record for the person thrown farthest by a motorcycle accident.
meaning_story: Write down a record of the events so we have a record, please. Don't want people to forget about this momentous occasion, when King Felix got his perfect game.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 三宅結花です。携帯電話を変えたので、新しい電話番号とメールアドレスの登録をお願いします。
ex_1_en: This is Yuka Miyake. I’ve changed my phone, so could you register my new number and email address in your address book, please? Thank you.
meaning_story: Climb up and record your information here. This is the registration because when you register, you are just applying to join. You may not actually get in. That's why it's like a climb up a mountain. You record your info, wait, and hope a lot.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「おい、修理屋。これはすぐに直せるか？」「って、君たちの関係ってこと？悪いけど、それはできないよ。」
ex_1_en: "Hey, repairman. Can you fix this right now?" "You mean, you guys’ relationship? Sorry. No can do."
meaning_story: Discipline is the reason why you're able to do a repair on things. It takes a lot of time to fix something, and takes a lot of studying. That discipline is what you need, and you have it. Thus, it was repaired!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私はホットドッグのことが好きで、逆もまた同じ。こないだ夢であるホットドッグに’好きだ’ってちゃっかり言われちゃったんだから。
ex_1_en: I like hotdogs, and the reverse is also true. I was told by a hotdog that they like me very much the other night in my dream.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji as well. Lucky! Reverse face time!

ex_1_jp: 私は修辞学の先生に恋をしています。
ex_1_en: I have crush on the rhetoric teacher.
meaning_story: The discipline in which you study words so that you can out talk anyone is called rhetoric. Get the rhetoric right and you can be a boss in any word related situation or discipline, yo!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 会合の後、素晴らしい刺身弁当があるレストランで昼食を予定しています。
ex_1_en: After the meeting, we’re scheduling lunch at a restaurant that has a great sashimi bento box.
meaning_story: Slash somebody, take their flesh, then eat it raw. This kind of food is known as sashimi, yum!
reading_story: The reading is a little weird. It's double kun'yomi where the 刺す becomes stem form and gets pushed inside the kanji to become さし. The 身 is just the word 身's reading.

ex_1_jp: 兄は、十年前に私の貯金箱を盗んだ事を白状しました。
ex_1_en: My brother confessed that he had stolen my piggy bank ten years ago.
meaning_story: Remember how 貯金 is your savings? A box you put said savings in is a savings box.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 演奏会の日程は、次の日曜日に変更されました。
ex_1_en: According to the concert schedule, it’s been changed to next Sunday.
meaning_story: The extent of the day is that we're going to do this, this and this. That is our schedule and agenda, so stick to it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 兵隊ごっこをしているの？面白そう。私も入れてよ。
ex_1_en: Are you guys playing soldiers? That looks fun. Let me in too.
meaning_story: A soldier in a squad is a real soldier or sailor, unlike those "soldier" who are not in a squad. They don't have jobs, and can't be called real soldiers.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 誰かがいびき録音用枕の特許を取得したというのは本当ですよ。
ex_1_en: Someone actually got a patent for a snore recording pillow.
meaning_story: A record of sound is a sound recording of some kind. Might be minidisk, might be CD, might be digital. Whatever it is, it's still the record of sound.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 先生は「精神を養わなくてはならない」と言った。
ex_1_en: My teacher told me that I must cultivate my mind.
meaning_story: Spirit of the gods. This refers to both the "religious spirit" and the "spirit spirit." It's your spirit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 海上自衛隊音楽隊に採用された時、彼女は他の自衛隊員と同様に肉体的にも厳しいトレーニングを受けなくてはいけないことを知らなかった。
ex_1_en: When she was hired by the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force Band, she didn’t know that she had to physically work out as hard as them as well.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned, probably because this is stuck onto things, describing various squads.

ex_1_jp: 世界の息を飲むような絶景をたくさん紹介している有名なFacebookページがあります。
ex_1_en: There is a famous facebook page that introduces lots of stunning views from around the world.
meaning_story: All good things are fleeting. When a scene in front of you dies out, it is gone. But, it was beautiful, it was amazing, it was a superb view.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 君が女性に対して口がうまいのは知ってたけど、その練習のためにそんな風にブツブツ独り言を言ってるなんてこれっぽっちも知らなかったよ。
ex_1_en: I knew you were super smooth with the ladies, but I had no idea that you practice talking to them by talking to yourself like that.
meaning_story: 独り is when you're alone. 言 is when you say something. So, when you say something and you're alone, you're just talking to yourself.
reading_story: The reading for 独り is just the reading for 独り. The reading for 言 is an exception, though. It's ごと, which comes from こと. Just think that as you're talking to yourself you're telling yourself over and over to go to hell. You're mean to yourself, and you're also insane, which is why you keep saying that out loud to nobody but you.
pitch_accent: ヒトリコ°ト *** ヒトリコ°トꜜ

ex_1_jp: 度重なる無断遅刻故に、 休暇日数が減らされてしまった。
ex_1_en: I was repeatedly late without permission and consequently my vacation days were cut short.
meaning_story: With 故 meaning "reason" if you head towards that reason, you transition towards it. To say that in words, you might say therefore or consequently. You stated your case and ideas, then in order to go towards reason we use these words to transition towards it.
reading_story: By knowing the word 故 you'll know the reading for this word too!

ex_1_jp: 三ヶ月の定期券をもらえますか？
ex_1_en: Can I get a commuter pass for three consecutive months?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Usually it's attached to things, because it tells you what kind of ticket something is.

ex_1_jp: そのピッチャーはバッターを変化球で攻めることが多い。
ex_1_en: That pitcher often assaults batters with curve balls.
meaning_story: You don't say "to aggression." When you do aggression on someone, you're probably doing something to hurt them in some way. This is an attack, making this word to attack. This refers to a a planned attack, though. Think about what you're going to do. Plan it out. Then, 攻める!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you (I'm talking about you) attack something, you don't use weapons or thinking or anything silly like that. No, you use your intense sexiness (せ). Bam! So sexy. Attack!

ex_1_jp: エコバッグを買うために十二時間も行列に並ぶなんて信じられないよ。
ex_1_en: I can’t believe that people wait in line for twelve hours just to get some eco-friendly bags.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means line up so the verb vocab version is to be lined up. You know this is the version where things are just lined up (you're not doing the lining up) because you keep saying boo (ぶ), why is everyone already lined up? I should have got here earlier so I don't have to wait (if you were doing the lining up yourself, you'd put yourself in the front, duh).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Only for you, when you visit Nara (なら), the deer there are to be lined up for you to inspect, as you are the deer inspector. If you don't know about Nara and its deer, you should look it up, they're pretty awesome.

ex_1_jp: 同じ年齢の女の子と比較すると、私の娘は体力があまりありません。
ex_1_en: My daughter lacks physical strength compared to the other girls at her age.
meaning_story: 比較 is comparison. So, verb version of that? It's to compare.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help a lot to know the word 比較 as well.

ex_1_jp: オレンジジュースを凍らせて氷を作ったことはありますか。
ex_1_en: Have you ever made ice cubes by freezing orange juice?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means frozen, so the vocab version is to freeze.
reading_story: The reading actually comes from the word 氷, which means "ice." You can kind of see where the origins of these words come from, now... really cold frozen things. So, think back to こおり, then change the り to a る and put it outside the kanji. That makes the reading for this こおる, in all (or most) of 氷's glory.

ex_1_jp: 「うわ！お前目のとこに青たんできてるじゃん。」「そうなんだよ。昨日の夜お袋に逆らったら、こてんぱに殴られてさ。」
ex_1_en: "Wow! You have a bruise above your eye." "Yeah, I disobeyed my mom last night and I got the shit kicked out of me."
meaning_story: The kanji means reverse, so think about what you do when you reverse something. This word isn't "to reverse," but it's close. When you go reverse to what people want, you have to go against them. You also have to oppose them. You are going reverse to their rules.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just like when you play soccer (さか). You never play right, causing you to go against all things you're supposed to do and shoot goals into your own goalie's net.

ex_1_jp: 私はヨーロッパからワインとチョコレートを輸入する仕事をしています。
ex_1_en: My job is to import wine and chocolate from Europe.
meaning_story: 輸入 is import. Now let's make it a verb. To import.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 輸入 as well.

ex_1_jp: 今日私が面接した男はすごく馬鹿な奴で、オリンピックは三年毎に開催されるって言ってたよ。
ex_1_en: The man I interviewed today was so stupid that he said the Olympics are held every three years.
meaning_story: 面接 is an interview. Make that into a verb and you have to interview with.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 面接 as well.

ex_1_jp: こんな簡単な問題を間違えるなんて、悔しいよ。
ex_1_en: Making a mistake on such a simple question is so frustrating.
meaning_story: Remember how 間違い means "a mistake?" Well this is the verb version. It means to make a mistake.
reading_story: It's read the same as 間違い! Nice and easy!

ex_1_jp: 彼が意識を回復することは難しいだろうと医者に言われました。
ex_1_en: The doctor told me that he is not likely to regain consciousness.
meaning_story: 回復 is recovery. Make it into a verb and you have to recover.
reading_story: The reading comes from 回復, but you can also figure it out via the readings of the kanji as well.

ex_1_jp: 酒を絶つことが約束できますか。
ex_1_en: Can you promise me you’ll abstain from alcohol?
meaning_story: This one is a little bit off and will take a little extra remembering. The kanji means extinction or die out, but the verb version here is to sever or to cut off. The ideas are pretty similar, but the wording isn't the same. Just think, when you put something to extinction, you have to cut off that thing from your life. Put it in extinction. You have to sever it.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In terms of things you need to sever, tacos (た) are #1 on your list. No more tacos for you, going to cut those off from my diet.

ex_1_jp: 私は苺をミキサーに移しました。
ex_1_en: I transferred the strawberries to the blender.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shift so the verb vocab version is to shift.
reading_story: All that dubstep (うつうつうつうつうつ) playing downstairs is causing all of your glassware to shift off the shelf and onto the floor. Damn that dubstep. うつうつうつうつうつ♪

ex_1_jp: 動くな。じっとしていないと、撃つぞ！
ex_1_en: Don’t move. Hold still or you’ll be shot!
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means to attack, though it usually means to shoot, because that's a very common way in which to attack someone. Pow!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who are you going to shoot? You are going to shoot You (う). Why? Because there's another version of you in front of you, so if you don't shoot that version of you who is you, ammirght?

ex_1_jp: 彼は無我夢中で働き、二十代で家を建てたが、三十代で墓を建てることとなった。
ex_1_en: Working feverishly, he built his house in his twenties and built his tomb in his thirties.
meaning_story: 夢中 is crazy about. So, if I (talking about you here) am nothing when put next to this thing you're crazy about, then you are really, really into it. You have become nothing, at least when you compare yourself to it. This is total absorption (though it can also be ecstasy).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その研修は午後3時に始まる予定です。
ex_1_en: The training session is set to begin at 3 p.m.
meaning_story: Sharpen your discipline, whatever that might be. Could be kanji, could be baseball, could be curling. Whatever it is, when you sharpen it, you have to study. You have to do training. It's the only way to get better.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 誰か彼に応急処置ができる人はいませんか。
ex_1_en: Is there anyone who could give him first aid?
meaning_story: We're going to deal with it by putting this up your butt and giving you the treatment you need. Kancho!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は傘をクロークに預けました。
ex_1_en: I left my umbrella in the cloakroom.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 傘立てに濡れた傘を立てないで下さい。
ex_1_en: Please do not put a wet umbrella in the umbrella stand.
meaning_story: This is when you take your umbrella and you stand it up. Wait, how is an umbrella standing up? Good question, my dear Crabling, you are putting your umbrella in an umbrella stand.
reading_story: The reading is the readings for 傘 (learned with the kanji) and 立つ (to stand).

ex_1_jp: お宅の庫は何階建てですか？
ex_1_en: How many stories does your warehouse have?
meaning_story: The kanji means storage, but the vocab is warehouse. If it's any consolation, a warehouse is a type of storage. Usually refers to a traditional style of Japanese warehouse, not a modern warehouse.
reading_story: What do you put in your warehouse? Nothing that nice. Just your totally crashed (くら) car. So sad, it was a nice car, too and now it's all crashed and stored in your warehouse.

ex_1_jp: 我々はその問題を熟考する必要がある。
ex_1_en: We need to carefully consider the problem.
meaning_story: 我 is me, so two of me makes we! Or us!
reading_story: The reading is 我, twice.

ex_1_jp: これは二日酔いに良く効く妙薬です。
ex_1_en: This a really effective miracle cure for hangovers.
meaning_story: A strange drug that seems too good to be true? Sometimes they're not bad. They are known as wonder drugs.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: ミョꜜーヤク *** ミョーヤク

ex_1_jp: 「横浜から大阪までずうっと乗せてくれて、本当に有難うございます。」「どういたしまして！」
ex_1_en: "Thank you so much for giving me a lift from Yokohama all the way to Osaka." "Don’t mention it!"
meaning_story: It's the the side of the beach! Well, wait, what is it? This will make better sense when you look at the reading for the word, since it's a place: Yokohama.
reading_story: The reading is 横 and 浜 put together into one nice word, よこはま

ex_1_jp: 時間の都合上、今は詳細については省略せざるを得ませんが、また後ほどご説明させて頂きます。
ex_1_en: I have to omit the details for now due to time constraints, but I’ll explain it to you later.
meaning_story: Conserve those letters with abbreviation. That will allow you to abbreviate and leave out things from the word (or anything, really).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あなたの略語辞典を貸してもらえませんか？
ex_1_en: Can I borrow your dictionary of acronyms and abbreviations?
meaning_story: Abbreviation in language is abbreviation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 2chの野球板に書き込みをしたんですが、板違いだと言われてしまいました。
ex_1_en: I posted some comments on a forum about baseball on 2chan, but I was told it was the wrong board.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When you get hit in the face with a board, it hurts. It is very 痛い (いた).

ex_1_jp: 私の怒りは三分以上続かない。
ex_1_en: My anger will not go on for more than three minutes.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of 怒る. So instead of being "to be angry," it's just the idea and concept of anger and wrath.
reading_story: This will make you angry. The reading isn't the on'yomi reading nor is it the reading that you learned with 怒る. It's something completely different! Wait, calm down, calm down. Here, use this mnemonic: You are filled with so much anger. Why? Because this isn't いか (squid), it's tofu! Wth, they were supposed to bring you いか...

ex_1_jp: 彼の鼻の穴は怒気を含んで膨らんでいる。
ex_1_en: His nostrils swelled with anger.
meaning_story: An angry energy comes out of you when you have anger. It also can refer to a fit of anger.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 俺の伯母さん、クソしてる時に胸にするどい痛みが走って、119に電話したんだ。
ex_1_en: My aunt had a sharp pain in her chest while pooping and called 119.
meaning_story: 痛い is "painful." This is the noun version, it is a pain or a pain.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 痛い. No pain here.

ex_1_jp: 彼のおでこの面積は100平方メートルある。
ex_1_en: The area of his forehead is 100 square meters.
meaning_story: The surface that accumulates into one area is a particular area. This has to do with math. When you add all the surfaces together by accumulating them into one calculation, you get yourself the area!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 人事部長様、 恐れ入りますが、このEメールに添付された履歴書にお目通し頂けますでしょうか。お忙しいとは存じますが、よろしくお願い申し上げます。
ex_1_en: Dear hiring manager, please have a look at the resume attached to this email. Thank you for your time.
meaning_story: Append and attach this document to your email. It's an attachment.
reading_story: The reading for 添 is what you'd expect. The reading for 付 is the on'yomi reading, which you've never learned. It's ふ, but for this word it becomes ぷ from the rendaku fairies. Just think of an attachment where instead of a document or something, you get an attachment of poop (ぷ). What a gross attachment. Your friend who likes to send poop attachments is dumb.

ex_1_jp: あの航空会社は四月に新路線を増やす予定だ。
ex_1_en: That airline company is adding a new route in April.
meaning_story: Navigation in the sky is aviation and flight. Vroom vroom sky flying!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 宴会で嫌な奴とお酒を飲むのは、会議で議事録を記録するより退屈な仕事だ。
ex_1_en: Drinking alcohol with someone you don’t like at a dinner party is a much more tedious task than recording the proceedings of a meeting.
meaning_story: A banquet meeting is when you meet together for a banquet (or dinner party).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 俺はその宴で、ドイツ語訛りの英語を話すとても美しい女性に出会ったんだ。
ex_1_en: I met a beautiful woman who speaks English with a German accent at the dinner party.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: At a banquet or dinner party, you don't only get food, you also 歌 GET (うたげ), which is you getting a song from a singer, because entertainment is just as important as the food when you have a feast such as this.

ex_1_jp: 「お夕飯の支度ができましたよ！いらっしゃい。」「ああ、よかった！お腹ペコペコだよ。」
ex_1_en: "Supper is ready! Come and get it." "Oh, thank god! I’m starving!"
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is an exception, but it isn't too hard to remember. It's the same as 中 (なか), so if you think about it it makes sense. It's your insides, just like your belly is your insides!

ex_1_jp: 黒板が使えないので、ホワイトボードを持参しています。
ex_1_en: We can’t use the blackboard so I’ll bring in a whiteboard.
meaning_story: A black board is a blackboard.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the はん changing to ばん.

ex_1_jp: あの官僚が我々の素晴らしい提案を断ったなんて信じられないよ。
ex_1_en: I can’t believe that the bureaucrats turned down the great offer we made.
meaning_story: A government colleague is one who works for and is part of the bureaucracy, making him/her a bureaucrat.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: さっきの閣議では何が議題だったんだっけ？忘れちゃった。
ex_1_en: What did we discuss at the cabinet meeting held earlier today? I forgot.
meaning_story: When the cabinet meets for deliberation they are having a cabinet meeting. So governmenty.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼は閣僚のふりをしたが、嘘丸出しだった。
ex_1_en: He pretended that he was a cabinet minister, but it was such an obvious lie.
meaning_story: The cabinet colleagues are the cabinet ministers. They're the people in the Cabinet that are all colleagues with each other. They just happen to be known as ministers.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 中欧を旅してみたいなと随分長い間思っていたんですよ。
ex_1_en: I’ve wanted to travel around Central Europe for a really long time.
meaning_story: The middle part of Europe is Central Europe, wherever that is.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 政治学が専門なのですが、何故か織物会社に就職しました。
ex_1_en: I’m majoring in politics, but somehow I started working for a fabric company.
meaning_story: The things that are weaved are, essentially, just cloth or fabric.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. With 織 you can pull the reading from 織る. With 物 you've probably seen it enough to know that it's often もの and not ぶつ. Just think of a piece of cloth that is monochrome.
pitch_accent: オリモノ *** オリꜜモノ *** オリモꜜノ

ex_1_jp: 私の祖父母の家はとても古いので、雪の重みで倒壊しかねません。
ex_1_en: My grandparents’ house is so old that it could collapse under the weight of the snow.
meaning_story: When something collapses and breaks, it is when a collapse happens. When this happens, it is destruction. It is also probably something that was already crumbling apart.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 残念な事に、私の同僚はあの電車の事故によって大きな商談のスケジュールの組み直しを余儀なくされた。
ex_1_en: Unfortunately, the train accident forced my coworker to rearrange his big business meeting.
meaning_story: We work at the same place and are colleagues, making us colleagues / coworkers.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: マイホームを持っていたんですが、台風で全壊しちゃったんですよ。
ex_1_en: I had my own house, but it was completely destroyed by the typhoon.
meaning_story: To break it all is to break everything. Everything is broken. Complete destruction!!!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 毎年少しだけ、母校へお金を寄付しています。
ex_1_en: I contribute a little money to my alma mater every year.
meaning_story: If you approach a building and attach some stuff to it, you're making a contribution. They get to keep it, after all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguが世界平和に寄与していることを知っているかい？
ex_1_en: Did you know that Tofugu is contributing to world peace?
meaning_story: When you approach to give something, you are probably giving a contribution.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 子どもの頃、私は好奇心旺盛でした。
ex_1_en: When I was a child I was full of curiosity.
meaning_story: You like it because it gives you an odd feeling in your heart. You don't quite know what it is you like, but that's because it's curiosity that you have.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「私の娘は人魚なんだ。」「ええっ、それってつまり、あんた魚とやっちまったってことか？」
ex_1_en: "My daughter is a mermaid." "Whoa! Does that mean you bang fish?"
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: うまく締切を明日まで延ばせたの？
ex_1_en: Did you have any luck with putting the deadline off till tomorrow?
meaning_story: You saw 締める, which means "to tighten." So when things tighten, and then they get cut off, it's when you've reached the deadline. You know that feeling? When you get close, you feel a tightening in your stomach. The deadline is near! But, then when your tightening gets cut off completely, it's because you've reached the end. The deadline.
reading_story: The reading is 締める and 切る put together. Notice how the hiragana bits get pushed into the kanji though, that's the interesting part, but also the part that's hard to remember. It's probably because this is a short version of 締め切り, but you'll see 締切 more often.

ex_1_jp: 労働組合は賃上げを要請した。
ex_1_en: The labor unions demanded a wage increase.
meaning_story: You need something so you request it. But, since it's such a strong need, it's not really a request, it's more of a demand.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 請求書の金額が間違っているように思うので私はその請求を取り消す。
ex_1_en: I’m going to cancel that bill because I think we were invoiced for the wrong amount.
meaning_story: You request then you request again. This is starting to turn into more of a demand if you ask me. Also can refer to a claim or a charge as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私の息子は四歳の時に喘息だと診断されませした。
ex_1_en: My son was diagnosed with asthma when he was four.
meaning_story: I'm going to cut off the part of me that I'm trying to diagnose... well, not literally cut off, but cut off my diagnosing. I have come to a conclusion. A diagnosis!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: いつもはこの時期は既に乾季になっているが、依然として雨が降り続けている。
ex_1_en: By now it’s usually the dry season already, but it continues to rain.
meaning_story: The dry seasons is the dry season.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: だらだらしてないで、さっさと二階に行って宿題をしなさい。日本の江戸時代についてレポートを書かないといけないって言ってたでしょ！
ex_1_en: Stop mucking around and go upstairs and do your homework. You said you gotta write an essay about Edo period in Japan, right?
meaning_story: The bay door isn't what you might think, it refers to Edo, which is what Tokyo was called back in the day. You'll still see references to it everywhere, though, so it's good to learn. You can also call this Tokyo if you want, but I'd prefer if you answered "Edo," instead.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. Of course, it will be easy if you know the word Edo already.

ex_1_jp: 欧米でピンクの薔薇を栽培している所がないか探しているんですが。
ex_1_en: I’m searching for a place in Europe and America that grows pink roses.
meaning_story: You have Europe and America. This word represents the relationship between Europe and America (or America and Europe).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日欧貿易に関する会議は、司会者の不在によって横道に逸れてしまった。
ex_1_en: The meeting concerning trade between Europe and Japan was sidetracked due to the moderator’s absence.
meaning_story: The 日 refers to Japan (It's the 日 of 日本). So, you have Japan and Europe, which is Japan and Europe or Europe and Japan.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 君がこの問題の解決方法について具体的には何も考えていないというのは、極めて明白な事実だ。
ex_1_en: It’s extremely obvious that you don’t have any idea how we can solve this problem.
meaning_story: 極める is "to carry to extremes." So, 極めて is something similar. It's used to refer to something that's extremely _______.
reading_story: The reading comes from 極める.

ex_1_jp: このプロジェクトのリーダーを買って出たことを、今猛烈に後悔しています。
ex_1_en: I seriously regret that I volunteered to be the leader of this project now.
meaning_story: If you're fierce and violent then you are fierce and violent.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: バイクが猛スピードで突っ込んできた。
ex_1_en: The motorcycle came rushing forward at breakneck speed.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can put this on other words to say that it's a "Fierce ____" or "Energetic _____," or something along those lines. If you see this, you know that something is done fiercely or really energetically.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because it's stuck onto things making it all jukugo and such.

ex_1_jp: 侍の腹切りをテーマにした映画は来週公開されます。
ex_1_en: The movie based on samurai harakiri will be released next week.
meaning_story: You cut your abdomen. This is what you do when you're doing harakiri, aka ritual suicide.
reading_story: The readings come from 腹 and 切る. If you're lucky, you already know the word harakiri as it's made its way into English as well.
pitch_accent: ハラキリꜜ *** ハラキꜜリ

ex_1_jp: この言葉は、英雄たちについて書かれたとある本からの引用です。
ex_1_en: This phrase is quoted from a book about heroes.
meaning_story: An English brave person. Okay, there are probably other kanji meanings that aren't as common being put into effect here, but if you just think about this as King Arthur, an English brave person, then you can get the meaning of this word. King Arthur is probably England's most well known hero.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: なんとか迷いを断ち切りました。
ex_1_en: I was somewhat hesitant about breaking things off.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 迷う means "to go astray" or "to get lost?" Well when you feel like you're about to go astray or get lost it causes hesitation. You end up with a lot of doubt about where to go or what to do. It's a natural progression.
reading_story: You learned this reading already when you learned 迷う! Just swap the う for an い.

ex_1_jp: 東海道、中山道、日光街道、甲州街道、奥州街道は、五街道と呼ばれ、江戸時代の五大陸上交通路であった。
ex_1_en: Tokai-do Road, Nakasen-do Road, Nikko-kaido Road, Koshu-kaido Road, and Oshu-kaido Road are called Gokaido, which were the five principal routes used during the Edo period.
meaning_story: A street road is as wide as a street plus a road combined together. So cool! So wide! It's a highway!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It uses the かい reading (not the がい) because it's at the beginning of the word.
pitch_accent: カイドー *** カイドꜜー

ex_1_jp: 腹が減ったな。この件については、昼飯を食べながら話さないか？
ex_1_en: I’m hungry. Would you like to continue this over lunch?
meaning_story: When your belly has decreased in the amount of stuff inside it, you become hungry.
reading_story: The reading is 腹 plus 減る put together. With these two combined, you have はらがへった. Sometimes you'll see and hear people use just 腹減った, without the が. Just so you know.

ex_1_jp: 彼女はどうやらお前の熱烈なファンみたいだな。
ex_1_en: She seems to be a passionate fan of yours.
meaning_story: This fever is violent. This is the feeling you get when you have crazy passionate enthusiasm, aka you are impassioned.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 英語索引も付けた方がいいんじゃないかな。
ex_1_en: We should make an English index too.
meaning_story: You search then pull items from the index. Best way to search, since it gives you a clear idea of what's going on on a large scale.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just think of the first part of the word index (いん). Where do you search? In the index.

ex_1_jp: バルト海の北の入江で知らない人からプロポーズされたんですが、とてもロマンチックだったのでつい承諾してしまったんです。
ex_1_en: I was proposed to by someone I didn’t know in a cove north of the Baltic Sea. It was so romantic that I accepted.
meaning_story: When you enter an inlet, you've gone into the inlet. It's also where water goes inside of the inlet (it's entering the inlet from the ocean, or whatever), so that's another way to think about it.
reading_story: The reading is a little weird. You have 入り pushed into a single kanji. Then, you have the regular reading for 江 as well.

ex_1_jp: この風習は日韓両国でよく見られます。
ex_1_en: This custom is frequently seen in both Japan and Korea.
meaning_story: With the 日 of 日本, the 日 means Japan. Then, you add Korea into the mix and you have Japan + Korea. This word means Japan and South Korea or South Korea and Japan (depending on where you're from, I guess).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: さあ、乾杯、乾杯！それ、ぐいと一杯、飲み干したまえ。
ex_1_en: Alright, cheers cheers! Hey, bottoms up!
meaning_story: A dry cup of liquid is one that's worth cheering to. This is the Japanese way to say "cheers!" or "toast" or whatever else you say before drinking something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 後でネットで検索してみるよ。
ex_1_en: I’ll look it up on the internet later.
meaning_story: You examine then search. These are the steps you take in order to perform a lookup of some kind (or, as the case may be in modern times, do an internet search).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 先生は診察の予定がみっちり詰まっています。
ex_1_en: The doctor has a jam-packed medical exam schedule.
meaning_story: I'm going to diagnose you and then make a guess as to what's wrong with you during this medical exam.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は大臣たちに会議の前に資料を配るのを忘れてしまったために、首になっちゃったんだよ。
ex_1_en: She was fired because she forgot to hand out the documents to the cabinet members before the meeting.
meaning_story: A big servant is bigger than the rest of the servants. One type of servant is one who serves the people (as is the case with this one). A big servant is someone high up in the realm of serving the people. So, let's call this big servent a minister or cabinet member. Big cheese.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: オトꜜド *** オトド *** ダꜜイジン

ex_1_jp: 運転中に居眠りしてたみたいなんだ。
ex_1_en: It seems like they dozed off while driving.
meaning_story: Sometimes even though you're very much awake and alive you need to sleep for a little bit, so you take a nap. But you're not dead! You're totally alive, so let's hope no one thinks you're doing anything but dozing off.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どこで空中航法を学んだんですか。
ex_1_en: Where did you learn aerial navigation?
