meaning_story: The navigation methods are the methods used for navigation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: コーホー *** コꜜーホー

ex_1_jp: この船は神戸港に直航します。
ex_1_en: This ship is on a direct voyage to Kobe Port.
meaning_story: Remember how 直行 is "nonstop"? Well, with 直航 it's the same thing, but more like with flying things, making this a nonstop flight.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: サラ金から、借金の返済を求める催告状が何度も何度も届いています。
ex_1_en: A consumer credit company has been sending me notification letters over and over, demanding that I pay back my debt.
meaning_story: When you sponsor an announcement, you're allowing those you're sponsoring to create some kind of notification for all those they want to get in contact with.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 奇数とは2で割り切れない数字のことです。
ex_1_en: Odd numbers are numbers that cannot be divided by two.
meaning_story: Odd numbers are odd numbers (as in, 1, 3, 5, 7, though they are a bit strange as well).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: ADVERB, NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「ちょっと一杯飲みに行かない？」「いいね。」
ex_1_en: "Let’s go for a drink." "Sounds like a plan."
meaning_story: One cup of liquid is equal to one cup (or one cup of liquid).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「何でのっけから彼女に一人娘が売春しているなんて言ったんだ？」「ごめん。軽率だったよ。」
ex_1_en: "Why did you tell her that her only daughter is prostituting to begin with?" "I’m sorry. I spoke out of turn."
meaning_story: An alone (一人) daughter is a daughter with no other daughter siblings, making her the only daughter.
reading_story: The readings are 一人 plus 娘 put together into one, single (daughter) word.

ex_1_jp: 彼は痛み止めを飲んで、また畑を耕し始めた。
ex_1_en: He took a painkiller and kept plowing the field.
meaning_story: 痛み is "pain." 止める is "to stop." What stops pain if you use it? How about a painkiller.
reading_story: The reading is 痛み and 止める put together into one word. Not too painful, right? Just remember the rendaku on the ど.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: もしご迷惑でなければ請願書に署名して頂けませんでしょうか。
ex_1_en: If you wouldn’t mind, would you please sign this petition?
meaning_story: I request and then I request again. So many requests, but nobody will listen to me. My last hope is to get a bunch of people who have the same ideas together and make a petition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私も父も高所恐怖症です。
ex_1_en: My dad and I are both afraid of heights.
meaning_story: You have a fear, this fear is scary, oh, and it's a symptom, so it's kind of just in your head. What kind of symptoms occur when you are scared and have fear? How about when you have a phobia.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: キョーフꜜショー *** キョーフショー

ex_1_jp: 「君みたいに綺麗な女性に会ったのは初めてだよ、サーモン。」「フグったら、嘘ばっかり。」
ex_1_en: "Salmon, you’re the most beautiful woman I’ve ever met." "Fugu, that’s such a lie."
meaning_story: Things that are beautiful and lovely are very beautiful, pretty, and often clean, too. You can call someone 綺麗. You can also mention how clean something is with 綺麗. Gives you some insight as to what "beauty" is in Japan, I suppose. Take your baths, folks.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女が、世界宗教会議の記録を取る書記を務めます。
ex_1_en: She will be the secretary who records the transactions of the world religions meeting.
meaning_story: The religion teachings are what makes up a religion. If you don't have the teachings of the religion, nobody will learn about it, and it will stop being a religion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今は貸し倉庫で寝泊まりしているんです。
ex_1_en: I’m living in a rental warehouse now.
meaning_story: To lend is 貸す. This is the noun version. It is something that has been rented, a rental.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 貸す.

ex_1_jp: あなたの家からうちまでの略図を書いて、Eメールでお送りします。
ex_1_en: I’ll draw a rough map from your house to mine and email it to you.
meaning_story: An abbreviation version of a diagram isn't the completed diagram, nor is it one you spend a lot of time on. It's the abbreviated version, so it's more like a rough sketch.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 火星でマグニチュード7の地震が起きたんだってさ。怖いね！
ex_1_en: It seems that a magnitude 7 earthquake occurred on Mars. Scary!
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of scary? It's also scary.
reading_story: You know what's really scary, like double scary (because kanji and vocab both mean scary)? How about your coworkers (こわ). They are all insane, and you know it. Absolute nutjobs they are.

ex_1_jp: 恐ろしいと思うかもしれないが、自然の法則には逆らえないんだよ。仕方がないさ。
ex_1_en: You may feel scared, but you can’t defy the laws of nature. It’s no use now.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of fear? When you feel fear, you think something is scary.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: How scary is it? It's Oh so (おそ) scary!

ex_1_jp: 警察は捜索活動を続けています。
ex_1_en: The police are continuing to work on the investigation.
meaning_story: A search search is a more intense search, like the ones for for a missing person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この宗派には、会議で議長を務めるための規則があります。
ex_1_en: There are some rules for acting as chairman of meetings in this religious sect.
meaning_story: A religion sect is a sect within religion, most likely, but it can be simply referred to as a sect or denomination.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: シュꜜーハ *** シューハ

ex_1_jp: 私の弟は正真正銘の馬鹿だよ。昨日、鼻で牛乳を飲んでみたかったみたいで、商店街に牛乳を買いに行ったんだけど、そこで道に迷って結局牛乳買わずじまいだったんだから。
ex_1_en: My brother is a complete moron. Yesterday, he went out to get some milk in the shopping district so he could try and drink milk with his nose, but he got lost there and ended up not buying it.
meaning_story: A merchandise shop street is a street with all kinds of shops and merchandise on it. Sounds like a lot of shopping goes on here in this shopping district!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ここを出る時、電動招き猫のコンセントを挿しっぱなしにしないでね。
ex_1_en: Don’t leave the electrical Maneki Neko’s plugged into the outlet when you leave here.
meaning_story: 招く is "to invite" or "to summon." A cat that does this beckoning is known as a maneki neko or a shop window cat. These are the cat statues that move their arms up and down and are all like "hey, come on in!"
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: さっき飲んだ睡眠薬のせいで、手足が思うように動かないんだけど。
ex_1_en: I’m so uncoordinated right now because of the sleeping pill I took.
meaning_story: Sleepy sleep medicine is sleeping pills. Don't take too many or you might get addicted.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: おい、お前、今の見てたか？俺、今ドリブルで三人のバックを抜いたんだぜ！俺ってば、ほんと、最高！相手チームにあげた眠り薬入りのオレンジジュースがうまく効いてたみたいだな。
ex_1_en: Did you see that? I just dribbled around three defenders! I am the man! The orange juice with sleeping pills that I gave the other team worked perfectly!
meaning_story: Some kind of sleep medicine? That's sleeping pills.
reading_story: The reading is 眠い plus 薬 put together in one ... zz zzzzzZZZzz

ex_1_jp: この韓国ドラマ、再放送されるのかな。
ex_1_en: I wonder if this Korean drama series will be rebroadcasted.
meaning_story: The Korea Country is Korea, of course... well, South Korea that is.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: めいわくめーる, めいわくメール
ex_1_jp: 迷惑メールが次から次へと送られてくる。
ex_1_en: The spam mail was sent out one after the other.
meaning_story: When you have troublesome (迷惑) mail, you have mail you don't want. This is known as spam or junk mail. On a more technical level it's unsolicited mail.
reading_story: The reading comes from 迷惑, so if you know that you know this (and then this vocab word won't be unsolicited as well!)

ex_1_jp: 競馬場の芝についてのシンポジウムが市当局の主催で開かれた。
ex_1_en: The racetrack turf symposium was able happen because of city government sponsorship.
meaning_story: The master who sponsors you is the one who provides your sponsorship. Without this person, you wouldn't have sponsorship at all, which is why you call them "master" (plus, that was one of the rules with the sponsorship).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 酔っぱらいの男が殴ったせいで、お店の看板がへこんでいるんです。
ex_1_en: There is a dent in the store sign because some drunk guy punched it.
meaning_story: A watch over board is a board that goes over your store and watches over everything. What board on a store watches everything? It's the one that gets the most visibility, so it's probably the store sign.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 今年の夏が例年になく暑かったせいなのかは分かりませんが、奇妙な発疹が胸に出ましてね。
ex_1_en: I’m not sure if it was because this summer was unusually hot, but a strange rash broke out on my chest.
meaning_story: That's very odd and strange, making it odd and strange.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「明日、就職の面接があるんで、ちょっと緊張してるんだよね。」「え〜そうなの？うまくいくといいね。」
ex_1_en: "I have a job interview tomorrow. I’m a little nervous." "Oh, really? Well, I’m sure you’ll do fine."
meaning_story: When your tenseness is stretched out as far as it is, it becomes not just tenseness, but stress as well. The tension is crazy when you stretch it out like this!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ひっさびさにタバコ吸ったら、強烈なヤニくらくらっちまったよ。
ex_1_en: If I smoke for the first time in a while, I get an intense tobacco high.
meaning_story: Things that are strong and intense are strong and intense (the "strong" meaning is more along the lines of the "intense" meaning, so not so much like my muscles are super muscly and strong).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: まずは事件の大略を説明してくれないか？
ex_1_en: Can you explain the outline of the incident first?
meaning_story: The big abbreviation is where you take everything and abbreviate it down to show the big picture. This abbreviation is the summary or outline of something bigger.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ヤクザにお釣りが百円足りないと言われた時に、とてつもない恐怖を感じました。
ex_1_en: When a yakuza told me that the change I gave him was 100 yen short, I felt an incredible amount of fear.
meaning_story: I fear it. It is scary. It is pure terror.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: キョꜜーフ *** キョーフ

ex_1_jp: その時ちょっとへこみ気味だったもんで、ビールを三杯一気飲みしちゃったんだよね。
ex_1_en: I was depressed at the time, so I chugged three glasses of beer.
meaning_story: Three cups of liquid is three cups of liquid, or more simply, three cups.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: サꜜンバイ *** サンバイ

ex_1_jp: 日本の若者はすぐ単語やフレーズを略したがる。
ex_1_en: Young Japanese people tend to abbreviate words and phrases.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means abbreviation, so the verb vocab version is to abbreviate.
reading_story: The reading is, strangely, the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. りゃくす.

ex_1_jp: 体重を減らすために、日常の食事の量を極端に減らす必要はないよ。それよりも、バランスの良い、健康な食事を取ることの方が重要だ。ちりも積もれば山となるって言うじゃないか。
ex_1_en: You don’t have to drastically decrease the amount of food you normally eat to lose weight. It is more important to have a balanced, healthy diet. It’s said every little bit counts.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accumulate and the verb version is to accumulate.
reading_story: If something accumulates, you can start with one, but you need at least two (つ) things to say it has accumulated. If you don't, then there's nothing accumulating at all.

ex_1_jp: 父さんを怒らせると後が面倒よ。
ex_1_en: You’ll be in trouble after making dad mad.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 怒る means "to get angry?" Well this is when someone else gets angry and it's because YOU made them angry. It means "to anger someone."
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 怒る, so you should know this one too!
pitch_accent: イカラセꜜル *** イカラセル

ex_1_jp: そのシェフは、ステーキにバニラアイスクリームを添えた。
ex_1_en: The chef garnished the steak with some vanilla ice cream.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means append, so the verb vocab version is to append.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To append something to something else, you can just sew (そ) it onto something else.

ex_1_jp: 学校の帰りに、図書館に寄るつもりです。
ex_1_en: When I come home from school I plan on dropping by the library.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means approach, so the verb version is to approach.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're too shy to approach people just learn how to use a yo-yo (よ)! Then people will approach you to compliment you on your sick skills. You won't have to do it yourself!

ex_1_jp: ポーカーをする時は、気長に構えることが大切です。
ex_1_en: When you play poker it’s important to prepare patiently.
meaning_story: You know 構え, which is a stance? This is the verb version, making it to assume a stance, or most often, to get ready to fight.
reading_story: The reading comes from 構え, so if you know that you'll be ready for this fight.

ex_1_jp: 昨日の夜から歯が酷く痛むんですが、診てもらえますか。
ex_1_en: I’ve had a bad toothache since last night, so could you check that for me please?
meaning_story: 痛い is "painful." The verb version of that is to hurt or to be painful.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 魚の骨が喉に詰まっちゃった。
ex_1_en: I got a fish bone stuck in my throat.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stuffed. The vocab word is to be stuffed, as in something is stuffed and you're not doing the stuffing. You know this because when it comes to まる the cat, he stuffs himself into boxes on his own, so you don't have to stuff him into boxes for him. It just happens, and you can watch and be entertained (obviously you need to go watch some Maru videos if you haven't on YouTube, just saying).
reading_story: This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji!

ex_1_jp: この河豚を自分なりに料理してみたんですが、お腹を壊してしまいました。
ex_1_en: I cooked this blow fish in my own way and it wrecked my stomach.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means break so the verb vocab version is to break something, because you're doing the breaking. You know this because someone is trying to sue (す) you for the things you broke of theirs.
reading_story: The thing you broke? A beautiful ceramic koala (こわ). Watch it shatter to the ground, because you threw it there. What a jerk you are.

ex_1_jp: 赤ちゃんがちゃんと育っているのか、お医者さんに診てもらいたいんです。
ex_1_en: I want a doctor to examine my baby to see if she’s growing well.
meaning_story: In order to diagnose a patient, you must first go to examine a patient. When you examine them you know what's wrong with them and then you can diagnose them, which is why this verb is to examine.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 見る, which you have to do when you are examining a patient. So, you look and see all you can about the patient while you examine them, making this reading み as well.

ex_1_jp: 洗濯物はまだ乾いていません。
ex_1_en: Our laundry hasn’t dried yet.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dry. This verb vocab version is to get dry. You're not doing the drying, it's just happening. That's coo', you say, things can get dry.
reading_story: The 川 (かわ) has started to get dry. Need to use less water around here otherwise it'll become completely dry.

ex_1_jp: 私は道に迷うのが得意です。
ex_1_en: I’m good at getting lost.
meaning_story: Remember 迷う? It means "to get lost." If you get lost on a road, you are still lost, wandering around looking for the correct turn. This word means to be lost or to get lost.
reading_story: The reading comes from the words 道 and 迷う.

ex_1_jp: そんなに腹立てるなって。大したことじゃないじゃん。放っておきなよ。
ex_1_en: Don’t get so upset about it. It’s not that big a deal. Let it go.
meaning_story: What's that feeling when your belly stands up? It's that feeling where something jumps up into your throat (in this case your belly) and you get all pissed off. This word means to get mad.
reading_story: The readings are 腹 plus 立つ put together. The たつ becomes だつ, though.

ex_1_jp: お前の顔を立てるためだけにこの仕事を請けたんだからな。
ex_1_en: I only took this job so that you could save face.
meaning_story: When you request something, you are going to receive it. That's how the world works, at least in a perfect world.
reading_story: What's another word for "to receive"? How about 受ける? They share a reading.

ex_1_jp: 自分のこの目で真実を見極めたいんです。
ex_1_en: I want to see the truth with my own eyes.
meaning_story: 極める is "to carry to extremes." If you carry something to the extremes (aka the end), and then you see it to the extremes while doing it, you're going to see through whatever you're doing.
reading_story: The readings come from the words 見る and 極める put together. See through this word and learn it.
pitch_accent: ミキワメꜜル *** ミキワメル

ex_1_jp: 「ぐっすり眠れた？」「ああ。爆睡したよ。」
ex_1_en: "Did you sleep well?" "Yeah, I crashed."
meaning_story: 眠い is "sleepy." The verb version is to sleep. *yawn*
reading_story: The reading comes from 眠い.

ex_1_jp: お弁当にご飯を詰めといてくれない？
ex_1_en: Can you put some rice in my bento box for me?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stuffed, this word means to stuff in, as in you're doing the stuffing. You know that this is the case because when it comes to the mail (める), you stuff that mail into the garbage as hard as you can (it's all junk).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the kanji, so you should have no troubles here.

ex_1_jp: 彼女はたくさんの男を誘惑する悪魔だ。
ex_1_en: She is a devil who seduces many men.
meaning_story: If 誘惑 is temptation, then the verb version would be to tempt.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 誘惑 first, though.

ex_1_jp: 初めての管理職ということで、身の引き締まる思いをしています。
ex_1_en: This is my first managerial position and I’m very tense.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tighten, so the verb vocab version is to tighten.
reading_story: If anything is going to tighten, it better be the knots holding Charlie Sheen (し) in place, because of all the people you don't want him to escape.

ex_1_jp: お天気のお姉さんが、視聴者に傘を持って行くよう促した。
ex_1_en: The weather lady urged viewers to take their umbrellas with them.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means urge so the verb vocab version is to urge.
reading_story: Someone with a weird accent is trying to urge you to eat "Unagah" (うなが). This person really means "unagi," and this person also doesn't realize how delicious unagi is (and thinks he's tricking you). You ask him what "Unagah" is. Go ahead and say it out loud.
pitch_accent: ウナカ°ꜜス *** ウナカ°ス

ex_1_jp: もしあのラーメン工場に訪れたいのであれば、できるだけ早くに予約を入れる方がいいですよ。
ex_1_en: If you want to visit the ramen factory you should make your reservations as far in advance as possible.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means visit and the verb vocab version is also to visit. What makes it different from 訪ねる, though? With 訪れる, you tend to be doing something for fun but with a purpose. So, if you were visiting Tokyo for sightseeing, you could say 訪れる. If you were going to visit Tokyo for no real reason, you could say 訪ねる. That being said, they are almost exactly the same, just the nuance is different.
reading_story: The reading isn't the same as 訪ねる, though, I'm afraid. It's おとず, so think how this verb is the one where you do have a (fun) purpose to visit wherever you're visiting. That being said, you forgot what you were visiting as well. When you finally remember, it's because you were looking down to think. It's to look at the toes of the giant Buddha statue. "Oh Toes!" (おとず) you exclaim.

ex_1_jp: 電車が運行を見合わせている間に、珈琲を二杯飲みました。
ex_1_en: I had two cups of coffee while railroad operation was suspended.
meaning_story: Two cups of liquid equals two cups of liquid, aka two cups, not to be confused with 二女一杯, however.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 不健康な野球選手についてのテレビ番組は、全国放送される予定ですよ。
ex_1_en: The TV show about unhealthy baseball players will be broadcasted nationwide.
meaning_story: If 健康 is "health," then something that is not this is unhealthy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 健康 first.

ex_1_jp: どうすれば顧客に未払分の支払手続きを丁寧かつ強く催促することができるのでしょうか。
ex_1_en: How can I press a customer to take action on his overdue payment politely but also strongly?
meaning_story: I'm so all for this I'm willing to sponsor you. I am going to urge you to do this until you do it, so much so I'll give you money. This is one great urge and press for you to do this!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 緊急地震速報を携帯で受信した三秒後に、地震が起きました。
ex_1_en: Three seconds after receiving an emergency earthquake report on my cellphone, the earthquake occurred.
meaning_story: Things are tense and we have to hurry! This is quite the urgent emergency!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 父さんにガレージの体積を測るように言われたんだけど、理由は知らないよ。何か変だよね。
ex_1_en: My dad told me to measure the volume of our garage, but I don’t know why. It seems kind of weird to me.
meaning_story: In the body, liquids accumulate. It can be the body of a cup, a body of a bucket, or the body of your body. Whatever it is, this body accumulation represents the volume of liquid in your body.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その禅宗に関する映画は、この映画館で上映中です。
ex_1_en: The movie about the Zen sect of Japanese Buddhism is playing at this theater.
meaning_story: The zen religion is a part of Buddhism. It is the Zen Sect of Buddhism.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「彼は浮気をして、それを携帯電話を持っていないあなたのせいにしたってこと？」「要約するとそんなところね。」
ex_1_en: "So he had an affair and then blamed it on you for not having a cellphone?" "That about sums it up."
meaning_story: You are floating above everything, at least that's how your spirit feels. You're having an affair, and feel like nothing will catch you but... wait, what's that? Is that your wife? Oh no... not floating anymore, you're not.
reading_story: This kanji uses the kun'yomi read for the first kanji, and the on'yomi reading for the second. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this too.

ex_1_jp: 留学後、更に英語を上達させるには、ネイティブスピーカーと喋り続ける必要があります。
ex_1_en: After studying abroad you need to continue speaking to native speakers to further improve your English.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is a bit different from what you learned with the kanji, though. Just think about how again he dropped the 皿 (さら). Wow, what a screw up. Again and again.

ex_1_jp: 私はゴルフの魅力に取り憑かれてしまいました。
ex_1_en: I became obsessed with the charm of golf.
meaning_story: The alluring power is the power of allure.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 連絡先の一覧から中々上司の名前が見つからないんだけど。
ex_1_en: I’m struggling to find my boss’s name on my contact list.
meaning_story: One look at... just one. A little one. Just a look. Just a glance. That's all I want. It also has another meaning! When you're talking about computers and you want to see everything in one look, you will arranged it into a nice list or table. That way you only have to look at the data one time!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 上司に、もっとお互いのメリットを強調するような企画書に変更するように言われました。
ex_1_en: My boss told me to alter the business proposal so that it emphasized the mutual benefits more.
meaning_story: You change again. This is more along the lines of an alteration, because you changed once in order to get to where you are, and then you get changed again to become altered, which is why it's an alteration (though change works too).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「スカイダイビングをして、その後遊園地に行くんだけど、一緒に行かない？」「えーっ、絶対に嫌！」
ex_1_en: "I am going to go skydiving then afterwards go to a theme park. You want to join me?" "What? Absolutely not!"
meaning_story: The play park ground is where you go play. It's fun. It's an amusement park!
reading_story: You know the readings for everything but 遊, because you learned the kun'yomi for that one. The on'yomi is ゆう, you can remember this because if anyone is going to that awesome amusement park, it's you (ゆう)... extend that youuuuuu out.

ex_1_jp: 居酒屋で、同僚がウェイトレスに「適当に頼みます」と言って注文をしたことに驚きました。
ex_1_en: I was surprised when my colleague told a waitress to pick the proper thing for him when ordering in a Izakaya restaurant.
meaning_story: Everything is suitable and right. Therefore it is appropriate and proper. Strangely enough, this also means irresponsible. Maybe it's because when everything is suitable and right for you, you're taking too much and not leaving enough for everyone else, making you irresponsible?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は服飾専門学校を卒業しました。
ex_1_en: I graduated from a fashion technical school.
meaning_story: The clothes with which I decorate myself with is my attire.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 先程あなたからの手紙を読ませて頂きました。
ex_1_en: I read the letter from you some time ago.
meaning_story: The previous extent of time was a while ago. Just think to a previous extent of time that was indeed a while ago, now, associate!
reading_story: The reading is the words 先 and 程, put together.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの本社を背景にして写真をとてもらえませんか。
ex_1_en: Could you take my picture with the Tofugu headquarters in the background?
meaning_story: The back scene is the scene going on in the back. You don't really notice it, because it's the background.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 背後に敵が潜んでいたことに全く気づかなかった。
ex_1_en: I completely didn’t notice the enemy lurking in the background.
meaning_story: Something that's behind your back is in the background. It's also probably plotting against you, behind the scenes. Sneaky, sneaky.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

ex_1_jp: 彼は帆立の養殖で稼いだ金は全て預金している。
ex_1_en: He deposits all the money he earns from raising scallops.
meaning_story: Deposit your gold here in the bank. When you do that, it is a bank deposit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この会社では官僚的な形式主義がまかり通りすぎている。
ex_1_en: There’s too much bureaucratic red tape in this company.
meaning_story: If 官僚 is "bureaucracy," then adding a 的 to it would make it bureaucratic.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 官僚 will help a lot too.

ex_1_jp: 銀行強盗をやってみないか？今を逃がすと一生ないよ。
ex_1_en: Do you want to rob a bank? It’s now or never.
meaning_story: You are strong so you break into someone's home, hold them up, then steal from them. Ha ha! Take that, next door neighbor! This is a burglary / robbery, depending on how crazy you get after you use that strength to break down that door.
reading_story: The reading for 強 is all messed up. Think about how when you commit a robbery, you go (ごう) into someone's house, then you go to jail as well, if you're caught.

ex_1_jp: 背広のボタンをなくした。
ex_1_en: I lost a button from my suit.
meaning_story: If your back is wide, you need a nice business suit to cover it up when you go to work. Otherwise you'll look completely out of place sitting at a desk like a giant, wide-backed wrestler. Is that what you want to look like? Of course not! You need to go out and buy a fancy suit to cover your wide back up right now!
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too! Just watch out for the weird rendaku here making it び not ひ.

ex_1_jp: この手紙には、版権に関する契約更新予定日が記載されています。
ex_1_en: This letter states the possible contract renewal date for the copyright.
meaning_story: You have edition rights over this. This edition is yours, and if anyone copies this edition, they get in trouble. You have copyright.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 省エネのために電飾にOAタップを使ってるって聞いたんだけど、タコ足配線にするのは危ないわよ。
ex_1_en: I heard that you use power strips for decorative lighting to eliminate wasted energy, but you might overload the circuits so it’s dangerous.
meaning_story: The 電 is what powers electric things. Many times, these electric things light up (especially back in the day, when electricity did this a lot more than other things). So, you have "lighting." Then, you have decorate. So, if you decorate with lighting, you have decorative lighting.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「おお、そういえば、あいつら結婚するって聞いた？」「おお、マジかよ？ 詳しく教えてくれよ。」
ex_1_en: "Oh, by the way, did you hear they’re getting married?" "Wow! Really? Tell me everything."
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of detailed? It's also detailed.
reading_story: Things that are detailed... how about that plan you made to perform that coup, what (くわ)?? You're doing a coup?

ex_1_jp: 詳細を調べている時間がありません。
ex_1_en: I don’t have enough time to look up the details.
meaning_story: A thing that is detailed and thin is the details. It will help to remember that 細かい also means detailed, which is probably where this meaning is more coming from. Detailed + Detailed = the details.
reading_story: The reading for 詳 is one you've learned. 細 is on'yomi, which you didn't learn. It's さい, so think about all the details you have to think about (so many!), then sigh (さい) at the whole prospect of having to remember them. There are so many...

ex_1_jp: この博覧会は無料で入場できます。
ex_1_en: You can enter this exhibition free of charge.
meaning_story: An exhibition that you look at and all the people come meet together. Well, that just sounds like the description of an exposition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼の小説の初版は半年で売り切れた。
ex_1_en: The first edition of his novel sold out in six months.
meaning_story: The first edition is the first edition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は可愛い爪楊枝の旗を衝動買いしてしまいました。
ex_1_en: I bought the cute toothpick flags on impulse.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: The one with the flag is the Mad Hatter (はた). Just imagine looking through a group of people. You have to find the Mad Hatter, and he has to find you. That's why he offered to wear a flag on his hat.

ex_1_jp: 紫色のドレスを着ている背の高い女性は、あなたのご友人ですか？
ex_1_en: Is your friend the tall woman in the purple dress?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Say (せ) your height right now. Say it. SAY IT. Imagine I'm getting all in your face, saying "say it" at you.
pitch_accent: セꜜ *** セꜜイ *** セ *** セꜜー

ex_1_jp: 電車内で居眠りしているところを盗撮されたんです。
ex_1_en: Photos were taken of me in secret while I was napping on the train.
meaning_story: Stealing photographs of you. Wait, you didn't know you were being photographed / filmed? That's because I was using a hidden camera. Creepppy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: コウイチは、昨晩、150キロの快速球を投げ込んで才能の違いを見せつけている夢を見た。
ex_1_en: Koichi dreamt last night that he showed off his talent of throwing with a 150 kilometer-per-hour fastball.
meaning_story: It's pleasant but also fast. When getting on a train, it's nice to find a train that's both of these things. What makes it pleasant? That would be the high speed. What makes it fast? Also the high speed. Really, if you're on a train you'd rather get to your destination sooner than later, so a high speed 快速 train is the way to go.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 新婚旅行でハワイに行くのが待ちきれないよ〜。円高の恩恵にあやかって、お金使い果たすぐらい買い物しまくるつもり！笑
ex_1_en: I can’t wait to go to Hawaii for my honeymoon! Yen is high, so I’m going to spend all my money on shopping. Haha.
meaning_story: You know that 旅行 is a trip. The other part is new marriage. What's the trip you go on after a new marriage? The honeymoon!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 照明器具の周りを蠅が2-3匹ブンブン飛び交っている。
ex_1_en: A couple flies are buzzing around the lighting equipment.
meaning_story: Illuminate and make things bright, my illumination!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の妻は日系アメリカ人の三世です。
ex_1_en: My wife is a third generation American of Japanese descent.
meaning_story: The 日 is the 日 in 日本, making it mean Japanese in this word. If you are Japanese in lineage then you are of Japanese descent.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 幼稚園のクリスマス会のスケジュールをまた微調整しなくちゃいけないかもしれないの。
ex_1_en: We might have to make another small adjustment to the kindergarten Christmas party schedule.
meaning_story: If 幼稚 is childish, then a garden for childish people would be a place full of lots of children, probably growing in some way. When you're growing little children in a garden, you're putting them into some kind of school. In this case, it's a kindergarten.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 幼稚 as well.

ex_1_jp: ビタミンDが欠乏しているかどうかはどうすれば分かりますか。
ex_1_en: How can I know if I’m deficient in Vitamin D?
meaning_story: We are lacking and things are scarce. We have a lack and scarcity of resources.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 原油の海への漏出事故を防ぐために、どんな手段を講じていますか。
ex_1_en: What kind of measures does your company take to prevent accidental leakage of crude oil into the sea?
meaning_story: Something is leaking and whatever is leaking is exiting what it was in before. This is when a leak out occurs.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 娘さんの試験の結果はもうご覧になられましたか。
ex_1_en: Have you seen your daughter’s examination results yet?
meaning_story: You'll hear this a lot of in polite speech, used in place of 見る (it'll be ご覧になって下さい, literally "please become so that you are looking at _____"). The meaning is the same as the kanji, though, so this part should be easy at least. Why don't you ご覧 the reading explanation, now.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Go look at the next lesson, now.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「シャーク、私がフグと結婚したってどうして分かったの？」 「ただ人づてに聞いただけさ。」
ex_1_en: "Shark, how did you know that I got married to Fugu?" "You know. I just heard it through the grapevine."
meaning_story: Let's bind this marriage up with a marriage. No better way to make a marriage happen than a marriage, right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ホタルは、どの求婚者にも、結婚の条件として無理難題を突き付けた。
ex_1_en: Hotaru sets impossible tasks for any man who wants to marry her.
meaning_story: When you request marriage with someone else, you are doing a marriage proposal. Will you marry me, Brad Pitt?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この池には、古池の主と呼ばれる大きな殿様蛙がいると言われています。
ex_1_en: It’s said that in this pond there is a huge leopard frog called the master of the old pond.
meaning_story: This has a similar meaning to 主人 (head of household), but we're mainly learning it so you can learn some other vocab later on. You can remember it also as the meaning you learned with the kanji 主, which is master.
reading_story: The reading is of course different from what you learned with the kanji. Think of this: The person who was your head of household was very strict. Anytime you did anything that was incorrect or bad, he/she would pull out the noose (ぬし), but would call it a "noosey" to be cute, since you were just a kid.
pitch_accent: アꜜルジ *** オꜜモ *** シュꜜ *** ヌꜜシ

ex_1_jp: 僕の友達は精神病で頭が少しイッっちゃてるけど、良い人だよ。
ex_1_en: My friend is kind of messed up in the head from some type of mental illness, but he’s a nice guy.
meaning_story: 精神 is your spirit, both religiously and spiritually. When those are sick, you have a problem. Back in the day, a mental illness was thought to be a sickness with your spirit. Nowadays you can just call it a mental illness or mental disorder.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know 精神 already, though.

ex_1_jp: やっべーな。お前この巨大国旗を買ったのかよ？いったいどこに掲げるつもりなの？
ex_1_en: No way! You bought this huge national flag? Where the heck are you thinking of putting it up?
meaning_story: A country's flag is the flag they use for their nation. It's the national flag.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The こく gets shortened to こっ, though, so look out for that.

ex_1_jp: 騒音問題について、お隣さんにどうやって切り出したらいいんだろう。
ex_1_en: How should I approach my neighbor about a noise problem?
meaning_story: Boisterous sound is when there's a lot of noise around you. It's the din of the crowd or environment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 懐かしい曲がスピーカーから鳴り響いていました。
ex_1_en: A nostalgic song was echoing out of the speakers.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of nostalgia? It's nostalgic.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. Do you remember doing that? Oh man, those were the days. How 懐かしい.

ex_1_jp: お巡りさん、差し出がましいようですがそれは越権行為では無いでしょうか。
ex_1_en: Officer, I’m afraid you are overstepping your bounds.
meaning_story: If you go beyond your rights, you are going too far. You're doing what you're not supposed to do, and you're overstepping your authority.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: お待たせして申し訳ございません。それでは、撮影を始めましょうか。
ex_1_en: I’m sorry to have kept you waiting. Let’s start shooting now.
meaning_story: Back in the day, you'd use shadows to photograph things. Now it's all fancy and digital. So, with that in mind, a photograph shadow was someone doing a photoshoot of some kind. And, in even more modern times, it has become a movie shoot as well. More simply, it can be photographing or filming as well. Basically, if it has to do with taking photos or video, 撮影 is your dude.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 結局夫のために高い枕を買うはめになりました。
ex_1_en: I ended up buying an expensive pillow for my husband.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, huzzah!

ex_1_jp: 他人の作品をパクったら、盗作で訴えられるかもしれないよ。
ex_1_en: If you stole someone else’s work, you could be sued for plagiarism.
meaning_story: Steal what other people make? Wow. Way to go. That is plagiarism.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 最近学校で流行っている遊びを教えて下さい。
ex_1_en: Please tell me about the popular games in schools nowadays.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji play, so it means play or playing!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, so this should be easy!

ex_1_jp: エアコンのある生活は快適だ。
ex_1_en: Life with an air conditioner is pleasant.
meaning_story: Something that is both pleasant and suitable is still really pleasant.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女の声は小川のせせらぎのように耳にとても快い。
ex_1_en: Her voice is very pleasing to the ear, like the babbling of a brook.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of pleasant? It is also pleasant.
reading_story: This word's reading is pretty weird. We're going to think back to a couple different words to put this one together. The word for heart (心), is こころ. The word for good is よい (or いい, but for this word's sake, よい). A "good heart (feeling)" is one where your heart feels nice and warm and fuzzy (figuratively, not literally. If it's literal, go to the hospital please). That is a pleasant feeling. A こころよい feeling.

ex_1_jp: もう少しで、快楽に溺れるところだったわ。
ex_1_en: I was close to drowning in pleasure.
meaning_story: Pleasant comfort brings you a lot of pleasure and you get a lot of enjoyment out of it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: カイラク *** カꜜイラク

ex_1_jp: 人に恥をかかせることで快感を味合うような人にはなってもらいたくないわ。
ex_1_en: I don’t want you to be a person who derives pleasure from humiliating people.
meaning_story: When you have the feeling of pleasantness, you are experiencing pleasure.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: もしまた貧しい環境に陥ったとしても、また億万長者になれるように努力すると思います。
ex_1_en: Even if I went back to being poor again, I’d probably still work hard to become a billionaire.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of poor? It's poor.
reading_story: You know the word 先ず (まず)? It means something along the lines of "first of all." So, if you're poor, first of all (まず), you're going to want to get some help. Second of all, learn how to play the guitar and make funny jokes.

ex_1_jp: サーモンって本当に物欲が強い女性だよね。フグが言ってるほどお金持って無いって知った途端、彼のこと貧乏って呼んで、振っちゃったんだもんね。
ex_1_en: Salmon is a really materialistic girl. When she found out that Fugu didn’t have as much money as he said he did, she called him poor and left him.
meaning_story: You are poor and money / food is very scarce for you, making you poor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 延長コードがごちゃごちゃになっているのが許せないの。
ex_1_en: I can’t stand how extensions cords get tangled up.
meaning_story: Prolong it for a long while. We need more time. We need a prolonging or extension of some kind.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ひき肉を程よくこねます。
ex_1_en: Mix the ground meat well.
meaning_story: If the extent you go to do something is properly (よく) done, then you did it properly and well!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already! Nice!

ex_1_jp: その本を出版するのに二年もかかりました。
ex_1_en: It took me two years to publish the book.
meaning_story: If you exit that edition out of your hands and into the world, you've gotten something published! That is publishing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この店で偽のシャネルN°5を購入しました。
ex_1_en: This is the store where I bought the fake Chanel Number 5.
meaning_story: When your subscription enters into effect, you have made your purchase. This one's a bit weird because it seems like it should refer to a subscription, but I guess it is a one time subscription, and your subscription lasts your whole life?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は消費者の購買意欲について研究をしています。
ex_1_en: I’m researching customers’ purchasing motivations.
meaning_story: Open your subscription and buy something. When you do this, you are doing purchasing. Strangely, not a subscription, more just buying something or procuring something.
reading_story: The reading is on'yomi, which is great for 購 but not as great for 買. Luckily, the reading for 買 is buy (ばい), which is the same as the meaning, which is a pretty awesome coincidence.

ex_1_jp: 俺は押しに弱いんだよなあ。
ex_1_en: I’m too weak to push it I guess.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 彼女は自分の息子は更生の見込みがあると信じている。
ex_1_en: She believes that there is hope of rehabilitation for her son.
meaning_story: Again you have life! Either this is a rebirth of some kind, or you have received resuscitation and another shot at life. Whatever it is, you have life again, so that's great!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 先方は、いくつかの修正を伴う契約更新を提案してきているんだが、あまり気が進まないんだよね。
ex_1_en: They are proposing an updated contract with several alterations, but I’m still reluctant.
meaning_story: And again it has become new! It was old, but now it's all nice. This is quite the renewal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本語能力だけじゃなく、対人能力も乏しいんです。
ex_1_en: Not only are my Japanese abilities lacking, but my personal abilities are too.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of scarce? It's also scarce.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When things are scarce, you have to boat (とぼ) all the way across the lake to find any resources or food, as your side of the lake is picked dry.
pitch_accent: トボシꜜイ *** トボシイ

ex_1_jp: 太陽系には惑星はいくつあるんだっけ？
ex_1_en: How many planets does the solar system have?
meaning_story: The lineage of the sun (太陽) is that of everything surrounding it. This is the solar system.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 太陽.
pitch_accent: タイヨーケイ *** タイヨꜜーケイ

ex_1_jp: 精神的に病んでいた時、毎日一人で公園をブラブラしていました。
ex_1_en: When I was mentally troubled, I was wandering aimlessly around the park alone every day.
meaning_story: Your 精神 is your spirit. If you add 的 to it, you spirit becomes spiritual.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: ここではみんな盗品を売ってるので、「泥棒市場」と呼ばれています。
ex_1_en: People sell stolen goods here, so it’s called "thieves’ market."
meaning_story: These are stolen (steal) goods. So, I'll give you a deal, because, you know, they're stolen goods.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 全アメリカ人がTofuguのニュースレターを購読しているという噂が、日本中に広まった。
ex_1_en: The rumor that all American people subscribe to the Tofugu news letter spread throughout Japan.
meaning_story: A subscription has been read. Each magazine that comes in you read. This is your subscription.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 読 (どく) with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. You just got a subscription to dock (どく) magazine. It's all about docks and dock related things. How exciting.

ex_1_jp: 私達は、体系的な日本語学習教材を提供しています。
ex_1_en: We are offering systematic Japanese learning material.
meaning_story: The body of the lineage is part of a bigger system. Add 的 to it, and you have systematic.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 列車は翌日平常運転に戻りました。
ex_1_en: The railroad service went back to normal the next day.
meaning_story: The following day is the day coming the day you're talking about. It's the next day.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: アクルヒꜜ *** アクルヒ *** ヨクジツ

ex_1_jp: 彼は翌月黄色いドアがある小さな家に引っ越しています。
ex_1_en: He is moving to the small house with the yellow door next month.
meaning_story: The next moon refers to the next month.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: よくちょう, よくあさ
ex_1_jp: 申し訳ありませんが、お客様の足つぼマッサージのご予約は、本日の夜9時から翌朝9時30分にご変更されております。
ex_1_en: I’m afraid that your 9:00 p.m. foot-pressure massage has been pushed back to 9:30 tomorrow morning.
meaning_story: The next morning is the the next morning.
reading_story: The reading can be what you've learned with the kanji, よくあさ, or it can be the on'yomi reading across the board, よくちょう. Both are good to remember because 翌朝 is more formal (you'll use that reading in writing more often) and よくあさ is more informal - you'll use that in speaking more often.
pitch_accent: アクルアꜜサ *** ヨクアサ *** ヨクチョー

pronunciation: よくねん, よくとし
ex_1_jp: 翌年彼は起業しました。
ex_1_en: He started his business the next year.
meaning_story: The next year is the next year.
reading_story: The reading can be the on'yomi for 年 or the kun'yomi. So, you can do either よくねん or よくとし, or preferably both.
pitch_accent: アクルトシꜜ *** アクルꜜトシ *** ヨクトシ *** ヨクネン

ex_1_jp: そのツアーの切符は、現地で購入することもできます。
ex_1_en: You can buy tickets for that tour on site.
meaning_story: A cut token is a token you cut out from a sheet of paper into smaller sheets, and each of these pieces is a ticket.
reading_story: The reading is 切る cut short to きっ, then ふ rendaku'd to ぷ. It's a bit of a troublesome word, so concentrate on this now a bit so you can get it in the reviews.

ex_1_jp: 「コウイチ！怒り狂ったライオンの群れが俺たちの町に向かって突撃してくるよ。俺たち、もうすぐ攻撃されちまうよ。どうしたらいいんだ？」「心配するな。俺に任せとけ。」
ex_1_en: "Koichi! There’s a pride of raging lions charging toward our town! They are going to attack us very soon. What do we do?" "Don’t worry. Leave it to me."
meaning_story: 攻撃 is an attack. Make that into a verb and you have to attack.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 攻撃 as well.

ex_1_jp: ええっと、喉がカラカラに渇いてたから、ビールを飲み過ぎちゃったんだよね。俺は今、ベロベロだ〜。
ex_1_en: Well, I was really thirsty so I drank too much beer. I’m drunk~
meaning_story: When you have a thirst, you tend to become thirsty.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go grab a cup of water so you don't become dehydrated, okay?

ex_1_jp: 臭いが服に移るから、焼肉は好きじゃないの。
ex_1_en: I don’t like Korean barbecue because the smell gets on your clothes.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shift and the verb vocab version is to be shifted. You know that this is the one where something is shifted (and you're not doing the shifting), because it's really rude (る) to be shifted, and you don't like it when people do it to you (because it happens quite a lot, strangely).
reading_story: The reading is the same as 移す, so use that to remember this!

ex_1_jp: 指をドアで挟んじゃって、今氷で冷やしてるの。
ex_1_en: My finger got caught in the door and I’m chilling it with ice now.
meaning_story: 冷たい is "cold." This is the verb version, so you're making something cold. This word is to chill something.
reading_story: To Chill something, you need to apply cold, not heat (ひ).

ex_1_jp: クリスマスツリーの飾り付けをするのが好きです。今年はツリーを暖炉の横に飾りました。
ex_1_en: I like decorating the Christmas tree. I put it beside our fireplace this year.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decorate. The verb vocab version is to decorate.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To decorate something, you don't really need a cause (かざ). You should just do it, just because.

ex_1_jp: え？今、いくら預けたって言った？
ex_1_en: What? You deposited how much?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deposit so the verb vocab version is to deposit.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In terms of places where you want to deposit your money, #1 on your list is the Bank of Azgard (あず). Why? Because it's protected by Norse Gods, and that's the protection your money deserves.

ex_1_jp: その医者が私に癌だと診断するほんの少し前に、ある看護婦さんが私の事をちらっと振り返って見たんです。
ex_1_en: Right before the doctor diagnosed me with cancer, a nurse glanced over her shoulder at me.
meaning_story: 診断 is a diagnosis. Make this into a verb, and you have to diagnose.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguメンバーが笑い茸と呼ばれるキノコを食べてからというもの、Tofuguのオフィスでは、笑いが絶えることはない。
ex_1_en: Since Tofugu members ate a mushroom called "panaeolus papilionaceus," there has been no end to the laughter in the Tofugu office.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means die out so the verb vocab version is to die out. You know that this one is "to die out" because you're up in the air (える), looking down at the dinosaurs, who are all dying out. Thank goodness you're up in the air, because the ground is all on fire.
reading_story: The reading can come from 絶つ, so as long as you know that word you know this one as well.

ex_1_jp: えっ、有り難う。照れるなぁ。
ex_1_en: Oh, thank you. I’m blushing!
meaning_story: If you illuminate the things I've done, I start to feel embarrassed. Please don't embarrass me. :(
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you feel the most embarrassed about is your 手 (て). It's all blue and scary looking.

ex_1_jp: スイカも南瓜も水に浮く。
ex_1_en: Watermelons and pumpkins float in water.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means float so the verb vocab version is to float.
reading_story: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji. う!

ex_1_jp: 日本語では、線路は続くよどこまでもの歌は、「線路は続くよどこまでも、野を越え山越え谷を越え」という感じで始まります。
ex_1_en: In Japanese, the song "I’ve Been Working on the Railroad" begins with, "the railroad continues forever, over fields, mountains, and valleys."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means go beyond, the verb vocab version is to go beyond.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: to go beyond child (こ) years in order to become an adult, you have to be 18 years old in the USA, and 20 years old in Japan.

ex_1_jp: ちょっと懐中電灯であそこの方を照らしてくれない？
ex_1_en: Can you shine the flashlight over there for a moment?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means to illuminate. Don't get it confused with 照れる which is "to feel embarrassed," though, that would be embarrassing. You know this is "to illuminate" because the らす is the rash (らす) you get every time you're illuminated.
reading_story: Speaking of things that illuminate, your hands (手) illuminate all the time for some reason.

ex_1_jp: ねえ、なんかガスが漏れてる臭いがしない？
ex_1_en: Hey, doesn’t it smell like leaking gas?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means leak so the verb vocab version is to leak.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Causing you to leak all over the floor (we're talking blood, here) is your friend Moe (も). If you know someone named Moe, imagine them doing this. If you don't, think of a famous Moe.

ex_1_jp: ボーリングのピンを並べるのにどうしてそんなに時間がかかったんですか。
ex_1_en: Why did it take you so long to set up the bowling pins?
meaning_story: 並ぶ is when something is lining up. 並べる is when you're lining something up. You know this because when it comes to bears (べる), you have to line them up yourself, because they won't be doing it for you, that's for sure.
reading_story: The reading can come from 並ぶ, so if you know that you can figure out the reading for this one as well.

ex_1_jp: 騒ぐな！死にたいのか？死にたくなけりゃ黙ってろ。
ex_1_en: Don’t make so much noise! Do you wanna be killed? If not, just shut up.
meaning_story: The kanji is boisterous. The verb version is to make noise or to be boisterous. Basically, you're being boisterous when you make a lot of noise, so that's where it comes from.
reading_story: When you go to make noise and be boisterous, you go to the local 沢 (さわ) swamp. It's an awesome place, and people don't complain about the noise.

ex_1_jp: 「宿題が済むまで、外で遊んじゃだめだからね。」「言われなくても分かってるよ！」
ex_1_en: "You can’t play outdoors until you finish your homework." "You don’t have to tell me, I know!"
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means play and the verb vocab version is to play.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, あそ.

ex_1_jp: その洪水は広範囲に及ぶ被害を引き起こしたため、被害地域の高校は期末試験を一ヶ月延期した。
ex_1_en: Since the flood caused widespread damage, the high schools in the area postponed their final exams for another month.
meaning_story: Can we prolong this period of time to a later date? I want to postpone, if possible.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この写真を延ばして壁に飾りたいなと思ってるんです。
ex_1_en: I want to enlarge this photo to put it on the wall.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means prolong and this verb means to prolong.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Do you mind if I go to prolong things? The answer? "No (の), I don't mind."

ex_1_jp: すみません。今朝タイムカードを押し忘れちゃったんですが、どうすればいいですか？
ex_1_en: I’m sorry I forgot to punch my timecard this morning. What should I do?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means push so the verb vocab version is to push.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, actually!

ex_1_jp: 臓器提供者として登録をしたきっかけは何ですか。
ex_1_en: What motivated you to register yourself as an organ donor?
meaning_story: 登録 is registration. Make that into a verb and you have to register.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あいつは絶対に中途半端なことはしない奴だから、3106カラットのダイヤモンドを盗むための壮大な計画を立てているに違いない。
ex_1_en: He’s the kind of guy who never does something halfway, so he must have a magnificent plan to steal the 3106 carat diamond.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means steal, so the verb vocab version is to steal.
reading_story: What are you going to steal? How about a noose (ぬす)? Wait, why are you stealing a noose? That sounds like trouble to me...

ex_1_jp: 写真を撮るために、彼は野球帽を後ろ向きに被り直した。
ex_1_en: He put his baseball cap on backwards to take the picture.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means photograph. When you make that into a verb, you are doing a photograph, aka making it become to take a picture. It can also be to film as well. Really anything to do with a camera.
reading_story: Think of the reading as in "To take a photograph." You "take" all these things, and how do you say "to take" in Japanese? It's 取る, aka とる, which happens to be the same reading!

ex_1_jp: こちらが、新しい研修生の三浦くんです。
ex_1_en: This is the new trainee, Miura.
meaning_story: 研修 is a training or study of some kind. If it's your current life to do training, then you are a trainee. This is a lot like how a student is in the status of "study life."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading from 研修 should also help you too.

ex_1_jp: 私、アキバ系のオタッキーな男性に何故か魅力を感じるんだよね。
ex_1_en: Somehow I’m attracted to Akihabara style, nerdy men.
meaning_story: When you associate with a certain lineage, you trace yourself back with a group of people. This group of people is your tribe, your lineage, your group.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because this word gets stuck onto other things to describe tribes and groups.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 彼ってほんと年齢不詳だよね。
ex_1_en: His real age is unknown, isn’t it?
meaning_story: Something is not detailed at all. I don't know anything about it. No details whatsoever. It's a totally unknown entity.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 結局、未婚の女性ではないという真実を彼に話すはめになりました。
ex_1_en: In the end I told him the truth that I’m not an unmarried woman.
meaning_story: Not yet marriage? You haven't been married. You're unmarried.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 上司の不快なジョークに笑いたくもないのに笑っている自分が嫌いです。
ex_1_en: I don’t want to laugh at my boss’s unpleasant jokes and I hate myself when I do.
meaning_story: Things that are not pleasant are unpleasant or uncomfortable.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: この職が私にとって適不適かを考えているんですが、まだ答えは出ていません。
ex_1_en: I’ve been thinking about whether this job suits me or not, but I haven’t found the answer yet.
meaning_story: Something that is not suitable is unsuitable and inappropriate.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: どうして蝶々を逆さまに描いたの？
ex_1_en: Why did you draw the butterfly upside down?
meaning_story: Something is reverse, that much you know. The さま comes from 様, which could mean manner. So, something that is in a "reverse manner," is something that is upside down.
reading_story: The reading comes from 逆らう and 様, put together. A bit of an upside down reading if I do say so myself, but you do what you gotta do.

ex_1_jp: TofuguTVの撮影現場を観覧しました。
ex_1_en: I watched the TofuguTV shooting.
meaning_story: If you view and look at something, you are viewing that thing, or seeing it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どんなに値段が高くても、その漏水検出器を買うべきだと思います。
ex_1_en: No matter how expensive it is, we should buy the water leakage sensor.
meaning_story: A leak of water is a water leakage.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: しらはた, はっき, しろはた
ex_1_jp: 白旗を上げるということは、敵に降伏するということだ。
ex_1_en: Raising a white flag means surrendering to the enemy.
meaning_story: A white flag is a white flag. It's one for surrender. I give up! Too many kanji!
reading_story: The reading is either the vocab kun'yomi readings put together, or the jukugo on'yomi readings. Up to you. I like しらはた the best, though it's a bit altered with its しら instead of しろ. Another reading is はっき, which is more like the written style of reading.
pitch_accent: シラハタ *** シロハタ *** ハꜜッキ

ex_1_jp: 今は古い写真を捨てることが私にできる精一杯です。
ex_1_en: Getting rid of old pictures is the best I can do for now.
meaning_story: You put one cup of liquid... no, one full cup of liquid spirit into what you're doing. None of this half-cup garbage. A full one. That means you're going at it with all one's might.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you've seen 一杯 before.

ex_1_jp: その浮世絵についてお話をしませんか？
ex_1_en: Why don’t we talk about the woodblock print?
meaning_story: A floating world painting is what you call a woodblock print in Japan. The "floating world" refers to an evanescent world that is impermanent (floating), just as beauty and entertainment is. Back in the day, woodblock prints were one form of such beauty.
reading_story: The readings don't really line up perfectly, but they're close (although mixed in terms of what has what reading). Take a look at the word and break everything down. 浮 takes the kun'yomi うき (from 浮く), 世 also takes the kun'yomi よ, and then 絵 takes the on'yomi え. Put that all together and you have うきよえ! Or if you already know the word ukiyoe, that works too!
pitch_accent: ウキヨꜜエ *** ウキヨエ

ex_1_jp: その太陽光発電所の規模に驚嘆しました。
ex_1_en: I was amazed at the size of the solar power plant.
meaning_story: I'm so surprised it caused me to sigh. This is like when you run into a movie star, and you go in surprise shock. Then, you breath out in a sigh because of your great amount of admiration and wonder for this person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 博多までの航空券を手配してもらえますか。
ex_1_en: Could you arrange a flight for me to Hakata?
meaning_story: An aviation (航空) ticket is the kind of ticket you need to fly on an airplane. That's an airplane ticket.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 救急車が急発進して男性にぶつかったため、もう一台別の救急車も必要になった。
ex_1_en: The ambulance suddenly took off and hit a guy, so we needed another ambulance.
meaning_story: Rescue in a hurry using this car. What kinds of cars can do this? How about an ambulance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私が電話した時、彼は既に退社してしまってました。
ex_1_en: He had already left his office when I called him.
meaning_story: One of the meanings is the same as the kanji, previously. But, it really is more like as mentioned before or as mentioned previously.
reading_story: The reading is different from what you learned with the kanji. As mentioned before, I'll be there on Su-day (すで). It's like Sunday, but not quite the same. Imagine your confusion when someone says this over and over, but you don't know what Suday is.

ex_1_jp: 散歩をする時は、小銭しか持ち歩きません。
ex_1_en: I bring change with me when I go for walks.
meaning_story: Scatter around the ground and walk. When you walk in a scatter all around, you're going for a walk or a stroll.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ほ goes to ぽ, though.

ex_1_jp: 2014年のセンター試験の平均点が出ました。
ex_1_en: The average grade for 2014’s National Center Test for University Admissions was revealed.
meaning_story: Something that's flat and equal to everything around it, all those flat things around it, are average. They're the mean (same as average).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

pronunciation: はちのす, ハチのす
ex_1_jp: ハチの巣の周りで沢山のハチがブンブン飛び回っている。
ex_1_en: There are a lot of bees buzzing around the beehive.
meaning_story: ハチ is a bee. Buzz buzz. Just imagine "eight bees" combining into one bee, making it a "hachi." Then, there's a nest. What is a nest for bees? A beehive.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 白い帯はお手入れが大変です。
ex_1_en: It’s difficult to care for a white obi.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: What is the first letter in belt? Hmm, I can't remember. OH! "B" (おび)! I remember now.

ex_1_jp: 我々の血脈を絶やさせるべきではない。
ex_1_en: We shouldn’t allow our bloodline to die out.
meaning_story: A blood's vein is a blood vessel.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私の用心棒をしてくれない？
ex_1_en: Will you work as my bodyguard?
meaning_story: Who do you know that will use a pole to stop someone from breaking your heart? Your bodyguard! He's there to make sure no one hurts you, and for some reason he really likes using a pole to do it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私達にとって、衆議院を解散するメリットとデメリットは何ですか？
ex_1_en: What are the advantages and disadvantages of dissolving the House of Representatives?
meaning_story: Untie and scatter everything. This will cause a breakup and dissolution of whatever is being untied then scattered.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 中華料理が食べたい気分だ。今夜一緒に中華食べに行かないか？
ex_1_en: I’m in the mood for Chinese. Do you want to go out to eat Chinese with me tonight?
meaning_story: 中国 is China, right? That's what this 中 represents. And, of course the Chinese are known for being super showy, which is why you have showy there.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: まずやるべきことをやらなくてはね。部屋の掃除から始めようか。
ex_1_en: First thing’s first. Let’s start by cleaning your room.
