meaning_story: Sweep and exclude all that dirt from the floor, please. When you do this a lot, it becomes cleaning.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. For this one though, you have to remember to read the 除 part as じ. Just keep in mind that cleaning (cleanliness) is next to godliness and so is Jesus (じ). So, Jesus is like cleaning. Easy.

ex_1_jp: ムー大陸って本当に実在したんですか？
ex_1_en: Did the continent of Mu really exist?
meaning_story: A big land is the biggest types of land on this earth that there are. That is a continent.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
pitch_accent: タイリク *** タꜜイリク

ex_1_jp: 私はこの通貨をよく知っています。
ex_1_en: I am quite familiar with this currency.
meaning_story: The thing that will pass through freight is currency. Why? Because when you want freight to be your own, you have to put money through it and to the person who owns it. When you do that, it becomes yours. Use that currency!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: あなたのケースでは、既決囚救済制度が適用される可能性もなきにしもあらずだと思います。
ex_1_en: I think that applying for post-conviction relief may be a possibility in your case.
meaning_story: It was previously decided, which means it's been decided and settled.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼は宮家の子孫です。
ex_1_en: He is a descendant of the imperial family.
meaning_story: A child who is the grandchild of someone else is a descendant of that person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 直径100フィートもある巨大な新種のクラゲが、ビーチをドロドロにしてしまいました。
ex_1_en: A new, giant 100 foot in diameter species of jellyfish oozed on the beach.
meaning_story: Fix the diameter. It is the wrong diameter and must be a new diameter. Test it now, what's the diameter?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 「彼とは離婚するつもりなの。」「ちょっ…早まらないで。決断する前によく考えて。」
ex_1_en: "I’m going to divorce with him." "Don’t be so rash. Think about it more before you make a decision."
meaning_story: Detach from your marriage. This is a divorce.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: どうしてブログ記事を編集するのに一時間もかかったんですか。
ex_1_en: Why did it take you an hour to edit a blog article?
meaning_story: Knit and gather everything back together, which you knit. When you do this to fix things and bring it back together, this is an edit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: こちらの雑誌の編者を務めてくれた丸山君です。
ex_1_en: This is Mr. Maruyama, who worked as the editor for this magazine.
meaning_story: A knit someone is one who knits words together and makes them better. This someone is an editor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: キャリアを積む機会は、男女に均等に与えられるべきです。
ex_1_en: Career opportunities should be given equally to both men and women.
meaning_story: This is equal and that is equal. They're both the same, amazing! They are even and uniform.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: その馬はソエにより競争除外となりました。
ex_1_en: The horse was excluded from the race due to shin soreness.
meaning_story: Exclude this one and put it outside what we're considering. This is the exception.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: メールで語尾に必ず感嘆符を付ける友達がいます。
ex_1_en: I have a friend who puts an exclamation mark at the end of every single sentence in her emails.
meaning_story: A feeling where you sigh is one in which you're surprised by something, and can't believe it, so you sigh. Ugh, *sigh*. What token represents this in writing? An exclamation mark!!!!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: どれでもいいから、既存のファイルを開いてみてください。
ex_1_en: Any of them are fine, so please open an existing file.
meaning_story: It was around previously, I suppose, so it's probably around right now, too. It's still existing, I think.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: お前が赤ん坊の本当の父親かどうかを調べるために、DNA鑑定を受けた方がいいんじゃないか。
ex_1_en: You should take a DNA test to find out if you are his real father.
meaning_story: When someone determines something, it's probably okay. But, when the model determiner determines something, that is the best determination ever. That is the expert opinion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 土砂崩れの恐れがあります。
ex_1_en: I’m afraid there will be a landslide.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji fear, so it means fear too.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: 銀行の融資を受けるのは思っていたよりも難しかったです。
ex_1_en: Getting a bank loan was more difficult than I thought.
meaning_story: Dissolve your resources, because you need to pay back your financing and loans now.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 小さい頃からずっと華道を習っています。
ex_1_en: I’ve been learning flower arrangement since I was little.
meaning_story: Everyone knows that the way to showy decor is through flower arrangement. Not only do you get to make beautiful works of art, but you make your insides reflect that beauty. Give it a try, if you can!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 小包に、「壊れ物、取扱注意」って書いておいた方がいいかな。
ex_1_en: Should I write down "Fragile - Handle with Care" on the package?
meaning_story: A thing that could break easily, is a fragile thing. Be careful with things like this.
reading_story: The reading is 壊れる and 物 put together.
pitch_accent: コワレモノ *** コワレモノꜜ

ex_1_jp: 毎日札幌貨物ターミナルと福岡貨物ターミナル間を走行する貨物列車があります。
ex_1_en: There is a freight train that runs between Sapporo cargo terminal and Fukuoka cargo terminal every day.
meaning_story: Freight things is freight or cargo.
reading_story: The reading is the 物 reading that's もつ. You can know this because you have to carry the freight and cargo (持つ it!).

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 俺たちのバンドは、ジャズとロックが融合した音楽を演奏しています。
ex_1_en: Our band plays music that is a fusion of jazz and rock.
meaning_story: Dissolve and then join together again to create a reaction, a fusion reaction.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 華美な服装は控えた方がいいんじゃないですか。
ex_1_en: Shouldn’t you restrain yourself from wearing gaudy clothing?
meaning_story: If something has both splendor and beauty then it's going a little overboard and is going to come across as gaudy. Too much is too much.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 幾何学のテストでAプラス取ったの？すごいじゃん、よくやったね！
ex_1_en: Did you get an A+ on the geometry test? That’s amazing, you did really well!
meaning_story: How many? What? In this area of study, you ask these questions a lot. This area of study is geometry, because you have to ask how many sides and how much the area is or something (can you tell I don't remember any maths?).
reading_story: The 学 is read correctly, in terms of what you learned. The 幾 and 何 is weird, though. Just think how when you're asking a question in Japanese, you end the sentence with か. So, it's like, "何か????" and that's why it becomes か. Then, for 幾 think about how the key (き) to answering geometry questions correctly is figuring out "how many" sides something has. So, "do you have the keyか?"

ex_1_jp: 新しいコンピューターを接続することは、 私の孫にとってはお茶の子さいさいだ。
ex_1_en: Hooking up the new computer is a cinch for my grandchild.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You are the grandchild of your grandfather. His favorite thing is to call you a maggot (まご). Your grandfather was in the military and is very hard on you, maggot.

ex_1_jp: 僕たちの墓を太平洋に浮かぶ小さな島に作ることを、いつも夢見てきたんだよ。
ex_1_en: I’ve always dreamed of placing our graves on a small island in the Pacific.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: When you finally have a grave and you're dead and buried, your one wish is for the New Zealand All Blacks to do the Haka (はか) over your grave. If you don't know what the haka is, look it up, it's pretty neat.

ex_1_jp: うちの庭は墓地に隣接している。
ex_1_en: Our garden is adjacent to a graveyard.
meaning_story: A grave ground is an area with lots of graves in the ground. This is a graveyard, or cemetery.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: プロポリスが花粉症に効くって聞いたよ。
ex_1_en: I heard that propolis extract is good for hay fever.
meaning_story: The flower powder symptoms are when you start sneezing from flower powder, aka pollen that comes from all sorts of flowers, which is pretty much all plants. This word, however, refers to the most common version of this sickness, which is hay fever.
reading_story: The reading is all on'yomi readings, which you learned for all but 花. Instead, 花 is か, and to remember that you can think about how the only way to escape the hay fever is to jump in your car and turn on the filter. Sweet, sweet relief.
pitch_accent: カフンショー *** カフꜜンショー

ex_1_jp: 録音に適したマイクを幾つ知っていますか。
ex_1_en: How many mics do you know of that are adequate for recording?
meaning_story: This has the same meaning as the kanji, specifically the "how many" meaning. You know this because you ask "how many" and they answer "つ."
reading_story: The reading comes from what you learned in the kanji, nice job.

ex_1_jp: 彼は、幾度失敗しても、諦めなかった。
ex_1_en: Even though he failed many times, he didn’t give up.
meaning_story: How many occurances is just another way of asking how many times.
reading_story: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: 送料が幾らになるのか教えて頂けませんでしょうか。
ex_1_en: Could you tell me how much the shipping will be, please?
meaning_story: This has the same meaning as the kanji, specifically the how much meaning. To remember this, just think about how Ra, the Egyptian God, is always asking "How much will it cost to build this pyramid?" Ugh, too much, let's hire some slaves.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 四歳になる娘が、見るもの全てを真似するので困っています。
ex_1_en: I am having trouble because my 4 year old daughter imitates everything she sees.
meaning_story: You're taking reality and trying to resemble it. To do this, you have to do an impersonation.
reading_story: You didn't learn the reading for 真, so just think about how when you're doing an impersonation, you're doing an impersonation of your ma (ま). Now go ahead and do an impersonation of your ma.

ex_1_jp: 私達は陸軍訓練を見に来たただの見学です。
ex_1_en: We’re just here to observe the army training.
meaning_story: The land army is the land army, also known as the plain old army.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうして鳥は飛べるようになる前に巣立ちをするのですか。
ex_1_en: Why do birds leave the nest before they can fly?
meaning_story: When you stand up out of the nest, you're getting ready to leave it. Your mother may be sad about this, but this means it's time to leave the nest and become independent.
reading_story: The readings are from the words 巣 and 立つ put together.

ex_1_jp: うわっ！めっちゃ豪華やん。美味しそう。（関西弁）
ex_1_en: Wow! That’s splendid. They look delicious. (Kansai-ben)
meaning_story: So luxurious! So showy! Whatever this thing is, it is luxurious and splendid and I want one.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「パパ、僕、雄犬がほしいな。雄犬を飼える？」「様子を見ようか。でも、どうして雌犬じゃないの？」
ex_1_en: "Daddy, I want a male dog. Can we have a male dog?" "We’ll see, but why not a female dog?"
meaning_story: A male dog is a male dog. Do you know what a female dog is?
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings, which is probably A-Okay for 犬, but for 雄 you'll want to think about how a male dog is probably pretty pushy, always trying to push (押す) other dogs around, being male and moody and all that.

ex_1_jp: とにかく、手短に言うとね、フグと僕は外務大臣について口論をして、それ以来、僕は彼に会っていないんだ。
ex_1_en: Anyway, to make a long story short, Fugu and I had an argument about the Minister of Foreign Affairs and I haven’t seen him since.
meaning_story: An outside tasks minister (大臣) is someone who is tasked with dealing with things that are outside the country. This is the minister of foreign affairs.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうして動物には道徳感がないって断言できるの？
ex_1_en: Why are you so sure that animals have no sense of morality?
meaning_story: The way of virtue is the way you take if you have morals. Hopefully you have some.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ヒマラヤ山脈は多種多様な自然に恵まれています。
ex_1_en: The Himalayan Mountain range is rich with a wide variety of nature.
meaning_story: A mountain vein is a vein that extends across the land, and is covered in mountains. This refers to a mountain range.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: コウイチ：明日富士山に登るなんて、もう気が狂っちゃいそうだよ。 ビエト：分かる分かる。俺もめちゃくちゃ不安。
ex_1_en: Koichi: I am getting freaked out about climbing Mt. Fuji tomorrow. Viet: I know, I know. It’s freaking me out too.
meaning_story: Did you know that the mountain that is rich in samurai happens to be Japan's most famous mountain? It makes sense considering samurai are probably Japan's most famous thing as well. Combine the two most famous things and you have Mt Fuji (or Mount Fuji if you'd rather write it that way).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「おい、ちょっと待て！お前今、床に泥を付けただろ？」「えっ！泥なんて付けてませんよ。私のうんこなら付けましたが。」
ex_1_en: "Hey, hold on! Did you just get mud on the floor?" "Oh! It’s not mud. It’s actually my poop."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Many of you may know of Dora the Explorer. Fewer of you know about her dirty, muddy sister, "Doro (どろ) the Not-So-Great Explorer." Imagine them working together as a team. Dora and Doro, united!

pronunciation: でいすい, どろみず
ex_1_jp: 「ちょっと！今私の雑誌にコーヒーをこぼしたでしょ？」「ああ、ごめん！悪かったよ。」「あ〜ぁ〜…ジョニーデップの股間のところに泥水みたいな染みができちゃったじゃない！」
ex_1_en: "Hey! Did you spill coffee on my magazine?" "Ah, sorry! My bad!" "Aww... now it looks like there is a muddy water stain right on Johnny Depp’s crotch."
meaning_story: Mud water is muddy water. Don't step in it, if you can help it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 巣の中では、ツバメの雛が五羽、ぴいぴい鳴いていました。
ex_1_en: There were five baby swallows chirping in the nest.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This can refer to all kinds of things, like a spider's nest or a mouse's burrow or a bee's hive, etc. Basically, it's a place where animals live, not necessarily just a nest as in a bird's "nest," etc.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 普通、人間は他人に影響されるものだと考えられています。
ex_1_en: It’s generally believed that people are influenced by others.
meaning_story: You pass through like completely normal. You are normal. You do things normally, normally.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 監視カメラは持ってるんですが、まだテープを確認した事はないんですよね。ちゃんと撮れてるのかな。
ex_1_en: I have a surveillance camera, but I haven’t checked the tape yet. I wonder if it’s working properly.
meaning_story: You oversee and look at all that is in your domain. You are keeping an observation over everything.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 人脈作りは、ビジネスに関わる殆ど全ての人にとってとても重要なスキルですが、事業家にとっては殊更です。
ex_1_en: Networking is a very important skill for most business people, but it’s especially true for entrepreneurs.
meaning_story: Your person veins are all the veins you have going out to all the different people you know. These are your personal connections, your network.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は自分の画廊を開いた。
ex_1_en: She opened her own picture gallery.
meaning_story: A drawing corridor is a corridor in which there are drawings hanging up on the wall. This is a picture gallery.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: もし私があんたのお父さんなら、この棒でお尻をぶっ叩いてやったのに。
ex_1_en: If I were your father, I would have tanned your hide with this pole.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 最近私は粉ものを食べ過ぎています。
ex_1_en: I’ve been eating too many flour-based food lately.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also mean flour.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You have this great ice cream... that is, until your cone (こな) turns to powder, and your ice cream falls to the ground. A sonic boom powdered your ice cream cone, and left you very messy.

ex_1_jp: 新鮮な鷹の爪があるので粉状の唐辛子にしたいなと思っているんですが、やり方がよく分かりません。
ex_1_en: I have a fresh red hot chili pepper but I want powdered chili pepper and I’m not sure how to do that.
meaning_story: Something that is in a powder condition is something that has been powdered. Puff!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: よぉみんな！コウイチ総理大臣がここに登場だぜ！チェケラ！
ex_1_en: Hey y’all. Prime Minister Koichi is in da house, yo! Check it out!
meaning_story: The prime minister (総理) minister is the official word for the prime minister.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the words 総理 and 大臣 from previous levels.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 彼女は結局探偵になりました。
ex_1_en: She ended up becoming a private detective.
meaning_story: You look for things and you spy on people. Your job isn't as glamorous as it sounds. You're a private detective.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 犯人は恐らくこの辺りに潜んでいるのでしょう。
ex_1_en: The criminal is probably lurking in this area.
meaning_story: A fear rock (らく) will probably come straight at your face. It's pretty likely.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: 警察は関係者全員を尋問しました。
ex_1_en: The police questioned everyone who was involved.
meaning_story: When you inquire about a problem, you tend to do questioning about said problem. Why is it like this? What happened? Is it bigger than a breadbox?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 半径3cmの球体の体積は何立方センチメートルですか。
ex_1_en: What is the volume in cubic centimeters of a sphere with a radius of three centimeters?
meaning_story: Half a diameter is a radius.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 我々はその原因を探究している。
ex_1_en: We’re researching the cause.
meaning_story: Look for something. Research answers. This is research.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: このアパートから東大までの一番速くて安い通学経路を教えてください。
ex_1_en: What is the fastest and cheapest route to commute from this apartment to Tokyo University?
meaning_story: If you pass through the roads, you are figuring out which roads to use, when to use them, and essentially coming up with the route and course to take to get to wherever you're going.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 俺の母親は世界で一番恐い。
ex_1_en: My mother is the scariest in the world.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of fear? Scary or frightening. It can also mean I'm afraid or I'm scared too.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know what's really scary? Koalas (こわ). Have you ever heard one of those things? They're super scary, don't go near them.

ex_1_jp: 警察はどんな時に内偵捜査をするのですか。
ex_1_en: When do the police conduct their secret internal investigation?
meaning_story: Inside spying is when you get inside enemy territory and spy on them. This is scouting and reconnaissance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 公的な印鑑が押された書類が必要になります。
ex_1_en: You need an officially sealed document.
meaning_story: A seal model is the best kind of seal, but it's still just a seal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: インカꜜン *** インカン

ex_1_jp: クリームを牛乳から分離させる方法をググってみるよ。
ex_1_en: I’m going to google how to separate cream from milk.
meaning_story: If you take part and detach it from the group into its own separate group, that's just segregation, isn't it?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: いつか綺麗なドレスを着て、華やかなカクテルパーティーに行ってみたいな。
ex_1_en: I want to go to a glamorous cocktail party in a beautiful dress someday.
meaning_story: Something that is showy is showy.
reading_story: For the reading, think about something that's showy... in particular, 花s (はな). Flowers are super showy, always showing off their colors and stuff.

ex_1_jp: 他人よりも自分がずっと短足だと気づいた時、彼は深々と嘆息して、日本短足協会へと向かった。
ex_1_en: When he realized that his legs were much shorter than other peoples’ he sighed deeply and headed to the Japan Short Leg Association.
meaning_story: A sigh breath is a sigh.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: くものす, クモのす
ex_1_jp: 屋根裏部屋で、クモの巣が掛かった祖父の未完成の絵を見つけたんです。
ex_1_en: I found my grandpa’s unfinished painting covered in spiderwebs in the attic.
meaning_story: クモ is a spider. Add a nest to it, and you have a spider nest. What do spider's call their nests? They call it a spiderweb (that is, if they can talk).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 倉庫の鍵を閉めるには、カチッという音が聞こえるまでレバーを上げる必要があります。
ex_1_en: You need to lift the lever until you hear a click to lock the warehouse.
meaning_story: A storage warehouse is some kind of storehouse, some kind of warehouse.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は高熱と鼻詰まりに苦しんでいます。
ex_1_en: I’m suffering from a terrible fever and stuffy nose.
meaning_story: 詰まる is "to be stuffed." So, if your nose is stuffed, then you have a stuffy nose.
reading_story: The reading is 鼻 and 詰まる put together. the 詰まり is rendaku'd, probably because you're trying to say this word with a stuffy nose.
pitch_accent: ハナズマリ *** ハナズꜜマリ

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あの映画監督の名前が思い出せないんだけど。何て名前だっけ。もうここまで出かかってるんだけどな。あー、気持ち悪い！
ex_1_en: I can’t remember the name of that movie director. What was his name? It’s on the tip of my tongue though. Uhg, crap!
meaning_story: The one who oversees and coaches is the one who gives the supervision and direction. I see it all! I coach!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼女はとても均整のとれた体形をしている.
ex_1_en: She has a very well proportioned body.
meaning_story: Things are equal in how they're arranged. They have perfect symmetry and balance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 寝過ごして朝ごはんを食べ損ねた上に、車が壊れたんだ。本当に今日はついてないよ。
ex_1_en: I overslept, missed my breakfast, and then my car broke down. It’s really not my day today.
meaning_story: 壊す is "to break something." 壊れる is when something just gets broken or is broken, and you're not doing the breaking. This is to be broken.
reading_story: The reading comes from 壊す, so try not to break any of your memories and remember this.

ex_1_jp: カナダはカナディアンベーコンに富む。
ex_1_en: Canada is rich with Canadian bacon.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rich so the verb vocab version would be to be rich.
reading_story: Think about the richest person you know. That person is Tom (む). Imagine Tom as being super rich. If you don't know a Tom, think of a famous Tom, like Tom Cruise, who definitely is pretty rich.

ex_1_jp: 私の主人は逆さ睫毛の手術を受けるのをとても怖がっていたんですよ。
ex_1_en: My husband was very scared of getting surgery for his ingrown eyelashes.
meaning_story: 怖い is "scary." This is a verb version, making it to be scared or to be afraid of.
reading_story: The reading comes from 怖い.

ex_1_jp: 「ねえ、聞いてるの？」「あっ、うん。聞いてるよ。ごめん、ごめん。でも、ちょっと気が散っちゃってた。」
ex_1_en: "Hey, are you listening?" "Oh, yes. I’m listening. Sorry, sorry, I just got distracted for a moment."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scatter so the verb vocab version is to be scattered. You know that this verb represents when something is scattering (you're not doing the scattering), because you would never be so rude as to scatter someone or something yourself. It only happens when it happens on its own.
reading_story: Think about something scattering. That something is cheese (ち), scattering all over the floor, going everywhere, getting in everything. Ugh, you hate how cheese scatters, don't you?

ex_1_jp: 「フグ？お前、フグか？」「サンマか？こいつは驚いた。高校以来だね。元気かい？」
ex_1_en: "Fugu? Is that you, Fugu?" "Salmon? I’ll be damned. I haven’t seen you since high school. How are you?"
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surprised, so the verb vocab version is to be surprised.
reading_story: What are you so surprised by? Your friend's odor (おどろ). Think of a friend that you wouldn't expect to be so smelly. Then, be surprised by the odor. Eww, bro, you have to take a shower.

ex_1_jp: 赤い紙を除く全ての紙を、その折り目まで折ってください。
ex_1_en: Fold all the papers, excluding the red one, to meet the crease.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means exclude so the verb vocab version is to exclude.
reading_story: You would like to exclude your nose (のぞ) because you don't like your nose. Imagine your strong feelings about your nose as you decide to exclude it.

ex_1_jp: 目が見えなくなること以外は、何も恐れることはないよ。
ex_1_en: I’m not afraid of anything except for going blind.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fear so the verb version is to fear.
reading_story: The reading is shared with 恐ろしい, which is "fear." Use that, and don't be afraid. You'll be able to learn this reading yet.

ex_1_jp: 自分のウンコを食べてみて、それがすっごい苦かったんだけど、どうして苦いのかって先生に尋ねてみたら、「胆汁酸がいっぱい含まれてるから苦いんだよ」って教えてくれたよ。
ex_1_en: I told my teacher I ate my own poop and that it was very bitter so I asked him why that was. He told me our poop contains a lot of bile acid and that’s why it’s very bitter.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means inquire so the verb vocab version is to inquire.
reading_story: I'd like to inquire about a few things. Wait, what? You won't cooperate? How about I just taze (たず) you with this tazer then? BzzzbbzbhhhAHHHHHH!

ex_1_jp: 夜の間、火を絶やさないように気をつけるんだぞ。
ex_1_en: Make sure the fire doesn’t go out during the night.
meaning_story: 絶える is "to die out." 絶やす is "to kill off." You know this because if something is to die off, you'd say "no." But if you're the one doing the killing off, you'd say yes (やす).
reading_story: The reading comes from 絶える.

ex_1_jp: ブラジャーを編んでみようと思ったきっかけはなんですか。
ex_1_en: What inspired you to knit bras?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means knit so the verb vocab version is to knit.
reading_story: When you start to knit, you always end up with the same thing every time when you're done, no matter what you're trying to make: The letter "A" (あ). It's so frustrating that you can't knit anything else.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は歴女で、徳川幕府にはとても精通しています。
ex_1_en: She likes Japanese history and is very familiar with the Tokugawa Shogunate.
meaning_story: This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading. The "Virtue River" isn't some virtuous river, it's in fact the Tokugawa family name, also known as the Tokugawa Shogun. They ran Japan for a while, you know?
reading_story: The readings are 徳 and the vocab 川 put together into one word. Once you can read this, you'll know the meaning too, so focus on the reading for this one.

ex_1_jp: 知事は、徳島県をどういう風に変えていくおつもりですか？私は今のままがいいと思うのですが。
ex_1_en: Governor, in what ways would you change Tokushima Prefecture? I like things just the way they are.
meaning_story: The virtue island prefecture is Tokushima prefecture. The reading will give away the meaning of this one, so long as you knew "prefecture."
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the individual kanji. Put them together and you'll know this is Tokushima Prefecture.

ex_1_jp: どんなにくよくよ嘆いても、死んだ人はもう戻っては来ないんだから、彼女のことはさっさと忘れて、代わりに私と結婚してよ。
ex_1_en: No amount of grieving can bring the dead back to life, so forget about her quickly and marry me instead.
meaning_story: When you sigh, you feel a certain type of emotion. A type that makes you feel sad and causes you to lament and to grieve.
reading_story: For the reading, just think about this feeling you're having (this lamenting grieving one). Then, decide you're done with it. Throw (投げる) it out the window. You don't want these feels anymore!

ex_1_jp: もし俺の娘を路頭に迷わすようなことがあったら、一生許さないぞ。
ex_1_en: If you lead my daughter astray, I’ll never forgive you.
meaning_story: The word 迷う means "to go astray" but this word is to lead astray. You are doing the astraying to someone or something else. You know this because the other person was (わす) just fine until you came along to lead them astray.
reading_story: The reading comes from 迷う, so use that so you aren't lead astray too.

ex_1_jp: 三本足の犬がバーにやって来てこう言った。「俺の足を打った男を探しているんだ。半分河豚で半分豆腐みたいな男なんだが。」
ex_1_en: A three legged dog walked into a bar and said, "I’m searching for the man who shot my paw. He looks like half fugu and half tofu."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means look for and the verb version of the kanji is to look for.
reading_story: You are looking for a sagger (さが) amongst the products you're shipping off overseas. The saggers are the boxes that have weird lumps sagging out of them, which means they broke and are getting things wet. So, find the saggers. Go to search for them, because they could ruin the whole shipment.

ex_1_jp: それじゃあ2人組を作って、トラックに七面鳥を積み始めて下さい。
ex_1_en: Now please grab a partner and begin loading the truck with turkey.
meaning_story: 積もる is "to accumulate." Now you're doing the accumulating, and in order to do that you must go to pile things up. More and more and more. How do you know that this verb is when you're doing the accumulating? It's because you are piling up cows (む). Wow, a cow piler.
reading_story: The reading comes from 積もる, so pile up your knowledge and remember it that way.

ex_1_jp: 友人のブログが荒らされています。友人を救うための知恵を貸してください。
ex_1_en: My friend’s blog has been trolled. Give me some advice to rescue her from it.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rescue so the verb vocab version is to rescue.
reading_story: The すく in the reading is a lot like the scue (すくう) part of to rescue, don't you think? Hopefully you do, so you can make the connection.

ex_1_jp: お前が彼女の兄貴だって？嘘つけ！全然似てないじゃねえか。
ex_1_en: Are you telling me that you’re her brother? Liar! You look nothing alike.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means resemble so the verb vocab version is to resemble.
reading_story: What are you trying to resemble?? Is that... oh no. A knee (に) face resemble surgery, where you make your face look like you knee and vice versa? Do you know how dangerous that surgery is?

ex_1_jp: 親元から離れて一人暮らしをすることは思っていたよりも簡単でした。
ex_1_en: Being away from my parents and living by myself was easier than I thought.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means detach, but what happens when something detaches? It causes it to separate and to leave. This refers to when something separates on its own. You aren't doing the separating. You know this because it's rare (れる) to see things separate, but sometimes you do see them. Also, whenever you see れる usually it's a safe bet that you're not the one doing the action, right? Think about it.
reading_story: For the reading, think about what is separating. It's quite sad, because all of the 花s (はな) are separating from their stems and falling on the ground, and nobody knows why. Just falling off and being sad.

ex_1_jp: うちの学校で土曜日にカラオケパーティーを主催するんだけど、よかったら来ない？
ex_1_en: Our school is hosting a karaoke party this Saturday. Would you like to join us?
meaning_story: If 主催 is sponsorship, the verb version of that would be to sponsor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 主催 already as well.

ex_1_jp: その犬は、真っすぐ上へ上へと飛んで行く風船をじっと見詰めていた。
ex_1_en: The dog was motionlessly staring at the balloon flying straight up, higher and higher.
meaning_story: When you really stuff in (詰める) what you are seeing, you're really looking at something, causing you to stare at whatever it is you're stuffing your seeing into.
reading_story: The reading is 見 and 詰める.

ex_1_jp: 赤ちゃんが逆子で産まれてくるって分かってたので、出産時は緊張しました。
ex_1_en: I was nervous during delivery because I knew my baby was going to be a breech birth.
meaning_story: 緊張 is stress. So, the verb version is to stress out.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 会議が始まる前に、会議室をちょっと掃いておいてもらっていいかな。
ex_1_en: Could you sweep the meeting room before the meeting starts?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sweep so the verb version is to sweep.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: While you sweep you laugh. "HA (は) HA HA!" Just imagine yourself doing this, or do it for real if you want to clean up a bit.

ex_1_jp: 私は失業中ですが、そのことを思い詰めてはいません。
ex_1_en: I’m between jobs, but I’m not worrying too much about it.
meaning_story: 詰める is "to stuff in," so if you're really stuffing in your thoughts (think), you're really trying to think hard.
reading_story: The reading is 思い and 詰める put together into one reading.
pitch_accent: オモイツメꜜル *** オモイツメル *** オモꜜイツメル

ex_1_jp: 催促するようで申し訳ありませんが、東京タワーの写真を何枚か撮って月曜日までに送ってもらえませんでしょうか。
ex_1_en: I’m sorry to be so demanding, but can you take some pictures of Tokyo Tower and send them to me by Monday, please? Thanks.
meaning_story: If 催促 is urge, then the verb version would be to urge.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 催促 first.

ex_1_jp: ちょっくら地下街に行くところだよ。
ex_1_en: I’m off to the underground shopping mall.
meaning_story: An underground (地下) street isn't as underground streety as it sounds. A lot of the underground streets and areas in Japan tend to be underground shopping malls, though. That or subways/trains, but underground shopping centers are way more interesting.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 私は普段殆ど電話をしないことを、母に謝りました。
ex_1_en: I apologized to my mother for not calling her more regularly.
meaning_story: The normal steps are the ones that are totally usual and ordinary, unlike those weird not usual steps.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どんなにお腹が苦しくても、野菜なら食べられます。
ex_1_en: No matter how full I am, I can eat vegetables.
meaning_story: A field vegetable is still a vegetable, whether it comes from the field or not.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 菜食主義者の人は偽善者が多いっていう意見に賛成してくれる人はいますか。
ex_1_en: Does anyone else agree that vegetarians tend to be hypocrites?
meaning_story: If you eat vegetable food you practice vegetarianism.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 倉で見つけた地図を広げてみた。
ex_1_en: I unfolded the map I found in the warehouse.
meaning_story: The kanji means warehouse, and the vocab is also warehouse!
reading_story: What do you put in your warehouse? Nothing that nice. Just your totally crashed (くら) car. So sad, it was a nice car, too and now it's all crashed and stored in your warehouse.

ex_1_jp: 巨万の富を築くことは思ったより簡単ではありません。
ex_1_en: Making a fortune of millions is not as easy as I thought.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: For the reading, think about the person you know with the most wealth. It is Tommy (とみ) Hillfiger.

ex_1_jp: どうして人は富裕層と貧困層に分けられるのでしょうか。
ex_1_en: Why do we separate people into the rich and the poor?
meaning_story: If you're rich and abundant, you are super wealthy, probably.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今日久々に麦粉が入った袋を開けたら、緑色のクネクネした幼虫が大量発生していました。
ex_1_en: Today I opened a bag of wheat flour for the first time in long time and found a bunch of green worms wriggling in it.
meaning_story: Wheat powder is wheat flour.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi readings. Since you didn't learn that reading for 粉 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. What sort of people like wheat flour the most? 子! 子 like wheat flour the most since it is both fun to eat and to play with. Silly 子, wheat flour is a food, not a toy.

ex_1_jp: ここは、あなた以外には安全地帯です。
ex_1_en: This is a safe zone for everyone but you.
meaning_story: This earth belt is the area within the belt, which holds this area of earth in. It is separate from the rest of the earth, making it its own zone or district.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: チꜜタイ *** チタꜜイ *** チタイ

ex_1_jp: 成功が誰の功績かを判断するのは難しい。
ex_1_en: It’s difficult to decide who deserves credit for success.
meaning_story: Your achievements and exploits are your achievements.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 日本が新たな移民を受け入れることには賛成ですか。
ex_1_en: Do you support Japan accepting new immigrants?
meaning_story: It has become that we agree. We have agreement!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: うちの家族には、六世代に渡って先祖代々受け継がれてきた特別なおむつがあります。
ex_1_en: Our family has a special diaper that has been passed down from father to son for six generations.
meaning_story: Your previous ancestors are your ancestors. All ancestors are previous to you, after all, unless you want to talk time travel, then who knows.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ダイエットをしたいんですが、食欲があり過ぎるんですよね。
ex_1_en: I want to go on a diet, but I have too much of an appetite.
meaning_story: I have a food want. When I want food (or when I don't want food), it has to do with your appetite.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ショクヨク *** ショクꜜヨク

ex_1_jp: どうして血液は赤いのですか。
ex_1_en: Why is blood red?
meaning_story: Your blood fluid is your blood.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 僕が君のゆで卵を盗んだと思っているのなら、とんだお門違いだよ。
ex_1_en: If you think I stole your boiled egg, you’re barking up the wrong tree.
meaning_story: The ゆ comes from 湯, which is "hot water." So a "hot water egg" Is a boiled egg.
reading_story: The reading comes from the kanji.
pitch_accent: ユデタꜜマコ° *** ユデタマꜜコ°

ex_1_jp: カレーを零して、手に火傷を負った。
ex_1_en: I spilled curry and got a burn on my hand.
meaning_story: A fire wound is a burn or scald you got from fire (or other hot things). Ouch!
reading_story: The reading for this is unlike anything you've seen with these kanji. Try to think about a burn (on your arm) being caused by a yakky dodo bird (which is a dodo bird that has yak-like features). Take a look at how weird it is, and wonder why it is burning you. Feel the pains.

ex_1_jp: どうしてキリスト教徒と仏教徒の中には、肉欲を罪深いものだとして否定する人がいるのですか。
ex_1_en: Why do some Christians and Buddhists deny their carnal desires like they’re something sinful?
meaning_story: Your meat wants are your deepest desires, your carnal desires.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この桜んぼ、やばいくらい美味しいんだけど。
ex_1_en: These cherries are ridiculously tasty.
meaning_story: A cherry tree can create a cherry. This is what this word is.
reading_story: The reading comes from the kanji.

ex_1_jp: どこかの国で、子供用の股の部分が開いたセクシー下着が販売されて大騒ぎになっていたことがあったよね。
ex_1_en: I remember that selling crotchless panties for kids created an uproar in some country.
meaning_story: If 騒ぐ is "to make noise," then a big version of this is even louder. It's a clamor and an uproar.
reading_story: This is word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, which you should know already because 大 is pretty familiar to you by now (I hope) and you just learned 騒ぐ as well! Put them together, with a little tweaking at the end, and you have your reading. Ta-da!

ex_1_jp: 彼女を誘拐して押入れに閉じ込めたあの日から、僕はずっと彼女のことばかり考えているんだ。
ex_1_en: I’ve done nothing but think about her since the day I kidnapped her and locked her up in my closet.
meaning_story: You push things in to insert them into the closet or wall cubbard.
reading_story: The reading is 押し (push the し inside the 押) plus 入れる's reading.

ex_1_jp: 私は妻のために死ぬまで働いて銭を稼ぐだけの奴隷ですよ。
ex_1_en: I’m just a slave to making money for my wife until I die.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading for the kanji is せん, the reading for this vocab word is ぜに. They're pretty similar, but only ぜに rhymes with "penny."

ex_1_jp: 最初に気づいたのは、彼が共産党員だということでした。
ex_1_en: The first thing I noticed was that he was a member of the Communist Party.
meaning_story: Together we'll give birth to a group, that is all together one group no matter what family gives birth to you. This belief comes from the communist party.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 当時、家庭環境が複雑だったので、高校には行っていません。
ex_1_en: I didn’t go to high school because my family life was complicated at the time.
meaning_story: There are duplicates of everything, not to mention the duplicates are random. Nothing makes sense, and everything is super complicated.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVENOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 便秘がひどくてさぁ。もう一週間以上ウンコしていないんだよ！
ex_1_en: I’ve been constipated. I haven’t pooped in a week!
meaning_story: For this word, the 便 comes from 便所, which you know as "toilet." A toilet secret is one you take with you to the bathroom, one that you don't want people to know about. This is constipation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ひ changes to ぴ because "P" stands for "Poop."

ex_1_jp: 世界で一番危険な伝染病は何ですか。
ex_1_en: What is the most dangerous infectious disease in the world?
meaning_story: A sickness that can transmit and then dye into you (aka get inside you and infect you, via transmission) is a contagious disease. Everyone cover their mouths when they cough and sneeze, and please wash your hands, okay?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 一枚目はお手元にお持ちください。私達は複写の方を頂きますね。
ex_1_en: You can keep the original, but we’ll take a copy.
meaning_story: When you make a duplicate copy you are copying things. You are making a duplication.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: そろそろ正月飾りの準備をしておかなくちゃ。
ex_1_en: We have to slowly start preparations for the New Year’s decorations.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji decorate, so it means decoration.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: この仕事を志望する動機は何ですか？
ex_1_en: What is your motivation for applying for this job?
meaning_story: Your intention for your hope is what you want. It's not just a hope. You have intention behind it. This is your desire. This is your ambition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「君の机の上に、コウイチの写真を置いておいたよ。」「ありがとう。恩に着るよ。」
ex_1_en: "I put the picture of Koichi on your desk." "Thanks. I owe you one."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 雪の日に汚水の配管が詰まってしまいました。
ex_1_en: Sewage pipes get blocked on snow days.
meaning_story: Dirty water is dirty water. Gross. Could also be sewage. Even grosser.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「卵がかえる前にひなを数えるな」という諺は、日本語では「とらぬ狸の皮算用をするな」です。
ex_1_en: The proverb "Don’t count your chicken’s before they hatch" in Japanese is "Don’t assume you can grab a tanuki"
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
pitch_accent: タマꜜコ° *** タマコ° *** ラꜜン

ex_1_jp: 日本語から英訳することしかできません。
ex_1_en: All I can do is to translate from Japanese to English.
meaning_story: English translate is an English translation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は自分の左の眼球をあちこち捜したが、なかなか見つけられなかった。
ex_1_en: I searched high and low for my left eyeball, but I just couldn’t find it.
meaning_story: An eyeball sphere is an eyeball. Eww.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: コンピュータを使う仕事は眼を酷使しやすい。
ex_1_en: Using computers to work can easily overwork your eyes.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is a little more technical than 目, like how "eyeball" is more technical than "eye" in English.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the word "eye" (目), so use that to remember this!

ex_1_jp: 老眼は大体いつ頃から始まるんですか。
ex_1_en: When does age-related farsightedness usually start?
meaning_story: An elderly eyeball is one that can't see things close up. That's why this word means farsightedness. But this is the kind of farsightedness that only comes with age. So you have to be an elderly oldey to have 老眼.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 脇毛を永久脱毛したから、今脇はツルツルだよ。
ex_1_en: I’ve removed my armpit hair permanently, so my armpits are very smooth now.
meaning_story: Eternity is a long time... as in forever. This word has to do with an actual forever. So, like, forever. Not like a "oh man I haven't done that in forever," because if you've done something before, it's not forever. This is forever for realsies.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 久 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. Something that is truly cute (きゅう) will be cute forever. This isn't the cute that fades over time. This is true cute that lasts forever.
pitch_accent: エイキュー *** トコシエ *** トコシナエ *** トꜜワ

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: もう永遠に日本には帰ってこないの？
ex_1_en: Will you never come back to Japan again?
meaning_story: An eternity that is far away is not really an eternity, it just feels like it. It's forever, but not the real kind of forever that's actually forever. That's 永久, which is a real forever, this is more like "whoa, I haven't eaten sushi in forever" (actually, you have).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 家庭教師の先生のお陰で、成績がグンと上がりました。
ex_1_en: My grades have gotten a lot better thanks to my personal tutor.
meaning_story: You become exploits... as in, your exploits become a thing you can actually see, and you can see them in the form of grades. Ouch, some of your exploits weren't all that amazing...
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: う〜ん、何て言ったらいいのかな。僕の祖父は単なる気分屋なんだよね。機嫌がいい時もあれば、悪い時もあるっていうか。だから、あんまり気にしないで。
ex_1_en: Ummm... what can I say? My grandpa just a moody kind of a guy. He has highs and he has lows. So, don’t even bother him.
meaning_story: Your ancestor father isn't your father, it's the father that came before your father's generation, your grandfather.
reading_story: The reading is all on'yomi, which is great for 祖 but not as great for 父. To remember that this 父 is ふ, just think about how much of a fool (ふ) your grandfather was, even if he wasn't.
pitch_accent: ジꜜー *** ジジꜜー *** ソꜜフ

ex_1_jp: 私の祖母はいつも指にド派手な指輪を嵌めています。
ex_1_en: My grandmother always has flashy jewelry on her fingers.
meaning_story: Your ancestor mother isn't your mother, it's the mother before your mother, your grandmother.
reading_story: The reading for 祖 is known to you, but the 母 part is not. To remember the on'yomi reading for 母 in 祖母, just think about how your grandmother had a boat (ぼ), even if she didn't... and what an amazing boat it was. If you want, you can imagine your grandma is a boat too, but that might not be very nice.

ex_1_jp: 彼に振られて傷心気味なので、パリに傷心旅行に行くんです。
ex_1_en: He dumped me and I’m a little heartbroken, so I’m going on a trip to Paris to get over it.
meaning_story: A wound of your heart. That could be many things, but in this case it's heartbreak.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お前も一緒に桜肉パーティーに来いよ。イカしたパーティーになるぜ。
ex_1_en: You should come with me to the horse meat party. It’s going to be hip.
meaning_story: Strangely, cherry tree meat isn't just some kind of cherry steak... it's horse meat. Hopefully you'll just remember that due to the strangeness of this word's kanji.
reading_story: The reading is the words 桜 and 肉 put together into one horse steak of a word.

ex_1_jp: その歯科衛生士は、お口を開けてください、と私に言いながらにやりと笑い、日焼けした顔に白い歯をキラリと見せた。
ex_1_en: As the dental hygienist told me to open my mouth I saw a flash of white teeth from her tanned face.
meaning_story: In defense of life, you have to remain clean. If you are dirty, you will die earlier (think: plagues). So, to defend said life, you must have good hygiene.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 歯周病は感染症の一種だとは知りませんでした。
ex_1_en: I didn’t know that periodontitis is a type of infectious disease.
meaning_story: The feeling of dye, covering your body, is the feeling of nasty germs and diseases penetrating your skin, getting inside of you. This is an infection, and it's gross.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その事故による死者は三名、傷者は二百人以上にのぼるという。
ex_1_en: It’s said that there were three killed and more than 200 wounded in that accident.
meaning_story: Someone who has a wound is someone who is wounded. They are an injured person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ビエトは高い志を持っており、どんどん夢を実現していってる。
ex_1_en: Viet has high aspirations and is steadily making his dreams come true.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This is a long reading, but I think it has some sense to it. Think about how when you have intention to do something, you have a feeling of being stabbed in the heart (with intention, of course). To say that in Japanese, you could go こころざし (心刺し). Guess what? The reading is the same thing as that, bringing it to こころざし.
pitch_accent: ココロザシ *** ココロザシꜜ

ex_1_jp: 俺はエロゲに全く興味が無いふりをしている。
ex_1_en: I’m pretending that I have no interest in hentai games.
meaning_story: I have an interest in the flavor... You do? Yes, I have a very deep interest in it.
reading_story: As a jukugo kanji, you can guess the reading is the on'yomi kanji readings, which it is, so you should be able to read it.
pitch_accent: キョꜜーミ *** キョーミꜜ

ex_1_jp: もし私が全能の神だったら、この会話を通訳してあげることができるけど、そうじゃないから無理だわ。ごめんよ。
ex_1_en: If I were omnipotent, I would be able to interpret this conversation for you, but I’m not, so I can’t. Sorry.
meaning_story: If you let words pass through you, and as they do you translate them, you are doing interpreting.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: いくつか小さな間違いはあるものの、うまく和訳できていると思いますよ。
ex_1_en: Aside from some minor mistakes, I think your Japanese translation was pretty good.
meaning_story: Remember how 和 represents Japan? Now, take that and add translate to it. With that, you have Japanese translation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 我らが自民が今年は熱いな。もう誰も我々のことを「愚民党」なんて呼ぶことはないだろう。
ex_1_en: Our Liberal Democratic Party is hot stuff this year. Nobody would call us the Loopy Democratic Party anymore.
meaning_story: The individual peoples group is the political group that believes in each individual of the people (or something?). The translation doesn't really get hinted at in this meaning, but this group is the Liberal Democratic Party, aka the LDP.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 機内に持ち込み可能な液体の量はどれぐらいですか。
ex_1_en: What is a practical amount of water to bring on a plane?
meaning_story: Things that have a fluid body are made of liquid.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「もう明日だけど、でも、やっぱり、私たちの結婚式を中止するべきだと思うの。」「僕もそれを言おうと思っていたんだ。」
ex_1_en: "It’s tomorrow, but I think we should still cancel our wedding." "You took the words right out of my mouth."
meaning_story: If 結婚 is marriage, then a marriage ceremony is a marriage ceremony or wedding.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日本の大学生の食費と雑費の平均はいくらぐらいですか。
ex_1_en: What is the average cost of a Japanese college student’s food and miscellaneous expenses?
meaning_story: Random expenses are miscellaneous expenses. Not actually random, but they feel that way.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ざつ goes to ざっ and the ひ goes to ぴ, making it into a dumb sounding word, like "zappy" (ざっぴ), so you can think about how some of your miscellaneous expenses were on zappy items.

ex_1_jp: 私には複数のニックネームとアカウントがあります。
ex_1_en: I have multiple nicknames and accounts.
meaning_story: The duplicate numbers are when you duplicate the numbers into more numbers, representing multiple.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この音声ファイルの雑音を消したいんです。
ex_1_en: I want to get rid of the static in this sound file.
meaning_story: Random noise is still noise, though more specifically it is random noise, like static.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この幼稚園では、子どもたちのお遊戯会は撮影禁止です。
ex_1_en: Photography and video recordings are prohibited for Parents’ Day at this kindergarten.
meaning_story: 撮影 is photography. 禁止 is prohibition. So if photography is prohibited, then we can assume there's a no photos or no photos allowed rule in place.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the words 撮影 and 禁止.

ex_1_jp: 背中のニキビを無くす方法が知りたいよ。
ex_1_en: I want to know how to get rid of the acne on my back.
meaning_story: The middle of your back is one's back (or your back).
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi readings, put together, making it the words 背 and 中 combined.

ex_1_jp: 毎日午後に有酸素運動をしています。
ex_1_en: I do aerobic exercises every afternoon.
meaning_story: The acid element is oxygen. In German it’s the same as in Japanese - it’s called “Sauerstoff”, including “sauer”, the word for “sour”. The noun version is “säure” which means both “sourness” and “acid” (which again is the same in Japanese, the same kanji is used in both words). The word “oxygenium” in Greek/Latin literally means “acid maker”. Long ago chemists thought oxygen was a defining characteristic of acids, later they found out there are also acids without oxygen like hydrochloric/muriatic/salt acid and the defining characteristic actually is hydrogen. But the name stuck. Or you could just imagine all the oxygen you breathe has turned into acid (oh no!), and it sucks to breathe. Whatever works for you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ある共和党の党員の演説にとても感動しました。
ex_1_en: I was deeply moved by a speech made by a member of the Republican Party.
meaning_story: A group member is someone who's a member of a group, specifically a political one, making you a party member.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 自分が二歳か三歳の頃に、一丁前に桜色のタキシードを着てる写真を見ました。
ex_1_en: I saw a picture of me in a full-fledged pink tux when I was two or three years old.
meaning_story: A cherry blossom color is what color? Kind of a pink, wouldn't you say? Also, pink can be ピンク, if you want it to be.
reading_story: The reading is the readings for 桜 and 色 combined.

ex_1_jp: 日本での政党の成立要件を教えてください。
ex_1_en: Could you tell me what the requirements are for establishing a political party in Japan?
meaning_story: A politics group is a political party.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 自国のPM2.5汚染レベルはどうすれば分かるのでしょうか。
ex_1_en: How can I find out about PM2.5 contamination levels in my community?
meaning_story: A dirty dye that's all throughout the sky and makes things gross when it touches them is pollution. If it's bad enough it really is like a dye, too, making your white clothes brown, yuck.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お前は自分のことを素晴らしいと思っているみたいだけどな、ただの貧乏家族の貧乏人だってことを、よ〜く肝に銘じておくんだな。
ex_1_en: You think you’re so great, but bear in mind, you are just a poor person from a poor family!
meaning_story: 貧乏 is poor, so a poor person is a poor person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 貧乏 already.

ex_1_jp: 私はいつも本の序文は飛ばします。
ex_1_en: I usually skip a book’s preface.
meaning_story: Preface writing is the preface.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: もし別の惑星で金を見つけることができて、それを地球に持ち帰って販売した場合、採算は取れるのでしょうか。
ex_1_en: If we found gold on another planet, took it back to Earth and sold it, would we make a profit?
meaning_story: Gather the money and then calculate how much of it you have. Oh, nice, looks like you have a profit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 祖父の一日は、銭湯から始まります。
ex_1_en: My grandfather starts his day by going to a public bath.
meaning_story: Give a coin and get hot water. So you hand over a coin and then you get hot water in the form of a bath. It's a bath for anyone willing to pay, making it a public bath.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You don't know the on'yomi reading of 湯, though, so just think about how when you get in the public bath, you're in Tokyo (とう), because there are a lot of public baths in Japan, and Tokyo is the most well known city there.

ex_1_jp: その出版社では、入館の際に身分証明書を提示しなければなりません。
ex_1_en: You have to show your ID card to enter the publishing company.
meaning_story: If 出版 means publishing, then a company that does said publishing is a publishing company.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 出版 as well, though.

pronunciation: おしぼたん, おしボタン
ex_1_jp: 押しボタン式のドアでも、自動ドアって呼ぶのかな。
ex_1_en: If you have to push a button to open the doors, can you still call them automatic doors?
meaning_story: If 押し is push, and a ボタン is a button, then you have yourself a push button.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 押す.

ex_1_jp: 「生卵アレルギーはありますか？」「私の知る限りではありません。」
ex_1_en: "Do you have raw egg allergy?" "Not that I know of."
meaning_story: Remember how 生 can mean raw? Well, it does now. So, a raw egg? First of all, delicious. Second of all, it means raw egg.
reading_story: The reading is the vocab 生 and 卵 combined into one 生卵.
pitch_accent: ナマタꜜマコ° *** ナマタマꜜコ°

ex_1_jp: どうして便器の上で逆立ちをしようとしたのか訳を聞かせてください。
ex_1_en: Can you tell me the reason why you tried doing a handstand over the toilet?
meaning_story: This word takes the reason meaning of the kanji, making it reason. What's the reason for it having two meaning? You've got me, I have no clue.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: What's your reason to wake (わけ) up this morning? Think about it. Now think of your reason to wake up tomorrow. What is it?

ex_1_jp: 功労に準じて恩賞が付与されるということを覚えておいてくださいね。
ex_1_en: Please keep in mind that rewards will be assigned proportionate to your work.
meaning_story: A kindness prize is one that someone gives you out of kindness. Perhaps you've done something nice, which is why they are giving you a reward.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 相手の気を引いたりうまく釣ったりする人のことを英語ではデコイと言うが、日本語では桜、ネット用語では釣りと言う。
ex_1_en: A person who entices or lures another person is called decoy in English, sakura in Japanese, and troll on the internet.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 落下する衛星を避けることは、不可能ではありません。
ex_1_en: It’s not impossible to avoid a falling satellite.
meaning_story: A defense star isn't really a star, but it is something shiny in the sky that can look like a star if it's bright enough. This is a satellite, and while it's not always defensive, satellites can have defensive properties. Think ion canons and video and things like that.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember that the 星 is read as せい. You can remember this the Hard Gay way. SEI (せい) SEI SEI~!~!

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 秘密は誰にも言わないよ。ちゃんと、口にチャックしておくよ。
ex_1_en: Your secret is safe with me. My lips are sealed.
meaning_story: Secret and secrecy. Combine the two and you have quite the secret.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 僕たちは、お互いの家族にも知らせず、密かに入籍をしたんだ。
ex_1_en: We entered the family registry in secret, without even letting the whole family know.
meaning_story: Something that has secrecy is secret and private.
reading_story: Think about that really secret and private dude. He so (ひそ) secret...

ex_1_jp: とある会社の脱税について、税務署に密告したいと思ってるんです。
ex_1_en: I’d like to inform the tax office about a company’s tax evasion.
meaning_story: In secrecy you must announce this information. It's not for anyone to hear, it's secret information.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The みつ goes to みっ.

ex_1_jp: 私達は密会によくこの部屋を利用しています。
ex_1_en: We often make use of this room for secret meetings.
meaning_story: A secrecy meet is a secret meeting. You know the password?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 自衛のための殺人は合法なのでしょうか。
ex_1_en: Is it legal to murder someone in self defense?
meaning_story: Self defense is when you protect yourself. It's self defense.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ヤフオクで入札した後の手続きの順序についてブログでまとめてみました。
ex_1_en: After I successfully bid on Yahoo auctions, I wrote about the order of procedures on my blog.
meaning_story: The order of things is the preface to the entire sequence and steps we're planning on taking. So, just remember. The order is just the preface. It is what allows us to come up with a sequence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あいつは本当に飾り気のない女だ。
ex_1_en: She’s a really plain woman.
meaning_story: If you decorate your spirit with a bunch of pretty things like streamers and balloons, people will think you're just showing off. Yes, you know your spirit is awesome, but everyone else doesn't want it pushed in their face with your over the top decorations.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading for 気 yet, so here's a mnemonnic to help you: At the height of showing off, you bend one arm to your hip and the other out in the air. You pretend to be a kettle (け). You show off your spirit to all your friends singing "I'm a little ke-ttle, short and stout. Here is my handle, here is my spout. EVERYONE LOOK HOW GREAT I AM!" Your kettle dance is sure to impress them.

ex_1_jp: 俺は一度麻薬の密輸をする話を持ちかけられたことがあるよ。もちろん断ったけどね。
ex_1_en: I was asked to smuggle narcotics once. Of course I refused.
meaning_story: A secrecy transport is when you transport something in secrecy. If you don't want people to know what you're transporting, you'll have to resort to smuggling.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 社会党の主張は現実的ではないような気がする。
ex_1_en: The Socialist Party’s statements don’t seem to be realistic.
meaning_story: The society (社会) group is the socialist party. They're into society, and they're in a group, so it makes sense.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 最初に食べた食べ物は腐りかけていて酸っぱかったです。
ex_1_en: The first food I ate was rotten and sour.
meaning_story: The taste of something with acid is... well... you'd think it'd be acidic, but it's a sour taste. Some acidic things are pretty sour, though. Lemons are pretty acidic, and they're super sour too, so think about that when you need to remember this word.
reading_story: Something was so sour that it broke your mouth. You were so upset about this, that you decided to sue the maker of this nasty sour thing.

ex_1_jp: 人生の汚点は日本語では黒歴史とも呼ばれる。
ex_1_en: A disgrace in life is also called dark history in Japanese.
meaning_story: A dirty point is a little point of dirtiness on something. This is a stain or smudge.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 背丈の低い男が千鳥足でバーから出てきて、私の目の前でゲロを吐いたんです。
ex_1_en: A short guy staggered out of the bar and threw up in front of me.
meaning_story: Someone's back height is their height. It also refers to their stature.
reading_story: The reading comes from the vocab readings of 背 and 丈, combined together.

ex_1_jp: インターネットでは厳しいコメントを書く人が多い。
ex_1_en: Many people write harsh comments on the internet.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of strict? It is also strict.
reading_story: The most strict creature in Japan is the key bee (きび). Little key bees have to be very strict about locking the doors to their hive. If they aren't strict enough, the scary Japanese hornets will get in and kill them all. Have you seen those things? They're terrifying!
pitch_accent: イカメシꜜイ *** キビシꜜイ

ex_1_jp: 従業員同士の私語は厳禁です。
ex_1_en: Private conversations with coworkers are strictly prohibited.
meaning_story: Something with strict prohibition is strictly forbidden / strictly prohibited.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: こんなに背が高いホビットは見たことがないよ。
ex_1_en: I’ve never seen such a tall hobbit before.
meaning_story: This is the words 背 and 高い put together to make one adjective. When your height is tall it means you are a tall person. This word is only used for tall people though, not anything else that's tall like a building or a tree.
reading_story: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). You've learned both of these readings before now, so you should be able to read this word already!

ex_1_jp: 「コウイチ、忘れ物は無い？」「無いよ。」「あ、ちょっと待って。あんたのお弁当に照り焼きサーモン入れるの忘れてたわ。」「ええっ！母さん、早くしてよ。」
ex_1_en: "Have you got everything, Koichi?" "Yes, mom." "Oh, wait. I forgot to put the teriyaki salmon in your bento box." "What! Hurry, mom!"
meaning_story: You illuminate and then bake some food. To illuminate it, you put on some shiny sauce. Then, you cook it. Sound familiar, in terms of a type of food? This is teriyaki, though I have to warn you it's quite different from what you get at "teriyaki shops" in the west.
reading_story: The reading comes from 照れる and 焼く. Put them together and you have something delicious.

ex_1_jp: 私は冷え性で、特に足がいつも冷えています。
ex_1_en: I’m really sensitive to the cold, especially my feet which are always cold.
meaning_story: If 冷やす is "to chill something," then this would be the version where something is just chilled. You're not doing the action of chilling anything, it's just that way. You know this because if you get involved, there's always some kind of chilling error (える). So, you step back and let the fridge do its job without messing.
reading_story: The reading comes from 冷やす. Know that and you know this as well.

ex_1_jp: 休日だろうが何だろうがディズニーランドはいつでも込んでるよ。
ex_1_en: Disney Land is always crowded, even if it is a holiday.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means crowded and the verb vocab version is to be crowded.
reading_story: Lucky for you, the reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here.

ex_1_jp: たくさんの人がオリンピックに浮かれすぎている。
ex_1_en: Many people get too carried away by the olympics.
meaning_story: 浮く is "to float." This more describes the feeling you get when floating, which is to be happy or to be in high spirits. You know this because you really care (かれる) about how you feel, and to feel happy is great!
reading_story: The reading comes from 浮く, so if you know that you' are going to be happy.

ex_1_jp: 彼は内に秘めるタイプなので、心配しています。
ex_1_en: I’m worried about him because he tends to hide his feelings.
meaning_story: If you secret something, you are trying to keep secret something. That, or you're trying to conceal it.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, strangely enough. Nothing to conceal about this reading, you gots it.

ex_1_jp: 染毛剤は髪の毛を傷める。
ex_1_en: Hair dye damages your hair.
meaning_story: If you go to wound something, you are going to damage it. Ouch!
reading_story: When you damage something, though, how does it feel? Does it hurt, like 痛い? Wait, what's the reading of this? It's いためる, just like 痛い's reading. That should be easy to remember, unless I accidentally damage your brain with these mnemonics or something.

ex_1_jp: 髪を何色に染めるか迷っています。
ex_1_en: I’m wondering what color to dye my hair.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dye so the verb vocab version is to dye.
reading_story: You need to dye something that you just sewed (そ) together. It's all sewed and looks like a shirt, but it's colorless. That's where the dying comes in.

ex_1_jp: 高熱で体が火照っています。
ex_1_en: My body feels hot from this high fever.
meaning_story: If fire illuminates your face, you're going to feel hot. Sometimes you start to flush when you're embarrassed and it just feels like there is fire making your face light up.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 火 yet, but it's easier to remember this with a mnemonic for the whole thing: When are you going to feel hot? When is your face going to flush? When I ask you to go to a hotel (ほてる) with me!

ex_1_jp: 僕のお父さんはカブト虫を採る名人です。
ex_1_en: My daddy is good at catching beetles.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gather so the verb vocab version is to gather.
reading_story: When you gather things, you go around and take things from their original location to put them together in your gathering spot. In Japanese, when you take something, you could say 取る, right? This word has the same reading: とる.

ex_1_jp: 汚れやすいので白いコントローラーはお勧めしません。
ex_1_en: I don’t recommend white controllers because they get dirty easily.
