meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dirty so the verb vocab version is to get dirty. You know you're not doing the dirtying, because it's rare (れる) for you to get anything dirty, though things do get dirty on their own.
reading_story: Things seem to get dirty easily around here, which is why you go (よご) to great lengths to keep things clean.
pitch_accent: ケカ°レꜜル *** ヨコ°レル

ex_1_jp: どうすればNBA選手のように身長が6.5フィートを越すのでしょうか。今、6フィートなのですが、6.5を越したいのです。
ex_1_en: How can I be taller than 6.5 feet like NBA players? I’m 6 feet now and I want to surpass that.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means go beyond so the verb vocab version is also to go beyond.
reading_story: The reading can come from 越える. So if you know that you know this too!

ex_1_jp: 何か爬虫類をペットに飼いたいな。
ex_1_en: I want to keep some reptiles as pets.
meaning_story: The kanji is domesticate. When you domesticate an animal, you get to keep a pet of some kind. You'd use this to describe when you are keeping a dog or cat or something.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. The か of cat!

ex_1_jp: もう限界だ！君の行動にはうんざりだよ、フグ。どうしていつも小便を漏らすんだ？ああ、また海出身だからなんて言わないでくれよ。君のお決まりの言い訳はもう聞き飽きているからね。
ex_1_en: Bloody hell! I’m just totally fed up with your behavior, Fugu. Why do you wet your pants all the time? Oh, don’t tell me again that you are from ocean. I’ve heard enough of the same excuses.
meaning_story: If 漏れる is "to leak," then this is when you do the leaking yourself. The reason this thing is leaking, though (and it shouldn't be), is because you rushed (らす) the job (because you did it yourself), which is why you know this is to leak something.
reading_story: The reading comes from 漏れる, so if you know that, you know this! Don't let that memory leak from your head.

ex_1_jp: お前、もう元カノについて考えるのはよした方がいいぞ。特に、サーモンのお父さんに彼女と結婚していいかどうか聞いて、許しも得ちまったんだからな。
ex_1_en: You’ve gotta stop thinking about your ex-girlfriend, especially because you asked Salmon’s dad if you could marry her and he said yes.
meaning_story: 結婚 is marriage, so the verb version of that would be to marry or to get married.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 結婚 first, though.

ex_1_jp: 今更ですが、マイ箸を持ち歩き始めました。
ex_1_en: It may be a little late, but I started carrying around my own pair of chopsticks.
meaning_story: It's now again? Well, if it's already now, then it's now. It's also too late to do what you want to do... if it was the past, then maybe it would have been okay.
reading_story: The reading is the vocab words 今 and 更に's 更 put together.
pitch_accent: イマサラ *** イꜜマサラ

ex_1_jp: うちに仔犬を迎えたいなと思ってるんですが、無駄吠え防止の訓練をしやすいのは何犬でしょうか。
ex_1_en: We are thinking of getting a puppy, but which kind can be easily trained to avoid the unnecessary barking?
meaning_story: The kanji means welcome, but the verb version is to pick someone up or to meet someone. That's weird. But, think of it this way: When you go to welcome someone, you are going to meet someone too. You have to go somewhere to wait and welcome them, which is why you are going to pick someone up or going to meet them. Something like that anyways.
reading_story: To pick someone up you are going to drive your moo car. It's a car that's designed to look like a cow, but you think it will be a nice way to welcome your friend.

ex_1_jp: ビザを延長するにはどこに行ったらいいのか知ってる？
ex_1_en: Do you know where I should go to extend my visa?
meaning_story: If 延長 is prolonging, then the verb version is to prolong.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は有名な小説家だが、時々自費出版することもあるんだよ。
ex_1_en: Although he is a famous fiction writer, he sometimes self-publishes his books.
meaning_story: If 出版 is publishing, then the verb vocab version is to publish.
reading_story: The reading comes from 出版, so if you know that you know this. Also, it's just the kanji readings too, so no problemo for a person like you, I'm sure.

ex_1_jp: その雑誌は購読する価値がありますよ。
ex_1_en: It’s worth subscribing to this magazine.
meaning_story: If 購読 is a subscription, then the verb vocab version would be to subscribe.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私の主人は、たとえ一日でも賞味期限が過ぎていたら捨てるんですよ。
ex_1_en: My husband throws away food that’s passed it’s freshness date, even if it was only by one day.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means throw away so the verb version is to throw away.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, so no need to throw away that bit of knowledge just yet!

ex_1_jp: この単語を訳すのは難しい。
ex_1_en: This word is difficult to translate.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means translate so the verb version would be to translate.
reading_story: The reading for the kanji part is surprisingly the やく you learned with it, even you wouldn't expect that. I suppose that's the kind of thing you have to look forward to if you were to go into translating.

ex_1_jp: 日本語の中には、良い英語の訳語が無い時がある。
ex_1_en: For some Japanese words, there are no good English equivalents.
meaning_story: A translated bit of language is a translated term.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この本の訳者の名前、何て読むか知ってる？
ex_1_en: Do you know how to read the name of this book’s translator?
meaning_story: Someone who translates things is a translator.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: よくあるように、その会社は女性は顔で採用するそうですよ。
ex_1_en: As is often the case, it’s said that company only employs attractive women.
meaning_story: I gather things and use them. The things I've gathered, are the things I use.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: じゃあ、多数決で採決しよう。夕食にてっちり（ふぐ鍋）が食べたい人は？
ex_1_en: OK, let’s take a vote. Who wants Fugu-nabe for dinner?
meaning_story: When people gather and decide things, they decide together, usually by voting.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: サꜜイケツ *** サイケツ

ex_1_jp: 「欲しいものを買っていいよ。金額の制限は無しだよ。」「まあ！熱でもあるの？ 何かあったの？」
ex_1_en: "You can buy anything you want. Money is no limit." "Wow! Do you have a fever? What’s up with you"
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of want? It's also wanted.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want? A hoe (ほ), like a garden hoe, you sicko.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私の妻は、頻繁に欲求不満になります。
ex_1_en: My wife is constantly sexually frustrated.
meaning_story: What you want and request are your wants and desires. You want these things so you request for them. I wants them!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. よく goes to よっ, so be careful not to want the wrong reading.

ex_1_jp: 今年の冬は例年よりも寒くて雪も凄く降ったけど、本当に地球は温暖化してるのかね。
ex_1_en: This winter is unusually cold and we have had tons of snow, so is the earth really getting warmer?
meaning_story: Warm warm is warm.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: あたたかい, あったかい
ex_1_jp: 今日はポカポカと暖かい一日だった。
ex_1_en: It was a nice warm day today.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of warm? It's warm as well! Though this is for a warm place, not some warm food or something like that, that would be 温かい, a different あたたかい. Confusing, right?
reading_story: The reading is the same like 温かい, which also means warm, though it refers to a warm thing unlike 暖かい which refers to a warm temperature or place. *Note that あったかい is for spoken Japanese. The "correct" reading is still あたたかい. But we've added this reading too for you chattygattors out there.
pitch_accent: アタタカꜜイ *** アッタカꜜイ

ex_1_jp: 自分が意志の弱い人間だってことは自覚してますよ。
ex_1_en: I’m aware that I’m a weak-willed person.
meaning_story: You have an idea and you have intent to carry it out. This is your will and volition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 金メダル獲得に意欲をみせた。
ex_1_en: I showed the will to win a gold metal.
meaning_story: If you have an idea of what you want already, then that's good! You have will, desire, and ambition. Those who don't know what they want can't have any of these.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ウクレレに傷がついちゃったんです。
ex_1_en: I got a scratch on my ukulele.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: To remember this reading, just think about what your mommy did for you when you were little and you got yourself a wound... she would kiss (きず) the wounds better. Of course, that never worked and was a total farce, but try to forgive mommy this one time, okay?

ex_1_jp: 異常気象が続いています。
ex_1_en: The abnormal weather continues.
meaning_story: When something differs from normal it's called abnormal or strange.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 子宮がん検診の結果が「異状あり」だったのでびびっています。
ex_1_en: My Pap test was "abnormal" and I’m freaking out.
meaning_story: It differs from the normal condition of things, making it weird. It is an abnormality. There is something wrong.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 彼の忠告を侮るでないぞ、さもなくば命を落としかねんぞ。
ex_1_en: Don’t make light of his advice, if not you might lose your life.
meaning_story: A loyalty announcement is the kind of announcement you give to someone who you're loyal too. To this type of person, your announcement would come in the form of advice or maybe admonishment, if you're upset with what they've done.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: レーシングカーは、裏通りを縫うようにして走っていった。
ex_1_en: The race car sped, weaving through the side streets.
meaning_story: A backside street (or "avenue") is a street that's not a main street... it's hidden and behind everything, making it an alley.
reading_story: The reading is 裏 and 通り put together into one word.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: どうやら、武装勢力に襲われたようだ。
ex_1_en: It seems that they were attacked by armed insurgents.
meaning_story: The most important part of your military attire are your arms (not the ones attached to your body, your guns and stuff). Arms are what make you a real military person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 鹿児島の桜島の火山の噴火で、近くの街は灰だらけになってしまいました。
ex_1_en: The Sakurajima volcano eruption in Kagoshima covered a nearby city with ash.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 念のため灰皿を買っておきました。
ex_1_en: I bought an ashtray just in case.
meaning_story: An ash plate is a plate you use for ashes. That's an ashtray.
reading_story: The reading is the two vocab words, 灰 and 皿, put together.
pitch_accent: ハイザラ *** ハイザꜜラ

ex_1_jp: 彼のことは好きなんだけど、服装があまり好きじゃないのよね。
ex_1_en: I like him, but I don’t like any of his clothes.
meaning_story: Your clothes which attire you is your attire. It's how you dress.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: もうすっかり春の装いだね。
ex_1_en: You’re already in a spring dress.
meaning_story: This looks like it's an adjective, but it's just a tricky word. It's a noun, and it means the same thing as the kanji, making it attire.
reading_story: "Yo, so, you gonna wear that attire today or what?"
pitch_accent: ヨソオイ *** ヨソオꜜイ

ex_1_jp: なんと私の姉もその本の著者でした。
ex_1_en: Surprisingly, my sister was the author of that book too.
meaning_story: Someone who is an author is an author.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女の家には隠された裏口があるという彼の話は、信憑性を増した。
ex_1_en: His story that there is a secret backdoor to her house grew in credibility.
meaning_story: The backside mouth (think: entrance) is the back door or rear entrance.
reading_story: The reading is 裏 and 口 put together into one word.

ex_1_jp: 私の紹介はパンフレットの裏表紙に記されています。
ex_1_en: My profile can be found on the back page of this pamphlet.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji as well.

ex_1_jp: 奴らは裏切り者を殺すのにこの施設を利用している。
ex_1_en: They use this facility to kill traitors.
meaning_story: From the backside you cut someone. Wow. What a jerk. What a backstab.
reading_story: This word is 裏 and 切る's readings, put together.
pitch_accent: ウラキ°リ *** ウラキ°リꜜ

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: この体操は見た目よりもずっときついんですよ。
ex_1_en: This exercise is actually a lot harder than it looks.
meaning_story: Take your body and manipulate it around for exercise. This is Calisthenics or gymnastics.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私の兄は、女の子は結婚するまで操を守るべきだって言うの。
ex_1_en: My brother says that girls should preserve their virginity until marriage.
meaning_story: This takes the second meaning of the kanji you learned, chastity.
reading_story: Who is doing the chastity thing, keeping her virginity? That missa, oh, yes she is.

ex_1_jp: 昨日その熟語を学んだところです。
ex_1_en: I just learned that compound word yesterday.
meaning_story: Ripened languages are words that have taken some time to come into their form. They ripened up, starting with just one kanji, but then became two, or three, or more. That is a compound word or compound kanji. You know that "jukugo" thing I talk about so much? That's this!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 皇太子殿下に「うまくいくといいですね」と言った。
ex_1_en: I told the crown prince that I hope things work out for him.
meaning_story: The emperor's fat child is the crown prince, not because he's fat, but because he's the emperor's child.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: その女優はダイエット中であることを否定した。
ex_1_en: The actress denied that she was on a diet.
meaning_story: No! I will not determine that. I refuse. I am in denial.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は砂漠探索の経験が豊富です。
ex_1_en: I have a lot of experience in exploring the desert.
meaning_story: A sand desert is just a desert.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 異義がある人は手をあげてください。
ex_1_en: People with different opinions, please raise your hands.
meaning_story: My idea of righteousness is different from yours. Really, it's just a different meaning.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 変装教室にギリギリ間に合いました。
ex_1_en: I made it to the disguise class at the last minute.
meaning_story: Change your attire to look like someone else. This is a disguise.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その本の編集者として任命されてから、過労気味です。
ex_1_en: Since being designated as editor of the book, I’ve been feeling overworked.
meaning_story: An edit is 編集. Someone who does those edits is an editor!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the readings from 編集 should help you.

ex_1_jp: 天皇陛下に「プラス思考であれば、何でも最後にはうまくいきますよ」なんて助言した奴は一体どこの誰だ？
ex_1_en: Who is the guy who gave the Emperor of Japan the advice to be optimistic and that everything would turn out right in the end?
meaning_story: The Japanese emperor is supposed to have come from the heavens, so that just makes this heaven emperor the emperor of Japan.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just have to remember that 皇 is read as のう here. You just found out you can never be the Emperor of Japan because you aren't Japanese. NOOOOOOOOOOOOO~ (のう).

ex_1_jp: どうやってそんなにピアスの穴を拡張したの？
ex_1_en: How did you expand your ear piercing hole that much?
meaning_story: Go ahead and extend it and stretch it. That's how we'll do this enlargement.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Of course, just to be dirty, the people who made up this word decided to use a kanji that read as かく. Dirty old monks that could see the future and speak English, ugh.

ex_1_jp: 今日は電気制御装置の使い方を学びました。
ex_1_en: I learned how to use a electrical control unit today.
meaning_story: This attire is put inside this equipment, where it's changed into something else. This attire device is strange and interesting. Imagine something that it does to your attire.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は厄介な仕事をうまくやってのけた…あることを除いて、だが。
ex_1_en: She managed to do well on those tricky jobs... except for that.
meaning_story: 除く is "to exclude." This is the te-form, and it means "except." So, something like "please get everything except broccoli," because who wants broccoli?
reading_story: The reading comes from 除く. It's just the te-form of it.

ex_1_jp: 私達の子どもはあなたの子と違って、忠実に言うことを聞くんです。
ex_1_en: Our kids loyally do what they’re told, unlike yours.
meaning_story: I have loyalty to you, so I always tell you the truth. I am very faithful and devoted to you!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: うわっ最悪。さっき買った高級小麦粉、電車に忘れちゃった。
ex_1_en: Oh no. I left the expensive flour I just bought on the train.
meaning_story: 麦粉 is "wheat flour." So, a really small version of wheat flour is one that isn't so whole grainy and big. If you make wheat flour small enough, it becomes regular old flour.
reading_story: The 小 portion uses a secondary kun'yomi reading for it. Just think about how "small" things are like "children" (子), which is why it's こ. The other readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, so besides that you should be a-ok!

ex_1_jp: 私の貨物船の中で騒ぐんじゃない！
ex_1_en: Don’t roughhouse in my freighter!
meaning_story: A freight things ship is a boat that freights things. It's a freighter.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The 物 takes its もつ reading, which makes sense since it sounds like 持つ, which is "to hold." What is this freighter doing? It's holding freight! So, that's how you can remember that bit.

ex_1_jp: ブドウ糖果糖液糖は体に悪いって言うじゃない？
ex_1_en: It’s said that high-fructose corn syrup isn’t good for you, right?
meaning_story: A fruit sugar is the type of sugar that's more commonly known as fructose. Mmm, delicious fructose.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 諸君、Tofuguオフィスで独身の 10 人がみんな集まるのってこれがたぶん最後だってこと、気がついていたかい？
ex_1_en: My friends, do you realize this is probably the last time we’ll all be here in the Tofugu office as ten single people?
meaning_story: My various buddies! Wait, that didn't come out right. Gentlemen! My friends! There we go, much better.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その左利きの投手は、大リーグで華々しいデビューを飾りました。
ex_1_en: That left‐handed pitcher made a brilliant major league debut.
meaning_story: 華やか is "showy." Now we're doubling it, making it doubly showy. If you make something showy enough, it becomes gorgeous, but it also becomes pretty flamboyant. So, so, so flamboyant.
reading_story: The reading comes from 華やか. Note the second はな becomes ばな, to be はなばなしい.

ex_1_jp: 墓場の隣に住んだら、お化けがドアをノックすることもあるかもしれない。
ex_1_en: If you live next to a cemetery, ghosts might knock on your door.
meaning_story: A grave location is a place where there are graves. It is a graveyard, or cemetery.
reading_story: The reading for 場 is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, but 墓 is read as はか here. Here's a mnemonic to help you out. When you're finally dead and buried in a graveyard, your one wish is for the New Zealand All Blacks to do the Haka (はか) over your grave. If you don't know what the haka is, look it up, it's pretty neat.

ex_1_jp: この灰色のお守りは、悪い気を追い払ってくれます。
ex_1_en: This gray charm drives out evil spirits.
meaning_story: Ash color tends to be a kind of gray color, wouldn't you say? That makes this word gray (or grey, depending on where you're from).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの女が私に敬語を使わないなんて、本当に屈辱的だわ。
ex_1_en: It’s so humiliating that she never uses honorifics with me.
meaning_story: Respect language is what you speak to someone you respect and want to elevate. You can do this using this type of Japanese, which is known as honorific language.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: フグが私にどんな扱いをしてたか考えてみると、彼がどれぐだけ最低男だったかが分かるわ。私は彼の家賃から電話代から食費から何から何まで払ってあげていたのに、あの男は私に浮気してたのよ！
ex_1_en: When I think about the way Fugu treated me, I realized that he was a real jerk. I paid his rent, phone bills, groceries, and everything, but he ended up cheating on me!
meaning_story: Your house rent is your house rent, though it can be your apartment rent too.
reading_story: The reading for 家 is an exceptional one. It is や, because when your landlord asks if you paid your rent, you always say yah (や), whether you did or not.

ex_1_jp: 時々電車は、皇族専用の駅に特別に止まることがあります。
ex_1_en: Trains sometimes make an unscheduled stop at a special station for the Imperial Family.
meaning_story: The emperor's tribe is his family. This family is known as the imperial family.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 皇室はここ最近、かなり大変な状況に陥っています。
ex_1_en: The Imperial household has been going through a very difficult time lately.
meaning_story: The emperor's room is more than just a room. It's quite big and nice and luxurious. It is the imperial palace.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「いつも何してるの？」「毎日一日中物真似の練習をしてるよ。」
ex_1_en: "What do you do everyday?" "I practice impersonations all day, every day."
meaning_story: 真似 is "impersonation." Actually, this word is too. It's also impersonation.
reading_story: The reading is 物 plus 真似 put together.

ex_1_jp: お姫様は美しい宝石のついた指輪を時計回りに回しました。
ex_1_en: The princess turned the beautiful jeweled ring clockwise.
meaning_story: A treasure stone is a very valuable stone. What kind of stones are considered treasures? How about a jewel?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. You may not remember the せき reading for 石 (it's the on'yomi), so to help you to remember, just think about how sexy (せき) it is to give a loved one a jewel... at least that's what the jewel shops want you to think, but we won't go there.

ex_1_jp: お地蔵さんの頭がへこんでるよ。
ex_1_en: The head of Jizou is dented.
meaning_story: The ground storehouse refers to a person's name. It may be easier to learn this one reading first because of that. Anyways, this person is Jizo(u), a Bodhisattva, and protector of children. You can read about him here.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: スーパーの散らし、ここに置いてなかった？
ex_1_en: Don’t you leave supermarket fliers here?
meaning_story: What do people usually scatter in a rush (らし)? Leaflets and flyers. Handing them out takes way too much time, so if you just scatter them all over the place your job will be done so much faster!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the 散る, so you should be able to read it already!

ex_1_jp: 肺気胸は日本ではイケメン病としても知られている。
ex_1_en: Pulmonary pneumothorax is also known as handsome guy disease in Japan.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. OH HAI THERE LUNG. OH HAI THERE YOU.

ex_1_jp: 君の辛さはすごく分かるよ。僕も肺がんなんだ。
ex_1_en: I really understand what you’re going through because I also have lung cancer.
meaning_story: 肺 is lung, がん is "cancer," I suppose because you want it gone (がん) from you. That makes this word lung cancer, which, with all the smoking in Japan, happens a decent amount.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 肺病の治療のために、三日後に入院するんです。
ex_1_en: I’ll be hospitalized in three days to treat my lung disease.
meaning_story: A lung sickness is bad for those lungs of yours. It means you have lung disease.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この雑誌の表紙のインターバル撮影された写真すごい好きかも。
ex_1_en: I really like the time-lapse photography on this magazine’s cover.
meaning_story: Random magazine is pretty much all magazines. Just a bunch of random stuff inside, making it a magazine.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 毎日七時に仕事を終え、筋肉を鍛えるために帰り道にジムに寄ります。
ex_1_en: I leave work at 7 p.m. every day and then stop by the gym on my way home to develop my muscles.
meaning_story: Your muscle meat is your muscle.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私の記憶が正しければ、これは国宝ではありません。
ex_1_en: If I remember correctly, this is not a national treasure.
meaning_story: A country's treasure is their national treasure.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: いな, いいえ, いえ, いや
ex_1_jp: そのビデオを見るか否か、まだ決めきれていない。
ex_1_en: I haven’t decided if I’ll watch the video or not yet.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Instead of saying "no" you say "na," and instead of saying "na" you say いな. It's also commonly used for just about every way to say "no" like いいえ and いや, so as long as you know how to say no, you know this reading!

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 俺も昔は未熟で好き勝手してたよ。
ex_1_en: I used to be immature and I did whatever I wanted too.
meaning_story: Not yet ripened, means you haven't really come into form yet. It means you're not yet good at something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ミジュク *** ミꜜジュク

ex_1_jp: 開閉時刻の変更は、小さな混乱と誤解を招いた。
ex_1_en: Changing the opening and closing times caused a little bit of confusion and misunderstanding.
meaning_story: Opened and closed things are opening and closing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 他人にスマフォの遠隔操作を可能にさせるバックドアを発見しました。
ex_1_en: Someone found a backdoor that enables remote operation of your smartphone.
meaning_story: If you manipulate the things you make, you are in operation of said things.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今日は異性といつもより長く話しをしました。
ex_1_en: Today, I talked to a person of the opposite sex longer than usual.
meaning_story: If someone differs in gender to you then they are of the opposite sex.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 五日以内にその製品を納入して頂きたいのですが、可能でしょうか。
ex_1_en: I’d like to receive payment within five days, is that possible?
meaning_story: When you enter your supply into the machine, that is your payment for the day. Every day you have to enter your supply, otherwise they crack down on you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼のお気に入りのアイドルが、年末に引退するって宣言したから、彼も他のファンもショックを受けちゃってるのよ。
ex_1_en: His favorite idol shocked him and other fans by announcing that she will retire at the end of this year.
meaning_story: You proclaim things by saying them. This is a proclamation or declaration.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの広告宣伝費はいくらぐらいですか。
ex_1_en: How much money does Tofugu spend on advertising?
meaning_story: All the things the leader proclaims is transmitted to the people. It's all propaganda, which is why you transmit it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: なんでタトゥーで冷蔵庫なんて彫ったの？
ex_1_en: Why did you get a tattoo that says refrigerator?
meaning_story: A cool storehouse storage is a place you put things (like food) to keep them cool. This is a refrigerator.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今朝新聞で上院は議案を否決したって読んだよ。
ex_1_en: I read that the senate rejected the bill in the newspaper this morning.
meaning_story: "No" is the decision I've made. Sorry, but this is rejection.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 親馬鹿かもしれませんが、娘の英語力の上達が著しい気がするんですよね。
ex_1_en: I know I am a doting parent, but I think there has been remarkable improvement in my daughter’s English skills.
meaning_story: The kanji means author, but if you think about it, what do authors do? They write about remarkable or marked things, whether it's fiction or nonfiction.
reading_story: Something is so remarkable you let out one jeer (いちじる) at the opposing team. Just one, because you're not that mean.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 友人が賃貸のアパートを探してるんですが、どこかいい物件を知りませんかね。
ex_1_en: My friend is looking for an apartment to rent, don’t you know any good places?
meaning_story: Rent it and I will lend it to you. This thing that is being lent and rented? It's a rental.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just have to remember that 貸 is read as たい for this one. What is your rental? It is a tie (たい) fighter. Sweet.

ex_1_jp: 彼の事、知れば知る程尊敬するのよね。
ex_1_en: The more I know him, the more I respect him.
meaning_story: You are revered and you have my respect. This is respect.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 息子に、「命ってどれくらい尊いの？」なんて聞かれちゃってさ。言葉に窮しちゃったよ。
ex_1_en: My son asked me something like, "How precious is life?" I had difficulty answering him.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of revered? It's also revered!
reading_story: You are revered because of your Toe toe, which is a toe on your toe. It's weird, but people seem to like it.
pitch_accent: タットꜜイ *** トートꜜイ

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 成熟した女性の脳と成熟した男性の脳の相違点について、論文を書いています。
ex_1_en: I’m writing a paper about the differences between the mature female brain and the mature male brain.
meaning_story: To become ripe(n) is to ripen and mature.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 泥棒になるためのトレーニングは、ブートキャンプ並にハードです。
ex_1_en: The training to become a burglar is as hard as boot camp.
meaning_story: I don't know why a mud pole is a robber, but for some reason it is. Just imagine a robber covering himself in mud and standing behind a pole to hide, then jump out, then rob you of everything you've got.
reading_story: The reading is 泥 plus the reading for 棒 put together.

ex_1_jp: 小さい頃、あなたとビーチで作った砂のお城を思い出します。
ex_1_en: It reminds me of the sand castle that you and I made on beach when we were little.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you walk around on the beach, you'll get sand in your shoes sooner (すな) or later.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: もしうちに泊まりたいなら、簡易ベッドがあるよ。
ex_1_en: If you want to sleep over at our place, we have a cot.
meaning_story: It has simplicity and is easy. Whatever it is, it is simple and easy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: iPadはノートパソコンよりも持ち運びが簡単です。
ex_1_en: iPads are easier to carry around than laptops.
meaning_story: Simplicity is simple, making this simple as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 珈琲メーカーからの蒸気でやけどをしちゃった。
ex_1_en: I was burned by the steam from a coffee machine.
meaning_story: Steam energy is steam or vapor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私の部屋にはあまり収納スペースがないので、ちょっとした工夫が必要です。
ex_1_en: There isn’t much space to store things in my room, so it requires a little ingenuity.
meaning_story: When you obtain supply, you have to put it all together somewhere. You have to put it in storage.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「営業時間は何時から何時までですか？」「午前10時開店で、午後8時閉店となります。」
ex_1_en: "What are your business hours?" "We are open from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m."
meaning_story: A closed shop is when a store's status is store closed or closed store.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今、蔵の掃除をしているんです。
ex_1_en: We are cleaning our storehouse now.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the other storehouse reading (倉) you learned earlier. They're both basically the same thing, and lucky for you they share the same reading too (くら).

ex_1_jp: ブラウンシュガーは日本語では粗糖と呼ばれ、黒砂糖とは区別されます。
ex_1_en: Brown sugar is called sotou in Japanese and it’s different from muscovado sugar.
meaning_story: A sand sugar is just sugar. Nom nom nom, sugar.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: さっきも言ったけど、珈琲は無糖派なの。
ex_1_en: As I told you earlier, I drink black coffee.
meaning_story: Something with not sugar is something that is sugar free or unsweetened.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ジョギングをしてる時に筋を痛めちゃってさ。
ex_1_en: I pulled a muscle when I was jogging.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, at least on the tendon side of things.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You get a horrible tendon injury, making it so you can't walk anymore. You're so upset that you blame it on jesus. So, you go and sue jesus for this tendon injury, and win in court, amazingly.

ex_1_jp: 窓口の仕事ではあったが、彼女はその面接をとてもうまくこなした。
ex_1_en: She really aced the job interview even though it was just for a ticket window position.
meaning_story: A window mouth is where you go to buy tickets out of the window. You know how there's those windows with holes in them, or the window is the hole itself? That's the kind of ticket window I'm talking about.
reading_story: The reading is the readings for 窓 and the reading for 口.

ex_1_jp: 彼女に裏切られて落ち込んでいるんです。
ex_1_en: She betrayed me and I’m feeling depressed.
meaning_story: If you cut someone from the backside you're doing a backstabbing, making this word to backstab or to betray.
reading_story: The reading is 裏 plus 切る put together into one word.

ex_1_jp: この靴、可愛いんだけど、足が蒸れて臭うんだよね。
ex_1_en: These shoes look cute, but they make my feet sweaty and stinky.
meaning_story: If something is steaming, it makes the room all humid, making this word to be humid (because you're not doing the humiding).
reading_story: What is making things to be humid? That would be that cow. Every time he says, "Moo" (む) he spurts out a ton of steam making the room all humid.

ex_1_jp: 「今朝は4時から起きてるよ。」「嘘でしょ？いったい何してるの？」「えっと…家を大掃除してるの。」
ex_1_en: "I’ve been awake since four this morning." "No way! What have you been doing?" "Well, just cleaning around the house."
meaning_story: 掃除 is cleaning, so the verb version would be to clean.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, it'll help to know the word 掃除 as well.

ex_1_jp: 旦那がペットボトルのキャップを閉める時、キツく締めすぎるのが嫌です。
ex_1_en: I hate when my husband twists the caps back on plastic bottles really tightly.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means closed so the verb vocab version is to close.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you are going to close the door on anyone, it's probably going to be Charlie Sheen, because really, Charlie Sheen.

ex_1_jp: あの娘が涎を垂らしながら一服しているブルドッグの絵を描いたんだけど、それがすっごく可愛くってさ。
ex_1_en: She drew a picture of a bulldog drooling while napping and it was really cute.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dangle so the verb vocab version is to dangle or to dangle something. You're doing the dangling.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What are you dangling? You're dangling a taco in front of a hungry person. He just wants the taco, and you keep dangling it like that.

ex_1_jp: それぞれの薬には、異なる副作用があります。
ex_1_en: Each medicine has varying side effects.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means differ so the verb vocab version is to differ.
reading_story: Look at your coat (こと), now look at mine. They are different. If you look at them, they are going to differ.

ex_1_jp: あなたを愛しています。僕にはあなたが必要なんです。太陽さん、どうか僕の濡れたシャツを今すぐ乾かしてくれませんか？お願いします！！！
ex_1_en: I love you so much. I need you. Could you please dry my wet shirts right now, Mr. Sun? Please!!!!
meaning_story: 乾く is "to be dried." This is the version where you're doing the drying, making this to dry something.
reading_story: The reading comes from 乾く.

ex_1_jp: 今オフィスで資料の要約を編集しているところよ。
ex_1_en: I’m editing a document summary in the office right now.
meaning_story: 編集 is edit, so the verb version is to edit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 薄暗い部屋の床に、血が静かに拡がっていった。
ex_1_en: Blood was silently spreading on the floor in a dim room.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means extend so the verb vocab version is to extend.
reading_story: Does the kanji look familiar, kind of like 広い, perhaps? This word shares the same reading as 広い, and the meanings are kind of similar too! That means 拡がる is read as ひろがる.

ex_1_jp: 妻が、今日は早目に仕事を切り上げて犬の散歩をしてほしいと言っているのですが、よろしいでしょうか。
ex_1_en: My wife wants me to leave work early and take the dog for a walk today. Is it okay with you?
meaning_story: 散歩 is "a walk." Make that into a verb and you have to go for a walk or to go for a stroll.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 散歩 as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本人の中には、不幸や悪霊を追い払うために玄関先に塩を盛る人がいます。
ex_1_en: Some Japanese people heap up salt on their doorsteps to drive away misfortune and evil sprits.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means heaps, so the verb vocab version is to heap up. It can also mean to serve food, as in you're heaping on food onto someone's plate.
reading_story: Please keep heaping up the food. I want more (もる), more, more.

ex_1_jp: 彼は今は幸せに暮らしているが、ああ見えて苦難を経験してるんだぜ。
ex_1_en: He is living a happy life now, but he actually experienced a lot of hardships.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means livelihood. The verb version is to live. It's not really "to live" literally, though. It's more like to live one's life, rather than just to live.
reading_story: If anyone is going to live one's life, it's gotta be the great Kublai Khan (く). He conquered most of the world and was super badass.

ex_1_jp: クマが裏でみんなを操っている黒幕だっていう噂があるんだ。
ex_1_en: There is a rumor that Kuma manipulates everyone behind the scenes.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means manipulate, so the verb vocab version is to manipulate.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A guy using eye arts (あやつ) isn't a great guy, it's the type of guy who might try to manipulate you via hypnosis of the eyes.

ex_1_jp: そろそろ桃が熟れる頃だ。
ex_1_en: It’s about the time of year for peaches to ripen.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ripen so the verb vocab version is to ripen.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If something starts to ripen too much, it gets all gross, and you're all like, "ew (う), that's gross."

ex_1_jp: 私の部屋には脱ぎっぱなしの服が床に散らかっています。掃除しても、次の日にはまたすぐ散らかしちゃうんだよね。
ex_1_en: There are dirty clothes scattered all over the floor in my room. Even if I cleaned them up, it would just get messy again the next day.
meaning_story: 散る is "to be scattered." This is when you're doing the scattering. You know that because you're causing a ruckus (らかす) from all the scattering of money you're doing, down on the people below.
reading_story: The reading of the 散 comes from 散る. So, go ahead and scatter more memories around your brain, you got this already.

ex_1_jp: ごめん。いま手が離せないんだ。後でかけ直してもいいかな？
ex_1_en: Sorry, I’m in the middle of something. I’ll call you back. Okay?
meaning_story: Remember how 離れる is "to separate," where something is just separating and you're not doing the separating? Well, this one has the same meaning, but now you're doing the separating. This word is 離す, and you know that you're doing the separating because if you don't, that person will sue (す) you for grabbing onto them and not letting go.
reading_story: The reading comes from 離れる.

ex_1_jp: そのワンピには絶対デニムのジャケットが似合うと思うよ。
ex_1_en: I think a denim jacket would totally match your dress.
meaning_story: It resembles you! It suits you! Wow, your good looks really cause this scarf to suit you, you know?
reading_story: The reading is from 似る and 合う, put together.

ex_1_jp: 血税の使い道が理にかなってさえいれば、政府に税金を納めるのは私は一向に構いませんよ。
ex_1_en: I don’t mind paying the tax to the government as long as they spend it on reasonable things.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means supply so the verb version is to supply.
reading_story: So you're supplying something... let's say nuclear warheads... to Osama Bin Laden. You gonna be in soooo much trouble, especially since it's zombie Osama Bin Laden.

ex_1_jp: 23歳の新入社員は82歳のCEOと結婚して、一緒に仕事をする人全員を驚かした。
ex_1_en: The 23 year old new recruit surprised everyone who works with him by marrying the 82 year old CEO.
meaning_story: Remember how 驚く is "to be surprised"? This is when you are surprising someone else, doing the surprising, making this word to surprise or to shock.
reading_story: The reading comes from 驚く. Don't be surprised if you remember the reading of this word because of your past knowledges.

ex_1_jp: 宝をどこに隠したんだ？
ex_1_en: Where did you hide the treasure?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Treasure is very expensive (高/たか). And, all this nice treasure? It's going to go to the Egyptian Sun God, Ra, making this an expensive Ra treasure, a Takara, if you will.

ex_1_jp: うちの学校は本当に野暮だから、生徒たちのソーシャルメディアの利用を禁止してるんだよ。
ex_1_en: Our school is so stupid that they ban the use of social media by students.
meaning_story: A field of livelihood is so lively! Look at everything jumping around. It is so fresh and new and awesome! That being said, being so lively and fresh and new, it's pretty unrefined and rustic.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 科学者は、宇宙はある巨大な掃除機だと言うでしょ？だったら、それをカーペットを掃除するのに使ったらいいんじゃない？？
ex_1_en: Scientists say that space is one giant vacuum, right? So why don’t we just use that to clean our carpets?
meaning_story: A cleaning (掃除) machine is a vacuum cleaner. Suck that dirt up!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 漠然とした不安を感じながら、私は川の流れを見詰めていました。
ex_1_en: While I was looking at the flow of the river I had a vague feeling of anxiety.
meaning_story: Something with a vague nature is also quite vague.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 各出席者の方に、まず諸書類をお配り致します。
ex_1_en: We are going to pass out various documents to each person present first.
meaning_story: This has the same meaning as the kanji. Stick this onto another word and you have "various _____."
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji as well.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ロケットは垂直に発射した。
ex_1_en: The rocket took off vertically.
meaning_story: Something is dangling in front of you, so you fix it so it's straight and not moving. It becomes perfectly vertical, perpendicular to the floor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この窓は何で作られているんですか。
ex_1_en: What’s this window made of?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は少なくとも五十は著作があります。
ex_1_en: She has no less than 50 books published.
meaning_story: The things an author makes is writing and other bits of authorship.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 写真を拡大した時に、彼氏の鼻毛が出てることを発見しちゃったんだよね。どん引きだったわ。
ex_1_en: I enlarged the photo and found out my boyfriend’s nose hairs were sticking out. I was turned off.
meaning_story: Extend the lens nice and big to zoom in on the subject, please.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 新しい純毛のセーター、チクチクして痒いんだよね。
ex_1_en: My new all-wool sweater prickles and makes me itchy.
meaning_story: Something that is pure fur is pure fur... but what kind of fur? In this case it's wool, making this mean all wool.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私の弟は、京王沿線に住んでいます。
ex_1_en: My brother is living along the Keio Line.
meaning_story: To run alongside the line (referring to the train line) means along the train line. What's along the train line? All kinds of things if you look carefully.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 委員会から承認を得られる自信はあまりありません。
ex_1_en: I don’t have enough confidence to get approval from the committee.
meaning_story: I recognize your consent. It is approval of what I'm doing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: カウンターの上に「チップ大歓迎」と書かれた箱がありましたよ。
ex_1_en: I saw a box on the counter that had "tips welcome" written on it.
meaning_story: It is a delight that you come so I welcome you. This delight welcome is a welcome.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 餡こは小豆から作られているが、けっこう糖分が高い。
ex_1_en: Adzuki bean paste is made of adzuki beans, but it’s pretty high in sugar.
meaning_story: Small beans refer to a type of bean known as azuki beans. It will help if you've heard of this delicious popular bean, because there's not really anything effective we can do with the meaning mnemonic from this point on. Just know that small beans are azuki beans.
reading_story: The reading doesn't make sense either. If you know that small beans are azuki beans, then you know that this is referring to a thing known as azuki (あずき). Other than that, there's not much else to do.

ex_1_jp: 幕府が俺の家族を皆殺しにした。
ex_1_en: The bakufu slaughtered my family.
meaning_story: A government behind a curtain is the bakufu. They didn't let anyone know their government secrets so they would hide behind that curtain and keep everything to themselves.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 幕 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you try to peek through the bakufu's curtain you'll only see someone's back (ばく). They all huddle together to discuss things so a row of hunched backs is all you'll get out of the shogunate. That's not helpful.

ex_1_jp: お豆さん、お豆さん、魔法の野菜。たくさん食べれば食べるほど、たくさん屁が出るぷっぷぷぷ。たくさんぷっぷぷ屁が出れば、気持ちが良くなるウッフフフ。だから毎食お豆を食べなさい。
ex_1_en: Beans, beans the magical fruit, the more you eat, the more you toot, the more you toot, the better you feel, so eat some beans at every meal.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: You want your beans, but you're also super lazy, so you call for your mom, yelling: "MAMEYYYYY, MAMMMEEYYY!" (まめ).

ex_1_jp: 「この牛丼は、私のおごりね。」「わあ、ありがとう。じゃあ、お言葉に甘えます。」
ex_1_en: "This beef bowl is my treat." "Oh, thank you. I’ll take you up on that."
meaning_story: A cow rice bowl is a bowl of rice covered in beef, making it a beef bowl. Go get some Yoshinoya.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 聖書を半分ぐらい読み終わりました。
ex_1_en: I’m halfway through the bible.
meaning_story: The holy writing is the bible.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お紅茶はどのようにおいれ致しましょうか。
ex_1_en: How do you like your black tea?
meaning_story: A deep red tea isn't a deep red tea... it's a black tea. If you think about it, a lot of black tea is really deep red, which is why a deep red tea is a black tea instead.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は血液型がB型の人が苦手です。
ex_1_en: I don’t like people whose blood type is B.
meaning_story: Your blood fluid type is your blood type. This is a very important thing to know in Japan for some reason.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, at least the 血液 part. The 型 uses the kun'yomi reading, probably because it's an add-on word.

ex_1_jp: 枝は真っ赤な林檎でたわんでいた。
ex_1_en: The branches were bent by blood red apples.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This tree consists of many branches. This particular branch, the one you're looking at, is Eだ. Those others are other letters, but this is E...だ.

ex_1_jp: 彼女の右の小指の爪の長さはなんと六メートルもあります。
ex_1_en: Her right pinky nail is six meters long.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though it adds a few more meanings as well, like nail or talon or hoof or really any hard thing on the ends of fingers or feet.
reading_story: The reading takes the second 爪 reading, つめ.

ex_1_jp: 今度の日曜日にヨットで沿岸を一緒に帆走しないかって彼に誘われたんだ。
ex_1_en: He asked me to sail along the coast in his yacht with him this Sunday.
meaning_story: The run alongside coast basically just describes the coast.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 沿海部での生活について、月一でコラムを書いてみませんか。
ex_1_en: Would you like to write a monthly column about life in coastal areas?
meaning_story: The run alongside sea is the sea that runs alongside the land, making it the coastal waters aka the coast.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: すごく暑かったので、喜劇を観ながらずっと自分をうちわで扇いでいました。
ex_1_en: It was so hot that I kept fanning myself while watching the comedy show.
meaning_story: Rejoice drama isn't so much drama as it is comedy, since it makes you rejoice.
reading_story: The readings are the on'yomi readings. You didn't learn the on'yomi reading for 喜 yet, so here's a way to remember it: Just think about how the key (き) to comedy is funny things that make you rejoice.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: アメリカ軍を指揮している司令官に一度会ってみたいな。
ex_1_en: I’d like to meet the commanding officer of the American army.
meaning_story: Take your finger and brandish it to command the troops.
reading_story: The readings are the on'yomi readings, so if you know those you may take command of this vocab word.

ex_1_jp: 通勤は時間を浪費するので、私は職場の近くに住む方がいいですね。
ex_1_en: Commuting can eat up a lot of time, so I prefer to live near my office.
meaning_story: The things you pass through on your way to work are the things you see and run into during your commute.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: わしの娘がお前と結婚することは承知できん。
ex_1_en: I can’t consent to your marrying my daughter.
meaning_story: You consent and know everything that's going on. You consent and know about all this.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ステンレスは腐食作用への耐久性があるんじゃなかったっけ？
ex_1_en: Stainless steel is supposed to withstand the corrosion, isn’t it?
meaning_story: When something rots and eats away at something, that is corrosion. Not a good thing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あいつら、人込みに紛れて俺に浣腸しようとしてやがるんだ。お前らは俺を守ってくれるよなあ？
ex_1_en: They’re going to try and shove their fingers up my butt in the crowd. You guys are gonna protect me, right?
meaning_story: You know that 込む means "to be crowded" so when you are crowded with people... well... you have a crowd of people.
reading_story: The reading comes from 人 and 込む combined together into one. Just keep in mind that the こ from 込み changes to ご and you'll be fine.

ex_1_jp: その劇では、女主人公が死んで幕が下りました。
ex_1_en: In the play, the curtain came down when the heroine passed away.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck.

ex_1_jp: トラックの衝突で積荷がダメージを受けたが、小さな損害で済んだ。
ex_1_en: The truck crash damaged the cargo, but it was only minor damage.
meaning_story: Your loss comes from damage done to you. This is damage.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 多くの人々が腐敗した政治組織にうんざりしています。
ex_1_en: Many people are tired of the corrupt political ring.
meaning_story: The rot failure is when something rots and fails itself away. It disappears. It is decomposition or decay.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その紅色の花の名前は何ですか？
ex_1_en: What’s the name of the dark red flower?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: A dark red color isn't your favorite color, it is Benny's (べに) favorite color. If you know someone named Benny, it will help. For the secondary reading, think if you see so much 紅 color (like blood, right?) you know that the person is going to die. You know that there is no cure, aka cure ない (くれない). Get it?
pitch_accent: クレナイ *** クレꜜナイ *** クレナꜜイ *** ベꜜニ

ex_1_jp: ポーカーで五百ドル損をした。
ex_1_en: I had a loss of $500 in poker.
meaning_story: A loss will give you a disadvantage and handicap. So, try not to get any losses... or you'll be at a disadvantage.
reading_story: The reading comes from the kanji, so you aren't at a disadvantage... this time.

ex_1_jp: 私にとって、使い捨てカイロは冬には無くてはならないものです。
ex_1_en: For me, disposable pocket warmers are indispensable in winter.
meaning_story: After you use it you throw away it, making whatever it is you used a disposable item.
reading_story: The reading comes from 使う and 捨てる, combined into one.

ex_1_jp: 隣の席の人が劇の最中にずっと指をポキポキ鳴らしてて、すっごく苛々しました。
ex_1_en: The person next to me was constantly cracking their knuckles during the show and it was so annoying.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well (drama). Can also mean play or show as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji. No more drama from you, okay?

ex_1_jp: 応援してるチームが劇的なさよならホームランで勝利を納めた時、思わずウルッときてしまいました。
ex_1_en: I got tears in my eyes when my favorite team won the game with a dramatic home run.
meaning_story: Something that is drama al is dramatic.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 練習の後、劇団員はみんな汗だくだった。
ex_1_en: All of the drama troupe members were sweating after practice.
meaning_story: A drama group is a drama troupe.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 宝くじが当たってから、奴は数週間最高の気分を味わったんだ。
ex_1_en: After winning the lottery, that dude was on a high for weeks.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Some dude... he did it two times. yah, two (やつ) times. This can seem kind of derogatory, if you say it the wrong way. But as long as you're duding to your dude friends and not your no-dude boss, you should be a-okay to dude-bro it up!

ex_1_jp: 「じゃあね、たまには連絡してね。」「もちろん。てか、近いうちにうなぎ丼でも食べに行こうよ。」「いいね。」「よかった。じゃあ、また連絡するね。」「ええ、またね。」
ex_1_en: "Take care and call me once in a while." "Of course. Let’s go eat eel rice bowls soon." "Sounds good." "Okay. I’ll get in touch with you." "Yeah, see you later."
meaning_story: An unagi rice bowl is an eel bowl, and it is very good.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 震源地に近いところに住んでる友達が心配だよ。
ex_1_en: I’m worried about my friends who live close to the epicenter.
meaning_story: The earthquake origin ground is where the earthquake started from. It is the epicenter.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: そのサバンの男は群衆の規模を534人と推定したのだが、実際の数とピッタリ当っていた。
ex_1_en: The guy, who is a savant, estimated the scope of the crowd to have 534 people and he was exactly right.
meaning_story: I will determine what you are inferring via an estimate.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 分かってもらえることを願って、言い訳を書いたEメールを送りました。
ex_1_en: I sent her an explanation email and I hope she can understand.
meaning_story: You say a reason for your actions, but really it's just an excuse.
reading_story: The reading is 言う and 訳 combined.

ex_1_jp: 子どもがもうちょっと大きくなるまでは、常勤でのお仕事はちょっと無理かな。
ex_1_en: I won’t be able to work full-time for now until my child gets a little older.
meaning_story: Normal work is work you do all day long, 8-hours a day, 5 days a week. That is full time employment or full time.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうして娼婦やホステス、キャバ嬢、芸者さんなどが使う偽名を「源氏名」って言うんですか？
ex_1_en: Why is the fake name for prostitutes, hostesses, and geisha’s called a "Genji name?"
meaning_story: The origin family name is the original dude. The original dude comes from the original and first novel ever written, the Tale of Genji. These kanji represent Genji, good ol' Genji. Perhaps hopping over to the reading will help you to know the meaning of this kanji.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「あのジェットコースター、どうだった？」「すっごく良かったから、降車した瞬間にゲロっちゃったよ。」
ex_1_en: "What did you think of that roller coaster?" "It was so intense that I threw up right after getting off."
meaning_story: Descend off the (train) car. You are getting off a train.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 眼鏡を拭いた方がいいですよ。
ex_1_en: You should wipe your glasses.
meaning_story: An eyeball mirror is something that refracts and focuses light into your eyeball in a different way so you can see better. Really, these things are glasses, not eye mirrors, but same sort of things when you get down to it. Just imagine someone wearing mirrors on their eyes, and when you ask them what those are for, they just say they're glasses.
reading_story: The reading for 眼 is the same as the vocab 眼. The reading for 鏡 is an exception, totally different. It shares a reading with 金 (gold), though, so think of the mirrors on the person's eyes being made of gold. What nice glasses!

ex_1_jp: 私の祖父母はまだ小児科医にかかっています。
ex_1_en: My grandparents still see their pediatrician.
meaning_story: You know that 祖父 is grandfather and 祖母 is grandmother. This is both combined. Is it some hybrid grandmapa monster you've created in your lab? Hardly, it just refers to your grandparents.
reading_story: The reading comes from 祖父 and 祖母, which are exceptional readings on their own, so you'll need them in order to be able to read this one too.

ex_1_jp: 音楽が私の日々の生活のパワーの源です。
ex_1_en: Music is a source of power in my daily life.
meaning_story: The origin is the origin, but it also refers to the ground springs, where the origin of water comes from.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Think of how this ground spring is everyone's (皆) origin (元). Everyone can use it, it's the 皆 元!

ex_1_jp: 電話恐怖症みたいなのがあって、電話で話をする時に心臓がバクバクするんです。
ex_1_en: I have a kind of telephone phobia and my heart starts beating very fast whenever I talk on the phone.
meaning_story: The heart internal organs is the heart, of course.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 大儲けするつもりでパチンコに行ったが、結局大損してしまった。
ex_1_en: I went to a pachinko parlor in a hopes of making a lot of money, but I ended up with a heavy loss instead.
meaning_story: A big loss is a heavy loss.
reading_story: The reading is the おお reading of 大 coupled with the on'yomi reading for 損. Just keep in mind that the そん changes to ぞん and you'll be good here.
pitch_accent: オーゾン *** オーゾꜜン

ex_1_jp: 村人たちは、自然に対し神聖な敬意を持っています。
ex_1_en: The villagers have a holy respect for nature.
meaning_story: God is holy. Everything about a holy god is full of holiness.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今日はユダヤ教の聖日にあたります。
ex_1_en: Today is a Jewish holy day.
meaning_story: A holy day is a holy day.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この道は聖地に続いています。
ex_1_en: This road leads to the holy land.
meaning_story: Holy ground is holy land.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は不純な動機から日本語を勉強し始めました。
ex_1_en: I started studying Japanese out of impure motives.
meaning_story: Not pure things are impure.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ご近所さんのガレージで鹿の内臓を取り出すんです。
ex_1_en: They take the internal organs out of deer in my neighbor’s garage.
meaning_story: Inside internal organs are your internal organs, though you'd think the second kanji would give a hint to that without the 内.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: たてよこ, じゅうおう
ex_1_jp: 壁の縦横の長さを測りたいんだけどちょっと手伝ってくれない。
ex_1_en: Can you help me measure the vertical and horizontal lengths of this wall?
meaning_story: Vertical and side (horizontal). That means you have the length and width and the vertical and horizontal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ジューオꜜー *** ジューオー *** タꜜテヨコ

ex_1_jp: 私の祖父は肺臓炎で亡くなりました。
ex_1_en: My grandfather died of inflammation of the lungs.
meaning_story: The lung internal organ is the lung.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お土産に可愛い磁石をいくつか買ったわよ。
ex_1_en: I got some cute magnets for your souvenir.
meaning_story: A magnet stone is a magnet. Magnets look like little stones, right?
reading_story: The 磁 reading makes sense. The しゃく reading for 石 is an exception. To remember this, just think how you are using a magnet to find this shack (しゃく) full of other magnets. It pulls you towards the shack, and when you find it and open it, all the magnets fly out and crush you because of magnety reasons.

ex_1_jp: 地球にはとても強い磁場があります。
ex_1_en: The Earth has a substantial magnetic field.
meaning_story: A magnet location is an area with a magnetic field.
reading_story: The readings are the same as the ones you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 磁気カードと磁石を一緒にしない方がいいよ。
ex_1_en: You shouldn’t put magnetic cards and magnets together.
meaning_story: Magnetic energy is when magnetism occurs.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は英語がペラペラだと思ったが、とんだ誤算だった。
ex_1_en: I was wrong in thinking that she would speak decent English.
meaning_story: A mistake in what you calculate is a miscalculation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 君は誤解しているよ。あれは俺の姉貴だよ。
ex_1_en: You’ve got the wrong idea. She’s my older sister.
meaning_story: A mistake in what you solve... wow, sorry, I thought I was supposed to solve this, not that. What a terrible misunderstanding.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 薬の誤用は命に関わることがあります。
ex_1_en: Misuse of medicine can be fatal.
meaning_story: A mistake in use is a misuse.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 犬の爪を爪切りで切ってあげようとしてたんですけど、つい携帯に気を取られちゃいました。
ex_1_en: I was trying to clip my dog nails but my mobile phone distracted me.
meaning_story: When you cut your claw you use a nail clipper.
reading_story: The reading is the reading you learned for the kanji 爪 and the word for the reading 切る.
pitch_accent: ツメキꜜリ *** ツメキリꜜ

ex_1_jp: 誤解しないでね。日本料理は大好きなんだけど、納豆だけはどうしても食べられないの。
ex_1_en: Don’t get me wrong. I love Japanese food, but I could never just eat natto alone.
meaning_story: A supply of beans is when you take a bunch of beans, mash them up into a supply, and then ferment them all together to make them into natto (also known as fermented soybeans).
reading_story: The reading is an exceptional one. 豆 is okay, and is the on'yomi reading from the kanji. The 納 part is weird though. Instead of being のう it's なっ. But, if you can remember the meaning of this word, you can just think about how you do not (なっとう) want to eat natto. At least a lot of people don't want to eat it. It's quite the acquired taste.

ex_1_jp: 俺は顧客と個人的に仲良くなることには興味がないんだ。
ex_1_en: I’m not interested in building personal relationships with customers.
meaning_story: 興味 is interest in something. If you do not have (がない) that interest, then you have no interest or you're not interested.
reading_story: Reading comes from the on'yomi as well as 興味.

ex_1_jp: お前の兄貴はイケてるけど、俺の兄貴はダサイからな。
ex_1_en: Your older brother is a really cool guy, but mine is not.
meaning_story: The older brother is valuable to you. But, no matter how valuable he is to you, he's still just your older brother. P.S. You'll often see some gangstah thug call a higher ranking gangstah thug (one that acts like an older brother to all the other gangstah thugs) this. It's like family within the gang.
reading_story: The reading is 兄 on its own plus the reading for 貴. ANIKIIIII.

ex_1_jp: 歌劇のチケットの値段を2%値上げします。
ex_1_en: We are going to increase our opera ticket prices by 2%.
meaning_story: A song drama. Ugh, I hate these. They sing so much and they're so dramatic. This is an opera.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: もし犬の飼い主が水疱瘡になったら、その犬も水疱瘡になる可能性はあるんでしょうか。
ex_1_en: If a dog’s owner had chickenpox, could the dog get it too?
meaning_story: You know that to 飼う is "to keep a pet." If you're the master that is keeping a pet (飼う), then you are the pet owner.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi readings for both. You'll need to remember the words 飼う and 主 to be able to remember the reading of this word.
pitch_accent: カꜜイヌシ *** カイꜜヌシ

ex_1_jp: 歓楽街のツアーには何が含まれていますか。
ex_1_en: What does the tour of the pleasure quarter include?
meaning_story: The delight and comfort street. Sounds nice. Sounds like the "pleasure quarter." You'll see these most often in samurai films, or in sketchier areas.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日本語では英語に比べて単語を複数形にすることは少ないです。
ex_1_en: In Japanese you don’t need to change things to the plural form as often as in English.
meaning_story: If 複数 is multiple, and 形 is shape, then when something is in a "multiple shape," it has more than one version of itself. It is plural
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 複数 as well.

ex_1_jp: このお芋、レンジでチンしてくれない？
ex_1_en: Could you microwave this potato, please?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 出かける時は、完全に電源を切るために全部のコンセントを抜きます。
ex_1_en: When I go out, I turn off all the power by unplugging everything from the electrical sockets.
meaning_story: The electricity origin is where the electricity comes from. It is the power source.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: デンケ°ン *** デンケ°ꜜン

ex_1_jp: 貴重なご意見を有難うございます。
ex_1_en: Thank you for your valuable opinions.
meaning_story: Something that's valuable and heavy is extremely precious and probably even more valuable than your less heavy things.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 重 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Keep things precious to you very close, because the evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will come and steal it away if you don't. She'll take every valuable you have and destroy them.

ex_1_jp: 純粋に金銭的な理由だけで、夫とまだ一緒にいるんです。
ex_1_en: I’m still with my husband for purely financial reasons.
meaning_story: You're pure and that's stylish, which makes you even more pure, somehow. But your purity also makes you genuine, unlike all the people who aren't pure trying to be stylish.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 放射冷却のせいで今朝起きた時はものすごい冷え込みだったよ。
ex_1_en: It was very cold when I got up this morning because of radiational cooling.
meaning_story: It releases and shoots out of the bomb. It's not fire. It's radiation, and it sticks around a long time once it has been released.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 日付の書き方から、その脅迫状はアメリカ人によって書かれたものだと推理しました。
ex_1_en: I inferred that the intimidating letter was written by an American due to the way the date was written.
meaning_story: To infer reason is to have reasoning.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今回のモデルへの応募について、自薦・他薦は問いません。
ex_1_en: We accept both recommendations and direct applications for this modeling position.
meaning_story: As for myself? I recommend this product. It is my recommendation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: あなたを、優秀な屁こき野郎として、屁こき大会に推薦しておきましたよ。
ex_1_en: I recommended you as a good farter for the fart competition.
meaning_story: To infer and recommend something is to give a recommendation. What do you recommend?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: うちの会社、他社との競争に勝つために、利鞘を縮小することを検討しているんだ。
ex_1_en: Our company is thinking of reducing our profit margin to be competitive with another company.
meaning_story: Shrink what you have into something small. It was big, now it's small. This is a reduction.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 雪野原は、巨大な鏡のように、冬の太陽の光をキラキラと反射します。
ex_1_en: The field of snow brightly reflects the winter sunlight like a giant mirror.
meaning_story: You shoot yourself at a mirror, and it is the anti-you. It is your reflection.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 朝から丼なんて食べてるの？あんたって、本当に朝型人間ね。
ex_1_en: Are you eating a rice bowl for breakfast? You are really a morning person.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: You learned the on'yomi reading which is どん. This is just an extension of that, coming out to どんぶり. You can remember the ぶり part because you know what your favorite rice bowl is... it's a brie (ぶり) cheese rice bowl. So delicious, yum.

ex_1_jp: 私の彼氏、本当にムカつくんだけど！私がすっごくすっごく楽しみしてた焼き芋、食べちゃったの。
ex_1_en: My boyfriend is such a jerk! He ate my roasted sweet potato that I’d been really, really looking forward to eating.
meaning_story: A baked potato is a baked potato (or roast potato).
reading_story: The reading is the readings from 焼く and 芋 put together.

ex_1_jp: 甲状腺異常のある日本の子どもたちの数が増えているのは、深刻な問題です。
ex_1_en: It’s a serious problem that the number of Japanese children with thyroid abnormalities have been increasing.
meaning_story: A deep carve is very serious and grave. Just imagine getting cut with a sword. If the carve is deep, well, that's serious.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 腰が痛かったんですが、お医者さんが痛み止めの注射を打ってくれました。
