ex_1_en: My lower back was sore so the doctor gave me shot of painkillers.
meaning_story: When you shoot something into someone that you actually have to pour (aka a liquid), you're shooting them up with a needle, giving them a shot / injection.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日本語で単純な文章なら作れますが、難しいのはまだ無理です。
ex_1_en: I can make up simple sentences in Japanese, but I can’t do complicated ones yet.
meaning_story: Simple and pure. This is simple.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: そう取り乱すなよ。心配ないって。俺らはまだ奴隷だけど、そのうち何とかなるよ。
ex_1_en: Don’t lose your cool. Don’t worry. We are still slaves now, but things will work out.
meaning_story: Some dude who is a slave is just a slave.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この染みなんとか取れないかなあ。
ex_1_en: Couldn’t you find some way to remove this stain?
meaning_story: This is the noun version of 染. A dye would seem like the right answer, but what else is a dye? If you get it on you when you don't want to get it on you, it becomes a stain.
reading_story: The reading is unlike what you learned with this kanji before. Just think about how you have this stain on your shirt, and it was all because Charlie Sheen spilled tiger blood all over you.

ex_1_jp: 自分で粋な会話をしてるって思ってるところがムカツクんだよね。
ex_1_en: He believes that he carries on refined conversations, but they’re actually irritating.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: You are stylish. If you're stylish, you always いきます (いき) to the clothing stores to buy more stylish clothes.

ex_1_jp: 字幕のせいで気が散ることもあります。
ex_1_en: Subtitles can be a distraction.
meaning_story: A curtain of letters that goes on your screen are subtitles. Sometimes they have black bar backgrounds too, which are like curtains!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あいつ、飛び込み自殺をするために家を出る前、俺のプレイステーションをあいつのテレビに繋いだんだよな。何か意味があったのかな？
ex_1_en: He hooked up my PlayStation to his TV before leaving our house to commit suicide by jumping in front of a train. Do you think it means something?
meaning_story: If you fly to make yourself crowded with something (say a moving train), and it also involves suicide (自殺), that is going to be suicide by train. Not a pretty way to go, plus it stops the train lines and makes everyone late, not to mention your family has to pay a fee for your idiocy. Don't do this, obviously. Learn kanji instead.
reading_story: The readings come from 飛ぶ, 込む, and 自殺. Combine them together to come up with this grim word.

ex_1_jp: 私はまだ降参していません。
ex_1_en: I haven’t given up yet.
meaning_story: I am going to descend my participation in this conflict. I am going to descend all my weapons to the ground. I am going to surrender.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 劇場までの毎日の 通勤に、片道二時間以上かかります。
ex_1_en: My daily commute to the theater is over two hours each way.
meaning_story: A drama location is where people do drama. This is a theater.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ああ、もし私が貴族の家柄に生まれていたら、彼女と話をすることも可能だったかもしれないのに。
ex_1_en: If I had been born to a noble family, I would have been able to talk to her.
meaning_story: People of a valuable tribe are part of the nobility. Unlike our tribes, they are valuable.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 通勤・通学者にとって、電車の時刻表は絶対に必要なものです。
ex_1_en: The train schedule is a must-have for commuters.
meaning_story: Something that carves out all the times for something (say, on a big sign) and then expresses them to the world, is a timetable or schedule.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: それがどんな汚い手を使ってでも勝たなきゃいけない試合だってことには賛成するよ。
ex_1_en: I agree that it’s a game we must win by any means necessary.
meaning_story: The 賛成 portion means agreement or support, so the verb version would be to agree or to support.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は麻疹に免疫がないので、病院に麻疹の予防接種を受けるための申込をしました。
ex_1_en: I’m not immune to the measles, so I submitted an application for the measles vaccine at the hospital.
meaning_story: I would like to say humbly in this crowded place that I am going to apply. If there are a lot of other people applying, you feel humbled, so you say humbly you want to apply.
reading_story: The readings come from 申す and 込む, stuck together... humbly.
pitch_accent: モーシコꜜム *** モーシコム

ex_1_jp: このアボカド、昨日買ったところなのにもう傷んでるよ。
ex_1_en: I bought this avocado yesterday and it’s already bad.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 傷める means "to damage." Well this is the intransitive version and it means to be damaged.
reading_story: You learned this reading already when you learned 傷める. Yay!

ex_1_jp: 子供たちがこの悪い環境に染まってしまうことを心配してるのよ。
ex_1_en: I’m worried that our kids will be tainted by this bad environment.
meaning_story: If 染める is "to dye," then this is to be dyed. You aren't doing the dying, because you know that if you did it you would have done things right, unlike the other person who dyed your hair. This person marred (まる) it up really bad.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 染める.

ex_1_jp: 娘が小学校に上がったので、私は図書館に勤め始めました。
ex_1_en: I started working at a library ever since my daughter got into primary school.
meaning_story: The kanji is work which means this verb has something to do with working. It's not straight up "to work," instead it's "to work for" or "to be employed at."
reading_story: The reading is the same as the other word that means "to work for" (務める). Remember this and you'll be able to remember the reading for this word too.

ex_1_jp: 葱を刻むのは面倒くさいよ。
ex_1_en: I can’t be bothered to cut up the green onion.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carve so the verb version is to carve.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: to carve up the steak, you wish you could use a knife, but you don't have one. Instead, you'll have to use your keys (きざ) to cut it. Imagine trying to cut up the steak with these keys. It's very difficult.

ex_1_jp: ご伝言を承りましょうか。
ex_1_en: Would you like to leave a message?
meaning_story: This is a weird word. It's like confirming you heard and understand something, but doesn't mean you agree. So, "to consent" isn't 100% accurate. So, it's kind of like saying "to hear or "to be informed.
reading_story: You received (受けた) some information. Now, you are going to take that information that you received and then revolve it (回る) around in your head to think about it. Hmmm... hmm... Ok, I like what I'm hearing. I am going to consent what it is you said. I am going to be informed now that I received the information and have revolved it around my brain a bit. Thank you.
pitch_accent: ウケタマワꜜル *** ウケタマワル

ex_1_jp: 問題解決にリーダーシップを一番発揮していたのは誰ですか。
ex_1_en: Who demonstrated the most leadership in solving the problem?
meaning_story: Departure and brandish this thing. This means you're sending something out to show to everyone. That's why this is to exhibit or to demonstrate (because when you brandish, and send it out to show, you're demonstrating it!).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The はつ becomes はっ, though.

ex_1_jp: お昼過ぎ、にわか雨が降る中、私は愛犬の散歩をしていました。
ex_1_en: I was walking my dog in the afternoon while the rain fell.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means descend, but this word means something closer to to fall or to come down. Usually used with things like rain or snow.
reading_story: The rain is to fall and you're outside anyway with your mouth open so you'll get a mouth full (ふる) of rainwater! All the ponds, wells, and your yard will be full of water too!

ex_1_jp: 急いで申込書に書き込んだ方がいいよ。あと十分で事務所は閉まっちゃうんだから。
ex_1_en: You better hurry up and fill out an application. The office will close in ten minutes.
meaning_story: You write something on this paper but it is crowded. Why is it crowded? Because there are little boxes for you to write things in. You are filling out a form, which makes this verb to fill out or to write in.
reading_story: The reading comes from 書く and 込む combined into one.
pitch_accent: カキコꜜム *** カキコム

ex_1_jp: おばちゃんって呼ばれる年齢かなあ。傷つくなあ。
ex_1_en: Aren’t I too young to be called a middle-aged woman? I’m hurt.
meaning_story: Remember how 傷 is "wound"? Now you are つくing a wound, which is like attaching a wound to yourself. If you attach a wound to yourself, you are probably going to get hurt.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the word 傷.

ex_1_jp: 働きすぎてあんたが健康を損なうんじゃないかって、心配してるのよ。
ex_1_en: I’m worried that you may ruin your health by working too hard.
meaning_story: To do loss to something means you are doing something to make something have loss. This is to harm or to injure.
reading_story: In order to harm your opponent, you go way overboard. You soak (そこ) them in acid. Soaked head to toe. Too far man, too far.

ex_1_jp: あなたが描いた日陰に座っている少女の絵を拝見しました。
ex_1_en: I took a look at your painting of a girl sitting in the shade.
meaning_story: You worship only the things you see. So, in order to see if something is worth worshiping, you'll go to have a look at that thing.
reading_story: And just so you know, this is a very formal word used when you're trying to be polite. So keep that in mind, please!

ex_1_jp: コンタクトレンズを傷つけちゃったかも。
ex_1_en: I might have scratched my contact lens.
meaning_story: You have your wound, and something is attached to it (つける). This is when you attach the hurt onto someone else, so you are going to hurt someone or to injure them.
reading_story: The reading is 傷. If you remember the reading for that you got this too.

ex_1_jp: ショットガンに弾を込める時間がなかったんだ。
ex_1_en: I didn’t have enough time to load a bullet into the shotgun.
meaning_story: You know that 込む is "to be crowded." This, however, is when you make something crowded. How do you make something crowded? You have to include more and more things into the thing you want crowded until it is crowded. To do this act (which you are doing), you mail (める) things in over and over again. This will crowd the post office if I include all this mail in this mail box! Ha ha! What a rebel!
reading_story: The reading comes from 込む. No reading too crowded to include here.

ex_1_jp: ミサイルは予定通り発射された。
ex_1_en: The missile was launched as planned.
meaning_story: Departure and shoot something off. If you do that to something, you are going to launch it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 綺麗な涎かけが無くなっちゃった。うちの赤ちゃんが全部汚しちゃって。
ex_1_en: We are out of clean bibs. Our baby boy got them all dirty.
meaning_story: 汚れる is "to get dirty." This is when you make something dirty, aka "to make dirty." You know that this is the version where you make things dirty yourself because when you make someone dirty with all that poop you're flinging, they sue (す) you immediately. This happens a lot.
reading_story: The reading comes from 汚れる, so if you know that you can read this.
pitch_accent: ケカ°ꜜス *** ケカ°ス *** ヨコ°ス

ex_1_jp: 「パパ、フグと私、結婚して日本に引っ越すつもりよ。」「俺の目の黒いうちはそんなことはさせないぞ。」
ex_1_en: "Dad, Fugu and I are getting married and moving to Japan." "Not while I’m alive, you won’t."
meaning_story: 越す is "to go beyond." Now you're going beyond your home and pulling everything with you to go to another home. You are trying to move / to move homes.
reading_story: The readings come from 引く and 越す put together. Careful of that っ.

ex_1_jp: 他の自転車走者を追い越す時、いつも挨拶代わりに手を振ります。
ex_1_en: I always wave my hand to say hi whenever I pass other bikers.
meaning_story: 越す means "to go beyond." 追 is follow. If you are following someone, and then you go beyond them, you have overtaken them. That's why this word means to overtake.
reading_story: The reading comes from 追う and 越す put together into one. You can overtake this word now that you know that.

ex_1_jp: 「遅れてごめんなさい。朝、少し気分が悪くて吐いてしまって。」「大丈夫だよ。遅れても来ないよりはましだよ。」
ex_1_en: "I’m sorry I’m late. I was sick and threw up this morning." "It’s okay. Better late than never."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means throw up so the verb version is to throw up or to puke or to barf.
reading_story: The reading is from the reading you learned with the kanji. HA HA HA! Barf.
pitch_accent: ツꜜク *** ツクꜜ *** ハꜜク

ex_1_jp: この番組を彼に薦められたんだけど、アニメを観るのはあまり好きじゃないんだよね。
ex_1_en: He recommended this show to me, but I don’t really like watching anime.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means recommend so the verb vocab version is to recommend.
reading_story: To remember the reading think about how you are going to recommend this restaurant to your friends, Sue and Sue (すす). You refer to them as "Sue Sue" to make things easier on yourself, and they're always looking for recommendations.

ex_1_jp: 牛乳は腐りやすいんだから冷蔵庫の外に出しっ放しにしないでね。
ex_1_en: Don’t leave milk out of the fridge because it goes bad easily.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rot so the verb vocab version is to rot.
reading_story: Remember the word 臭い, which means "stinky"? When something rots, it becomes stinky, and all くさい.

ex_1_jp: 川の両岸に沿って、ずうっと、美しい桜並木があるんです。
ex_1_en: There are beautiful cherry blossom trees all along the river banks.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means run alongside so the verb vocab version is to run alongside.
reading_story: Think about how you're sewing something, and your thread has to run alongside the edge of the cloth.

pronunciation: ちぢまる, ちじまる
ex_1_jp: 雷がゴロゴロ鳴っている間、うちの犬は怖がって縮まっていました。
ex_1_en: My puppy was shrinking in fear while the thunder was rumbling.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shrink so the verb vocab version means to shrink.
reading_story: Jesus couldn't cause the monster to shrink. He had to transform into cheese jesus (ちぢ), a more powerful version of himself, in order to shrink the monster down to size.

ex_1_jp: なんとか洋服を全部スーツケースに詰め込めました。
ex_1_en: I managed to cram all my clothes into my suitcase.
meaning_story: You know that 詰める is "to stuff in" and 込む is "to be crowded." So when you stuff something and crowd it up, you are going to stuff or to cram it in.
reading_story: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. If you remember your kanji readings, you'll be fine here.
pitch_accent: ツメコム *** ツメコꜜム

ex_1_jp: 車が全損してしまった場合、修理代は保険で全額支払われないことが多いです。
ex_1_en: If it turns out that the car is a total loss, many insurance companies will not pay the full repair cost.
meaning_story: An all loss is when you lose it all. It is a total loss.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今朝、六時に目覚ましがなった時に、その時計を投げ捨ててしまいました。
ex_1_en: I threw my alarm clock away when it went off at six this morning.
meaning_story: You throw and throw away something. That's why this means to throw away.
reading_story: The reading comes from 投げる and 捨てる, combined into one garbage inducing dump of a word.
pitch_accent: ナケ°ステꜜル *** ナケ°ステル

ex_1_jp: 私の家族は、毎朝仏壇の前に集まって仏様に拝みます。
ex_1_en: My family gathers in front of our family Buddhist altar to pray to Buddha every morning.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means worship so the verb vocab version is to worship.
reading_story: You have to worship the ogre (おが), because if you don't it'll eat your face off.

ex_1_jp: あなたには悲劇がお似合いよ。
ex_1_en: Tragedy is suitable for you.
meaning_story: A sad drama always ends in tragedy. That's what makes it sad.
reading_story: The reading is all on'yomi readings, but you never learned the on'yomi reading for 悲. When it comes to tragedy, though, he (ひ) always dies. Always. He is always dying.

ex_1_jp: とりあえず今は誤字脱字を見つけてくれればそれでいいから。
ex_1_en: For now, all you have to do is find typos.
meaning_story: A mistake in letters is a typo.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 命ってのはベーコンと同じくらい貴いものなんだよ。
ex_1_en: Life is as precious as bacon.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of valuable? It's valuable.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What is most valuable to you? Of course it's your toe toe (とうと). It's your big toe (the long とう) with another small toe growing out of it (short と). Imagine your toe toe, and then imagine how valuable it is to you. So valuable! You can also think about 尊い, a similar word which means "revered." It's a similar idea, and it has the same reading.
pitch_accent: タットꜜイ *** トートꜜイ

ex_1_jp: 縦100cm横160cmの窓に合う良いカーテンを探しています。
ex_1_en: I’m looking for nice curtains that will suit our 100 centimeter by 160 centimeter window.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!
pitch_accent: タꜜテ *** ホシꜜイママ *** ヨꜜシ

ex_1_jp: 文章を縦書にしたいんです。
ex_1_en: I want to write compositions using vertical style writing.
meaning_story: Vertical writing is vertical writing. That's when you see Japanese and it's written top to bottom instead of sideways.
reading_story: The readings are the reading you learned with the kanji 縦 and かき (changes to がき), though the き gets smushed inside the kanji, because it wants to be confusing like that.

ex_1_jp: 駅まで迎えをよこすよ。
ex_1_en: I’ll send someone to meet you at the station.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji welcome, so it means a welcome or a greeting.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: 「じゃが芋の皮、向ける？」「心配しないで。朝飯前だよ。」
ex_1_en: "Can you peel the potatoes?" "Don’t worry. It’s piece of cake."
meaning_story: A じゃが potato happens to be a white potato, or maybe an irish potato. There are different kinds of potatoes, and this is one of them.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 結局、あんたが黒幕だったんだな。どうりてあの女を殺した時手慣れていたと思ったよ。
ex_1_en: So, you are the mastermind, huh? No wonder you seemed so professional when you killed her.
meaning_story: Just imagine a black curtain off in the background. You don't know what's behind it, but you know what's in front of it. Thing is, the thing in front of the curtain is controlled by whoever is behind the black curtain. This person is the wirepuller or mastermind of the situation. Like the Wizard of Oz, or something.
reading_story: The reading is the vocab readings for 黒 and 幕, though the vocab reading for 幕 is the same as the on'yomi reading, making things easy for you.

ex_1_jp: 貴様がうるさかったせいで、昨日全然寝れなかったじゃねぇか。
ex_1_en: I couldn’t sleep well because YOU were very noisy.
meaning_story: A valuable formal name title. It's like saying something like "the valuable great you"... or something. Anyways, this means you, but it isn't as nice as it sounds. Probably a lot of irony and sarcasm going into this word, because if you use きさま to say "you" to someone, you're probably not pleased with that person, or you're just trying to be rude.
reading_story: The readings are the reading you learned with 貴 plus the vocab reading for 様.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は二種類の味のアイスクリームを交互に舐めた。
ex_1_en: She alternately licked two kinds of ice cream.
meaning_story: You mix, then you go mutual, then you mix, and then you go mutual. Alternately, you could go mix again?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼の祖父は江戸時代の破産した百姓だという噂だ。
ex_1_en: It’s rumored that his grandfather was a bankrupt farmer of the Edo period.
meaning_story: You'd think this one would have a much different meaning, considering it's tear and give birth. This word means bankruptcy, which seems a bit odd, but I guess there's another bankruptcy word with 産 in it too (倒産). That one is fall, and this one is tear. They're both pretty bad, and they both refer to bankruptcy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その兵舎には異臭が漂っており、息をするのもやっとだった。
ex_1_en: The barracks were filled with such an offensive stench that I could barely breathe.
meaning_story: A soldier cottage is a place where the soldiers stay. This is the barracks.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ありえない！今温泉に浸かっている熊を見たんだけど！
ex_1_en: No way! I just saw a bear soaking in the hot springs!
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 三日連続で遅刻してしまいました。
ex_1_en: I was late three days in a row.
meaning_story: A slow carve is so slow. If you carve something slowly, it will take you a long time. You will be late with a slow carve like that.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ある超能力者が、ホワイトハウスが一時間もしないうちに炎に飲み込まれてしまう予知夢を見たと噂になっています。
ex_1_en: There is a rumor a psychic had a vision that flames swallowed up the White House in under an hour.
meaning_story: There is a big fire. It is a big fire. It is a flame. Usually this refers to nice little fires, like campfires, not so much things like forest fires or house fires.
reading_story: Hoohhhh no (ほのお), there is a big fire.

ex_1_jp: ねぇ、私、あなたと喋るだけで、いい気分になるわ。あなたって、私にとって本当に理想の彼氏だわ。
ex_1_en: You know what, I get in a good mood just from talking to you. You really are my ideal boyfriend.
meaning_story: A he mister is not just he, it's "mister he," and mister he is your he, your boyfriend.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: おいおい、頼むよ。明らかにお前たちの相性全然よくなかっただろ！絶対にあの三つ編みの女に電話なんてしない方がいいって！
ex_1_en: Oh come on, it was so obvious! There was no chemistry between you two! You definitely shouldn’t call that girl with the braided hair!
meaning_story: 編む is "to knit." When you knit in threes, you are knitting in a braid style. What do you braid? Hair. That makes this braided hair.
reading_story: The reading is 三つ and 編む combined into one (or should I say three?) braids.

ex_1_jp: 青銅でコウイチの像を鋳造するっていうのはどうよ。
ex_1_en: Why don’t we cast a bronze statue of Koichi?
meaning_story: Blue copper is bronze. Bronze gets a bluish tint to it, which is why it's a blue copper.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: うちのお店では、国産杉を使った家具をお手頃なお値段で提供しております。
ex_1_en: We offer Japanese cedar furniture for a reasonable price.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. This will be particularly useful for names, as there's a lot of names with 杉.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私の推測では、彼は宝くじが当たって、バハマに引っ越した。
ex_1_en: My guess is that he won the lottery and moved to the Bahamas.
meaning_story: You can infer and measure all you want. If you do enough, you'll get some good conjecture and speculation off that inferring and conjecture.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうせお前は娘を金ずくで納得させたんだろう？
ex_1_en: You made my daughter consent by using money, didn’t you?
meaning_story: I will supply and you will acquire. Does that sound good? Do I have your consent?
reading_story: The reading is a bit weird for 納. Just imagine asking the consent question from the meaning, then have the other person say "Nahh! (なっ), no consent!"

ex_1_jp: 日本では、銅山は次々に閉山していっています。
ex_1_en: In Japan, copper mines have been closing one after another.
meaning_story: In a copper mountain you go in and make a copper mine.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 誰かが銅像を粉々に破壊しました。
ex_1_en: Somebody broke the the copper statue into pieces.
meaning_story: A copper statue is a copper statue.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 著作権の対象となるかどうかに関わらず、他人の作品は使用しないでください。
ex_1_en: I don’t want you guys to use someone else’s work regardless of whether or not it is subject to copyright.
meaning_story: 著作 is "writing" or "authorship." The rights that writing has is what's known as copyright.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 著作 first, too.
pitch_accent: チョサꜜクケン *** チョサクꜜケン *** チョサꜜッケン

ex_1_jp: 田舎道で死にかけのフクロネズミを見ました。
ex_1_en: I saw a dying possum on a country road.
meaning_story: A rice paddy and a cottage. This is the image of the countryside to me. This is rural. Just cottages and rice paddies...
reading_story: The reading doesn't really make sense for the kanji, and is an exception for sure. Just think about how when you're in the countryside you're in 中 (いなか) of nowhere.

ex_1_jp: 原油の値段は上がり続けている。
ex_1_en: The price of crude oil is going to keep rising.
meaning_story: The original oil is oil in its original state. That is crude oil.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 完璧に泥酔していて、方向感覚を失っていました。
ex_1_en: I was completely drunk and lost my sense of direction.
meaning_story: If you're mud drunk, you're so drunk you're rolling around on the ground. You are dead drunk.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私がそのような残虐行為を繰り返したのは、その度に達成感を得られることができたからです。

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: バスの大幅な遅延により会議に遅れてしまった。
ex_1_en: The bus was delayed for a long time and I missed the meeting.
meaning_story: I was too slow, so we'll have to prolong the time in which this product will come out. This is a delay :(
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その動画を遅滞なく削除せよ。
ex_1_en: Delete the video without delay.
meaning_story: I am too slow so things have really began to stagnate. What a delay.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 兎小屋は火事によって破壊されました。
ex_1_en: The rabbit hutch was destroyed by the fire.
meaning_story: Tear and break everything, taking it all down. Destruction! Demolition!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: こんなことを言うのは恥ずかしいんですが、私は安物買いの銭失いみたいなところがあるんですよね。
ex_1_en: It’s embarrassing to tell you, but with me you get what you pay for; buying cheap goods is a waste of money.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of shame? It could be ashamed or even embarrassing.
reading_story: When you're ashamed it's even worse when someone laughs at you: ha (は) ha ha!"

ex_1_jp: 夜勤の為に寝ておきたかったが、電車の音がうるさすぎた為に眠れなかった。
ex_1_en: I wanted to sleep so that I could be ready for my night shift, but I couldn’t because the trains were too noisy.
meaning_story: You move towards the sake. When you move towards it, you are doing something for the sake of.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: For the sake of public safety, you will need to tame (ため) the wild beasts loose in our city. Now go, tame them!

ex_1_jp: 俺が果汁百パーセントのオレンジジュースをストローですすっていると、誰かが俺の肩をトントンと叩いた。
ex_1_en: When I was sucking 100% orange fruit juice through a straw, someone tapped on my shoulder.
meaning_story: Fruit soup isn't really a soup, it's more of a fruit juice.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 給油ポンプが車に届きません。
ex_1_en: The fuel pump doesn’t reach my car.
meaning_story: You take your salary and buy oil. When you are doing this, you are fueling something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 庁舎に雷が落ちたみたいだよ。
ex_1_en: I heard that the government office building was struck by lightning.
meaning_story: A government office cottage is the place where the government office is stored. That's the government office building.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 福寿と書かれた年賀状を受け取りました。
ex_1_en: I received a New Year’s greeting card with happiness and longevity written in it.
meaning_story: Luck for your whole lifespan, that's a life of happiness and longevity.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: しまった！急須を壊しちゃった。彼が知ったらめちゃくちゃ怒るだろうな。
ex_1_en: Shit! I just broke the stupid teapot. He would get so upset if he knew.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 死後地獄に堕ちる事を願って、ありとあらゆる拷問について研究しています。
ex_1_en: I study every possible type of torture in hopes of living in Hell after I die.
meaning_story: The earth prison is a prison down inside the earth. What prison is under the earth? That would be hell.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 同音異義語に関するYoutubeビデオを作ったので、よかったら見てみてください。
ex_1_en: I made a youtube video about homonyms, so please take a look.
meaning_story: You have the same sound with a different meaning (異義), and it's a part of language. Same sounds... different meanings... that sounds like a homonym, you know?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. All I know is there's probably not a homonym for this word, for it is huge.

ex_1_jp: よく尊敬語と謙譲語がゴチャゴチャになってしまいます。
ex_1_en: I often mix up honorific Japanese with humble Japanese.
meaning_story: 尊敬 is respect. A respect language is honorific Japanese (or honorific language, though usually this refers to Japanese).
reading_story: The reading is 尊敬 plus 語 put together.

ex_1_jp: 今年の夏は絶対去年よりも蒸し暑いよね。
ex_1_en: This summer is definitely more humid than it was last year.
meaning_story: 蒸れる is "to be humid." So, if you have a humid hot, you have weather that is hot and humid (or you can just say humid, because that implies hotness too, usually). This is a useful word for summers in Japan, since you'll complain about this all the time.
reading_story: The reading comes from 蒸れる and 暑い. Know those and you know this too.

ex_1_jp: 初めて入獄した時、何故か安心感を得たんですよね。
ex_1_en: When I was imprisoned for the first time, for some reason I felt secure.
meaning_story: When you enter prison that's imprisonment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: コウイチには油断をするな。奴は中々手強い男だぞ。
ex_1_en: Don’t let your guard down around Koichi. He’s a really tough guy.
meaning_story: If you let someone cut off your oil supply, it's probably because of your inattentiveness. You let your guard down.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 筋肉の炎症には、ノンステロイドの痛み止めを処方しておきますね。
ex_1_en: I’m going to prescribe some non-steroidal pain relievers for your muscle inflammation.
meaning_story: When you have flame symptoms that's when you feel like you're filled with fire, which is inflammation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あなたの獄内での話、最後はどうなるの？
ex_1_en: How does your story about being in prison end?
meaning_story: If you're inside prison you're in prison.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 警察の介入により、事態は一層複雑化した。
ex_1_en: Police intervention made the situation more complicated.
meaning_story: I jammed in myself and entered your personal life. Because I care, you know? I don't want you to be addicted to My Little Pony anymore, so this is an intervention.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 「こんにちは。サーモンいますか？妹なんですけど。」「わぁ、イクラじゃない！！！」「わぁ、紹介してよ！」「こちらが、フグ。（フグを指さしながら）」「初めまして。」「鰐蟹とキンニクマは知ってるわよね！」「やあ、イクラちゃん。久しぶり。」
ex_1_en: Salmon-Roe: "Hi, is Salmon here? I’m her sister." Salmon: "Oh my God, Salmon-Roe!" Fugu: "Oh, introduce us!" Salmon: "This is Fugu." (Points at him.) Salmon-Roe: "Nice to meet you!" Salmon: "And you know Crabigater and Kinnikuma!" Crabigator & Kinnikuma: "Hi." Salmon-Roe: "Long time, no see."
meaning_story: My introduce was jammed in there for you to hear. That is my introduction. Jammin' it in.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼の母親は彼に脱獄を強要した。
ex_1_en: His mother forced him to break out of jail.
meaning_story: Undress the prison from yourself, you're getting out of here, pal! Jailbreak!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: コウイチには大きな目標がある。剣道で世界一になりたいんだ。
ex_1_en: Koichi has high aspirations. He wants to be the best in the world at kendo.
meaning_story: The path of the sword is known as kendo. You could also say Japanese fencing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 夜行バスは、熊本県で発生した事故のため一時不通になった。
ex_1_en: The night bus service was temporarily suspended because of an accident in Kumamoto prefecture.
meaning_story: Bear origin prefecture is Kumamoto Prefecture. Probably best to learn this meaning via the reading. Also, you should look up Kumamon of Kumamoto-ken.
reading_story: The reading is 熊's reading, the alternate "origin" 本 reading, and the reading for 県.

ex_1_jp: 仕事に向かう前に、湖のほとりに沿って寄り道をするのが好きだ。
ex_1_en: I like taking a little detour along the lake before I head to work.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is crazy long, but also crazy easy! You know みず means "water," and うみ means "sea." So, you have a "water sea" which is a lake, which is a みずうみ.

ex_1_jp: 安物のカメラで撮ったにしては、山中湖の写真すごく綺麗に撮れてるじゃん。
ex_1_en: Given how cheap the camera was, all the pictures of Lake Yamanaka turned out beautiful.
meaning_story: The mountain middle lake is lake Yamanaka, a famous and very nice lake in Japan. It's also a lake that will help you to learn the lake kanji reading better.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of 山 and 中, then the on'yomi reading of 湖.

ex_1_jp: その講師、講演会場にリムジンで登場したんだよ。
ex_1_en: The lecturer came to the lecture hall in a limo.
meaning_story: Perform your lecture. This is your lecture. This is your address to the people.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 講義の頭に、教授は私達がナイフにニックネームを付けているかどうかを尋ねました。
ex_1_en: At the beginning of the lecture, our professor asked us if we have nicknames for our knives.
meaning_story: Lecture of righteousness is still a lecture.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その大学の講師としての資格を得ました。
ex_1_en: I qualified as a lecturer for the university.
meaning_story: A lecture expert is a lecturer or instructor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 田舎暮らしは退屈だ。
ex_1_en: Country life is boring.
meaning_story: If 暮らす is "to live" or "to live one's life" then the noun version would be simply life.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 暮らす.

ex_1_jp: 携帯の電池の寿命が短くなってきてるんだけど。
ex_1_en: My phone battery’s lifespan is getting shorter.
meaning_story: Your lifespan is your fate and will show you how long your lifespan is.
reading_story: You did learn the reading of 寿, but the reading for 命 is an exception. When you think of a lifespan, think of how that affects everyone. Me, you... well, just those things. Combine them both into myou (みょう). That is who the lifespan affects. Myou!

ex_1_jp: 婆ちゃんにいつも、「バナナを食べることは長寿に繋がる」と言われるんだよね。
ex_1_en: My grandmother always tells me that eating bananas leads to a long life.
meaning_story: A long lifespan is a long life.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「妹が宝くじに当たったのよ。」「すごいね！で、いくら？」「一万円。」
ex_1_en: "My sister won the lottery." "Oh cool! How much?" "10,000 yen"
meaning_story: 宝 is a treasure. くじ is a lottery. So if you have a treasure lottery (you win treasure if you win the lottery) then you have yourself a lottery.
reading_story: The reading uses the 宝 vocab reading, たから.
pitch_accent: タカラꜜクジ *** タカラクꜜジ

ex_1_jp: 味噌と醤油は和食には欠かせません。
ex_1_en: Miso and soy source are essential for a Japanese-style meal.
meaning_story: A flavor that makes foods boisterous is a great flavor. In this case, it's the flavor of miso, which goes in a lot of Japanese dishes, and certainly does make the flavor of things boisterous.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの二人は、「どうぞお座りください」とお互いに席の譲り合いをしたんだ。
ex_1_en: The two people said, "Here, take my seat," to each other.
meaning_story: Despite it looking like an adjective, this is the noun version of the kanji, making it mutual. It also means each other and reciprocal and together, too.
reading_story: Let's help each other. Maybe if we work together we can get rid of this tagger (たが) tagging graffiti all over our neighborhood.

ex_1_jp: 相互リンクしてもらえませんか。
ex_1_en: Could you set up a mutual link with me, please?
meaning_story: Mutual and mutual is mutual.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この文章を否定形にすることができますか。
ex_1_en: Can you change this sentence into a negative sentence?
meaning_story: 否定 is denial. Remember how 形 sometimes refers to grammar tense / type? Well, with a denial type grammar, you have a negative form, making it a negative sentence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 南極観測隊のメンバーになるにはどうすればいいですか。
ex_1_en: How can I become a member of Antarctic exploration party?
meaning_story: View and measure what you are watching. This is observation. It is no mere viewing, it is more than that.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 石油価格が高騰している。
ex_1_en: Oil prices are rising steeply.
meaning_story: Oil that has stones in it is from the ground. It's not olive oil, it's petroleum!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その割りには油は綺麗だね。
ex_1_en: Comparatively, this oil is pretty pure.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: You need to apply oil to a bra (あぶら) because it's stuck on you. You can't get it unhooked, so you have to slide it off. Problem is, it's too tight, which is why a bra needs oil to slide off.

ex_1_jp: 残念ですが、どの油田も私のものではありません。
ex_1_en: Unfortunately, none of those oil fields are mine.
meaning_story: An oil rice paddy is really more like an oil field.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 田 yet. Just think about how you walk into the oil field and you see a bear den (でん), filled with oil.

ex_1_jp: 俺は、みんな死ぬ前に己の墓は己で建てるべきだと思うけどね。
ex_1_en: I think people should build their own graves before they die.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It also means myself and I.
reading_story: As for myself? I'm not Bob. oh no, Ray (おのれ), Ray is my name.

ex_1_jp: どうしてここに白熊がいるんだ？
ex_1_en: Why is there a polar bear here?
meaning_story: A white bear is a polar bear! They're the only white bears in the whole world!
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this too!

ex_1_jp: 彼女が彼氏にキムチ鍋を作らせた。
ex_1_en: His girlfriend got him to cook kimchi casserole.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 科学者たちは、大地震の予測に失敗した。
ex_1_en: Scientists failed to predict the massive earthquake.
meaning_story: A beforehand measure is when you make a prediction of something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: そして、出獄の日が近づくにつれて、憂鬱になって、何故か危機感を感じたんです。
ex_1_en: Then, as the day that I would be released from prison drew near, I became depressed and for some reason I sensed impending doom.
meaning_story: If you exit from prison you are getting your release from prison. But, before you move on, let me tell you one thing: Hope is a dangerous thing. Hope can drive a man insane.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彫刻を落として、真っ二つに割ってしまいました。
ex_1_en: I dropped the sculpture and it broke in half.
meaning_story: You carve then you carve again. So much carving until, wait, wow, it looks like something! All that carving became a sculpture!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その種の海亀は、絶滅の危機にあります。
ex_1_en: That kind of sea turtle is in danger of extinction.
meaning_story: A sea turtle is a sea turtle. Cowabunga!
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of these kanji, put together. I suppose it's because it's like two separate words put together into one. That makes this word read as うみがめ, where the かめ gets rendaku'd.
pitch_accent: ウミカ°メ *** ウミꜜカ°メ

ex_1_jp: 彼は、「俺様が一番好きな歌手は俺様自身だよ」と自己満足の笑みを浮かべながら豪語していた。
ex_1_en: He was very proud of himself and said, "I’m my own favorite singer," with a very self-satisfied smile.
meaning_story: Your self oneself, is your oneself or self.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 売上げを損ねずに値上げする方法を真剣に考えているんです。
ex_1_en: I’m seriously thinking about a way to raise prices without losing sales.
meaning_story: The reality of the sword is that it will cut you right in half and kill you, easily. The fact that this is true is a very serious thing. Very serious.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: バイトのみんなで、店長の喜寿をコンビニでお祝いする予定なんだよ。
ex_1_en: All of the part-time workers are going to celebrate the owner’s 77th birthday in his convenience store.
meaning_story: You can rejoice because your lifespan has reached this special point. That special point is your seventy seventh birthday. So many sevens, lucky!
reading_story: The readings are the on'yomi reading. You've seen the on'yomi reading of 喜 before, though it may be hard to remember at this point. Maybe you can think about how when you reach this seventy seventh birthday, all you want is a key (き) to the city so you can do whatever you want.

ex_1_jp: あいつ、俺にみんなの前で恥をかかされたって思ってるみたいでさ。
ex_1_en: He thinks I embarrassed him in front of everybody.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This is also the reading you learned. How nice! But if you don't remember it, what a shame. What an embarrassment this must be for you.

ex_1_jp: 江戸時代の有名な刀を載せた船は、嵐によって破船してしまいました。
ex_1_en: The ship carrying the famous sword of the Edo period was shipwrecked in a storm.
meaning_story: A tear in your ship will cause it to wreck, making it a shipwreck.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: これは普通の醤油じゃなくて、最高の醤油だよ！
ex_1_en: This isn’t normal soy sauce. This is supreme soy sauce!
meaning_story: Soy sauce oil is soy sauce, or as it's called in Japanese, shoyu.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 卒論のための研究で、統計学的に有意な値を導けなかったんです。
ex_1_en: The research for my graduation thesis wasn’t statistically significant.
meaning_story: If you have an idea, it means you are important. You have significance. Those without ideas are just big jokes and can't do anything at all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: うちの長男は野球一筋なのよ。女っ気も無くてさ。
ex_1_en: Our oldest son does nothing but play baseball. He doesn’t have a girlfriend either.
meaning_story: You have one muscle, therefore it only does one thing. That's it. It is single mindedly doing that one thing. It is intently and earnestly doing that one thing.
reading_story: The reading is a bit weird. It's the kun'yomi readings, where 一 is ひと and 筋 is すじ. Look back on the vocab words that use these readings to remember this one.

ex_1_jp: 熱々の豚汁をもらえますか。
ex_1_en: Can I have the boiled pork miso soup, please?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You are given some soup. You take a bite and your mouth is cut clean off. That is because you're eating sheer (しる) soup.

ex_1_jp: 近所にお寿司屋さんがあるんだけど、すごく旨いちらし寿司をたったの10ドルで出しているんだよ。これ以上のものはないね。
ex_1_en: There is a sushi restaurant in my neighborhood that has great Chirashi-zushi for just $10. It’s tough to beat.
meaning_story: This is ateji, meaning the meanings of the kanji don't mean anything, only the sounds are being borrowed to make the word in Japanese. So, skip to the reading and use that to remember the meaning. It's an English word too now, after all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私達は午前二時に剣で戦うことにした。
ex_1_en: We decided to fight with swords at two in the morning.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well. Just remember that this is the kind of sword that usually has two sharp sides, not one.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 彼らはみんな、電車の切符を買っていなかったため、無賃乗車者として捕まった。
ex_1_en: None of them bought train tickets and they were caught for riding without paying.
meaning_story: This is he but plural, and includes ladies too. The "ra" makes it plural, making it "they" or "them." While this gennnnnnerally refers to a group of males, it can include ladies too.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: みんな船に酔ってしまい、そこら中に吐き散らかしていました。
ex_1_en: Everybody got seasick and puked all over the ship.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drunk so the verb vocab version is to be drunk.
reading_story: I'm not drunk, yo (よ). YO. I'm not drunk, yo. YO. Yo, I'm not drunk. Yo.

ex_1_jp: もし飛行機が遅れたら、補償金のようなものは支払われたりするんでしょうか。
ex_1_en: If the flight is delayed, can I get some kind of compensation?
meaning_story: If something or someone is slow, and they "do slow" they are going to be late.
reading_story: What is slow and probably going to be late all the time? A big oak (おく). Oaks have trouble moving, and are slow, and therefore are always late, too.

ex_1_jp: 家主が六ヶ月間家賃が滞っている男の家に出向くと、男は家の中で死んでいた。
ex_1_en: The landlord visited a guy who was six months behind with his rent and found him dead in the house.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stagnate. The verb vocab version is to be overdue. This is probably because something that has stagnated is running late, and therefore causes it to be overdue.
reading_story: The reading for this one is wildsauce. I'm going to leave this one to your capable hands. Just think of Tod (とど and some coot (こお) doing something wild even though they're overdue for something else, or something. Anyways, best of luck to you on this one.
pitch_accent: トドコール *** トドコꜜール

ex_1_jp: 突然、扉がひとりでに閉まりました。
ex_1_en: Suddenly, the door shut by itself.
meaning_story: If 閉める is "to shut" or "to close" this is going to be the version where you don't do anything and something shuts on its own. This word is to be shut or to be closed. You know this because you put your hand in the door to open it, but then it shuts (on its own) on your hand, marring your hand forever.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 閉める.

ex_1_jp: 物置にこの自転車納まるかなあ。
ex_1_en: I wonder if I can put this bicycle in my storage room.
meaning_story: If 納める is "to supply" or "to deliver," then this word is to be supplied or to be delivered. You aren't doing the supplying, and you know this because if you were to be caught supplying your reputation would be marred (まる for life).
reading_story: The reading is the same as 納める.

ex_1_jp: ほら！母乳だと乳が垂れるって言うじゃない？
ex_1_en: Say! Isn’t it said that breastfeeding causes saggy breasts?
meaning_story: If 垂らす is "to dangle something" then this is to dangle or to drip. You're not doing the dangling, which is rare (れる), because usually it's you who's doing the dangling.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 垂らす.

ex_1_jp: 私は納豆がご飯に合うって説は否定しますね。
ex_1_en: I deny the theory that natto goes well with rice.
meaning_story: If 否定 is "denial," then the verb version would be to deny.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 否定 as well.

ex_1_jp: 予想していた昇進が無かったが、彼は平気を装って昇進した社員たちにおめでとうと言った。
ex_1_en: Although he didn’t get the promotion he had been expecting, he put on a good face and congratulated the people who did.
meaning_story: If you go to attire yourself, you're covering up who you are and trying to be someone else. You are trying to feign. You are trying to wear a lie. You are trying to pretend.
reading_story: While you go to feign that you're someone or something else, someone calls you out on it: "you so (よそお) much a liar!"

ex_1_jp: 早くしないと、日が暮れるわよ。
ex_1_en: If you don’t hurry up, it will get dark.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 暮らす means "to live?" Well when you're in too much of a rush (らす) to live life to the fullest, you won't notice it start to get dark. You try to live day and night until it starts to end. Shine on in that darkness!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 暮らす, so if you can remember that, you should be able to remember this one too!

ex_1_jp: 俺の友達はメチャクチャ面白くて、パーティーを盛り上げるのが得意なんだよ。
ex_1_en: My buddy is ridiculously interesting and he’s great at livening up parties.
meaning_story: 盛る is "to heap up." If you "raise" (上げる) what you heap up, well, that comes with heaping something up, making this word to heap up or to pile up.
reading_story: The reading comes from 盛る and 上げる. Know those words and you'll be able to read this one too.

ex_1_jp: その看護婦さんは、血圧を測るのが上手です。
ex_1_en: The nurse is good at measuring people’s blood pressure.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means measure so the verb vocab means to measure. This word generally has to do with scientific or medical measurements.
reading_story: Remember another word that means "to measure?" It is 量る, and has the same reading as this word. That should make things easier to remember.

ex_1_jp: えっと、シャンパンとキャビアの代金を払えるほどお金を持っていない気がするんですが。
ex_1_en: Well, I don’t think I have enough money to pay for champagne and caviar.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pay so the verb vocab version is to pay.
reading_story: The reading comes from the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: あの時、日本政府は非常事態を宣言するべきだったと思わないかい。
ex_1_en: Don’t you think that the Japanese government should have declared a state of emergency at the time?
meaning_story: If 宣言 is a "proclamation," then the verb version will be to proclaim.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: またかよ。女はすぐ昔の話を蒸し返すよな。やってられないわ。
ex_1_en: There you go again. Girls always bring up old issues. I don’t want to deal with that.
meaning_story: You steam something to return it to its previously warm state. This is when you go to reheat something.
reading_story: The reading comes from 蒸れる and 返す. Combine this knowledge to reheat your memories.
pitch_accent: ムシカꜜエス *** ムシカエス

ex_1_jp: 尊敬する人はいますか？
ex_1_en: Do you have anyone you respect?
meaning_story: If 尊敬 is "respect" then the verb version would be to respect.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女はノートパソコンを閉じて、両腕を伸ばし、欠伸をした。
ex_1_en: She shut the laptop, stretched her arms, and yawned.
meaning_story: Another way to say to shut or to close. A verb version of the kanji 閉.
reading_story: The reading is different from, say, 閉める or しまる. Instead, the reading is とじる. Why? Because you shut your toe (と) in the door because it jeered off the hinges and out of control.

ex_1_jp: うちのワンコがクリスマスプレゼントの包装をビリビリ破っているビデオを撮ったのよ。
ex_1_en: We took a video of our puppy tearing open Christmas presents.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tear so the verb version is to tear.
reading_story: You start to tear the cloth. You don't know if you're supposed to or not. The crowd isn't sure either. You hear kind of a yah boo (やぶ) reaction going on, making you unsure if you should continue or stop. Yah! Boo. Yah! Boo!

ex_1_jp: 彼は裏切り者なんかじゃないよ。ただ、生まれつきちょっととぼけているだけさ。
ex_1_en: He is not a traitor. He’s just naturally a little slow.
meaning_story: Someone who backstabs (裏切り) someone is a traitor.
reading_story: The reading is 裏切り and an exception reading for 者. Just think about how you'd think of a traitor as a "thing" (物) and not a person.

ex_1_jp: ビエットの顔に落書きなんてしたら、後々厄介なことになるよ。
ex_1_en: If you draw on Viet’s face, you’re asking for trouble.
meaning_story: The unlucky is just getting jammed in there. So much unluckiness leads to a very troublesome and burdensome time.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The やく gets changed to やっ.

ex_1_jp: なんかその亀に親近感を感じるんだよな。
ex_1_en: I feel an affinity with the turtle for some reason.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. BURN BURN BURN.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 諸々の理由がありまして、しばらく一時的に店を閉めることにしました。
ex_1_en: We decided to temporarily close our shop for a bunch of reasons.
meaning_story: You have various various things. They are various. You have all kinds of them.
reading_story: The reading is a bit weird. Just think about how when you have various things, you probably have a lot of things. What do you want? You want more (もろ) of those things. More more more!

ex_1_jp: お酢は常温で保管しています。
ex_1_en: I keep vinegar at room temperature.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji!

ex_1_jp: 大人になったら酢の物が好きになりました。
ex_1_en: She came to like pickled food as she grew up.
meaning_story: A vinegar thing is a thing that has been vinegared. This is a vinegared food or a pickled food.
reading_story: The readings are the readings for 酢 and the kun'yomi reading for 物 which you've seen quite a bit by now.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 死刑制度廃止には、賛成ですか、反対ですか。
ex_1_en: Do you agree or disagree with the abolition of the death penalty?
meaning_story: It is obsolete so we must stop it. No more of it anymore. This is abolition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: コウイチはアメリカ合衆国の大統領になることを渋々受諾した。
ex_1_en: Koichi reluctantly agreed to become the president of the United States.
meaning_story: I will accept and I have agreement in the matter. I have come to acceptance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ああ、そういうことか。Tofuguは一番のライバル会社と同盟を組んだんだよ。
ex_1_en: Oh, now I see what happened. Tofugu formed the alliance with its closest competitor.
meaning_story: We are of the same alliance. We are in an alliance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 会議の資料が大幅に変更されました。
ex_1_en: The meeting’s documents were largely changed.
meaning_story: Something big in width is still big, in fact it's of a pretty substantial size.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: オーハバ *** オーハバꜜ

ex_1_jp: 車が移動献血車に衝突するのを見ました。
ex_1_en: I saw a car bump into the mobile blood bank van.
meaning_story: I would like to offer my blood to someone else in the form of a blood donation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 債券市場は何時まで開いてますか。
ex_1_en: What time is the bond market open until?
meaning_story: I have debt for the ticket you gave me. Forever we shall have this bond of me owing you for all the great things (like giving me a concert ticket to see Flight Of The Concords in concert).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: サꜜイケン *** サイケン

ex_1_jp: どちらの主将もそんなに強くはなかった。
ex_1_en: Both of the team captains weren’t very strong.
meaning_story: The master commander is the commander of all commanders, the commander in chief if you will... or, even the team captain.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どちらの指揮者もまだ来てないんだよ。
ex_1_en: Neither commander has come yet.
meaning_story: If 指揮 is "command" or "lead" then someone who does those things is a commander, or conductor. Usually the kind that conducts an orchestra!
reading_story: The reading for this is the reading of 指揮 plus the on'yomi reading of 者.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 父は、私達の結婚を二つ返事で承諾した。
ex_1_en: My father agreed to our marriage without hesitation.
meaning_story: You have my consent and agreement. This is my consent and agreement.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: もし娘さんとの結婚を許可してくださるのなら、あなたに我が社の登録商標の使用を許諾します。
ex_1_en: If you allow me to marry your daughter, I’ll give you my consent to use our company’s trademark.
meaning_story: I will permit this, and you have my agreement. Both of these things combine to be my consent.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「諾否を御一報ください」という言葉は、仕事の手紙やEmailなどでよく使われるフレーズです。
ex_1_en: "Please let us know whether this is acceptable or not" is a common phrase used in business letters and emails.
meaning_story: Do we have agreement or no? Which is it? consent or refusal? Yes or no? Choose!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 平仮名がうまく漢字に変換できない時は、大体タイプミスが原因です。
ex_1_en: Typos usually happen when you can’t change your hiragana to kanji properly.
meaning_story: If you change something then exchange it, you are making a conversion or a change.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうして犯人が遺体の唇を舐めたのかは不明です。
ex_1_en: We have no idea why the murderer licked the corpse’s lips.
meaning_story: You leave behind your body to join the spirit realm. This body remainder is your corpse or remains.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 債権者は破産手続きによっていくらかお金を受け取れることが多いが、株主は滅多に受け取ることがない。
ex_1_en: Creditors often receive some money from bankruptcy proceedings, but stockholders barely do.
meaning_story: Your debt rights state that you have a certain amount of credit with your bank. And if they try to say you don't have that credit you can file a claim against them!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: サꜜイケン *** サイケン

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 半年ぶりの舞踏会でした。
ex_1_en: It was the first dance in six months.
meaning_story: You dance, you step, you dance, you step. Good job! Now you're doing dancing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: これは、日本最古の舞です。
ex_1_en: This is Japan’s oldest dance.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: People think you're dancing, but you're really jumping from the mice (まい) running on your floor. You don't want the mice running up your legs so you have to hop from one to the other, making it look like you're dancing.

ex_1_jp: 牡鹿と牝鹿の区別がつきません。
ex_1_en: I can’t distinguish between male and female deer.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You take a look at the deer. It looks nice. But oh no, here comes a car to run it over (again!). Not just anyone's car, it's the Charlie Sheen car (しか), and he really wants to run this deer over.

ex_1_jp: 自分が携帯依存症だってことは認めます。
ex_1_en: I admit that I’ve become dependent on my cell phone.
meaning_story: I am reliant on you, I suppose. It is merely dependence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: Tofugu思想を普及するための歌を作曲しました。
ex_1_en: I made a song to spread Tofugu-ism.
meaning_story: When something reaches normal, it has finished diffusion. Normal things aren't all bunched up and concentrated. Normal things are spread out nice and evenly, via diffusion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 汚い雑巾が、トイレに落ちていました。
ex_1_en: The dirty wash cloth fell into the toilet.
meaning_story: This is the adjective form of 汚, which is dirty. This word is the adjective dirty, but you can also use it to say things like filthy, foul, or unclean.
reading_story: The reading is different from the other kun'yomi readings you've learned so far with this word. It is きたない. Think of it like you're saying "来た、な", as in "it came, huh?" What came? A really dirty looking monster, and it's coming for you.

ex_1_jp: 政治献金としていくらかお金を包んだ。
ex_1_en: I wrapped some money up as a political donation and gave it to them.
meaning_story: I'd like to offer money, no strings attached. It's free. It's a donation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お勤め先はどちらですか？
ex_1_en: Who do you work for?
meaning_story: If 勤める is "to be employed at," then the noun version of this is the things you do when you are employed somewhere. These things are your duties, so be sure to get them done if you want to remain employed at where you are.
reading_story: The reading comes from 勤める.

ex_1_jp: 「お早うございます。何にいたしましょうか？」「いつものやつ頼むよ。」「かしこまりました。ビールと枝豆でございますね。」「そうだよ。」
ex_1_en: "Good morning. What can I get you?" "I’ll have the usual." "Alright. Beer and Edamame, right?" "That’s it."
meaning_story: A branch bean doesn't mean a whole lot this way, but you probably know the food that this describes anyways. This is edamame, a food made from steamed soybeans, usually with a bit of salt added for flavor.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the two kanji, unfortunately. That's the vocab words 枝 and 豆 combined into one.

ex_1_jp: 私の父は、電磁場発生装置の特許を持っているんですが、私はそれが何のためのものなのかよく分かりません。
ex_1_en: My father has a patent for an electromagnetic field generator, but I’m not sure what it’s for.
meaning_story: A 磁場 is a "magnetic field." An electricity version of this is an electromagnetic field.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will of course help to know 磁場 as well.

ex_1_jp: 核廃絶運動家たちは、核兵器を廃絶することは実現可能だと信じている。
ex_1_en: The anti-nuclear movement believes that the abolition of nuclear weapons is feasible.
meaning_story: You are obsolete so it's time for extinction. Now you're all wiped out, and this is extinction.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ハロウィン用の偽物の牙の在庫が切れそうです。
ex_1_en: Our stock of fake fangs for Halloween is running out.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Using your animal fang you are able to eat kibble (きば).

ex_1_jp: 私の姓名を使用しないでください。
ex_1_en: Please don’t use my full name.
meaning_story: Your surname and your name put together create your full name.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 将来いつか、もっといい飼い犬の名前を思いつくかもしれない。
ex_1_en: I may come up with a better name for my dog someday in the future.
meaning_story: The commander will come in the future. Not anytime soon, but in the future.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 大将が机の角に頭をぶつけて、たんこぶを作っちまったんだよ。
ex_1_en: The admiral hit his head on the corner of the desk and got a lump.
meaning_story: The big commander is the general or admiral (or head or leader). Basically, they're big stuff.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私みたいな一般庶民には、そのパンプスはちょっと高すぎるかな。
ex_1_en: Those pumps are a little too expensive for an ordinary citizen like me.
meaning_story: One generally does things... in general. It's more common this way.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that the はん changes to ぱん for 般.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 日本では、遺伝子組み換え食品にはパッケージへの表示が義務づけられています。
ex_1_en: In Japan you are obligated to display whether foods are genetically modified on the package.
meaning_story: What I leave behind and transmit to you is your heredity. You have my genes, even after I'm gone.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 伝 before, here's a mnemonic to help you out. You keep records of your heredity in the den (でん). That's the best place for them. In the den.

ex_1_jp: お前がそこまで馬鹿じゃなければ、お前がどれだけ馬鹿なのか説明することができるんだけどなあ。
ex_1_en: If you weren’t so stupid, I could explain to you how stupid you are!
meaning_story: A horse deer is a stupid idea. You're an idiot for thinking about it, really. It's quite dumb.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 父の遺産を巡る家族間の争いが起きてるんです。
ex_1_en: We’re going through a family conflict over my father’s inheritance.
meaning_story: What you leave behind to those you give birth to is known as an inheritance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 印鑑を高級な象牙の物に変えました。
ex_1_en: I switched out my name stamp for an expensive ivory one.
meaning_story: An elephant tusk is the material known as ivory (or just an elephant tusk).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 縄文時代にもおしゃぶりみたいなものはあったのかな。
ex_1_en: I wonder if there was the equivalent of teething rings in the Jomon era.
meaning_story: The rope writing people are known as the Jomon People, which are the ancient Japanese.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 歌舞伎のチケットが見当たらないんだけど。
ex_1_en: My kabuki ticket is missing.
meaning_story: A song dance deed is a deed you do that involves singing and dancing. This is the traditional form of stage deeds, known as kabuki. Watch it on YouTube if you want a taste.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 鹿児島県で、今までで運転した中で一番デッコボコの道路をドライブしました。
ex_1_en: I drove on the most bumpy road I’ve ever driven on in Kagoshima prefecture.
meaning_story: The deer child island prefecture is Kagoshima Prefecture.
reading_story: The readings are part on'yomi, part kun'yomi, but you should know them all if you look at them one by one. Just remember that 児 is read as ご here. Go, Kagoshima Prefecture! Go!

ex_1_jp: 神奈川県では漫画がブームです。
ex_1_en: There is a boom in manga in Kanagawa Prefecture.
meaning_story: The god Nara river Prefecture is Kanagawa Prefecture.
reading_story: The か of 神 is used here (losing the み). Then, everything else should be self explanatory.

ex_1_jp: スケート選手たちは、日本スケート連盟について不平を漏らしています。
ex_1_en: Figure skaters are complaining about the Japan Skating Federation.
meaning_story: If we take along our alliance and move it forward to something better, we have a league or federation. It's like we're one group now!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 口紅をポケットに入れっぱなしにしてたみたいで、乾燥機の中で溶けちゃったのよね。
ex_1_en: I left my lipstick in my pocket and it melted in the dryer.
meaning_story: A mouth deep red is a deep red you put on your mouth. This is lipstick.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of both. 口 and 紅 vocab words combined into one.

ex_1_jp: この空港に遺失物取扱所があるかどうかをご存知ですか。
ex_1_en: Do you know if there is a lost and found office in this airport?
meaning_story: The thing we leave behind at a fault is a loss.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: いつもパスワードに母親の旧姓を使うんですよ。
ex_1_en: I always use my mother’s maiden name as my password.
meaning_story: Your former surname is your maiden name, the name you had before you got married.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 車は維持費が高いし、今はまだそんな余裕はないな。
ex_1_en: The cost of car maintenance is really high and I can’t afford that yet.
meaning_story: Maintain what we have and put it on hold. We need to keep it up to date and fixed, so we need maintenance.
reading_story: The reading for 維 makes sense, the reading for 持 is a little different. It's じ, which is a different reading from what you've seen or learned. This kanji does look a lot like 時, though, right? It shares that reading.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 虫歯の治療をするために、五年ぶりに歯医者に行きました。
ex_1_en: I went to a dentist to treat my cavities for the first time in 5 years.
meaning_story: Cure and heal me. That is medical therapy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日本で医者になりたいので、今は医療用語を勉強しています。
ex_1_en: I want to be a doctor in Japan, so I’m studying medical terminology now.
meaning_story: A medicine can heal. This is medical treatment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: イꜜリョー *** イリョー

ex_1_jp: ようやく誤りに気がついた。
ex_1_en: I finally noticed my mistakes.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji mistake, so it means a mistake or if it's on a computer, an error.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you make a mistake, you need admit to it. When someone asks, "Who's responsible for this mistake?" You say, "I am (あやま)."
pitch_accent: アヤマリꜜ *** アヤマリ *** アヤマꜜリ

ex_1_jp: 私は歯のしつこい着色汚れを奈良の歯医者さんで落としました。
ex_1_en: I removed stubborn color stains on my teeth at the dental clinic in Nara.
meaning_story: Nara is good and it is Nara (the place, we're talking about).
reading_story: The reading for 奈 is good, the reading for 良 is pretty off in terms of what you've learned. But, if you know that the meaning is Nara, you know the reading is なら as well.

ex_1_jp: ちょうど国債を売ろうとしたところで、値が急激に下がって、売り損ねちゃったんだ。
ex_1_en: We were on the verge of selling the government bonds, but the price rolled down too quickly and we couldn’t sell.
meaning_story: A country's debt is the national debt. It can also be bonds, like the ones you buy from your country.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ビールでいい気分になったんだけど、その後吐き気がひどくてさ。
ex_1_en: The beer made me feel great, but after I got awful nausea.
meaning_story: The feeling of throw up is nausea.
reading_story: The reading comes from 吐く and the (irregular) reading of 気 put together.

ex_1_jp: 予算の都合上、核実験への臨時スタッフの採用は増やせない。
ex_1_en: Budget-wise, we are unable to increase our temporary staff for nuclear testing.
meaning_story: A nucleus experiment (実験) is a nuclear test.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 核兵器を使用する前に、説明書に書かれている操作方法を必ずお読みください。
ex_1_en: Before using the nuclear weapon, please carefully review the instruction booklet.
meaning_story: Nucleus arms (へいき), aka weapons, are nuclear weapons.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 核ミサイルの発射が、もう予定より三時間も遅れています。
ex_1_en: The nuclear missile launch is three hours behind schedule now.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

ex_1_jp: ピンク色の怪獣は海岸から約8km沖合いにいるとの報告を受けました。
ex_1_en: They reported that the pink monster is about eight kilometers offshore.
meaning_story: The open sea is where the sea joins together to be the open sea.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings that you learned when you learned the kanji. Just remember that this time 合 takes the あい reading.

pronunciation: おやこどんぶり, おやこどん
ex_1_jp: てか、あの親子丼超まずかったよね！トイレで吐いちゃったよ！
ex_1_en: God! That parent and child bowl was so disgusting! I threw up in the bathroom.
meaning_story: A very common food item, though the name for it is a little weird. 親子丼 is Parent and child rice bowl, aka a parent and child bowl. The parent is a chicken. The child is an egg. So, this is a chicken and egg donburi, basically.
reading_story: The reading is 親 and 子 and 丼 combined together into one sick parent and child meal. Just think, that egg could be that chicken's child. At least they're together.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ねぇ、及第点って何点だったか覚えてる？
ex_1_en: Hey, do you remember what score you need to get a passing grade?
meaning_story: I reached the ordinal prefix number that represents a passing score on my test. This means I was able to make the grade and have a status of passing an exam!
