reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女があの盟約書にサインをしたなんて信じられないよ。
ex_1_en: I can’t believe that she signed that treaty.
meaning_story: An alliance promise is one that's made with a pledge or pact. Imagine making an alliance with someone, pledging your support.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ちょっと間違いを指摘させてもらってもいいですか。
ex_1_en: Do you mind if I point out your mistakes?
meaning_story: Take your finger and pluck out the one thing out of all the things that needs pointing out or identification. Yep, that's the one. Pluck that one.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that 指 is read as し here. Charlie Sheen needs no identification because he is easy to point out.

ex_1_jp: 放射能に関する会議を招集する前に、出席者を決める方がいいだろう。
ex_1_en: Before calling the meeting about the radioactivity, we should decide who should attend.
meaning_story: 放射 is "radiation." Add the ability of radiation and you have radioactivity, for some reason. I guess things don't have radioactivity until you have given them the ability of radiation, right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: そのスリッパは私のお薦めです。
ex_1_en: Those slippers are my recommendation.
meaning_story: If 薦める is "to recommend," then the noun version would be a recommendation or some advice. This generally refers to a recommendation of a person or thing, not an action.
reading_story: The reading comes from 薦める. Might I make the recommendation to learn that word first?

ex_1_jp: 彼は信頼できるような気がするし、早合点はしたくないね。
ex_1_en: I don’t wanna jump to conclusions because he seems to be pretty trustworthy.
meaning_story: I believe I can trust you. That's why I put so much reliance and trust on you to do well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 依頼は断られちゃうかもしれないけど、聞くだけ聞いてみたら。
ex_1_en: Your request may be turned down, but it never hurts to ask.
meaning_story: I am reliant on you and I trust you. Therefore, I have a request for you that I'd like to entrust with you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 学校で明治維新について勉強はしたんですが、名前以外は何にも覚えていません。
ex_1_en: I studied the Meiji restoration in school, but I can’t remember anything about it other than it’s name.
meaning_story: We must maintain the new and get rid of the old. It's time for a restoration of policy! This also refers to the Meiji Restoration too. In fact, it probably mostly refers to this, though you'll learn a more full version of this later.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ビエトがTofuguのシステム復旧のために今一生懸命頑張っています。
ex_1_en: Viet is working his hardest to restore the Tofugu system right now.
meaning_story: Restore to the former self. This is restoration.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私にはどっちの縄も同じに見えますね。違いは全く分かりません。
ex_1_en: Both ropes look the same to me. I can’t tell the difference at all.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Please hand me the rope, right now (なわ), otherwise I will fall to my death!

ex_1_jp: つまり、敵の将軍と付き合っているってこと。
ex_1_en: That is to say, I’m dating the enemy shogun.
meaning_story: The commander of the army is the shogun. Do you know the shogun? He ran Japan, and was like the ruling general over the states. You can also call him the general or commander, if you like.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: すごくいい声持ってるね。舞台で歌を歌ってみようと思った事はないの？
ex_1_en: You have such a great voice. Have you ever thought about singing on stage?
meaning_story: A dance machine isn't really a machine... a 台 is a large machine thing counter, so in this case it's talking about a stage. A dancing stage is a stage.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that 台 is read as たい here, not だい.

ex_1_jp: 小さい頃、継父にいつもおんぶをしてもらっていました。
ex_1_en: My stepfather used to give me piggyback rides all the time when I was little.
meaning_story: A father you've inherited isn't your original father, he's your stepfather.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 依然父の消息は不明です。
ex_1_en: I still have no news about my father.
meaning_story: If you have a dependent nature, then even if you go off on your own, you're still going to ask for help. Dependent people still need help because that's just how they are.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 王位継承者の暗殺を企てている者がいるとの噂があります。
ex_1_en: There is a rumor that someone is plotting the assassination of the successor to the throne.
meaning_story: I will inherit at your consent. It's not just given straight to me at birth, though it kind of is. I get succession, but only if people say it's okay.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: そういえば、私の超自然的な力についてお話したことってありましたっけ？
ex_1_en: Have I ever told you about my supernatural power?
meaning_story: Something that is ultra natural (自然的) is supernatural. Too natural! Super!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 僕のパンダロボットは、超音速で空を飛べるんだぜ。
ex_1_en: My panda robot can fly at supersonic speeds.
meaning_story: A super sound that's fast is supersonic speed.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 甘いケーキと美味しいワインを買って、うちに招待すれば、必ず友達を作れるよ。
ex_1_en: My sure-fire way to make friends is to buy some sweet cake and good wine and invite them over.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of sweet? It's sweet.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 私は甘党で、ケーキには目がないの。
ex_1_en: I have a sweet tooth and I’m extremely fond of cake.
meaning_story: The sweet group is a group of people who love sweet things. They really have quite the sweet tooth.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the readings you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 私は源氏物語を漫画でしか読んだことがありません。
ex_1_en: I’ve only read the manga version of the Tale of Genji.
meaning_story: Remember 源氏? He has his own 物語. This is the very first novel ever written (that we know about). This is the Tale of Genji.
reading_story: The reading is the combination of 源氏 and 物語 which you have learned before so you should have no problems with this one.

ex_1_jp: 奴ら、俺たちは働いてるってのに、呑気に日光浴なんかしてやがるぜ。
ex_1_en: Those guys are bathing and relaxing in the sun while we are working.
meaning_story: If a 奴 is just some dude or some guy, adding a ら on there makes it plural. Now it's those dudes or those guys.
reading_story: The reading comes from 奴.

ex_1_jp: 「茹でたワニカニ、いつまでに必要ですか？」「できるだけ早く頼むよ。」
ex_1_en: "When do you need boiled crabigater by?" "I need it as soon as possible."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means trust, but the verb vocab version is to ask for or to rely on or to request. When you trust someone you can 頼む them, but only when you trust them. You put it in their hands. You trust them, after all.
reading_story: But, you're entrusting this task to your friend not because you are busy, but because you want to go have a 楽しい time at the waterpark. Sucker!

ex_1_jp: ビエトはカップケーキブームは既に廃れていると主張した。
ex_1_en: Viet insists that the cupcake boom has already died out.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means obsolete and this word means to become obsolete.
reading_story: Everything has to become obsolete. Even the biggest most fiery things, like a star, for example, will go obsolete at some point.
pitch_accent: スタレル *** スタレꜜル

ex_1_jp: どうして彼女の英語力がグングン伸びてるのか知ってる？
ex_1_en: Do you know why her English skills are rapidly improving?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stretch and the verb vocab version is to be stretched. You know that this is the version where you aren't doing the stretching, because you're letting someone stretch you on a torture rack in order to win a beer (びる). You're that desperate.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck!

ex_1_jp: 彼の言葉を信じて投資信託を買ったんですが、結局大きく損害してしまいました。
ex_1_en: I believed what he said and bought an investment fund, but I ended up losing a lot of money.
meaning_story: If 損害 is "damage" then the verb version would be to damage.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Reading is the same as 損害 as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼氏の部屋、埃がすっごい舞ってて最悪だったんだけど、綺麗な花びらが舞っているんだって思い込むように頑張ってみたさ。ま、無理だったけど。
ex_1_en: In my boyfriend’s room a bunch of dust was fluttering about and it was disgusting, so I tried to imagine that they were beautiful petals fluttering about instead. It didn’t work.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dance and the verb vocab version means to dance, as well as to flutter.
reading_story: Who is the greatest dancer of them all? China's previous ruler, Mao (まう).

ex_1_jp: 一つ大きいサイズの靴に換えてもらえませんか。
ex_1_en: Can you exchange these shoes for a pair that is one size bigger, please?
meaning_story: The kanji is exchange, so this verb is to exchange. If you exchange one thing for another thing, you are going to exchange it, after all. This word refers to exchanging one thing for a similar thing.
reading_story: I don't like this car. I would like to exchange it for another car (か).

ex_1_jp: うーん。どっちの豆腐もいまいちかな。実は豆腐はあんまり好きじゃないんだよね。
ex_1_en: Well, neither tofu tastes very good to me. I’m actually not a fan of tofu.
meaning_story: Bean rot is when you take soy beans, let them ferment, and then you make tofu out of them! Yep, that's what tofu is. Rotten beans.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼の奥さんだと思っていた女性が実はスパイでね、電車から飛び降りたんだよ。
ex_1_en: The woman I thought was his wife was actually a spy and jumped off the train.
meaning_story: The kanji is descend, but this verb vocab word is to get off, as in, to get off the train, or to get out of the car. If you think about trains back in the day, you had to descend down to the platform to get out of them, which is how this word became what it is. You know that this word is the "to get off" word because once you get off the train, you enter the real (りる) world, where hardships are real and not as comfy as the train.
reading_story: The reading is unlike anything you've seen with this kanji. Just think about how you have to get off at O-station. None of the other letters are your stop. Just O-Station (お).

ex_1_jp: 日本では、通常は長男が一家の跡を継ぎます。
ex_1_en: The oldest son usually becomes the head of a family in Japan.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means inherit and the verb vocab version is to inherit.
reading_story: You not only inherit one fortune, but two! You're lucky both sides of your family "accidentally" died at the same time. TWO (つ) fortunes! TWO! HAHAHAHA. Also, you can think of it like the つ of 次, because you are the "next" successor when you inherit something.

ex_1_jp: シャツを入れないと、お客さんに甘く見られるかもしれないよ。
ex_1_en: Tuck in your shirt or your client may not take you seriously.
meaning_story: When you see something as sweet, you're just looking at it like it's some little sweet kid with sweet flavoring. You are not taking it seriously, or you are taking it lightly. So sweet! That's why this word is to not take seriously or to take lightly.
reading_story: The reading comes from 甘い and 見る. Don't take this word lightly and you should be able to learn it no problem.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は薔薇の花びらを一枚一枚丁寧に手で摘んでいきます。
ex_1_en: She carefully picks each rose petal by hand.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pluck so the verb vocab version is to pluck or to pick or to prune, like with plants.
reading_story: You are going outside to pluck some tulips (つ).

ex_1_jp: その火山の噴火の被害は、広範囲に及んだ。
ex_1_en: The volcano eruption caused widespread damage.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means reach and the verb version is to reach. This is like "x reached y" or "x amounted to y." Not so much reaching out and touching something.
reading_story: Oh, yo, if you want to reach that number, you'll have to try harder.

ex_1_jp: 男は舐めていた飴を吐き出しました。
ex_1_en: The man spit out the candy he’d been sucking.
meaning_story: If 吐く is to throw up, and if 出す is to remove or hand over, then if you throw up and hand that throw up over to someone via your throwing up, you are going to spit out at them, or to spew out, or something gross along those lines. Then again, this word can be used to be like "spit the info out already!" too, so it's not all spitting for reals.
reading_story: The reading comes from 吐く and 出す.
pitch_accent: ハキダꜜス *** ハキダス

ex_1_jp: うわぁ！うんこ踏んじゃったの？きもーい。
ex_1_en: Eww! Did you step in poop! Yuck!
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means step and the verb vocab version is to step on. So, not quite "to step" like you might expect, but at least you're stepping still, though it's on something.
reading_story: You want to step on that bug? You fool (ふ)! That's a killer shoe stabbing bug, it will cut right through your sole and poison you via your foot! Fool!

ex_1_jp: 降参しようと思ったことは今まで一度もないんですか。
ex_1_en: Haven’t you ever thought about surrendering, even once?
meaning_story: 降参 is "surrender" so the verb version would be to surrender.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading is the same as 降参 as well, of course.

ex_1_jp: 私は警察官ですが、麻薬の密売組織を摘発するような機会に出くわしたことがありません。
ex_1_en: I’m a policeman but I’ve never had the chance to bust a drug trafficking ring.
meaning_story: To pluck off someone's mask and departure it off somewhere away from their face, that is to unmask or to expose someone.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 貿易事務の仕事を探しています。
ex_1_en: I’m looking for a job as the clerk of a trading company.
meaning_story: Trade is easy if you like trade and commerce.
reading_story: The 貿 reading is okay, but the 易 reading is different from what you're used to. Just think about how a lot of the trade that comes in will come into the train station (駅). So if you want good trade, you'll want to be at the えき.

ex_1_jp: たくさんの人達が津波に流されてしまいました。
ex_1_en: Many people were swept away by the tsunami.
meaning_story: A haven for waves would be inside the greatest most deadly wave of them all... the tsunami or tidal wave. Dun dun dunnnn!
reading_story: The reading is the 津 and 波 kun'yomi readings, combined together.

ex_1_jp: 今超貧乏でさ〜。砂糖も切らしてるんだけど、それすら新しいの買えないんだわ。
ex_1_en: I’m super broke right now. I’ve run out of sugar and I can’t even buy more.
meaning_story: This has the same meaning as the kanji. Stick this onto another word and you have "ultra _____."
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 超音波なら脂肪細胞を永久に破壊することができると言われたので、この3000ドルもする機械を買ったんですよ。
ex_1_en: I was told that ultrasonic waves destroy fat cells permanently, so I bought this machine for $3,000.
meaning_story: An ultra sound wave is an ultrasonic wave.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that the は changes to ぱ for 波.

ex_1_jp: 貴重品はご自身で管理して下さい。
ex_1_en: Please manage your own valuables yourself.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 貴重 means "valuable?" Well valuable products are your valuables!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ちょっと窓を開けて部屋の換気をしない？
ex_1_en: Why don’t we open the window and air out the room?
meaning_story: Something that will exchange energy is something that pulls in air, takes out the bad stuff, and then outputs good air, exchanging it for the bad. That is ventilation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: うちのお母さん、肩幅が広いから、私はそれが遺伝したの。
ex_1_en: My mom has wide shoulders and I inherited them.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: どうせアフィ狙いかステマの釣り記事だろ。
ex_1_en: It must be an affiliate program aiming for either click-throughs or stealth marketing.
meaning_story: Your aim is your aim. What are you aiming for? Despite looking like an adjective, this is a noun, so be careful!
reading_story: My aim is near (ねら) to here. Right there, in fact.

ex_1_jp: どうしてボスに逆らって、そのウィルスへの抗体を作り出そうとするのですか？予防接種を受ける！
ex_1_en: Why do you defy your boss and try to build up antibodies to the virus? Get a vaccination!
meaning_story: Confront your body? Sounds like it's something that's against bodies... perhaps, something that's antibody?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その患者は、左足が麻痺してもなお、サッカー選手になれるという希望に固執していた。
ex_1_en: That patient clung to his dream of being a soccer player even though his left leg was paralyzed.
meaning_story: An afflicted someone is someone who is a patient / medical patient. They are afflicted with some disease which is why they need medical attention.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 応募用紙は裁判所でもらえますよ。
ex_1_en: You can get the application form at the courthouse.
meaning_story: I respond to your recruitment with this application to try and join your group.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: コウイチ大統領は、報道陣と会見をする予定でしたが、食中毒にかかってしまったため中止となりました。
ex_1_en: President Koichi was supposed to meet with the press corps, but he got food poisoning and it was canceled.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 異常なほどお金に執着する男の小説を書いてみたいんだよね。
ex_1_en: I’d like to write a novel about a guy who has an abnormal obsession with money.
meaning_story: You tenaciously wear something. You have some kind of attachment to it. Some kind of tenacity that makes you obsessed with it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Unfortunately, you didn't learn the on'yomi reading for 着, which is ちゃく. Think about how you have a big attachment to chalk (ちゃく). Hold the chalk, love the chalk. You are obsessed with chalk.

ex_1_jp: 彼が塁を踏んだのかどうか、よく見えなかった。
ex_1_en: I couldn’t really see if he stepped on the base or not.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: あの一塁の塁審、試合中に屁をこきまくってたぜ。
ex_1_en: The umpire at first base kept farting during the game.
meaning_story: A baseball base judge is one who judges things on a baseball field. This is a baseball umpire, or more simply, an umpire.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼が塁打を打つのは久しぶりだね。いつもはホームランだからな。
ex_1_en: It’s been a long time since he made a base hit. He always hits homeruns.
meaning_story: A baseball base hit is a base hit or single in baseball terms. A 二塁打 is a double, a 三塁打 is a triple, and a homerun is something you'll learn here on WaniKani at some point if you haven't already.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 打 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic. Who just got a base hit? It was your da (だ), your daddy. Good job, da!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 実際のところ、忍者は直接戦闘することをできるだけ避けた。
ex_1_en: Actually, ninjas try to avoid combat as much as possible.
meaning_story: A war struggle is the part in war where you have to struggle at each other. This is a battle.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 爆弾を分解することは危険だってことは分かってたんだけど、すごく興味があったんだ。
ex_1_en: I knew taking apart the bomb could be very dangerous, but I was really interested.
meaning_story: An explode bullet is when an explode shoots out of something like a bullet, but much bigger, like from a bomb.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: そのチョコレート工場は、爆撃を受けて粉々になりました。
ex_1_en: The chocolate factory crumbled to pieces from the bombing.
meaning_story: An explode attack is when someone attacks with exploding things, like bombs. This is a bombing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 俺は弾丸の雨をとても上手くかわした。
ex_1_en: I expertly dodged a spray of bullets.
meaning_story: Back in the day, a bullet was a circle shape. So, this word is bullet.
reading_story: The 弾 part is okay, but you never learned the on'yomi reading of 丸, which is がん. When you shoot a bullet, you are using a gun (がん). Bang!

ex_1_jp: 先日、銃の弾のようなかたちの便が出た。
ex_1_en: My poop was shaped like a bullet for a gun the other day.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Remember 球? This is also a bullet shape (remember how bullets used to be round spheres?). These are both similar ideas, though their intent is different, and they share the same reading.

ex_1_jp: 敵の陣営が見えてくると、恐怖を感じ始めました。
ex_1_en: Once the enemy camp came into view, I started to feel afraid.
meaning_story: An army base is managed from the camp. This is where all the bigwigs get together, talk, and manage things, right over the open fire.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 吐血したのを契機に、煙草を止めました。
ex_1_en: Coughing up blood was my opportunity to give up smoking.
meaning_story: I pledge myself to the machines. It is my only chance to survive the upcoming machine apocalypse.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今朝の俺のクソが大き過ぎて、トイレの床が崩壊したんだ。
ex_1_en: My poop was so big this morning that the bathroom floor collapsed.
meaning_story: When something begins to crumble and break, it will certainly collapse at some point. It just can't hold up under the pressure.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの事件が先方に契約を解除させたんだよ。
ex_1_en: That incident led them to cancel the contract.
meaning_story: I pledge and promise to do that thing... so much so, I'm willing to sign a contract about it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 火葬のシステムは自動的に停止する訳ではありません。係の人が小窓から骨の様子を見ながら、終わったと思う時に止めるのです。
ex_1_en: The cremation system doesn’t shut down automatically. The person in charge checks how the bones are doing from a small window once in a while and stops it when they thinks it’s done.
meaning_story: A fire burial is when you burn the body. You call this cremation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 死刑執行は五時間も遅れました。
ex_1_en: The execution was delayed for five hours.
meaning_story: A death punishment is the death penalty.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: インターネット上からあんたの写真を全部削除するのは、時間はかかるだろうけど、俺の手に掛かれば不可能じゃないね。
ex_1_en: It’s gonna take some time to delete all your pictures off the Internet, but it’s not impossible for me.
meaning_story: Whittle down and exclude this item from the list. Time to remove it. It's deletion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その派遣社員は、新しい職場の雰囲気をすぐに掴みました。
ex_1_en: The temporary dispatch worker quickly got used to the atmosphere of her new office.
meaning_story: The sect of dispatch helps with all the dispatch and deployment duties.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 昨日の夜酔っ払いに絡まれた時、心臓がドキドキしました。
ex_1_en: My heart was pounding while I was hassled by a drunk last night.
meaning_story: Time to pay over your drunkedness. You try, but you can't pay over drunkedness. You must be super drunk to think that.
reading_story: This is a combination of 酔う and 払い, put together with some small っ and a rendaku added in because you're drunk.

ex_1_jp: お肌の弾力が無くなってきているの。
ex_1_en: The elasticity of my skin is disappearing.
meaning_story: If you want the power to stop a bullet you need to have just the right amount of elasticity. Bullets go right through rigid things, but if the material is strong and has the right amount of flexibility, the bullet with bounce right off!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ダンリョク *** ダꜜンリョク

ex_1_jp: 人員不足でごった返しになっていた病院が急患の受け入れを断ったせいで、男性が死亡したそうなんだけど、でもそれって病院だけのせいじゃないよね。
ex_1_en: The understaffed and overcrowded hospital refused to treat the emergency patient and he died, but it’s not all the hospital’s fault.
meaning_story: Someone who is so afflicted that you have to hurry and help is an emergency patient.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 試験地獄に苦しむ日本の学生にとっては、電車で勉強するのは当たり前のことです。
ex_1_en: Studying on the train is common for Japanese students who suffer from entrance exam hell.
meaning_story: An "examination hell" is the nickname given to the entrance exams you have to take in Japan to get into college. That's why examination hell is entrance exam hell.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that smooshes two previous vocabulary words together into a new one. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 部屋には犯罪の証跡はなかったが、警察は殺人事件ではないかと考えていた。
ex_1_en: Although there was no evidence of crime in the room, the police was determined that it was a murder.
meaning_story: Evidence traces are little bits of evidence left behind.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女の一言が彼の怒りを爆発させました。
ex_1_en: Her words caused him to explode with anger.
meaning_story: Explode departure is when an explode departures from a certain point, causing an explosion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 母さんと父さんを爆笑させるような、何かいいエイプリルフールの案はある？
ex_1_en: Do you have any good April fool’s ideas to make our parents explode with laughter?
meaning_story: Explode with laughs, what explosive laughter.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 笑 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic. Who has come down with explosive laughter? It's the shogun (しょう)! The shogun just can't stop laughing.

ex_1_jp: その戦闘ロボットは、メラメラと闘志を燃やしていた。
ex_1_en: The battle robot was full of fighting spirit.
meaning_story: You must struggle with intention. You know you're going to win this way. Show your fighting spirit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

translation: first ten days of the month
ex_1_jp: 気象庁は六月上旬に梅雨が始まると言っている。
ex_1_en: The Japan Meteorological Agency says the rainy season will start at the beginning of June.
meaning_story: The above time of the month Is the top part of the month. The first ten days of the month, or the beginning of the month.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私はその漁師を知っていますよ。私の義理の兄ですから。
ex_1_en: I know that fisherman because he is my brother in law.
meaning_story: A fishing expert is a fisherman.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading is the りょう reading, because you gotta get in your row boat to be a fisherman.

ex_1_jp: 昨夜漁船を盗まれました。
ex_1_en: I had my fishing boat stolen last night.
meaning_story: A fishing boat is a fishing boat.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: イサリブꜜネ *** ギョセン

ex_1_jp: ここは小さな漁村で、ここに住むほとんどの人は漁業に従事しています。
ex_1_en: This is a small fishing village and most of the people living here are engaged in fishing.
meaning_story: The fishing industry is the fishing industry or a fishery.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どの香りを付けるかを決めるのは難しいですね。毎朝短くとも一時間はそれに時間を費やします。
ex_1_en: It is hard to choose which perfume to wear. It takes me at least an hour every morning.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of 香, making it have the same meaning, fragrance.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The fragrance you smell is somebody's 顔 (かお). Just imagine smelling the fragrance of a bunch of people's faces. Yum!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 一万円札を崩してもらうことはできますか？もしそれができるなら、千円札を募金します。
ex_1_en: Could you break a ten thousand yen bill? If you can I’ll donate a thousand yen to your fundraiser.
meaning_story: If you recruit gold you are trying to raise money, aka you are fundraising.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: もし誰かから電話があったら、葬式に出ていて三時に戻ると伝えてください。
ex_1_en: If anyone calls, say I’m at a funeral and will be back at three o’clock.
meaning_story: A burial ceremony is a funeral.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: きゅうゆじょ, きゅうゆしょ
ex_1_jp: この給油所ではどのくらい働いているんですか？
ex_1_en: How long have you worked at this gas station?
meaning_story: A fueling (給油) place is a place where you get things fueled. This can either be a gas station or a filling station.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 大抵の外国人は納豆が苦手かと思いますが、私もその一人です。
ex_1_en: I think most foreigners usually don’t like natto and I’m one of them.
meaning_story: A big resist is something he generally and usually does... at least in most cases. He's usually a big resistor, that one.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 伯父は、殺されて、ドラム缶の中でコンクリート詰めにされて東京湾に沈められました。
ex_1_en: My uncle was killed, put in a concrete drum filled with cement, and sunk in Tokyo Bay.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though it contains some extra similar meanings as well, like a bay or inlet.
reading_story: Same reading as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 二日酔いだし、足もつるし今日は最悪だよ。
ex_1_en: I’m hungover and I also have a cramp in my leg. Today is the worst.
meaning_story: On the second day, you experience your drunkenness a different way... in the form of a hangover.
reading_story: The reading is 二日 and 酔い put together (the reading for that comes from 酔う).

ex_1_jp: 今日の午後に、盲目の人の聴力に関するレポートを提出するつもりです。
ex_1_en: I’m going to submit my report about blind people’s hearing abilities this afternoon.
meaning_story: Your listen power is your hearing ability.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 週の前半は出張で香港にいます。
ex_1_en: I’ll be in Hong Kong at the start of the week for a business trip.
meaning_story: The fragrance harbor, perhaps this is where the perfumes came from back in the day. This place is Hong Kong.
reading_story: The reading doesn't follow any of the rules you might expect. Try to use the meaning mnemonic to get the meaning, then know that it sounds something similar to the reading. "Hon(g) Kon(g)" goes to ほんこん. Almost the same, right?

ex_1_jp: 苺は旬ではありませんが、クリスマスケーキにたくさん使われます。
ex_1_en: Although strawberries aren’t in season, they are used a lot for Christmas cake.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

ex_1_jp: この刑務所は今満員なので、キャンセル待ちとさせて頂きますね。
ex_1_en: This prison is full at the moment, so we’ll put you on the waiting list.
meaning_story: The punish task place is the place you go to do your task of punishment. It is a jail or prison.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ケイムꜜショ *** ケイムショ *** ケイムショꜜ

ex_1_jp: フグ夫妻は二人とも香川県には住んでいるが、別居中です。
ex_1_en: Both Mr. and Mrs. Fugu live in Kagawa prefecture, but they live apart from each other now.
meaning_story: The fragrance river prefecture is Kagawa Prefecture. Might help to look at the reading first.
reading_story: This reading is made up of the kun'yomi readings for 香 and 川 (rendaku'd) and the on'yomi reading for 県. You haven't learned this reading for 香 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help: If you want to get to Kagawa Prefecture you're going to need a car (か). It's all the way over on Shikoku island, and you won't be able to cross the big bridge without a proper car!

translation: last ten days of the month
ex_1_jp: 四月の下旬に日本に戻って、六月上旬にまたアメリカに戻ってくる予定です。
ex_1_en: I’m planning to go back to Japan at the end of April and come back to the states at the beginning of June.
meaning_story: The below time of month is the bottom part of the month. It's the last ten days of the month, aka the end of the month.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この病院で予約をするには、お医者さんからの紹介状が要ります。
ex_1_en: You need a referral letter from a doctor to make an appointment at this hospital.
meaning_story: Remember how a 年賀状 is a new year's card? This is another kind of card/letter, but this time it's for an introduction (紹介), making it a letter of introduction.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 紹介 as well.
pitch_accent: ショーカイジョー *** ショーカꜜイジョー

ex_1_jp: 終身刑を言い渡されたのは初めてです。
ex_1_en: This is the first time I’ve been given a life sentence.
meaning_story: Until the end of somebody, you will be punished. If you are punished to your end, you are being given a life sentence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 電話が壊れてるのかも。だって、聴者から電話が一本もないなんて、おかしいよ。
ex_1_en: Something might be wrong with the phone because it’s weird that no listeners have called in.
meaning_story: A listen someone, is someone who listens. This is a listener.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. For this word, most often you'll hear the word リスナー but this is a kanji learning site, so you're going to be learning yourself some kanji, you hear?

ex_1_jp: 一人暮らしをしているので、冬時間が始まった時に、時計を一時間遅らせることを忘れてしまいました。
ex_1_en: I’m living alone and I forgot to set my clock back an hour when the winter time started.
meaning_story: If 暮らす is "to live" or "to live one's life," then to live one's life as 一人, means you are living alone.
reading_story: The reading is the vocab readings from 一人 and 暮らす.

translation: middle ten days of the month
ex_1_jp: 予定日は十一月の中旬です。
ex_1_en: My due day is around the middle of November.
meaning_story: The middle time of the month is the middle ten days of the month.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 奇跡でも起こらない限り、百人が同時におならをするのは不可能でしょう。
ex_1_en: Unless there is a miracle, a hundred people won’t be able to fart at the same time.
meaning_story: Some odd traces are left over here. We don't really understand what happened, because it was a miracle, but it certainly left some odd traces behind.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「明日までに、この味噌汁を飲んでしまわなければならないよ。」「じゃあ、さっさと片付けちまおうぜ。」
ex_1_en: "We have to finish eating this miso soup by tomorrow." "Okay, let’s get it over with."
meaning_story: You know that 味噌 is "miso," and that 汁 is "soup." So, combine them together and you have Miso Soup.
reading_story: The reading is 味噌 plus the vocab 汁 put together.

ex_1_jp: アヤは、レストランが臨時休業の掲示をしている紙に余白があるのを見つけては、そこに落書きをします。
ex_1_en: Whenever Aya sees that a restaurant put up a notice about shutting down for a holiday and there is some space left on the paper, she draws doodles there.
meaning_story: To display and indicate something is to put up a notice or bulletin.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この油絵はフリマで千五百円で買ったんですよ。
ex_1_en: I bought this oil painting for 1500 yen at a flea market.
meaning_story: An oil painting is an oil painting.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi readings, so combine 油 and 絵 together into one word.

ex_1_jp: この雲と風は嵐の前兆です。
ex_1_en: The clouds and wind are signs of a storm.
meaning_story: A before omen is something that tells you about something that will happen before it happens. Really this is just an omen or sign.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 支払いはカードでお願いします。
ex_1_en: Please make payments by card.
meaning_story: The pay that supports you is made in payments. Whether you make payments to keep your house or your car, or you get payments from your boss, they keep you going.
reading_story: This is a combination of the on'yomi reading of 支 and the kun'yomi reading of 払. You've learned them both, so you know this too!

ex_1_jp: 現金払いにして頂けるなら、5%引きにさせて頂きます。
ex_1_en: We offer 5% off if you pay with cash.
meaning_story: If 払う is "to pay" then the noun version is a payment.
reading_story: The reading comes from 払う, so know that and it will pay forward your knowledge to this one.

ex_1_jp: 学校では香水が禁止されているにもかかわらず、その男子生徒はいつも甘い香りの香水を付けていて、教師たちには自然な脇の臭いだと言っていた。
ex_1_en: Even though wearing perfume is banned at school, that guy always wears a fragrant perfume and he told the teachers that it was his natural armpit smell.
meaning_story: A fragrance of water is a perfume.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その刑事は俺の彼女の腕を突然掴んで、彼女にキスをしたんだ。だから、俺はそいつを殴りつけてやったんだけど、そしたら逮捕されたんだよ。そんなの不公平だよ。
ex_1_en: Without warning that officer grabbed my girlfriend’s arm and kissed her. So I punched him and he arrested me. It’s unfair.
meaning_story: A punish action is when someone goes out to try to find people who do bad things, so that they can be punished. The people who do this are people like a police detective (or detective).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 豆乳鍋を食べてみたことはありますか？
ex_1_en: Have you ever tried soy milk hotpot?
meaning_story: A ____pot is any kind of food that's made inside the pot, put together, and cooked. This refers to a type of pot, stew or hotpot, and is attached onto the names of said pots, stews, and hotpots.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その囚人は、十五年間の刑期を務めた後で釈放されたが、行く当てがなく自殺をしてしまいました。
ex_1_en: The convict was released after serving a fifteen-year prison term, but he had nowhere to go and committed suicide.
meaning_story: A punish period of time is the time in which you are being punished in prison. This is your prison term.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguに掲載されているブログ記事を何部かコピーして、日本語を学習している私の生徒たちに配っても構いませんか？
ex_1_en: Do you mind if I reproduce some copies of articles published on Tofugu and distribute them to my students who are studying Japanese?
meaning_story: Display and publish your writing into a publication or form of print.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 犯罪を根絶するには、火あぶりの刑みたいな残酷な刑罰を全部復活させるべきだと思うね。
ex_1_en: In order to root out crime, I think we should restore all the brutal punishments, like burning people at the stake.
meaning_story: A punish penalty is a punishment
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguはまだブロガーを募集中ですよ。
ex_1_en: Tofugu is still recruiting bloggers.
meaning_story: I want to recruit some people, so let's gather them up and do some recruiting and solicitation to get them.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: コストの削減に苦戦しています。
ex_1_en: I’ll have a hard time reducing the cost.
meaning_story: Whittle down and decrease something. This is a reduction or cutback, since you're whittling down and decreasing it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 撮影中に漁師さんの網を誤って破いてしまったため、弁償しなくてはならなかった。
ex_1_en: I ripped a fisherman’s nets by mistake while taking pictures, so I had to reimburse him.
meaning_story: My dialect has offended you? I will make reparation by giving you a reimbursement and some compensation. I'm sorry my dialect was so bad you couldn't understand the speech. Here's your money back.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 学生たちは、権威に対して徹底抗戦を強いられました。
ex_1_en: The students were forced to resist to the bitter end against authority.
meaning_story: We are ready to confront war, if we have to. We are going to start the resistance against your regime, confront you, and even make war.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 古代の遺跡で、フグの形をした石像を見つけました。
ex_1_en: We found a Fugu-shaped stone statue in the ancient ruins.
meaning_story: All you leave behind are traces of the past. These are the ruins of what happened before. The historic remains...
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この薬で船酔いを克服しました。
ex_1_en: I got over my seasickness with this medicine.
meaning_story: When you're boat drunk you have sea sickness.
reading_story: The reading for 船 goes to ふな (probably because you're sick and can't spell). The 酔い comes from 酔う.

ex_1_jp: 日本の学生の多くは、夏に臨海学校に行く事を経験します。
ex_1_en: Many Japanese students experience going to seaside schools during the summer.
meaning_story: If you look to the sea, you are seaside or coastal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 自己紹介では、いつもすぐ言うことがなくなっちゃうんだよね。
ex_1_en: Whenever I introduce myself, I quickly run out of things to say.
meaning_story: A one's self (自己) introduction (紹介) is a self introduction.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの俺の兄貴は恥知らずの嘘つきだ。何の事だかサッパリ分からないなんて言ってたくせに、俺のベーコンを平らげたのはアイツだったんだよ。
ex_1_en: My brother is such a shameless liar. He told me he had no idea what happened, but he was the one who ate all my bacon.
meaning_story: 恥 is a "disgrace." If you 知らず then you don't know something. In this case, you don't know disgrace, and a person who doesn't know disgrace is a shameless person, because they don't care what disgraces them and what doesn't.
reading_story: The reading is 恥 and 知る put together.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は服のセンスはいいが、体型がいまいちだ。
ex_1_en: She has good taste in clothes, but she doesn’t have the best figure.
meaning_story: A he woman is she. Also could mean girlfriend, depending on how it's used.
reading_story: The reading for this is a bit weird, at least for the 彼 portion. Just think about how she (your girlfriend) is a canoe (かの), and you love that canoe girlfriend more than anything. She is your best friend and your lover, and everyone thinks you're weird. Imagine everyone thinking you're weird as you give kisses to your canoe girlfriend.

ex_1_jp: 男は政治家を狙撃するために、そのホテルの部屋が見える場所までやってきた。
ex_1_en: He positioned himself in view of the hotel room to snipe the politician.
meaning_story: If you have to aim with your attack, you're probably shooting or sniping something with a projectile (like a gun, or something).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 昭和何年生まれですか。
ex_1_en: Which year of Showa were you born in?
meaning_story: The shining peace time was a time known as the Showa Era. This can also refer to the Showa Emperor or just Showa itself. Everything Showa is here.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ショーワ *** ショꜜーワ

ex_1_jp: 彼女は、私に下痢の兆候がきたと告げるやいなや、トイレに駆け込んでいった。
ex_1_en: She told me that she had symptoms of diarrhea and rushed into the bathroom.
meaning_story: An omen for the climate of things is a sign or indication of change. If there's an omen, there's going to be a sign as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私のパソコンはハードディスクの容量が無くなってきているので、動作がすごく遅いです。
ex_1_en: My computer is very slow because it’s running out of hard drive space.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of slow? It's slow (or, if you're slow, you're probably late, too).
reading_story: How slow are you? You are oh so slow (おそ).

ex_1_jp: あいつ、あのウェイトレスさんに三回もこのレストランに汁物はないのかって聞きやがったんだぜ。ウェイトレスさんその度にありませんって言ってさ、困惑してたよ。
ex_1_en: He asked the waitress three times if there was any soup in the restaurant and she answered no each time. She was bewildered.
meaning_story: A soup thing is what you use to refer to soups.
reading_story: The reading is both the kun'yomi readings combined to form one word. So, you'll want to make sure you know the word 汁.
pitch_accent: シルꜜモノ *** ツユꜜモノ

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 今月末までに、自爆テロを実行しなくてはなりません。
ex_1_en: I have to commit a suicide bombing by the end of this month.
meaning_story: If you self explode, it means you're blowing up yourself, and probably taking others with you. This is a suicide bomb.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この間、給食の時に生徒が何故か机の中から甘酢の瓶を取り出したのよ。
ex_1_en: During lunch the other day somehow one of the students pulled a bottle of sweet vinegar out of her desk.
meaning_story: Sweet vinegar is sweet vinegar. Them Japanese love their sweet things.
reading_story: The reading is 甘い plus 酢, combined together. It's the kun'yomi readings, but that's probably because we're combing two words into one. It also changes the す to ず so, remember that.

part_of_speech: NOUN, PROPER NOUN, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 感染源を台湾のアヒルの群れだと突き止めました。
ex_1_en: We’ve traced the source of the infection and it was a flock of ducks in Taiwan.
meaning_story: The machine gulf isn't what you'd expect. In fact, looking at the reading will probably help the most first, since this word represents Taiwan.
reading_story: The reading is たい for 台, which is a little different from what you learned, but not the end of the world (especially if you can get the meaning down). The わん is however what you learned, so even if you arrive to だいわん, you'll probably realize that this is たいわん.

ex_1_jp: マミは、臨時のボーナスが出たので、さらにベーコンを購入した。
ex_1_en: Mami got an extra bonus, so she bought more bacon.
meaning_story: Look to time to see how much longer this will last. It's not forever, it's temporary, which is why we must look to time to figure out how much longer it'll be around.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 妻への不信感は募るばかりです。
ex_1_en: My distrust for my wife is only growing stronger.
meaning_story: The kanji is recruit so the verb vocab version would, you'd think, be 'to recruit,' but it's to appeal for or to invite or to raise. So, it's kind of like recruiting, but instead of people you're recruiting you're recruiting for things and actions.
reading_story: You'd like to appeal for two, no (つの), three things! Three!

ex_1_jp: シェルターには、結核を患うホームレスの人がたくさんいます。
ex_1_en: In the shelter there are many homeless people sick with tuberculosis.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means afflicted and the verb vocab version is to be afflicted.
reading_story: I was afflicted with an ancient Egyptian disease that turned me into sun god Ra, but now I'm okay. I was a Ra (わずら), but now I'm just me again.
pitch_accent: ワズラウ *** ワズラꜜウ

ex_1_jp: ストリッパーになると自分で決断したにも関わらず、彼女はまだ人前で裸で踊ることを恥ずかしがっているんだよ。
ex_1_en: Although she was determined to become a stripper by herself, she’s still shy about dancing naked in public.
meaning_story: 恥ずかしい is "embarrassing." This is the verb version. What happens when someone is embarrassed? They become shy and bashful. That's why this word is to be shy or to be bashful.
reading_story: The reading comes from 恥ずかしい.

ex_1_jp: 彼との会話がこんなに弾むなんて、思ってもみなかったわ。
ex_1_en: I never expected such a lively conversation between the two of us.
meaning_story: Weird that this kanji means bullet but the verb vocab version means to bounce. Just imagine someone shooting a bullet. What does it do when it hits the right materials? It's going to bounce.
reading_story: If you're going to bounce something off that wall, it has (はず) to be made of rubber, otherwise it will just go right through. It has to.

ex_1_jp: その事件の真相が闇に葬られるのではないかと心配しています。
ex_1_en: I’m worried that the truth of the incident might be buried.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means burial, so the verb version would be to bury or to inter.
reading_story: We're going to bury you, so this is your new home (ほうむ) now, friend.

ex_1_jp: たとえあなたが死をもって罪を償っても、問題は解決しないでしょう。
ex_1_en: Even if you atoned for your sins with your own death, it wouldn’t solve the problem.
meaning_story: To make reparation is to compensate for or to make up for. Take responsibility for your actions and make up for everything.
reading_story: When you go to compensate for what you did, you become too good for your own britches. You are too good now (つぐなう).

ex_1_jp: 義理の両親と暮らすのって、毎日気を遣うだろうし、疲れちゃうと思うのよね。
ex_1_en: I think living with my in-laws would mean I’d have to take care of them every day, and I’d get worn out.
meaning_story: The kanji means dispatch but this word is to consider or to make use of. Just think about how if you have people that are on dispatch for you, you can send them information to consider and to make use of.
reading_story: This has a similar meaning to 使う, and has the same reading too. If you remember that, you can remember this word's reading.

ex_1_jp: 対向するバイクの存在を完璧に見落としていました。
ex_1_en: I completely failed to see the oncoming motorcycle.
meaning_story: We are versus yonder (that side). We need to switch things around on that side, and we need to counter them now that it's our turn.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「1ドル札を崩してもらえませんか？」「ええっと…25セント硬貨が2枚と10セント硬貨が5枚あります。これでよろしいですか？」「はい。有難うございます。」
ex_1_en: "Do you have change for a dollar?" "Let me see. I have two quarters and five dimes. Is this good?" "Yup, thanks."
meaning_story: The kanji is crumble, so what happens when you crumble something? You are going to demolish it. You are going to break it. You know you're doing the crumbling / demolishing because someone's going to sue (す) you for what you've done here today.
reading_story: You are Zeus, and you demolish everything in your path. Your friend Hercules watches and is all like "That's coo' Zeus (くず), that's so cool."

ex_1_jp: 本日のTofuguの収益の全額が、恵まれない子どもたちに寄付されます。
ex_1_en: All of Tofugu’s proceeds from today will be donated to underprivileged children.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means favor and the verb vocab version is to do a favor for.
reading_story: If you are going to do a favor for anyone, it's going to be for your good buddy meg (めぐ). Imagine a Meg you know (or know of) and imagine yourself doing a favor for her. Meg Ryan is so happy you're in her life.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの本社は、オレゴン州という、太平洋に臨むアメリカ北西部の州に位置しています。
ex_1_en: The Tofugu headquarters is located in Oregon, which is a state in the northwestern United States facing the Pacific.
meaning_story: If you look to something, you are facing it, taking it head on. That's why this verb vocab is to face, as in "to face terrorism," etc.
reading_story: The reason you must (to) face terrorism is because the terrorists have threatened to take everyone's noses (のぞ) away. We must face them head on if we are to save our noses!

ex_1_jp: ズボンのお尻の部分がいつも最初に破れるんだけど、どうしてだろう。
ex_1_en: Why do my pants always start wearing out in the butt area first?
meaning_story: If 破る is "to tear" or "to rip," then this is to get torn or to get broken or to get ripped.
reading_story: The reading comes from 破る.

ex_1_jp: 母熊は自分の赤ん坊を抱き上げ、顔中を舐め回した。
ex_1_en: The mother bear embraced her baby and licked it all over its face.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hug and the verb vocab version is to hug or to embrace. 抱いて抱いて！
reading_story: What are you going to hug? How about a cute duck (だく), or even just your dad (だ). duckを抱く?

ex_1_jp: お前にどの娘を紹介するかを選ぶのは難しいよ。
ex_1_en: It’s hard to choose which girl to introduce to you.
meaning_story: A 紹介 is an introduction. So the verb version is to introduce.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Helps that I introduced introduction to you earlier.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は完璧なトリプルアクセルを跳んだのに、スコアはあまり伸びなかった。
ex_1_en: She performed a perfect triple axel, but her score wasn’t very good.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hop and the verb vocab version is to hop or to jump or to leap. Basically anything that gets both feet off the ground via your own foot propulsion.
reading_story: Know how 飛ぶ means "to fly"? This is a similar idea, though this time you're not flying nearly as much, because you're just hopping or jumping. Anyways, the readings are the same.

ex_1_jp: その癒し系の曲を聴いてると、眠くなってきたよ。
ex_1_en: I’m listening to this relaxing song and I’m getting sleepy.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means listen and the verb vocab version is to listen to or to hear.
reading_story: The meaning is really similar to 聞く, right? The reading is the same.

ex_1_jp: ジェームズは、鉛筆削りの技術のレベルを上げるという目標を掲げた。
ex_1_en: James set a new goal: to bring his pencil sharpening to the next level.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means display, so if you're doing the action of displaying something, you're going to put up something, or, sometimes more specifically, to put up a sign.
reading_story: You have to put up a sign for your newest invention, the car car. It is a car made so that other cars can drive the car. Nobody wants to buy it, which is why you have to put up a sign.
pitch_accent: カカケ°ル *** カカケ°ꜜル

ex_1_jp: 犬が私に反抗したので、「お前は悪い犬だ！」って叱りつけてやりましたよ。
ex_1_en: The dog was hostile towards me, so I screamed at him, "You are a bad dog!"
meaning_story: If you're anti something and you confront the government about it, in some cases you are going to rebel against the government... that is, if you're crazy enough about it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうしてあのケーキを食べるのを抵抗したんだ？
ex_1_en: Why did you resist eating the cake?
meaning_story: Resist and confront those who oppose you. This is to resist.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「彼にあんなひどいこと言わなければよかったわ。」「そうね。でも、言ってしまったことはもう元には戻せないわ。」
ex_1_en: "I wish I hadn’t said that horrible thing to him." "Yeah, but once you say something you can’t go back to before."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return and the verb vocab version is to return or to return something. You know you're doing the action of returning someone or something because when you do, they just sue (す) you because you broke the thing you were supposed to return before returning it.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 母親が病気になったので、私は国に戻ることにしました。
ex_1_en: I decided to return to my country because my mother got sick.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return and the verb vocab version is to return or to be returned. This is when something does this on its own. You aren't doing the returning of something in this case.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: この子たちは、みんな病気と闘っているんです。
ex_1_en: These kids are all fighting against their diseases.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means struggle so the verb version is to struggle or to fight. This struggle is fairly figurative, too. It's more like "the struggle against terrorism" or "the fight against drugs." Not so much a fight with people, which would be 戦う.
reading_story: Your neighborhood is fighting a struggle against car theft. Sadly, your car was stolen. So, you say: "ta ta, car (たたか). Ta ta."

ex_1_jp: 子どもっていうのは、どんなささいなことでも手当たり次第に盛り上がることができるのよね。
ex_1_en: Kids can take the most mundane, random things and get so excited.
meaning_story: 盛り上げる is "to heap up" - this has a similar idea, except now this is more like an excitement or swelling. As excitement heaps up in you, you are going to get excited. Note how 上がる is in here. This means something is happening to you (or something else), but you're not doing the action. When you get all sorts of excitement building up in you, you aren't really doing it, it's just happening on its own in reaction to something else.
reading_story: The reading comes from 盛り上がる. Let the excitement build as you realize you know the reading already.

ex_1_jp: あなたにこのプロジェクトの指揮を執ってもらいたいんです。
ex_1_en: We want you to direct this project.
meaning_story: If you are tenacious you will be able to take control of and to carry out any plan you want. You are tenacious, you are.
reading_story: Notice how the word "take" is in this verb. If you take something, you might say 取る. This word shares take's reading.

ex_1_jp: 歯を削る音ってのは、私にとっては最も不快な音の一つだね。
ex_1_en: The sound of shaving down teeth is one of the most unpleasant sounds to me.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means whittle down and the verb vocab version is to whittle down as well.
reading_story: To whittle down or not to whittle down. Will have to take it on a case (けず) by case basis.

ex_1_jp: 私は、ワイングラスに付いた彼女の唇の跡を指でなぞった。
ex_1_en: Her lips left marks on the wine glass and I traced it with my finger.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When something leaves traces or marks behind, it's because they were there, but now they're gone, and you've come 後 (あと) they left.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 誰かがTofuguのオフィスに盗聴器を仕掛けたのですが、私達は犯人も理由も分かりません。
ex_1_en: Someone bugged the Tofugu office, but we have no idea who or why.
meaning_story: I steal by listening to what people say. I do this by wiretapping their phone and bugging their homes.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 無い知恵を絞ってこのラブレターを書いたよ。
ex_1_en: I racked my brain to write this love letter.
meaning_story: You are favored with knowing things. You have wisdom and intelligence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 最後に短編小説を執筆したのはいつですか？
ex_1_en: When was the last time you wrote a short story?
meaning_story: If you have a tenacious writing brush, you are doing a lot of writing. Also, if you write for a magazine you probably write a ton too, because they have to come out with new issues every week or month.
reading_story: The 執 is a little altered, where しゅう goes to しっ. It's a weird shortening, but hopefully it makes sense in your head after a couple repetitions. 筆 just goes to ぴつ, like you might expect.

ex_1_jp: 全く馬鹿らしいにもほどがある！！！
ex_1_en: That’s completely absurd!!!
meaning_story: 馬鹿 is "stupid" so if you hear a rumor about something (らしい) that's stupid, you'll just respond by saying "that's absurd."
reading_story: The reading comes from 馬鹿.

ex_1_jp: 馬鹿馬鹿しいこと言わないでよ。
ex_1_en: Don’t say stupid things.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 馬鹿 means "idiot?" Well put two idiots together and everything they say and do is absolutely absurd. Remember how ridiculous that "Dumb and Dumber" movie was? Yeah. Like that.
reading_story: You alreadly learned 馬鹿, so as long as you can remember it twice in a row, you should be able to read this too!

ex_1_jp: コウイチはビエトに窓を開けるよう頼みましたが、ビエトは仕事に集中していて聞こえませんでした。
ex_1_en: Koichi asked Viet to open the window, but he was concentrating on his work and he couldn’t hear it.
meaning_story: To 頼む is "to ask for" or "to request." The noun version of that is a favor or a request.
reading_story: The reading comes from 頼む.

ex_1_jp: 暑すぎだよ〜。ちょっと冷房付けてもらえないかな。
ex_1_en: I’m cooking. Could you turn on the air conditioning please?
meaning_story: A cool cluster is something that has a cluster of cool-creating coolant. This device is an air conditioning.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: このセキュリティー対策アプリは、AndroidOS及びiOSのどちらでもご利用頂けます。
ex_1_en: This security app is for Android OS as well as iOS.
meaning_story: To 及ぶ is "to reach" or "to amount to." The noun version is more like a grammar thing, as it means "as well as." Perhaps if you are reaching a certain point or certain amount, then you are adding things on. That's why "as well as" is the meaning of this one.
reading_story: The reading comes from 及ぶ, so if you know that one you know that one as well as this one.

ex_1_jp: 今回の舞踏会には、前回よりも明るい色のドレスを着て行くつもりです。
ex_1_en: For this dance, I’m thinking of wearing a brighter color dress than the last time.
meaning_story: A dancing (舞踏) meet is when you all get together to do dancing, the kind that's like "step step swing" (or whatever). This is a ball or dance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ベーコン事業に先立ち、まずは資金基盤を築くつもりです。
ex_1_en: We are going build a fund base for the bacon business first.
meaning_story: A foundation tray is a flat thing that is your foundation. It holds everything up. It is the base of everything that goes above it. It is the foundation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 我が社にとってその受託契約を受注することがどんなに重要か、分かっているよな。
ex_1_en: Do you know how desperately we need the brokerage contract?
meaning_story: You accept and consign the job. You are going to be entrusted with this property for the winter. Don't go into room 237.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 今年の新年の抱負の一つは、ちゃんと避妊をすること、です。
ex_1_en: One of my New Year’s resolutions is to properly use contraception.
meaning_story: I dodged being pregnant. Whew. Good thing I was taking my birth control.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 最初は、どんなもんかなと思って湯豆腐を食べてみただけなんですが、そしたら好きになっちゃったんですよね。
ex_1_en: At first, I just tried the boiled tofu out of curiosity, and then I grew to like it.
meaning_story: 豆腐 is tofu, and 湯 means hot water, making it tofu you've put in hot water, aka boiled tofu.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will of course help to know 豆腐 as well.

ex_1_jp: 彼にはビッグマック以外の賄賂は効かないよ。
ex_1_en: It’s impossible to bribe him with anything other than a Big Mac.
meaning_story: A bribe bribe is a bribe.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 父は、私が三歳の時に、「その贈収賄事件には私は関与していない」と母に言うように教えた。
ex_1_en: When I was three my father taught me to say, "I have nothing to do with the bribery case," to my mother.
meaning_story: The presents you acquire are a bribe. What? That is bribery!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: もう少し我慢すれば、依頼人が誰だか分かったのに。
ex_1_en: If you had a little more patience, you could have found out who the client was.
meaning_story: The person who is reliant on you and trusts you is your client. They came to you for help, so you're going to help them.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この葡萄、三房で298円だったんですよ。
ex_1_en: I bought three bunches of grape for 298 yen.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: "How many things are in this cluster?" asks your boss. "Just a few sah," (ふさ) you reply.

ex_1_jp: お母さん、大人って子供への配慮が欠けていると思わない？
ex_1_en: Mom, don’t you think that adults lack consideration for kids?
meaning_story: If you distribute your considers, you will be giving consideration and care to whatever you're distributing these cares to.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私の家族ではなく自分の家族のことを考慮してください。
ex_1_en: Please consider your own family instead of mine.
meaning_story: I'll think and consider this. I'll give it consideration.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 考 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. Who needs your consideration? こういち does. He's very sensitive, that こういち.

ex_1_jp: そいつがさ、男の目隠しまではしたけど、残りの殺人業務は他の暗殺者に委託したって言うんだよ。
ex_1_en: He says that he did blindfold the guy, but entrusted the rest of the murder to the other assassin.
meaning_story: To the committee I would like to consign these things. This is what I consign. These are my goods for sale.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 生理前は、月経前症候群のせいで、感情をうまく抑制することができません。
ex_1_en: I can’t control my emotions well before my period because of PMS.
meaning_story: Try to surpress and control the enemy. We must control them. We must restrain them.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: アヤが描いたパグのイラストが、ある日刊紙のマスコットキャラクターに選ばれました。
ex_1_en: Aya’s illustration of the cute pug was selected as a daily newspaper’s mascot character.
meaning_story: The day's edition is the daily edition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The にち goes to にっ.

ex_1_jp: TofuguTシャツは需要は大きいかもしれないけど、コスパがあまり良くないんだよね。
ex_1_en: Tofugu t-shirts may be in high demand, but their cost performance isn’t great.
meaning_story: You demand and need this thing, which is why you must make this demand.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: アヤは、Tofugu殺人事件を細部に渡って描写した。
ex_1_en: Aya drew a detailed depiction of the Tofugu murder case.
meaning_story: Draw a copy of the world and you are making a depiction of the world.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 心の奥底でほくそ笑みました。
ex_1_en: I chuckled from the depths of my heart.
meaning_story: Something is in the interior AND the bottom? Why, it's in the very depths! And if it's in the interior and bottom of you, then it's at the bottom of your heart!
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どの国が一番素晴らしい犯罪抑止モデルを有していると思われますか。
ex_1_en: Which country do you think has the best crime prevention model?
meaning_story: Surpress and stop what's coming at you. You must deter it or stave off it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: しばらくすると、ジェームズは円盤を脇に抱えて戻ってきて、UFOを見つけたんだと言いました。
ex_1_en: After a while, James came back with a disk under his arm and told us he found a UFO.
meaning_story: A round tray is a disk, though if it goes through the air it becomes a flying saucer.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「ゲッツー」というのは、併殺を意味する和製英語です。
ex_1_en: "Get two" is a Japanese word derived from English meaning double play.
meaning_story: A join kill is when in one play you get two kills (outs) in baseball, making it a double play.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: クロード・モネは、点画法という、点描画法とは少し違った技法を得意としていました。
ex_1_en: Claude Monet was very good at stippling, which is a bit different from pointillism.
meaning_story: If you draw a drawing or painting, you will end up with a drawing or painting.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 足が泥にはまって、一生懸命抜こうとしてみたんですが、できなかったんです。
ex_1_en: My foot was stuck in the mud and I tried with all my might to get it out, but I couldn’t.
meaning_story: Go ahead and suspend fate, let's get this done before the time we are fated to do it. We are that eager to get started.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 高齢者たちは、雇用について難しい問題を抱えています。
ex_1_en: Elderly people have difficult problems with employment.
meaning_story: Someone of tall age is going to be an elderly person or an old person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私の弟は優し過ぎて犯罪者達の逃亡を助けてしまい、そのせいで逮捕されてしまいました。
ex_1_en: My little brother is so generous that he aided in the criminals’ escape and was arrested for it.
meaning_story: If you escape death you have, well, an escape.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その避難梯子はひどく痛んでいるので、交換する必要があります。
ex_1_en: The fire escape is badly damaged, so we need to replace it.
meaning_story: Dodge a difficult situation by getting away from it. Do an evacuation to get out of there!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どの新聞の夕刊でも、株式市場の大暴落が一面記事で報じられた。
ex_1_en: The evening edition of every newspaper reported the stock market crash as their front page story.
meaning_story: The evening edition is the evening edition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 奥にもっと小さいサイズのものも置いてますよ。
ex_1_en: We have ones in smaller sizes in the back.
meaning_story: Something that is in the interior of something else is inside of it, deep, and far back / in the back. Just imagine something interior to something else, it's probably in the back.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 生徒とのスキャンダルは、彼の教師生命にとって致命的でした。
ex_1_en: The scandal with his student was fatal to his teaching career.
meaning_story: Do you fat al... is fatal!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: このホラー映画は、一人称の視点から撮影されています。
ex_1_en: This horror movie was shot from the first-person perspective.
meaning_story: The one person title is the title one person gives themselves. They are speaking in the first person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 全般的に、犬は猫を怖がるものじゃないんですかね。
ex_1_en: Dogs are generally scared of cats, aren’t they?
meaning_story: All generalal! It's super general. It's general and overall and across the board. Nothing specific going on here.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 本当に彼らは父親を鑑定する遺伝子検査を受けたいんでしょうか。
ex_1_en: I’m wondering if they really want to get the paternity test done.
meaning_story: If 遺伝 is heredity and you pass your heredity to your child, how is it being passed? Via genes, of course.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ここに鞄を置かせてもらっても宜しいですか？
ex_1_en: Is it okay for me to put my bag here?
meaning_story: You send your best regards to everyone. Is this good? Is it okay? Is it all right? Yes, of course, how nice of you.
reading_story: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 何で暖房消したの？パイプが全部凍っちゃったじゃない。
ex_1_en: Why did you turn off the heater? All the pipes are completely frozen!
meaning_story: A warm cluster is when you get a bunch of warmth together, and then use it to warm your home. This is heating, kind of like the same way how an air conditioner is a "cool cluster."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その小川が緩やかに東にカーブしているところがあるんだけど、そこが釣りの穴場なんだよ。
ex_1_en: The stream curves gently towards the east and is a good fishing spot.
meaning_story: This is the na-adjective version of loose, so that means this word means loose or mild or gentle.
reading_story: The reading comes from what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: このシャツは首回りが緩いんですよね。
ex_1_en: The neck of this shirt is pretty loose.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of loose? It's loose.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, so feel nice and loose and move on to the next item.

ex_1_jp: 蛍光灯は明治維新の頃にはまだ無かったんだよね。
ex_1_en: Fluorescent lights didn’t exist yet during the Meiji Restoration, right?
meaning_story: You know Meiji, (明治), and you know restoration (維新). Combine them together and you have the Meiji Restoration.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: アメリカ合衆国は、私が生まれた年にテキサスを併合しました。
ex_1_en: The United States of America annexed Texas the year I was born.
meaning_story: Join and join with each other. This is a merger.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that 合 is read as ごう here. Who orchestrated this merger? Good ol' grandpa ごういち.

ex_1_jp: 月刊誌『ベーコン』は、エープリルフールのジョークとして、「ノーベルベーコン賞はマミに授与された。」と報じた。
