ex_1_en: A monthly magazine named "The Bacon" reported that the Nobel prize for bacon was awarded to Mami as an April Fool’s joke.
meaning_story: The moon edition is the monthly edition, since 月 also means "month."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今日の朝刊の大ニュースには、誰もが多かれ少なかれ興味を抱いているんじゃないかな。
ex_1_en: I’d say every one of us is more or less interested in the headline from this morning’s newspaper.
meaning_story: The morning edition is the morning edition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 千円くらいの、奏楽用のハンドベルはありますか？
ex_1_en: Do you have a musical handbell for around 1000 yen?
meaning_story: Play music that will give me comfort, why then I should go see a musical performance to keep me nice and calm.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: バンドが舞台で演奏をしている最中に、電球が切れてしまいました。
ex_1_en: The light bulb burned out while the band was performing on stage.
meaning_story: If you perform and play music you are doing a musical performance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私が奈良県に住んでいる時は、彼女は親友の一人でしたが、私が大阪に引っ越してからは疎遠になりつつあります。
ex_1_en: She was one of my best friends when I lived in Nara prefecture, but we’ve drifted apart since I moved to Osaka.
meaning_story: Remember Nara (奈良)? This is the prefecture of it, making it Nara Prefecture.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 新生児にとっての必需品って何だろう。
ex_1_en: I wonder what the necessities for a newborn baby are.
meaning_story: I have certain demands for goods to take on this trip. Don't worry, it's just the necessities and essentials.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ヒツジュヒン *** ヒツジュꜜヒン

ex_1_jp: うちの娘は沖縄が大好きで、一体いつ戻ってくるのかさっぱり分かりません。
ex_1_en: I am not sure when my daughter will be back from Okinawa because she likes it there so much.
meaning_story: The open sea rope is the rope that attaches Okinawa to the mainland.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, put together.

ex_1_jp: 日本の老齢年金の仕組みについてご説明してもらえませんでしょうか。
ex_1_en: Could you please explain the structure of Japan’s old-age pension to me?
meaning_story: If you are at an elderly age you are at an old age.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 善かれと思ってしたことが、却って仇となって友人のストレスになってしまいました。
ex_1_en: I just wanted to do the right thing but instead it backfired and I just stressed my friend out.
meaning_story: Something that is contrary... this is the te-form version of contrary, meaning you're starting to say something, making this on the contrary.
reading_story: The reading is like 変える, which is to change. So, if you change what the other person is saying to another way, then you're saying you're changing things. It has the same reading, so remember it that way.

ex_1_jp: 警察は、その暴動を抑圧するのにしばらく時間がかかりました。
ex_1_en: It took the police a while to suppress the riot.
meaning_story: I want to suppress and pressure you! Muahaha! This is oppression.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 大学卒業後も実家に住み続けることは、日本ではそこそこ一般的です。
ex_1_en: Continuing to live in your parents’ home after graduating from college is pretty common in Japan.
meaning_story: If 一般 is "general"/"common" then something that has 的 attached to it is ordinary or normal or common.
reading_story: The reading comes from 一般 plus 的.

ex_1_jp: 妊婦さんのためのカウンセラーという、臨時の仕事が見つかりました。
ex_1_en: I got a temporary job as a counselor for pregnant women.
meaning_story: A pregnant wife is a pregnant woman.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: おくぶかい, おくふかい
ex_1_jp: 狩人とは非常に奥深い職業です。
ex_1_en: A hunter is a very profound occupation.
meaning_story: If your interior is deep, then you're a really profound person.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned おく when you learned the kanji, and ふかい from 深い, so you should be able to read this on your own. Most of the time the ふ is rendaku'd into ぶ, but it can be read the other way too.

ex_1_jp: 行方不明の英語教師は、足が凍傷になっていたものの、無事に生還しました。
ex_1_en: Although his feet were frostbitten, the missing English teacher safely came back alive.
meaning_story: We got life by sending back our runner to home plate. That run allowed us a more life in this game, and maybe we'll win! It was all by reaching home plate.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguメンバー全員がバンジージャンプに挑戦するというアイディアは、速攻で却下されました。
ex_1_en: My idea for all of the Tofugu members to bungee jump was quickly rejected.
meaning_story: It is contrary to what I think is good. It is below my standards. Thus, rejection.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: キャꜜッカ *** キャッカ

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 質問があればどんなものでも遠慮なくおっしゃって下さいね。
ex_1_en: Don’t hesitate to ask me any questions.
meaning_story: A far consider is when you let your considerations go far from you so you don't think about how angry you are about what's going on in front of you. It allows you to have some restraint, since your considerations are far from here. It also allows you to decline things, since you're not considering the other person's feelings.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 遠 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic for ya. An ent えん needs to show restraint or it will go into decline. An ent needs to practice restraint - it's very important.
pitch_accent: エꜜンリョ *** エンリョ

ex_1_jp: 優勝旗が毎年返還されなくちゃいけないなんて、知らなかったよ。
ex_1_en: I didn’t know that the championship flag had to be returned every year.
meaning_story: If we return and send back things, we will have done a return or restoration.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 我々は円高還元セールを実施します。
ex_1_en: We are going to have a strong yen reduction sale.
meaning_story: Send back to the origin means you are going to return to origins. Make a reduction down to the original.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 案の定、その場所はヤクザの縄張りだった。
ex_1_en: Sure enough, the place was Yakuza’s territory.
meaning_story: Take your rope and stretch it out to show where the cutoff is. This is when you rope off something. It shows your territory and turf. Don't cross this rope I've stretched out, it's my domain.
reading_story: The reading is 縄 and 張る put together into one word.
pitch_accent: ナワバリ *** ナワバリꜜ

ex_1_jp: 私はICレコーダーで会話を内緒で録音します。
ex_1_en: I secretly record conversations with my IC recorder.
meaning_story: We're inside together on this information. Just you and me, inside our knowledge. It is secret and confidential.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ナイショꜜ *** ナイショ

ex_1_jp: 私の大学では、第二外国語は自由に選べるんですが、どの言語を選択するか迷いに迷っています。
ex_1_en: In my university, we can freely choose our second language and I’m at a loss as to which language to choose.
meaning_story: Choose and select your choice. This is your selection.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: アシメっていう左右非対称のショートカットにしてみようかなって思ってるんだよね。
ex_1_en: I’m thinking of getting a short asymmetrical haircut called "ashime."
meaning_story: If you versus (compare) the title of these two things, you'll notice that they're the same as each other. They have symmetry.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 病院にお見舞いに行くと、彼女の部屋はたくさんの花で飾られていました。
ex_1_en: When I visited her in the hospital, her room was decorated with many flowers.
meaning_story: The dance of going to see someone. It's a sympathy visit. Because, you know, you gotta dance the dance of sympathy.
reading_story: The readings come from the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. 舞い comes from 舞う.

ex_1_jp: 日本人は外国人と喋る時、英語訛りの日本語を話す傾向があります。
ex_1_en: Japanese people tend to speak Japanese with an English accent when they talk to foreigners.
meaning_story: If you usually lean yonder, in that direction, that will be your tendency.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 教師陣が制服を廃止するかどうか検討しているそうですよ。
ex_1_en: It seems that teachers are considering abolishing uniforms.
meaning_story: 廃止 is abolition, so the verb version of that would be to abolish.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 廃止 as well.

ex_1_jp: 技術の進歩に伴って人々は自然環境にだんだん関心がなくなってきた。
ex_1_en: As technology advanced, people grew less and less concerned about the environment.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accompany and the verb vocab version is to accompany. This can be used both literally and figuratively.
reading_story: You need to accompany your friend, so to call out to them you yell "友, NOW!" (ともなう) to command them to come near you to accompany you to somewhere else.

ex_1_jp: 今日は奥さんが同伴するのかと思ってたよ。
ex_1_en: I thought you would be accompanied by your wife today.
meaning_story: The same accompany means you are in the same place as someone, and you are accompanying them. This word means to accompany. This is only used for accompanying people.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 明日車で母を東京の名所へ案内する予定なんだけど、渋滞をうまく避ける方法とか知らないよね？
ex_1_en: I’m going to show my mother the famous sights of Tokyo by car tomorrow, so do you know any good ways to avoid the traffic?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means avoid or dodge and the verb vocab version is to avoid or to dodge!
reading_story: Each reading has a slightly different meaning. Here's some mnemonics to help you remember them: You need to avoid people who drink sake (さけ) all the time. Why? Because when they get drunk you'll have to dodge all the yogurt (よ) they throw at you. Sake and yogurt don't mix. That's why sake drinkers throw it. And they're throwing it at you! Avoid them or you'll have to get good at dodging!

ex_1_jp: その松の木は、少し南の方向へ傾いています。
ex_1_en: That pine tree leans a bit toward the south.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lean, and the verb vocab version means to be leaned or to be tilted. You aren't doing the leaning or the tilting, though, you're just watching, which is why you say "cool" (く) when you see it, because it's already done.
reading_story: You cut a moo (かたむ), that is, a cow, in half. Then you request it is leaned up against the fence so you can start harvesting its meat for sustenance.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は尿で妊娠反応検査をして、お医者さんから妊娠していると言われました。
ex_1_en: She got a urine pregnancy test done and the doctor told her that she is pregnant.
meaning_story: To do pregnant pregnant is to be pregnant.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: もしよろしければ私が町をご案内致しますよ。
ex_1_en: I’ll guide you around the city, if you’d like.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means do and the verb vocab version is to do. This is a polite way to say "to do."
reading_story: What are you going to do? You're going to become a professional eater (いた), because you like to do eating a lot, and you are very polite about your eating despite how fast you eat in these competitions.

ex_1_jp: うちのロゴを違う色でも描いてみてもらえますか。
ex_1_en: Can you draw our logo with different colors?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means draw so the verb vocab version is to draw or to sketch.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 書く, which is similar to drawing something (you use a writing instrument on a piece of paper, which you can do with drawing). Another reading is えがく, which is like saying 絵を書く, but combined and rendaku'd.

ex_1_jp: 探偵を託して写真を全部渡したのが間違いでした。
ex_1_en: It was a mistake to entrust all the pictures to that detective.
meaning_story: If you consign something to someone, you are going to entrust them with that item. Here you go, I entrust you.
reading_story: The reading for this one is super weird, but I will entrust you with this knowledge, nonetheless. The reading comes from the on'yomi reading, which is たく, and is the one you learned. It doesn't make any sense, but that's how the ball bounces here.

ex_1_jp: 怒り狂った妻から逃げ回っているうちに、スーツがボロボロに痛んでしまいました。
ex_1_en: While running away from my furious wife, my suit got really torn up.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means escape so the verb vocab version is to escape. Also, it can be to flee or to run away. Basically, if you're trying to get away from someone or something, you could be doing this.
reading_story: You are trying to escape from something chasing you, but you can't run fast because of your knee (に). You try to run, but it keeps holding you back. Feel the fear and pain of running with a hurt knee, and curse that knee of yours for holding you back.

ex_1_jp: 彼はあまり自分の気持ちを言葉で表さない人なので、度を超す程私に執着していることを隠していました。
ex_1_en: He’s not really the kind of person who talks about their own feelings, so he hid that he was excessively obsessed with me.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ultra or super so the verb version is what happens when do something ultra or super much. You start to exceed the amount you were meant to do it. If you ultra drive a car, you exceed the speed limit. If you ultra study, you exceed your brain capacity. Get it?
reading_story: Who likes to exceed everything? Your 子 (こ)! Or you, when you were a 子. No bedtimes, parents, or other limitations could stop you! You were able to go over them all!

ex_1_jp: 放射能汚染は人体にどのような影響を及ぼすと考えられているのでしょうか。
ex_1_en: What effect do people think radioactive contamination has on the human body?
meaning_story: If 及ぶ is "to reach" then this is something similar. Now you're doing the reaching, and to reach something you have to exert yourself to do it. Also, you have to reach to the goal you're trying to reach.
reading_story: The reading comes from 及ぶ, so if you know that, you'll reach the ability to know this word's reading as well.
pitch_accent: オヨボꜜス *** オヨボス

ex_1_jp: 「ご一緒してもよろしいですか？」「全然、構いませんよ。どうぞお座りください。」
ex_1_en: "Do you mind if I join you?" "No, not at all. Please have a seat."
meaning_story: You are one and together. If you're together as one, you are together.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The 一 becomes いっ.

ex_1_jp: ファンタジーベースボールの優勝者には、何か賞品が贈られます。
ex_1_en: The winner of fantasy baseball will be given something as a prize.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means presents so if you do presents, you're giving them, making this to give a present.
reading_story: If you want to give someone a present, maybe you would think about sending/送る (おくる) it to them?

ex_1_jp: 夫の連れ子にまるで他人の用に扱われて、すごくストレスが溜まります。
ex_1_en: My step child treats me like I’m a stranger and it really stresses me out.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means handle so the verb vocab version is to handle.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, actually! Can you handle that?
pitch_accent: アツカウ *** アツカꜜウ

ex_1_jp: 何か命を懸けるほどのものはありますか。
ex_1_en: Do you have something to put your life on the line for?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means suspend, but this is kind of a figurative suspend. It's more like "hang" though, as in to hang your luck on one thing, etc.
reading_story: Do you remember the other "to hang"? It has the same reading as 掛ける, and has a similar meaning.

ex_1_jp: そのトンネルのボルトは、何本か緩んできています。
ex_1_en: Some of the bolts in the tunnel are coming loose.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means loose, so the verb version is to loosen. This is when something loosens on its own, and not via your actions. You know this because a cow is loosening things, moo (む)...
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

ex_1_jp: 健康を維持するために、何か運動をする方がいいよ。
ex_1_en: You should do some exercises to maintain your health.
meaning_story: To "do maintenance (維持)" is keeping something in that maintained position, which is to maintain.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the reading from the vocabulary you learned earlier. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 偽のベーコンに残された指紋は、マミのものと一致しました。
ex_1_en: The fingerprints left on the fake bacon matched Mami’s.
meaning_story: You do one do and I'll do another do. I'll do the same thing to match it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The いち is shortened to いっ.

ex_1_jp: もし今赤ちゃんができたら、俺の収入だけで家族を賄うのは無理だと思うんだよ。
ex_1_en: I don’t think my income would be enough to feed my family if we had a baby now.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bribe, but when you pay a bribe, you are going to pay something or to cover something, like a meal, or something like that.
reading_story: You need to make a payment, make a payment now (まかなう) to cover the cost of this room.

ex_1_jp: 何名かの歩行者が、運転者が赤信号を無視したことを指摘しました。
ex_1_en: Some pedestrians pointed out that the driver ignored the stoplight.
meaning_story: If 指摘 is "pointing out" then the verb version is to point out.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading comes from 指摘.

ex_1_jp: マミはアヤに、ベーコン雑誌を一緒に刊行しないかと尋ねた。
ex_1_en: Mami asked Aya to publish a bacon magazine with her.
meaning_story: The edition will go out to the public if we were to publish it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼の事を頼っていいものか決めかねています。
ex_1_en: I’ve been wondering if I should trust him.
meaning_story: 頼む is "to ask for" or "to request." This word is "to rely on or to trust or to depend on. You know it is this word because it is rude to rely on your friends, but you are anyways.
reading_story: The reading is a bit different from 頼む, however. It's たよ, because you go to rely on your friends so much they become tiyored (たよ). They say "tired" like that, for some reason.

ex_1_jp: おっと。すみません。トランプを繰るのが苦手なんです。
ex_1_en: Oops. I’m sorry. I’m bad at shuffling cards.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spin so the verb vocab version is to spin.
reading_story: The reading you learned with the kanji is used here.

ex_1_jp: ルームメートが、私のプライバシーに踏み込みすぎだと思うのよね。
ex_1_en: I think my roommate invades my privacy too much.
meaning_story: To step on (踏む) and then to crowd (込む) something, you're really stepping into something. This is to step into or to rush into something.
reading_story: The readings come from 踏む and 込む, put together.

ex_1_jp: 祖母は死ぬ間際、私の顔に手を伸ばし、「愛してるよ」と言ってくれました。
ex_1_en: My grandmother reached her hands up to my face and told me "I love you," right before she passed away.
meaning_story: If 伸びる is "to be stretched" then 伸ばす is to stretch something, where you're doing the stretching. You know this because you took a bus and you stretched it out to be an even longer bus.
reading_story: The reading comes from 伸びる, so if you know that you should know this.

ex_1_jp: 荷物を降ろすのを手伝ってくれ。
ex_1_en: Could you help me take down my luggage?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that 降りる means "to get off." This is when you're helping something else descend down from something, not when you yourself are getting down. So it means to take down or to lower.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 飛行機をうまく乗り換えることができるかどうか心配しています。
ex_1_en: I’m worried about how well I’ll be able to transfer planes.
meaning_story: You have ride and exchange, so you take your ride (bus, train, whatever) and exchange to another bus, train, or whatever. That's why this word means to transfer (or more commonly) to change trains.
reading_story: The reading comes from 乗る and 換える.
pitch_accent: ノリカエꜜル *** ノリカꜜエル

ex_1_jp: 三百人以上の人がその貿易会社の職に応募したが、誰も採用されなかったそうだよ。
ex_1_en: Over 300 people applied for the position at the trading firm, but it looks like none of them were hired.
meaning_story: A trade (貿易) company (会社) is a company that makes a lot of trades, because it's easy for them, making this word a trading firm.
reading_story: The reading for the 易 portion is a bit weird. Just think about how this one trade firm only trades in train stations (えき).

ex_1_jp: 私はビートルズのビニール盤を収集しています。
ex_1_en: I’m collecting the Beatles’ vinyl records.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私はその証券マンを信頼して、投資信託に大金をつぎ込みました。
ex_1_en: I trusted the investment broker and invested a lot of my money into the mutual fund.
meaning_story: If you believe you can consign your trust to someone, then you can trust them, or you are being entrusting.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「おまえの奥さんって、どんな人？」「彼女は何でもバリバリやるタイプだよ。」
ex_1_en: "What kind of person is your wife?" "She’s the type that does everything energetically."
meaning_story: The interior person (the honorific さん shows it's a person) is the person who stands in the interior of the house and doesn't leave, making that person your wife. Ouch. Sexist kanji strikes again.
reading_story: The reading comes from what you learned in the kanji.

ex_1_jp: タイトルはまだ単なる仮称です。
ex_1_en: The title is just a temporary name for now.
meaning_story: A temporary title is what you give something when you don't have a final title for it. it's a working name or a tentative name.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 退屈すぎて欠伸が出てきた。
ex_1_en: It was too boring and I yawned.
meaning_story: When you lack stretching, your body has to get that energy out somehow, so you end up yawning.
reading_story: The reading for this is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You've never seen more yawning than when you performed acupuncture (あく) on a bee (び). It was so relaxed from being the one poked for once that it just couldn't stop yawning.

ex_1_jp: 「年齢はおいくつですか？」「あまり言いたくないです。」「じゃあ、別にいいよ。ただ、百歳を超えてるかどうかだけ教えてくれない？」
ex_1_en: "How old are you?" "I’d rather not say." "Okay, then. Just let me know if you are older than 100."
meaning_story: Your year age is the number of years old you are.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: リレーのレースで、彼は五人をごぼう抜きにする活躍をみせ、彼のチームは見事一等賞に輝いた。
ex_1_en: In the relay race, he beat five runners in a row and his team won first place.
meaning_story: A lively leap is what you do when you are doing some kind of activity or great efforts. It's no normal leap, it's a lively one, after all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お子さんには月々お小遣いはいくら渡しているんですか。
ex_1_en: How much spending money do you give your kid a month?
meaning_story: If 遣う is something along the lines of "to consider" then a "small consider" is what I'll give you for your spending money. Can I have some money? $50? No, how about a smaller consideration on that, maybe something that's more along the lines of an allowance?
reading_story: The reading is the alternate reading of 小 and 遣う's reading. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 南極圏にはペンギン以外にも動物はいるんですか？
ex_1_en: Are there any animals other than penguins in the Antarctic Circle?
meaning_story: If 南極 is Antarctica, then the Antarctica Range is the area that makes up Antarctica. That's the Antarctic Circle.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私の家は火災保険に入っていますが、もし誰かが原子爆弾を落として、それで家が燃えちゃった場合はどうなるんでしょうか。それでも保険金は降りるんでしょうか。
ex_1_en: My house has fire insurance, but what if someone drops an atomic bomb and my house catches on fire? Would I still get the insurance money?

ex_1_jp: 控えの選手には誰がいたっけ？

reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already! Good for you!

ex_1_jp: コウイチはDDOS攻撃に渋い顔をして、拳で机をバンバンと叩いた。

meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. The adjective form of bitter is bitter, or more specifically, a bitter flavor.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: She gives you some food, and it's terribly bitter. You look at the lady who gave you this bitter food. You say, "She boooo" as in, she's no good, and she serves bitter food.

ex_1_jp: 仙台に行くまでに地図を買っておきます。
ex_1_en: I’ll buy a map by the time I get to Sendai City.
meaning_story: The hermit machine is a giant machine that lives in the Sendai area of Japan.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 指せば指すほど将棋が好きになります。
ex_1_en: The more I play, the more I like shogi.
meaning_story: Commander chess piece is a game known as shogi (or Japanese chess, but shogi is better). It's similar to chess in a lot of ways and it's pretty interesting. Check it out if you already like chess.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 母はいつも棋院の真ん前に車を止めて、私を降ろしてくれます。
ex_1_en: My mother always pulls up in front of the shogi hall and drops me off.
meaning_story: A chess piece institution is where you go to play chess... or, in Japan, it's not chess, it's a shogi hall or a go hall (both interesting games, you should look them up!).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その棋士は、この建物に自分専用の練習部屋を構えています。
ex_1_en: The shogi player has his own practice room in this building.
meaning_story: A chess piece samurai is someone who plays chess or go, making this word a shogi player or go player.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 大学生活の最初は、部活の勧誘をたくさん受けました。
ex_1_en: I got a lot of invitations to participate in club activities at the beginning of the university year.
meaning_story: I recommend this to you, so I'd like to invite you to try it. This is a solicitation or invitation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 御免。流石に今日の今日で、空港まで迎えに行くのは無理だわ。もうちょっと早く言ってくれたらよかったのに。
ex_1_en: Sorry. I won’t be able to pick you up at the airport today. You should’ve asked me earlier.
meaning_story: An honorable excuse is all I have, and that is no good. I'm sorry and I beg your pardon.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: そのゲームで鋼の鎧っていくらだったっけ？
ex_1_en: How much is the steel armor in the game?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You take a look at the steel. It's shaped like a person. Turns out you turned that hag into a steel statue. You say, "huh, that's the hag ね?" (はがね). Whoops, sorry hag lady.

ex_1_jp: 賃金カットなんかしたら、製鋼所の工員達がストライキを起こすかもしれませんよ。
ex_1_en: If you cut their wages, the steelworkers might go on strike.
meaning_story: If you manufacture steel that is steel manufacture.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 鋼材不足には早急に対処する必要があります。
ex_1_en: We have to deal with the steel shortage as soon as possible.
meaning_story: Steel lumber isn't really lumber, but think of the lumber as a material instead of lumber. This would make the word steel material.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 帰る前にプリンタの紙を補充しておいてもらえるかな。
ex_1_en: Could you refill the printer paper before you leave?
meaning_story: If you take a supplement and allocate it to something else, you are providing a supplement, because that's what you do with supplements.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 免税店がどこにあるかご存知ですか？
ex_1_en: Do you know where the duty-free shops are?
meaning_story: An excuse from taxes? That's a tax exemption.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 一応忠告しておくと、奴はお前のポジションを狙ってるみたいだぞ。
ex_1_en: Just a word of advice, it looks like he’s aiming to take over your position.
meaning_story: Remember 狙い and how it means "aim"? Make that into a verb, and you have to aim at.
reading_story: The reading comes from 狙い, so if you know that you'll be able to aim at knowing this word's reading as well.

ex_1_jp: あいつ、ビキニ姿のギャルが見れるからっていう理由だけで、市民プールの監視員の仕事に応募したんだよ。
ex_1_en: He applied for a job as a lifeguard at the community pool only to see girls in bikinis.
meaning_story: If 応募 is "application" then the verb version is to apply for or to enlist.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 応募's reading, though knowing the readings of the kanji will take care of things too.

ex_1_jp: 電車の乗客は、携帯での会話を慎むべきだ。
ex_1_en: People on the train should refrain from having cell phone conversations.
meaning_story: If you have humility you will try to be discreet.
reading_story: Why are you going to be discreet? Because that tutu she (つつし) wears is really embarrassing.

ex_1_jp: きっと誰かがもう話をしてると思うんだけど、私達、あの肉屋をあんたの庭に埋めたのさ。良かったかな。
ex_1_en: I’m sure someone’s already told you, but we buried the butcher in your yard. I hope you don’t mind.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bury so the verb vocab version is to bury as well.
reading_story: You learned this reading with the kanji, how nice for you!

ex_1_jp: 彼は、絶版になっている古い小説を私に譲ってくれました。
ex_1_en: He gave me an old novel that is out of print.
meaning_story: If you are going to defer to someone, you are going to concede something. I concede / defer this to you.
reading_story: What are you conceding? Some delicious yuzu (ゆず). You are sad, because they're so much better than lemons and now you don't have them.

ex_1_jp: ああっ！またお化粧が崩れてきちゃった。
ex_1_en: Oh no! My make-up is coming off again.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means crumble and the verb vocab version means to crumble, like, something is crumbling or collapsing.
reading_story: The reading comes from 崩す, so if you know that you know this reading as well!

ex_1_jp: 今お送りしたメッセージを削除して頂いてもよろしいでしょうか。別の方に送信するはずだったものなんです。
ex_1_en: Could you delete the message I just sent you? It meant to send it to someone else.
meaning_story: If 削除 is "deletion," then the verb version would be to delete.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あなたを雇いたいのは山々ですが、就業許可証が発給されるのを待ってはいられないのです。
ex_1_en: I’d like to hire you, but we can’t wait for your work permit to be issued.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means employ so the verb vocab version is to employ.
reading_story: You are going to employ more people to your business so you can make more money and eventually buy a yacht (やと). That's the dream life, it is.

pronunciation: まぬかれる, まぬがれる
ex_1_jp: 後部座席に座ってシートベルトを締めていたので、私達は重傷を免れました。
ex_1_en: We avoided serious injury because we sat in the backseat and wore our seat belts.
meaning_story: You are going to excuse yourself from the situation, and in order to do that, you have to escape from the person / thing trying to hold you there in order to avoid them.
reading_story: In order to do that, you jump inside your man(u) car (まぬか) which is a car for a tough man(u) that needs to drive fast, just like you.
pitch_accent: マヌカレꜜル *** マヌカ°レꜜル

ex_1_jp: シャークは事あるごとに規則違反をするので、そろそろ解雇する必要があると思います。
ex_1_en: Shark has been stepping out of line every chance he gets and I think it’s time for us to let him go.
meaning_story: You are going to untie the person who is in your employ from being employed with you. They are free. This means you fired them, which is why this verb means to fire someone.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あのピョコピョコ飛び跳ねている兎が超可愛くてやばい。
ex_1_en: That jumping bunny is SO cute.
meaning_story: Not to be confused with 跳ぶ, this word has the same meaning. The reading is different, however.
reading_story: The reading for this one is は because you're laughing (HAHAHA!!) at the person who put Nair (ねる) on their legs, then only finding it to be really painful, so they have to jump around to get the pain to go away.

ex_1_jp: ずっと探していた60年代に生産中止になったクラッシックカーを見つけた時は、嬉しくて胸が躍りました。
ex_1_en: When I found the classic car discontinued in 1960 that I’d had been looking for, I was so happy that my heart leapt.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means leap so the verb vocab version means to leap. It also means to jump or to bounce.
reading_story: You go to leap and leap again. You do it so much that you start sweating, which is causing a foul odor (おど) to come from your body.

ex_1_jp: もう三階へ行かれて新しい部屋を御覧になられましたか？
ex_1_en: Have you been to the third floor and seen the new rooms already?
meaning_story: It honorable(y) becomes (なる) that you look at something. This is the humble way to say to look or to please look at something. The reading を御覧になって下さい！
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼がまたピアノを弾き始めたというニュースに、私は胸を躍らせました。
ex_1_en: I was thrilled by the news that he started playing piano again.
meaning_story: You'd think that this means "to bullet" but it does not. It means to play a stringed instrument (just stringed ones). Just imagine taking a bullet and using it as a pick for a guitar, which is the stringed instrument you're playing.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 引く, which is "to pull." When you play a stringed instrument, you are pulling the string in a direction to make it vibrate and create a sound. So, "to pull" and "to play a stringed instrument" share a reading.

ex_1_jp: このコンテンツは、過激すぎて掲載することはできません。
ex_1_en: The contents are way too extreme to be published.
meaning_story: 掲載 is publication so the verb version of that is to publish or to print.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will also help to know 掲載 as well.

ex_1_jp: あのお化け屋敷は本当に楽しかったわ。あなたも行ってみることをお勧めするわ。
ex_1_en: That haunted house was a real blast. I really recommend you to go there, too.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means recommend so the verb vocab version is to recommend.
reading_story: This has the same reading as 薦める, which means essentially the same thing. I recommend you learn them both.

ex_1_jp: 私のかかりつけのお医者さんは、私が大腸癌検査を受けるのを拒みました。
ex_1_en: My family doctor refused to let me get the colorectal cancer screening done.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means refuse and the verb vocab version is to refuse.
reading_story: What are you refusing? You are refusing a child, because children are all bad. You say "子 bad, 子 bad" over and over again.

ex_1_jp: 恐れ入りますが、お客様は鍵を失くされたので、保証金の払い戻しは出来かねます。
ex_1_en: I’m afraid that we cannot refund your deposit since you lost the key.
meaning_story: 払い is a "payment" and 戻す is "to return." If you return a payment, you are going to repay or to refund someone for their payment.
reading_story: The readings come from 払い and 戻す.
pitch_accent: ハライモドꜜス *** ハライモドス

ex_1_jp: 母親は、少女に、悪霊が犬の命を奪ったのだと教えました。
ex_1_en: Her mother told her that their puppy life was stolen by an evil spirit.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rob so the verb vocab version is to rob.
reading_story: Someone robs you of all your things. As he runs away, you yell: "u bad. You bad." Because that person was a bad person, you know?

ex_1_jp: コンピュータを出荷時の設定に初期化することでこの問題は解決しますが、バックアップがなければ失われたデータを取り戻すことはできません。
ex_1_en: You can solve this type of problem by restoring the computer to factory settings, but you can’t regain the lost data if you don’t have a back-up.
meaning_story: To take and return something to yourself is to take back something. Give it back!
reading_story: The readings come from 取る and 戻す. Combine them to get this.
pitch_accent: トリモドꜜス *** トリモドス

ex_1_jp: もうすぐ日も暮れるぜ。全くこの馬鹿げた渋滞のせいで今日は一日何にもできなかったな。
ex_1_en: The day is almost over. We couldn’t do anything today because of this stupid traffic jam.
meaning_story: A bitter stagnate is when you're stagnated in traffic. It feels bitter, doesn't it? Why can't people drive faster? Why are people looking at the accident instead of driving? I'm so bitter about it! That's why this word is traffic jam and traffic congestion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 校長が権力を他の人に移譲したがらないんだよ。
ex_1_en: The principal doesn’t want to transfer his authority to someone else.
meaning_story: Shift the person and defer him/her somewhere else. This is a transfer or assignment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ロード・オブ・ザ・リングの邦訳、もう図書館に返却しちゃった？
ex_1_en: Have you already taken the Japanese version of the Lord of the Ring back to the library?
meaning_story: A home country translation is a translation to your home country's language. Since this is a Japanese word, this translation would be a translation into Japanese.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 左足の甲にタトゥーを彫りました。
ex_1_en: I got a tattoo on my left instep.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word also has a few more meanings: instep (the top part of the arch in your foot) and the back of the hand. These are parts of you that kinda look like turtle shells in shape, don't you think?
reading_story: This word is made up a single kanji, but it uses the on'yomi reading, not the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Just imagine こういち (こう) with a turtle shell on, running around, acting like a turtle, probably on fire since this is WaniKani.

ex_1_jp: スムージーを飲みながら壁をペンキで塗ってるところです。
ex_1_en: I’m drinking a smoothie and painting my walls.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji!

ex_1_jp: いつも壁紙はアヤのイラストにしています。
ex_1_en: I always use Aya’s illustrations as my desktop wallpapers.
meaning_story: A wall's paper is wallpaper.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. It's what you learned with 壁 and the vocab reading of 紙, rendaku'd.

ex_1_jp: 戻り道がどれだか分からなかったんです。
ex_1_en: I didn’t know which way was the way back.
meaning_story: If 戻る is "to return" then you return on the street you came from, you are taking the way back.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of everything. Think 戻る for the 戻り portion.

ex_1_jp: 日本の社会福祉制度の問題点とは何だと思いますか。
ex_1_en: What do you think is the problem with the Japanese social welfare system?
meaning_story: You have much luck in your welfare, making you have good welfare and well being.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 今日ゲームをプレイすると、いつもの二倍のコインが獲得できるよ。
ex_1_en: If you play the game today, you can get double the usual amount of coins.
meaning_story: If you seize and acquire you're making an acquisition or possession of something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女が私の尻を触ったことはセクハラに当たります。即刻戒告処分にしてください。
ex_1_en: Her touching my butt is sexual harassment. I want you to reprimand her immediately.
meaning_story: If I announce my commandment and you break it, I'm going to have do an admonition at you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は良いバスケ部の顧問だとの評判があります。
ex_1_en: Rumor has it, he’s a good coach for the basketball club.
meaning_story: The people who will review a problem are those who know more about the problems. They are the advisors.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ベーコンの平和を唱える主唱者にお会いすることはできますか？
ex_1_en: Could I meet the leading advocate of Bacon Peace?
meaning_story: The master chanter is the one who is the loudest. He makes sure everyone hears his chants. He's the main advocate.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「これ、君への贈り物。干しふぐだよ。気に入ってもらえるといいけど。」「有難う。聞いただけで既にとっても気に入ったわ。」
ex_1_en: "Here’s a present for you. It’s dried Fugu. I hope you like it." "Thank you. Just hearing that makes me happy."
meaning_story: Remember 贈る, which means "to give a present"? A thing that you give as a present is a present.
reading_story: The reading comes from 贈る and 物.

ex_1_jp: 壁の絵はとても雅致がありますね。どなたの作品ですか？
ex_1_en: This picture on the wall is very tasteful. Who painted this?
meaning_story: If everything you do is elegant you have artistry and good taste. So much elegance!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お母様に宜しくお伝えくださいね。
ex_1_en: Please say thank you to your mother.
meaning_story: The kanji is best regards and this can be best regards as well. It can also mean well, properly and suitably as well.
reading_story: The reading comes from what you learned with the kanji.

pronunciation: よろしくおねがいします
ex_1_jp: どうして日本人はいつも「宜しくお願いします」って言うの？
ex_1_en: Why do Japanese people say "please treat me well" all the time?
meaning_story: A 宜しい (good, okay, all right) request is when you send your best regards to someone. This is a set phrase you say when someone is going to help you out and you're all like "thank you for your help" or "I'm counting on you" or some combination of the two. It's a word you'll see a lot to varying degrees of kanji and length.
reading_story: The readings come from 宜しい and お願いします.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 本当に俺たちの柴犬を繁殖させることができると思う？
ex_1_en: Do you really think we can breed our own Shiba dogs?
meaning_story: Something that is overgrown and will multiply is obviously breeding and multiplying a ton.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: これは、ある国では「プレゼント」と呼ばれるかもしれないが、この国では「贈賄」である。
ex_1_en: This is what may be called a ’present’ in some countries but it’s called a ’bribery’ in this country.
meaning_story: Presents that you give as a bribe is a form of bribery.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私達は堀川のほとりを並んで歩きました。
ex_1_en: We walked side by side along the canal.
meaning_story: A ditch river is a canal.
reading_story: The readings are the ones from the kanji 堀 and the vocab 川.

ex_1_jp: このメモ帳に、巨人の捕獲についての思いついたことを全部メモしています。
ex_1_en: In this memo pad, I’ve kept notes on all my ideas for capturing titans.
meaning_story: To catch and seize is capture and seizure.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 合唱団員は、みんなで手を繋いで歌っています。
ex_1_en: The members of the choir are all singing hand in hand.
meaning_story: People who join in a chant group are people who are in a chorus or choir.
reading_story: The reading for 合 is pretty weird. It's a がっ instead of a ごう. Just imagine a bunch of people in a chorus singing "ga ga ga ga gaaaa!"

ex_1_jp: ウェイトレスってのは機敏に動くものなのに、彼女はとんでもなく鈍いんだよ。
ex_1_en: Waitresses are supposed to move quickly, but she is ridiculously slow.
meaning_story: A machine alert is an alert that is timed by a machine, not by a human. That is pretty clever and shrewd, to use a machine...
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は薄情者だし、どっちの味方かサッパリ分からないよ。
ex_1_en: He is cold hearted and I have no idea who’s side he’s taking.
meaning_story: If you dilute feeling from someone, they have no feelings. They become cold hearted.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ハクジョー *** ハクジョꜜー

ex_1_jp: 高速道路で、車が次々と衝突しました。
ex_1_en: On the highway, cars collided one after another.
meaning_story: To collide and stab into each other is to be in a collision or impact.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: この食事は朝昼兼用にします。
ex_1_en: I’d call this meal brunch.
meaning_story: If you concurrently use one thing for multiple purposes, you're using something with a combined use. Something that is serving two purposes.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 当人達は内緒話をしているつもりのようだが、声がでかいので全部筒抜けだよ。
ex_1_en: They are trying to whisper to each other, but their voices are so loud that I can hear everything.
meaning_story: The inside together talk is talk that's only inside between us. It's confidential talk.
reading_story: This word uses the on'yomi of 内緒 and kun'yomi of 話, only rendakued.

ex_1_jp: どうして洗剤一本買うだけで三時間もかかるの。
ex_1_en: Why did it take you three hours to buy one bottle of detergent?
meaning_story: Wash your clothes with a dose of detergent.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: コピー機のインクの色が薄くなってきちゃった。新しいトナーを買わなくっちゃ。
ex_1_en: My copier is printing with lighter ink. I have to buy new toner.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dilute? It's dilute.
reading_story: This drink is way too dilute. You sue (うす) the makers for their thin drink.

ex_1_jp: 自分の家族の不孝になるようなことは、絶対にしたくない。
ex_1_en: I never want to do anything that would be disrespectful toward my family.
meaning_story: Not filial piety is when you don't listen to your parents. This is disobedience to parents.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 堀があれば、ゾンビとうまく闘えると思わないか？
ex_1_en: Don’t you think that if there was a moat, we could fight well against the zombies?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 記念硬貨を排水溝に落っことしちゃった。
ex_1_en: I dropped the commemorative coin down the drain.
meaning_story: The process of rejecting water and letting it go somewhere else is called drainage.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は自称「優雅なマダム」です。
ex_1_en: She is a self-appointed "elegant madam."
meaning_story: Something that is superior and elegant has much elegance and grace.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 植物は二酸化炭素を吸収し、酸素を排出します。
ex_1_en: Plants absorb carbon dioxide and give off oxygen.
meaning_story: The things I reject and make exit from (my factory) is my emissions. Poof poof poof.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日本記者クラブはかなり排他的だよ。
ex_1_en: The Japanese press club is fairly exclusive.
meaning_story: If you reject others, you are excluding them, doing exclusion. That's not a nice thing to do.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 各下水道施設は、下水排除規準を満たす必要があります。
ex_1_en: Each sewage facility needs to meet sewage removal standards.
meaning_story: If you reject and exclude something, you are doing exclusion to it. You could also call this removal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 自動車の排気ガスの臭いが好きなのは、私達の共通点ですね。
ex_1_en: Liking the smell of the automobile exhaust is something we have in common.
meaning_story: The reject energy that you push out of a machine is exhaust. It can also be ventilation, since this is the air coming out and being rejected out.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 暇つぶしにイケメンの殿様の絵を描きました。
ex_1_en: I drew a handsome feudal lord to waste time.
meaning_story: Milord (you say very formally with a formal name title). You say it very formally because this person is a lord, or more specifically, a feudal lord.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 殿 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Feudal Lords were pretty brutal back in the day. If you did something wrong he'd get to punish you. What kind of punishment? Well, he'd cut off your toe! That left most people yelling, "My toe?! NO!" (との). Imagine screaming "Toe no!" over and over as the feudal lord got closer and closer. Holding a pair of hedge clippers or something. Maybe if you yell "toe no" enough times, he'll change his mind.

ex_1_jp: 女房が死ぬ前に、もっと孝行しておくんだったな。
ex_1_en: I wish I devoted myself more to my wife before she passed away.
meaning_story: If you go towards filial piety, you are going to be doing filial piety. Do this for your parents.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: みんな、頻発する地震に、ストレスが溜まりに溜まっているんだよ。
ex_1_en: Everyone is extremely stressed out with these repeated earthquakes.
meaning_story: Something that frequently departures has much frequency and is a frequent occurrence. Oh, that? Yeah, it departures with much frequency.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どれくらいの頻度で家に掃除機をかけますか？
ex_1_en: How often do you vacuum your house?
meaning_story: The frequentness of something, measured in occurrences is measured in frequency.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は「ライオンキングは子どもから大人まで楽しめるショーだ」ということを頻りに強調した。
ex_1_en: He repeatedly emphasized that both kids and adults can enjoy the Lion King show.
meaning_story: Something that goes towards being frequent is something that is frequently happening.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Something that happens frequently is something that has really caught on. People want to do this thing frequently, because it is so chic (しき).

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: その会社は最新鋭のパソコンを購入することを決定しました。
ex_1_en: The company decided to buy the cutting-edge computer.
meaning_story: Something that is new and sharp (presumably because it's so new) is something that is freshly picked. Just imagine a fruit with some thorns on it. New and fresh ones have especially sharp thorns, but ones that aren't as new are kind of dull, which is why sharpness is associated with freshness here.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 逃亡者は逃走中に病気の子どもに会い、自首を決意したそうです。
ex_1_en: I hear that the fugitive met a sick child while he was running away and decided to turn himself in.
meaning_story: Someone who has escaped death by running away is a fugitive or a runaway. I think there was a movie about that once!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この問題集は俊才児を対象にして作られているので、あなたのお子さんには難しすぎますよ。
ex_1_en: This textbook is designed for genius children, so it will be difficult for your kid.
meaning_story: A genius genius is a genius, aka a person of exceptional talent. So smart!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ワイングラスの扱いに気をつけるようにと言われた直後に、案の定一つ割ってしまった。
ex_1_en: Right after I was told to be careful with the wine glass, sure enough, I broke one.
meaning_story: If 扱う is "to handle," the noun version of that is handling or treatment.
reading_story: The reading comes from 扱う, so if you know that you'll have a good handling of this one.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguで仕事をするという栄誉を得たとき、そのオファーに感激して言葉に詰まりました。
ex_1_en: When I got the honor of working for Tofugu, I was so thrilled at the offer that I stumbled over my words.
meaning_story: You have a prosperity of honor, therefore you have honor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あいつは名誉を得ることには興味がないなんて言ってるけど、俺は嘘だと思うね。
ex_1_en: He says he has no interest in gaining prestige, but I think that’s a lie.
meaning_story: A famous honor is still an honor, but it is also a prestige to have, since you are famously honorable. So prestigious!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お前は頻繁にくだらない事を気にし過ぎなんだって。
ex_1_en: You frequently sweat the small stuff.
meaning_story: Something that is frequently overgrown is something that is super incessant. Never stops attacking, never stops coming, and is so frequent in how often it overgrows. Those darn [put plant name here].
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は彼を内堀に通すために道をあけた。
ex_1_en: I stepped aside to let him pass through to the inner moat.
meaning_story: The inside ditch is the inner ditch, or, if you make it awesome enough, the inner moat. If they get through the outer moat, we have the inner one, at least!
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi / vocab readings of these kanji. 内 + 堀 added into one word.

ex_1_jp: 雅楽の演奏会の後は、何をしましょうか。
ex_1_en: What should we do after the Japanese court music concert?
meaning_story: It's so elegant and so comforting. This is Japanese court music, and it's what fancy court people listened to in Japan back in the day. You can also call it gagaku if you'd like.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 信長殿にお伝え頂きたい。
ex_1_en: Please tell Lord Nobunaga.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is put on people's names, though most likely you'll only see this when someone is being sarcastic or if you're watching a samurai TV show. "おはようございます！こういち殿！"
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Who is your great lord? Imagine it being someone named Don (どの). If you know a Don, that's great, imagine that person. If you don't, think of a famous Don that's out there.
pitch_accent: シンカ°リ *** トꜜノ *** ドꜜノ

ex_1_jp: 庭に雑草が繁茂しているので、この週末に草刈りをします。
ex_1_en: Our yard is overgrown with weeds, so I’m going to mow them this weekend.
meaning_story: Something that is overgrown and luxuriant must have quite the luxuriant growth. Lots and lots of growth.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 褒賞を受け取るために舞台に上がろうとした時、彼女は階段につまづきました。
ex_1_en: When she tried to go up on the stage to get her prize, she tripped on the stairs.
meaning_story: I praise you for what you did, so here's your prize to go along with my praise, a medal!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 解毒剤の極秘開発を行う予定だとちょいと小耳に挟みましたよ。
ex_1_en: I heard it through the grapevine that you guys are going to do some hush-hush antidote experiments.
meaning_story: If you take a dose of something, you are taking a dose of medicine. Take your cough syrup, child!
reading_story: The reading is the same one you learned with the kanji, probably because it's attached to things usually, so it's treated like on'yomi.

ex_1_jp: 薬剤を使い終わったら、必ず薬剤入れに戻してください。
ex_1_en: Make sure you put the medicine away in the medicine case after you use it.
meaning_story: A medicine dose is medicine or drugs you're taking.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ヤクザイ *** ヤクꜜザイ

ex_1_jp: なんてつまらない回顧録なんだ。
ex_1_en: This is such a boring memoir.
meaning_story: You revolve to review the record of the past. These records are memoirs or reminiscences.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 子育ては隣町でしてたんですが、子どもたちがみんな大きくなったので主人と私はこの町に越して来たんですよ。
ex_1_en: We raised our children in a neighboring town, then my husband and I moved to this town after they grew up.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Remember the movie "Tonari (となり) no Totoro"? That is the Tonari.

ex_1_jp: 私の隣人は、幸運を呼ぶお守りを持っていることで有名です。
ex_1_en: My neighbor is famous for having a charm that brings good luck.
meaning_story: A neighbor person is a neighbor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: コウイチ大統領は、近隣諸国との関係をないがしろにはしなかった。
ex_1_en: President Koichi never ignored relationships with neighboring countries.
meaning_story: All the near neighbors are the people who live around you and near you. They're a part of the neighborhood.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうして隣国の肩を持つのさ？日本人じゃないの？
ex_1_en: Why are you taking sides with the neighboring country? Aren’t you Japanese?
meaning_story: A neighbor country is a neighboring country. For us, our 隣国 in America are those sneaky Canadians... always waiting to strike, I can tell...
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
pitch_accent: リンコ°ク *** リꜜンコ°ク

ex_1_jp: 隣家ではどうやら窓は新聞紙で拭くようです。
ex_1_en: It seems that the people in the neighboring house wipe their windows with newspapers.
meaning_story: A neighbor house is a neighboring house. That house is right next to ours!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 我々は、人々が沖縄県から去るのを食い止めた。
ex_1_en: We stopped everyone from leaving Okinawa Prefecture.
meaning_story: Remember how 沖縄 is "Okinawa"? This is the prefecture, Okinawa Prefecture.
reading_story: The reading comes from 沖縄 and 県 put together.

ex_1_jp: ちょっと気が変わって、外堀は必要がないようと思うようになりました。
ex_1_en: I’ve changed my mind, I don’t think we need an outer moat.
meaning_story: The outside ditch is the ditch around our town that's on the outside (not the inside ditch, which is the inner moat). This is the outer moat.
reading_story: This word uses the same readings from the previous vocabulary except that 堀 gets rendakued - don't forget!

ex_1_jp: 過敏性大腸症候群に苦しんでいます。
ex_1_en: I’m suffering from irritable colon syndrome.
meaning_story: You've surpassed what is normal alertness. You are too alert. You notice everything. This is oversensitivity.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お前にとって、殿堂入りを果たした選手といえば、誰になる？
ex_1_en: Who would you say are the players that should be inducted into the hall of fame?
meaning_story: Milord's hall is a nice place. It's where a lord would live. A palace.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ショッピングモールの駐車場で渋滞に巻き込まれちゃってるよ。クリスマス前の日曜日なんかに、こんなところに来るんじゃなかったよ。
ex_1_en: I’m stuck in a traffic jam in a parking lot at the mall. I shouldn’t have come here on the Sunday before Christmas.
meaning_story: A location where cars can be a resident is a parking lot.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 場 with the kanji. here's a mnemonic to help you out. Who is parking his car in the parking lot? Why, it's Joseph (じょう) Stalin!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 天気予報が外れて、巡回中に雨が降り出しました。
ex_1_en: The weather forecast was wrong and it started to rain while I was on patrol.
meaning_story: You patrol and revolve around the block to make your patrol. You're going around patrolling.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 薬剤師は別に白衣を着る必要はないと思うんだよな。
ex_1_en: I don’t think pharmacists really need to wear white coats.
meaning_story: A medicine dose expert is someone who knows exactly how much dose of each medicine you should be getting. The person who specializes in this is a pharmacist.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 世界中の聖地を巡礼しようと決心しました。
ex_1_en: I’ve decided to go on a pilgrimage to sacred places around the world.
meaning_story: A patrol of thanks is a patrol you make to something you're thanking. Sounds religious. Sounds like a pilgrimage.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: そのスーパーで買い物をしてる間、私は犬を柱に繋ぐんですが、いつもちゃんと大人しく待ってますよ。
ex_1_en: While shopping in the grocery store, I tether my dog to a pole and he always waits for me obediently.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: You'll have to imagine a pillar standing tall, and made entirely of the Egyptian god Ra and hashbrowns. It is a hash-ra (はしら) pillar, made by the Egyptians who love breakfast.
pitch_accent: ジ *** ハシラꜜ *** ハシラ

ex_1_jp: その巡査は、スコッチを一気にゴクリと半分飲み干した。
ex_1_en: The policeman drank half the scotch in one gulp.
meaning_story: Those who patrol and inspect on their patrols are the police or policeman.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ジュꜜンサ *** ジュンサ

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 携帯の電源を入れるには、電源ボタンを五秒間長押しする必要があります。
ex_1_en: To turn on your cell phone you need to press the power button for five seconds.
meaning_story: A portable belt is something so portable you can put it on your belt. It is portable. Note, this is also a very common term for a cell phone or mobile phone. You'll learn more about that in the coming levels.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 古い防腐剤はどこに捨てればいいですか。
ex_1_en: Where should I throw away old antiseptics?
meaning_story: A prevent rot dose is a dose of something you put on your cut or wound that prevents it from rotting (or you put it on something else to prevent it from rotting). This is a antiseptic or preservative.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ボーフꜜザイ *** ボーフザイ

ex_1_jp: 信じられないかもしれませんが、私が生まれ育ったこの港町は、かつては繁栄していたんですよ。
ex_1_en: You might not believe it but this port town where I was born and raised was once prosperous.
meaning_story: If you're overgrown with prosperity you are probably really prospering.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 今、生殖器が二つある女の子と付き合ってるんだよ。
ex_1_en: I’m dating a girl who has two reproductive organs.
meaning_story: Life, when it multiplies (multiply), is doing reproduction.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 海外駐在員と一緒に外国に来ている妻は、駐在さんと呼ばれることがある。
ex_1_en: A wife of an expatriate employee who came abroad with him is sometimes called Mrs. Expatriate.
meaning_story: You're a resident and you exist in the place you're residing in. That means you have residence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今夜は駐日アメリカ大使主催のパーティーに行かなくちゃいけないんです。
ex_1_en: I have to go to a party tonight that is hosted by the U.S. Ambassador to Japan.
meaning_story: A resident of 日本 (Japan) is a resident of Japan. Alternatively you could be stationed in Japan.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 頑張ったご褒美がもらえることを期待しています。
ex_1_en: I’m hoping to get a reward for my hard work.
meaning_story: I praise you for your beauty. I'm so into your beauty, I hand you a reward... a prize, basically.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 犠打にならないか心配です。
ex_1_en: I can’t help but worry about the sacrifice fly.
meaning_story: A sacrifice hit is one you do in baseball, when you hit the ball in the air, and then the person on third tags up and scores. This is a sacrifice fly.
reading_story: You didn't learn this reading for 打 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. Who catches your sacrifice fly? It's your da だ. Your da is playing for the other team and he gets you out with he catches the ball :(

ex_1_jp: 葡萄を三房買ってきたわよ。
ex_1_en: I went to buy three bunches of grapes.
meaning_story: Remember when you learned 房? Well it can be used as a counter for clusters of fruit. Like a section of an orange or a bunch of grapes! Yum!
reading_story: You learned this reading already when you learned 房!

ex_1_jp: 敷金を全額返金してもらいました。
ex_1_en: I got a full refund on my security deposit.
meaning_story: Spread the gold around. First part, I want you to put in a security deposit.
reading_story: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 耳がすっごい敏感だから、コショコショ話はしないで。
ex_1_en: Please don’t whisper because my ears are really sensitive.
meaning_story: If you have an alert feeling, you are sensitive to things going on around you. That means you have a lot of sensitivity!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は森で熊に遭遇し、鋭い爪で顔を引っ掻かれました。
ex_1_en: I ran into a bear in the forest and it scratched my face with its sharp claws.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of sharp? It's sharp.
reading_story: Something that is sharp will stab someone, but they will sue you for your rude behaviors. They sue rude (するど) behaviors...

ex_1_jp: 通り魔は、鋭利な刃物で私の全身を切りつけた。
ex_1_en: The random attacker slashed at my body with a sharp knife.
meaning_story: Something that is sharp will benefit from its sharpness, since that's all it has, really.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その犬の鋭敏な嗅覚は、何人もの麻薬密売人を捕らえました。
ex_1_en: That dog’s keen nose caught so many drug dealers.
meaning_story: Someone on sharp alert has a sharpness about them. They are quick witted and have a strong keenness to them.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あなたは爆発の衝撃で気絶したのよ。
ex_1_en: You passed out from the shock of an explosion.
meaning_story: If you collide and attack what you're colliding into, you're going to not only cause a large shock but also crash and impact into them. Blamo!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 最近では、兼業ヤクザが増えてきています。
ex_1_en: The amount of yakuza who have side jobs has been increasing lately.
meaning_story: Concurrently with my current business I have a side business. It's really a second job, actually.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あなたの歌唱力をみんなに見せつけるために、このビデオをFacebookに投稿してもいいですか？
ex_1_en: Can I post this video on Facebook to show everyone your skills as a singer?
meaning_story: You're singing and you're chanting. It's a gay ol' time. You're singing and singing and singing!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 愛国唱歌は聴きたくないね。
ex_1_en: I don’t want to listen to the patriotic school song.
meaning_story: You're chanting and you're singing and you're having a gay ol' time. You're singing all your songs and even the chanting sounds like singing. It's so fun.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 花粉症なのに、発表会で独唱しなくちゃいけないんです。
ex_1_en: Even though I have hay fever, I have to do a solo in the recital.
meaning_story: An alone chant is one you do alone. It's a solo!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 都会には、我々の詐欺の獲物がたくさんいるんだよ。
ex_1_en: There is a lot of easy prey for us to swindle in this city.
meaning_story: A seized thing is something you've seized from your victory. It's your spoils. It's your trophy!
reading_story: Since you didn't learn the kun'yomi for 獲 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. Eh (え)? We won the game? Ehhhh?! No way! To the victor belong the spoils! Yay!

ex_1_jp: 駐留軍向けの洗濯サービスとかはありますか？
ex_1_en: Is there a laundry service for the stationed troops?
meaning_story: A resident detained in a location who is in the army is a member of the stationed troops at this location. They could also be the occupying troops as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お座敷のどこかでコオロギが鳴いている。
ex_1_en: There’s a cricket chirping somewhere in the tatami room.
meaning_story: A sitting spread is a spread of tatami mats, making up the tatami room in a Japanese house.
reading_story: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今日車を電柱にぶつけちゃったんだよね。
ex_1_en: I ran my car into a telephone pole today.
meaning_story: An electricity pillar is a telephone pole. All those wires and telephone wires going to and from those telephone poles.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 妖婆の庭には雑草が生い茂っていた。
ex_1_en: The hag’s garden had grown thick with weeds.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means luxuriant and the verb vocab version is to be luxurious or to grow thickly.
reading_story: She gave (しげ) me a razor because my beard was growing to be luxurious... too luxurious. But, I won't shave my awesome beard no matter what she gave me.

ex_1_jp: 光っている電球の上に銀色のスクラッチカードを当てると、その銀色の部分の下に何が書かれてるかが透けて見えちゃうことがあるんだよ。
ex_1_en: If you put a silver scratch card over a bright lightbulb, sometimes you can see through the silver part at what’s written underneath.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transparent and the verb vocab version is to be transparent (since usually people can't "to transparent" something).
reading_story: To remember the reading, just think about something that is supposed to not be transparent, but is transparent after you give it to someone for a while. You're so upset that your (dog/cat/plant/car/etc) is transparent that you sue the guy who was supposed to not make it transparent.

ex_1_jp: 我慢するんだ！諦めるなよ。明日は明日の風が吹くんだからさ！
ex_1_en: Be patient and don’t give up. Tomorrow’s wind will blow tomorrow!
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blow so the verb vocab version is to blow.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 背の高い魔法使いが呪文を唱えると、辺りは一瞬真っ暗になった。
ex_1_en: When the tall wizard uttered the magic word, there was a moment of total darkness.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means chant so the verb vocab version is to chant.
reading_story: Really, when you are going to chant, the most important thing to do is to figure out your tone (とな). If you get the tone down, the rest comes naturally.
pitch_accent: トナエꜜル *** トナꜜエル

ex_1_jp: できれば台所と居間を兼ねるような部屋がある方がいいなぁ。
ex_1_en: I prefer to have a kitchen-cum-living room if possible.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means concurrently, but since you can't "to concurrently", we're going to have to come up with another word to use: "to combine" or "to double as." Since this kanji has to do with something having a dual purpose, we can say that something can combine as being another thing, or double as being another thing, which is where these words come from.
reading_story: For example, a car (か) can double as a place to sleep at night when not enough people become members of WaniKani.

ex_1_jp: 明日、健康診断なので、できれば今日はお酒はご遠慮させてください。
ex_1_en: Tomorrow is my physical check-up, so I’d rather not have alcohol today, if that’s okay.
meaning_story: If 遠慮 is "decline" or "restrain" then the verb vocab version is to decline or to restrain.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the reading comes from 遠慮.

ex_1_jp: 同僚の評価に携わるのは嫌だったが、選択の余地はなかった。
ex_1_en: I didn’t want to participate in an evaluation of my coworkers, but I didn’t have a choice.
meaning_story: Somehow the kanji portable turns into the verb to engage in or to participate or to take part in. I suppose if you are portable, you're able to engage in all kinds of things, since you can move all over the place, participating everywhere you can (rather than being not portable and being stuck in one place).
reading_story: A Taz saw (たずさ) is a saw owned by a Tazmanian, and it is particularly portable. It allows you to participate in all kinds of things, like cutting down trees, or being in a horror film.

ex_1_jp: 雨が突然降り出したので、先輩と私は桜の木の下で避難しました。
ex_1_en: My senior and I found shelter under a big cherry blossom tree when the rain suddenly started.
meaning_story: If you know that 避難 is "evacuation" then you know that this is the verb form of that: to evacuate.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will also help to know the reading of the word 避難.

ex_1_jp: 先生が腕を組んだまま廊下を駆けて行くのを見て、大笑いしました。
ex_1_en: We burst out laughing when we saw the teacher dashing down the hallway with his arms folded.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gallop and the verb vocab version is to gallop.
