reading_story: If you're going to gallop you'll get there fairly fast on your horse. But... if you really want "to gallop" fast you'll jump in your car (か).

ex_1_jp: 今日は五つのお寺を巡る予定です。
ex_1_en: We’ve arranged to go around to five temples today.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means patrol, but what do you do when you patrol? You go around, which is to go around.
reading_story: You're going around patrolling to protect the house of Meg (めぐ) Ryan. Just imagine Meg Ryan's house, and you walking around it. Imagine Meg Ryan looking out at you.

ex_1_jp: 彼の安否が気に懸かります。
ex_1_en: I’m worried if he is okay.
meaning_story: If something is suspended, it is going to hang or to depend on your actions. We need you to make sure it goes right! Your actions are what we're suspended on!
reading_story: We're depending on you to help us to get this car (か), okay?

ex_1_jp: みんな、コウイチの話に、一心に耳を傾けた。
ex_1_en: People hung on Koichi’s every word.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lean and the verb vocab version means to lean.
reading_story: You learned this reading already with 傾く, so remember that and you'll know this one too!

ex_1_jp: 主人がクシャミをしたので、シャッターチャンスを逃してしまいました。
ex_1_en: I missed the perfect shot when my husband sneezed.
meaning_story: You know that 逃げる is "to flee" or "to run away." This is when you do fleeing to someone else. You let them go, or you let them escape, making this to let go or to let escape.
reading_story: Here's a mnemonic to remember the kun'yomi for this word: There's someone you really like but you have to let go. Why? Because this school's policy is no guys (のが)! You should just set him free now, because you aren't allowed to be together here.

ex_1_jp: あなた、我が子のことをもう少し顧みてあげてくれませんか。
ex_1_en: Honey, can’t you concern yourself with your own child a little more?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means review. What do you do when you review something? You look back on it. Meaning to look back on or to reflect on.
reading_story: For the reading, think about another word that is similar: 帰る. With 帰る you are returning to somewhere. With this word, you're returning to look back on something. They share the same first part reading, so you should take advantage of that. 帰る → かえり.

ex_1_jp: どうぞネクタイをお緩めになってください。
ex_1_en: Please feel free to loosen the necktie.
meaning_story: 緩む is "to loosen," but has to do with loosening on its own. This word is when you loosen or relax something, meaning to loosen or to relax.
reading_story: The reading comes from 緩む, so you can use that!

ex_1_jp: その話題については、次の記事で取り扱う予定です。
ex_1_en: I’m going to handle that topic in the next article.
meaning_story: To take and then handle means you're taking it and handling it, causing you to manage or to handle something. You got it because you took it.
reading_story: The readings come from 取る and 扱う.
pitch_accent: トリアツカꜜウ *** トリアツカウ

ex_1_jp: なんだか毛が殖えてるなあと思ったら、植毛手術をしたんだぁ！なるほどねぇ。
ex_1_en: I thought your hair had multiplied somehow, but you had hair replacement surgery, huh? I see.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means multiply and the verb vocab version means to multiply or to increase.
reading_story: What is multiplying? Your use of the word "fu" (ふ) for when you laugh. You used to say just "ha ha ha" like everyone else. Now the occurrences of you saying fufufu is really multiplying. You might also notice that this is similar to the word 増える, which means "to increase." This has a similar meaning and the same reading, use that to your advantage!

ex_1_jp: どう返答していいか分からないので、人に褒められるのは苦手です。
ex_1_en: I’m bad at being complimented because I don’t know how to respond.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means praise and the verb vocab version is to praise.
reading_story: If you are going to praise this guy in front of you, it would have to be for his amazing hoe-using (ほ) abilities. Look at him go with that hoe.

pronunciation: たたえる, となえる
ex_1_jp: 私が焚き火にあたって温もっていると、自分の事をドラえもんと称える一人の男が現れました。
ex_1_en: When I was thawing out by the fire, a guy who called himself Doraemon, showed up.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means title, so just think about when someone gives you an awesome title. They are doing this to praise or to give praise to you.
reading_story: After they go to praise you, you're all like "I don't need praise! Ta ta (たた)! I'm outa here."
pitch_accent: タタエル *** タタエꜜル *** タタꜜエル *** トナエꜜル *** トナꜜエル

part_of_speech: INTRANSITIVE VERB, TRANSITIVE VERB, AND GODAN VERB
ex_1_jp: 同じ失敗を何度も繰り返すのはやめようじゃないか。
ex_1_en: Can’t you stop repeating the same mistakes over and over?
meaning_story: 繰る is "to spin" (so spinning) and 返す is "to return" (so returning). Put them together and you have something that's spinning and returning to the same spot over and over. Something that does that is repeating itself, making this to repeat or to repeat over and over.
reading_story: The readings come from 繰る and 返す. Combine them together to get the reading.
pitch_accent: クリカꜜエス *** クリカエス

ex_1_jp: 結婚相手にどちらの女性を選択するか決めましたか？
ex_1_en: Have you decided which girl to choose as your marriage partner?
meaning_story: 選択 is "selection" or "choice." If you do the verb version of this, you are going to select or to choose.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading also comes from 選択.

ex_1_jp: 彼に、部屋にカーペットを敷くよう説得しました。
ex_1_en: I persuaded him to put a carpet in his room.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spread and the verb vocab version is to spread out or to lay out.
reading_story: What is getting spread out? Charlie Sheen is getting all spread out, nice and flat. Someone's been huntin' Sheens, it seems.

ex_1_jp: 誰かが彼女の無茶苦茶な運転を戒める必要があるんじゃない？
ex_1_en: Someone needs to warn her about her reckless driving, right?
meaning_story: I say my commandment in order to warn and to caution the people not to do bad things.
reading_story: The first commandment I say to warn them of not doing bad things is I mash (いまし) my own potatoes. Nobody else mashes my potatoes. Got it?
pitch_accent: イマシメꜜル *** イマシメル

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 透明人間の男は、バスタオルで自分の体をよーく拭きました。
ex_1_en: The invisible man carefully dried himself with a bath towel.
meaning_story: Something that is transparent and bright so that you can see through it is transparent.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ちょっと警戒していることがあるんです。
ex_1_en: There is something I’m a bit cautious of.
meaning_story: My warning commandment is there to make sure you take precaution and show vigilance when it comes to that precaution. It's only a warning commandment, though, which is why it has to do with prevention and precaution.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: いつも勉強会で居眠りする同僚がいてさ、ついに上司が今日それについて訓戒を与えてたよ。
ex_1_en: My coworker always dozes off during study sessions and our boss finally admonished him for it today.
meaning_story: My instruction is my commandment. You must do what I say in my instructions/commandments. This is my warning. This is my admonition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お兄さんに言われたわ。あなたは意志薄弱だから私と別れることができないけど、本当は別れたいんだって。
ex_1_en: Your brother told me that you are too weak-willed to break up with me, but that you really want to.
meaning_story: Something is diluted to the point of weakness. It has much weakness and feebleness.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 遅れを取り戻すために一生懸命働かなくてはいけないのは分かっているんですが、中々難しいです。
ex_1_en: I know I have to work my hardest to catch up with everyone, but it’s difficult.
meaning_story: You have only one life so do everything with lots of eagerness (懸命). Do everything with all one's might. Go all out.
reading_story: Everything except the 生 uses the readings you learned with the kanji. To remember 生 as しょう, think of how you are running your own Broadway show (しょう), and you're doing it with all one's might (your might). You're going all out.

ex_1_jp: お話中恐れ入りますが、奥様がエレベーターに閉じ込められてしまったようなんです。
ex_1_en: I’m sorry for the interruption, but it seems that your wife’s just gotten stuck in an elevator.
meaning_story: Your interior formal name ender (person) is the person who's waiting internal, out of the picture (remember, kanji was made forever ago and is pretty sexist). This person is your wife.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: それが不法投棄になるとは知らなかったんです。
ex_1_en: I didn’t know it would be unlawful dumping.
meaning_story: Something you throw out and abandon has been sent to the realm of abandonment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi for 投 when you learned 投資 a long time ago.

ex_1_jp: その航空母艦は突然視界から消えたんです。
ex_1_en: The aircraft carrier suddenly disappeared out my field of vision.
meaning_story: An aviation (航空) mother warship is a warship that is like mother to all the aviation things (the airplanes). They come home to their mother warship, which is an aircraft carrier.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 英語を徹夜で勉強するなんて、いかにもあの子らしいよね。
ex_1_en: It’s just like her to study English all night.
meaning_story: Penetrate the night and go on through to the morning. You were up all night and had a sleepless night aka all nighter.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 鉱山で働いてる時は、いつも背中に痛みがありました。
ex_1_en: When I worked in a mine, I always had back pain.
meaning_story: A mineral mountain is one that you should build a mine in, to get all those minerals.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 古いテレビの廃棄に支払うお金、五千円もあれば十分なんじゃないの？
ex_1_en: 5,000 yen should be enough to dispose of the old TV, shouldn’t it?
meaning_story: It's obsolete so I'm going to abandon it. This is annulment. You are sending something to disposal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 原爆のことを言ってるんじゃないよ。
ex_1_en: I’m not talking about atomic bombs.
meaning_story: 原 is often tied to atomic things, as atoms are the origin of all things. If an atom explodes, you have yourself an atomic bomb.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: とても綺麗な手の甲を持っていることが彼女の自慢です。
ex_1_en: She is proud that the backs of her hands are so beautiful.
meaning_story: Your hand's turtle shell is the back of it (see you can make it shaped like a turtle shell if you try hard!). That's why this is the back of one's hand.
reading_story: The readings are the respective vocab readings of 手 and 甲.

ex_1_jp: 彼が高所恐怖症だと思ったのには何か根拠があるんですか？
ex_1_en: What basis is there for you to think that he has a fear of heights?
meaning_story: The root that this is based on is the basis and grounds for my argument. Look, it goes all the way down to the root problem!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 軍艦プラモの専門店を開く予定なんだよ。
ex_1_en: I’m going to open a specialty shop for plastic battleship models.
meaning_story: An army warship is a battleship. Did you sink it? Oh oh! You sunk my 軍艦!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: スズメ蜂に腕を刺され、大きく腫れ上がりました。
ex_1_en: A hornet stung my arm and it got really swollen.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 郷里を訪れるのはお金と時間の無駄です。
ex_1_en: Visiting my hometown is a waste of time and money.
meaning_story: Your hometown home village is the one that's your hometown. It's also your birthplace, where you were born.
reading_story: The reading for 郷 is the one you learned, but the reading for 里 isn't the one you learned. To remember this reading, just think about how your birthplace is the place you were reared (り), and you really (り) miss the place.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 伯父は、自社製品の表示を偽装して逮捕され、現在は刑務所にいます。
ex_1_en: My uncle was arrested for disguising his products with false labels and is currently in prison.
meaning_story: Some fake attire doesn't make you look fake, it makes you disappear. This fake attire is fake surroundings. So, if you're in a shrub, it's shrub attire. If you're in the darkness, it's dark attire. This is camouflage.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 一酸化炭素と二酸化炭素の違いは何ですか？
ex_1_en: What’s the difference between carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide?
meaning_story: Things of the charcoal element are made up of much carbon. Just look deep into the charcoal to see all the carbon in there.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 封筒の表には「御祝儀」と自分の名前を、裏には金額を書いたよ。
ex_1_en: I wrote "congratulations" and my name on the front of the envelope and the amount of money on the back.
meaning_story: A celebrate ceremony is a celebration.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember that 祝 is read as しゅう for this one and you'll be fine.

ex_1_jp: 昨夜我が家で生贄の儀式が行われた。
ex_1_en: The sacrificial ritual was held in my house last night.
meaning_story: A ceremony ceremony is a ceremony.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今更衣室であの女のロッカーを探しているところよ。
ex_1_en: I’m in the dressing room looking for her locker now.
meaning_story: An again clothes room is a changing room. You get to change again, even after changing in the morning for the first time to leave your house. This can also be a locker room or a dressing room, so really anywhere you can change that's not your home, usually.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼の口車に乗って、炭をしこたま購入してしまった。
ex_1_en: I ended up buying a lot of charcoal because of his cajoling.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: I'm gonna put charcoal in your mouth. Whatchoo gonna do? Sue me (すみ)?

ex_1_jp: 父は、僕に拳骨を食らわせるふりをしました。
ex_1_en: My dad pretended to hit me with his fists clenched.
meaning_story: A fist that's like a bone (hard) is a fist that's clenched and ready to punch, making this a clenched fist or knuckles, if you want to get even bonier about it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. But 拳 doesn't use the one you learned, it uses げん instead. Just imagine someone clenching their fist at you. You gulp and say げん instead of けん out of fear.

ex_1_jp: 衣替えをするのって、とても面倒くさいと思うんだけど、どう思う？
ex_1_en: I think dressing for the season is so tiresome, what do you think?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: You pick up some clothes. Hmm, I'd like to wear these, you think. But, the shopkeeper comes up and says, in a really weird accent, "No, I'm afraid those are ころも clothes." ころも clothes? What is that? Oh... you find out this guy has a speech impediment and is trying to say "こども (子供) clothes." Try to say the word with him, but he keeps saying it wrong.
pitch_accent: イꜜ *** キꜜヌ *** コロモ

ex_1_jp: あなたが彼女の衣服を盗んだんですね。
ex_1_en: You stole your girlfriend’s clothes, didn’t you?
meaning_story: Clothes clothes are still clothes!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は、石炭ビジネスでの成功を自慢しました。
ex_1_en: He boasted about his success in the coal business.
meaning_story: A stone charcoal is charcoal shaped like a little stone. Or, maybe it's often found in stone. That's coal.
reading_story: The reading for 石 isn't the one you learned for the kanji, but you've seen this reading before with 宝石. Coal is like a little black "jewel," right?

ex_1_jp: うーん。この炭鉱が閉山するってのは、本当に残念ですね。
ex_1_en: Well, it is really disappointing that this coal mine is going to be closed.
meaning_story: Charcoal mineral has been found! Time to dig a coal mine or coal pit to retrieve it!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: こんなに臭い部屋でいつまでも待たせるなんて、あいつはなんて思い遣りのないやつなんだ。
ex_1_en: It’s not very considerate of him to keep us waiting for so long in such a stinky room like this.
meaning_story: If you dispatch what you think to the other person, you're thinking about them, and you're being nice. You're showing consideration and sympathy for the other person.
reading_story: One reading comes from 思う, so that's all good. 遣り has a weird alternate reading, though (やり). To remember it, just think about how much consideration you're always showing. You're always like "Yah (や), yah, no, I totally understand. SOOO sad." /end sympathy/

ex_1_jp: うちの妹は今年の夏に潜水士免許を取得したんだよ。
ex_1_en: My sister got her diver’s license this summer.
meaning_story: To conceal yourself in water, you'd better start diving and get under the water where it can conceal you!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 雇用者に新しい電話番号を何度も教えてるのに、いっつも古い方の番号に掛けてくるんだよな。
ex_1_en: I’ve told my new phone number to my employer over and over again, but he always calls me at the old number.
meaning_story: An employment (雇用) someone is someone who gives you employment, aka an employer.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうして俺が偽札を偽札じゃないということが皆の為になるのさ？
ex_1_en: What benefit is there to telling everyone this forged document isn’t a forged document?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: It turns out she is a fake. Your niece (にせ) was a robot this whole time, just pretending to be your niece. What is wrong with this world, where your niece can be an imitation niece. A 偽niece, if you will.

ex_1_jp: 今時田畑を機械を使わずに耕すなんて、時間の無駄だよ。
ex_1_en: Nowadays ploughing fields without any machinery is a waste of time.
meaning_story: A rice paddy field. You'd think this would refer only to a rice field, but it actually refers to other types of fields too, making this word simply field. I guess that shows how important rice is, because if a field isn't growing rice, it ain't no field o' mine.
reading_story: The readings come from what you learned with the kanji. 畑 uses the shorter はた reading that you learned.

ex_1_jp: 私は、苺畑づたいにヨロヨロと歩いている老人を見かけました。
ex_1_en: I saw an old man stumble along the strawberry field.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Stick this onto a type of crop, and you have a ____field or ____crop.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.
pitch_accent: ハタꜜ *** ハꜜタ *** ハタケ

ex_1_jp: 蛍の光は、誰にとっても見ていて心地の良いものです。
ex_1_en: The glow of fireflies is pleasant for anyone who watches.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 彼は拳についた血をハンカチで拭いました。
ex_1_en: He cleaned the blood off his fist with his handkerchief.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You make a fist. Why? Because she stole your corn on the cob. "Cob! She (こぶし) stole my cob!"

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 全く同じ日に、二種類の偽造紙幣が東京で出回り出しました。
ex_1_en: Two kinds of fake bills started floating around in Tokyo on the very same day.
meaning_story: Let's create a fake. This fake we've created? It's a forgery.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 地面はガラスの破片だらけなので、気をつけて下さい。
ex_1_en: The ground is covered with glass fragments, so be careful.
meaning_story: Tear off a one-sided piece. It's only one part, not all the parts. It's a fragment.
reading_story: The 破 reading is the one you learned, the 片 reading isn't one you've learned. Just think about how you're tearing off pieces of a hen (へん), one fragment at a time. Here little chicken, I want another feather from you please. *CAW*

ex_1_jp: 果樹園での仕事は結構退屈です。
ex_1_en: The job at the orchard is pretty boring.
meaning_story: A fruit wood is what a fruit grows on (the wood of a fruit is a tree, dummy). That makes this word a fruit tree.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 中村は、葬儀に一人で行くと言って聞かなかった。
ex_1_en: Nakamura insisted on going to the funeral by himself.
meaning_story: A burial ceremony is known as a funeral.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 岐阜県に行くには、電車の乗り換えが必要ですか？
ex_1_en: Do I have to change trains to get to Gifu prefecture?
meaning_story: You've seen how 岐阜 is "Gifu." Now make it a prefecture to make Gifu prefecture.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: こきょう, ふるさと
ex_1_jp: 聞いたところによると、彼女、離婚後故郷に戻ったらしいぜ。
ex_1_en: From what I’ve heard, she moved back to her hometown after the divorce.
meaning_story: By circumstance this is your hometown. Not much to say other than it's your hometown and birthplace.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その熊は、蜜の入った瓶を五本、次々飲み干しました。
ex_1_en: The bear swallowed five jars of the honey, one after the other.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That's honey, baby!

ex_1_jp: 彼女は私の蜂蜜プリンを一口味見しました。
ex_1_en: She took a bite of my honey pudding.
meaning_story: A bee's honey is its honey, honey.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 私の一番好きな日本の諺は、「身を殺して仁を成す」です。
ex_1_en: My favorite Japanese proverb is "sacrifice one’s life to do good."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

ex_1_jp: 盗人には仁義はない。
ex_1_en: There is no honor among thieves.
meaning_story: Humanity and righteousness. This is your duty. This is humanity and justice.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: その四十歳のGoogle社員は、自分の事を謙遜して「過去の遺物だ」なんて言っていたが、実際は全然そんなことないからね。
ex_1_en: The 40-year-old Google worker was so humble that he called himself a relic from another age, which really isn’t true at all.
meaning_story: If you have modesty and are humble, then you are probably humble and have humility (and have modesty too, I guess).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 子どもへの性教育はある時期では必至になると思うんですが、日本はそうした教育については通常どのように行われるんですか。
ex_1_en: I think it’s necessary to teach kids sex education at some point, but how do people usually teach those things in Japan?
meaning_story: If it's certain that you will attain it, then it is inevitable. It is a foregone conclusion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 髭を禁止することは人権侵害です。
ex_1_en: Banning facial hair is a human rights violation.
meaning_story: You invaded and damaged me. You are doing infringement on my territory. This is a violation of me.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: このコンピュータウィルスは、大晦日の夜に時計の針が12時を告げると、何千台ものパソコンに侵入をするんですよ。
ex_1_en: This computer virus is going to penetrate thousands of computers at the stroke of midnight on the night of New Year’s Eve.
meaning_story: If you invade and enter that is an intrusion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 奴らが山のてっぺんにある俺たちの村を侵攻しようとした時、敵陣が全員高山病に罹ってしまったのには笑えたよ。
ex_1_en: It was funny that when the they tried to invade our village high atop the mountain, the entire enemy camp got altitude sickness.
meaning_story: If you invade with aggression that's an invasion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: マイクラでたくさん鉄鉱石を採掘した。
ex_1_en: I mined a bunch of iron ore in Minecraft.
meaning_story: The iron mineral is iron ore.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は小躍りして喜びました。
ex_1_en: I jumped for joy.
meaning_story: If 躍る is "to leap" or "to jump," then this noun version will be jumping or leaping.
reading_story: The reading comes from 躍る.

ex_1_jp: 包丁を研いで二、三時間潰しました。
ex_1_en: I killed a couple hours by sharpening my kitchen knife.
meaning_story: Wrap up the street and take it away. I cut it apart with my kitchen knife (don't ask why this word comes from these kanji). Just imagine yourself using a kitchen knife to cut up the street so you can wrap it up and take it away.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今振り返ってみると、ハチ公は絶対的な忠誠心を持ったいい犬だったよな。
ex_1_en: Looking back, Hachiko was a dog that had absolute loyalty.
meaning_story: I have sincerity about my loyalty. That shows loyalty, right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日本の礼儀作法について学んでいます。
ex_1_en: I’m studying Japanese etiquette.
meaning_story: The thanks ceremony is the dance you do in life when it comes to your manners and courtesy to others. Also means etiquette.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その生徒の今後の措置についてはどうお考えですか。
ex_1_en: What do you think of the next steps for that student?
meaning_story: Set aside and put what you'll need to get the job done over there. These are the measures and steps we're taking to make sure things get done properly.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: これは今までで最高の鉱物さ。これに敵うものはないね。
ex_1_en: This is the best mineral I’ve ever seen. Nothing can match it.
meaning_story: A mineral thing is a mineral.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は鉱業の過去十年間を振り返りました。
ex_1_en: He looked back on the past 10 years of the mining industry.
meaning_story: The mineral business is the mining industry.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 敵の艦隊からもっと激しい抵抗があると思っていたので、なんだか拍子抜けです。
ex_1_en: I expected stronger resistance from the enemy’s naval fleet, so I’m kind of disappointed.
meaning_story: A warship squad is a naval fleet or an armada.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: カンタイ *** カꜜンタイ

ex_1_jp: 原子力潜水艦は、略して原潜と呼ばれることもある。
ex_1_en: Nuclear submarines are sometimes called Gensen, for short.
meaning_story: The original (often associated with atoms and nuclear tech) concealing machine is the nuclear submarine. It is nuclear, and it conceals itself.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どんな鉱石でも、彼が触ると金に変わってしまうのさ。
ex_1_en: Every mineral he touches turns to gold.
meaning_story: A mineral stone is an ore / mineral.
reading_story: The reading for 石 is abnormal, but you've seen it before in the word: 宝石. An ore is like a jewel of the ground, right? Something like that, anyways.

ex_1_jp: 私が不法侵入をしたという証拠はあるんですか。
ex_1_en: Do you have any physical evidence that I trespassed?
meaning_story: The evidence is based on something. What is it based on? This physical evidence. Ha ha! Guilty!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember that 拠 is read as こ and you'll be fine.

ex_1_jp: 我々は生産拠点を海外に移します。
ex_1_en: We are going to move our production bases overseas.
meaning_story: Something based on points has a ranking, meaning you'll know where your position or location is, compared to everyone else.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「沈む瀬あれば浮かぶ瀬あり」なんていう言い回しがあるのは知ってるけど、今はマジで沈んでるわ。
ex_1_en: I know there’s a saying, "life has its ups and its downs," but right now I’m really down.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, actually!

ex_1_jp: ロッククライミングは私の生き甲斐です。
ex_1_en: Rock climbing is what I live for.
meaning_story: You know that 甲斐 is "effect" or "worth." So, the "worth for being alive" is your reason for living. It gives life worth. It's your reason for living.
reading_story: The readings come from 甲斐 and 生き, so if you know those you may have a reason for living, or at least a reason for doing your kanji study.
pitch_accent: イキカ°イ *** イキカ°ꜜイ

ex_1_jp: 渋々自分がやったことを認めました。
ex_1_en: I reluctantly admitted to the things I did.
meaning_story: If you bite into something bitter (twice!) you'll take your next bite reluctantly. Because who would want that much of something bitter? Not you.
reading_story: This is the kun'yomi reading twice. You learned this reading when you learned 渋い. If you remember that, you know this too!
pitch_accent: シꜜブシブ *** シブシブ

ex_1_jp: 私は典型的な育児放棄をされた子どもで、孤児院で育ちました。
ex_1_en: I was a typical neglected child who grew up in an orphanage.
meaning_story: I release and abandon my post. This is my resignation. This is my abandonment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうしてあの甲斐性無しが彼女の愛を復活させることができたのか、全く理解できないね。
ex_1_en: I really can’t understand how such an incompetent man like that was able to rekindle her love.
meaning_story: The result (甲斐) of being your own gender shows your resourcefulness. Depending on your gender, certain things are harder than others, so your resourcefulness and competence will help you to overcome those hurdles.
reading_story: This word combines the word 甲斐 (that you already learned) with the on'yomi reading for 性. You know them both, just put them together!
pitch_accent: カイショꜜー *** カイショー

ex_1_jp: 何時までに御手洗からバスに戻らなくてはいけませんか？行列ができているので、遅れないか心配してるんですが。
ex_1_en: How long before we have to be back to the bus from the bathroom? There is a long line, so I’m worried I’ll be late.
meaning_story: You know 手洗い, right? This is like that, but way more polite sounding. The meaning is still the same though: restroom, bathroom, toilet.
reading_story: The reading for the 御 is お, the rest is てあらい, even though the い isn't showing on the end. It gets pushed into the 洗い.

ex_1_jp: 私は拳銃を派手なスパンコールで飾り付けしてみました。
ex_1_en: I decorated my revolver with flashy sequins.
meaning_story: A fist gun is a small fistish sized gun that has some punch (because, you know, fist!). The gun I'm describing is a revolver, or a handgun.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 昨日廃墟で鬼ごっこをしたので、筋肉痛になりました。
ex_1_en: I have muscle pain because I played tag in the abandoned building yesterday.
meaning_story: Obsolete ruins are places that are abandoned because nobody can run them anymore (due to being obsolete, or due to not having money, or due to whatever else). These things are ruins or abandoned buildings. People like to explore these, a lot.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今日市場ですごくいい瀬戸物を見つけたんだよ。
ex_1_en: I found really nice chinaware at the market today.
meaning_story: The rapids door is like a door of water coming in to somewhere. This is a strait or channel. Also, this is the Seto area.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この川はこの辺りは高瀬になってるから、きっと足が底に着くと思うよ。
ex_1_en: The river is pretty shallow around here, so I’m sure you’ll reach the bottom.
meaning_story: The tall rapids are the shallows. I have no idea how this makes sense, but I suppose if the water is taller, it's not going to have as much rapids going on, meaning it's just shallows (but not too tall to become something else, like a lake, or whatever).
reading_story: The reading comes from 高い and the reading you learned for 瀬.

ex_1_jp: 私はよく渋谷駅で外国人を見ます。
ex_1_en: I usually see foreigners at Shibuya Station.
meaning_story: The bitter valley is a place known as Shibuya. This is a very famous area in Tokyo. Very busy too.
reading_story: The reading of 渋 comes from 渋い. The reading for 谷 is an exception. Just think about someone asking you if Shibuya is cool. Your answer of course is "yah." (や)

ex_1_jp: この焼酎のもっと大きい瓶ってありますか。
ex_1_en: Do you have a bigger bottle of this shochu?
meaning_story: Cooked sake is slightly higher in alcohol content. This is shochu, which I'm guessing gets cooked in some way during its production.
reading_story: The reading for 焼 and 酎 are the on'yomi readings, which you didn't learn. But, if you know the (also English) word Shochu, you'll be able to remember the reading for this one as well too.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: その建物はじきに警察に包囲されるでしょう。
ex_1_en: The building will be surrounded by the police in a moment.
meaning_story: Wrap and surround them. We are going to siege the enemy. This is encirclement around their base!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は僕の誠実な友人だから、心配する必要は無いよ。絶対に取引から手を引いたりなんかしないさ。
ex_1_en: He is my faithful friend, so don’t worry. He will never back out of the deal.
meaning_story: You have sincerity and you have truth. You are so sincere and honest and faithful, good friend.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 誠意のこもった説明が聞けたので、今回は彼女の言い分を聞いて上げることにしました。
ex_1_en: After hearing her sincere explanation, I decided to give her the benefit of the doubt this time around.
meaning_story: The idea of sincerity is sincerity. It's also to have good faith in others.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 裁判官が彼の心神喪失による刑事責任能力の回避の申し立てを受け入れたことは、誠に遺憾です。
ex_1_en: I’m sincerely upset that the judge accepted his plea of not guilty by reason of insanity.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The "things" (こと) I do with my "ma" (ま) are always supported by sincerity and truth. I am always sincere with my mom. That's why the things I do with ma are always sincere. I have a name for this, it is ma 事 (まこと), because with ma, sincerity is the most important thing to do.

ex_1_jp: 明日なら、家族の墓参りをした後に、その社会福祉施設に寄れなくもないよ。
ex_1_en: I could stop by the social welfare facility after visiting my family’s graves tomorrow.
meaning_story: 福祉 is welfare, 社会 is society. So, a society's welfare is social welfare.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: シャカイフクꜜシ *** シャカイフꜜクシ

ex_1_jp: 御免なさい。このＴシャツのMサイズは売り切れちゃったんです。
ex_1_en: I’m sorry. We’re sold out of medium sizes for this shirt.
meaning_story: Remember 御免? This is a polite way to say it. It means sorry and I beg your pardon.
reading_story: The reading comes from 御免. The addition is all kana.

ex_1_jp: 夢ってのは、僕たちの潜在意識を反映しているとよく言われるよね。
ex_1_en: Dreams are often said to reflect our subconscious.
meaning_story: If 意識 is consciously, then what exists concealed in your mind is your subconscious.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 多分あの潜水艦の中で片方のイヤリングを失くしてしまったの。
ex_1_en: I probably lost my other earring while I was on the submarine.
meaning_story: A conceal in the water warship is a submarine.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 父に夏至から11日目のことを何と呼ぶか知っているかと聞かれたので、得意気に「ハゲ症」って答えたんですけど、それって「ハゲ頭の症状」って意味になるみたいで。父は笑って、正しい答えは「半夏生」だよって教えてくれましたけどね。
ex_1_en: My dad asked me if I knew what to call the eleventh day after the summer solstice, so I said triumphantly "hageshou," which literally means "baldness-symptom". He laughed and told me the correct answer was "hangeshou."
meaning_story: If you have attained summer, that must mean you finished out with the previous season and are going into summer. This is the summer solstice.
reading_story: You didn't learn the 夏 reading with the kanji, so we'll have to come up with a mnemonic to remember the reading of summer solstice, especially the first half. Just think about how cute little geckos (げ) start to come out into the open during the summer solstice. It's too cold for them to be out in the open before that, so if you look outside at the right time, you'll see geckos popping out of the ground all over the place!

ex_1_jp: 彼は名門大学を主席で卒業した頭のいい男性なんでしょうが、明らかに白人至上主義者なのでそこが嫌いなんですよ。
ex_1_en: He may be a smart guy who graduated at the top of his class from an elite university, but he is obviously a white supremacist and I hate that.
meaning_story: If you attain above it means you're up above everyone, and you're looking down on them. You have supremacy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 小舟は早瀬で横転してしまいました。
ex_1_en: The boat flipped over in the rapids.
meaning_story: A quick rapids is going to have swift currents.
reading_story: The reading comes from 早い and the reading you learned for 瀬.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は徹底した化粧を施さないと、外出することができません。
ex_1_en: She can’t go out until she thoroughly applies her make-up.
meaning_story: Penetrate to the bottom. ALL the way to the bottom. Don't stop half way. This is thoroughness. This is completeness.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.

ex_1_jp: 恐い虎の顔が描かれたお揃いのTシャツを着たカップルが、今目の前を腕を組みながら歩いています。
ex_1_en: A couple in matching T-shirts that have scary tigers on them are walking arm in arm in front of me right now.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: お酒を控えるなんてらしくないね。もしかして、妊娠したとか？
ex_1_en: It’s not like you’re abstaining from alcohol. Unless maybe, are you pregnant?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means abstain and the verb vocab version is to abstain as well!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You are trying to abstain... but from what? You're trying to abstain from eating jicama (ひか). It's so delicious, but you're allergic to it, so you have to abstain.
pitch_accent: ヒカエꜜル *** ヒカꜜエル

ex_1_jp: そういう訳で、あの化け物は今日に至るまで牢屋にぶちこまれることになったんですよ。
ex_1_en: And that’s how the monster ended up behind bars to this very day.
meaning_story: The kanji means attain but the meaning of this verb is to arrive at. I suppose that's because if you attain something like enlightenment, you also arrive at that enlightenment as well. Thus, to arrive at.
reading_story: To arrive at enlightenment is to eat (いた) all the knowledge and understanding that you can. You are enlightened!

ex_1_jp: 皆様のお力に拠って、成功することができました。感謝の気持ちをこめて、ベーコンをプレゼントさせて頂きます。
ex_1_en: I was able to succeed because of everyone’s support. I’ll give you guys a lot of bacon in thanks.
meaning_story: The kanji means based on and the verb means to be due to. This is probably because when something is based off something, it does something else, which is due to what it was based on. It was caused by what it was based on.
reading_story: For example, yogurt is due to milk. If milk didn't exist, neither would yogurt.

ex_1_jp: 日本人はどうしてペコペコお辞儀ばっかりするんですか？
ex_1_en: Why do Japanese people bow so often?
meaning_story: The quit ceremony is when you quit and are ready to go somewhere, so you bow and then get going. That's why this verb is to bow.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 充電するのを忘れたから携帯の電源が切れて、目覚ましが鳴らなかったんだ。
ex_1_en: I forgot to charge my battery and my cellphone died, so my alarm didn’t go off.
meaning_story: If 充電 is a recharge then the verb version is going to be to recharge or to charge a battery.
reading_story: The reading comes from 充電.

ex_1_jp: どうにかこの損失を埋め合わせることはできないだろうか。
ex_1_en: Can’t we make up for this loss in some way or another?
meaning_story: 埋める is "to bury." 合わせる is "to unify together." If you bury somebody in order to unify them with you, you're almost certainly trying to compensate for something.
reading_story: The readings come from 埋める and 合わせる. Combine them into one big happy word.

ex_1_jp: ギャンブルに徹する覚悟を決めました。
ex_1_en: I am determined to devote myself to gambling.
meaning_story: If you do penetrate, sure, you can to penetrate. But, if you penetrate something you really get into it, like, you are going to devote oneself.
reading_story: The reading comes from the one you learned with the kanji. Look out for the shortening on this one.
pitch_accent: テッスル *** テッスꜜル

ex_1_jp: どうして日本では、不良少年少女は、コンビニの前で群れる傾向があるんでしょうか。
ex_1_en: I wonder why delinquent kids tend to hang out in front of the convenience stores in Japan.
meaning_story: Remember how 群れ is a flock? This is the verb version, and means to flock or to crowd. This time you're doing the flocking, like you're flocking sheep, or people, or something. You know this because it's rare (れる) that anyone listens to you, but here you are, flocking people!
reading_story: The reading is the same as 群れ, so if you know that you can flock together the two memories in your brain.

ex_1_jp: 昨夜、雪が30cmも積もり、車が埋もれてしまいました。
ex_1_en: The snow piled up 30 centimeters deep last night and my car got buried.
meaning_story: You know that 埋める is "to bury." This verb is to get buried or to be buried. You know this because it's more rare (もれる) to get buried than it is for you to bury someone else. Really you can only get buried once, to be honest, because you're probably going to die.
reading_story: The reading comes from 埋める.
pitch_accent: ウズモレル *** ウズモレꜜル *** ウモレル

ex_1_jp: 残って最後まで彼の話を伺いたいのは山々なんですが、残念ながらどうしても行かなくてはいけないんです。
ex_1_en: I’d love to stay here and hear his whole speech, but unfortunately I have to go.
meaning_story: The kanji means pay respects but the verb is to implore or to inquire. Basically this is a polite way to ask about something. When you are asking about something politely, you are paying your respects in a way, too. You are imploring and inquiring about something.
reading_story: Excuse me, I'd like to inquire about you you, kaga (うかが). You're asking questions about Chairman Kaga, the ruler over the Iron Chef kingdom.

ex_1_jp: たくさんの人たちが、プライバシーを侵されたことに憤慨しています。
ex_1_en: Many people are upset about their privacy being violated.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means invade and the verb vocab version means to invade as well!
reading_story: I'm going to invade your country, okay (おか)? Sorry about that, but everything will be okay when I'm done.

ex_1_jp: 日本では「言わぬが花」だと聞いたので、日本にいる間中自分は口がきけないと偽りました。
ex_1_en: I heard "silence is a virtue" in Japan, so I pretended that I was incapable of speech while I was there.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fake and the verb vocab version is similar, it means to lie or to cheat or to deceive.
reading_story: Someone tries to lie to you. You can't believe it. It's what (いつわ)??? You can't believe it.

ex_1_jp: ワニカニはあなたの部屋の片隅に潜んでいるかもしれませんよ。
ex_1_en: The crabigator might be lurking in the corners of your room.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conceal, so if you conceal yourself and walk around you are going to lurk or you are going to lie dormant.
reading_story: He so (ひそ) hidden. Where you at?

ex_1_jp: ほとんどの博打打ちが思っているように、彼女も自分には天分があると思っていたんだが、結局あるポーカーのゲームで全財産を失って、帰郷するはめになったんだ。
ex_1_en: Like most gamblers, she believed she had talent, but in the end she lost everything to a poker game and had to go back to her hometown.
meaning_story: If you return to the hometown you are going to return to one's hometown.
reading_story: The reading for 帰 is the on'yomi reading, which you haven't learned. Just think about how when you return to your hometown, you're going to need a key (き) to get into your old home, which you haven't been to in a long time.

ex_1_jp: 睡眠薬をビニールラップで包みました。
ex_1_en: I wrapped up my sleeping pills with the plastic wrap.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wrap so the verb vocab version is to wrap.
reading_story: You never wrap things once, you always wrap them twice. And then you double that. It's a two two (つつ) wrapping technique.

ex_1_jp: その樹皮は食べられますか？
ex_1_en: Is the bark edible?
meaning_story: A wood skin is tree bark. It's the wooden skin around trees.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 結婚の記念として、主人と私はメープルシュガーの木を植樹しました。
ex_1_en: My husband and I planted a maple sugar tree to commemorate our marriage.
meaning_story: If you plant wood you are doing tree planting, since only trees are made of wood.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 脱衣する前に、鞄を脇へ置いたのは覚えています。
ex_1_en: I remember I put my bag to the side before undressing.
meaning_story: If you undress from clothes you are undressing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: いったいまたどうして艦船に住むことになったんですか？月々のお家賃はいくらぐらいですか。
ex_1_en: How did you end up living in a warship? How much is the rent for this every month?
meaning_story: A warship ship is a warship.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 麦畑が見えてきたとたんに、くしゃみが出始めました。
ex_1_en: Once the wheat field came into view, I started sneezing.
meaning_story: A wheat field is a wheat field or barley field
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings, but they're also the readings you learned with the kanji. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: どうして日本では冬至の日にカボチャを食べると良いというのですか？
ex_1_en: Why do people say it’s good to eat squash on the winter solstice in Japan?
meaning_story: If you are about to attain winter, then it's the winter solstice. Happy winter, everyone!
reading_story: The reading for 冬 is the on'yomi reading, and one you haven't learned before. You're going to want to think about how you are celebrating the winter solstice in one particular place, that place being とうきょう (とう). See the Tokyo landmarks around you, think that you are there on the winter solstice, and also think about the things you are doing to celebrate, here in Tokyo. Also, watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 瓦礫の撤去に関するニュースをネットで読みました。
ex_1_en: I read the news about removing rubble on the internet.
meaning_story: A withdrawal is something you do to remove something from the past. It is a withdrawal or repeal of what you did or submitted before.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Look out for the shortened てつ.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ごめん。前言撤回するよ。
ex_1_en: Sorry, I take back what I said.
meaning_story: If you do a withdrawal of something it's like you're revolving back to how things originally were. This is a withdrawal or repeal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Look out for the shortened てつ.

ex_1_jp: 私はその撤兵を恥じた事は一度もありません。
ex_1_en: I never felt ashamed about the withdrawal of the troops.
meaning_story: A withdrawal of soldiers is a withdrawal of troops.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Look out for the shortened てっ spot.

ex_1_jp: 君の詩の措辞が素晴らしいことに感動しました。
ex_1_en: I was impressed that the wording of your poem was so beautiful.
meaning_story: You set aside these words specifically so you could get the wording right. Wording is important sometimes, like when you're trying to talk about something sensitive, or when you're writing a poem. Sometimes only certain words will do.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この仕事は、誰かのために役に立つことができるので、とてもやり甲斐があります。
ex_1_en: This is a satisfying job for me because I can be useful to other people.
meaning_story: The やり part is from やる which is "to do." So, if the effect (甲斐) is good to do, then it is worth doing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ありえねえ！お前ってほんと、超天然キャラだよな。なんで蝉の鳴き真似に挑戦なんてしてるんだよ？

meaning_story: A challenge for war? I accept this challenge. A challenge is always worth accepting!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 日本では焼き菓子作りとか料理の計量方法が違うんだよね。いっそ世界中の計量方法が一括で同じだったらいいのにね。
ex_1_en: In Japan they use a different method of measurement for baking sweets and cooking. I think it would be better to have one way of measuring throughout the world.
meaning_story: Fasten everything into one. All together in one batch or lump.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortened いち.

ex_1_jp: それは先生の息の質の分析結果です。
ex_1_en: That’s the result of the teacher’s breath quality analysis.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 父親は息子に円弧を描くように命令しました。
ex_1_en: The father ordered his son to paint an arc.
meaning_story: A round arc is, well, the shape of an arc. It has that round shape to it, you know?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 日本に到着した時、私はちょっとテンションが高すぎましたよね。
ex_1_en: I was too hyper when I arrived in Japan, wasn’t I?
meaning_story: At the arrival time you will arrive. This is your arrival.
reading_story: This word uses the on'yomi readings for the kanji. You learned the on'yomi reading for 着 from the word 執着.

ex_1_jp: 昨日、珊瑚虫の中軸骨格を夢に見た。
ex_1_en: Last night I had a dream about a coral insect’s axial skeleton.
meaning_story: The middle of the axis is where the axis is, of course, but it's also where the pivot is too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 地軸の延長が北方で天球と交わる点で会いましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s meet up at the intersection of the earth’s axis and the celestial sphere in the Arctic.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 「ぐるぐるバット」は、おでこをバットの先に付けて、そのバットを枢軸としてぐるぐる回転した後に、誰が目的地まで速く辿り着けるかを競う遊びです。
ex_1_en: "Guruguru-bat" is a game where you compete on how fast you can get to the goal after spinning around a bat with your forehead on the end of the bat.
meaning_story: The hinge axis of something is the axle or pivot. It's the axis where things hinge.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この双眼鏡の黒はありますか？
ex_1_en: Do you have these binoculars in black?
meaning_story: A pair of eyeball mirrors - that's binoculars. Binoculars have mirrors in them to allow you to see through the pair of eye holes, which is how this word makes sense.
reading_story: The 鏡 part uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn. To remember this, just think about how when you look down binoculars, you see something strange (like a strange reading for 鏡). That strange thing you see through these fantastic binoculars is... tomorrow. Your binoculars are so strong that you can already see tomorrow, today (きょう)!

ex_1_jp: この金融危機について、誰が糾弾されるべきだと思われますか？
ex_1_en: Who do you think is to blame for this economic crisis?
meaning_story: I'm going to twist this bullet and turn it around on you. You're the one I'm going to blame, which is why my blame bullet is twisted back at you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうしてそれが彼女の中枢神経系を刺激したの？
ex_1_en: How could it stimulate her central nervous system?
meaning_story: The middle hinge is the center pivot point.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 時計が時刻を告げた瞬間、全ての通信網が途絶えました。
ex_1_en: The clock announced the time for a moment and all the communications networks stopped.
meaning_story: It will pass through what you believe and run into some netting. Just think about how all these communications are passing through between people, and everyone believes everything that's being said. Netting this all up (all these communications!) leaves you with a communication network. What fun!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この問題をこれ以上紛糾させたくないんです。
ex_1_en: I don’t want to complicate this problem any more.
meaning_story: Distract me with a twist in what we're doing. Just imagine you're working on something. Then, you get distracted by a twist in whatever it is that you're working on. This little twist doesn't destroy everything, but it does cause a complication and confusion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 徐々にホームシックを克服していってます。
ex_1_en: I’m slowly getting over my homesickness.
meaning_story: Time to overcome the clothes of our enemies. They all wear the same kind of clothes (let's say blue clothes) so we know that if we overcome the blue coated people, we will have won. It will be a conquest!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 十年前の旧正月のことは、克明に覚えていますよ。

meaning_story: If you're overcome with brightness, you'll be able to see all the little fine detailed things.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの不孝者は、ダイビングか何だか知らないが馬鹿な事をしに行って、潜水病になって死んじまったんですよ。

reading_story: 不孝 is a reading you should know already. Add the もの reading for 者 and you have yourself a reading. Now go be obedient to your parents and keep studying your kanji.

ex_1_jp: 英語で円滑なコミュニケーションを取るために、最も重要なことは何だと思いますか？
ex_1_en: What do you think the most important things are to have a smooth conversation in English?
meaning_story: Something that is round and slippery just moves around with no trouble at all. It is so effortless in how it slides around. It is also super smooth.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: もしその野菜が全部安全だというのなら、まず先に彼らがそれを食べて我々に範を垂れるべきだ。
