meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned as well!

ex_1_jp: ある日、金を求めて穴を掘っていると、大量の古代ギリシャのお宝を発掘しました。そこで、その幸運を分かち合う妻を娶ろうと決意しました。
ex_1_en: One day, he excavated a large number of old Greek treasures while digging for gold, so he decided to take a wife with whom he could share his fortune.
meaning_story: Let's departure on our digging up of this site. It is more than just digging, we're going somewhere and learning new things with this dig. This is an excavation!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the 発 getting shortened.

ex_1_jp: 君を模範としよう。
ex_1_en: I’ll follow your example.
meaning_story: An imitation of an example is the exemplification of something. It is also a model of the example of what you're making.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は守備範囲の広いセンターで、大活躍すると踏んでいたんだが、とんだお門違いだったよ。
ex_1_en: I thought he was a wide-ranging center fielder and would play really well, but I was completely wrong.
meaning_story: Let's take a look at this example and surround it. This example shows the extent or scope of what we're doing, and the line that surrounds it shows how far that scope goes.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 何か両親に親孝行してあげたいと思っています。
ex_1_en: I think I want to do something to show my filial piety toward my parents.
meaning_story: You know how 孝行 is "filial piety," right? Well, this is basically the same thing. You're just showing said filial piety to your parents, which, of course, is what filial piety means. That makes this word mean filial piety.
reading_story: The reading is 孝行 plus the kun'yomi of 親. Put them together and you'll become a good filial child.

ex_1_jp: テレビを見てる時は、大抵足を組みながら床に寝転がっています。
ex_1_en: When I watch TV, I usually lay on the floor with my legs crossed.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You look at the floor. It's disgusting. Dirtiest and nastiest floor you've ever seen. You say yucka (ゆか) because it's covered in yucca (ゆか). Plus, it's all rotten.

ex_1_jp: 先生が顕微鏡の焦点を合わせ方について説明をしてくれていた時、私は上の空でした。
ex_1_en: When our teacher explained how to focus the microscope, I was spacing out.
meaning_story: The char point is the part you're looking at so hard it burns a little hole in it. Just imagine yourself looking at a single point so hard that it begins to smolder. This is the focal point or the focus.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ショꜜーテン *** ショーテン

ex_1_jp: ちょうど斎場に到着するところです。
ex_1_en: We’re about to arrive at the funeral hall.
meaning_story: A purification location is the place where you perform purification on people. Who needs the most purification? The dead. Where do you purify them? In a funeral hall.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi for 場 when you learned 入場 ages ago.

pronunciation: ゴミぶくろ, ごみぶくろ
ex_1_jp: 駅員さんに、電車に自転車を持ち込む場合は、持ち運び用の袋の使用が義務づけられているって言われたんだけど、代わりにゴミ袋を使っちゃだめなのかなぁ。
ex_1_en: The train station staff told me that I’m required to use a carrying case in order to take a bicycle onto the train, but I’m wondering if I could use a garbage bag for it.
meaning_story: A garbage (ゴミ) sack is a garbage sack or garbage bag.
reading_story: The word for sack (ふくろ) is rendaku'd, so be careful of that.

ex_1_jp: 自分の父親なんだから、善意に解釈してあげるべきよ。例えば、年を取って握力が弱っているせいで、あなたのビンテージのバカラのグラスを割っちゃったんだ、っていう風に。
ex_1_en: He is your father so you should give him the benefit of the doubt. His grip has gotten worse with age and that’s why he dropped your vintage Baccarat crystal‎ glass.
meaning_story: Your grip power is your handgrip.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: CDを買うと、オマケで握手券が二枚ついてきた。
ex_1_en: I bought a CD that came with two handshake tickets as a bonus. (Handshake tickets are similar to meet and greet tickets.)
meaning_story: A grip with your hand (onto another hand) is a handshake.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. With 手 just think back to other vocab words that use the on'yomi reading.

ex_1_jp: アヤに、掛け軸のための絵を描いてもらいたいんです。
ex_1_en: I want Aya to paint a picture for the hanging scroll.
meaning_story: It hangs on an axis point. The axis opens up, and reveals a hanging scroll. This might take a little extra imagination, but I believe in you.
reading_story: For 掛 you'll want to think back to the word 掛ける, then shorten it and shove it into the kanji half way (the かけ part at least). For 軸 that's the reading you learned with the kanji, so at least you have that to work off of.

ex_1_jp: あのA型肝炎の患者は愛に飢えており、いつも医者や看護師の気を引こうとしている。
ex_1_en: The hepatitis A patient is starving for love and always tries to get attention from the nurses and doctors.
meaning_story: If you have the ol' liver flame then you probably have hepatitis. AUGH! MY LIVER IS ON FIRE.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この公園は地元では犯罪の温床になっていることで知られているので、近づかない方がいいですよ。
ex_1_en: This park is known as a breeding ground for criminal activity in this area, so you shouldn’t go near there.
meaning_story: A warm floor is a "hotbed."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 悪阻がひどくて、暫く全然家事ができてないんですよね。
ex_1_en: I haven’t done any housework in a while because I have terrible morning sickness.
meaning_story: Please temporarily wait. In a little while something will happen, but temporarily you'll have to sit still.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In a little while, we're going to be listening to shiba rock (しばらく). This is a form of rock and roll performed by shiba dogs. You should look up shiba inu puppy pictures if you haven't ever heard of shiba inus.

ex_1_jp: もう手遅れですが、私は本当に親不孝な息子でしたよ。
ex_1_en: It’s already too late, but I was a really disobedient son.
meaning_story: You know that 不孝 means "disobedience to parents. So, if you add parents to it, it just means the same thing. Just a longer version of the word, basically. This means lack of filial piety or disobedience to parents.
reading_story: The reading for 不孝 is the one you learned. Then, add 親's reading (vocab) to it.
pitch_accent: オヤフꜜコー *** オヤフコꜜー

ex_1_jp: 去年の夏、秋田県の八郎潟にバス釣りに行きました。
ex_1_en: Last summer, I went bass fishing in Hachiro Lagoon in Akita prefecture.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: この芝草が、芝草クッキーを緑色にしてくれるんです。
ex_1_en: The turf in these turf cookies gives them their green color.
meaning_story: The lawn grass is the lawn or the turf.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi readings, which you learned already!

ex_1_jp: この公園では、芝生の上を歩くのは禁止されています。
ex_1_en: Walking on the lawn in this park is prohibited.
meaning_story: Your lawn of life is just your lawn. Of course it's alive, otherwise it wouldn't be a very good lawn.
reading_story: The reading for 芝 is the one you learned with the kanji. The reading for 生 is one you haven't seen before (exception). It's ふ, and you can remember it by thinking how you were such a fool (ふ) for putting all that poison on it. Now it's dying, and now it's becoming less of a lawn.

ex_1_jp: 芝に水は撒いてくれた？
ex_1_en: Did you water the lawn for me?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: トイレに行く前に、鳥の肝をもう一口かじりました。
ex_1_en: I took another bite of chicken liver before going to the bathroom.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Though, it also means chutzpah or courage (besides just being liver). Maybe your liver is where your courage is.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Your liver isn't doing great. You have cancer in your liver, so now they're giving you chemo (きも) to help get rid of that cancer.

ex_1_jp: 「もし世界中の食料が無くなって、お前がすっげぇお腹がすいてるとしたら、俺の肝臓、食べるか？」「さあ、どうだろう。」「さあ、どうだろうって、それ、どういう意味だよ。」「今は分かんないってこと。」
ex_1_en: "If all the food in the world ran out and you were really hungry, would you eat my liver?" "Hmm, Dunno." "What do you mean you dunno?" "I just don’t know right now."
meaning_story: The liver internal organ is your liver.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: まだ今夜の宿泊先を探しているんです。
ex_1_en: I’m still searching for a lodging place for tonight.
meaning_story: A lodge where you will stay overnight is lodging. It is where you will stay the night.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 介護施設に、どうやら記憶喪失らしいお婆さんがいるんだけど、その人がすっごく面白いのよ。
ex_1_en: In the nursing home there is an old woman who seems to have lost her memory, but she is really funny.
meaning_story: You are mourning your fault. Because of your fault, you have gotten a loss and forfeit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 大変申し訳ありませんが、喪に服しているため年賀状が送れないのです。
ex_1_en: I’m very sorry but I’m afraid I can’t send a New Year’s card because I’m in mourning.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: What's the first two letters of the word mourning? It's mo (も). You can use that to remember.

ex_1_jp: 元旦に、福袋を買う列に並ぶため、妹と私は朝の四時に起きました。
ex_1_en: On New Year’s Day my sister and I woke up 4 a.m. to line up to buy Lucky Bags.
meaning_story: The luck sack is a mystery bag. These are bags that are sold during the New Year's holiday. They contain various goods that are sold for a certain price. You don't know what's in them, but you know the minimum value of it at least. These are known as mystery sacks as well. Also, watch out for the rendaku.
reading_story: The reading is 福 and 袋, put together.

ex_1_jp: それぞれの国にはそれぞれのお国柄ってものがあって、私達はそれをお互いに尊重し合うべきだと思います。
ex_1_en: Each country has their own national character and I think that’s something we should all respect.
meaning_story: The country pattern is the pattern of things a country does. This is the national character of a nation.
reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. 国 is くに and 柄 is the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: うちの娘が虫取り網が欲しいと鼻を鳴らしてせがむもんだから、ついつい買ってあげたんだよ。
ex_1_en: My daughter sucked up to me to get the butterfly net she wanted and I ended up buying one for her.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When it comes to nets, you gotta go talk to Amy (あみ) if you want a good one. Only Amy makes good nets.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ねぇ、そう堅いこと言わないでさ。うちに泊まってけばいいじゃん。たったの一泊だけだよ。
ex_1_en: Come on! Don’t be so stiff. Stay over at my place! Just for one night!
meaning_story: One overnight is a one night's stay.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortened 一 and the rendaku in this one.

ex_1_jp: 不透明な窓がある女子の更衣室です。
ex_1_en: The girls’ locker room has opaque windows.
meaning_story: You know that 透明 is "transparency" or "transparent" - so, if something is not transparent, then it is opaque, making this word opacity.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 妹と私は二卵性双生児ですが、外見がすごく似ています。
ex_1_en: My sister and I are fraternal twins, but we look very similar.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the one used here. They're a pair, you know?

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 左の括弧を読む時は単に「括弧」と言いますが、右の括弧を読む時は「括弧閉じる」と言います。
ex_1_en: When people read the left bracket, they just say "kakko," but when they read the right bracket, they say "kakko-tojiru," which means "close bracket."
meaning_story: The fasten arcs are arcs that go around something to fasten these things all together. What are these things? They are (parentheses) and [brackets].
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, watch out from the shortening.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は私にヒョウ柄の名刺をくれました。
ex_1_en: She gave me her leopard print business card.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck. Follow that reading pattern to here, and you should be okay. That being said, there's a second reading worth learning too. It's え, and you can remember that because a pattern/design is like a painting, and a painting is 絵 (which is also え.

ex_1_jp: 本の内容を表紙で判断するみたいに、人の人柄を見た目で決めつけないでよ。
ex_1_en: Don’t judge people’s personalities by their appearance like you’d judge a book by its cover.
meaning_story: A person's pattern is the pattern of actions which they take to become who they are. What do they usually do? What is their pattern? This is the same as their personal character or personality.
reading_story: The readings are both kun'yomi readings, combined. For 人 you'll just have to remember this. With 柄 that's the reading you learned anyways, so that makes things easier. Just keep it consistent!

ex_1_jp: 彼は哲学者だが、理路整然と考える人ではない。
ex_1_en: He is a philosopher, but he isn’t a logical thinker.
meaning_story: The philosophy study is the study of philosophy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: テツꜜカ°ク *** テツカ°ク

ex_1_jp: 「あなたの携帯電話をお借りしてもいいですか？」「ええ、どうぞ。」
ex_1_en: "May I use your cell phone?" "Sure, go ahead."
meaning_story: You know that 携帯 means "portable" or "cell phone" or "mobile phone." And then 電話 means "telephone." This is basically just the longer version of simply saying 携帯, making this a portable phone or cell phone or mobile phone. It's sort of like the difference between saying "my cell" and "my cell phone," you dig?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the readings of 携帯 and 電話 for this one.

ex_1_jp: 抗議者の一人が、警察を挑発するために火炎瓶を投げつけました。
ex_1_en: A protester threw a Molotov cocktail toward the police during a riot to provoke them.
meaning_story: My challenge has made a departure and is being sent to the enemy. This challenge that I'm sending is a provocation to see if they'll take me up on my challenge.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 彼は起床時間になっても、まだいびきをかいています。
ex_1_en: He is still snoring even though it’s time to get out of bed.
meaning_story: Wake up from the floor and get up. You are rising or getting out of bed (remember that Japanese people traditionally slept on futon, on the floor, so rising from the floor is waking up, in a way!).
reading_story: The readings are the on'yomi readings for both of these. For 起, just remember how in order to get up out of bed, you have to be let out of your chains, which requires a key (き). Otherwise, you stay laying down forever.

ex_1_jp: 二つの気球の間を綱渡りした男の人の話はもうお聞きになりましたか？
ex_1_en: Have you heard of the guy who walked a tightrope between two hot air balloons?
meaning_story: The kanji is cable but this word refers to more of a rope, which is pretty similar. That being said, it's often used to talk about a sumo belt, so just think about that one.
reading_story: The reading used here is the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 野球用語の犠飛と犠打の意味について教えてもらえませんか？
ex_1_en: Could you teach me what the SF and SH baseball terms mean?
meaning_story: A sacrifice fly is a sacrifice fly. In baseball, this is when you hit the ball in the air so the runner can tag up and move up a base.
reading_story: The reading is the on'oymi readings. For 飛 just think about how he (ひ) hit a sacrifice fly, and he hit it so hard the ball heated up.

ex_1_jp: 彼女の自然な美しさと魅力的な笑顔に息も出来なくなり、会議中ずっと動揺していました。
ex_1_en: Her natural beauty and charming smile took my breath away and I was trembling during the meeting.
meaning_story: If something moves then shakes, it is shaking and trembling!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は病床に臥してついにまた起ちません。
ex_1_en: He laid down on his sickbed, never to rise again.
meaning_story: A sick floor is the floor you lay upon while you are sick. It is elevated, luckily, making it a sickbed.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: その店では、一人の小柄なおばあさんが買い物をしていた。
ex_1_en: The short old woman did her shopping alone in the store.
meaning_story: Someone built from a small pattern has a small build. I know lots of little old ladies that were built from these small patterns.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: レシピには、美味しくてしっとりしたクッキーって書いてあったのに、出来上がったクッキーはすっごく堅かったんだよね。
ex_1_en: The recipe calls them delicious, moist cookies, but they turned out to be really hard.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of solid? It's solid or tough. This "solid" and "tough" is a figurative version of the word.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: かつて、少し前までは、3Dプリンタは最新鋭の機械でした。
ex_1_en: Once, a little while ago, 3D printers were cutting edge machines.
meaning_story: 最新 is, as you can probably guess, "the newest." So, the newest sharp thing, is the cutting edge. It is state of the art.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今日は一日中書斎で重要書類を探していたんですが、まだ見つからないんですよ。
ex_1_en: I was searching for an important document in my study all day today, but haven’t found it yet.
meaning_story: I write for purification. I do this purification writing in my study and den.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私は情報を総括し、上司の注意を促すために報告しましたが、彼は聞く耳を持ちませんでした。
ex_1_en: I summed up the information and reported it to my boss, but he wouldn’t listen.
meaning_story: I want to take the whole and fasten it together. Take all the parts and put it together in a synthesis and recap of the information.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ソꜜーカツ *** ソーカツ

ex_1_jp: こちらの料金設定は暫定的ですのでご留意下さいませ。
ex_1_en: Please bear in mind that these prices are temporary.
meaning_story: Temporarily determine something. That makes it tentative and temporary.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 一定にかき混ぜることで、鍋の底が焦げることが防げるとお母さんが言っていたわ。
ex_1_en: My mom told me that constant stirring keeps the bottom of the pan from burning.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means char, but the verb version is to be burned or to get burned. You're not doing the burning, of course, but you're getting burned (owch!).
reading_story: The times where you were burned were mostly when you were a kid (子 (こ). That's because kids aren't good at working with hot things.

ex_1_jp: 俺の新しい髪型を見て、あいつプッと吹き出したんだぜ。失礼だよな。
ex_1_en: She chuckled when she saw my new hairstyle. That’s rude, isn’t it?
meaning_story: If 吹く is "to blow" and 出す is "to remove," then you are removing your blowing. You need to begin to blow to do that!
reading_story: The readings come from 吹く and 出す.
pitch_accent: フキダꜜス *** フキダス

ex_1_jp: 美容師として働いている限りは、手が荒れるのはどうしようもありません。
ex_1_en: My hands will be rough as long as I’m a beauty artist, there’s nothing I can do about it.
meaning_story: The kanji is wild and the verb is to be stormy or to be rough. If something is wild, like a storm or something, then it will be stormy and rough, after all.
reading_story: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 彼女の手は透き通るほど白かった。
ex_1_en: Her hand was so white it was almost transparent.
meaning_story: This is a combination of the words 透ける and 通る. When you are transparent enough to pass through other things, you're still going to be transparent and people will be able to see through you.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: パーティーに行って、憂鬱なんて吹き飛ばしちゃおうぜ。
ex_1_en: Let’s go to the party and brush off your depression.
meaning_story: You know that 吹く is "to blow" and that 飛ばす is "To let fly." So, if you use your blowing to let something fly, you are going to blow away it.
reading_story: The reading comes from 吹く and 飛ばす, put together.
pitch_accent: フキトバꜜス *** フキトバス

part_of_speech: INTRANSITIVE VERB, TRANSITIVE VERB, AND GODAN VERB
ex_1_jp: 家はおんぼろで、嵐が来る度に雨風が吹き込むのが現実です。
ex_1_en: The reality is that the house is so old that the rain and wind blows in whenever a storm comes.
meaning_story: You know that 吹く is "to blow" and 込む is "to be crowded." So if you blow into something to the point where it's crowded, you are blowing into it, making this word "to blow in.
reading_story: The reading comes from 吹く and 込む.
pitch_accent: フキコꜜム *** フキコム

ex_1_jp: 私はこの日曜日、有名なベーコン鑑定家に挑みます。
ex_1_en: I’m going to challenge the famous bacon connoisseur this Sunday.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means challenge and the verb vocab version is to challenge someone.
reading_story: I don't (いど) just challenge anyone, but when I challenge someone, it's for real. My challenging reflexes come from my Id (いど), after all.

ex_1_jp: クママンは中年の男やもめで、家業で金を掘っています。
ex_1_en: Kumaman is a middle-aged, widower living and digging gold like his father before him.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dig and the verb vocab version is to dig.
reading_story: If you are going to dig you are going to end up making a hole (ほ).

ex_1_jp: この味噌汁はしょっぱすぎるよ。もうちょっと薄めてもらってもいいかな？
ex_1_en: This miso soup is too salty. Can you water down a little bit?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dilute and the verb vocab version means to dilute or to water down.
reading_story: The reading comes from 薄い, so if you know that you'll be able to read this too.
pitch_accent: ウスメル *** ウスメꜜル

ex_1_jp: 不快な気分を紛らすために、裁縫針で耳にピアスの穴を開けました。
ex_1_en: I pierced my ear with a sewing needle to distract myself from my unpleasant feelings.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means distract and the verb vocab version of this word is to distract and to divert.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to divert and to distract Maggie (まぎ).

ex_1_jp: 万が一ゾンビが実際に現れた場合を想定して、どうやってゾンビから逃れるのかを考えているんです。
ex_1_en: I’m thinking about how to escape from zombies if they actually showed up.
meaning_story: You've seen 逃げる and 逃す. This one is 逃れる. This one simply means to escape. So that's not too bad. The difference between this one and the other escapes is that it has to do more with luck.
reading_story: This is the same reading you learned for 逃す, so you should be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: どうしてこの文章を括弧で括ったんですか？
ex_1_en: Why did you enclose this sentence in brackets?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fasten and the verb vocab version is to fasten or to tie up or to tie together.
reading_story: You are fastening up the coocoo (くく) clock, so the coocoo bird doesn't come out anymore. That annoying coocoo bird.

ex_1_jp: 初めて人に会うのは手をぎゅっと握りました。
ex_1_en: When I meet someone for the first time, I tightly grasp their hand.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grip and the verb vocab version is to grasp.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go to grasp someone. You really need them. You are soooo needy (にぎ). Except, you can't really pronounce "d" sounds very well, so you say にぎ.

ex_1_jp: ちょうど今からトンカツを揚げるところです。
ex_1_en: I’m just about to deep fry pork cutlets.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hoist. This strange word means to hoist, to fly, to raise, and (most importantly) to deep fry. The hoisting part usually has to do with hoisting or raising a flag, or something similar.
reading_story: Remember the other "to raise" vocabs? They are all あげる as well. For example, 上げる is あげる and 挙げる is あげる as well.

ex_1_jp: あの犯人を逃がすことはできない。
ex_1_en: We can’t let the criminal escape.
meaning_story: Remember how 逃す means to let go and to set free? Well this one means the same thing. If you know 逃す then you know 逃がす.
reading_story: You haven't learned the kun'yomi for this kanji yet, do here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: When you go to let go of someone, make sure they have their knee guards (にが). It's a dangerous world, you can't have them running free without some extra protection, you know.

ex_1_jp: レシピにサフランがいるって書いてあったから、あちこち駆け回って探したんだけど見つからなくて、結局今回はサフランは使わなかったの。
ex_1_en: The recipe said to put in saffron, so I ran around searching for it everywhere, but I couldn’t find any, so I didn’t add saffron this time.
meaning_story: To 駆ける is "to gallop." 回る is "to revolve." So if you're galloping around in a revolving fashion, you are going to run around.
reading_story: The readings come from 駆ける and 回る.
pitch_accent: カケマワꜜル *** カケマワル

ex_1_jp: 終電に駆け込み乗車をしようとしましたが、目の前でドアが閉まりました。
ex_1_en: I was rushing onto the last train, but the door closed before my eyes.
meaning_story: 駆ける is "to gallop" and 込む is "to be crowded." If you gallop into someone and crowd them, you are going to rush into them.
reading_story: The readings come from 駆ける and 込む.
pitch_accent: カケコム *** カケコꜜム

ex_1_jp: 彼に質問を尋ねた時、駆け出しただけだ。
ex_1_en: When I asked him a question he just ran off.
meaning_story: 駆ける is "to gallop" and 出す is "to remove." So if you gallop out to remove yourself you are probably going to rush out a little fast. Calm down and slow down, man!
reading_story: The readings come from 駆ける and 出す.
pitch_accent: カケダꜜス *** カケダス

ex_1_jp: カヌーを揺らないで！
ex_1_en: Don’t rock the canoe!
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shake and the verb vocab is to shake.
reading_story: If everything starts to shake what else will shake along with it? You (ゆ), of course.

ex_1_jp: 東芝のお客様センターから届いたメールは、全文文字化けしていました。
ex_1_en: The email from Toshiba’s customer center was all garbled.
meaning_story: The east lawn isn't some eastern lawn, it's in reference to the company Toshiba. Might be better to look at the reading first for this one.
reading_story: The readings come from the readings you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 雪解けは始まったけど、まだ滑りやすい場所もあるから気をつけてね。
ex_1_en: Although the snow is starting to thaw, there are still some places where it’s easy to slip, so you should be careful.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means slippery and the verb vocab version is to slide or to slip.
reading_story: It wouldn't be so slippery in here if your friend Beth hadn't spilled something all over the floor. This is the third time you've slipped this month! You know what you have to do. You have to sue Beth (すべ)! She'll pay for making you slip and slide!

ex_1_jp: 今までで一番面白い最高傑作のお笑いのDVDを買ったんだけど、今日うちに泊まって一緒に観ない？
ex_1_en: I bought a DVD of the funniest comedy skits ever, so why don’t you stay over and watch it with me tonight?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means overnight and the verb vocab version is to stay the night.
reading_story: We are just going to stay tonight (と) and maybe tomorrow (と) tonight.

ex_1_jp: 口笛を吹くことにどんな魅力を感じますか。
ex_1_en: What attracts you to whistling?
meaning_story: You know that 口笛 is "whistling." So, if you're blowing your whistle you're going to whistle.
reading_story: The readings are of 口笛 and the reading you learned from 吹.

ex_1_jp: 大地震が首都圏の交通網を麻痺させました。
ex_1_en: A massive earthquake paralyzed the transportation network in and around Tokyo.
meaning_story: A mix of cars that pass through a net, thats a traffic network.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 綱引きは、日本と同じくらいアメリカでも人気がありますか？
ex_1_en: Is tug of war as popular in America as it is in Japan?
meaning_story: The cable pull. Both sides are pulling on the cable. That is a tug of war.
reading_story: The readings are from 綱 and 引く.
pitch_accent: ツナꜜヒキ *** ツナヒキꜜ

ex_1_jp: 「男の子ですか？女の子ですか？」「実は双子の男の子なんです。」
ex_1_en: "Is it a boy or a girl?" "They are actually twin boys."
meaning_story: The pair of children are the same as each other. They're twins.
reading_story: The reading is like 二人, (the ふた part) plus 子, combined together. A little weird, but makes sense. Watch out for the rendaku.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 継母がうちに二泊泊めてくれって言ってるんだけど、どう思う？
ex_1_en: My stepmother is asking if she can stay at our place for two nights, what do you think?
meaning_story: Two overnights is a two night's stay.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 俺たちはいつもリスク統括部の奴らとは意見が合わないんだよ。
ex_1_en: We don’t always agree with people in the risk management department.
meaning_story: Unite it all together and fasten it. That is unification.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: トꜜーカツ *** トーカツ

ex_1_jp: 私の初めての彼氏はいつも鼻が詰まっていて、電話をする時は息づかいが荒かったです。
ex_1_en: My first boyfriend always had a stuffy nose and would breathe hard when we talked on the phone.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of wild? It's wild or rough.
reading_story: The reading is one of the readings you've learned from the kanji. The あら one.

pronunciation: よこづな, よこずな
ex_1_jp: 今は単なる凡人のように見えるかもしれないけど、こう見えてもかつては横綱だったんだよ。
ex_1_en: I may look like just an ordinary man now, but I used to be a Sumo grand champion.
meaning_story: The "side cable." This doesn't make much sense. What this is, though (you'll want to look at the reading), is the Yokozuna. This is the Sumo Grand Champion.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 僕が空を見上げると、ちょうど空襲が始まるところだった。
ex_1_en: When I looked up at the sky, the air raid was just about to happen.
meaning_story: A sky attack is an air raid / air attack. Tora tora tora!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 野球のシーズンが到来する春に近づくにつれて、あの投手の球威は益々増しています。
ex_1_en: As it gets closer baseball season in spring, that pitcher gets better at his pitches.
meaning_story: A sphere of majesty, is the majesty someone has over a sphere, that sphere being a baseball, making this a pitcher's stuff, as in what he throws and how he throws it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 原子炉の建設について、政府に忠告をした人もいました。
ex_1_en: Some people warned the government against building nuclear reactors.
meaning_story: If a 原子 is an atom and a 炉 is a furnace, what is a furnace that has atoms? It is an atomic reactor or nuclear reactor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 警察の車は、暴走族に襲撃された。
ex_1_en: A police car was attacked by a motorcycle gang.
meaning_story: An attack attack is an attack or assault.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 権威を失ったのにまだ過去の栄光にしがみついていて、全く往生際が悪いったらありゃしないよ。
ex_1_en: He is a sore loser who lost his authority but still clings to his faded glory.
meaning_story: The rights of the majesty are clear. His and Her Majesty have authority over all in the realm.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: アイツはぜんぜん面白くないな。話題といったら軍艦島の都市伝説だけだし。
ex_1_en: He isn’t interesting at all. All he talks about is the urban legend of Battleship Island.
meaning_story: A 軍艦 is a battleship, and 島 is an island. Welcome to... Battleship Island (go Jurassic Park music).
reading_story: This word uses the on'yomi readings for 軍 and 艦, and the kun'yomi reading for 島. You learned all of them, so you should know the reading already! Oh, but watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 今朝の朝刊で、その鉄鋼会社は世界一大きな高炉の建設を計画していると読んだよ。
ex_1_en: I read in the newspaper this morning that the steel company is planning to build the world’s largest blast furnace.
meaning_story: A high furnace is one that's particularly hot and blasty. This is a blast furnace.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: コスタリカの泥沼で、忍者トカゲとしても知られているバシリスクを見ました。
ex_1_en: I saw some green basilisk lizards, known as the Jesus lizard, in a marsh Costa Rica.
meaning_story: A mud bog is a bog or marsh. Seems kind of redundant to call a bog muddy, but whatever.
reading_story: The readings are the vocab readings of the two words, 泥 and 沼.

ex_1_jp: どっちにしろ沼に飛び込まなきゃいけないと思うしね。
ex_1_en: I guess I have to jump into the swamp anyway.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, ぬま.

ex_1_jp: あの男は奴らの決裂を、牢屋の中で舌なめずりをしながら待っていたに違いない。
ex_1_en: That guy must have eagerly waited out their breakdown from behind bars.
meaning_story: The decision is split, causing a breakdown in all we've decided. A big ol' rupture.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼はかつては明朗快活な青年だった。
ex_1_en: He used to be a cheerful young man.
meaning_story: A bright bright is something that's bright.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 朗らかな声をした知らない人から国際電話がかかってきました。
ex_1_en: I got an international call from someone I didn’t know with a melodious voice.
meaning_story: This is the na-adjective version of bright. The word is brightness or cheerfulness.
reading_story: Of all the people who are filled with brightness and cheerfulness, one man comes to mind. The cheerful Hulk Hogan (ほが).

ex_1_jp: 日付が変わる瞬間に包みを開けてもいい？
ex_1_en: Is it okay if I open this package at the stroke of midnight?
meaning_story: Something that you wrap is a bundle or package.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What's better than one bundle? Two bundles. Two packages. (つつ). Two times two is つつ.

ex_1_jp: 日本国籍がないんですが、司法試験を受験することは可能ですか？
ex_1_en: I don’t have Japanese citizenship, but is it possible for me to take the bar examination?
meaning_story: I would like to enroll into this country. This is citizenship.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 慰謝料をよこせと脅されています。
ex_1_en: They’re threatening us to send compensation.
meaning_story: Remember how 慰謝 means "consolation?" Add fee to that and you get compensation. Or consolation money, depending on the situation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私達は毎週日曜日、セラピー犬たちと一緒に老人ホームを慰問します。
ex_1_en: We visit a nursing home with therapy dogs every Sunday.
meaning_story: The consolation of a problem is when I show my condolences. It is my sympathy call.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 保険会社から受け取る慰謝料は、税務署に申告する必要がありますか。
ex_1_en: Do I have to declare the consolation money I receive from an insurance company to the revenue office?
meaning_story: I show my consolation by apologizing. This is consolation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうしてG20は財政支援への貢献を否認したのですか。
ex_1_en: Why did G20 reject financially contributing to the bailout?
meaning_story: The tribute I offer is my contribution.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: パックマンは、追ってくるモンスターを逆襲して食べ始めた。
ex_1_en: Pac-Man counterattacked and started eating the monsters that were chasing him.
meaning_story: A reverse attack is a counterattack.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は痛風なのでビールを飲まない方がいいのは分かっているんですが、友人からビールに良く合う珍味をもらったので今日ばかりは我慢できませんね。
ex_1_en: I have gout and I know I should avoid beer, but I can’t help drinking it today because my friend gave me some delicacies that go well with beer.
meaning_story: A rare taste is a taste you can't have very often, because it's rare. This is a delicacy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: めっちゃ旨いお好み焼きの店見つけたから、今度一緒に行かへん？
ex_1_en: I found a really delicious okonomiyaki restaurant, wanna go with me next time?
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of delicious? It's delicious. It also means "skillful" and "clever" as well, because delicious things are skillfully delicious, right?
reading_story: What's especially delicious? Horse (うま) is delicious. Mmm, that delicious horse.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: その都市は原爆により壊滅しました。
ex_1_en: The city was annihilated by the atomic bomb.
meaning_story: If you break and destroy something, that is destruction. That is annihilation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 全ての種の鯨が絶滅の危機に瀕している訳ではない。
ex_1_en: Not all species of whales are in endangered.
meaning_story: Extinction where everything is destroyed is destruction. It is extinction.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 葉っぱの上に乗っている露を集めているんだ。
ex_1_en: I’m collecting dew that’s on the leaves.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi reading of the kanji, but you haven't learned it yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you: Dew is just the earth's way of giving water to you (つゆ). Rain is too forceful, you may not go to the ocean or a lake, so the earth gives dew to you by putting it on the grass outside your house everyday!
pitch_accent: アꜜラワ *** アラワ *** ツꜜユ *** ロꜜ

ex_1_jp: 彼はそれを威厳をもって言いました。
ex_1_en: He said that with dignity.
meaning_story: Majesty is strict. If you don't have dignity and majesty, you won't be very majestic.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 違反者には懲罰が与えられる。
ex_1_en: Violators will receive punishment.
meaning_story: I will chastise you and give you penalty. I do this as a discipline. A punishment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: チョꜜーバツ *** チョーバツ

ex_1_jp: 暴露本の出版については現在再考中です。
ex_1_en: I’m having second thoughts about publishing a tell-all book.
meaning_story: Using violence I'm going to expose the truth! This is disclosure. This is exposure.
reading_story: The reading for 暴 is strange and new, not what you learned with the kanji. Just think about how when there is disclosure or exposure of something, you are surprised. You can't believe that's the truth. You have to take a step back (ばく) to deal with the new information.

ex_1_jp: 彼氏が道端で立ちションしてるのを見ちゃってさ。もう、完璧に幻滅した。
ex_1_en: I saw my boyfriend taking a piss in the street and I was completely disillusioned.
meaning_story: The illusion is destroyed. If your illusion is destroyed, that is disillusionment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 年を取ったら長距離のフライトはきつくなるだろうね。
ex_1_en: Long‐distance flights will be tough for me when I get old.
meaning_story: The distance that is detached from the distance is the distance and range. Just think of one part of the distance, stretch it out, and then look at it. It shows the distance and range!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: もしその超巨大火山が噴火をすれば、我々は滅亡を免れないだろう。
ex_1_en: If the super volcano erupted, we would not be able to escape destruction.
meaning_story: Destroy to death. If you are destroyed to this point, this will be your downfall and ruin.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの男、俺に偽物のグッチの財布を自慢してきたんだぜ。
ex_1_en: That guy bragged about his fake Gucci wallet to me.

reading_story: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. No fakes there.

ex_1_jp: 私は戸籍謄本の写しが必要です。
ex_1_en: I need an official copy of my family register.
meaning_story: Enroll your door... and by door, I mean enroll your family, because each family has one door to their house. Enrolling your family means you are enrolling them into the family register. This is actually an interesting topic. Look up "koseki" in Google and you're sure to find many fascinating histories.
reading_story: The reading for 戸 is an exception. Instead of と it's こ. Just think about how the person who runs this census doesn't care about number of toes. They care about number of children (こ).

ex_1_jp: 犬が逃げないように、家の周りに垣を巡らすことしたんです。
ex_1_en: We are going to put a fence around our house to prevent our dog from running away.

reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 今日は歴史の授業で封建主義について学びました。
ex_1_en: Today we learned about the feudalism in history class.
meaning_story: You know that 主義 is "-ism." Add that onto an ism that is building a seal(ed) in system, and you have feudalism. Why? Because with feudalism, power is sealed in with one group or one family. Nobody else can get in (until they are overthrown, anyways), making this feudalism.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その会社の株主総会の後には、懇親会があります。
ex_1_en: There will be a friendly reunion after the company’s stockholders’ meeting.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あなたのセーターはとっても柔らかいですね。
ex_1_en: Your sweater is so soft.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of gentle? It's gentle... but in this word's case, it's also flexible, soft, and tender.
reading_story: You find something that is so gentle and soft to the touch. You touch it. You can't stop. The monkey you're touching tells you to stop. It doesn't like to be touched. But, you won't stop. "Yah what (やわ) you gonna do about it, monkey?" "Yah, what can I do, I guess," replies the monkey.

ex_1_jp: あそこで柔和な笑みを浮かべている理髪師は、実はこの辺りのポン引き男どもの親分なんだ。
ex_1_en: That gentle looking barber over there is actually this area’s pimp boss.
meaning_story: Gentle and peace. These are signs of gentleness.
reading_story: You didn't learn this reading of 柔 with the kanji, so let's remember it a different way. You have to provide a lot of gentleness if you want to touch something that's new (にゅう) to this world... a puppy, a kitty, a baby, etc. Anything new needs gentleness.

ex_1_jp: 先生には、家庭の方針として、主人と私は子どもにそうした漫画は読ませたくないと思っているという旨を伝えました。
ex_1_en: I explained the gist of our family policy and how my husband and I don’t want to let our kid read comic books to the teacher.
meaning_story: The point of something is the gist and principle of it. So, what's the gist of this vocab word? It's gist as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the word 胸 (chest). So, the gist of your body is your chest (it's at the center, and holds everything together, right?). That's why these words are both read as むね.

ex_1_jp: こんなに趣のあるお持ち帰り用の容器を見たのは初めてです。
ex_1_en: I’ve never seen such a tasteful doggie bag before.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Oh my goodness. The reading of this word! Try to think of it as your thought (思) cow (む) key (き). In your thoughts, you think of the cow key, which will unlock the door in front of you... at least that's what you think it is... you're not sure. But, you're pretty sure it's the gist of how you get inside the door. Is it?
pitch_accent: オモムキ *** オモムキꜜ

ex_1_jp: 朗報を伝えるためにここに来ました。
ex_1_en: I’m here to tell you some good news.
meaning_story: A bright news report is going to be one full of good news. A dark news report is probably bad news, but we only care about good news right now, don't we?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 男は垣根の上にそっと義手を置きました。

reading_story: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. With 垣 that's the one you learned and with 根 that's the vocab version of the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 一番釣りに適しているのは満潮時でしょうか？

ex_1_jp: 即効で目の疲れを取る方法をお教えしましょう。

reading_story: The reading comes from 伺う.

reading_story: With 草 you learned a different reading from the one here. Just think about how with this pasture you have to constantly sew (そう) it together to make it come together, otherwise it comes apart and moves all around, and that's no good for any pasture.

ex_1_jp: 二、三年くらいしたら、父親が死んで、俺は父さんの牧野を相続する事になると思うよ。

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The secondary reading is a bit different. That's a family name, and uses the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. We'll consider this secondary for now, but you may have to come back to this when you see this as a name and are all like "what's going on here??"

ex_1_jp: あの忌まわしい家族が未来永劫安泰でいられるなんて、誰が信じたいと思う？
ex_1_en: Who would want to believe that horrible family would have eternal peace?
meaning_story: Relax in peace. Wherever you are that's allowing you to do this, it is certainly peace. You feel security too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 富山県には、剣の山という意味の、剣岳と呼ばれる山があります。
ex_1_en: There is a mountain called Tsurugidake, which literally means Mt. Sword, in Toyama prefecture.
meaning_story: The peak of the mountain is a peak or mountain.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When you climb to the top of the peak, you're so amazed to find vegetation at this altitude. The only thing that grows here, and in thick amounts, is 竹 (たけ). It is impeding your progress to the very top of the peak, in fact, which is a bother. It's as if it's guarding something...

ex_1_jp: 使い終わったら、体温計を筒の中に戻しておいてね。
ex_1_en: Can you put the thermometer back in its tube when you’re done using it?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Additionally, a cylinder is a pipe as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When it comes to pipes, you always want to have two sets of two of them, just in case. So, that's a two two (つつ) set of pipes, lined up next to each other for backup.
pitch_accent: ツツ *** ツツꜜ *** トꜜー

ex_1_jp: 授業前にその本の要旨を理解しておくと、プラスになると思うよ。
ex_1_en: I think it would be a plus to understand the fundamentals of the book before the lesson.
meaning_story: The parts we need. The point of that. That is the point. That is the essentials. It's what we need and it's to the point, you know?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 我々の広告を上質の紙に料理のレシピと一緒に印刷すれば、みんなそれを冷蔵庫に貼っておいてくれるんじゃないかな。
ex_1_en: We should print our advertisements on nice paper with cooking recipes so that people will keep them on their fridge.

ex_1_jp: この辺ではベーコンの乗ったドーナッツはそう珍しいものではありませんよ。
ex_1_en: It’s not rare to see bacon on donuts around here.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of rare? It's rare. But, this can also mean unusual or curious (as in "odd" curious, not that you're curious about something).
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know what's unusual and rare? This maze (めず). I don't think there's a way out of it. We've been walking around for days now, and we haven't gotten any closer to the exit!

ex_1_jp: あなたの珍増税政策の理論的根拠を述べてくださいよ。

reading_story: The reading for this kanji is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That in itself isn't too rare, wouldn't you say?

ex_1_jp: この回転肉焼き器は、注文日の即日に発送致します。
ex_1_en: We sent out this rotisserie on the same day as you order.
meaning_story: The instant day is the day that's going on this instant. It's the same day as now.
reading_story: The reading for 即 is the normal one. For 日 you're going to want to use the じつ reading, because, the truth (じつ) is that it's the same day today.

ex_1_jp: 自分が六歳の子どもだってことは分かってたけど、父さんが勝手に封を開けて友達からの手紙を読んだことにはすごく腹が立ったわ。

reading_story: The reading is the same as one of the readings you learned: ふう. Don't be a fool, make sure you seal your envelopes.

ex_1_jp: 契約書にサインをして封筒に入れてありますが、まだその封書を郵送していません。
ex_1_en: I signed the contract and put it in an envelope, but I haven’t mailed the sealed letter to them yet.
meaning_story: A seal in writing is writing that has been sealed into an envelope. This is a sealed letter.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 生徒達は一斉に温度計に目をやりました。
ex_1_en: The students looked at the thermometer simultaneously.
meaning_story: At one moment it happened simultaneously. It was simultaneous. It was all at once.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening of 一.

ex_1_jp: うちの会社では、毎年強制参加の慰安旅行があります。

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: うちの家族の誰かが、母の死にあの善良な外科医が関与していると訴えたんですか？

meaning_story: 誰 is who, 誰か is like asking "who?" If you don't know who it is, you just know it's someone.
reading_story: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: その政党は三派に分裂したと思っていたんだけど、実際は四派に分裂していたんだね。
ex_1_en: I thought the political party was split three ways, but it was actually split four ways.
meaning_story: A part split is when things split into two parts. This is a split and division.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 景気の沈滞により、たくさんの労働者が首を切られました。
ex_1_en: A lot of laborers were laid off due to business stagnation.
meaning_story: Sink and stagnate. Imagine something is doing just that. It is in the state of stagnation and inactivity.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は義足を付けていたので、石垣を乗り越えられませんでした。
ex_1_en: He couldn’t climb over the stone wall because he has artificial legs.
meaning_story: A stone hedge is a wall (hedges are nice walls), but it's made of stone. It's a stone wall.
reading_story: The reading is the readings for 石 and 垣 combined into one word. Be careful of the rendakus.

ex_1_jp: あの露店で買ったアクセは全部すぐ壊れちゃったよ。
ex_1_en: Every accessory I bought from the street stall broke immediately.
meaning_story: An exposed shop is one that's not inside. It's outside, and exposed. It's a street stall.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今夜ビールを飲みながら相撲を見るってのはどうだい？
ex_1_en: Do you want to drink some beer and watch sumo wrestling tonight?
meaning_story: A mutual slap is when two big guys run at each other and slap each other. This is sumo wrestling.
reading_story: The reading is pretty weird, and not one you've learned. But, you know what sumo is, right? It's just the same as that. It's すもう.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 敵の奇襲を予想できなかった。
ex_1_en: We didn’t expect our rival’s surprise attack.
meaning_story: An odd attack is an attack you don't expect. This is a surprise attack.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この黄色い花を咲かせる植物は、沼沢地に生息します。
ex_1_en: This plant with yellow flowers lives in swamps.
meaning_story: A bog swamp is a swamp or marsh.
reading_story: Oddly, this is the one word that uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. To remember this particular swamp, note how there are two kanji in here that make this area particularly swampy. Because it's the swampiest, boggiest place in all of Japan, of course the Shogun (しょう) wants it for himself. Even though it's useless land, he wants the best of everything, being the Shogun and all.

ex_1_jp: インターネットで調べたら潮の満ち引きの時刻が分かるんじゃない？
ex_1_en: Can’t we find out when the tide rises by looking online?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you think of the tide, you think of the ocean. If you think of the ocean and what it's filled with (besides water) you think of salt (しお).

ex_1_jp: 彼らは、富裕層に反対する社会的風潮を生み出した。
ex_1_en: They brought about a social trend against the rich.
meaning_story: The wind tide is the direction in which the tide is blowing. Is it blowing in? Is it blowing out? It is the tide and current.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 荒い潮流に逆らってボートを漕ぐのは簡単ではないが、コテージに戻るにはそれしか方法がない。
ex_1_en: It’s not easy to row against the rough tide, but that’s the only way for us to get back to our cottage.
meaning_story: A tides stream is the stream going through the tide. It's the tide or the tidal current.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 俺は文字通りズボンを下げたところで、突然の激しい腹痛に襲われました。
ex_1_en: I was literally caught with my pants down by a sudden, severe attack from a stomach ache.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means attack and the verb vocab version is to attack.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You going to attack me or something? Oh so scary you are. Oh so scary. Ho ho ho."

ex_1_jp: カナダでは、十階建てのアパートが雪で埋まる。
ex_1_en: In Canada, ten story apartment buildings are being covered in snow.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 埋める means "to bury?" Well this is something is being buried, maybe even you! Either way, you're not the one doing the burying. It means to be buried.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

ex_1_jp: 昨年最高額の売上を上げて歴代最年少の部長に昇進したんだから、きっと優秀なセールスマンなんだろうけど、確実に今は組織のトップのような顔をして威張り散らしているからね。私はあいつの事が嫌いだし、今後も尊敬することはないと思うよ。
ex_1_en: He must be a good salesman because he made the most sales during the past year and was promoted to be youngest manager in the company’s history, but he definitely feels like the top dog right now and is he’s being really arrogant. I don’t like him and I will never respect him.
meaning_story: Take my majesty and stretch it. Your majesty is so stretched! That makes me so proud! That's why this word is to be proud or to be arrogant.
reading_story: The reading is from 威 and 張る.

ex_1_jp: ペティコートは、スカートが肌と擦れることを防ぎます。
ex_1_en: Petticoats prevent skirts from rubbing against your skin.
meaning_story: The kanji means grate (as in, "to grate" on something). The verb vocab version is to chafe and to rub, which is pretty close.
reading_story: If you're going to chafe on me like that, I'm going to sue (す) you. It's making me very uncomfortable.
pitch_accent: カスレꜜル *** カスレル *** コスレꜜル *** スレꜜル

ex_1_jp: 落ち込んでいると、いつもうちのワン子が慰めてくれます。
ex_1_en: Our dog consoles us whenever we get depressed.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means consolation and the verb vocab version is to console.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going to console you for what happened to you. The nag saw (なぐさ) was turned on and buzzed through your leg. What a nagging feeling. You need some consoling.
pitch_accent: ナク°サメꜜル *** ナク°サメル

ex_1_jp: 奴らはメディアで情報操作を行って、日本を滅ぼそうとしているんだ。
ex_1_en: They are trying to ruin Japan by manipulating information.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means destroy and the verb vocab version is to destroy and to annihilate.
reading_story: You are going to destroy the hoe roe. This is the roe that comes from the hoe tools. If they create too much roe, they will create too many hoes. And if there are too many hoes, bad things will happen.
pitch_accent: ホロボꜜス *** ホロボス

ex_1_jp: 空港に到着するとファンが群がっていて、驚きましたよ。
ex_1_en: We were surprised that fans had gathered to wait for us when we arrived at the airport.
meaning_story: Remember 群れる, which means "to flock" or "to crowd."? This also means that!
reading_story: The reading is a little different from 群れる, though. There's an extra ら in there. That being said, it's pretty similar, so you should be able to use one to remember the other after a few reps. You can also think about it this way: Everyone is flocking together in one place. Strange thing is, it's to a small 村 (むら). There's a 村 reunion going on, that's why.

ex_1_jp: 彼女に三度も振られてるっていうのに、お前まだ懲りてないのか。
ex_1_en: You got turned down by her three times already and you still haven’t learned, have you?
meaning_story: The kanji means chastise but the verb vocab version is to learn by experience. I guess these are kind of similar. When you make a mistake, someone will chastise you, and then you will learn by experience (either via the experience or via the chastising).
reading_story: As a child (こ) you got a lot of chastising, I bet. A lot of learning by experience (of chastising).

ex_1_jp: うちの犬は、フラフープをジャンプして潜る技を身につけました。
ex_1_en: My dog learned a trick to jump through a hula hoop.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conceal, but the verb vocab version is to pass through or to pass under. Technically, you're concealed, but it's a little more active. You're passing through unnoticed, or passing under something. You're evading.
reading_story: Why are you trying to pass through without getting seen? Because there's a cougar (くぐ) hunting you, and if it sees you... well... you're dead meat.

ex_1_jp: 今年は年賀状何枚刷ればいいかなあ？
ex_1_en: How many New Year’s cards should we print this year?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means printing so the verb vocab version is to print.
reading_story: When you print something out, it's usually the paperwork needed in order to sue (す) someone. You're just that kind of person, always looking to sue.

ex_1_jp: 彼はソファに身を沈めながら、アカデミー賞の授賞式の生中継を観ています。
ex_1_en: He is watching the broadcast of the Academy Awards ceremony and sinking into the sofa.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sink so the verb vocab version is to sink. This is when you're doing the sinking.
reading_story: When you sink something, like a battleship, you go on and say: "she's (しず) sunk, I sunk her." That's like your tagline, or something. You say it for some reason because you think it's cool.
pitch_accent: シズメル *** シズメꜜル

ex_1_jp: なんだか沈んだ顔をしているけど、何を思い詰めてるの？
ex_1_en: You look a bit depressed. What’s on your mind?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sink so the verb vocab version is to sink. You know this is when something is just sinking on its own (you didn't sink it), because of the む, which shows it's a cow sinking. The cow stepped into some quicksand and now it's sinking, not because of you.
reading_story: You look at the cow. Poor cow. She's (しず) sinking.

ex_1_jp: 私は彼女の才能を妬んでおり、彼女が絵画コンクールに向けて絵を描いていたキャンバスを切り裂きました。
ex_1_en: I was jealous of her talent, so I tore the canvas she was painting for an art competition to pieces.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means split, but if you split something, you are going to tear it or to rip up it.
reading_story: In order to get it open, you need to tear and rip up a sack (さく). Sacks don't have tabs or zippers or any of those fancy things. If you want to get at the stuff in a sack you have to tear the top right off!

ex_1_jp: 開封前の商品であればいつでも返品可って書いてあるけど、開封後に中身が壊れてたり、その商品が好きじゃなかった場合はどうなんだろう。
ex_1_en: It says I can return unopened products at any time, but what if I opened it and the stuff inside was broken or I didn’t like it?
meaning_story: Open a letter that's been sealed already, it becomes an unsealed letter.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「彼女は誰かしら。」「名前を知らないの？クラスであなたの後ろに座っているよ！」
ex_1_en: "I wonder who that girl is." "You don’t know her name? She sits behind you in class!"
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は自分の古い考え方にしがみついて、毎晩パジャマの代わりに浴衣を着て過ごした。
ex_1_en: She clung her old ways of thinking and and wore a yukata instead of pajamas every night.
meaning_story: The bathe clothes are the clothes you take with you to bathe with. This is Yukata.
reading_story: The reading is totally an exception. The reading comes from the meaning, though. Yukata = ゆかた.

ex_1_jp: 腕相撲の挑戦者は、握力を見せつけるために、右手で林檎を潰してみせました。
ex_1_en: The arm‐wrestling challenger crushed an apple in his right hand, showing off the strength of his right hand.
meaning_story: A challenge (挑戦) someone is someone who is going to challenge you. They are a challenger.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「さぁ、そろそろ寝床に着く時間じゃぞ。」子供の頃、毎晩祖父にこう言われました。
ex_1_en: "Come now, isn’t it about time for bed?" My grandfather used to say that to me every night.
meaning_story: A sleep floor is where you sleep. Since Japanese beds (futon) are traditionally rolled out on the floor, this makes sense. That's why a floor sleep is a bed or crib.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the second kun'yomi reading for 床. You take とこ and rendaku it into どこ. How do you remember this? Just think about your bed. Then wonder, "where (どこ) is it?"

ex_1_jp: 心配は要りませんよ、患者さん。私のこの手術用メスの鋭い刃で、すぐに盲腸を取ってあげますからね。
ex_1_en: Don’t worry, my patient. I can immediately remove your appendix with the sharp blade of my surgical scalpel.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
pitch_accent: ハꜜ *** ヤꜜイバ *** ヤイバ

ex_1_jp: 金髪になりたかったので、コカコーラで髪を脱色しました。
ex_1_en: I wanted to be blonde so I bleached my hair with Coca-Cola.
meaning_story: Gold hair is blonde hair. Makes sense!
reading_story: The reading for 髪 isn't the one you learned. It's actually はつ, but it's getting rendaku'd here. So, to remember the reading of it for this word, just think about how if you were blonde, you'd wear many hats (はつ) to hide it. I have no idea why you'd hide it, but you can come up with a compelling reason that makes sense to you.

ex_1_jp: 彼の本棚に、食い逃げの仕方について書かれた本を見つけたんだよね。
ex_1_en: I found a book in this bookcase about how to eat and run.
meaning_story: A book shelf is a bookcase or bookshelf.
reading_story: The readings are the ones you learned with the individual kanji. Be careful of the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 二遊間、外野の両翼のポジションはまだ空いています。
ex_1_en: A ball was hit between the second baseman and the shortstop, and both outfield positions are still vacant.
meaning_story: Both wings are both wings! There are two and you have them all!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: かんびーる, かんビール
ex_1_jp: ああ、この缶ビールはマジでうますぎる。
ex_1_en: Oh, this canned beer is way too good for me.
meaning_story: A can of beer (ビール) is a can beer or canned beer. Not a bottled one.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

pronunciation: かんこーひー, かんコーヒー
ex_1_jp: 彼らは、とても美味い缶コーヒーを販売して、大儲けしている。
ex_1_en: They’re making a killing selling delicious canned coffee.
meaning_story: A can coffee (コーヒー) is coffee that's in a can. That's canned coffee or can coffee.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 大砲がズドーンと鳴り響き、男は三人の子どもたちを残したまま逝ってしまいました。
ex_1_en: The cannon went off with a bang and the man passed away leaving three children behind.
meaning_story: A big cannon is... wait for it... just a cannon. I guess all cannons are big, right? At least when you compare them to guns.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: けいたいストラップ, けいたいすとらっぷ
ex_1_jp: あの携帯ストラップが気色悪すぎて、考えるだけもで吐きそうだわ。
ex_1_en: The cell phone strap is so gross just thinking about it makes me puke.
meaning_story: You know how 携帯 refers to a mobile phone? This is a strap (ストラップ) for a mobile phone, making this a cell phone strap or mobile phone strap.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the reading of 携帯.

ex_1_jp: 結局それはバスケットボールだったんですが、とても紛らわしかったです。私は完全に妊婦さんの大きなお腹だと思っていました。
ex_1_en: It was a basketball after all, but it was really misleading. I thought it looked exactly like a pregnant woman’s stomach.
meaning_story: The kanji is distract and the adjective version is confusing or misleading.
reading_story: You know who is particularly confusing? That maggie (まぎ) girl. She's confusing because she uses magic (まぎ). Think of a Maggie you know, if possible.

ex_1_jp: 私は彼女の笠にこっそりエーデルワイスの花を飾りました。
ex_1_en: I secretly put some edelweiss flowers on my girlfriend’s conical hat.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: もし巨大な竜巻がこの地域を襲ったら、管制塔はどうなるんでしょうか。
ex_1_en: If a huge tornado hit this area, how do you think the control tower would fare?
meaning_story: The pipe control tower is the tower that controls all the pipes... think of the pipes not as pipes, but as directions things are moving in. You're controlling all of that on a map, and the pipe shows where everything is going and you're changing it to be where it needs to go. You are in the control tower.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今日買った単三電池は戸棚の上に置いておいたよ。
ex_1_en: I put the double A batteries that we bought today in the cupboard.
meaning_story: A door shelf is a shelf with a door on it. What kinds of shelves do you know of that have doors on them? How about cupboards?
reading_story: The reading are the ones you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 恐竜の化石を見つけるのに一番いい方法はなんでしょうか。
ex_1_en: What’s the best way to find dinosaur fossils?
meaning_story: The fear dragon is a dinosaur. Not sure why dinosaurs > dragons on the fear scale, but I'm sure they'll take what they can get.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その小説家は、55冊目の竜を題材にした小説でようやく大儲けすることができた。
ex_1_en: The novelist finally hit pay dirt with his fifty-fifth novel about dragons.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 縁が無い眼鏡はありますか？
ex_1_en: Do you have any rimless glasses?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Things left near the edge tend to fall off. Remember the old Koichidamus proverb, "Only a fool (ふ) leaves his cheese (ち) on the edge of a table."
pitch_accent: エꜜニシ *** エꜜン *** フチꜜ *** ヘリꜜ *** ユカリ *** ヨꜜスカ° *** ヨスカ°

ex_1_jp: 刃物をちらつかせながら、男は低い声で私に「こっちへ来い」と言いました。
ex_1_en: While brandishing his knife, he said to me in a low voice, "Get over here."
meaning_story: A blade thing is an edged tool or cutlery.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned 刃's reading with the kanji, and you probably remember 物 from so many other words.

ex_1_jp: 刃先を俺の首に当てながら、奴は、皆にいつもご機嫌をとられてるってのはどんな気分なのかと聞いてきたんだ。
ex_1_en: While putting the edge of the blade in my neck, the guys asked me what it’s like to have people fawning over me all the time.
meaning_story: The blade's ahead is the farthest part of the blade away from you (since it's ahead of you). This is the edge of the blade or blade edge.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. For 刃 you learned that with the kanji. For 先 that's the vocab version of the kanji.

pronunciation: えっふぇるとう, エッフェルとう
ex_1_jp: エッフェル塔のどんなところが好きでしたか？
ex_1_en: What did you like about the Eiffel Tower?
meaning_story: The Eiffel (エッフェル) tower is the Eiffel Tower.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 三人のホームレスの老人が、公園で空き缶拾い競争を行った。
ex_1_en: Three old homeless men had an empty can gathering competition in the park.
meaning_story: A sky can is a can that has nothing but sky in it. It's an empty can.
reading_story: The reading for 空き isn't one you've seen before. Remember how 開く means "to open"? Well, this can is also open, because nothing is filling it. The readings are the same between the two, as well. 開く and 空く, though in this case it becomes the stem form: 空き.

ex_1_jp: 誰かがジェットコースターの上で、「覚悟しろ！」と絶叫した。
ex_1_en: Someone screamed "brace yourself!" on the roller coaster.
meaning_story: Extinction caused by a shout. You are making everyone else's voices go extinct, and you scream and shout over them. You are making an exclamation, gosh darn it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the shortening.

ex_1_jp: 父親同様、魚釣りは彼のお気に入りの気晴らしだ。蛙の子は蛙ってことだね。
ex_1_en: Fishing is his favorite pastime, just like his father. They say like father, like son.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

ex_1_jp: うちの四匹のマルチーズは、昨日、誕生日だったので、とても美味しい晩ご飯を食べました。
ex_1_en: My four Maltese dogs had a scrumptious supper because yesterday was their birthday.
meaning_story: Four small animals is four small animals. Use this to count four dogs, or cats, or whatever else.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どんな食べ物でも、彼女の手にかかれば、美しく美味しい金色の揚げ物になるんです。
ex_1_en: Every food she touches turns into beautiful, delicious fried food.
meaning_story: Remember how 揚げる can sometimes mean "to fry"? This is the noun version of that meaning of that word, making it fried... delicious fried...
reading_story: The reading comes from 揚げる as well.

ex_1_jp: どうして裸んぼで手袋だけはめて走り回ってるの？あんたは本当に馬鹿ね。
ex_1_en: Why are you running around naked with only gloves on? You’re such an idiot!
meaning_story: A hand sack is a sack for your hands... better put, these are gloves.
reading_story: The readings are both the kun'yomi vocab readings, so think of 手 and 袋 as individual words, put together to make hand sacks. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: みんな、結婚式の日に吉日を選びたいのよ。
ex_1_en: Everyone wants to choose a lucky day for their wedding.
meaning_story: Having good luck is a good omen to have. Good luck means more good luck, right?
reading_story: This word uses the きち reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 私は一粒の岩塩をオブラートで包みました。
ex_1_en: I wrapped a single grain of sea salt in a wafer.
meaning_story: Grains are made of single grains. You can also use this to refer to a bead or use it as a counter for grains.
reading_story: You take all the grain and put it in a tube (つぶ). Just imagine doing this, grain by grain.

ex_1_jp: 怒ったコウイチは、握りこぶしで机をバンバン叩いた。
ex_1_en: Angry Koichi banged on the desk with his clenched fists.
meaning_story: Remember how 握る is "to grasp"? This is the noun version, making it a grip.
reading_story: The reading comes from 握る, so get a grip on that!

ex_1_jp: 生まれたての赤ちゃんは、毎日お風呂に入れてあげて髪を洗ってあげた方がいいのかな。
ex_1_en: I wonder if I should give my newborn baby a bath and wash her hair every day.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Just be sure to know that this is the hair on your head.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: ビートルズみたいな髪型だね。
ex_1_en: Your hairstyle looks like the Beatles’.
meaning_story: Your hair model is how you model your hair. It's your hairstyle or hairdo.
reading_story: The readings are the vocab readings of the individual kanji. For 髪 that's no problem. For 型 just remember that it's the individual vocab reading. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 「ねえ、サーモン。今何してんの？」「髪の毛セットしてるとこ。」「終わったら、ちょっと時間ある？」「無理〜。これが終わったらネイルもしなきゃなの。」
ex_1_en: "Salmon, what are you doing right now?" "I am doing my hair." "After that, do you have time?" "Nope. I have to do my nails next."
meaning_story: Your hair fur is the hair fur that's specifically on your head. It's your head hair.
reading_story: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings, 髪 and 毛, put together.

ex_1_jp: 初めてマニュアルで運転した時、丘のてっぺんでエンストしてしまいました。
ex_1_en: On my first day of driving a stick, my car stalled at the top of a hill.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading for the vocab version of this word is the same as 岡 which has the same meaning and the same reading. Lucky!

ex_1_jp: 僕に任せろ。
ex_1_en: Leave it to me.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well!
reading_story: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. I certainly like that and I bet you do too.
pitch_accent: シモベ *** シモベꜜ *** ボꜜク *** ボク

ex_1_jp: やあ、コウイチ！俺、久しぶりにお前に会ったから、話したいことが山ほどあるよ。
