ex_1_en: Hey Koichi, we’ve got a lot to catch up on.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 一斗のお米が入った袋は置いてますか？
ex_1_en: Do you have a bag of 18 liters of rice?
meaning_story: How much can you hold in this ladle? Why, exactly eighteen liters of course! Eighteen is your favorite number, how convenient.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 取材であの左翼支持者の方とお会いできるのがとても楽しみです。
ex_1_en: I am so excited that I get to meet with the left wing movement supporter for an interview.
meaning_story: The left wing is the left wing, as in the "left wing party" or "left wing politics" or something like that.
reading_story: The reading for 左 is the on'yomi reading, さ. You can remember this because the left wing uses saws (さ) to cut down their right wing enemies. Imagine left wing hippies sawing down old right wing conservatives. BBrrrrbbbbbbzzzzz!

ex_1_jp: 高卒以下の学歴の男との縁談を私に持って寄越すなんて、一体どういう神経してる訳？
ex_1_en: How dare you to bring me a marriage proposal from a guy who has less than a high school education?!
meaning_story: Let's take the edge and discuss it. That edge is the edge of getting married. But, when you reach that edge, before you jump over, you have to do a marriage proposal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この寸法は正しいですか？
ex_1_en: Is this measurement correct?
meaning_story: One of the easiest methods of measurement is to just check the size and dimensions, and there you go, you've got the measurement.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that the ほう changes to ぽう.

ex_1_jp: 私の妹は拒食症なのですが、喪服を着ているとより一層痩せ細ってみえました。
ex_1_en: My sister is anorexic and when wearing her mourning dress, she looked even skinnier.
meaning_story: Your mourning clothes is your mourning dress or mourning clothes.
reading_story: The reading comes from the on'yomi for 服 and the kun'yomi for 喪, which you learned with the word 喪. You should know how to read this word!

ex_1_jp: あなたすごく考えすぎてるのよ。さっさと辛子を口の中に放り込んじゃいなさいよ。きっとそこまで辛くないわよ。
ex_1_en: You’re thinking about this way too much. Just throw the mustard in your mouth. Surely it’s not that hot.
meaning_story: The spicy child is the child of spicy. So, not as spicy as mamma spicy, but still a bit spicy. This child spicy is mustard. Not too spicy, but not too mild.
reading_story: The reading is 辛い (からい) and the on'yomi reading for 子 combined together. It's one of those weird words that mixes the on'yomi and kun'yomi readings.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguは著作権侵害の裁判で辛勝しました。
ex_1_en: Tofugu won a narrow victory in a copyright infringement suit.
meaning_story: A spicy win is a narrow victory. Kind of makes sense, right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: コウイチは忍者に、正々堂々と勝負で勝った。
ex_1_en: Koichi beat the ninja fair and square!
meaning_story: An endure someone is someone who can endure. Who endures everything better than anyone? A ninja.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: カラスは、日本だけでなくヨーロッパでも、縁起の悪い鳥とみなされます。
ex_1_en: The crow is seen as an ominous bird not only in Japan but also in Europe.
meaning_story: The edge of wake up is right before you wake up. And, by wake up I mean you're about the wake up to the truth. But, you're only at the edge, so for now what you see is an omen... an omen that will show the truth.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that 起 is rendaku'd and becomes ぎ here.

ex_1_jp: すごく不吉な夢を見たもんで、あんたのことが心配になってこうして電話をした訳さ。
ex_1_en: I had such an ominous dream that it made me really worried about you, and that’s why I called.
meaning_story: Something that is not good luck is ominous and sinister. It's also bad luck and an ill omen.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「なあ、今夜俺たちと遊ばないか？金曜日の東京の繁華街はめちゃくちゃ楽しいぜ。」「俺は一匹狼なんだよ。放っておいてくれ。」
ex_1_en: "Do you want to hang out with us tonight? Downtown Tokyo is crazy on Fridays." "I’m a lone wolf. Leave me alone."
meaning_story: One small animal is one small animal. Use this to count small animals like cats and dogs.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening and the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 私の会社は破産寸前である。
ex_1_en: My company is on the verge of bankruptcy.
meaning_story: Before you take the last measurement, you know you're on the brink of something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

ex_1_jp: 大きなプロジェクトの一翼を担えることになりました。
ex_1_en: I’ll handle part of the big project.
meaning_story: If you only have one wing you only have part of a bird. Or a plane. Either way, you only have a part of it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 光が粒子なのか波なのかを考えていて、昨日は眠れませんでした。
ex_1_en: I was thinking about whether light was a particle or a wave and I couldn’t sleep last night.
meaning_story: A grains child is even smaller than a grain. It's a particle, sometimes even an atomic particle.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 場違いだって思うかもしれませんが、私のためだと思って辛抱してください。
ex_1_en: You may feel a little out of place, but please be patient for me.
meaning_story: A spicy hug is a hug that feels not so great. But, it's not really painful all at once, either. As you're receiving a spicy hug, you just have to show patience and endurance while it lasts.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the reading of 抱's on'yomi reading, so think about how much patience and endurance you need to learn how to be good at bowling (ぼう). And watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 大リーグの試合で、ピッチャーがボールの代わりに桃を投げました。
ex_1_en: The pitcher threw a peach instead of a ball in the MLB game.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 桃色のバンで母親が迎えにきた時は、恥ずかしかったですね。
ex_1_en: I was embarrassed when my mom came to pick me up in the peach colored van.
meaning_story: A peach color is a peach color.
reading_story: The readings come from the vocab readings (and kanji readings, actually) of the two kanji.

ex_1_jp: この洋梨のマカロンは、お好みで冷やしても美味しく御賞味頂けます。
ex_1_en: These bartlett pear macarons can also be refrigerated if you’d like that.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: その哲学者は強風を通って歩いたので、自分のベレー帽をしっかりと掴まなくてはならなかった。
ex_1_en: The philosopher had to hang on to his beret as he walked through the strong wind.
meaning_story: A philosophy scholar (学者) is someone who studies philosophy. They're known as a philosopher.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 甥っ子の誕生日祝いに滑り台を作ってるんですが、少々予定が遅れ気味なんですよね。
ex_1_en: I’m making a slide for my nephew’s birthday, but I’m a little behind schedule.
meaning_story: Remember how 滑る is "to slide"? Then, how 台 is a counter for machines? In this case, this slippery machine is a slide, more specifically a playground slide.
reading_story: The reading comes from 滑る and 台.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 娯楽小説を読むことの何が悪いって言うんですか？
ex_1_en: What’s wrong with reading light novels?
meaning_story: Recreation and comfort are things you do for pleasure and amusement. So nice!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: わかったわ。じゃあ、これからはアヤのこと、アヤ姫って呼ばないといけないの？
ex_1_en: Okay, so from now on we have to call her Princess Aya?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be used to refer to a noble girl as well, as in a girl of the noble family.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: お迎えにあがりましたよ、僕の小さなお姫様。
ex_1_en: I’m here to pick you up, my little princess.
meaning_story: The princess (formal name ender) is the princess, and you're talking to her politely. She is the princess.
reading_story: The reading is the reading of 姫 and 様 combined together.

ex_1_jp: この紙に御朱印を押してもらえますか？
ex_1_en: Could I get the red seal of the shogun on this paper?
meaning_story: A vermillion colored seal is a red seal. Just look up the (Japanese) word in Google Image search and you'll see what this is.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの映画のその場面がいつも謎なんだよね。
ex_1_en: That part of the movie always a mystery to me.
meaning_story: A riddle is a riddle and a mystery.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. No mystery there.

ex_1_jp: 子どもはみんな謎々遊びをするのが好きだろう。
ex_1_en: Pretty much all kids like solving riddles, right?
meaning_story: A puzzle puzzle is a puzzle, but it's also a riddle or enigma as well.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 自分は、極端な右翼思想を持って生まれたように感じます。
ex_1_en: I feel that I was born with extreme right-wing ideas.
meaning_story: The right wing is the right wing. As in, "right wing politics" or "right wing beliefs."
reading_story: The reading for 右 is the on'yomi reading, one you didn't learn. To remember that the reading here is う, just think about how you (う) are a right winger, and how you want to make everyone else right wingers too. You and you and you and you, you're becoming right wingers with me. Use your actual political affiliation to help yourself to feel emotional about this situation.

ex_1_jp: 「今の侍としての仕事が気に入らないのなら、他の仕事を探したら？」 「口で言うほど簡単じゃないよ。」
ex_1_en: "If you don’t like your job as a samurai, why don’t you find another one?" "Easier said than done."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the meaning and the reading of the kanji: さむらい.

ex_1_jp: その砂丘には駱駝もいるんですよ。
ex_1_en: There are some camels on that sand dune.
meaning_story: A sand hill is a sand dune.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの古い網戸は本当に気持ち悪いね。
ex_1_en: That old screen door is so gross!
meaning_story: A netting door is a screen door. Makes sense, right? Screen doors are like little meshy nets made into a door shape.
reading_story: You've seen 網 on its own. We're going to use that reading. Then, add the 戸 reading with rendaku and you have yourself あみど.

ex_1_jp: フグが僕のことをデブって呼ぶんだよね。自分のことを棚に上げてよく言うよ。
ex_1_en: Fugu calls me fat. Talk about the pot calling the kettle black. (Literally: to talk about it while putting himself up on the shelf)
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 大きい方の犬は車庫にいて、もう一匹は室内にいるよ。
ex_1_en: We keep our bigger dog in the garage and the other one in our house.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 中々手堅い仕事みたいだから、葬儀屋になるための勉強をしようかなって思ってるんだよね。
ex_1_en: I’m thinking of learning how to become an undertaker because it looks like a pretty secure job.
meaning_story: You know that 堅い is "solid" or "tough." When you hand is solid and tough, it's solid and steady. If your hand is shaky, it's the opposite, or something.
reading_story: The reading is the two words 手 and 堅い combined together. Watch out for the rendaku.
pitch_accent: テカ°タꜜイ *** テカ°タイ

ex_1_jp: クミンシードは、インドカレーには欠かせない香辛料のうちの一つです。
ex_1_en: The cumin seed is one of the most important spices for Indian curry.
meaning_story: The fee for fragrance and spicy in your food is the fee of spices. If you don't pay your spices fee, you aren't going to have any spice or fragrance in your food. If you do, you'll have those things and your food will be awesome!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「やばい〜！超辛い～！でも、このカレーすっげ〜美味しい！」
ex_1_en: "Omg! My mouth is on fire, but this curry is sooo good!"
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. That being said, this can also mean difficult or painful as well. I guess if you're in a spicy situation it's going to be a difficult one.
reading_story: Depending on the context, the reading for this word could be からい or つらい. The からい reading is the spicy one, you can remember that because that spicy feeling comes from (から) your mouth. The つらい reading is the difficult or painful one. You can remember this because two Ras (つら) are way more difficult to deal with than one Ra.

ex_1_jp: ニンニクの芽はいつもどうやって料理に使いますか？
ex_1_en: How do you usually cook the garlic shoots?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: うちの子、幼稚園のお泊まり会をすごく楽しみにしてたんだけど、風邪を引いちゃって、今抗生物質を飲ませたところなんです。だから、残念ながら今夜は欠席させて頂きます。
ex_1_en: My kid was really looking forward to the kindergarten sleepover, but he got a cold and I just made him take antibiotics. So, sadly, he’ll be absent tonight.
meaning_story: You know that 泊まる is "to stay the night." The noun version is a stay or stopover.
reading_story: The reading comes from 泊まる, so pull from that and you shall know this.

ex_1_jp: 「彼女、もしかして本当は全然怒ってないんじゃない？」「ただの嵐の前の静けさだよ。」
ex_1_en: "Isn’t it possible that she really isn’t that upset?" "This is just the calm before the storm."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: アイツはまだ社会の荒波に揉まれた事のないただの若造だよ。
ex_1_en: He is just a young boy who hasn’t been tossed in the stormy seas of life yet.
meaning_story: A wild wave will make for some stormy seas or raging waves. Don't go out in these kinds of waves.
reading_story: The readings come from the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, 荒 (the secondary reading you learned with this kanji) and 波 (just the vocab version).

ex_1_jp: 1寸は1尺の10分の1で、約3.03センチです。
ex_1_en: 1 sun is 1/10th of 1 shaku, which is approximately 3.03 centimeters.
meaning_story: This measurement also refers to a specific measurement, a "sun", which is about 3.03 centimeters. You'll hear it brought up from time to time to measure things, though usually with more traditional Japanese items.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji! Congrats! Now to remember it's three point zero three centimeters.

ex_1_jp: 面白過ぎて片腹が痛いし、涙も出てきたよ。
ex_1_en: It’s so funny that my side hurts and there are tears in my eyes.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Your teardrops are like little waves. What are they? They're 波だ (なみだ).

ex_1_jp: どんな時に人は感涙にむせび泣くと思いますか。
ex_1_en: When do you think people would burst into tears of gratitude?
meaning_story: The feeling of teardrops is a feeling that makes you cry. But, it's not a bad feeling, these are tears of gratitude.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 雷の音で、洗濯物を取り入れなくちゃいけないことを思い出しました。
ex_1_en: The thunder reminded us that we had laundry to bring inside.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: To remember the reading think about thunder. Back in the day, it was probably terrifying. It probably came from the Gods! So, what if you got hit with this electricity? Would you become a God too? Let's pretend that's true, and let's pretend that's why 雷 is read like 神成り (かみなり) which means "to become a god!"
pitch_accent: イカズチ *** カミナꜜリ *** カミナリꜜ *** ラꜜイ

ex_1_jp: 落雷が直撃したのに、奇跡的に無傷だった。
ex_1_en: Even though the thunderbolt was a direct hit, I was miraculously unhurt.
meaning_story: Thunder that falls from the sky is a thunderbolt.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今朝の強烈な雷雨で停電になったので、今はインターネットが使えません。
ex_1_en: The severe thunderstorm this morning caused a power outage, so I can’t use the internet right now.
meaning_story: A thunder rain is a rain that's coming with thunder. For all intents and purposes, if you see this, you'll think thunderstorm.
reading_story: The reading is the on'yomi readings. For 雨, you haven't seen the on'yomi reading, which is う. To remember this, just think about how in a thunderstorm, it rains uni (sea urchin). You go outside, dodging the thunder, to collect these uni.

ex_1_jp: 私のお父さんは桃の缶詰工場で働いています。
ex_1_en: My father works in a peach canning factory.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. It also just sounds like can.

ex_1_jp: 解熱剤が他の薬に紛れちゃってて、どれがどれだか分かりません。
ex_1_en: The fever medicine slipped in with other pills and I’m not sure which one is which.
meaning_story: You know that 紛らす means "to divert" or "to distract." This is when you're not doing the action, now, making this word to be diverted or to be distracted.
reading_story: The reading comes from 紛らす.

ex_1_jp: 焦るなよ。小便に行きたい以外は、急ぐ必要はないよ。一日一日を着実にな。
ex_1_en: Take your time. Other than needing to pee, there is no rush. One day at a time.
meaning_story: This is a bit of a weird word. The kanji is char, and a previous word you learned (焦げる) is "to be burned." This, on the other hand, is "to be in a hurry" or "to be impatient." I guess if you're getting burned or have that feeling, you're going to be in a hurry and you're going to be impatient. You can tell that this is that word because it only has one kana, る, which stands for rude. You're feeling someone is being rude (or maybe you are), which is why you have this feeling of impatience and hurrying.
reading_story: You're being rude, but you're also being a big ass (あせ) with your impatience.

ex_1_jp: 今あの子のおっぱいがボインボイン揺れてるのを見てたよね？
ex_1_en: You were looking at her bouncing boobs, weren’t you?
meaning_story: Remember 揺る which means "to shake" or "to jolt"? This is like that, but now you're not doing the shaking and jolting, making it to be shaken or to be jolted. You know this because it's really rare (れる) for you to be shaken like this.
reading_story: The reading comes from 揺る.

ex_1_jp: いつもトーストを真っ黒に焦がしてしまう。
ex_1_en: I always burn my toast completely black.
meaning_story: You know that 焦げる is "to be burned" or "to get burned." This word however is when you're doing the burning, making it to burn or to scorch. You know this because when it comes to burning, you pull out all the stops. You use lots of gas (がす) to burn whatever it is you burn.
reading_story: The reading comes from 焦げる, so if you know that you know this word as well.

ex_1_jp: 三歳の頃犬に噛まれてから、ずっと犬に恐怖心を抱いていたんですが、この小さな仔犬に出会って犬嫌いを克服しました。
ex_1_en: I’ve been afraid of dogs since I was bitten by one when I was three, but I’ve overcome my hatred for them since meeting this little puppy.
meaning_story: 克服 is "conquest" so the verb version of that is to conquer.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 父さん、どうして僕たちはアイツらの侮辱を忍ばなきゃならないの？
ex_1_en: Why do we have to endure their insults, dad?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure so the verb vocab version is to endure.
reading_story: Those who are able to endure are those who have had a lot of training. Who has had the most training of anyone? Ninjas. What group are they part of? The shinobi (しの).

ex_1_jp: 犯罪者を取り逃すふりをするのは、ちょっとやり過ぎじゃない？
ex_1_en: Don’t you think pretending that you failed to catch the criminal is a bit overkill?
meaning_story: The thing you want to take has escaped. Meaning you failed to catch this thing. This word is to fail to catch.
reading_story: The readings come from 取る and 逃がす.
pitch_accent: トリニカ°ꜜス *** トリニカ°ス

ex_1_jp: 後で何匹釣れたかお知らせしますね。
ex_1_en: I’ll let you know how many fish we caught later.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fishing so the verb vocab version is to fish.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 昨夜車上荒らしにあって、マックを盗まれました。
ex_1_en: My car was broken into last night and my mac was stolen.
meaning_story: 荒れる is "to be stormy" or "to be rough." This is when you do the stormy rough things. You go wild on everyone, trying to lay waste and to devastate everything around you.
reading_story: The reading comes from 荒れる.

ex_1_jp: うちに知らない人を泊めるのは嫌です。
ex_1_en: I don’t want to have some stranger stay at our house.
meaning_story: 泊まる is "to stay the night." Now you're letting someone else stay the night, which makes this to let someone stay over or to let someone stay the night.
reading_story: The reading comes from 泊まる.

ex_1_jp: その法律に抜け穴があることを今の今まで見逃していました。
ex_1_en: I hadn’t noticed that there was a loophole in the law until now.
meaning_story: 逃す is "to let go" or "to let escape." If something escapes your seeing, then you are going to overlook it.
reading_story: The reading comes from 見 and 逃す.
pitch_accent: ミノカ°ス *** ミノカ°ꜜス

ex_1_jp: 昨夜、竜巻警報が出て、停電にもなりました。
ex_1_en: There was a tornado warning and a power outage last night.
meaning_story: A dragon scroll is a dragon that's shaped kind of like a scroll, spinning around. This is a tornado.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. For 竜 just think about how it's a standing (立つ) dragon, because it would have to be if it's a tornado. Your まき reading comes from 巻く, but the kana is pushed into the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 小包を開けると、中には自動追尾魚雷が入っていた。
ex_1_en: When I opened the package there was a homing torpedo inside it.
meaning_story: Fish thunder is underwater thunder that shoots at things and are kind of shaped like fish. That's a torpedo. Load the fish thunder!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 二重瞼の整形手術をした時、親から貰った顔に傷をつけたと両親からこっぴどく叱られました。
ex_1_en: When I got double eyelid surgery done, I was harshly scolded by my parents because I hurt the face I inherited from them.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scold and the verb vocab version also means to scold.
reading_story: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 僕の伯父さんは、今まで蜂に刺されたことがなくて、どんなものか試してみたかったから、蜂の巣がある木を揺すったんだそうです。
ex_1_en: It seems that my uncle shook a tree with a beehive in it because he had never been stung by a bee and wanted to try it out.
meaning_story: Shake plus "to do" is the verb version of shake. That's to shake or to jolt.
reading_story: The reading comes from 揺る.

ex_1_jp: コウイチが木を揺さぶったので、ビエットは枝に掴まった。
ex_1_en: Viet held onto the branch because Koichi shook the tree.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shake so the verb vocab version is to shake.
reading_story: The reading comes from 揺る.

ex_1_jp: 「感情を吐き出すために叫ぶのが終わったら、ちゃんと電気を消してね。」「了解。」
ex_1_en: "Turn the light off when you’re done screaming about your emotions." "Roger."
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shout so the verb vocab version is to shout. Can also be to scream.
reading_story: To remember the reading of this, just think about how you start to shout and to scream when you drink way too much sake (さけ).

ex_1_jp: 五重の塔の売買契約の手付金を支払いました。
ex_1_en: I paid the deposit on a contract for a five-storied pagoda.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be a pagoda. If you think about it, pagodas were the towers of the olden days.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: ばべるのとう, バベルのとう
ex_1_jp: バベルの塔に辿り着く一番速い方法はなんですか？
ex_1_en: What’s the fastest way to get to the Tower of Babel?
meaning_story: バベル's 塔 is Babel's tower. That's the Tower of Babel.
reading_story: The reading comes from the reading of the kanji.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: この田舎道は、渋滞とは無縁です。
ex_1_en: This country road is free from traffic jams.
meaning_story: If something has a nothing edge, it's probably unrelated to what you're doing. There's no edge, your stuff always has edges.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この布を朱に染めたいんです。
ex_1_en: I want to dye this cloth crimson.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can also say it's scarlet red or blood as well, though more in a poetic sense, I'd say. I don't think you'll hear surgeons calling blood 朱.
reading_story: The reading あけ is like the beginning of 開ける, which means "to open." Just imagine you're opening (あけ) a person up, and out gushes out a vermillion colored blood. You shouldn't open people up like that.

ex_1_jp: ごめん。 俺らがこの会話をするのは明らかにすごく早すぎたよな。でも、ただ、俺はお前と結婚したいと思ってるってこと、言いたかったんだ。
ex_1_en: I’m sorry. It’s obviously way too early for us to be having this conversation, but I just wanted to tell you that I want to marry you.
meaning_story: I with a ら on it makes it plural. It's less formal than 俺たち (if you've seen that word yet), but has the same meaning. It's we.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji's reading.

ex_1_jp: 俺たち、生き別れになっていた妹に会いに、来月北海道に行くんだ。
ex_1_en: We’ll go to Hokkaido next month to meet our younger sister, who has been separated from us for all these years.
meaning_story: I plus たち is we. Remember 私達? It's just like that. Remember, 俺 is going to be much more casual and rough sounding, so be careful to only use it amongst friends / when you're shaking someone down.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は荒々しい声で、寝ている時に奥さんが毎晩顔に小便を掛けてくることに怒り心頭していることを公言しました。
ex_1_en: He in a wild voice he proclaimed that he was totally “pissed off” at his wife for "pissing" on his face every night while he was sleeping.
meaning_story: 荒い is rough. Double that to 荒々しい and you have the same thing: wild, rough, or even desolate (because wild places are desolate sometimes).
reading_story: The reading comes from 荒い. Since you already know that 々 means it repeats, you already know this reading!

ex_1_jp: つけたい翼を選んで下さいね。
ex_1_en: Please pick up the wings you want to wear.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: In each political wing there is two bosses (つばさ). It's a weird system, but that's how they're doing it these days. Imagine your favorite / least favorite political wings, all with two bosses, arguing with each other.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguはいつ頃Eブックマーケットに参入するつもりですか？
ex_1_en: How soon will Tofugu enter into the e-book market?
meaning_story: いつ is "when" and 頃 is "about." Combine those together and you have "about when?" or "how soon?"
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, just rendaku'd.

ex_1_jp: 研究者たちは、どれだけ速く氷山が溶け出しているかについて警鐘を鳴らしている。
ex_1_en: Researchers are sounding the alarm on how quickly the icebergs are melting.
meaning_story: A warn bell is a bell that goes off when you need to be warned about something. This is usually an alarm bell or a fire bell.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: うちの年頃の娘に一体何をしてくれたんだ？
ex_1_en: What have you done with my adolescent daughter?
meaning_story: The year approximate is your approximate age.
reading_story: The reading is the reading of the vocab version of 年 plus 頃, put together.

ex_1_jp: 今日のお昼の三時頃、この公園でツキノワグマが目撃されました。
ex_1_en: Around three o’clock this afternoon, a moon bear was seen in this park.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also means approximate time and around (as in "around 3:00").
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 誰もが、その凶悪犯が刑務所で大人しく刑期を務めるのは無理だろうと思っていました。
ex_1_en: Everyone believed that the atrocious criminal would not fare well in prison.
meaning_story: A villain who is bad is the most atrocious and fiendish villain of them all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 最近真剣に細菌について勉強をし始めました。
ex_1_en: Recently, I started seriously studying bacteria.
meaning_story: A thin bacteria is... well... a bacteria. I guess all bacteria are really thin. So thin you can't see them with your naked eye, in fact.
reading_story: The reading for 細 is one you haven't learned. Just think about the reading as a whole as さいきん which is the same as 最近. Just think about how 最近 (さいきん) you've really had a bad bacteria problem. Then, imagine the bacteria overflowing from every crevice in your home.

ex_1_jp: 母は、父が悪趣味な人形を集めることを禁止しました。
ex_1_en: My mom forbade my dad from collecting tasteless dolls.
meaning_story: Your 趣味 is your hobby. It's the thing you do on habit. A bad hobby is a habit that you do all the time that's no good. This is a bad habit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私が旅行者だと言うと、男は鐘の形をしたお守りの値段を明らかに釣り上げたが、何だかそいつに悪い気がして、そのまま何も言わずに言われた通りの値段を払ったんだよ。
ex_1_en: Apparently he raised the price of the bell shaped charm since I told him that I was a tourist, but I felt a little sorry for him, so I didn’t say anything and paid the price he told me anyway.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Seeing the bell, you decide you need to ring it. You take your cane (かね) and hit the bell as hard as you can, making it chime.

ex_1_jp: 一か八かでお前に賭けてみるよ。
ex_1_en: I’ll take a chance on you.
meaning_story: The noun version of gamble is gambling or betting or a gamble or a bet. Whatever you do, put it all on black 13. Trust me.
reading_story: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: いさり舟をハンマーで叩いて破壊した。
ex_1_en: I destroyed the fishing boat with a hammer.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that this word isn't usually used by itself (that would be 船). It's usually attached to things that are boat-related, but I wanted you to learn it individually so you can use it that way.
reading_story: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Also the same as 船.

ex_1_jp: 太平洋上には小舟がひしめきあっていた。
ex_1_en: The Pacific Ocean was filled with little boats.
meaning_story: A small boat is a boat or small craft. If something is a "big boat" it's better to call it a "ship" I think, which is why this is just a boat.
reading_story: The readings are all ones you've seen before. 小 uses its こ reading, so just think of this like a "child boat." This makes sense because it's small. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 靴下を裏返しに履いちゃうと、嫁が怒ってうるさいんだわ。
ex_1_en: My wife gets upset with me whenever I wear my socks inside out.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 頼むから電卓を叩くのをやめてくれ。気が狂いそうになるだろ！
ex_1_en: Please stop drumming on the calculator. You’re driving me crazy!
meaning_story: An electricity table is a calculator. Why is this? You can think about it in a couple of different ways. Maybe in the past, a calculator (aka abacus) would take up a whole table, making this "electric" version a calculator. Or, maybe it can be used to solve tables. Wrong kind of table, but should help you to remember the meaning of this word.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: うちの会社は暦通りの営業になります。
ex_1_en: Our company’s business days follow the regular calendar.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: When looking at a calendar, the 子読み (こよみ) of it is to... well... not be able to read it at all. Because, children can't really read. So, when you look at a calendar you have to explain it to a child, since they cannot read it.

ex_1_jp: ある日天井に小さな穴が空いてるのを見つけたんですが、ストーカーがたまに屋根裏に上ってその穴から私のことを覗いていたことが後から判明したんです。
ex_1_en: One day I saw a small hole in the ceiling, then later I found out that I had a stalker who would occasionally peep at me through the hole from my attic.
meaning_story: The heaven well is the well that goes up into the heavens. This is above you, and it is a ceiling. Maybe the "well" part is referring to the chimney that goes up through the ceiling to the heavens when you look up in a super old house?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 家族でうちの犬をペット専用霊園に連れて行きました。
ex_1_en: My family took our puppy to a pet cemetery.
meaning_story: A ghost garden is where many ghosts are harvested and where many ghosts grow. This is a cemetery.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 昭和は西暦何年に終わったんですか？
ex_1_en: What year in the Western calendar did the Showa era end?
meaning_story: The West's calendar shows the history and time period of "The West." To the Japanese and Chinese, this era is known as the Christian Era.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 実は、眩しい午後の日差しの下よりも、曇りの日の方が写真撮影には適しています。
ex_1_en: Cloudy days are actually better for photography than bright afternoon sunlight.
meaning_story: The noun version of cloudy is cloudiness or cloudy weather.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 一度しかない人生だろ！なぁ！一緒に全裸でスカイダイビングしに行こうぜ。すんげぇいい経験になると思うんだよね。
ex_1_en: You only live once! Come on. You should go skydiving nude with me. It would be a great experience for us.
meaning_story: You're all naked, which makes you completely nude or totally nude.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日本で初恋の人にバッタリ出くわした時は、可也驚きました。
ex_1_en: I was quite surprised when I bumped into my first love in Japan.
meaning_story: It's possible that it's considerably considerable. It's considerably, fairly, and quite... something. Also please note that this is almost always written in kana and not kanji. But, we're learning kanji here, so gosh darn it we're going to learn some kanji.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 塾に何か問題でもあるの？
ex_1_en: What’s the matter with your cram school?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned in the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 彼は塾生たちの中で一番記憶力が悪かった。
ex_1_en: He has the worst memory out of all the cram school students.
meaning_story: Remember how 学生 is "student"? This plays off that. A cram school "student" is a student of a cram school, a cram school student.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 魔女はお姫様に、コップを逆さまにしか持てなくする呪いをかけた。
ex_1_en: The witch put a curse on the princess that made it so she could only hold cups upside down.
meaning_story: Despite looking like an adjective this is a noun. It means the same thing as the kanji: curse.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.
pitch_accent: ノロイ *** ノロꜜイ *** ノロイꜜ

ex_1_jp: 「アチョーーーーーー!」と叫び声を上げながら、コウイチはビエトの手から凶器を叩き落とした。
ex_1_en: As he screamed, "Achooo!" Koichi knocked the dangerous weapon from Viet’s hand.
meaning_story: A villain vessel is a vessel used by a villain. This vessel holds bullets, and is a dangerous weapon.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私がお皿を洗うから、あなたは食卓を綺麗にしてくれる？いいかしら？
ex_1_en: I’ll wash the dishes and you can set the table for me. Is that okay?
meaning_story: An eating table is a dining table.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お風呂の排水溝が髪の毛で詰まっちゃったみたいなの。
ex_1_en: It looks like hair clogged the drain for the bathtub.
meaning_story: A reject water gutter is drainage. That's exactly what drainage ditches do, they are ditches and they reject water.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ハイスイコー *** ハイスꜜイコー

ex_1_jp: 結婚式の前に入籍をする予定です。
ex_1_en: We are planning to be entered in the family register before the wedding ceremony.
meaning_story: Remember how 戸籍 is the family register? This is referring to that, and that makes this word mean entry in family register.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: あくりょう, あくれい
ex_1_jp: 悪霊がいると聞いたので、トンネルの中ではスピードを上げて運転しました。
ex_1_en: She drove speeding through tunnel because she heard there was an evil spirit in there.
meaning_story: An evil ghost isn't so much a ghost as it is an evil spirit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note this uses the secondary 霊 reading of りょう, so imagine an evil spirit rowing a boat.
pitch_accent: アクリョー *** アクꜜリョー

ex_1_jp: 今納税の手続きをしているんだけど、もう疲労困憊だよ。
ex_1_en: I’m doing the taxes and I’m already totally exhausted.
meaning_story: You're exhausted from labor. From this, you're showing fatigue and weariness.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その男は強引な押し売りで私に肌色のクレヨンを一箱売りつけました。
ex_1_en: The guy used high pressure sales tactics to sell me a box of skin colored crayons.
meaning_story: Skin color is flesh colored or skin colored.
reading_story: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings of each kanji, 肌 and 色 combined into one.
pitch_accent: ハダイロ *** ハダイロꜜ

ex_1_jp: ホームレスだからって、俺がまるでばい菌のように人にジロジロ見られるのは、とても腹立たしい。
ex_1_en: Even though I’m homeless, it’s really irritating when people stare at me like I’m some kind of germ.
meaning_story: A "ばい" bacteria is a germ. In case you're wondering, the ばい is referring to the kanji 黴, but people don't usually write that part.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 亡霊はめげずに、人々を怖がらせ続けました。
ex_1_en: The ghost continued to scare people without getting depressed.
meaning_story: A deceased ghost is a ghost (all ghosts are deceased). Can also refer to "the dead."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: アイツのYoutubeビデオを見るまでは、てっきり陰気な男だと思っていたよ。
ex_1_en: I was certain he was a melancholy guy until I saw his Youtube videos.
meaning_story: A shade energy is a shady feeling. It's a feeling of gloom and melancholy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「ゴキブリ」という名前を聞くだけで、鳥肌が立ちます。
ex_1_en: I get goosebumps just from hearing the name "cockroach."
meaning_story: Bird skin is goosebumps. Makes sense, since a goose is a bird and a bird's skin is bumpy.
reading_story: The reading is the individual vocab readings of the two kanji, 鳥 and 肌.

ex_1_jp: コインパーキングの横の溝に、万札が落ちてるのを見つけたんだよ。
ex_1_en: I found a 10,000 yen bill in a ditch beside a coin operated parking space.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: What goes in the gutter? 水. But, the reading isn't exactly right. It's みぞ not みず, but close enough to create a hook.

ex_1_jp: この美しい矛は、白金とプラチナで作られています。
ex_1_en: This beautiful halberd is made from white gold and platinum.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The person who's holding the halberd is a little hoe 子. It's a child who learned to fight with a hoe, and he's turned the hoe into a halberd to fight with. Imagine him swinging his hoe halberd around like a little dork.

ex_1_jp: きゃー！たった今夢が叶っちゃった！半裸のイケメンが淹れたての珈琲を飲みながら、私が目を覚ました瞬間に「おはよう」って言ってくれるっていう夢が！
ex_1_en: Ahh! My dream just came true! It was the dream where a half naked hunk said "Good morning" the moment I woke up, while drinking freshly brewed coffee!
meaning_story: If you're half naked you're half nude or half naked.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その温泉に入った後は、お肌がツルツルになるよ。
ex_1_en: Your skin will be really smooth after bathing in the hot spring.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though you'll want to know that this refers most specifically to human skin.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 最近加湿器の調子が悪いんだよね。
ex_1_en: Something has been wrong with my humidifier.
meaning_story: An "add dampness container" is a container that adds dampness to the air. That's a humidifier.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 狩人が週休二日制だってのは初耳だな。
ex_1_en: I didn’t know the hunters used the five-day workweek system.
meaning_story: A hunt person is a person who hunts. A hunter.
reading_story: The reading for this word makes almost no sense at all. Just think about how you're hunting for the car ryuu dog, which is half car, half Ryuu (from Street Fighter) and half dog. Imagine this beast in your head. You are the hunter. You must hunt it.
pitch_accent: カꜜリュード *** カリュꜜード

ex_1_jp: 来週はずっと山で狩りをしている予定です。
ex_1_en: I’ll be hunting in the mountains all of next week.
meaning_story: You have the noun version of hunt. That is hunting.
reading_story: The reading uses the reading from the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は非常に霊感の強い霊能力者で、あの世の人と話をすることができます。
ex_1_en: She’s a spiritual person with a strong sixth sense and can talk to people on the other side.
meaning_story: A ghost feeling is inspiration. For some reason, the feeling of ghosts is the feeling of inspiration. I guess a ghost goes inside you and makes you feel this inspiration?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 黒潮の流域とは正確にはどこになりますか？
ex_1_en: Where exactly is the basin of the Kuroshio Current?
meaning_story: The black tide isn't what you think, most likely. This is the Japan current, aka the Kuroshio Current. It's a Northern flowing current on the West side of the Pacific Ocean. Have you heard of the Gulf Stream? It's kind of like that.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the two kanji, put together. 黒 and 潮.

ex_1_jp: 近頃は製菓工場で夜勤の仕事をしているんだ。
ex_1_en: Recently I’ve been working the graveyard shift in a confectionery factory.
meaning_story: The near approximate is the approximate time that was near to you. This period of time is the lately period of time. It's recently.
reading_story: The reading is 近い and 頃 put together.

ex_1_jp: 夜になると脚がムズムズして、よく眠れないんです。
ex_1_en: My legs are restless at night and I can’t sleep well.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 足, which also means leg and foot.

ex_1_jp: 彼女はとても素晴らしい遠距離走選手だよ。ほら、今も急にペースを上げたから、前のランナーに追いつくと思う。
ex_1_en: She is a great long distance runner. She’s suddenly picked up her pace and I think she’s going to catch up with the runner ahead of her.
meaning_story: A far distance detachment is a distance that is far. It is long distance. Also remember that 距離 is a "distance" so a far distance is a long distance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 店に入ると、カウンターにドンと置かれた肉の塊がまず一番に目についた。
ex_1_en: When I went in the store the first thing I noticed was the lump of meat that was placed on the counter.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Recognize this word? Na naaa na na na na na na naaa ♬.

ex_1_jp: 旧暦の正月といえばいつになりますかね。
ex_1_en: When will it be the lunar calendar’s New Year?
meaning_story: The former calendar is the calendar from before. It's the lunisolar calendar and the traditional Japanese calendar. Certainly not the current calendar, anyways.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その申し出を断るなんて狂気の沙汰だよ。
ex_1_en: You must be insane to decline that offer.
meaning_story: Lunatic energy is madness and insanity.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 手頃な値段ですね。
ex_1_en: This is a reasonable price, isn’t it?
meaning_story: When you control your hand an approximate amount, you are going to be a very moderate and reasonable person.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日本の梅雨は湿気が多いので嫌いです。
ex_1_en: I don’t like the rainy season in Japan because it’s very humid.
meaning_story: A damp energy is a feeling of dampness. It is moisture and humidity.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful of the shortening, and the irregular reading for 気.
pitch_accent: シッキ *** シッキꜜ *** シッケ *** シッケꜜ

ex_1_jp: キモイ！今あそこの横断歩道で、裸に袖無しエプロンを着た男を見かけたんだけど。警察に通報した方がいいかな。
ex_1_en: Gross! I just saw a naked dude wearing just a sleeveless apron at the crosswalk over there. Should we call the police?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: You are naked now. You used to wear a car, but you don't have it anymore (and you're not wearing it). You had a car (はだか), but now you don't have a car. That's what you'll explain when someone asks you why you're naked.

ex_1_jp: 核分裂の過程について、分かりやすいスライドショーを作ってもらえますか。
ex_1_en: Can you make an easy-to-understand slide show on the process of nuclear fission?
meaning_story: 分裂 means "split" or "division." The nucleus version of this split is nuclear fission.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 鰻がフィリピン海溝の近くで産卵することは、フィリピン人に知られているのでしょうか。
ex_1_en: I wonder if Filipinos know that the spawning place for eels is close to the Philippine Trench.
meaning_story: An ocean gutter is an ocean trench.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 若い頃は食べ物について気にしなかったけど、今はお医者さんに糖尿病予備軍だって言われたので、食べ物に気をつけるようになったし、いつもレシピに書かれてるよりも少ない砂糖を入れるようにもなりました。
ex_1_en: When I was young, I didn’t care about what I ate, but now I do and I always add a little less sugar than the recipe calls for because my doctor told me that I’m at risk for diabetes.
meaning_story: The young approximate is the approximate age of when you were young. This, approximately, is one's youth or early life.
reading_story: The reading is 若い and 頃 combined into one.

ex_1_jp: この小包は、ほんの友情の印です。
ex_1_en: This package is just a symbol of our friendship.
meaning_story: A small bundle is merely a package. Something big would be a big package, I guess.
reading_story: The reading comes from 小 (which is a reading you've seen a couple times now, I'm sure) and 包み, with the み pushed inside the package. Beware of the somewhat weird rendaku. You don't see づ too often.

ex_1_jp: 申し訳ありませんが、お客様の靴はすごく汚れているので、時間内に磨き終わるのは難しいかと思われます。
ex_1_en: I’m sorry but it will be difficult for me to finish polishing your shoes in time because they are so dirty.
meaning_story: A polish is a polish or even a shine.
reading_story: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 義塾に通い始めた初日、思いっきり場違いだと感じました。
ex_1_en: I felt completely out of place on my first day of private school.
meaning_story: A righteousness cram school is, for some reason, a private school. Maybe because they don't think the public cram schools are any good, so they take their righteousness somewhere else to start a private one? I'm not sure.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: そのホテルの部屋からは美しく青い海を眺望することができました。
ex_1_en: We were able to view the beautiful blue ocean from our hotel room.
meaning_story: You stare at hope. It looks good. That is your prospect and view, as you stare at hope.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 祖母に、滝川を泳ぐのは危険だと言われました。
ex_1_en: My grandma told me that it is very dangerous to swim in the rapids.
meaning_story: A waterfall river is a river that's moving like a waterfall! Fast and furious! Water that moves like this are rapids.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of each kanji: 滝 and 川. Careful of the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: つい先頃までとても仲良くしてたのに、彼が急によそよそしくなったんだけど、理由が全然分からないの。
ex_1_en: We’d been good friends until just recently, but he suddenly grew really cold toward me. I don’t understand why.
meaning_story: The previous approximate was the previous approximate time, which is recently or the other day.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of the two kanji. That's 先 and 頃 (the reading you learned) put together. The 頃 is the rendaku'd version, ごろ so be careful.

ex_1_jp: この頃、風味を出すために砕いたヘーゼルナッツを珈琲に加えてるんです。
ex_1_en: These days I’ve been adding chopped hazelnuts to my coffee for added flavor.
meaning_story: This (この) approximate is this approximate time. It is recently or nowadays or these days.
reading_story: The reading is the 頃 reading from the kanji reading. Be careful, it's the rendaku'd form.

ex_1_jp: 死後どのぐらいで死後硬直が起きるんでしょうか。
ex_1_en: I wonder how long after death rigor mortis sets in.
meaning_story: A stiff fix is when you fix something to be stiff. When you do that, it becomes rigid.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: げんきょう, がんきょう
ex_1_jp: 人類の半分を一掃した凶悪なウィルスの元凶は、ウォッカのつまった西瓜だった。
ex_1_en: The source of the terrible virus that wiped out half of mankind was a vodka-filled watermelon.
meaning_story: The origin villain is the villain who's running everything. They're the person responsible for the villainy going on. They are the ringleader or main culprit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 他の脚本では出来なかった事を、彼の脚本はやってのけたんだよ。
ex_1_en: What the other scripts weren’t able to do, his script did.
meaning_story: A leg book is just the legs of a book. Not a whole book. It only contains the parts that walk around and move, not so much the descriptions (things that don't move). This kind of book is a script or screenplay. These "books" are focused on actions and things people say, which is why it's just the legs.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 陰でこそこそ私の陰口言うの、止めてくれない？言いたいことがあるなら、はっきり言ってよ！
ex_1_en: Can’t you stop making fun of me behind my back? If you have something to say, say it to my face.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also means shadow.
reading_story: Look at a shadow. It's long, surprisingly long. It's in the shape of a cage (かげ), because that's what is producing the long shadow. Check out each bar of the cage. Maybe you're inside the cage? Whatever is going on, a long shadow is being created by the cage and shade.

ex_1_jp: タクシーの運ちゃんは大体みんな近距離乗車は嫌がるよね。
ex_1_en: Taxi drivers generally dislike short distant trips, don’t they?
meaning_story: A 距離 is a distance and 近 is near. A near distance is a short distance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ほんの数年後、彼女はようやく自分がその短距離走で優勝した短距離走者だったことを認めました。
ex_1_en: Only years later did she finally admit she was the sprinter who won the short distance race.
meaning_story: A 距離 (distance) that is short is a short distance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 派遣社員たちは、景気の悪化で一斉に解雇されることを心配しています。
ex_1_en: The temporary workers are worried about being fired simultaneously in the recession.
meaning_story: 一斉 is simultaneous or all at once. Add the に in there and you're heading towards those things. For "simultaneous" that becomes simultaneously. For "all at once" it stays at all at once.
reading_story: The reading comes from 一斉.

ex_1_jp: 小さな天使とベーコンのビデオを観て、魂が震えました。
ex_1_en: The video about the little angel and the bacon deeply moved my soul.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 死者の霊魂に捧げる為のイラストを描いてほしいとアヤに頼みました。
ex_1_en: I asked Aya to draw an illustration to offer to the souls of the dead.
meaning_story: When attached to a word, this refers to a ____ spirit. It's the same meaning as the kanji, too.
reading_story: This isn't the reading you learned with the kanji, so just think of the spirit of the condor (こん) when you think of a type of spirit. Caw! Cawww!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: トイレを殺菌する一番いい方法は何ですか？
ex_1_en: What’s the best way to sterilize a bathroom?
meaning_story: If you kill bacteria you are performing sterilization. You're killing those bacteria.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguのステッカーが無菌かどうかの問い合わせのメールが来たんだけど。
ex_1_en: I just got an email asking whether or not the Tofugu stickers are sterilized.
meaning_story: Someplace with nothing amounts of bacteria is sterilized.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: なんて硬いベーコンなんだと思ってたら、夢を見ながらスマートフォンを噛んでたみたいなのよね。どうりて硬いはずだわさ。
ex_1_en: I thought that it was the hardest bacon I’d ever had, but it was a dream and it seemed that I was biting my smartphone. No wonder it was so hard.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of stiff? It's stiff.
reading_story: The reading is the same as a very similar word, 固い. So, if you can use that word to help you to remember, you'll remember the reading of this word in no time as well!

ex_1_jp: 麻雀するなら、うちに雀卓があるけど。
ex_1_en: There is a Mahjong table in my house if you want to play.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: あの卓球の音のせいで気が変になりそうだ！
ex_1_en: That ping pong noise is driving me crazy!
meaning_story: Table sphere is a sport where you have a table and then you use a sphere on it. That's table tennis or ping pong. Makes sense, right? You use a ping pong ball and you play on a table.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of たく's shortening.

ex_1_jp: このタオルはとても柔らかくて心地よい肌触りです。
ex_1_en: This towel is very soft and pleasant to the touch.
meaning_story: The skin touch is the feeling of touching with your skin. That is the touch of, feel of, or texture of something. It's what you feel when you touch your skin to something!
reading_story: The reading is 肌 plus 触る's reading, combined. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 今こそタバコをやめる潮時だ。今すぐニコチンパッチを買いに行くんだ。
ex_1_en: It’s high time that you quit smoking. Go get some nicotine patches right now.
meaning_story: The tide time is the tidal hour.
reading_story: The reading comes from the individual words, 潮 and 時. Watch out for the rendaku.
pitch_accent: シオドキ *** シオドキꜜ

ex_1_jp: 飛行機で巨人を襲撃することができるようになるとは、知る由もなかった。
ex_1_en: Little did they know that they would be able to air Attack on Titan.
meaning_story: Remember how 襲撃 is an assault or attack? This is the verb form, so it's to attack or to assault.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 池の水、昨日は濁って緑色だったのに、今はすっかり澄んでいるじゃないか。一体何があったの？
ex_1_en: The water in the pond was green yesterday, but it’s totally cleared up now. What happened?
meaning_story: Something with lucidity is clear. That's why this word is to become clear or to become transparent.
reading_story: Think of something that becomes clear. Something you don't want to become clear. Something that's yours. You're so pissed about this that you sue (す) the person who made your thing clear.

ex_1_jp: 昨日の夜、寝汗をたくさんかいちゃったから、ベットが何だか湿ってるのよね。
ex_1_en: I sweat a lot when I was sleeping last night and my bed is a little damp.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means damp so the verb vocab version is to be damp or to be moist. Ewww.
reading_story: You have to think of something that's damp and moist. To do that, think of He-Man's girlfriend, She-Man (しめ). She has been hanging out in a greenhouse and is now kind of damp. He-Man hands her a towel to dry off.

ex_1_jp: 地球がじきに滅びるんだとしたら、どうしてベーコンを食べるのを我慢しなくちゃいけないの？
ex_1_en: If the earth is going to be destroyed, why should I resist eating bacon?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means destroy so the verb vocab version is to be destroyed. You know you're not destroying things because of the beer (びる). You'd never destroy beer... but someone else might. Grrr.
reading_story: "YOU WHORE!" (ほろ) someone yells, right before they destroy your beer.
pitch_accent: ホロビꜜル *** ホロビル

ex_1_jp: トイレが詰まって、すっぽんで詰まり抜きをする前に水が溢れちゃって、朝早くから掃除をしなくちゃいけなかったから、とっても疲れました。
ex_1_en: The toilet was clogged and it flooded before we used the plunger, so I had to clean it up early in the morning and I’m really exhausted.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means exhausted making the verb version to be exhausted or to be tired. Don't confuse this with "to be sleepy." No, this is a different kind of tired, like a physical or mental one, like you just worked out or studied a ton.
reading_story: For example, if you tried to lift two cars (つか) you'd become exhausted for sure. So, think about that as you learn this word's reading.

ex_1_jp: 夫が心的外傷後ストレス障害と診断された後、私はそれが誰であれその戦争を始めた人を呪いました。
ex_1_en: After my husband was diagnosed with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder I cursed whoever it was that started the war.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means curse, and the verb version is to curse or to put a curse on.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 現職の大統領が、前大統領よりもどれだけ多くのお金を稼いでいるか知っているかい？
ex_1_en: Do you know how much more money the incumbent president earns than the former president?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means earnings and the verb vocab version is to earn income, because you can't "to income" something. Can also be to make money.
reading_story: You earn your income, and every time you're paid, you're given your money in a briefcase (かせ). Imagine getting your income from a briefcase, opening it up, and grabbing the money from within. Then, you have to give the briefcase back at the specified dropoff.

ex_1_jp: それは、まるで天空を高く翔る不死鳥のようでした。
ex_1_en: It looked just like a phoenix soaring high in the air.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means fly, so the verb version means to fly.
reading_story: You learned this reading already! You should be able to read this too!

ex_1_jp: 彼女は競馬で、中々の大金を賭けるんだよ。
ex_1_en: She gambles considerable amounts of money at the horse races.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gamble and the verb vocab version is to gamble.
reading_story: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: ラーメンの湯気で眼鏡が曇っちゃうのが好きじゃないんだよね。
ex_1_en: I don’t like it when my glasses get cloudy from ramen steam.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cloudy and the verb vocab version means to get cloudy or to become cloudy.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. It also happens to be the same as 雲, which has a very similar meaning (clouds).

ex_1_jp: 「サーモン、今週末、ラスベガスで結婚しよう。」「フグ、気でも狂ったの？」
ex_1_en: "Salmon, let’s get married in Las Vegas this weekend." "Fugu, have you lost your mind?"
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lunatic or crazy. The verb version of this is to go mad (you don't really "go lunatic" now, do you?) or to go crazy.
reading_story: To remember the reading, just think about how when you go crazy, you are coming (来る) to crazy town. Just imagine some voice beckoning you to come. Come here! Please come here! Come to crazy town! Give in to the voices!

ex_1_jp: 嫁ぎたての頃は、息子の嫁はかまととぶっていました。
ex_1_en: Around the time they got married, my son’s wife pretended she was a prude.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bride and the verb vocab version is to marry, because you can't really "to bride" someone.
reading_story: Imagine you're getting married to a valley girl. You're all like. Hey, I'm gonna marry you! And she's all like Tots (とつ), we gonna get, like, married! Imagine her saying more "tots" things (tots = short for totally in valley girl speak, at least in my imagination).

ex_1_jp: 何で切れた電球なんか磨いてるの？
ex_1_en: Why are you polishing a light bulb that’s already burnt out?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means polish and the verb vocab version is to polish or, strangely specifically (and we'll learn an even more specific word for this later) to brush your teeth.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 花粉症で目を擦ってたら、片方のコンタクトレンズが破けました。
ex_1_en: I was rubbing my eyes because of my allergies and one of my contact lenses was torn.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grate and this verb means to rub or to scrub. It will help to think back to 擦れる which means "to chafe" or "to rub," which is more similar to this verb than the kanji meaning is.
reading_story: This kanji shares the reading from 擦れる but it also has another reading, こする. Both are considered "common." Most likely, you'll use する's reading the most because it is the same as すれる's reading, but for now try to keep the other one in your mind as well.
pitch_accent: カスꜜル *** スꜜル *** ナスꜜル

ex_1_jp: うちの甥っ子は新幹線を見るのが好きで、一日中眺めていることもできます。
ex_1_en: My nephew likes watching the Shinkansen so much that he can stare at it all day long.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stare and the verb vocab version is to stare at (or to look at in a very staringish way).
reading_story: To learn the reading, just think about how you're looking at something for a lonnnnng time if you're staring at it. In Japanese the word "long" is 長い, and guess what the reading of the kanji part is? It's なが, just like ながめる's kanji-part reading.

ex_1_jp: あのカップルの仲をうまく引き裂く事ができたら、お知らせ致します。
ex_1_en: I’ll let you know if I succeed in splitting up the couple.
meaning_story: You know that 裂く is "to tear" or "to rip up." So, if you're trying to tear or rip up something, and you're pulling it at the same time, you are going to tear up that thing, or more accurately perhaps to tear off something, since you're pulling.
reading_story: The reading comes from 引く and 裂く.

ex_1_jp: 一位のチームには、賞品として滝修行が授与されます。
ex_1_en: The top team will be awarded with a prize of doing aesthetic waterfall meditation.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: よく冷えた井戸水を飲むと、冷たいアイスクリームを食べた時のように頭がキーンと痛みました。
ex_1_en: When I drank cold water from the well, I got brain freeze like when I ate cold ice cream.
meaning_story: A well door is just a well. It's the door that goes into the well hole, making it a well.
reading_story: This kanji uses the kun'yomi readings for each kanji, for some reason. You learned the kun'yomi reading for 戸, but in this case it's rendaku'd so it becomes ど instead of と. You didn't learn the kun'yomi version of 井 with the kanji. Think of this well, and look inside. There you see an eagle (い), stuck inside. As you pull it out, it scratches your eyes out.

ex_1_jp: 確か、北海道には湿地が多いんだよね？
ex_1_en: If I am not mistaken, there are a lot of wetlands in Hokkaido, right?
meaning_story: The damp earth is where water seems to congregate, but not so much that there's a lake or ocean or anything like that. Just damp. This is a wetlands.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この包み紙には点字が施してあるわ。
ex_1_en: There is braille on this wrapping paper.
meaning_story: A 包み is a bundle or package, and 紙 is paper. What paper goes around bundles and packages? That would be wrapping paper.
reading_story: The reading is 包み and 紙 combined together. Be careful of rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 瞬きせずに、この絵を見続けてください。
ex_1_en: Don’t blink and just keep looking at the picture please.
meaning_story: A blink is a blink and a wink as well, depending on how many eyes you use.
reading_story: A wink is all it takes to get the "Ma butter" (まばた) from the store. It's hidden, and they only bring it out if you do the wink.
pitch_accent: マタタꜜキ *** マタタキꜜ *** マタタキ *** マバꜜタキ

ex_1_jp: 一番最初にしなくちゃいけないことが、陶芸用の粘土から気泡を取り除くことです。
ex_1_en: The first thing we have to do is remove the air bubbles from the pottery clay.
meaning_story: Energy bubbles are bubbles filled with the "energy" that's all around us (air). That's why this is an air bubble.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ある錬金術士が鉛を金に変えようとして失敗した日、外は雨がザザ降りでした。
ex_1_en: The rain poured down outside on the day the alchemist utterly failed at transforming lead into gold.
meaning_story: The art of tempering gold. That is alchemy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 蜘蛛の巣にぶつかった瞬間に、人は突然空手の達人へと変身する。
ex_1_en: The moment they walk into a spider web, people suddenly turn into karate experts.
meaning_story: A blink interval of time is a very short period of time. It's an instant.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「お前には捕まらないぞ！」「捕まえたっ！」「うわっ！速い！一瞬だったな。でも、大人げないよ。子どもなんだからもう少し手加減してよ。」
ex_1_en: "You’ll never catch me!" "Gotcha!" "What! That was fast! You caught me in an instant, but that’s childish. You should go a little easier on your kid."
meaning_story: One blink is one instant. That is an instant or a moment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どの政府にも、特別歳入基金はあるものなのですか。
ex_1_en: Does every government have a special revenue fund?
meaning_story: Years old you have entered. These are your yearly (years old) amounts of money you've entered into the coffers. These are the annual revenue.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 誰かが土俵にパンの欠片を投げ込みました。
ex_1_en: Someone threw a piece of bread into the sumo arena.
meaning_story: The soil sack, for some reason, is an arena or sumo arena. Just think of the sacks they throw around on the soil in the sumo arena.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 突き指が癖になってしまっているんです。
ex_1_en: I’ve fallen into the habit of spraining my fingers.
meaning_story: The kanji itself means habit but it usually refers to a bad habit, so try to remember that meaning if you could.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: トフグのコウイチに万歳三唱をしましょう！万歳！万歳！万歳！
ex_1_en: Three cheers for Koichi of Tofugu! Hip hip hooray! Hip hip hooray! Hip hip hooray!
meaning_story: Ten thousand years old! That's a lot of time. This is the word for the turned-English Japanese phrase, banzai!
reading_story: The reading isn't the same as 万's normal reading. It's ばん instead of まん. But, since the word "banzai" is so well known, you probably can remember this reading.
pitch_accent: バンザꜜイ *** マンザꜜイ

ex_1_jp: 零下十度だろうが二十度だろうがに関係なく、洗い物はここでします。
ex_1_en: It doesn’t matter if it’s ten or twenty below zero, we do our wash here.
meaning_story: Zero below is below zero. Sub zero.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「好き嫌いしないの！黒魔術だけじゃなくて白魔術もちゃんと勉強しなさい！」「はいはい。いつも同じこと言ってるよね。」「"はい"は一回でしょ！」
ex_1_en: "Don’t be so picky! You shouldn’t just study black magic, but white magic too!" "Yeah, yeah. You always say that." "One yeah is enough!"
meaning_story: The devil art is black magic and sorcery. The kind of things that devils do.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 毎月の鈍器代はいくらですか。
ex_1_en: How much do you spend on blunt weapons every month.
meaning_story: A dull weapon is a blunt weapon.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「新しい寮生はセクシー？」「ああ、セクシーだよ。フグなんて、すでに彼女に熱を上げているよ。」
ex_1_en: "Is the new boarding student sexy?" "Yup, she is. Fugu’s got the hots for her already."
meaning_story: A dormitory student (comes from 学生) is a boarding student or a boarder. This is a student who lives in a dormitory.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: わっ！うちの父さん、お前のと全く同じ書架を持ってるぜ。お前もIKEAで買ったの？
ex_1_en: Wow! My dad has the exact same bookshelf as you. Did you buy it at IKEA?
meaning_story: A write shelf is a shelf with writing on it. That's a bookshelf or bookcase.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: マリファナを一服した瞬間、男は口から泡を吹いて地面に倒れ込んだ。
ex_1_en: The moment he took a puff of marijuana, he fell to the ground foaming at the mouth.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: It's a bubble! A Wha---? (あわ) A BUBBLE. A WHA???

ex_1_jp: 彼女は穏やかに眠っているようだった。
ex_1_en: The woman seemed to be sleeping peacefully.
meaning_story: This is a な adjective version of the kanji which means calm. The vocab version here is calm as well, though you can use it to mean mild as well.
reading_story: What is calm? "Ode (おだ) to Joy" is nice and calm and mild, as far as music goes.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 俺は平穏無事に暮らすことが嫌いだ。
ex_1_en: I don’t like living in peace and quiet.
meaning_story: A flat calm is a calm and tranquil place.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は紛れもない田舎っぺの女の子だ。
ex_1_en: She is an unmistakable country bumpkin girl.
meaning_story: 紛らわしい is "confusing" or "misleading." This is the negative of that (you can tell by the ない), meaning it's kind of the opposite of those things. This word is certain, unmistaken, and obvious.
reading_story: The reading comes from 紛らわしい.
pitch_accent: マキ°レモナꜜイ *** マキ°レꜜモナイ

ex_1_jp: この椅子の色違いは置いてますか？
ex_1_en: Do you have this chair in any other colors?
meaning_story: A chair child is for some reason just a chair. Not sure why it's a child, but it is.
reading_story: The reading for 子 is weird. It's す, so think about how you sat on this chair and it broke, so you sued (す) the person who made the chair (who happened to be a child).

ex_1_jp: 昔の上海とフランス租界について知りたいのなら、彼がそれについては詳しいよ。
ex_1_en: If you want to know about the history of the Shanghai French Concession, he knows a lot about that.
meaning_story: The tariff of the world is a concession or settlement. That's just how the world works.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 専業主婦になってからというもの、まるで捕虜になって、台所に幽閉されてでもいるかのようだわ。
ex_1_en: After becoming a housewife, it’s like I’ve become a war prisoner, confined to the kitchen.
meaning_story: Secluded and closed off, putting you in confinement and imprisonment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今まで一度も橋梁を架設したことがありません。
ex_1_en: I’ve never built a bridge before.
meaning_story: The shelf, once established, makes up the construction and building of the building. Just think of a building that's being built. It looks like a little shelf, doesn't it?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 十分間にどれだけの炭酸入り清涼飲料水を飲めると思いますか？
ex_1_en: How many carbonated soft drinks do you think you can drink in ten minutes?
meaning_story: A pure cool is cool and refreshing, isn't it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 残念ながら、今日はとても涼しかった。
ex_1_en: Unfortunately, it was really cool out today.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cool? It's cool (or refreshing).
reading_story: If you want to experience a place that is cool and refreshing go to Sue's Zoo (すず). Imagine yourself walking into the entrance of Sue's Zoo. Then walk in and feel how cool and refreshing it is.

ex_1_jp: 窓を開けると、心地よい涼風とともに美しいピアノの音色が舞い込んできた。
ex_1_en: When I opened the window there was a pleasant, cool breeze and the beautiful sound of a piano.
meaning_story: A cool wind is a cool breeze.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: スズꜜカゼ *** リョーフー *** リョーフꜜー

ex_1_jp: 綿でも、ジャケットは手洗いにした方がいいと思う。
ex_1_en: I think you should hand-wash the jacket, even though it’s cotton.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading can be either the kun'yomi or on'yomi reading, so you have a choice there. Let's learn the わた reading, though. Just think what (わた) is cotton? What is it? What does it mean? Ask a lot of questions with "what" in it about cotton to yourself.

ex_1_jp: 木綿のハンカチをプレゼントしてもらいました。
ex_1_en: I got you this cotton handkerchief as a present.
meaning_story: Cotton that comes off a tree is still cotton!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own as long as you watch out for 木. It drops the く from もく making this reading just もめん.

ex_1_jp: 水をよく吸収するので、私は綿布を布巾に使います。
ex_1_en: I use a cotton cloth as a dish towel because it absorbs water well.
meaning_story: A cotton cloth is a cotton cloth of cotton material.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: これは出来たてホカホカの美味しい揚げ出し豆腐ですよ。
ex_1_en: Here is a plate of delicious deep fried tofu I just made.
meaning_story: Remember how 揚げる can mean "to deep fry?" Something that was deep fried and then put in front of you is deep fried.
reading_story: The reading is 揚げる and 出す's reading.

ex_1_jp: 今は「魔の二歳児」ですからねー。
ex_1_en: It’s the terrible twos now, you know.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 今夜は悪魔と出かける気分じゃないの。
ex_1_en: I’m not in the mood to going out with devil tonight.
meaning_story: A bad devil is a devil (because they're all bad), or a demon or satan.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: もしこの寮にご両親を宿泊させたいのであれば、この宿泊カードに記入をお願いします。
ex_1_en: If you want your parents to stay in this dormitory, could you fill out this registration form?
