meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also refer to a hostel.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 現在妊娠中で、お腹に時々鈍い痛みを感じるんですが、これは普通ですか。
ex_1_en: I’m pregnant and sometimes I feel a dull pain in my stomach. Is this normal?
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dull? It's dull.
reading_story: To remember the reading, think about how when you're inebriated (にぶ) you need to use a dull knife. The にぶい reading talks about a thing that is dull. For のろい, which refers to a dull mind (someone who's thickheaded). Think about a Norse (のろ) God, the God of dullbrains.

ex_1_jp: 「素粒子」って言葉は物理の教科書で見た事がある気がするよ。
ex_1_en: I feel like I’ve seen the word "elementary particle" in my physics textbook.
meaning_story: A particle (粒子) that is the element version of it is an elementary particle.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 皇帝はお酒には目がない。
ex_1_en: The emperor has a weakness for sake.
meaning_story: The sovereign emperor of Japan is also the emperor of other places too!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: Tofugu帝国では、殺人事件の時効は廃止されました。
ex_1_en: The statute of limitations for murder was abolished in the Tofugu Empire.
meaning_story: A sovereign country is one that is part of its own empire.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: テイコク *** テꜜイコク

ex_1_jp: 本当にちゃんと上司へのお歳暮持ったの？
ex_1_en: Are you sure you have the proper year-end gift for your boss?
meaning_story: Years old of livelihood. This is each year of livelihood that you have, and at the end of each year you've reached the end of the year. This may also refer to a year end gift.
reading_story: The reading for 歳 is one you haven't learned with the kanji, though it's similar (which makes things more difficult). Just think about Hard Gay giving you a year end gift. "Sei sei sei (せい)!" he yells, as he hands you a box.

ex_1_jp: 四人に一人が広告は誇張されていると思っていることは知っていますが、私は全部が全部誇大広告ではないと思うんです。
ex_1_en: I know three in four people think advertising is exaggerated, but I don’t think all advertisements are an exaggeration.
meaning_story: Your pride is too big. You make it bigger than it is, in fact. You do this with exaggeration and hyperbole.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: レビューで今までで最高のカメラだとか何とか書かれてたけど、それはやっぱり誇張だったね。
ex_1_en: The review said that it was the best camera ever, but it was an exaggeration just like I thought.
meaning_story: Take your pride and stretch it out. It's an exaggeration, because you've stretched your pride out pretty thin.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 蒸しタオルで眼孔を覆うと気持ち良いですよ。
ex_1_en: It feels so good when you cover your eye sockets with a steamed towel.
meaning_story: Your eyeball cavity (hole) is where your eye is held. This is your eye socket.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「何々が旬の季節です」ってあのシェフの口癖だよね。
ex_1_en: That chef’s catchphrase is, "Such and such is in season."
meaning_story: A mouth habit is something you say with your mouth a lot. It's a habit. It's your favorite phrase or catchphrase.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of both kanji. 癖 is the reading you learned with the kanji. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: データを保存する前にブラウザがクラッシュしてしまったため、長文のメッセージを書いていた努力が水泡に帰してしまった。
ex_1_en: My browser crashed before I saved my data so my efforts to write a long message ended in failure.
meaning_story: Water bubbles are bubbles that come from the water. This is usually in the form of foam, but could also be a bubble.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 発泡スチロールはこの袋に入れてもらってもいい？他のゴミとは分別して捨てるんだよね。
ex_1_en: Could you put the styrofoam in this plastic bag? We throw away the rest of the garbage separately.
meaning_story: The departure of bubbles is when bubbles leave something, like a mouth. That's why this is foaming.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「今日、学校サボってゲーセン行こうぜ。人生は一度っきりだしな！」「そうかな。僕はよく幽霊を見るから、死後の世界を信じてるんだけど。」
ex_1_en: "Let’s skip school and go to the arcade today. YOLO!" "I don’t think so. I see ghosts all the time, so I believe in a world after death."
meaning_story: A secluded ghost is someone who's secluded and a ghost, because everyone's forgotten about him (thus the "ghostness" of him). This thing is a ghost or specter.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 年寄りたちと碁は打ちたくないんだよね。
ex_1_en: I just don’t want to beat old people at Go.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 彼は囲碁トーナメントの決勝に進みました。
ex_1_en: He advanced to the finals of the Go tournament.
meaning_story: The game of go is one where you surround the enemy with your go pieces. So, adding this to the name of go makes sense, and just makes this the go board game.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 濡れ衣だよ。じいちゃんの碁盤を壊したのは俺じゃないよ。
ex_1_en: That’s a false accusation. I didn’t break grandpa’s Go board.
meaning_story: A go tray is a tray for playing the game "go." This tray is a go board.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今朝俺たちの碁会所を覗き見していた男を取っ捕まえてやったよ。
ex_1_en: I caught him peeping into our Go parlor this morning.
meaning_story: A go meeting place is a place where you go play go. It's a go parlor or go playing parlor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
pitch_accent: ゴカイショ *** ゴカイショꜜ

ex_1_jp: 私達はお腹がペコペコだったので、麦の穂を集めてそのまま生で食べたんです。
ex_1_en: We were so hungry that we gathered ears of wheat and ate them raw.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: お米は私達の主食ですが、だからといって日本人全員が風に靡く美しい金色の稲穂を見た事がある訳ではありません。
ex_1_en: Rice is our staple food, but that doesn’t mean all Japanese people have seen beautiful, golden ears of rice bowing in the breeze.
meaning_story: A head of plant of a rice plant is the head of rice or ear of rice.
reading_story: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: あんたの病棟で、かっこいい男は見た？
ex_1_en: Did you see any hot guys in your hospital ward?
meaning_story: A sick pillar is the pillar that holds up the side of the building that's made for sick people. That's a hospital ward.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 吾輩が貴殿に久しく手紙を書いていなかったことをどうかお許しください。
ex_1_en: Please forgive me for not writing to you in such a long time.
meaning_story: I, my comrade (which is me), is I, it's myself, it's me. This is a weird way to say "I" and has a hint of arrogance to it.
reading_story: The reading comes from the readings you learned with the kanji readings.

ex_1_jp: 警察はその地域では多くの犯罪を黙殺しています。
ex_1_en: The police ignore most of the crime in this area.
meaning_story: Shut up and kill your talking or I'll kill it for you. I'm not listening to this. I'm ignoring it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 会議に行かなくちゃいけなかったのに、脚がやばいくらいつって全然動けなかったので、焦りを感じましたよ。
ex_1_en: I had a terrible cramp in my leg and I couldn’t move it at all even though I had to go to a meeting, so I felt really impatient.
meaning_story: Remember 焦る, which means "to be in a hurry" or "to be impatient"? This is the noun version, which is impatience.
reading_story: The reading comes from 焦る.

ex_1_jp: ローマ帝政時代、皇帝はその村の人達に目をつけていました。
ex_1_en: In the time of the Roman Empire, the emperor was keeping an eye on the village people.
meaning_story: Sovereign government and Politics are those who are part of the imperial government. This type of government is imperialism. Of course, back in the day there weren't as many sovereign governments out there, so imperialism is the one that fits the bill in this word's case.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: おっと。墨が校章についちゃった。
ex_1_en: Oops. I got ink on my school badge.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は、完成したと同時にその墨絵を真っすぐ立てました。
ex_1_en: As soon as she completed the ink painting she stood it up.
meaning_story: An ink painting is an ink painting.
reading_story: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 人々は、帝がお出でになるということで、国旗を掲げました。
ex_1_en: People hung the national flag for the Japanese Emperor’s visit.
meaning_story: The one true sovereign is the Japanese Emperor, aka the Emperor of Japan. All other emperors aren't simply 帝 on its own.
reading_story: To remember the reading, think about how the Japanese Emperor, can always pull out his "me card" (みかど) when he's in trouble. It's like how people pull the "race card" sometimes, but with the emperor, he pulls out his "me card," because he's emperor, and can do whatever he wants.

ex_1_jp: いや〜鍵を中に置いたまま車に鍵をかけちゃってさ、今鍵屋さんが来るのを待ってるんだよ。
ex_1_en: Well, I locked myself out of my car and am waiting for a locksmith to come.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 僕のお気に入りのアニメキャラクターが斬殺されてしまった。
ex_1_en: My favorite anime character was slaughtered.
meaning_story: A slice kill is a killing with a sword. You don't want to hear this, if at all possible.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: わぁ、A級の新しい魔法を習得中なの？上手くいけば、万歳ものだね！
ex_1_en: Wow, are you learning new A rank magic? If it goes well we should celebrate!
meaning_story: The devil's method is magic and witchcraft. That's their method of doing things, after all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 庄園制度導入への準備は全て整っています。
ex_1_en: Everything is in order for the introduction of manorialism.
meaning_story: A manor park is just a manor. That's what a manor is, though. It's a big house that has an awesome garden/park around it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 零時頃、彼女が町中を一人で猛スピードで歩いているのを見かけました。
ex_1_en: I saw her walking really fast downtown by herself around midnight.
meaning_story: Zero o'clock is 0:00. That's midnight or twelve o'clock.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 言いたかったことを彼が瞬時にズバッと言ってくれたので、とても感心しました。
ex_1_en: I was so impressed with him when he said that at the moment I was going to say it.
meaning_story: A blink of time is a mere moment or instant.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 夫は、いつも寸暇を惜しんで働いています。
ex_1_en: My husband devotes every spare moment to working.
meaning_story: You have a measurement (3.03 cm!) of spare time. This isn't much free time, but it's a free minute that you have.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その飼育員さんが、猿たちが囲いから出ることを防ぎました。
ex_1_en: That zookeeper kept the monkeys from leaving their enclosure.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
pitch_accent: サꜜル *** マシラ *** マꜜシラ

ex_1_jp: 猿真似をするのはよせ。みっともない。
ex_1_en: Don’t blindly follow people. It’s embarrassing.
meaning_story: If 真似 is impersonation and if a monkey is doing said impersonation, that's summed up by the saying: monkey see monkey do.
reading_story: The readings are 猿 plus 真似 put together.

ex_1_jp: すごく斬新なアイディアなので、後者よりも最初の案の方がいいと思います。
ex_1_en: I prefer the former idea to the latter because it is a much more original idea.
meaning_story: Something that has sliced newness into the world is a novel idea. It is original and novel. Just imagine the world as a place of things that are already done. If you want to get something new and novel in there, you have to slice that oldness open to make space for the new.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今日の宿題は、英語で「お盆」の説明を考えてくる事です。
ex_1_en: Today’s homework is to make an explanation of what Obon is in English.
meaning_story: 盆 refers to the lantern festival. The お just makes it higher status. The meanings are pretty much the same, too. Lantern Festival works and obon and obon festival works too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その証人が法廷で証言するのを、何としてでも阻止するんだ。
ex_1_en: Do whatever it takes to prevent that witness from testifying in court.
meaning_story: If you thwart and stop something, you are an obstruction or hinderance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: カフェインを含む飲み物は、睡眠を阻害します。
ex_1_en: Drinks containing caffeine inhibit sleep.
meaning_story: Thwart and damage the advancement of something. That's an obstruction and inhibition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は息子がコンビニのお握りを食べることを禁止しました。
ex_1_en: I forbade my son from eating convenience store rice balls.
meaning_story: 握り is a "grip." When you add お it's elevated a bit. For some reason it becomes a rice ball (aka onigiri). To make a rice ball, you use your grip to make them into a ball shape, which is probably where it comes from.
reading_story: The reading comes from 握り.

ex_1_jp: 鳩たちは、一斉に飛び立ちました。
ex_1_en: The pigeons took off all at once.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 有名人なのに、私の説明に丁寧に答えてくれて、すごく感激しました。
ex_1_en: Even though she is a celebrity, she politely answered my questions and I was really impressed.
meaning_story: A street rather than a not-street. That's what I'm offering you to walk on. It's much nicer this way. I am being polite and courteous by offering you this street.
reading_story: The reading for 丁 is an unexpected one. It's てい instead of ちょう, so think about how the street is lined with tater (てい) tots, and how you can eat from them as you walk along on your trek. How polite of someone to leave them there for you!

ex_1_jp: 彼が嫌いだと言うわけじゃないんだけど、あそこであの発言はちょっと穏当でないなと思ったわけよ。
ex_1_en: It’s not that I don’t like him, I just thought his remarks at the time were improper.
meaning_story: Everything is calm and right. It is proper and reasonable.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: オントー *** オꜜントー

ex_1_jp: 父の再婚相手の気怠い瞳を見ると、いつもたじろいでしまいます。
ex_1_en: When I look at my stepmother’s listless eyes I always end up wincing.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Remember, this is the eyeball pupil.
reading_story: A person's (ひと) seeing (見) ability comes from their pupil. That's how you can remember ひとみ.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: いつ、どうして瞳孔の縮小と拡張が起きるのか、説明できますか？
ex_1_en: Can you explain when and why contraction and expansion of the pupil occurs?
meaning_story: Your pupil hole is still your pupil. It can also be called your pupillary.
reading_story: The reading for 瞳 is a little different from the one you learned. Instead of とう it's どう. Just think about how your pupils are weird shaped, like doughnuts (どう).

ex_1_jp: お姫様よりも寧ろ猫になりたい。
ex_1_en: I’d rather be a cat than a princess.
meaning_story: This is the same as the kanji, rather. Can also mean better or instead.
reading_story: Just think: rather than a bug (むし), how about an animal?

ex_1_jp: 俵先生は、自分の名前が俵なので、あの金の米俵のキーホルダーを鞄に付けていると言っていましたよ。
ex_1_en: Tawara-sensei told us that her name means straw bag and that’s why she has a gold straw rice-bag keychain on her bag.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: A bunch of sacks or straw bags are stacked upon each other to make a tower (たわら). Imagine walking into this sack tower and wonder how it's all held together. Such poor architecture.

ex_1_jp: この人形に単四電池を入れて電源を入れると、叫び出すんです。
ex_1_en: If you put two triple A batteries in this toy and turn on the power, he will scream.
meaning_story: 叫ぶ is "to shout" and "to scream." This is the noun version. This is a shout or scream.
reading_story: The reading comes from 叫ぶ.

ex_1_jp: マミは叫び声を上げながら、ベーコンを上下に動かしました。
ex_1_en: Mami lifted the bacon up and down while she screamed.
meaning_story: A shout voice is a shout or a yell.
reading_story: The reading comes from 叫ぶ and 声, put together. Careful of the rendaku.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 気まずい沈黙の後、私は塩の入った小瓶を掴みました。
ex_1_en: There was an awkward silence and I grabbed a salt shaker.
meaning_story: You sink down and shut up. You go into a silence and hush. This tends to be an awkward silence or hush.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: このペースじゃ、夕方までにお茶の新芽を摘み終わるのは無理じゃないかな。
ex_1_en: At this rate, it will be impossible to finish picking all the tea sprouts by evening.
meaning_story: A new sprout is a sprout or bud or shoot. All sprouts are new, after all.
reading_story: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji, combined.

ex_1_jp: あそこ家の息子さん、交通事故に巻き込まれて担架で病院に担ぎ込まれたんだけど、結局植物状態になっちゃったんだって。
ex_1_en: Their son was in a car accident and was carried to the hospital on a stretcher, but he ended up in a vegetative state.
meaning_story: It will carry or bear people like a shelf. This thing that carries people is a stretcher or litter.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その入れ墨には今までいくら費やしているんですか。
ex_1_en: How much money have you spent on tattoos?
meaning_story: If you enter ink into (your body), you are getting yourself a tattoo.
reading_story: The reading comes from 入れる and 墨 combined together. Careful of the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 田んぼには特定の租税が課されているんですか？
ex_1_en: Is there a specific tax for rice paddies?
meaning_story: A tariff tax is a form of taxes or taxation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 発音が一晩で上手くなる人なんていません。発音を上達させるには、継続的かつ正しい鍛錬が必要です。
ex_1_en: Nobody can get perfect pronunciation overnight. To improve your pronunciation you need continuous and proper training.
meaning_story: Forging and tempering of things is tempering and forging of things.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あんたって、ほんと鈍感。今はフグの話はしたくないの。それくらい空気を読んでよ。
ex_1_en: You are really insensitive. I don’t feel like talking about Fugu right now. Take a hint.
meaning_story: A dull feeling in your head is thickheadedness.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: それから半世紀の歳月が流れ、彼のことなんてほとんど忘れかけていた時に、私達は小さなパン屋さんで偶然再会したんです。
ex_1_en: After fifty years had passed and I was almost starting to forgot about him, we ran into each other in a tiny bakery.
meaning_story: Years old in months shows time in years. Just imagine counting time by months and years... You kind of do anyways, right? How old are you? 5 years old. Or, 5 and a half years old (that's five years six months). So, it makes some sense.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この短編映画では、日本が世界に誇るロボット産業をテーマとしています。
ex_1_en: This short film is about the robotics industry that Japan boasts of to the world.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pride and the verb version is to be proud of or to boast of.
reading_story: The hoe 子 (ほこ) is the kid who is carrying around a hoe all the time, swinging it around, doing dumb things with it. He's so proud of it, though, and it shows on his face. He's always boasting about his hoe skillz too.

ex_1_jp: 辺りの景色は瞬く間に雪に覆われ、真っ白になった。
ex_1_en: The landscape was covered by snow in a flash and everything turned white.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blink and the verb vocab version is to blink.
reading_story: Mah ta ta (またた) is showing, causing you to blink. I don't know what a "tata" is, but I bet you could come up with something that's blink-worthy.
pitch_accent: マタタꜜク *** マバタꜜク

ex_1_jp: その侍は、早口言葉が上手く言えなければお前の舌を斬るぞ、と私に言いました。
ex_1_en: The samurai told me he would cut off my tongue if I couldn’t say the tongue twister properly.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means slice and the verb vocab version means to cut down or to slice off or to lop off. This word mainly refers to cutting people with a sword, if you haven't figured it out yet.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 切る, which means "to cut." Similar meaning, same reading.

ex_1_jp: 生まれたての頃からミッチリ鍛えたおかけで、息子は今ピアノの天才児と呼ばれています。
ex_1_en: Thanks to the strict training I’ve given him since birth, my son is now called a child prodigy at piano.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means forge and the verb vocab version is to forge and to temper.
reading_story: To forge something, you need to have your kit (きた) with you. Without it, you won't be doing any forging at all.

ex_1_jp: どうしたの？どうして黙っているの？
ex_1_en: What’s the matter? Why are you so quiet?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shut up so the verb vocab version is to shut up.
reading_story: You need to damn (だま) your mouth shut and shut up.

ex_1_jp: 「あんた、今カーペットに珈琲を零したでしょう？」「しまった!ごめん!」「ごめんで済んだら警察はいらないわよ！」
ex_1_en: "Did you just spill coffee on the carpet?" "Oh no! Sorry." "If sorry fixed everything, we wouldn’t need the police!"
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means zero, but the verb vocab version means to spill or to drop. Just imagine something that's spilling and dropping. Eventually it will reach zero.
reading_story: Imagine a barrel of corn cobs, spilling and dropping out corn cobs, until they reach zero.

ex_1_jp: それっぽっちのことで、気持ちが揺らぐんだ。
ex_1_en: So few things sway my feelings.
meaning_story: Hey look! If you weren't sick of them yet, it's another verb that goes with shake! This one means to shake too!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 揺る, 揺する, and 揺れる so I reeeeally hope you can remember it by now!

ex_1_jp: 誰かが、彼が今日娘さんを連れてバージンロードを歩くのを阻もうとしているようなんです。
ex_1_en: It seems like someone is trying to prevent him from walking his daughter down the aisle today.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means thwart and the verb vocab version is to thwart or to hamper.
reading_story: Someone walks up to you, saying "habbah habbah habbah" (kind of like hubbah hubbah). He's trying to flash you or something. So, you go to thwart him with your taser.

ex_1_jp: 「僕は二十歳になる前に社長になるよ。」「そうだといいけどね。」
ex_1_en: "I’ll be company president before I’m twenty years old." "I hope you’re right about that."
meaning_story: Two time ten years old is twenty years old.
reading_story: The reading for twenty years old, specifically, is a really weird reading. It's はたち. When you turn twenty years old you become a hater of cheese. A hater cheese (はたち) kinda person.

ex_1_jp: 今夜の三日月は、何だか不穏な感じがするわ。
ex_1_en: Tonight’s new moon looks a little disquieting to me.
meaning_story: Something that's not calm is in a status of unrest and turbulence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 家の前に大量の白菊を並べるなんて、迷惑行為以上のことだよ。だって、白菊は日本では死者を弔う花だからね。言ってる意味が分かりますか？
ex_1_en: Placing a bunch of white chrysanthemums in front of a house is more than just a nuisance because they are are used to mourn the dead in Japan. Do you get what I’m saying?
meaning_story: A white chrysanthemum is a white chrysanthemum.
reading_story: The reading of 白 is a bit different from normal. It's しら instead of しろ, so do your best to keep that in mind. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 「ちょっと言ってもいいかな？」「もちろん。」「あのさ…やっぱいいや。」「ほら、白状しなって！」「えっと、実は私魔女なんだよね。」
ex_1_en: "Can I tell you something?" "Of course." "Well… never mind." "Oh come on, out with it." "Well... to be honest, I am a witch."
meaning_story: A devil woman is a witch. She uses magic, so she must be a witch! Also, does she float like wood / a very small rock?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 三十歳を過ぎてから、全身がすごく痒いんだよね。
ex_1_en: Ever since I turned thirty, my whole body has been itchy.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is put on the end of numbers to show how old someone is.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: うちの母親は、僕が零点を取ると、キーッと癇癪を起こします。
ex_1_en: My mom really loses her temper if I get zero marks on my exams.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That's 零 extra things for you to learn.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私はTofugu営業部の補佐として働きました。
ex_1_en: I worked as an assistant in the Tofugu sales department.
meaning_story: A supplement of help is an aid or help or assistance. Not a full on help, but an aid of sorts.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 水虫になりたくないなら、スリッパを裸足で履かない方がいいですよ。
ex_1_en: You shouldn’t wear slippers barefoot if you don’t want to get athlete’s foot.
meaning_story: If you have a naked foot, it means you're not wearing anything on your foot, making you barefoot.
reading_story: The reading here is a bit weird. It's like the words 裸 (はだか) and 足 (あし) were smushed together into one word. The 裸 becomes はだ and the 足 becomes し. You can think of it this way: You were barefoot too long, and because of this, you don't have feet anymore, though you had ashi (はだし) at one point in the past.

ex_1_jp: 君は今までみた中で一番胴体が長いよ。
ex_1_en: You have the longest torso I’ve ever seen.
meaning_story: Your torso body is the body area that's your torso. It's your body and trunk and torso, depending on what kind of body you have.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: アイツの話によると、彼女、本の挿絵を描いてるんだってさ。
ex_1_en: According to him, she draws illustrations for books.
meaning_story: If you insert a drawing into a book, it becomes a book illustration.
reading_story: The reading used for 挿絵 is an exceptional one. Instead of そう it's さし. When you think of a book illustration, think of an illustration of a sash. Just picture after picture of a sash. Purple sashes. Green sashes. Flashy sashes. What a weird book, that only has illustrations of sashes. 絵, however, is the reading you learned with the kanji, so at least you have that.

ex_1_jp: 口コミがあっという間に広がって、その折りたたみ式の陶器のお箸はとても人気が出ました。

meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: さすがベテランアナウンサーなだけあって、彼女はとてもよく聞き取れる明瞭な声でその質問に答えました。
ex_1_en: As one would expect from a veteran announcer like her, she answered the question in an easy to understand, clear voice.
meaning_story: Something that is bright and clear has great clarity and clearness. Just look at something with such brightness and such clearness! It has so much clarity!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 粘土を買おうかなと思ってるの？

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 崖っぷちではさすがに携帯圏外だったわ。
ex_1_en: Of course my phone had no reception at the edge of the cliff.

reading_story: You can't believe how big the cliff is. You look at it for so long, you just become another gawker (がけ) who can't stop staring at the huge cliff. It really is huge.

ex_1_jp: どうして粘着テープを宝石箱に仕舞っているの？

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. And for once the kanji 川 doesn't use the kun'yomi reading. When you think of a comic haiku, think of something hilarious... like a centaur (せん), doing a standup act with a comedy haiku.

reading_story: The readings for both kanji are ones you haven't seen before. But, just think about how when you go on a date (だて) you probably want to have as much elegance as possible. Makes the date go better.

reading_story: Out of the front door jumps (飛び) Ra (ら). Every morning he can't wait to burst forth from the front door to soak in the Sun. He is the Egyptian sun god, after all.

ex_1_jp: この度は本当にご愁傷様です。あなたのお婆さんはとても素敵な人だったので、あなたのお爺さんの代わりに私が一緒にいられればいいのにといつも願っていたほどですよ。残念ながら願いは叶いませんでしたがね。
ex_1_en: I am so sorry for your loss. Your grandmother was such a nice lady that I always wished she was with me instead of your grandfather. Sadly, my wish never came true.
meaning_story: An old woman, even with an honorific and an お is still an old woman. She might be your grandmother as well, though, so be nice!
reading_story: Even if she is your grandmother, something is wrong. You look closely at her face. She's a sheep! Baa! (ばあ).

ex_1_jp: 恐らく気づいていないと思うが、コウイチ大統領は全てを掌握しているんだよ。

ex_1_jp: こないだ海でフグって名前のめちゃくちゃ大きい男に会ったんだけど、その人シルクハットみたいな帽子被っててさぁ、…あ、そういう感じの帽子、分かる？

reading_story: The reading is the same as 狩り, so if you know that you'll know this, no need to hunt for the reading of this word.

ex_1_jp: アメリカに行くと、お財布に紙幣がギッシリ入るのでお金持ちになった気がするんですよね。まあ、それは全部一ドル札なんですが。
ex_1_en: Whenever I go to America I feel like I’m rich with all the money in my wallet. Though, they are all one dollar bills.
meaning_story: Paper cash is paper money.
reading_story: This word uses the on'yomi reading for 紙 even though you went through all that trouble to learn the kun'yomi reading. Just think about how when it comes to paper money, there's one man who loves it more than anyone, and that is Charlie Sheen (し). Imagine him carrying a ton of paper money wherever he goes, throwing it around just because he can.

ex_1_jp: お酒を付き合い程度にしか飲まない人のこと、なんだか可哀想だなって思うんだよね。
ex_1_en: I think it’s a little pathetic to be a social drinker.
meaning_story: A possible pathetic concept. It's not just possibly pathetic, to be honest. It's pitiful and pathetic, for sure.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Well, at least most of it does. To remember the reading for 哀 imagine some pathetic person who lost their home. They may be pitiful but at some point after losing their home they decided that the hood of your car would make a fine place to live. You can't help but ask them, "Why (わい) my car?" There are so many other cars this pathetic person could be camping out on, but they chose yours.

ex_1_jp: 衣食住もままならない彼らの事を哀れに思います。
ex_1_en: I pity them because they don’t have enough food, clothing, or shelter.
meaning_story: If something is pathetic then you should have pity on it. You should also feel a little sorrow and grief for it, because seriously, so pathetic!
reading_story: You look at the thing you're feeling is so pathetic that you feel pity for and just think... aww (あわ), that's really pathetic.

ex_1_jp: でも、どうしてハッカーは攻撃の矛先を俺たちに向けてきたんだ？

meaning_story: The halberd ahead is the most ahead part of the halberd. That's the point of spear or spearpoint.
reading_story: The reading comes from the vocab versions of 矛 and 先 combined together.

ex_1_jp: はためく日本国旗の上には、美しい虹が掛かっていた。
ex_1_en: There was a beautiful rainbow above the fluttering Japanese flag.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 虹色の山葵を購入してみたんですが、味はまんま山葵ですね。
ex_1_en: I purchased rainbow colored wasabi but it tastes just like regular wasabi.
meaning_story: Rainbow colored things are rainbow colored.
reading_story: The readings are the kanji readings for both 虹 and 色.

ex_1_jp: 点滴を受けた後、彼は綿密な診察を受けました。
ex_1_en: After getting an IV drip, he was thoroughly examined.
meaning_story: Point drips are drips coming down in little points. Those are raindrops, or really any falling drops of water, actually.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は花柳小説の有名な著者ですよ。
ex_1_en: He’s a famous author of red-light district novels.
meaning_story: The flower willow for some reason is a red light district. Just imagine a shady red light district, and right in the middle is a flowering willow.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 爽やかなイケメンが横を通り過ぎたので、思わず三度見をしちゃいました。
ex_1_en: An eloquent hunk passed by me and I had to do a triple-take.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji, making it refreshing as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same reading you learned with the kanji!

ex_1_jp: 痛恨のミスをしてしまい、彼にアドバイスしてもらうはめになりました。
ex_1_en: I made a mistake I regret and ended up asking him for advice.
meaning_story: A pain grudge is pain you feel from the grudge. I wish I could change my grudge. It is my regret.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今までに、休憩を取ることを考えたことはありますか。
ex_1_en: Have you ever thought about taking a break?
meaning_story: A rest rest is a rest. A break. A recess.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私達はみんな、剛志が炊飯器を買うのを楽しみにしています。
ex_1_en: We are all looking forward to Takeshi buying a rice cooker.
meaning_story: A cook food container is a container used to cook the main food staple in Japan. In this case it's a rice cooker.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この道は現在砕石舗装工事中です。
ex_1_en: This road is currently being paved.
meaning_story: Smashed stone is smashed stone. It's rubble and broken stone.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: シャワーの後、髪の毛が半乾きのまましばらく部屋の窓からの眺めを見つめていました。
ex_1_en: After taking a shower, she was staring at the view out her bedroom window for a short while with her hair still damp.
meaning_story: 眺める is "to stare at." The noun version is scene or view. It's what you're staring at.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 眺める.

ex_1_jp: うちのチワワに二平方尺の犬小屋を作ってあげました。
ex_1_en: I made a two square foot dog house for our Chihuahua.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: iPhoneで軍事飛行機がヘリコプターを撃墜する瞬間を撮影しました。
ex_1_en: My iPhone captured the moment that the military plane shot down the helicopter.
meaning_story: An attack that causes a crash is when you're shooting down something, usually an aircraft.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ベーコンを取り上げられたプードルは、悲哀と悲しみに満ちた声でクーンクーンと鳴いていました。
ex_1_en: The poodle, whose bacon had been taken away, was whining with a voice full of sorrow and grief.
meaning_story: I am sad and pathetic in how I feel. Such a deep sorrow! Such grief from my sad pathetic feelings.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

ex_1_jp: 日本の首相を歓迎するために、通りは割り箸で飾られました。
ex_1_en: The streets were decorated with chopsticks to welcome the Japanese prime minister.
meaning_story: Divideable chopsticks are chopsticks you can split apart. They are splittable chopsticks, almost always made from wood of some kind.
reading_story: The reading comes from 割る and 箸 put together. Be careful of the rendaku.

part_of_speech: ADVERB, NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 綿棒で犬の耳垢を取ったら何だか粘々していたんですが、それは普通ですか。
ex_1_en: I removed my dog’s ear wax with a cotton swab and it was kind of sticky. Is it normal?
meaning_story: Sticky sticky things are really sticky and covered with stickiness.
reading_story: The reading comes from 粘る. I suppose you never never want to touch something sticky.

ex_1_jp: 彼女が突如彼をセクハラで訴え始めたのには理由があります。
ex_1_en: There is a reason for her sudden accusations of sexual harassment.
meaning_story: You stab your likeness suddenly. The reason it's so all of a sudden is because who stabs their likeness? The person looks just like you, and... well... wow, really? Is this highlander?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: トꜜツジョ *** トツジョ

ex_1_jp: この巻尺で胸囲を測るのを手伝ってもらえませんか。
ex_1_en: Could you help me get my chest measurement with this tape measure?
meaning_story: A scroll of shaku. So, a scroll is all rolled up, right? And a shaku is an older form of Japanese measurement. If you roll up a measuring thing into a scroll-like container... what does it become? A tape measure!
reading_story: The reading for 巻 is the 巻く reading, pushed into the kanji. The 尺 reading is the normal reading of 尺. Careful of the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 私は畳の上に脱ぎ捨てられた、表裏が逆になった皺々のワイシャツを見つけました。
ex_1_en: I found his inside out, wrinkled dress shirt on the tatami where he threw it.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading comes right from the vocab meaning, which is tatami mat. The たたみ part, specifically.

ex_1_jp: 皆様のお陰で、我々は甲子園球場で開催されている高校野球のトーナメントで、準々決勝にまで進出することができました。
ex_1_en: Thanks to everyone, we could go to the quarter-finals of the Japan National High School Baseball Tournament held in Koshien stadium.
meaning_story: 陰 is a shade or shadow. For some reason when you add お to shade it becomes "thanks to," as in "thanks to you, I was able to pass the test." Just think about a shade helping you out. Perhaps thanks to the shade you were able to survive the heat of the desert.
reading_story: The reading comes from the word 陰. Thanks to that other vocab word, you can read this one!

ex_1_jp: ホームステイ先のお父さんが、今日の夕飯の際に黒い霧事件について説明をしてくれました。
ex_1_en: My home stay father explained the Black Mist Scandal to me at dinner tonight.
meaning_story: A black fog is going to be a really thick fog that you can't see through. Not too often you see black fog.
reading_story: The reading comes from 黒い and 霧.

ex_1_jp: うちの町が大雪に見舞われて、昨日は一日中雪かきしなきゃいけなかったんだよ。もう疲れてクタクタだよ。
ex_1_en: Heavy snow hit my town and I had to shovel it all day yesterday. I’m already worn out.
meaning_story: 疲れる is "to be exhausted." This is the noun version, which makes it tiredness or fatigue.
reading_story: The reading comes from 疲れる.

ex_1_jp: ええっ！あのセールスマンまだうちの母ちゃんと話をしてるよ。粘るね〜！
ex_1_en: Wow! That salesman is still talking to my mom. How persistent!
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sticky and the verb vocab version is to be sticky. It can also mean to persevere, because if you're being sticky towards the situation, not giving up and not letting go. You're totally persevering by sticking around.
reading_story: Will I give up? I'll nevah (ねば) give up! I'll also nevah unstick from you.

ex_1_jp: 「どうして歯を磨かないの？」「だって、食べ物の味が口に残っているのが好きなんだもん。それっていけないことかしら？」
ex_1_en: "Why don’t you brush your teeth?" "Because I like how the taste of food stays in my mouth! What’s so wrong with that?!
meaning_story: 磨く is "to polish" or "to shine." If you're doing that to your teeth you are brushing them. That's why this is to brush one's teeth.
reading_story: The reading comes from 歯 and 磨く, put together.

ex_1_jp: 私は、一つ上の階からコンスタントに聞こえてくる気味の悪い金切り声を聞くために、耳を澄ましました。
ex_1_en: I strained my ears to hear the faint but constant screeching coming from upstairs.
meaning_story: 澄む is "to become clear" - this is when you make something clear, because you must (ます) make it clear. You have to. That's why this is to clear or to make clear.
reading_story: The reading comes from 澄む, though, so if you know that this answer will become clear too.

ex_1_jp: ご飯を炊きながら、妹は私に家計が火の車だとぼやきました。
ex_1_en: My sister grumbled to me about how the family is in extreme poverty while she cooked rice.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cook and the verb vocab version is to cook or to boil. Often it has to do with cooking grains (to cook grains).
reading_story: When you cook something, it's like you're attacking (たく) the food with boiling water or fire or whatever. Attack the food by cooking it!

ex_1_jp: 孝志は彼女をうまく欺いた。
ex_1_en: Takashi successfully deceived his girlfriend.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deceit, so when you're doing deceit, you are going to deceive someone.
reading_story: As a human everyone would know who you are. You can't deceive anyone like that. But, as a moo (あざむ)... a cow is what I mean... nobody would know who you are.

ex_1_jp: 彼の額から、血が滴り落ちました。
ex_1_en: The blood dripped from his forehead.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drip and the verb vocab version is to drip.
reading_story: To drip drip drip on your head... what's dripping on your head? You're standing below a toilet that's leaking. The dripping sounds like "sh*tt, ta, ta (したた), with each drip making a "ta" sound because it's kind of thick and poopy.

ex_1_jp: 重ね着しすぎてすごく暑いんだけど、ちょっと私に向かって扇いでくれない？
ex_1_en: I’m wearing too many layers and it’s so hot. Could you fan me?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means folding fan and since you don't "to folding fan" something, this word means to fan instead.
reading_story: Imagine yourself trying to fan yourself with an 青 (あお) fan. For some reason blue fans feel cooler. Maybe it's because they're the color of ice/water?

ex_1_jp: 私は母を憎んだが、母も同様に私のことを憎んでいました。
ex_1_en: I hated my mom and she hated me just the same.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hate and the verb vocab version is to hate or to detest.
reading_story: What do you hate and detest more than anything? 肉 (にく). That stuff is gross, and you detest it.

ex_1_jp: どうしてあのスタントマンを恨んでいるんだい？
ex_1_en: Why do you have a grudge against that stuntman?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grudge and the verb vocab version is to hold a grudge.
reading_story: Who do you hold a grudge against the most? That would be you, Ra (うら). You and your dumb sun.

ex_1_jp: 唇を舐めて湿らせることは、結局その後乾燥させてしまうことになりうるので、あまりいいことではありません。
ex_1_en: Licking your lips to moisten them isn’t good because it can actually dry them out instead.
meaning_story: Remember how 湿る is "to be moist"? This is the version where you're doing the moistening, making it to moisten or to dampen.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 湿る.

ex_1_jp: この山小屋でちょっと憩わないか。
ex_1_en: Why don’t we rest for a bit in this hut?
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rest and the verb vocab version is to rest or to relax.
reading_story: I'm going to rest and play some Ico (いこ) on the ol' Playstation.

ex_1_jp: 剣道の試合で、コウイチは竹刀で相手の胴を完璧に討ち取りました。
ex_1_en: In a kendo match, Koichi hit the lower part of the opponent’s torso perfectly with his bamboo sword.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: クッキーが粉々になるまで、伸ばし棒で叩いて砕きました。
ex_1_en: I smashed the cookies with a rolling pin until they were broken into small pieces.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means smash and the verb vocab version of the kanji is to smash or to break.
reading_story: You want to smash my stuff? That's coo' だ (くだ). Whatever you wanna do.

ex_1_jp: 車掌は、乗客たちを待たせていることについて、お詫びをした。
ex_1_en: The train conductor apologized to the passengers for keeping them waiting.
meaning_story: A car manipulator is someone who manipulates the car. This 車 riffs off of 電車, which is a train, making the train manipulator a train conductor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: うわくちびる, じょうしん
ex_1_jp: 疲れると、上唇がよく腫れちゃうんですよね。
ex_1_en: When I’m tired my upper lip usually swells.
meaning_story: The above lip is the upper lip.
reading_story: The reading for 上 is a bit weird, it's うわ instead of うえ. It's almost like うえ, just a little different.
pitch_accent: ウワクチꜜビル *** ウワクꜜチビル

ex_1_jp: ブロック塀の取付け費用がいくらかかるのかが知りたいんですが。
ex_1_en: I want to know how much concrete-block wall installation will cost.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: お買い得だったので、HBのシャー芯を百ケース買いました。
ex_1_en: I bought one hundred cases of HB mechanical pencil lead because they were at a bargain price.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also refer to a bunch of other things as well that have similar ideas behind them to a wick (like marrow, a stapler staple, pencil led, and more!
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: あの居酒屋の柳模様の暖簾が好きなのよね。
ex_1_en: I like the willow design on that Izakaya restaurant’s curtain.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The willow you have outside is a naggy willow, always asking for more water. That's yah naggy weeping willow.

ex_1_jp: 部長のお嬢さんは確か歌手志望じゃなかったですっけ？
ex_1_en: Isn’t the manager’s daughter a wannabe singer?
meaning_story: This is like 嬢さん, but even more polite. You'll see this in anime, manga, and dramas a lot, especially when someone is the daughter of someone powerful.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 嬢さん and uses the reading from the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 恥ずかしいことに、その任務の遂行に失敗してしまいました。
ex_1_en: I am embarrassed that I failed the execution of the mission.
meaning_story: Accomplish and go forth! These are your accomplishments. This is your execution of actions.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は陰では顧客のことを「カモ」と呼んでいる癖に、表ではペコペコ頭を下げておべっかを言っている。
ex_1_en: He calls his clients suckers behind their backs and yet he bobs his head and says flattering things to their faces.
meaning_story: Even though you have this habit you're still able to win. That's why this is And yet, though, and in spite of. Because, in spite of your bad habit, you still won. Frustrating.
reading_story: The reading comes from the word 癖.

ex_1_jp: 麻酔でまだ寝ぼけています。
ex_1_en: I’m still half asleep from the anesthesia.
meaning_story: A hemp drunkness is when you take some "hemp" and put it into your body so you don't really feel anything anymore. This is anesthesia.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: このトウモロコシは畜産用飼料なので、人間用ではありません。
ex_1_en: This corn is stockbreeding feed and not for human consumption.
meaning_story: Livestock will give birth to more livestock. You're in the biz of raising livestock, that's why. This is animal husbandry.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 昨日は一日中石膏を乾式工法の壁に塗布していました。
ex_1_en: I applied plaster to drywall all day yesterday.
meaning_story: Let's paint a cloth's worth of paint on the wall. This is one application or coating of paint.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 俺が逆らうと、兄貴はよく脇をこしょばしてきました。
ex_1_en: My older brother used to tickle my armpits when I opposed him.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now isn't that a bit wacky (わき)?

ex_1_jp: 彼は取り付け騒ぎを防ぐ為にもう少しで預金者に嘘をつくところだったが、結局未遂に終わった。
ex_1_en: He was very close to lying to depositors to prevent a bank run, but in the end he gave up on the attempt.
meaning_story: I have not yet accomplished anything yet. This is only an attempt, so we'll see how it goes.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は友人の後ろ盾に勇気づけられました。
ex_1_en: I was encouraged by my friend’s support.
meaning_story: The rear shield is the shield that protects your back. This is your backing or support. So, not a literal shield, but the kind of protection that you want to have anyways.
reading_story: The reading comes from 後ろ and 盾 put together. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: みんなが、私に一緒に盆踊りをやってみるようにしつこく言ってきたんです。
ex_1_en: Everyone insisted that I try doing the Bon Festival dance with them.
meaning_story: The lantern festival dance is the bon festival dance (or bon odori or lantern festival dance). It's a fun time, be sure to go to one sometime!
reading_story: The reading is 盆 plus 躍り put together into one word.

ex_1_jp: 私は鉢にピーナッツを植えました。
ex_1_en: I planted peanuts in the pot.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 私は正座をして、火鉢に手をかざしました。
ex_1_en: I sat with my legs bent beneath me and warmed my hands over the brazier.
meaning_story: A fire bowl is something you use to put fire in. It's a brazier.
reading_story: The reading is the vocab reading for 火 and the reading you learned for 鉢, rendaku'd.

ex_1_jp: 彼は光輝燦然と旗を掲げました。
ex_1_en: He raised the flag in all it’s splendor.
meaning_story: The sunlight's radiance is that of brightness and splendor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今日迷彩柄のズボンを買いに行ったんだけど、ひとつも見つけられなかったよ。
ex_1_en: I went out to buy some camouflage pants today, but I couldn’t find any.
meaning_story: Astray coloring is coloring that's all over the place. It's all astray all over your clothes. This astray coloring is camouflage. You can use it as a disguise.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: これは麻の木じゃないって、何回説明したら分かってもらえるんですか？
ex_1_en: How many times do I have to tell you that this is not a hemp plant?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, but it also means cannabis as well.
reading_story: You always smoke your cannabis in the 朝. No other time. Just the 朝.

ex_1_jp: その騎兵の写真、なんだか若かりし頃を思い出すな。
ex_1_en: That photo of the cavalries reminds me a bit of my youth.
meaning_story: A horse soldier is a member of the cavalry.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 僕はあまり賢くはないけど、やるときはちゃんとやってみせるよ。
ex_1_en: I’m not too clever, but I have my moments.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of clever? It's clever or intelligent.
reading_story: If you're clever enough, you can start up an awesome company that makes tons of cash. A cash co (かしこ).

ex_1_jp: 遅くなって、本当にすみません。トイレの壁の塗装が思ったよりも長引いてしまって。
ex_1_en: I am so sorry for being late. Painting my bathroom walls took me longer than I thought.
meaning_story: With paint I want to attire the wall. Let's put a coating of painting up on the wall.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 先生は、その生徒は鋭い色彩感覚を持っていると判断しました。
ex_1_en: The teacher concluded that the student had a keen sense of color.
meaning_story: The color coloring is the color of something.
reading_story: 色 uses the しき reading (remember 景色?). Use that here with the 彩 kanji reading.

ex_1_jp: 九回裏から逆転ホームランで見事返り咲いた。
ex_1_en: It was a magnificent comeback in the bottom of the ninth from a come from behind home run.
meaning_story: The return blossom is when the blossoms return. A second bloom. This is another word for a comeback.
reading_story: The readings are the readings from 返る and the kanji 咲. Watch out for the rendaku.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: それってすごく矛盾した状況じゃない？
ex_1_en: They’re really contradicting circumstances, aren’t they?
meaning_story: A halberd and a shield. Totally different things. Not at all like each other. A complete contradiction.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女がマシンガントークを繰り広げていたので、私が会話に入る隙はこれっぽっちもありませんでした。
ex_1_en: She talked like a machine gun and there was no room for me to get into the conversation.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 二台の自販機の隙間に、小銭が2-3枚落ちているのを見つけました。
ex_1_en: I found a few coins in the gap between two vending machines.
meaning_story: A crevice interval is an area with a crevice or crack.
reading_story: The reading for 隙 is the one you learned with the kanji and the 間 is the 間に合う reading.

ex_1_jp: 細胞培養を作るには、何を準備する必要がありますか。
ex_1_en: What do I need prepare for making a cell culture?
meaning_story: Cultivate and foster something. That's cultivation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この畜生め！何でシラチャソースを俺のベッドにぶちまけやがったんだ！
ex_1_en: You stupid son of a bitch! How dare you to spray sriracha sauce on my bed!
meaning_story: The livestock life. The life of a beast! Arghhh, damnit, I hate the life of a beast. Damnit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 盆踊りの練習をして時間を潰しました。
ex_1_en: I killed time by practicing the Bon Festival Dance.
meaning_story: A dance is a dance.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 彼女はクラブでベロベロに酔っ払い、踊り場でトロンとした目つきでろれつの回らない会話を繰り広げていた。
ex_1_en: She got so drunk at a club that her speech on the dance floor was slurred and her eye movements were slower than normal.
meaning_story: A dance location is a location in which you dance. This is a dance hall or dance floor.
reading_story: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 僕はある梟と目を交換したから、暗闇でも目が見えるんだよ。
ex_1_en: I switched eyes with an owl so now I can see in the dark.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 暗闇で戦う時は、相手の出方を見て、その上でどうするか判断した方がいいよ。
ex_1_en: When you fight in dark you should let the other guy make the first move and then decide what to do.
meaning_story: A dark darkness is a darkness. It's the dark.
reading_story: The reading is the kun'yomi reading of both kanji. The reading from 暗い and the reading of the kanji 闇.

ex_1_jp: 警察は、その寝たきりの老人は餓死したと考えている。
ex_1_en: The police think the bedridden old man starved to death.
meaning_story: Starve to death is death from starvation... Starving to death.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 水平な横線を引くように言ったのに、ちょっと斜めになっています。
ex_1_en: I told him to draw a horizontal line, but it’s slightly diagonal.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: A diagonal is anything that's not a right angle. Even if something is at a 七 (なな) percent angle is a diangonal, slanting, tilted angle.

ex_1_jp: 彼女を雑誌の表紙に起用することは、恥辱を受けるようなものです。
ex_1_en: Using her for the cover of our magazine is like covering it with disgrace.
meaning_story: If you shame and humiliate me, I will have a sense of disgrace, shame.
reading_story: The reading from 恥 is the ち reading, a reading you haven't learned yet. To remember this, just think about how the cheese jock is the biggest disgrace to this sports team. He is cheese, after all. He falls apart and smells funny.

ex_1_jp: 前年度優勝校と一回戦で当たってしまい、屈辱的な敗北を味わったが、相手が悪かった。
ex_1_en: We got matched up in the first round with last year’s champions and suffered a humiliating defeat. It was a bad match.
meaning_story: Yield a humiliation onto your life. What a disgrace. What a humiliation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日本独特の家畜っていうのはいるんですか？
ex_1_en: Is there any livestock unique to Japan?
meaning_story: House broken livestock are domestic animals / livestock. They're made to live with us in or near our homes.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 太陽光発電のパネルの耐久性がどんなもんなのか気になっています。
ex_1_en: I’m wondering how durable solar panels are.
meaning_story: I have the nature of being resistant for a long time. Things that are resistant for a long time have good durability.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その力士は土俵際で踏ん張り、相手力士に打っ棄りを食らわせた。
ex_1_en: The sumo wrestler braced himself at the edge of the ring and was able to throw his opponent out.
meaning_story: A soil sack on the edge. Pretend the sacks are lined up around in a circle. It's the edge of a sumo ring. Can also be a sumo ring.
reading_story: The first two kanji (土俵) use the on'yomi reading you learned. The last kanji 際 uses the kun'yomi reading, which you should know via the vocabulary. Just think of these two parts as somewhat separate bits of the word, which is why one part is on'yomi and another (the addition) is kun'yomi.

ex_1_jp: Tofuguの社長として、コウイチはサービスの向上に尽力致します。
ex_1_en: As the president of Tofugu, Koichi does his utmost to improve the service.
meaning_story: If you exhaust power you are putting out efforts.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ジꜜンリョク *** ジンリョク

ex_1_jp: うちの嫁さんは全然電灯を消さないんだよね。きっとスイッチがあることを知らないんだと思うよ。
ex_1_en: My wife never turns off the light. She probably doesn’t even know there is a switch.
meaning_story: An electricity lamp is an electric lamp. Nowadays they're all electricity, though, which means it's a lamp.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 地下室に一年分のトイレットペーパーの備蓄をしてるんです。
ex_1_en: We have a year’s supply of toilet paper stored in our basement.
meaning_story: I need something to provide to me in an emergency, so I'm amassing emergency stores.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 俺は社長の腰巾着かもしれないが、それって俺にはすごい忍耐力があるってことにもならないかな？
ex_1_en: I may be following our president around like a shadow, doesn’t that mean I have great endurance?
meaning_story: I'm resistant and I Endure. I have much endurance and perseverance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この消防士さんの人形は、実際に耐火性の服と手袋を身につけています。
ex_1_en: This firefighter figurine is actually wearing fireproof clothes and gloves on his body.
meaning_story: If something is resistant to fire then it is fireproof. Turtles are not this.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: そのクイズの答えが当たったのはただの紛れです。
ex_1_en: It was just a fluke that I was able to answer the questions on the quiz.
meaning_story: 紛れる means "to be diverted." A thing that is diverted goes in another weird direction. It's just a fluke or chance.
reading_story: One reading does follow the 紛れる reading. But the more common reading is まぐれ. Very similar to まぎれる, but the ぎ goes to ぐ.
pitch_accent: マキ°レꜜ *** マꜜク°レ *** マク°レꜜ

ex_1_jp: お父さんなら今うちの冷蔵庫の霜取りをしてるよ。
ex_1_en: My dad is removing the frost from our fridge right now.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 人々は、その試合は八百長だったのではないかと憶測している。
ex_1_en: People are speculating that the match may have been fixed.
meaning_story: A recollection and measurement of the situation is what I use to make a guess and speculation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お米の収穫期は今年はいつ頃になりそうですか？
ex_1_en: When do you think the rice harvest will be this year?
meaning_story: Obtain a harvest. When you do this you have a harvest or crop.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どいつが新入生の首班を占めることになると思う？
ex_1_en: Who do you think will be the leader of the first-year students?
meaning_story: The neck of the squad is the most important part of the squad, for if you lose the neck you lose the head (they're all one thing). This person is the head or leader of a group.
reading_story: The reading of 首 is on'yomi reading, one you haven't learned before. Imagine the leader of the group as the most important person (because they are). Because they're so important, they're the only person who gets to wear shoes (しゅ). Everyone else in the group is barefoot and suffering.

ex_1_jp: そのラーメン屋の店主は、いつも色あせた綿の鉢巻を絞めていました。
ex_1_en: The owner of that ramen shop was always wearing a faded cotton headband.
meaning_story: A bowl scroll is a little bowl thing that you put on your head. It's a headband.
reading_story: The reading is the reading of 鉢 and 巻く, put together into one word. The reading's pretty weird, but hopefully you can wrap it around your head.

ex_1_jp: 友達が耐熱容器の漫画を書いてるんだけど、主人公の容器の「耐熱容器としての限界を感じた」っていう台詞が気に入ってるのよね。
ex_1_en: My friend is writing a manga about heat-resistant containers. The protagonist container said, "I’ve reached my limit as a heat-resistant container." I really like that line.
meaning_story: If something is resistant to heat then it is heat resisting.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 君が失業したのは本当に気の毒に思うけど、でも一体どうして大麻なんて庭で育てていたんだい？
ex_1_en: I think it’s really unfortunate that you’re unemployed, but why the hell were you growing cannabis in our garden?
meaning_story: Big hemp is still hemp, though this can also refer to shinto paper offerings. Mostly just hemp, though.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 突然、背後から知らない男に後頭部を殴打されました。
ex_1_en: Suddenly, I was struck on the back of the head from behind by some random guy I didn’t know.
meaning_story: An assault hit is a hit or strike or blow. Not a friendly hit, that's for sure.
reading_story: The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji.

ex_1_jp: その騎手は、自分の初めてのG1レースの日に朝寝坊をしました。
ex_1_en: The rider overslept on the day of his first G1 race.
meaning_story: A horse hand is the hands that ride the horse. These hands belong to a horse rider.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 運動会の騎馬戦の練習があるので、明日は早起きしなくてはいけません。
ex_1_en: I have to wake up early tomorrow morning to practice for the athletic meet’s mock cavalry battle.
meaning_story: Horse horse, look at all these horses. What do you do with horses? You do horse riding.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あなたの国は、帝国主義国家ですか？
ex_1_en: Is your country an imperialistic nation?
meaning_story: The Empire (帝国) ism (主義) is when you are doing imperialism. Long live the emperor!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the two words this word is made up of, 帝国 and 主義.

ex_1_jp: どうしてこの単語の文字のフォントを斜体に変えたんですか。
ex_1_en: What did you change this word’s font to italics?
meaning_story: When text has a diagonal body to it, it is leaning. It is in italics or the italic font style.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その騎士は、アメリカ国旗を掲げることを断った。
ex_1_en: The knight refused to fly the American flag.
meaning_story: A horse samurai is also known as a knight. Onward, knights of the round! Off to find the holy grail!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その部屋には、小さなロウソクの灯りだけが灯っていました。
ex_1_en: There was only a little candle light in the room.
meaning_story: The meaning of this noun is the same as the kanji, lamp. Can also mean light and torch as well, depending on where you herald from.
reading_story: The reading is like that of 明るい, which means "bright." At least the あか part is the same. What is a lamp if not 明るい (あか)? Another way to think of it is "what is a bright color?" The color 赤 (あか) is a bright color and would make a sexy lamp.

ex_1_jp: 冬が長引いたため、今年はうちのお庭の桜は遅咲きでした。
ex_1_en: The cherry trees in our yard experienced a late bloom this year due to the lingering winter.
meaning_story: A slow bloom is a bloom that happens late. It's a late flower or late blooming. Important to know if you're going to go do 花見.
reading_story: The reading is 遅い and 咲く put together (the same reading you learned from the 咲 kanji). Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 火山が溶岩を吹き出していて危険なので、これ以上近づくことはできません。
ex_1_en: We can’t go any closer because the volcano is spewing out lava and it’s dangerous.
meaning_story: It can melt a boulder? What is this stuff that's so hot? It's lava. It's also probably made from melted boulders too, come to think of it.
reading_story: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the kanji, but you haven't learned the on'yomi reading for 岩, which is がん. When you think of lava, think about Gandhi, coming out of the lava. He's immune, because he's a robot.
pitch_accent: ヨꜜーカ°ン *** ヨーカ°ン

ex_1_jp: いてぇ。どこに目ぇつけて歩いてるんだ！脇見しながら歩いてんじゃねぇぞ！
ex_1_en: Ouch. Watch where you’re going! Don’t be looking from side to side while you’re walking!
meaning_story: From your armpit you see. Just imagine trying to see from your armpit. Go ahead and move your head the best you can to see from the view of your armpit. How are you looking at things now? You're looking from the side, because your head is so turned to the side.
reading_story: The reading is the reading you learned with 脇 and the reading for 見る.

ex_1_jp: 例えば、太陽の輝度値はとても高いです。
ex_1_en: For example, the sun’s luminosity value is very high.
meaning_story: The degrees of radiance show the luminance and brightness of something, so long as the degree is the right degree.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: めもちょう, メモちょう
ex_1_jp: 話の途中で申し訳ありませんが、あなたのメモ帳のことでどうしても質問したいんです。
ex_1_en: Forgive me for interrupting, but I must ask you a question about your memo pad.
meaning_story: A memo (メモ) notebook is a memo book or memo pad that you use to write notes in.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, plus メモ.

ex_1_jp: ある臭いが、ある記憶を引き起こすって、聞いたことある？俺は今まさに、下水道に落ちた時のことを思い出しているんだけど。
ex_1_en: Do you know how a certain smell can trigger a certain memory? Well, right now I’m thinking about that time I fell in a sewer.
meaning_story: When you record recollections in your mind, that concept is the concept of memory. This word is not a specific memory, instead it's the idea of memory itself. So, uh, try to memorize that.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 根っからの蚊取り線香派なんで、電気のやつを使うのは好きじゃないんですよね。
ex_1_en: I’m a die hard mosquito coil user, I don’t like using the electric ones.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 十人用の大きな蚊帳はありますか？
ex_1_en: Do you have a mosquito net big enough for ten people?
meaning_story: A mosquito notebook, for some reason, is a mosquito net. Think of a notebook with graph paper lines on it, perhaps. These lines are shaped like a net. Surround yourself with it to make your own mosquito net.
reading_story: The first kanji, 蚊, uses the reading you learned. The second kanji has an exceptional reading, や. To remember や, think about how you had to take a giant mosquito net and cover all of Yankee (や) Stadium. They have a rough mosquito problem.

ex_1_jp: 手帳を盗み見すると、彼女は物凄く怒りました。
ex_1_en: She got unbelievably angry at me when I peeped at her notebook.
meaning_story: A hand notebook is a notebook you can hold in your hand. This could simply be a notebook, but it could also be a memo pad.
reading_story: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 油彩画のコツを掴んできました。
ex_1_en: I’m getting the hang of oil painting.
meaning_story: Oil coloring is better known as oil painting. What fine strokes! What fine lines!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 刷毛に蛍光塗料を付けました。
ex_1_en: I dipped the paint brush in the fluorescent paint.
meaning_story: The painting fee isn't one of money. If you want to paint, you will have to pay the fee for paints and painting materials.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: こちらの件に関して、迅速かつ丁寧にご対応頂き誠に有り難うございます。
ex_1_en: I appreciate your prompt and polite response to this matter.
meaning_story: Things that are swift and fast are going to be quick and fast and rapid and swift. So many quick things.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 帳簿に記帳をし忘れたため、上司に叱られました。
ex_1_en: I was scolded by my boss for forgetting to register some items in the account book.
meaning_story: Please record it in the notebook. This will be the registry.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 美人局にいとも簡単に引っ掛かってしまったことを後悔しています。
ex_1_en: I regret how easily I got caught in her badger game.
meaning_story: My behind regret is the regret from before, which is all regret. That's regret.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 他の人が日本語で何を話しているのか理解できない時、私はいつも悔しい思いをします。
ex_1_en: I always think it’s frustrating when I can’t understand what the other people are saying in Japanese.
meaning_story: The kanji is regret and this is regrettable. Could also be vexing or annoying as well.
reading_story: The coup, yah (くや), that was regrettable. The new government isn't all that great.

ex_1_jp: うちの祖母は葬式代分しか貯蓄していないと言っていました。
ex_1_en: My grandma said her savings is to be used only on her funeral costs.
meaning_story: Take your savings and amass them. That is your savings.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 盾を買いたいんだけど、どこに行けば買えるのか知りませんか？
ex_1_en: I want to buy a shield, do you know where I can go to buy one?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Think of a big ol' shield. It's so big it will stand (立て) tall right in front of you.

ex_1_jp: うちの私道は急斜面になってるので、上まで上がってくるにはスノータイヤがいります。
ex_1_en: Our driveway has become a steep slope, so you need snow tires to get up it.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この町で蛇がペットとして普及した時には、身震いしましたよ。
ex_1_en: When keeping snakes as pets spread throughout the city, I trembled.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
pitch_accent: クチナワ *** ジャꜜ *** ヘꜜビ

ex_1_jp: あの班は、五輪の左端の輪っかに間違った色を選びました。
ex_1_en: That group chose the wrong color for the far left olympic ring.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 彼は社交的でみんなから好かれているので、班長に選ばれました。
ex_1_en: He is sociable and everyone likes him, so he was elected to be the team leader.
meaning_story: The squad leader is the squad leader. Can also be the honcho (ever wonder where this word came from?).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうしてそんな風にクッキーを踏みつけたりしたんだ？毎日何千何百人という人が飢餓で亡くなるのを知らないのか。
ex_1_en: Why would you step on a cookie like that? Don’t you know that thousands of people die from starvation every day?
meaning_story: One person starves and another person starves. Then more people. So much starve that there's starvation going on. It's famine and hunger, everywhere.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 大量の蛾が、各街灯の周りを飛び交っています。
ex_1_en: There are a ton of moths flying around each street lamp.
meaning_story: A street lamp is a streetlight. Brightening up my street!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女、オーディションに受かったって言いふらしてるけど、ただの脇役みたいだよ。
ex_1_en: She keeps talking about how she passed the audition, but it looks like she only got a supporting role.
meaning_story: If you're on armpit duty you're definitely not the lead. You're standing next to the lead's armpit, because you're the supporting actor. You're in a supporting role.
reading_story: The reading is 脇's reading and 役's reading, put together.

ex_1_jp: この電話帳を整理してしまう方がいいと思います。
