ex_1_jp: ここにいる人は皆、総合格闘技の礎を築いた故人の死を悼んでいると思います。
ex_1_en: I think everyone here is mourning over the deceased who laid the foundation of mixed martial art.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: A foundation is made of stone (いし). And it holds up an entire zoo A (ずえ) but none of Zoo B. Zoo B will fall apart when an earthquake hits.
pitch_accent: イシズエ *** イシズエꜜ *** イシズꜜエ

ex_1_jp: 金魚は淡水魚だから、水槽に塩を入れてはいけませんよ。
ex_1_en: Goldfish are freshwater fish so you shouldn’t put salt in the tank.
meaning_story: A faint water is water that's not thick with salt. It's fresh water.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ほとんどの無神論者は、神や神々の概念に対して否定的です。
ex_1_en: Most of the atheists have negative feelings regarding the concept of God or gods.
meaning_story: An approximation of thought is just thinking up the general idea. The concept or notion.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お婆ちゃんに、嘘をついたことで責められた。
ex_1_en: My grandma accused me of telling lies.
meaning_story: An old woman is who this is. Then, you add ちゃん for the name ender. You add お to be nicer. This person is a granny or grandma or old lady or old woman.
reading_story: The reading isn't the ば you learned with the kanji. It's a slightly longer ばあ, because you gotta be nice, you know? Also, the person you thought was a granny is actually a sheep. Baaaa! (ばあ).

ex_1_jp: アポを取ろうとしたんだけど、彼はどうやらうちの社長に何か恨みがあるみたいで、時間をくれなかったんだよね。
ex_1_en: I asked for an appointment, but he wouldn’t give me the time of day because he apparently has a some kind of grudge against the president of our company.
meaning_story: 恨む is "to hold a grudge." This is the noun version, which is a grudge or a resentment.
reading_story: The reading comes from 恨む, so if you know that no need to hold a grudge.

ex_1_jp: 候補者のコウイチ氏は、大統領候補討論会の前、憎らしいほど落ち着いていました。
ex_1_en: Candidate Koichi was provokingly cool before the presidential debate.
meaning_story: 憎む is "to hate" - the adjective version is hateful.
reading_story: The reading comes from 憎む as well, so if you know this no need to show any hate towards this vocab.

ex_1_jp: こんなに誰かのことを憎いと思ったのは生まれて初めてです。
ex_1_en: I’ve never hated someone this much in my life.
meaning_story: If 憎む means "to hate" then this adjective version is hateful.
reading_story: The reading comes from 憎む as well. Good times.

ex_1_jp: てっきり彼らはお互いに憎しみ合っているものだと思っていました。
ex_1_en: I certainly thought they hated each other.
meaning_story: If 憎む is "to hate" then the noun version would be hatred.
reading_story: The reading comes from 憎む.
pitch_accent: ニクシミ *** ニクシミꜜ *** ニクシꜜミ

ex_1_jp: 劣悪な職場環境の会社は、日本ではしばしば「ブラック企業」と呼ばれます。
ex_1_en: Companies with very rough work environments are often called "black companies" in Japan.
meaning_story: Inferiority is bad. It is inferiority, after all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女が私に対して劣等感を抱いていると誤解していました。
ex_1_en: I was under the impression that she had an inferiority complex towards me.
meaning_story: Inferiority is how I feel because I don't have an "equal" feeling with you. This is due to my inferiority complex.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 万引きをするのは大概、退屈で孤独を感じている女性だと言う人がいますが、ある調査が男性の方が女性よりも万引きをすることが多い可能性を示唆しているそうですよ。
ex_1_en: Some people think shoplifters are mainly bored, lonely women, but I heard that a study suggested that more men shoplift than women.
meaning_story: A big approximation is when I say something in general. I'm mainly and mostly telling everything.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 成功の秘訣は、鋭い勘をもつことです。
ex_1_en: Having sharp intuition is the key to success.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also could mean perception or hunch.
reading_story: The reading is the one you learned from the kanji.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 彼は二日酔いであまりにも酒臭すぎるので、別の部屋に隔離しています。
ex_1_en: We have quarantined him to a separate room because he is hungover and reeks of liquor.
meaning_story: Isolate and detached from everything else. This thing (or person) is in isolation and quarantine.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私はあの病院の抽選で、胃のバイパス手術が当たったんです。
ex_1_en: I won a gastric bypass surgery from that hospital’s raffle.
meaning_story: Pluck lucky ticket out to choose the winner of the lottery / raffle! Today I pluck... number 23! We've chosen a winner!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 覆面のスーパーマンは、ボッロボロのマントを身につけていました。
ex_1_en: The masked superman was wearing such a tattered cloak.
meaning_story: Cover your face. Not with your hands or a puppy, but with a mask! Okay, I guess you could cover it with a puppy mask, but that's all you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 母国語でも唯物論について説明できないのに、どうして外国語で説明できるというのか。
ex_1_en: I can’t even explain materialism in my native language, so how can I explain it in a foreign language?
meaning_story: The solely things theory is the theory that only things are important. This is also known as materialism.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「すみません、間違えました。違う人と 勘違いしました。」「正確には誰と間違えたんですか？お願いします。教えてください。」
ex_1_en: "Excuse me, my mistake. I thought you were someone else." "Exactly who did you mistake me for? Please. Tell me."
meaning_story: An intuition difference is a misunderstanding or wrong guess. Sorry! My intuition was off.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 昨日は俺が悪かったよ。本当にごめん。お詫びの印に、今日は草刈りをするよ。
ex_1_en: I am really sorry for being a jerk yesterday. I’ll mow the grass today to apologize.
meaning_story: Let's take the grass and prune it. This is called mowing, but can also refer to a mower.
reading_story: The reading is 草 and 刈 put together into one. The か reading for 刈り comes from the kanji's reading.
pitch_accent: クサカꜜリ *** クサカリ *** クサカリꜜ

ex_1_jp: かつては桑畑がたくさんあったため、この場所は「桑原」と呼ばれるようになりました。
ex_1_en: People started calling this place "Kuwabara" because there used to be a lot of mulberry fields here.
meaning_story: A mulberry field is a mulberry field.
reading_story: These are both the kun'yomi readings, but you haven't learned this for 原 yet. It's actually the rendaku'd version, so let's just use mnemonic to remember it instead: You know you're in a mulberry field when you see a bunch of capybaras (ばら) rolling around in there with you. Capybaras love mulberries! Picture a whole family of capybaras munching on mulberries. Mm Mmm!

ex_1_jp: 私の地元には、桑畑があちこちにあります。
ex_1_en: Mulberry fields are everywhere in my hometown.
meaning_story: A mulberry field is a mulberry field or mulberry plantation. This is more like a commercial / organized mulberry growing operation, so not some random field of mulberries.
reading_story: The reading comes from 桑 (kanji reading) and the vocab word 畑. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 桑の実と林檎と胡桃の組み合わせが最強に美味しいんだよね。
ex_1_en: Mulberries, apples, and walnuts taste best when they’re combined.
meaning_story: The kanji means mulberry, but this refers to a mulberry tree.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: お雑煮そろそろ煮えたんじゃないかな。
ex_1_en: The New Year’s mochi soup should be ready by now.
meaning_story: A random boil isn't all that random. It's specifically the new year's dish or mochi soup, eaten on new years. Old people and children tend to die every year from this (choking on the mochi), so be careful if you eat it! Maybe the reason it's called "random boil" is because someone decided to boil a bunch of random things (like mochi) and then it became a new years dish later on. Who knows. That information isn't even known by the ancients.
reading_story: You learned the reading for 煮 on the kanji page, but the reading for 雑 is an exceptional one. You did learn this reading with 雑巾, though. Just imagine yourself with a dust cloth in your new year's dish.

ex_1_jp: その尼僧は、寝起きはいつも顔がむくんでいます。
ex_1_en: That nun’s face is always swollen when she wakes up.
meaning_story: A nun priest is a nun or priestess.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は尼さんなのにお酒をたくさん飲みます。
ex_1_en: Even though she’s a nun, she’s a heavy drinker.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Are you a nun? I am a (あま) nun.

ex_1_jp: あいつは奴の家族の中で唯一まともな人間だよ。
ex_1_en: He is the only decent person in his family.
meaning_story: It's solely one. The only one. The sole one. Totally unique.
reading_story: The reading for 唯 is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, though there is also a shortened version which has ゆい shortened to ゆ. The 一 is a shortened version of 一つ. It's like the "h" and と is dropped.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は私の母ではなく唯の付き添い人です。
ex_1_en: She is not my mother, she’s just a chaperone.
meaning_story: The kanji means solely, but the meaning is ordinary or common. A nice word to hear! I suppose something that is solely one thing is an ordinary, common thing.
reading_story: You get to experience ordinary things every single day! Ta da! (ただ). It's like magic! Normal lives are great!

ex_1_jp: 青年海外協力隊についての概要は、こちらのページでお読み頂けます。
ex_1_en: You can read an outline of the Japanese Peace Corps on this page.
meaning_story: An approximation of what we need is my outline / summary.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 勘弁してちゃぶ台。今日は忙かったし、滅茶苦茶疲れているんだ。
ex_1_en: Cut me some slack. It’s been a long day and I’m terribly tired.
meaning_story: Intuition from my dialect tells me that I should pardon you. Give you forgiveness. You're lucky I speak this dialect.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 真珠を身につける人は減ってきています。
ex_1_en: Less and less people are wearing pearls.
meaning_story: A reality pearl is a real pearl! That's just a pearl.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: こちらの化粧水は、お肌の奥深くまで浸透するということで、すごく人気が出てきています。
ex_1_en: This face lotion is getting really popular because it deeply permeates into the skin.
meaning_story: Immersed to the point where it's transparent, because it's so soaked... that is total permeation and soaking and osmosis.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 壇上で、小さな可愛いフラワーガールの女の子が、しばらく花嫁の人気をさらいました。
ex_1_en: The cute little flower girl upstaged the bride on the on the podium for a moment.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: もう使わないんだったら、白い陶器は全部誰かにあげちゃえば？
ex_1_en: Why don’t you give away all these white ceramics if you don’t use them anymore?
meaning_story: A pottery container is pottery. It's ceramics.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: フグは、わざとサーモン妃にぶつかりました。
ex_1_en: Fugu bumped into Princess Salmon on purpose.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 日本には資源超過利潤税は無かったと思うよ。
ex_1_en: I don’t think there is a Resources Super Profits Tax in Japan.
meaning_story: The profits that I'm watered with are pouring all over me. That's my profit and returns.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 暗闇の中でキラキラ光る紫色の光を見た瞬間、「母だ」と思ったんです。
ex_1_en: The instant I saw purple light shining through the darkness, I thought, "Mom."
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is different from the one you learned with the kanji. To remember this reading, think about how the previous village you went to was all purple. It was the "村先" (むらさき) that you went to. Everything. Absolutely everything was purple.

ex_1_jp: 私は王妃と友情を育んだ。
ex_1_en: I cultivated my friendship with the queen.
meaning_story: The king of princesses is the greatest and highest ranking princess of them all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私の娘を止めてもらえませんか。無謀にもスパイ活動をしようとしているんです。
ex_1_en: Could you stop my daughter? She is recklessly engaging herself in espionage.
meaning_story: The conspiring I'm doing? Nothing... that's how much. If I don't conspire, I don't think about my actions. If I don't think, then I am just bing reckless and thoughtless.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 畑は違えど、新規市場を開拓するという点においては、前職とさほど変わりはないよ。
ex_1_en: Although it’s a completely different field, there isn’t much of a difference in terms of cultivating a new market.
meaning_story: Open up cultivation back on this land. It was closed before, due to it being a wasteland, but now it's time for reclamation and cultivation of this land.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: このカボチャのパイは、焼き上がりでも美味しく召し上がって頂けるのですが、私たちは御賞味の前に少し冷蔵庫に入れて頂くことを推奨しています。
ex_1_en: This pumpkin pie is delicious right after it’s been baked, but we recommend refrigerating for a short time before eating it.
meaning_story: I'd like to infer and encourage this item to you. It is my recommendation. It is my endorsement.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 花柳界を経験してみるのが夢だったんだ。
ex_1_en: I’ve always dreamed of experiencing the red-light district.
meaning_story: The red light district (花柳) world of the red light district is the red light district, though this can refer especially to the "pleasure quarters" or "world of the geisha" as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は痩身手術を受ける覚悟を決めました。
ex_1_en: I resigned myself to undergo weight loss surgery.
meaning_story: I've memorized this to the point of comprehension. It was my resolution to learn all this to comprehension. This way I have readiness.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私はうちの食堂を忙しいサラリーマンの憩いの場にしたいんです。
ex_1_en: I want to make my restaurant a place of rest and relaxation for busy salarymen.

reading_story: The reading comes from 憩う, so if you know that you can rest easy.

ex_1_jp: 逮捕された男は、休憩所に不法侵入した疑いがかけられていた。

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 高額な数珠を私に売りつけようとした男の名前が思い出せません。
ex_1_en: I can’t remember the name of the guy who tried to force me to buy an expensive rosary.

reading_story: The reading for this word is different from both of the kanji readings you learned. This word sounds a lot like Jews (じゅず), so we'll have to go with that. Just imagine a Jewish rosary or prayer beads, with a Jewish person using it.

ex_1_jp: その占い師に、私は奨学金をもらえるだろうって予言されたんだけど、当たったよ。
ex_1_en: The fortuneteller predicted that I would receive the scholarship and she was right.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ショーカ°クキン *** ショーカ°クꜜキン

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 母親が老衰で亡くなったとき、妻が「厄介者がいなくなってせいせいした」と独り言を言っているのを私は聞き漏らしませんでした。
ex_1_en: When my mother died from old age, I didn’t fail to hear my wife mutter, "that parasite is gone, good riddance," to herself.
meaning_story: An elderly person in decline is someone who is old and in decline. They are experiencing senility or senile decay.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 貧乏から金持ちに成り上がった人は、俗に成金と呼ばれます。
ex_1_en: People who went from rags to riches are commonly called nouveau riche.
meaning_story: Things that are vulgar are things like slang, local manners, or local customs.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 生理痛程度の陣痛が15分から20分ぐらいの間隔で始まって、今行った方がいいのか病院に電話をしました。
ex_1_en: Mild contractions are starting 15 to 20 minutes apart and I called the hospital to see if we should go now.
meaning_story: I'd like to isolate this interval of time. Take it, make it separate, and then look at it. A small gap is what this little isolated interval of time is.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は下戸でお酒を飲まないので、お酒のお勘定は割り勘じゃない方が嬉しいんですが。
ex_1_en: I can’t drink because I get drunk easily, so it would be nice if we didn’t split the alcohol bill.
meaning_story: I will divide the intuition up. For some reason when I say "intuition" I mean "money" because this is referring to splitting the cost, like when you're at a restaurant.
reading_story: The reading is 割る and 勘, put together.

ex_1_jp: 一生懸命粘り強く努力すればいつかは報われると思っていましたが、それは間違いでした。
ex_1_en: I believed hard work and persistent efforts would pay off some day, but it was wrong.
meaning_story: If 粘る is "to be sticky" then the noun version is stickiness.
reading_story: The reading comes from 粘る.

ex_1_jp: その教師は、教室で見て見ぬふりをされている問題に取り組む気概がなかった。
ex_1_en: The teacher didn’t have the guts to deal with the problems in the classroom.
meaning_story: A spirit of approximation is the approximation of spirit. My approximation of your spirit? I think you have a strong spirit. I think you have backbone.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 気温が上がるのは素晴らしいことだけど、私達は雪解け水による浸水を心配しています。
ex_1_en: It’s great that the temperature is rising, but we’re worried about a flood from the melting snow.
meaning_story: Immersed in water. That sounds like submersion. Possibly like a flood, even.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 「ねぇ、今俺のこと、嘘つきって言った？」「そうは言ってないけど、詐欺師とは言ったよ。」「はぁ？何言ってんだよ。マジ、信じらんねぇ。」
ex_1_en: "Hey, did you just call me a liar?" "No, but I called you a crook." "Huh? What are you talking about!? I seriously can’t believe you."
meaning_story: You know that 詐欺 is "fraud." An expert at fraud (詐欺) is someone who does this a lot and possibly for a living. A swindler, some would say.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the reading of 詐欺 as well.

ex_1_jp: この投資に関して、どのようなリスクを勘案していますか。
ex_1_en: What kinds of risks have you taken into considered concerning this investment?
meaning_story: Using our intuition we will come up with a plan. We'll be taking into consideration the information we have along with our intuition, so don't worry.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私の妻は私の背広をハンガーに掛る時に、「今日も一日お仕事お疲れ様でした」といつも言ってくれるんです。
ex_1_en: When my wife puts my jacket on the hanger she always says, "Thank you for working hard again today."
meaning_story: You are a 疲れ (tired) 様 (honorific that kind of refers to whoever's being mentioned with this word). You say this to people after a day of hard work or after a good practice, etc. お疲れ様でした! I suppose the assumption here is that everyone worked until they were tired, so it was a good work, and then you thank them for it and mention how tired everyone is.
reading_story: The reading comes from 疲れ and 様, combined together into one word.

ex_1_jp: 今、彼は私のこと嫌っているから、私の立場は挨拶程度の人よりも劣っているってのははっきりしてるわ。
ex_1_en: Now, because he hates me, I’m pretty sure he sees me as nothing but a nodding acquaintance, who is clearly inferior to him.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means inferiority and the verb vocab version is to be inferior to.
reading_story: When thinking about cars, an automatic (おと) car is inferior to a manual car. Sure, manual is harder, but way more interesting to drive.

ex_1_jp: このローションを使えば、あなたのお肌はプルプルに潤いますよ。
ex_1_en: If you use this lotion your skin will moisturize your skin so that it’s firm and soft.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means watered. When something is watered, it is moist and damp. That's why this verb is to be moist or to be damp or to be watered.
reading_story: If you get moist and damp, then you're all (うるお) wet. It's just how it is.

ex_1_jp: お風呂で図書館から借りたホーソンの『巌の顔』を読んでいたんですが、うっかりお湯に浸ってしまったんです。
ex_1_en: I was reading Hawthorne’s "The Great Stone Face" that I borrowed from a library in the bath and thoughtlessly soaked it in bathwater.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means immersed. Things that are immersed are described by verbs like to be soaked in or to be submerged or to be flooded.
reading_story: What is soaked and submerged in water (that shouldn't be)? It is your heater (ひた). It's all soaked and doesn't work anymore :(

ex_1_jp: 今日は、この脂ののった秋鮭を煮てみたいと思います。
ex_1_en: We are going to simmer this fatty autumn salmon today.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means boil and the verb vocab version is to boil.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: スポーツはずっとそんなに好きではなかったんですが、一度野球の試合を見に行った時にそれが覆りまして、今ではマリナーズの大ファンです。
ex_1_en: I didn’t always like sports, but that was overturned once I went to see a baseball game and now I’m a big fan of the Mariners.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means capsize and the verb vocab version is to capsize or to topple over.
reading_story: Of all the people to capsize or to topple over, it's the 靴 guy (くつがえ) who falls over, despite how proud he is of his shoes. His shoe caught on something and he toppled over. Quite sad, considering.

ex_1_jp: あいつらはフィレンツェのダビデ像の前でのドラマチックな暗殺を謀っているんだ。
ex_1_en: They’re plotting a dramatic assassination in front of the Statue of David in Florence.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conspire and the verb vocab version is to conspire or to plot.
reading_story: A group of hackers (はか) are getting together and trying to conspire and plot to take down the mainframe! Those hackers!

ex_1_jp: 数年前にこの牛肉を食べた時は、非常に良く熟成されて霜が降っていることに感動したんですが、今はちょっと味が衰えたみたいでとても残念ですね。
ex_1_en: When I had this beef several years ago I was really impressed by how well it was aged and marbled, but the taste seems to have declined a bit and I’m really disappointed.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decline and the verb vocab version is to decline.
reading_story: You're wandering through the jungle exploring, when you come upon a deep pit. Since you're looking for treasure, you decide to go down into the pit to look for some. You take out your handy auto rope (おとろ), made of organic, environment friendly materials, and easily rappel down into the pit. Unfortunately, you get lost down there, and it takes you fifty years to get back to the pit you came in from. But your auto rope is gone! This is the last time you buy an organic rope, made to decay and to wither away when left in the wild.
pitch_accent: オトロエꜜル *** オトロꜜエル

ex_1_jp: DVDはここから挿入できるよ。
ex_1_en: You can insert the DVD from here.
meaning_story: 挿入 is "insertion" so the verb version is to insert.
reading_story: The reading comes from 挿入, so if you know that you can insert this reading into your memory no problem.

ex_1_jp: 私のアパートでは、浴槽と洗面所はシャワーカーテン一枚で隔てられています。
ex_1_en: In my apartment, the bathtub and the washroom are separated by a single shower curtain.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means isolate and the verb vocab version is to isolate or to partition or to separate. You get the idea, anyways.
reading_story: Why did you have to isolate him from the rest of the soccer players? Because all he could do was headers (へだ) and that was getting pretty dangerous. He would head everything in his reach. He was going crazy with headers. He had to be isolated!

ex_1_jp: 私の実家は農家で米を育てているので、今週末は稲の刈り取りを手伝わなきゃいけないんです。
ex_1_en: My parents are farmers who raise rice so I have to help them harvest rice this weekend.
meaning_story: If you prune and take from what you pruned, you're going to mow or to reap or to harvest whatever it is you're pruning.
reading_story: The reading is the reading you learned with 刈 and the reading from the vocab 取る.

ex_1_jp: 彼女のお婆さんが、「あの子の人見知りは哀れむべきものだ」とぼやくのを聞きました。
ex_1_en: I heard her grandmother grumble, "That girl’s shyness should be pitied."
meaning_story: If something is pathetic then you should try to pity that thing.
reading_story: Awww (あわ), you're so pathetic it's cute! I will pity you. Reading also comes from 哀れ.

ex_1_jp: 草を刈り終わったから、放してやってよ。
ex_1_en: I’ve finished mowing the grass, so turn him loose.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means prune and the verb vocab version is to prune (or to mow or to cut).
reading_story: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 背中の曲がったお婆さんは、不法滞在者として拘置所に拘留された時、そこで自分が死を迎えることになることを悟りました。
ex_1_en: When the hunchbacked old lady was sent to a detention center for being an illegal immigrant, she realized that it would be where she met her death.
meaning_story: If you have comprehension, then you are probably going to realize something about something else. Comprehension leads to realization, after all.
reading_story: You realized something so amazing that you couldn't believe it. That comprehension, wow! The realization was so big that you sat (さと) down in disbelief. If you didn't you would have fallen on the ground.

ex_1_jp: あんたはまずその紫外線恐怖症を克服しなきゃいけないね。
ex_1_en: You must first conquer your fear of the ultra violet rays.
meaning_story: The purple outside line is the color spectrum that's outside purple. Those are ultra violet rays (the lines are the rays).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 定額給付金は一概に良い事だとは言えない。
ex_1_en: I can’t say that tax rebates are unconditionally good things.
meaning_story: We're moving towards one approximation. It used to be more approximations, but now it's just one, and because it's just one it's not really an approximation anymore. It's unconditionally set. It's set as a rule.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: イチカ°イニ *** イチꜜカ°イニ

ex_1_jp: 彼は剛健な昔の武士のような見た目だが、彼の足にある血豆を誤って押してしまった時に、泣き叫んでいました。
ex_1_en: He looks like a strong warrior of long ago, but he wailed when I accidentally pressed a blister on his foot.
meaning_story: When you are sturdy and healthy you are full of vigor and virility.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女はいつも制服の上に紫色のベストを着ている。
ex_1_en: She always wears a violet colored vest over her school uniform.
meaning_story: A purple color is a violet color, mainly, for some reason, though I'll let "purple" slide as well.
reading_story: The reading for 紫 is different from the one you learned with the kanji. To remember this reading, think about how the previous village you went to was all purple. It was the "村先" (むらさき) that you went to. Everything. Absolutely everything was purple.

ex_1_jp: 結婚の誓いの言葉を述べている時、自分が間違った男の人と結婚しようとしていることは分かっていました。
ex_1_en: When I was saying my wedding vows I knew I was marrying the wrong man.
meaning_story: This looks like an adjective, but it's actually a noun. This word is the same as the kanji meaning: vow (or oath).
reading_story: This has the same reading as 近い (ちかい). Just think about how when you're making a vow or oath, you become closer to the thing or person you're vowing too. You belong to them, in a way, which is why you become close (近い).

ex_1_jp: こちらが誓約書となっておりまして、こちらとこちらにサインをして頂く必要があります。
ex_1_en: Here is the written pledge. You need to sign it here and here.
meaning_story: A vow promise is the promise that you made with your vow. It is often thought of as a written vow, but you can call it a pledge or covenant as well.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 陛下、恐れ入りますが会議にご出席のご予定だったのでは。
ex_1_en: Your Majesty, I’m sorry to impose but you were supposed to attend the meeting.
meaning_story: Your highness I am so below you because your majesty is so great and amazing!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 帳簿を燃やしてしまうという考えは思いつきませんでした。
ex_1_en: I didn’t think of the idea to burn the account book.
meaning_story: A notebook that is also a record book is an account book or register, showing the records of all the transactions that have gone through.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: チョーボ *** チョꜜーボ

ex_1_jp: 話が巧すぎるぜ。何か企んでるだろ？
ex_1_en: It’s too good to be true. What are you scheming?
meaning_story: You're so adept! That makes you adept at that thing. Skillful and clever are other ways to do it too.
reading_story: Remember 旨い, which means "delicious"? Remember how it also means "skillful" and "clever"? It's the same with this word, and the reading is the same as well.

ex_1_jp: 鰐の剥製が部屋に飾ってあります。
ex_1_en: I have an stuffed alligator displayed in my room.
meaning_story: The great alligator! This can mean both alligator or crocodile, because really, they're not so different, are they? No crabigator, that's for sure.
reading_story: The reading is a reading you've known your whole life. It's like you were born with the reading, whispering in your ear, ready to emerge at just the right moment... and that moment is now.

ex_1_jp: 近年その古墳を訪れる人が増えています。
ex_1_en: The number of people visiting the ancient tomb has been increasing in recent years.
meaning_story: An old tomb is an ancient tomb though it can refer to the ancient mounds (of the Jomon, I'm assuming).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 伯母はどうして私達の結婚式に来ようとしなかったんだろう。
ex_1_en: I wonder why my aunt didn’t come to our wedding ceremony.
meaning_story: The chief mother isn't your own mother, but she is the chief of your mother. She's your mother's lady sibling, who has always owned your mom. She's the chief mother. She's your aunt.
reading_story: The reading for the 母 part is just the first は in はは, rendaku'd. You can also think of your aunt as a sheep, too, if you'd like.

ex_1_jp: 後どれくらいでお客さんに推奨する銘柄が決まりそうですか。
ex_1_en: How much longer will it take you to decide which brand to recommend to your customer?
meaning_story: The inscription's pattern shows what brand or make this item is. If the pattern of the inscription is an apple, you'll know the brand is Apple. If it's a Window, you know it's Microsoft. Etc.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 空港で偶然、高校時代の友人に会ったんですよ。
ex_1_en: I unexpectedly ran into a friend from high school at the airport.
meaning_story: Accidentally but naturally (as in nothing was set up artificially before). So, the accident was a true, natural accident. This kind of accident is something that happens by chance, unexpectedly.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日曜の夜七時までに全ての作品を搬出する必要があります。
ex_1_en: We need to carry out all of our work by 7pm on Sunday night.
meaning_story: Transport and exit these goods from here (by transporting them). Take it away. It's time to carry out.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その薄気味悪い洞は、村の北外れにひっそりと佇んでいました。
ex_1_en: The eerie cave stood silently in the outskirts north of the village.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Hoe Ra (ほら), the version of Ra who carries a hoe around, is using said hoe to dig out a cave for himself, to provide shade from the sun (despite being the god of sun). He digs digs digs and then sits in his nice cave, hoe in hand.

ex_1_jp: その洞穴で躓いて、足首を捻挫しました。
ex_1_en: I stumbled into the cave and sprained my ankle.
meaning_story: A cave hole is a cave or den.
reading_story: The reading of 洞 is one you've learned. The reading of 穴 isn't one you've learned, though. So, think about how you go inside this cave, only to find yourself covered by some red goopy liquid. You think it's blood, but luckily it just turns out to be ketsup (けつ).
pitch_accent: ドーケツ *** ホラアナ

ex_1_jp: 白熊が木の空洞の中でうたた寝をしていると、近くに木こりがやって来ました。
ex_1_en: A polar bear was snoozing in the hollow of a tree and a lumberjack soon came along.
meaning_story: A sky cave is a cave with sky (open space) in it. This is a cave, but can also refer to a hollow or cavity in something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この結婚について、絶対に翻意することがないことを誓います。
ex_1_en: I swear, I will absolutely not change my mind about this marriage.
meaning_story: When you flip your idea of something, you're changing how you think about it. That's why this word is change one's mind.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: フグの爵位を伯爵にして、フグ伯って呼ぶことにするのはどうかな。
ex_1_en: How about giving Fugu the title of an earl, and calling him Count Fugu?
meaning_story: The chief of this district is that guy, the count. He's also the earl of another district, and the chief of yet another.
reading_story: The reading is the はく reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 「なんで母親の葬式に来ないの？」「風邪ひいてるからだよ。」
ex_1_en: "Why aren’t you coming to your mom’s funeral?" "’Cause I caught a cold."
meaning_story: A wind that is wicked comes and blows on you. It's so cold, and ends up getting you sick. You now have a cold.
reading_story: Strangely, the reading for this word is the same as the vocab reading of 風 (かぜ). That's probably going to be the easiest way to remember this, especially since otherwise the reading would be one big horrible exception.

ex_1_jp: 父の弁当は、彩りについて全く考慮がされておらず、全部茶色だったので嫌でしたね。
ex_1_en: I didn’t like my dad’s bento because he never really took coloring into account and all of it was brown.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji and has the same meaning as well: coloring.
reading_story: The reading has いろ (like 色) in it, then a ど, so think about an 色 dog, running around coloring things, because that's what an 色 dog does.
pitch_accent: イロドリ *** イロドリꜜ

ex_1_jp: 漫才を見て大声で笑うことはストレス解消になる。
ex_1_en: Watching two man comedy acts and laughing loudly relieves my stress.
meaning_story: A manga genius! For some reason, this is a comic dialogue or two man comedy. Look up "manzai" on YouTube for some good times if you don't know what this is. It's not exactly the same, but 漫 DOES refer to manga, which is a type of comic book. Take the "comic" part from "comic" book, then change it to the "haha funny!" meaning of "comic," and then imagine people doing a dialogue. Then, you have a comic dialogue. Lots of steps, but hopefully it'll get you there.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: もし私の日本語に間違いがあれば、その場で訂正してもらってもいいですか？
ex_1_en: If I make a mistake in Japanese would you mind correcting it on the spot for me?
meaning_story: When you revise something to make it correct you are doing a correction and revision.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: わっ！ほうれん草一把で九十八円だって。
ex_1_en: Wow! A bundle of spinach is only ninety-eight yen!
meaning_story: The kanji refers to a bundle, but this refers to a counter for bundles. Put this on a number, and you have "1 bundle" or "2 bundles" or even three, oh my!
reading_story: The reading is the わ reading you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: あとどれくらい私達がこの法廷にいることになるか分かりますか？
ex_1_en: Do you know how much longer we will be in this courtroom?
meaning_story: The law courts are the courts you visit to get law distributed. The room in which you do this in is a courtroom.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お腹がすいてきた。晩ご飯の蟹が楽しみだ。
ex_1_en: I’m getting hungry. I’m looking forward to having crab for dinner.
meaning_story: The meaning is the same as the kanji's meaning, crab. If you know this word, and you know the word 鰐 as well... then, well, you know something, though I'm not sure what that something is.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. But you knew that already, didn't you?

ex_1_jp: この水晶は大中小の三つの大きさがあります。
ex_1_en: This crystal comes in three sizes; small, medium, and large.
meaning_story: A water crystal is just a crystal. I guess crystals are clear and look kind of like water, yeah? That's why it's being referred to as a water crystal, making it really just a crystal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私の息子は、ある日突然、堰を切ったように日本語をペラペラ話し始めたんです。
ex_1_en: One day, my son suddenly started speaking Japanese fluently, as if a dam in him had been broken.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 私達は彼のピアノの演奏に深く感銘を受けました。
ex_1_en: We were deeply impressed by his piano performance.
meaning_story: A feeling of inscription is the feeling one gets when something so strong happens that it's like the feeling gets inscribed into your soul. This is something that left a very deep impression.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あいつは悪賢い男で、猫かぶりが大のお得意なんだ。
ex_1_en: He’s such a cunning guy and he’s very good at feigning innocence too.
meaning_story: Someone who is bad but also clever (賢い) is someone who is using their cleverness for evil. When you refer to clever evil people, usually you describe them not as "clever" but as devious, cunning, or other things.
reading_story: The reading is 悪い and 賢い combined together into one word. Be careful of the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 帆が折れて、ヨットが海に漂流し始めた時は、ちょっと悲観的でしたね。
ex_1_en: When the mast broke and my yacht started drifting out to sea, I got a little pessimistic.
meaning_story: Drifting down the stream. Something that is doing this is drifting. It could also be the drift of something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 傷ついた赤ちゃん鯨が、とある砂浜に漂着するところを想像してみてください。
ex_1_en: Imagine a wounded baby whale drifting ashore onto a sandy beach.
meaning_story: Something has drifted to the point where it has arrived. Where do drifting things arrive? They arrive on shore (as they drift on top of water). That makes this word drifting ashore.
reading_story: This word uses the on'yomi readings for the kanji. You'll need to remember the on'yomi reading of 着 for this word by looking back at the word 執着 where you first learned this reading.

ex_1_jp: うちの家族の銘々がその写真を持っています。
ex_1_en: Each member of my family has this photo.
meaning_story: You look at this inscription then you look at that inscription and you notice that each one is an individual inscription.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 水が堤防を越えそうになっているから、近づかない方がいいですよ。
ex_1_en: The water is almost running over the embankment, so you should be careful.
meaning_story: The embankment prevents the water from going over the edge. It's an embankment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 村長は、堤が切れるのを防ぐため、堤に人柱を埋めることを決意しました。
ex_1_en: The village head decided to bury a human sacrifice in the embankment to prevent it from collapsing.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: The reading is like the reading of 包み, which means "bundle" or "package." Try to think of an embankment that's made purely from bundles and packages. These 包み (つつみ) are the only thing holding the water in!

ex_1_jp: 止まれの標識を無視する度に、興奮するんです。
ex_1_en: Every time I ignore a stop sign I get excited.
meaning_story: My interest is stirred up! I'm feeling excitement and stimulation from all this stirring up, in fact!
reading_story: The reading for 興奮 is one you didn't learn with the kanji, though it's similar. Instead of きょう it's こう, so just think of how whenever you feel excitement, it's thanks to こういち. So just think of こういち exciting you in some way to remember this vocab's reading.

ex_1_jp: 俺の連れは今クラブで殴り合いの喧嘩の真っ最中さ。
ex_1_en: My man is in the middle of the fist fight in the club.
meaning_story: Remember 殴る, which means "to assault"? This is when your assaults are join with other assaults. By "joined" I mean your fist is coming in contact with their face, and their fist is coming in contact with your kidneys. This is a fistfight.
reading_story: The readings come from 殴る and 合う, punched together.

ex_1_jp: 言うだけ無駄だよ。フグは決して忠告には耳を貸さないんだから。
ex_1_en: Just saying it is useless. Fugu never listens to advice.
meaning_story: Nothing but burdensome. That's all you get out of doing this task. The futility of it is ridiculous. The uselessness is huge.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: こちらの下駄は二色のお色をご用意しております。
ex_1_en: These wooden clogs come in two colors.
meaning_story: Look below you. These things carry your burdensome weight. All of it. These are the shoes you wear, though in this case they are specifically geta, or Japanese wooden clogs. The clogs themselves are kind of burdensome and hard to wear too, actually, so you can think of it that way as well.
reading_story: The reading for 駄 is the secondary kanji reading. Instead of だ it's た. Hopefully you've heard of "geta" before. This will make it really easy for you to remember the reading of this vocab word.

ex_1_jp: 「この女マジ鬱陶しいんだけど。」「よー。気にすんなって。」
ex_1_en: "This girl is so depressing." "Yo, don’t worry about it."
meaning_story: Gloom pottery is... well, it's gloomy. And it puts me in a gloomy mood. It's depressing, really!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening, and don't be tricked by the hiragana sticking out. The readings of the kanji don't change.

meaning_story: A gloomy energy has filled the room. This makes for a gloomy feeling. One of melancholy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the shortening of 鬱 or you'll feel gloomy.

ex_1_jp: 正直、まだ事態の把握すら出来ていない状況です。
ex_1_en: Honestly, I haven’t even been able to grasp the overall situation yet.
meaning_story: Using the grasp meaning of 把 and combining it with grip, you can tell you're grasping at something and then gripping it. I usually grasp then grip at things flying at me, which makes this word mean grasp or catch.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ツタンカーメンの墳墓は絶対に訪れた方がいいよ。
ex_1_en: You should definitely visit the tomb of Tutankhamen.
meaning_story: A tomb grave is a grave... or it could be a tomb. Or maybe both.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 麻布の服が好きなんだけど、結構お値段が高いんだよね。
ex_1_en: I like clothes made of hemp cloth, but they’re rather expensive.
meaning_story: A hemp cloth is a hemp cloth.
reading_story: The reading is the individual vocab readings of 麻 and 布 combined together.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NA ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 私の邪魔をするな。一人で出来るよ！
ex_1_en: Don’t stand in my way. I can do it by myself!
meaning_story: A wicked devil! Ugh, I hate those things. They're always a hindrance and intrusion. Just imagine a wicked devil hanging out in your house, eating your food, and sleeping on your bed. What a hindrance.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 飢えに苦しむ子どもたちの写真を見る度に胸が痛みます。
ex_1_en: My heart aches whenever I see the pictures of those starving children.
meaning_story: You've seen that 飢える is "to starve." The noun version is hunger or starvation.
reading_story: The reading comes from 飢える.

ex_1_jp: いつも微熱とひどい頭痛があるのでお医者さんに行ったら、免疫機能が弱ってきていると言われました。
ex_1_en: I went to the doctor because I always have a slight fever and terrible headache, and I was told that my immune system is weakening.
meaning_story: To excuse yourself from the epidemic, you'll have to have immunity or immunization from the disease.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 宮廷では咳風邪が流行っています。
ex_1_en: A chest cold is going around the Imperial Court.
meaning_story: A shinto shrine courts are the courts of the Shinto shrines. Shinto is often associated with the emperor, which is why this the imperial court. Royal court will do as well.
reading_story: The reading for 宮 is one you haven't seen before. Just think about how cute (きゅう) this imperial court is. It's a My Little Pony imperial court, or something.

ex_1_jp: その村の人々は、全員疫病で亡くなりました。
ex_1_en: Everyone in that village died from the plague.
meaning_story: An epidemic if sickness is going to come from an infectious disease. Perhaps a plague or epidemic of some kind?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: エキビョー *** エキꜜビョー *** ヤクꜜビョー *** ヤクビョー

ex_1_jp: ある邪悪な魔法使いが、巧妙に偶然を装って女性に近づきました。
ex_1_en: The evil witch cleverly pretended to approach the girl by mere chance.
meaning_story: Something that is adept but strange in how adept it is would have to be something truly ingenious and skillful. Like looking at alien technology.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 子供達は無邪気に笑い合っていた。
ex_1_en: The children laughed innocently.
meaning_story: If there is nothing wicked about your spirit at all, you are a going to be an innocent and simple minded person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は誤って皇后であった母親を殺害してしまいました。
ex_1_en: He accidentally killed his mother, the Japanese Empress.
meaning_story: The emperor empress is the emperor's wife. That's the Japanese Empress, specifically, since 皇 usually refers to the Japanese emperor.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 俺の投げたライターがテレビに当たって、液晶画面にヒビが入りました。
ex_1_en: The lighter I threw hit the TV and cracked the LCD screen.
meaning_story: A fluid crystal is a liquid crystal.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: なんて壮大な曲なんだ。凄く感動しています。
ex_1_en: This is such a magnificent song. I’m so impressed.
meaning_story: It's so robust and big! Things like this are magnificent, grand, and epic!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 漫画には色々な形式があります。
ex_1_en: There are various styles in manga.
meaning_story: A manga drawing is manga, aka Japanese comics.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今日の連峰はよく晴れていて見晴らしがいいです。
ex_1_en: Today’s mountain range cleared up nicely and the view is great.
meaning_story: Take along this summit and move it across a range, visiting more summits. One summit after another you take the summit along to. By covering this many summits, you notice there's a string of mountains. This is a mountain range!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 男の子と旅行に行くのは、絶対に駄目ですからね！
ex_1_en: You absolutely cannot go on a trip with a boy!
meaning_story: If something is burdensome to the eye (when you look at it), you know that that thing is not good or hopeless. Just look at that burdensome thing with your eye. This can also mean not allowed. Parents say this to their kids all the time.
reading_story: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: 偶にぎっくり腰になるんですよね。
ex_1_en: I strain my back every once in a while.
meaning_story: Something you do accidentally is hopefully something you do occasionally or once in a while.
reading_story: For the reading, think about the word 弾 (たま), which means bullet, and how you occasionally shoot people with bullets when you're out hunting... but not too often. Dick Cheney level.

ex_1_jp: 生涯ずっと独身なんて嫌だよう。
ex_1_en: I don’t want to stay single my whole life.
meaning_story: A life horizon is your life, which you're looking out over, all the way to the very end. This is one's lifetime, though it could also refer to one's career. Basically, at the end of it something dies.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ロケットが軌道に入ったというニュースを聞いて、誰もが喜びました。
ex_1_en: Everyone was delighted to hear the news that the rocket entered orbit.
meaning_story: A rut in the road is for some reason an orbit or trajectory. Maybe imagine a big ol' rut in the road. You drive at it at very high speeds, hit it, and fly into the sky at a trajectory that will send you into orbit. Now you're up in space, circling the earth, wishing you didn't drive so fast.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 仰々しい言葉遣いをする人は嫌いです。
ex_1_en: I hate people who use pompous wording.
meaning_story: You look up to someone... twice. That's too many times that you're looking up to someone. They must be pretty amazing for that to happen. Really, though, you're being fooled. This person is pompous and exaggerated. So you think they're cool, but really they're pretending to be more than they are.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, x2 with a しい added on for good measure.

ex_1_jp: 彼のお兄さんは壮年期に心臓発作を起こして亡くなりました。
ex_1_en: His older brother had a heart attack and passed away in the prime of life.
meaning_story: Your robust years are the best years of your life! This is the prime of life.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 表彰式には出席せずに帰ってきてしまいました。
ex_1_en: I came home without attending the awards ceremony.
meaning_story: I'd like to express patently that you really are the hoopiest frood to walk this earth. I will express this to the world, in fact. This is a public acknowledgement of your skills. A public recognition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: オーストラリアの検疫法はすっごく厳しいから、食べ物は何も持って行かない方が身のためだよ。
ex_1_en: Australia’s quarantine laws are very strict, so you shouldn’t take any food there.
meaning_story: We have to examine you during this epidemic... soooo, if you could come over here and just stay here for a long time, that'd be great. Yeah, it's kind of a quarantine, sorry about that.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: その日は経済財政諮問会議が開催される予定です。
ex_1_en: The Council on Economic and Fiscal Policy plans to hold a meeting on the same day.
meaning_story: I need to consult you on this problem, if I could. I have a question / enquiry I'd like to ask you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私はそのダイヤモンドの輝きに目がくらんでしまいました。
ex_1_en: I was disoriented by the radiance of the diamond.
meaning_story: If 輝く is "to shine" or "to glitter" think about the noun version of this. This would be radiance. Radiance can come in the form of shining and glittering.
reading_story: The reading comes from 輝く.
pitch_accent: カカ°ヤキ *** カカ°ヤキꜜ *** カカ°ヤꜜキ

ex_1_jp: 殴り込みの前に早めの昼食を取りました。
ex_1_en: We had an early lunch before the raid.
meaning_story: To assault then crowd. That means you're assaulting a place, then crowding into it, presumably doing a raid on the place.
reading_story: The reading comes from 殴る and 込む.

ex_1_jp: 彼は仰向けに寝転がって、名簿の全ての名前に目を通した。
ex_1_en: He laid face up and looked through all the names in the register.
meaning_story: A name record book is a book that contains names. That is a register of names or a list of names. Is your name on the list?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私はキリスト教を信仰していて、神への揺るぎない思いを持っています。
ex_1_en: I believe in Christianity and I have unwavering faith in God.
meaning_story: I believe and look up to a higher power, for I have religious faith.
reading_story: The reading for the 仰 portion is an exceptional one. Instead of ぎょう it's こう. Just remember, when it comes to religious faith, all you need to believe in is こういち.

ex_1_jp: 多くの人が、コウイチは最初のレストランを「Tofugu亭」と名付けるのではないかと踏んでいる。
ex_1_en: Many people think that Koichi would name his first restaurant Tofugutei.
meaning_story: If you see the kanji restaurant attached to a place name, there's a good chance that it's a restaurant. Usually refers to a traditional Japanese restaurant, though.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

ex_1_jp: バスの時刻が改訂されたなら、改訂版の時刻表をもらわなきゃ。
ex_1_en: If the bus schedule was revised, I need the revised edition.
meaning_story: The renewed and revised edition of something is the revised edition.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 彼のために金曜日壮行会を予定してるんですが、ご都合は如何ですか？
ex_1_en: We are planning a farewell party for him on Friday. Are you available?
meaning_story: Feeling so robust I just want to get up and go! It's so rousing!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 新しい配偶者を探そうかとずっと考えているんです。
ex_1_en: I’ve been thinking about looking for a new spouse.
meaning_story: Distribute yourself accidentally to someone. That person ended up becoming your spouse. You distributed yourself to one person a little too much, it seems.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女の一言が、彼を奮起させ、受験勉強をさせた。
ex_1_en: Her one word roused him to study for the test.
meaning_story: I'm stirred up causing me to wake up. I'm stirring and rousing oneself.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女、唐突に車の修理をしてほしいって俺に頼んできたんだよ。
ex_1_en: She suddenly asked me to repair her car.
meaning_story: A stab from China is sudden and unexpected. Whoa, what? China, why would you stab me? I thought we were neighbors? No, I thought we were friends?!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 妹と私は、雲の上にそびえる富士山の峰に登頂しました。
ex_1_en: My sister and I climbed up to the peak of Mt. Fuji, rising up above the clouds.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be peak or ridge.
reading_story: Look up at the summit. It's such a mean (みね) summit. So big, so stormy, so mean.

ex_1_jp: 私は真美がどれだけ速くベーコンを食べれるのかってことにびっくり仰天しました。
ex_1_en: I was astonished at how quickly Mami could eat bacon.
meaning_story: I look up to heaven, and I am taken aback and amazed by it. It's just so amazing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ギョーテン *** ギョーテꜜン

ex_1_jp: 今日は、昨年の英語学習の軌跡を辿っています。
ex_1_en: Today I’m going down the path I took to learn English last year.
meaning_story: Rut traces left in the road are usually left by tires. This is a tire track left on the ground.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 諦めないで！やり遂げるんだ！お前なら出来るよ！
ex_1_en: Don’t give up! Accomplish it! You can do it!
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accomplish and the verb vocab version is to accomplish.
reading_story: Everything you've accomplished can put stored in your single little pinky toe (と)... you haven't accomplished that much, apparently.

ex_1_jp: あの部屋に明かりが灯るのを見たんだ。
ex_1_en: I can see light burning in that room.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lamp, so the verb version is to burn or to be lit. Just like what you'd do with a lamp.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who wanted the candle to be lit? Tom (とも) Cruise. He's afraid of the dark so he always wants all the lights and candles in the house to be burning at all times.

ex_1_jp: この問題は取締役会に諮る必要があります。
ex_1_en: We need to discuss this problem at the board of directors meeting.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means consult and the verb vocab version is to consult with or to discuss.
reading_story: You need to consult with a hacker (はか) to solve your hacking problem. Imagine consulting with a hacker, whatever a hacker looks like in your mind.

ex_1_jp: 焼き芋を食べた後のおならは、他のおならよりも長い間空気中を漂う気がするよ。
ex_1_en: Farts after eating roasted sweet potatoes seem to hang in the air longer than normal farts.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drift and the verb vocab version is to drift.
reading_story: You're going to drift away. Drifting drifting drifting. Then, you turn into a yo-yo and yell "ta da yo-yo (ただよ)! Not sure why drifting turns you into a yo-yo, but imagine it and don't question it.

ex_1_jp: 「これ、明日までにできるかな？」「わかりました。最善を尽くします。」
ex_1_en: "Can you do this by tomorrow?" "I see, I’ll give it my best."
meaning_story: 尽きる is "to exhaust." 尽くす is when you're doing the exhausting of something, which makes it to exhaust or to run out.
reading_story: The reading comes from 尽きる.

ex_1_jp: 彼女のスカートが風で翻ったのは分かるんですが、その時の彼の心象を翻訳するのは私には難しすぎます。
ex_1_en: I know her skirt fluttered in the wind, but rendering how I felt at the time is too difficult.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means flip and the verb vocab version is to flip or to turn over.
reading_story: The here guy (ひるがえ) is the guy who's here right now. He's here, and he's ready to flip over.

ex_1_jp: 色んな人から、彼の指導を仰げば間違いないと言われましたが、それは明らかに間違いでした。
ex_1_en: I was told by various people that if I looked to him for guidance it could be trusted, but that was clearly a mistake.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means look up to and the verb vocab version is to look up at or to look up to.
reading_story: Personally, I look up to the color 青 (あお). Literally and figuratively. I love the color blue, so I look up to it and respect it. Also, I look up at the sky and it's blue.

ex_1_jp: あの光り輝く星々が、夜空に溶けるのを想像してみてください。
ex_1_en: Imagine that the glittering stars are all melting into the night sky.
meaning_story: 溶かす is "to melt something" and that makes 溶ける to melt (where something just melts, and you're not doing the melting).
reading_story: The reading comes from 溶かす.

ex_1_jp: ガンガン響く頭と共に目を覚ます度に、前日の夜飲み過ぎたことを悔やみます。
ex_1_en: Whenever I wake up with a pounding headache, I lament drinking too much the night before.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means regret and the verb vocab version is to regret or to mourn.
reading_story: The reading comes from 悔しい.

ex_1_jp: その教師は何名かの男子生徒を刃物で脅したとして解雇されました。
ex_1_en: That teacher was fired because he threatened some male students with a knife.
meaning_story: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means threaten and the verb vocab version is to threaten.
reading_story: I'm going to threaten you with your life if you have a bad odor (おど). Imagine someone with a bad odor, then threaten them.

ex_1_jp: ちょうど君の翻訳を見させてもらってたところだよ。
ex_1_en: I was just looking over your translation.
meaning_story: Flip the translation of a word from one language to another. That is the translation of that word (or phrase, etc).
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: このレストランには、食事やその他の細々したものを運搬するためのミニエレベータがあります。
ex_1_en: There is a mini elevator used to transport food and other small things in this restaurant.
meaning_story: To carry you and transport you. That's a form of transport. Could also be a carriage, which is also a form of transport.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND TRANSITIVE VERB
ex_1_jp: 搬送作業時に左肩を脱臼してしまいました。
ex_1_en: I dislocated my left shoulder when I was doing conveyance work.
meaning_story: Things that transport and send you places are forms of transportation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 伯父は銀行員です。
ex_1_en: My uncle is a banker.
meaning_story: The chief father isn't your own father, but he is the chief of your father. He's your father's older brother, who has always owned your father. He's your uncle. This word can be used for your mother's brother too, but in both cases he has to be the older brother, not younger.
reading_story: The reading for this is an exception, at least the 父 part is, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: Your uncle is a very religious man, he is the chief, after all. Whenever you see him he's always shouting, "Oh Jesus! (おじ)" at the sky. Your uncle and Jesus are pretty close.

ex_1_jp: 神様は私の邪な心を見透かしていらっしゃったんだわ。
ex_1_en: God saw through my wicked heart.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This is a long reading for such a short word! The Think of something being wicked. Evil, even! But what is wicked? It's the side of the island... but only the side. It's the 横 島 (よこしま).

ex_1_jp: 汚い水にも怯まず、彼女は淀川で泳いだ。
ex_1_en: The dirty water didn’t stop her swimming in the Yodogawa.
meaning_story: The eddy river isn't so much a thing as it is a famous place. We're talking about Yodogawa. It might be better to look at the reading to learn the meaning. Look up this Osaka Prefecture river if you'd like more info.
reading_story: The reading is 淀 plus 川. Be careful of the rendaku.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は慈愛に満ちた微笑を僕に向けた。
ex_1_en: She turned her affectionate smile toward me.
meaning_story: When you have mercy upon those you love it's called affection. You end up doing things out of the kindness of your heart because they mean a lot to you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この辺りには耕地が広がっています。
ex_1_en: The arable land is spread out in this area.
meaning_story: Plowed land is called arable land. This is the kind of land you use for growing crops or for pastures.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 大学の入学式で、学生たちに飲酒やカルト宗教についての注意喚起が行われました。
ex_1_en: At the university entrance ceremony the students were alerted to the dangers of alcohol and cults.
meaning_story: If you scream wake up! at someone you can bet they're going to awaken. Screaming anything at a sleeping person would probably rouse them. They'll probably be mad at you though.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 駿河湾西沿岸は田子ノ浦と呼ばれます。
ex_1_en: The west coast of Suruga Bay is called Takono Bay.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 沸点は何度ですか。
ex_1_en: How many degrees is the boiling point?
meaning_story: The point at which something starts to boil is the boiling point.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: フッテン *** フꜜッテン

ex_1_jp: 瓶ビールを一本ください。
ex_1_en: One bottled beer, please.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: メープルシロップを瓶詰しています。
ex_1_en: I’m bottling maple syrup.
meaning_story: What's stuffed in the bottle? Jam you bottled for later! How could you forget?
reading_story: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 瓶 and the kun'yomi reading for 詰 that you learned when you learned 詰める. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too! Just remember that 詰 is taking the め from 詰める with it in this word too. You can't see it, but it's there.
pitch_accent: ビンズメ *** ビンズꜜメ *** ビンズメꜜ

ex_1_jp: お勘定をお願いします。
ex_1_en: Can I have the check, please?
meaning_story: When you use your intuition to determine the amount of something, you'll end up doing the calculations in your head. You do the same thing when it's time to pay your bill at dinner too, just determine the amount in your head, go with your intuition, and it should be the right amount.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 定 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're having trouble with the calculation of the amount on your bill, just call Joseph (じょう) Stalin. He's really great at numbers and he will be able to figure out the numbers in his head really fast.

ex_1_jp: この本は慈善事業支援の目的で出版されました。
ex_1_en: This book was published for the purpose of supporting charitable projects.
meaning_story: A morally good person who has mercy upon people gives to charity. These people prove they're good by mercifully giving all their money away to the poor and needy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの男が彼女の貞操を奪ったのよ。
ex_1_en: That man robbed her of her virtue.
meaning_story: You are a strong, independent person and you are the only one who can manipulate your chastity. Nobody else can. So if you want to keep your chastity that's completely up to you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は最後まで貞節を守ったんだ。
ex_1_en: She protected her chastity until the end.
meaning_story: Chastity is always in season so it's always cool to try to keep your chastity. Spring, summer? Doesn't matter. Your decision to stay that way is fine no matter what time of year it is.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 襟が曲がっていますよ。
ex_1_en: Your collar is twisted.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 祖母は本当に慈悲深い人だった。
ex_1_en: My grandmother was a really compassionate person.
meaning_story: If you have mercy for people who are sad you have a lot of compassion. You just can't help but go easy on sad people.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: そのことが心の片隅にずっと引っかかっていたんです。
ex_1_en: That had always been stuck in the corner of my mind.
meaning_story: A one sided corner is still a corner, just a really small one.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: カタスミ *** カタスꜜミ

ex_1_jp: この部屋の隅に、少女の霊がいます。
ex_1_en: There is a girl’s ghost in the corner of the room.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: この土地を耕作するには許可がいります。
ex_1_en: You need approval in order to cultivate this plot of land.
meaning_story: Plow the earth to make it ready for cultivation and farming.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 乾燥対策でマスクをつけています。
ex_1_en: I’m wearing a mask to counter the dryness.
meaning_story: Even something dry will dry up more if it's got dehydration. There's a lot of dryness going on here.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 洗濯粉がきれちゃった。
ex_1_en: We ran out of detergent.
meaning_story: Wash wash powder is the detergent you put in the wash you make sure your clothes are washed well. Detergent used to only be available in powder form back in the old days.
reading_story: This is a mix of the on'yomi readings for 洗濯 and the kun'yomi reading for 粉. You already learned this reading for 粉 when you learned the word 麦粉. If you can remember that, you should know the readings for this one too!

ex_1_jp: この遺跡には、竪穴住居郡があります。
ex_1_en: These historic ruins contain a district of pit dwellings.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: もうすぐ石油は枯渇する。
ex_1_en: The petroleum will dry up very soon.
meaning_story: Something that withers from thirst ends up drying up. If you let a plant dry up like this it might die if you don't water it soon.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 渇 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If all of your plants are drying up you should just give them to your cats (かつ). Cats love to play with dried up plants. At least they won't go to waste.

ex_1_jp: ここには多くのラーメン屋台が軒を連ねています。
ex_1_en: There are a lot of ramen carts standing in a row here.
meaning_story: In order to use a house counter in the first place, you need to have something to count. That's why you have to find eaves or a bunch of houses that stand in a row so you can count them easily.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: These houses that stand in a row are neat and fun to count, but you can't go in because you have no key (のき). With no key, those eaves are just there for you to look at.

ex_1_jp: 私は愛媛県の出身です。
ex_1_en: I am from Ehime Prefecture.
meaning_story: The prefecture in Japan where they love princesses is Ehime Prefecture.
reading_story: This reading is a little messy. This reading for 愛 is an exception, 媛 uses the kun'yomi reading ひめ, and 県 uses the on'yomi reading けん. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading for 愛: If you ask anyone outside of Ehime Prefecture what they think of princesses they'll respond with, "Eh" (え). They don't really care either way. If someone from Ehime heard that they'd says, "EH? EH?! Princesses are the BEST!"

pronunciation: あきびん, からびん
ex_1_jp: 空瓶はこちらに捨ててください。
ex_1_en: Please throw away empty bottles here.
meaning_story: A sky bottle is a bottle that has nothing but sky in it. It's an empty bottle.
reading_story: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. You learned this reading for 空 when you learned 空き缶. If you can remember that, you can remember this too! Oh and sometimes you'll see this written 空瓶 without the kana too. And when that happens it can be read からびん! So if you learned it one way and not the other, don't worry, we'll take both here. Just know that seeing it as 空き瓶 (and pronouncing it あきびん) is way more common.

ex_1_jp: 玄関で靴を脱いでください。
ex_1_en: Please take off your shoes in the entranceway.
meaning_story: The most mysterious thing that's connected to a house is the entranceway. When you're walking into one you never know what's coming next. You just take of your shoes and hope the rest of the house isn't really weird or something. If it is, the entryway is then your only way out.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: これについて、正式に釈明をする必要がある。
ex_1_en: You need to formally explain this.
meaning_story: An explanation that's bright is just a really clear and well developed explanation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その解釈は間違っていると思います。
ex_1_en: I think that explanation is wrong.
meaning_story: Even if you untie an explanation it's still a pretty good explanation anyway.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 僕のおじいさんは農耕をしています。
ex_1_en: My grandfather farms.
meaning_story: Farming with a plow is still farming.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 太ももの脂肪を落としたいんです。
ex_1_en: I want to lose the fat from my thighs.
meaning_story: Something that's both fat and obese has even more fat on it than you first thought. Like the blubber on a really big whale.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: このホテルは色々な要望に柔軟に対応してくれます。
ex_1_en: This hotel flexibly deals with various requests.
meaning_story: A gentle and soft thing will be really flexible and pliable. Soft things are really easy to bend, like towels and flower petals.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 写真の四隅を暗く加工するにはどうすればいいのか教えてください。
ex_1_en: Can you teach me the best process to make the four corners of a picture dark?
meaning_story: Four corners are four corners!
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both by now, so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 社長がそんなに偉いんですか？
ex_1_en: What makes the company president so great?
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of greatness? Great!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The only thing a great person doesn't do is make errors (えら). That's what makes them so great. They can always sense when an error is about to happen and they correct it before it even has a chance!

ex_1_jp: 人類史上最も偉大な発明は何ですか。
ex_1_en: What is the greatest invention in all of human history?
meaning_story: Big greatness is still greatness, just a lot of it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 世界の偉人たちの名言を集めました。
ex_1_en: I’ve collected wise sayings from great men of the world.
meaning_story: A person with a lot of greatness is a great person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: これは、邸内の写真です。
ex_1_en: This is a picture of the grounds.
meaning_story: The land inside of a residence is called the grounds or the premises. Only really big residences have land inside them big enough to be called the "grounds" though.
