reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は自宅軟禁下に置かれました。
ex_1_en: She was placed under house arrest.
meaning_story: Soft prohibition isn't going to be as bad a jail or prison. They went soft on you, so you're only under house arrest. That's not so bad, right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この人は、マンションを五軒持っています。
ex_1_en: This guy has five apartments.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 度重なる事業の失敗で、すっかり焦燥しきっているんだ。
ex_1_en: I’m thoroughly irritated with this repeatedly failing project.
meaning_story: If you want to char fish for dinner it will dry up because of your own impatience. Charring fish takes time and if you're too uneasy and shove it too far in the fire it will dry out, burn, and get gross.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 洗濯屋にワイシャツを取りに行ってきます。
ex_1_en: I’m going to pick up my dress shirt from the laundromat.
meaning_story: The wash wash shop is where you go to get your clothes washed extra well. It's the laundromat! They wash you clothes way better than you can because they wash them twice.
reading_story: This is a mix of the on'yomi readings for 洗濯 and the kun'yomi reading for 屋. You've learned all of these readings by now, so you should be able to read this word too!

ex_1_jp: この池にはいつから蓮花があるのですか。
ex_1_en: How long have lotus flowers been in this pond?
meaning_story: A lotus flower is a lotus flower!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 花 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Something is on the lotus flower... something little and kinda shiny. It's a little gecko (げ). It's hiding in the lotus and trying to catch flies. How cute!

ex_1_jp: この邸宅は、幽霊が出ることで有名です。
ex_1_en: This mansion is famous for ghosts appearing in it.
meaning_story: If you have a residence that's also your house, it's still your residence. But you probably have a lot of money if you can own your own house, so it's probably a nice, big mansion too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この化粧水が、あなたのお肌の潤いを保ちます。
ex_1_en: This lotion will help keep the moisture in your skin.
meaning_story: This may look like an adjective, but it's actually the noun version of the kanji watered. Watered things, like plants, hold a lot of moisture in them.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 潤う, so you should know this one too.
pitch_accent: ウルオイ *** ウルオꜜイ

ex_1_jp: 男は火炎瓶を投げつけた。
ex_1_en: The man threw a Molotov cocktail.
meaning_story: A fire in a bottle that makes a big fire when thrown is called a Molotov Cocktail. Don't throw them in the house please.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 塚を見下ろすことのは失礼です。
ex_1_en: It’s rude to look down at a mound.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 会釈をしたら会釈を返すのが礼儀でしょう。
ex_1_en: You might have the decency to return my nod with a nod.
meaning_story: Before you can give an explanation of who you are to someone you're about to meet, you have to nod or bow as a greeting first. It's rude to start explaining who you are before you greet them.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 会 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When someone bows to you, you always feel a little uncomfortable, so you say, "Eh" (え) and try to get them to stop. You're so uncomfortable that you can't think of words and "eh" is all you can manage to get out.

ex_1_jp: 今日は部屋を隅々まで掃除しました。
ex_1_en: Today I cleaned every nook and cranny of my room.
meaning_story: Corner corners are still corners. Sometimes they're the corners TO corners, so they're the little nooks and crannies that are hard to get at.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice, with the second one rendaku'd. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: スミꜜズミ *** スꜜミズミ

ex_1_jp: その場合は、注釈を付けてください。
ex_1_en: In that case, please add notes.
meaning_story: If your brain can't stop pouring out all the explanations your teacher gives you, you'll need to keep notes. That way when the information pours out of your head, you'll still have your comments and annotations to help you remember the teacher's explanations later.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: チューシャク *** チューシャクꜜ

ex_1_jp: 大統領公邸が何者かに襲撃されました。
ex_1_en: The President’s official residence was raided by someone.
meaning_story: A public residence is the one you tell everyone for things like documents and loans and stuff. That means it's your official residence and it's in everyone's books.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 首相官邸ツアーに参加しました。
ex_1_en: I participated in a tour of the Prime Minister’s official residence.
meaning_story: A government residence is one that is assigned to government officials. That means it's their official residence, and it goes on all their official paperwork.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうして肯定も否定もしないんですか。
ex_1_en: Why won’t you say yes or no?
meaning_story: You are determined to get an agreement out of people so you decide to be really positive with them. As long as you make it seem like everything is super great, and totally good for them, they'll end up agreeing with everything you say.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この豪華な建物は、大統領の私邸です。
ex_1_en: This gorgeous building is the president’s private residence.
meaning_story: A private residence is a private residence!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: これを透明の樹脂で固めました。
ex_1_en: This was hardened with transparent resin.
meaning_story: The fat that comes out of the wood from trees is used to make resin. Trees don't have fat, you say? Well you're wrong, look it up. Trees are super fat and we use the resin from them to do all sorts of stuff.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 蓮の花の花言葉は何ですか。
ex_1_en: What does the sacred lotus mean in the language of flowers?
meaning_story: This isn't just any lotus. It's THE lotus. The Sacred Lotus. When you see it blooming all alone in a murky pond, you'll know.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: The sacred lotus has (はす) a strong significance and (probably some powers). It has something at least, just remember it has something special going on, and you'll be fine.

ex_1_jp: 四月に苗を植えました。
ex_1_en: I planted seedlings in April.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: The best time to plant seedlings is at night (なえ). If you plant them at night they'll sleep through the whole transplanting process and they'll wake up happy and ready to grow.

ex_1_jp: 港には、七隻の船が止まっています。
ex_1_en: Seven ships are stopped in this harbor.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: ギターを弾くので指先の皮膚が厚いんです。
ex_1_en: The skin on my fingertips is thick because I play the guitar.
meaning_story: The skin under your skin is still skin. The extra layer is there to make sure when you get little cuts they don't bleed all over the place.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この子は本当に聡い子だよ。
ex_1_en: This is a really smart kid.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's another way of saying wise? Smart or discerning.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What did you do to get so smart? You sat (さと) in class all day. You didn't even get up after class was over. You planted your butt down and sat in your desk until class started again the next morning. You absorb knowledge through your behind, so as long as you sat down all day, you sucked up all the knowledge in the world!

ex_1_jp: 都心と郊外、どちらに住みたいですか。
ex_1_en: Would you rather live in the city center or the suburbs?
meaning_story: Suburbs on the outside of town are still suburbs. They're sometimes called the outskirts of town too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は東京近郊に住んでいます。
ex_1_en: I live in the suburbs of Tokyo.
meaning_story: Suburbs near you are still suburbs. They're all pretty much the same.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 富士山の山頂には住所がありません。
ex_1_en: There is no address for the summit of Mt. Fuji.
meaning_story: The mountain summit is still called the summit.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 魔法使いを召喚しました。
ex_1_en: I summoned a magician.
meaning_story: If you call someone by screaming, you're probably trying to summon them like a magician would. Magicians have to scream their spells out in order for them to work. So you have to scream out their name when you call them if you want to summon someone.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その苗字、初めて聞きました。
ex_1_en: That was the first time I’d heard that surname.
meaning_story: A seedling letter is the very first letter you learn when you're little. What's the first thing you learn to spell when you're little? Your surname! You need to know who your family is, otherwise if you get lost or something happens, you won't know how to get home! Or even who you are!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私はお湯が沸くのを待っている。
ex_1_en: I’m waiting for the water to boil.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means boil, so the verb version is to boil. It can also be used to mean to get excited, because you're boiling with that excitement.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want to boil for dinner tonight? Walrus (わ). Boiled walrus is a delicacy where you're from, and the only way to be able to eat it's yummy walrus flesh it to boil it for a long time until it's soft. Mmm smells good.

ex_1_jp: 私の庭は落ち葉に覆われています。
ex_1_en: My garden is covered in fallen leaves.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cover, so the verb version is to cover or to hide.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to cover yourself with a sheet because you want to pretend to be a ghost. But covering yourself isn't enough. If you really want people to believe in your disguise you have to say, "おお!" Otherwise they'll think you're a covered chair or a bush. If you おお at them they'll definitely know you're a ghost covered in that sheet.

ex_1_jp: あなたのお姉さまは神に召されたのですよ。
ex_1_en: Your older sister was called by the gods.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means call, so the verb version is to humbly call. It can also be used as to humbly eat or to humbly invite too. It's a really useful word like that. As long as you remember it's the humble way of doing things you should be fine.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to humbly call out to someone you need to make sure you don't look them in the 目 (め) because that's super rude. Always remember to turn your 目 away to show respect.

ex_1_jp: お祝いを頂き、本当に有難うございます。
ex_1_en: Thank you very much for your congratulations.
meaning_story: If you humbly do something you are going to humbly receive, to humbly accept, or eat or drink it. Basically you're humbly doing a lot of things. And you can use this word for all of them!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You technically already know this reading! You know how people say いただきます? Well that's the same as this! You're humbly receiving your meal. So to humbly receive is いただく!

ex_1_jp: パンにハムと卵を挟みました。
ex_1_en: I put the egg and ham between the bread.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means between, so the verb version is to insert or to put between.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: 酔っぱらいが喚いているんだよ。
ex_1_en: A drunk guy is shouting.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scream, so the verb version is to scream or to shout.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to shout at someone you should pick a word that will really hit them. Give them a big whammy (わめ) to the face! Hey, that word works. Shout WHAMMY!

ex_1_jp: どうして野菜を水に浸しているの？
ex_1_en: Why are you soaking the vegetables in water?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means immersed, so the verb version is what happens when you immerse something in a liquid. It's to soak or to dip.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 浸る, so you should know this one too.

ex_1_jp: この機械で畑を耕すんですよ。
ex_1_en: I’ll plow the field with this machine.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means plow, so the verb version is to plow or to till.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to till your land because you want to have a tiger yard (たがや). Thats either when you have a yard full of live tigers, or you plant bushes and shape them into tigers. I hope it's the second kind of tiger yard. Either way, you have to plow the land to get it ready.

ex_1_jp: せっかく植えた木が枯れてしまいました。
ex_1_en: The tree I took great pains to grow withered.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wither, so the verb version is to wither or to die.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: How do you get plants to wither? You hit them with your car (か). It isn't very good for your car either, but the plants will definitely die, so problem solved!

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 妻が不貞をはたらいたので、離婚しました。
ex_1_en: My wife was unfaithful so we got divorced.
meaning_story: When you do not have chastity, it's probably because you were unfaithful to your promise to whoever you told you'd stay chaste to.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 玄米は体に良い。
ex_1_en: Unpolished rice is good for your health.
meaning_story: Mysterious rice is unpolished rice, or brown rice. You're used to seeing nice white rice, so seeing rice look any other way is really strange for you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 米 so here's a mnemonic to help you: The biggest problem when you buy unpolished rice is the mice (まい)! Mice like to eat and sleep in unpolished rice, so you have to be careful when you buy a bag that you get rid of all the sleeping mice before you try to cook it.

ex_1_jp: これは素敵な花瓶ですね。
ex_1_en: This is a beautiful vase.
meaning_story: A bottle for flowers is a vase. You should get some flowers and put them in a vase for someone special right now.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は離婚騒動で渦中の人だよ。
ex_1_en: He’s in a vortex of divorce turmoil.
meaning_story: In the middle of a whirlpool you'll find a spinning vortex of water. You really don't want to get sucked in there.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: せんたくき, せんたっき
ex_1_jp: 洗濯機が壊れたみたい。
ex_1_en: The washing machine seems to be broken.
meaning_story: A wash wash machine is just another way of saying washing machine. It does extra washing that you can't do by hand so there are two washes here.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: センタクꜜキ *** センタꜜクキ

ex_1_jp: 海に渦が発生するのはどうして？
ex_1_en: Why do whirlpools appear in the ocean?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: There are lots of whirlpools at the uni zoo (うず). Unis really like being spun around in whirlpools, so when you go to the zoo to see them look out for the tank full of them!

ex_1_jp: 三村崇は非常に聡明な少年だった。
ex_1_en: Takashi Mimura was a very wise boy.
meaning_story: A wise and bright person has a lot of wisdom. In fact, they have so much that it's showing up as brightness their your skin.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あいつは殊勝な女だったよ。
ex_1_en: That’s an admirable woman.
meaning_story: When you win especially well everyone will find you admirable. So get out there and win!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_en: It seems that my wife is committing adultery.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_en: A commemoration exhibition is planned 50 years after their death.
meaning_story: All the art, music, or books that come out after a person dies are considered to be released after death or posthumously.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: うちの息子は、若いのに覇気が無い。
ex_1_en: Despite his youth, my son lacks ambition.
meaning_story: If you have the leadership spirit it means you have a lot of ambition to go after the things you want. And you'll be able to lead others because of it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日本各地でクマが大量出没している。
ex_1_en: Bears appear frequently in large quantities all over Japan.
meaning_story: Animals exit the mountains into your land and never seem to die! They end up appearing frequently in your garden, eating all your yummy carrots and watermelons, and then make their exit back into the hills. They're infesting your home now and you don't know what to do!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうせ出馬者を擁立しようとしているだけだろう。
ex_1_en: Anyway, I think that candidate is the only one I’m going to be supporting.
meaning_story: Stand behind someone and embrace them. That's how you show them you're backing and supporting them. Do this to your local politicians.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ゆっくりお風呂に浸かりたいなあ。
ex_1_en: I want to slowly soak in the bath.
meaning_story: Let the wind in from the window above your bath so the water is cool enough for you to take a bath! If the water is too hot, you'll get all dizzy and that's dangerous!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 銀行が潰れて、預金が封鎖されてしまったんです。
ex_1_en: The bank was bankrupted and my account was frozen.
meaning_story: A sealed chain won't break or open so it gets in the way of everyone, forming a blockade. This can happen at banks too and it will result in them freezing your account!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 地震であそこの道路が陥没したそうです。
ex_1_en: It looks like that highway over there collapsed from the earthquake.
meaning_story: A cave in where everyone dies is still a cave in, just a really sad one.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 逃げないように鎖で繋いでいます。
ex_1_en: They were tied with chains so they wouldn’t escape.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: The best way to break out of the chains life puts on you is to put on a cool sari (くさり). A cool sari will remind you where you come from. Who your family is. And how beautiful you look. Cast off those chains and put on a cool sari!

ex_1_jp: まずはこの負の連鎖を断ち切る必要があります。
ex_1_en: First, you must sever ties with this negative chain.
meaning_story: If you take along a chain with you it's still a chain, it's just moving somewhere new.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 突貫工事で犬小屋を建てました。
ex_1_en: We built the doghouse by constructing it at top speed.
meaning_story: Pierce someone when you stab them with a mighty charge with your sword. Better yet, hit them with your lightning attack!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は慢性胃腸炎を患っているんです。
ex_1_en: I suffer from chronic gastroenteritis.
meaning_story: If it's in your nature to ridicule people, it will become a chronic problem. You can't change something that's so imbedded in who you are, which is a shame, since you're a jerk.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 陳腐な台詞しか思い浮かびません。
ex_1_en: I can’t think of anything but cliched lines.
meaning_story: If you keep exhibiting the same actions and emotions and phrases eventually they're going to rot and sound cliched to everyone. You have to mix things up once in a while. You don't want to get stale, do you?!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for ふ becoming ぷ.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: このプールは今月で閉鎖されます。
ex_1_en: The pool is closed this month.
meaning_story: A closed chain lets everyone know that a building or store is closing for good. It's got to lockout everyone so they won't try to get in anymore.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は実力があるのにどうしてこんなに冷遇されているんですか。
ex_1_en: If he’s so great then why did he get such a cold reception?
meaning_story: When you are given cool treatment it's called a cold reception or inhospitality. This sucks.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: わが校の野球部が、秋のリーグ戦を制覇しました。
ex_1_en: Our school’s baseball club dominated the autumn league match.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: このシステムで部屋の温度を恒常に保っています。
ex_1_en: With this system we can consistently keep it at room temperature.
meaning_story: The constant normal things in your life are also constant. If you normally always do them, then they're also probably apart of your everyday routine.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 消費者からこの商品の安全性の欠陥が指摘されています。
ex_1_en: The safety defect in this product was identified by consumers.
meaning_story: If there is a cave in because it was lacking something that means there was a defect or a fault in there somewhere.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 危うく遭難するところでした。
ex_1_en: We narrowly missed having a disaster.
meaning_story: If you encounter something difficult it's going to result in disaster. Especially if you're in a boat. Encountering really difficult water will result in a shipwreck! Ick!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: こないだの原稿は没になってしまった。
ex_1_en: The manuscript was rejected the other day.
meaning_story: When a plant or an animal dies you have to discard it. You can't just keep it sitting around the house, that's weird.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: その映画の、主役の二人が甘い抱擁を交わすシーンがとても美しかったよ。
ex_1_en: The scene in that movie where the two leading actors exchanged a sweet embrace was so beautiful.
meaning_story: An embrace and a hug are pretty much the same thing. So you're still going to embrace and hug people!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 抱 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who gives the best hugs in the world? Harry Houdini (ほう)! He knows what it's like to be hugged too tightly because he's always in straight jackets. So his hugs are nice and gentle. Just the way you like them!

ex_1_jp: 悲惨な交通事故に遭遇しました。
ex_1_en: I encountered a tragic traffic accident.
meaning_story: It doesn't matter what kind of treatment you get on your encounter with new people because it's the encounter itself that's scary! Don't worry, people are just people. They shouldn't make you nervous.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning_story: I get ridiculed a lot, but it makes me have really strong endurance. If you get picked on a lot, just say, "I have patience and self control, and I can make it through this."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 犬 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who has the best hunting dog in the world? Ken (けん) from Street Fighter! His dog is also named Ken, because that's how Ken and Ken do things.

ex_1_jp: 好きなことに没頭できるなんて、幸せですね。
ex_1_en: If you can immerse yourself in things you like, you’ll be happy.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 頭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The best place to immerse yourself in Japan is Tokyo (とう)! It's so full of interesting stores, events, and people, that you can't help but get completely sucked in.

ex_1_jp: 整形手術で二重の埋没手術をしました。

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 埋 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Wait that's not a person you're embedding things into. It's a bunch of mice (まい). I guess that's okay. Just don't go putting the mice into people. That's... don't cross that line.

ex_1_jp: 子供が偏食がちなので困っています。
ex_1_en: I’m worried because kids tend to have unbalanced diets.
meaning_story: People who are biased about what they eat usually only eat sweet stuff like candy and ice cream. This gives them a really unbalanced diet. Candy and ice cream are okay, but you have to be open to eating other things too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: だれかを犠牲にしてまで成功したいかい？
ex_1_en: Do you want to succeed so badly that you’re willing to sacrifice someone?
meaning_story: Who do you sacrifice as an offering to the gods? A poor victim will be your sacrifice.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 鰐蟹で漢字を猛勉強中です。
ex_1_en: I’m working hard studying kanji on WaniKani.
meaning_story: This is it. You're finally here. This is the moment where you learn the true meaning behind WaniKani!
reading_story: You should be able to read this on your own. And seriously... if you ever get this one wrong we're gonna show up at your house and look down at you with really, really disappointed looks on our faces. Don't let us down, kids.

ex_1_jp: あそこの噴水で待ち合わせをしましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s meet at the water fountain over there.
meaning_story: Water erupts from water fountains. Sometimes they're big eruptions and sometimes they're small, but they're always fun to watch and enjoy in the hot summer.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 虐待を受けた子供は、自己評価が非常に低くなることが多い。
ex_1_en: Many children who were abused have extremely lowered self esteem.
meaning_story: If you can't wait to oppress people when you grow up, you're the kind of person who's prone inflicting abuse on other people. You should try to correct that right away.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: IT関連の株価が軒並み下落しました。
ex_1_en: IT-related stock prices fell across the board.
meaning_story: Line up house counters and you'll see that all the houses you've counted are the same across the board. It also turns them into a row of houses.
reading_story: This is a combination of the words 軒 and 並 that you've already learned, so you should be able to read this word too.

ex_1_jp: わずかですが、稿料をもらいました。
ex_1_en: It wasn’t much, but I got an advance for the manuscript.
meaning_story: The fee you charge to produce your draft is called an advance for manuscript. Also known as copy money.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: コーリョꜜー *** コꜜーリョー

ex_1_jp: 誕生日会で、手品を披露しました。
ex_1_en: Slight of hand was performed at the birthday party.
meaning_story: Expose what you want to expose by making an announcement. Then show the world!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 露 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're making the announcement from a row (ろう) boat. People will pay more attention when you're in a row boat because it's kind of weird. Especially since you're in a row boat on a stage.

ex_1_jp: 新しい情報が入れば、随時ご連絡致します。
ex_1_en: If new information comes in, contact me at any time.
meaning_story: If you have all the time in the world you can do whatever you want at any time.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 南京大虐殺が捏造だったというなら、その証拠を説明してください。
ex_1_en: If you say the Nanking Massacre is a fabrication, please explain the evidence.
meaning_story: To oppress people and then kill them is an atrocity. It's also called a massive killing because that's what you're actually doing. And you're awful, why would you ever do that?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 真鯉の刺青を背中に彫りました。
ex_1_en: I got a black carp tattoo done on my back.
meaning_story: In reality, carp are usually black carp. The colored ones aren't as common, people just wish they were.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 搭乗手続きはどこですればいいですか。
ex_1_en: Where should I check-in?
meaning_story: When you board a plane or a car to take a ride it's called boarding or check in. You have to get on the right way or you can't ride.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 乗 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who greets you when you're boarding your plane? Joseph (じょう) Stalin. He's trying to make sure certain people don't get on. Uhg, what a jerk. You have to try to slip around him to board.

ex_1_jp: 競艇で大儲けしました。
ex_1_en: I made a killing in the boat race.
meaning_story: Rowboats compete in a boat race. Who are you gonna bet on?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: スープが沸騰してグツグツいってますよ。
ex_1_en: The soup was boiling and simmering.
meaning_story: The inflation of boiling water means that bubbles are being inflated in there and bubbling to the top. This is called boiling, or if it's happening in a person it's called seething.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: どうほう, どうぼう
ex_1_jp: お前は同胞を裏切るつもりか。
ex_1_en: Do you intend to betray your brethren?
meaning_story: People who have the same cells as you are your brethren, they're you're brothers!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ドーホー *** ハラカラ *** ハラꜜカラ

ex_1_jp: 故郷に錦を飾ることが夢だったんだ。
ex_1_en: I dream to return home in triumph.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 今度の機種には、どんな新機能が搭載されるんでしょうか。
ex_1_en: What kinds of features are built in to this model?
meaning_story: You nail a board to the wall of a house you're selling and publish in the listing that it was built in with the house! No one will know you just put it there.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 鯉に餌をあげないでください。
ex_1_en: Please do not feed the carp.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

pronunciation: さいぼう, さいほう
ex_1_jp: 私は、人工多能性幹細胞(iPS細胞)の研究をしています。
ex_1_en: I study induced pluripotent stem cells (iPS cells).
meaning_story: Thin cells are what make up our bodies. They're still cells but they can also be called biological cells.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: サイボー *** サイホー

ex_1_jp: 三十万円の浄水器を売りつけられそうになりました。
ex_1_en: I almost had a three hundred thousand yen water filter sold to me.
meaning_story: When you cleanse water it becomes clean water that you can drink.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 襟元にファンデーションがついていますよ。
ex_1_en: There’s foundation on your collar.
meaning_story: The origin of your collar is your collar! And the nape of the neck because that's where collars go.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: エリモト *** エリモꜜト *** エリモトꜜ

ex_1_jp: 庭の池に錦鯉を放ちました。
ex_1_en: I released the colored carp into the garden pond.
meaning_story: A brocade carp is a fancy way of saying it's a carp that has a lot of pretty colors on it. It's a colored carp or a colored koi.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ニシキꜜコ°イ *** ニシキコ°ꜜイ

ex_1_jp: それは、ヒトラー総帥の指令だったのです。
ex_1_en: That was Fuhrer Hitler’s order.
meaning_story: The commander of the whole army is just called " the commander." No one knows his real name and everyone is too afraid to ask.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 頂きものなんですが、良かったらどうぞ。
ex_1_en: If there is anything of mine that you’d like, please help yourself.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You should already know this reading from when you learned 頂く. If you can remember that, you can remember this too!

ex_1_jp: これは非常に残虐な犯行です。
ex_1_en: This is an extremely brutal crime.
meaning_story: The remainder of oppression is cruelty. Even when you're done oppressing people the brutality you caused will linger in their minds and hearts.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日本はワールドカップで惨敗してしまった。
ex_1_en: Japan suffered a crushing failure at the World Cup.
meaning_story: Failure that causes disaster is a crushing failure and you were utterly beaten by your opponent.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ザンパイ *** サンパイ

ex_1_jp: たまに胡瓜の糠漬けが無性に食べたくなるんだ。
ex_1_en: Occasionally, I’ll want to eat pickled cucumbers so badly.
meaning_story: Barbarians have melons too, but they're long and funny looking. Wait, those aren't melons, they're cucumbers! Barbarians must have mixed them up.
reading_story: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Cucumbers have cute ribs (きゅうり)! I mean just look at them. Cute little green ribs. Adorable!

ex_1_jp: 春の曙の空はいくら見ても見飽きません。
ex_1_en: No matter how many times I see dawn in the spring sky, I don’t get tired of it.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 枯れ木に花を咲かせましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s make the dead tree bloom.
meaning_story: A withered tree is a dead tree and it's got really dry wood. Perfect for a campfire!
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Sometimes you'll see it spelled 枯木 without the kana too. Keep your eyes open for it!

ex_1_jp: 上品で繊細な味の日本食が好きです。
ex_1_en: I like the elegant and subtle flavors of Japanese food.
meaning_story: Slender and thin things are very delicate and dainty. They're easily broken, so you have to be careful.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は皮膚科に通院しています。
ex_1_en: I’m going to a dermatologist.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 皮膚 is "skin?" Well the science of skin is dermatology!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は、これまでの経緯を静かに語りだした。
ex_1_en: He quietly told us about how it all started.
meaning_story: If you are trying to manage latitudes you're really trying to manage the details of something. Managing latitudes is just a fancy way of saying it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 熟練の染師が、一つ一つ丹念に染め上げました。
ex_1_en: The skilled dyeing master diligently finished dyeing each one.
meaning_story: If you don't want your thoughts to turn rust colored, you need use diligence to keep studying, learning, and experiencing new things. Without diligence your brain and all your thoughts will get old, and stale, turning a rusty, gross color.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 惨事を招くことは避けたい。
ex_1_en: I want to avoid causing a disaster.
meaning_story: Disaster in action means the disaster is still happening. Get outta there!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 残された加害者の家族の末路は、悲惨なものだった。
ex_1_en: The assailant’s remaining family member’s last days were tragic.
meaning_story: A sad disaster is one that's especially disastrous and tragic. It's the worst kind you can imagine.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 東北大震災の惨状を忘れることができません。
ex_1_en: I can’t forget the disastrous scene of the Great Tohoku Earthquake.
meaning_story: Disastrous conditions in the weather lead to you seeing a disastrous scene. Just don't look outside and you won't see the horrible stuff out your window right now.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 我々が大衆を啓蒙するのです。
ex_1_en: We enlighten the general public.
meaning_story: Enlighten the darkness of people's minds with instruction and they'll reach enlightenment like you did!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 最近は、自己啓発本ばかり読んでいます。
ex_1_en: Lately I’ve only been reading self-improvement books.
meaning_story: When you are enlightened enough you'll need to make your departure from this world into enlightenment.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 随筆の書き方を教えてください。
ex_1_en: Please teach me how to write essays.
meaning_story: All that comes out of a writing brush is essays. You can't paint or doodle, you have to write with it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この寿司屋には、店の随所に、日本の美を感じさせるインテリアが飾られています。
ex_1_en: You can feel the beauty of Japan everywhere in this sushi restaurant from the way the interior is decorated.
meaning_story: All places are everywhere.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 過剰包装は紙の無駄です。
ex_1_en: Over wrapping is a waste of paper.
meaning_story: If you surpass your surplus then you have lots of excess stuff.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 水商売の玄人と素人を見分けるのが趣味です。
ex_1_en: My hobby is to try to differentiate between professionals and amateurs in the "water trade."
meaning_story: A mysterious person is really really good at what they do. So good that they aren't exactly sure what is it they do, but you know they're definitely an expert at whatever it is.
reading_story: This reading for this word is mysteriously an exception (sorry). So here's a mnemonic to help: If you're such an expert you should be able to tell what anything is if someone asks you. Even this crow toe (くろうと). Crow toes are pretty hard to recognize, unless you're a professional crow guy. But I guess you are, huh?
pitch_accent: クꜜロート *** クロꜜート

ex_1_jp: お肉の脂身って苦手なんですよね。
ex_1_en: I don’t like the fatty meat.
meaning_story: The fat on an animal's body is called fatty meat. Some people really like to eat it and others really like to hate it.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 脂 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Mmm, all that fatty meat. Think about fatty meat on your own body. If you have a lot of fatty meat, then you need a way to support said fatty meat. To do that, you would use a bra (あぶら).

ex_1_jp: 毎日サラダを食べて、ちゃんと食物繊維を摂るようにしています。
ex_1_en: I eat a salad everyday and consume the perfect amount of dietary fiber.
meaning_story: The fiber you use to maintain your own health is the fiber you eat!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この会社は、圧倒的な強さで、他社の追随を許しませんでした。
ex_1_en: This company is unrivaled by other companies with it’s overwhelming strength.
meaning_story: Even if you follow all the people you've ever met, you're still following them. Once a follower, always a follower.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 追 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: They get you to follow them by yelling SOOEY (つい)! You certainly aren't a pig, but something about hearing them yell sooey makes you feel like you have to follow them.

ex_1_jp: これが、あの有名な最高司令官のマッカ—サ—元帥です。
ex_1_en: That’s famous supreme commander, General MacArthur.
meaning_story: The commander's origin was as the general of the army. He stepped down, but that's where he started. Maybe he's working the system backwards...
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 住宅地や学校の近くでは、徐行で運転してください。
ex_1_en: Please drive slowly near residential districts and schools.
meaning_story: If you go gently you're actually going slowly. You can't be gentle if you don't move slowly.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 二学期に入って、徐々に成績が上がり始めました。
ex_1_en: Second semester came and my grade slowly started to rise.
meaning_story: If you do it gently gently then you're only doing it gradually. You have to go slowly if you want to be as gentle as possible.
reading_story: The reading is just the on'yomi readings (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

ex_1_jp: ベビー用品は、いつも赤ちゃん本舗で買います。
ex_1_en: I always buy baby things at the main baby shop.
meaning_story: The main shop is the main shop or the head office.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 徳川氏の家紋といえば、「三つ葉葵」が一番有名だ。
ex_1_en: Speaking of the Tokugawa family crest, the "three hollyhock leaves" is the most famous.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: ママのこの指輪、大きくなったら私に頂戴ね。
ex_1_en: My mother’s ring is being given to me when I grow up.
meaning_story: Humbly receive something and you'll be humbly receiving it. Or humbly eating it if they gave you food and not a puppy or something inedible.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because たい becomes だい here.

ex_1_jp: GPSで経度や緯度が検索できます。
ex_1_en: I can look up the latitude and longitude on my GPS.
meaning_story: Degrees of latitude are still called latitude.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 蓮根と人参のキンピラを作りました。
ex_1_en: I made kinpira with lotus root and carrot.
meaning_story: Lotus root is lotus root.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 原稿に珈琲を零してしまいました。
ex_1_en: I spilled coffee on the manuscript.
meaning_story: Your original draft is called a manuscript.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: これは瓜の漬物です。
ex_1_en: This is pickled melon.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Bite into a melon and what do you taste? Uni reese's pieces (うり)! Did you know that? The next time you eat a melon see if you can taste the difference!

ex_1_jp: 海軍の艦艇の乗組員が不足しています。
ex_1_en: The crew of the navy’s war fleet is lacking.
meaning_story: What does a warship and a rowboat have in common? At wartime they're both considered military vessels.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: そんなことを言われて、人がどれだけ惨めな気持ちになるのか分かる？
ex_1_en: You say something like that, but do you understand how miserable people feel?
meaning_story: If you face a lot of disasters in your life you're going to be really miserable. It's a shame, but it's hard to be anything but sad when your life is full of disastrous stuff.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You'll be really miserable if you find out your going to have a really 短い (みじ) life.

ex_1_jp: この絵には、蒙古襲来の時の様子が描かれています。
ex_1_en: This picture depicts the the state at the time of the Mongolian invasion.
meaning_story: In the old times Japan thought one country was full of nothing but darkness. That country was Mongolia. It was mostly because when the Mongolians invaded it was always night time. So everyone just started thinking they were used to the darkness because they lived in it all the time back home.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 江ノ島とギリシャのクレタ島の北緯は同じです。
ex_1_en: Enoshima and Greece’s Crete island are on the same northern latitude.
meaning_story: North latitude is north latitude or northern latitude.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: スピーチの草稿を作成しています。
ex_1_en: I’m writing up a draft of the speech.
meaning_story: You end up writing your rough draft on some grass leaves because you forgot your notes. This grass will serve as your notes now.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ソーコー *** ソーコꜜー

ex_1_jp: 今日は夫と苗床を作りました。
ex_1_en: I made a nursery with my husband today.
meaning_story: A floor just for seedlings is called a nursery. It's were all the little seedling grow before they're sold or replanted outside.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 緯度0度の緯線のことを、赤道と呼びます。
ex_1_en: The 0 degree parallel is called the equator.
meaning_story: A latitude line can also be called a parallel.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この道路はまだ舗装されていない。
ex_1_en: This highway still hasn’t been paved.

pronunciation: へいじょう, ぴょんやん
ex_1_jp: 平壌で英語を教えていたことがあります。
ex_1_en: I taught English in Pyongyang.
meaning_story: What's the city of flat soil? Pyongyang in North Korea. Which is pretty misleading, it's got more than a bunch of flat dirt, but back in the old days before the illustrious Kim Jong line built it up, that's all that was there.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It can also pronounced the way we say it in English sometimes too. That's ピョンヤン, if you're wondering, and these kanji are used for it too.

ex_1_jp: 新戦略兵器削減条約の批准を最優先課題としています。
ex_1_en: The ratification of New START is a maximum priority issue.
meaning_story: If there is only semi criticism on a law ratification is still possible. It's only if everyone criticizes it that it won't be ratified.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ニシキゴイは緋鯉をもとに改良されたものです。
ex_1_en: The colored carp was an improvement on the red and golden carp.
meaning_story: A scarlet colored carp is called a red carp and sometimes a golden carp because sometimes people don't understand colors.
reading_story: The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

ex_1_jp: 余剰資金で株を買いました。
ex_1_en: I bought stock with surplus funds.
meaning_story: If you have a surplus surplus it's a little redundant and you end up having a surplus of surpluses!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: それはまるで神の啓示のようだった。
ex_1_en: That’s just like divine revelation.
meaning_story: What indicates that you've been enlightened enough to reach enlightenment? A revelation! That's the only way you can know you've been enlightened enough.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ピンクの襟巻きを巻いているのが私の妹です。
ex_1_en: The girl wrapped in the pink scarf is my little sister.

reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この盆栽は苗木から育てたんです。

reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この事件が業界の自浄を促すだろう。
ex_1_en: This incident will promote the self-purification of the industry.

ex_1_jp: 空港の近くにここのレンタカーの店舗はありますか？
ex_1_en: Is there a rental car shop here near the airport?

ex_1_jp: おかげ様で自分の舗を構えることができました。

reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: こんなところで胡座をかいてないで、さっさと仕事にとりかかりなさい。
ex_1_en: Don’t sit cross legged here, start your work quickly.
meaning_story: When barbarians sit they only sit cross legged. Sitting on your feet hurts and they don't care how they look, so they're going to be comfortable and cross their legs.
reading_story: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: If you're sitting cross legged lots of people will think you're a grouch (あぐら). Back in the day sitting like this was thought to be really manly, and if you were a woman who did it they'd call you a grouch too.

ex_1_jp: 息子は皮膚病を患っています。
ex_1_en: My son suffers from a skin disease.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 皮膚 is "skin?" Well when your skin is sick, you have a skin disease. You should probably go to a dermatologist right away.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 土壌が悪い時は育てられない。

ex_1_en: We receive cheap crude oil and cheap naphtha and the price of synthetic fibers is also falling.

ex_1_jp: 掃除には、化繊箒を使っています。
ex_1_en: I use a synthetic fiber broom for sweeping.

ex_1_jp: あの教諭、昔の教え子と結婚したらしいよ。
ex_1_en: Apparently that teacher married a student a long time ago.

ex_1_jp: うちの父は俺のことを叱るけど、本当は諭すのが正解だと思う。
ex_1_en: Even though he scolds me, my father thinks admonishing is the solution.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means admonish, so the verb version is to admonish or to warn.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your mom started to admonish you so you instantly sat (さと) down. Maybe if she sees you sat down right in front of her, looking guilty and feeling remorseful, she won't yell as hard.

ex_1_jp: お風呂を沸かしておきましたよ。
ex_1_en: I’ll heat the bath.
meaning_story: You already learned the word 沸く which means "to boil" or "to grow hot" but this is when you are the one heating the water. It means still means to boil or to heat. But remember that you're the one who is doing the heating.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 沸く, so you should be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: アスパラガスが歯に挟まっています。
ex_1_en: You have asparagus caught in your teeth.
meaning_story: You already learned the word 挟む which means "to put between." Well this is when something is between two things and you're not putting it there. It just kinda doing it by itself. It means to get between or to be caught in.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 挟む, so you should be able to read this word as well.

ex_1_jp: もしよければお召し上がり下さい。
ex_1_en: Please eat if you’d like.
meaning_story: You've seen that 召す can mean "to humbly eat," so adding 上がる, "to rise," means you're lifting the other person up. In polite language you use this when you're talking to someone higher up than you so you have to raise the humbly eating up. So it still means to humbly eat, but raising it makes it a higher politeness level.
reading_story: This is a combination of the words 召す and 上がる that you learned already. 召す becomes 召し and then you add that to 上がる. Pretty straightforward, right?
pitch_accent: メシアカ°ル *** メシアカ°ꜜル

ex_1_jp: 今度、この機械を工場に据えようと思っているんだ。
ex_1_en: I think I’m going to have the machine fixed by the factory this time.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means install, so the verb version is to install or to fix.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: それは寛大な処置だったと思います。
ex_1_en: I think they were tolerant measures.

ex_1_jp: 自分には厳しいけど、他人には寛容です。
ex_1_en: I’m strict with myself but tolerant of others.
meaning_story: All forms of tolerance are still tolerance. Usually people like this are really open minded and generous too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 水をやりすぎて、サボテンを枯らしてしまいました。
ex_1_en: I gave the cactus too much water and I killed it.
meaning_story: You already learned the word 枯れる which means "to wither," but this is when you are the one making a plant wither. It means to let dry or to kill your plants. They didn't just die on their own, you did it.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 枯れる, so you should be able to read this word as well.

pronunciation: うなずく, うなづく
ex_1_jp: 母は話を聞きながら、ウンウンと肯きました。
ex_1_en: While I listened to my mother talk, I nodded, "Uh huh."
meaning_story: If you want to show your agreement with someone you need to nod at them so they know.
reading_story: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: You seem to nod your head a lot when you're at the unagi zoo (うなず). Unagi zoos are really rare and hard to get into. So while you're there to keep nodding to everyone because you're so honored to be there!

ex_1_jp: あの男は、妻と子供をずっと虐げてきたのよ。
ex_1_en: That man always oppressed his wife and children.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means oppress, so the verb version is to oppress or to persecute.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The best way to oppress someone is to make it so they can't use the sh*tter (しいた). Just imagine any kind of oppressive monarch from history. They know your weakness. They know you need to poop at some point. What would it be like 48 hours from now if you didn't have a place to poop. If you didn't have your "sh*tter." To help you to remember that there's an い in there, think about an eagle, as we often do for い. This eagle represents "American Freedom." If you had this freedom you'd be pooping all you want and nobody would take your sh*tter away from you.

ex_1_jp: まるで自分の家のように寛いでいました。
ex_1_en: I relaxed like it was my own home.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tolerance, so the verb version is what happens when you're a really tolerant person. You're able to relax in and to feel at home because nothing really gets to you.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to relax so you go down to old coots road (くつろ). It's a road with a bunch of old coots who don't bother nobody. They just kinda sit around and complain. That's where you like to relax. Something about being surrounded by a bunch of old coots on old coots road makes you feel at home.

ex_1_jp: あいつらは暴虐の限りを尽くしたんだ。
ex_1_en: The committed all kinds of tyrannical acts.
meaning_story: Violence and oppression are all signs of tyranny and that someone is being really cruel.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: インドでは、左手を不浄の手として、右手でご飯を食べる。
ex_1_en: In India the left hand is considered to be unclean and the right hand is used to eat.
meaning_story: If you have not cleansed yourself you're going to be covered in uncleanliness and dirtiness. Eww.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 随分大胆なことをしたんですね。
ex_1_en: You did a very bold thing.
meaning_story: If you manage to make all parts of something work together you worked very, extremely, considerably hard to do it. Doing all of anything is hard so lots of work had to happen.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 電気ポットはどうやって洗浄してますか？
ex_1_en: How do you do the wash with a hot water dispenser?
meaning_story: You wash something to cleanse it by doing the washing and cleaning. You have to do the washing if you really want to get all the dirt out and make your things clean.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 夏といえば西瓜ですよね。
ex_1_en: Speaking of summer, it’s a watermelon.
meaning_story: Melons that grow in the west are round and striped and green and wait a second. That's a watermelon. I guess they come from the western part of Japan.
reading_story: The reading for 西 here is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Watermelons taste best after you swing (すい) them around. Whether you tie a rope to them or swing them on an actual swing, it mixes up the yummy watermelon insides and they end up tasting the best this way. So always remember to swing your watermelon before you crack it open.

ex_1_jp: 蚊取り線香はどうして渦巻き状になっているんですか。
ex_1_en: Why are mosquito coils in a whirlpool shape?
meaning_story: This is a combination of the word 渦 meaning "whirlpool" and 巻く meaning "to roll." A rolling whirlpool is still a whirlpool, just a really violent one.
reading_story: This is a combination of the words 渦 and 巻く. 巻く becomes 巻き and you just add 渦 to it. So reading this should be pretty simple.

ex_1_jp: お婆ちゃんが丹誠込めて育てたトマトだよ。
ex_1_en: Grandma worked earnestly and raised the tomatoes.
meaning_story: A miner works with such sincerity that her arms and legs start turning rust colored from working earnestly. All the clay and rocks she's putting her effort into digging are turning her the same color. That color is how you know someone works with serious diligence.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この絵は、人間の顕在意識と潜在意識を象徴しています。
ex_1_en: This picture symbolizes humanity’s conscious and subconscious.
meaning_story: If it appears to exist, then it's probably an actual thing... you know, existing and stuff. That should be pretty obvious.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この学校には面白い逸話があってね。
ex_1_en: This school has an interesting anecdote.
meaning_story: How do you deviate from a normal talk? With lots of anecdotes. If you add enough of them into your conversations no one will ever be able to keep track of what you were talking about to begin with.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 干し杏のジャムを作りました。

reading_story: You learned this reading with the kanji! Yay!

ex_1_jp: 兵糧攻めをするつもりなんだ。
ex_1_en: They plan to use starvation tactics.

But here's a mnemonic to help you: The army said it would provide you with some army provisions. That's great! You go to the drop site where the provisions are, and the only thing there is the only thing you need: a rowboat to get across the river. "heyo! a row boat," (ひょうろう) you say out loud. You're pretty happy that you have a row boat.

ex_1_jp: 電子書籍で自叙伝を販売しようと思っています。

ex_1_en: Can you buy bonsai in America too?

ex_1_jp: 本を読む時に栞は使いますか。

ex_1_jp: 昔々あるところに、水飴が大好きな和尚がおりました。
ex_1_en: Once upon a time there was a high priest who loved starch syrup.
meaning_story: Who works for peace and is held in high esteem? A Buddhist high priest. They work harder than anyone else to reach world peace so they're held in very high esteem.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 和 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The only thing you ever hear the Buddhist High Priest say is "Oooooo" (お). It must be some kind of Buddhist humming or chanting. Every time you think about him you hear that o sound in your head.

ex_1_jp: この欄は空けておいてください。

meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 毎年、春と秋に春秋叙勲が実施されます。

ex_1_jp: あなたのこと、ずっと冷酷な人だと思っていました。
ex_1_en: I always thought you were a cruel person.

ex_1_jp: 彼女の作った料理は、どれも酷い味だった。
ex_1_en: All of the food she made tasted awful.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cruel? Cruel or awful.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think of a man who is cruel. Doesn't matter who, but pick one that you know of that is actually cruel. He can be a real person or someone in a movie or on TV. What does this man do? He do (ひど) cruel things.

ex_1_jp: 私は、ひどく残酷な決断を迫られました。

ex_1_jp: 殊に、来年はコウイチ様生誕100周年を記念するメモリアル・イヤーとなります。
ex_1_en: Additionally, next year will be the memorial year commemorating the one hundredth year anniversary of Koichi-sama’s birth.

reading_story: This is the kanji followed by the particle に, so it uses the kun'yomi reading like a kanji does if it's alone. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you wear when it's especially cold out? Your favorite coat (こと). You only wear it when it's unusually cold though, never any other time.

ex_1_en: Shiny, toned skin is a must for popular women.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私は孤児院で幼少期を過ごしました。

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_en: I think it’s premature to broach that topic.
meaning_story: You already learned that the word 時期 means "time period," so when you add furthermore and early to that, it means that something happened ahead of time. It means premature.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あんな傲慢な男は初めてだよ。
ex_1_en: This is the first time I’ve met such an arrogant man.
meaning_story: If you ridicule other people because you're so proud of yourself that everyone seems like crap in comparison, you've got too much pride. You should also work on toning down your arrogance and haughtiness, because people won't like you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 風呂屋に来るのは初めてです。
ex_1_en: This is my first time going to a public bathhouse.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 風呂 means "bath?" Well the store you pay to take a bath in is the public bathhouse!
reading_story: This word consists of the jukugo word 風呂 and the kun'yomi reading for 屋. You've learned all of these readings, so you should be able to read this already too!

ex_1_jp: 退職後は田舎で悠々と暮らしたいな。
ex_1_en: After retirement I want to live a quiet life in the countryside.

reading_story: The reading is just the on'yomi readings (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

ex_1_jp: 我が社の業績は顕著に回復しています。
ex_1_en: Our company’s results are making a remarkable recovery.
meaning_story: When an author appears in public it's always remarkable. People usually don't remember there's anyone behind those pages, so when the actual author shows up in person it's pretty striking.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 賠償金をお支払い頂く可能性があります。

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 三冊の本は、どれも内容が酷似している。
ex_1_en: All the content in the three volumes of the book resemble each other.
meaning_story: If you resemble someone who's cruel, you, well, you resemble them. Maybe you're really mean too. I guess only you can know that. But you do look like that other guy...
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 似 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Which cruel guy do you resemble? Jesus (じ), of course. I mean, you look just like him. Look in the mirror if you don't believe me. Look, there he is. Wait, what do you mean he isn't a cruel guy? I guess you're the cruel one then. Sucks to be you.

ex_1_jp: このプロジェクトが成功すれば、報酬として、クリステンがほっぺにキスをしてくれます。
ex_1_en: If this project is a success, Kristen will give me a kiss on the cheek as a reward.
meaning_story: Repay people for the news they tell you by rewarding them! Everyone deserves compensation for the time they take to pass information to you.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 役員の不祥事発覚を受け、本日は全社員が営業活動を自粛致します。

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: それをあいつに頼むのは、ちょっと酷すぎやしないか。

ex_1_jp: 静粛に願います。

ex_1_jp: その儀式は荘厳に行われました。

You didn't learn this reading for 厳 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To help you understand the solemnity of a moment of silence, usually a gong (ごん) will play a few times. As you listen to the echo and silence that comes after it. The gravity of what you're being silent for really sinks in.

ex_1_jp: 今日のカラオケは、昭和歌謡縛りにしよう。

ex_1_jp: 昼間は賑やかですが、夜になると人通りも疎らになります。
ex_1_en: It’s bustling during the day, but at night pedestrian traffic is sparse.
