reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When things are sparse, you won't have food or toys or internet. It's hard for everyone. So your mama would baa (まば) to entertain you and get you to stop thinking about how thin you and her were getting. Mama baaing made you calm and happy. Thanks mama.

ex_1_jp: 少年は、駅の構内を全力疾走していた。
ex_1_en: The boys sprinted around the station.
meaning_story: A rapid run is called a sprint or a dash.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 薔薇の茎を食べることはできますか？
ex_1_en: Can you eat rose stems?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 今までためていた怒りが一気に噴き出した。
ex_1_en: The anger that had built up burst out at once.
meaning_story: "To Remove" an eruption it needs to burst out of the earth or volcano it's in.
reading_story: Remember how you learned the word 吹き出す? Well this is read the exact same way and means almost the exact same thing. If you know one reading, you know both!

ex_1_jp: 希望は膨らむばかりだった。
ex_1_en: My hopes just got bigger.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means swell, so the verb version is to swell or to expand.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If someone comes up to you and says, "Hey it looks like you've really started to expand around the middle." Go ahead and say a big old, "F@#$ (ふく) you!" If someone is rude to you, dish it right back out. F@#$ that guy!

ex_1_jp: 彼は最後まで自分の信念を貫き通しました。
ex_1_en: He stuck to his beliefs until the end.
meaning_story: This is a combination of the words 貫く meaning "To Go Through" and 通す meaning "To Let Pass." So when you're trying to go through an area and also let someone pass with you, you start to follow them. Not intentionally, but you're both trying to go through at the same time so you decide to stick with them.
reading_story: This is a combination of two words you already know, so you should already know this too!
pitch_accent: ツラヌキトꜜース *** ヌキトꜜース

ex_1_jp: あの芸人は呆けるのが本当にうまい。
ex_1_en: That actor is really good at acting senile.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shock. What happens when you're so old that your brain goes into shock? You start to grow senile. It's sad, but lots of people can't handle being old and they get like this.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you start to grow senile you'll make a new friend. It's Bobo (ぼ) the clown! No one else can see him though, but that's okay! He'll become your very best friend. And he won't leave until you finally kick the bucket.

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 音痴なので、カラオケは苦手です。
ex_1_en: I’m tone-deaf so I’m bad at karaoke.
meaning_story: If you're stupid when it comes to sounds, then you're tone deaf.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 努力する人は希望を語るが、怠ける人は不満を語るのさ。
ex_1_en: A person who works hard talks of hope but a person who is idle talks of dissatisfaction.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means neglect and lazy, so the verb version is to neglect or to be idle.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to neglect everything. Your school, your family, even your own name (なま). You've managed to slack for so long that you can't even remember your name? That's pretty impressive, actually.

ex_1_jp: うちにもその商品を卸してもらえませんか。
ex_1_en: Will you sell these goods wholesale?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wholesale, so the verb version is to sell wholesale.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: 彼女は颯と目を逸らした。
ex_1_en: She quickly averted her eyes.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deviate, so the verb version is to turn away or to avert.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to turn away from this movie because it's not worth watching. I mean, it isn't bad, but it isn't good. It's just so-so (そ). But that's not enough to keep your interest.

pronunciation: かん, かむり, かんむり
ex_1_jp: この冠を被れるのは王だけです。
ex_1_en: Only the king can wear this cap.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This word is a bit of an exception and it even has three different, totally acceptable readings. (Sorry, I swear I didn't make this up.) So here's a mnemonic to help you remember them: The traditional caps can have tree different styles. A can (かん) shape, a camel rib shape (かむり), or a canned 'murica (かんむり) shape (it's a bald eagle in a can). Can you picture them all in your head? You only need to choose one at least! Yay!

ex_1_jp: こんな空疎な論争を続けるのは時間の無駄だ。
ex_1_en: Continuing such a futile dispute is a waste of time.
meaning_story: The sky has an air of neglect about it and makes it seems like everything you're doing is in vain. Why even bother? The sky doesn't even believe in you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: その飛行機事故では、事故で多くの犠牲者がでました。

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: A whale is actually gojira's (godzilla) cool cousin kujira (くじら). Godzilla mutated from a whale, so they're still related. That's where he gets his name from!

ex_1_jp: 美味しい鯨肉の店を知っているよ。

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE

ex_1_jp: 神の怒りを鎮めるには、生贄を捧げる必要があります。
ex_1_en: In order to appease the god’s anger we need to offer a sacrifice.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tranquilize, so the verb version is what happens when you've already been able to tranquilize someone. It's to appease or to suppress.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to appease her because she's (しず) SUPER mad. She's pissed and she's angry and she's going to beat you up if you don't find out how to calm her down!

ex_1_jp: 妻の料理の盛り付けは、いつも凝っています。
ex_1_en: I’m always absorbed in the arrangement of my wife’s food.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means congeal or freeze, so the verb version is to grow stiff. But it's also used to mean what happens when your emotions or interests freeze on one thing. You start to be absorbed in whatever that thing is. Try to remember both meanings.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What have all your friends started to be absorbed in? Their 子s (こ). They all keep having kids and now that's all they seem to care about. Damn kids.

ex_1_jp: お前がちょっとした手間を惜しんだために、全ての計画がおじゃんになったんだぞ！

meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means frugal, so the verb version is to be frugal or to be sparing.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You should try to be frugal when you go to the ocean (おし). There are lots of things to buy, like delicious food, sun hats, and tofugu dolls, but you really shouldn't spend all your money there. Try to plan on spending less when you head to the ocean next time, okay?

ex_1_jp: 栃木県の出身なんですか？
ex_1_en: Are you from Tochigi Prefecture?
meaning_story: The prefecture with lots of horse chestnut trees is Tochigi prefecture.
reading_story: This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for 栃 and 木 and the on'yomi for 県, like most with prefectures. As long as you remember that き is changed to ぎ here, you should be able to remember this reading easily!

ex_1_jp: どうして弟が犯罪者であることを伏せていたんだ。
ex_1_en: Why would I cover up my younger brother being a criminal?
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bow or lay, so the verb version is what when you try to cover or to hide something. You're doing the action to something, you're not the one hiding.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who's that you're trying to cover up? It's your fool (ふ) brother. He keeps doing embarrassing things and trying to get you in trouble. So you're trying to hide him with your jacket. Well we see him, we know he's a fool, so you can stop now.

ex_1_jp: 親が子供の将来を憂えるのは当然のことだ。
ex_1_en: It’s natural for parents to be anxious about their children’s’ futures.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grieve, so the verb version is to grieve or to lament.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your aunt starts to grieve really loudly at your Uncle Ray's funeral. "Ooh, Ray (うれ)! OOoh, Ray why did you have to leave me!" It's really sad. You even hear it in your head after you've left and gone home. You've never seen someone start to be distressed like that in public.

ex_1_jp: ここに戸棚を据え付けるつもりだよ。
ex_1_en: I’m planning to install cupboards here.
meaning_story: This is a combination of the words 据える, meaning "to install," and 付ける, meaning "to attach." Put them together and you're still going to install something or to equip something. There's just more hands on work happening.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 生理前はどうしても感情の起伏が激しくなってしまう。
ex_1_en: Before my period I always get violent emotional ups and downs.
meaning_story: Wake up, now lay down, now wake up again, okay now lay again. What you're doing is called undulation. If your emotions do it it's called ups and downs. Everyone goes through stuff like this sometimes.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 病院で尿検査をして、妊娠していると言われました。
ex_1_en: I took a urinalysis test at the hospital and it said I was pregnant.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
pitch_accent: イバリ *** ニョꜜー *** ユバリ

ex_1_jp: やはり、すりたての山葵は美味しいね。
ex_1_en: Of course, freshly shaven wasabi is delicious.
meaning_story: If you dig up hollyhocks in the mountains, and grind up their roots, you'll have wasabi! Don't eat too much, or you'll burn your tongue off.
reading_story: This reading is an exception, but I'm sure (at least I hope) that you've heard the word wasabi before. It's the same in Japanese so just remember the meaning and you'll know the reading too!

ex_1_jp: 友人の披露宴に出席する際のマナーを教えてください。
ex_1_en: Please teach me manners for when I attend my friend’s wedding reception.
meaning_story: You already learned that 披露 means "announcement" or "display," so add a banquet to that and you're at a wedding reception! Or if no one's getting married but they're showing off something at a big place with food and stuff it's a just a normal reception.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 弥生時代のはじまりは紀元前300年頃です。
ex_1_en: The beginning of the Yayoi Period was approximately 300 BCE.
meaning_story: Life in Japan was increasing at it's fastest rate during the Yayoi Period. It's one of the earliest periods of history in Japan that we know about! You should look it up, if you don't already know about it.
reading_story: The reading for this word is an exception but it's the same in Japanese as it is in English. So if you just remember it's Yayoi (やよい) in English, you'll remember the Japanese too!

ex_1_jp: あなたのことが尚更嫌いになりました。
ex_1_en: I came to dislike you all the more.
meaning_story: Say furthermore again and you'll be saying it all the more.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼女は、美しく、尚且つ頭も良いが、性格は悪い。
ex_1_en: She’s beautiful, smart, and yet she has a terrible personality.
meaning_story: Okay these words are really vague so this is kinda bad. I'm sorry. But if you have any ideas to make this better email them to us! Someone that says furthermore and also a lot also says and yet all the time. People that use transition words, tend to use a bunch!
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 舞台が終わった後、拍手が鳴り止まなかった。
ex_1_en: After the scene ended, the applause did not stop roaring.
meaning_story: Hands beating together is actually applause. Though... you might be doing it wrong if you're actually beating them together.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この商品のデザインは、匠の技をもって初めて実現することができました。
ex_1_en: This product’s design was the first time I was able to implement that technique.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You meet an artisan and they're tacking pictures on a wall to sell. You want the artisan to make a picture of you too so you yell, "TACK ME (たくみ)!"

ex_1_jp: 本日は、皇太子殿下御生誕の嘉日なり。
ex_1_en: It’s the auspicious day of the Crown Prince’s birth today.
meaning_story: A day you hold in high esteem is an auspicious day. That's a fancy way of saying it's a really lucky day!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 4分の4拍子の曲では、通常、1拍目と3拍目の頭に強拍が来ます。
ex_1_en: For music in four-four time, the stress usually comes to a head at the first and third beats.
meaning_story: This counter is used to count musical beats when you're listening to or playing music.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

translation: bitter enemies in the same boat
ex_1_jp: 利害が一致すれば、呉越同舟も厭わない。
ex_1_en: If we can share mutual interests, I won’t mind being in the same boat as my rivals.
meaning_story: You give your rival information that will go beyond what you normally say and you realize the two of you are in the same boat on a lot of personal things. You are bitter enemies in the same boat! Or classic rivals, like you see in movies and read about. You never would have known if you hadn't gone beyond what you normally give people.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 舟 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What are bitter enemies in the same boat supposed to do? They shoot (しゅう) each other!
pitch_accent: ゴꜜエツドーシュー *** ゴꜜエツ・ドーシュー

ex_1_jp: ギターの弦が緩んでいます。
ex_1_en: The guitar strings are loose.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Snap all the bowstrings! Now none of the musicians can play their instruments. "You're too rude (つる)!" they yell, as they cry over the snapped bowstrings. They aren't wrong, that was just too rude of you.
pitch_accent: ゲꜜン *** ツルꜜ *** ツꜜル

ex_1_jp: 父は、毎日色の違う蝶ネクタイをしていた。
ex_1_en: My father has a different colored bow tie every day.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
pitch_accent: チョꜜー *** チョꜜーチョ *** チョーチョー

ex_1_jp: 大尉の死を決して無駄にはしません。
ex_1_en: The captain’s death wasn’t useless by any means.
meaning_story: The big military officer is in charge of everyone else. He's the captain. You can tell because he wears a really big captain hat.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今日の最高気温は、摂氏二十五度です。
ex_1_en: Today’s highest temperature was twenty-five degrees celsius.
meaning_story: Okay, so this is a stretch but stay with me! In addition to your family name, the first thing you need to learn as a child is how to understand centigrade. If you can't tell what temperature it is outside, or in your house, or in your body to tell if you're sick, you won't do so well with this living thing. So when you think back to the first things you learned in addition to your own family name, think centigrade!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 平凡な毎日に退屈していたんです。
ex_1_en: I’m bored with the ordinary every day.
meaning_story: You're so mediocre that you're flat. That's really common. Look at most of the midwest. It's really mediocre and flat too. And there's a whole lot of it out there.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 薬で意識が錯乱しているようでした。
ex_1_en: Their consciousness seemed to be confused by the medicine.
meaning_story: A confused riot causes even more confusion. Soon there will be so many distractions happening, what with cars tipping over and fires starting, that no one will know which way it up!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ご満悦のようですね。
ex_1_en: They seem to be delighted.

ex_1_jp: これは、意匠が凝らされた素晴らしい作品です。

ex_1_en: It was driven into a corner and finally showed it’s tail.

ex_1_jp: 誰も自然の摂理には逆らえないよ。
ex_1_en: No one can defy the law’s of nature.
meaning_story: Some things happen outside of reason. They happen in addition to it. That's called divine providence. You can't explain it, but something outside of reason definitely influenced the things around you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は呉服屋の一人息子でした。
ex_1_en: He’s the drapery store’s only son.
meaning_story: If you want to give clothes to other people, you have to buy draperies first and then sew them together. That's a fancy word for cloth.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 子供にゲームをさせないことによる弊害も考えておくべきです。
ex_1_en: You should also think about how evil it is to not let children play video games.
meaning_story: The evil damage you do is evil and really harmful. You should think before you do things.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 人口が増えない限り、地方経済の疲弊が回復することはないでしょう。
ex_1_en: It seems that the local economy will not recover from impoverishment unless the population increases.
meaning_story: If you're exhausted by all the evil things in your life you might die of exhaustion!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: このエージェントは、ギャラをかなり搾取することで有名だ。
ex_1_en: This agent is famous for considerably exploiting his guarantees.

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お前に三日間の猶予を与えてやろう。
ex_1_en: I suppose I’ll give you a three day extension.

ex_1_jp: その鐘の音は、遥か彼方まで響き渡った。
ex_1_en: The chimes echoed from far away.

ex_1_jp: おじいさんは、山で柴刈りをしていました。

reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 我が軍の中尉が敵軍に拉致され、処刑されました。
ex_1_en: Our army’s first lieutenant was captured by the enemy and executed.

ex_1_jp: 台風で川が氾濫し、洪水になりました。
ex_1_en: The river overflowed from the typhoon and became a flood.
meaning_story: A flood of water still makes a flood.

ex_1_jp: あいつも愚かなことをしたもんだよ。
ex_1_en: He does such stupid things.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A foolish person will take the old road (おろ), instead of the new, safe one. You have to be really stupid to take an old road that's all cracked and full of scary people. Take the new one!

ex_1_jp: 無報酬でもかまいませんよ。
ex_1_en: There’s no pay, but I don’t mind.
meaning_story: You already learned that 報酬 means "compensation," so adding not to it means you don't have to pay anything. It's free of charge. Nice!

ex_1_jp: 少年は、凛々しい青年に成長した。
ex_1_en: Boys grow into gallant young men.
meaning_story: A cold cold person is so cold that they're super cool. They're sooo cool and gallant and manly. Touch a manly person and feel how cold their skin is. It's like that all the way down to their heart.
reading_story: Usually when you see 々 it means that the reading is two on'yomi readings repeating. Well this is a bit of an exception. Saying りんりん is kinda hard so just drop the んs and you'll have the reading りり!

ex_1_jp: 彼は、英国紳士の鏡のような人でした。

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: アイドルの度重なるプッツン発言に、世間はみんな呆れました。

reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you were going to be shocked, you'd shout, "ACK (あき)!"

ex_1_jp: 新しい恋人に飽きてきたところなの。

reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you start to get tired of something you can't help but yawn "Ahh (あ)." It doesn't matter how hard you try to hold back. The "A-ah's" keep coming out.

ex_1_jp: 家庭科の授業で、雑巾を縫いました。

meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sew, so the verb version is to sew or to stitch.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to sew yourself some clothes because if you don't you'll be completely nude (ぬ). You don't want anyone to see your bits! Sew quickly!

ex_1_jp: レモンを唐揚げに搾ってもいいですか？

meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means squeeze, so the verb version is to squeeze or to wring.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A diehard fan comes up and says she would like to squeeze your hands. You let her and she bows (しぼ) over and over as she squeezes you hand really hard. You don't know why she bows so much, but you don't know how to tell her to stop.

ex_1_jp: すぐ話が脇道へ逸れてしまう。

Even if you don't do it often, if you stray, say sorry!

You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want to tie up? Your Shiba (しば) Inu! She's always running off and getting into trouble. You have to tie her up outside when you leave the house. It's sad, but at least it keeps her safe!

If you watch the news you know that this name and everything it stands for is always a topic of current debates.
reading_story: This is a combination of two words. The first two kanji take the kun'yomi readings and the second two are the jukugo word 神社. You already learned all of these readings, so you should already be able to read this word!

ex_1_jp: 当院には、循環器専門医が五人います。
ex_1_en: There are five circulatory organ specialists in this hospital.
meaning_story: You already know that 循環 means "circulation," so adding container makes it what holds things that circulate. They're your circulatory organs. They contain all the air moving throughout your body like a container.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ニモやその家族は、隠熊之実という魚だよ。
ex_1_en: Nemo and his family are fish called clownfish.
meaning_story: I want you to try to bear this truth and that's these kanji make up the word clownfish! Do you think a clownfish is this bear? I'm telling the truth! Maybe.
reading_story: This word consits of the kun'yomi readings for all the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 之 yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Clownfish love to drink egg nog (の)! But the nog gets diluted when you put it in water. Clownfish love nog but they can never taste it the way they should. How sad.

ex_1_jp: 色盲って治るんですか。
ex_1_en: Can color-blindness be cured?
meaning_story: If you're only blind to color then you have color blindness.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は私にとって、人生の羅針盤だったのです。
ex_1_en: He was my life’s compass.
meaning_story: Spread out a needle in a tray of water after rubbing it with a magnet and you'll have made a compass! Try it at home kids! It really works!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの男はたった一ヶ月で、ここでの業務を網羅した。
ex_1_en: That man covered all the tasks here in just one month.
meaning_story: If you spread out some netting enough you'll be able to see what it's comprising. But you can only do that if you spread it out really far.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: エレインという馬が、ステイゴールドの最後の子を受胎しました。
ex_1_en: The last child a horse named Elaine conceived was Stay Gold.
meaning_story: Accept a child into your womb with conception. Now there's a baby in there!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 弔意を表して花を贈りました。
ex_1_en: I sent flowers to express my condolences.
meaning_story: Express your unique idea of condolence by offering your condolences and sympathy to people who are going through hard times.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: レーシック手術では、角膜をレーザーで削るんですよ。
ex_1_en: In Lasik surgery your cornea is shaved with a laser.
meaning_story: Membranes that wrap around at an angle are in your eye. Eyes are round and the membranes have to bend around the front part at an angle. It's called your cornea.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 兄は酒と女に溺れ、敢然に堕落した生活を送っています。
ex_1_en: My brother nearly drowns in women and alcohol, and is buried in his horribly corrupted life.
meaning_story: Fall into the life of a degenerate and you'll probably get involved in lots of corruption. Stealing, stabbing, money laundering, that kind of stuff.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 烏がゴミをあさるんですよ。
ex_1_en: Crows pick through garbage.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: あなただからこそ、敢えて厳しいことを言わせてもらったんだよ。
ex_1_en: I only dared to say something so intense because it was to you.
meaning_story: This is the adverb version of the kanji daring, so it means dare to or daringly.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're about to daringly jump off a cliff and you shout, "AAAHHH (あ)!" to get your courage up! You always have to yell AAHH before you dare to do daring things!

ex_1_jp: 黒と濃紺のスーツが一着ずつあると便利ですよ。
ex_1_en: Having one black and one dark blue suit is convenient.
meaning_story: Put a thick drop of dark blue paint on a canvas and it will look like an even bolder dark blue.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 本当にこの作戦を敢行するつもりですか。
ex_1_en: Do you really intend to carry out this strategy?
meaning_story: You use your daring and just go! You made a decisive action by just going like that! It was go or not go and you chose go!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お腹がパンパンで太鼓みたいになっています。
ex_1_en: I beat my stomach "pom-pom" like a drum.
meaning_story: A really fat thing you hit to make a beat is called a drum. A taiko drum, that is. They're really big and fat looking and are super cool to watch and play!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: そんなに大声を出されたら鼓膜が破れるよ。
ex_1_en: If you play things so loudly you’ll wear out your eardrums.
meaning_story: You can hear something beat because of a membrane in your ear called an eardrum. Make sure you don't stick your fingers too far in your ear of you could really hurt it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: エコーで胎児が足を伸ばしたり縮めたりするところが見れました。
ex_1_en: I was able to see the fetus stretch and shrink on the echo.
meaning_story: A child that's still in a womb is a fetus.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 一見すると意味不明な文字の羅列のように見える。
ex_1_en: At first glance, it just looks like a random list of words.
meaning_story: Spread out a complete row of numbers in the right order and you have enumeration!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今若い女の子の間では、酵素ダイエットが流行っています。
ex_1_en: Enzyme diets are popular among young women right now.
meaning_story: The one element you need to ferment something is an enzyme. That breaks whatever you're trying to ferment down in just the right way.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 不倫でバランスをとって、なんとか心の均衡を保っているんです。
ex_1_en: I’m having an affair to keep my balance and my calm.
meaning_story: Equal out your equilibrium and you'll have solid equilibrium.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ワインの甘みを残して発酵を止める方法を教えてください。
ex_1_en: Please teach me how to keep the sweetness in wine and stop fermentation.
meaning_story: When you ferment something it makes a departure from what it originally was and transforms during fermentation into something new.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 優勝候補を相手に、よく敢闘したと思います。
ex_1_en: I think I fought pretty bravely against a favorite for the championship.
meaning_story: If you're involved in a daring struggle you need to be strong and fight bravely. Even if you might get hurt, you should do your best!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どのくらい頻繁に水槽の掃除をしますか。
ex_1_en: How often do you clean the fish tank?
meaning_story: A tank of water can be used as a fish tank or a water tank for drinking. It really only depends on you and how many fish you have.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あなたの役目は、二人の恋の萌芽を絶つことよ。
ex_1_en: Your duty is to suppress the germination of love between people.
meaning_story: A sprout that sprouts can thank germination for being able to sprout nice and big and strong.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 芽 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When a plant sprouts out of the ground it's still a baby so all it can say is goo goo ga ga (が).

ex_1_jp: 彼女は、憂いを帯びた顔でこちらを見ていた。
ex_1_en: She looked this way with a sorrowful expression on her face.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of grief? It's grief or distress.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 憂える. Remember that and you'll remember this!

pronunciation: ちょう, わた, はらわた
ex_1_jp: 腸の働きをよくする運動をご紹介します。
ex_1_en: I introduced exercise to improve my bowel movements.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
pitch_accent: チョꜜー *** ハラワꜜタ *** ハラワタ *** ハラワタꜜ *** ワタꜜ

ex_1_jp: あの女性の鼓の打ち方は絶品だ。
ex_1_en: The way that woman hit her hand drum was superb.
meaning_story: What do you hit to make a sick beat? A cool little hand drum.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You like to use your hand drum when two dudes meet (つづみ). You drum and tap it and it as they high five and it makes them super uncomfortable with makes you super happy. That's why you love your hand drum so much.

ex_1_jp: この映画は何遍みても泣けます。
ex_1_en: No matter how many time I see this movie, I always cry.
meaning_story: What's universal? How many times do you think that question's been asked throughout time? Probably a lot of times.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because へん becomes べん here.

ex_1_jp: あの監督は、選手たちの士気を鼓舞するのがうまい。
ex_1_en: That coach is good at encouraging player morale.
meaning_story: The beat makes you want to dance. It's the inspiration you need to dance.The beat gives you encouragement to dance all night long. And without such a rockin' beat you would have lame dance moves.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: サイトへのアクセスが遮断されました。
ex_1_en: Access to the site has been cut off.
meaning_story: If you intercept trade and cut off a country from the rest of the world they'll be stuck in a state of isolation or if they have some kind of disease like zombie-itus, it's a quarantine.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 大腸がんが見つかりました。
ex_1_en: They found large intestine cancer.
meaning_story: The big intestines are called the large intestine, or the colon. It's where your poop goes and comes from!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 我が社では、特殊な技術を用いて、樹脂凸版の直接製版を格安で行っています。
ex_1_en: At out company we use special techniques to cheaply do resin relief printing and direct plate making.
meaning_story: Press uneven carvings into paper to make the newest edition of your magazine. What you're using is a letterpress. This made mass printing nice and cheap(ish) in Japan!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because はん becomes ぱん here.

ex_1_jp: 日本が多くの国に円借款を提供しているのはご存知ですか。
ex_1_en: Did you know that Japan offers international yen loans to many countries?
meaning_story: An article that proves that you're only borrowing money or stuffed animals, and it's called a loan. You have to pay that person back for those fluffy critters.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 森林を伐採する際は、事前に届け出が必要です。
ex_1_en: Notification is necessary before felling a forest.
meaning_story: Fell trees and gather them up. That's called lumbering. Or if you cut them all down and take every last one, it's deforestation and you should be ashamed!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼氏がいつも鍋奉行をしてくれます。
ex_1_en: I always let my boyfriend be in charge of the nabe.
meaning_story: If you can dedicate yourself to going to a bunch of meetings and dealing with everyone's problems you'll make a good magistrate.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned either of these readings yet. Sorry! Here's a mnemonic to help you: The magistrate is the only person who's allowed to wear boots in Kyoto (ぶぎょう). If you see someone wearing boots while you're there, you'll know that person is the magistrate!

ex_1_jp: 楓の葉も色づいてきました。
ex_1_en: The maple leaves started to change color too.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

pronunciation: ふうとう, かえでとう
ex_1_jp: 料理には砂糖の代わりに楓糖を使うことが多いです。
ex_1_en: I often use maple sugar instead of sugar in my cooking.
meaning_story: Maple sugar is maple sugar!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの家からは、いつも美しいピアノの旋律が聞こえていました。
ex_1_en: I can always hear the melody of a beautiful piano from that house.
meaning_story: If you follow the law of rotation while you play music you'll end up with a lovely melody. If you don't, you'll miss all the cues on beat that rotation gives you and it will sound like crap.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 牛乳を温めると薄い膜が張ることがあります。
ex_1_en: A thin film forms when I warm milk.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 誰が弔辞を読むのですか。
ex_1_en: Who will read the funeral address?
meaning_story: When someone quits living you need to offer your condolences during their memorial address. Let it all out and tell everyone what you thought about that dead guy.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 少女の白い肌に、紺のワンピースがよく似合っていた。
ex_1_en: The navy blue dress suits that young lady’s fair skin.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: 一遍だけでいいから、キャビアを食べてみたかったの。
ex_1_en: I wanted to eat caviar but one time was enough.
meaning_story: One universal event can only happen once. It's too rare to happen more than that.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because へん becomes ぺん here.

pronunciation: うーろんちゃ, ウーロンちゃ
ex_1_jp: 烏龍茶を氷抜きでください。
ex_1_en: Oolong tea without ice, please.
meaning_story: Imperial tea the color of a crow's feathers can only be the famous, delicious Oolong tea. It came from the imperial people of China to Japan (probably) and there are lots of different variants. But the leaves are all that blackish/grey crow feather color.
reading_story: This word takes the on'yomi readings except for 龍 which is an exception (sorry). You haven't learned the on'yomi for 烏 yet either, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who loves Oolong tea more than anyone else? Oooo Ron (うーろん) Weasley from Harry Potter. He's British, so of course you'd think he loves tea, but Oolong is his jam. Just picture him and think, oooooh it's Ron, when you drink this kind of tea. And make sure you remember that, because this is also a written in katakana when the kanji isn't used, to type out the long mark ー when you enter your answer.

ex_1_jp: 航海の途中で海賊に襲われました。
ex_1_en: During the voyage they were attacked by pirates.
meaning_story: Robbers who sail on the high seas are pirates! Arrr!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 出産後、妻の胎盤を食べてみました。
ex_1_en: I ate my wife’s placenta after she gave birth.
meaning_story: Something comes out of a womb and is then put on a tray. It's the afterbirth. Yeah, yeah, eww. Grow up, it's a word you should know.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この峡谷に架かる吊橋を渡ったことはありますか？
ex_1_en: Have you ever crossed the bridge that spans over the this ravine?
meaning_story: A ravine in a valley is still a ravine. It can also be a gorge or a canyon. They're usually really big. Like the Grand Canyon!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 谷 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're going to travel through a huge ravine you have to stay hydrated. The best thing to bring is some taste, cold Coke (こく). Nothing quenches your thirst from sweating through a long, rough ravine like delicious Coke!

ex_1_jp: 私は、迎賓館に招待されました。
ex_1_en: I was invited to the reception hall.
meaning_story: A public building where you welcome VIP guests is a reception hall. Or a guest house if they're staying the night.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 惜しい人を亡くしたものだ。
ex_1_en: I lost a precious person.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of frugal? It's regrettable or precious. If you're too frugal to buy something your actions are regrettable later when you realize you wanted that thing. If you're so frugal you only buy one single thing, it's very precious to you.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You made a regrettable decision. You didn't buy that clock you wanted and now it's been discontinued. The salesperson tells you this and all you can say is, "Oh..." (お) really really quietly. How disappointing.

ex_1_jp: 彼は、世界各地で果敢な取材をしていた。
ex_1_en: He boldly collected data from all over the world.
meaning_story: A daring fruit is very resolute and bold! She's going to go out and be a fruit superhero or scientist or something.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 網膜とは、カメラのフィルムに似た、眼の奥の膜のことです。
ex_1_en: The retina is a membrane inside your eye that resembles a camera’s film.
meaning_story: The nerve netting in the back of your eye is made up of membranes called the retina. It's what let's light in to help you see!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: モꜜーマク *** モーマク

ex_1_jp: 原稿を校閲してもらえませんか。
ex_1_en: Could you revise my manuscript for me?
meaning_story: An inspection you make of your homework before school is a revision. Sometimes proofreading will help you find mistakes before you hand it in too. Just make sure you look everything over.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ガレージで八の字旋回の練習をしてみました。
ex_1_en: I practiced a figure eight turn in the garage.
meaning_story: It doesn't matter how many times a rotation goes around, it's still a rotation.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 会社から、三割の減俸を言い渡されました。
ex_1_en: A thirty percent salary cut was announced by the company.
meaning_story: Your boss says she's going to decrease your salary with a company-wide salary reduction. You should probably start looking for a new job that won't do salary cuts like this.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because ほう becomes ぽう here.

pronunciation: あらじお, あらしお
ex_1_jp: お風呂に粗塩を入れると体にいいらしいですよ。
ex_1_en: Putting sea salt in baths seems to be good for you.
meaning_story: If you want to find some coarse salt just dive in the sea and collect sea salt! The pieces are nice and big and lumpy, so you really taste it when you're cooking.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どーも、報告乙です。
ex_1_en: Hey, thanks for the report.
ex_2_jp: 合同会社Tofuguを甲とし、Wanikaniを乙として、甲の業務の委託に関して、次の通り契約を締結する。
ex_2_en: We agree with the contract as outlined below with regards to the subcontract of the first company, Tofugu, and the second company, WaniKani.
ex_3_jp: こうして山頂から生まれ故郷を見渡すのも、また乙なものですねぇ。
ex_3_en: It’s very neat to look over my hometown from the top of the mountain.
meaning_story: If something is the latter, it can't be first, it has to be at least second. This works for lists too. So if you have A through D, it's going to be B.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
pitch_accent: オꜜツ *** オツ *** キノꜜト

ex_1_jp: 烏賊の刺し身が大好物です。
ex_1_en: Squid sashimi is my favorite food.
meaning_story: Look in the sea and you'll see what looks like a crow moving under the water and it's a thief! It's stealing from all the fish. As it comes closer you see that it isn't a crow, it's a squid. Or a cuttlefish? One or the other.
reading_story: The reading for this word is an exception. I'd give you a mnemonic to remember it but it looks like the mnemonic for いか is いか! If you've been paying attention, you know this is squid already!

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 胃腸がそんなに丈夫な方ではありません。
ex_1_en: My stomach isn’t very strong.
meaning_story: Intestines and stomach make up the stomach in your body.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 今度こそ盗賊の隠れ家を突き止めてやる。
ex_1_en: I’ll find the thief’s hiding place this time.
meaning_story: A robber who steals is a thief. And still a robber, I guess.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: アイドルの大胆な発言が物議を醸している。
ex_1_en: The idol’s bold statement is giving rise to public criticism.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means brew, so the verb version is to brew or to distill.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to brew up some beer but not the regular boring stuff. You're going to make it from the water in the hump of a camel (かも). Camel beer is definitely not a horrible idea, right?

ex_1_jp: 人の話を遮るのは失礼です。
ex_1_en: It’s rude to interrupt a person.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means intercept, so the verb version is to intercept or to interrupt.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you want to interrupt and to intercept is your roommate's sighing guitar (さえぎ). He keeps playing it and all it does is make these horrible, long sighing sounds. You want to interrupt it any any cost.

ex_1_jp: ここには、殉職者の魂を弔う石碑が建てられています。
ex_1_en: We’re building a stone memorial for the souls of soldiers who died in battle.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means condolence, so the verb version is to mourn for or to condole.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You seem to mourn for things you really care about. Well then you would mourn for your toe mural (とむら). You had a mural made for your favorite toe so if anything were to happen to it, you would want to mourn for it.
pitch_accent: トブラꜜウ *** トムラꜜウ

ex_1_jp: とりあえず、今は父の怒りが鎮まるのを待ちましょう。
ex_1_en: For the time being, let’s wait until dad’s anger has calmed down.
meaning_story: You already learned that 鎮める means "to appease," but this one is what happens after they've been appeased. They start to quiet down.
reading_story: ince this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you're in the library the librarian is always telling you to quiet down. She's (しず) so mean! She never let's you talk in the library. Who's mean to you? She's mean to you!!

ex_1_jp: こうやって醤油に漬けて食べてください。
ex_1_en: Please eat it dipped in soy sauce like this.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pickle or soak, so the verb version is to pickle or to soak.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji. Good for you!

ex_1_jp: 過去の男性遍歴を語ってくる女ってマジでうざいよな。
ex_1_en: Don’t you think a woman who talks about her history with men is super annoying?

reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_en: Periodic thinning of forests makes the rest of trees grow thick trunks and tough, healthy branches and leaves.
meaning_story: Fell trees in intervals, instead of all at once, and it's called tree thinning. That way there's still some forest there, but you get your wood to use for other things too.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: While you live as a normal human citizen you also have another life as a cutter walrus (かたわ)! That's a walrus that cuts fish up while eating. It's your secret double life. You do it at night while you are a human by day!

ex_1_jp: つまり彼は二人にとって触媒のような役割を果たしたということだ。
ex_1_en: In other words, he managed to play the role of the catalyst for those two people.

ex_1_jp: 監督の更迭が求められている。

ex_1_jp: 育てたひよこが鶏になりました。
ex_1_en: The chick I raised became a chicken.

reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: A chicken is a newer 鳥 (にわとり). Well, it's a newer type of 鳥 compared to falcons and condors that have been around for ages. But chickens have only been around as long as us humans. Making them newer birds.

ex_1_jp: 鶏卵は日本が自給自足できる唯一の蛋白源です。
ex_1_en: Chicken eggs are the only source of protein in Japan that is self sufficient.
meaning_story: A chicken egg is a chicken egg.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 卵 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who loves chicken eggs? Randy (らん) Savage! Especially when he eats them with slim jims. Mmm eggs and slim jims. You should give it a try.

ex_1_jp: 養鶏経営の難しさを痛感しました。
ex_1_en: I realized how difficult managing poultry raising is.
meaning_story: Foster a bunch of chickens and start chicken farming! They will be your best friends! Your only friends.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

pronunciation: とりにく, けいにく
ex_1_jp: できるだけ鶏肉のささみを食べるようにしています。
ex_1_en: I try to make sure I eat as much white meat from chicken as I can.
meaning_story: Chicken meat is chicken meat!

ex_1_jp: この作家の年譜を作ってくれないか。

ex_1_jp: 七月には、妻の父の一周忌の法事があります。

Maybe it was the death of your mom, your grandad or your goldfish, this is the first year since they died.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あいつらとは紳士協定を結んでいるはずだ。

ex_1_jp: 未だに淑やかな女性が好きな男性は多い。
ex_1_en: Even now there are many men who like modest women.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're trying to be graceful and polite you have to cut certain words out of your vocabulary. The number one being sh*t (しと). You can't say you need to "go take a sh*t" during an international conference or a fancy dinner! You need to be modest and not use that word, geez.

ex_1_jp: 犯人と間違われて手錠を掛けられたんだ。
ex_1_en: I was mistaken for a criminal and handcuffed.
meaning_story: You want to lock this criminals hands up so he wont go punching anymore grandpas. You need some handcuffs to make sure he doesn't go around being a criminal anymore. Then you can lock him up good.

ex_1_jp: 江戸時代には縛り首という刑罰があった。
ex_1_en: In the Edo period, there was a punishment called death by hanging.
meaning_story: Remember how 縛る means "to tie?" Well if you tie something around someone's neck then it's called hanging. They'll probably die from it too, so it can also be death by hanging.
reading_story: This is a combination of the words 縛る and 首. Both use the kun'yomi readings, so just change the る to り and it's pretty simple!

ex_1_jp: 日本史上、 最強の豪傑は誰だと思いますか。

meaning_story: If you look back in history and see someone who's greatness seems sooo luxurious to you, they're probably a hero. Not just a normal person, but like Hercules or Mae Jemison.

ex_1_jp: あいつは色呆けしてるんだよ。

reading_story: Remember when you learned 呆ける? Well just cut the る part off the end and it's exactly the same! If you can remember that, you'll remember this reading as well.

ex_1_jp: これは不朽の名作です。
