ex_1_jp: 譜面を無料でダウンロードできるサイトを探しています。
ex_1_en: I’m looking for a site where I can download music for free.
meaning_story: On the surface of a score you'll find music. This is only written music though, so remember that this music has to be on the surface of some paper.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 子供に管弦楽を習わせたいと思っています。
ex_1_en: I want to let the children learn orchestral music.
meaning_story: You already know that 弦楽 means "string music," so add some pipes to that, like trumpets and saxophones, and you'll have orchestral music. You can't have a whole orchestra with just the string section!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 罪人は容赦なく罰せられなくてはならない。
ex_1_en: The criminal must be punished without mercy!
meaning_story: Form a pardon with your mouth and actually pardon someone. Show your forgiveness with the words "I'm sorry."
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの人は、再雇用制度を利用した嘱託社員なんです。
ex_1_en: That person is a part-time employee who used the reemployment system.
meaning_story: A company requests consignment work and you take it to become a part time employee.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 錠剤を飲み込むことができないので、砕いて飲んでいます。
ex_1_en: I can’t swallow pills, so I smash and drink them.
meaning_story: You take a dose of medicine but it gets locked in your throat because it's the kind of pill you chew, not shallow! You need to pay attention to which one is which or it won't help at all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 湖の水質汚濁を防止するために規制が設けられた。
ex_1_en: A regulation was established to prevent the pollution of the lake.
meaning_story: If the air is muddy and dirty it's because there is too much pollution in that area. You should wear a mask and be careful of contamination.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの画家に私の肖像を描かせてみよう。
ex_1_en: I’ll let the artist paint my portrait.
meaning_story: Art that's so good it resembles a statue of a person is actually a portrait. Really, it resembles the original person, but it looks like it's a portrait of a statue of a person.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は特別に罪の赦免が認められた。
ex_1_en: The special absolution of his crimes were recognized.
meaning_story: Your excuse to pardon yourself from cancer treatment is that you went into remission! Congrats!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 職場では理不尽なことが多くて憤りを感じています。
ex_1_en: There are many unreasonable things to feel resentment about at work.
meaning_story: This is the noun version of the kanji resent, so it means resentment.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You feel some pretty strong resentment toward your roommate because you had to touch their icky door (いきどお) today and it was covered in what you hope was glue. Or frosting. UHG what an icky door. This is an outrage!!!
pitch_accent: イキドーリ *** イキドーリꜜ

ex_1_jp: うちの社長は資金繰りに奔走しています。
ex_1_en: My company is running fundraising.
meaning_story: If you bustle and run around all day from being busy you end up running about to get them all done. It takes a lot of running to get every activity you have planned done in one day.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: そろそろ帆を替えるなくちゃいかんなあ。
ex_1_en: Looks like you have to replace the sail soon.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When you sail in a ship you can't forget to bring a garden hoe (ほ). If you lose your sails or your paddles, you can always use a hoe to paddle your way back. Or if you wreck on an island you can use the hoe to garden so you won't die of starvation! Hoes are very handy!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ほら、あそこにヨットが帆走しているよ。
ex_1_en: Look, there’s a yacht sailing over there.
meaning_story: A sail runs boats along the sea by sailing! You can't run along the water unless the sail is out and catching the wind.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ピアノは弾けますが、楽譜は読めません。
ex_1_en: I can play the piano but I can’t read sheet music.
meaning_story: The kind of score that comforts you is a musical score. The music is really relaxing.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 自分で縫ったので縫い目がガタガタなんです。
ex_1_en: I sewed it myself, so the stitches are crooked.
meaning_story: Remember how 縫う means "to sew." Well the only way you can see if a pair of jeans has been sewed with your eye is if you see a seam. If your eyes can't spot the stitches, then it probably wasn't sewed at all. Maybe it was superglued together.
reading_story: This is a combination of the words 縫う and 目. Both use the kun'yomi readings so just change the う to い and it's easy! You'll also see this word spelled 縫い目 too. They're exactly the same!

ex_1_jp: 蟹の殻はこの皿に入れてください。
ex_1_en: Please put crab shells on this plate.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Shells come from (から) living animals. You can't have a shell unless something was once in there. They have to come from something.

ex_1_jp: 妻は、美しい絹のガウンを羽織って死んでいました。
ex_1_en: My wife put on a beautiful silk gown and died.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Wearing silk is the the key (き) to not being nude (ぬ). Wear it!

ex_1_jp: 西陣の糸屋で絹糸を買ってきてちょうだい。
ex_1_en: Please go buy silk thread at the Nishijin thread store.
meaning_story: A silk thread is silk thread!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 糸 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who only uses silk thread in his clothes? Charlie Sheen (し)! Picture Charlie Sheen wrapped up in silk threads. Mmm.

ex_1_jp: 交通事故で脊椎を損傷し、下半身不随になったのです。
ex_1_en: My spine was damaged in the traffic accident and the bottom half of my body became paralyzed.
meaning_story: Your height can only reach the size of an oak if you have a strong spine to back you up.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: セキツイ *** セキꜜツイ

ex_1_jp: 私の叔父は、弦楽器の修理をしています。
ex_1_en: My uncle repairs stringed instruments.
meaning_story: You already know that 楽器 means "musical instrument" so adding a couple of bowstrings to it will make it a stringed instrument.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 感慨がこめられた彼女の歌声に感動しました。
ex_1_en: I was deeply moved by the strong feelings in her voice when she sang.
meaning_story: Feelings that make you sigh out loud are really strong feelings. You wouldn't sigh if they didn't move you so much.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どこで硫酸を手に入れたんだ。
ex_1_en: Where can I get my hands on some sulfuric acid?
meaning_story: Mix sulfur and acid and you'll get sulfuric acid! That's how science works! How simple!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 扶養の範囲内で働かせてください。
ex_1_en: Please let me work in support.
meaning_story: Aid and foster someone to show your support for them.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あいつは執行猶予期間中に他の刑事事件を起こしたんだよ。
ex_1_en: That guy caused other criminal cases during his suspended sentence.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 猶予 means "extension?" Well the jury is tenacious grip on the idea of trying to let you go and they request an extension, so they give you a suspended sentence until they can figure out how to do it properly. You might be set free! E... eventually.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 起訴猶予処分がくだされました。
ex_1_en: The suspension of indictment punishment was passed.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 猶予 means "extension?" Well you wake up ready to sue people when you're told there has been an extension, meaning there was a suspension of indictment on your case. What the heck, you woke up ready for this! Now you have to wait to try and sue them.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: よく、禁忌を犯すと手足をもがれると言われますが、これは本当でしょうか。
ex_1_en: It’s often said that your hands and feet are plucked off when you commit a taboo, is that true?
meaning_story: Prohibition of something with a punishment so serious that you'll end up in mourning after is a taboo.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 拍子抜けしてしまったよ。
ex_1_en: Well that was anticlimactic.
meaning_story: The child of musical beats is the tempo. You can only keep time if you have a good beat to guide you, like a father.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 拍 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You get the tempo and the rhythm going in your body. You can't help but sing out loud, "Heyo (ひょう), heyo!" Feel that rhythm and sing with me! HEYO HEYO!
pitch_accent: ヒョーシꜜ *** ヒョーシ

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ストレス解消に窃盗を繰り返していたそうだ。
ex_1_en: It seems that he keeps stealing for stress reduction.
meaning_story: You decided to steal... and then you steal again a few minutes later! Now you're wanted for theft. Stealing is wrong, you should have known better!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 金縛りにあったことはありますか。
ex_1_en: Have you ever had sleep paralysis before?
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that gold 縛る means "to bind?" Well if you're being bound because of gold then you're tied down by money. This word also means sleep paralysis. Just imagine if you were dreaming that your body felt like it had turned to gold and that you were tied down too.
reading_story: This is a combination of the words 金 and 縛る. Both use the kun'yomi readings, but 金 becomes かな instead of かね. If you can remember that exception, this should be easy!
pitch_accent: カナシバリ *** カナシꜜバリ

ex_1_jp: 部屋があまりに汚かったので、呆れ返ってしまいました。
ex_1_en: I was utterly amazed because the room was horribly dirty.
meaning_story: This is a combination of the word 呆れる meaning "to be amazed" and 返る meaning "to be returned." You're so amazed at something that it keeps returning to your mind. It means to be utterly amazed!
reading_story: This is a combination of the words 呆れる and 返る. 呆れる becomes 呆れ and you just add 返る to it. So reading this should be pretty simple.

ex_1_jp: 結局成功もせず、女もできずに朽ちていくはめになった。
ex_1_en: In the end, I didn’t succeed, never had a girlfriend, and now I’m going to die out.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decay, so the verb version is to decay or to die out.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The entire world would start to die out if there were no cookies (く) left! Can you imagine your life without cookies? The trees and animals would all die too. Because they love cookies. Not just us humans.

ex_1_jp: 貧乏な時は、雑草を食べて飢えを凌いでいました。
ex_1_en: When I was poor I ate weeds to stave off starvation.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure, so the verb version is to endure or to keep out.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: 核心をついた質問に、社長は言葉を濁した。
ex_1_en: At the heart of the problem, the company president was vague.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means muddy, so the verb version is to make muddy or to make cloudy.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to make muddy, meaning make yourself muddy, you should have your knees go (にご) first. When you have your knees go first the mud splashes all over you but you don't hurt your hands or your butt doing it.

ex_1_jp: 急いでバケツに水を酌んできてください。
ex_1_en: Please pour water into this bucket quickly.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means serve, so the verb version is to serve or to pour.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you decide to serve your guests? Cookies (く)! But not just any cookies. Cookie smoothies! They're delicious and you won't pour anyone anything else. They must drink your delicious cookie drinks.

ex_1_jp: 飽くまでも、これは個人的な見解です。
ex_1_en: This is a stubbornly self-centered opinion.
meaning_story: I'm so bored. On top of my boredom is くまでも. If you took this separately, it would mean "even as a bear." So it's like you're saying I'm so bored, even if I was a bear. If you're so bored that you'd be bored even as a bear, you're going to be bored to the last or to the end. Nothing will please you, you bored bear person.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned 飽きる so you should be able to read this one too!

ex_1_jp: 子犬と戯れている少女の写真を撮りました。
ex_1_en: I took a picture of the puppy and the girl playing with it.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means play, so the verb version is to play with or to toy with someone.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Everyone always seems to yell at you when you start to toy with your towel (たわ). Just because you don't have anything on under it doesn't mean you can't mess with it! Right?!
pitch_accent: ザレꜜル *** ジャレꜜル *** タワムレꜜル

ex_1_jp: この忌まわしい記憶をどうか消し去ってください。
ex_1_en: Please erase this disgusting memory somehow.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of mourning? It's unpleasant or disgusting. Nobody said mourning was fun.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your mourning is especially unpleasant because it's your pet eagle (い) you're mourning for. Your parents wouldn't let you bury him so you're just staring at his week old, dead eagle body. It's super disgusting, actually.

ex_1_jp: 私って、飽きっぽいのよね。
ex_1_en: Well, I’m fickle.
meaning_story: If you're bored all the time it makes you tired and the weariness you feel will show on your face.
reading_story: Remember how you learned 飽きる? Well just take of the る and it's the same thing. If you can remember that, you'll know this no problem!

ex_1_jp: あの自由奔放な性格に惹かれてしまったんだ。
ex_1_en: I was attracted to his free and uninhibited personality.
meaning_story: Some day you'll run around, released from the world and its troubles and you'll end up running wild. All your actions will be completely uninhibited when you aren't tied to your school or your job. It will be great!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because ほう becomes ぽう here.

ex_1_jp: その時、日本のマグロ漁船「第五福竜丸」がたまたまビキニ環礁を航行しており、乗組員が被ばくしてしまった。
ex_1_en: The Japanese tuna boat "S.S. Lucky Dragon 5" accidentally sailed around Bikini Atoll and the crew was exposed to radiation.
meaning_story: A reef in the shape of a loop is an atoll. If you don't know what that is, it's a circular coral reef.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 一遍にいろんなことを言われても、分からないわ。
ex_1_en: If you say a bunch of things at once I won’t understand.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 一遍 means "once?" Well if you add に and make it an adverb, it becomes at once.
reading_story: This has the same reading you learned with 一遍 so you should be able to remember this too!

ex_1_jp: 叔母は学校の先生をしています。
ex_1_en: My aunt is a school teacher.
meaning_story: An aunt on your mother's side is still your aunt. This aunt always has to be younger than her though.
reading_story: The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the 伯母 which means aunt too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one aunt, you know them all!

ex_1_jp: 親しい友人の慶事は自分のことの様にうれしい。
ex_1_en: The happy events my close friends have make me as happy as if they were my own.
meaning_story: A thing that happens that makes you want to congratulate the person who it happened to makes it an auspicious event. You'll remember this for a long, long time.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 失恋の憂き目に合いました。
ex_1_en: I met with the misery of a broken heart.
meaning_story: Grief shows in your eyes by making them look like you've gone through a lot of bitterness and hardship. You can always see it in someone else if you look them in the eyes too.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for the kanji. You kind of learned this reading for 憂, but not exactly. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: The bitterness that shows in your eyes takes the rays (れ) of light out of them, leaving you with just the う part of the reading that you know. That's why this reading is just う and not うれ like the others.

ex_1_jp: グループは、大胆にも真っ昼間から犯行に及んだのです。
ex_1_en: The group is bold to commit crimes in broad daylight.
meaning_story: If you have really big guts you're a super bold and daring person. In fact, you might even be superman. That's how big your guts are. Don't worry, I don't tell anyone I know who you are. It'll be our little secret.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 岬の突端にカフェがあるんです。
ex_1_en: There’s a cafe on the tip of the cape.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: ここで、プラチナ・コインの鋳造をします。
ex_1_en: Platinum coins are cast here.
meaning_story: If you want to create a cast you need to learn casting first. Then you can make lots of neat art, crafts, and counterfeit money. Wait, no, don't do that last one.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned both of them, so you should already know this word!

ex_1_jp: 1996年から2013年までのトップ日本語学習サイト20の変遷を見てみましょう。
ex_1_en: Let’s look at the changes in the top 20 Japanese language learning sites between 1996 and 2013.
meaning_story: Change and transition mean change and transition! Nifty.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 慶祝の意を表して、乾杯！
ex_1_en: To show our congratulations, a toast!
meaning_story: You congratulate someone and celebrate by saying congratulations and having a celebration!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 慶弔用の礼服は持っているのか。
ex_1_en: Do you have ceremonial dress for celebration and condolences?
meaning_story: If you are saying congratulations and also giving your condolences then they are congratulations and condolences. Pretty easy, right?
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 父が危篤だという電話がありました。
ex_1_en: There was a call saying dad was in critical condition.
meaning_story: If someone is so dangerous that they deliberately hurt you, you're going to end up in critical condition. This wasn't an accident, they knew what they were doing and they didn't miss. Now you're on the verge of death. Hold on, kiddo.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 遮断機が降りている時に、線路を渡ってはいけません。
ex_1_en: When the railroad crossing gate comes down, do not cross the tracks.
meaning_story: Remember how 遮断 means "isolation?" Well the machine that isolates you from a train is a crossing gate. That way you won't walk, bike, or drive your car into an oncoming train.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ここは日本酪農発祥の地です。
ex_1_en: This is the location of the origin of Japanese dairy farming.
meaning_story: Dairy farming is dairy farming!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 田舎の支店に左遷されました。
ex_1_en: I was demoted to a branch store in the country.
meaning_story: Usually if you're going to the left in Japanese, it's not a good thing. So if you transition to the left it's seen as a demotion. Going to the right is way better.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 駅の南裏は、いつも閑散としています。
ex_1_en: The south side of the station is always deserted.
meaning_story: It's such a leisurely day that everyone has scattered and left the area deserted. It's just you now. Lounging in the shade.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 息子は、受験に失敗して落胆しているんだ。
ex_1_en: My son failed an exam and is discouraged.
meaning_story: Your guts feel like they're falling when you experience a lot of discouragement. You know that sinking feeling you get in the pit of your stomach? That's your guts falling!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 食品会社の擬装を許してはいけません。
ex_1_en: You must not excuse the food company’s disguise.
meaning_story: Use attire that imitates your surroundings to create a disguise. Or throw on some camouflage so that no one will be able to find you in Walmart.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 太平洋戦争のことを、大東亜戦争と呼ぶのは何故ですか。
ex_1_en: Why is the Pacific War called The Greater East Asian War?
meaning_story: East Asia is East Asia! That's where Japan is!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 大腸菌を美少女に擬人化させたカードアプリ・ゲームがあります。
ex_1_en: There’s a card app game that personifies E. Coli as a beautiful woman.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 大腸 means "large intestines?" Well when you get bacteria in there you end up with E. Coli. Go to a doctor right away! You're gonna be stuck in the bathroom for a while. Sorry...
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: ダイチョーキン *** ダイチョꜜーキン

ex_1_jp: この犬は雌ですか？
ex_1_en: Is this dog female?
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

ex_1_jp: ヒマラヤスギは、樹齢30年を超えないと雌花を付けません。
ex_1_en: You can’t cross a 30 year old Himalayan Cedar with a female flower.
meaning_story: A female flower is a female flower!
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 取り敢えず枝豆とビールをください。
ex_1_en: Edamame and beer for now please.
meaning_story: If you only take daring and you don't have any yourself, you only have it for the time being. It will go away if you can't make it yourself.
reading_story: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for the kanji. You learned both of these already, so you should be able to read this with no problems!

ex_1_jp: 親睦を深めるためのパーティーを準備しています。
ex_1_en: Our friendship is deepening as we prepare for the party.
meaning_story: If a parent is friendly enough you can form a friendship with them, not just a kid/parent bond.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 胆嚢炎は、ほとんどの場合、胆石が原因です。
ex_1_en: With inflammation of the gallbladder, the most likely cause is gallstones.
meaning_story: Stones that form in your guts are gallstones. Sometimes you have to get them surgically taken out. Scary!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: タンセキ *** タꜜンセキ

ex_1_jp: 先進国と新興国・発展途上国間の経常収支の不均衡は是正されるのでしょうか。
ex_1_en: Will the current account imbalances of developing countries be corrected between developed and undeveloped countries?
meaning_story: Remember how 均衡 means "balance?" Well if you do not have any balance, you're going to have an imbalance instead.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 模擬試験の結果はどうだったの？
ex_1_en: How were the results of the mock exam?
meaning_story: Food that imitates an imitation of some OTHER food, is an even worse imitation. You don't want to eat that. It's a sham! It's mocking real food! It's probably made of dust and cardboard!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 大型台風が甚大な被害をもたらした。
ex_1_en: An immense typhoon brought on serious damage.
meaning_story: Another way to say something is very big is to say it is immense or enormous.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: こんな侮辱を受けて、黙っていろというのか。
ex_1_en: I received the insults and remained silent.
meaning_story: You despise this one guy so much that you want to humiliate him so you insult him in public. That wasn't very nice, but it did seem to embarrass him. I guess you won.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 漆黒の闇に青い地球が浮かんでいた。
ex_1_en: The earth appeared in the black darkness.
meaning_story: Lacquer black looks jet black, or pitch black. It's as black as black can be!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 漆の葉を触ると手がかぶれますよ。
ex_1_en: If you touch a lacquer leaf you’ll get a rash on your hand.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You make lacquer out of uni root sh*t (うるし). You gotta get deep in the uni to the root of it's sh*t and rub it into a paste to make the lacquer. Then rub that on wooden stuff! Yay! Uni root sh*t!

ex_1_jp: 漆器の手入れの仕方を教えてください。
ex_1_en: Please teach me how to maintain lacquer ware.
meaning_story: Lacquer containers are called Lacquerware. Those pretty bowls you're eating out of? That shininess is because it's lacquerware!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 法曹を目指そうと思ったきっかけは何ですか。
ex_1_en: What made you pursue your dream of becoming a lawyer?
meaning_story: The official method of doing anything requires hiring a lawyer. They have to be there when you sign forms or sue people, or it isn't official at all.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: お前はもう少し胆を練る必要がある。
ex_1_en: You need to build up your courage.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: You already learned that 肝 means liver too, well they have the same reading. So if you remember that one, you know this one too.

ex_1_jp: 自然の崇高な美しさに感動しました。
ex_1_en: I was deeply moved by the noble beauty of nature.
meaning_story: You worship someone who is so high above you that you can't help but be in awe of their loftiness. Their nobility is the reason you feel like you should worship them in the first place.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 婚姻届を役所に提出しました。
ex_1_en: I submitted the marriage registration at the public office.
meaning_story: Marry and marriage still make marriage. Congratulations! Wooh! Yay!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 卑劣な手段を使いやがって。
ex_1_en: You played a mean trick!
meaning_story: If you treat someone in a lowly manner because you think they're inferior to you then you're a mean person. Plain and simple.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: どうしてすぐに卑屈になるの？
ex_1_en: Why do you immediately become subservient?
meaning_story: A lowly person who yields to everyone ends up doing menial labor and is really subservient. They'll do everything people tell them because they don't have the nerves to speak up and just say no.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 来年は、遷都1500年記念のイベントが開催されます。
ex_1_en: Next year an event is being held for the 1500 year anniversary of the relocation of the capital.
meaning_story: If you want to transition the capital to a new, better place, you need to move the capital. This used to happen a lot way back in Japanese history. It's actually pretty interesting so you might want to read up on it!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: ご無沙汰しております。
ex_1_en: I haven’t seen you in so long.
meaning_story: If you select to talk to nothing but sand for a really long time, you're neglecting to contact anyone else. Your relatives miss you! Stop talking to sand and call them!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 胡瓜の浅漬けならありますよ。
ex_1_en: These are lightly pickled cucumbers.
meaning_story: You already learned that 漬ける means "to pickle," so if you add that to the end of a food word (and leave off the る) it means that food as been pickled.
reading_story: You already learned 漬ける meaning "to pickle" so just take the る off and you've picked whatever comes next! Easy peasy.

ex_1_jp: あわよくばおこぼれに預かりたいという魂胆が見え見えだよ。
ex_1_en: You are so transparent. I can tell that you’re plotting to get a share of the profits if you get the chance.
meaning_story: The soul and guts of a story lie in the plot!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
pitch_accent: コꜜンタン *** コンタꜜン *** コンタン

ex_1_jp: この辺りは、閑静な住宅街になっています。
ex_1_en: This neighborhood is now a quiet residential area.
meaning_story: Leisurely quiet is the best kind of quiet. Even your brain gets to be quiet because you don't have a care left in the world.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 岩礁を埋め立て、人工島に造り替えたんです。
ex_1_en: The reef was filled up and replaced with an artificial island.
meaning_story: A reef made of boulders is still a reef, but it's made of sunken rocks.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 船長は、暗礁に気をつけてと言って、僕に操縦を任せた。
ex_1_en: The captain told me to be careful of reefs and then left the steering to me.
ex_2_jp: 捜査は暗礁に乗り上げてしまったな。
ex_2_en: The investigation went cold unexpectedly.
meaning_story: A dark reef is still a reef. It's just really deep underwater so it's kinda dark under there. Because of that it can also be called a sunken reef.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 昔は稲の苗を水田に植えつける女性のことを「早乙女」や「植女」と呼んでいました。
ex_1_en: Long ago, women who planted rice seedlings were called Saotome or Ueme.
meaning_story: A young woman who is planting rice from early morning into the latter evenings is a rice planting girl. You'll see them out there all day long, from dawn till dusk, planting, taking care of, and picking rice.
reading_story: This is a really weird exception, sorry. You've kind of learned these reading, but they're like... weird variations of them. Take the さ from 早速, the おつ becomes おと, and then the 女 kun'yomi め (hey that one's normal!). And you get さおとめ. You might need to just memorize this one.

ex_1_jp: この峠で転ぶと、三年だけしか生きられないという言い伝えがあります。
ex_1_en: Legends says, if you fall off this ridge you’ll only have three years left to live.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: You climb the ridge and see adorable little Tokyo geckos (とうげ) climbing all over the place. They use the mountain pass too! They're climbing with you now!

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 受験に失敗し、浪人生活に突入しました。
ex_1_en: I failed the exam and entered the life of a failed student.
meaning_story: A person who wanders because their lord was killed, is known as a ronin, or a masterless samurai. Now they're just like the rest of us, but they can't stop wandering because they have nowhere they belong.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: できれば禍根を残すことは避けたい。
ex_1_en: I want to avoid turning a blind eye to future trouble, if I can.
meaning_story: Evil's root is the root of evil. It's the source of evil things.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 叔母の言葉は、いつも軽い侮蔑を帯びている。
ex_1_en: My aunts speech always has light traces of contempt.
meaning_story: Despise someone and your scorn for them just becomes even stronger scorn.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私、あの人のこと軽蔑しているの。
ex_1_en: I despise them.
meaning_story: Lightweight scorn, no matter how light, is still scorn. Those feelings are pretty strong no matter what.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 軽 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have more scorn and disdain for the KKK (けい) than any other group in the whole world. And I'm not going to argue with you, they're pretty hatable.

ex_1_jp: 結婚相手はよく吟味してから決めたい。
ex_1_en: I want to decide on a spouse after a lot of careful investigation.
meaning_story: If you tasted the air at a recital the flavor would taste like scrutiny. That's really what everyone is doing when they watch. They don't really want to hear you, they just want to judge you.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 牽切紡績とは、化学繊維特有の紡績方法で、綿からの紡績ではありません。
ex_1_en: Kensetsu bouseki is a spinning method particular to synthetic fibers is not spun from cotton.
meaning_story: Spinning exploits sheep, but you keep spinning anyway because you're cold and you need the sweater you're making.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 日本繊維産業は、綿紡織、化繊を中心として復興しました。
ex_1_en: The Japanese textile industry was revived mainly by cotton spinning and weaving and synthetic fibers.
meaning_story: Spinning and weaving means spinning and weaving. Yay!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 織 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: While you're spinning and weaving you are always absolutely shocked (しょく) by what you make. You never really know when you start and then BAM! You made elephant slippers. That's just how it works and it shocks you every single time.

ex_1_jp: このブログでは、萌え系を中心に、僕の好きなアニメや漫画を紹介していきます。
ex_1_en: This blog introduces me to the moe characters in my favorite anime and manga.
meaning_story: What is a spout doing? It's sprouting and budding. A crush you have on someone can sprout too.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about that newly sprouting moe (もえ) character you have a crush on. Yes, this is the same moe. Congrats, you already know it!

ex_1_jp: あそこには米軍が駐屯しているんだよ。
ex_1_en: US armed forces are stationed over there.
meaning_story: Resident soldiers live in barracks when they've been stationed in another country. They have to serve their occupancy for a certain amount of time before they get to go back home.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 弁慶の泣き所を棚にぶつけたんだ。
ex_1_en: I hit my Achille’s heel on a shelf.
meaning_story: You should congratulate a person who speaks lots of different dialects because they have to be a really strong person to be able to do it. You think learning Japanese is hard now, just wait till you hear Osaka-ben and Hokkaido-ben. It takes a really strong person to learn all those dialects, so congratulate them and tell them how strong they are!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 失恋で凹んでいます。
ex_1_en: I’m sinking in unrequited love.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hollow, so the verb version is to become hollow and to sink
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You feel like you've started to become hollow when you have a head cold (へこ). You may be all stuffed up, but it's making you so sad that you feel hollow somehow.

ex_1_jp: 温泉に漬かってゆっくりした。
ex_1_en: I soaked and relaxed in the onsen.
meaning_story: You already learned that 漬ける means "to pickle," so this means "to be pickled."
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned 漬ける, so you should be able to read this one too.

ex_1_jp: 俳句を詠む人のことを俳人と呼びます。
ex_1_en: People who compose haiku are called haijin.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means compose, so the verb version is to compose.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to compose a poem but all you have for inspiration is what's in your pocket. You reach in and find a yo-yo (よ). Ah yes, this will do. So you compose a poem about your yo-yo: One string to rule them all, One string to find them, One string to- hey wait a minute...

ex_1_jp: 子供だからといって侮らない方がいい。
ex_1_en: You shouldn’t make light of it just because it’s a child.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means despise, so the verb version is to despise.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think of all the things you start to despise and to disdain. Now come up with some anecdotes (あなど) for each one of those things. Be sure to think in your head, "I'm coming up with anecdotes for things I disdain, why am I coming up with anecdotes?"

part_of_speech: INTRANSITIVE VERB, TRANSITIVE VERB, AND ICHIDAN VERB
pronunciation: たえる, こたえる, こらえる
ex_1_jp: この作品は読むに堪えない出来栄えだ。
ex_1_en: In the end, I couldn’t bear reading the work.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure, so the verb version is to endure and to bear.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're at your friend's house and you have to bear with what they made for dinner. It's tacos (た). Normally you can't stand tacos but tonight you'll have to endure. It's rude to refuse food when you're a guest. But tacos are so gross!

ex_1_jp: あの先輩に憧れているんです。
ex_1_en: I have a crush on that senpai.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means long for, so the verb version is to long for and to yearn after.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

ex_1_jp: あの男は、無意識に人のことを蔑んでいるのよ。
ex_1_en: That man unconsciously looks down on people.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scorn, so the verb version is to scorn and to despise.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You start to scorn your boss because she's been wearing that same sage suit (さげす) for a month now. She knows you want to wear a sage suit too but you can't wear the same color as her! It's really making you start to despise her. Uhg!
pitch_accent: サケ°スꜜム *** サケ°スム

ex_1_jp: 昔はこうやって糸を紡いでいたんですよ。
ex_1_en: A long time ago thread was spun in this way.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spinning, so the verb version is to spin and to make yarn.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Before you start to spin you have to let out two moos (つむ) as tribute to the cows that gave you their fur to make yarn out of. Go on, two moos, right now. Hey, out loud, not in your head!

ex_1_jp: この漬物は誰が漬けたんですか。
ex_1_en: Who pickled these tsukemono?
meaning_story: Pickled things are Japanese pickled vegetables! Or tsukemono if you've already been eating yummy pickled ginger, daikon, and umeboshi!
reading_story: You already learned 漬ける meaning "to pickle" so just take the る off there shove the け into the kanji. You read it still, but it's hiding. It probably shrunk in the pickling process. Stick some things (もの) on there are you know the reading! Not bad! By the way, sometimes you'll see this word spelled like 漬け物 too.

ex_1_jp: 叔父はこの学校の校長です。
ex_1_en: My uncle is the principle of this school.
meaning_story: An uncle on your father's side is still your uncle. This uncle always has to be younger than him though.
reading_story: The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the 伯父 which means uncle too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one uncle, you know them all!

part_of_speech: NOUN, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 床がちょっと凸凹しているのが気になるね。
ex_1_en: I’m worried that the floor is a little uneven.
meaning_story: Remember how you learned that 凹凸 means "uneven?" Well spin something uneven around and it's still uneven! Just kinda backwards, just like this word!
reading_story: However, just because the meaning stays the same when you flip it, doesn't mean the reading does. Doing that actually made the reading change from on'yomi to kun'yomi readings! You haven't learned either of these yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you have the convex parts first and the concave parts second in something uneven is ends up looking like a deco box (でこぼこ). An art deco box that is. They have lots of stuff stick out of them on the outside, but you can open them up and put stuff on the inside.
pitch_accent: デꜜコボコ *** デコボコ

ex_1_jp: とても普遍的なテーマだと思います。
ex_1_en: I think it’s a really universal theme.
meaning_story: Remember how 普遍 means "universal?" Well when you add like it's still universal! Easy!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 稚拙な文章ですがもしよければ読んでください。
ex_1_en: It’s not a very good article, but please read it if you’d like.
meaning_story: Clumsy and immature people end up being really unskillful. You can't do your job if you're always dropping things and whining, can you? They're usually also really childish, if you didn't already guess that.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 全てのジプシーが貧しい流浪の民というわけではない。
ex_1_en: That doesn’t mean all Gypsies are poor, nomadic people.
meaning_story: Wander from stream to stream and you'll get really used to wandering. You'll love it so much that you'll convert to nomadism. The open sky is your home!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 浮浪者でも7割の人は何らかの仕事をして日銭を稼いでいる。
ex_1_en: 70% of vagrants do some kind of work and earn a daily cash income.
meaning_story: Someone who floats and wanders from place to place is a vagrant. They don't really have a home, but they keep hanging around yours. It's kind of annoying. (This word has a negative connotation, you wouldn't use it for someone who is just homeless, unless you're really mean.)
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 浮 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: All the vagrants you know are fools (ふ). They just left their homes and now they float around your city for no reason. You ask them why and they shrug. You've never seen a better definition of a fool before in your life!

ex_1_jp: そのようなことが事実だとすれば、甚だ遺憾である。
ex_1_en: If that sort of thing is true, I’m very sorry.
meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_story: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you're very tired and very giggly, you'll try to say your friend's name but start laughing right away so it ends up sounds like, "Hannah ha ha ha (はなは)."

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE

ex_1_en: In those days I had to wander from place to place in order to escape.
meaning_story: Release your worldly ties and wander the word. You'll get used to wandering and you'll spend the rest of your days roaming the world until you die. It's quite the life! But you can only do it if you let go of everything else.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 戦禍を逃れて田舎に疎開した。
ex_1_en: We escaped the ravages of war and evacuated into the countryside.
meaning_story: One of the most evil things about war are the war damages that happen during it. Whole countrysides, cities, and lots of people can die. So I'd say the ravages of war are the most evil thing about war. Period.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning_story: This is a combination of the words 感慨 meaning "strong feelings" and 深い meaning "deep." Something that makes you feel strong emotions deep down inside is deeply moving.

ex_1_jp: 男女計5人から細菌性の赤痢が検出されました。

meaning_story: Red diarrhea means there's blood in there and you're probably dying of dysentery! Have you been playing too much Oregon Trail? Either way, get to a doctor!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 赤 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know what dysentery isn't? Sexy (せき). That's right. If anyone tries to seduce you by saying they have dysentery and they'd like to share it with you, tell them how NOT sexy that is and get the heck away from them!

ex_1_jp: 漸く作家としてのスタートラインに立つことができました。

reading_story: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Finally your time has come. Finally you can throw yogurt on the Yankees (ようや). It took you seven years, but now here you are in their dugout with a giant vat of yogurt. Finally Yankees. Your yogurty time has come.

ex_1_en: When I counted the boxes there were 400 total.
meaning_story: Measure that shape on the paper with you eyes. It's got four sides.. it's.. it's a square! Or a box from above maybe... But it's definitely the kind you fill in on a graph.
reading_story: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: この温泉には硫黄が含まれています。
ex_1_en: There’s sulfur in this hot spring.
meaning_story: Sulfur that's yellow is still sulfur. It smells like rotten eggs, which are also kinda yellow.
reading_story: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: This sulfur smells like an eagle's OOHHH (いおう)!! Oh no. Sulfur smells... it smells... like an eagle's... OH.. Oh eww no.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 今子供達の間で流行っている悪戯ですよ。
ex_1_en: Pranks are popular among children right now.
meaning_story: A bad kind of playing is when you tease or prank someone. It's mean and you shouldn't do it!
reading_story: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: If you tease someone with a prank that makes them eat zoo rats (いたずら), you're a jerk. That's less of a prank and more like abuse. Cut it out.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, NA ADJECTIVE, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: いくらマイホームを買いたいからって、度を過ぎた倹約を強いるのはどうかと思います。
ex_1_en: I don’t think it’s a good idea to force a higher amount of frugality on yourself just because you want to buy your own home.
meaning_story: I promise this will be a really thrifty place because it's a thrift store! They wouldn't lie about that!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 煙草の煙で部屋の空気が濁っています。
ex_1_en: The air in the room is getting cloudy with tobacco smoke.
meaning_story: You already know that 濁す means "to make muddy," but this is when you're the one getting muddy. It means to become muddy.
reading_story: This has the same reading as 濁す. If you can remember that one, you should be able to remember this one.

part_of_speech: NOUN, SURU VERB, AND NO ADJECTIVE
ex_1_jp: 俺の姉は、マフィアから残虐な拷問の受けたんだ。
ex_1_en: My older sister was brutally tortured by the mafia.
meaning_story: Torture may be a problem but that doesn't stop people from using torture to get their way.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 私のおじさんは、唄うアコーディオン弾きです。
ex_1_en: My uncle is a singing accordion player.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means Shamisen song, so the verb version is to sing.
reading_story: Remember how 歌う means "to sing" too? Well it has the same reading. If you know that one, you know this one. Yay!

ex_1_jp: 悔し涙が湧きました。
ex_1_en: Bitter tears welled up.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means well, so the verb version is to well up.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're fishing in a hole in the ice when suddenly the water starts to well up and to gush forth out of it. A huge walrus (わ) splashes out and jumps on you. No wonder there weren't any fish! This is a walrus hole.

ex_1_jp: 私は彼のことを兄のように慕っていました。
ex_1_en: I adored him like an older brother.
meaning_story: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means yearn for, so the verb version is to yearn for.
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You realize you're starting to yearn for someone way more than you used to. "Sh*t (した)... " you say to yourself. This wasn't supposed to happen. Anytime you start to adore someone like that you always know you're getting into a bunch of sh*t you don't want to deal with. Damn these emotions!

ex_1_jp: 地下20mのところに坑道が掘られています。
ex_1_en: They’re digging a tunnel somewhere 20 miles underground.
meaning_story: A pit that's used as a road is called a tunnel. Or a mine, if they're taking valuable things out of it.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 老婆の幽霊が、醜悪な顔でこちらを睨んでいた。
ex_1_en: The old woman’s ghost glared at me with her ugly face from over there.
meaning_story: Someone who is ugly and mean can't hide their ugliness or meanness from the rest of us! If you're really mean, it shows on your face.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: あの女は、顔は美しいが心は醜い。
ex_1_en: That woman’s face is beautiful but her heart is ugly.
meaning_story: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of ugly? It's ugly still!
reading_story: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The most ugly thing you've ever seen was a mini cookie (みにく). Why would any one want a tiny cookie? Cookies should be huge, and enough to fill you up. The more you look at the mini cookie it seems to become uglier and uglier to you.

ex_1_jp: 泌尿器の病気で入院することになりました。
ex_1_en: I was hospitalized from a urinary organ disease.
meaning_story: The containers your urine secretes into are your urinary organs.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 温泉湯舎から渓谷美を一望することができます。
ex_1_en: We can overlook the beautiful valley from the onsen’s bath huts.
meaning_story: A valley in a valley is still a valley!
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 船は桟橋に繋いでいます。
ex_1_en: The ship is tied to the pier.
meaning_story: Add a bridge to a jetty and you'll have a pretty cool wharf. Put a ferris wheel on there and make some money!
reading_story: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 桟 and the kun'yomi reading for 橋. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too!

ex_1_jp: 寡婦控除について詳しく教えてください。
ex_1_en: Please explain widow deductions to me in detail.
meaning_story: A widowed wife is a widow.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 異国の地で、母への思慕を重ねています。
ex_1_en: I constantly yearn for my mother in my home country.
meaning_story: If you can't stop thinking about how much you yearn for someone, that yearning can drive you crazy. Try to keep it in check, and enjoy how you can hold such deep affection for someone.
reading_story: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

ex_1_jp: 彼は中古車を買ったばかりです。
ex_1_en: He has just bought a used car.
meaning_story: pretty straightforward! used/secondhand + car
reading_story: straight onyomi

meaning_story: I believe it's the flower power...
reading_story: onyomi, 花 is read か I think
